headline: García Widens Distance From a Rued Remark
abstract: Sergio García, no longer heckled over his “fried chicken” reference to Tiger Woods, led the Deutsche Bank Championship after two rounds.
lead_paragraph: NORTON, Mass. — Gone are the shouts of “Fried chicken!” that pierced the quiet during Sergio García’s swing at the United States Open, in response to García’s unfunny joke that he would have his adversary, Tiger Woods, over to dinner and serve him, of all dishes, that one. García played his second round of the Deutsche Bank Championship in relative peace and quiet Saturday, the birdsong broken only by applause for his good shots, of which there were many, or cries of “Keep it rolling, Sergio!”

headline: Penn State Unveils a New Quarterback and Closes the Door on Syracuse
abstract: Led by the freshman quarterback Christian Hackenberg, the Nittany Lions outlasted Syracuse in a matchup of two rebuilding programs.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The Battle in the Apple, as organizers labeled the matchup between Syracuse and Penn State at MetLife Stadium on Saturday, started more like an arm wrestling match between two opponents sizing each other up cautiously.

abstract: Some witnesses said there were children in the home, located in the town of Elmira, but officials have not released the identities of the victims.

headline: Democrats Go for a Senate Gain as G.O.P. Rivals Vie in Georgia
abstract: National Democrats see a slim but tantalizing chance to steal a Republican Senate seat as Republicans compete to replace Saxby Chambliss, who is retiring.
lead_paragraph: WINDER, Ga. — The flock of Republican candidates vying to succeed retiring Senator Saxby Chambliss gathered last weekend in this small-town birthplace of Georgia’s legendary statesman, Senator Richard Russell, to appeal to the restive electorate.

headline: For Older Players, Anticipation Can Replace Speed
abstract: The 30-somethings are on a good run in tennis, but what they almost certainly aren’t doing is running as fast as they used to.
lead_paragraph: This United States Open began with dozens of players in the singles draws who have seen their 30th birthday, including the No. 1-ranked woman, Serena Williams. With so many veterans still playing top-shelf tennis, there’s nothing odd about seeing one in a final of a tournament. The Wimbledon tuneup in Halle, Germany, even had two: Roger Federer and Mikhail Youzhny.

headline: Seeking Solace on the Field
abstract: A family and a high school football team chose to turn to the sport that united them as a way of healing after a player died from head trauma.
lead_paragraph: RIVERSIDE, Calif. — As Arlington High School’s football players lined up along the goal line, awaiting the kickoff to their season Friday night, their eyes turned toward the home stands. A few of the players pointed in that direction, where a rainbow, standing against the darkening sky, stretched from one end of the bleachers to the other.

headline: For a Classic Motown Song About Money, Credit Is What He Wants
abstract: The songwriter Barrett Strong has had his name struck from copyright documents for “Money (That’s What I Want),” Motown’s first national hit.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — On the lawn outside Motown Records’ former headquarters here, a historical marker honors the pivotal role that the song “Money (That’s What I Want)” played in building the Motown empire. With its hypnotic piano riff and unabashedly materialistic refrain, “Money,” recorded in 1959, was the first national success for the label that came to be known as “Hitsville U.S.A.,” giving the fledgling company credibility and a vital infusion of cash.

headline: World Cup Adapts a Tennis Format
abstract: After being rejected by players for use in the world title game, a tennis-like elimination system is used to decide the winner of an important chess tournament.
lead_paragraph: In 1998, the World Chess Federation’s championship was decided in a tournament based on the 128-player elimination system used in professional tennis. Matches consisted of two slow games followed by faster games in the case of a tie.

headline: David Frost, Interviewer Who Got Nixon to Apologize for Watergate, Dies at 74
abstract: A longtime broadcaster, Mr. Frost was best known for incisive interviews with public figures, including talks with former President Richard M. Nixon, which he called the highlight of his career.
lead_paragraph: David Frost, the British broadcaster whose interviews of historic figures like Henry Kissinger, John Lennon and, most famously, Richard M. Nixon often made history in their own right, died on Saturday aboard the ocean liner Queen Elizabeth, where he was scheduled to give a speech. He was 74.

headline: What’s on Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (13, 49) SILK It’s called “taking silk”: the merit-based appointment of a British lawyer as Queen’s Counsel, which confers the right to wear a specially designed silk gown in court (and, for ceremonial occasions, a large wig). And Martha Costello, a sharp-witted defense barrister in London played by a crackling Maxine Peake, above, wants to take silk — badly — in this “Masterpiece Mystery!” series created by Peter Moffat, inspired by his own experiences. Already stretched thin, Martha strategically overloads on cases that could bolster her reputation and tutors an ambitious if occasionally bumbling pupil (Tom Hughes). But she has competition in her quest for justice and professional prestige: Clive Reader (Rupert Penry-Jones), a fellow barrister at Shoe Lane Chambers whose skill set is heavy on cunning and charm, which he uses to bed his own pupil (Natalie Dormer). In Episode 2, Martha defends a teenager.

headline: Weekend Revelry Cut Short After 2 Die at Electronic Music Festival
abstract: The deaths, at Electric Zoo on Randalls Island, were consistent with use of the drug Ecstasy, according to the mayor’s office, which recommended the event be called off.
lead_paragraph: A multiday electronic music festival that drew tens of thousands of people to Randalls Island over Labor Day weekend was canceled on Sunday, its last day, after city officials said two concertgoers had died and at least four others had fallen critically ill during the first two days of the event, known as the Electric Zoo.

headline: In Telluride, a Peek at ‘Gravity’
abstract: The Telluride Film Festival ofers a sneak peak of “Gravity,” starring Sandra Bullock and George Clooney.
lead_paragraph: TELLURIDE, Colo. — In its 40th year, the Telluride Film Festival has added an extra day and a new site, the 650-seat Werner Herzog, housed in an ice rink at the edge of town and named for the German director who has been a regular presence here for most of the festival’s history. The Herzog was the scene Saturday night of the first North American showing of “Gravity,” which arrived from the Venice Film Festival on a vapor trail of excited buzz.

headline: Disruptions: More Connected, Yet More Alone
abstract: A YouTube video about pervasive smartphone use may have landed at a moment when people start questioning if something has gone too far and start doing something about it.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Last weekend, I was watching television with a few friends, browsing the week’s most popular YouTube videos, when a piece in the comedy section called “I Forgot My Phone” caught my eye. As I was about to click play, however, a friend warned, “Oh, don’t watch that. I saw it yesterday, and it’s really sad.”

headline: Lotfi Mansouri, 84, Opera Troupe Director, Dies
abstract: Mr. Mansouri, who ran the San Francisco Opera and Canadian Opera Company in Toronto, introduced a system of showing the works’ translations on video screens during performances.
lead_paragraph: Lotfi Mansouri, the Iranian-born opera director and manager who ran the San Francisco Opera and the Canadian Opera Company in Toronto and pioneered the use of synchronous translations in performances, died on Friday at his home in San Francisco. He was 84.

headline: Sept. 1: Where the Candidates Are Today
abstract: The candidates’ daily campaign schedule at a glance.
lead_paragraph: Planned events for the mayoral candidates, according to the campaigns and organizations they are affiliated with. Times are listed as scheduled but frequently change.

headline: Erst kommt das Fressen
abstract: Barbecue beats blogging.
lead_paragraph: Dann kommt die Moral.

headline: Against Williams, Challenge Begins With the Serve
abstract: Chris Evert and Pam Shriver weigh in on how to compete against Serena Williams’s serve, considered to be the best in the history of women’s tennis.
lead_paragraph: Trying to come to a consensus on the best strokes in the history of tennis can be a futile exercise. The man with the best serve ever is Pete Sampras. Or maybe he’s John Isner. Or someone else.

headline: Brazil’s Humor Guerrillas
abstract: Few start-ups in Brazil have had success like Porta dos Fundos, a comedy troupe whose YouTube channel is the country’s most popular.
lead_paragraph: Few start-ups in Brazil have had success like Porta dos Fundos, a comedy troupe whose YouTube channel is the country’s most popular.

headline: Senior Chinese Official Falls Under Scrutiny as Some Point to Larger Inquiry
abstract: Jiang Jiemin is the first full member of the elite Central Committee to be publicly singled out on corruption charges under the country’s leader, Xi Jinping.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The Chinese Communist Party announced Sunday that a senior official responsible for overseeing state-owned corporations was under investigation, and people with knowledge of that case and many others said that, according to senior officials, the inquiries were part of a larger corruption investigation encroaching on the retired chief of the domestic security apparatus.

headline: Gandhian Goodness Confronting Greed
abstract: In “Satyagraha,” a movement arises over corruption and efforts to combat it in an Indian town.
lead_paragraph: A populist streak runs through Bollywood, never more so than in the work of Prakash Jha, whose new movie, “Satyagraha,” states plainly what concerns him: “The system is rotten.”

headline: Arab League Endorses International Action
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: The Arab League adopted a resolution urging action against the Syrian government for what it called the “ugly crime” of using chemical weapons, but it stopped short of an explicit reference to military intervention.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The Arab League on Sunday urged international action against the Syrian government to deter what it called the “ugly crime” of using chemical weapons. It was a major step toward supporting Western military strikes but short of the explicit endorsement that the United States and some Persian Gulf allies had hoped for.

headline: Real Madrid Completes Long-Awaited Deal for Tottenham’s Bale
abstract: The Welsh midfielder Gareth Bale’s transfer from Tottenham to Real Madrid was believed to be worth about $130 million, which would set a record.
lead_paragraph: Midfielder Gareth Bale’s transfer to Real Madrid, from Tottenham Hotspur, was finally completed Sunday, and Tottenham Coach André Villas-Boas told reporters in London that Bale had “left us with great memories.”

headline: In Performance: Jon Norman Schneider
abstract: Jon Norman Schneider plays Ralph in the National Asian American Theater Company revival of Clifford Odets’s 1935 play, “Awake and Sing!” about a Jewish family in the Depression-era Bronx.
lead_paragraph: Jon Norman Schneider plays Ralph in the National Asian American Theater Company revival of Clifford Odets’s 1935 play, “Awake and Sing!” about a Jewish family in the Depression-era Bronx.

headline: Arsenal Shows Money Can’t Buy Magic
abstract: Tottenham made a flurry of purchases that were enabled by its fee for Gareth Bale, but Arsenal showed the value of timing and teamwork in a 1-0 victory in the rivals’ derby match.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Twenty-four hours before the end of the summer sales in European soccer, Arsenal beat Tottenham Hotspur in one of the oldest derby matches in the world game.

headline: Iraqi Camp for Iranians Faces Deadly Clashes
abstract: The circumstances of the violence, which left at least 15 people dead, were contested by the Iraqi government and representatives of the group of dissidents.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Clashes on Sunday at a camp in northeastern Iraq that houses a group of Iranian dissidents, who until last year were considered terrorists by the United States government, left at least 15 people dead, according to two security officials.

headline: Verizon Nears Deal to Buy Out Vodafone’s Stake in Wireless Unit
abstract: Verizon Communications neared a deal on Sunday to buy the 45 percent stake in its wireless business held by Vodafone of Britain for about $130 billion, people briefed on the matter said, potentially completing a corporate breakup over a decade in the making.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:35 p.m. | Verizon Communications neared a long-anticipated deal on Sunday to buy the 45 percent stake in its wireless business held by Vodafone of Britain for about $130 billion, heralding a continued sweeping realignment within the global telecommunications landscape.

headline: Son of Tennis Club Custodial Worker Qualifies for U.S. Open Juniors Event
abstract: Francis Tiafoe grew up at the Junior Tennis Champions Center in College Park, Md., where his father, Constant, an immigrant from Sierra Leone, was a live-in custodial worker from 1999 to 2010.
lead_paragraph: Francis Tiafoe, a 15-year-old American looking to reach his first main juniors draw at the United States Open, faced three successive match points against a boy three years older than him.

headline: No Matter Who Leaves, Premier League Wins
abstract: Gareth Bale, transferring to Real Madrid from Tottenham, is the latest top player to go somewhere other than England. But the Premier League has shown it is bigger than any stars.
lead_paragraph: Gareth Bale is gone. Even after Tottenham Hotspur officials spent months issuing don’t-even-talk-about-it, don’t-even-think-about-it, no-seriously-stop-thinking-about-it statements regarding any potential sale of Bale, a midfielder who was last season’s Premier League player of the year, the North London club surprised absolutely no one on Sunday when it sent him to Real Madrid.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday. There will be no auctions on Monday in observance of Labor Day. At the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 0.03 percent. The rate on the six-month issue was 0.05 percent, and the rate on the four-week issue was 0.02 percent.

headline: Remembering the Spark That Ignited a Creative Fire
abstract: Readers from the worlds of television, classical music, dance, pop music, video games, art and theater share experiences that kindled their first creative and professional sparks.
lead_paragraph: With her descriptions of furtive television watching as a child, Alessandra Stanley kicked off our “First Crush” series this summer. She and several colleagues were asked to revisit their artistic inspirations, the one thing or series of events that set them on paths toward becoming cultural critics for The New York Times.

headline: Board-a-Match Teams at World Youth Open
abstract: The final event at the 3rd World Youth Open Championships here last month was the Board-a-Match Teams.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The final event at the 3rd World Youth Open Championships here last month was the Board-a-Match Teams.

headline: Afghan Envoy to Pakistan Is Appointed Interior Minister
abstract: President Hamid Karzai’s appointment of Umar Daudzai as interior minister was public confirmation that he would not be Mr. Karzai’s favored successor.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — President Hamid Karzai on Sunday chose his ambassador to Pakistan, Umar Daudzai, as the new Afghan interior minister. The move, on the eve of the declaration period for potential presidential candidates, was public confirmation that Mr. Daudzai would not be Mr. Karzai’s favored successor.

headline: News Corp.’s Tight Grip on Australia’s Papers Shapes Its Politics
abstract: The company owns roughly 60 percent of the newspaper market share and recent outlandish front pages depicting political leaders have some saying it holds too much political sway.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — A lot has happened since Col Allan, the editor in chief of The New York Post, returned to Sydney to provide “extra editorial leadership” for Rupert Murdoch’s Australian newspapers.

headline: Automakers Build Showroom in an App
abstract: Using a technology called augmented reality, carmakers can embed images and video over a picture on a smartphone or tablet.
lead_paragraph: VENICE BEACH, Calif. — Automakers trying to reach young buyers face a conundrum: How do they sell a car to people who stay away from a showroom?

headline: A Grand Tennis Theater in Twilight
abstract: The Grandstand court at the United States Open, to be replaced, holds decades of memories.
lead_paragraph: The sun had dipped on the Grandstand court at the United States Open match between Sam Querrey, the American, and Adrian Mannarino, a Frenchman, so the lights were on. A soft breeze riffled through the trees, whose branches poked over the low bleachers. Noise drifted from Armstrong Stadium next door. The crowd in the Grandstand returned the favor with regular explosions after every point.

headline: From the Stands
abstract: Scenes from the Grandstand court at the United States Open in Flushing.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Grandstand court at the United States Open in Flushing.

headline: Hayao Miyazaki, Japanese Animator, Said to Be Retiring
abstract: The Japanese animation director will retire from filmmaking, according to a report on Variety’s Web site.
lead_paragraph: The Japanese animation director Hayao Miyazaki will retire from filmmaking, according to a report on Variety’s Web site. Mr. Miyazaki, 72, has directed 11 animated features over 34 years, including “My Neighbor Totoro,” “Princess Mononoke” and “Spirited Away,” which won an Oscar for best animated feature in 2003. Koji Hoshino, who is the president of Mr. Miyazaki’s production company, made the announcement on Sunday at the Venice Film Festival, where Mr. Miyazaki’s latest work, “The Wind Rises,” was shown. “Miyazaki has decided that ‘Kaze Tachinu’ (‘The Wind Rises’) will be his last film, and he will now retire,” Mr. Hoshino said. More details are to be revealed at a news conference in Tokyo next week. The language of the announcement does leave the door open for Mr. Miyazaki to work on shorter projects.

headline: Huge Summer for Hollywood, but With Few Blockbusters
abstract: Ticket revenue in North America totaled $4.71 billion, up 10.2 percent from last summer, but a competition glut hurt films that could have been hits in a thinner field.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Here in Hollywood, the land of false-front movie sets and business-has-never-been-better studio spin doctors, summer ticket sales are being summed up with a single word: blockbuster.

headline: Record for Later Viewing
abstract: A solving week opener by Jim Peredo that for some reason reminded me of the Fonz from “Happy Days.”
lead_paragraph: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — With the summer drawing to a close, it’s important — if you’re a homeowner — to remember to clean up your property and prepare it for its move into autumn and its eventual winter nap. No need to thank me for this foray into gardening advice: Jim Peredo kindly provides us with the tools necessary for the job by including a RAKE and some HOES in his Monday grid.

headline: Once Called Victim, She Forgives but Can’t Forget
abstract: In “The Girl,” Samantha Geimer, the woman at the center of the Roman Polanski case, tells her story.
lead_paragraph: It’s a line that Roman Polanski used so memorably in his 1974 “Chinatown,” screenplay by Robert Towne: “You see, Mr. Gittes, most men never have to face the fact that in the right time, the right place, they’re capable of anything.”

headline: Gay Couples in New Mexico Line Up for Marriage Licenses
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Clerks in six of the state’s most populous counties have decided to start issuing marriage licenses to same-sex couples.
lead_paragraph: Clerks in six of the state’s most populous counties have decided to start issuing marriage licenses to same-sex couples.

headline: Lohan Skips Venice to Focus on Health
abstract: Lindsay Lohan has spoken up to dispute reports that she ditched the premiere of her latest film, “The Canyons,” at the Venice Film Festival.
lead_paragraph: Lindsay Lohan has spoken up to dispute reports that she ditched the premiere of her latest film, “The Canyons,” at the Venice Film Festival. In a post on her personal Web site, Ms. Lohan said that she was never confirmed to appear to promote the film and instead wanted to focus on her health, The Associated Press reported on Sunday. Paul Schrader, the director of “The Canyons,” said in a news conference on Friday that he was “a free man,” adding: “For the last 16 months I’ve been hostage, by own choosing, to a very talented but unpredictable actress. She was supposed to be here today; she said she would be, but she is not.” In her statement, Ms. Lohan, who completed her latest court-ordered rehab stint in July, said that she would have enjoyed attending the festival. But, she said: “My focus is on my health and well-being. Plain and simple, it is of the utmost importance.”

headline: Tourists Wary of Turmoil in the Middle East Are a Boon to Southern Europe
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Summer (Season)']
abstract: For Spain, Portugal, Italy and Greece, economists are hoping that this year’s record influx of sun-seeking tourists and their money will continue past summer’s end.
lead_paragraph: TARIFA, Spain — Spain, Portugal, Italy and Greece are hoping that this year’s record influx of sun-seeking tourists and their money from Northern Europe will continue past summer’s end.

headline: Another Judge for ‘American Idol’
abstract: Harry Connick Jr. will join Keith Urban and Jennifer Lopez on the judging panel for the show’s 13th season, in January, according to The Hollywood Reporter.
lead_paragraph: After appearing on Fox’s “American Idol” a number of times as a performer and mentor, Harry Connick Jr. will join Keith Urban and Jennifer Lopez on the judging panel for the show’s 13th season, in January, according to The Hollywood Reporter. No announcement has been made by Fox, but Mr. Connick has apparently stepped in at the last minute to replace the producer and songwriter Dr. Luke, who dropped out because of a conflict with his imprint at Sony Music.

headline: Dancing in the Eternal Present, Before Harsh Reality Intervened
abstract: The news of two deaths at Electric Zoo 2013, the fifth annual Labor Day weekend of electronic music on Randalls Island, casts a sorrowful shadow over what was supposed to be a celebration.
lead_paragraph: It was supposed to be the bigger, better party. Electric Zoo 2013 was the fifth annual Labor Day weekend of electronic dance music on Randalls Island, and its promoter, Made Event, had expanded it by adding another stage with additional headliners. But after two concertgoers died, apparently from using MDMA (known in different formulations as Molly or Ecstasy), Made Event followed the recommendation of the mayor’s office and abruptly canceled Sunday, the third day of the festival. Last week, the House of Blues in Boston closed temporarily after drug overdoses following a show by Zedd, who would have been one of Sunday’s Electric Zoo headliners.

headline: Two Plans for Safety at Bangladesh Factories
keywords: ['Factories and Manufacturing', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: North American and European-led retailers and apparel brands created separate plans to try to inspect and improve workplace conditions in Bangladesh, with significant differences, as this side-by-side comparison shows.
lead_paragraph: North American and European-led retailers and apparel brands created separate plans to try to inspect and improve workplace conditions in Bangladesh, with significant differences, as this side-by-side comparison shows.

headline: Riot Grrrl Back From the Brink
abstract: After six years of battling illness, the singer Kathleen Hanna is returning in a big way, notably with her band the Julie Ruin.
lead_paragraph: Donating her file cabinet, full of old journals, letters and zines to New York University’s Fales Library archive was a bittersweet move for Kathleen Hanna. A singer and founder of the riot grrrl band Bikini Kill and the feminist electro-pop act Le Tigre, Ms. Hanna had been a den mother to contemporary-girl culture for a generation, but she was still only a midcareer artist, too young to grapple with archiving her work. The donation helped legitimize the riot grrrl movement.

headline: Fast and Flawed Inspections of Factories Abroad
keywords: ['Rana Plaza Building Collapse, Bangladesh (2013)', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: While some audits are performed in depth, retailers often choose “check the box” inspections that fail to uncover substandard conditions and outright fraud.
lead_paragraph: Inspectors came and went from a Walmart-certified factory in Guangdong Province in China, approving its production of more than $2 million in specialty items that would land on Walmart’s shelves in time for Christmas.

headline: Ballet and TV Make Uneasy Pas de Deux
abstract: When it comes to dance on television, maybe the best move is to reach for the remote.
lead_paragraph: “Breaking Pointe,” a reality-television show about Ballet West, is breaking my heart. “So You Think You Can Dance” is as feckless as ever. And Amy Sherman-Palladino’s wise, snappy “Bunheads” was canceled. When it comes to dance on television, the best move is to reach for the remote.

headline: History Aside, Obama Bets on Congress
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: By asking Congress for authorization to retaliate against Syria, President Obama has put himself at the mercy of an institution that has bedeviled his presidency for years.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In President Obama’s telling, Congress plays host to an “endless parade of distractions and political posturing.” It is the “challenging” place where his second-term agenda meets Washington gridlock, forcing him to issue executive orders and make appeals to the public to get anything done.

headline: Bullpen Collapse Costs Yankees Sweep After Effective Start by Pettitte
abstract: Andy Pettitte pitched well through six innings, but a seven-run seventh helped the Orioles salvage the finale of a three-game series.
lead_paragraph: For days now the Yankees have made the point with grave certainty that they no longer have any room for mistakes. They are trailing in the chase for a playoff spot, and one pitch, one faulty swing, a base-running mistake or a fateful decision by the manager could doom them.

headline: Walking While Black in the ‘White Gaze’
abstract: Even 50 years after “I Have a Dream,” the racial logic that equates black bodies with danger persists.
lead_paragraph: I.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week of Sept. 2
abstract: Information to be released this week includes construction spending for July and the Institute for Supply Management index of manufacturing activity in August.
lead_paragraph: ECONOMIC REPORTS Information to be released this week includes construction spending for July and the Institute for Supply Management index of manufacturing activity in August (Tuesday); the United States trade deficit for July, the Federal Reserve’s beige book regional economic report, and the Challenger, Gray & Christmas report on job cuts in August (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims, ADP employment for August, and factory orders for July (Thursday); and the United States unemployment report for August (Friday).

headline: Gilmar, Pelé’s Last Line of Defense, Dies at 83
abstract: Gilmar dos Santos Neves, with his teammate Pelé, helped lead Brazil to World Cup titles in 1958 and 1962.
lead_paragraph: Gilmar dos Santos Neves, a goalkeeper for Brazil’s national soccer team when it won its first World Cup title in 1958 and when it successfully defended the title in 1962, died on Aug. 22 in São Paulo. He was 83.

headline: Thai Protester Killed at Blockade
abstract: One protester was shot and killed and another seriously wounded in southern Thailand at the site of a blockade by farmers protesting a fall in rubber prices.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — One protester was shot and killed and another seriously wounded in southern Thailand on Sunday at the site of a blockade by rubber farmers who are protesting a sharp fall in rubber prices.

headline: Campaign Journalism in the Age of Twitter
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Social Media', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A far younger campaign reporter now feeds a never-ending news cycle named Twitter.
lead_paragraph: In Timothy Crouse’s seminal campaign book, “The Boys on the Bus,” the crusty political reporters settle on the story that they will tell the world at the end of the day.

headline: Walker Cup Returns to Roots, With a Twist
abstract: Matt Fitzpatrick, the reigning United States Amateur champion, is on the Britain and Ireland team as the Walker Cup returns to its original site, the National Golf Links of America.
lead_paragraph: Nearly a century later, the Walker Cup matches are returning to where they originated, the National Golf Links of America in Southampton, N.Y. The National, as it’s known, is one of golf’s cherished antiques, the site of the 44th duel Saturday and Sunday between an amateur team representing the United States and one representing Britain and Ireland. Its fabled course, designed by Charles Blair Macdonald, the father of American golf architecture, is virtually unchanged since it opened in 1911. New tees at the 7th, 14th and 16th holes have stretched it to 6,995 yards, only 122 yards longer than when Bobby Jones, Francis Ouimet and Chick Evans — three of golf’s revered names — won the inaugural cup matches there in 1922.

headline: Big Screens That Not All of Hollywood Adores
abstract: For many in the audience of the Hollywood Bowl, the arrival of four high-definition video screens has been a gift. But not all are thrilled by the technology.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The Hollywood Bowl has survived the Beatles, Bill Clinton, Liberace and Leonard Bernstein, not to mention reconstructions, earthquakes, coyotes and the thump-thump-thumping of helicopters crossing the night sky, inevitably at the most pianissimo of moments.

headline: Williams’s Skill Speaks Volumes in Easy Victory Over Stephens
abstract: The infighting between the top American female players Serena Williams and Sloane Stephens over the last few months served as a backdrop to Williams’s dominant 6-4, 6-1 victory.
lead_paragraph: It can be challenging to wade through the pleasantries offered between professional tennis opponents, and get at the heart of whether they can actually stand each other. Most are complimentary to a fault, tiptoeing as gingerly as possible around potential controversy or insult.

headline: No Clear Winner in Debate Between Merkel and Challenger
abstract: Chancellor Angela Merkel and her Social Democratic rival, Peer Steinbrück, fought each other to a virtual draw in their sole television debate of the German election campaign.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Chancellor Angela Merkel and her Social Democratic rival, Peer Steinbrück, fought each other to a virtual draw in their sole television debate of the German election campaign on Sunday night. The face-off was a mostly decorous 90-minute affair that commentators had cast as Mr. Steinbrück’s last chance to show his mettle and overcome earlier stumbles.

headline: Jets Claim 3 Players Off Waivers
abstract: The Jets added running back Alex Green, offensive tackle Ben Ijalana and linebacker Scott Solomon to the roster.
lead_paragraph: Alex Green, who started four games at running back for Green Bay last season, was among three players the Jets claimed off waivers Sunday. They also added offensive tackle Ben Ijalana (Indianapolis) and linebacker Scott Solomon (Tennessee). To make room, the Jets cut running back Kahlil Bell and linebacker Danny Lansanah and placed linebacker Josh Mauga (back) on injured reserve.

headline: Japan’s E-Reader Industry Struggles to Keep Up as Amazon Takes the Lead
abstract: Although local companies brought e-readers to market in Japan before Amazon did, Amazon’s experience elsewhere with e-book sales rapidly gave it an edge with consumers and publishers.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — When Rakuten, Japan’s leading e-commerce company, introduced its Kobo e-reader in Japan in July 2012, the company’s chief executive, Hiroshi Mikitani, presented a gift to Yoshinobu Noma, the president of Kodansha, Japan’s largest publisher.

headline: Surprising Friend of Gay Rights in a High Place
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Homosexuality', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: When President Ronald Reagan nominated Anthony M. Kennedy to the Supreme Court, few could have imagined the esteem Justice Kennedy would one day earn among advocates of gay rights.
lead_paragraph: The San Francisco Gay Men’s Chorus sang “Give ’Em Hope” for a revered and in some ways surprising guest who shared a California stage with them last month: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy.

headline: Opening a Door to the Burmese Past, and the Present, Too
abstract: Curators are working in Myanmar to assemble a collection of Buddhist art that will travel to the United States and offer a rare glimpse into the country’s history.
lead_paragraph: BAGAN, Myanmar — In a delicate operation here, specialists gingerly eased a priceless, 1,000-year-old national treasure — a Buddhist bronze casting in the shape of a lotus flower — from its perch in a museum showcase.

headline: A Roof Is Planned, but It’s a Waiting Game for Fans and Players
abstract: As dark clouds formed over the United States Open, rain-weary fans began asking: when is that roof coming anyway?
lead_paragraph: With ominous daggers of lightning on the Weather Channel’s Web site, dark clouds scudding across the sky and rumors of cloudbursts in the vicinity, most people at the United States Open cannot help but obsess about Teflon flaps covering the main stadium and the reassuring plock-plock-plock of tennis being played.

headline: Lottery Numbers
abstract: Lottery numbers for Sept. 1 for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Amid Struggles, Nationals Win One Against Mets
abstract: The Washington Nationals, who have had a disappointing season, scored three runs in the eighth inning to beat the Mets and avert a sweep.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Nationals expected to play meaningful baseball in September. Their roster was brimming with the essential components for another playoff run. They had pitching and hitting. They had clubhouse chemistry and a seasoned manager, whose imminent retirement was sure to provide inspiration.

headline: Subcontractor Servitude
abstract: Guest-worker programs in the United States are plagued by debt, fraud and coercion. The government should curb the system’s worst abuses.
lead_paragraph: THE words “guest workers” and “strike” are not often seen together. Yet twice this summer, members of a group of more than 150 Jamaican guest workers who clean luxury Florida hotels and condos walked off the job. The workers came to the United States in April anticipating a summer of hard work and decent earnings to send home. Instead, they encountered the black hole of labor subcontracting.

headline: Morsi and Muslim Brotherhood Leaders Charged With Inciting Murder
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: The charges seemed to extinguish hope of a political resolution that would bring the Muslim Brotherhood out from underground and back into the political process.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Egypt’s chief prosecutor ordered former president Mohamed Morsi and other Muslim Brotherhood leaders on Sunday to stand trial on charges including inciting murder, the state news media reported. The order seemed to extinguish hope of a political resolution that would bring the Brotherhood out from underground and back into the political process.

headline: Storm Clouds at U.S. Open Are Untimely but Not New
abstract: The delay of recent men’s finals at the United States Open has prompted calls for a retractable roof, but bad weather at the tournament is hardly a recent phenomenon.
lead_paragraph: The last five years, rain pushed the men’s final at the United States Open to a Monday, prompting more calls for a retractable roof to be built at Arthur Ashe Stadium. Plans for that roof, and another on a new Louis Armstrong Stadium, have been made, but bad weather at United States championships is hardly a recent phenomenon. The Open media guide devotes three pages to “Rain and the U.S. Open” in its historical highlights section, citing 18 times the event was extended because of the weather and instances when the Open finished on time despite lots of rain. Here are some notable examples:

headline: When City Elections Were Fun
abstract: When Norman Mailer ran for mayor, the race was fueled by the outsize talent that powered New York itself.
lead_paragraph: IN 1969, in the midst of devastating strikes, rising racial conflict, sinking finances, terrifying crime rates and an expanding, dysfunctional city bureaucracy, the pugilistic writer Norman Mailer made a quixotic bid for mayor of New York. The columnist Jimmy Breslin campaigned alongside him for City Council president. Far from being a gimmick, the pair electrified the electorate with bold plans and even bolder political theatrics.

headline: 6 Boys Killed While Swimming in Northern Afghanistan
abstract: The boys, ages 9 to 14, were apparently the victims of fishermen who fired a rocket into a river in Baghlan Province, intending to stun or kill the fish.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Six boys were killed on a swimming outing in northern Afghanistan, apparently the victims of fishermen who fired a rocket into a river, according to Afghan officials and relatives of the victims.

headline: A New Kind of Union
keywords: ['Collective Bargaining', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Organized Labor', 'Campaign Finance', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: If workers can’t bargain together, let them organize politically.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — THE financial challenges low- and middle-income Americans face are daunting. But the poor and middle class are in an equally serious, if less well recognized, political predicament: the government has become almost entirely unresponsive to them.

headline: García Finds Much Light in the Darkness
abstract: Sergio García posted his third consecutive sub-70 round, a six-under-par 65, at the Deutsche Bank Championship on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: NORTON, Mass. — Working as long and hard this Labor Day weekend as lifeguards, some golfers will spend Monday at the Tournament Players Club of Boston trying to save their seasons.

headline: Love for Labor Lost
keywords: ['Labor Day', 'Income Inequality', 'Welfare (US)', 'Labor and Jobs', 'United States Economy']
abstract: How the right came to have contempt for workers.
lead_paragraph: It wasn’t always about the hot dogs. Originally, believe it or not, Labor Day actually had something to do with showing respect for labor.

headline: Chasing JPMorgan Chase
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Editorials']
abstract: Will scrutiny lead to greater scrutiny at banks that now seem too big to manage?
lead_paragraph: Not too long ago, JPMorgan Chase and its chief executive, Jamie Dimon, were celebrated for navigating the 2008 financial crisis, which brought other big banks to their knees. Now this one-time darling of federal regulators, long thought to be the best managed of all the big banks, is in trouble or apparently headed there on multiple fronts. While the outcome of the various investigations into the bank’s dealings remains unclear, they raise the obvious question of whether banks have become not only too big to fail but too big to manage.

headline: A Saner Approach on Drug Laws
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'Marijuana', 'States (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic']
abstract: The Justice Department says that states are free to legalize pot, but that the government will be watching.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department took an important step toward sanity in the enforcement of drug laws last week when it announced a “trust but verify” approach to states permitting the growth, sale and possession of marijuana.

headline: Reality Intrudes Before the Kickoff
abstract: The agreement to pay retired players who claim damage from concussions is an overdue step in the N.F.L.’s evolution.
lead_paragraph: In a chilling prologue to the professional football season, the National Football League has agreed to pay $765 million to more than 4,500 retired players who claim long-term damages from the violent concussions that are part of the game. The payment settles a pending lawsuit but hardly resolves the continuing threat to players from the traumatic hits — “bell ringers” in the sport’s jargon — that mounting research shows are linked to brain disease in athletes’ later years.

headline: The Turning at Labor Day
abstract: The holiday may not mark a seasonal shift (just look at the temperature), but we can still pause, look and consider the small changes.
lead_paragraph: “Season of mists and mellow fruitfulness” — well, not quite yet. It is still a little early to have John Keats’s autumnal words running through your head. Yet no matter how desperately you cling to summer, it’s almost impossible not to feel the changes that begin to gather around Labor Day. On a warm, muggy day, they are not very evident. Only the shifting of the light at evening suggests the changing season. But when the wind is fresh and the temperature falls a little, it is hard not to imagine the season leaping ahead of itself, even as summer lingers.

headline: On Obama’s Plan, a Message Emerges in Israel: Stay Quiet
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: After President Obama said he would delay a military strike against Syria, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s government has characterized the situation as delicate.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Since reports surfaced of an apparent chemical attack outside Damascus, Israeli leaders have called for an American response, both on moral grounds and as a warning to Iran over its nuclear program. But on Sunday, after President Obama said he would delay a military strike to obtain Congressional approval, a new message emerged from Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s government: Do not say anything.

headline: Drug Agents Use Vast Phone Trove, Eclipsing N.S.A.’s
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Telephones and Telecommunications', 'Industrial Espionage', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic']
abstract: The scale and longevity of a data storage program run by the government in partnership with AT&T was unmatched by other government programs, including the National Security Agency’s gathering of phone call logs.
lead_paragraph: For at least six years, law enforcement officials working on a counternarcotics program have had routine access, using subpoenas, to an enormous AT&T database that contains the records of decades of Americans’ phone calls — parallel to but covering a far longer time than the National Security Agency’s hotly disputed collection of phone call logs.

headline: Hewitt Continues Run With Win Over Young Russian
abstract: Lleyton Hewitt, ranked 66th, is in the fourth round of the United States Open for the first time since 2006.
lead_paragraph: During Lleyton Hewitt’s upset of Juan Martin del Potro on Friday night, two Australian spectators waved their country’s flag in support of Hewitt from a loge section high up in Ashe Stadium.

headline: Synopsis of the Hemisphere Project
abstract: A slide presentation given to The New York Times shows that the Hemisphere Project was started in 2007 and has been carried out in great secrecy.
lead_paragraph: A slide presentation given to The New York Times shows that the Hemisphere Project was started in 2007 and has been carried out in great secrecy.

headline: Rubber-Suit Monsters Fade. Tiny Tokyos Relax.
abstract: In an era when digital effects have made the use of small models and suited actors look quaint, tokusatsu, or “special filming,” is on the way out.
lead_paragraph: CHOFU, Japan — Daisuke Terai plays one of the best-known characters in the history of science fiction, but few fans have ever seen the actor’s face. That is because Mr. Terai puts on a bright silver and red rubber suit before stepping onto a set made of miniature trees and buildings to do battle as the cosmic superhero Ultraman.

headline: Quinn to File Court Papers Supporting a Police Monitor
abstract: The announcement by Christine C. Quinn, in response to a judge’s ruling on the department’s stop-and-frisk policy, drew criticism from one of her mayoral rivals.
lead_paragraph: Christine C. Quinn, whose campaign for mayor of New York has been damaged in part by a perception that she is less critical of the Police Department’s stop-and-frisk practices than her leading rival, said on Sunday that she would submit court papers to support a monitor for the police.

headline: Quinn Reversal, Meant to Help Her, Now Hurts
abstract: Christine C. Quinn changed her position against overturning New York’s term limits law after prodding from Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg. But the about-face haunts her still.
lead_paragraph: There was no wiggle room. No equivocation.

headline: A Quintessential Politician
abstract: Throughout her campaign to be mayor, Christine C. Quinn, the New York City Council speaker, has repeatedly had to address criticism of her role in securing a third term for Michael R. Bloomberg.
lead_paragraph: Throughout her campaign to be mayor, Christine C. Quinn, the New York City Council speaker, has repeatedly had to address criticism of her role in securing a third term for Michael R. Bloomberg.

headline: Beating the Streak
abstract: After two decades of losing, the Pittsburgh Pirates are rolling. This month could bring a celebration of an actual berth in the playoffs.
lead_paragraph: After two decades of losing, the Pittsburgh Pirates are rolling. This month could bring a celebration of an actual berth in the playoffs.

headline: New Summer Destination: Hamptons Police Stations
keywords: ['Police', 'Drunken and Reckless Driving', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: The Hamptons police files this year stand as an example of the area’s struggle to balance its popularity with tourists with the high quality of life of its residents.
lead_paragraph: EAST HAMPTON, N.Y. — It was the perfect night to take the dog out. The temperature was just so. Clear skies made for spectacular star gazing. And the light sea breeze gently caressed the dense greenery of the normally peaceful village of East Hampton.

headline: United Behind a Son’s American Dream, No Matter the Consequences
abstract: As Marco Saavedra, who was brought to the United States as a toddler, seeks to change immigration law, his parents, despite their own unauthorized status, are supporting him.
lead_paragraph: Antonio Saavedra and Natalia Mendez wanted their three children to stay in school and stay out of trouble. They raised them without television, but with plenty of books, many of which are now crammed into a well-stocked library at La Morada, the Mexican restaurant the family runs on Willis Avenue in the South Bronx.

headline: Pittsburgh’s Stirring Leap From the Abyss
abstract: After 20 consecutive losing seasons, a record for futility in the major American professional sports, the Pittsburgh Pirates are poised to make the playoffs.
lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH — The lights go down on the makeshift studio behind Section 103 at PNC Park. The fans are long gone, the postgame show is over, and Kent Tekulve undoes his tie. It is light blue, not black and yellow, but otherwise, Tekulve looks about the same as he did when he threw the final pitch of the 1970s, the one that made the Pittsburgh Pirates champions.

lead_paragraph: The special effects genre known as “tokusatsu” helped take the Japanese film industry global, but now it is being replaced by computer graphics.

abstract: In a desperate move, Bob and Mike Bryan switched sides to throw off their Canadian opponents, Daniel Nestor and Vasek Pospisil.
lead_paragraph: For the twins Bob and Mike Bryan, one lost set was enough to change a winning formula.

headline: Outside Groups Have Spent $3 Million on Mayor’s Race
keywords: ['Citizens United v Federal Election Commission (Supreme Court Decision)', 'Campaign Finance', 'Elections, Mayors', 'Political Advertising']
abstract: With the majority of candidates abiding by spending caps in exchange for participating in the city’s matching-fund program, any outside financing could make a difference.
lead_paragraph: With little more than a week to go before the Democratic primary for New York mayor, outside groups have poured $3 million into supporting and opposing their preferred candidates, according to the most current figures through Sunday.

headline: Chasing Off Wildlife, With Course Etiquette
abstract: Working dogs help golf course superintendents by carefully guarding the grounds from intruders, like geese, and greeting visitors, the friendly kind.
lead_paragraph: For many golf course superintendents, working dogs are as essential as the lawn mowers and the sprinklers. Patrolling the course, working dogs greet players and chase away wildlife that can damage the turf. Some even have duties beyond the course, like visiting hospitals to comfort patients.

headline: 4 Die in Car Crash in Westchester
abstract: A rental car veered off Sprain Brook Parkway in Greenburgh on Sunday, slammed into a bridge abutment and burst into flames.
lead_paragraph: Four people were killed early Sunday when their car veered off a highway in Westchester County, slammed into a bridge abutment and burst into flames, officials said.

headline: Stephens Wins Style Points; Williams Wins Match
abstract: Sloane Stephens hit the flashy winners Sunday, but Serena Williams prevailed with superior discipline, will and tactical acumen
lead_paragraph: Serena Williams takes her losses very seriously, and her memory is long. Consider how Maria Sharapova has fared against Williams in the last several years, since Sharapova beat Williams in the Wimbledon final. In last year’s Olympic final, Sharapova barely got one game in a drubbing on Centre Court. Like any great champion, Williams hates to lose, and she shows up to play anyone with a recent win over her with a steely-eyed resolve that makes her even more formidable.

headline: Arrests of 3 Mayors Reinforce Florida’s Notoriety as a Hothouse for Corruption
abstract: In a state that led the nation in convictions of public officials last decade, the leaders of Homestead, Sweetwater and Miami Lakes were apprehended within a month.
lead_paragraph: HOMESTEAD, Fla. — Even by Florida standards, the arrests of three suburban Miami mayors on corruption charges within a month were a source of dismay, if not exactly a surprise.

headline: Pleased With the City’s Progress, but Wary of the Price
abstract: Residents of Windsor Terrace say New York City is safer thanks to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, but the improvements have come at the expense of those who scrape by.
lead_paragraph: “This is a working-class neighborhood,” Robert Mecea said, with more than a dollop of sarcasm. “But the houses sell for a million and a half, so I don’t know how working class that is.”

headline: With Isner Reaching New Heights, Karlovic Responds
abstract: John Isner’s height was officially changed this summer from 6-foot-9 to 6-10 to tie Ivo Karlovic for title of tallest man in tennis. Karlovic took to Twitter on Sunday to assert that he had grown, too.
lead_paragraph: Ivo Karlovic is not taking John Isner’s recent growth spurt sitting down. He’s standing up and being counted, in inches. Earlier this summer, Isner’s height was officially changed from 6-foot-9 to 6-10 to tie Karlovic for the title of tallest man in tennis.

headline: While Radwanska Is Upset, Djokovic Cruises
abstract: Agnieszka Radwanska became the highest-seeded player, on the men’s or women’s side, to lose thus far, while Novak Djokovic won his match in straight sets.
lead_paragraph: By at least one measure, Agnieszka Radwanska had been the most consistent player on the women’s tour this year: with a victory at the United States Open on Sunday night, she would have been the only woman to advance to the quarterfinals at all four Grand Slam events. Across from her was the erratic Russian Ekaterina Makarova.

headline: 1-Year-Old Boy Is Fatally Shot in Brooklyn

lead_paragraph: A 1-year-old boy died on Sunday night after being shot in the head on a Brooklyn street, the police said.

lead_paragraph: Some of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s health policies — banning smoking in most public places, posting calorie counts in chain restaurants — have become so entrenched, even popular, that it is hard to imagine they would be rolled back by his successors.

headline: Paul Poberezny, Pilot Who Founded Popular Fly-In, Dies at 91
abstract: At 15, Mr. Poberezny flew the first aircraft he ever traveled in and later founded the Experimental Aircraft Organization.
lead_paragraph: Paul Poberezny, who at 15 piloted the first aircraft he ever traveled in — a single-seat glider he had restored to working condition — and later founded what became one of the largest aviation organizations in the world, died on Aug. 22 in Oshkosh, Wis. He was 91.

headline: What’s on Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (TCM) THE STORY OF FILM: AN ODYSSEY Turner Classic Movies begins a 15-week festival of 119 films and dozens of short subjects representing 29 countries and 6 continents, and centered on Mark Cousins’s 2012 examination of the birth and evolution of cinema, and the innovations in storytelling, style and technology that resulted in its current form. Mr. Cousins, a film critic from Northern Ireland, “aims for comprehensiveness and coherence,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times of this 900-minute movie, presented in eight chapters. “He wants to tell the whole story, from Genesis to Revelation, as the saying goes, but he also wants this vast chronicle to have a shape and a point: themes and patterns amid the names, places and images. He succeeds to an impressive extent. The results of his dogged research, compulsive travel and hard thinking are exemplary, useful and sometimes thrilling.” Mr. Cousins and Robert Osborne will introduce each Monday episode, which begins here with movies from Thomas Edison’s New Jersey studio, at 8, and the Lumière brothers’ French studio, at 9:30, and “Birth of the Cinema (1900-1920),” the first episode of Mr. Cousins’s film, at 10. Georges Méliès’s short “Trip to the Moon” (1902), follows at 11:15, and Alice Guy-Blaché’s shorts “Falling Leaves” (1912), “Canned Harmony” (1912) and “A House Divided” (1913), at 11:30. The lineup concludes with three silent films: Oscar C. Apfel’s “Squaw Man” (1914), about a wrongly accused Englishman who escapes to Wyoming and takes an American Indian bride, at 12:30 a.m.; “D. W. Griffith’s Civil War epic, “The Birth of a Nation” (1915), at 2; and his “Orphans of the Storm” (1921), above, starring Lillian and Dorothy Gish as sisters struggling to find each other during the French Revolution, at 5:15.

headline: No U.S. Men in Final 16 Is a First at Open
abstract: Tim Smyczek, ranked 109th, was the last American man to fall at this year’s United States Open. For the first time in the tournament’s history, no American man advanced to the Round of 16.
lead_paragraph: After the other 14 American men bowed out in the first six days of the United States Open, the burden of 133 years rested on the shoulders of Tim Smyczek.

headline: What to Watch at the U.S. Open on Monday
abstract: Camila Giorgi, 21, is a potential star to keep an eye on, especially after her comeback, three-set victory over the No. 6 seed Caroline Wozniacki on Saturday. On Monday, she faces her fellow Italian Roberta Vinci, the No. 10 seed.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to remember a United States Open that featured so many young, talented players on the women’s side. At just 21, Camila Giorgi is another potential star to keep an eye on, especially after her three-set comeback victory over the No. 6 seed Caroline Wozniacki on Saturday.

headline: Bad History Mars Indian Movie On Rajiv Gandhi’s Assassination
keywords: ['Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Movies', 'Tamils (Ethnic Group)', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: Madras Cafe, a Bollywood movie on the assassination of former Indian Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi and the civil war in Sri Lanka gets its history wrong.
lead_paragraph: The movie “Madras Cafe,” which opened in India and elsewhere in the world recently, seeks to chronicle the Sri Lankan civil war through the events leading up to the assassination in 1991 of former Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi of India.

headline: South Korea Pledges Aid to the North
abstract: South Korea promised $8.4 million worth of humanitarian aid to North Korea on Monday, the latest effort to improve relations on the peninsula.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — South Korea promised $8.4 million worth of aid to North Korea on Monday, a conciliatory gesture that followed recent steps toward easing inter-Korean tensions and reviving economic and humanitarian cooperation.

headline: Takeover Bid for Chinese Food Company Rebuffs Short-Seller Attack
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Short Selling', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: Shares in the China Minzhong Food Corporation, targeted last week by the California short-seller Glaucus Research Group, surged 112 percent after the company received a $576 million takeover offer from Indofood Sukses Makmur.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG – The China Minzhong Food Corporation, whose Singapore-traded shares lost half their value last week after it came under attack from a California short-seller, said on Monday that it had received a timely takeover offer from its biggest shareholder, an Indonesian food company.

headline: Summer of Fire
abstract: The lessons learned from the summer of 1988 when fires burned nearly one third of Yellowstone National Park continue to shape the way we fight wildfires raging across the West today.
lead_paragraph: The lessons learned from the summer of 1988 when fires burned nearly one third of Yellowstone National Park continue to shape the way we fight wildfires raging across the West today.

headline: Ex-Nazi, 92, Goes on Trial in War Death
abstract: The prosecution of Siert Bruins, who served as a border guard in Adolf Hitler’s elite Waffen-SS troops, is part of an effort in Germany to bring elderly former Nazis to justice before it is too late.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — A 92-year-old man who served as a border guard in Adolf Hitler’s elite Waffen-SS troops went on trial on Monday on charges that he shot and killed a Dutch resistance fighter in the final months of World War II. His prosecution is part of a German effort to bring aging Nazis to justice before it is too late.

headline: Lessons From the Yellowstone Fires of 1988
keywords: ['Fires and Firefighters', 'Forests and Forestry', 'Wildfires', 'National Parks, Monuments and Seashores', 'News and News Media', 'Baby Boomers']
abstract: This Retro Report video looks at the enormous wildfires that defied the formulas and changed firefighting policy in the West.
lead_paragraph: While even little children know that Smokey Bear can spot a fire before it starts to flame, whether to douse that fire or let it burn out on its own is hard for even the best trained grownups to get right.

headline: Daily Report: Automakers Embrace Augmented Reality for Virtual Showrooms
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Automobiles', 'Mobile Applications', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Virtual Reality (Computers)']
abstract: Automakers, facing reluctance by young buyers to visit showrooms, are using a digital marketing tool to bring the showroom to them.
lead_paragraph: Young car buyers are seen as reluctant to visit showrooms, instead preferring to educate themselves online about their options. In response, automakers like Cadillac and Toyota are starting to embrace technology that tries to take the showroom to the buyer.

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Sara Corbett on Collaborating With Amanda Lindhout to Tell a Harrowing Tale
abstract: Unraveling the three-year mind meld that resulted in the book, “A House in the Sky,” from which this week’s cover article was adapted.
lead_paragraph: Sara Corbett is the co-author of this week’s cover story told from the point of view of Amanda Lindhout, a young woman who was kidnapped and held captive in Somalia for 460 days. The article is adapted from the book the two wrote together about Lindhout’s experience, “A House in the Sky,” published this month. Corbett, a contributing writer to the magazine, last wrote about the artist Shea Hembrey.

headline: Rupee Continues Decline on New Evidence of Weakness in Indian Economy
abstract: A survey of purchasing managers at manufacturers across India, released on Monday, showed them to be at their gloomiest since March 2009.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI — The Indian rupee began slipping lower in currency markets again on Monday and Tuesday after a two-day respite, as further signs emerged of broad troubles in the Indian economy.

headline: Dressing for Kindergarten Success
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Computer and Video Games', 'Education (Pre-School)', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Parenting', 'T-Shirts (Apparel)']
abstract: It wasn’t just my son who loved his shirt. Any kid who saw it pointed and yelled, “Angry Birds!” I could see why he wanted to wear it; I just couldn’t allow it.
lead_paragraph: There was little anxiety in our house about the first day of kindergarten until my son, Johnny, told me what he wanted to wear. “Angry Birds,” he said in an “of course” tone, choosing the one shirt in his wardrobe that was completely contrary to my image of what a well-parented child would wear.

headline: Whac-A-Hack
abstract: The Russian crackdown is entering its carpet-bombing stage: Now it’s going after hack artists.
lead_paragraph: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia — The Museum of Power was open for 12 days before the police raided it and shut it down. This was the first most people had heard of it, even in the Russian art world. The grandly named museum was really a small gallery in what used to be a communal apartment. It claimed to be “the only museum devoted to people who rule us and influence us on a daily basis.” It professed adherence to no particular movement in politics or art. It did not appear to be a particularly serious effort at an art gallery.

headline: Russia Rejects U.S. Evidence on Syrian Chemical Attack
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Foreign Minister Sergey V. Lavrov dismissed as unconvincing the evidence presented by Secretary of State John Kerry, indicating that Russia would continue to block action at the United Nations.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russia’s foreign minister dismissed as unconvincing the evidence presented by Secretary of State John Kerry of chemical weapons use by the Syrian government, saying on Monday that the United States had fallen far short of making a case for international cooperation on military strikes against the government of President Bashar al-Assad.

headline: How the Other 47 Percent Lives
abstract: A bit of Marxism talk, according to Rick Santorum.
lead_paragraph: I couldn’t make space for it in today’s column, but any affluent reader who wants a sense of what America is like for many hard-working people should read about the website McDonald’s has established to help its workers manage their family budget. The sample monthly budget they offer includes $900 from a second job; monthly rent of just $600 (which is very low even for a single-bedroom apartment in inexpensive cities, and of course ludicrous in metro New York), and zero heating expenses.

headline: ‘Sesame Street’ Widens Its Focus
abstract: With its usual silliness, “Sesame Street” is introducing serious concepts about nature, science, math and engineering to its target audience of children too young to read.
lead_paragraph: On “Sesame Street,” a distressed cow has a big problem. She made it up the stairs to the beauty parlor but now, her bouffant piled high, she’s stuck. Cows can go up stairs, she moans, but not down.

lead_paragraph: Updated, 11:16 p.m. | When it comes to ranking which merger advisers are on top of their industry, landing a role on a $130 billion deal can help out a lot.

headline: Israeli President Voices Strong Support for Obama’s Decision on Syria

headline: Why Female Journalists in India Still Can’t Have It All

headline: ‘Redshirts’ Takes Hugo Award for Best Science-Fiction Novel
abstract: John Scalzi’s novel is about members of a spaceship crew who discover they are actually part of a television show.
lead_paragraph: The annual Hugo Awards for excellence in science fiction writing were announced Sunday night, and the winner of the award for best novel was the prolific John Scalzi. Though best known for his “Old Man’s War” series, which began as an homage to Robert Heinlein’s “Starship Troopers,” Mr. Scalzi was honored for “Redshirts,” a comedic novel about a group of ensigns aboard a spaceship who discover they are actually part of a television show similar to “Star Trek.”

headline: Joe Fendel’s Long Walk Home
abstract: You promise to come right home after school to do chores, but you didn’t promise to come straight home. How long can your trip be?
lead_paragraph: Our puzzle this week is a brilliant original by Joe Fendel, who most recently suggested Rectangled Square. Long Walk Home is a perfect back-to-school challenge, which Mr. Fendel presents this way:

abstract: In this special issue of the podcast, we look at science and math education through three lenses: curriculum, technology and experimentation.
lead_paragraph: In this special issue of the podcast, we look at science and math education through three lenses: curriculum, technology and experimentation.

headline: Verizon Seals Long-Sought $130 Billion Deal to Own Wireless Unit
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Telephones and Telecommunications', 'Wireless Communications']
abstract: Verizon will pay about $58.9 billion in cash and about $60.2 billion in stock for Vodafone’s stake. Other considerations are also part of the deal.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:15 p.m. | Verizon Communications agreed on Monday to spend $130 billion to take full control of its enormous wireless unit because it said it believed that the American desire for cellphones and broadband services was not yet nearly sated.

headline: Image of the Day: Sept. 2
abstract: The Tibetan government in exile in India celebrated the 53rd Tibetan Democracy Day in Dharamsala, Himachal Pradesh.

headline: Mets Sign Aaron Harang to Minor League Deal
abstract: Aaron Harang, 35, was 5-11 for Seattle this season with 5.76 earned run average, and is likely to pitch in the Mets’ doubleheader on Sept. 14.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The Mets announced Monday that they signed the right-hander Aaron Harang to a minor league contract and assigned him to Class AAA Las Vegas.

headline: Recession Reverses California Airport’s Growth
abstract: Analysts say a change in how airlines operate has also affected business at Ontario International Airport.
lead_paragraph: ONTARIO, Calif. — Rolling into Ontario International Airport is a traveler’s delight. The parking lots, across from either terminal, are mostly vacant. The spacious, tidy terminals are filled with natural light and few lines at the ticket counters. Jostling around the baggage carousel is not like trying to box out LeBron James for a rebound — there is plenty of elbow room for everyone.

headline: President Gains McCain’s Backing on Syria Attack
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The White House pushed forward for Congressional approval of an attack on Syria as President Obama got qualified support from a hawkish Republican critic, Senator John McCain.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House’s aggressive push for Congressional approval of an attack on Syria appeared to have won the tentative support of one of President Obama’s most hawkish critics, Senator John McCain, who said Monday that he would back a limited strike if the president did more to arm the Syrian rebels and the attack was punishing enough to weaken the Syrian military.

headline: What Memorable Experiences Have You Had in Learning Science or Math?
abstract: This is a special edition of our daily Student Opinion question. Posting a comment here by Sept. 27 will enter you in a contest that we will judge in collaboration with The Times’s science desk.
lead_paragraph: Update: Oct. 16: Winners have been announced! Thank you for participating!

headline: At Transfer Deadline, Arsenal Gets Its Man
abstract: On the frenzied final day of the European transfer period, it was Arsenal that appeared to make the loudest move by landing Real Madrid midfielder Mesut Özil.
lead_paragraph: The final day of the European transfer period always brings a rash of transactions and a topsy-turvy feel. So it was again on Monday, though with a twist: Manchester United, a club known for its impact signings, was noticeably quiet, while Arsenal, a club conspicuous by its silence this summer, made the day’s loudest move.

headline: Jets Sign Quinn and Stoke Intrigue
abstract: The arrival of Brady Quinn, recently cut by Seattle, is the latest sign that Geno Smith will start in the Jets’ season opener on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — The Jets have four quarterbacks on their roster. Two have never attempted a regular-season pass in the N.F.L. Another, at this rate, will not throw again until Halloween. Or next week. Or the afternoon of the first snowfall. It is all a bit confusing.

headline: ‘Fifty Shades’ Film Gets Its Christian and Anastasia
abstract: Charlie Hunnam will play Christian Grey and Dakota Johnson will be Anastasia Steele in the movie adaptation of E.L. James’s blockbuster novel.
lead_paragraph: It’s a long way from “Ben and Kate” and “Sons of Anarchy” to “Fifty Shades of Grey,” but the model and actress Dakota Johnson and the British actor Charlie Hunnam are about to make that big leap.

headline: Rainy Day Yields an All-Italian Quarterfinal Matching Two Veterans
abstract: No. 10 Roberta Vinci beat Camila Giorgi, 6-2, 6-2, to advance to the quarterfinals, where she will face her fellow Italian Flavia Pennetta.
lead_paragraph: In the quarter of the United States Open women’s draw so loaded with Italians it should have been officially named Little Italy, intracountry clashes have flourished. Fittingly, there will be an all-Italian quarterfinal.

headline: Flying the Surly Skies, Stay Positive
abstract: Shawn Achor is chief of Good Think Inc., a positive psychology consulting firm.
lead_paragraph: I GIVE about 100 lectures a year, which translates to about 300 flights. I try to stay positive about everything, which shouldn’t be a surprise considering I’m a researcher, author and educator in the field of positive psychology.

headline: Learning Math? There's An App for That.
abstract: A team of software developers and academic researchers are trying to create a suite of educational apps that will hopefully ease the learning process for pre-schoolers (and their educators).
lead_paragraph: A team of software developers and academic researchers are trying to create a suite of educational apps that will hopefully ease the learning process for pre-schoolers (and their educators).

headline: Conversations With Andy Murray: The Women’s Game
abstract: Andy Murray discussed women’s tennis, who he liked to watch play and why there was still disagreement over equal prize money.
lead_paragraph: After his 7-6(2), 6-2, 6-2 third-round victory over Florian Mayer on Sunday, Andy Murray, the defending United States Open champion, discussed his thoughts on women’s tennis, a topic he has talked about more than most of his peers. In previous conversations with The Times, Murray has discussed his return to New York, his time away from the court, and the intensity of rivalries in modern tennis.

headline: Field-Testing the Math Apps
keywords: ['Mobile Applications', 'Education (K-12)', 'Children and Childhood', 'Computer and Video Games', 'Mathematics']
abstract: With the advent of interactive touch screens, educational apps have taken off. Until recently, there has been little research into their effectiveness, but that is starting to change.
lead_paragraph: LAWRENCE, Mass. — Elias was shy at first. “He’s 4,” his teacher whispered when he would not say his age. He made no sound as his peers rushed to the tables with the iPads. When a friend grabbed the device to take his photo, he covered his eyes with his hands.

headline: Very Young Programmers
abstract: After a program to teach children 8 and up to code proves successful, its creators adapt it for even younger students.
lead_paragraph: Ten years ago, a computer programming language called Scratch emerged from the Media Lab at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Using colorful stackable icons to represent the sequencing and logic of computer code, Scratch was designed to make programming easy for children 8 and older. Today the free program is used in more than 150 countries and thousands of schools, with more than 1,500 animations and games uploaded to the online Scratch community each day. Even third and fourth graders call themselves coders.

headline: U.S. Open Replay: Week 1
abstract: Lleyton Hewitt upsets Juan Martin del Potro and Serena Williams breezes through in the first week of the U.S. Open.
lead_paragraph: Lleyton Hewitt upsets Juan Martin del Potro and Serena Williams breezes through in the first week of the U.S. Open.

headline: With Common Core, Fewer Topics but Covered More Rigorously
abstract: As states adopt the new Common Core standards for math education, teachers prepare for a shift from breadth to depth, particularly in the earlier grades.
lead_paragraph: If the new mathematics standards adopted by New York and 44 other states work as intended, then children, especially in the lower elementary grades, will learn less math this year.

headline: Life Expectancy Grows for Women Age 50 and Up
abstract: A new World Health Organization report indicated that while women are living longer, poor and middle-income countries could easily make greater gains.
lead_paragraph: Life expectancy for women who live to age 50 is going up around the world, but poor and middle-income countries could easily make greater gains, according to a new World Health Organization report.

headline: Hit-and-Run Case Seen as Reflection of Inequality in Thailand
abstract: A grandson of the creator of the Red Bull energy drink admitted to fatally striking a police officer with his Ferrari and dragging his dead body down a Bangkok street.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — The Bangkok policeman was fatally struck by a gray Ferrari, his body dragged down a darkened Bangkok street. In contrast to his sudden and brutal death 12 months ago, the Thai judicial process that has followed has been slow and labored.

headline: Mystery of the Missing Women in Science
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Mathematics', 'Tests and Examinations', 'Science and Technology', 'Education (K-12)']
abstract: Female students are catching up or surpassing male counterparts in math and science, yet the fields like engineering and computer science remain male dominated.
lead_paragraph: Peter Ostrander, the tireless coordinator and cheerleader for a renowned science and mathematics magnet program at Montgomery Blair High School in Silver Spring, Md., was not satisfied. Over the past few years, the pool of applicants had included nearly as many girls as boys, and the acceptance rate — based largely on test scores and grades — had followed suit.

headline: Images of Her Russian Aunts Win Award for Brooklyn Photographer
abstract: Nadia Sablin is the winner of the Firecracker Award for her documentary project, “Two Sisters.”
lead_paragraph: The Brooklyn-based photographer Nadia Sablin has won the second annual Firecracker Award, which provides money to female photographers working on documentary projects. She was honored for a series called “Two Sisters,” about aunts of hers in a Russian village, where they live in ascetic fashion, chopping their own firewood, making their own clothes and cooking meals from scratch.

headline: Data Security Begins With the Traveler
keywords: ['Credit Cards', 'Identity Theft', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Computer Security', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Business Travel']
