headline: Beatles Albums Go Platinum in Britain, Belatedly
abstract: Changes in methodology by a British music industry trade group mean that “Revolver” and “Rubber Soul,” among other albums, now get the designation.
lead_paragraph: It may be hard to believe, but only now are 13 classic Beatles albums being certified as platinum discs in Britain, where they were recorded and first released. That very belated recognition — the Beatles broke up in 1970 — is the result of changes announced by the British Phonographic Industry, the music industry trade group responsible for awarding gold and platinum status to best-selling records in Britain.

headline: Ideas for Improving Science Education
abstract: If you could make one change to improve science education in the United States, what would it be? Science Times asked that question of 19 Americans — scientists, educators, students — with a stake in the answer.
lead_paragraph: If you could make one change to improve science education in the United States, what would it be? Science Times asked that question of 19 Americans — scientists, educators, students — with a stake in the answer.

abstract: Science Times asked 19 experts, “If you could make one change to improve science education in the United States, what would it be?”
lead_paragraph: If you could make one change to improve science education in the United States, what would it be? Science Times asked that question of 19 Americans — scientists, educators, students — with a stake in the answer. Their responses follow.

headline: In Dallas, a Garden Designed for Children
keywords: ['Flowers and Plants', 'Gardens and Gardening', 'Travel and Vacations']

lead_paragraph: Giving earth science a Disney touch, the Dallas Arboretum will unveil its expansive Rory Meyers Children’s Adventure Garden on Sept. 21.

headline: Chinese Educators Look to American Classrooms
abstract: While the world may be dazzled by Chinese students’ test scores, educators in China worry that the lack of hands-on science learning is stifling innovation and critical thinking.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — To prepare for an endless barrage of secondary-school exams, Zhang Ruifan learned to memorize entire science textbooks. So when his family sent him to high school in the United States, he was so far ahead of his fellow freshmen in math and science that he usually knew the correct answer even before the teacher had finished speaking.

headline: Young Students Against Bad Science
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Evolution (Biology)', 'Science and Technology', 'Creationism and Intelligent Design', 'Global Warming', 'Abstinence (Sexual)']
abstract: Meet some high school and college students who have taken stands on issues connected to science education.
lead_paragraph: Your parents may have had to walk uphill, both ways, to get to school. But as ideological warfare threatens the teaching of climate science and evolution in many schools, it is clear that today’s students face their own obstacles on the road to a respectable science education — and some are speaking out.

headline: 'Change This City'
abstract: In the third television ad from the de Blasio campaign, the candidate tries to claim the mantle of "the progressive candidate."
lead_paragraph: In the third television ad from the de Blasio campaign, the candidate tries to claim the mantle of "the progressive candidate."

headline: Standard-Bearer in Evolution Fight
abstract: Eugenie C. Scott, longtime director of the National Center for Science Education, has spent a career beating back efforts to teach creationism in schools across America.
lead_paragraph: Eugenie C. Scott’s journey to the front lines of the evolution wars began in 1974, when James Gavan, a physical anthropologist at the University of Missouri, accepted an invitation to debate Duane Gish, a biochemist and a leader in the creationist movement.

headline: Cognitive Science Meets Pre-Algebra
abstract: Mixing related but distinct concepts in lessons has proved more effective than focusing on one subject at a time, though it feels harder.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — The math students at Liberty Middle School were not happy.

keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Tea Party Movement', 'United States International Relations', 'Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: The Congressional vote will offer the best insight yet on which wing of the Republican Party — the party’s traditional hawks, or a growing bloc of noninterventionists — has the advantage.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Congressional vote on whether to strike Syria will offer the best insight yet on which wing of the Republican Party — the traditional hawks, or a growing bloc of noninterventionists — has the advantage in the fierce internal debates over foreign policy that have been taking place all year.

headline: U.S. Open Food Review: A Chance of Meatballs
abstract: Monday’s U.S. Open food review: the meatball sub at the South Plaza Cafe.
lead_paragraph: Because eating at the United States Open is a high-stakes game, we will feature a daily review of items available at the food courts at the National Tennis Center.

headline: Mixed Feelings Over N.F.L. Concussion Settlement
abstract: A former N.F.L. player writes that he is conflicted by the concussion settlement, which will bring relief to retired players but does not answer what was known by the league about head injuries.
lead_paragraph: I expected a settlement to come at some point. What I didn’t expect was to feel so oddly conflicted about it.

headline: Guesses and Hype Give Way to Data in Study of Education
abstract: Amid a sore lack of data, one federal office is conducting randomized trials of various educational programs to determine which live up to their claims.
lead_paragraph: What works in science and math education? Until recently, there had been few solid answers — just guesses and hunches, marketing hype and extrapolations from small pilot studies.

headline: Russia Issues Travel Warning to Its Citizens About United States and Extradition
abstract: The Foreign Ministry warned citizens wanted by the United States not to visit nations that have an extradition treaty with it, citing recent arrests.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Countries often issue travel advisories warning citizens of danger abroad: war, for instance, or a terrorist threat or an outbreak of disease. The Russian Foreign Ministry posted advice of a somewhat different nature on Monday, cautioning people wanted by the United States not to visit nations that have an extradition treaty with it.

headline: An Insider’s Guide to Eating at the Open
abstract: When it comes to cuisine, the United States Open is unlike any other sporting event. Lynn Zinser, a veteran of several Opens, shares her secrets about what to eat without going broke.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to cuisine, the United States Open is unlike any other sporting event. Lynn Zinser, a veteran of several Opens, shares her secrets about what to eat without going broke.

headline: Sharks Absent, Swimmer, 64, Strokes From Cuba to Florida
abstract: The endurance swimmer Diana Nyad, 64, on Monday became the first person to swim the 110 miles from Cuba to Key West, Fla., without a shark cage.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — This time, nature tipped its hat, and Diana Nyad finally conquered the 110-mile passage from Cuba to Florida that had bedeviled her for 35 years.

headline: STEM Doesn’t Mean Flowers
abstract: An excerpt from a 2010 essay by Natalie Angier that objected to “the odious and increasingly pervasive term ‘STEM education.’”

headline: A Centuries-Old Sport, Fit for a Prince
abstract: Archery is the national sport of Bhutan, a tiny Himalayan nation squeezed between India and China, past and present.
lead_paragraph: Archery is the national sport of Bhutan, a tiny Himalayan nation squeezed between India and China, past and present.

headline: De Blasio Family Dance
abstract: Bill de Blasio and members of his family performing a dance move at the West Indian American Day Parade in Brooklyn on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Bill de Blasio and members of his family performing a dance move at the West Indian American Day Parade in Brooklyn on Monday.

headline: Archery Gives Bhutan Its Sporting Chance
abstract: Bhutan held the Yangphel archery tournament, its national championship, last weekend, and there was much singing, dancing and drinking as the arrows flew.
lead_paragraph: THIMPHU, Bhutan — By the final round Saturday, the baby-face prince and his team of ringers had an almost insurmountable lead in this reclusive kingdom’s national archery tournament, but a fierce fight broke out for second place.

headline: Expecting the Best Yields Results in Massachusetts
abstract: Adopting rigorous standards, and sticking with them while giving teachers some breathing room, has helped Massachusetts’ students rise to No. 1 in the nation on science and math achievement.
lead_paragraph: BRAINTREE, Mass. — Conventional wisdom and popular perception hold that American students are falling further and further behind in science and math achievement. The statistics from this state tell a different story.

headline: Revisiting the Scenes of Unsolved Crimes
abstract: “Cold Justice” and “Deadline: Crime With Tamron Hall” reopen unsolved crimes.
lead_paragraph: The line between televised entertainment and real-life criminal justice blurs a bit more this week with the arrival of “Cold Justice” on TNT and “Deadline: Crime With Tamron Hall” on Investigation Discovery. Neither series premiere is very satisfying, but “Cold Justice” picks up considerably in its second episode and seems as if it might be a worthy addition to the genre.

headline: Still Lonely, Troubled and Singularly Heroic
abstract: Idris Elba (and a couple of his nemeses) return on Tuesday for the third season of the BBC America series about the unusual London police detective John Luther.
lead_paragraph: The last time we saw Detective Chief Inspector John Luther, a young woman he had just rescued from the pornography business offered him an endorsement that pretty much summed up the thinking behind the BBC crime drama “Luther.” “You’re totally epic,” she said, and though he was taken aback for a moment, he couldn’t disagree. Then he bought her a 99 Flake — because epic coppers love their ice cream — and she asked, “So what’s next?”

headline: David Frost: Newsman, Showman, and Suave at Both
abstract: Mr. Frost was  a newsman with a flair for show business, an entertainer with a thoughtful side, and at times a slightly ludicrous schmoozer with sophistication and charm.
lead_paragraph: People tend to think that the line between comedy and hard news was breached first by Jon Stewart, host of “The Daily Show.”

headline: 10 Late de Kooning Works to Go on View, and on Sale
abstract: The Willem de Kooning Foundation and Gagosian Gallery plan to exhibit, and sell, 10 paintings by de Kooning in New York this fall to raise money for scholarly and educational programs.
lead_paragraph: When Willem de Kooning was a struggling young artist and needed money, he would frequently sell a painting or sculpture as quickly as he made it. After his death in 1997, when the Willem de Kooning Foundation needed cash, it, too — like many artists’ foundations — would sell a work from its holdings, but always privately.

headline: Attacks Delayed, Syrians Juggle Anticipation With Attempts at Normalcy
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: The delay in an expected missile strikes left Syria struggling to return to normalcy, with the military and rebels still bracing and everyone uncertain whether an attack would happen at all.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Two days after President Obama shocked Syrians by delaying expected American missile strikes, the country remains off balance, with the military still bracing, the rebels still hoping to capitalize on the confusion, civilians increasingly fleeing across the borders and everyone uncertain whether the attack has been called off for good.

headline: Albums From Neko Case, Ariana Grande, Gorguts and Chelsea Wolfe
abstract: The songs on Ms. Case’s sixth solo studio album, “The Worse Things Get, the Harder I Fight, the Harder I Fight, the More I Love You,” are brief but mutable.
lead_paragraph: NEKO CASE“The Worse Things Get, the Harder I Fight, the Harder I Fight, the More I Love You”(Anti-)

headline: In Mountain Air, Foresight (Maybe)
abstract: At the Telluride Film Festival in Colorado, previews of films to come.
lead_paragraph: TELLURIDE, Colo. — I know, I know, it’s much too early to be thinking about the Academy Awards, and Oscar talk is considered a bit gauche up here, but the Telluride Film Festival has had the distinction, for three years running, of providing the first North American screens for the eventual best picture winners. If your head for recent Oscar trivia is as bad as mine, I’ll share the fruits of my Googling and remind us all that those movies were “The King’s Speech,” “The Artist” and “Argo.” So maybe the road to the Dolby Theater in Hollywood will once again run downhill from this scruffy-chic former mining town in the San Juan Mountains.

headline: Weaving Science Into Fiction
abstract: Science and progress are featured in “Archangel,” Andrea Barrett’s collection of fiction set between 1873 and 1939.
lead_paragraph: “The Ether of Space,” the second of five interlaced stories in Andrea Barrett’s elegantly contemplative new collection, takes place in 1920. Like the other four tales, and like Ms. Barrett’s National Book Award winner, “Ship Fever,” it is immersed in a scientific world of the past and set at a juncture where science and history collide. At that time, Einstein’s theory of relativity was supplanting earlier ways of envisioning the universe, yet some of Ms. Barrett’s characters are frightened by the lack of humanism in such progress. They cannot easily part ways with the past.

headline: Milestones in Science Education
abstract: Highlights of science and math education though the years.
lead_paragraph: “Leadership tomorrow depends on how we educate our students today — especially in science, technology, engineering and math,” President Obama has declared. While the words may be new, the sentiment goes back a long way.

headline: CBS Returns, Triumphant, to Cable Box
abstract: An agreement with Time Warner Cable restores CBS and its related channels, like Showtime, to millions of cable subscribers largely in three major cities, New York, Los Angeles and Dallas.
lead_paragraph: CBS and Time Warner Cable ended their protracted contract dispute Monday evening with CBS winning not only a significant financial increase for its programming, but also its stake in the digital future.

headline: In Mayoral Race, Attacking Real Estate Industry but Taking Its Cash
abstract: A new set of dirty words has cropped up in the race for New York City mayor: “real estate,” “developers” and “condos.” But that hasn’t stopped the major campaigns from collecting donations from the industry.
lead_paragraph: In the Democratic primary for New York City mayor, a new set of political dirty words has surpassed the usual favorites, like “lobbyist” and “flip-flop,” that are traditionally used to spritz opponents and adversaries with a film of slime.

headline: A Bet on the Environment
abstract: The company Mosaic functions as an online renewable energy bank, soliciting investments for solar projects and making loans for them.
lead_paragraph: Just after his sophomore year at Yale in 2002, Billy Parish stood before a rapidly retreating glacier in India that feeds the Ganges River, convinced that he had come face to face with climate change and that he had to do something about it.

headline: Kanye West Sings at Kazakh Wedding
abstract: Mr. West performed at the wedding reception for the grandson of Kazakhstan’s longtime president, Nursultan Nazarbayev.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Kanye West serenaded the grandson of Kazakhstan’s longtime president, Nursultan Nazarbayev, at a wedding reception in Almaty on Saturday, seeming to put aside concerns about human rights abuses during the leader’s 23-year autocratic rule. Photographs and video of Mr. West at the Royal Tulip hotel in Almaty began appearing Saturday evening, when he stepped out of a black Mercedes onto a red carpet. Video on Instagram showed a gaggle of young wedding guests, their backs to the stage, posing for pictures with Mr. West as he performed “Can’t Tell Me Nothing.” Alyona Gadjilova, the photographer who uploaded the video to Instagram, refused to comment on the wedding when reached by phone on Monday evening.

headline: French Release Intelligence Tying Assad Government to Chemical Weapons

lead_paragraph: Paris — The French government sought to bolster the case for military action against Syria on Monday, releasing a declassified summary of French intelligence that ties President Bashar al-Assad’s government to the apparent use of chemical weapons outside Damascus last month.

headline: China Graft Inquiry Sweeps Up Billionaire Oil Entrepreneur

lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A billionaire Chinese petrochemical entrepreneur on Monday became the fifth senior industry figure in a week to become enmeshed in a corruption investigation that continues to reach higher into China’s political and economic elite.

headline: Yankees Roll Past the White Sox With an Eight-Run Fourth
abstract: After a nearly two-hour rain delay in the second inning, the Yankees broke open the game in the fourth for a runaway win over last-place Chicago.

lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The elements of an interminable afternoon were locking into place early Monday.

headline: Davis, Headed to New York for M.R.I., Seems Unlikely to Return This Season
abstract: Ike Davis, who strained his right oblique muscle Saturday, is expected to have a magnetic resonance imaging exam Tuesday, and then rest for the remainder of the month.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Ike Davis has not yet seen a doctor after straining his right oblique muscle Saturday night, but he acknowledged it was unlikely that he would return to the field this season as he wished teammates and reporters well after the Mets’ 13-5 loss to the Atlanta Braves on Monday afternoon.

headline: Bertelsmann Joins Venture for New Music by Established Acts
abstract: The German media giant will buy most of the publishing assets of Primary Wave, and they will form a joint venture to release and market new recordings.
lead_paragraph: Bertelsmann, the German media giant, has expanded its recent efforts to return to the music business through a $150 million deal with Primary Wave Music, an American company that handles music publishing rights, artist management and marketing, the companies plan to announce on Tuesday.

headline: Cruz Expects to Be Ready for Opener
abstract: Wide receiver Victor Cruz, defensive end Jason Pierre-Paul and fullback Henry Hynoski returned to practice for the Giants, with Cruz saying he expected to play Sunday against the Cowboys.
lead_paragraph: Giants wide receiver Victor Cruz returned to practice Monday, running pass routes with the starting lineup and making cuts on his bruised left heel with no apparent discomfort. Cruz said after practice that he expected to play in Sunday night’s season opener against the Dallas Cowboys.

headline: Amid Coral Reefs and Ruins, Ripples of Fear Over a Recent Attack
abstract: After two Western women were harmed in an acid attack, residents are worried that the island, known as a vacation paradise, will be branded hostile territory.
lead_paragraph: ZANZIBAR, Tanzania — Said Ola began training early for the tourist trade in Zanzibar. As a youth he would come down to a popular park overlooking the Indian Ocean, one of the young men known as “practice boys” who learn English by chatting with visitors.

headline: Janusz Lewandowski, 82, Polish Peace Envoy in Vietnam, Dies
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Vietnam War', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'International Relations']
abstract: In Operation Marigold, Mr. Lewandowski, then a diplomat from Poland, was given the task of trying to initiate talks between Washington and Hanoi in 1966.
lead_paragraph: The Vietnam War was raging with no end in sight in June 1966 when President Lyndon B. Johnson was told of a bold diplomatic peace offensive in the works called Operation Marigold. In comments caught on tape in the Oval Office, he called it “the most realistic, the most convincing, the most persuasive peace feeler I’ve had since I’ve been president.”

headline: Zanzibar Faces Scrutiny
abstract: An acid attack on two Western women has brought unwelcome attention to a Tanzanian island better known as a vacation paradise.
lead_paragraph: An acid attack on two Western women has brought unwelcome attention to a Tanzanian island better known as a vacation paradise.

headline: Tommy Morrison, Boxer and Co-Star in ‘Rocky V,’ Dies at 44
abstract: Mr. Morrison defeated George Foreman for the heavyweight title and starred as a boxing protégé of Rocky Balboa’s in “Rocky V.”
lead_paragraph: Tommy Morrison, who displayed his hard-hitting boxing style as a protégé of Sylvester Stallone’s Rocky Balboa in the 1990 movie “Rocky V” and defeated George Foreman to capture a heavyweight boxing championship, but was banned from the ring in 1996 when he tested positive for H.I.V., died Sunday in Omaha. He was 44.

headline: With Change Coming, Aetna Targets Employers
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: The insurance company’s “Our Healthy” campaign will focus on cutting waste in health care spending through technological innovation.
lead_paragraph: AS the country marches toward a new health insurance system, insurance companies have spent millions on consumer advertising to position themselves as health care companies.

headline: National Gun Debate Hits Close to Home in Colorado Recall Vote
abstract: Two recall elections in the state are being watched closely as a litmus test of how voters respond to new measures where gun culture is ingrained.
lead_paragraph: COLORADO SPRINGS — Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York and the billionaire philanthropist Eli Broad have each donated hundreds of thousands of dollars. The National Rifle Association is buying political advertisements. New York’s junior senator sent a fund-raising e-mail. And the election has attracted news coverage from as far away as Sweden.

headline: Amid Exits, President of Hunter College Is Assailed for Her Management Style
abstract: Jennifer J. Raab has created “a culture of fear,” according to one departing assistant dean, but supporters say the college’s fortunes have risen during her tenure.
lead_paragraph: Jennifer J. Raab, the fast-moving, fast-talking president of Hunter College, recently landed a $25 million donation, the largest in the college’s history. A science and health building that Hunter is constructing with Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center won approval last month from the Department of City Planning. And on Tuesday, Ms. Raab will cut the ribbon on Phase 1 of a $45 million redesign of the college’s library — a bright, inviting, communal space that could transform the compact vertical campus.

headline: As Summers’s Odds Rise, Stimulus Easing Is Seen
abstract: Anticipation that Lawrence H. Summers will be President Obama’s choice to lead the Federal Reserve Board has some investors speculating about a faster withdrawal of stimulus.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The spreading expectation that President Obama will name Lawrence H. Summers to lead the Federal Reserve Board appears to be working against the central bank’s efforts to stimulate the economy.

headline: Brazil Angered Over Report N.S.A. Spied on President
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Privacy']
abstract: Brazil’s government summoned the United States ambassador on Monday to respond to new revelations of American surveillance of President Dilma Rousseff and her top aides.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Brazil’s government summoned the United States ambassador on Monday to respond to new revelations of American surveillance of President Dilma Rousseff and her top aides, complicating relations between the countries ahead of Ms. Rousseff’s state visit to Washington next month.

headline: The Vatican: Pope Sends New Year’s Greetings to Jews
abstract: Pope Francis on Monday wished Jews worldwide a “sweet and peaceful” Rosh Hashana, which is the Jewish New Year, citing “important decisions lying ahead.”
lead_paragraph: Pope Francis on Monday wished Jews worldwide a “sweet and peaceful” Rosh Hashana, which is the Jewish New Year, citing “important decisions lying ahead.” The pope also called for “increased dialogue among the world’s religious communities” and pledged to oppose restrictions on religious freedom, according to a statement released by the World Jewish Congress after a private meeting at the Vatican. Ronald S. Lauder, president of the Jewish group, said the pope’s leadership had “given a new momentum to relations with Judaism.” He said of the Roman Catholic Church that the “leadership of successive popes over the past five decades has helped to overcome a lot of prejudice.” At the meeting the pope also said the Vatican would investigate the ban on the religious slaughter of animals in Poland, which has incensed Jews.

headline: Federer Tumbles to Earliest Exit in 10 Years
abstract: Roger Federer, seeded seventh, lost to 19th-seeded Tommy Robredo of Spain, 7-6 (3), 6-3, 6-4, in a fourth-round stunner at Louis Armstrong Stadium.
lead_paragraph: As Roger Federer’s summer of decline continued on Monday, he refused to blame his bad back or an unfamiliar stadium for his earliest loss at the United States Open in 10 years. That left only his performance to explain another defeat and the pattern that continued.

headline: Big Dreams, but Little Consensus, for a New Detroit
keywords: ['Area Planning and Renewal', 'Bankruptcies', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Agriculture and Farming']
abstract: Detroit’s bankruptcy gives an American city a rare chance to reinvent itself from top to bottom, but questions about how it should proceed loom as large as the answers.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — There are 78,000 abandoned buildings in this city standing in various levels of decay. Services have fallen into dysfunction, and debts are piling ever higher. Yet for all the misery, Detroit’s bankruptcy gives an American city a rare chance to reshape itself from top to bottom.

headline: Newtown Shows It’s Moving Forward, in Step
abstract: The Connecticut town where 20 children and 6 adults were massacred did its best to be respectful of the tragedy while grasping for normalcy at its Labor Day parade.
lead_paragraph: NEWTOWN, Conn. — She had not expected this. But at the judge’s stand at the end of the parade, after carrying the Sandy Hook Elementary School banner with three other mothers, Kristen Kinsey found herself proud, happy, teary and confused.

headline: China Debates Effect of Trial’s Rare Transparency
abstract: There are competing arguments about whether the trial of Bo Xilai, the former official charged with bribetaking, has contributed to progress in establishing rule of law.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The melodramatic trial of Bo Xilai, the former elite Communist Party official, has been trumpeted by the state news media here as a sure sign that Chinese citizens enjoy the benefits of a robust legal system.

headline: Stenson Wins Day, and Spieth, 20, Has Dibs on Future
abstract: Henrik Stenson finished at 22 under to capture the Deutsche Bank Championship, but a final-round surge by Jordan Spieth vaulted him into contention in the FedEx Cup playoffs.
lead_paragraph: NORTON, Mass. — Jordan Spieth completed his final round at the Deutsche Bank Championship to the accompaniment of thunder, the rumbling in the background heralding the impending arrival, it seemed, of both inclement weather and the next player to take the PGA Tour by storm.

headline: How a Cabal Keeps Generics Scarce
abstract: The critical shortage of generic drugs continues unabated.
lead_paragraph: ABOUT a year ago, President Obama signed a law that was supposed to end chronic shortages of lifesaving drugs. But the critical lack of generic drugs continues unabated. It is a preventable crisis that is inflicting suffering on patients and, in some cases, causing needless deaths.

headline: Conjuring the Ghosts of Iraq’s Brutal Past
abstract: Even as the government takes steps to remind Iraqis about Saddam Hussein’s brutal ways, critics accuse Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki of mimicking many of his repressive tactics.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — These days in Iraq, state-supported reminders of the horrors of Saddam Hussein’s rule are always close at hand.

headline: The Fix for Europe: People Power
abstract: Only a transnational grass-roots movement can save the E.U.
lead_paragraph: IN next year’s European elections, we must unmask our national politicians’ best-kept secret: that what they see as the be-all and end-all of modern governance, the nation-state, is fast becoming an obsolete political structure.

headline: Upset Binge Boosts a Supposedly Lower College Division
abstract: Eight teams from the Football Championship Subdivision, formerly known as Division I-AA, knocked off teams from college football’s top tier.
lead_paragraph: McNeese State was about to play a bigger team from a bigger division in a bigger stadium, but Coach Matt Viator wanted to make sure that his players were not overwhelmed by the stage. So on Friday, the day before McNeese State opened its season against South Florida, Viator had his team tour Raymond James Stadium.

headline: McKinsey & Co. Isn’t All Roses in a New Book
abstract: “The Firm,” by Duff McDonald, chronicles the rise of the world’s most influential management consulting firm, but also cites its many failures.
lead_paragraph: “You can’t get fired for hiring McKinsey & Company.”

headline: NATO Must Help Obama on Syria
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Kosovo, where NATO intervened with force in 1999 despite the lack of a United Nations Security Council resolution, is an important precedent.
lead_paragraph: MEDFORD, Mass. — President Obama has sensibly opted to seek support from Congress on Syria, which provides a window of time to approach another body that should offer more than moral support: NATO.

headline: No Ordinary Passenger
abstract: In this short film, Stan Dibben, a winner of the World Sidecar Championship in 1953, recounts the thrills and perils of his profession.
lead_paragraph: In this short film, Stan Dibben, a winner of the World Sidecar Championship in 1953, recounts the thrills and perils of his profession.

headline: ‘No Ordinary Passenger’
abstract: Stan Dibben, a winner of the World Sidecar Championship in 1953, recounts the thrills and perils of his profession.
lead_paragraph: This Op-Doc tells the story of Stan Dibben, a fascinating British man who won the World Sidecar Championship in 1953. Sidecar racing is an extremely dangerous, three-wheeled motor sport that was particularly popular in postwar Europe. Now, at age 87, Mr. Dibben recounts the thrills and perils of his profession, and we see that he is so much more than a mere “passenger.”

headline: In Iraq, Echoes of Another Era
abstract: As the Iraqi government puts renewed emphasis on memorializing victims of Saddam Hussein’s rule, critics say security crackdowns mimic the old regime’s repressive tactics.
lead_paragraph: As the Iraqi government puts renewed emphasis on memorializing victims of Saddam Hussein’s rule, critics say security crackdowns mimic the old regime’s repressive tactics.

headline: For Votes, a Common Appeal to the Struggling  Residents in the City
abstract: The good news for those New Yorkers who need their help is that the leading Democratic candidates for mayor are focused on them.
lead_paragraph: In search of Democratic mayoral primary voters, I took a humid hike on Monday up the precipitous streets and stairways of Highbridge in the Bronx. A working-class aerie perched above the Harlem River, the neighborhood embraces native-born and immigrant New Yorkers by the thousands.

headline: The Storm on New York’s Horizon
abstract: In the race to succeed Mayor Bloomberg, the campaigns seem to be avoiding any talk of unpleasant budgetary realities.
lead_paragraph: Come January, a new mayor of New York will take office with the city facing a bad budget forecast: cloudy, chilly, with a chance of apocalypse.

headline: Lottery Numbers
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Traveling Without Seeing
abstract: In our digital cocoons, we go everywhere and nowhere.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — I’m half a world from home, in a city I’ve never explored, with fresh sights and sounds around every corner. And what am I doing?

headline: Empty Barn-Rafters
abstract: The swallows have moved on yet again. How did they know it was time to leave?
lead_paragraph: The swallows have gone, and I do not understand it. How do they arrange to depart? At one moment the birds are here, chattering in and out of the barn, arcing across the pasture. And the next moment they have vanished. Do they leave during a flight they’re already making, or do they somehow gather themselves together beforehand?

headline: Debating the Case for Force
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Editorials', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: President Obama needs to explain why limited military strikes against Syria would be effective.
lead_paragraph: President Obama made the right decision to seek Congressional authorization for his announced plan to order unilateral military strikes against Syria for using chemical weapons. There has to be a vigorous and honest public debate on the use of military force, which could have huge consequences even if it is limited in scope and duration.

headline: Fighting Poverty, and Critics
abstract: Jeffrey Sachs is trying to help villages in Africa, but is his work making a difference?
lead_paragraph: Nina Munk’s new book, “The Idealist,” is about the well-known economist Jeffrey Sachs and his “quest to end poverty,” as the subtitle puts it. I know: That subtitle sounds like classic book-industry hyperbole, but, in this case, it’s not. That really is what Sachs has been trying to do. The question of whether or not he is succeeding is where things get tricky.

headline: Women in Philosophy? Do the Math
abstract: We don’t need harassment to keep women and minorities from succeeding in philosophy — alienation, bias and outright discrimination will do the job.
lead_paragraph: Since the resignation of the well known philosopher Colin McGinn from his tenured post at the University of Miami, following sexual harassment allegations made against him by a graduate student, the longstanding debate about the obstacles faced by women in academic philosophy has been renewed. The Stone recently asked several women philosophers about their views on the status of women in philosophy, both inside and outside academia. Five of them will be published on consecutive days this week. This is the first.

headline: Catsimatidis Campaigns With Heart, Tongue and Checkbook Unfettered
abstract: At campaign appearances, no one would ever guess that John A. Catsimatidis, a Republican, was the billionaire in the room, but he has run this year’s most idiosyncratic race for New York City mayor.
lead_paragraph: His tie is often askew, his clothes often stained. He fell asleep on a car ride with a reporter from WNYC radio, who dutifully recorded his gentle snoring.

headline: The Ad Campaign: De Blasio’s Message of 2 Cities, Again
abstract: Bill de Blasio’s latest 30-second commercial, “Change This City,” ties Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to Park Avenue, Wall Street and other signifiers of elitism.
lead_paragraph: Judging by a recent surge in the polls, Bill de Blasio has profited handsomely from his long-cultivated stance as the “anti-Bloomberg” outsider candidate in the Democratic mayoral primary. Now he is doubling down on his “tale of two cities” rhetoric in a new 30-second commercial, “Change This City,” which ties Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to potent signifiers of elitism like Park Avenue and Wall Street.

headline: Drawing a Line on Syria, U.S. Keeps Eye on Iran Policy
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Two recent diplomatic ventures have raised hopes that the United States will be able to strike Syria without compromising efforts toward easing tensions with Iran.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the Obama administration makes a case for punitive airstrikes on the Syrian government, its strongest card in the view of some supporters of a military response may be the need to send a message to another country: Iran. If the United States does not enforce its self-imposed “red line” on Syria’s use of chemical weapons, this thinking goes, Iran will smell weakness and press ahead more boldly in its quest for nuclear weapons.

headline: On Parade, Candidates Get Exposure and Advice

Mr. Obama had made considerable progress with Dmitri A. Medvedev, the caretaker president, and wanted to preserve the momentum.

headline: Taxing Homeowners as if They Were Landlords
abstract: The tax code would be fairer if homeowners were taxed as landlords on their own property, which would equalize the tax treatment of all investments, including in one’s own home, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of “The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform – Why We Need It and What It Will Take.”

headline: Flow of Refugees Out of Syria Passes Two Million
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Humanitarian Aid', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: The United Nations high commissioner for refugees says neighboring countries are not receiving nearly enough help to handle the influx.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — As the United States and its allies struggled for a course of action to punish the use of chemical weapons in Syria, the United Nations said the number of civilians who had fled to neighboring countries had surpassed two million — a new milestone in what it called “the great tragedy of this century, a disgraceful humanitarian calamity.”

headline: Microsoft Gets Nokia Units, and Leader
abstract: Microsoft will acquire the handset and services business of Nokia for more than $7.1 billion in an all-cash deal, and Stephen Elop, the chief of Nokia and a former Microsoft executive, will rejoin Microsoft.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Microsoft said it has reached an agreement to acquire the handset and services business of Nokia for about $7.2 billion, in an audacious effort to transform Microsoft’s business for a mobile era that has largely passed it by.

headline: What’s on Tuesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 5:10 P.M. (MoreMax) MAGIC MIKE (2012) In a role loosely inspired by his stint as a stripper in Florida, Channing Tatum, above center, stars as the gyrating main attraction at the Xquisite dance club, in what Manohla Dargis, writing in The New York Times, called “Steven Soderbergh’s funny, enjoyable romp about male strippers and the American dream.” Alex Pettyfer plays Adam, a college dropout who is pushed onstage at Xquisite. At first Adam is resistant. Then Madonna’s “Like a Virgin” begins to throb. “What happens will be familiar if you’ve ever seen one of those variations on the fallen-woman movie,” Ms. Dargis wrote. “In the past, the movies were very much preoccupied with the moral regulation of women, but here, the stress is on Mike’s struggle to succeed as he juggles his part-time gigs (dancing, auto detailing and construction) with his desire to build custom furniture.” She added: “The collaboration between Mr. Soderbergh and the relatively untested Mr. Tatum is itself a gamble, one that has brought out the best in each. What could have been an embarrassing misfire hinted at by the movie’s misleading trailers is instead a smoothly distilled collaboration that balances Mr. Tatum’s heat and charm — and ambitions that are as transparent as Mike’s — with Mr. Soderbergh’s cool, cinematic intelligence and ongoing preoccupations.”

headline: Military Rape, Enemy Within the Ranks
keywords: ['Photography', 'Sex Crimes', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Less than 20 percent of military sexual assault victims come forward, and those that do often face retribution. Mary F. Calvert set out to document the human repercussions of this statistic.
lead_paragraph: PERPIGNAN, France — Mary F. Calvert has dedicated herself to covering under-reported stories of women and children in crisis around the world, including the effects of systematic rape in the conflict-torn Democratic Republic of Congo.

abstract: In an age of luxury sneakers, the new Swedish brand Eytys offers a refreshing alternative in the form of low-key platform plimsolls that riff on the ’90s skater shoe.
lead_paragraph: On the heels of the now ubiquitous high-end luxury sneaker, the new Swedish brand Eytys offers a refreshingly low-key alternative: platform plimsolls that channel ’90s Venice Beach skater shoes.

headline: Values Conflict at the End of Life
keywords: ['Death and Dying', 'Elder Care', 'Living Wills and Health Care Proxies']
abstract: Family members often make end-of-life decisions according to their own values, not the patient’s, a new study finds.
lead_paragraph: In theory, or in a more perfect universe, our family members wouldn’t have a hard time deciding what to do when we were near death. However painful the task, the decisions would be clear: We would have prepared a written document, an advance directive, stating what we wanted doctors to do or not do, and our about-to-be survivors would follow our instructions. Simple.
