In this scene, Ralph considers his options for the future. The show continues through Sunday at Walkerspace.

headline: Reporter Returns to Texas Capitol, Where Father’s Voice Still Rings
keywords: ['Baby Boomers', 'Politics and Government', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Babe Schwartz, my politician father, didn’t get why I chose journalism, but now we both know that life can take us full circle, if on different paths.
lead_paragraph: A little while ago, my bosses asked me to fill in for a colleague by reporting from Austin, Tex., where the State Legislature was considering one of the toughest abortion bills in the country. I was happy to say yes. Not only was it a fascinating topic, but Austin is also one of my favorite towns. Not coincidentally, my parents and my daughter and son-in-law live there.

headline: Microsoft-Nokia Could Woo Buyers Trading Up to Smartphones
abstract: Microsoft could help Nokia keep customers who are transitioning from lower-end feature phones, rather than let them escape to an Apple iPhone or Google Android ecosystem.
lead_paragraph: It’s clear that converting people from one brand of smartphone to another is a costly and difficult transaction. Apple iPhone owners swear by their iPhones. Google Android owners love the openness of the Android ecosystem.

headline: Intersection: Siam Shopping Style
abstract: In Bangkok’s Siam Square neighborhood, a choreographer describes a local trend involving contact lenses.
lead_paragraph: In Bangkok’s Siam Square neighborhood, a choreographer describes a local trend involving contact lenses.

headline: Microsoft’s Nokia Deal
abstract: Microsoft to acquire the handset and services business of Nokia for about $7.2 billion. | Verizon is betting the American desire for cellphones and broadband services is far from being sated. | A new book asks whether advice from McKinsey & Company is worth it. | The trustee for victims of Bernard L. Madoff has added claims to his lawsuit.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft has reached an agreement to acquire the handset and services business of Nokia for about $7.2 billion, an audacious effort to reshape itself for a mobile era that has largely passed it by, Nick Wingfield reports in The New York Times. Microsoft and Nokia said 32,000 Nokia employees would join Microsoft as a result of the all-cash deal, which makes the Finnish mobile phone pioneer the engine for Microsoft’s mobile efforts.

headline: Germany Sends 30 Death Camp Cases to Local Prosecutors
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Concentration Camps', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: Justice officials recommended investigations of surviving guards from Auschwitz-Birkenau in renewed efforts to punish Holocaust crimes.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — German justice officials recommended Tuesday that local prosecutors open investigations against 30 surviving guards from the Auschwitz-Birkenau death camp on suspicion that they were accessories to murder, part of an effort to bring lower-level perpetrators of the Holocaust to justice.

headline: Microsoft to Buy Nokia Units and Acquire Executive
abstract: The $7.2 billion all-cash deal is meant to turn the Finnish mobile phone pioneer into the engine for Microsoft’s mobile efforts. Stephen Elop, the former Microsoft executive who was running Nokia, will rejoin Microsoft.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Microsoft said it had reached an agreement to acquire the handset and services business of Nokia for about $7.2 billion, in an audacious effort to transform Microsoft’s business for a mobile era that has largely passed it by.

headline: Pixies Motor On, With New Bassist
abstract: The Pixies are releasing a new EP and going on tour, without the beloved Kim Deal, who announced a few weeks ago that she was leaving the band.
lead_paragraph: A couple of years ago, when the Pixies were almost 300 concerts into their second life as reunited heroes of alternative rock, they played a casino in Canada. The symbolism stopped them for a moment: had the Pixies succumbed to stereotype and become an oldies act?

headline: What Does a Democrat Look Like?
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A young woman in Bryant Park is told by a stranger that she looks like a Democrat.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: ‘Crazy’ Three Ways: Willie, Patsy and Willie Again
abstract: After Willie Nelson wrote it, Patsy Cline recorded it, giving rise to a host of cover versions, including one by the songwriter himself.
lead_paragraph: Val Haller, a music-obsessed baby boomer and the founder of the Web site Valslist.com, matches tracks from her generation to those of her 20-something sons’ generation.

headline: Amazon Pairs Print and Digital Books With New Program
keywords: ['Amazon Kindle', 'Book Trade and Publishing', 'Books and Literature', 'E-Books and Readers', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: Amazon is about to test readers’ appetite for owning both paper and electronic editions of their books, by offering retroactive discounts on combined packages.
lead_paragraph: For most readers, print and electronic books are an either-or proposition. There just isn’t a compelling reason to buy both editions of one book, at least not at full price.

headline: Frenzied but Steadfast
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Terrorism']
abstract: If last week Israelis seemed panicky, this week they seem dissatisfied that military action against Syria has been postponed.
lead_paragraph: TEL AVIV — Last week my wife made a curious trade with a friend. She gave him an old baby gas mask we had to spare him from having to obtain one from a military distribution center when just about every other Israeli was doing the same. In return, we got a Bob the Builder helmet.

headline: Datto, a Data Backup Service, Raises $25 Million in Round Led by General Catalyst
abstract: Datto, which provides both local and cloud-based data backup and continuity services, plans to announce on Tuesday that it has raised $25 million in its first-ever round of venture capital financing, led by General Catalyst Partners.
lead_paragraph: Helping companies protect and restore their data is a growing business. Now, a six-year-old start-up is aiming to get a bigger piece of the action.

headline:
Ronald H. Coase, ‘Accidental’ Economist
Who Won a Nobel Prize, Dies at 102
abstract: Professor Coase was a law professor whose papers on why companies work and when government regulation is unnecessary influenced modern economics.
lead_paragraph: Ronald H. Coase, whose insights about why companies work and when government regulation is unnecessary earned him a Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science in 1991, died on Monday in Chicago. He was 102.

headline: Israel and U.S. Conduct Missile Test in Mediterranean
abstract: The testing of the Sparrow target missile caused concern in Russia and Syria, given the tensions over a possible American military strike on Syria.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israel and the United States tested a new air-defense system on Tuesday morning, launching a missile from deep in the Mediterranean Sea that caused consternation in Syria and Russia given the heightened tension in the region as the Obama administration weighs a military strike in Syria.

headline: House Leaders Express Their Support for Syria Strike
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Biological and Chemical Warfare']
abstract: President Obama won the support of Republican and Democratic leaders in the House for an attack on Syria, as a Senate panel agreed on the wording for a measure to permit military action.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama won the support on Tuesday of Republican and Democratic leaders in the House for an attack on Syria, giving him a foundation to win broader approval for military action from a Congress that still harbors deep reservations.

headline: Fertility Diary: Finding a Doctor Who ‘Gets’ Me
abstract: I know having a baby is all that should matter, but when you are opening yourself up — literally and emotionally — to an ob/gyn weekly, shouldn’t you be able to have a connection?
lead_paragraph: “There’s something wrong here.” That is one of the first things Dr. C. says to us as he looks over our medical history. I look at my husband, Solomon, and we both sigh with palpable relief: finally.

headline: Keeping Score: Using the Monte Carlo Method in Tennis
abstract: Monte Carlo analysis uses a random process to assess a complicated problem and can help predict the winner of the U.S. Open.
lead_paragraph: A Monte Carlo analysis uses a random process to assess a complicated problem. In the financial world, Monte Carlo methods can help study the risk of investment strategies or to evaluate derivatives. Sporting events can also show the power of Monte Carlo simulations because sports can be broken down into specific events like an at-bat in baseball, or a possession in football or basketball.

headline: Massachusetts: Math Capital?
abstract: Massachusetts has sharply improved math achievement for its eighth graders. Kenneth Chang visited one city in the state to see how they’re doing it.
lead_paragraph: Massachusetts has sharply improved math achievement for its eighth graders. Kenneth Chang visited one city in the state to see how they’re doing it.

headline: In Norman Rush’s Manuscripts, a Partnership in Play
abstract: Norman Rush describes his wife, Elsa, whose handwriting appears on his typed draft of “Subtle Bodies,” as “a partner in the process.”

headline: Sept. 3: Where the Candidates Are Today
abstract: The candidates’ daily campaign schedule at a glance.
lead_paragraph: Planned events for the mayoral candidates, according to the campaigns and organizations they are affiliated with. Times are listed as scheduled but frequently change.

headline: N.H.T.S.A. Investigates 110,000 Nissans Over Transmission Leak
abstract: Nissan had sent out a technical service bulletin to dealers containing repair instructions for C.V.T. fluid leaks.
lead_paragraph: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration is investigating failures of the continuously variable transmission on an estimated 110,000 Nissan Pathfinders and Infiniti JX sport utility vehicles from the 2013 model year, according to a report posted Monday on the agency’s Web site.

headline: After Rape and Neglect, a Survivor’s Family Fades Into Oblivion in Delhi
keywords: ['Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Families and Family Life', 'Police', 'Sex Crimes']
abstract: The bleak aftermath of rape in India.
lead_paragraph: In April, a 5-year-old girl was raped and tortured in eastern New Delhi, then left for dead, with her internal organs and sexual organs damaged. The horrific nature of the crime set off a renewed fury in the streets of Delhi, which had already seen thousands of people protest after the gang rape of a 23-year-old student on a moving bus.

headline: Today in Small Business: Is Podcasting Back?
abstract: Five business stories to watch. How to terminate an employee you don’t want to terminate. Nine Israeli start-ups.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: The Gun Report: Labor Day Weekend Edition
abstract: A weekend in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Two weeks ago we announced a breather from the Gun Report. In that time, according to Slate’s gun-death tracker, which we quote at the bottom of each post, 580 people lost their lives to gun violence in America.

headline: Exploring the New Food Focus at Scientific American
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Blogs and Blogging (Internet)', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Food', 'Genetic Engineering', 'Medicine and Health', 'Science and Technology']
abstract: A video chat with Scientific American’s new team of food bloggers.
lead_paragraph: Scientific American is obsessed with food at the moment, running Food Week on its blogs and devoting its September print issue to all aspects of the substances we consume. You can follow the discussion on Twitter using #SciAmFood.

headline: LeBron James Developing TV Series for Starz
abstract: LeBron James, the Miami Heat forward and NBA star, will help to develop “Survivor’s Remorse,” a comedy series about two cousins from a tough Philadelphia neighborhood who struggle with the downsides of fame and fortune.
lead_paragraph: Having fulfilled his goal of winning an NBA championship a couple of times over, LeBron James is taking his talents to cable television. The Starz cable channel said on Tuesday — not in an hourlong TV special, but in a news release — that it was working with Mr. James, the Miami Heat forward and four-time NBA most valuable player, to develop a half-hour comedy series called “Survivor’s Remorse.” This series, Starz said, will “explore the complexity, comedy and drama of an experience that everyone reads about, but few understand – what truly happens when you make it out.” The network said this scripted series will chronicle two fictional cousins who grew up in a tough Philadelphia neighborhood and, having since achieved fame and fortune, now struggle “with the rewards of money, stardom, love and, occasionally, the guilt of having ‘made it.’”

headline: To Vladivostok and Beyond
abstract: Despite its turbulent history and uncertain finances, the Kontinental Hockey League, based in Russia, is set to open its sixth season with 28 teams in 8 nations and 9 time zones.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Admiral, one of two new teams in the Kontinental Hockey League, cobbled together a roster in a matter of weeks this summer, picking up youthful prospects in an expansion draft as well as journeymen from Russia, Germany, Sweden and Canada. The team began practicing at an arena outside Moscow only last month, its foreign players delayed by hitches in obtaining work visas. Its home arena in Vladivostok, a port city on the Pacific Ocean, 4,000 miles from Moscow (and only 70 from North Korea), remains unfinished, forcing the team to play its first seven games on the road.

headline: A Second Act for the Legendary Stage Actor Joel Grey
abstract: The actor, director, and photographer, perhaps best known for playing the sinister M.C. in Bob Fosse’s “Cabaret,” will show an enigmatic series of photographs of decaying billboards at Steven Kasher gallery in New York.
lead_paragraph: Since playing the sinister M.C. in Bob Fosse’s “Cabaret,” Joel Grey has kept busy: he acts, directs (currently a production of “On Borrowed Time,” the play in which he made his theatrical debut at age 9) and takes photographs, a hobby that has yielded four books and work in the Whitney’s permanent collection. His latest series — enigmatic images of peeling, weather-worn billboards — will be published in a Sam Shahid-designed monograph next month, and can be seen at Steven Kasher Gallery in New York. The twist? The photos were shot with an iPhone 5, demonstrating that Grey, 81, is quite adept at changing with the times.

headline: London Production of ‘Merrily We Roll Along’ to Be Screened in Movie Theaters
abstract: The acclaimed London production of the Stephen Sondheim-George Furth musical “Merrily We Roll Along” will be shown in movie theaters on Oct. 23.
lead_paragraph: An acclaimed London production of the Stephen Sondheim-George Furth musical “Merrily We Roll Along,” which Mr. Sondheim said was the best “Merrily” he had ever seen, will be screened in movie theaters in New York City and worldwide on Oct. 23, the producers and the film distributors announced on Tuesday.

headline: Summers the Shiftless
abstract: Continuity is the last thing we need.
lead_paragraph: A few months ago Christy Romer gave an excellent talk on the prospects for monetary policy in a liquidity trap, titled It Takes A Regime Shift (pdf). As many of us have noted, the central bank has very little direct traction when safe short-term rates are at the zero lower bound; maybe it can achieve something by buying lots of unconventional assets (“quantitative easing”), but its main hope of achieving anything is through “expectations management” — convincing both financial markets and players in the real economy that it will hold off much longer on tightening once the economy improves than they currently expect, which will lead to higher expected inflation and demand, and hence higher spending now.

headline: AMC Aims to Raise $400 Million in I.P.O.
abstract: An initial public offering would be the latest corporate maneuver for AMC Entertainment, the second-largest movie theater owner in North America.
lead_paragraph: A year after being acquired by the Wanda Group, AMC Entertainment Holdings is looking to go public.

headline: A Sweet German Riesling With Steamed Fish
abstract: The fragility of the wine perfectly fits this dish’s delicacy.
lead_paragraph: For this gentle steamed fish, one wine stands out as a brilliant match: lightly sweet German riesling, at either kabinett or spätlese levels of ripeness. The fragility of the wines perfectly fits the delicacy of the fish, while their snappy acidity and suggestion of sweetness will softly buttress the flavors of the fish and seasonings. Even so, other choices will work well, as long as they are not overpowering, tannic or deficient in acidity. You could try an Austrian grüner veltliner or any number of crisp Italian whites. If you prefer a red, try lighter pinot noirs from New Zealand or Oregon, perhaps, or airy reds from northern Italy like Valpolicella or grignolino.

headline: Altidore Back on the Field
abstract: Sunderland striker Jozy Altidore has been ruled fit and will be with the U.S. national team for two coming World Cup qualifying matches.
lead_paragraph: Sunderland striker Jozy Altidore, who missed last weekend’s match in England’s Premier League nursing a tender hamstring, has been cleared to return to the field.

headline: Crossing the Lines Dividing the Races
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Books and Literature', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: White women who became denizens of black neighborhoods and culture during the Harlem Renaissance are the subject of Carla Kaplan’s “Miss Anne in Harlem.”
lead_paragraph: Today, the mustard-yellow brick building at 321 Edgecombe Avenue in Harlem doesn’t look like much. A metal security gate guards the small courtyard, while drab curtains and collapsed Pampers boxes cover the windows, blocking the summer sun.

headline: Frederik Pohl, Science Fiction Master Who Vaporized Utopias, Dies at 93
abstract: Mr. Pohl, who grew up in Brooklyn, edited magazines and books before finding renown as a writer. Perhaps the most famous of his novels was “The Space Merchants.”
lead_paragraph: Frederik Pohl, whose passion for science fiction while growing up in Brooklyn led to a distinguished career as one of its most literate and politically sophisticated practitioners, though one who was skeptical about attempts to perfect society through scientific means, died on Monday. He was 93.

headline: Obama Turns to Former Advisers
abstract: The White House is deploying President Obama’s political brain trust from the 2008 campaign to help make the case for military action in Syria.
lead_paragraph: The White House is deploying President Obama’s political brain trust from the 2008 campaign to help make the case for military action in Syria. Several of Mr. Obama’s closest former aides gathered at the White House on Tuesday morning at the behest of the chief of staff, Denis R. McDonough, to coordinate their message.

headline: Image of the Day: Sept. 3
abstract: Lyonchhen Tshering Tobgay, prime minister of Bhutan, met business leaders in Hyderabad, Andhra Pradesh.

headline: 'Not Even Close'
abstract: A new ad from the Catsimatidis campaign attacks his Republican rival, Joseph J. Lhota, in comparison to former mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.
lead_paragraph: A new ad from the Catsimatidis campaign attacks his Republican rival, Joseph J. Lhota, in comparison to former mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

headline: Federer Paid Price for Not Adjusting His Game Plan
abstract: Roger Federer held fast to a game plan that seemed better suited for playing Rafael Nadal than Tommy Robredo.
lead_paragraph: The humility of Tommy Robredo triumphed over the stubbornness of Roger Federer on Monday in the intimate confines of Louis Armstrong Stadium.

headline: ‘Natasha, Pierre and the Great Comet of 1812’ Moving to Midtown
abstract: The immersive nightclub-meets-musical production, based on a section of Tolstoy’s “War and Peace,” is moving to an empty lot on West 45th Street for a 14-week run.
lead_paragraph: The big red pop-up tent in the meatpacking district – home to the unusual nightclub-meets-musical production of “Natasha, Pierre and the Great Comet of 1812” – is moving uptown to the theater district, though not to a Broadway house. At least not yet.

headline: For BlackBerry, Bad News in the Microsoft-Nokia Marriage
keywords: ['BlackBerry (Handheld Device)', 'Cellular Telephones', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Smartphones', 'Wireless Communications']
abstract: Now that Microsoft has thrown its financial muscle behind Nokia, BlackBerry is left to find another suitor.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — If misery loves company, BlackBerry had a friend in Nokia while both companies were struggling to adapt to a changed mobile phone world.

headline: Two More Hedge Funds Scoop Up Stakes in J.C. Penney
abstract: Since William Ackman sold his 18 percent stake in Penney , Glenview Capital Management and Hayman Capital Management have become some of its largest stockholders.
lead_paragraph: The hedge funds Glenview Capital Management and Hayman Capital Management have swooped in on J.C. Penney shares, joining a list of hedge funds that have disclosed bullish views on the struggling retailer.

headline: Are Novelists Too Wary of Criticizing Other Novelists?
abstract: Zoë Heller and Adam Kirsch on the challenges involved when one fiction writer reviews another.
lead_paragraph: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on pressing and provocative questions about the world of books. This week, Zoë Heller and Adam Kirsch discuss the challenges involved when one fiction writer reviews another.

headline: Budget Battles Keep Agencies Guessing
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: The combination of cuts and a breakdown in the budgeting process leaves offices reluctant to hire or to commit to big projects.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The collision of the $1 trillion in budget cuts known as sequestration and the breakdown of the normal budgeting process is creating headaches not just for Washington but also for a vast web of offices dependent on federal financing. Many have been left uncertain as to how much money — if any — they will have to spend in the year ahead.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
abstract: Was there something  extra added to the Old Navy logo?
lead_paragraph: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

headline: Catwalks and Pillow Mints
abstract: Here are a few hotels where you can hobnob with glitterati during Fashion Week and even snag a seat to a fashion show.
lead_paragraph: You can tell when Fashion Week hits New York, London, Milan or Paris: stylish hotels are flooded with fashion editors, celebrities and models teetering in heels. Here are a few spots where you can hobnob with them and even snag a seat to a fashion show.

headline: Kenya Considers Leaving International Criminal Court
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: A vote in Parliament on Thursday will come days before  William Ruto, the deputy president, is scheduled to go to trial on a charge of crimes against humanity.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — Kenya’s Parliament will meet on Thursday to vote on whether to pull out of the International Criminal Court.

headline: Hollywood’s Tanking Business Model
abstract: After a series of big-budget bombs at the box office, Hollywood could learn a thing or two from economists.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 40 years ago, a great white dorsal fin sliced through American cinemas with its ominous, minor-second-interval leitmotif, and a new business model was born. “Jaws,” which cost $7 million to make, was deemed a good fit for a June release in 1975 partly because it took place at a beach around Independence Day. But its extraordinary success — the movie went on to earn $471 million at box offices worldwide — subsequently helped spawn Hollywood’s now-conventional wisdom that if you’re going to make a blockbuster, then summer, when kids are out of school and people are in search of industrial-strength air-conditioning, is the best time to release it. After “Star Wars” became a huge hit two summers later, all the big studios seemed to take notice.

headline: Hotel Says ‘G’Day,’ and ‘G’Night,’ With Music-Centric Campaign
abstract: A campaign does double duty by promoting the Redbury, a boutique hotel in Los Angeles, and the Rubens, an Australian rock band.
lead_paragraph: Remember the commercials that proclaimed Certs was both a candy mint and a breath mint, which “Saturday Night Live” famously spoofed with a mock spot for Shimmer, the floor wax that doubled as a dessert topping? Decades later, a video clip for a boutique hotel is also promoting a rock band — or is it a video clip for a rock band that is also promoting a boutique hotel?

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Public Relations and Publicity', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: American Express is teaming with Vanity Fair and Condé Nast Entertainment for “The Decades Series,” a collection of video clips that will mark the 100th anniversary of Vanity Fair.
lead_paragraph: American Express is teaming with Vanity Fair magazine and Condé Nast Entertainment for “The Decades Series,” a collection of video clips that will commemorate the 100th anniversary of Vanity Fair, which Condé Nast has published from 1913 to 1936 and again from 1983 onward. Each video will be devoted to a decade of the last 100 years and be created by filmmakers who include Judd Apatow (the 1990s), Don Cheadle (the 1980s), Bryce Dallas Howard (the 1960s) and Barbara Kopple (the 1930s). The video series will be available for viewing on a Vanity Fair Web site, the Vanity Fair YouTube channel and on a new American Express interactive brand channel, Amex Now.

headline: Romanian Charged With Genocide
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Prisons and Prisoners']
abstract: The charges against Alexandru Visinescu are part of Romania’s efforts to grapple with its Communist past by bringing to justice former commanders who enabled a brutal police state.
lead_paragraph: Romanian prosecutors on Tuesday charged Alexandru Visinescu, the commander of a Communist-era prison, with genocide. He is the first Romanian to face that charge since the dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, who was tried and executed in 1989.

headline: Business Owners Say They Have Yet to Figure Out Health Care
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Small Business']
abstract: One owner says she is having trouble pitching clients and budgeting because she does not know what her costs will be.
lead_paragraph: At the last meeting of the She Owns It business group, we talked about how, if at all, the owners expect the Affordable Care Act to affect their businesses. Several group members — Alexandra Mayzler, Jessica Johnson, and Susan Parker — were unable to attend the meeting, but they offered their thoughts in individual conversations afterward. (We had also discussed health care in a previous post.)

headline: JPMorgan Case Tests U.S. Law on Buying Influence Abroad
abstract: The United States government’s investigation into reports that JP Morgan Chase hired scores of children of powerful government officials throughout Asia will test how broadly the law applies to almost commonplace conduct by firms seeking any small advantage to win business from foreign governments.
lead_paragraph: Reports that JPMorgan Chase hired scores of children of powerful government officials throughout Asia have put the bank squarely in the sights of the United States government for violating the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act. An investigation will test how broadly the law applies to almost commonplace conduct by firms seeking any small advantage over rivals to win business from foreign governments.

headline: Dennis Rodman’s Back in North Korea
abstract: He said he was “just trying to go over there and meet my friend Kim, the Marshal.”
lead_paragraph: The ex-basketball player Dennis Rodman had a great time when he visited North Korea in March. He sat next to the country’s authoritarian leader, Kim Jong-un, at an exhibition basketball game and later ate sushi with him. He said Mr. Kim was “really awesome” and told reporters that North Koreans “love” their dictator.

headline: Li and Azarenka Battle to Three-Set Victories; Djokovic Coasts
abstract: No. 5 Li Na and No. 2 Victoria Azarenka each survived three-set matches, while No. 1 Novak Djokovic lost just three games to advance easily.
lead_paragraph: Li Na has had a lot of things going for her at the United States Open: an adoring crowd, a rejuvenated game, being a round ahead of almost everyone in the women’s draw because she has managed to play her matches while it was not raining. But that does not mean advancing to her first Open semifinal came easily on Tuesday.

headline: The Critics: Assigning the Stars
abstract: In the first video of a five-part series, Rick Berke, a senior editor at The Times, speaks with five restaurant critics, past and present, to discuss the star rating system.
lead_paragraph: In the first video of a five-part series, Rick Berke, a senior editor at The Times, speaks with five restaurant critics, past and present, to discuss the star rating system.

headline: AT&T Should Resist Buying Spree
abstract: Vodafone’s sale of its 45 percent stake in Verizon Wireless could tempt AT&T to make a big move overseas now. But the fat margins at home and the perils of cross-border M.&A. make a stronger case for discipline.
lead_paragraph: Verizon just put AT&T’s acquisition willpower to the test. Growth in the United States mobile market is slowing, and as AT&T learned the hard way, competition concerns preclude any transformative domestic deals.

headline: Japanese Smartphone Manufacturer Sees an Export Market in Older Users
abstract: Fujitsu is pursuing an export push aimed at older consumers, who, the company says, are not always served adequately by mainstream offerings.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — The Japanese electronics industry largely missed out on the smartphone revolution. Yet this summer, even as one Japanese company, NEC, exited the business, another one, Fujitsu, announced plans for a new export push.

headline: De Blasio Could Avoid Democratic Runoff, New Poll Suggests
keywords: ['Elections, Mayors', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: A new survey from Quinnipiac University finds that 43 percent of likely Democratic voters plan to support Bill de Blasio in the Sept. 10 mayoral primary.
lead_paragraph: Bill de Blasio, the front-runner in the Democratic primary for mayor, has surged to a commanding lead that, should it hold, could allow him to accomplish what once seemed unthinkable: become the party’s nominee without a runoff.

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: Spying Excesses
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: A former foreign correspondent is critical of the intelligence community. Readers are invited to respond.

headline: The Critics: The Foods They Won’t Eat
abstract: In the fifth video of a five-part series, Rick Berke, a senior editor at The Times, speaks with the restaurant critics about reviewing foods that give them pause.
lead_paragraph: In the fifth video of a five-part series, Rick Berke, a senior editor at The Times, speaks with the restaurant critics about reviewing foods that give them pause.

headline: The End of an Era in Mobile
abstract: The introduction of the Apple iPhone was the first blow to Nokia. Then it failed to respond quickly with a comparable product. And so began a long slide from which it has been unable to recover.
lead_paragraph: In the summer of 2007, Nokia was on top of the world. The company had a market valuation of around $120 billion, $10 billion more than Apple. Nokia’s share of the global smartphone market was an astounding 48.7 percent.

headline: The Critics: Trade Secrets
abstract: In the third video of a five-part series, the restaurant critics discuss the thought process behind each review.
lead_paragraph: In the third video of a five-part series, the restaurant critics discuss the thought process behind each review.

headline: The Critics: Overused Adjectives
abstract: In the fourth video of a five-part series, Rick Berke, a senior editor at The Times, speaks with the restaurant critics about certain adjectives they avoid when describing food.
lead_paragraph: In the fourth video of a five-part series, Rick Berke, a senior editor at The Times, speaks with the restaurant critics about certain adjectives they avoid when describing food.

headline: The Critics: Going Incognito
abstract: In the second video of a five-part series, Rick Berke, a senior editor at The Times, speaks with the restaurant critics about various disguises worn to conceal their identity while reviewing.
lead_paragraph: In the second video of a five-part series, Rick Berke, a senior editor at The Times, speaks with the restaurant critics about various disguises worn to conceal their identity while reviewing.

headline: For Microsoft, Nokia Deal Was Long and Arduous
abstract: The prospect of Nokia shedding its core business – the longtime pride of Finland – weighed heavily on the potential deal.
lead_paragraph: By buying Nokia’s handset business, Microsoft may have strengthened its control over the destiny of its mobile operations and gained a potential new chief executive.

headline: U.N. Chief Reaffirms Opposition to Force
abstract: Ban Ki-moon, the secretary general, said he welcomed President Obama’s efforts to engage Congress but insisted that the Security Council should approve any military action.
lead_paragraph: Ban Ki-moon, the United Nations secretary general, said Tuesday that he appreciated President Obama’s efforts to engage Congress and the American people before deciding on possible armed strikes against Syria over chemical weapons use, but reaffirmed his opposition to any further military action without Security Council approval.

headline: Paley Center’s Television Festival Coming to New York
abstract: The inaugural version of this festival, called PaleyFest: Made in NY, will run from Oct. 2 through 6 and include panels with actors and creators from shows like “Orange Is the New Black,” “Elementary,” “The Americans” and “Boardwalk Empire.”
lead_paragraph: For diehard television viewers in New York who aren’t satisfied seeing their favorite shows in their living rooms, and who want to share some in-person time with the casts and creators of these programs, the Paley Center for Media will soon offer some relief.

headline: Bookends: Columnists
abstract: A closer look at the columnists for Bookends, the back-page feature in The New York Times Book Review.
lead_paragraph: Siddhartha Deb was born in northeastern India. He is the author of two novels and “The Beautiful and the Damned,” a work of narrative nonfiction that was a finalist for the Orwell Prize and the winner of the PEN Open award. He is the recipient of grants and fellowships from the Society of Authors in the UK, the Nation Institute, the Radcliffe Institute of Advanced Studies at Harvard University, and the Howard Foundation at Brown University. His journalism, essays, and reviews have appeared in many publications, including The Guardian, The New York Times, The New Republic, The Baffler, The Nation, n+1, and The Times Literary Supplement.

headline: At the Critics’ Table
abstract: Past and present restaurant critics for The New York Times discuss the food, the star rating system and the tricks to eating anonymously.
lead_paragraph: Past and present restaurant critics for The New York Times discuss the food, the star rating system and the tricks to eating anonymously.

headline: Living in Spuyten Duyvil, the Bronx
abstract: Spectacular views and a population diverse in age and ethnicity characterize the neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: Spectacular views and a population diverse in age and ethnicity characterize the neighborhood.

headline: Spuyten Duyvil, the Bronx, Defined by the Views
abstract: A section of Riverdale, in the Bronx, offering affordability and great views of the Hudson and Harlem Rivers, along with the Palisades.
lead_paragraph: In what some people might consider an unlikely move, Chris Tokar and Lee Feldman recently traded their longtime Williamsburg, Brooklyn, rental for a co-op in an area with a significantly lower cool factor, Spuyten Duyvil, a section of Riverdale.

headline: Paid Vacation’s Decline
keywords: ['Employee Fringe Benefits', 'Family Leaves', 'Paid Time Off', 'Travel and Vacations', 'United States Economy']
abstract: A smaller share of private sector workers get paid vacation days than was the case two decades ago. But the number of days has increased for those who get them.
lead_paragraph: Americans working in the private sector are less likely to have paid vacation days than was the case 20 years ago, according to a recent report from the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

headline: With Plantronics Gaming Headset, Take a Call Without Hitting Pause
abstract: Plantronics has introduced the RIG gaming headset, which includes a mixer that allows players to blend game, chat and phone calls.
lead_paragraph: The headset market is oversaturated with options, but Plantronics may have found an unexploited niche: multitasking gamers.

headline: U.S. Open Food Review: Vegging Out
abstract: Tuesday’s United States Open food review: the roasted summer vegetable sandwich at Farm 2 Fork.
lead_paragraph: Because eating at the United States Open is a high-stakes game, we will feature a daily review of items available at the food courts at the National Tennis Center.

headline: Officials Make Case for Strike Before Senate Panel
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Two secretaries and the chairman of the Joint Chiefs sought to persuade senators on the Foreign Relations Committee to support military action against Syria.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Two cabinet secretaries who fought during the Vietnam War and a four-star general whose views on intervention were shaped by command tours in Iraq appeared before the Senate on Tuesday to argue the Obama administration’s case for Congressional authorization to attack Syria over chemical weapons use.

headline: Street Style: Grunge Inspired Beauty & Accessories
abstract: The best of readers’ photos from the week of Aug. 26.
lead_paragraph: The best of readers’ photos from the week of Aug. 26.

headline: A Look Behind What You Hear
abstract: The documentary “La Maison de la Radio” explores the inner workings of Radio France.
lead_paragraph: The soft babble that streams from the circular building in Nicolas Philibert’s documentary “La Maison de la Radio” is a singularly human hum. The imposing white structure, which overlooks the Seine in the 16th arrondissement in Paris, an easy walk from the Eiffel Tower, is home to Radio France, the state broadcasting company, which has seven networks and many more stations. Designed by the architect Henry Bernard and known as La Maison de la Radio, the building functions as something of a geographic placeholder in Mr. Philibert’s movie, which offers fleeting peeks at the news-gathering worker bees, velvet-voiced on-air personalities and visiting luminaries who congregate inside it.

headline: Be Wary of Even ‘Safe’ Investments
abstract: An assurance of a no-risk investment is no excuse for not doing your research before handing over your money, a financial planner writes.
lead_paragraph: What makes an investment “safe”?

headline: Allies’ Intelligence Differs on Details, but Still Points to Assad Forces
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The United States and its allies differ on some intelligence estimates when it comes to chemical weapons use in Syria, but all agree that only the Assad government had the means to launch attacks.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The British say that there have been 14 Syrian chemical attacks since 2012 and that the last, the most horrific, killed “at least 350” Syrian civilians. The Americans count fewer attacks, but put a stunningly higher, quite precise number on the casualties: 1,429.

headline: Motorsports: Lorenzo, Busch, Langdon and Pagenaud Take Hard-Earned Wins
abstract: Jorge Lorenzo duels an injured Marc Marquez for the MotoGP win, and Kyle Busch battles to the top spot at Atlanta, securing him a position in Nascar’s Chase for the Sprint Cup.
lead_paragraph: Jorge Lorenzo won a stirring battle against Marc Marquez in Sunday’s British Grand Prix in the MotoGP series. Dani Pedrosa finished third.

headline: The Search for Stars Begins
abstract: Familiar names take on new roles and some old favorite spots reopen after refurbishing.
lead_paragraph: New Yorkers like to think of their city as an incubator and importer of new ideas and talent. But many of the restaurant openings scheduled for the next several months have a distinctly familiar ring.

headline: Syria and the Pax Americana
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Civilian Casualties', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'United States International Relations', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: Weighing the case for a limited intervention.
lead_paragraph: I wrote my Sunday column in the voice of President Obama, making what I intended to be a stronger case for intervention in Syria than the mish-mash of moralism and strategery (complete with Munich analogies and straw-man attacks on “isolationism”) that the administration has served up to date. Readers can judge that case’s strength for themselves, but I should say something about whether I actually agree with the words I put in the president’s mouth. And the short answer is … I’m not sure.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Somalia and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Turkey, Syria, Somalia and Pakistan.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Turkey, Syria, Somalia and Pakistan.

headline: At 65, Michel Richard Is Tackling the New York Dining Scene
abstract: The acclaimed chef is making his return to a daunting restaurant scene at a time in his life when other chefs might be thinking about golf.
lead_paragraph: Over more than three decades, Michel Richard has risen to the highest ranks of American chefs, with acclaimed restaurants in Los Angeles and Washington. But as everyone in his business knows, making a big debut in New York’s tough, trend-happy dining scene is something else entirely — especially when you’re 65.

headline: ’62 Vette Stolen at Pebble Beach Is Recovered
abstract: Pat and Terry Monahan were upset when someone took their ’62 Corvette, but they now have the car back.
lead_paragraph: The Internet seems to have worked its magic for at least one of the four classic Chevrolets stolen from Pebble Beach events a few weeks back. Pat and Terry Monahan’s red 1962 Corvette has been returned to its owners.

headline: Gallery | The Chelsea Hotel’s Resident Hairstylist Recalls Her Greatest Celebrity Clients
abstract: Eighteen years after she opened Suite 303, a salon on the third floor of the Chelsea Hotel beloved by celebrities, April Barton has moved her operation downtown.
lead_paragraph: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Someday Worth Billions, but Now, They Need a Desk
abstract: As tech start-ups push demand for office space in San Francisco, RocketSpace is responding with long tables, Internet access and rules against getting too big.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — In the 20th-century workplace, Duncan Logan might be considered an abusive landlord. He rents working spaces without doors or walls between tenants. Instead, his renters work at long tables, and sometimes those tables are shared with other companies.

headline: Whiskey and Hotels Stir the Drinkers
keywords: ['Bars and Nightclubs', 'ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES', 'Whiskey', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings']
abstract: This fall, hotels continue to be a busy stage for the bar scene, and whiskey seems to be the spirit of the season.
lead_paragraph: The rising tide of high-end bartending is lifting every type of spirit, but whiskey seems to be riding a slightly higher crest. A quick scan of the names of New York’s new and expected openings — American Whiskey, Barley & Grain, Whiskey Bar, Whiskey Soda Lounge NY — will make that point. If you open shop these days and can’t boast of having 100 or 200 whiskeys behind the bar, you’re already at a disadvantage.

headline: The Greatest Stories Ever Told Can Now Be Read Too
abstract: The stories of The Moth are something like first cousins to the stories we run in the Lives column: true stories told by real people. The difference, of course, is that The Moth’s stories are supposed to be told in the oral tradition.
lead_paragraph: You know the apprehension you feel when you learn that a favorite novel is getting a movie treatment? How will the change in medium change your perception of the subject? Will the very essence of what you love about the book be ravaged by the movie?

headline: Tracking the Syrian Crisis and the International Response
abstract: The Times is following the conflict in Syria as the United States and its allies consider military action and will provide updates, analysis and public reaction from around the world.
lead_paragraph: The Times is following the conflict in Syria as the United States and its allies consider military action and will provide updates, analysis and public reaction from around the world.

headline: Car Bombings in Baghdad Follow a Familiar Pattern
abstract: At least 46 people were killed in a string of blasts around Baghdad, reinforcing fears that Iraq is reverting to the dark days of sectarian civil war.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — This time the targets were an ice cream shop, a bus station and a famous restaurant near the Shiite slum of Sadr City. A string of coordinated car bombs struck around Baghdad at dusk on Tuesday, killing at least 46 people, in the latest burst of violence that appears to be steadily pulling the country back toward the worst days of the last decade.

headline: An Austin Mansion Becomes a Modern Hotel
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: The Hotel Ella, in an historic mansion in Austin, Tex., will open in late September.
lead_paragraph: Old is new in Austin, where one of its most historic mansions will open as the Hotel Ella on Sept. 25.

headline: A Sisterhood of Power Lunch Spots
abstract: The places where they choose to network.
lead_paragraph: The places where they choose to network.

headline: Ladies Who Power Lunch
abstract: Women in New York are redefining the ritual of red meat and business talk.
lead_paragraph: If Tom Wolfe were to write a novel about power, style and status in New York City at this moment in the 21st century, there is one restaurant dish he might have to build a whole scene around, to convey the right tang of anthropological exactitude.

headline: Pair of Nimble Hands Ever Ready at U.S. Open, With a Needle
abstract: Kathy Karadza, sewing machine close by, is constantly coming to the rescue of players at the tennis tournament, be it to repair a rip or to affix a patch from a last-minute sponsor.
lead_paragraph: Kathy Karadza is under intense pressure during the early stages of the United States Open tennis tournament. She is in near-constant motion and the demand for perfection is often intense.

headline: Hotel Review: Playland Motel in Rockaway Beach, N.Y.
abstract: This new 12-room property offers a taste of Brooklyn cool for those not wedded to a good night’s sleep.
lead_paragraph: Rates

headline: Testing a Premise on the Health Care Law and Part-Time Work
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Part-Time Employment', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Working Hours']
abstract: Recent statistics show that the incidence of involuntary part-time work is positively correlated with a state’s unemployment rate, evidence that it is the job market at work, not the Affordable Care Act, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: Restaurant Report: The Piggy in Walker, Minn.
abstract: Diners are lining up for the Kansas City-style barbecue served at this small-town spot, which opened in May 2012.
lead_paragraph: Walker, a classic resort town in the heart of Minnesota’s lake country (population: 1,000) is exactly the sort of place you’d expect to find pine trees, sandy beaches, plentiful fishing opportunities and nighttime campfires. But thanks to one Steve Blake, you can add a more surprising delight to that list: Kansas City-style barbecue.

headline: The Microsoft-Nokia Deal: Risks and Messiness
abstract: It’s hard to understand why Microsoft bought Nokia. But the purchase won’t affect the fortunes of Windows Phone.
lead_paragraph: By now, perhaps you’ve heard: Microsoft just bought Nokia’s cellphone division for $7.2 billion.

headline: The ‘Mysterious’ Disappearance of a Quotation Has a Mundane Explanation
abstract: Critics charge that the Times changed an article in response to political pressure, but the actual explanation is less exciting.
lead_paragraph: Was a quote about a pro-Israel group mysteriously scrubbed from a New York Times story? A number of online commenters, in blog posts and on Twitter, wrote Tuesday that a quote calling the American Israel Public Affairs Committee “the 800-pound gorilla in the room” had been taken out of an article without explanation, suggesting that The Times was responding to political pressure. On the face of it, it sounds mighty bad.

headline: Thorny Side Effects in Silicon Valley Tactic to Keep Control
abstract: Adopting a dual-class stock structure may be bad not only for technology companies but also for their founders.
lead_paragraph: The gods of Silicon Valley have repeatedly sought to take the companies they founded public while retaining control as if they were still private.

headline: Tips for the Next Heartland Road Trip
abstract: The Frugal Traveler used a number of your suggestions for his drive through America’s center — but many tips went unused. Here’s advice he wishes he could have followed.
lead_paragraph: This summer, I became the opposite of an advice columnist. Instead of doling out guidance, I took it in. Lots of it. Way too much, in fact.

headline: Tufted Velvet Chairs From Cherry, Glasses to Serve Vodka and More
abstract: Recommendations for the week of Sept. 3.
lead_paragraph: To Luxuriate: Taking a Seat With a Velvet Touch

headline: Harrowing Questions, and Ethics, During Katrina
abstract: “Five Days at Memorial” is Sheri Fink’s gripping look at hospital care during an overwhelming disaster.
lead_paragraph: Eight years ago, Hurricane Katrina hit New Orleans. Floodwaters rose in the Uptown streets surrounding Memorial Medical Center, where hundreds of people slowly realized that they were stranded. The power grid failed, toilets overflowed, stench-filled corridors went dark. Diesel generators gave partial electricity. Hospital staff members smashed windows to circulate air. Gunshots could be heard, echoing in the city. Two stabbing victims turned up at this hospital, which was on life support itself, and were treated.

headline: New Role for Jackson on ‘American Idol’
abstract: The longtime “American Idol” judge Randy Jackson, left, will be back for that singing competition’s 13th season but in a new role as in-house mentor to the contestants, Fox announced on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: The longtime “American Idol” judge Randy Jackson will be back for that singing competition’s 13th season but in a new role as in-house mentor to the contestants, Fox announced on Tuesday. Though the network did not cast it this way, Mr. Jackson will essentially replace Jimmy Iovine, the music producer who was the in-house mentor the past three seasons. Mr. Iovine’s exit was first reported last month.

headline: I’ll Have What You’re Having
abstract: Entrees for two emphasize the negotiation in sharing.
lead_paragraph: These days, New York restaurant menus often overflow with a miscellany of small plates and snacks you’re supposed to share. But how do you divvy up four raw scallops that arrive in a cup the size of an infant’s palm, or pinches of sea urchin on Lilliputian rafts of toast?

headline: Bezos Makes First Visit to Washington Post as Owner
abstract: In an interview, Jeffrey P. Bezos, the founder of Amazon.com, said he expected the  newspaper to have a new “golden era” under his ownership.
lead_paragraph: Jeffrey P. Bezos, the new owner of The Washington Post, kicked off a packed, two-day visit to the paper on Tuesday, his first since purchasing the newspaper for $250 million on Aug. 5. Mr. Bezos was meeting with managers on the editorial and business sides, according to people with knowledge of his schedule, at times chaperoned by Katharine Weymouth, the publisher and a member of the Graham family from whom Mr. Bezos bought the paper.

headline: In a Puzzle, a Clearer Look at 9/11
keywords: ['September 11 (2001)', 'World Trade Center (Manhattan, NY)', 'Flags, Emblems and Insignia', 'Service Dogs and Other Animals', 'Television']
abstract: “The Flag,” a CNN film about Sept. 11, does more than simply retell a familiar story or push the obvious buttons.
lead_paragraph: A dozen years of distance expands the options for documentarians who want to mark the anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks, but it requires insight and subtlety to take full advantage of the possibilities. “The Flag,” an absorbing film by Michael Tucker and Petra Epperlein, being broadcast on Wednesday night on CNN, has both of those qualities, making it as rewarding as it is thought-provoking.

headline: Gallery | The Cult ’80s Fashion Illustrator Tony Viramontes Gets a Second Look
abstract: The artist, who documented the jet-set lifestyle in Manhattan and Paris before succumbing to AIDS in 1988, is the subject of an auction, window displays and a new book.
lead_paragraph: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Curators Chosen for American Pavilion at Architecture Biennale
abstract: The State Department has named three curators to focus on the last 100 years of American building abroad.
lead_paragraph: The State Department has selected three curators who will turn the United States pavilion at the 2014 Venice Architecture Biennale into an experiment in reimagining the last 100 years of American building abroad. They are Eva Franch i Gilabert, executive director and chief curator of the Storefront for Art and Architecture in Manhattan, which is leading the effort; Ana Miljački, an architecture professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology; and Ashley Schafer, editor of the Boston-based architecture journal Praxis. The State Department’s Bureau of Educational and Cultural Affairs chose the trio with advice from a committee of curators and design experts, said Susan Pittman, a spokeswoman for the department.

headline: A Film-Fueled Culture Clash Over Values in China
abstract: A Chinese book and film franchise by Guo Jingming has become a lightning rod for this nation’s evolving view of its growing youth culture.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Amid the usual crop of Western-imported blockbuster fare (see “Jurassic Park 3D,” “Monsters University,” “Pacific Rim”), two homegrown movies about four fashion-obsessed girlfriends at a Shanghai university have unexpectedly made their way to the top of China’s box office here this summer.

headline: A Scandal-Scalded Murdoch as a Song-and-Dance Man
abstract: Rupert Murdoch’s many missteps get stage treatments in Australia and Britain.
lead_paragraph: It has been an eventful couple of years for Rupert Murdoch. In Britain, evidence that reporters at several of his newspapers routinely hacked into private cellphones as they pursued hot stories led to the demise of News of the World, one of his mightiest tabloids, and incited an official government inquiry into the culture, practices and ethics of the British press.

headline: Baroque Embedding, Feet First
abstract: Classes offering Baroque dance lessons can help unlock the physical dimensions encoded in the music.
lead_paragraph: The strains of softly undulating lute music filled the space in a teaching studio inside Dance New Amsterdam as two rows of dancers, clad in Lycra and cotton exercise wear, closed in on one another and detached again in a graceful motion, then glided through a turn, ornamented with a quick, circular flick of the wrist. We were a group of 18 dancers taking part in a workshop on Baroque dance led by Catherine Turocy, the founder of the New York Baroque Dance Company and one of the leading figures in the historical dance movement of the past 40 years.

headline: Summer Attendance Falls on Broadway, but High Prices Lift Sales Totals
abstract: The tourist-heavy summer months of 2013 saw attendance fall by 8 percent compared to the same period last year, but high prices brought overall sales slightly higher.
lead_paragraph: Broadway’s attendance problem continued through the tourist-heavy summer months of 2013, with 8 percent fewer audience members between Memorial Day and Labor Day compared to the same period in 2012, according to data supplied by producers of Broadway shows.

headline: A Way to Listen to Music and Outside Noise, Too
abstract: A device adds a microphone to headphones, allowing in environmental sounds to provide alerts to hazards.
lead_paragraph: Listening to music with earphones that block the sounds of hazards is dangerous for anyone, particularly runners and cyclists.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Tasty New Android and a Marriage Made in Finland?
abstract: Tuesday’s highlights from around the Web include the announcement of the latest version of Android, Google’s mobile operating system, which is called Kit Kat. Plus, reflections of Nokia’s once-dominating cellphone presence.
lead_paragraph: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: When Movies Trade on Real Life
abstract: Do the makers of films claiming to be based on or inspired by real stories have an allegiance to the truth, or just to the art of storytelling?

headline: Kerry Calls for Action on Syria
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry testified on Tuesday before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State John Kerry testified on Tuesday before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

headline: Hagel Outlines Goals in Syria
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel testified on Tuesday before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.
lead_paragraph: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel testified on Tuesday before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

headline: Michelle Williams to Make Broadway Debut in ‘Cabaret’
abstract: The three-time Oscar nominee will star as Sally Bowles in the new production, aiming for an opening in early 2014.
lead_paragraph: Updated, Sept. 4 Michelle Williams, the three-time Academy Award nominee and former star of the television series “Dawson’s Creek,” will make her Broadway debut as Sally Bowles in Roundabout Theater Company’s revival of “Cabaret,” the theater confirmed on Wednesday.

headline: Detours and Divisions, but Few Wild Exaggerations in Debate
abstract: Beginning at 7 p.m., the New York Times political unit will be live-blogging the entire 90-minute debate, illuminating the shadings of truth and exaggerations in the claims the candidates make, and calling out the inaccuracies or out-and-out howlers in the facts they toss around.
lead_paragraph: There were mathematics errors large and small, a lengthy detour into one candidate’s conspiracy theory, and a me-first contest over who was the earliest to propose a moratorium on school closings. But Tuesday’s second and final televised debate in the Democratic primary for mayor of New York City featured few brazen howlers, wild exaggerations or embarrassing gotcha moments.

headline: News Corp. Sells a Group of Small Local Publications
abstract: The deal sends 33 local newspapers and magazines to the Fortress Investment Group, a private equity firm.
lead_paragraph: In one of its first moves since a corporate spinoff in June, News Corporation said on Tuesday that it had sold 33 local publications to a private equity and hedge fund firm.

headline: A Television Designed for the Outdoors
abstract: The SunBrite borrows technology from industrial televisions to withstand the elements.
lead_paragraph: Outdoor spaces typically suffer — or benefit — from the lack of television. SunBrite TVs  are designed to work outside.

headline: What to Watch For
abstract: Be on the lookout this season for the following culinary trends.
lead_paragraph: A CUT ABOVE Lamb neck has overtaken oxtail as the boniest and most gnawable entree on the menu, and may be giving pork belly a run for the trendiest. Look for its soft, fatty meat shredded into agnolotti at Calliope, braised with juniper at the Marrow and roasted with Calabrian chile salsa verde at Cannibal. — Melissa Clark

headline: Two ‘It’ Girls, Palling Around in Paris
abstract: To celebrate the return of the classic Virgule heel, the 21-year-old model Atlanta de Cadenet Taylor and the 19-year-old photographer Olivia Bee spent two days getting silly by the Seine. Here, they share their stories.
lead_paragraph: Roger Vivier created his signature, comma-shaped Virgule heel in 1963, or about three decades before the birth of the model Atlanta de Cadenet Taylor, 21, and the photographer Olivia Bee, 19, who teamed up to celebrate a new version of the shoe (featuring a slightly higher heel) that was reintroduced last January during couture week. The redesigned Virgule hit stores today along with 15,000 copies of a book featuring images of Taylor wandering Paris in the iconic heels, all taken by Bee, who began her career when she was 15. “I was so surprised when I got to Paris and they were like, ‘So, the photographer is a 19-year-old girl,'” said Taylor, the daughter of Amanda de Cadenet, a British photographer and TV host, and John Taylor, the bassist for Duran Duran. “I’m so used to being the youngest person on set.”

headline: No Ground Troops in Syria, Kerry Insists
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: In an effort to clarify earlier remarks, Secretary of State John Kerry emphasized that the plan for United States military action in Syria did not include the use of ground troops.
lead_paragraph: In an effort to clarify earlier remarks, Secretary of State John Kerry emphasized that the plan for United States military action in Syria did not include the use of ground troops.

headline: Jazz Greats in Rare Form
abstract: A conversation with Joe Lauro, who collected stereo slides of photographs taken of musicians like Billie Holiday and Dizzy Gillespie.

headline: The Austerian Mask Slips
abstract: Rehn gives the game away.
lead_paragraph: Simon Wren-Lewis looks at France, and finds that it is engaging in a lot of fiscal austerity — far more than makes sense given the macroeconomic situation. He notes, however, that France has eliminated its structural primary deficit mainly by raising taxes rather than by cutting spending.

headline: Quarterfinal Opponents Meet in Doubles First
abstract: Sara Errani and Roberta Vinci of Italy defeated Flavia Pennetta, also of Italy, and Anabel Medina Garrigues of Spain in a third-round match. Vinci plays Pennetta in a singles quarterfinal Wednesday afternoon.
lead_paragraph: Playing in front of 235 spectators and 5,850 empty seats Tuesday, Italy’s Sara Errani and Roberta Vinci, the No. 1 doubles team, defeated Flavia Pennetta, also of Italy, and Anabel Medina Garrigues of Spain, 6-1, 7-5, in a third-round match at the United States Open.

headline: North Carolina: College Student’s Candidacy Allowed
abstract: The State Board of Elections ruled that a college student living in a dormitory can run for office in that city.
lead_paragraph: The State Board of Elections ruled Tuesday that a college student living in a dormitory can run for office in that city. Montravias King, who attends Elizabeth City State University, wanted to run for the City Council, but a local Republican activist argued that he was not a permanent resident because the dormitories are not open to students year-round. The elections board in Pasquotank County agreed and blocked Mr. King’s candidacy last month. The state panel voted unanimously to reverse that decision, which Mr. King’s supporters had said threatened to undermine the voting rights of college students throughout North Carolina.

headline: Chile: 3 Sue Over Sexual Abuse Cases
abstract: Three men who say they were sexually abused as teenagers by a prominent Catholic priest filed a lawsuit against the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Santiago.
lead_paragraph: Three men who say they were sexually abused as teenagers by a prominent Catholic priest filed a lawsuit on Tuesday against the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Santiago for failing to protect them or to investigate their accusations. Juan Carlos Cruz said that he and the others who have accused the Rev. Fernando Karadima of abusing them when he headed the El Bosque parish in Santiago in the 1980s “hope to establish the responsibility of the church, which always knew what was going on and looked the other way.” In 2011, the Vatican found Rev. Karadima guilty of the abuses and ordered him to retire “to a life of prayer and penitence.” A Chilean judge dismissed criminal charges later that year because a statute of limitations had expired, but he also described the accusations as “truthful and reliable.”

headline: No Bounce for Europe in Rebound by Germany
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Euro (Currency)', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: The crisis has weakened ties in the euro zone as German companies, with the government cheering them on, look to China and the United States.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Whenever Germany thrived, so did the rest of Europe. But that long-held belief is being questioned by its neighbors, which see evidence that the country is taking off without them.

headline: Business Losing Clout in a G.O.P. Moving Right
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Campaign Finance', 'Corporations', 'Citizens United v Federal Election Commission (Supreme Court Decision)', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists']
abstract: Scholars have proposed many reasons for the diminished role businesses have with Congressional Republicans, and, yes, it’s about money.
lead_paragraph: How did corporate America lose control of the Republican Party?

headline: Pier’s Developer Looks for a Creative Tenant Mix
keywords: ['Area Planning and Renewal', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: A Fashion Week marketplace will offer a taste of redevelopment plans for a Hudson River site.
lead_paragraph: At an old pier in Manhattan, the hotelier André Balazs is transforming a rubble-strewn rooftop into a health spa and beach, while in the enormous hollow cement caissons beneath the Hudson River that hold up the pier, a rock-climbing wall is being created.

headline: Voter-Guide Videos Catch Many Candidates in the Headlights
keywords: ['Elections', 'Video Recordings and Downloads', 'Voting and Voters', 'Elections, Mayors']
abstract: This summer, more than 150 candidates for a variety of local offices paraded through a production studio to record clips for the city’s official voter guide.
lead_paragraph: Cathy Guerriero could not get over her tongue.

headline: 65 Years Later, a Memorial Gives Names to Crash Victims
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents and Safety', 'Deportation', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Migrant Labor (Agriculture)', 'Tombs and Tombstones', 'Funerals and Memorials']
abstract: Twenty-eight Mexican victims of a plane crash in 1948 were memorialized in Fresno, Calif., with a new gravestone that lists their names.
lead_paragraph: FRESNO, Calif. — A fiery plane crash here decades ago that killed 32 people, most of them unidentified Mexican farmworkers, inspired a protest song by Woody Guthrie that has been performed by Bruce Springsteen, Joan Baez and Bob Dylan, among others. Yet here in the heart of the Central Valley, one of the most productive agricultural counties in the country, the story of that crash had been largely forgotten.

headline: Ray Grebey, Negotiator in ’81 Baseball Strike, Dies at 85
abstract: Mr. Grebey was hired by Major League Baseball in 1978, and some thought he pushed too hard and provoked a strike that could have been avoided.
lead_paragraph: Ray Grebey, a tough labor negotiator who represented major league baseball owners in the 1981 players strike that led to the cancellation of 713 games over nearly two months, died on Aug. 28 in Stamford, Conn. He was 85.

headline: With a Burst of Color, Turkey’s Public Walkways Become a Focus of Quiet Protest
abstract: When city authorities in Istanbul tried to quash the initiative of a public-spirited citizen who painted a set of public steps in bright colors, their heavy-handed response started a new wave of protests.
lead_paragraph: In Istanbul, known as the city of seven hills, dozens of public stairways crisscross centuries-old neighborhoods, giving pedestrians a way to avoid heavy car traffic on the streets.

headline: Oracle Down 2 Races Before America’s Cup Starts
abstract: Oracle Team USA will begin the America’s Cup with a score of minus-2, meaning it needs to win 11 races; its challenger, Emirates Team New Zealand, will need to win nine.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Oracle Team USA will begin defense of the America’s Cup on Saturday with a two-race deficit after being penalized for prohibited modifications to its racing yachts in 2012.

headline: Disgraced in Albany, and Vying for Council
abstract: Vito J. Lopez, who resigned as an assemblyman after a sexual harassment scandal, may have a fair chance of winning in an off-the-radar election for New York’s City Council.
lead_paragraph: A criminal investigation into allegations that he sexually harassed subordinates did not deter him. Nor did civil suits accusing him of groping and other unwanted intimacies. Nor censure by the State Assembly, nor the clamor of fellow Democrats that forced him to resign as the party’s chairman in Brooklyn and step down from the Legislature.

headline: Egypt Speeds Use of Trials for Jailing of Islamists
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'News and News Media', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots']
abstract: An administrative court also banned four satellite networks considered sympathetic to supporters of the ousted president, Mohamed Morsi.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The two-month-old Egyptian government on Tuesday stepped up its use of swift military trials to lock up Islamist supporters of the ousted president, Mohamed Morsi, while an administrative court banned four satellite networks considered sympathetic to them, including an Egyptian affiliate of Al Jazeera.

headline: Playing Detective in Finding Films of Opponents
abstract: Video coordinators must navigate the rules for exchanging game films that can turn their profession into an alchemy of dogged legwork of a detective and the backslapping of a car salesperson.
lead_paragraph: Every day during his numerous trips through the United States Naval Academy’s football offices, Todd Green passes rooms where coaches and players are gathered watching video that he, the team’s video coordinator, has collected, vetted and organized.

headline: Senate Resolution on Syria
abstract: Senate resolution to authorize the limited and tailored use of the United States Armed Forces against Syria.
lead_paragraph: Senate resolution to authorize the limited and tailored use of the United States Armed Forces against Syria.

headline: A Practical Farmer Who Showed the Way
abstract: Dick Thompson wanted a system that would also work for the land, the animals and the customer.
lead_paragraph: Dick Thompson was a farmer near Boone, Iowa, whom I kept meaning to visit but did not. That was a mistake; he died on Aug. 17 at 81.

headline: Preserving a Skateboarding Park and Its Creator’s Memory
abstract: Riverside Skate Park was designed in the 1990s by the New York skateboarding pioneer Andy Kessler, who died in 2009. But it had fallen into disrepair until friends of Mr. Kessler took on a refurbishing project in his honor.
lead_paragraph: In many parts of Riverside Park, people can find the past evoked — magisterially in the columns and dome of Grant’s Tomb or touchingly in the tiny memorial to the Amiable Child. Ian Clarke sees it in the sky-blue ramps and half-pipes of Riverside Skate Park, which was designed by the New York skateboarding pioneer Andy Kessler.

headline: A Lesson in Adjusting to Lower Expectations
abstract: Lleyton Hewitt, like Roger Federer, is 32 and was once No. 1 in the world, but he has moved on from those increasingly distant days and found meaning at a new, lower level.
lead_paragraph: The assumption is that Roger Federer will not be happy playing tennis unless he plays like the Federer in our mind’s eye: smoothly gobbling up court space and whipping airborne forehands into the corners with his hair and aura still neatly in place and another Grand Slam trophy within elegant reach.

headline: The Limits of Nullification
abstract: On issues like gun control, the states are not powerless in the face of federal law, but there are limits to what they can do to prevent enforcement of constitutionally valid regulation.
lead_paragraph: BILTMORE LAKE, N.C. — ON Sept. 11, anti-gun-control legislators in the Missouri General Assembly are likely to pass a bill, over the governor’s veto, that renders almost all federal gun laws void in the state, and even makes it a crime for federal agents to enforce them.

headline: Russian Youth Group With a Mission: Sniffing Out Illegal Migrants
abstract: Calling itself a rights organization, Moscow Shield seeks to root out unregistered immigrant workers, especially those from former Soviet republics.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — As dusk fell, nine young men gathered on a leafy street in Chertanova, a bedroom community on the outskirts of Moscow. Their hair cropped short, some put on surgical masks and thick work gloves. Aleksei Khudyakov, their leader, issued final instructions like a platoon leader briefing his soldiers for a raid.

headline: Judge Is Asked by Creditors of Archdiocese to Leave Case
abstract: Where one side in a Milwaukee Archdiocese bankruptcy case sees a conflict of interest, the other sees an effort at judge shopping.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge who ruled in favor of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Milwaukee in bankruptcy proceedings, and against sexual abuse victims and other creditors, is being asked by the creditors to recuse himself because they say he has a conflict of interest.

headline: Extra Week of Summer Break? Time to Panic
abstract: When Rosh Hashana comes early and the school year starts a week late as a result, New York parents have been known to panic and quickly make plans to fill the gap.
lead_paragraph: Labor Day, that fading-summer Monday, has always been central to the biorhythms of parents in the New York area. It means vacations are done and the start of classes, mercifully, is just a day or two away.

headline: On Syria, a U.N. Vote Isn’t Optional
keywords: ['International Relations', 'Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: For all its failings, the post-1945 legal order has made for a safer world.
lead_paragraph: NEW HAVEN — THE world is in a bind. Syria has violated basic norms of international law and humanity by using chemical weapons on its own people. The United Nations, which is supposed to secure international peace, is paralyzed by the intransigence of Russia and China, which hold vetoes on the Security Council.

abstract: Americans have stuck with the practice because all parties thought it worked in their favor, but a re-evaluation is now in order.
