headline: Indian Police Officer Says Leaders Approved Executions
keywords: ['Police', 'Terrorism', 'Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: An officer awaiting trial on suspicion of staging extrajudicial killings and passing them off as shootings  during terrorism arrests accused political leaders of approving the acts.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — A high-ranking Indian police officer awaiting trial on suspicion of staging extrajudicial killings and passing them off as shootings committed during major terrorism arrests accused political leaders in the state of Gujarat on Tuesday of approving the executions.

headline: Recent Commercial Real Estate
abstract: Notable properties that have been recently listed for sale, sold or leased.
lead_paragraph: Recent Sale

headline: Arm and Shame
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'United States International Relations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The United States should definitely respond to Syria’s murder of innocent civilians with poison gas. But a limited “shock and awe” missile attack isn’t the best strategy.
lead_paragraph: The Obama team has clearly struggled with its Syria policy, but, in fairness, this is a wickedly complex problem. We need a policy response that simultaneously deters another Syrian poison gas attack, doesn’t embroil America in the Syrian civil war and also doesn’t lead to the sudden collapse of the Syrian state with all its chemical weapons, or, worse, a strengthening of the Syrian regime and its allies Hezbollah and Iran. However, I think President Obama has the wrong strategy for threading that needle. He’s seeking Congressional support for a one-time “shock and awe” missile attack against Syrian military targets. The right strategy is “arm and shame.”

headline: Taxes, Benefits and Equality
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'States (US)', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Editorials']
abstract: The recognition of same-sex marriages by the Internal Revenue Service makes state bans look even more discriminatory.
lead_paragraph: As federal agencies continue to roll out their rules for allowing federal benefits for lawfully married same-sex couples, the reach of the Supreme Court’s wise ruling in June striking down part of the federal Defense of Marriage Act has come into sharper focus.

headline: Mr. Bloomberg and ‘the Ideologues’
abstract: The mayor is using the shooting of a young Brooklyn boy to level baseless charges against critics of his unconstitutional policing tactics.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael Bloomberg has seized on a tragedy — the shooting death of 16-month-old boy, Antiq Hennis, in a stroller in Brownsville, Brooklyn, on Sunday — to level baseless charges against those who criticize his administration’s unconstitutional policing tactics.

headline: Britain’s Syria Vote in Perspective
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Editorials', 'Biological and Chemical Warfare']
abstract: Prime Minister David Cameron can use other tools, including diplomacy, to advance the common goals it shares with the United States.
lead_paragraph: While President Obama tries to persuade Congress to support his plan for punitive airstrikes against Syria, Britons are still debating the meaning of Parliament’s 285-to-272 vote last week not to authorize Prime Minister David Cameron to commit British military forces to join in those strikes. With military action excluded, at least for now, Mr. Cameron has promised a new diplomatic push to end the Syrian fighting that has killed at least 100,000 people and created millions of desperate refugees.

headline: An Old Campaign Learns a New Song
abstract: Mentos is introducing a campaign for the chewy mint rolls that is meant to evoke the upbeat mood and cheerful tone of the original jingle from the 1990s.
lead_paragraph: A BRAND once lovingly mocked for commercials proclaiming it as “the freshmaker” is refreshing its approach to marketing.

headline: The Ad Campaign: ‘Lhota, You’re No Rudy’
abstract: One of Joseph J. Lhota’s credentials in appealing to Republican voters is his association with former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. Now, Mr. Lhota’s top rival in the Republican mayoral primary, John A. Catsimatidis, is taking aim at that pairing.
lead_paragraph: One of Joseph J. Lhota’s credentials in appealing to Republican voters is his association with former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, for whom he worked as budget director and deputy mayor. Mr. Lhota’s top rival in the Republican mayoral primary, John A. Catsimatidis, is now taking aim at that pairing, seeking to portray Mr. Lhota as a lackluster public servant compared with his former boss. Mr. Catsimatidis’s 30-second commercial “Not Even Close” is the latest in a series of advertisements he has made attacking Mr. Lhota; it began being shown on Tuesday on cable and broadcast stations.

headline: As Wolves Return to French Alps, a Way of Life Is Threatened
abstract: Though conservationists are thrilled that the gray wolf is back, shepherds say that their flocks and livelihoods are increasingly in danger.
lead_paragraph: VIGNOLS, France — High in the thick grass meadows of the southern French Alps, a modern parable of man and nature, sheep and wolf, is being written in a great quantity of blood.

headline: Susan Hewitt
abstract: Ms. Hewitt is a partner and the founder of the Cheshire Group, which owns and operates rent-regulated and market-rate apartments in the New York area.
lead_paragraph: Ms. Hewitt, 56, is a partner and the founder of the Cheshire Group, which owns and operates rent-regulated and market-rate apartments in the New York area. Its projects have included the conversions of the Philip House on the Upper East Side and the Devonshire House in Greenwich Village.

headline: Taking First Career Steps on a Path Set by McEnroe
abstract: Noah Rubin, a 17-year-old from Long Island and a product of the John McEnroe Tennis Academy, recorded his first singles victory at the Billie Jean King National Tennis Center.
lead_paragraph: It would certainly be a stretch to call Noah Rubin a work-in-progress from the John McEnroe mold. He is not left-handed and does not play serve-and-volley tennis in an era of baseline slugging. He doesn’t throw on-court tantrums, or at least did not lose it like McEnroe even once during his first-round junior boys’ match Tuesday at the United States Open.

headline: Wolves, Once Endangered, Now Threaten French Shepherds’ Livelihood
abstract: French shepherds increasingly call the wolf an existential threat, not just to their sheep but also to their way of life.
lead_paragraph: French shepherds increasingly call the wolf an existential threat, not just to their sheep but also to their way of life.

lead_paragraph: Calling it a matter of “basic human dignity,” the mayor of Jersey City wants to require all but the smallest businesses to provide their employees paid sick days.

headline: In Nokia, Microsoft Bets on Apple-Like Revival
abstract: Microsoft’s predicament recalls the situation Apple found itself in during the early 1990s, with high-quality products overlooked in the marketplace.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — With its purchase of Nokia’s phone business, Microsoft is taking inspiration from Apple’s way of making products, bringing hardware and software under a single roof where they can be more elegantly woven together.

headline: From Nokia, an Executive Who Knows the Difficulties at Hand
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Cellular Telephones', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Smartphones', 'Software']
abstract: As Nokia’s chief, Stephen Elop took harsh measures to right the company, preventing an even worse outcome, analysts say. But Nokia has not yet halted its slide in market share.
lead_paragraph: When Stephen Elop takes on Microsoft’s challenges as the new head of its mobile computing business, he will find plenty of parallels from his three years running Nokia: both are established companies blindsided by new innovators and troubled almost as much by pride and internal fiefs as by technology shifts, according to former executives and company watchers.

headline: Shedding Handsets, Nokia Looks to the Future
abstract: Nokia, despite the sale of its handset unit to Microsoft, will still be in business with two major technology components: networking and mapping.
lead_paragraph: Nokia, which began making rubber boots for Finnish workmen 150 years ago and was an innovative leader of the cellphone industry in the 1990s, is once again evolving.

lead_paragraph: Some top tennis players grew up near public courts in places like Compton, Calif.; Fort Lauderdale, Fla.; and Douglaston, Queens. Some lived in expensive houses overlooking exclusive golf courses, and others were raised near dusty clay courts on islands in the Mediterranean Sea.

headline: Errors Cast Doubt on Japan’s Cleanup of Nuclear Accident Site
keywords: ['Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant (Japan)', 'Japan Earthquake and Tsunami (2011)', 'Radiation', 'Nuclear Energy', 'Nuclear Wastes']
abstract: Analysts are questioning whether Japan’s government and the operator of the stricken Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant have the expertise and ability to manage the crisis.
lead_paragraph: NARAHA, Japan — In this small farming town in the evacuation zone surrounding the stricken Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant, small armies of workers in surgical masks and rubber gloves are busily scraping off radioactive topsoil in a desperate attempt to fulfill the central government’s vow one day to allow most of Japan’s 83,000 evacuees to return. Yet, every time it rains, more radioactive contamination cascades down the forested hillsides along the rugged coast.

headline: Microsoft Gambles on Nokia
abstract: Microsoft just purchased Nokia's cell phone division. Will the move help the company in the crowded smartphone market? Nick Bilton, Bits columnist, takes a look at the competition.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft just purchased Nokia's cell phone division. Will the move help the company in the crowded smartphone market? Nick Bilton, Bits columnist, takes a look at the competition.

headline: With Tap, Mets Reliever Gets on Track
abstract: Vic Black, a new Met, had lost the velocity on his fastball and was looking to reset his career when he made an adjustment in his windup.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Vic Black’s career as a pitcher was unsettled in 2011. His fastball fell to 88 miles per hour from 97. As a 23-year-old right-handed reliever pitching in an age of power arms, throwing a pedestrian 88 m.p.h. was not going to get him out of Class A ball. It was more likely to run him out of baseball.

lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The American bar mitzvah, facing derision for Las Vegas style excess, is about to get a full makeover, but for an entirely different reason.

abstract: Most of the heat and animation in the final debate among the candidates in the Democratic mayoral primary came from the two rivals competing for rock bottom.

headline: With Little Time Left, Mayoral Candidates Pounce on de Blasio

lead_paragraph: Bill de Blasio, the New York City public advocate, fended off relentless attacks on Tuesday night from his rivals in the mayoral race, who sought to depict him as a panderer to the real estate industry, a facile flip-flopper and a naïve dreamer whose bold-sounding plans would quickly fizzle in the face of political reality.

headline: Detours and Divisions, but Few Wild Exaggerations in Mayoral Debate
abstract: Mathematical errors and a conspiracy theory cropped up in the debate among the Democrats vying for mayor of New York City, but few brazen howlers emerged.
lead_paragraph: There were mathematics errors large and small, a lengthy detour into one candidate’s conspiracy theory, and a me-first contest over who was the earliest to propose a moratorium on school closings. But Tuesday’s second and final televised debate in the Democratic primary for mayor of New York City featured few brazen howlers, wild exaggerations or embarrassing gotcha moments.

lead_paragraph: It did not have the glamour of the Titanic, the infamy of the pirate ship Whydah, or the historical importance of Christopher Columbus’s Santa Maria.

headline: What to Do if Your Child Tears an A.C.L.
abstract: When my 16-year-old son wracked his knee this summer, tearing his anterior cruciate ligament and other structures in the “terrible triad,” I learned many lessons I could have spent my parenthood happily not learning.

headline: What’s on Wednesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (BBC America) LUTHER Idris Elba, above, continues his third season as Detective Chief Inspector John Luther — this time as the subject of an internal-affairs investigation, instigated by his nemesis, Erin Gray (Nikki Amuka-Bird), that threatens his already tenuous partnership with the young detective Justin Ripley (Warren Brown). Two themes soon become evident: “Luther is larger than life, practically superheroic, and Luther is alone, not by choice but because he burns so hot that ordinary mortals have to keep their distance,” Mike Hale wrote in The New York Times. More than just about any drama on television, he said, “Luther” would be nothing without its star, “who strides through the show — he’s constantly on the move — with such authority that the exaggerations and the risible plot twists don’t intrude on your enjoyment, for the most part.” They, and Mr. Elba, he added, “are still pretty epic.”

headline: California: Prisons to Allow Same-Sex Marriages
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Inmates in California prisons will be permitted to marry same-sex partners who are not incarcerated, state officials announced.
lead_paragraph: Inmates in California prisons will be permitted to marry same-sex partners who are not incarcerated, state officials announced Tuesday. In a memorandum to wardens, the California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation stated that marriages between two inmates will not be permitted, due in part to “security concerns.” The policy, the memo said, was consistent with the United States Supreme Court ruling in June, which has allowed same-sex marriages to resume in California for the first time since 2008, when voters approved a statewide ban.

headline: The Global Elite’s Favorite Strongman
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Hutu Tribe', 'Tutsi Tribe']
abstract: Paul Kagame is an international hero for reforming Rwanda. But cleaning up a country doesn’t come without moral hazards.
lead_paragraph: Paul Kagame, the president of Rwanda, agreed to meet me at 11 a.m. on a recent Saturday. Kagame’s office is on top of a hill near the center of Kigali, Rwanda’s capital, and I took a taxi there, driven by a man in a suit and tie. Whenever I’m in Kigali, I am always impressed by how spotless it is, how the city hums with efficiency, which is all the more remarkable considering that Rwanda remains one of the poorest nations in the world. Even on a Saturday morning, platoons of women in white gloves rhythmically swept the streets, softly singing to themselves. I passed the Union Trade Center mall in the middle of town, where traffic circulates smoothly around a giant fountain. There was no garbage in the streets and none of the black plastic bags that get tangled up in the fences and trees of so many other African cities — Kagame’s government has banned them. There were no homeless youth sleeping on the sidewalks or huffing glue to kill their hunger. In Rwanda, vagrants and petty criminals have been scooped up by the police and sent to a youth “rehabilitation center” on an island in the middle of Lake Kivu that some Rwandan officials jokingly call their Hawaii — because it is so lush and beautiful — though people in Kigali whisper about it as if it were Alcatraz. There aren’t even large slums in Kigali, because the government simply doesn’t allow them.

headline: Putin Says Proof of Chemical Arms Attack Is Not Enough to Justify U.S. Action
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Biological and Chemical Warfare']
abstract: In an interview, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia warned that an attack on Syria without authorization from the United Nations Security Council would violate international law.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — In an interview published on Wednesday, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia said that it seemed “completely ridiculous” for the government of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria to have used chemical weapons and that there was still not sufficient proof to justify the military strike that President Obama has asked Congress to authorize.

headline: Diana Nyad on Pride, Survival and Her Plans at Age 10
abstract: “I want to be the best in the world at two things,” Diana Nyad wrote when she was a child. “I want to be a great athlete and I want to be a great surgeon.”
lead_paragraph: When Diana Nyad walked up onto the beach in Key West on Monday, 110 miles from Havana, where she had begun her swim — achieving a dream she’d been pursuing for 35 years — everybody wanted her to say something profound. What a monumental human being! What a passage! What was it like? She did a staggering job dispensing wisdom, for someone who’d been swimming for 53 hours straight. Still in her swimsuit, she leaned on her best friend’s shoulder, and with a swollen tongue and lips told the world never to write themselves off because of old age or give up on their dreams.

lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Thousands of dead fish floating along a 19-mile stretch of a river in Hubei Province in central China were killed by pollutants emitted by a local chemical plant, provincial environmental officials said Wednesday.

abstract: The arrest of Lee Seok-ki, an opposition lawmaker, rekindles concerns that South Korea’s intelligence agency, which is filing the charges, is meddling in domestic politics.

But Microsoft already bears a striking resemblance to Apple — the Apple of two decades ago, not the trailblazer of the mobile era, Nick Wingfield reports.

headline: After the Punks Comes … Charles James.
abstract: The Costume Institute at the Metropolitan Museum of Art announced on Wednesday that Charles James, the great 20th-century designer, will be the focus of its spring exhibition in May 2014.
lead_paragraph: The Costume Institute at the Metropolitan Museum of Art announced Wednesday that Charles James, the great 20th-century designer, will be the focus of its spring exhibition in May 2014, which is also when the museum unveils its renovated galleries. While the recently closed “Punk: Chaos to Couture” was not a favorite among designers (but nevertheless was successful), the idiosyncratic James, who died in 1978, is long revered in fashion but nevertheless mostly forgotten in the broader culture. The Costume Institute treatment could do for James what it did for Paul Poiret a few years back.

Recall one of the more memorable cautionary tales from “Seinfeld” when George Costanza was goaded into parking in a spot reserved for handicapped drivers. Hilarity did not exactly ensue when George and friends returned to find an angry mob had demolished the car.

headline: The Liberation of Knoxville
abstract: After years under Confederate control, the center of Tennessee Unionism is captured by the North.
lead_paragraph: On Sept. 1, 1863, an engineer for the Union Army named Orlando Poe arrived in Knoxville, Tenn., alongside thousands of soldiers under the command of Gen. Ambrose Burnside. The town was until recently a rebel stronghold, the last in northeastern Tennessee. Yet in a letter home to his wife he remarked: “I wish you could see the delight of the people — such loyalty to the Union I have never seen in my life before. We don’t know at the North what loyalty means.” Indeed, their long march over the Cumberland Mountains culminated in scenes of wild celebration as citizens of all ages greeted the liberating Federal army. A lithograph in Harper’s Magazine portrayed General Burnside riding among the crowd, elevated like a savior. Long a symbol of defiant Southern Unionism, the city of Knoxville, Tenn., was, at last, liberated from Confederate control.

headline: The Gun Report: September 4, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: At a children’s event called Reading Roundup in Lodi, Calif., on Aug. 24, a police SWAT officer was showing off the department’s truck, vest and other gear when a boy, around 6 to 8 years old, managed to pull the trigger on his Glock 35, shooting the officer in the leg. Police say because the gun was in a holster to accommodate the attached flashlight, the trigger was more accessible.

headline: School by Proxy
abstract: Two new picture books treat the school day as a wonderful adventure.
lead_paragraph: The problem with issue books (bibliotherapy, as some people call them) is that they can introduce new anxieties. Not every 5-year-old thinks about going to school for the first time and worries, “What if my teacher doesn’t like me?” So it is refreshing to see books that treat the school day as a wonderful adventure, and let kids cozy up to the idea by allowing other sorts of creatures — like pigs and grown-ups — make initial forays into that new environment on their behalf.

headline: A Pioneering Auction Company Shows the Way to China
abstract: Deb Weidenhamer of Auction Systems Auctioneers & Appraisers talks about the evolution of auctions from a last resort for sellers to a first resort.
lead_paragraph: Deb Weidenhamer is happy to say she practices the world’s oldest profession — it’s just not the one that occurs to most people. “Auctions are truly the oldest known profession,” she said. “They’ve got a longer recorded history than even prostitution.”

headline: What Does It Take to Do Business in China?
keywords: ['Auctions', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Small Business', 'Social Media']
abstract: It took a great deal of time and effort for Deb Weidenhamer to get “Chinafied” — but now she’s trying to make it easier for other small companies.
lead_paragraph: We just published a Conversation With Deb Weidenhamer, chief executive of Auction Systems Auctioneers & Appraisers, an 18-year-old auction company with $135 million in annual revenue. The company is based in Phoenix, but two years ago, Ms. Weidenhamer set up shop in Shanghai, where her auctions offer Western manufacturers an easy way to export their goods, or simply test demand and learn about pricing. In this portion of the interview, she talks about what it has been like doing business in China — why she studies Mandarin 15 hours every week, how she got “Chinafied” and how she can help other businesses get started there.

It is the largest gift ever made to the Manhattan-based school, according to the announcement.

abstract: “The Unknown Known” is one of two documentaries in competition. It is the first year that documentaries have been in the running at Venice.
lead_paragraph: VENICE — “I’ve made a whole number of movies over the years about characters that seem to be completely unaware of themselves. I suppose in English the word that we often use is ‘clueless,’” Errol Morris said at a news conference here on Wednesday to promote “The Unknown Known,” his new film-length interview with Donald Rumsfeld, the former secretary of defense. “That’s the central feeling I’m left with at the end of making this movie.”

headline: Trying to Shame Dune Holdouts at Jersey Shore
abstract: Townspeople are using various tactics to pressure more than 1,000 homeowners who are standing in the way of building a protective barrier along the coast.
lead_paragraph: SURF CITY, N.J. — Anchor Produce Market sells homemade mozzarella, its own fresh salsa and what many regulars swear is the best sweet corn on Long Beach Island.

headline: Related’s Ross Gives $200 Million to University of Michigan
abstract: The $200 million gift from the real estate developer Stephen M. Ross is the single largest gift in the university’s history.
lead_paragraph: The real estate developer Stephen M. Ross is giving the University of Michigan $200 million, the single largest gift in the university’s history.

headline: Deciding When to Enter a Palliative Care Unit
abstract: Patients with fatal conditions who aren’t ready for hospice care may opt for a plan  that focuses on treating symptoms and offering emotional support.
lead_paragraph: It’s a tough situation: you have a fatal condition. You require care beyond what family members can provide at home. But with a prognosis of more than six months to live, you are not ready for hospice care.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: ‘Touchy Feely’
abstract: Lynn Shelton, the director of “Touchy Feely,” discusses a scene from her film.
lead_paragraph: Lynn Shelton, the director of “Touchy Feely,” discusses a scene from her film.

headline: Museums Depart From the Obvious
abstract: The 2013-14 art season promises an unusually interesting mix of material from the distant past and art that engages with a politically fraught present.
lead_paragraph: Coming after a ho-hum stretch in museums, the 2013-14 art season promises an unusually interesting mix of material from the distant past and art that engages with a politically fraught present. As the months go by, we should get a sense of what our art institutions can do when they depart, even a little, from the obvious.

headline: Toyota to Recall 235,000 Vehicles Over Stalling Problem
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Automobiles', 'Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: Toyota recalled 82,000 hybrids in 2011 for a similar problem, but says the new recall is different.
lead_paragraph: Toyota will recall about 235,000 vehicles in the United States, including about 133,000 Lexus and Toyota hybrids, for a loss of power or stalling, a condition similar to that which led to a hybrid recall in 2011. In a news release early Wednesday, Toyota said it was recalling almost 77,000 Highlander Hybrids from the 2006-10 model years and 53,000 Lexus RX 400h hybrids from 2006-8.

headline: Some Fruits Are Better Than Others
abstract: New research suggests that eating blueberries, grapes, apples and grapefruit is associated with a lower risk of developing Type 2 diabetes.
lead_paragraph: Eating fruits is good for you, but new research suggests that some fruits may be better than others, and that fruit juice is not a good substitute.

headline: Outbid, but Not Down or Out
abstract: Amber Krause and Deepak Rao decided to buy instead of rent.
lead_paragraph: For two years, Amber Krause and Deepak Rao were happy in a one-bedroom with a view of the American Museum of Natural History. Then the rent rose from $3,100 a month to $3,600. “Renting wasn’t very economically sound for us,” Mr. Rao said. “We were paying more for the location and the view than for anything else.”

headline: Spanning Styles and the Globe
abstract: From multicultural textiles at the Met to the photographer John Divola in Los Angeles, the fall offers a range of intriguing shows.
lead_paragraph: Here we go again. Another art season, another who knows how many shows. Some to look forward to, some to dread.

headline: In San Francisco, It’s Rich Club, Poor Club
abstract: The exclusive St. Francis Yacht Club has a history of winning every major sailing race, except the biggest one, which was won by its less-distinguished neighbor, the Golden Gate Yacht Club.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Twenty years ago, before its failing finances were rescued by the billionaire Larry Ellison and before it won the America’s Cup, the Golden Gate Yacht Club was just a forlorn building at the end of a quarter-mile jetty. To get there, its members had to pass by the exclusive St. Francis Yacht Club, one of the most prestigious in the world.

headline: Nevada’s Jobless Feel the Sequester
abstract: Through the end of the month, benefits to the long-term unemployed will be cut by 59 percent because the state delayed carrying out cutbacks in federally funded programs until the fiscal year’s final weeks.
lead_paragraph: As of this week, unemployment insurance payments going out to more than 20,000 of Nevada’s long-term unemployed shrunk a whopping 59 percent, with the across-the-board federal budget cuts known as sequestration to blame.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: Video of ‘Touchy Feely’
abstract: Lynn Shelton, the writer and director of “Touchy Feely,” discusses a sequence from her film.
lead_paragraph: Some awkward moments on a reiki table are at the core of this anatomy of a scene video. The writer and director Lynn Shelton narrates a sequence from her film, featuring Allison Janney as a Reiki healer and Josh Pais as a new client.

headline: Will Swenson to Replace Will Chase in ‘Little Miss Sunshine’
abstract: Mr. Swenson will replace Mr. Chase in the coming musical adaptation of the Oscar-nominated film.
lead_paragraph: The Tony Award-nominated actor Will Swenson (“Hair”) will replace Will Chase in Second Stage’s fall production of the musical comedy “Little Miss Sunshine,” the theater has announced. Mr. Chase withdrew from the production after being cast as a country music singer on the second season of the ABC show “Nashville.” His departure was first reported on Broadway.com.

headline: For Prospective Brides, a Hotel With Gown Service
abstract: The St. Regis Bahia Beach Resort in Puerto Rico offers brides-to-be who book their weddings at the resort the opportunity to purchase gowns from the designer Lela Rose.
lead_paragraph: Brides who book their weddings at the St. Regis Bahia Beach Resort in Puerto Rico can anticipate more perks than a welcome rum punch. The resort has teamed with the  New York-based bridal designer Lela Rose to offer brides-to-be a choice of three bridal gowns  for purchase.

headline: In Hearing, House Panel Seems Split on Syria Strike
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Members of President Obama’s national security team took the case for intervention before the House Foreign Affairs Committee on Wednesday, a day after appearing before the panel’s Senate counterpart.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Members of the House Foreign Affairs Committee appeared divided on Wednesday over a possible military strike on Syria, as members of President Obama’s national security team took the case for intervention before the panel.

headline: Week 1 in Fantasy Football: Matchup Breakdown
abstract: Tony Romo, Steven Jackson and Pierre Garcon are among the players looking to exploit their favorable matchups in Week 1.
lead_paragraph: Upward of 36 million people play fantasy sports in North America, and many of them will be participating in the first week of the fantasy football season. There are almost as many fantasy football experts out there these days, and we are honored that you chose us to help you prepare for Week 1.

headline: A Multitasking Video Game Makes Old Brains Act Younger
abstract: Using a video game for training, researchers gave older people more youthful cognitive thinking, according to a study published in Nature.
lead_paragraph: There may be a new market for video games: octogenarians.

abstract: A look at works in new exhibitions this fall.
lead_paragraph: A look at works in new exhibitions this fall.

abstract: A Victorian in the Hudson Valley, a contemporary in Dallas and Puget Sound views in Washington.
lead_paragraph: A Victorian in the Hudson Valley, a contemporary in Dallas and Puget Sound views in Washington.

abstract: A Victorian in the Hudson Valley, a contemporary in Dallas and Puget Sound views in Washington.
lead_paragraph: RHINEBECK, N.Y.

headline: Hercule Poirot to Return in a New Christie Mystery
abstract: The novel, by Sophie Hannah, is authorized by the Agatha Christie estate and is to be released next year.
lead_paragraph: James Bond novels have carried on long beyond Ian Fleming. Decades after Margaret Mitchell’s death in 1949, “Gone With the Wind” spawned two sequels. In the latest continuation of a beloved literary property, a new Agatha Christie mystery will be released, the publisher said on Tuesday.

headline: A Critic of a Design Museum Will Lead It
abstract: Glenn Adamson, a researcher without the typical executive experience, wrote in 2011 that the museum he will soon lead “has little more than indiscrimination to call its own.”
lead_paragraph: The Museum of Arts and Design has named Glenn Adamson as its director, choosing a researcher without the typical executive experience who has been one of the museum’s most scathing critics.

headline: Fall Art Preview: From Braque to Balthus to Burtynsky
abstract: Retrospectives devoted to Robert Indiana and Georges Braque, a rare look at Balthus and an exhibition of New Deal photographs by Lewis Hine are in the mix of shows planned by American museums in coming months.
lead_paragraph: All dates are subject to change.

headline: Feeling For | Nashville, New and Improved
abstract: With a glut of new restaurant and retail openings this fall, Nashville seems ready to become the next hipster enclave of the South.
lead_paragraph: Nashville has spent the past few years slowly cultivating a more hipster-friendly identity, not unlike that of Austin, Tex., its spiritual compadre to the west. This fall, the city ups the ante in its bid to become the Williamsburg of the South. In the trendy Gulch neighborhood, the architect Nick Dryden has helped lead the transformation, designing hip spaces for clothing designer Billy Reid and for the denim mecca Imogene + Willie. Dryden’s latest endeavor, the 404 Hotel & Kitchen, which opens in October, is in an old garage next to a bluegrass landmark, the Station Inn, and preserves many of the original structure’s rustic charms: loftlike rooms with exposed ceiling beams and concrete floors (404 12th Avenue South). Then there’s Benjamin and Max Goldberg, the brothers behind the much buzzed-about restaurant the Catbird Seat. Next month they’ll open Pinewood Social — part restaurant, part bar and part hipster country club, with vintage bowling lanes, an outdoor pool, bocce-ball courts and karaoke rooms (33 Peabody Street). Chef Josh Habiger, who designed Pinewood’s menu, will also be cooking at Music City Eats, Nashville’s first food and music festival, the brainchild of the celebrity chef Jonathan Waxman and the local rockers Caleb and Nathan Followill of Kings of Leon (Sept. 21-22).

headline: Real Estate in the French Alps
abstract: A four-bedroom chalet on half an acre of landscaped gardens that slope down toward Lake Annecy.
lead_paragraph: A four-bedroom chalet on half an acre of landscaped gardens that slope down toward Lake Annecy.

headline: House Hunting in ... the French Alps
abstract: The continuing popularity of lakefront property, especially for overseas buyers fleeing unstable economies, has helped Annecy weather the financial crisis better than most areas.
lead_paragraph: A CONTEMPORARY CHALET ON LAKE ANNECY

headline: India’s Central Bank Chief May Have a Short Honeymoon
abstract: Glowing coverage of Raghuram Rajan, the new governor of the Reserve Bank of India, could be quickly eclipsed by escalating economic troubles.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — Indian newspapers have been gushing about the new governor of the central bank, Raghuram Rajan, in terms usually reserved for Bollywood film stars: his trim physique, his long-distance running, even his “rather photogenic appeal,” as The Mumbai Mirror tabloid wrote this week.

headline: On the Edge of Poverty, at the Center of a Debate on Food Stamps
abstract: As lawmakers cast a fight over cuts to food stamps in terms of spending, budget analysts and hunger relief advocates warn of a spike in “food insecurity” among Americans.
lead_paragraph: DYERSBURG, Tenn. — As a self-described “true Southern man” — and reluctant recipient of food stamps — Dustin Rigsby, a struggling mechanic, hunts deer, doves and squirrels to help feed his family. He shops for grocery bargains, cooks budget-stretching stews and limits himself to one meal a day.

headline: Architecture in Tune With the Climate
keywords: ['ARCHITECTURE', 'Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design (LEED)', 'Sustainable Living']
abstract: From a state-of-the-art recycling center in Brooklyn to sustainable rebuilding efforts for places hit by Hurricane Sandy, a host of green projects are on the horizon.
lead_paragraph: Building “green” is nothing new. For decades, many architects have tried to adapt their designs to forestall a new normal, choosing materials that will be less damaging to the environment and arranging rooms to be heated or cooled by the sun and wind, not the grid. As well they might: Buildings, and the industries that make and assemble the materials that become buildings, are among the biggest contributors to the greenhouse gas emissions that are warming the planet.

headline: Adventures for Murray on His Way to Victory
abstract: Andy Murray survived a challenge from Denis Istomin in their fourth-round match Tuesday night. He also was involved in two of the strangest points of the tournament.
lead_paragraph: Andy Murray survived a challenge from Denis Istomin in their fourth-round match Tuesday night. He also was involved in two of the strangest points of the tournament.

headline: The Early Birds of Fashion Week: Visvim, Harbison
abstract: In most people’s minds, Fashion Week begins on Thursday, but don’t tell that to the nearly 30 designers who are having presentations all day today.
lead_paragraph: In most people’s minds, Fashion Week begins on Thursday, but don’t tell that to the nearly 30 designers who are having presentations all day today. There were two this morning that were especially worth checking out: Charles Harbison, a former designer for Michael Kors and Luca Luca, who started his own line, Harbison, for fall; and Visvim, the cult Japanese men’s sportswear label that is branching out into women’s this season.

headline: Triple Play: Week 22 Results
abstract: Put your predictive skills to the test each week of the baseball season.
lead_paragraph: Almost 58 percent of respondents picked Miguel Cabrera as the player who would collect the most hits in Question No. 1. They were right, as Cabrera had nine hits in Week 22, but the Cardinals’ Matt Carpenter made it close with eight hits.

headline: Feats of Engineering
abstract: A look at the work of the artist Chris Burden.
lead_paragraph: A look at the work of the artist Chris Burden.

headline: Stock Sale Looks Right for LinkedIn
abstract: Even though LinkedIn does not need the money, its plans to raise $1 billion through a stock sale looks a lot better for shareholders than an overpriced buyback.
lead_paragraph: LinkedIn’s stock sale looks a lot better for shareholders than an overpriced buyback. The $27 billion job-focused social network is raising another $1 billion. With $900 million in cash and rising profit, it doesn’t really need the money. But when a company trades at more than 1,000 times reported 2012 earnings and more than 800 times estimated earnings for this year, selling stock makes sense.

headline: Auto Sales Are Soaring, Propelled by Leases
abstract: General Motors, Ford and Chrysler all had strong months as lower lease payments helped dealers move the inventory of new cars and trucks.
lead_paragraph: Automakers have traditionally used the lease as a way of making high-end cars and trucks more accessible for consumers who could not afford the full sticker price. But today, with credit more available and consumer confidence increasing, automakers are extending the strategy to more moderately priced cars, which in turn is helping bring about surprisingly strong sales results.

headline: The Puppet Masters
abstract: After successful collaborations with the New York Philharmonic, the theater production company Giants Are Small is launching an online video series hosted by Wigglesworth, a puppet.
lead_paragraph: After successful collaborations with the New York Philharmonic, the theater production company Giants Are Small is launching an online video series hosted by Wigglesworth, a puppet.

headline: Nadal Rolls to Semifinals by Thrashing Robredo
abstract: After missing last year’s Open, Rafael Nadal has stormed through his draw and improved his record on hardcourts this year to 20-0.
lead_paragraph: A year’s absence from the United States Open has made Rafael Nadal hungrier to win another championship and even more prepared for the challenge.

headline: With Microsoft-Nokia Deal, Competing in the Smartphone Market
abstract: Microsoft’s $7.2 billion deal for Nokia’s phone units is an attempt to catapult the company up the ranks in the smartphone market, which has been dominated by more established players, like Apple and Google.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft is under enormous pressure to reinvent itself for a world where mobile devices are the animating force in technology, rather than personal computers.

headline: 100 Seconds With Pogue: AvantGrand Piano
abstract: The Times’s David Pogue breaks down Yamaha’s latest AvantGrand hybrid piano.
lead_paragraph: The Times’s David Pogue breaks down Yamaha’s latest AvantGrand hybrid piano.

headline: Thinking About the Next Revolution
abstract: Virtual reality is a decades-old concept, but as processing power improves it is changing in important ways. More processing power and better, smaller cameras enable new uses, and faster interactions between virtual and real objects. Controls are moving from hands and sensors to thoughts themselves. What we think really may affect the world in new ways.
lead_paragraph: The man in the picture is turning on a light with his thoughts. Depending on how you look at it, this is an interesting technology trick, a possible aid to paraplegics or another way that the virtual and physical worlds are becoming indistinguishable.

headline: 4 Hands and 2 Hearts Beating as 1: Bound by Piano and, Soon, by Matrimony
abstract: Ran Dank and Soyeon Kate Lee played a program of four-hand pieces at Le Poisson Rouge on Tuesday, four days before their wedding.
lead_paragraph: Most couples just days from getting married are frantic with last-minute things to do. But on Tuesday night, four days before their wedding, the pianists Ran Dank and Soyeon Kate Lee played a program of four-hand piano pieces at Le Poisson Rouge in Greenwich Village. This was not an offering of the kind of four-hand duets that were meant for informal sight-reading sessions at home with friends. The program included the premiere of a fiercely difficult work by the flinty American composer Frederic Rzewski simply called “Four Hands.” To end, Mr. Dank and Ms. Lee played Stravinsky’s formidable four-hand arrangement of “The Rite of Spring,” a tour-de-force account of a stunning piano piece.

headline: Questions of Policy and Leadership Dog Obama Before Meeting in Russia
abstract: President Obama’s standing has undoubtedly suffered from recent turmoil over Syria and American spying, even though he can point to a strengthening economy.
lead_paragraph: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia — Not even a month ago, President Obama canceled a planned summit meeting with President Vladimir V. Putin, citing Russia’s decision to grant asylum to Edward J. Snowden as evidence of a broader deterioration of relations. “We weren’t going to have a summit for the sake of appearances,” the president’s deputy national security adviser, Benjamin J. Rhodes, said then.

headline: Gerard Mortier Undergoing Cancer Treatment
abstract: Mr. Mortier, the opera impresario with a penchant for shaking things up, is being treated for cancer, a Spanish newspaper reported.
lead_paragraph: Gerard Mortier, the opera impresario with a penchant for shaking things up in some of Europe’s most storied opera houses and music festivals, is being treated for cancer, the Spanish newspaper El País reported this week.

headline: No Strings on a Piano, but the Tone Is Grand
abstract: To its line of hybrid grand and upright pianos, Yamaha adds the NU1 — more compact and less expensive, but with real piano sound, not digital noise.
lead_paragraph: There are some things you just don’t expect to read about in a column about electronics. Gluten-free waffles, for example. Ferrets. Moist towelettes.

headline: General Grant Takes a Spill
abstract: Was the famous American military leader really a raging alcoholic?
lead_paragraph: On Sept. 2, 1863, Gen. Ulysses S. Grant arrived in New Orleans for the sort of event he usually avoided — a full-dress military review, to be staged in his honor two days hence by Gen. Nathaniel Banks. Still savoring the fall of Vicksburg in early July, Grant was also anticipating a forthcoming campaign against the Confederate general Braxton Bragg that fall in eastern Tennessee. A victory there — especially at the vital city of Chattanooga — promised to open the way to Atlanta.

headline: Taking On a Role She Grew Up With
abstract: Mary Bridget Davies grew up in Cleveland listening to Janis Joplin. Now she’s playing Joplin on Broadway.
lead_paragraph: Mary Bridget Davies, a 35-year-old actress and blues singer from Cleveland, has spent much of her career channeling Janis Joplin, one of her heroes, and will do so again, on Broadway, when “A Night With Janis Joplin” begins previews on Sept. 20 at the Lyceum Theater.

headline: Syria and the Constitution
keywords: ['Constitution (US)', 'Impeachment', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Why the president’s decision to go to Congress isn’t actually likely to restrain executive power in the future.
lead_paragraph: After President Obama’s surprise weekend announcement that he would seek congressional approval before ordering a strike on Syria, there was a flurry of commentary praising the president for taking a step back on the march toward ever-more-expansive executive power. “It may well be the most important presidential act on the Constitution and war-making powers,” wrote Walter Shapiro, “since Harry Truman decided to sidestep Congress and not seek its backing to launch the Korean war.” Dan McCarthy suggested that the president “has chosen the occasion of a war that over 50 percent of Americans oppose to teach a civics lesson,” that this partial self-limiting is “perhaps the best thing he’s done as president,” and that a Congress that voted down the Syria authorization would be serving notice to the public and to future administrations “that Article I, Section 8, Clause 11 of the U.S. Constitution is still in force.”

headline: Their Next Big Thing Is Actually Small
abstract: The stage and film directors Doug Fitch and Edouard Getaz are starting a Web series, “Hot Culture,” starring a pushy puppet and a few famous names.
lead_paragraph: When the stage director Doug Fitch and the filmmaker Edouard Getaz speak about their collaborations, they inevitably touch on matters of scale — ways of making tiny objects seem huge, and sometimes the opposite.

headline: Student Killed and 3 Are Hurt at Houston-Area High School
abstract: A fight, possibly gang related, broke out a few minutes before classes began at Spring High School, and a 17-year-old was stabbed to death.
lead_paragraph: SPRING, Tex. — A fight, possibly gang related, broke out at a suburban Houston high school early Wednesday, leaving one student dead of stab wounds and three other students injured, the authorities said.

headline: Let Us Now Praise Infamous Men
abstract: The iconic male hero – think James Dean, Elvis, or John F. Kennedy – was once a celebrated part of the American tradition, but the apotheosis of these men was supported by a consolidated media machine that has since lost its dominance. Now, in a more cynical age steeped in Web culture, icons remain, but the concept of heroism is in decline.
lead_paragraph: The male hero, once in ample supply, has entered a period of steady decline, and today our most iconic men are more likely to inspire cynicism than reverence.

headline: V.A. to Provide Spousal Benefits to Gays, Administration Says
keywords: ['Veterans', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Defense of Marriage Act (1996)']
abstract: In letters to Congressional leaders, Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. said President Obama directed the executive branch to stop obeying a statute that limits such benefits to spouses “of the opposite sex.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Wednesday escalated its effort to dismantle federal barriers to same-sex marriages, announcing that the Department of Veterans Affairs would immediately begin providing spousal benefits to gay men and lesbians despite a federal statute that limits such benefits to veterans’ spouses who are “of the opposite sex.”

headline: Katy Perry’s ‘Roar’ Dethrones Robin Thicke
abstract: After 12 weeks as Billboard’s No. 1 single, Robin Thicke’s “Blurred Lines” was bested this week by Katy Perry’s latest hit, “Roar.”
lead_paragraph: On the music charts, summer may be ending with a “Roar.”

headline: Verizon’s Deal Financing Moves Quickly, as Debt Markets Remain Open
abstract: Verizon’s deal, which included $61 billion in financing, highlights what bankers describe as the continued health of the debt markets.
lead_paragraph: Verizon Communications’ blockbuster deal to take full control of its wireless unit may seem dauntingly large. But for the two banks leading the arrangement of its $61 billion financing, it’s possible to pull off.

headline: Pennetta Stays Focused on Opponent’s Weakness
abstract: Flavia Pennetta refused to allow Roberta Vinci to coax her into playing points that would take her away from her game plan.
lead_paragraph: Flavia Pennetta gained her first Grand Slam semifinal with a straight sets victory over Roberta Vinci, outplaying her Italian compatriot with superior consistency and an intelligent use of power. Pennetta worked over Vinci’s one-handed slice backhand tirelessly, playing her two-handed backhand crosscourt with depth and penetration. When Vinci ran around to play an inside-out forehand, Pennetta stepped in and laced a backhand down-the-line winner.

headline: Fund Responds to Chief’s Prostitution Arrest
abstract: Common Sense Investment Management, a $2.9 billion fund of funds based in Oregon, sought to distance itself on Wednesday from a prostitution scandal involving its chief executive.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 7:11 p.m. to provide details on the ownership of Common Sense. |

headline: Split Senate Panel Approves Giving Obama Limited Authority on Syria
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: The 10-to-7 vote in the Foreign Relations Committee sets up a showdown next week in the full Senate on whether President Obama should be given the power to strike Syria.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A sharply divided Senate committee voted Wednesday to give President Obama limited authority to use force against Syria, the first step in what remains a treacherous path for Mr. Obama to win Congressional approval for a military attack.
