abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Weinstein Lands a Big-Name Executive Producer for ‘Finding Neverland’
abstract: The Broadway producer Barry Weissler will be an executive producer of “Finding Neverland,” the first big-budget stage musical from Harvey Weinstein.
lead_paragraph: The Broadway producer Barry Weissler (“Pippin,” “Chicago”) has signed on as an executive producer of “Finding Neverland,” the first big-budget stage musical from the filmmaker Harvey Weinstein, who is aiming the recently overhauled show for a United States premiere in 2014 at the American Repertory Theater in Cambridge, Mass. Given Mr. Weissler’s track record of success, his involvement increases the odds that Mr. Weinstein will extend his powerful producing hand into theater in New York and London with “Finding Neverland.”

headline: Enter the New Designer Stars at New York Fashion Week (or So They Hope)
abstract: This Fashion Week is chockablock with new names.
lead_paragraph: IF YOU HAVEN’T ALREADY HEARD of Rosie Assoulin, or Chris Gelinas, or Dion Lee, or Charles Harbison, or Jérôme LaMaar, then you haven’t been doing your fashion homework, people.

headline: 'Closer Look'
abstract: The most recent ad from the Quinn campaign is the first negative ad produced by a candidate in the Democratic primary.
lead_paragraph: The most recent ad from the Quinn campaign is the first negative ad produced by a candidate in the Democratic primary.

headline: Buy a Book, Get an E-Book, Too
abstract: Amazon announced that it would let customers who bought certain print books download the electronic version for a small fee.
lead_paragraph: Amazon announced this week that it would let customers who bought certain print books download the electronic versions of those titles for a small fee, or for free. For anyone who buys both kinds of books, myself included, the service, which Amazon calls Kindle MatchBook, raises a simple question: What took so long?

headline: Retailing as a Forum for Art
abstract: Dior Homme commissions a work for the 57th Street store and Garage, the magazine edited by Dasha Zhukova, asked five perfumers to create scents based on famous artworks.
lead_paragraph: THE INTERSECTION of fashion and art has produced some strange bedfellows over the last decade (Richard Prince purses for Louis Vuitton; Cindy Sherman’s Chanel series), but Kris Van Assche, the Dior Homme designer, takes a straightforward approach to art appreciation. He hires artists to create pieces for his stores, like the poetic Robert Montgomery light sculpture that hangs in the SoHo store.

headline: Back to School Resolution: I Won’t Overschedule My Family This Fall
abstract: This school year, I will consider a free afternoon a booked afternoon, and I will not rush to fill it.
lead_paragraph: And … we’re back.

headline: Opponents of Summers Must Overcome His Bond With Obama
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Decision time is here, and while President Obama has not settled on who should take over the Federal Reserve, he still favors Lawrence Summers.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As President Obama turned to second-term job openings soon after his re-election, the topic one day in the Oval Office was probably the most important economic decision he would make: Who should succeed the Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, after 2013?

headline: Wheelies: The Price of Efficiency Edition
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Frankfurt Auto Show', 'Small Cars (Compact, Subcompact and Microcars)', 'Speed Limits and Speeding']
abstract: Volkswagen announced pricing for its limited-production diesel plug-in hybrid, and Carhenge has a new owner.
lead_paragraph: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Beauty in the Eye of the Dreamer
abstract: From Marc Jacobs, a cosmetics shop on Bleecker Street; from Rachel Zoe, a hair salon in the Flatiron district.
lead_paragraph: IF FASHION IS SPINACH, as the clothing designer and critic Elizabeth Hawes proclaimed 75 years ago, then beauty is mesclun salad: a sprightly, ever-changing mix that we continue to gobble up even though it’s probably overpriced.

headline: Renée Fleming to Sing ‘Streetcar’ at Los Angeles Opera
abstract: Ms. Fleming created the role of Blanche DuBois in the inaugural production of André Previn’s opera based on the Tennessee Williams play.
lead_paragraph: Woody Allen brought a reimagined Blanche DuBois — in the form of Cate Blanchett’s Jasmine French — to the streets of San Francisco this summer in his film “Blue Jasmine.” Another Blanche is heading to California next spring: the Los Angeles Opera announced on Wednesday that Renée Fleming would reprise the role, which she created, in three semi-staged performances of André Previn’s opera of “A Streetcar Named Desire.”

headline: U.S. Open Food Review: Crepes Revisited
abstract: Wednesday’s United States Open food review: the vegetarian crepe at Sweet & Savory Crepes.
lead_paragraph: Because eating at the United States Open is a high-stakes game, we will feature a daily review of items available at the food courts at the National Tennis Center.

headline: A Macabre Mystery: Poe Ballantine Talks About Memoir and True Crime
abstract: Mr. Ballantine’s new book, “Love and Terror on the Howling Plains of Nowhere,” is about his life in a small Nebraska town and the mysterious death of a professor.
lead_paragraph: For several years, Poe Ballantine has written essays about his life in the small town of Chadron, Neb., for The Sun magazine. His new book, “Love & Terror on the Howling Plains of Nowhere,” is part memoir and part true-crime story. In it, Mr. Ballantine writes about his own life — his chronic wanderlust, the many low-paying jobs he’s held, his rocky marriage to a Mexican woman and the challenges of raising an autistic son. He also chronicles a gruesome event that shocked his quiet corner of Nebraska. In December 2006, Steven Haataja, a math professor, went missing from Chadron. In March 2007, his body was found on a ranch south of the town, bound to a tree and severely burned. Police eventually and unofficially considered the death a suicide. In a recent e-mail interview, Mr. Ballantine discussed his belief that Mr. Haataja was murdered, his approach to writing about his own life alongside Mr. Haataja’s death, and more. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation:

headline: For Fashion Models, Quirk Is In
abstract: Models who don’t fit the image of pristine perfection are suddenly in demand.
lead_paragraph: A decade or so ago came Gisele Bündchen and the Brazilians, with their va-va-voom bodies, golden tans and sun-streaked hair. Then there was a flood of Eastern bloc models, led by Natalia Vodianova, with ethereal, almost feline features.

headline: Switching to Lipstick
abstract: As temperatures begin their gradual slide, the great switch from balms and glosses to proper lipsticks begins. Here, four brands are assessed.
lead_paragraph: As temperatures begin their gradual slide, the great switch from balms and glosses to proper lipsticks begins. Here, four brands are assessed.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Jerusalem and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Jerusalem, Syria, Thailand and Cambodia.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Jerusalem, Syria, Thailand and Cambodia.

headline: In an Unknown Territory With a Sense of Mission
abstract: Tarbaby, featuring Oliver Lake on alto saxophone, brought its sense of adventure to the Jazz Standard on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Tarbaby opened its first set at the Jazz Standard on Tuesday night in search-party mode, warily poking around uncertain terrain. The pianist Orrin Evans was the first on the scene, his sparsely darting intervals evoking the trace of a flashlight beam. He was soon joined by the others: Eric Revis on bass, Nasheet Waits on drums, Oliver Lake on alto saxophone. After some formless preamble, they locked into the slinky syncopations of “Rolling Vamp,” by Mr. Lake. It led them down a trail without giving up any secrets.

headline: Conversations With Andy Murray: On Beating Cheating
abstract: Andy Murray discussed doping in sports and the need to have a good drug-testing program in tennis.
lead_paragraph: After his four-set, fourth-round win over Denis Istomin, Andy Murray again spoke to Straight Sets about another topic important to him: the growing specter of doping across the sports world.

headline: Verizon Never ‘Seriously Considered’ Move Into Canada, Chief Says
abstract: There had been speculation that Verizon Communications would buy two struggling Canadian start-up carriers, allowing it to bid for radio spectrum at a government auction.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Speculation that Verizon Communications would enter Canada by buying two struggling start-up carriers, allowing the company to bid for radio spectrum at a  coming government auction, dominated political debate here in recent weeks.

headline: A New Raffles Hotel on Hainan Island
keywords: ['Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Swimming Pools', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: Raffles Hainan opened this month in the Clearwater Bay area of the Chinese island.
lead_paragraph: China’s answer to Hawaii, Hainan Island,  in China’s southernmost province, continues to grow on the high end with the opening earlier this month of the Raffles Hainan.

headline: As Mets’ Season Winds Down, Audition at First Gets Started
abstract: Lucas Duda has been playing first base since Ike Davis was injured and General Manager Sandy Alderson hinted that Duda was in the midst of an audition for the spot.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Once again, the dog days of August have become the dog days of September for the Mets. The club is playing irrelevant games, as far as the standings are concerned, and the ambience for the outsider does not look very inviting. The team’s two biggest stars, pitcher Matt Harvey and third baseman David Wright, are injured, and the quest for a .500 season is nearly a fruitless cause.

headline: Shopping for Mirrors
abstract: Ashley Whittaker, an interior designer, likes to use decorative mirrors in prominent places throughout the home.
lead_paragraph: Ashley Whittaker, an interior designer, likes to use decorative mirrors in prominent places throughout the home.

headline: Choosing Emotion Over Virtuosity
abstract: The pianist Soheil Nasseri, in a solo recital at Merkin Concert Hall featuring works by Beethoven and Michael Hersch, displayed a sure eye for drama.
lead_paragraph: Pianists blessed with formidable technique are often tempted by programs that show off virtuosic extremes. In his solo recital at Merkin Concert Hall on Tuesday evening, Soheil Nasseri went in search of other extremes in a selection of works that demonstrated the piano’s ability to reflect the whole gamut of human emotions. From the playfulness of Brahms’s Capriccios and the Punch-and-Judy humor of Beethoven’s Sonata No. 16 in G to the bitter anguish of two powerful new pieces by Michael Hersch, Mr. Nasseri revealed a sure eye for drama and the psychologically telling detail.

headline: A-List Dinners, Parties and Events During New York Fashion Week
abstract: Here’s your guide to maneuvering fashion week parties.
lead_paragraph: A PREVIEW of the A-list dinners, parties and live shows during New York Fashion Week. Party photos at nytimes.com/fashion.

headline: Samsung Unveils Galaxy Gear Smartwatch
abstract: The timing of the release could also give Samsung a leg up over Apple, which has yet to unveil a similar device but has long been rumored to be working on one.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Samsung Electronics unveiled on Wednesday its highly anticipated digital wristwatch that can snap photos, track workouts and use an array of apps — gadgetry that the company hopes will catapult it into a market of smart portable devices that leave cellphones in users’ pockets.

headline: They Make Nice Neighbors (and Good Belts)
abstract: Alligators are popular this week, with “Ragin’ Cajun Redneck Gators” and “Buying the Bayou” offering both fact and fiction about the reptiles.
lead_paragraph: Location, location, location, they say in real estate, but timing is important too. And the timing of the house hunters in Destination America’s new real-estate show, “Buying the Bayou,” couldn’t be worse. They are settling into their freshly purchased waterside getaways just as mutant alligators are marching out of the swamp with blue tongues, spike-shooting tails and really bad tempers.

headline: Green Eggs and E-Books? Thank You, Sam-I-Am
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'E-Books and Readers', 'Book Trade and Publishing']
abstract: Dr. Seuss’s “Cat in the Hat,” “Green Eggs and Ham,” “There’s a Wocket in My Pocket!” and “The Lorax” will soon be downloadable, with more of his books to follow.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Seuss books, those whimsical, mischievous, irresistibly rhymey stories that have been passed down in print to generations of readers, are finally catching up with digital publishing.

headline: A Couple, Into Themselves, Make Room for One More
abstract: In “Everything Is Ours,” a couple’s life changes when a child suddenly arrives.
lead_paragraph: Stop me if you’ve heard this one before. There’s this self-centered, seemingly shallow, young(ish) woman (or, in a pinch, man), who is totally devoted to her career and/or personal pleasure. Suddenly, out of that left field where comedy writers grow their plots, a life-changing new arrival enters this narcissist’s life. Why, it’s a little stranger, forced by circumstance into a ménage that is hardly child-friendly.

headline: Abundantly Wealthy, But Not Living It Up
abstract: The heiress Huguette Clark sequestered herself in a hospital room and had not visited any of her luxurious homes in more than 20 years.
lead_paragraph: The story of how the book “Empty Mansions” came to be, in the words of Bill Dedman, one of its two authors, begins with “an exercise in American aspiration.” And when Mr. Dedman, a journalist, embarked on that exercise, he could not have guessed how right that phrase would be. In 2009 he and his wife were looking for a house outside New York City. Just for fun, Mr. Dedman Googled real estate listings in the astronomical range. He found a markdown in New Canaan, Conn., a house that had gone from $35 million to $24 million and had one very unusual feature, even more unusual than its room for drying draperies. The place had been unoccupied since it was purchased. In 1951.

headline: Feeling For | A Customizable Collection From Tod’s
abstract: The new collection by J.P. Tod focuses on customization, allowing you to choose from a selection of fine leathers and hand-burnished patinas for a variety of shoes and accessories.
lead_paragraph: With a nod to the brand’s original name, the new J.P. Tod’s Sartorial Touch collection allows you to customize monk-straps, wingtip loafers, unstructured briefcases and even its iconic driving shoes in a choice of fine leathers and hand-burnished patinas.

headline: The Instruments Are Typical, but the Sound Is Far From Cookie Cutter
abstract: Dawn of Midi played songs from their new album, “Dysnomia,” in a concert at Le Poisson Rouge.
lead_paragraph: Dawn of Midi is an instrumental trio from Brooklyn that makes something like minimal dance music using piano, acoustic bass and a drum kit with a high-hat but no other cymbals. Its music is all rhythm, more or less, and all composed. The individual contributions can be small, as little as one beat or note per bar, but they are cumulative, and constructed in tandem. One player completes another’s rhythmic phrase, or one player’s precise rhythmic cycle produces friction against another’s. The music keeps growing and changing, through distinct but unbroken episodes; it becomes a network of bones with very little meat.

headline: A Live Google+ Conversation with President Carter on Global Health
abstract: President Carter answered questions about eradicating persistent diseases around the world.
lead_paragraph: For my second Google+ Hangout of the day, I spoke with former U.S. President Jimmy Carter about global health and how to eradicate disease.

headline: Michael Bastian Carries a Torch
abstract: Mr. Bastian was in his normally safe mode of making luxurious gym shorts and intarsia sweaters, snugly and suggestively fitting trousers, and swimsuits for guys with both style and swagger to spare.
lead_paragraph: Alice Smith made a surprise appearance at the start of Michael Bastian’s runway show on Wednesday at the Pierre Hotel, belting out a torch song that began with the words, “Where are you going with your life?”

headline: Julie Gilhart: Bouncing Back With a Digital Twist
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Shopping and Retail', 'E-Commerce', 'New York Fashion Week']
abstract: Julie Gilhart has reinvented herself as a fashion consultant focusing on Web commerce.
lead_paragraph: “I’m in a completely virtual space,” Julie Gilhart said recently.

headline: Roth Open Swiss Teams
abstract: The winners of the Freeman Mixed Board-a-Match Teams in Atlanta last month were Judith Bianco and Win Allegaert of New York, Petra Hamman of Dallas and David Grainger of Roseville, Calif.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The winners of the Freeman Mixed Board-a-Match Teams here last month were Judith Bianco and Win Allegaert of New York, Petra Hamman of Dallas and David Grainger of Roseville, Calif. They finished 0.24 points ahead of Dana Berkowitz and Craig Ganzer of New York, Robert Brady of McLean, Va., and Mihaela Balint from Romania.

headline: Simplicity Is the Goal With Calendar Apps
abstract: Several smartphone calendars make a specialty of clean, readable interfaces for keeping track of events and to-do items.
lead_paragraph: My phone just pinged to remind me that next Thursday my son begins “big” school.

headline: Jeanette Hayes: The Internet, Rendered in Oil
abstract: The artist looks to the Safari and Firefox icons for inspiration.
lead_paragraph: AGE 24

headline: Adultery, and Other Pleasures
abstract: A celebrity couple and a rising star are featured in a revival of Harold Pinter’s “Betrayal.”
lead_paragraph: A celebrity couple and a rising star are featured in a revival of Harold Pinter’s “Betrayal.”

headline: Summertime, and Broadway Living Is Hard: Attendance Drops 8 Percent
abstract: Broadway hits like “The Book of Mormon,” “Wicked,” “Matilda” and “Pippin” are doing well, but overall, summer turnout was low.
lead_paragraph: Broadway’s hit shows are as popular as ever — and selling more seats at high prices. But this summer was a tough one for other musicals and plays, leading to the weakest summertime for overall attendance since 2003.

headline: Planting Your Flag on a Patch of the Web
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Trademarks and Trade Names', 'Domain Names (Internet)']
abstract: New options will make buying an Internet domain easier, but the process can still be fraught with problems.
lead_paragraph: Owning an Internet domain is a bit like owning real estate. After buying one, a patch of the Internet is your playground. You can open for business at, say, “wicked-awesome-pizza.com,” you can publish a blog or you can sell the domain to the highest bidder.

headline: Scene City: An Empire Lives On
abstract: HBO toasts the fourth season of “Boardwalk Empire.”
lead_paragraph: HBO toasts the fourth season of “Boardwalk Empire.”

headline: Schwab Case Casts Spotlight on Securities Arbitration and Its Flaws
keywords: ['ARBITRATION, CONCILIATION AND MEDIATION', 'Financial Brokers', 'Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: A skirmish between regulators and the brokerage firm Charles Schwab has brought attention to the arbitration process used by the securities industry.
lead_paragraph: Class-action lawsuits are the bane of most financial firms, and many recoil at the prospect of paying out millions to groups of clients if investments go sour. Now, the discount brokerage firm Charles Schwab & Company finds itself at odds with regulators as it seeks to eliminate the option of such suits for its clients.

headline: The Gangsters Are All Here
abstract: Steve Buscemi and Michael Kenneth Williams turned out for the fourth-season premiere of HBO’s “Boardwalk Empire.”
lead_paragraph: The red carpet was ready at the Ziegfeld Theater, and the reporters and photographers were waiting to pounce. But where were the stars of “Boardwalk Empire” for its fourth-season premiere?

headline: The Wristwatch May Be Making a Comeback, but With Some Smarts
abstract: Few freshmen entering college in 2010, so accustomed to keeping time with their smartphones, had any idea that pointing at a wrist was the universal language for asking the time. But a new generation of computerized watches could reintroduce timekeeping to wrists.
lead_paragraph: Want to try a little experiment? Walk up to someone under the age of 25, don’t say a word, but instead point to your wrist. They will likely walk away, very quickly.

headline: Dressing for the Fashion Shows and After
abstract: No need to leave your favorite jeans back home during New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: Put a Little Kick (And Shine) In Those Boots

headline: Il Divo Is Coming to Broadway
abstract: The shows, running from Thursday, Nov. 7, through Wednesday, Nov. 13, with no show on Sunday, will feature songs from classic shows like “Phantom of the Opera,” “Carousel” and “West Side Story,.
lead_paragraph: Il Divo, the operatic pop vocal group, is coming to Broadway for a limited run at the Marquis Theater on Nov. 7 and plans to release an album of show tunes the same week.

headline: In Hynes Ad, Praise for the Boss
abstract: Kenneth P. Thompson, who is running against Charles J. Hynes for Brooklyn district attorney, criticized him for using a staff member in a political commercial.
lead_paragraph: Diana B. is grateful to  Charles J. Hynes, the Brooklyn district attorney, she tells viewers. Through his innovative programs, “we’ve been able to cut crime to its lowest level in decades” in her native borough, she says.

headline: Irving Azoff Starts New Entertainment Business
abstract: The multifaceted company, backed by $175 million from the Madison Square Garden Company, will be called Azoff MSG Entertainment.
lead_paragraph: Since the music executive Irving Azoff resigned as Live Nation Entertainment’s executive chairman at the end of last year, speculation about his next venture has been something of an industry pastime. Would he go into television? Music publishing? Something digital?

headline: Bringing in Light With Mirrors
abstract: Mirrors can act like another window in a room. Just don’t blame the designer if you don’t like the views they offer.
lead_paragraph: A crucial part of designing a room is figuring out “interesting ways to use your walls,” Ashley Whittaker said. “And mirrors are a wonderful way to do that.”

headline: A House Called Flip-Flop
abstract: Designed by the architect Dan Brunn, this home is named for its louvers, which open to a view of Venice Beach.
lead_paragraph: Designed by the architect Dan Brunn, this home is named for its louvers, which open to a view of Venice Beach.

headline: Bauhaus on the Beach
abstract: For one architect, it was a dream commission: a budget of $8 million and clients who never said no.
lead_paragraph: Is it possible for an architect to be adopted by a client?

headline: Sales at Modani Furniture, Ankasa and Others
abstract: Bargains on beds, lamps and other furniture.
lead_paragraph: Modani Furniture is discounting many items both online and in stores by up to 70 percent, through Monday (the Miamo sofa bed, regularly $1,290, is $490; the Jackson floor lamp, regularly $1,340, is $490); 40 East 19th Street (Broadway), (212) 780-1800, modani.com.

headline: Decadent as a Bite of Velvet Cake
abstract: Squint, a London furniture company, introduces velvet-covered tables and vases.
lead_paragraph: Squint, the London furniture maker that mixes harlequin-bright fabrics on traditional English upholstered pieces, has gone in for flocking. On Sept. 14, it will introduce its Velvet Collection, carved mahogany tables and sinuous glass vases sheathed in fleecy stuff.

headline: Public School Designers Who Grasped a Helping Hand
abstract: The award-winning team behind Public School has thrived on a second chance from the Council of Fashion Designers of America.
lead_paragraph: Among New York’s current class of young designers, men’s wear division, Dao-Yi Chow and Maxwell Osborne, the designers of Public School, would handily win the title of most likely to succeed.

headline: The Impossible Table
abstract: Poised, a table that appears to be on the verge of falling over, is a star attraction of the British designer Paul Cocksedge’s first solo show.
lead_paragraph: Poised, a 1,000-pound steel table, was built to give the impression that it is falling over. “It looks as if it’s improbable,” said Paul Cocksedge, the Londoner who designed it. “But because of the calculations of weight and angles, it’s balanced in a way that it behaves itself.”

headline: Mira Nakashima: Not Far From the Tree
abstract: On preserving, and building on, the legacy of a celebrated furniture maker.
lead_paragraph: Mira Nakashima worked in the shadow of her legendary furniture-maker father, George Nakashima, for two decades. But when he died in 1990, many clients canceled their orders or demanded a discount because the pieces wouldn’t have the signature of “the master.” For a time, his daughter, who holds two degrees in architecture, thought she would have to shutter the family business.

headline: Sure, It Purifies Air, but Can It Save the Galaxy?
abstract: The Patrull air purifier from Ikea has been compared to a robot.
lead_paragraph: With its rectangular white body, round black eyes (a control and vent, really) and stubby feet, the Patrull air purifier from Ikea has been compared to a “Star Wars” robot. Part of Ikea’s collection of home-safety products (“patrull” is Swedish for “patrol”), the appliance was introduced in Europe a few years ago, but has finally arrived in the United States. The unit, made of plastic, is said to be vigilant in filtering pollen, dust, dust-mite allergens and tobacco-smoke particles. Relatively small (it is a foot high) and easily portable (it weighs 11 pounds), it has three fan settings and a replaceable filter. It runs on low power (8 to 32 watts) and at a low volume (30 to 45 decibels), a plus for sensitive sleepers. Patrull is $96 and is available in Ikea stores only.

headline: Tap on the Surface to See if It’s Ripe
abstract: From the Brooklyn designers Chen Chen and Kai Williams, planters and bowls cast from cut fruit.
lead_paragraph: In 2011 Chen Chen and Kai Williams, who met as industrial design students at Pratt, opened a studio in Brooklyn after a few years of working independently. (Mr. Chen, born in China and raised in the United States and Canada, was on the staff at the design emporium Moss. Mr. Williams, the son of the architects Tod Williams and Billie Tsien, had started a digital fabrication company.) Today they are known for their freewheeling use of materials. Their new planters and bowls shaped like cut fruit, for example, are made of Rockite, a cement often used to anchor bolts into walls. The designers make rubber molds from actual fruit and line them with the material, which hardens in place; no firing is needed. “In the past year we’ve been working a lot in resin, but we wanted to use something not so toxic,” Mr. Chen said. The cantaloupes shown here are $28 each. Information: chen-williams.com.

headline: Chapter One: Chintz
abstract: Throughout his career, Mario Buatta has been an unabashed practitioner of English country style.
lead_paragraph: Throughout his career, Mario Buatta has been an unabashed practitioner of English country style.

headline: Mario Buatta: The Beauty of a Bad Pun
abstract: When decorating for the rich, you have to keep your sense of humor. Just ask Mr. Buatta, who has done it for 50 years.
lead_paragraph: One muggy afternoon last week, Mario Buatta was sitting in the living room of a Midtown penthouse of his design, slightly overheated by his pinstripe suit and the late August sun. When a photographer loomed, he brandished a cane topped with a silver hound.

headline: What’s Best, LED or Incandescent Lights?
keywords: ['Light-Emitting Diodes', 'Electric Light Bulbs', 'Energy Efficiency', 'Lighting', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Advice on lighting that will appeal to home buyers.
lead_paragraph: Q. I’m replacing the lights in my home before putting it on the market. Is it better to install LED fixtures, if it’s true that incandescent bulbs are being phased out?

headline: Portraits and Keepsakes of Coco Chanel
abstract: The designer, who famously dismissed requests by Salvador Dali and Pablo Picasso to paint her portrait, sat late in life for the artist Marion Pike. The paintings, and mementos of the duo’s friendship, go on display tomorrow in London.
lead_paragraph: Coco Chanel was fiercely protective of her life’s narrative, omitting less savory details involving her working-class roots and, where revisionism fell short, outright destroying personal documents and other records. And so it is both intriguing and fortuitous (at least for those interested in demystifying her past) that in her final years, Chanel befriended the privileged and unguarded artist Marion Pike, a third-generation Californian who had already traveled throughout much of Europe by age 16 and studied at Stanford University. Pike meticulously preserved telegrams, clothing, photographs and other mementos of the duo’s time together. These keepsakes, along with five acrylic portraits of Chanel, are the subject of the exhibition “Coco Chanel: A New Portrait by Marion Pike,” which opens tomorrow at the Fashion Space Gallery in London.

headline: Images of the Vietnam War That Defined an Era
keywords: ['Photography', 'Vietnam War', 'News and News Media', 'Nineteen Hundred Sixties', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: A retrospective book and exhibitions highlight war photographs that turned the tide of public opinion.
lead_paragraph: Half a century after the nation’s fateful early missteps into the quagmire, what are Americans likely to remember about the Vietnam War?

headline: A Veteran Reporter Reflects on a Distant War
abstract: On the eve of a book and exhibits about the Vietnam War culled from Associated Press archives, Ralph Blumenthal reflects on covering the conflict’s early years.
lead_paragraph: The Associated Press culled from tens of thousands of its images from the Vietnam War for a new book and accompanying exhibitions that detail the news service’s crucial role in documenting the conflict. The book, “Vietnam: The Real War,” will be published by Abrams on Oct. 1 and features some of the era’s most famous images, including Nick Ut’s photo of a young girl running after a napalm attack.

headline: How to Secure the Castle
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Locks and Keys', 'Robberies and Thefts', 'Home Repairs and Improvements', 'Security and Warning Systems']
abstract: Short of a moat and a dragon, ways to make your family safe at home.
lead_paragraph: In my leafy suburban neighborhood, burglaries happen just rarely enough to give me a false sense of safety. I watch our home’s security with a fair amount of diligence, but I’m otherwise as complacent about this realm of home maintenance as I am about everything else around the place.

headline: Michael Bastian: Spring 2014 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Scientists Expand Scale of Digital Snooping Alert
keywords: ['Research', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Cryptography, Codes and Ciphers', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods', 'Computer Security']
abstract: A team in England said that it had taken a step toward bringing improved security to computer networks, developing a technique that will extend protection to a group of users.
lead_paragraph: Scientists reported on Wednesday that they had taken a step toward bringing improved security to computer networks, developing an encryption technique that will extend protection to a small group of computer users.

headline: A Bloody Ballmer and Stalled Discussions on the Long Road to a Nokia Deal
abstract: Microsoft’s purchase of some of Nokia was marked by a series of high-level negotiations that went nowhere.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — “We are on different planets.”

headline: Iran’s President to Speak at the U.N.
abstract: President Hassan Rouhani intends to deliver three speeches at the United Nations in New York this month, and the visit will afford him a chance to distinguish himself from Mahmoud Ahmadinejad.
lead_paragraph: President Hassan Rouhani of Iran, a cleric who was elected in June after promising to ease the country’s economic isolation and tensions with the West over a disputed nuclear program, will attend the opening session of the United Nations General Assembly in New York this month and deliver three speeches, his foreign minister said Wednesday.

headline: Building It, and Hoping the Big Leagues Come
abstract: A town in the Netherlands is toiling on a $15 million ballpark project meant to lure visits from Major League Baseball. But meeting league standards has been taxing.
lead_paragraph: HOOFDDORP, the Netherlands — Major League Baseball wants to play ball, exhibition games or even regular-season games, in Europe. But the ballpark it is eyeing for possible games lies not in big sports centers, like London with its Wembley Stadium, or Paris, with the Stade de France, but this midsize Dutch town on land that until about 150 years ago lay deep under water.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Spotify Is Sued, and Is Technology Scrambling Babies’ Brains?
abstract: Wednesday’s highlights from around the Web include news that Spotify, the music streaming service is being sued over its use of playlists. Plus, one tech-loving parent considers how devices might be impacting his baby, for good and for ill.
lead_paragraph: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items. Here’s what we noticed today:

headline: How Companies and Executives Diverge Politically
keywords: ['Citizens United v Federal Election Commission (Supreme Court Decision)', 'Corporations', 'Political Action Committees', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Two charts show how political contributions by corporate political action committees tend to treat the two parties evenly, while executives’ donations generally go only to one side.
lead_paragraph: Could corporate America really be losing control of the political process when corporate executives are spending so much to sway elections?

headline: Judith Daniels, Editor of Savvy Magazine, Dies at 74
abstract: Ms. Daniels, who saw a big gap in the magazine industry, was the first to focus on the emerging class of high-earning professional women.
lead_paragraph: Judith Daniels, the founding editor in chief of Savvy, the first glossy magazine aimed at executive women, died on Sunday at her home in Union, Me. She was 74.

keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Biological and Chemical Warfare']
abstract: Europeans, divided over Syria, arrive at this week’s meeting of the Group of 20 nations waiting for the United States to take the lead on the conflict.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Europeans, who prided themselves on a muscular foreign policy in Libya, arrive at this week’s meeting of the Group of 20 nations deflated and divided, waiting for the United States to take the lead on Syria and wondering just how much resistance to intervention Russia will ultimately muster.

headline: Italian Plant’s Abrupt Shutdown Stirs a Debate
keywords: ['Factories and Manufacturing', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )']
abstract: An Italian maker of elevator components closed while its workers were on vacation, fueling outrage over a move that one worker called “a knife to the stomach.”
lead_paragraph: PERO, Italy — Like it or not, Italy’s labor force recognizes that the long manufacturing slump may make factory closings inevitable. But this, they say, is no way to do it.

headline: Syria Is Not Kosovo
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Citizens’ lives are at stake again, but a different strategy is needed.

headline: William Glasser, 88, Doctor Who Said One Could Choose Happiness, Is Dead
abstract: Dr. Glasser, through “choice theory,” posited that people were in much more control of their lives than they realized in solving emotional and mental problems.
lead_paragraph: Dr. William Glasser, a psychiatrist who published more than two dozen books promoting his view that mental health is mostly a matter of personal choice, a precept that found a vast popular audience and influenced teachers, drug counselors and personal therapists, died on Aug. 23 in Los Angeles. He was 88.

headline: Wheelchairs and Cabs
abstract: A reader proposes a “trunk fee” to make New York cabs truly accessible.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Adapt, or Wither
abstract: For one reader, the Kodak company restructuring is a metaphor.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Sprint Breaks Record With Big New Bond Offering
abstract: Sprint Nextel on Wednesday sold $6.5 billion worth of high-yield bonds, breaking the record for the single biggest noninvestment-grade offering ever sold directly to investors. The sale comes only days after Verizon announced that it has taken out $61 billion in financing to support its mammoth deal to buy full control of its wireless unit.
lead_paragraph: For setting records for the debt markets, it appears that telecommunications companies can’t be beat.

headline: Not Very Giving

lead_paragraph: STANFORD, Calif. — AS school gets rolling across the country, many parents will be asked to make a large financial contribution to their children’s school. In Hillsborough, Calif., for example, parents receive a letter from the Hillsborough Schools Foundation in which the amount requested is $2,300 per child.

headline: Rockets in Syrian Attack Carried Large Payload of Gas, Experts Say
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Rockets delivering toxic sarin gas to neighborhoods around Damascus held up to 50 times more nerve agent than previously estimated, a study by weapons experts concluded.
lead_paragraph: A new study of images apparently from the Syrian attack last month concludes that the rockets delivering toxic sarin gas to neighborhoods around Damascus held up to 50 times more nerve agent than previously estimated, a conclusion that could solve the mystery of why there were so many more victims than in previous chemical attacks.

headline: Clothier for the Culture of Swagger
abstract: A boutique in Harlem is known for its distinctive line of caps, shirts and hoodies.
lead_paragraph: For some young men, the right cap or basketball sneaker is more than a fashion statement: It reflects an approach to life itself.

headline: The Six-Figure Price Tag for Selling a $2 Hot Dog
abstract: Vendors who want to sell drinks and snacks in city parks bid hundreds of thousands in annual fees for the privilege — particularly in Central Park.
lead_paragraph: Call it the half-million-dollar hot dog cart. Mohammad Mastafa of Astoria, Queens, has to sell almost that much in drinks and snacks annually to break even on the pushcart he owns at Fifth Avenue and East 62nd Street near the Central Park Zoo. He pays the city’s parks department $289,500 a year just for the right to operate his single cart there.

lead_paragraph: In Harlem, connoisseurs of streetwear travel to Frederick Douglass Boulevard to distinguish themselves.

lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Brandon Gaudin surveyed the four front-row chairs in the Georgia Tech radio booth last Saturday.

headline: Putin and the Presidents

lead_paragraph: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia has asserted himself as a major opponent of military action in Syria. It’s just the latest development in a fraught relationship with the United States.

headline: Off to the Mayoral Races
abstract: From kittens on the rails to Central Park carriage horses, in New York this year, we have four-legged issues.
lead_paragraph: Big primary election for mayor of New York City next week, people. Let’s take a look at what’s been going on. If you stick with me, I promise animal stories. Including kittens.

headline: The Next Abortion Case Is Here
abstract: An appeal in Oklahoma has drawn little attention, but at issue is the Supreme Court’s own unstable abortion doctrine.
lead_paragraph: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy, author of the 5-to-4 opinion in June that struck down the Defense of Marriage Act, may well be a hero to the gay rights community, and deservedly so. But he’s also the author of the 5-to-4 opinion that upheld the federal ban on so-called partial birth abortion back in 2007, and abortion-rights advocates have viewed with something close to dread the prospect that he could play a similarly decisive role in the Supreme Court’s next abortion case.

headline: The Disappearing Women
abstract: Before drinking the hemlock, Socrates banished the weeping women so the men could be left to philosophize. Other banishments followed.
lead_paragraph: This is the third of five posts this week on women in philosophy.

headline: Clinton Urges Americans to Sign Up for Health Care Exchanges
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Medicaid']
abstract: Less than a month before the start of insurance shopping under the health care law, former President Bill Clinton’s speech comes at a pivotal time for the Obama administration.
lead_paragraph: LITTLE ROCK, Ark. — He chose his home state as the venue, and did not refrain from ticking off several problems he saw with the law. But former President Bill Clinton on Wednesday made a meticulous, if wonkish, case for Americans of all political leanings to embrace the Obama health care law.

lead_paragraph: Weapons experts believe this is the design of the rockets used in a suspected chemical attack last month in Syria, based on videos and photographs posted online.

lead_paragraph: If you’re a New Yorker who is only now focusing seriously on the mayoral primary election, just five days away, you might feel bad about missing the Democrats’ final televised debate on Tuesday night.

headline: Britain to Examine Why BBC Severance Payments Exceeded Contract Terms
abstract: Hearings will look at payments the British Broadcasting Corporation made to senior editors as it tried to reduce its budget, and Mark Thompson, the former BBC chief, will testify.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — When it comes to the BBC and funding that is mostly provided by Britons who pay a fee to watch television, there is no end to the argument, or the accounting.

headline: A True Champion, Williams Perfects the Double Bagel
abstract: Serena Williams wasn’t the least bit defensive about her lopsided victory in the quarterfinals over Carla Suárez Navarro — nor should she have been.
lead_paragraph: Not long after she had stormed past another hopelessly overmatched victim on Tuesday night at the United States Open, Serena Williams was asked if she felt compassion while administering the double-bagel beating also known as love and love.

headline: Bill Clinton Defends Affordable Care Act
abstract: The former president countered some common criticisms of President Obama’s health care bill in a speech at the Clinton Presidential Center in Little Rock, Ark.
lead_paragraph: The former president countered some common criticisms of President Obama’s health care bill in a speech at the Clinton Presidential Center in Little Rock, Ark.

headline: Cooking Is Freedom
abstract: When I was 14, in 1972, girls took home ec and boys took shop. But I wanted to make lasagna, not birdhouses.
lead_paragraph: In 1972, I was hungry. Very hungry. After all, I was a 14-year-old boy. I played sports and was constantly working out. I could eat every hour. My mother packed my lunch in a grocery bag.

headline: Uninsured in Texas and Florida
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicaid', 'Law and Legislation', 'Editorials', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Two states with the worst records for health coverage see no reason to do much about it.
lead_paragraph: A new Census Bureau report documents the alarming percentages of people in Texas and Florida without health insurance. Leaders of both states should hang their heads in shame because they have been among the most resistant in the nation to providing coverage for the uninsured under the Affordable Care Act, the law that Republicans deride as “Obamacare.”

headline: Obama Faces Barrier in His Own Party on Syria
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Democrats say they are confronted with a difficult choice: go against the wishes of President Obama or defy voters who are overwhelmingly opposed to involving the United States in another unpredictable Middle East war.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Congressional Democrats, torn over involving the United States in another unpredictable Middle East war, are emerging as a major barrier to President Obama’s plan to strike Syria.

headline: Acxiom Lets Consumers See Data It Collects
keywords: ['Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Privacy', 'Consumer Behavior', 'Computer Security', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']
abstract: Visitors to the site can review many seemingly innocuous facts about themselves, but critics say it provides a sanitized view of the information mining behind data-driven marketing.
lead_paragraph: Aboutthedata.com, a Web site introduced on Wednesday by a leading marketing technology firm called the Acxiom Corporation, is offering individual consumers a glimpse of some of the details the company has collected about them.

headline: Seeking to Succeed Bloomberg, While Keeping Him at a Distance
abstract: The race for mayor has taken on an anti-Bloomberg message, and his endorsement, once coveted, is now seen as a detriment to both Democratic and Republican candidates.
lead_paragraph: Michael R. Bloomberg is a data-loving, health-enforcing nonpartisan who defined what it meant to be a mayor over the past 12 years, mentoring big-city chief executives from New Orleans to Philadelphia.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, September 5, 2013
abstract: Quotation of the day for Thursday, September 5, 2013.
lead_paragraph: “I didn’t set a red line. The world set a red line.”

headline: What Sir William Would Do in Syria
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Civil War (US) (1861-65)']
abstract: Intervention in Syria without a political plan for peace is folly.
lead_paragraph: MEDFORD, Mass. — THE use of nerve gas in Syria is abhorrent, and those within the Syrian military command who ordered it are war criminals. But it is folly to think that airstrikes can be limited: they are ill-conceived as punishment, fail to protect civilians and, most important, hinder peacemaking.

headline: The Films of the Coen Brothers
abstract: A look back at the films and career of Joel and Ethan Coen.
lead_paragraph: A look back at the films and career of Joel and Ethan Coen.

headline: In Giants’ Openers Against Dallas, Results Are Sour (for a Week, Anyway)
abstract: Beginning in 1965, the Giants have stumbled out of the gate whenever they’ve faced the Cowboys. Twice, though, the Giants have recovered to win the Super Bowl.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — As one of the N.F.L.’s oldest and most renowned franchises, the Giants usually open the season against a notable opponent. On Sunday, that tradition will continue in Dallas, where for the sixth time the Giants will start the season against the Cowboys.

headline: ‘We Are the Establishment Now’
abstract: The Coen brothers discuss nearly 30 years of making movies, including the mistakes they still make and their surprise at being mainstream, sort of.
lead_paragraph: When Joel and Ethan Coen were growing up, they used to make Super 8 films, including remakes of Hollywood movies that they had watched on TV. Since then, the Coens have continued to let their imagination loose while ranging wide across cinematic and literary genres, drawing on pulp literature (“Blood Simple,” “Miller’s Crossing”), screwball cinema (“The Hudsucker Proxy,” “Intolerable Cruelty”), Homer’s Odyssey (“O Brother, Where Art Thou?”), the Bible and their own suburban Minneapolis childhood (“A Serious Man”) to make movies that, increasingly, have the quality of an evolving, distinctly American mythopoeia.

headline: The Stakes in Congress
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'United States International Relations', 'Editorials', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: President Obama walks a difficult line in seeking military action on Syria. The American public deserves more answers.
lead_paragraph: The divided 10-to-7 vote on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee on Wednesday authorizing a strike against Syria for the use of chemical weapons showed there is no strong consensus yet on this critical question.

headline: Privacy Groups Ask F.T.C. to Block Facebook Policy Changes
abstract: Privacy advocates say coming changes to Facebook’s privacy policies violate a 2011 order by federal regulators requiring the social network to obtain explicit consent from its users before using their personal information for commercial purposes.
lead_paragraph: A coalition of six major consumer privacy groups has asked the Federal Trade Commission to block coming changes to Facebook’s privacy policies that they say would make it easier for the social network to use personal data about its users, including children under 18, in advertising on the site.

headline: Bezos Is a Hit in a Washington Post Newsroom Visit
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: Jeffrey P. Bezos assured editors and reporters of his commitment to preserving quality journalism at the newspaper, which he is buying for $250 million.
lead_paragraph: Jeffrey P. Bezos, Amazon’s founder and the prospective new owner of The Washington Post, assured newsroom employees on Wednesday that he was committed to preserving quality journalism, investing in news and making sure The Post adhered to his underlying philosophy about content: “Don’t be boring.”

headline: Red Sox Have Edge in Beanball Wars
abstract: When Ryan Dempster threw at Alex Rodriguez last month, he continued a long-established trend in which Red Sox pitchers plunk Yankee hitters far more than the other way around.
lead_paragraph: Ryan Dempster, a Boston Red Sox starting pitcher, managed to do something last month that few thought possible. By repeatedly throwing at the Yankees’ embattled third baseman, Alex Rodriguez, until he hit him, he left any number of people rushing to Rodriguez’s defense.

lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Mexico took a major step this week toward instituting evaluations of public schoolteachers and ending their practice of buying and inheriting their posts, but analysts said violent protests by teachers had led Congress to include provisions in the new legislation that might undermine the overhaul.

keywords: ['Computer Security', 'Consumer Protection', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Privacy', 'Cameras']

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The so-called Internet of Things — digitally connected devices like appliances, cars and medical equipment — promises to make life easier for consumers. But regulators are worried that some products may be magnets for hackers.

headline: New Generation of Jewish Sect Takes Up Struggle to Protect Place in Modern Israel
abstract: Karaite Jews, who split from rabbinical Judaism more than 1,000 years ago, say that the Orthodox authorities have tried to subsume them into the rabbinical mainstream.
lead_paragraph: RAMLA, Israel — The men and boys offered their prayers in a full-throated chant, raising their arms in supplication and prostrating themselves, barefoot, on the plush red carpet lining the synagogue floor. Many of the women did the same in a balcony above. Outside in the yard, Shuki Cohen, the local butcher, was barbecuing mounds of chicken skewers and aromatic lamb kebabs for a communal feast at long tables laid out in the adjacent hall.

keywords: ['Roads and Traffic', 'Taxicabs and Taxicab Drivers', 'Bicycles and Bicycling']

headline: The Era of Disbelief
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: This time, Americans are questioning everything — as they should.
lead_paragraph: This is a particularly bad time to sell the American people a war, and make no mistake: we are being sold, and this “military action,” in another time and place — and in some quarters, here and now — would be called an act of war.

headline: Employees at Brooklyn School Are Accused of Sexual Attacks
abstract: A report said that an assistant principal at a high school in Williamsburg raped a former student in 2009, and a worker there forced a student to perform oral sex on him in 2011.
lead_paragraph: An assistant principal at a Brooklyn high school raped a 17-year-old former student in his office in 2009, after threatening to report her to immigration authorities, according to a report released on Wednesday by the office that investigates misconduct in New York City schools.

abstract: The Internet services company once known for advertising replete with scantily clad women and double entendre is rethinking its approach.
lead_paragraph: A MARKETER whose sexy advertising polarized consumers for years is trying to distance itself even more from its previous provocative approach, as executives seek to strike a balance between being noticed and being castigated.

abstract: As the United States team arrived in Costa Rica for a game Friday, resentment was evident over a match in the snow in Colorado last March that prompted a protest.

abstract: The Democratic candidates for New York City comptroller sparred on Wednesday, hours before a new poll was released suggesting they are in a dead heat.
lead_paragraph: Eliot Spitzer and Scott M. Stringer sneered, scoffed and all but snarled at each other on Wednesday during a final, testy encounter before the primary election in the race for New York City comptroller.

headline: Weiner vs. Heckler at a Brooklyn Bakery
abstract: A man hurls insults at Anthony D. Weiner, a Democratic candidate for mayor, and a shouting match ensues.
lead_paragraph: Just when Anthony D. Weiner seemed to be fading from public view — his poll numbers sagging, his entourage of supporters dwindling — he walked into a bakery in Brooklyn.

headline: Barred From Debate, McDonald Asks Why Catsimatidis Isn’t
abstract: George T. McDonald says the fund-raising rule that excludes him from the televised event should also apply to another candidate: John A. Catsimatidis, the billionaire owner of Gristedes.
lead_paragraph: George T. McDonald, stinging over his exclusion from the final Republican mayoral debate because of his lackluster fund-raising, wants to know why the city’s Campaign Finance Board is not rejecting another candidate: John A. Catsimatidis, the billionaire owner of Gristedes.

headline: Efforts to Eliminate Tick-Borne Diseases
abstract: Those involved in Lyme disease research and treatment address funding issues.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Yankees Sweat Out a Sweep, With Tougher Opponents Up Next
abstract: With his best outing in nearly three months, C. C. Sabathia helped the Yankees head into a treacherous slate of games with a win over the White Sox, whose rally fell short.
lead_paragraph: A series against the Chicago White Sox, sandwiched between games against playoff contenders, was to serve as a bit of a breather for the Yankees. The White Sox, with nothing to play for but a better draft pick, cannot hit, pitch or field very well these days, so an unexpected stumble by the Yankees in these three games could have proved catastrophic at a time when every game matters.

headline: 330,000 Viewers Tuned Into Primary Debate
abstract: The ratings for Tuesday’s televised Democratic skirmish fell short of an earlier forum hosted by WABC-TV on Aug. 13, which had an audience of 449,000.
lead_paragraph: Bill de Blasio endured 90 minutes’ worth of attacks in Tuesday evening’s Democratic mayoral debate, as his opponents called him a hypocrite, a naif, a flip-flopper and worse.

headline: German President Attends World War II Ceremony in France
keywords: ['World War II (1939-45)', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: President Joachim Gauck and President François Hollande of France joined hands on Wednesday in a ceremony commemorating the massacre of Oradour-sur-Glane, in central France, by Nazis.
lead_paragraph: For the first time since World War II, a German leader joined French officials in commemorating the worst atrocity committed by the Nazis in France. President Joachim Gauck of Germany and his French counterpart, François Hollande, joined hands on Wednesday in a quiet ceremony commemorating the massacre of Oradour-sur-Glane, in central France, where Nazi troops killed 642 villagers in 1944. The presidents were joined by Robert Hébras, one of the two remaining survivors of the attack, as they stood silently before the ruins of a church where women and children were locked in before a toxic gas was released and the building was set on fire. The men later walked through Oradour-sur-Glane, which was preserved by the state after the war and turned into a memorial.

headline: Liu Unveils Secret Weapon: His Smiling Wife
abstract: At a senior center in Lower Manhattan on Wednesday, the Democratic mayoral candidate John C. Liu’s wife, Jenny Liu, made her campaign debut.
lead_paragraph: On a two-step-high stage beneath crimson-and-gold Chinese lanterns, next to an American flag, Jenny Liu on Wednesday made her campaign debut, urging a crowd gathered in a senior center in Lower Manhattan to vote for her husband, John C. Liu, in the Democratic mayoral primary next week.

headline: The Ad Campaign: Quinn Takes Aim at de Blasio
abstract: With six days to catch an ascendant rival, Christine C. Quinn has released her first negative ad of the Democratic mayoral primary campaign, “Closer Look.”
lead_paragraph: With six days to catch an ascendant rival, Christine C. Quinn has released her first negative ad of the Democratic mayoral primary campaign. “Closer Look,” a direct attack on Bill de Blasio, suggests he is a hypocrite for accepting campaign contributions from landlords he had criticized, and seeks to undermine the perception that Mr. de Blasio is tougher than his opponents on New York City’s stop-and-frisk policing tactic.

headline: Population Fallout
abstract: More than 82,000 people were evacuated from areas affected by the meltdown of the Fukushima nuclear plant. The figures on the map show the number of evacuees for the affected municipalities.
lead_paragraph: More than 82,000 people were evacuated from areas affected by the meltdown of the Fukushima nuclear plant. The figures on the map show the number of evacuees for the affected municipalities.

headline: Couples Opts for Youth in the Presidents Cup
abstract: The selection of Jordan Spieth, 20, came at the expense of Jim Furyk, 43, who has been on every team at the biennial event since 1997.
lead_paragraph: Golf’s summer of youth rolls on. First, there was Charley Hull, the irrepressible 17-year-old who parlayed a captain’s pick into a star turn for the Europeans at the Solheim Cup. Next up is Jordan Spieth, who, in a mild upset, was named Wednesday to the 12-man United States team for the Presidents Cup.

headline: Sprinter in 1988 Olympic Scandal Deplores Doping
abstract: Ben Johnson wants to present himself as a cautionary tale, a living lesson about the perils of doping, and a truth-teller in a world where he said cover-ups were as common as cleats.
lead_paragraph: It has been nearly 25 years since the “dirtiest race in history,” the Canadian sprinter Ben Johnson’s gold-medal-winning, and steroid-infused, 100-meter dash at the Seoul Olympics.

headline: British Soldiers Charged in Assault of Off-Duty Police Officer
abstract: Six British soldiers got into a fight outside a bar on the East Side, the police said. They face the prospect of short jail terms and possibly discharge from the army, officials said.
lead_paragraph: The six British soldiers have served in the world’s most intractable conflicts, all but one having been deployed to Iraq or Afghanistan. But they now find themselves in a very different kind of quagmire.

headline: Nets’ Coach Is Set to Be an Owner, Too
abstract: Jason Kidd is in the process of purchasing a tiny share of the franchise from the rapper Jay Z, according to two people with knowledge of the transaction.
lead_paragraph: As a rookie coach with a championship-caliber roster, Jason Kidd already had a lot riding on his maiden season on the Nets’ bench. His stake in their success is about to get a little bigger.

headline: Governor Chafee of Rhode Island Won’t Run Again
abstract: Gov. Lincoln Chafee’s surprise announcement narrows the Democratic primary field to two candidates who had already surpassed him in the polls and outraised him financially.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Gov. Lincoln Chafee of Rhode Island, an independent who recently became a Democrat in a bid to hold on to his seat, abruptly announced Wednesday that he would not seek re-election next year.

headline: Arizona: Aid Denial Appealed
abstract: Gov. Jan Brewer appealed the federal government’s decision to deny a major disaster declaration for the village of Yarnell, damaged in a wildfire that also killed 19 firefighters in June.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Jan Brewer on Wednesday appealed the federal government’s decision to deny a major disaster declaration for the village of Yarnell, heavily damaged in a wildfire that also killed 19 firefighters in June. Ms. Brewer, in a letter to President Obama, listed the financial burden of repairing the water system and rebuilding the more than 100 structures in a community where 56 percent of the residents earn less than $25,000 a year and 36 percent are elderly. Most of the homes lost in the fire were uninsured or underinsured, she said. The Federal Emergency Management Agency denied the disaster declaration on Aug. 9, saying repairs were not “beyond the capabilities” of state and local agencies.

headline: California: Court Rules Against Oyster Company
abstract: A three-judge federal appeals court panel ruled that the federal government can refuse to renew the lease of Drake’s Bay Oyster Company.
lead_paragraph: The operators of the Drake’s Bay Oyster Company are looking for a way forward after a three-judge federal appeals court panel ruled 2 to 1 on Tuesday that the federal government can refuse to renew the lease of the oyster farm, which has operated for decades within the boundaries of Point Reyes National Seashore. Kevin Lunny, who owns Drake’s Bay, said it would have to close in coming weeks if it cannot find a way to overturn the decision, perhaps by asking the entire Ninth Circuit Court to rule. “We are encouraged by it having been a split decision,” Mr. Lunny said.

headline: Nebraska: Deaf Student Wins
abstract: Creighton University violated the Americans with Disabilities Act and the Rehabilitation Act when it failed to provide accommodations requested by a deaf medical student.
lead_paragraph: Creighton University violated the Americans with Disabilities Act and the Rehabilitation Act when it failed to provide accommodations requested by a deaf medical student, a federal district court jury in Omaha ruled Wednesday. Although the jury decided that Creighton did not intentionally discriminate against the student, Michael Argenyi, it said making the accommodations would not have caused an undue burden. Mr. Argenyi, 26, took a leave because officials would not allow him to use an interpreter during clinical training. The judge will decide whether Creighton must accommodate him in his final two years and reimburse him for the aides he paid.

Menino of Boston did not intend to cause offense when he recently told The New York Times that if he were in Detroit, he’d “blow up the place and start all over,” a spokeswoman said Wednesday. Detroit’s mayor, Dave Bing, invited Mr. Menino to come see the city for himself. “He would love to go to Detroit,” said Dot Joyce, the spokeswoman for Mr. Menino, who is known by some here as “the urban mechanic.” Ms. Joyce added, “I think the Motor City needs a mechanic.”

headline: What’s on Thursday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (FX Movie Channel) HEREAFTER (2010) Clint Eastwood imagines what happens after people die by braiding together three story lines, each involving a collision between the living and the dead. In San Francisco, George Lonegan (Matt Damon, above), who receives messages from the deceased loved ones of anyone he touches, chooses a life of obscurity instead of exploiting his gift. In London, Marcus, a solemn boy, feels the presence of his twin, Jason, whose violent death has left Marcus adrift. (The brothers are played by George and Frankie McLaren.) And in Paris, Marie Lelay (Cécile de France), who nearly died in the 2004 tsunami in South Asia, is convinced that she has seen a metaphysical reality the world is determined to ignore. “Persuasion is not really the point, though if anyone could make me believe in ghosts, it would be Clint Eastwood,” A. O. Scott said in The New York Times of this film, written by Peter Morgan. “What does seem new — newly strange, newly beautiful — is what ‘Hereafter’ makes of the here and now,” Mr. Scott added. “It is a curious movie in both senses of the word: an unusual experience and an open-ended inquiry into something nobody can really claim to understand. It leaves you wondering, which may be the most fitting way of saying that it’s wonderful.”

headline: The Steely, Headless King of Texas Hold ’Em
abstract: How a poker-playing machine taught itself to be all but unbeatable.
lead_paragraph: Stroll among the games at the Cosmopolitan, the newest casino on the Las Vegas Strip, and you might be overwhelmed by the latest whooping and flashing gambling machines. All the high-resolution monitors and video effects, devoted to themes ranging from deep-sea-fishing expeditions to Spider-Man to the unsubtlest visions of cash washing over lucky winners, are only the most obvious signs of technology’s move onto the casino floor. Behind the scenes, server-based gaming now enables managers to rapidly alter payouts, raise or reduce betting minimums, even change games themselves. (In just minutes, a bank of slot machines styled for dance clubbers can be rethemed to appeal to church ladies on a Sunday afternoon.) But a few deceptively prim-looking machines represent an even greater technological leap, the biggest advance in automated gambling since Charles Fey introduced the one-armed bandit in 1895. They owe the way they play to artificial intelligence.

headline: A Catalog for All the World’s Viruses?
keywords: ['MERS (Middle East Respiratory Syndrome)', 'Viruses', 'Nipah Virus', 'Science and Technology', 'Research']
abstract: A new study suggests that a catalog of 85 percent of all mammal viruses on earth could be made for $1.4 billion and be used to help fight future viral epidemics.
lead_paragraph: Viruses have a knack for ambush. Time and again, they have struck our species without warning, producing new diseases. H.I.V. burst on the scene in the early 1980s, and it took years for scientists to figure out that it had evolved from a chimpanzee virus in the early 1900s. In 2003, a previously unknown bat virus in China began to cause SARS in humans. Today we are in the midst of yet another ambush, as a new virus called MERS is infecting people, mostly in in Saudi Arabia. Scientists have yet to definitively pin down its origin, although preliminary evidence points to another species of bat.

headline: Last Laugh? He Doesn’t Need It Yet
abstract: For Billy Crystal, 65, the comic actor, director and perennial Academy Awards show host, the relationship with age is delicate.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — BILLY CRYSTAL has a side to him that few get to see. When he isn’t being genial or eager to please, he can go to a place that his friend Robin Williams calls “the other side.” There, he is free to be funny in a crankier, more caustic way, and he becomes — in Mr. Williams’s words — “an angry old Jew.”

headline: Robert Rauschenberg and the ‘New Realists’ in New York
abstract: An exhibition at the Sperone Westwater gallery features work from Robert Rauschenberg, Jean Tinguely, and a group of other New York artists who in the 1960s believed in closing the gap between art and life.
lead_paragraph: To the restlessly inventive Robert Rauschenberg, an art material could be anything in sight. A stuffed goat, a torn shirt or tie, a wheelbarrow and even his own bed — all became fodder for paintings or sculptures, which would later incorporate sound and electronics as well. Rauschenberg had a counterpart in the Swiss-born Jean Tinguely, who had his debut at the Museum of Modern Art after arriving in New York in January 1960. The show consisted of a gigantic motorized sculpture assembled from bicycle wheels, a piano, a bathtub and other detritus, which was designed to self-destruct in flames before a live audience. Rauschenberg made an ad hoc contribution to the piece with a toaster that spit out silver dollars. That “collaboration” spurred a lifelong friendship that would embrace other bricoleurs of the French “New Realist” group then living in New York: Arman, Martial Raysse and Tinguely’s future wife, Niki de Saint Phalle — all artists who subscribed to Rauschenberg’s belief in closing the gap between art and life. This month, the Sperone Westwater gallery brings the group together again with “Radio Waves: New York ‘Nouveau Réalisme’ and Rauschenberg,” an exhibition of 13 rarely seen scrap assemblages and drawings from the artist’s personal collection (Sept. 17 to Nov. 2).

lead_paragraph: Standing on Old Army Pass, a trail in the Sierra Nevada in California, my brother Sean looked back at me and said we would have to scramble over boulders. “With exposure?” I asked, referring to the steepness of the rock face — and how far down it was to the bottom.

headline: In a Costa Rican Beach Town, the Road Less Paved
abstract: The debate over paving a road in Santa Teresa speaks to larger tensions between development, preservation and health.
lead_paragraph: Sitting on a patch of white sand on a nearly deserted beach, steps away from a dense jungle, we were mesmerized by the thundering waves and transfixed by a family of howler monkeys, leaping from tree to tree. My 3-year-old son, James, ambled by and threatened to drop a pair of heavy coconuts right on our heads. But I was lost in a reverie, listening to the surprisingly deep, guttural calls of the monkeys.

headline: Uncovering Charms in Montenegro’s Capital
abstract: Few visitors spend much time in pocket-size Podgorica. Here’s a taste of what they’re missing.
lead_paragraph: For more than a decade after the breakup of Yugoslavia, Montenegro — the smallest of the country’s six republics — seemed to hold no place in the traveler’s mind beyond that of Serbia’s little sidekick. Now independent since 2006, the Adriatic nation sandwiched between Croatia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, and Albania is quickly enticing Western travelers with a promising mix of history, beauty and culture. And for many English-speakers the country remains a largely unknown gem — a Croatia before Croatia was cool.

headline: On Assad’s Social Media Accounts, an Effort to Project Calm

keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Muslims and Islam']

There is a sickly grin on his face. He raises four fingers — a symbol of solidarity with Islamist protesters killed in Rabaa al-Adawiya Square (rabaa means four). A soldier swats down his hand.

lead_paragraph: While opponents of President Obama’s plan to strike Syria invoke the cautionary tale of Iraq — where an American-led invasion was justified by intelligence claims about a Baathist leader’s chemical weapons stockpile that turned out to be flat wrong — some supporters of military intervention argue that there might be more to learn from another United States-led bombing campaign, the one that helped to end the brutal sectarian civil war in Bosnia in 1995.

lead_paragraph: When Zack Wheeler takes the mound against Scott Kazmir on Friday night in Cleveland, the Mets’ hopes for the future will collide with one of the more embarrassing moments of their past.

headline: How Amanda Lindhout Emerged on the Other Side of a Nightmare
abstract: In her years since being released from captivity, Amanda Lindhout has returned to Somalia and started projects to improve lives there.
lead_paragraph: Every morning before Amanda Lindhout gets out of bed, she goes through the ritual — a thought experiment of sorts — of forgiving the people who have hurt her, and also forgiving herself. It’s a strategy she developed after being kidnapped when she was on the way as a journalist to visit an internally displaced persons (I.D.P.) camp in Somalia; held captive in that country for 460 days, she was subjected to torture, starvation and repeated sexual abuse. Lindhout decided that when others harmed her, it was “an indication of their own suffering” — without this way of thinking, she says, she would have been so filled with fury and hopelessness that she never would have survived.

headline: Months After Storm, Mennonites Stay and Rebuild
abstract: A volunteer crew of Mennonites arrived in New York within days of Hurricane Sandy’s landfall, and with some 80 projects in various stages of rehabilitation, they have now set up house in temporary quarters.
lead_paragraph: Within days of Hurricane Sandy’s arrival in New York, Frank Hoover started coordinating vans full of Mennonites to repair homes ravaged by the storm. His impromptu crews finished their farm chores in Pennsylvania Dutch country in the middle of the night and left for Staten Island or Far Rockaway, Queens, by 3 a.m. They worked 8 or 10 hours, then drove back to Lancaster County.

headline: Elegantly Functional Furniture From Hermès
abstract: Hermès teamed up with the French designer Philippe Nigro to create a new collection that features an element of the subtle whimsy for which the brand has long been known.
lead_paragraph: For its latest collection of furniture, Hermès has teamed with the up-and-coming French designer Philippe Nigro. Les Nécessaires d’Hermès consists of eight versatile pieces, rendered in Canaletto walnut and leather, and incorporates the elegance and whimsy — what Nigro calls “the refined humor” — for which the French luxury brand is known. For instance, the delicate Table à Cachette has a hidden tray that pivots out from under its top, while the Cheval-d’Arcons bench, which is based on the form of a pommel horse, has concealed drawers at each end as well as at its center. “The point was to design really functional objects,” Nigro said, “but the function shouldn’t be so obvious.”
