keywords: ['Nine-One-One (911) (Emergency Phone Number)', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Emergency Medical Treatment']
abstract: Unions for emergency workers say a $2 billion overhaul of the computer network is at fault for recent problems, but the Bloomberg administration says the issues are mostly unrelated to the upgrades.
lead_paragraph: Struck by an out-of-control driver fleeing the police, a 4-year-old girl lay dying on an Upper West Side sidewalk in early June. Officers immediately radioed for an ambulance, and one arrived about eight minutes later — an eternity to those waiting on the street. The girl, Ariel Russo, was declared dead at the hospital less than an hour later.

headline: An Unusually Crowded Summer Box Office, in Charts
abstract: It’s not your imagination: there really were more would-be blockbusters than usual this summer. A look at historical trends in summertime releases, and the effect of “Jaws.”
lead_paragraph: Hollywood’s summer season officially ended last weekend, and overall box-office revenues were up even after adjusting for inflation. Yet there were also a lot of high-profile flops and disappointments (“Lone Ranger,” “Turbo,” “R.I.P.D.,” “White House Down,” and so on). What gives?

headline: Scene Partners Step Into the Void
abstract: Ian McKellen and Patrick Stewart will team up in “No Man’s Land” and “Waiting for Godot” on Broadway this season.
lead_paragraph: The insinuating manservant would have you know that these are classier digs than you’re used to. “You’re in the home of a man of means, a man of achievement,” says the thuggish character called Foster (at least sometimes) in Harold Pinter’s “No Man’s Land,” which is being revived on Broadway this fall in a production at the Cort Theater starring Ian McKellen and Patrick Stewart.

headline: Lasting Lessons of a Rosh Hashana Amid a Naval Buildup
keywords: ['Chaplains', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Rosh Hashana']
abstract: As tensions flared in the Middle East, the mission was to perform a symbolic ritual in Kuwait on the first day of the Jewish year.
lead_paragraph: “U.S. Adds Forces in Persian Gulf, a Signal to Iran.” I surveyed this headline on the New York Times’ Web site in July 2012 with concern. News like this had always felt comfortably remote during my childhood on the Upper East Side and my undergraduate years at Yale, and I had assumed that would continue when I began my studies at Hebrew Union College to join the Jewish clergy.

headline: When Med Students Get Medical Students’ Disease
abstract: Some medical students notice something innocuous about their health and then attach to it exaggerated significance, often related to disease they’ve recently learned about. But are med students more likely to be anxious hypochondriacs than others?
lead_paragraph: Each year hundreds of medical students think they have contracted the exact diseases they are studying. But they haven’t.

headline: Big Fish, Big Budget
abstract: Susan Stroman, the director of the new Broadway musical "Big Fish," puts pressure on herself to rein in costs - and keep investors happy - while being imaginative with her staging.
lead_paragraph: Susan Stroman, the director of the new Broadway musical "Big Fish," puts pressure on herself to rein in costs - and keep investors happy - while being imaginative with her staging.

headline: Bold Experiments in Stage Chemistry
abstract: On Broadway and off this fall, some shows feature unlikely pairings onstage. Some matchups are natural, some decidedly not.
lead_paragraph: Great performers have always been one of the signal attractions of the theater, and in our star-besotted era they are undoubtedly the biggest draw. But nobody wants to watch even an able actor perform in a void. Pick up a stage memoir from almost any era, and the writer will likely opine that he or she did the best work when acting with equals, or with actors whose particular personas created an instant, indefinable spark when they were onstage together.

headline: School’s In
abstract: Readers respond to a recent review of Amanda Ripley’s “Smartest Kids in the World.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

abstract: A reader responds to a recent interview with Edwidge Danticat.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

abstract: A reader responds to a recent review of James Purdy’s “Complete Short Stories.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Gun Report: September 5, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: According to the Centers for Disease Control, 31,672 people were killed by firearms in America in 2010. Slate’s gun-death tally, which we include at the end of each post, has recorded 7,897 deaths since the Newtown massacre last December—almost three times the total killed on Sept. 11, and nearly double the number of U.S. soldiers killed over the course of the nine-year-long Iraq War.

headline: Decorating With Mirrors
abstract: A mirror is a great way to expand space, add light and enhance the overall visual interest of the room, says designer Ashley Whittaker.
lead_paragraph: A mirror is a great way to expand space, add light and enhance the overall visual interest of the room, says designer Ashley Whittaker.

headline: Teenagers in The Times | August 2013
abstract: The latest monthly collection of stories about young people published in The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: In this monthly feature we collect everything published in The Times about young people so you can find it in one handy spot.

headline: Her Job Now Includes Reeling in Money
abstract: For the new Broadway musical “Big Fish,” Susan Stroman isn’t just the director and choreographer. She is also a rainmaker.
lead_paragraph: For the new Broadway musical “Big Fish,” Susan Stroman isn’t just the director and choreographer. She is also a rainmaker, leveraging her reputation as a five-time Tony Award winner for hits like “The Producers” and “Contact” to persuade investors to finance the $14 million show. She has talked up scores of potential backers at a dozen cocktail parties, dinners and receptions over the last two years, as well as at workshops and rehearsals. While she fields any and all questions, including oddball ones like her choice of lipstick for one actress, her primary role is to reassure.

headline: Volvo to Recall Nearly 7,800 New Vehicles for Electrical Problems
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Automobiles', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: Volvo announced a recall for electrical problems that could make the wipers run continuously, as well as affecting the functionality of turn signals, headlamps and cruise control.
lead_paragraph: Volvo will recall almost 7,800 of its 2014 models because a computer problem could cause electronic malfunctions, including a problem similar to what many will remember from Detroit’s malaise era where the windshield wipers operate continuously when the ignition is on, according to a report from Volvo posted Thursday on the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration Web site.

headline: Lasting Tributes Meet Early End in Bankruptcy
abstract: A Roman Catholic diocese’s modernization efforts for the Crystal Cathedral in Orange County, Calif., include digging up inscribed granite stones purchased by churchgoers.
lead_paragraph: GARDEN GROVE, Calif. — The inscribed granite stones that form the Walk of Faith outside the Crystal Cathedral here were supposed to last forever, sustained in perpetuity by the thousands of dollars churchgoers paid for them. Or so parishioners were told.

headline: Veterans’ Benefits for Same-Sex Spouses
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Veterans']
abstract: Benefits will no longer be restricted to spouses “of the opposite sex.”
lead_paragraph: The Obama Administration announced on Wednesday that the Department of Veterans Affairs would immediately begin providing benefits to gay or lesbian spouses — a welcome move, and one that followed similar decisions by the Pentagon and other federal agencies in the wake of the Supreme Court’s Defense of Marriage Act ruling.

headline: ‘Schools’
abstract: A new ad from William C. Thompson Jr. features the candidate's daughter, Jennifer.
lead_paragraph: A new ad from William C. Thompson Jr. features the candidate's daughter, Jennifer.

headline: Americans Go to Great Lengths to Mask Web Travels, Survey Finds
abstract: Ordinary Americans seem to be going to great lengths to keep some of their online behavior to themselves, challenging the “if you’ve got nothing to hide” meme.
lead_paragraph: Most Americans say they believe the law is inadequate in protecting their privacy online. The e-mail or social media accounts of one in five have been broken into. And most American consumers take great efforts to mask their identities online.

headline: Brazilian Regulators Open a New Inquiry Into Batista
abstract: Brazil’s securities and exchange commission says it has opened a new formal investigation into the business dealings of the onetime billionaire Eike Batista and five other executives of the petroleum company OGX.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil – Brazil’s securities and exchange commission said on Thursday that it had opened a new formal investigation into the business dealings of the onetime billionaire Eike Batista.

headline: A World Cup Qualifier Is a Hostage to History
abstract: Hungary will play at Romania on Friday in a critical 2014 World Cup qualifier for both teams against a politically charged backdrop and amid rising tensions between the nations.
lead_paragraph: BUDAPEST — There are many ghosts that walk the streets of Hungary’s capital, but none is more alive than that of Ferenc Puskas.

headline: A Dim Sum Outpost Far From Chinatown
abstract: A restaurant in a former bank is a combination of urban and rural experiences.
lead_paragraph: Dim sum is undergoing a resurgence in New York, but there are not many places to get a good version of the bite-size treats in Westchester — Aberdeen in White Plains is the only restaurant that comes to mind. Now, aficionados who acquired a taste for the food in, say, Lower Manhattan can satisfy their craving at the end of a pleasant drive north of the county line. Dim Sum Go Go, an outpost of the Chinatown restaurant of the same name, opened in Beacon in April. The Dutchess County spot offers about 40 fried, steamed or baked dim sum for both lunch and dinner. In addition to being rare for the area, much of the fare is delicious — from fried shrimp balls and spring rolls with plum sauce to nearly translucent rice roll crepes, filled with, for example, simple steamed shrimp or roast duck and served with intense homemade condiments like spicy mustard and dumpling sauce.

headline: How to Recall What I Already Knew
abstract: The director Terence Nance’s original video for the New York Times.
lead_paragraph: The director Terence Nance’s original video for the New York Times.

headline: A Culinary Landmark, Back on the Map
abstract: The Ryland Inn, which reopened in a former stagecoach stop in October after having been closed for five years, is back with memorable food and impeccable service.
lead_paragraph: I fell in love with the reopened Ryland Inn because of how we were greeted. It was a miserable, rainy night, and we were a half-hour late for our 6:30 reservation. As if she had nothing better to do than wait for us all day, a woman wearing a simple dress and cardigan approached our car, umbrella in hand, and escorted my companion and me out of the rain and into the restaurant.

headline: Latest Airport Amenity? Old-Fashioned Rocking Chairs
abstract: Four airports in Finland recently introduced rocking chairs for passengers awaiting flights.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 5:33 p.m. | High tech is the mantra at many airports, but some airports are taking a more retro approach to improve the travel experience: Old-fashioned rocking chairs were recently introduced at four airports in Finland.

headline: Amgen Investors Gain From Having an Ex-Investment Banker as C.E.O.
abstract: Amgen’s deal to buy Onyx Pharmaceuticals shows the value of having a tough negotiator at the helm, the author writes.
lead_paragraph: An investment banker as chief executive may have some merits – at least Amgen shareholders should think so.

headline: Aftermath of Egyptian Bomb Attack
abstract: Video shows the scene after an attack whose target was the convoy of Mohamed Ibrahim, the Egyptian interior minister, on Thursday in Cairo.
lead_paragraph: Video shows the scene after an attack whose target was the convoy of Mohamed Ibrahim, the Egyptian interior minister, on Thursday in Cairo.

headline: An App That Sorts Your E-Mail Shopping Offers
abstract: What’s PeeqPeeq? A good start for sorting the promotional offers you receive on e-mail from the stuff that’s plain-old junk mail.
lead_paragraph: Everybody loves to hate e-mail. It eats up too much time, it’s used improperly, it’s filled up with junk. Entire careers have been launched around the premise of getting your in-box to zero.

headline: Heating Up American Cuisine
abstract: The menu at 500° on Main Street manifests the fusion of culinary cultures that has come to be called American cuisine, and has been assembled with a light touch that elsewhere is often missing.
lead_paragraph: At the confluence of the Housatonic and Naugatuck rivers, the city of Derby is better known for its manufacturing history, fueled by river power, than for its dining. So 500° on Main Street, which opened in October on the site formerly occupied by Chianti’s of Derby, is a nice surprise.

headline: New Hendrix Documentary to Be Released in November
abstract: The documentary, “Jimi Hendrix: Hear My Train a Comin’,” which will be shown as part of PBS’s “American Masters” series, will conclude a yearlong commemoration of the 70th anniversary of the guitarist’s birth.
lead_paragraph: A new two-hour documentary DVD about Jimi Hendrix and a compact disc with a previously unreleased concert 1968 recording by the Jimi Hendrix Experience will be released on Nov. 5, as the concluding installments of a yearlong commemoration of the 70th anniversary of the guitarist’s birth.

headline: Rachel Comey’s Intimate Dinner to Kick Off Fashion Week
abstract: The guests, who included fashion world insiders and boldfaced names like Maggie Gyllenhaal and Cindy Sherman, gathered for cocktails, delicious food, warm conversation and a graceful new collection.
lead_paragraph: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Homey Italian in a Strip Mall, Prix Fixe
abstract: At Tate’s, the chef makes his own breads and pastas, and his osso bucco with pork.
lead_paragraph: Motorists on Smithtown Boulevard in Nesconset may whiz past Tate’s Restaurant, thinking this modest spot in a strip mall is ordinary. That would be their mistake; Tate’s has a talented chef who makes his own bread, fresh pastas and desserts.

headline: Malbec, Doing Fine on Its Own
abstract: Although only a few Long Island vintners make malbec, samples of current releases suggest that it could become the third most successful red wine in the region.
lead_paragraph: Although only a few Long Island vintners make malbec, samples of current releases suggest that it could become the third most successful red wine in the region, after merlot and cabernet franc. Malbec’s appeal lies not only in its drinkability but also in how it teams with grilled steaks and barbecue.

abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: The New Season in Theater
abstract: A look at shows coming to New York and elsewhere this fall.
lead_paragraph: A look at shows coming to New York and elsewhere this fall.

headline: New York Theater Ballet Is Seeking New Home After Building Is Sold
abstract: The company, which stages classic works and new choreography and also runs a ballet school, has until Sept. 30 to vacate its home of three decades.
lead_paragraph: The New York Theater Ballet, a small company with an outsize reputation for staging classics and the work of emerging choreographers, is desperately seeking a new home, says Diana Byer, the founder and artistic director. The company has until Sept. 30 to vacate its studio and office space in Murray Hill because the building has been sold. Since 1980 the company has been at 30 East 31st Street, on the fifth floor of the parish house of the Madison Avenue Baptist Church.

headline: The Short Life of a Rock Star in Offbeat Glasses
abstract: The jukebox musical about Buddy Holly’s career is presented in Bellport, N.Y., by a cast that includes actors doubling as the show’s band.
lead_paragraph: The actors in “Buddy: The Buddy Holly Story” at the Gateway Playhouse in Bellport are fine musicians — no one has to pretend to play an instrument, and most of them double as the show’s band. Those who impersonate recognizable people — like Holly and other stars of the era — bear a reasonable resemblance to them, even if a few look too old for their roles. But good acting? That isn’t required of anyone in this production, which is directed and choreographed by D. J. Salisbury in a cartoonish style that heightens the heavy-handed exposition in the musical’s book, written by Alan Janes.

headline: Fall Theater Preview: Oh, Romeo, Romeo, What a Season Ahead
abstract: An expanded list of new shows coming to New York and elsewhere this fall.
lead_paragraph: All dates are subject to change.

headline: Rise Is Seen in Students Who Use E-Cigarettes
abstract: The increased popularity of e-cigarettes among middle and high school students is prompting concerns that the devices could be creating new health problems.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The share of middle and high school students who use e-cigarettes doubled in 2012 from the previous year, federal data show. The rise is prompting concerns among health officials that the new devices could be creating as many health problems as they are solving.

headline: Iraqis, Looking Across Border, See Replays of Past and Fears for the Future
keywords: ['Shiite Muslims', 'Sunni Muslims', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: As the debate over military action in Syria has unfolded in the West, Iraqis see the fate of the two countries as inextricably intertwined.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Abu Mohaned spent Tuesday night washing the bodies of victims of that evening’s car bombs, preparing them for burial. When a couple of roadside bombs went off the next day, he did the same thing.

headline: Prints of Gritty Nostalgia
abstract: In “Telling American History: Realism From the Print Collection of Dr. Dorrance T. Kelly,” a collection shows in black ink scenes of social history and everyday life across the 20th century.
lead_paragraph: You can peer up close at the softly diminishing glow. You can back away. You can stare through one of the magnifying glasses provided at the entrance to “Telling American History,” the enthralling new print show at the Bruce Museum in Greenwich, Conn. But you won’t be able to figure out how Stow Wengenroth (1906-1978), the Brooklyn-born master lithographer, managed to bring the diffuse haze of city streetlamps on a damp night to a sheet of inked paper.

headline: 3 Cities in Running for 2020 Olympics Have Shortcomings
abstract: All three candidate cities to host the 2020 Summer Games — Istanbul, Tokyo and Madrid — presented risks ahead of Saturday’s vote.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — The recent trend of the International Olympic Committee and FIFA, the organizer of soccer’s World Cup, has been to award the planet’s two largest sporting events to cities, countries or regions that have never hosted the global competitions.

headline: Fresh Look for the Fall Theater Season
abstract: More than a dozen plays and musicals, either brand-new works or those being seen for the first time in New Jersey, are expected to be among the productions at the state’s theaters.
lead_paragraph: The most celebrated play ever to originate in New Jersey is arguably Thornton Wilder’s “Our Town,” which had a one-night-only shakedown showing at the McCarter Theater in Princeton in 1938, before moving to Boston for tryouts and ultimately to Broadway.

headline: A Banking Bankruptcy That Takes a Different Path
keywords: ['Bankruptcies', 'Emergency Economic Stabilization Act (2008)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis']
abstract: A small bank holding company in Wisconsin plans to use Chapter 11 to recapitalize, not to liquidate as typically happens. The company hopes to use the bankruptcy to save its bank, AnchorBank.
lead_paragraph: When a bank holding company files for bankruptcy, it usually occurs after the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation has taken away its banking subsidiary. In such a Chapter 11 case, the only thing left for the company to do is marshal the assets — including a typically large tax refund — and pay out the results to creditors before liquidating. Washington Mutual provides the most obvious example of this basic model.

headline: Hollywood Goes Global in Toronto Film Festival Offerings
abstract: The growing willingness to cast non-American actors may partly be a business decision, but it also points to the changing character of awards-season cinema.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — Chiwetel Ejiofor, major movie star. Who’d have guessed?

headline: Where Lawmakers Stand on Military Action in Syria
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: A tally of lawmakers’ stances on military action in Syria.
lead_paragraph: A tally of lawmakers’ stances on military action in Syria.

headline: When Health Deductibles Rise, Men Delay Emergency Care
keywords: ['Medicine and Health', 'Men and Boys', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: A recent study found that men are more likely to delay treatment for serious conditions under high-deductible plans, in contrast to women, who tend to cut back care for minor ailments only.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a situation that may sound familiar to you: A man visits his doctor’s office with his wife, who laments how stubborn he is about seeking medical care.

headline: Answers to Questions About New York
abstract: A question about the remnants of a Jenny Holzer public art exhibition in Central Park.
lead_paragraph: Q. As I wandered through the northern reaches of Central Park, I happened upon a broken slab of marble with words etched along the side: “A man can’t know what it’s like to be a mother.”

headline: Poor Infrastructure Hampers India’s Export Chances in Downturn
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Indian Rupee (Currency)', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Typography', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Without an earlier manufacturing boom, India is now bereft of companies that can build the things its builders need.
lead_paragraph: BANGALORE —On the outskirts of Bangalore, Karnataka, in a manufacturing unit for Indo-US MIM Tec Private Limited, dozens of workers in blue uniforms stood behind tall, nearly noiseless machines. The equipment pumped and swerved, quietly fusing bits of metal and polymer. Founded in 1997, the company builds a range of parts for cars, factories and consumer goods using a rare manufacturing technique called metal injection molding. It pioneered the technique in India, and claims to be the world’s largest practitioner.

headline: Memorials and Traces of 9/11
abstract: Books examine the struggle to rebuild the World Trade Center, ephemera from the site and the nooks of Central Park.
lead_paragraph: It took 20 years to complete the Pearl Harbor memorial, so maybe New Yorkers should be grateful that the World Trade Center and its memorial museum are almost finished as we approach the 12th anniversary of Sept. 11.

headline: Richard Chai — Love: Spring 2014 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Sam Harris and Scientism
abstract: Answering the new atheist’s answer to his critics.
lead_paragraph: Since I took a passing swipe at his work in my recent post on Steven Pinker and scientism, it seems worth noting that Sam Harris, the noted “new atheist” polemicist, has issued a public challenge to anyone interested in refuting his recent book on “how science can determine human values,” offering $2,000 to the best rebuttal essay and $20,000 to any writer who can persuade him to recant his central argument outright. That argument he distills as follows:

headline: Opposition Lawmaker Arrested in Treason Plot in South Korea
abstract: The lawmaker, Lee Seok-ki, who is affiliated with the far-left United Progressive Party, became the first South Korean politician arrested on the criminal charge of plotting treason.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — An opposition lawmaker was arrested on Thursday on charges of plotting an armed rebellion to help overthrow the South Korean government in the event of war on the divided Korean Peninsula.

headline: Image of the Day: Sept. 5
abstract: Teachers’ Day was observed across India on Thursday, it marks the anniversary of the birth of second Indian president, Sarvepalli Radhakrishnan.

headline: As Busy as His Bees
abstract: Chase Emmons, 45, a managing partner and the apiary director at Brooklyn Grange, a rooftop farm, inspects beehives, harvests vegetables and goes on a nighttime run.
lead_paragraph: Chase Emmons, 45, is a managing partner and the apiary director at Brooklyn Grange, a rooftop farm with locations in Long Island City and the Brooklyn Navy Yard. He splits his time between his childhood home — a garden duplex apartment in the West Village — and a home in Sunderland, Mass. He commutes to the apiary in a 2005 Volkswagen Golf, which he adapted to run on 90 percent vegetable oil. His Sundays are spent inspecting the 35 beehives in the Brooklyn Navy Yard, helping Ben Flanner, head farmer and president of Brooklyn Grange, harvest vegetables to sell at a farmers’ market, and going on a nighttime run.

headline: A ‘Peculiar’ Peek at Thomas Pynchon’s Latest
abstract: The book trailer for Mr. Pynchon’s new novel, “Bleeding Edge,” has viewers scratching their heads.
lead_paragraph: Bloggers have called it “bizarre,” “highly bizarre,” “peculiar” and “appropriately odd.” It’s the book trailer for Thomas Pynchon’s new novel, “Bleeding Edge,” which will be published on Sept. 17.

headline: Amerisleep Continues to Figure Out How to Sell Mattresses Online
abstract: The owner of Amerisleep talks about discovering that it was cheaper to manufacture mattresses in the United States than in China.
lead_paragraph: In my post last week, we took a look at how AmeriSleep is trying to overcome consumer concerns about to buying big-ticket items, like mattresses, online. Firas Kittenah, the company’s chief executive, is confident he made the right decision when he closed his bricks-and-mortar retail location, but the challenges remain.

headline: All the Rage | Men’s Wear That Channels a Classic French Vagabond
abstract: The deliberately unkempt looks of the season recall quite vividly the style of an obscure French film character.
lead_paragraph: It seems as if Boudu — the irrepressible tramp from Jean Renoir’s 1932 masterpiece, “Boudu Saved From Drowning” — must have made multiple appearances on designers’ mood boards this season, because his dishabille swagger could be seen all over the men’s runways. Dries Van Noten and Junya Watanabe channeled the disheveled drifter with a profusion of oversize tweed jackets, bathrobelike outerwear and patched-up suits. At Yohji Yamamoto, some models even wore fluffed-up Boudu-like beards.

headline: The Latest New York Times/Siena College Poll
abstract: Bill de Blasio has built a broad base of support in the Democratic primary for mayor, the latest New York Times/Siena College poll found.
lead_paragraph: Bill de Blasio has built a broad base of support in the Democratic primary for mayor, the latest New York Times/Siena College poll found.

headline: Tuition Aid From a Zombie Elf
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Scholarships and Fellowships', 'Cards and Card Games', 'Tuition']
abstract: Players of the fantasy trading card game “Magic: The Gathering” are helping their younger counterparts with scholarships.
lead_paragraph: Douglas Johnson began his sophomore year at the State University of New York at Oswego last week in an enviable position. He made the dean’s list his freshman year and expects to graduate early with a double major in psychology and public justice. Even better, his family back in Watertown, N.Y., didn’t have to take out any loans this fall, thanks to a scholarship that covers about half of his tuition.

headline: Gut Bacteria From Thin Humans Can Slim Mice Down
abstract: Mice exposed to gut bacteria of overweight humans become overweight, while those exposed to the microbiomes of thin humans lose weight, a new study found.
lead_paragraph: The trillions of bacteria that live in the gut — helping digest foods, making some vitamins, making amino acids — may help determine if a person is fat or thin.

headline: For Federer and Nadal, Best Debate Is Still Ahead
abstract: If Rafael Nadal can close the gap in Grand Slam titles, his rivalry with Roger Federer will thrive no matter what Federer does from here on.
lead_paragraph: It is safe to assume that Roger Federer would not have had much of a chance against Rafael Nadal had he made it to their anticipated quarterfinal Wednesday night at the United States Open. In other news, as they used to say on “Saturday Night Live,” Generalissimo Francisco Franco is still dead.

headline: Kerouac’s Epic Road Trip Novel Was Cast Into the Limelight 56 Years Ago
abstract: Many Americans have at least heard of “On the Road,” but it took years for Jack Kerouac to find a publisher.
lead_paragraph: When Jack Kerouac’s novel “On the Road” was published by Viking Press in 1957, the Beat Generation writer had spent several years shopping it around to publishing houses. Within the staid culture of the 1950s, Kerouac’s epic tale of free-for-all road tripping across America with socially liberated friends left many publishers doubtful that the book would bring anything other than obscenity charges.

headline: On the ‘Inherent Problem’ of the Public Editor’s Role at The Times
abstract: A reader writes about the potential for conflicts of interest with this job, and the public editor responds.
lead_paragraph: The Roman poet Juvenal posed this pretty good question that has traveled down the centuries: “Sed quis custodiet ipsos custodes?”

headline: Dr. Dog: Still at Home in the B-Room
abstract: The Philadelphia-based group has a new album and big tour dates with the Lumineers, but it still seems to be most comfortable as a basement band.
lead_paragraph: Fresh off the summer-festival circuit and about to begin a big tour with the Lumineers, Dr. Dog stopped by the Mercury Lounge on Tuesday to reconnect with their small-room roots, unleashing a two-hour, scorched-earth campaign of songs old and new, including three from their eighth album, “B-Room,” which will be released Oct. 1. The show was announced only a few days in advance and sold out in minutes.

headline: Glenn Beck’s ‘Man in the Moon’
abstract: A sprawling, vaudevillian production about American history from a birds-eye view.
lead_paragraph: A sprawling, vaudevillian production about American history from a birds-eye view.

headline: 20 to Watch
abstract: Co-chief movie critics Manohla Dargis and A. O. Scott discuss their list of 20 great filmmakers 40 years and younger.
lead_paragraph: Co-chief movie critics Manohla Dargis and A. O. Scott discuss their list of 20 great filmmakers 40 years and younger.

headline: Fashion Week Parties: Warm Up
abstract: Surface to Air, MADE Fashion Week and Galore Magazine get a jump start on the partying.
lead_paragraph: Surface to Air, MADE Fashion Week and Galore Magazine get a jump start on the partying.

headline: Creatures of the Wind: Spring 2014 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: The Ad Campaign: Daughter Helps Present Thompson as the Education Candidate
abstract: Following Bill de Blasio’s effective ad featuring his son, William C. Thompson Jr. has turned to his daughter to carry his appeal to those interested in the school system.
lead_paragraph: William C. Thompson Jr., the mayoral choice of the influential teachers’ union, the United Federation of Teachers, is making education the centerpiece of his campaign in the closing days of the race for the Democratic nomination. On Wednesday, he campaigned in the morning with Michael Mulgrew and Randi Weingarten, the current and previous presidents, respectively, of the union, unveiled a five-point plan to help teachers, and then joined Mr. Mulgrew and Ms. Weingarten for a late-afternoon teleconference town hall meeting. Small wonder, then, that his latest television advertisement, “Schools,” released on Wednesday, also focuses on education.

headline: The Perils When Megabanks Lose Focus
keywords: ['Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Deposit Insurance']
abstract: Bailouts were necessary in 2008 to keep the financial system operating, but it is now more important than ever to distinguish why that was important.
lead_paragraph: Five years ago, as Lehman Brothers teetered, there was remarkably little concern about what would happen if it failed and virtually none about what would happen to the rest of Wall Street if it did.

headline: Overcommitted
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Andrew J. Bacevich examines American militarism and the gulf between citizens and the all-volunteer Army.
lead_paragraph: Thanks to the magic of American national security politics, a number of young men who grew up in Nepal have found their way west, over northern India and across the breadth of Pakistan, to work at Kandahar Airfield in Afghanistan, destroying million-dollar trucks bought by American taxpayers. They wield blowtorches and wear fireproof suits in the crushing heat, and — according to reporting by Ernesto Londoño at The Washington Post — it takes about 12 hours to demolish each of the vehicles. The trucks need to be cut into pieces small enough to be fed into industrial metal shredders, which grind the parts down into tiny bits of scrap that are sold locally for a few cents per pound. In May, about 11 million pounds of this scrap were apparently sold; by now it is probably more. The contractors who buy it call it “gold dust.”

headline: Bomb Scare
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Books and Literature', 'Nuclear Weapons']
abstract: Kenneth M. Pollack assesses Iran’s nuclear ambitions, and the consequences for America.
lead_paragraph: President Obama is drifting toward an unwarranted and ultimately unwinnable war with Iran, according to the well-known Mideast expert Kenneth M. Pollack. With “Unthinkable,” he hopes to persuade the administration to reverse course.

headline: Critical Conditions
abstract: A doctor’s actions in the days after Katrina are called into question.
lead_paragraph: “The juror was convinced — and, she believed, all of her fellow jurors were too — that a crime had occurred on that fifth day at Memorial.” So concludes Sheri Fink’s harrowing and minutely detailed description of the hellish events that took place at a New Orleans hospital during Hurricane Katrina and its aftermath in late August and early September 2005. The members of the special grand jury convened two years after those desperate days were in agreement that the state of Louisiana should not indict Dr. Anna Pou for the murder of four patients during the disaster. Why then, did they nevertheless continue to believe that a “crime had occurred”? The only crime they had been assembled to investigate was homicide, the evidence for and against which they had been studying for weeks. If they thought the 51-year-old surgeon was guilty, why did they let her go free?

headline: Glasserie
abstract: Inside the Greenpoint restaurant at the northernmost tip of the Brooklyn waterfront.
lead_paragraph: Inside the Greenpoint restaurant at the northernmost tip of the Brooklyn waterfront.

headline: A Rabbit That Takes Some Searching
abstract: Glasserie brings Middle Eastern flavors to Greenpoint.
lead_paragraph: “Seventy-two dollars for rabbit at a Superfund site?” my friend said, incredulous, when I invited him to dinner at Glasserie, a new restaurant in Greenpoint at the northernmost tip of Brooklyn, next to oil-spill-besieged Newtown Creek. He declined.

headline: N.S.A. Able to Foil Basic Safeguards of Privacy on Web
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Privacy', 'Computer Security', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: The National Security Agency has secretly circumvented or cracked much of the digital scrambling that protects global commerce, e-mails, phone calls, medical records and Web searches.
lead_paragraph: The National Security Agency is winning its long-running secret war on encryption, using supercomputers, technical trickery, court orders and behind-the-scenes persuasion to undermine the major tools protecting the privacy of everyday communications in the Internet age, according to newly disclosed documents.

headline: Just Beyond the Bar, a Patch of Urban Green
abstract: The bar Louis 649 provides drinks and a view of La Plaza Cultural, which is right across East Ninth Street on the Lower East Side.
lead_paragraph: ONE of the many attributes of the bar Louis 649 is not actually inside Louis 649.

headline: Unlocking Private Communications
abstract: Encryption tools the N.S.A. has had some success in cracking, according to documents provided by Edward J. Snowden describing the agency’s code-breaking capabilities.
lead_paragraph: Encryption tools the N.S.A. has had some success in cracking, according to documents provided by Edward J. Snowden describing the agency’s code-breaking capabilities.

headline: Oral History | Remembering Andy Warhol, the Man With the Camera
abstract: The artist was always obsessed with photography, but he took it increasingly seriously later in life. Here, a pair of Warhol associates and a student of his work recall his approach to portraiture.
lead_paragraph: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Coach Carlos Holds Court
abstract: Deploying a relentless enthusiasm, Carlos Gautier instructs children, and some adults, in a decidedly non-fancy corner of Central Park, teaching tennis where handball rules.
lead_paragraph: “O.K., this is the U.S. Open of Central Park,” Carlos Gautier, 54, yelled to his 6-year-old tennis student. “Come on, it’s pressure time — all the birds are watching.”

headline: With $10 Million Gift, Theater for a New Audience Home Gets a Name
abstract: The Polonsky Shakespeare Center will open this fall with Julie Taymor’s production of “A Midsummer Night’s Dream.”
lead_paragraph: The new home for Theater for a New Audience in Downtown Brooklyn is now officially the Polonsky Shakespeare Center, in honor of a $10 million gift from the Polonsky Foundation, the largest the theater has ever received.

headline: New U.S. Envoy to U.N. Strongly Condemns Russia
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'United States International Relations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The ambassador, Samantha Power, in her first extensive public remarks on Syria, said Russia was holding the Security Council hostage in taking action.
lead_paragraph: Samantha Power, the new United States ambassador to the United Nations, strongly criticized Russia on Thursday in her first extensive public remarks about Syria, accusing the Kremlin of holding the Security Council hostage by blocking even modest efforts to condemn the use of chemical weapons in the Syrian conflict.

headline: The Punishment for Being Publicity-Shy
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Writing and Writers', 'Books and Literature', 'Movies']
abstract: The documentary “Salinger,” about the author of “The Catcher in the Rye,” seeks to tear down the fortress of privacy he erected around his life.
lead_paragraph: “Salinger,” the doorstop-thick new biography by David Shields and Shane Salerno, announces itself on the dust jacket as “the official book of the acclaimed documentary film” of the same title. (The film itself credits Paul Alexander’s biography of Salinger as its source.) “Acclaimed” is perhaps wishful thinking, but the most dubious words in that puffy phrase are “documentary film.” There are plenty of archival images and talking-head interviews, but “Salinger,” directed by Mr. Salerno, is less a work of cinema than the byproduct of its own publicity campaign. It does not so much explore the life and times of J. D. Salinger as run his memory and legacy through a spin cycle of hype. Salinger moved to the woods of New Hampshire partly to escape the intrusions and indignities of American celebrity culture. “Salinger” is that culture’s revenge.

headline: Garden of Earthly Delights
abstract: Herbs aren’t only for cooking.
lead_paragraph: The extent to which teenage girls will torture their mothers knows few limits. For me, part of the program was a Ye Olde Herbalist phase. I often took over the family kitchen to brew hyssop tea and goldenseal tincture and to prepare poultices of sage and compresses of comfrey. I grew my hair very long and learned how to write my name in runes. My favorite bedtime reading was a facsimile edition of the 17th-century English botanist Nicholas Culpeper’s opus, “The Complete Herbal.” I was totally going to Scarborough Fair.

headline: Horton Foote, With More to Say
abstract: The Signature Theater has unearthed a previously unseen Foote play, “The Old Friends.”
lead_paragraph: Horton Foote, the great American playwright who made moving drama and heartfelt comedy from close examination of small-town life, died in 2009. But the Signature Theater, which presented many of Foote’s plays over the years, has unearthed a previously unseen play, “The Old Friends,” and is producing it this fall with a terrific cast, including Foote’s daughter Hallie Foote, Betty Buckley, Veanne Cox, Cotter Smith and Lois Smith.

headline: Triple Play: Make Your Picks for Week 24
abstract: Put your predictive skills to the test each week of the baseball season.
lead_paragraph: The Bats blog again tests our readers’ predictive skills with three questions about the coming week. Feel free to lean on research, tea leaves, your gut instinct or maybe just dumb luck.

headline: At Lincoln Center, the Fashion Won’t Stop
abstract: Imagine the surprise this morning to arrive at Lincoln Center for the Richard Chai show, one of the first big ones to take place on the first official day of Fashion Week, to discover a scene of fashion bedlam.
lead_paragraph: Imagine the surprise this morning to arrive at Lincoln Center for the Richard Chai show, one of the first big ones to take place on the first official day of Fashion Week, to discover a scene of fashion bedlam. Outside in the plaza, there were beautiful women in towering shoes, beautiful women in intentionally mismatched tropical prints, beautiful women with lacquered lips, beautiful women with pale skin and oversize sunglasses and perfectly bleached hair and this season’s Saint Laurent leopard-spotted cardigan. (Thank God, I didn’t buy that.) People took their pictures.

headline: Ford Is Working on a Warning System to Protect Police Officers
abstract: Cameras and sensors are great at detecting traffic hazards, but Ford has put them into service protecting occupants in police cruisers from sneak attacks.
lead_paragraph: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kG60dmGdGzk

headline: The Finish Line Starts Here
abstract: The city’s specialty running shops offer much more than the standard collection of Technicolor sneakers and short shorts available online and at larger competitors.
lead_paragraph: AS an enthusiastic New York-based marathoner, I love to take advantage of the city’s excellent specialty running shops. Often owned by local runners, these stores offer much more than the standard collection of Technicolor sneakers, short shorts and carbohydrate-saturated gels available online and at larger competitors.

headline: Heading to Queens, Just Not for the Tennis
abstract: Forget the Open. The Miser considers other appealing attractions this weekend in Flushing, including mini-golf and the Panorama of the City of New York.
lead_paragraph: This weekend, tennis pilgrims by the thousands will descend upon the Billie Jean King National Tennis Center in Flushing, Queens, for the final matches of the United States Open. Though a tennis fan, the Miser, priced out of even the cheapest seats at Arthur Ashe Stadium, won’t be one of them. But there are still plenty of good reasons to be in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park this weekend.

headline: A New Divestment Focus on Campus: Fossil Fuels
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Endowments', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: Concern over global warming has spurred students to dust off investment choice as a weapon in their campaign. But whether it will be as effective this time is another matter.
lead_paragraph: In the 1980s, it was South Africa. In the 1990s, it was tobacco.

headline: Thai Trader Settles Smithfield Insider Trading Case
abstract: A Bangkok-based trader has agreed to pay $5.2 million to settle charges that he traded on insider information tied to Smithfield Foods’ proposed $4.7 billion sale to a Chinese food processor, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: A Bangkok-based trader has agreed to pay $5.2 million to settle accusations that he traded on insider information tied to Smithfield Foods’ proposed $4.7 billion sale to a Chinese food processor, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced on Thursday.

headline: Book a Room, Help a Student
abstract: Rollins College owns the new Alfond Inn near Orlando, and income from the hotel will help fund a new scholarship and financial aid program.
lead_paragraph: Rare is the Orlando hotel that doesn’t openly appeal to Disney-bound travelers. But the new Alfond Inn in suburban Winter Park, Fla., offers an interesting alternative.

headline: Vintage Thomas Molesworth Furniture Heads to Auction
abstract: This craftsman’s rustic pieces, often made from branches, bring high prices decades later.
lead_paragraph: The newspaper tycoon Moses Annenberg spent months at a time on a ranch in Beulah, Wyo. But he enjoyed it for only a few years in the 1930s before he was sent to prison for tax evasion.

headline: Richard Avedon Portraits Go to Israel Museum
abstract: Portraits by Richard Avedon go to Israel Museum, and a Jeff Koons “Balloon Dog” goes to auction.
lead_paragraph: It was in 1994, at the Whitney Museum of American Art’s Richard Avedon retrospective, that Leonard A. Lauder, the New York philanthropist who was then chairman of the Whitney’s board, remembers falling in love with the photographer’s murals. One was of the poet Allen Ginsberg and his extended family, taken in 1970 when he posed with aunts, uncles, nieces and nephews to celebrate a reading that he and his father, Louis, gave in New Jersey. Another, Mr. Lauder recalled, was of members of the Mission Council, a group of the senior American officials guiding the Vietnam War.

headline: Alec Baldwin to Host TV Interview Show on MSNBC
abstract: The actor’s once-a-week show builds on his recent experience of conducting interviews for his podcast.
lead_paragraph: The long-rumored move of the actor Alec Baldwin to the new position of talk show host was confirmed on Thursday with the announcement that MSNBC had hired Mr. Baldwin for a once-a-week program in prime time.

headline: Creatures of the Wind, for Real People
abstract: “Hail Hyperborea” was the theme of the Creatures of the Wind show at noon, though it was written in such small type on the program that what these eyes saw was “Hail Hyperbole.”
lead_paragraph: “Hail Hyperborea” was the theme of the Creatures of the Wind show at noon, though it was written in such small type on the program that what these eyes saw was “Hail Hyperbole.”

headline: Chilean’s Family Files Suit in U.S. Over His Torture and Death in ’73
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Alien Tort Statute (1789)', "Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat", 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: The family of Víctor Jara, who was killed after a coup, is suing under federal laws allowing legal action against human rights violators living in the United States.
lead_paragraph: SANTIAGO, Chile — A former Chilean Army officer charged with murdering Víctor Jara, a popular folk singer, shortly after the 1973 military coup has been sued in a Florida court under federal laws allowing legal action against human rights violators living in the United States.

headline: Australia’s Premier Faces Bleak Predictions on Eve of Elections
abstract: Prime Minister Kevin Rudd is battling widespread forecasts of a defeat in federal elections on Saturday that would end his party’s tumultuous years in power.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Prime Minister Kevin Rudd, who emerged triumphantly from the political wilderness to regain Australia’s leadership this year, is battling widespread predictions of a defeat in federal elections on Saturday that would bring an end to his party’s tumultuous six years in power.

headline: Who Needs Melody When You’ve Got a Move On?
abstract: The Dusan Tynek Dance Theater’s program at BAM Fisher featured three dances, none accompanied by music.
lead_paragraph: In the decade since the Czech-born choreographer Dusan Tynek founded a dance company in New York, he has earned a reputation for his imagination, his choreographic craft and his musicality. Yet none of the three works in his thematically and formally unified 10th-anniversary season, which opened at BAM Fisher on Wednesday, are accompanied by music. It would seem that Mr. Tynek has handicapped himself.

headline: Tanya Taylor: Spring 2014 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Kuwaiti Sheik’s Influence in Olympic World Grows
abstract: Sheik Ahmad al-Fahad al-Sabah has quietly become one of the most powerful people in global sports, yet remains largely overlooked outside Olympic political circles.
lead_paragraph: As hundreds of members of the sports industry elite gather this week in Buenos Aires, one member of the International Olympic Committee is likely to play a major role in all the big decisions, from which city will host the 2020 Games to which sport will be added to the roster.

headline: A Soft Pitch on Education From a Hard Hitter
abstract: Davis Guggenheim, who made “Waiting for ‘Superman,’” a documentary on American education, returns with a CBS special.
lead_paragraph: People tuning into “Teach” on CBS on Friday night because they see Davis Guggenheim’s name attached to it and expect another barn-burning look at dysfunction in the educational system may find themselves asking, “What have you done with the real Davis Guggenheim and who is this bouquet-lobbing impostor?”

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Bold Red Lips at Creatures of the Wind
abstract: Based on today’s show, bright orange lips against otherwise barely-there makeup are here to stay.
lead_paragraph: Colorful, crayon-box lips like the ones seen on spring runways last year show no sign of fading for next spring. At the Creatures of the Wind show earlier today, the makeup artist James Boehmer opted for a matte orange hue that made references to the saturated, psychedelic landscape works of the artist Eugene von Bruenchenhein. After defining the lips with a burnt red pencil, Boehmer layered on Nars Timanfaya Satin Lip Pencil (available this spring), a shocking orange with a yellow base so bright “it almost glows,” he noted. He took a light approach elsewhere, just dusting powder on the face and a pale, shimmery green shadow around the eyes. Eyeliner and mascara were ditched entirely. “The lip color almost reminds me of what your grandmother would wear in the ’40s,” Boehmer said. “But she’d wear it with a full face of makeup, eyeliner and mascara, so we stripped that away to keep the look from being too granny.”

headline: Costello Tagliapietra: Spring 2014 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: A Spicy Meatball for a Spicy Bottle
abstract: The spiciness of these wines welcomes more global aspirations.
lead_paragraph: There’s spice in those bottles, and some sunny heat. That brightness welcomes the tomatoes, herbs, eggplant, lamb and olives of the Southern Rhône region, to be sure, but it can also have more global aspirations.

headline: Where Sorrow Is as Constant as the Tides
abstract: In Edwidge Danticat’s new novel, her perennial subjects are addressed through the stories of a 7-year-old girl and her family and neighbors in a small town in Haiti.
lead_paragraph: The images in Edwidge Danticat’s haunting new novel, “Claire of the Sea Light,” have the hard precision and richly saturated colors of a woodblock print or folk art painting: a great, Hokusai-like wave — “a wall of water” rising from “the depths of the ocean” like a “giant blue-green tongue” to devour fishermen and their flimsy boats; a group of girls singing and dancing on the beach, “six little brown and black angels skipping around fallen sea hearts and sand dollars”; a solitary woman “standing alone under a flame-colored weeping willow by the cemetery gate,” wearing “the same plain black dress” she had worn to the funerals of other townspeople.

headline: Hannah Fidell on ‘A Teacher’
abstract: The director of the drama “A Teacher” discusses her film about a high school teacher who has an affair with one of her students.
lead_paragraph: The director of the drama “A Teacher” discusses her film about a high school teacher who has an affair with one of her students.

headline: Two Men, 58 Years and Counting. A Love Story.
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Homosexuality']
abstract: Peter Cott and Kenneth Leedom, now in their late 80s, face cancer, Alzheimer’s, and concern about remaining able to take care of each other.
lead_paragraph: In the last apartment they are likely ever to live in together, Kenneth Leedom and Peter Cott were talking about eros and the public life of New York — which is to say, sex on a moving subway train. Mr. Leedom is 88; Mr. Cott is 89.

headline: Red Queens
abstract: Jonathan Lethem’s “Dissident Gardens” spans 80 years and three generations in a family of American leftists living in Queens.
lead_paragraph: Longtime readers of Jonathan Lethem will not be surprised to learn that New York City is the setting of his new novel, “Dissident Gardens,” though center stage this time is not the author’s native Brooklyn or the Upper East Side but Queens — specifically, Sunnyside Gardens, the planned community complex built in the 1920s. Readers may, however, be either disappointed or relieved to find no superheroes, no aliens, not even a Tourette’s-afflicted self-appointed private detective. No genre-bending this time, the novel seems to say: spanning 80 years and three generations, it realistically portrays an enchanted — or disenchanted — garden of American revolutionaries.

headline: Off the Runway: Day One
abstract: Scenes from the first day of New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the first day of New York Fashion Week.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Egypt, Pakistan, Russia and Indonesia.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Egypt, Pakistan, Russia and Indonesia.

headline: Why Quinn Angers Voters
abstract: The public’s distaste for Christine C. Quinn is evident in polls as she seeks to become the Democratic nominee for mayor on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: One morning last month, not long before Bill de Blasio was scheduled to appear in Greenwich Village to talk about the dangers of hospital closings — something he has done during the mayoral campaign as regularly as others take their morning juice — supporters of Christine C. Quinn staged a rival news conference to counter the criticism she has endured over the demise of St. Vincent’s Hospital.

headline: Life Without Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac
abstract: As the housing market strengthens, Congress is interested in transferring some or all of that risk back to the private sector.
lead_paragraph: Talk of doing away with Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac is still just that — talk. But as Congress considers whether and how to get rid of these agencies, consumers ought to be aware of how a substantial reduction in the government’s role in housing finance could affect their ability to borrow in the future.

headline: Playing at NewFest
abstract: Images from films in NewFest 2013, at the Film Society of Lincoln Center, featuring films on gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender issues.
lead_paragraph: Images from films in NewFest 2013, at the Film Society of Lincoln Center, featuring films on gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender issues.

headline: The Refugees
abstract: More than 6.5 million Syrians have been displaced by the war, according to the United Nations. The New York Times visited the homes of four of them to hear their stories.
lead_paragraph: More than 6.5 million Syrians have been displaced by the war, according to the United Nations. The New York Times visited the homes of four of them to hear their stories.

headline: A Valentine for One, a Mother’s Day Card for Another
abstract: “Adore,” the first-English language film of the French director Anne Fontaine, has mothers finding lovers at the neighbor’s.
lead_paragraph: “Adore” sounds like a brand of perfume or a Manhattan restaurant that opened during the stand-alone verb craze a few years back. The movie, based on the Doris Lessing novella “The Grandmothers,” was shown in festivals as “Two Mothers.” Plenty of variations on its theme of intergenerational lust can be found on the Internet, though you may want to clear your browser history after you’re done searching for them.

headline: Murray Loses Cool and, Soon, the Match
abstract: Ninth-seeded Stanislas Wawrinka defeated the defending United States Open champion, Andy Murray, in the quarterfinals. For Wawrinka, it was a breakthrough victory.
lead_paragraph: For a few hours, Andy Murray seemed to go back in time, back to the days before he had won majors, when mental meltdowns marked many of his Grand Slam efforts.

headline: Jolie Among 4 Recipients of Honorary Oscars
abstract: Angelina Jolie will receive the Jean Hersholt Humanitarian Award; the actors Angela Lansbury and Steve Martin and the costume designer Piero Tosi will receive Governors Awards this fall.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Angelina Jolie will receive the Jean Hersholt Humanitarian Award for her philanthropic work, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences announced on Thursday.

headline: Putting the Sex in Homosexuality
abstract: The 25th edition of NewFest, which features films on gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender issues, appears mostly concerned with primal physical acts between same-sex couples.
lead_paragraph: Amid the euphoria following the Supreme Court’s striking down the Defense of Marriage Act, allowing married gay and lesbian couples to enjoy federal benefits granted to wedded heterosexuals, one word that remains seldom heard is “sex.” Sex, as sexual orientation? Yes. Sexual, as in sexual equality? Yes. But the thing itself, the primal catalyst? Not much.

headline: A South African Heroine, With the Flaws Air-Brushed
abstract: Darrell J. Roodt’s biopic “Winnie Mandela” is a sanitized dash through a life of fortitude and controversy.
lead_paragraph: Early in Darrell J. Roodt’s rushed, patchy biopic, “Winnie Mandela,” the title character makes a grand entrance in a South African courtroom wearing a stunning outfit you might see in a glossy magazine devoted to African fashion.

headline: Châteauneuf That Proves Bigger Is Not So Bad
abstract: The 2010 vintage wins over a traditionalist who remembers it way back when.
lead_paragraph: The skirmish lines among wine lovers feature many flash points, subjects so divisive that antagonists bristle even before they’ve said a word or tasted a drop. Napa cabernet is one, and so are natural wines. Right up there in the argumentative forefront is the southern Rhône, particularly the wines of Châteauneuf-du-Pape.

lead_paragraph: Farook interview video.

abstract: Mohhamed interview video.
lead_paragraph: Mohhamed interview video.

headline: The Jewishness Is in the Details
abstract: In “Elaine Reichek: A Postcolonial Kinderhood Revisited,” Ms. Reichek raises questions about the effects of suppressing religious and ethnic identity.
lead_paragraph: Twenty years ago, the Jewish Museum commissioned Elaine Reichek, the artist known for embroidered and knitted social commentary, to create an installation about being Jewish. What she produced and exhibited in 1994 was “A Postcolonial Kinderhood,” an exceptionally savvy and elegant instance of identity politics in art.

headline: Sol Lewitt
abstract: LeWitt’s “Wall Drawing #564: Complex forms with color ink washes superimposed” is 2,448 square feet of visual sumptuousness at Paula Cooper’s main space.
lead_paragraph: Paula Cooper Gallery

headline: She Creates Herself in Multitudes
abstract: “Eleanor Antin’s ‘Selves,’ ” at Columbia University, displays how the title artist made herself into character-based performance art, again and again.
lead_paragraph: As we cycle through avatars in our online lives, we are discovering a new appreciation for the artist of many identities: a figure like Cindy Sherman, with her parade of photographic personae, or the younger contemporary artists Kalup Linzy and Tamy Ben-Tor, who inhabit multiple characters in their satirical videos. “Multiple Occupancy: Eleanor Antin’s ‘Selves,’ ” a riveting show at Columbia University’s Wallach Art Gallery, suggests that we should also be celebrating Ms. Antin.

headline: Aum Nabeel
abstract: Aum Nabeel interview video.
lead_paragraph: Aum Nabeel interview video.

headline: Modernism Blooming in Iran
abstract: Asia Society and the N.Y.U. Grey Art Gallery are mounting exhibitions of art from Iran that illustrate the idea that Modernism has always been a global adventure.
lead_paragraph: Most accounts of modern art say, basically, one thing: the West creates while the world waits, like a grateful beggar, for a nourishing handout. This is false history. Modernism has always been a global adventure happening for different reasons, in different ways, on different schedules, everywhere.

abstract: Imad interview video.
lead_paragraph: Imad interview video.

headline: Basem Rifai
abstract: Basem Rifai interview video.
lead_paragraph: Basem Rifai interview video.

headline: Diana Rifai
abstract: Diana Rifai interview video.
lead_paragraph: Diana Rifai interview video.

headline: A Stripped-Down Strongman for Our Times
abstract: The title character of “Riddick” undergoes a rebirth of sorts in this latest film in the series.
lead_paragraph: Movies like “Riddick,” a satisfyingly primitive spectacle, help explain the unlikely ascendancy of Vin Diesel as a man of cinema. With his hypertrophied body and Barry White purr, Mr. Diesel — much like his more sweetly appealing brother in brawn, Dwayne Johnson — embodies a particularly salient caricature of masculinity, one that appears to transcend obvious racial identity to make him an ideal modern Everybrute. If Arnold and Sly became the cartoon emblems of Reagan-era might, Mr. Diesel has come into his own as a contemporary hero, one who suggests a postrace ideal, even as he affirms old-fashioned power with displays of annihilating violence.

headline: Cristina de Middel: ‘The Afronauts’
abstract: The Spanish artist Cristina de Middel’s “Afronauts,” a body of photographs, drawings and related sculptures, is a smart and charming show.
lead_paragraph: Dillon

headline: What’s an Avant-Garde Evening Without a Poet and Plush Toys?
abstract: Steve Dalachinsky, Charlemagne Palestine and Joe McPhee at the Issue Project Room.
lead_paragraph: The poet Steve Dalachinsky  is as consistent an indicator of a high-quality concert experience as any I have found during 20 years of concertgoing in New York. Surely, you reckon, he’s also seen some duff dates in his decades as a regular habitué of the city’s nightclubs, concert halls, lofts and provisional spaces. But I have trouble recalling any significant, edifying or exhilarating free-jazz or total-improvisation concert I’ve attended at which Mr. Dalachinsky has not been in the audience, rough-edged, congenial and ready with an opinion.

headline: Carissa Rodriguez: ‘La Collectionneuse’
abstract: There is a lot going on in and among the works in Carissa Rodriguez’s surgically precise New York gallery debut.
lead_paragraph: Front Desk Apparatus

headline: U.S. Open Food Review: Going Fishing, Again
abstract: It was time to give the Fulton Fish Market stand another chance.
lead_paragraph: Because eating at the United States Open is a high-stakes game, we will feature a daily review of items available at the food courts at the National Tennis Center.

headline: Monika Grzymala: ‘Volumen’
abstract: Monika Grzymala, who was born in Poland and has lived most of her life in Germany, is a kind of wizard at conjuring installation pieces out of different kinds of tape.
lead_paragraph: Morgan Library & Museum

headline: Josh Kline: ‘Quality of Life’
abstract: In Josh Kline’s latest exhibition there is no such thing as aging gracefully.
lead_paragraph: 47 Canal

headline: Daniel Subkoff
abstract: Daniel Subkoff has been making painting unusually real for at least a decade, cutting, tearing and folding stretched canvases to form objects that reach out into space.
lead_paragraph: James Fuentes

headline: Getty Images Announces Winners of Photography Grants
abstract: On Thursday at the Visa Pour l’Image festival in Perpignan, France, a Getty Images Grant for editorial photography was awarded to Eugene Richards — allowing him to expand on his work documenting Iraq war veterans in the United States — and others.
lead_paragraph: PERPIGNAN, France — Eugene Richards received his second Getty Images Grant for editorial photography Thursday evening at the Visa Pour l’Image photography festival. The grant will allow him to expand his project, “War Is Personal,” about Iraq war veterans returning to the United States. His earlier work, which resulted in a book, was partially funded by his first Getty Images Grant in 2008.

headline: Secretary, Take a Letter, and Be Sure to Type It Fast
abstract: The French film “Populaire,” set in the late 1950s, recalls the romantic comedies of Doris Day and Rock Hudson.
lead_paragraph: Charm. It emanates like a seductive natural perfume from those who are blessed with it. But this elusive quality can also be cultivated. If you can’t put your finger on exactly what charm is, you recognize it from the moment you fall under its spell.

headline: A Delicate Balance Tested
abstract: “Touchy Feely” centers on two adult siblings dealing with unexpected upheaval.
lead_paragraph: A full appreciation of Lynn Shelton’s new-age comedy, “Touchy Feely,” depends on your knowledge of reiki. In this gentle holistic therapy that originated in Japan, a practitioner moves healing energy through the body using touch or passing the hands above the body. Although I have tried reiki, I can’t personally attest to major psychological or spiritual benefits. But it certainly didn’t hurt. What you take away from it may depend on the faith you invest in it.

headline: Xiaomi Makes Another Big Move in Consumer Electronics
abstract: The Chinese smartphone maker is undercutting competitors with low-cost, 3-D television. But you’ll have to be in China to buy one.
lead_paragraph: TAIPEI — Fresh from poaching a top Google executive to lead its global expansion plans, the Chinese smartphone maker Xiaomi on Thursday announced another jaw-dropper: a 3-D television with a 47-inch screen, capable of hooking up to Internet, all for less than $500.

headline: 36 Hours in Berlin
abstract: In the evolving German capital, where neighborhoods are being transformed, there are fresh spots to see art, sip cocktails and savor a bite.
lead_paragraph: Berlin, which has been Germany’s modern capital for only 23 years, has reached a coming-of-age moment. As it attempts to evolve from a city that relies heavily on government support to one with sustainable industries, companies like Google and Etsy have opened up offices, joining technology start-ups like SoundCloud and ResearchGate, giving credit to the hype that Berlin is becoming a contender for Europe’s Silicon Valley.

headline: Scenes From the German Capital
abstract: Eat, drink and browse your way around Berlin.
lead_paragraph: Eat, drink and browse your way around Berlin.

headline: The Condo Conversion Crunch
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Rent Control and Stabilization', 'Condominiums']
abstract: As rentals are turned into condos, negotiations can turn into lawsuits.
lead_paragraph: On first blush, it looks like Carol Cohen, a top residential broker in Manhattan who has counted the fashion designer Vera Wang and the publishing scion Lachlan Murdoch as clients, has a great setup. She lives with her husband in a sprawling two-bedroom apartment on a prime block on Park Avenue, for which she pays about $3,000 a month in rent, far less than the $9,500 a month a nearby two-bedroom on Park Avenue costs.

headline: Minnesota Orchestra Musicians Reject Latest Contract Offer
abstract: The locked-out musicians voted on Thursday to reject the latest contract offer put forward by management, extending a bitter labor dispute.
lead_paragraph: The labor standoff that cost the Minnesota Orchestra its entire last season, and is imperiling the coming season, was extended on Thursday, when the orchestra’s locked-out players voted to reject the latest contract offer put forward by management.

headline: Comedy Listings for Sept. 6-12
abstract: A selected guide to stand-up, improv and comedy shows in New York.
lead_paragraph: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Theater Listings for Sept. 6-12
abstract: A guide to theater productions in New York, with a special note of shows in previews or about to open.
lead_paragraph: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Woman Who Wrote About Life Under the Taliban Is Killed
abstract: Sushmita Banerjee, an Indian who married an Afghan, was abducted and shot 18 years after being sentenced to death for refusing to wear a burqa in public.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The author of a popular memoir of life under the Taliban that was made into a major Bollywood movie was shot dead early Thursday morning, 18 years after militant leaders sentenced her to death after she refused to wear a burqa in public.

headline: Police Hunt for Driver Who Raced Around Manhattan
abstract: Police are on the lookout for a superspeeder after a YouTube video featuring someone driving a BMW around Manhattan in 24 minutes hit the Web last week.
lead_paragraph: The old debate raised by participants in the Cannonball Baker Sea-to-Shining-Sea Memorial Trophy Dash in the 1970s is back: Can a good driver drive fast without endangering other motorists? Our laws and those who enforce them say no, they cannot, but there are some people willing to challenge that notion.

headline: The Once and Future Marquand
abstract: An Upper East Side building, the successor to a mansion, is entering a new chapter: luxury condominiums.
lead_paragraph: Who now remembers the name of Henry Gurdon Marquand, the financier who was one of the great art collectors of the 19th century? In the 1880s he put up one of the most opulent of the Fifth Avenue-style mansions — but he built it on Madison Avenue. It vanished a century ago, leaving only a monogram, but now the Marquand name is back.

headline: Movie Listings for Sept. 6-12
abstract: A critical guide to movies playing in New York, including film series.
lead_paragraph: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Yahoo’s New Look and Netflix’s Big Data Dilemma
abstract: Thursday’s selections from around the Web include reactions to Yahoo’s new logo and an argument for how Netflix could harness big data to make more money off users.
lead_paragraph: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: Food Matters | Ali Larter’s Book of Seasonal Menus for Homegrown Parties
abstract: The actress’s cookbook, chock-full of original recipes, comes out next Tuesday and features photos of her family and friends. Make her lagered turkey chili to celebrate today’s start of the football season.
lead_paragraph: Ali Larter, the Los Angeles-based actress best known for her roles in “Heroes” and “Varsity Blues,” nearly put herself under house arrest for two and a half years while creating her first cookbook, “Kitchen Revelry” ($32.50, St. Martin’s Press). “This book has been my every day, nights and weekends,” said Larter, who wrote and art directed the “petite little party book,” as she put it, at home. “It’s taken over my house.” And it was all accomplished with what Larter called “an incredible team of women”: her good friend Tracy Zahoryin visited almost daily to help taste and develop the recipes, which Alison Attenborough food styled around Larter’s home and Amy Neunsinger photographed while friends and family poured in, gobbling it all up. (Her nearest and dearest are pictured in the book, too.)

headline: ‘Iran Modern’
abstract: Photos from Asia Society’s new exhibition of Iranian artwork.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Asia Society’s new exhibition of Iranian artwork.

headline: Iran’s Foreign Minister Opens a Twitter Channel to the West
abstract: Iran’s new foreign minister engaged in a flurry of Twitter diplomacy on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Last Updated, 10:24 p.m. | Iran’s new foreign minister, the veteran diplomat Mohammad Javad Zarif, formally took charge of the country’s nuclear negotiations on Thursday, but still managed to find time to reach out to the West through a more informal channel — his new Twitter account.
