headline: This Week’s Movies: Sept. 6, 2013
abstract: The New York Times film critics on "Riddick," "Salinger" and "Touchy Feely."
lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics on "Riddick," "Salinger" and "Touchy Feely."

headline: Spare Times for Children for Sept. 6-12
abstract: A listing of cultural events for children, teenagers and families.
lead_paragraph: Arts in the Gardens

headline: Secret Documents Reveal N.S.A. Campaign Against Encryption
abstract: Details on N.S.A. efforts to defeat widely used Internet encryption technologies.
lead_paragraph: Details on N.S.A. efforts to defeat widely used Internet encryption technologies.

headline: Weight Off Your Mind
abstract: Suggestions for dealing with a mother-in-law’s issues with a grandchild’s weight, reticent neighbors, slumbering stepsons and a touchy waiter.
lead_paragraph: My husband and I have a beautiful 6-month-old daughter. She is chubby but not overweight by any means. My mother-in-law, who obviously has a weight obsession and is quite thin, has started making comments about my daughter’s size: “I can’t believe her legs are so big when she kicks all the time.” Or: “She’ll thin out when she starts to crawl.” My husband knows that these comments bother me, but he will not address them with her. I want to protect my daughter from her grandmother’s damaging and unhealthy fixation with weight. What should I do?

headline: Countdown to Fashion Week
abstract: In a five-part series of reports on young, under-the-radar fashion designers we visit each at a different stage in the process as they prepare for New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: In a five-part series of reports on young, under-the-radar fashion designers we visit each at a different stage in the process as they prepare for New York Fashion Week.

headline: A Low-Rise Feel at High-Rise Prices
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']
abstract: A rental building that offers the kind of perks that have become common in Williamsburg condominiums.
lead_paragraph: The apartments that agents begin leasing this month at 50 North 5th Street, in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, will be among the first rental buildings in the neighborhood to offer the kind of perks that have become increasingly common in the neighborhood’s most expensive condominiums.

headline: Timken Agrees to Split in Two After Pressure From Activist Investors
abstract: Activist investors scored another victory on Thursday when the board of the Timken Company agreed to spin off its steel business from its industrial bearings operations amid pressure from two big shareholders.
lead_paragraph: Activist investors scored another victory on Thursday when the board of the Timken Company agreed to spin off its steel business from its industrial bearings operations amid pressure from two big shareholders.

headline: Marissa Webb: Spring 2014 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Spare Times for Sept. 6-12
abstract: A listing of street fairs and festivals, cultural events, recreational activities and more in New York.
lead_paragraph: NYC Century Bike Tour (Sunday) Cooler weather this weekend may turn a bicyclist’s thoughts to this annual ride — the 24th — through the streets, parks and green spaces of the city. Sponsored by Transportation Alternatives, the tour features courses of 15 to 100 miles, with all the bumps, dips and climbs of open streets, as well as the relative smoothness of bicycle paths and the straightaways of bridges.

headline: Chained to the Hearth or Warmed by It?
abstract: My husband, Chris, and I had made a clear agreement regarding child rearing. But reality played out very differently.
lead_paragraph: I have waited my whole life to be oppressed.

headline: Past and Future, Scrolling By
abstract: “Tracking the Thrill,” at the Kitchen, is a selection of works by Gretchen Bender (1951-2004), whose work points backward, forward and sideways.
lead_paragraph: The Pictures Generation of artists from the 1970s and 1980s extended Pop art’s fascination with mass-media images to show how sophisticated and seductive they could be — and how, despite the supposed divide between high art and mass culture, the two were frequently made by the same people. “Tracking the Thrill,” at the Kitchen, a selection of works by Gretchen Bender (1951-2004), makes this explicit by exhibiting her artworks alongside music videos she edited for bands like Megadeth, R.E.M. and New Order, and the credits she created in 1988 for the Fox network’s “America’s Most Wanted.”

headline: Samantha Power on Syria
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'International Relations']
abstract: Ms. Power, the United States ambassador to the United Nations, spoke at a news conference on the crisis in Syria.
lead_paragraph: Ms. Power, the United States ambassador to the United Nations, spoke at a news conference on the crisis in Syria.

headline: Broadway ‘Annie’ to Close in January
abstract: The revival will close at the Palace Theater on Jan. 5, 2014, after 38 preview performances and 487 regular performances, the producers announced.
lead_paragraph: The Broadway revival of “Annie,” which opened last November to lukewarm reviews, will close at the Palace Theater on Jan. 5, 2014, after 38 preview performances and 487 regular performances, the producers announced on Thursday.

headline: New York Fashion Week: Creatures of the Wind Spring/Summer 2014
abstract: Scenes from the New York fashion week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the New York fashion week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.

headline: Inmates End Hunger Strike in California
abstract: A protest of the use of solitary confinement had dwindled to about 100 prisoners after an early peak of 30,000.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Inmates at California state prisons have ended a two-month hunger strike, corrections officials and inmate advocates announced on Thursday.

headline: Russia: Bill Would Allow Children to Be Taken Away From Gay Parents
abstract: A member of the State Duma, the lower house of Parliament, has proposed legislation allowing the authorities to take custody of children if one or both of their parents are gay.
lead_paragraph: In the latest sign of government pressure on gay men and lesbians in Russia, a member of the State Duma, the lower house of Parliament, has proposed a bill that would allow the authorities to take custody of children if one or both of their parents are gay. Russia is already facing a barrage of international criticism, including some calls for a boycott of the coming Winter Olympics in Sochi, over a new law that bars “propaganda on nontraditional sexual relationships.” Supporters of the law say it is intended to protect children, while critics argue that it is a transparent effort by officials to suppress homosexuality. In an interview with The Associated Press and the state-controlled Channel 1 television station that was made public on Wednesday, President Vladimir V. Putin insisted that gay men and lesbians do not face government-sanctioned discrimination. The legislation was introduced this week by Aleksei Zhuravlyov, a member of United Russia, the party that nominated Mr. Putin for president and controls a majority in the Duma.

headline: Sophisticated Cameras to Begin Tracking Every N.B.A. Play
abstract: The N.B.A. will install sophisticated tracking cameras in every arena this season, creating an unprecedented treasure trove of data about virtually every wrinkle of the game.
lead_paragraph: By most accounts, Carmelo Anthony was a better, more dedicated passer last season. Knicks fans saw it. Teammates praised him for it. Yet Anthony’s assist average, 2.6 per game, was the lowest of his career. Clearly, there was a piece missing in this equation.

headline: Shaving Seconds
abstract: Average response time to some 911 calls has improved slightly since last year.
lead_paragraph: Average response time to some 911 calls has improved slightly since last year.

headline: Israel Backs Limited Strike Against Syria
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Israel sees the enforcement of President Obama’s “red line” as essential to halting Iran’s nuclear ambitions, and seems to prefer an attack that would maintain the status quo without strengthening either side.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — President Obama’s position on Syria — punish President Bashar al-Assad for using chemical weapons without seeking to force him from power — has been called “half-pregnant” by critics at home and abroad who prefer a more decisive American intervention to end Syria’s civil war.

headline: The Importance of the Start to Running
abstract: For down-ballot Texas candidates, the first challenge is financial traction. Candidates have to find a way to show that they are worth investing in.
lead_paragraph: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

headline: In an Affair With a Student, Someone Learns Painful Lessons
abstract: In Hannah Fidell’s debut feature, a young high school teacher has an affair with one of her teenage students.
lead_paragraph: Long on atmosphere and short on believability, “A Teacher” tracks a young Texas high-school teacher sometime after she has started having sex with one of her students. Diana (Lindsay Burdge) is pounding drinks at a bar with her roommate not long after this debut feature by Hannah Fidell opens, giggling at a text message on her cell. Soon enough, though, she’s breaking the law with her mystery texter, Eric (a solidly real Will Brittain), in a car parked on a suburban street so inky black and conveniently deserted that the setting looks like what it is: a location that was cleared for a shoot.

headline: National Parks Try to Appeal to Minorities
keywords: ['National Parks, Monuments and Seashores', 'Minorities', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: Only about one in five visitors to a National Park site is nonwhite, according to a report commissioned by the Park Service, and only about 1 in 10 is Hispanic.
lead_paragraph: LA PUSH, Wash. — Thrusting out into the Pacific Ocean, Olympic National Park can feel like a lost world, with its ferny rain forests, violent surf and cloud-shrouded peaks.

headline: Mayoral Run by Putin Critic Vexes Kremlin
abstract: Aleksei A. Navalny’s improbable campaign for mayor of Moscow has exposed disarray in President Vladimir V. Putin’s carefully constructed political system.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The ground rules were set in the moments before the mayor, Sergei S. Sobyanin, arrived on the Kremlin embankment of the Moscow River accompanied by Patriarch Kirill I, the leader of the Russian Orthodox Church.

headline: Navalny Shakes Up Moscow Mayor’s Race
abstract: In 2013, as Moscow prepared for its first mayoral elections in a decade, the anti-corruption candidate Aleksei A. Navalny energized the youth vote, irritating the Kremlin.
lead_paragraph: In 2013, as Moscow prepared for its first mayoral elections in a decade, the anti-corruption candidate Aleksei A. Navalny energized the youth vote, irritating the Kremlin.

headline: Poor, Black and Hispanic Women Are More Often Counseled on Emergency Contraception
abstract: Are doctors more likely to brief a woman on the use of emergency contraceptives if the woman’s demographics make the doctor think she is likely to need a “Plan B”?
lead_paragraph: The number of women using emergency contraceptives — commonly known as the morning-after pill or Plan B — has increased significantly in the last decade, according to the results of a new survey released by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. From 2002 to 2006-10, the percentage of women who reported using an emergency contraceptive in the last 12 months rose to 2.2 percent from 0.9 percent, a 144 percent change.

headline: Market Report | Men’s Watches That Keep a Low Profile
abstract: When it comes to men’s watches, the age of big, complex movements appears to be on the wane. Now, the slender profiles of the early 20th century are back in the form of ultrathins.
lead_paragraph: After years of bigger and more complicated movements, watches are returning to a slender profile, reminiscent of early-20th-century classics. Here, a few ultrathins.

headline: Facebook Delays New Privacy Policy
abstract: Facebook, the world’s largest social network, said it would delay the rollout of new privacy rules, which it had planned to put in place on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Facebook has apparently decided to delay a proposed new privacy policy after a coalition of privacy groups asked the Federal Trade Commission on Wednesday to block the changes on the grounds that they violated a 2011 settlement with the regulatory agency.

headline: That’s One Devil of a Fixer-Upper
abstract: In “Hell Baby,” an expectant couple move into a wreck of a place and soon need an exorcist or two.
lead_paragraph: Leslie Bibb certainly puts her all into the job of carrying the spawn of Satan in “Hell Baby.” But the film, written and directed by Robert Ben Garant and Thomas Lennon, rarely dares to be smart, settling instead for familiar gags that would have the Devil himself yawning.

headline: A Biotech King, Dethroned
keywords: ['Frauds and Swindling', 'Sentences (Criminal)', 'Biotechnology', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Genetics and Heredity', 'Securities and Commodities Violations']
abstract: David Blech, who was once biotechnology’s top gunslinger and was worth about $300 million, is about to begin a four-year prison term, having pleaded guilty to stock manipulation.
lead_paragraph: He was once hailed as the king of biotechnology. In the industry’s frontier days, David Blech was the top gunslinger, quick to draw his checkbook to start new companies or prop up faltering ones.

headline: Stuck in Mexico City Traffic
abstract: In a crowded city of 20 million people and about four million cars, congestion is a way of life.
lead_paragraph: In a crowded city of 20 million people and about four million cars, congestion is a way of life.

headline: Stranded in a Sea of Cars, Where Speedometers Barely Budge
abstract: Mexico City’s roads are clogged with vehicles, and six-hour commutes are not uncommon. But in a land where cars are status symbols, resignation rules.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — From the top of a tall building on a clear night, the traffic here looks like a stream of light — bright white flowing one way, ruby red the other. On the ground, however, it’s painfully obvious that the opposite is true: nearly everyone is stuck.

headline: Rallies for Immigration Overhaul Planned
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Illegal Immigration']
abstract: Groups supporting an overhaul said they were planning a mobilization next month to press the House of Representatives to vote on a bill giving legal status to illegal immigrants.
lead_paragraph: Groups supporting an immigration overhaul said they were planning a mobilization early next month to press the House of Representatives to vote on a bill giving legal status to illegal immigrants. They will hold rallies in at least 40 cities nationwide on Oct. 5 and a large rally in Washington on Oct. 8, said Gustavo Torres, executive director of Casa de Maryland, one of the organizations leading the events. Immigrant leaders said they hoped to keep pressure on House lawmakers so they would not lose sight of immigration amid debates over military action in Syria and the budget.

headline: Donovan Returns, But Does He Make U.S. Team Better?
abstract: Landon Donovan is back with the U.S. World Cup team for a qualifying match at Costa Rica on Friday night, but his role in the squad remains nebulous.
lead_paragraph: SAN JOSÉ, Costa Rica — No player has scored more goals for the United States men’s national team than Landon Donovan, and six months after his 31st birthday, he insists that he has never performed better on a soccer field than at this moment.

headline: Love in a Time of Quarantine
abstract: A rescue worker falls in love with a virologist and single mother during a devastating outbreak of avian flu in the Korean disaster film “Flu.”
lead_paragraph: Save the toddler, save the world is the premise of “Flu,” a South Korean riff on Steven Soderbergh’s “Contagion” that thumbs its nose at that film’s measured restraint. Charging gleefully over the disaster movie cliff, the director, Kim Sung-soo — who’s been lying low since making his goofy 2003 comedy, “Please Teach Me English” — has clearly decided to return with a bang.

headline: Kenyan Lawmakers Vote to Leave International Court
keywords: ['Legislatures and Parliaments', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: Parliament took the first step toward withdrawing the country from the International Criminal Court on Thursday, less than a week before Kenya’s deputy president is tried.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — Kenya’s Parliament took the first step toward withdrawing the country from the International Criminal Court on Thursday, less than a week before Kenya’s deputy president goes on trial in The Hague.

headline: A Japanese Social App Contacts New Shores
abstract: Line, which has hundreds of millions of users in Asia and parts of Europe and Latin America, is beginning a push into the United States.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Traditionally, Japanese bow when greeting others. They do not tend to shake hands. But millions of them have started shaking their smartphones.

headline: Zvonko Busic, 67, Croatian Hijacker, Dies
abstract: Mr. Busic was a Croatian nationalist who in 1976 hijacked a Trans World Airlines flight out of La Guardia Airport and planted a bomb beneath Grand Central Terminal that killed a police officer.
lead_paragraph: Zvonko Busic, a Croatian nationalist who used fake explosives in 1976 to hijack a Trans World Airlines flight out of La Guardia Airport and planted a real bomb beneath Grand Central Terminal that killed a police officer, was found dead at his home in Rovanjska, Croatia, on Sunday. He was 67.

headline: Macroeconomics and the Little Guy
abstract: “American Made Movie” pins the decline of the manufacturing sector on forces seemingly beyond anyone’s control and the hopes for reversing it on plucky individuals.
lead_paragraph: “American Made Movie” is harmless propaganda on behalf of re-establishing American manufacturing and encouraging consumers to support it. But it contains a contradiction of sorts, attributing the decline of the manufacturing sector to macroeconomic forces seemingly beyond anyone’s control, while pinning the hopes for reversing it on small-scale successes and plucky individuals.

headline: Academia’s Fog of Male Anxiety
abstract: Yes, the PC police are out there, and the real worry for men is that they will have to change their ways.
lead_paragraph: This is the fourth of five posts this week on women in philosophy.

headline: The Bush Burden
abstract: History should hold George W. Bush accountable for the current muddy debate over what to do in the face of a state-sanctioned mass killer.
lead_paragraph: He’s there in every corner of Congress where a microphone fronts a politician, there in Russia and the British Parliament and the Vatican. You may think George W. Bush is at home in his bathtub, painting pictures of his toenails, but in fact he’s the biggest presence in the debate over what to do in Syria.

headline: Europe Offers U.S. a Deal, Hoping for Global Rules on Airline Emissions
abstract: Europe said it would pare back its law in exchange for support on a global deal on airline emissions that would be in place by the end of the decade.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Seeking to end years of acrimony, the European Union has made concessions to the United States to try to gain support for global rules on airline emissions.

headline: Hi, It’s Your Doctor
keywords: ['Doctors', 'Elderly', 'Emergency Medical Treatment', 'Hospitals', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: After a half-century, the doctor’s house call is making a comeback.
lead_paragraph: MY father, a pediatrician, kept all his medical equipment in a black leather bag. He used to take it on house calls. My brothers and I would frequently tag along to watch him treat patients. He would remove stitches from over an eye or look into a throat and ears, providing a few pills to start a regimen of antibiotics for an ear infection.

headline: Childhood Friends, Torn Apart by Ambitions
abstract: “Mission Park,” directed by Bryan Anthony Ramirez, is about four childhood friends whose ambitions land them on opposite sides of the law.
lead_paragraph: If real F.B.I. agents were as inept as those in “Mission Park,” their average on-the-job life span would approximate that of a very lucky mayfly. And if actual drug honchos were as careless as the ones presented here, we wouldn’t need the F.B.I.

headline: Years of Tragic Waste
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Recession and Depression', 'Unemployment']
abstract: It’s been five years since the fall of Lehman Brothers and the start of an immense failure of economic policy in the United States.
lead_paragraph: In a few days, we’ll reach the fifth anniversary of the fall of Lehman Brothers — the moment when a recession, which was bad enough, turned into something much scarier. Suddenly, we were looking at the real possibility of economic catastrophe.

headline: It Takes A Government (To Make A Market)
abstract: The good news on Obamacare.
lead_paragraph: Lots of reporting on the new Kaiser Family Foundation analysis of what we know so far (pdf) about premiums under Obamacare. It definitely looks as if there will be a mild “rate shock” — in the right direction. KFF:

headline: Networks Get a Victory in Court Over Streaming Service
abstract: A federal court in Washington blocked one service from streaming the networks’ programs until a copyright infringement lawsuit concludes.
lead_paragraph: For the first time in nearly a year, the nation’s major television broadcasters have won a round in their legal battle against start-up firms that stream programs from local stations over the Internet without their consent.

headline: Deference to a Revered Record in Japan Is Going, Going ...
abstract: As Wladimir Balentien closes in on a single-season home run record of 55, first set by Sadaharu Oh, many fans are now rooting for Oh’s record to fall, a development that once seemed unthinkable.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — For decades, the Japanese have called Sadaharu Oh the world’s true home run king. With 868 career home runs and many other hitting records to his name, Oh, now 73, is worshiped here as much as Babe Ruth is in America.

headline: Caught Between the U.S. and China
abstract: The current campaign has done little to clarify the difficult economic and security choices Australia faces or articulate the country’s place in the world.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — BUOYED by a mining boom, Australia was one of the only major developed economies to avoid recession during the global financial crisis. Its economy has been growing for two decades. So why is the ruling Labor Party, in power since 2007, badly trailing in most public opinion polls?

headline: Thursday Friday Night Music: Sarah Jarosz
abstract: Means so much to me.
lead_paragraph: This is going up tonight instead of tomorrow because, as I mentioned the other day, I have some crazy travel. Regular readers know that Sarah Jarosz and her trio are big favorites of mine, and this, via her publicist, is the new official video for one of the songs off her new album, released Sept. 24:

headline: Iran Signals an Eagerness to Overcome Old Impasses
abstract: Iran’s new foreign minister, an American-educated diplomat, was assigned responsibility on Thursday for leading negotiations over the nation’s disputed nuclear program.
lead_paragraph: Iran’s new foreign minister, an American-educated diplomat, was officially assigned responsibility on Thursday for leading the negotiations with big powers over the disputed Iranian nuclear program, another signal that the country seems eager to overcome the impasses that have stalled those talks for years.

headline: As Doubts Over Detective Grew, Prosecutors Also Made Missteps
keywords: ['Confessions', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Elections, District Attorneys']
abstract: The Brooklyn district attorney’s office is reviewing cases handled by Louis Scarcella, a detective accused of fabricating confessions. But the work of prosecutors is also in question.
lead_paragraph: After a murder defendant took the stand and accused a Brooklyn homicide detective, Louis Scarcella, of beating a false confession out of him, the detective had someone important vouch for his trustworthiness to the jury: the prosecutor.

headline: Moms and Dads Take On Failing Schools
abstract: James Takata’s documentary “We the Parents” chronicles the efforts of a group fighting to save a struggling school.
lead_paragraph: There was a time, as James Takata’s matter-of-fact documentary “We the Parents” recalls, when moms and dads got involved with their children’s education by helping out with bake sales and showing up at parents’ night. But there was also a time when the American public school system was not something to cry yourself to sleep over.

headline: Highlights From Our Social Feeds at NYFW, Day 1
abstract: New York Times fashion reporters and editors describe day one of New York Fashion Week in 140 characters.
lead_paragraph: Slide Show: Off the Runway: Day One

headline: Selling Health Care Reform
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Editorials']
abstract: After years of Republican obstruction and obfuscation, supporters of the law are fighting back to raise enrollment.
lead_paragraph: The long years of Republican obstruction and obfuscation on health care reform have taken their toll. More than half of Americans still say they don’t know how they and their families will be affected by the Affordable Care Act, according to a new Kaiser Family Foundation poll, about the same percentage as in 2010. More Americans have a negative view of the act than a positive one.

headline: The Federal Reserve Nomination
keywords: ['Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Editorials']
abstract: Senators should tell President Obama that Lawrence Summers would be the wrong choice for the Fed, and a big mistake.
lead_paragraph: In July, when news broke that President Obama might nominate Lawrence Summers to be the next chairman of the Federal Reserve, several Democratic senators wrote a letter to the president in praise of Janet Yellen, the current Fed vice chairwoman who many presumed would be the nominee. The letter didn’t mention Mr. Summers; rather, it recounted Ms. Yellen’s formidable qualifications and urged the president to nominate her. Perhaps it was too subtle.

headline: Plan at G-20 Is to Tighten Global Rules on Taxes
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Corporate Taxes', 'Currency', 'Law and Legislation', 'Politics and Government', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Tax Evasion', 'Tax Shelters']
abstract: The Group of 20 summit meeting is expected to enact new laws that would tighten rules on multinational companies that use subsidiaries to legally avoid paying taxes.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Many of the leaders of the world’s richest economies are convening at the eighth Group of 20 summit meeting in St. Petersburg, Russia, with the economic winds at their back, ready to sign on to a sweeping new set of tax rules for multinational corporations.

headline: Pentagon Is Ordered to Expand Potential Targets in Syria With a Focus on Forces
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The Obama administration is now talking about using aircraft to strike specific targets, as intelligence indicates the Syrian government has moved troops and equipment.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama has directed the Pentagon to develop an expanded list of potential targets in Syria in response to intelligence suggesting that the government of President Bashar al-Assad has been moving troops and equipment used to employ chemical weapons while Congress debates whether to authorize military action.

headline: Stop-and-Frisk in Public Housing
abstract: A federal judge made the right decision to grant class-action status to a lawsuit brought by public housing residents and their visitors.
lead_paragraph: Judge Shira Scheindlin of Federal District Court in Manhattan made the right decision last week when she granted class-action status to a lawsuit brought by public housing residents and visitors who say they were illegally stopped or arrested by the police in their buildings.

headline: Germany’s Conspicuous Silence
abstract: In an age that calls for leadership, Europe’s strongest state shies from a global role.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Germany is the world’s most popular country, according to a BBC World Service survey this year, not bad for a nation that has probably fretted more over its self-image than any other. It is also an enigma, a powerful state wary of power, a lusterless leader. Angst is a German word but not a German condition.

headline: Billie Jean King’s Victory for Women
abstract: A reader says Billie Jean King has done more for American women generally than any other athlete.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Intervening in Syria: The Debate Goes On

abstract: Another sampling of the daily outpouring about what the United States should do.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: More Glass Towers for New York?
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Zoning', 'Area Planning and Renewal']
abstract: Readers respond to an Op-Ed article about the Midtown East rezoning proposal for New York City.

headline: A Growing County Fights for Every Resident to Be Counted
abstract: Officials in Hidalgo County, Tex., say its population was drastically undercounted in the 2010 census, and they are taking action to undo the consequences.
lead_paragraph: Armed with maps, photos and data, Hidalgo County officials say they are fighting to undo the consequences of what they see as a drastic undercount of the county in the 2010 census.

headline: Bryan Twins See a Grand Slam Slip Away
abstract: Bob and Mike Bryan said that the chance to accomplish a calendar-year Grand Slam would likely never come again after their loss in the U.S. Open semifinals on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Bob and Mike Bryan were two victories from becoming the first men’s doubles team since 1951 to win the Grand Slam in a calendar year, but their quest was ruined Thursday in the semifinals of the United States Open by the fourth-seeded team of Radek Stepanek and Leander Paes.

headline: Snakeskin Loafers at Creatures of the Wind
abstract: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway. Today’s pick: western-inspired shoes.
lead_paragraph: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: A Newspaper in Las Vegas, at Risk of Closing, Divides a Family
abstract: The publisher and editor of The Las Vegas Sun, Brian Greenspun, is suing to block a deal that could force the newspaper to close.
lead_paragraph: Tanned and fit, collar unbuttoned and no socks under his loafers, Brian Greenspun, the president of The Las Vegas Sun, stood in the middle of the newsroom, surrounded by $500 Herman Miller chairs, flat-screen monitors and floor-to-ceiling third-story windows offering an unmatched view of the Las Vegas Strip.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Friday, September 6, 2013
abstract: Quotation of the day for Friday, September 6, 2013.
lead_paragraph: “This is the golden age of spying.”

headline: Young Man Shows His True Colors
abstract: In the comedy “American Milkshake,” Tyler Ross plays a white boy in mid-1990s who wishes he were black.
lead_paragraph: Written and directed by David Andalman and Mariko Munro, “American Milkshake” merrily bumps along as if it were the first movie to find humor in a white kid’s idolizing desire to “be black,” whatever that may mean to him. Set in the 1990s — as insisted upon by references to O. J. Simpson, Tupac, Netscape, Marion Barry, and so on — this half-baked comedy stars a likable Tyler Ross as Jolie, a high schooler obsessed with the racial clichés he has bought into.

headline: Trimmings, NYFW Day 1
abstract: Accessories highlights from the first unofficial and official days of New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: Accessories highlights from the first unofficial and official days of New York Fashion Week.

headline: The Closer: Not Quite as Important as You Think
abstract: Koji Uehara’s success this season as the closer for the Boston Red Sox adds weight to the argument that spending highly on that role is not always the best investment.
lead_paragraph: For his success on the field and humanity off it, Mariano Rivera deserves the praise, gifts and money he has earned as the greatest closer in major league history. Yet as Rivera prepares to leave the stage, it is time to let the secret out: the importance of a proven closer is a myth.

headline: San Antonio Passes Far-Reaching Antidiscrimination Measure
keywords: ['Discrimination', 'Homosexuality', 'Law and Legislation', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The City Council’s vote capped weeks of debate that exposed racial, religious and gay-and-straight divisions and drew the scorn of the state’s Republican leaders and candidates.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Nearly 200 cities across the country have enacted ordinances in recent years that prohibit bias by municipal employees or in city contracts over someone’s race, sex, age, religion or sexual orientation. Houston, Austin, Dallas and Fort Worth are a few of the Texas cities that adopted such measures.

headline: Williams Still Faces Roadblocks
abstract: It is tempting to get ahead of ourselves in light of Serena Williams’s dominance thus far, but no one has been more point-in, point-out impressive than Williams.
lead_paragraph: It has been more than a year since Patrick Mouratoglou became that rare figure in Serena Williams’s life: a coach outside her family circle.

headline: Taking to the Streets in Cambodia
abstract: Opposition leaders geared up for a protest Saturday against the government of Prime Minister Hun Sen.
lead_paragraph: Opposition leaders geared up for a protest Saturday against the government of Prime Minister Hun Sen.

headline: In an Unsettled Cambodia, Preparing to Confront the Government
abstract: Opposition leaders plan peaceful protests on Saturday because of reported irregularities in July elections, but the government is portraying the effort as an attempt to instigate riots.
lead_paragraph: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia — He screamed, “This is so unjust!” But Yann Rith, a 25-year-old resident of Phnom Penh, did not struggle against the group of men who carried him away.

headline: ‘The Hill Town Plays’
abstract: Photos from Lucy Thurber’s five-play cycle.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Lucy Thurber’s five-play cycle.

headline: Corrections: September 6, 2013
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on September 6, 2013.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: A Small-Town Girl Who Wants Out
abstract: “The Hill Town Plays,” the cycle of five dramas by Lucy Thurber set in rural western Massachusetts, is filled with drinking, violence, misguided sex and other troubling activity.
lead_paragraph: The tourism bureaus of western Massachusetts will probably not want to send potential visitors to “The Hill Town Plays,” the cycle of five dramas by Lucy Thurber that is mostly set in those leafy parts, and whose plays are being presented concurrently across stages in Greenwich Village, courtesy of the Rattlestick Playwrights Theater. Although occasional reference is made to the appealing “smell of wood smoke hitting the cold air,” or the cozy intimacies of small-town life, the world presented in Ms. Thurber’s plays is not a place that would tempt you to start browsing real estate brochures.

headline: Not the Party Type
abstract: Brad Wilber and Doug Peterson strike fear into the hearts of even the bravest solvers.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — This puzzle is a thing of beauty, even if it did almost Nothnagel me (for those of you just joining us, to be Nothnageled means to be defeated by tricky entries in the grid. It’s named after tricky constructor Mike Nothnagel, who is otherwise a very nice guy.) We should probably come up with a name for a puzzle by Brad Wilber and Doug Peterson, because they are another team of constructors whose byline can strike fear into the hearts of even the bravest solvers.

headline: New Inquiry for Bachmann on Her Presidential Race
keywords: ['Campaign Finance', 'Political Action Committees', 'Ethics (Institutional)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A federal inquiry is seeking to determine whether an outside “super PAC” coordinated strategy with Representative Michele Bachmann’s campaign staff in violation of election laws.
lead_paragraph: Representative Michele Bachmann’s presidential hopes ended 20 months ago, but her brief and chaotic campaign continues to be the focus of ethics investigations.

headline: Jets Approach Revis Island Cautiously
abstract: Darrelle Revis, once a cornerstone of the Jets’ defense, will find out Sunday if his former team will challenge him.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — For six brilliant seasons, the Jets built up Darrelle Revis with a series of intimidating nicknames.

headline: The C.E.O. at the Center of a Catastrophe
abstract: Out of the Clear Blue Sky” is Danielle Gardner’s documentary about the Sept. 11 destruction and subsequent rebirth of the investment firm Cantor Fitzgerald.
lead_paragraph: How does a company continue to do business when all of its infrastructure and more than two-thirds of its work force have been wiped out in a single day? That’s one of the questions asked, and answered, by “Out of the Clear Blue Sky,” Danielle Gardner’s eloquent insider documentary about the Sept. 11 destruction and subsequent rebirth of the investment firm Cantor Fitzgerald.

headline: Preparing Autistic Pupils to Face the World
abstract: The documentary “Best Kept Secret,” by Samantha Buck, follows a teacher at the John F. Kennedy High School in Newark and her class of young men with autism.
lead_paragraph: The titular secret is John F. Kennedy School in Newark, a public school for children with special education needs. The film follows one dedicated teacher, Janet Mino, as her class of young men with autism is about to graduate to an uncertain future.

headline: Skepticism and Wariness in Talk of Syria Attack
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: As President Obama tries to rally domestic support for military action against Syria, the skepticism in Waynesburg, Pa.,  underscores the political hurdles he faces.
lead_paragraph: WAYNESBURG, Pa. — From his bar-side perch at Hot Rod’s House of Barbeque here, 57-year-old Wolf Tripp argued that President George W. Bush had ample cause a decade ago to dispatch troops and armor into Iraq to topple Saddam Hussein. “Look at the mass graves,” he declared. “Hussein gassed his own people.”

headline: Rescued Hens Fly Cross-Country, No Flapping Required, to Find New Lives
abstract: Some 1,200 rescued hens that had been living in harsh conditions in California completed a chicken run to Elmira, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: It may just be the greatest airlift of escaped egg-layers ever.

headline: Soldiers of Fortune Fighting Corporate Greed
abstract: In Henry Saine’s dystopian “Bounty Killer,” the superstars hunt white-collar criminals.
lead_paragraph: Henry Saine’s “Bounty Killer” begins with a Tarantino-esque soul music soundtrack and copious blood splatters — like a ketchup Action painting — as the leggy Mary Death (Christian Pitre) gets her revenge. In Mr. Saine’s futuristic dystopia, the superstars are bounty killers who hunt white-collar criminals while “providing the survivors of the apocalypse with retribution.” They also, apparently, are chasing a “fat stack of cash” while “ending the plague of corporate greed.” (The paradox of fighting greed while inflicting mass decapitations and lacerations for fame and fortune is never addressed.)

headline: Where AIDS Steals Life by the Millions
keywords: ['Movies', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome']
abstract: Dylan Mohan Gray’s “Fire in the Blood” centers on the millions of Africans with AIDS who have died because they could not afford lifesaving drugs.
lead_paragraph: “The only reason we are dying is because we are poor.” That is the heartbreaking refrain heard twice in the documentary “Fire in the Blood,” about an urgent and shameful topic: the millions of Africans with AIDS who have died because they couldn’t afford the antiretroviral drugs that could have saved their lives.

headline: New York City's Public Education Challenges
abstract: Testing, school choice, accountability and more testing. Where should the next mayor start?

headline: Remote-Controlled Model Helicopter Fatally Strikes Its Operator
abstract: A 19-year-old man was killed when a model helicopter that he was piloting in Calvert Vaux Park struck him in the head, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: A 19-year-old man was killed on Thursday when a remote-controlled model helicopter that he was piloting in a Brooklyn park struck him in the head, the authorities said.

headline: Two Orphans Wonder, What Now?
abstract: The grieving teenagers of “Il Futuro” seek security in the care of some shady men and a love affair with a recluse.
lead_paragraph: Alicia Scherson’s third feature, “Il Futuro,” opens like vintage Hitchcock, but that’s just a feint. As slippery as its female star’s often oil-slicked body, this shape-shifting tale of two newly orphaned teenagers and the men who would prey on them plays with our eyes even more than our minds.

headline: Rehearsing for a Protest in Cambodia
abstract: Opposition leaders called for a peaceful demonstration Saturday after reported irregularities in July elections, but the police have also begun gearing up.
lead_paragraph: Opposition leaders called for a peaceful demonstration Saturday after reported irregularities in July elections, but the police have also begun gearing up.

headline: Strangeness, Even for New York
abstract: Survivors of a plane crash are dying in “36 Saints,” and two detectives try to stop the apparently supernatural forces behind the killings.
lead_paragraph: Supernatural thriller meets New York police procedural in Eddy Duran’s wobbly “36 Saints,” a modest effort only fitfully attaining its aims. Joseph Reyes (Franky G) and Michael Montoya (Jeffrey De Serrano, also one of the screenwriters) are detectives who have drifted perilously far from their Christian faith, only to face a malevolent force against it. Now someone is knocking off innocents — survivors of a plane crash — and the two are on the case.

headline: A Surprise at the Door
abstract: Joey Dedio is a bachelor who inherits his sister’s six (six!) children after an accident in Fro Rojas’s “Tio Papi.”
lead_paragraph: The Washington Heights neighborhood of Manhattan is a family-friendly wonderland in “Tio Papi,” starring a relaxed and charming Joey Dedio as Ray Ray, the single “Uncle Daddy” of the title, who inherits his sister’s six (six!) children after an accident.

headline: Fight Over a Communications Tower Unsettles the Hudson Valley
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Telephones and Telecommunications', 'Historic Buildings and Sites']
abstract: Environmental activists are trying to prevent a 190-foot tower from being built and blocking the view from a castle built in the late 1800s.
lead_paragraph: HUDSON, N.Y. — When Frederic Church, the esteemed Hudson River School painter, built a Persian-style castle on a bluff overlooking the river here in the late 1800s, he framed the views from his windows with ribbons of colored glass, as if declaring the scenes to be works of art.

headline: Man Is Sought in 6 Sexual Assaults Over 2 ½ Years
abstract: One man is responsible for several attacks in and around Forest Park in Queens, including the rape last month of a 69-year-old jogger, police said on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: The police said on Thursday that one man is responsible for at least six daylight sexual assaults in and around a sprawling Queens park since 2011, including the rape last month of a 69-year-old jogger.

headline: Group Financed by Business Leaders Has Put Nearly $7 Million Into Council Races
abstract: As Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg departs, Jobs for New York, a political action committee, is throwing its support behind allies who are pro-development.
lead_paragraph: A group aligned with the city’s real estate industry has unleashed a torrent of spending to support pro-business candidates for the City Council, upending the frequently sleepy local contests and angering other candidates.

headline: A City Council Race Takes a Vicious Turn
abstract: The Democratic candidates vying for Christine C. Quinn’s seat in Chelsea hold similar positions on many issues, but that hasn’t stopped the mudslinging.
lead_paragraph: Sniping among the mayoral candidates gets more attention, but the knives are out in some down-ticket races, too.

headline: Research Cites Role of Warming in Extremes
abstract: In examining a dozen extreme weather events last year, scientists found evidence that human activity was a partial culprit in about half.
lead_paragraph: Scientists have long predicted that global warming will worsen heat waves and torrential rainfalls. In some parts of the world, that is exactly what happened last year, climate scientists reported Thursday.

headline: Catsimatidis: No Friend of Hoodlums
abstract: John A. Catsimatidis, a Republican mayoral hopeful, has a fondness for the word “hoodlum,” mentioning it in televised debates, at events for supporters and on Twitter.
lead_paragraph: John A. Catsimatidis went to Patsy’s restaurant in Midtown Manhattan last week with a warning about the next occupant of City Hall.

headline: Lottery Numbers
abstract: Lottery numbers for Sept. 6 for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: A Bad Mix: A Father, a Son and a Star
abstract: “My Father and the Man in Black,” about Johnny Cash, his onetime manager Saul Holiff and the black dog of depression, was made by Jonathan Holiff.
lead_paragraph: “My Father and the Man in Black” is about the singer Johnny Cash and his onetime manager Saul Holiff. But this troubling documentary is also about man and the black dog of depression, here including Mr. Holiff, Cash and the “my” of the title: the film’s director, Jonathan Holiff, who is Saul’s oldest, estranged son and who was named after Cash.

headline: China’s Assault on Bordeaux
abstract: China has become the biggest importer of wines from Bordeaux, and the documentary “Red Obsession” looks at the tension this has generated in the clubby French wine scene.
lead_paragraph: With the fierce purchasing power of its elite class, China has become the biggest importer of wines from the Bordeaux region of France. The tension generated by these new kids on the clubby French wine scene — who were driving up prices and clearing out cellars just a few years ago — is the subject of Warwick Ross and David Roach’s fast-paced, ripped-from-the-headlines documentary, “Red Obsession.”

headline: The Protest in the Park
abstract: The documentary “99%” is more than a vivid, you-are-there record of a gathering of idealists in Zuccotti Park in New York; it outlines the issues that gave birth to a movement.
lead_paragraph: Titles at the start of “99%” cite the almost 100 filmmakers who contributed to this informative, inspiring documentary. Such pluralism is a metaphor for its subject, as the variety of physical perspectives lends a vivid you-are-there aspect to this record of the Zuccotti Park protest in New York in 2011, which spawned similar demonstrations in Philadelphia; Los Angeles; Seattle; Oakland, Calif.; and around the world.

headline: Strong Enough to Laugh
abstract: “I Am Breathing” delicately chronicles the final months of Neil Platt, a resilient young Scotsman stricken with Lou Gehrig’s disease.
lead_paragraph: Paralysis is a challenging subject for cinema (“The Diving Bell and the Butterfly” notwithstanding), but “I Am Breathing” benefits from having a witty co-creator of the film on the screen. Directed by Emma Davie and Morag McKinnon, “I Am Breathing” delicately chronicles the family routine and final months of Neil Platt, a resilient young Scotsman stricken with the motor neuron degeneration known as Lou Gehrig’s disease.

headline: Djokovic Easily Reaches Semifinals
abstract: Mikhail Youzhny became the first player of this United States Open to take a set from Novak Djokovic, but Djokovic still rolled to a victory in their quarterfinal match.
lead_paragraph: The deeper Novak Djokovic advances in this United States Open, the more his path to the final seems to open up.

headline: A Billionaire’s Story
abstract: “The Ultimate Life,” a follow-up to “The Ultimate Gift,” is about the billionaire oilman Red Stevens and the life lessons he wants pass on to his grandson.
lead_paragraph: “The Ultimate Life” is the unsought follow-up to “The Ultimate Gift,” the 2007 film adaptation of Jim Stovall’s sermon as novel. In “Gift,” the dead billionaire Red Stevens (played on tape by James Garner) posthumously instructs, via video, his playboy grandson Jason on how to live a good, meaningful life. Spoilers: It includes spending less time at the office and more with loved ones.

headline: Prominent Doctor Said to Be Tied to Insider Trading Case at SAC
abstract: The doctor, Joel Ross, is one of two physicians who prosecutors say leaked secret information about clinical drug trials that are at the center of the government’s insider-trading prosecution of the hedge fund SAC Capitol Advisors.
lead_paragraph: A prominent New Jersey doctor specializing in Alzheimer’s disease has become ensnared in the government’s criminal case against a former portfolio manager at SAC Capital Advisors, the hedge fund owned by the billionaire investor Steven A. Cohen.

headline: Contribute to Our Reporting on Youth Unemployment in Europe
abstract: The Times is taking a close look at how years of economic turmoil have affected young people in Europe. If you are under 30 and European, we would like to hear from you.
lead_paragraph: The Times is taking a close look at how years of economic turmoil have affected young people in Europe. If you are under 30 and European, we would like to hear from you.

headline: Fertility Rate Stabilizes as the Economy Grows
abstract: The number of babies born in the United States in 2012 remained flat, the first time in five years that the number did not significantly decline, federal data show.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The sharp decline in the country’s fertility rate during the economic downturn has come to an end, federal data show, as an improving economy encouraged Americans to resume having babies.

headline: In This Online Psychology Class, the Key Words Are Real Time
abstract: This year taking Introduction to Psychology at the University of Texas at Austin can be done online and in real time, even if you aren’t a U.T. student.
lead_paragraph: Before they took their seats in front of the camera under the warm lights of a new studio, Sam Gosling reminded his co-host, James Pennebaker, the chairman of the psychology department at the University of Texas at Austin, to run down the hall and apply his makeup.

lead_paragraph: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

headline: Red Sox Rally in Ninth Against Rivera and Foil Big Yankee Comeback
abstract: The Yankees effort to advance in the wild-card race suffered a demoralizing blow after Mariano Rivera allowed a tying run in the ninth, and Jacoby Ellsbury scored in the 10th.
lead_paragraph: A cool breeze blew through Yankee Stadium on Thursday night, a clear signal that postseason baseball is close at hand. Certainly that is the case for the Boston Red Sox, who have a commanding lead in the American League East. For the Yankees, the chilly weather was more suggestive of the off-season.

headline: Parking Rules
abstract: Because of Rosh Hashana, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Friday. Other regulations will remain in effect.
lead_paragraph: Because of Rosh Hashana, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Friday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

headline: For Giants’ Top Pick, Talent Outweighs Nerves and Nausea
abstract: Right tackle Justin Pugh, drafted 19th over all out of Syracuse, will have a starting role in the Giants’ season opener at Dallas.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Justin Pugh, the Giants’ right tackle, expects to feel extremely nauseated minutes before the season opener at the Dallas Cowboys on Sunday night.

headline: Following Her Fears to Greater Heights
abstract: Sandra Bullock, who returns to theaters on Oct. 4 in the space thriller “Gravity,” may be Hollywood’s gutsiest A-list actress.
lead_paragraph: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. — Like most movie stars, Sandra Bullock has been endlessly sliced into snackable bites by the celebrity media. In Vanity Fair’s estimation, this Oscar-winning actress is “friendly and direct and so unpretentious.” (True.) Ms. Bullock is “America’s sweetheart,” according to dozens of color-by-number profiles, a gifted physical comedian who has suffered the occasional flop. (Fair enough.)

headline: Parking Rules
abstract: Because of Rosh Hashana, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Thursday and Friday. Other regulations will remain in effect.
lead_paragraph: Because of Rosh Hashana, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Thursday and Friday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

headline: What’s on Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (Starz) ZERO DARK THIRTY (2012) Jessica Chastain, in an Oscar-nominated role, portrays Maya, a C.I.A. officer obsessed with finding Osama bin Laden, in Kathryn Bigelow’s fictionalized intelligence procedural. (Above, Ms. Chastain with Christopher Stanley.) Tushaar Mehra is Abu Ahmed al-Kuwaiti, the lead that Maya and her colleagues, including Dan (Jason Clarke) and Jessica (Jennifer Ehle), chase over the next eight years, using controversial interrogation techniques on prisoners to extract information. “The abuse scenes are crucial to ‘Zero Dark Thirty’ because they serve as a claim — one made cinematically rather than with speeches — that these interrogation methods are unreliable when it comes to producing actionable information,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. To omit them “would have been a reprehensible act of moral cowardice.” She added: “Ms. Bigelow’s direction here is unexpectedly stunning, at once bold and intimate: she has a genius for infusing even large-scale action set pieces with the human element. One of the most significant images is of a pool of blood on a floor. It’s pitiful, really, and as the movie heads toward its emphatically nontriumphant finish, it is impossible not to realize with anguish that all that came before — the pain, the suffering and the compromised ideals — has led to this.”

abstract: Select images of films opening this fall.
lead_paragraph: Select images of films opening this fall.

abstract: A listing of films releasing this fall.
lead_paragraph: All dates are subject to change.

abstract: See what you know about the news of the day.
lead_paragraph: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: What to Watch at the U.S. Open on Friday
abstract: Li Na, at 31, has been working to add new dimensions to her game, but is it enough to challenge Serena Williams?
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to imagine a more dominant performance than that of Serena Williams on Tuesday night. Williams, the top seed and defending champion, denied Carla Suarez Navarro a single game in a match that was over in less than an hour.

headline: U.S. Drone Strike Kills 6 in Pakistan, Fueling Anger
abstract: Among the dead was a senior commander in the Haqqani network, a pro-Taliban militant group.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — An American drone strike in Pakistan’s tribal belt late Thursday killed a senior militant commander wanted by the United States who was implicated in a long-running kidnapping drama involving an American soldier, Pakistani officials and militant commanders said on Friday.

abstract: Can you identify the missing punctuation marks in a paragraph from a New York Times article?
lead_paragraph: Take the Quiz

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Video Games Can Improve Brain Function in the Elderly, Study Says
abstract: How optimistic are you that this type of research with video games will eventually lead to real-world solutions for older adults?
lead_paragraph: In the article “A Multitasking Video Game Makes Old Brains Act Younger,” Matt Richtel writes about a new study with promising results for improving brain function in older people.

headline: Declining Rupee Brings Gains for IT Giants, Woes for Small Units
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Indian Rupee (Currency)', 'International Trade and World Market', 'United States Economy', 'US Dollar (Currency)']

headline: Daily Report: Many of Web’s Encryption Tools Compromised by N.S.A.
keywords: ['Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Cryptography, Codes and Ciphers', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: Newly disclosed documents assert that the National Security Agency is winning its long-running secret war on encryption, using supercomputers, technical trickery, court orders and behind-the-scenes persuasion.
lead_paragraph: The National Security Agency is winning its long-running secret war on encryption, using supercomputers, technical trickery, court orders and behind-the-scenes persuasion to undermine the major tools protecting the privacy of everyday communications in the Internet age, according to newly disclosed documents, Nicole Perlroth, Jeff Larson and Scott Shane report.

headline: Iran Ruling In Europe Draws Anger From U.S.
keywords: ['Embargoes and Economic Sanctions', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'United States International Relations']

lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — In a setback for the United States’ attempts to isolate Iran, a European Union court threw out sanctions Friday on seven Iranian companies, including four banks, rejecting arguments that they were acting as front companies to bypass the punitive measures.

headline: Is Silicon Beach Over-Hyped?
abstract: One entrepreneur, Chris DeWolfe, says the start-up ecosystem needs to coalesce more but that it’s difficult given the geography of Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: As a city, Los Angeles has been better known more for sprawl, gang violence and Botox than its tech start-up scene. But in the last five years the start-up community has seen tremendous growth. Startup Genome, a collaborative research project that compiles data on start-ups around the world, recently ranked Los Angeles third, behind Silicon Valley and Tel Aviv, among the world’s top start-up ecosystems.

abstract: Prosecutors say a prominent New Jersey doctor leaked secret information to a portfolio manager at SAC Capital Advisors. | Five years after the crisis, a reminder of why the financial system was worth saving. | The biotechnology industry has matured from its get-rich-quick days. | Fossil fuels are now the focus of those who would change the world through the power of investing.
lead_paragraph: DOCTOR ENSNARED IN SAC INSIDER TRADING CASE  |  Joel Ross, a prominent New Jersey doctor specializing in Alzheimer’s disease, is one of two physicians who federal prosecutors say leaked secret information about clinical drug trials to Mathew Martoma, then a portfolio manager at the hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors, a person with direct knowledge of the case tells DealBook’s Peter Lattman. The charges against Mr. Martoma are at the center of the government’s prosecution of SAC, which is owned by the billionaire investor Steven A. Cohen.

headline: America’s Self-Defeating Wars
abstract: Our economic woes at home are the result of trying to settle ancient tribal disputes in Iraq, Afghanistan and a few North African countries.
lead_paragraph: Regarding “Forcing Obama’s hand in Syria” (Views, Sept. 2): Vali Nasr, dean of Johns Hopkins University’s Paul H. Nitze School of Advanced International Studies, is wrong to say that it is in America’s interest to “take decisive action” against the Assad regime. Our economic woes at home are the result of trying to settle ancient tribal disputes in Iraq, Afghanistan and a few North African countries. Now we are contemplating an attack on Syria. But we will never end these tribal disputes, no matter how many American lives are lost in the process or how many U.S. dollars are spent. It’s time to leave the people of these countries to their own devices and instead start paying attention to American infrastructure and an economy that has suffered so heavily from making war in Islamic countries.

headline: Assessing the Role of Global Warming in Extreme Weather of 2012
abstract: Scientists find strong evidence of a greenhouse role in extreme heat and shifted odds of storm surges, but say most extreme weather is driven mainly by natural variability.
lead_paragraph: British and American climate agencies, drawing on work from around the world, have produced the second in what is planned as an annual roundup of studies seeking to characterize the contribution of human-driven global warming to rare and consequential weather and coastal events. The package, “Explaining Extreme Events of 2012 from a Climate Perspective,” was published yesterday in the Bulletin of the American Meteorological Society. (You can listen to a discussion of the findings between authors and reporters here.)

headline: Who Made That Catcher’s Mask?
abstract: A bird cage for your face.
lead_paragraph: In the early 1870s, catchers played bare faced. Balls routinely struck their eyes, broke their noses and knocked out their teeth. The danger increased when catchers, who had stood two dozen feet behind the batter, moved closer to the plate — an innovation, says the baseball historian Peter Morris, “that allowed the top pitchers to throw their best pitches.” The facial injuries finally decreased when a team from Harvard University rigged up a mask to protect its catchers that resembled a sturdy bird cage. The manager of the team, Frederick Thayer, patented the mask in 1878. Fans hated it. When the Harvard catcher James Tyng stepped onto the field with his head swaddled in steel and leather, he endured jeers from the crowd — people hooted at the mad dog who had to be “muzzled.” Editorial writers complained that the innovation detracted from the game. What was next — a lightning rod to save the catcher from freak storms? Would players limp around the bases with stovepipes on their legs for protection?

headline: Top Coaches Evaluate Trends at Junior Tournament

lead_paragraph: Martin Redlicki was upset. Shaking his head and raising his arms, he watched shot after shot skim past him into the corners for winners.

headline: Persistent Scars of Long-Term Joblessness
abstract: About 4.3 million Americans have been out of work for six months or more, and hundreds of thousands without jobs for long spells have simply given up.
lead_paragraph: Hugely elevated levels of long-term unemployment remain one of the worst and most persistent scars from the Great Recession, as underscored yet again in the mediocre August jobs report. All in all, about 4.3 million Americans have been out of work for six months or more.

headline: The Right to Remain Silent
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'E-Mail', 'Ethics (Personal)', 'Ethicist, The (Times Column)', 'Lying', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Crime and Criminals']
abstract: Taking back that e-mail.
lead_paragraph: While applying for a new job, I may need to state whether I have ever been arrested. I was arrested a few years ago for leaving the scene of a fender bender. I strenuously argued my innocence, and the charges were dropped and even erased — so I have been arrested but never charged with a crime. I am comfortable explaining the situation, but do I have an ethical duty to disclose this information on the application? JIM, VERMONT

headline: The Old Haunts
abstract: Memories can return so strongly that they take physical form.
lead_paragraph: The intersection of Route 27 and Main Street in East Hampton has charmed and delighted me since I was a child. There is the postcard loveliness: the town pond reflecting reeds and sky, the swans, the worn cemetery stones set in lush grass. Every summer of my childhood I felt that catch-your-breath thrill at the unchanging sight of it as my father drove us through town for our two-week vacation in what he called “the country.”

headline: Lives of the Cells
abstract: A journalist’s report on what cancer is and how it occurs illuminates deep biological processes.
lead_paragraph: Cancer would seem a dreary, frightful topic if it weren’t also such a universal one. In this era of longer human life spans, it’s almost as inevitable as death and ­taxes. Most of us will experience some form of cancer — if not in our own bodies then at close remove, through the suffering of loved ones — and therefore none of us can afford to ignore it. Knowledge is better than ignorant dread, and good writing based on keen reporting is far better than medical jargon, garbled hearsay or misinformation from the Web. That’s just one reason for reading George Johnson’s graceful book, “The Cancer Chronicles.” Another is that the biological details of just what cancer is and how it occurs are (forgive me for saying so) fascinating. And not just fascinating but also, as handled by Johnson, revealing of certain deep truths about life itself. Those truths involve two elemental concepts, familiar (if dimly) from high school biology and physics: mitosis and entropy. More on that fateful pair in a moment.

headline: A Special Purchase to Curb Behavior Could, Just as Easily, Terrify a Pet
abstract: Americans spend billions on pet products, from automatic litter boxes and anti-scratch spray to special harnesses and leashes. The results are mixed.

headline: Just Before Brooklyn Boy’s Funeral, 2 Arrests in His Killing
