lead_paragraph: Hours before mourners began filing past the open coffin of a 16-month-old Brooklyn boy who was fatally shot in his stroller last weekend, detectives on Friday broke into a Pennsylvania apartment and arrested two suspects in the killing.

headline: Listen Up | The British Folk Rockers Bear’s Den Explore the American Frontier
abstract: The young trio, a product of the same London scene that gave us Laura Marling and Mumford and Sons, shows off its appealing brand of Anglo Americana in this exclusive video.
lead_paragraph: “I think that honesty as a universal language is a really cool idea,” said Andrew Davie, the lead vocalist and guitarist of the acoustic folk-rock trio Bear’s Den. The band’s debut EP, “Agape,” bears out that sentiment. Released last week by the independent label Communion Records, it’s a collection of lyrically sincere and emotionally raw songs. It also reflects the band’s D.I.Y. approach, right down to the hand-carved potato paw prints they stamp every CD with. (Davie and his bandmates Kevin Jones and Joey Haynes showed up to their breakfast interview last month with their hands still stained with paint from the night before.)

headline: Crying for the Common Father
keywords: ['Environment', 'Forests and Forestry', 'National Parks, Monuments and Seashores', 'Trees and Shrubs']
abstract: A citizens’ movement to save a forest in northern Vietnam marks the Vietnamese’s shift toward less pragmatic, more forward-looking activism.
lead_paragraph: HO CHI MINH CITY — Vietnamese people can find an aphorism by Ho Chi Minh for nearly any occasion. A favorite schoolyard banner has him saying: “For the sake of 10 years, we must plant trees; for the sake of 100 years, we should cultivate people.”

headline: Final Showdown
abstract: Margaret Atwood brings her dystopian trilogy to a conclusion.
lead_paragraph: “Where, where is the town?” Talking Heads sang. “Now, it’s nothing but ­flowers.”

headline: The Drift of Years
abstract: Alice McDermott’s novel centers on an ordinary life, as captured in scattered recollections.
lead_paragraph: Over a decade ago, The New Yorker ran a short story I’ve never been able to forget. A wisp of a thing, barely more than twice the length of this review, it contains little action, less plot. It doesn’t seem to be about anything — except a whole life. We meet the unnamed protagonist as a child clearing ice-cream dishes from the family dinner table, surreptitiously licking the “creamy dregs” from each one. We glimpse her as a teenager necking on the couch, as a young wife reveling in the domestic sensuality of motherhood, as an older woman attending her husband’s deathbed, even then unable to keep from physical contact, “her open lips brushing . . . the surgical tape that secured the respirator in his mouth.” In the end, Alice McDermott’s “Enough” is a portrait of a woman filtered through a sensory lens, capturing the life of the body, replete with exultation and ache. Which means this is also a story about mortality.

headline: Memorial Days
abstract: After a friend dies in a freak accident, former classmates converge on his hilltop estate.
lead_paragraph: His name’s all wrong for starters. Steve Rush, Marty Rush, Jake Rush all have a hard-boiled literary glamour. There is even a DJ Rush. But Norman? Only one last name goes with Norman, and that was nabbed by Mailer. Rush couldn’t be more inappropriate; Norman has never been in a. . . . His first book, “Whites,” a story collection, was published in 1986, when he was 53. Between that and “Subtle Bodies” there have been just two novels: a long one, “Mating,” and the even longer “Mortals.” It’s not the frequency of these sturdy ol’ buses so much as their speed that is remarkable, their emphatic rejection of notions of narrative urgency. Walking, to put it oxymoronically, is Rush’s preferred pace. In “Mating” the narrator recounts how she hiked to a utopian village presided over by the enigmatic Denoon, on whom she had developed a high-I.Q. crush. This was not a stroll to Fruitlands in Massachusetts; it was a trek through the Kalahari. She barely made it, almost gave up the ghost. Me too.

headline: Two Indias
abstract: Despite its vaunted success, the country has failed to meet the basic needs of many of its people.
lead_paragraph: In late June, a television reporter named Narayan Pargaien spent three days in the northern Indian state of Uttarakhand to cover the region’s devastating monsoon floods, which have killed more than 5,700 people. Like most journalists covering the disaster, Pargaien dutifully described families who had lost everything, including their modest thatch-roofed homes. Unlike most journalists, Pargaien reported from the scene while perched on the shoulders of a flood victim in the middle of a swollen river. As the outrage poured in, Pargaien tried to explain himself. In an interview with the Indian Web site Newslaundry, he said the man who carried him had insisted upon it. “He was grateful to us and wanted to show me some respect,” Pargaien said, “as it was the first time someone of my level had visited his house.”

headline: By Design
abstract: The Book Review unveils its first full redesign since 2007.
lead_paragraph: With this issue, the Book Review unveils its first full redesign since 2007. Under the guidance of our art director, Nicholas Blechman, and Kelly Doe, The Times’s director of design, we’re now sleeker, more engaging and more vibrant. The new design updates the reviews that form the heart of our presentation and showcases the other features rounding out each issue — two of which debut this week. As Blechman puts it, “The redesign gives the Book Review more of a feel of a magazine — improved pacing between sections, with smaller features in the front and a reinvented back of the book.”

headline: Difficult Women
abstract: New books by Terry McMillan, Chelsea Cain, Nicole Galland and Kate Manning.
lead_paragraph: WHO ASKED YOU?By Terry McMillanViking, $27.95.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: ELSEWHERE,  by Richard Russo. (Vintage, $15.) In this bittersweet memoir, the Pulitzer-­winning novelist reflects on his enduring bond with his mother — a proud, idiosyncratic working woman — and the decaying industrial town she spent her life trying to escape. Balancing darkly funny anecdotes and profound sympathy, “Russo has a fine, subtle way of describing how he saw himself and his mother,” Meg Wolitzer wrote in the Book Review.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: THE CHILDHOOD OF JESUS,  by J. M. Coetzee. (Viking, $26.95.) With hints of Beckett and Kafka, Coetzee’s enigmatically titled dystopian allegory presents a quasi-socialist state in which conformity and anonymity are the highest values.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Kathy Reichs, whose latest Temperance Brennan mystery is No. 7 on the hardcover fiction list, bases her books on her own career in forensic anthropology. “She’s me,” she says of her protagonist.
lead_paragraph: She Is Me: Genre writers are generally spared the hoary advice to “write what you know.” George R. R. Martin has never bludgeoned anybody with a battle-ax (as far as I can tell), and Jane Austen probably never met a zombie. But Kathy Reichs — whose mysteries about the forensic anthropologist Temperance Brennan sold well even before they were adapted for the Fox television series “Bones” — knows where she’s coming from. Reichs earned her Ph.D. in physical anthropology from Northwestern University in 1975, and among other highlights in her busy career she has consulted with the United Nations on the Rwandan genocide and helped to identify the remains of 9/11 victims in Manhattan. Tempe Brennan, in other words, is a lot like her creator. “She’s me,” Reichs told a Canadian TV interviewer last month. “She does what I do. . . . She thinks the way I think.”

headline: Born of Struggle
abstract: Rana Mitter’s account of how the Sino-Japanese conflict helped shape modern China.
lead_paragraph: Between 14 million and 20 million Chinese died in the “war of resistance to the end” against Japan last century. Another 80 million to 100 million became refugees. The conflict destroyed China’s great cities, devastated its countryside, ravaged the economy and ended all hopes for a modern, pluralistic society. “The narrative of the war is the story of a people in torment,” Rana Mitter, a professor of Chinese history at Oxford University, writes in his superb work, “Forgotten Ally.”

headline: One Month’s Data May Not Sway the Fed
abstract: Although some say the August jobs report makes it less likely the Federal Reserve will pull back this month from its stimulus campaign, Fed officials have sounded eager to taper.
lead_paragraph: A number of economic commentators said Friday morning that the disappointing August jobs report makes it less likely the Federal Reserve would begin to pull back in September from its economic stimulus campaign.

headline: Letting Go
abstract: Exploring the flaws of American health care at the end of life.
lead_paragraph: In 1968, a letter to The British Medical Journal titled “Not Allowed to Die” described the ordeal of a retired 68-year-old doctor admitted to “an overseas hospital” (almost certainly in America) with metastatic stomach cancer. After much of his stomach was surgically removed and a blood clot cleared from his lung, he asked that “no further steps be taken to prolong his life, for the pain of his cancer was now more than he would needlessly continue to endure.” Two weeks later the unfortunate doctor had a heart attack in the hospital. His heart was shocked and restarted five times in a single night; morning found him in a persistent vegetative state. His body remained alive for another three weeks.

headline: In Toronto, ‘Fifth Estate’ Filmmakers Embrace Ambiguity
abstract: The makers of “The Fifth Estate,” about Julian Assange and WikiLeaks, said their aim was not to pass judgment on their subject.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — “Thumbs up, thumbs down, I find that very limiting.”

headline: Other People’s Pain
abstract: In their own peculiar ways, Tom Barbash’s characters struggle to recover from emotional trauma.
lead_paragraph: If your best friend has just had his heart broken, give him a copy of Tom Barbash’s new collection of stories, “Stay Up With Me.” Inscribe it: “Everybody in this book is worse off than you.” Barbash’s characters are lonely, unhappy and at least temporarily ruined. And yet there’s something addictive about these stories — like potato chips or a stiff drink.

headline: Journey Into Darkness
abstract: A memoir of a young wanderer’s brutal ordeal in captivity, and how it was transformed into spiritual triumph.
lead_paragraph: Amanda Lindhout grew up rough. Born in Alberta, Canada, she spent childhood nights lying in her top bunk, listening to her mother, Lorinda, being beaten badly by her boyfriend. By the fourth grade, Lindhout was Dumpster diving for bottles and cans with her older brother. Flush with recycling money, she haunted a nearby thrift store to buy National Geographics. Between the yellow borders, she studied “the mossy temples at Angkor,” “skeletons brushed free of volcano ash on Vesuvius,” Palestinian refugee children squatting “in tents the color of potatoes.” She trained her mind to escape from the violence around her.

headline: A Cool Classic, Sliced and Diced
abstract: Five ways to enjoy cucumbers — a perfect food for hot end-of-summer days — inspired by cuisines around the globe.
lead_paragraph: Cucumbers are the ultimate summer vegetable — cool, crisp and refreshing. So it’s only fitting that Martha Rose Shulman celebrates the cucumber as we say goodbye to the sunny, hot days of summer and usher in the fall. She writes:

headline: Obama Falls Short on Wider Backing for Syria Attack
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: President Obama emerged from the Group of 20 summit meeting with a few international supporters, but other leaders urged him not to attack without United Nations backing.
lead_paragraph: STRELNA, Russia — President Obama raced home on Friday to confront one of the biggest tests of his presidency as he ramped up a campaign to persuade Congress to support airstrikes against Syria that many world leaders he had consulted declined to back.

headline: The Case Against Tapering in September
abstract: The latest jobs report is by no means terrible, but the economy remains too fragile for the Federal Reserve to pull back from its bond-buying program this month, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: The Gun Report: September 6, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: We’ve written a few times about Jewelry for a Cause, which melts down guns procured from buybacks in New Jersey and makes bracelets and necklaces out of them. Many of the firearms collected in these buybacks were acquired illegally, and destroying them means taking them out of circulation. To those concerned with public safety, this would seem to be a good thing.

headline: Syria News Quiz
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States International Relations', 'Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: The New York Times invites you to test your knowledge of the Syrian civil war and its effects across the region.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times invites you to test your knowledge of the Syrian civil war and its effects across the region.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: In the Wake of Katrina
abstract: This week, Sheri Fink discusses “Five Days at Memorial”; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Katy Butler talks about “Knocking on Heaven’s Door”; Jennifer McDonald introduces the new feature Bookends; George Johnson discusses “The Cancer Chronicles”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.
lead_paragraph: This week, Sheri Fink discusses “Five Days at Memorial”; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Katy Butler talks about “Knocking on Heaven’s Door”; Jennifer McDonald introduces the new feature Bookends; George Johnson discusses “The Cancer Chronicles”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: A Lasting Experiment With Music
abstract: Kim Gordon, a member of Sonic Youth who has never considered herself a musician, has formed a duo with Bill Nace; their album will be released Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: There are no wrong notes on “Coming Apart,” the first album by Body/Head, a duo of the musicians Kim Gordon and Bill Nace. Nor is there a possibility of any.

headline: The Exclusive | 655 Park Avenue
abstract: A one-of-a-kind 12-room duplex at 655 Park Avenue is about to enter the market at $16.9 million.
lead_paragraph: A one-of-a-kind 12-room duplex at 655 Park Avenue is about to enter the market at $16.9 million.

headline: On Park Avenue: Elegant and Homey
abstract: Marble fireplaces, antique English pine woodwork and 24-carat gold-leaf molding adorn this 12-room duplex, listed at $16.9 million.
lead_paragraph: A one-of-a-kind 12-room duplex at 655 Park Avenue, whose distinctive layout was commissioned in 1924 by its first owner, a Rockefeller family member with a fondness for massive marble fireplaces and antique English pine woodwork, is about to be placed on the market by its third owner, Karen McGarry Karp.

headline: For Cheaper Homes, Skip Manhattan
abstract: Real estate in the other boroughs is a comparative steal. And you might even get a tree or a backyard.
lead_paragraph: With the prevalence of fierce bidding wars for apartments in Manhattan, homes that get poached within a day of the open house, and interest rates that keep inching up, a buyer could become so frustrated by hunting for real estate in the 212 area code that he or she might just decide to give up.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: In the Wake of Katrina
abstract: This week, Sheri Fink, Katy Butler and George Johnson.
lead_paragraph: This week, Sheri Fink, Katy Butler and George Johnson.

headline: For Kenneth Cole, a Tweet Too Far
abstract: Today, Mr. Cole is getting more attention than he probably wants.
lead_paragraph: In the “Encounters” profile of Kenneth Cole that ran in Thursday Styles this week, mention was made of the designer’s penchant for creating provocative advertisements that used real-world social issues — among them gun control, AIDS and abortion — to grab the attention of potential customers.

headline: 10 Questions for Tom Cole
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Representative Tom Cole, Republican of Oklahoma, spoke with John Harwood of The New York Times and CNBC on Syria and the coming fiscal negotiations.
lead_paragraph: Representative Tom Cole, Republican of Oklahoma, spoke with John Harwood of The New York Times and CNBC on Syria and the coming fiscal negotiations.

headline: Oklahomans React to Syria and Obama
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: At a town hall gathering in Midwest City, Okla., Representative Tom Cole listened to constituents sound off on whether the United States should take military action against Syria.
lead_paragraph: At a town hall gathering in Midwest City, Okla., Representative Tom Cole listened to constituents sound off on whether the United States should take military action against Syria.

headline: Obama Discusses Syria at the G-20 Summit
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Biological and Chemical Warfare']
abstract: In St. Petersburg, President Obama continued to hold his ground on Syria. He also said he intended to make his case in an address Tuesday to the American people.
lead_paragraph: In St. Petersburg, President Obama continued to hold his ground on Syria. He also said he intended to make his case in an address Tuesday to the American people.

headline: Fanfare Straining to Be Heard
abstract: Celebrations of the Verdi and Wagner bicentennials have complicated things for Benjamin Britten’s centennial.
lead_paragraph: Benjamin Britten was delighted to have been born on Nov. 22, the feast day of St. Cecilia, the patron saint of musicians and church music. That the year of his birth, 1913, was also the centennial of Verdi and Wagner is something Britten never particularly remarked upon in later life.

headline: Evoking Older Ideals and Earthly Realities
abstract: Gregory Porter’s new album, “Liquid Spirit,” his debut on Blue Note Records, harks back to the 1970s in its sentiments. It comes out Sept. 17.
lead_paragraph: “Not on the outside looking in,” Gregory Porter crows in passing during “The ‘In’ Crowd,” one of the few cover songs on “Liquid Spirit,” his soulful and assured new album. And in case you didn’t detect the mix of pride, validation and relief in that ad-libbed status report, Mr. Porter soon offers another one — “It feels nice” — that forms a malleable refrain as the tune struts to a close.

headline: British Ingenuity, Delivered by Americans
abstract: Frederick Ashton’s repertoire at the Sarasota Ballet, a Twyla Tharp triple bill at the Pacific Northwest Ballet, and the choreographers Justin Peck and Mark Morris are some of the storylines to watch this season.
lead_paragraph: The most extraordinary dance adventure in 2013-14 in the United States is hard to believe even when you know all about it. It’s set to happen on the Gulf Coast; and it concerns a dead choreographer who wasn’t American.

headline: Innovations With Fairy Tales
abstract: Christopher Wheeldon and Matthew Bourne will have ballets making their New York debuts this fall.
lead_paragraph: By tradition, ballet traffics in transformation. Most full-evening narratives that are the bread and butter of ballet companies draw their stories from fairy tales. New productions must find fresh life in much-used material, transforming it without forsaking the familiar. This fall two recent, high-profile remakes of classic stories will arrive in New York, coincidentally on the same day.

headline: The Balance of a Career
abstract: The artist Chris Burden, known for his daring feats and massive constructions, will be featured in a show at the New Museum.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Of all the things the artist Chris Burden did, and had done to, his body for the sake of art — shot, through the arm, with a .22 rifle; nailed, through the hands; cut, with broken glass; confined, for five days inside a tiny locker — perhaps his most poetic performance piece was the simplest.

headline: Sounds of Darkness and Ancient Jealousy
abstract: Highlights of the White Light Festival at Lincoln Center will include Le Concert d’Astrée’s performance of “Aci, Galatea e Polifemo,” and the JACK Quartet’s rendition of Georg Friedrich Haas’s third quartet.
lead_paragraph: When Jane Moss, the artistic director of Lincoln Center, inaugurated the White Light Festival in 2010 as a means to illuminate spirituality in disparate works, she set off a debate about transcendence in music and what role a commercial festival might (or might not) play in a listener’s spiritual journey.

headline: Design at Home, in Gardens, Up Walls
abstract: Exhibitions and auction previews this autumn offer wild rides through chunks of history via the decorative arts.
lead_paragraph: Old things that astonish and enlighten keep emerging from the shadows. In exhibitions and auction previews this autumn, long-hidden objects tell stories about Venezuelan pearls, Vesuvian eruptions, the political ramifications of British garden follies, porcelain forms that simulate craggy Western vistas and battles for fame in the pencil-making industry.

headline: Kanye West Plans Seven-Week Tour in Fall
abstract: Kanye West will hit the road for his first solo tour in five years.
lead_paragraph: Kanye West will headline his first solo tour in five years to promote his album “Yeezus,” it was announced on Friday. Press representatives for the tour said in a news release that the Yeezus Tour, as it is called, will begin Oct. 19 at the Key Arena in Seattle and run for seven weeks, when it will conclude Dec. 7 at the Toyota Center in Houston. New York-area tour dates include a Nov. 19 appearance at the Barclays Center in Brooklyn and a Nov. 23 appearance at Madison Square Garden.

headline: 10 Questions for Tom Cole
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: An Oklahoma Republican known for working across the aisle, Representative Tom Cole spoke to John Harwood about Syria, the budget negotiations and choices for the Republican Party.
lead_paragraph: Representative Tom Cole, a Republican, has brought the pragmatism of a former political operative to his work representing Oklahoma’s Fourth Congressional District. He served as a bridge between the two parties during last year’s fiscal negotiations, when he urged fellow Republicans to accept higher taxes on the wealthiest Americans. He continues to advocate a compromise budget deal to avoid a government shutdown or a debt crisis, and he maintains a good relationship with the White House.

headline: Three-Wheeled Motorcycles, Honda S.U.V.’s and Minivans Are Recalled
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Automobiles', 'Engines', 'Motorcycles, Motor Bikes and Motorscooters']
abstract: About 5,000 three-wheel motorcycles from Bombardier Recreational Products are being recalled for a defect that can cause a fire, and Honda recalled a handful of Pilot and Odyssey vehicles for an engine defect.
lead_paragraph: About 5,000 Can-Am Spyder RT and ST motorcycles from the 2013 model year are being recalled for a fire hazard, and Honda is recalling 270 Pilot sport utility vehicles and Odyssey minivans from the 2013 model year for an engine problem, according to reports posted Friday on the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration Web site.

headline: The Old Are Working, but Not the Young
keywords: ['Age, Chronological', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Men and Boys', 'Recession and Depression', 'Unemployment', 'United States Economy', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: People over 60 are more likely to have jobs than at any time in at least three decades. But younger workers are still having trouble finding jobs.
lead_paragraph: This summer has seen a larger share of a certain group of people working than at any time in the last three decades, according to government figures.

headline: No Immediate Risk Is Found From Arsenic Levels in Rice
abstract: Tests of more than 1,300 types of rice and rice products found that arsenic levels ranged from 3 to 7 micrograms per serving, amounts that the Food and Drug Administration said did not pose health risks.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Food and Drug Administration announced Friday that it had found no evidence that current levels of arsenic in rice pose an immediate health risk.

headline: Kering Takes Minority Stake in Altuzarra Fashion Label
abstract: Kering, the conglomerate that is home to brands including Alexander McQueen and Balenciaga, announced on Friday that it had taken a minority stake in the label started by the French-American designer Joseph Altuzarra.
lead_paragraph: Kering, the luxury conglomerate formerly named PPR and home to brands including Alexander McQueen and Balenciaga, announced on Friday that it had taken a minority stake in Altuzarra, the label started in 2008 by the French-American designer Joseph Altuzarra.

headline: Events in New Jersey
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Events on Long Island
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Peter Som: Spring 2014 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Events in Connecticut
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Events in Westchester
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Referee Has the U.S. Team’s Attention
abstract: A referee who is not shy about awarding red and yellow cards  will officiate Friday’s United States-Costa Rica World Cup qualifier only days before the American team hosts Mexico.
lead_paragraph: As if Friday night’s World Cup qualifier in San José between host Costa Rica and the United States did not have sufficient story lines:

headline: Yeah? Well, So’s Your Old Man!
abstract: This season, most new network sitcoms are created and written by men, about men, and in particular, about the bond between fathers and sons.
lead_paragraph: It’s a man’s world. Again.

headline: New Parent, Old Parent: What to Do When Your Child Won’t Go to School
abstract: Seeking advice from parents whose children just wouldn’t go to school — until they did. The Times’s Motherlode blog and Booming team up to tackle such issues.
lead_paragraph: We introduce a new feature: New Parent, Old Parent. As Michael Winerip writes on Booming, we’re hoping to connect the readers of two Times staples, the Motherlode blog and Booming, with the goal of providing the very best kind of parenting ideas and advice: the kind that has been tried and tested by those who have been through the mill wheel and come out the other side.

headline: Attacking Mitch McConnell From the Right
abstract: The Senator’s attempt to stay out of the government shutdown fight is making the Tea Party angry.
lead_paragraph: Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell has done his best to stay neutral in the intra-Republican war over whether to shut down the government in order to stop the implementation of the Affordable Care Act. Although he acknowledged in August that the plan wouldn’t actually work, he told The Washington Post’s Greg Sargent that he did not mean to take sides in the dispute.

headline: Saluting the Old Guards of Prime Time
abstract: A look at prime-time shows that have persevered through the renaissance of cable drama and have been influential in their own right.
lead_paragraph: September is not a prime time for old television shows. They quietly slip back onto the schedule, just happy to be there, while attention is lavished on the broadcast networks’ latest pretty young things.

headline: Obama Describes His Talk With Putin
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: President Obama said he had a “candid and constructive” conversation Friday with President Vladimir V. Putin. Syria dominated their discussion.
lead_paragraph: President Obama said he had a “candid and constructive” conversation Friday with President Vladimir V. Putin. Syria dominated their discussion.

headline: Jenni Kayne: Spring 2014 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Waiting to Woo Vodafone, and Paying the Price
keywords: ['Wireless Communications', 'Telephones and Telecommunications', 'Cellular Telephones', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: With the benefit of hindsight, Verizon should simply have paid whatever Vodafone wanted, since it was so much less than what it is paying now.
lead_paragraph: Verizon’s agreement to acquire Vodafone’s stake in Verizon Wireless is a megadeal by any measure: at $130 billion it ranks as the third-largest ever, and the largest since the collapse of the dot-com bubble in 2000.

headline: Yes, I Can, and, What’s More, as the Star
abstract: In new prime-time series, Michael J. Fox, J. K. Simmons, Blair Underwood and others play characters leading active lives despite a disability or severe medical condition.
lead_paragraph: “How can you hit a man in my condition?” Michael J. Fox complains when his television daughter gives him a playful smack on the arm in the premiere of “The Michael J. Fox Show.”

headline: A Witness to Gentrification in Cobble Hill
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Gentrification', 'Elderly', 'Historic Buildings and Sites']
abstract: Peggy White, a longtime resident of Warren Street, offers a window onto the evolution of a neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: In the morning, when Peggy White makes her way down Court Street in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, to the no-frills coffee shop where she likes to linger with friends, it can take her an hour to walk five blocks.

headline: Hyperactivity Linked to Inner Ear Defect
keywords: ['Ears and Hearing', 'Children and Childhood', 'Research', 'Genetics and Heredity', 'Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder']
abstract: A new study says a genetic defect may play a role in causing hyperactive behavior, suggesting that at least in some cases, hyperactivity can have a neurobiological root.
lead_paragraph: When hyperactivity is found in children with severe hearing loss, it is often assumed to stem from frustrations they have communicating or socializing. But a new study says a genetic defect in the inner ear may also play a role in causing hyperactive behavior, suggesting that at least in some cases, hyperactivity can have a neurobiological root.

headline: For Marvel, a Tricky Gene Transfer
abstract: Producers are gambling that “Marvel’s Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D.” can win over Marvel’s traditional male fans and ABC’s female viewers.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — How do you take a story born in comic books that most people know from the movies and successfully adapt it for television?

headline: Big Ticket | Opulent Duplex for $22 Million
abstract: A 12-room duplex at 950 Fifth Avenue has four bedrooms and ample Central Park views.
lead_paragraph: A 12-room duplex at 950 Fifth Avenue, a vertical bastion of billionaires with just seven residences and an infinitely selective co-op board, sold for $22 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: An Interview With Jason Wu
abstract: Malina Gilchrist, senior market editor at T Magazine, interviews the fashion designer Jason Wu on his new makeup collaboration with Lancome and looking beyond fashion for inspiration.
lead_paragraph: Malina Gilchrist, senior market editor at T Magazine, interviews the fashion designer Jason Wu on his new makeup collaboration with Lancome and looking beyond fashion for inspiration.

headline: Vanderbilt Football’s New Era
abstract: With rape charges against four former players as a backdrop, Vanderbilt played its football opener on Aug. 29 to a capacity crowd.
lead_paragraph: With rape charges against four former players as a backdrop, Vanderbilt played its football opener on Aug. 29 to a capacity crowd.

headline: Poised to Enter a Convent, Then She Fell in Love
abstract: Carol and Bob Kelly have weathered storms by communicating and staying committed, and they find they’re “better when we are together.”
lead_paragraph: Booming’s “Making It Last” column profiles baby boomer couples who have been together 25 years or more. Send us your story and photos through our submission form.

headline: A New Low at Rising Vanderbilt
abstract: The progress the Commodores have made on the field has been compromised by the charges brought against four since-dismissed players accused of raping a fellow student.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — Traffic snaked around Vanderbilt Stadium three hours before kickoff. Fans dressed, as instructed, in all black. Wynonna Judd belted out the national anthem, and red fireworks exploded overhead. The assembled discussed bowl games and winning seasons and Southeastern Conference upsets, and they were serious.

headline: Calendar: Coming Events in London; Los Angeles; Berlin
abstract: A weekly capsule of events around the globe curated by our writers and editors.
lead_paragraph: Frieze Art Fair, London From Oct. 17 to 20, London’s Frieze Art Fair will once again set up shop in Regent’s Park, with 175 international galleries, including heavyweights like Gagosian and Victoria Miro, in a hangarlike tent designed by Carmody Groarke. In addition to the over 1,000 artists showcasing their works, a number of talks will be held with artists, including Meredith Monk on Oct. 17, the photographer Stephen Shore on Oct. 19, and the choreographer Jérôme Bel on Oct. 20. Tickets start at £34.40 (about $52).

headline: T Time | Jason Wu on Beauty, ‘RuPaul’s Drag Race’ and the Unfashionable Allure of Las Vegas
abstract: The designer took a break from preparations for his spring/summer 2014 show, which takes place today, to talk about some of the larger passions that animate his work.
lead_paragraph: This afternoon, Jason Wu will unveil his spring/summer 2014 ready-to-wear collection, which he said last week will have “a new sense of ease that could be surprising for some.” To mark the occasion, T’s senior market editor, Malina Joseph Gilchrist, sat down with the designer in the first installment of a new series called T Time. Watch as Wu discusses his approach to beauty, his new collaboration with Lancôme, his passion for RuPaul and why he so values a Vegas getaway. Look for future episodes of T Time in the weeks ahead.

headline: For Young Designers, the Time Is Now
abstract: Kering, the company that owns top labels like Gucci, Stella McCartney and Balenciaga, announced Friday that it had invested in Altuzarra, the label started by the designer Joseph Altuzarra in 2008.
lead_paragraph: There has probably been no better time in recent history to be a young designer in New York than today, when the fashion audience is hungry for newness, the editors need constant content, and the businesspeople sense an opportunity to capitalize on the talent. Just this morning, Kering, the company that owns top labels like Gucci, Stella McCartney and Balenciaga, announced it had invested in Altuzarra, the label started by the designer Joseph Altuzarra in 2008. (It is a minority stake.)

headline: G-20 Leaders Agree to Continue Stimulus Plans
abstract: Leaders of the world’s 20 biggest economies said it was too early to reduce efforts to stimulate spending and growth.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The leaders of the world’s 20 largest economies issued a joint statement on Friday saying it was too early to ease off government stimulus spending, in spite of recent positive economic news.

headline: Knopf Acquires New Paolo Bacigalupi Novel
abstract: Mr. Bacigalupi, author of the science fiction novel “The Windup Girl,”  is moving from a tiny specialty press to one of the most highbrow publishers in the business.
lead_paragraph: Knopf has acquired a new novel by Paolo Bacigalupi, the science fiction writer whose 2009 book “The Windup Girl” sold 200,000 copies and was considered one of the top novels of the year.

headline: The Vulnerable Mr. Bond
abstract: Even Daniel Craig, who plays the classic symbol of cool, James Bond, has had moments of feeling shaken and stirred.
lead_paragraph: It’s funny how our emblems of cool can be so unsure underneath.

headline: In Toronto, the Oscar Smackdown Gets an Early Start
abstract: After opening blows in Venice and Telluride, Colo., the Academy Awards fray is under way in earnest at the Toronto International Film Festival.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — Through much of August, Harvey Weinstein seemed to be slugging his way through a one-film Oscar fight. While most of the movie world was waiting out the end of the summer blockbuster season, Mr. Weinstein was waging an early campaign for his film “Lee Daniels’ the Butler.”

headline: Fall TV Preview: Old Hits Return, New Worlds Open
abstract: A look at notable new and returning series arriving this fall.
lead_paragraph: All dates are subject to change.

headline: Shows to Watch For
abstract: A selection of notable fall television programming.
lead_paragraph: A selection of notable fall television programming.

headline: Corruption in the Confederacy
abstract: How Southern agents used the Act of Sequestration to enrich themselves at the expense of their innocent neighbors.
lead_paragraph: Between 1862 and 1865, officers of the Confederate District Court of North Carolina, empowered by a new national law, confiscated and sold millions of dollars worth of property from North Carolinians accused of being “alien enemies.” The proceeds of confiscated and sold property were to be sent immediately to Richmond, but most was never reported. Many officers of the District Court, like David Schenck of Lincoln County, became wealthy enforcing the Act of Sequestration while thousands of their fellow Tar Heels were deprived of their property, charged with disloyalty, and in some cases even executed as enemies of the Confederacy.

headline: 3 Quiet Museums in Rome
abstract: Dropping in on these rarely visited, notably distinct spots creates a chance to experience culture away from the crowds.
lead_paragraph: One of the joys of Rome is its ability to make you feel as if there is a place that has spent centuries accumulating layers of beauty and history, patiently waiting just for you to arrive.

headline: Marseille Polishes Its Image
abstract: A European Capital of Culture for 2013, this French city has added so many arts attractions and revitalized so many neighborhoods that travelers may find it hard to resist.
lead_paragraph: Until the European Union named Marseille a European Capital of Culture for 2013, it may have been one of the most underappreciated cities on the Continent. Situated on a splendid Mediterranean harbor, surrounded by hills and blessed with an average 300 days of sunshine, a variety of museums, great restaurants and a vital, multicultural population, it has just about everything a visitor could ask for. Yet because of its rough-edged reputation, people usually preferred to spend their sojourns in the South of France in the quieter, smaller cities of Aix-en-Provence, Avignon, Arles and Nîmes.

headline: A Mortgage Market Out of Balance
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Interest Rates', 'Mortgages', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis']
abstract: The vast system that provides home loans to millions of Americans has long been a strange place. A surprising development has made it even stranger.
lead_paragraph: The vast system that provides home loans to millions of Americans has long been a strange place. A surprising development has made it even stranger.

headline: New Consoles’ Special Game: Waiting
abstract: The PlayStation 4 and Xbox One each have a long list of launch titles, but the most interesting games for the new consoles seem to be coming next year.
lead_paragraph: Video game players are always excited to get their hands on new consoles, and in November, two new game machines are scheduled to be introduced: Microsoft’s Xbox One and Sony’s PlayStation 4. But while new consoles usually lead to better games, often that happens only in the long run. Some of the final games made for aging consoles have been better than the first games that were released for brand-new systems. Neither the PlayStation 3 in 2006 nor the Xbox 360 a year earlier went on sale with a single memorable initial title.

headline: High Holy Days, and Cantors Are on the Road Again
abstract: Hundreds if not thousands of ordained cantors, seminary students and trained laity crisscross the globe for Rosh Hashana and Yom Kippur to serve synagogues without full-time cantors.
lead_paragraph: On the eve of Rosh Hashana last year, as Lois Kittner was passing through security at the airport in Newark, a security screener halted her. He had a question about several strange items in her carry-on bag. One looked like some kind of animal bone; the other was a piece of metal that came to a suspiciously narrow point.

headline: Defying Expectations, TV Actors Try Different Roles
abstract: Some familiar faces are shaking things up in new TV series.
lead_paragraph: Sooner or later, everything old is new again, especially on television. In a season when the Hollywood gene pool teems with fresh specimens, some familiar faces are shaking things up, defying stereotypes — and showing those newbies how it’s done. Mid-glorious-career, four veteran actors are revealing different sides of themselves. Maybe we don’t know them as well as we thought we did.

headline: Tennis in Spain Anyone? Anyone?
abstract: A tennis fan traveling to Spain found it difficult to keep up with the United States Open despite the country’s 13 players in the men’s draw.
lead_paragraph: I love tennis and travel: balancing those two addictions during the year’s four tennis majors is never easy.

headline: Hyphens, Hybrids and Getting a Hand
abstract: With more options, the name-change calculus is more complex than ever before.
lead_paragraph: The aisle has been walked, the cake eaten and the bouquet tossed. Now, what name or names will the happily married couple use? These days, the options have become more varied.

headline: The Power of Stepping Back
abstract: The case for giving your brain a break from the phone calls, e-mail, texts, meetings and all the other distractions of a workday.
lead_paragraph: I am the chief executive of my company, with responsibility for 30 people in the United States and another two offices overseas. As part of my vacation last month, I took two weeks when I was completely offline and didn’t check in to my office at all.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Introducing Bookends
abstract: In the new feature, two distinguished columnists address a provocative question from the world of books.
lead_paragraph: This week, The New York Times Book Review unveils its first redesign in six years. In addition to the updated look, the Book Review’s back page is now home to a new feature: Bookends, where each week two distinguished columnists (from a rotating cast of 10) will address a provocative question from the world of books. First up, Zoë Heller and Adam Kirsch answer the question: “Are novelists too wary of criticizing other novelists?” Ms. Heller writes:

headline: Image of the Day: Sept. 6
abstract: A procession in Nagpur, Maharashtra, during the celebrations of a local festival.

headline: Weekend Wheels Calendar
abstract: The National Muscle Car Association will be drag racing in Las Vegas this weekend, while more sedate classic car aficionados will enjoy the 20th annual car show in Ridgewood, N.J .
lead_paragraph: A bite-size sampling of concours, cruise nights, auctions, club races and other upwellings of car culture happening across America this weekend.

headline: A Survivor Celebrates Its Spunk and Spirit
abstract: The Issue Project Room has reached its 10th year, a cause for celebration for an institution that has endured many tribulations.
lead_paragraph: For any grass-roots performing-arts presenter, surviving and flourishing for a decade in the face of ever-changing aesthetic currents and a treacherous economy is cause for celebration. But for Issue Project Room, reaching that landmark birthday is especially sweet, given the tribulations that this institution has endured since its modest birth in 2003, including multiple changes of location, emergency repairs and the death of its beloved founder, the photographer, gallerist and event producer Suzanne Fiol, in 2009.

headline: Keeping the Rock in the Family
abstract: The core members of Haim — the sisters Danielle, Alana and Este Haim — used to perform with their parents. “Days Are Gone” (Columbia) is their album debut.
lead_paragraph: Before Haim was Haim, a rock band made up of three sisters, its members — Este, Danielle and Alana, surnamed Haim — were three-fifths of Rockinhaim, a covers band made up of three sisters and their parents.

headline: ‘What Would the Electric Lady Think?’
abstract: Janelle Monáe’s “Electric Lady” (Bad Boy) — more tales of the renegade android Cindi Mayweather — features appearances by Prince, Erykah Badu and Esperanza Spalding.
lead_paragraph: “There’s nothing that I will not try,” Janelle Monáe said by phone from a car traversing Maryland. The album she is releasing on Tuesday, “The Electric Lady” (Bad Boy), bears her out. Its 19 tracks hint at Stevie Wonder and spy-movie soundtracks, Jimi Hendrix and hip-hop, reggae and gospel. It has guest appearances by Prince, Erykah Badu and Esperanza Spalding. Her goal, Ms. Monáe said, was “showing and showcasing how incredible R&B music can be.” She added, “I wanted to make sure that I was creating a very diverse album that was deeply rooted in R&B music.”

headline: The Power of Positive Thinking Doesn’t Fail Wawrinka
abstract: In his breakthrough victory in the quarterfinals of the United States Open, Stanislas Wawrinka made his opponent look like the anguished Andy Murray of old.
lead_paragraph: Tattooed on Stanislas Wawrinka’s left forearm is a quotation that sums up his philosophy of life. It’s from Samuel Beckett, whose writings dealt with the struggle to find meaning in a bleak, nihilistic universe. Written on his arm in blue script: “Ever tried. Ever failed. No matter. Try again. Fail again. Fail Better.”

headline: Crossing Deadly Landscapes, Syrians Reach Havens in Lebanon
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Families keep making the journey out of Syria to escape government forces, Islamist-ruled rebel areas, and now possible American missile strikes.
lead_paragraph: AYYAT, Lebanon — A family of nine crouched on a sunbaked plain here in the Bekaa Valley, the wind whipping the plastic awning that was their only shelter. The children’s faces were smudged with dirt, the baby girl’s pale pink patent-leather shoes caked with mud.

headline: Judge Sets Restrictions for Apple on E-Books
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'E-Books and Readers', 'Book Trade and Publishing']
abstract: Apple will face restrictions in its agreements with publishers, but not the extensive government oversight sought by the Justice Department.
lead_paragraph: As punishment for engaging in an e-book price-fixing conspiracy, Apple will be forced to abide by new restrictions on its agreements with publishers and be evaluated by an external “compliance officer” for two years, a federal judge has ruled.

headline: Photos Tell a Tale of Anguished Deliberations
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Photography']
abstract: In the images of tense meetings in Washington, the faces and body language of the president’s advisers offer a guide to their conflicting opinions on Syria.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the images of tense meetings in Washington, the faces and body language of the president’s men offer a guide to their conflicting opinions on Syria.

keywords: ['New York Fashion Week', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Celebrities']
abstract: Can’t get a ticket to a show but still want to soak up the scene? The fashion blogger Heather Cocks offers insider advice.
lead_paragraph: “Fashion Week is fantastic people watching.”

headline: E-Cigarette Marketers Have an Eye on Teens
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Parenting', 'Smoking and Tobacco', 'Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Youth']
abstract: With sports sponsorships, celebrity pitchmen and flavors like cola and cherry crush, e-cigarette marketers look to be aiming their product squarely at teens — and new numbers suggest that it’s working.
lead_paragraph: I was standing outside our neighborhood ice cream shop one recent evening when I noticed a plume of smoke rise above a gaggle of teenagers waiting in line ahead of me.

headline: European Automakers Hope Technology Can Lure Younger Buyers
abstract: Auto industry managers at the Frankfurt auto show will try to focus on shiny new technologies rather than the terrible state of the European car market.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Sometimes it is more fun to dream about the future than to dwell on the present, especially if you are a European car executive.

headline: Looking for Furloughs in the Jobs Data
abstract: The number of federal employees who report working part time because they cannot get full-time hours — a sign they might be on furlough — remains high.
lead_paragraph: The number of workers on federal government payrolls has fallen only 55,000 since January, which might lead you to conclude that the sequester has not had much impact on federal employment. But the number of federal employees who report working part time because they cannot get full-time hours — a sign they might be on furlough — remains high.

headline: The Latest Reinvention of Kim Gordon
abstract: Ben Ratliff and Jon Caramanica discuss Kim Gordon and her first post-Sonic Youth project, Body/Head.
lead_paragraph: Ben Ratliff and Jon Caramanica discuss Kim Gordon and her first post-Sonic Youth project, Body/Head.

headline: Museum of Moving Parts
abstract: Jérôme Bel explores the notion of normality in “Disabled Theater,” and Boris Charmatz expands the doorways of dance in “Musée de la Danse: Three Collective Gestures.”
lead_paragraph: This fall, two French choreographers of note continue to push the boundaries of contemporary dance. In “Disabled Theater,” Jérôme Bel collaborates with Theater Hora, a Zurich company — many in the group have Down syndrome — to explore the concept of normality. It’s a risky, haunting work. For Mr. Bel, who has created acclaimed theatrical portraits of dancers like Véronique Doisneau and Cédric Andrieux, “Disabled Theater” extends on his study of people and their bodies. The production is a co-presentation of Performa 13, the latest installment of the performance biennial, and New York Live Arts, where it will be shown starting on Nov. 12. In his daring piece, Mr. Bel questions notions of handicaps and abnormality with his seemingly innocent gaze and understated showmanship. In doing so he reveals the disturbing, uncomfortable point at which fragility and strength meet.

headline: Think Like a Doctor: The Gymnast’s Big Belly Solved
abstract: Readers solve the case of a 15-year-old gymnast with a terribly bloated belly.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, we challenged Well readers to solve the mystery of the 15-year-old gymnast who suddenly developed a huge, distended belly and intractable constipation. More than 500 readers weighed in.There were actually two diagnoses:

headline: Trekking Through Europe Without Leaving the U.S.
abstract: The Metropolitan Museum of Art is hosting after-hours early-music recitals in its galleries on Sept. 17 and 18.
lead_paragraph: Parasols, crinolines and leather trunks are strictly optional. This month, New Yorkers can embark on the Grand Tour — the cultural pilgrim route through Europe that was once an essential part of a civilized education — without boarding a steamship. On Sept. 17 and 18, the Metropolitan Museum of Art invites visitors to its newly renovated European painting galleries for after-hours music performances that promise to be eye opening and thought provoking.

headline: Runway Report | A Grown-Up Crop of Men’s Sweatshirts
abstract: With the use of new fabrics and some more structured takes on an oversize cut, these sweatshirts show they’re ready to graduate from weekend wear.
lead_paragraph: Thanks to techno fabrics and an oversize, structured cut, sweatshirts are no longer just for weekends.

headline: As It Increases Production, Tesla Worries About Battery Supply
abstract: With a goal of building 40,000 cars per year, Tesla Motors is poised to use 40 percent of the world’s cylindrical battery production.
lead_paragraph: Tesla Motors’ recent growth has been striking, but at the Teslive event in northern California last July, Elon Musk, the company’s chief executive, made it plain that further expansion might be hindered by problems in the supply chain.

headline: If You Believe They Put Glenn Beck on the Moon
abstract: Glenn Beck’s “Man in the Moon” is a sprawling, vaudevillian show, inspiring a Grateful Dead-like community among his conservative fans.
lead_paragraph: Glenn Beck likes to think about “Man in the Moon” as his conservative fans’ version of a Grateful Dead show. Or maybe it’s a Disney movie — or maybe “The Wizard of Oz.” The sprawling vaudeville production tells the story of America from the bird’s-eye perspective of a droopy-eyed 40-foot moon that looks vaguely like Beck and floats overhead amid pyrotechnics, spoken-word performances, black-and-white movie reels and acrobatics. The immersive circuslike show premiered July 6 in Utah and can be described only as, well, trippy.

headline: Finding Wind in Their Sails
abstract: David Hertz and Laura Doss met in sailing school and married in a ceremony overlooking the sea.
lead_paragraph: Five years ago, when David Hertz and Laura Doss first saw each other, they were at sailing school in an anchoring class. Both were adrift in their personal lives, but neither was looking for romance. Instead, each was seeking the freedom from life’s travails that comes with casting off from shore.

headline: Envoy Says Syria Inaction Would Give ‘Green Light to Outrages’
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'United States International Relations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Samantha Power, President Obama’s new envoy to the United Nations, warned that President Bashar al-Assad of Syria had barely put a dent in his chemical weapons stockpile.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Warning that President Bashar al-Assad of Syria has barely put a dent in his chemical weapons stockpile, President Obama’s new envoy to the United Nations said on Friday that a failure to intervene in Syria would “give a green light to outrages that will threaten our security and haunt our conscience” for decades to come.

headline: Knicks’ Smith Given Five-Game Suspension
abstract: J.R. Smith, who will be returning from two knee surgeries, will serve the five-game suspension by the N.B.A. once he is healthy enough to play.
lead_paragraph: J. R. Smith will serve a five-game suspension next season for violating the N.B.A.’s antidrug policy, adding one more blemish to a checkered résumé.

headline: Rays Keep It Light Even Though Losses Are Mounting
abstract: Tampa Bay’s lighthearted approach, meant to build camaraderie and relax the players, will be tested again this year as the team tries to lock up a playoff berth.
lead_paragraph: ANAHEIM, Calif. — In a week in which the Tampa Bay Rays commandeered a hotel ballroom to hold their fantasy football draft; their outfielder Sam Fuld was summoned to pitch even though relievers were rested; and their staff ace David Price threw a bullpen session in the football uniform of his alma mater (helmet included), it surprised no one when a couple of buses waited Tuesday night outside Angel Stadium for a 20-mile sojourn to a sports bar around the corner from Manager Joe Maddon’s home in Long Beach.

headline: Seeking Investments That Are Profitable and a Little Bit Green
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Sustainable Living', 'Personal Finances', 'Environment']
abstract: Many investors are no longer looking for companies in the vanguard of the green movement, but those that are making a profit while showing concern for social and environmental issues.
lead_paragraph: SARAH KUPFERBERG’S youthful rebellion was slightly unconventional — she wanted to invest in green companies, not the big industrials her parents had preferred. But like most novice investors, she stumbled along the way, once putting money into a company that was trying to use buoys to turn ocean waves into electricity.

headline: The Ad Campaign: Spitzer Attacks Stringer on Term Limits
abstract: Eliot Spitzer started airing the first negative television ad of the campaign for comptroller, saying Scott M. Stringer cut a “back-room deal” to allow Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to run for a third term.
lead_paragraph: With polls suggesting that the Democratic primary for New York City comptroller is a dead heat, Eliot Spitzer has started airing the first negative television ad of the campaign. Titled “Our Voice,” it accuses his rival, Scott M. Stringer, of having cut a “back-room deal” to lift term limits and allow Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to run for a third term. The Spitzer campaign also started airing a Spanish-language version of the ad and a similar one on the radio.PRODUCER Siegel StrategiesTHE SCRIPT Voice-over: “Term limits were voted in by the people, until 20-year career politician Scott Stringer worked to destroy them, cutting a back-room deal to hand a third term to the mayor against the people’s will, even testifying before the City Council to get it done. Eliot Spitzer has always fought against the same special interests and back-room politicians supporting Stringer. Because Stringer didn’t only take away our term limits. He took away our voice. But this Sept. 10, we get to use it.”ON SCREEN The music, brassy and solemnly patriotic, sounds ripped from the score of a Western. There are images of Mr. Stringer, including one with Mr. Bloomberg, and a graphic of a piece of paper with “Term Limits” written on it being gradually torn to shreds. A phrase from a Christian Science Monitor article about the term-limits debate (“counter to the will of the voters”) flashes across the screen. As the music shifts to a more hopeful mode, the ad closes with images of Mr. Spitzer shaking hands with voters and patting them on the back, and a close-up on a Hispanic woman and a black man standing next to Mr. Spitzer.ACCURACY Mr. Stringer did testify before the Council in 2008, urging members to vote to extend term limits to 12 years, from 8 years. There is no evidence, however, that he was part of any “back-room deal” to hand Mr. Bloomberg a third term. He endorsed Mr. Bloomberg’s 2009 opponent, William C. Thompson Jr.As to whether Mr. Spitzer fought against “the same special interests and back-room politicians” that support Mr. Stringer, the claim is so broad that it is hard to quantify its measure of truth. If “special interests” refers to the unions that have endorsed Mr. Stringer, Mr. Spitzer was himself endorsed in previous campaigns by some of the same groups. However, as governor he also prominently clashed with one of the unions backing Mr. Stringer, 1199 S.E.I.U., over cuts that he proposed to health care. Mr. Stringer, like most major New York City candidates who are not self-financing, has accepted donations from people working on Wall Street. As attorney general, Mr. Spitzer led investigations into financial industry practices and made many enemies on Wall Street. The former governor is financing his campaign with money from his family’s real estate fortune.SCORECARD Although Mr. Stringer did support lifting term limits to allow Mr. Bloomberg to run for a third term, his role in the debate was minor. To accuse him of being part of a “back-room deal” is misleading. And although Mr. Stringer has been heavily supported by labor, a political action committee that threatened to raise major Wall Street money to back him has fizzled. The ad speaks to the caustic tone the campaign has taken in its final days; soon after this ad began airing on Thursday, the Stringer campaign went up with its own negative ad.

headline: The Ad Campaign: Stringer Says Spitzer ‘Held Himself to a Different Standard’
abstract: Hours after Eliot Spitzer attacked him in a television commercial, Scott M. Stringer responded with his own negative spot, invoking the prostitution scandal that forced Mr. Spitzer to resign as governor in 2008.
lead_paragraph: Hours after Eliot Spitzer started broadcasting the first negative television commercial in the Democratic primary for comptroller, his opponent, Scott M. Stringer, responded with his own negative spot. Titled “Clear Choice,” it invokes the prostitution scandal that led Mr. Spitzer to resign as governor in 2008.PRODUCER GMMBTHE SCRIPT Announcer: “The Times, Post and Daily News all endorse Scott Stringer. He’ll audit every city agency to cut waste so we can invest in jobs and schools. And he far outdistances Eliot Spitzer in integrity. Spitzer jailed people for prostitution and financial crimes, but when he got caught doing the very same thing, he held himself to a different standard, and walked away scot-free. That’s why The Times, Post and Daily News all say the choice is clear: Scott Stringer, comptroller.”ON SCREEN The announcer speaks over what sounds like the upbeat theme music for an evening newscast, while the screen shows images of Mr. Stringer at his desk and talking to a man in a pharmacist’s coat, a flyover picture of City Hall and an image of a school hallway. When the narrator mentions Mr. Spitzer’s putting people in jail, a person is shown from the back in handcuffs. This is followed by black-and-white images of Mr. Spitzer, with the words “Same Crimes” and “Different Standard” and a CNN headline — “Spitzer Won’t Be Charged in Prostitution Scandal” — flashing on the screen. The ad ends with an image of the New York skyline and a photograph of Mr. Stringer on the Brooklyn Bridge.ACCURACY As far as prostitution goes, the ad is accurate. As governor, Mr. Spitzer was caught patronizing prostitutes, precipitating his resignation. The assertion that he committed financial crimes, however, is misleading. In announcing that they would not charge Mr. Spitzer, federal prosecutors said there was “insufficient evident to bring charges against Mr. Spitzer for any offense relating to the withdrawal of funds for, and his payments to” to the prostitution ring. The Times, The Daily News and The New York Post have all endorsed Mr. Stringer.SCORECARD If Mr. Stringer stuck to reminding voters that Mr. Spitzer patronized prostitutes — something that few have likely forgotten — he would be on solid ground. Bringing in financial crimes stretches the truth and the available evidence.

headline: Holding Designers Accountable on Race
abstract: Bethann Hardison, the former modeling agent who has been an outspoken critic of the lack of racial diversity on the runway, issued open letters of complaint to leaders of the four world fashion capitals.
lead_paragraph: Bethann Hardison, the former modeling agent who has been an outspoken critic of the lack of racial diversity on the runways in recent years, issued open letters of complaint to leaders of the four world fashion capitals on Friday, naming dozens of designers who have used no black models or only one black model on their runways. The letter accuses the designers of being guilty of a “racist act.”

headline: The Biggest Losers: How Acura Slimmed the MDX
abstract: To get the new MDX with all-wheel drive down by 275 pounds, Acura made trims all over the car, including to the seats, suspension and body.
lead_paragraph: For any automaker, reducing weight is a challenge, with lighter vehicles offering benefits that include improved handling and reduced fuel consumption.

headline: Positive Sign: Lost Weight, Drinks Less
abstract: The MDX was already Acura’s best-selling model, but for 2014 the company tinkered with its success by making the vehicle lighter and more fuel efficient.
lead_paragraph: EASTON, N.H. — Honda made significant improvements, including better fuel economy, when it redesigned the Acura MDX for 2014. In part, the advances are a result of the new model’s shift in strategy — dispensing with the fantasy of an MDX-borne family fording streams and boldly clambering over rough terrain — transforming it into a reality show.

headline: Review: 2014 Acura MDX
abstract: The new, lighter 2014 Acura MDX can still be had with the heralded Super Handling All-Wheel Drive system, only now it’s optional. In this installment of Driven, Tom Voelk drives a front-drive model.
lead_paragraph: The new, lighter 2014 Acura MDX can still be had with the heralded Super Handling All-Wheel Drive system, only now it’s optional. In this installment of Driven, Tom Voelk drives a front-drive model.

keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: The New York Times invites you to test your knowledge of the Syrian civil war and its effects across the region in this quiz.
lead_paragraph: Can you locate President Bashar al-Assad in the photo above? Which American official once called him “generous”? Which countries provide the most support for the Syrian government? As the United States debates whether to strike Syria over a chemical weapons attack on Aug. 21, The New York Times invites you to test your knowledge of the Syrian civil war and its effects across the region in this news quiz.

headline: Fantasy Football: Rating the Rookies, Part 1
abstract: One key to deciphering the unknown in fantasy football is properly understanding each year’s crop of rookies. Here is an analysis of quarterbacks and running backs.
lead_paragraph: One key to deciphering the unknown in fantasy football is properly understanding each year’s rookies. How will their game transform from college to the N.F.L.? Can they keep up with a different style of play? Are they fast enough and big enough?

headline: The New Science of Mind
keywords: ['Brain', 'Genetics and Heredity', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Psychiatry and Psychiatrists']
abstract: A better understanding of the workings of the brain means that psychiatric disorders are increasingly seen as being based in biology.
lead_paragraph: THESE days it is easy to get irritated with the exaggerated interpretations of brain imaging — for example, that a single fMRI scan can reveal our innermost feelings — and with inflated claims about our understanding of the biological basis of our higher mental processes.
