lead_paragraph: Travelers will have two new well-known brands to choose from when they visit Mecca, also known as Makkah.

headline: Fog of Politics Descends on I.O.C.
abstract: The hotel lobby was thick with handshaking and huddling on Friday ahead of the International Olympic Committee’s coming votes, on a 2020 host city and a new president.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — For Istanbul, Madrid and Tokyo, the big news comes Saturday, when one of those cities will be chosen to host the 2020 Olympics. On Friday, the Hilton Hotel lobby was thick with handshaking, huddling, rumor-mongering and promises inevitably to be betrayed.

headline: U.S. Open Food Review: Better Late Than Never
abstract: Friday’s United States Open food review: Pat LaFrieda’s filet mignon sandwich at the East Gate Grill.
lead_paragraph: Because eating at the United States Open is a high-stakes game, we featured a daily review of items available at the food courts at the National Tennis Center.

headline: Make Your Selection of Sounds (Kitchen Utensils Are on the Menu)
abstract: Contagious Sounds, a largely DIY series devoted to emerging composers and performers, offered a double bill at Cornelia Street Café on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Entrepreneurship is all the rage now at music conservatories in New York and elsewhere, with tomorrow’s performers expected to absorb lessons in presenting, marketing and documenting their art. But for plenty of players now swimming the city’s musical currents, DIY is already second nature. Case in point: Vicky Chow, the prodigious Canadian pianist currently embedded in the Bang on a Can All-Stars, de facto house band of the entrepreneurial revolution.

headline: One Man’s Toyota Rescue Mission
abstract: Luis Bonilla of Connecticut is an old-school car guy. While others worship older muscle cars, he is devoted to the classic Toyotas that were made until the late 1980s.
lead_paragraph: WEST NYACK, N.Y. — Luis Bonilla was inching his brown 1982 Toyota Corolla from a tight parking space outside the Clarksville Inn when something caught his eye. As he watched his mirrors for traffic approaching on Strawtown Road here, a Corolla nearly identical to his, but with shinier paint, drove by.

headline: Finding Treasure in Old Toyotas
abstract: Luis Bonilla, whose daily driver is a 1982 Corolla, makes a hobby of customizing and racing Toyotas built until the late 1980s.
lead_paragraph: Luis Bonilla, whose daily driver is a 1982 Corolla, makes a hobby of customizing and racing Toyotas built until the late 1980s.

headline: Easily Trapped in the Borough of Their Discontent
abstract: In “Why We Left Brooklyn,” a party is being given for an actor who has accepted a teaching job in Ohio.
lead_paragraph: If you cut through the verbiage of Matthew Freeman’s “Why We Left Brooklyn” — and there sure is a lot of it — you find a moderately intriguing question at the core: do people outgrow that particular borough?

headline: Video: Acura Combines Good Handling and Crossover Utility in the MDX
abstract: The MDX still has Acura’s Super Handling All-Wheel Drive, but Sun Belt customers can save money on the third generation model by opting for front-wheel drive.
lead_paragraph: The Acura MDX was the first premium three-row crossover in the United States, and Acura was rewarded handsomely for reading the automotive tea leaves properly; it’s the company’s best-selling model. That’s impressive considering the MDX is also one of its most expensive.

headline: Vocational Training From a Label Near You
keywords: ['Culture (Arts)', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Vocational Training', 'Careers and Professions']
abstract: College graduates and dropouts alike are adding to their formal educations with vocational training offered by commercial brands.
lead_paragraph: Camille Lapierre always wanted to be a fashion writer. As an undergraduate at the University of Nîmes, she majored in English and spent a year studying journalism at the University of Central Lancashire. She went on to receive a master’s degree in literature at the Sorbonne, where she wrote dissertations on the works of Zelda Fitzgerald and Virginia Woolf.

headline: A Cabinet of Curiosities
abstract: The whimsical “Hatmaker’s Wife,” by Lauren Yee, brings to the stage a talking wall, a Cheeto-eating golem and other deviations from reality.
lead_paragraph: Though his silhouette is hardly that of a sylph, the old man at the center of “The Hatmaker’s Wife,” a shaggy new comedy by Lauren Yee, doesn’t seem to be made of solid flesh. As portrayed by the hardy New York stage veteran David Margulies, Hetchman the hatmaker might have been drawn into existence in looping pen-and-ink swirls, perhaps by the cartoonist William Steig.

headline: An Election in Russia (Well, Almost)
abstract: Putin may rue the day he let an activist run for mayor of Moscow.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — MOSCOW’S mayoral election may seem like just another Russian election. The incumbent, Sergei S. Sobyanin, a loyal ally of President Vladimir V. Putin, is projected to win by a wide margin. His only real challenger stands practically no chance.

headline: Williams Turns Match Into Latest Mismatch
abstract: Victoria Azarenka beat Flavia Pennetta, 6-4, 6-2, on Friday at the United States Open, and will meet Serena Williams, who defeated Li Na, 6-0, 6-3.
lead_paragraph: Victoria Azarenka’s ride to the final of the United States Open looked routine enough on paper. She avoided any serious threat of an upset, and her workmanlike effort resulted in a predictable trip to the final for the second consecutive year.

headline: Stargazing: Earning a Spot in the Front Row
abstract: Gone, apparently, are the days when being an actress on a low-rated sitcom was enough to guarantee a front row seat at New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: Gone, apparently, are the days when being an actress on a low-rated sitcom or a table-flinging Real Housewife was enough to guarantee an invitation to sit in the front row at New York Fashion Week.

headline: Volvo Learns to Speak a New Body Language
abstract: The Volvo Concept Coupé, first of three studies to demonstrate the company’s new design theme, is making its public debut at the Frankfurt Motor Show.
lead_paragraph: The key elements of a new design language for Volvo were unveiled last month in a preview for journalists in Gothenburg, Sweden, the company’s hometown. The Volvo Concept Coupé, first of three design studies to demonstrate the new theme, is scheduled to make its public debut at the Frankfurt Motor Show, which opens Tuesday for two days of press previews.

headline: Giving Mobility When Legs Can’t
abstract: A professor at the University of Delaware is adapting battery-powered cars like the Barbie Jeep to provide mobility to children who can’t walk.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK, DEL. — When automakers conceive vehicles for the youth market, they aim to appeal to drivers 18 to 24 years old. Cole Galloway skews much, much younger: he designs cars for the 18- to 24-month bracket.

headline: Fearlessly Mining the 1990s for a Soul Sound to Call Their Own
abstract: AlunaGeorge, a British club-soul duo, made its New York debut on Thursday night at the Bowery Ballroom, supplemented by a drummer and bassist.
lead_paragraph: “Body Music,” the debut album by the British club-soul outfit AlunaGeorge, is one of the chilliest albums of 2013 so far and also one of the most piercing. Over the last couple of years, this duo — Aluna Francis, who sings, and George Reid, who produces — has found the electrifying overlap between the British 2-step garage of the late 1990s and the fleet, attitudinal American R&B of the mid-1990s, with a sprinkle of New Jack Swing on top. It’s made for some elegant, sassy and deconstructed modern soul music, both energetic and also strategically broken, as if they were rewiring the parts in real time.

headline: The Week in Pictures for Sept. 6
abstract: Subjects include the West Indian American Day Parade in Brooklyn, chickens at a farm sanctuary in Watkins Glen, and Newtown cheerleaders in Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: Subjects include the West Indian American Day Parade in Brooklyn, chickens at a farm sanctuary in Watkins Glen, and Newtown cheerleaders in Connecticut.

headline: Jason Wu: Spring 2014 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Trinity Choir Celebrates Britten
abstract: Benjamin Britten fans have plenty to look forward to in the coming months, with a multitude of centennial celebrations taking place.
lead_paragraph: Benjamin Britten fans have plenty to look forward to in the coming months, with a multitude of centennial celebrations taking place.

headline: Battles Won, King Reflects
abstract: “American Masters” recounts the hard-hitting times of Billie Jean King, 69, whom many consider the most important female athlete of the 20th century.
lead_paragraph: She played tennis like a man: muscular, aggressive, fast on her feet. But Billie Jean King was all about girl power, crusading for gender equality on the court and off. And in 1973 — a year in which “Ms.” was added to the United States government’s list of acceptable prefixes, and the Supreme Court legalized abortion — she faced Bobby Riggs in the Battle of the Sexes.

headline: Picture This, Embellished
abstract: Elad Lassry will show new work at the 303 Gallery in Chelsea, further exploring the intersection between pictures and sculpture.
lead_paragraph: The Pictures Generation artists of the 1970s and ’80s plowed into the avalanche of mass-media imagery, making work that stood outside the seemingly omnipotent visual landscape of the late 20th century. Elad Lassry, a sought-after Los Angeles photographer who is sometimes described as a post-Pictures Generation artist, makes brightly colored, high-gloss images that can appear to leave little distance between the commercial and the analytical. But Mr. Lassry has said he thinks about such imagery as “free radicals,” pictures that toy with their conventions and ask questions about the nature of seeing — and, in doing so, become objects in their own right.

headline: Offbeat Artists in Brooklyn
abstract: Art converges with Brooklyn pride at BEAT Festival 2013.
lead_paragraph: Art converges with Brooklyn pride at BEAT Festival 2013. Beginning Thursday, the festival, named for Brooklyn Emerging Artists in Theater, celebrates its second year with a lineup of choreographers and directors who have created site-specific works for nontraditional locations in four neighborhoods. On the dance end, the choreographer Yanira Castro offers the premiere of “Nancy,” an installation focusing on the performer Nancy Ellis that explores ideas revolving around the representation of a performer. LeeSaar the Company pairs a Gaga/people class — the movement language invented by Israeli choreographer Ohad Naharin — with an open rehearsal at Congregation Beth Elohim, where the troupe is based.

headline: In the Mood for a Concert
abstract: BasilicaSoundScape, now in its second year, covers the full range of ethereal doom.
lead_paragraph: BasilicaSoundScape, now in its second year, covers the full range of ethereal doom, making the case that a unified attitude and mood are far better organizing principles for a festival than genre.

headline: The First Rule ... Well, You Know
abstract: David Fincher’s fable “Fight Club” is showing at IFC Center on Friday and Saturday at midnight.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to believe that David Fincher’s fable “Fight Club” (1999), at IFC Center on Friday and Saturday at midnight, could ever have been financed. Yes, as its name suggests, it has plenty of action. (And if you’re disgusted by the sight of shirtless men pummeling one another to a pulp, this film is not for you.) But what sets it apart is its merciless attack on consumer culture in sequences brutal, comic and brutally comic. Rarely has a film employed product placement to such deleterious effect for the corporations involved. “Fight Club,” based on the Chuck Palahniuk novel, is as rich in brains as it is in testosterone.

headline: Senior Swiss Teams in Atlanta
abstract: A look at the winners of the Truscott/United States Playing Card Senior Swiss Teams in Atlanta last month at the Summer North American Championships.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The winners of the Truscott/United States Playing Card Senior Swiss Teams here last month at the Summer North American Championships were Dee Adams and Alvin Stone of Memphis; Fred Hamilton of Palm Desert, Calif.; Mark Itabashi of Murrieta, Calif.; Dan Morse of Houston; and John Sutherlin of Dallas.

headline: The Time Is Right for Lobster
abstract: When Maine lobster is abundant, just toss it with pasta.
lead_paragraph: What do you do when a luxury item like lobster becomes so plentiful that the usual high price comes down?

headline: The Top of the Standard Turns 5 in Typically Glamorous Fashion
abstract: Last night, at the unofficial celebration of the first night of New York Fashion Week, A-listers gathered at the Standard to toast to the lounge’s fifth anniversary.
lead_paragraph: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Campaigning via Fortune Cookies
abstract: Ken Biberaj, competing in a crowded race for Councilwoman Gale A. Brewer’s seat on the Upper West Side, is trying to win votes with fortune cookies and coasters sent to restaurants and bars.
lead_paragraph: In the seven-person race to replace Gale A. Brewer, a longtime member of the City Council from the Upper West Side who is running for Manhattan borough president, one candidate is trying to put his name before the public by supplying fortune cookies to Chinese restaurants and coasters to neighborhood bars.

headline: Pictures of the Day: West Bank and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from the West Bank, the Democratic Republic of Congo, Russia and Iraq.
lead_paragraph: Photos from the West Bank, the Democratic Republic of Congo, Russia and Iraq.

headline: For Stepanek, the Show Starts with the Shirt
abstract: From Czech colors to tributes to New York, Radek Stepanek has become a tennis fashion icon of sorts.
lead_paragraph: Radek Stepanek is known as a very good doubles player, having advanced to the men’s doubles final of the United States Open with Leander Paes.

headline: After 60 Years, Weak-Kneed and Starry-Eyed
abstract: In the PBS series “Last Tango in Halifax,” a woman and a man who were attracted to each other as teenagers reconnect through the Internet after 60 years and are ready to fall in love again.
lead_paragraph: There’s nothing to be gained from saying unkind things about “Last Tango in Halifax,” a warm comforter of a series beginning on Sunday on PBS. It’s based on actual, inspiring events in the life of the writer’s mother. And it has been expertly assembled and fine-tuned for maximum heartwarming effect, so those who like this sort of thing will like it very, very much. The voters at the British television academy liked it enough to name it the best drama series of 2012.

headline: TV Lets the All-Stars Play Together
abstract: A PBS series of eight hourlong programs will display some of the nation’s top orchestra players performing as a unit.
lead_paragraph: Assembling an all-star orchestra might seem like a surefire proposition. Bring together the top musicians from America’s major orchestras and — presto! — you have an instantly awesome ensemble.

headline: Hamish Bowles, He Was Born Dandy
abstract: Hamish Bowles, Vogue’s new columnist, brings an international aesthetic developed very (very) early on.
lead_paragraph: When Hamish Bowles was a toddler walking down the street with his mother near their home in the leafy north London neighborhood of Hampstead Garden Suburb, an elegant Indian woman came toward them dressed in an elaborate sari. “Hamish rushed up to her and plucked at it,” his mother, Anne Bowles, recalled recently. “ ‘Mummy, mummy, look, it has gold threads,’ ” she remembers her small son saying.

headline: Finding a Perch for Fashion Week
keywords: ['New York Fashion Week', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: Can’t get a ticket to a show? The fashion blogger Heather Cocks takes you inside.
lead_paragraph: Can’t get a ticket to a show? The fashion blogger Heather Cocks takes you inside.

headline: Parliament Hearing to Focus on BBC Severance Dispute
abstract: The BBC’s former director-general has challenged testimony about how much the BBC Trust knew about payouts to departing executives.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — An increasingly bitter dispute between Chris Patten, the head of the BBC Trust, and Mark Thompson, the former director-general of the BBC, will get a public airing on Monday before a committee of the British Parliament.

headline: Heartily Proclaiming Their Health in an Exuberant Tribute to Britten
abstract: Trinity Wall Street’s music program begins a four-month festival to honor the composer’s centenary.
lead_paragraph: If and when the Minnesota Orchestra comes back from the near-death experience of its present lockout, you have to hope that it does so as robustly as the music program of Trinity Wall Street has from its own seeming brush with death.

headline: No Sleep for the Wicked
abstract: Every year everyone complains that Fashion Week is too jampacked with events. And then everyone shows up everywhere.
lead_paragraph: The e-cigarette lady was working hard. It was Wednesday night at a party given by Treats!, a newish fashion magazine that mostly eschews clothing in favor of showcasing top models in a state of near-total undress.

headline: Forget the Clothes, Show Me the New Bars
abstract: New bars and parties are synonymous during Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: The barons of New York night life treat Fashion Week as if it were their battle royale: a golden moment to unveil their new bars, clubs and restaurants to the island’s captive population of thin-limbed party seekers.

abstract: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the West Indian American Day Parade in Brooklyn, chickens at a farm sanctuary in Watkins Glen, and Newtown cheerleaders in Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the West Indian American Day Parade in Brooklyn, chickens at an animal sanctuary in Watkins Glen, N.Y., and cheerleaders in Newtown, Conn.

abstract: NBC’s new quiz show, starting on Monday, is getting attention for its unspoken ambition: proving that broadcast TV still matters.
lead_paragraph: Pop quiz: what does broadcast television need right now?

headline: The Liquid Lunch With a New Hue
keywords: ['Juices', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'New York Fashion Week', 'Diet and Nutrition']
abstract: Fashionistas are up to their eyeballs in the juicing craze, especially before and during Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: Regarding the juicing craze that is sweeping through the fashion world, and everywhere else lately, let us look at things positively. For one thing, it is probably more common to see guests at the runway shows in New York this week sucking on a straw attached to some sort of green goop than smoking a cigarette.

headline: U.S. Security Panel Clears a Chinese Takeover of Smithfield Foods
abstract: The approval by an important government committee came despite deep-seated skepticism by a group of lawmakers, who professed concern about a Chinese company owning the country’s biggest pork producer.
lead_paragraph: Smithfield Foods won national security clearance on Friday for its proposed $4.7 billion sale to a Chinese meat processor, overcoming one of the biggest obstacles to a takeover.

headline: Playing With Acoustic Tension at Entertaining Frequencies
abstract: Three days of experiments with the human voice, with performances and with interaction with the audience at the Resonant Bodies Festival in Park Slope, Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: The Resonant Bodies Festival opened its inaugural three-day celebration of contemporary vocal music on Thursday evening at ShapeShifter Lab in Park Slope, Brooklyn. The raw yet cozy 4,200-square-foot space lived up to its name that evening. In equal measures intelligent, playful, ambitious and moving, the program, performed by three gifted sopranos, illuminated the shape-shifting power of the human voice.

headline: Yahoo Releases Its First Government Transparency Report
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA)', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: Yahoo’s first government transparency report shows that government agencies in several countries filed data requests, but the most by far came from American agencies.
lead_paragraph: Yahoo on Friday released its first government transparency report showing the number of requests about Yahoo users that it has received from global government agencies.

headline: F.D.A. Approves a Drug for Late-Stage Pancreatic Cancer
abstract: The Food and Drug Administration has approved Abraxane, which in a clinical trial prolonged the lives of patients by a little less than two months on average.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration on Friday approved Celgene’s drug Abraxane for use in treating advanced pancreatic cancer, supplementing the thin arsenal available to fight the disease.

headline: Rowing Revives in the Gym
abstract: The rowing machine, plucked from the recesses of the gym, is suddenly a crowd favorite, even to those who have never picked up an oar.
lead_paragraph: Like many group fitness workouts, at first this one sounds like a ridiculous idea: Take what is by far the least popular cardio machine in the gym — one that involves sitting down, endlessly sliding back and forth — and devote an entire class to it.

abstract: Doug Stanhope’s righteous scorn and unsparing logic are on full display in his new stand-up comedy special, “Beer Hall Putsch.”
lead_paragraph: Doug Stanhope is the least ingratiating of comedians.

headline: Small Island? Cameron Has a Riposte for Russia
abstract: Prime Minister David Cameron praised Britain’s role in history after a Russian official was said to have called Britain a “small island no one pays attention to.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Stung by a reported slight to Britain by a Russian official at the Group of 20 summit meeting, Prime Minister David Cameron abandoned diplomacy and opted for oratory on Friday, lauding the country’s historic role in the fight against slavery and fascism and its artistic, literary and even sporting heritage.

headline: Georgia Tackle Overcomes a Stubborn Foe: Steroids
abstract: Kolton Houston went to extraordinary lengths to rid his body of steroids, and three and a half years after arriving at Georgia, he finally played in a game.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS, Ga. — Kolton Houston said he paid $10,000 to sit in a sauna with drug addicts for 31 days to try to sweat an anabolic steroid out of his body. A University of Georgia offensive lineman, Houston also took a pill normally prescribed for tuberculosis and had 60 ultrasound treatments to dislodge the banned substance, known as 19-norandrosterone. He tried hours of deep tissue massage, but each time his urine was tested, more than 100 times in three and a half years, the results always came back positive.

headline: Europe’s Lesson For New York
abstract: Fashion is the main event of the shows in Europe; in New York, distractions abound.
lead_paragraph: NEXT FRIDAY NIGHT, I’ll be leaving for London and the beginning of the European leg of the spring fashion relays. Do I seem eager to forget the New York shows even as they start? Not at all — as they say, I love New York! There are always a bunch of shows here that I look forward to seeing: Joseph Altuzarra, Marc Jacobs, Proenza Schouler, Oscar de la Renta, Alexander Wang, Narciso Rodriguez, Calvin Klein, Louise Goldin, Ralph Lauren. I’m curious to see what Thom Browne will do this season. That’s a goodly number of shows to anticipate, and I’m sure I’ve missed someone.

abstract: From Gisele to Rachel Zoe, Kanye to Beyoncé, we’ve got all the numbers that matter from the last week in style.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: A Cranky Cryptographer and Taking the Internet Back
abstract: Friday’s selections from around the Web include the story of a cryptographer who is too much of a crank to be invited to cool security parties but not cranky enough for the National Security Agency. Plus, an essay from a well-known security expert on why engineers need to reclaim the Internet from government snoops.
lead_paragraph: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: Legislation Seeks to Bar N.S.A. Tactic in Encryption
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Law and Legislation', 'Computers and the Internet', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Computer Security']
abstract: A congressman’s proposal would prohibit the agency from installing “back doors” into encryption, the electronic scrambling that protects e-mail and other communications.
lead_paragraph: After disclosures about the National Security Agency’s stealth campaign to counter Internet privacy protections, a congressman has proposed legislation that would prohibit the agency from installing “back doors” into encryption, the electronic scrambling that protects e-mail, online transactions and other communications.

headline: U.S. Official Predicts ‘War of Attrition’ Among Syrian Fighters After Strike
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: As a debate ensues on the severity of a possible strike on Syria, a State Department official said an attack would most likely not alter the military balance in the country.
lead_paragraph: VILNIUS, Lithuania — A senior State Department official said on Friday that the military strike the United States is planning would not fundamentally alter the military balance in Syria and would likely be followed by a prolonged “war of attrition” among the Syrian combatants.

headline: Bright Ideas in Brooklyn
abstract: A review of shows by Creatures of the Wind, Jason Wu, Peter Som and Rachel Comey.
lead_paragraph: Naturally, Rachel Comey sought advice about having her spring show in Red Hook and, naturally, the word was: forget about it. Fashion people will not come to that remote part of Brooklyn during such a busy time, even with the succor of free booze and dinner.

headline: Mirnyi Adds Another Grand Slam Title to His Collection
abstract: Max Mirnyi of Belarus and Andrea Hlavackova of the Czech Republic defeated Santiago Gonzalez of Mexico and Abigail Spears of the United States, 7-6 (5), 6-3, in the mixed doubles final of the United States Open on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Max Mirnyi of Belarus and Andrea Hlavackova of the Czech Republic fought back nerves in a contentious opening set to defeat Santiago Gonzalez of Mexico and Abigail Spears of the United States, 7-6 (5), 6-3, in the mixed doubles final of the United States Open on Friday.

lead_paragraph: Johnny Logan, a feisty shortstop who helped the Braves win Milwaukee’s only World Series, in 1957, died on Aug. 9 at a hospital near his home in Milwaukee. He was 86.

headline: Somalia: Government Says Report Rebuts Fiscal Mismanagement Charges
abstract: Somalia said Friday that a foreign investigative team hired by the government had rebutted allegations of financial mismanagement by United Nations monitors.
lead_paragraph: Somalia said Friday that a foreign investigative team hired by the government had rebutted allegations of financial mismanagement by United Nations monitors. The United Nations Monitoring Group on Somalia and Eritrea issued a report in July in which it charged that Somalia’s central bank functioned effectively as a “slush fund.” The government report, released Friday but dated Aug. 30, said that the “allegations and purported findings have no basis in fact.” Charges of endemic corruption have made it difficult for Somalia’s year-old government to receive money directly from donors and to reclaim overseas assets. Jarat Chopra, the United Nations group’s coordinator, questioned whether the law firm and the consultancy retained by the government had financial conflicts of interest. “The Monitoring Group is standing by its findings, which are based on the evidence it obtained during its investigations,” said Mr. Chopra.

headline: China: Official Denies Taking Bribes
abstract: Lei Zhengfu, a former Communist Party official in the city of Chongqing, insisted during an appeals hearing on Friday that he had not taken bribes.
lead_paragraph: Lei Zhengfu, a former Communist Party official in the city of Chongqing, insisted during an appeals hearing on Friday that he had not taken bribes, the state news media reported. Mr. Lei was convicted in June of having accepted nearly $520,000 in bribes to help a businessman, Xiao Ye, and he was sentenced to 13 years in prison. In addition facing the bribery charges, Mr. Lei was a victim of a blackmail ring run by Mr. Xiao, in which young women had sex with officials and secretly filmed the act. A video of Mr. Lei having sex with an 18-year-old had been in the possession of the Chongqing police, who had investigated the blackmail ring but had not moved to prosecute anyone because city officials kept the case quiet, the state news media reported. Bo Xilai, the party chief of Chongqing at the time, was himself subsequently charged with corruption.

headline: Uncamouflaged Affection At a Tribute to Michael Kors
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: The designer is honored by the Couture Council of the Museum at the Fashion Institute of Technology.
lead_paragraph: Michael Kors does not miss much, least of all a chance to deliver a jot of his self-deprecating wit. Surveying a room filled with notables who had turned out to honor him at the Couture Council of the Museum at the Fashion Institute of Technology luncheon on Wednesday, he said, “It feels a little bit like a bar mitzvah.” Not his own, of course. “I didn’t know anybody there.”

headline: Bill Cunningham | Simple Does It
abstract: The one-piece dress was the favorite of many women going to work the day after Labor Day, and more than 500 women attending a luncheon at Lincoln Center on the first day of Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: The one-piece dress was the favorite of many women going to work the day after Labor Day, and more than 500 women attending a luncheon at Lincoln Center on the first day of Fashion Week.

headline: Bank of America to Pay $39 Million in Gender Bias Case
abstract: The settlement comes on the heels of a big payout last week for a racial discrimination lawsuit.
lead_paragraph: Bank of America agreed on Friday to pay $39 million to women who worked in its Merrill Lynch brokerage operation, another costly settlement of a discrimination case filed by its employees.

headline: Bold Play by CBS Fortifies Broadcasters
abstract: CBS and its chief, Les Moonves, have given the broadcast world a shot in the arm by pushing distributors to pay broadcasters just as they do cable networks.
lead_paragraph: Leslie Moonves, the longtime chief executive of CBS, has heard the jokes about CBS being old and out of step because of the age of its audience and because it does not have enormous assets in the cable network world.

headline: An Artist’s Revenge
abstract: The Missouri painter George Caleb Bingham got back at Thomas Ewing, the Civil War general behind the infamous Order No. 11.
lead_paragraph: By the time the Civil War broke out, the Missouri artist and politician George Caleb Bingham had, in the words of the art historian Joan Stack, “achieved national fame as a quintessentially American genre painter.” The New Orleans Daily Picayune called Bingham “a delineator of national customs and manners.” But from 1863 until his death in 1879, this great American painter used his art and his political connections to destroy one man, Thomas Ewing Jr., a Union general and politician from Kansas and Ohio.

headline: New York Fashion Week: Jason Wu Spring/Summer 2014
abstract: Scenes from the New York fashion week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the New York fashion week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.

headline: Dutch Peacekeepers Are Found Responsible for Deaths
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: A Dutch Supreme Court decision related to a 1995 Bosnian War massacre could affect the willingness of nations to supply troops for future United Nations missions.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — In a decision that may pose new risks for countries involved in international peacekeeping operations, the Dutch Supreme Court ruled Friday that the Netherlands was responsible for the deaths of three Bosnian Muslim men because Dutch peacekeepers had wrongfully ordered them to leave the United Nations compound during the 1995 Srebrenica massacre.

headline: Tighter Rules Will Make It Harder to Get a Reverse Mortgage
keywords: ['Home Equity Loans', 'Elderly', 'Retirement', 'Personal Finances', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Mortgages']
abstract: Reverse mortgages, through which people over 62 can tap home equity, are getting streamlined rules to protect both borrowers and lenders.
lead_paragraph: The spigot on reverse mortgages has been slowly tightened over the last several years. Borrowers can no longer tap as much of their home equity as they could before the housing crisis.

headline: A University Band, Chastened by Hazing, Makes Its Return
keywords: ['Hazing', 'Marching Bands', 'Colleges and Universities', 'College Athletics', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: Nearly two years after a drum major was beaten to death by fellow band members in a hazing ritual, the Marching 100 of Florida A&M University is back on its home turf.
lead_paragraph: TALLAHASSEE, Fla. — Knees sprang up, way up, as the students stepped into their slow march during practice this week. Sweat cascaded down their bodies, but they held the pose, five seconds, again and again. Then, they burst across the field, horns and drums at full blast, in frenzied precision.

headline: Alimony for Your Eggs
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Divorce, Separations and Annulments', 'In Vitro Fertilization', 'Infertility']
abstract: Should divorce settlements include money for fertility treatments?
lead_paragraph: THE end of a marriage is always sad, but divorce can be particularly devastating for a woman who still wants children but whose fertility is on the decline. Her ex may have many years left to start a new family of his own, but by the time she meets a new partner, it may be too late.

headline: Trimmings, NYFW Day 2
keywords: ['New York Fashion Week', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Shoes and Boots', 'Handbags and Purses', 'Hats and Caps']
abstract: Accessories highlights from the second day of New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: Accessories highlights from the second day of New York Fashion Week.

headline: Highlights and Analysis: Costa Rica 3, U.S. 1
abstract: Live analysis of the World Cup qualifying match between the United States and Costa Rica.
lead_paragraph: The Snowclásico of last March is an indelible memory to some, but a bitter one for others. That sour taste was wiped away, at least a little bit, when Costa Rica defeated the United States, 3-1, in a World Cup qualifying match Friday night in San José. The loss ended the U.S. winning streak at 12 games.

headline: Helmut Lang: Spring 2014 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Rochus Misch, Bodyguard of Hitler, Dies at 96
keywords: ['World War II (1939-45)', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era']
abstract: Mr. Misch was widely described as the last living witness to the Führer’s final days in his underground bunker and remained a devoted admirer of the man he called “the boss.”
lead_paragraph: Rochus Misch, Hitler’s wartime bodyguard, who was widely described as the last living witness to the Führer’s final days in his underground bunker as the Soviet Army closed in on Berlin, died in that city on Thursday. He was 96.

headline: Booker to End Association With Start-Up He Founded
abstract: His association with the Internet firm Waywire had become an embarrassment for Mayor Cory A. Booker of Newark even as he seemed poised to capture a Senate seat in a special election.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Cory A. Booker of Newark, the Democratic candidate for United States Senate in New Jersey, is cutting all ties to an Internet start-up that he founded with money from well-connected figures in Silicon Valley and elsewhere, his campaign announced on Friday.

headline: Remembering All the Children
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Civilian Casualties', 'Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Malnutrition', 'Gun Control']
abstract: The slaughter of innocents in Syria is horrific, but what about the kids who die every day away from the media spotlight?
lead_paragraph: One of the most gut-wrenching scenes from Syria is captured in the images of row upon row of dead civilians. The dead include many children, swaddled in white cloths, angels laid down never to rise again.

headline: Why Janet Yellen, Not Larry Summers, Should Lead the Fed
keywords: ['Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis']
abstract: Ms. Yellen, the central bank’s No. 2, has the stature and wisdom for the top job. Mr. Summers championed the deregulation that caused the 2008 financial crisis.
lead_paragraph: The controversy over the choice of the next head of the Federal Reserve has become unusually heated. The country is fortunate to have an enormously qualified candidate: the Fed’s current vice chairwoman, Janet L. Yellen. There is concern that the president might turn to another candidate, Lawrence H. Summers. Since I have worked closely with both of these individuals for more than three decades, both inside and outside of government, I have perhaps a distinct perspective.

headline: Obama Tries to Soothe Brazil and Mexico Over Spying Reports
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: Tensions have arisen since news organizations reported that the National Security Agency spied not only on American allies, but on their presidents and their inner circles as well.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — President Obama said Friday that he was seeking to ease tensions with the leaders of Latin America’s two largest nations, Brazil and Mexico, over reports that the National Security Agency had spied not only on their nations, but on them and their inner circles as well.

headline: On Syria Vote, Trust, but Verify
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: If the president wants Congress’s support, he has to be more open.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — THE documentary record regarding an attack on Syria consists of just two papers: a four-page unclassified summary and a 12-page classified summary. The first enumerates only the evidence in favor of an attack. I’m not allowed to tell you what’s in the classified summary, but you can draw your own conclusion.

headline: Montana Legal Officials Step In on Rape Case Sentence
abstract: The Montana Supreme Court is assessing who has the authority to correct a sentencing error after a judge issued a 30-day sentence for rape.
lead_paragraph: BILLINGS, Mont. — When a judge here sentenced a schoolteacher to 30 days in prison for raping a 14-year-old student — declaring her “older than her chronological age” and “as much in control of the situation” as the man who pleaded guilty — it set off a storm of outrage, magnified by heavy coverage on cable news and across social media. As the chorus of condemnation grew, the judge, G. Todd Baugh, apologized, saying that his remarks had been demeaning to women.

headline: In Moscow Mayoral Race, an Important Nonfavorite
abstract: No one expects Aleksei A. Navalny to win the mayoral election in Moscow, but as the anti-Putin candidate who was released from prison for the campaign, he is a critical part of the equation.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The campaigning in Moscow’s strange mayoral race concluded Friday evening on a fittingly strange note, with the main contenders holding dueling concerts in a last bid to draw large crowds of supporters before entering a 24-hour silent period before Sunday’s vote.

headline: The Double Bind
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Graduate Schools and Students', 'Philosophy', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: The structural sexism in academic philosophy affects the advice and guidance I try to give my female students.
lead_paragraph: This is last of five posts this week on women in philosophy.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Q. & A. with Guido Palau at Rag & Bone
abstract: The in-demand hairstylist explains the look he created for his first show of the season.
lead_paragraph: All eyes are on the British-born, New York-based hairstylist Guido Palau during Fashion Week. As the constantly-called-upon pro for designers like Calvin Klein, Alexander Wang and Marc Jacobs, Palau is known for setting trends with a flick of his brush. T caught up with the momentarily relaxed stylist at Rag & Bone, his first show of the season, to talk about the look he created, a good reason to retire a blow-dryer and how he stays in the zone.

headline: A.F.L.-C.I.O. Has Plan to Add Millions of Nonunion Members
abstract: Richard Trumka, the labor federation’s president, says a broad coalition could help restore the labor movement’s clout.
lead_paragraph: Richard L. Trumka, the president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., has a bold plan to reverse organized labor’s long slide: let millions of nonunion workers — and perhaps environmental, immigrant and other advocacy groups — join the labor federation.

headline: Gasquet, a Former Child Prodigy, Grows Into His Talent
abstract: Richard Gasquet, who graced the cover of France’s Tennis Magazine at age 9 and beat Rafael Nadal when they were both 13, felt the pressure of high expectations early on.
lead_paragraph: Stanislas Wawrinka and Richard Gasquet are first-time United States Open semifinalists this year. Both are in their late 20s; both have glorious one-handed backhands that have been making tennis aesthetes go weak in the knees for years.

headline: Violence Rises in Boston Off the National Stage
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Gun Control', 'Police', 'Boston Marathon Bombings (2013)']
abstract: Since the Boston Marathon bombings, community activists, clergy members and others have used the mounting tally of shootings to call attention to the everyday reality of violence in their communities.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — The Boston Marathon bombings produced an outpouring of attention to this city, but in violence-prone neighborhoods like Roxbury and Dorchester, some say the attention has made them feel only more isolated.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, September 7, 2013
abstract: Quotation of the day for Saturday, September 7, 2013.
lead_paragraph: “The school feels like it’s back.”

headline: Homesick Militants Are Offered a Way Back to Kashmir
abstract: Drawn by an attachment to India-controlled Kashmir, former militants have filed applications in order to return home from Pakistan-controlled territory.
lead_paragraph: LOLAB VALLEY, Kashmir — Many of them left as teenagers, impulsive boys fired by indignation who sneaked across the border to Pakistan-controlled territory without telling their mothers.

headline: When Jobs Are Not Plentiful
abstract: Weak employment numbers mean low wages and slow growth.
lead_paragraph: The widespread notion that the economy would pick up in the second half of 2013 was always overly optimistic. A rebound would require the replacement of this year’s ruinous federal budget cuts with a government spending plan for job creation. It would require a sustained recovery in the housing market to reduce debt and restore equity. It would require rising consumer demand, which in turn would require more and better jobs.

headline: Can Mr. Obama Avoid Mission Creep?
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Editorials']
abstract: The president hasn’t explained what “limited” military action would mean in Syria.
lead_paragraph: President Obama is scheduled to address the nation Tuesday on his plans for using military force in Syria. He will have a hard time persuading a skeptical Congress and an equally skeptical American public.

headline: The Group of 20 Tackles Tax Avoidance
abstract: The tax agreement was one of the few accomplishments at the G-20 St. Petersburg meeting.
lead_paragraph: The Group of 20 nations on Friday took an important step toward curbing tax avoidance by committing to exchanging information automatically on tax matters by the end of 2015.

headline: From Flooded Homes to Saltwater Marsh
abstract: One shoreline community in New York is the only one so far to embrace an ambitious post-Sandy plan.
lead_paragraph: Ten months after Hurricane Sandy, there still are residents of shoreline communities in New York who are waiting for more government help. But in one vulnerable neighborhood, Oakwood Beach in Staten Island, the best possible result is finally starting to happen.

headline: Long Island Club Emphasizing Tradition in Role as Walker Cup Host
abstract: The National Golf Links of America in Southampton, N.Y., has hosted only one major tournament in nine decades, the original Walker Cup match. Now the Cup returns.
lead_paragraph: SOUTHAMPTON, N.Y. — There was commotion at the National Golf Links of America on Friday, the telltale signs of preparations for a major tournament: cable wires strung through fescue; spectators wandering with clear merchandise bags; scores of maintenance assistants pacing the fairways, re-reading their firmness.

headline: Insurance Rolls to Rise in State Fighting Plan
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Medicaid', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Despite South Carolina’s refusal to expand Medicaid eligibility, a choice made by about half the states, enrollment is likely to grow under the new health law.
lead_paragraph: FLORENCE, S.C. — Brenda B. Culick has two stents in her heart and a severe wound in her right leg, injured while she was doing home repairs six months ago. But she cannot afford to see a cardiologist or go to a wound care center.

headline: Giants Hopeful About Status of Cruz but Not Pierre-Paul
abstract: The Giants’ leading receiver, Victor Cruz, was listed as probable for the season opener, but defensive end Jason Pierre-Paul was questionable.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The Giants are optimistic that Victor Cruz, their leading receiver last season, will be able to start their season opener Sunday night at Dallas. The status of Jason Pierre-Paul, the most disruptive of the Giants’ defensive ends, is less certain.

headline: One Way To Cruise Along
abstract: Bend your brains with this Saturday grid by Julian Lim.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — Note to self: There will be no “cruising along” with this puzzle. You will need all of your surviving brain cells and your complete set of wits about you* to make it through this brain bender by Julian Lim. You will not be solving this one ON AUTOPILOT.

headline: A Weapon Seen as Too Horrible, Even in War
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Civilian Casualties', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: Chemical weapons have caused only a small fraction of the deaths in Syria’s civil war, but the response they have provoked echoes that from wars around the world during the 20th century.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Wilfred Owen, the British soldier-poet, wrote in his best-known work, “Dulce et Decorum Est,” an effort to depict the horrors of chemical warfare, “If you could hear, at every jolt, the blood / Come gargling from the froth-corrupted lungs.”

headline: After 4 Decades, Memory of a Mob Killing Still Draws Gawkers
abstract: The mobster Joseph Gallo was gunned down at Umberto’s Clam House in 1972, and even though the restaurant has moved, tourists still come to look.
lead_paragraph: A guide leading tourists up Mulberry Street in Lower Manhattan on Thursday paused outside a restaurant on the corner of Hester. What he said was difficult to make out from across the street, but his gestures were clear. He cocked his thumb and pointed his finger toward the ground.

headline: Stephen Antonakos, Sculptor of Neon, Dies at 86
abstract: Mr. Antonakos made illumination an essential component of his work, using electrified neon gas as a painter uses paint.
lead_paragraph: His medium was light; his materials included glass, an electrical charge and Element No. 10 on the periodic table. The result was a series of abstract sculptures that illuminated indoor and outdoor spaces in cities around the globe, instantly recognizable for their vibrant colors and sinuous lines.

headline: Losing Support, Chamberlain Keeps Composure
abstract: Joba Chamberlain, almost an instant star when he arrived at Yankee Stadium in 2007 and who now hears mostly boos, has found comfort in the fact that he is still living out a dream.
lead_paragraph: Joba Chamberlain spoke calmly and without rancor late Thursday night after his latest disappointing outing in what will probably be the final season of his tumultuous Yankees career. He did the same in his previous poor outing, and the one before that as well, answering questions about his failures without any outward signs of bitterness or acrimony toward his questioners.

lead_paragraph: A New York City police officer and his two brothers, one of whom is also a law enforcement agent, smuggled military-grade firearms capable of piercing body armor and shooting down airplanes to the Philippines, prosecutors said on Friday.

headline: Vote Ends Australian Labor Party’s Six-Year Run in Power
abstract: The election ends six tumultuous years of leadership and ushers into power a strong conservative Liberal-National coalition.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Voters on Saturday delivered a stinging defeat to the Labor Party, led by Prime Minister Kevin Rudd, bringing an end to six tumultuous years of leadership and ushering into power a strong conservative Liberal-National coalition.

headline: Putting a Number on the Yanks’ Playoff Chances
abstract: A look at the Yankees’ postseason chances using a calculation that includes a team’s current win rate, the strength of their remaining schedule and their home-field advantage.
lead_paragraph: The Yankees are in unfamiliar territory for this time of year, scrambling to claim a playoff berth with less than a month left in the regular season.

headline: Debating a Fix for Hospitals in Dire Straits
abstract: While the Democratic candidates for mayor seem to agree on saving the city’s hospitals, the Cuomo administration is not throwing the struggling facilities a lifeline.
lead_paragraph: Of all the issues in the Democratic primary for mayor, one of the few that most candidates seem to agree on is that struggling New York City hospitals need to be saved.

abstract: Monte Kiffin has returned to the N.F.L. after spending the last four seasons working with his son in the college ranks.
lead_paragraph: IRVING, Tex. — Monte Kiffin looked impossibly fresh and enthusiastic after a recent practice in heat approaching 100 degrees. He promptly greeted members of the news media with a septuagenarian energy rush that surely had to subside into a nap at some point.

headline: De Blasio Goes Stumping in Quinn Country
abstract: Bill de Blasio, in campaigning at the neighborhood subway stop of Christine C. Quinn, ventured into the home territory of one of his main rivals.
lead_paragraph: An increasingly confident Bill de Blasio on Friday ventured into the home territory of one of his main rivals, campaigning at Christine C. Quinn’s neighborhood subway stop.

headline: Gay Supporters Cheer On Quinn
abstract: Christine C. Quinn met supporters at the Stonewall Inn, the West Village pub known as the birthplace of the modern gay rights movement.
lead_paragraph: Before a backdrop of fluttering rainbow flags and the facade of the Stonewall Inn, the West Village pub known as the birthplace of the modern gay rights movement, Christine C. Quinn and a slew of her supporters trumpeted the Democratic mayoral candidate’s record at a rally on Friday night and asked “gay New York,” as one speaker put it, to rally behind her as one of their own.

lead_paragraph: The BronxWorks Heights senior center is a serene place, known for its whole-wheat bagels, soothing nap-time music and afternoon bingo.

headline: Lead Vanishes; So Does Some Hope
abstract: The Yankees got a strong outing by Andy Pettitte, and an outburst of offense, but with limited options available amid a banged-up and overused group of relievers, it was not enough.
lead_paragraph: Boone Logan stood between home plate and first base Friday night with his hands on top of his head, barely able to comprehend what had just happened. A baseball flew over a Yankee Stadium wall, perhaps taking with it the Yankees’ playoff hopes.

headline: Streak Ends for U.S. in Qualifying Match
abstract: The United States players arrived with a strut that turned into a stagger after a determined Costa Rica team humbled them, 3-1, in a crucial World Cup qualifying match.
lead_paragraph: SAN JOSÉ, Costa Rica — The United States players arrived here this week exuding confidence, chests ever-so-slightly puffed, as they carried a 12-game winning streak into this crucial World Cup qualifying match.

headline: What’s on Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (HBO) ARGO  (2012) Ben Affleck, above, directed and stars in this Oscar winner for best film. It covers a little-known chapter of the Iranian hostage crisis in which Antonio J. Mendez, a Central Intelligence Agency officer and wizard of disguise, was tapped to help free six State Department employees stranded in Tehran after revolutionary forces seized the United States Embassy on Nov. 4, 1979. His plan: to have them pose as a Canadian movie crew filming a science-fiction flick called “Argo.” John Goodman and Alan Arkin play the Hollywood makeup artist and producer who assist him in his mission. Bryan Cranston, his neck tendons popping, is one of his bosses; and Clea DuVall, Tate Donovan, Scoot McNairy, Rory Cochrane, Christopher Denham and Kerry Bishé are the escapees. After setting your pulse racing, Mr. Affleck “smoothly downshifts, easing from the high anxiety of the opener — which evokes 1970s political thrillers like Sydney Pollack’s ‘Three Days of the Condor’ — into something looser, mellower and funny,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. “Mr. Affleck handles his own roles, on camera and behind it, with a noticeable lack of self-aggrandizement,” she added. “In the end, this is a story about outwitting rather than killing the enemy, making it a homage to actual intelligence and an example of the same.”

headline: Rodman, Leaving North Korea, Says Prisoner Issue ‘Not My Job’
abstract: The former basketball star Dennis Rodman on Saturday professed his admiration for North Korea’s dictator while angrily rejecting calls that he use his pull to help a detained American.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The former basketball star Dennis Rodman left North Korea on Saturday after visiting with the country’s leader, Kim Jong-un, and unleashed an expletive-laced tirade while rejecting calls that he push for the release of an American missionary who has been detained by North Korea since late last year.

headline: What to Watch at the U.S. Open on Saturday
abstract: In the men’s semifinals, Richard Gasquet is seeking an upset against Rafael Nadal, and Stanislas Wawrinka is looking to knock off top-ranked Novak Djokovic.
lead_paragraph: Andy Murray and Roger Federer are not here. Big deal. On Saturday, the men’s semifinals pit Novak Djokovic against Stanislas Wawrinka and Richard Gasquet against Rafael Nadal, the four best players of the tournament on the men’s side.

lead_paragraph: A rematch of the 2012 United States Open women’s final will pit Victoria Azarenka and Serena Williams against one another for Sunday’s championship.

abstract: The release of the prisoners, including a Taliban commander who was arrested in 2008, comes as both the Afghan government and the Taliban have been demanding that such militants be let go.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — At least 18 Taliban prisoners, some of them prominent figures, were released by Pakistan and Afghanistan, with no guarantees that they would not rejoin the insurgency, Afghan and Pakistani officials said Saturday.

lead_paragraph: For this week’s profile of the president of Rwanda, Paul Kagame, by Jeffrey Gettleman, we commissioned Nadav Kander to photograph Kagame in London. The picture above and the one below are two outtakes from that May session.

headline: Russian Players Stay Out of Debate Over New Law
abstract: Russian players at this year’s United States Open largely avoided outspoken stands on the new Russian law that effectively forbids public displays of support for gay rights.
lead_paragraph: Marat Safin, the 2000 United States Open winner and now a member of the Russian Parliament, the State Duma, was one of 436 members of the body to vote yes on Federal Law No. 44554-6.

headline: Rag & Bone Collection Shifts Gears
abstract: For spring they just went with a clean look.
lead_paragraph: I was surprised to read in Style.com’s review of the spring Rag & Bone collection, shown on Friday, that it began with a starting point of “Little House on the Prairie” and women’s pioneer workwear. I’m wondering if I was at the same show. The silver painted runway, crossing a large industrial space in Moynihan Station, the slicked back hair and bright orange lipstick on the models, the over-the-shoulder bags with thin leather straps (slung like those of a quiver), and the streamlined, modern clothes, to me, suggested the pioneer workwear of “The Hunger Games.”

headline: Kerry and French Foreign Minister Appeal Together for Strike Against Syria
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Laurent Fabius, the French foreign minister, who appeared with Secretary of State John Kerry, argued that a punishing military strike was needed to redraw the red line against the use of chemical weapons.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The two most vocal advocates of an international response to a chemical weapons attack in Syria teamed up on Saturday when Secretary of State John Kerry and his French counterpart made an unusual joint appeal for military action.

headline: Unrest Behind the Dream Car
abstract: With the approach of the Monza race, Ferrari officials acknowledge, there has been the annual round of fractiousness among engineers, racing team officials and executives.
lead_paragraph: MARANELLO, Italy — A distemper was in the air last week in this immaculately manicured town of ocher and soft yellow masonry in Italy’s heartland, home to Ferrari since its fabled racing and production cars began rolling out of a rundown workshop here in the late 1940s. The disquiet is keyed to the imminence on Sunday of the Italian Grand Prix at Monza, 125 miles north of here in a wooded parkland that was once a playground for Italian kings.

lead_paragraph: TORONTO — Halfway through the Friday night screening of “12 Years a Slave” at the Toronto International Film Festival, a woman roughly 15 rows back in the auditorium finally had to cut loose.

headline: Two ‘Country Strong’ Giants Are Finding Way in the City
abstract: The second-year players David Wilson and Rueben Randle are ready to assume important roles on offense as the Giants open the season at Dallas.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — David Wilson and Rueben Randle each hail from Southern country towns, one-time Confederate strongholds that eventually endured the effect of shuttered mills and a declining rural economy. Their fathers worked long hours, or two and three jobs, to make ends meet, and Wilson and Randle were weaned on the value of hard work and perseverance.

headline: Jets Look to Smith, at Least for Week 1

lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — After the Pittsburgh Steelers drafted Ryan Mundy in the sixth round in 2008, he decided he would do everything possible to emulate Troy Polamalu, who was established as a premier N.F.L. safety.

headline: Variety: A Surprising Acrostic
abstract: A surprising acrostic by Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — It shouldn’t surprise us, really. If you’ve ever had the privilege of being the companion to a non-human animal, you know that they are capable of so much more than we humans expect of them. And that’s only one reason I loved this acrostic by Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon.

abstract: Dallas last won the Super Bowl after the 1995 season, and hasn’t been a contender since, but today the franchise is valued at $2.3 billion.
lead_paragraph: OXNARD, Calif. — “Imagine,” Jerry Jones says, sliding to the edge of his chair and spreading his arms wide, “that this whole room is covered with about an inch of lighter fluid.”

headline: Baring the Flesh at Parke & Ronen
abstract: It was standing-room only and models in various stages of undress, might have had something to do with that.
lead_paragraph: The design team behind Parke & Ronen, Parke Lutter and Ronen Jehezkel, are not exactly household names. Yet their show at Industria Superstudio on Friday was packed, with the standing-room-only crowd pressed in tightly behind those lucky enough to get a seat.

headline: Video: Visions of Venus

lead_paragraph: Venus Williams reflects on the various outfits that she has worn over the years at the U.S. Open.

headline: Connolly’s Brief, Great Career Holds Up, 59 Years Later
abstract: Maureen Connolly captured nine consecutive Grand Slam events in which she participated starting in 1951, winning 50 straight matches.
lead_paragraph: Maureen Connolly was not yet 19 when she won the United States women’s singles championship 60 years ago at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills, Queens. With her 6-2, 6-4 victory over Doris Hart, Connolly became the second player after Don Budge in 1938 and the first woman to win the Australian, French, Wimbledon and United States championships in a calendar year. (Rod Laver in 1962 and 1969, Margaret Court in 1970 and Steffi Graf in 1988 followed.)

headline: 2 Blasts Leave Over a Dozen Dead in Somalia’s Capital
abstract: The bombings were the latest in a series of deadly attacks that have undercut recent security gains here, officials said.
lead_paragraph: MOGADISHU, Somalia — Two bombings killed at least 15 people on Saturday at a popular restaurant in Mogadishu, the Somali capital, the latest in a series of deadly attacks that have undercut recent security gains here, officials said.

headline: Will the Yankees Win a Wild-Card Berth? Don’t Bet on It
abstract: Probability suggests that the team’s chances of making the playoffs, based on factors like run differential, are minuscule.
lead_paragraph: Probability can be funny. If you were dealt a 19 in blackjack, and the dealer had 20, you would still have a small chance of getting a 2 and winning. Similarly, in baseball, a team has a chance to make the playoffs even if it is behind in the standings in early September and has struggled all season to score more runs than it allows.

headline: China Looks West as It Bolsters Regional Ties
abstract: President Xi Jinping of China referred to Kazakhstan as an increasingly important energy supplier for China and an anchor for its new “marching westwards” policy.
lead_paragraph: ASTANA, Kazakhstan — President Xi Jinping of China, evoking the camel caravans of the old Silk Road that traversed the ancient plains of Kazakhstan on their way from China to Europe, said Saturday that he wanted to create a contemporary version that would bind together China and its Central Asian neighbors.

headline: At Virgin America, a Fine Line Between Pizazz and Profit
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Frequent Flier Programs', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Business Travel']
abstract: An airline whose sleek style rates highly with its passengers is still struggling to make money for its investors, and has lost $675 million since 2007.
lead_paragraph: ON Monday, June 17, at 6:30 a.m., Robin Wolaner boarded a flight from San Francisco to Seattle. An executive for a nonprofit organization, Ms. Wolaner was no mere traveler. She was bounty, the kind of frequent flier who makes or breaks airline profits, and she’d been snared by Virgin America.

headline: Find the Loan Behind the Loans
keywords: ['Payday Loans', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Credit and Debt']
abstract: When regulators accuse financial firms of predatory lending, shouldn’t they track down where these firms are getting their capital?
lead_paragraph: ONLINE lenders who charge borrowers stratospheric interest rates are coming under pressure from state regulators — and it’s about time. But to get at the root of the problem, the regulators may need to dig much deeper.

headline: In Egypt, a Welcome for Syrian Refugees Turns Bitter
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Syrians, along with other foreigners, were made scapegoats as the military took power and warned of external plots to destabilize Egypt, unleashing a suffocating xenophobia in the news media and on the streets.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Dozens of men with clubs and knives stormed a charity for Syrian refugees a few days after the Egyptian military ousted President Mohamed Morsi — making it clear they were no longer welcome in Egypt.

headline: Greek Prime Minister Says Positive Economic Data Points to Austerity Easing
abstract: Prime Minister Antonis Samaras said the Greek economy had the smallest contraction since 2010 and the improvement was largely due to a strong rebound in tourism.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Prime Minister Antonis Samaras of Greece seized on new economic data on Saturday that indicated the country was on track to economic recovery and promised relief to Greeks weary of years of punishing austerity.

headline: Prabal Gurung: Spring 2014 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Harvard Business School Case Study: Gender Equity
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Gender', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Graduate Schools and Students', 'Business Schools']
abstract: An aggressive program intended to foster female success brought improvements, but also resentment and uncertainty.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — When the members of the Harvard Business School class of 2013 gathered in May to celebrate the end of their studies, there was little visible evidence of the experiment they had undergone for the last two years. As they stood amid the brick buildings named after businessmen from Morgan to Bloomberg, black-and-crimson caps and gowns united the 905 graduates into one genderless mass.

headline: More Data Can Mean Less Guessing About the Economy
keywords: ['Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'United States Economy', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: The ever-expanding ways to track behavior online could produce much more accurate economic forecasts — and more informed policy-making.
lead_paragraph: DAVID TABOR, 37 and a civil engineer, runs an eight-person home-inspection company in Hurricane, W.Va.

headline: A Brief History of Data Revolutions in Economics
abstract: Today’s optimism among economists that Big Data will yield breakthroughs in the ability to measure, monitor and guide the economy has echoes in the past. The twin engines of innovation in the field have long been technology and necessity.
lead_paragraph: Measurement is the lifeblood of economics. And today, economists are optimistic that all the new digital sources of information — Big Data, in the popular shorthand — will open the door to breakthroughs in the ability to measure, monitor and perhaps guide the economy. That is the subject of an article I wrote, which was published on Sunday.

headline: Hanni Rützler
abstract: The Austrian nutrition scientist who was the first to taste Sergey Brin’s $325,000 synthetic beef burger talks about economics and “The Sound of Music.”
lead_paragraph: Hanni Rützler is an Austrian nutrition scientist and food researcher who has written extensively about food quality, safety and trends. She was one of the first to taste the $325,000 synthetic beef burger financed by a Google founder, Sergey Brin.

headline: My Home, the House of the Dead
abstract: In family lore, my childhood home was a Union Civil War hospital. As a professional historian, I sought to learn the truth about the house.
lead_paragraph: The narrow old carriage house of my childhood home in Alexandria, Va., smelled dank. My parents could barely park our family’s Buick station wagons in two of its three bays. The lawn mowers and an assortment of tools were stored in the third, part of a later addition.

headline: EpiPens for All
abstract: My child has food allergies. Amarria’s story — a death caused by allergy — is my worst nightmare.
lead_paragraph: AMARRIA JOHNSON, who attended first grade at Hopkins Elementary School in Richmond, Va., was an outgoing and energetic girl who loved animals, singing and telling jokes. She won reading and citizenship awards and planned to become a teacher. She also was allergic to peanuts.

headline: My Adventures in Their Clutches
abstract: The perils of driving a stick shift in rural France.
lead_paragraph: ON the morning I was supposed to take a stick-shift driving class in Manhattan to prepare for my high-summer trip to Europe, I received an ominous e-mail from my driving school: “The lesson today has been canceled. The driver’s wife just informed us that he was rushed to the emergency room.” Undeterred, I booked a stick-shift class at a rival outfit, determined to handle my vacation rental car with panache, and even (so I hoped) with grace.

headline: Betting on the Apocalypse
abstract: What can we learn from Julian Simon and Paul Ehrlich’s famous wager over the earth’s carrying capacity?
lead_paragraph: ONE day in October 1990, the iconoclastic economist Julian L. Simon walked out to get the mail at his house in the Washington suburb of Chevy Chase, Md. In a small envelope sent from Palo Alto, Calif., he found a sheet of metal prices, along with a check for $576.07 from the biologist Paul R. Ehrlich. There was no note.

headline: You Can’t Have It All, but You Can Have Cake
abstract: I have been thinking about bakeries a lot recently because I have been reading yet another spate of articles about having it all.
lead_paragraph: MY favorite thing is a bakery, and my favorite thing about where I live is how many bakeries are a dog’s walk away. Dogs aren’t allowed in bakeries, but many Manhattan bakeries have little benches in front so you can tie your dog’s leash to a bench leg and keep watch out the window to make sure your dog isn’t dognapped while you are buying a croissant.

headline: The Value of Suffering
abstract: Calamity cracks you open, moves you to change your ways. Sometimes.
lead_paragraph: NARA, Japan — Hundreds of Syrians are apparently killed by chemical weapons, and the attempt to protect others from that fate threatens to kill many more. A child perishes with her mother in a tornado in Oklahoma, the month after an 8-year-old is slain by a bomb in Boston. Runaway trains claim dozens of lives in otherwise placid Canada and Spain. At least 46 people are killed in a string of coordinated bombings aimed at an ice cream shop, bus station and famous restaurant in Baghdad. Does the torrent of suffering ever abate — and can one possibly find any point in suffering?

headline: 9/11: The Day Everything Changed, in Chile
abstract: It was Claudio Jimeno, and not I, who fought by Allende’s side and who was taken prisoner and tortured and never seen again.
lead_paragraph: IF I am alive today, if 40 years later I am able to tell the story of the Chilean coup of Sept. 11, 1973, it is thanks to the blind generosity of my friend Claudio Jimeno.

abstract: Readers debate whether surveillance needs to be reined in.
lead_paragraph: Readers debate whether surveillance needs to be reined in.

keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'News and News Media']
abstract: The stakes of a decision to intervene or not are much bigger than the political fortunes of the celebrity politicians involved. The media must respect that.
lead_paragraph: OUR country is about to make the most excruciating kind of decision, the most dire: whether to commence a military campaign whose real costs and ultimate consequences are unknowable.

headline: The Great Stagnation of American Education
abstract: The decline in educational attainment — more high school dropouts, poor-quality schools — has serious consequences for the economy.
lead_paragraph: For most of American history, parents could expect that their children would, on average, be much better educated than they were. But that is no longer true. This development has serious consequences for the economy.

headline: Preflight Turbulence for Commercial Drones
abstract: Though drones operated by businesses won’t be in wide use until 2015, some lawmakers and others are already moving to restrict them.
lead_paragraph: BEFORE long, drones will be flying across the nation’s skies, part of the way companies do business every day.

headline: Pulling the Curtain Back on Syria
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Biological and Chemical Warfare']
abstract: Intervening in Syria is a bad option, but it’s better than letting President Bashar al-Assad massacre his people and break international norms with impunity.
lead_paragraph: WHEN I was a law student in 1982, I escaped torts by backpacking through Syria and taking a public bus to Hama, where the government had suppressed a rebellion by massacring some 20,000 people.

headline: Reducing Economic Guesswork
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Consumer Behavior', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Research']
abstract: In this week’s Unboxed column, Steve Lohr writes that ever-expanding ways to track consumer behavior online could be a boon to those in the business of making economic forecasts.
lead_paragraph: In this week’s Unboxed column, Steve Lohr writes that ever-expanding ways to track consumer behavior online could be a boon to those in the business of making economic forecasts. This is because online data collection is scooping up all kinds of previously untrackable consumer behavior — everything from what you browse and buy on the Web to the location info given off by your cellphone — and making it available. But the data is fallible, too. A study that used internet search data to predict future home sales was more accurate than forecasts by experts from the National Association of Realtors, but a similar approach using searches related the flu was not. Read the full article here.

headline: House Republicans in California Find a Struggle on Immigration
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Citizenship and Naturalization']
abstract: Representing districts full of Latino voters who support a path to citizenship for illegal immigrants, some G.O.P. congressmen in California are rejecting the party line.
lead_paragraph: HANFORD, Calif. — When Representative David Valadao came out in favor of a path to citizenship for millions of people living in the country illegally at an open forum this summer, the crowd erupted in applause, and young activists nearly knocked one another down as they rushed to embrace him.

headline: Unseeded American Advances to Girls Final
abstract: Alicia Black shrugged off leg pains and a 3-5 deficit in the first set to reach the United States Open junior girls singles final with a 7-5, 6-3 victory over seventh-seeded Antonia Lottner of Germany.
lead_paragraph: Alicia Black shrugged off leg pains and a 3-5 deficit in the first set to reach the United States Open junior girls singles final with a 7-5, 6-3 victory over seventh-seeded Antonia Lottner of Germany.

headline: A Dearth of Investment in Young Workers
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Youth', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'United States Economy', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: The bleak job picture for young Americans doesn’t bode well for their long-term careers, or for the economy’s future.
lead_paragraph: ONE of the most troubling features of the slow economic recovery is that it has largely bypassed young people. This doesn’t bode well for the future of the American economy.

headline: The Chatter for Sunday, September 8
abstract: Notable quotes from business articles that appeared in The New York Times last week.
lead_paragraph: “You’re eating away little by little at the infrastructure and effectiveness of government.”

headline: Eau de Prabal Gurung
abstract: The show was kind of cool and weird and also suggested a deeper meaning, which may be equally elusive.
lead_paragraph: So the future is weighing heavily on people’s minds these days, though at Fashion Week we are talking about the distant future. The early days of the New York collections have already seen a surfeit of strangely proportioned clothes (Peter Som and Suno) and matted-down hair (Jason Wu, Rag & Bone, Prabal Gurung) and boldly colored lips (Rag & Bone, Prabal again), and nothing really of this time.
