lead_paragraph: While President Obama seeks Congress’ approval for military action in Syria, Writer at Large Sam Tanenhaus looks at earlier American presidents who worked to expand their powers.

headline: The Hands-Tied Presidency
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: In asking that Congress be heard, President Obama might have been acknowledging that he holds office at a time when the presidency itself has ceded much of its power and authority to Congress.
lead_paragraph: AS the debate on the Syria intervention began in Congress last week, some wondered why President Obama, who has been frustrated repeatedly by Republican legislators, would risk being thwarted yet again and possibly jeopardize the ability of future presidents to pursue ambitious foreign policy objectives.

abstract: Trying for gutsy in handling Assad and his cronies, the president pauses for a gut check.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — THE winner of the Nobel Peace Prize had been up late pleading for war.

headline: Sept. 7: Where the Candidates Are Today
abstract: The candidates’ daily campaign schedule at a glance.
lead_paragraph: Planned events for the mayoral candidates, according to the campaigns and organizations they are affiliated with. Times are listed as scheduled but frequently change.

headline: Gambling With the Presidency

abstract: Can President Obama’s credibility survive the Congressional debate over whether to bomb Syria?
lead_paragraph: LADIES and gentlemen, welcome to a foreign policy fiasco.

headline: Shots Fired to the Body Often Engender Shrugs Instead of Spats
abstract: Body shots have long been a common practice in tennis. But they seem to have become more controversial or at least more commented upon lately.
lead_paragraph: In her first-round doubles match at the United States Open on Monday, Venus Williams channeled her inner Don Drysdale, slamming ball after ball off the bodies of her opponents, Silvia Soler-Espinosa and Carla Suárez Navarro.

headline: Same War, Different Country
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Who will prevail in the Arab awakening, Hobbes, Khomeini or Jefferson?
lead_paragraph: SAY, did you see the news from Libya — the last country we bombed because its leader crossed a red line or was about to? Here’s a dispatch from Libya in the Sept. 3 British newspaper, The Independent:

headline: Mexico’s Coach Is Fired After Home Loss to Honduras
abstract: Mexico fired the coach of its national soccer team after Friday night’s home loss to Honduras in World Cup qualifying.
lead_paragraph: José Manuel de la Torre was fired as manager of Mexico’s national team hours after Honduras rallied for a 2-1 victory in a World Cup qualifying match at Estadio Azteca on Friday night.

headline: Deportees, Then and Now
abstract: Immigrant workers, anonymous and exploited, are still trapped in a broken system.
lead_paragraph: Congress returns from recess this week with the immigration system still failing and repairs still undone. President Obama is still promising solutions, but his administration remains a huge part of the problem.

headline: Federal Oversight on Public Defense
abstract: The right to a lawyer gets a boost from the Justice Department.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department recently signaled that it may be taking on a greater role in assuring the quality of indigent defense in state criminal systems. It filed a brief last month in a lawsuit brought by the American Civil Liberties Union of Washington against two towns for failing to provide adequate legal assistance for poor defendants.

headline: Banning a Pseudo-Therapy
keywords: ['Therapy and Rehabilitation', 'Homosexuality', 'Law and Legislation', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Editorials']
abstract: The old idea that homosexuality is an illness that can be “cured” may at last be headed for the trash heap.
lead_paragraph: A discredited therapy that purports to convert homosexuals to heterosexuals was repudiated again late last month. This time, a three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit unanimously upheld a California law preventing licensed therapists from counseling minors to change their sexual orientation from gay to straight.

headline: New York Fashion Week: Lacoste Spring/Summer 2014
abstract: Scenes from the New York fashion week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the New York fashion week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.

headline: Hey, You Calling Me an Invasive Species?
abstract: With global warming altering habitats, it hardly matters whether a plant is called native or nonnative.
lead_paragraph: Since the 1880s, there have been blue gum eucalyptus trees growing on San Francisco’s Mount Sutro, which lies just south of Golden Gate Park. Recently, the University of California, San Francisco, which owns most of Mount Sutro, has been trying to thin the dense eucalyptus forest. The reason is fire control — eucalyptus trees are “fire intensive,” shedding a lot of debris and burning with unusual volatility. But the effort to cull the Mount Sutro forest has been met with strident protest by residents who want to see the eucalyptus left untouched.

headline: The Short Sentence as Gospel Truth
abstract: Express your most powerful thought in the fewest words.
lead_paragraph: As a writer and teacher, I try to learn something about the craft every day. A gold coin of inspiration may come in my reading, in a conversation with another writer or even in the process of revising this essay.

headline: Cambodian Opposition Rallies for U.N. Help on Vote Inquiry
abstract: Thousands of supporters of Cambodia’s opposition rallied on Saturday against Prime Minister Hun Sen’s authoritarian government in a potent symbol of defiance.
lead_paragraph: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia — Thousands of supporters of Cambodia’s opposition rallied against the authoritarian government of Prime Minister Hun Sen on Saturday, calling for the United Nations to help lead an investigation into accusations of cheating in the July 28 national elections that the governing party says it won.

headline: From Myspace’s Ashes, Silicon Start-Ups Rise
abstract: Almost every member of Myspace’s founding team has begun a new venture, and many are among the leaders of Los Angeles’s blossoming start-up industry, Silicon Beach.
lead_paragraph: IT is hardly uncommon for founders and employees of successful companies to cash in their chips and go on to start other successful companies. Perhaps the best-known example is PayPal, the Web payment service whose leaders went on to found and invest in a bunch of other companies — YouTube, LinkedIn, Yelp, Tesla — and to earn the nickname the PayPal mafia.

headline: For 2020 Olympics, I.O.C. Picks Tokyo, Considered Safe Choice
abstract: Tokyo was selected to host the 2020 Summer Games, beating out Istanbul and Madrid in a major victory for a country still recovering from a nuclear plant meltdown.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — Tokyo was selected Saturday to host the 2020 Summer Olympics in what was considered a safe rather than transformative choice in a time of political and economic uncertainty around the globe.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Sept. 8
abstract: Denis McDonough, the White House chief of staff, will appear on all five major Sunday shows to talk about the administration’s stance on Syria.
lead_paragraph: Congress will return from recess on Monday and confront the question of whether to authorize a military intervention in Syria. With many lawmakers leaning against giving President Obama the go-ahead, Denis McDonough, the White House chief of staff, will appear on all five major Sunday shows.

headline: Protests Fill City Streets Across Brazil
abstract: Fewer people turned out compared with the June wave of mass protests, pointing to the way that the flare-up of public ire over corruption has given way to more fragmented movements.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Thousands of demonstrators took to the streets in dozens of cities across Brazil on Saturday and were dispersed violently by the police while mounting some of the most vigorous expressions of anger with governing institutions since an outburst of antigovernment demonstrations shook the political establishment in June.

headline: 9 Militants Are Reported Killed in Egyptian Army Raid in Sinai
abstract: The operation was part of an effort to stamp out militant havens in Sinai, where reports of deadly attacks on the police and security forces have become an almost daily occurrence.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — A military spokesman said the Egyptian Army killed nine Islamist extremists in an operation on Saturday, part of a campaign in recent weeks to quell militant activity in the lawless Sinai region. The death toll could not be confirmed.

headline: Live Stream | Alexander Wang’s Spring 2014 Collection at New York Fashion Week
abstract: The Spring 2014 women’s collection from Alexander Wang at New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: The Spring 2014 women’s collection from Alexander Wang at New York Fashion Week.

headline: Obama’s Battle for Syria Votes, Taut and Uphill
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: People on Capitol Hill said the initial campaign for strikes against Syria proved unpersuasive, but administration officials insist the debate will continue when Congress returns from recess.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Each morning for the last week, at 7:45, more than a dozen White House aides have mustered in the corner office of President Obama’s chief of staff, Denis R. McDonough, to get their marching orders for what has become the most intense, uphill lobbying campaign of the Obama presidency.

headline: Daniel Lubetzky of Kind Snacks, on Reaching Multiple Goals
abstract: A chief executive says creative minds can find ways not to choose between two objectives, but to accomplish both.
lead_paragraph: This interview with  Daniel Lubetzky, the chief executive of Kind Snacks, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Men’s Final: A Showdown of No. 1 vs. No. 2
abstract: Novak Djokovic, who beat Stanislas Wawrinka, will face Rafael Nadal, who beat Richard Gasquet, in the United States Open men’s final, the 37th episode of their long-running miniseries.
lead_paragraph: The classic match has become a Grand Slam ritual for Novak Djokovic, who it would seem was put on this earth to push his and others’ limits on Paris clay, Wimbledon grass and the hardcourts of New York and Melbourne.

headline: Stargazing: Friday’s Faces and Weekend Grills at New York Fashion Week
abstract: Kanye West attends Louise Goldin; Allison Williams attends Prabal Gurung; Russel Westbrook shows up to Rag & Bone with Anna Wintour, and other scenes from the front row.
lead_paragraph: It should probably come as no surprise that a slim figure and attractive face are advantages in fashion week’s game of musical chairs, but sometimes it takes a visual reminder or two to iron that home. At least at Cushnie et Ochs there was no room for disguise. If you wanted to fit into one of the label’s come-hither dresses, of which there were many, paired with sharp heels, and stalk around Milk Studios, you would have to rethink your lunch order. (Burger no bun, please.) “Revenge” actress Ashley Madekwe was practically poured into her red dress but was still enjoying the experience. “I’m just soaking it all in,” she said. She added, having once lived in New York, that sometimes it takes just a wardrobe switch to fit in. “Everyone here has a great leather jacket.”

headline: Seeking Vital Signs in a Lifetime Warranty
abstract: If a product is covered by a lifetime warranty, who is to say it has reached the end of its life? A reader asks the Haggler for help in dealing with a backpack’s manufacturer.
lead_paragraph: THE Haggler gets a lot of e-mail from people with expired warranties on broken products, accompanied by plaintive lines like “Hey, I know the warranty ended a year ago, but I think the company should stand by its blah, blah, blah.”

headline: Unusual Open Final: The Usual Suspects Meet
abstract: The last time there was a repeat in the women’s final at the Open was in 2001, when Serena Williams defeated her sister Venus.
lead_paragraph: In a departure from the usually unpredictable results in women’s tennis, Sunday afternoon will have a pronounced “same time, same place” air to it when No. 1 Serena Williams and No. 2 Victoria Azarenka face off in the United States Open final for a second consecutive year.

headline: A Résumé That Stood Out
abstract: An insurance executive has traveled the world — from Switzerland to Australia to New York — in her career, but will always remember how her application was noticed by an early employer.

headline: Red Sox Again Bash Yanks, Who Are Running Out of Pitchers and Time

lead_paragraph: For three consecutive days, the Boston Red Sox have battered the Yankees’ pitching staff. Thunderous sounds have reverberated throughout Yankee Stadium, with one crushing blow after another. Boston’s hitters have not been fooled.

abstract: Renewed calls for immunization legislation have followed a measles outbreak at a North Texas church and soaring rates of whooping cough across the state.
lead_paragraph: A measles outbreak in a North Texas megachurch, where vaccinations were discouraged, and soaring rates of whooping cough across the state are drawing renewed calls for immunization legislation, which some lawmakers and medical professionals argue would help the state prevent and respond to public health crises.

headline: A Conductor’s Concert Strikes a Sour Note in Kashmir

headline: Readers School Me on Syria
abstract: Readers comment on my latest column about Syria
lead_paragraph: Here’s your chance to weigh in on my Syria views: My Sunday column is on line and argues that intervening with cruise missile strikes is our least bad option. Most of my friends disagree with me, perhaps a sign that my views aren’t so persuasive, and plenty of people are trying to make me see the light. So read the column and post your thoughts–and please be civil to each other.

headline: Storied U.S. Barracks Closes With Little Fanfare
abstract: Campbell Barracks in Heidelberg, Germany, which, as the headquarters of the United States Army in Europe, issued the orders for millions of American soldiers, closed on Friday.
lead_paragraph: HEIDELBERG, Germany — For Germans and Americans who had long imagined a dramatic coda to the cold war, it came instead in a few solemn, quiet moments. After both national anthems were played, seven American and five German soldiers lowered their national colors, marched at the edge of a bedraggled parade ground and carefully folded the flags for the last time.

headline: Jack Beal, Optimistic New Realist Painter, Dies at 82
abstract: Mr. Beal made minutely detailed portraits and narrative works, including large murals in the Times Square subway station.
lead_paragraph: Jack Beal, whose pensive nudes, densely detailed still lifes and earnest public murals depicting ancient myths and modern life helped define the New Realism of the 1960s and ’70s, a school of figurative painting notable for being unfashionable at the time, died on Aug. 29 in Oneonta, N.Y. He was 82.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Stripped-Down Makeup at Alexander Wang
abstract: Diane Kendal created a look that had models runway ready in less than five minutes.
lead_paragraph: Rarely does a “no-makeup” look truly mean just that. But at the Alexander Wang show this evening, there wasn’t a speck of foundation, eye shadow or lipstick anywhere in sight. “I call it raw beauty,” the makeup artist Diane Kendal said of the barely-there, extreme-minimalist look she created backstage. Proving the point, her routine took all of five minutes: she patted Nars Skin Aqua Gel Luminous Oil-Free Moisturizer on the skin to give it a “nice luminous” quality and dotted stick concealer down the sides of the nose and over any blemishes or redness. Lashes were curled; arches were set with a quick pass of brow gel. And that’s it. “It’s actually hard to tell which models have their makeup done and which don’t,” one observer noted, puzzled. Kendal couldn’t be happier about that. “Alexander loved that the girls looked so cool [when they came in for casting],” she said. “So we agreed that the more you do with makeup, the less cool it looks.” The models seemed to embrace the no-fuss effect. “It’s very au naturel,” Joan Smalls said, adding that “this is the fastest makeup I’ve had done for a show.” Jourdan Dunn called the pared-down approach “laid-back and easy,” while Hanne Gaby Odiele said, “It’s simple but fresh; it’s like how we walked in — but a little less tired.”

headline: The Day’s Best in College Football
abstract: Teams, players and games that stood out in the first week of college football.
lead_paragraph: SHILIQUE CALHOUN The Michigan State defensive end, right, returned a fumble 4 yards for a touchdown and ran back an interception 56 yards for a score in a 21-6 win over visiting South Florida. Calhoun also returned a fumble for a touchdown last week.

headline: Michigan Honors Its Past (Present Isn’t Bad, Either)
abstract: Devin Gardner and Jeremy Gallon, wearing the jerseys of past Wolverine greats, led Michigan past Notre Dame in the final game between the rivals in Ann Arbor for at least the next decade.
lead_paragraph: ANN ARBOR, Mich. — There was tradition in Michigan Stadium on Saturday night, even if it was only the second time the university hosted a night game.

headline: New York Fashion Week: Elements | Volume
abstract: Explore various interpretations of volume from New York Fashion Week in the third installment of Elements.
lead_paragraph: Explore various interpretations of volume from New York Fashion Week in the third installment of Elements.

headline: What to Watch at the U.S. Open on Sunday
abstract: The women’s final on Sunday is a rematch of last year’s final between Serena Williams and Victoria Azarenka, and Williams appears ready to defend her title.
lead_paragraph: Thank goodness the United States Open women’s final is here, because the well on adjectives to describe Serena Williams is running dry. Her dismantling of fifth-seeded Li Na in the semifinals Friday was surgical in its precision. The first set, which the top-seeded Williams won at love, took 29 minutes.

headline: Manson Whitlock, Typewriter Repairman, Dies at 96
abstract: Mr. Whitlock, often described as America’s oldest typewriter repairman, had a shop near Yale and fixed more than 300,000 machines — but never a computer.
lead_paragraph: For eight decades, Manson Whitlock kept the 20th century’s ambient music going: the ffft of the roller, the ding of the bell, the decisive zhoop ... bang of the carriage return, the companionable clack of the keys.

headline: A Conversation With: Chief Minister Omar Abdullah
abstract: Ahead of the conductor Zubin Mehta’s concert in Kashmir, Mr. Abdullah said, “It puts my state back in the spotlight, for better or for worse.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times spoke to Omar Abdullah, chief minister of the northern state of Jammu and Kashmir, at his residence in Srinagar on Saturday six hours before the event of the season: A concert by world-renowned conductor Zubin Mehta and the Bavarian State Orchestra, who had flown in from Munich, Germany, for the occasion. Despite criticism from separatists and civil society groups, there was clearly no stopping the event’s momentum, and thousands of police had been deployed to secure the venue, a 17th century Mughal garden.

headline: Economic Reports Ease Concerns in China
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Renminbi (Currency)', 'Gross Domestic Product']
abstract: Figures for August are bolstered by improving demand for the country’s goods in major markets.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — China’s trade surplus rose in August to its highest level this year, while inflation remained under control, government data released on Sunday and Monday showed, in further signs that the Chinese economy and possibly the global economy are faring a little better as the summer ends.

headline: A New Leader but a Familiar Scene in Australia
abstract: On Saturday, voters delivered a defeat to the Labor Party and picked Tony Abbott as prime minister. But on Sunday, they found a couple of customary sights on television.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — The prime minister-elect of Australia, Tony Abbott, wasted no time on Sunday in burnishing his image as a disciplined national leader, amid speculation about the future of the Labor Party led by Kevin Rudd, which was handily defeated by Mr. Abbott’s conservatives in national elections held over the weekend.

headline: Piecing Together the Scene of a Kidnapping
abstract: In order to capture the place where Amanda Lindhout was abducted, we had to send a photographer back to Somalia to retrace her captors’ steps.
lead_paragraph: For Amanda Lindhout’s article in last weekend’s magazine, we naturally wanted to get pictures from the place in Somalia where she spent more than a year in captivity. We focused on two locations: the road that connects Mogadishu with Afgoye, from which Lindhout and Nigel Brennan were abducted, and the mosque that Lindhout fled to during an escape attempt.

headline: Fighting Corruption in China
abstract: One step forward, two steps back.
lead_paragraph: One step forward, two steps back.

headline: Making Youth Football Safer, Tackles and All
abstract: As parents, we will do whatever it takes to make the world a better place for our children. For me, that meant learning how to tackle the safe way.

headline: Sunday at New York Fashion Week: Beckham, von Furstenberg, Posen, Rucci
abstract: Today is a marathon day for most fashion show mavens. Here’s what you need to look out for.
lead_paragraph: Sunday is a marathon day for most fashion show attendees. Not only does the day begin the halfway mark of New York Fashion Week, there are also several big shows, including: Victoria Beckham (10 a.m.), Derek Lam (noon), DKNY (1 p.m.), Thakoon (3 p.m.), Diane von Furstenberg (4 p.m.), Band of Outsiders (5 p.m.), Zac Posen (7 p.m.) and Ralph Rucci (8 p.m.). Let’s hope all the pre-fashion juicing and liquid lunches will leave the fashion crowd with enough calories to endure the lineup.

headline: Let’s Talk Spring 2014 Collections
abstract: What were your favorite collections so far and why?
lead_paragraph: With the spring 2014 collections well underway we have seen some interesting looks emerge, for example, logos and laser-cut leather at Alexander Wang;bold orange lips from Rag & Bone; and painterly embellishments from Prabal Gurung.

headline: Making History in Pakistan Simply by Serving a Full Term
abstract: President Asif Ali Zardari of Pakistan is ending his term in office, becoming the first democratically elected president in the country’s history to complete his full tenure.
lead_paragraph: Smoking an electronic cigarette and casually stooping to feed his cat, President Asif Ali Zardari cut a relaxed figure in a television interview broadcast on Sunday. Later, he strolled from the presidential palace while flanked by soldiers in gleaming uniforms, in a mark of honor for his last day at work.

headline: White House Adds Arab Support as It and Assad Use TV to Press Their Cases
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations', 'Biological and Chemical Warfare']
abstract: Meeting with Arab League foreign ministers, Secretary of State John Kerry said other declarations of support would come soon.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At home and abroad, the Obama administration redoubled its campaign Sunday to build support for military action against Syria, saying it had won the backing of Saudi Arabia for a strike while still laboring to persuade a deeply reluctant Congress.

headline: Drone and Taliban Attacks Hit Civilians, Afghans Say
keywords: ['Civilian Casualties', 'Terrorism', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Targeted Killings', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Drones (Pilotless Planes)']
abstract: Officials reported a drone strike in eastern Afghanistan that killed up to 16 people and a Taliban assault in another province that killed four intelligence officers and injured over 120 civilians.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Underscoring the continued threat to civilians in Afghanistan, a drone strike in an eastern province killed up to 16 people, Afghan officials said Sunday, while a Taliban assault in another province killed four intelligence officers and wounded more than 120 civilians.

headline: Taking New Rackets for a Spin
abstract: Polyester strings have amplified topspin in racket design, and Wilson and Prince are releasing new rackets that move even further in that direction.
lead_paragraph: Tennis players and the people who design their equipment are always looking for that little something extra.

headline: Auto-Corect Nt Wokring (Wonkish)
abstract: The economy’s very weak tendency to restore full employment.
lead_paragraph: Mike Konczal argues that the big divide between New Keynesians and Old Keynesians lies in the NK belief that, contra Keynes, the economy can be counted on to “auto-correct” back to full employment. I guess I’d quibble a bit both with the intellectual history and with Mike’s emphasis on rational expectations as the key divide, and I want to say a bit about that. On the main point, however, Mike and I are in complete agreement: any self-corrective forces in the economy of 2013 are very weak and slow, and we can stay depressed for a very long time.

headline: For Paes, Another Title Quest in a 20-Year Journey
abstract: On Sunday Leander Paes, 40, will play for the United States Open men’s doubles final with Radek Stepanek against Alexander Peya and Bruno Soares.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday afternoon Leander Paes, 40, will play for the United States Open men’s doubles final with Radek Stepanek against Alexander Peya and Bruno Soares.

headline: Disruptions: Apple’s Next Unveiling Could Make or Break a Business
abstract: The annual iPhone unveilings draw fans, entrepreneurs and technology executives who are praying that a new function does not make their company obsolete.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — On Tuesday morning, about 200 people — most of them from the news media — will gather in a Cupertino, Calif., auditorium to watch Timothy D. Cook, Apple’s chief executive, unveil new iPhones.

headline: ‘Riddick’ Is First on a Slow Weekend for Movies
abstract: The film, which took in $18.7 million in North America over the weekend, finished first on what is historically one of the year’s weakest box-office weekends.
lead_paragraph: Vin Diesel’s enormous following on Facebook – his personal page has nearly 47 million “likes” – did not translate into enormous ticket sales for “Riddick” (Universal), which took in a soft $18.7 million in North America over the weekend. That was enough for No. 1 on what is historically one of the slowest box-office weekends of the year. But box-office analysts, citing online chatter, had been hoping for more. “Riddick,” which may have suffered from its R rating, was independently financed for about $38 million.

headline: What’s on Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (13) LAST TANGO IN HALIFAX Derek Jacobi, above, and Anne Reid portray Alan and Celia, childhood sweethearts, now both widowed and in their 70s, who fall in love all over again — and begin to lament “what if?” — after being reunited on the Internet nearly 60 years later. Sarah Lancashire and Nicola Walker play the daughters who would be the last people to stand in the way of their parents’ happiness, but who can’t help themselves. “There’s nothing to be gained from saying unkind things about ‘Last Tango in Halifax,’ a warm comforter of a series,” Mike Hale wrote in The New York Times. “It’s based on actual, inspiring events in the life of the writer’s mother. And it has been expertly assembled and fine-tuned for maximum heartwarming effect, so those who like this sort of thing will like it very, very much.” But while the show “begins with a potentially interesting situation,” he said, it “proceeds to do little with it.” He added: “A good test of how you’ll respond to this ‘Last Tango’ could be how you responded to the film from which it (hilariously) borrows its title. If the portrait of despair in ‘Last Tango in Paris’ left you shattered but exhilarated, then ‘Last Tango in Halifax’ may not be your cup of tea.” In the season finale of “Silk,” at 9 on Channels 13 and 49, Martha (Maxine Peake) and Clive (Rupert Penry-Jones) have their Queen’s Counsel interviews as she takes on the biggest case in her career — defending a repeat offender charged with murder — while struggling to focus as the stress resulting from her personal life increases.

abstract: Will Barnet, an actor and street performer, is taking Shakespeare into New York City parks, performing soliloquies for passers-by.
lead_paragraph: Like so many fledgling actors before him, Will Barnet moved to New York City to become a star. It did not take very long for Mr. Barnet, a recent graduate of Brown University, to learn how unlikely that would be.

headline: Assad Denies Gas Attack; White House Presses a Strike
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Biological and Chemical Warfare']
abstract: As the White House chief of staff appeared on Sunday morning news shows to make the administration’s case for an airstrike, President Bashar al-Assad of Syria said in a CBS interview that his government was not behind a chemical attack.
lead_paragraph: The White House chief of staff, Denis R. McDonough, said Sunday that the American people’s skepticism about the prospect of military action in Syria was “understandable” after a decade of war in Iraq and Afghanistan, but that such a strike would be far different from those wars.

headline: Beckham Makes a Play for Wearability
abstract: Victoria Beckham rewarded us with one of her best collections, which she described as a sort of boy-meets-girl affair.
lead_paragraph: To truly enjoy the spoils of Fashion Week, meaning the after-parties, a person must demonstrate incredible stamina and have a resignation to appearing in public looking like he or she has been out at parties all night. This is especially true on Sunday morning, when the devoted make their way to Victoria Beckham’s 10 a.m. show.

headline: Drug Cocktail That Protects Monkeys From Deadly Virus May Aid Humans
abstract: A combination of two well-known antiviral drugs could potentially save humans from MERS, or Middle East Respiratory Syndrome, scientists said Sunday.
lead_paragraph: A combination of two well-known antiviral drugs protects monkeys against MERS and could potentially be used to save humans from the lethal disease, scientists said on Sunday.

headline: Bruno Mars to Play Super Bowl Halftime Show
abstract: The Grammy Award-winning pop artist’s second album, “Unorthodox Jukebox,” has sold over four million copies worldwide since its release in December.
lead_paragraph: The Grammy Award-winning pop artist Bruno Mars has been chosen by the National Football League to perform the Super Bowl XLVIII halftime show in February. Mr. Mars appeared in Times Square during a live broadcast of Fox’s “N.F.L. Sunday” to make the news official. He described being named as “an honor.”

headline: Wrestling, With Revamped Rules, Returns to Summer Games
abstract: As efforts to modernize pay off for an ancient sport, baseball/softball and squash remain on the outside looking in.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — After facing a wide backlash, the International Olympic Committee restored wrestling — one of the most traditional and elemental sports — to the Summer Games on Sunday.

headline: Picturing the Winners and Losers from Obamacare
abstract: Weep for the healthy and wealthy?
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Cohn has a useful, comprehensive summary of what we now know about premiums under Obamacare, and does a very good job of keeping his temper in the face of the obscurantists. lead_paragraph: City Opera is trying to overcome a cash crisis threatening its survival. The company is warning that it will have to cancel the remainder of this season and its next season if it fails to raise $20 million by year’s end.

headline: New York City Opera May Cancel Most of This Season
abstract: The company said that unless it raised $20 million by year’s end, it would abandon its 2014-15 season.
lead_paragraph: New York City Opera, which was founded 70 years ago to bring opera to the masses, will be forced to cancel most of its current season and all of its next season if it fails to raise $20 million by year’s end, company officials say.

lead_paragraph: The defending champion and top seed Serena Williams took a somewhat scenic route through the final but ultimately arrived at her fifth United States Open title, defeating No. 2 Victoria Azarenka, 7-5, 6-7(6), 6-1.

headline: Challenger in Race for Moscow Mayor Says He Can Force a Runoff
abstract: Exit polls for the Moscow mayoral election showed that the incumbent had narrowly won, but Aleksei A. Navalny, a prominent critic of President Vladimir V. Putin, asserted he had enough votes to force a second round.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The first mayoral election here in a decade ended with a narrow victory for the appointed incumbent on Sunday, according to preliminary results. But his main challenger, one of President Vladimir V. Putin’s most prominent critics, claimed that he had won enough votes to force a runoff, and he warned of efforts to falsify the outcome of a race that proved to be much closer than expected.

headline: Madrid and Istanbul Respond Differently to Rejection by Olympics
abstract: An unsuccessful bid by Spain’s capital to host the 2020 Games met with wider disappointment than a failed bid did in Turkey, where support was weaker.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Madrid and Istanbul started counting the costs on Sunday of failing once more to be named an Olympic host, after Tokyo was chosen to organize the 2020 Games.

headline: Moscow’s Mayoral Election Yields Low Turnout
abstract: Two hours before the polls closed in the election for Moscow mayor, a surge of young, liberal voters had failed to materialize to bolster the candidacy of the blogger, Aleksei A. Navalny.
lead_paragraph: Moscow voters on Sunday were given their first chance in a decade to vote for their mayor. But given a choice between a Kremlin-backed technocrat and an anti-corruption blogger among a smattering of other minor politicians, most Muscovites, it seems, chose to stay home.

abstract: Scott Anderson’s “Lawrence in Arabia” traces many conflicts in today’s Middle East back to World War I.
lead_paragraph: Scott Anderson’s fine, sophisticated, richly detailed “Lawrence in Arabia” is filled with invaluably complex and fine-tuned information. This demanding but eminently readable account of the Middle East during World War I is certainly no hagiographic T. E. Lawrence biography, as the tiny nuance (“in,” not “of”) coloring its title makes clear.

headline: Experience and Conditioning Lift Djokovic Over Wawrinka
abstract: Novak Djokovic’s experience and resourcefulness wore down the sublime play of Stanislas Wawrinka in their U.S. Open semifinal Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Novak Djokovic’s experience and resourcefulness wore down the sublime play of Stanislas Wawrinka in a five-set prize fight Saturday that was a fascinating study in contrasts. On the surface, this match looks similar to their five-set match in the fourth round of the Australian Open earlier this year, won by Djokovic in a 12-10 final set.

headline: Dance Historian to Be Honored
abstract: The dance historian Nancy Reynolds is to receive the 2013 Bessie Award for Outstanding Service to the Field of Dance.
lead_paragraph: The dance historian Nancy Reynolds is to receive the 2013 Bessie Award for Outstanding Service to the Field of Dance. Ms. Reynolds will be recognized for her work as the director of research at the George Balanchine Foundation, where she manages the Balanchine video archives, and as the author of dance history books like “No Fixed Points,” which chronicles ballet, modern and experimental dance in North America and Europe during the 20th century. The ceremony for the annual Bessie Awards, named after the dance teacher Bessie Schonberg and formerly known as the New York Dance and Performance Awards, are to be held on Oct. 7 at the Apollo Theater.

headline: Police at British Palace Stop a Stranger: Prince Andrew
abstract: Days after an intruder was captured inside Buckingham Palace, the police accosted Prince Andrew on Wednesday evening for wandering on the palace grounds, apparently without identification.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — These days in London, you can’t even stroll around your mother’s palace without getting stopped by the police.

headline: Redefining Bollywood Love Stories
abstract: In “Shuddh Desi Romance,” an unsure groom makes for an interesting wedding ceremony.
lead_paragraph: Apparently, in the Hindu marriage ceremony, it is a very important moment when the bride places a garland around the groom’s neck. So if a groom chooses that moment to excuse himself to go to the bathroom, it’s a bit disturbing.

headline: Buccaneers Give Jets the Push They Need in Smith’s Quarterback Debut
abstract: A 15-yard penalty for a late hit set up a Jets field goal with two seconds left, giving quarterback Geno Smith a victory in his N.F.L. debut.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The beauty of the first Sunday of the N.F.L. season is the optimism that abounds, the promise and potential. No team is immune from it, but some latch onto that hope — the “Why can’t we?” — more than others.

headline: Analyzing the Moves of a King
abstract: The cavernous Park Avenue Armory is the host stage for “The Machine,” a British play about a 1997 chess match.
lead_paragraph: In “The Machine,” which opened on Friday night at the Park Avenue Armory, the element of surprise is confined almost exclusively to a small board at the center of a very large space. It’s a chess board, and even audience members unfamiliar with the game played on it will gather that startling things are happening on this little square inhabited by barely visible wooden figures.

headline: La Dolce Vita Gone Sour (and This Time in Color)
abstract: “The Great Beauty,” the new film by Paolo Sorrentino, portrays Italy as a country where the culture is embalmed in elegant decline and inertia seems to overwhelm all forward momentum.
lead_paragraph: ROME — There is a striking scene in “The Great Beauty,” Paolo Sorrentino’s luscious new film, in which Jep Gambardella, a perpetually amused, impeccably tailored blocked novelist, looks down on the hulking body of the Costa Concordia cruise ship, which has been lodged off the Tuscan coast since its captain all but sank it there nearly two years ago.

headline: New York Fashion Week: Derek Lam Spring/Summer 2014
abstract: Scenes from the New York fashion week photo diary of Barbara Anastacio.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the New York fashion week photo diary of Barbara Anastacio.

headline: Rivera Blows Save, but Suzuki Rescues Win and Yanks’ Hopes
abstract: The Yankees, their postseason chances flickering, avoided being swept by the Red Sox.
lead_paragraph: The Yankees’ state of desperation while they linger on the fringes of the playoff race took an interesting turn Sunday when they asked the 43-year-old closer Mariano Rivera to do something he had not done in more than seven years: record a two-inning, regular-season save.

headline: Familiar Night Bird Reclaims a Perch
abstract: Arsenio Hall, whose late-night talk show was a phenomenon in the early 1990s, is returning to the genre, beginning Monday.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Arsenio Hall is on his feet, juking his hips back and forth in a steady rhythm.

headline: Calluses and Scars Besides Sex and Drugs
abstract: The major-label debut for the Weeknd (Abel Tesfaye) is pulpy, mournful and unnerving, with plenty of songs about the cheap thrills and unstructured lust of life on tour.
lead_paragraph: Abel Tesfaye, heart cold as tundra, sings with intense moral authority about deep immorality. He’s got an urgent, high voice that he deploys with nuclear force and focus on songs about the numbing effects of drugs and sex. For him, all love is vampiric, all women are unworthy of trust, all nights are to be squeezed to the last drop.

headline: Reaching Into a 33-Year-Old Trove to Find Songs That Stand Up
abstract: Depeche Mode brought its brand of synthesizer pop to Barclays Center in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: This review goes out to the audience at the Depeche Mode concert on Friday night at Barclays Center in Brooklyn, a kindhearted citizenry of cool realists around 30 to 50. Solid middle-class couples everywhere: gay, straight, romantic, platonic. British synth-pop of the 1980s may have been Eurocentric at the root, but it reached a lot of people. This crowd was multiracial and multiethnic. Secret ragers. No poseurs. A crowd to build a culture on, if not an economy.

headline: Opera and the Theater Have a Back and Forth
abstract: “No Hotel” blends opera, theater and video at St. Mark’s Church in the East Village.
lead_paragraph: “No Hotel,” the new opera by the multidisciplinary cabal Object Collection, lays its figurative cards on the table in relatively short order. Not long into the work, presented in its premiere by the Incubator Arts Project at St. Mark’s Church in the East Village on Saturday night, a disjointed semblance of conversation takes place among three performers: Avi Glickstein, Daniel Allen Nelson and Fulya Peker. Lounging in a hotel room with a view of Manhattan visible through a window, they appear life size on a video screen that takes up half the stage.

headline: Piano Offers More Than Just Sounds
abstract: A Miro Magloire premiere is among the offerings in a program by New Chamber Ballet at City Center.
lead_paragraph: At City Center’s Studio 5 on Friday, the same ordinary light fell upon the audience members in folding chairs and the piano they faced. That three women sat on the piano’s bench, rather than just one or two, was the first visual indication that a dance performance was about to begin.

headline: Bursts of Raw Comedy Holding Yahoo Hostage
abstract: Yahoo! Screen is adding five new shows on Monday, with contributions from Jack Black, John Stamos, Cheryl Hines, Zachary Levi and Ed Helms.
lead_paragraph: Netflix and Amazon are working hard to get us used to the idea that online shows can look and feel just like prime-time television, but not everyone in the original-streaming-video business is following the same path. Yahoo is adding five new shows to its Yahoo! Screen site on Monday, and they’re Web Video Classic: 6- to 12-minute episodes of uncomplicated, inexpensive comedy. If “House of Cards” is too much work for you, Yahoo has you covered.

headline: Young Performers Bask in an Old Favorite, at Least Once
abstract: The Sebastians performed one selection by the title composer in its “Bach by Popular Demand” program at All Angels’ Church.
lead_paragraph: “Though we take our music seriously, we’re not afraid of a good pun,” the Sebastians proffered in brief program notes for their concert at All Angels’ Church on Saturday evening, “Bach by Popular Demand.” Well, in this case, a bad pun.

headline: If the Parks Are Strewn With Garbage, It Must Be a Monday Morning
keywords: ['Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Waste Materials and Disposal']
abstract: Enforcing litter laws in the city’s parks is difficult. Park workers hand out trash bags to barbecuers and picnickers, but garbage is still left everywhere.
lead_paragraph: All summer and into the fall in Upper Manhattan, barbecuers and picnickers flock to the Riverside Park waterfront on Saturdays and Sundays to enjoy the Hudson River views and breezes. Hundreds, sometimes thousands, of people descend on a grassy stretch in the northern part of the park where grilling is permitted. Carne asada and barbecue chicken sizzles, children run, tattooed arms bop volleyballs and couples watch the sun settle over New Jersey.

headline: Footnotes
abstract: A one-woman show about the sex therapist Ruth Westheimer will have its New York premiere Off Broadway, and the Bedlam theater company is coming to the East Village.
lead_paragraph: Mark St. Germain’s “Becoming Dr. Ruth,” the one-woman show that stars Debra Jo Rupp (“That ’70s Show”) and chronicles the life of the sex therapist Ruth Westheimer, will have its New York premiere Off Broadway at the Westside Theater Upstairs, the producers announced. The play, directed by Julianne Boyd, had a well-received run at TheaterWorks Hartford this summer. Performances are scheduled to begin on Oct. 11 with opening night set for Oct. 29. ... The Bedlam theater company will bring its productions of Shakespeare’s “Hamlet” and George Bernard Shaw’s “Saint Joan” to the Lynn Redgrave Theater in the East Village, according to the producers. Both works are to be directed by Eric Tucker, and all the roles will be played by the same four actors (Ted Lewis, Andrus Nichols, Tom O’Keefe and Mr. Tucker), similar to the company’s run of “Hamlet” this year at Access Theater. Performances of “Saint Joan” will begin on Nov. 8, “Hamlet” will follow on Nov. 15.

headline: Ones Who’ve Got Something to Lose
abstract: How to tell that the seasons have changed, with Gary Cee.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Pop quiz: You first realize that football season is upon us when (a) the weather starts to turn cooler, (b) the men in your vicinity start painting their faces in weird colors, (c) someone comes out with a football-themed crossword puzzle in The New York Times, or (d) all of the above?

headline: Remembering Warren Rosner, 3-Time National Champion
abstract: Warren Rosner, one of the New York region’s best players in the 1970s and ’80s, died on Aug. 9.
lead_paragraph: Warren Rosner, one of the New York region’s best players in the 1970s and ’80s, died on Aug. 9. He was 69 and is survived by his wife, Ann Lou.

headline: Brad Pitt on ’12 Years a Slave’
abstract: Brad Pitt, a producer on “12 Years a Slave,” discusses his involvement in the film at the Toronto International Film Festival.
lead_paragraph: Brad Pitt, a producer on “12 Years a Slave,” discusses his involvement in the film at the Toronto International Film Festival.

headline: Mark McNairy New Amsterdam: Spring 2014 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Hurtling Through the Fashion Mall for DVF
abstract: The opening numbers in Diane von Furstenberg’s show included a long, lusty tomato red dress, and shorter white one.
lead_paragraph: The 3 p.m. show today was running late. It was at the Standard Hotel in the meatpacking district, for a new men’s wear label named Telfar, though it could have been mistaken for International Male for all the hot boys in flimsy bikini briefs and mesh tank tops. But more on that in a moment, as we have to get to Diane von Furstenberg!

headline: Assad Denies Chemical Attack in Interview for U.S. Viewers
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: The interview with President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, which took place on Sunday at the presidential palace in Damascus, will be broadcast on Monday by CBS and PBS.
lead_paragraph: President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, who has denied that his government attacked civilians with chemical weapons on Aug. 21, reiterated that denial to the American people on Sunday morning via the television interviewer Charlie Rose.

headline: With Kiffin as Coordinator, the Cowboys Are Hunting for Turnovers
abstract: Monte Kiffin, the defensive coordinator for Dallas, has returned to the N.F.L. after spending the last four seasons working with his son in the college ranks.
lead_paragraph: IRVING, Tex. — Monte Kiffin looked impossibly fresh and enthusiastic after a recent practice in heat approaching 100 degrees. He promptly greeted reporters with a septuagenarian energy rush that surely had to subside into a nap at some point.

headline: Vettel Wins Italian Grand Prix, but Alonso Earns Cheers
abstract: Sebastian Vettel took a big step toward his fourth consecutive Formula One driver’s championship, but much of the attention before and after the race was on the runner-up, Fernando Alonso.
lead_paragraph: MONZA, Italy — As the Italian Grand Prix brought an end to the Formula One season in Europe on Sunday at this celebrated track, Sebastian Vettel of Germany had posted another start-to-finish victory, outpacing Ferrari’s Fernando Alonso and taking a formidable step toward his fourth consecutive driver’s championship.

headline: Visiting Republicans Laud Egypt’s Force
abstract: Michele Bachmann and two other House Republicans pledged solidarity against the Muslim Brotherhood, which they, like Cairo’s new leaders, deem a terrorist group.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Two months after the military ousted Egypt’s first elected president and began a bloody crackdown on his supporters, a delegation of House Republicans visited Cairo over the weekend to tell the new government to keep up the good work.

headline: Tracy Reese: Spring 2014 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Diane von Furstenberg: Spring 2014 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Matsuzaka Gets Revenge Against Indians, Helping the Mets Avoid a Series Sweep
abstract: Pitcher Daisuke Matsuzaka, who was released by Cleveland in August, delivered for the Mets to avoid a sweep by the Indians.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Mets Manager Terry Collins asked Daisuke Matsuzaka this week whether he wanted to pitch Sunday or if he needed another day to rest.

headline: Toyota Recalls Vehicles a Second Time
keywords: ['Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Automobiles']
abstract: About 780,000 RAV4 sport utility vehicles and Lexus HS sedans needed repairs for a handling problem in 2012, but the repair was not effective, the automaker said.
lead_paragraph: Toyota is recalling about 780,000 vehicles for a second time after its first effort to prevent a handling problem did not work, according to a report posted Sunday on the Web site of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

headline: Things Fall Apart
abstract: Thinkers loyal to the Newtonian picture of science want unified theories to explain phenomena like human consciousness. Life isn’t like that.
lead_paragraph: Thomas Nagel, one of the world’s most eminent philosophers, is especially noted for his ability to write about the most difficult questions with subtlety and clarity. His recent book, “Mind and Cosmos,” has sparked lively discussion, as he observed recently in his précis of the book’s main argument in The Stone. He has found new – not always welcome – allies (“Nagel has paved the way for a religious world-view!”), and some long-time admirers have denounced his claims and arguments (“Nagel has paved the way for religious mumbo-jumbo!”). But the link with religion is a sideshow. Nagel’s main concern lies with the requirements of a complete metaphysical view.

headline: Barofsky, Watchdog to Government Bank Bailout Program, Joins Law Firm
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Inspectors General', 'Emergency Economic Stabilization Act (2008)']
abstract: Neil Barofsky, who oversaw the Troubled Asset Relief Program, has joined Jenner & Block as a partner.
lead_paragraph: Neil Barofsky, the former prosecutor who brought transparency and accountability to the federal government’s 2008 bank bailout program as its first special inspector general, has joined Jenner & Block, a law firm based in Chicago, as a partner.

headline: Band of Outsiders: Spring 2014 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: New York Fashion Week: Diane von Furstenberg Spring/Summer 2014
abstract: Scenes from the New York fashion week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the New York fashion week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.

headline: Worries That Microsoft Is Growing Too Tricky to Manage
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Enterprise Computing', 'Software', 'Tablet Computers', 'Wireless Communications', 'Xbox (Video Game System)']
abstract: Many feel that a more focused, nimble collection of mini-Microsofts could respond more effectively to the never-ending flow of disruptive technologies nibbling at its foundations.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — At a time when many people in business believe the number of products at Microsoft should be getting smaller, it is about to become a lot bigger.

headline: Some Bait to Tease Your Desire
abstract: Joseph Altuzarra and Louise Goldin show looks with plenty of hooks.
lead_paragraph: People with a reasonably serious view of fashion often ask: Where are the new ideas? And more often than not, this question is directed at New York designers, who tend to copy or dress up generic styles.

headline: Elections Board Rings In the Old, as Lever Machines Replace Scanners
abstract: New York City is restoring the hulking apparatus for the primaries this week and any runoffs, but electronic voting is due back again for Election Day.
lead_paragraph: Dented, dinged and dated, New York’s battleship-gray lever voting machines have been hauled out of retirement because the city can’t seem to get the hang of electronic voting.

headline: ‘PBS NewsHour’ Begins Its Overhaul
abstract: “PBS NewsHour” has added weekend newscasts and is set to introduce its new weeknight team with Gwen Ifill and Judy Woodruff, the first female co-anchors at any network.
lead_paragraph: The 38-year-old “PBS NewsHour” began a new era this weekend, adding Saturday and Sunday newscasts for the first time and preparing for the debut on Monday of Gwen Ifill and Judy Woodruff as the new weeknight anchor team and the first female co-anchors at any network.

headline: President of N.A.A.C.P. to Step Down
abstract: Five years after he became the civil rights group’s youngest leader, Benjamin T. Jealous is leaving his job.
lead_paragraph: Benjamin T. Jealous, who led the N.A.A.C.P. through a tumultuous period for civil rights with a focus on technological change, will leave his job as president of the organization in January, he announced Sunday.

headline: Popular Merkel, Warning of Threat From Rivals, Rallies Supporters
abstract: Warning that her rivals could still unseat her as chancellor, Angela Merkel fired up her backers for the last two weeks of a campaign she is widely expected to win.
lead_paragraph: DÜSSELDORF, Germany — Praised by her party as “a stroke of luck for Germany” but warning that her rivals could still unseat her as chancellor, Angela Merkel on Sunday fired up her supporters for the last two weeks of a campaign she is widely expected to win.

headline: Apple Is Set to Announce Two iPhones
abstract: One iPhone will feature a faster processor,  and the other will be a less expensive model in a variety of colors aimed at markets like China and India.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The handset market is so brutally competitive that Apple, the most successful smartphone maker, is preparing to step up its game this week by offering two new iPhones instead of one.

headline: Roman Polanski Lends Voice to Documentary About Him
abstract: “Roman Polanski: Odd Man Out,” a 2012 documentary about Mr. Polanski’s effort to avoid extradition to the United States to face a sexual assault charge, will have its debut on Showtime on Sept. 27.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Those who remember “Roman Polanski: Odd Man Out” from the Toronto International Film Festival last year may wonder if memory is playing tricks, should they happen to see the documentary on Showtime, where it is scheduled for a television debut on Sept. 27.

headline: Has Berlusconi Finally Run Out of Political Lives?
abstract: The former Italian prime minister may be stripped of his Senate seat, sending Italian politics into further turmoil.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Behind the high gates of his lavish 16th-century villa in Italy’s wealthy Po Valley, Silvio Berlusconi is plotting. His People of Freedom party is currently the most popular in Italy. He just won a victory by getting rid of a disliked property tax. And yet he could be facing his political end.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for Week of Sept. 9
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'States (US)', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Government Bonds']
abstract: The following tax-exempt, fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Highlights From Our Social Media Feeds at NYFW, Day 4
abstract: New York Times fashion reporters and editors describe day four of New York Fashion Week in 140 characters.

headline: The Final Republican Debate
keywords: ['Debates (Political)', 'Elections, Mayors', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Mayors', 'Search and Seizure']
abstract: Before New York City’s mayoral primary elections, Joseph J. Lhota and John A. Catsimatidis, two Republican candidates, discussed security, the police’s stop-and-frisk tactic and policy differences.
lead_paragraph: Before New York City’s mayoral primary elections, Joseph J. Lhota and John A. Catsimatidis, two Republican candidates, discussed security, the police’s stop-and-frisk tactic and policy differences.

headline: DKNY’s Nostalgic Platform Sneaker
abstract: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway. Today’s pick: platform sneakers, made modern.
lead_paragraph: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: Guilietta: Spring 2014 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Croatians Win Junior Titles at U.S. Open
abstract: Ana Konjuh, 15, of Croatia outlasted Alicia Black, 15, of Boca Raton, Fla., 3-6, 6-4,7-6 (6), to win the U.S. Open girls’ singles championship Sunday, and Konjuh’s countryman Borna Coric, 16, won for the boys’ singles championship.
lead_paragraph: Ana Konjuh, 15, of Croatia outlasted Alicia Black, 15, of Boca Raton, Fla., in a bruising battle of ground strokes, 3-6, 6-4, 7-6 (6), to win the United States Open girls’ singles championship Sunday.

headline: Olympians To Be Warned Not to Protest Law in Sochi
abstract: Jacques Rogge, the president of the International Olympic Committee, said that athletes would be warned about rules prohibiting demonstrations at the 2014 Winter Games in Sochi, Russia.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — Jacques Rogge, the president of the International Olympic Committee, said Sunday that athletes would be warned about rules prohibiting demonstrations at the 2014 Olympics in Sochi, Russia.

headline: Harder Edge From Vanity Fair Chafes Some Big Hollywood Stars
abstract: The magazine has sharpened its celebrity coverage and that has angered some in Hollywood.
lead_paragraph: For years, the relationship between Vanity Fair and Hollywood was like Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers: the magazine gave the movie business class and Hollywood gave Vanity Fair sex.

headline: Making Time for Sweetbreads, Even Amid a World Crisis
abstract: Jan Eliasson, the deputy secretary general of the United Nations, almost had to call off a lunch meeting because chemical weapons inspectors were under fire in Syria.
lead_paragraph: Jan Eliasson came close to calling off lunch. The Syrian crisis had kicked into high gear a few days earlier, and on this morning a convoy of United Nations chemical weapons inspectors found itself under fire. Mr. Eliasson, No. 2 at the United Nations as its deputy secretary general, was an extremely busy fellow.

headline: Urban, but Left Behind
abstract: In China, the timeline of the massive migration of 250 million rural residents into cities by 2025 is so rapid and far-reaching, there are concerns that some people will be left behind.
lead_paragraph: In China, the timeline of the massive migration of 250 million rural residents into cities by 2025 is so rapid and far-reaching, there are concerns that some people will be left behind.

headline: Nascar Investigating Race for Possible Manipulation
abstract: The investigation is intended to determine whether teammates altered Saturday’s race to help a third make the Chase and in the process knocked two other drivers out of the playoff.
lead_paragraph: Nascar has begun an investigation to find out if its 12-car field for the annual Sprint Cup playoff is tainted.

headline: In South Florida, a Polluted Bubble Ready to Burst
abstract: With heavy rain driving waters from Lake Okeechobee to estuaries in the east and west, devastating wildlife, officials are looking for solutions.
lead_paragraph: CLEWISTON, Fla. — On wind-whipped days when rain pounds this part of South Florida, people are quickly reminded that Lake Okeechobee, with its vulnerable dike and polluted waters, has become a giant environmental problem far beyond its banks.

headline: Picking Death Over Eviction
keywords: ['Immolation', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Land Use Policies', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Rural Areas', 'Series']
abstract: Some farmers commit suicide to protest eviction, a reminder of how China’s new urbanization push is at times a violent struggle with a powerful state.
lead_paragraph: As she drove down a busy four-lane road near her old home, Tang Huiqing pointed to the property where her dead sister’s workshop once stood. The lot was desolate, but for Ms. Tang it lives.

headline: A Reinvented Condé Nast Traveler Sets a New Course
abstract: A print and social media campaign for the revised magazine will carry the theme “I am a Traveler” with the subtheme, “Every Journey Begins Here.”
lead_paragraph: A TRAVEL magazine is using a campaign to signal an embarkation on a trip of its own to a land that is becoming increasingly popular among print publications, Reinventionstan.

headline: Inside the End of the U.S. Bid to Punish Lehman Executives
keywords: ['ACCOUNTING AND ACCOUNTANTS', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis']
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission officials sparred for months before concluding that suing executives at Lehman Brothers over the bank’s 2008 collapse would be legally unjustified.
lead_paragraph: At a closed-door meeting in early 2011, Wall Street regulators were close to throwing in the towel on their biggest case.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week of Sept. 9
keywords: ['Company Reports', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Producer Price Index']
abstract: Data to be released this week include consumer credit for July, retail sales for August and Dell shareholders will vote on the buyout offer by Michael S. Dell and Silver Lake Partners.
lead_paragraph: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data to be released includes consumer credit for July (Monday); the National Federation of Independent Business Small Business Optimism report for August (Tuesday); wholesale inventories for July (Wednesday); weekly initial jobless claims and the import price index for August (Thursday); and the producer price index for August, retail sales for August, and the Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan preliminary consumer sentiment index for September (Friday).

headline: The Pop! of the Wild
abstract: How can we claim the advantages of online education without losing the most essential triangular configuration — student, teacher and world — in higher education?
lead_paragraph: IF you put your head underwater in the Sea of Cortez, you will hear a crackling sound. In my summer field course for undergraduates, there were two students who noticed it before all the others. One was a young man who was blind; the other was a precocious musician.

headline: Chile Recalls Coup With Flurry of Events and New Openness
keywords: ["Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat", 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: The weeks leading up to the anniversary of the Sept. 11, 1973, military coup that brought Gen. Augusto Pinochet to power have been marked with an avalanche of events and media coverage.
lead_paragraph: SANTIAGO, Chile — Sunday dawned with the dark shadow of a Hawker Hunter jet painted on a Santiago street, pointing toward the presidential palace. Hours later, tens of thousands of Chileans marched through the capital to commemorate when 40 years ago Chilean Air Force jets bombed the palace, helping to overthrow an elected socialist government and obliterate what had been one of South America’s healthiest democracies.

headline: ‘Paraíso’
abstract: The Op-Doc “Paraíso” (Paradise) reveals the beauty and danger experienced by three immigrant window cleaners who work on Chicago’s skyscrapers.
lead_paragraph: I first got the idea for this film (whose title, “Paraíso,” is the Spanish word for “Paradise”) when I was living in Chicago working as a film editor. One morning, as I sat at my desk in a high-rise downtown, a man dropped down inches from my window, cleaned it, and disappeared to the next floor. This momentary interaction seemed a perfect metaphor for life in many multiethnic American cities where the work of immigrants often goes unnoticed. I hoped to find out more about what motivated these men to spend their working days dangling hundreds of feet in the air.

headline: Paraíso
abstract: The Op-Doc “Paraíso” (Paradise) reveals the beauty and danger of three immigrant window cleaners’ work on Chicago’s skyscrapers.
lead_paragraph: The Op-Doc “Paraíso” (Paradise) reveals the beauty and danger of three immigrant window cleaners’ work on Chicago’s skyscrapers.

headline: The Wonk Gap
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: What the G.O.P. doesn’t know can hurt us.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday, Senator John Barrasso of Wyoming delivered the weekly Republican address. He ignored Syria, presumably because his party is deeply conflicted on the issue. (For the record, so am I.) Instead, he demanded repeal of the Affordable Care Act. “The health care law,” he declared, “has proven to be unpopular, unworkable and unaffordable,” and he predicted “sticker shock” in the months ahead.

headline: Our New Isolationism
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: How does a president sell foreign involvement to a gun-shy public?
lead_paragraph: THE United States has just spent thousands of American lives in a distant land for a victory that now seems hollow, if indeed it can be called a victory at all. Our own country, moreover, is emerging from a recession, dispirited and self-absorbed, worried about the fragility of the recovery and the state of our democracy. Idealism is in short supply. So, as another far-off war worsens, Americans are loath to take sides, even against a merciless dictator, even to the extent of sending weapons. The voices opposed to getting involved range from the pacifist left to the populist right. The president, fearful that foreign conflict will undermine his domestic agenda, vacillates.

headline: Conquering the Wind, Williams Enters Rarefied Air With a 17th Title
abstract: Serena Williams, in a rematch of the 2012 women’s final, defeated Victoria Azarenka, 7-5, 6-7 (6), 6-1, to win her 17th Grand Slam singles title, including five at the U.S. Open.
lead_paragraph: As it turned out, after 2 hours 45 minutes of raw emotion and territorial tennis, Serena Williams really could play in the wind, just as she has played and prevailed in so many conditions and circumstances through the years.

headline: Mindlessly Gutting Food Stamps
abstract: House Republicans blame the needy for the lingering costs of recession.
lead_paragraph: Among the many scars of the recession, the most intolerable should be the pangs of chronic hunger that still assail a stunning 14.5 percent of the nation’s households, according to the Department of Agriculture’s latest survey. A decade ago, the figure was 11 percent — a group defined as regularly suffering food “insecurity,” or having 26 percent less to spend on food than households not going hungry. The survey shows that food insecurity rose with the recession and has remained stubbornly high.

headline: Spying on Muslims
abstract: The New York Police Department’s indefensible program of spying on law-abiding citizens is more aggressive than earlier reports had shown.
lead_paragraph: The New York City Police Department’s indefensible program of spying on law-abiding Muslims in their neighborhoods and houses of worship has turned out to be even more aggressive than earlier reports had shown.

headline: President of Mexico Proposes Tax Overhaul
abstract: President Enrique Peña Nieto described the outline of a sweeping plan intended to collect billions of dollars to finance new social programs.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Pressing ahead with plans to reshape Mexico’s economy, President Enrique Peña Nieto proposed on Sunday a sweeping overhaul of his country’s tax system, intended to collect billions of dollars to finance new social programs.

headline: Latest Overhaul of the MGM Studio Appears to Be a Moneymaker
abstract: After emerging from bankruptcy and cutting costs, the venerable studio is generating cash and has a number of movies and TV shows in the works.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — For much of the last decade, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has been troubled by financial turmoil and infuriating production stops and starts, including a debacle in which Tom Cruise helped run its United Artists label.

headline: Privacy, When Your Shoes Track Every Step
abstract: As more and more everyday objects are connected to the Internet, how can we minimize the privacy risks?

headline: U.S. Colleges in Less Open Societies
abstract: Readers react to an article that was critical of American university branches in authoritarian countries.

headline: India in Reverse
abstract: The country needs decisive reforms to revive growth, control inflation and support the rupee.
lead_paragraph: India’s once booming economy is sliding into a deep slump. The country grew just 4.4 percent this summer, a far cry from the 7.7 percent average for the past decade. Its currency, the rupee, has tumbled 16 percent against the dollar in the last three months. And analysts expect things to get even worse in the coming months.

headline: Celebration Gives Way to Questions and Doubt After a Record Swim
abstract: Diana Nyad became the first person to swim the 110-plus-mile route from Cuba to Key West, Fla., without a shark cage, but afterward, some questioned if she was truly unaided.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps it was inevitable: Minutes after Diana Nyad, the 64-year-old marathon swimmer, landed on the sandy shores of Key West, Fla., succeeding in her fifth attempt to swim the straits from Cuba, fellow swimmers unleashed a barrage of censure and doubt.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Q. & A. with Karen Elson at Diane von Furstenberg
abstract: The British model and musician, who opened DVF’s show today, talks about runway jitters and her recently popular haircut.
lead_paragraph: Individualized beauty was the theme backstage at Diane von Furstenberg today, and really, who better to embody a fiercely unique look than the show’s opener, the British model and musician Karen Elson? With her fiery red hair and haunting complexion, Elson is hardly one to nod to conformity. T stole a few moments with the seasoned runway pro to speak about walking for a fashion legend, her much-talked-about haircut (she wore extensions for the runway), and why she still gets pre-show jitters.

headline: To Recount the Financial Implosion, a Magazine Turns to Film
abstract: Bloomberg Businessweek is releasing a documentary, “Hank: Five Years From the Brink,” centered on the anniversary of the financial crisis and the Treasury secretary’s role in trying to contain it.
lead_paragraph: There are a few surprises in the documentary “Hank: Five Years From the Brink, ” a new film about the former Treasury Secretary Henry Paulson Jr. coming out on Thursday, five years after the financial meltdown on Wall Street.

headline: Kerry Asks European Union to Halt Ban on Aid to Israeli Institutions
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry said the move would show the Israeli public the benefit of pursuing a peace agreement with the Palestinians.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Secretary of State John Kerry said Sunday that he had asked the European Union to suspend its new restrictions on financial assistance to Israeli institutions in order to show the Israeli public the benefit of pursuing a peace agreement with the Palestinians.

keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'Law and Legislation', 'Citizenship and Naturalization', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: With the Syria debate and the budget crowding the House agenda, any action on a bill overhauling the immigration system may be delayed until well into 2014.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Congress is likely to postpone consideration of an immigration overhaul until the end of the year, if not longer, even as advocates are preparing for an all-out, urgent push this fall to win their longstanding goal of a path to citizenship for millions of immigrants here illegally.

headline: People Magazine to Offer New Subscription Deals
abstract: People remains the backbone of Time Inc.’s magazine empire. But the median age of its readers is 44.6, a number it hopes to freshen up.
lead_paragraph: As magazines have scrambled to find new revenue sources, People has stuck with a model that has worked for nearly four decades: high-paying and loyal subscribers, now about 3.5 million, and advertising. Now the magazine is changing its subscription model, adding a tiered plan to what has long been considered the financial backbone of Time Inc.’s magazine empire.

headline: The Artist’s Grave

keywords: ['Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Identity Theft']
abstract: No one has accused Barrett Brown, a journalist with ties to the hacker group Anonymous, of playing a role in the theft of data, only of posting a link to a trove of stolen documents.
lead_paragraph: Barrett Brown makes for a pretty complicated victim. A Dallas-based journalist obsessed with the government’s ties to private security firms, Mr. Brown has been in jail for a year, facing charges that carry a combined penalty of more than 100 years in prison.

abstract: A decision by President François Hollande to back President Obama’s call for a military strike against Syria is playing very badly at home.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — As portrayed in a satirical television show here this week, President François Hollande is left behind to hold President Obama’s coat while the American leader and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia hold private talks. Mr. Hollande gullibly concludes he is playing a key role.

headline: Stargazing Day 3.5: Weekend Soundtrack

lead_paragraph: The hip-hop artist Kanye West was the talk of the weekend. On Saturday, he turned up at Louise Goldin around the lunch hour and then a few hours later at Alexander Wang, where he caused such a camera frenzy that his neighbor Miguel remarked, “This is kind of crazy.”

headline: Rookie May Not Be Perfect, but He Provides Reason to Hope
abstract: Geno Smith scrambled away from traffic, drew a flag and gave the Jets a chance to win against the Buccaneers. He also gave Jets fans an unfamiliar feeling: confidence in the quarterback.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The signature play of the start of the Geno Smith era took place late in the fourth quarter, with the outcome all but decided, on yet another Sunday afternoon when it appeared the Jets would lose a game they should have won.

headline: Paul Scoon, Who Invited Grenada Invaders, Dies at 78
abstract: Mr. Scoon was appointed to the ceremonial post of governor general of Grenada before playing the role of power broker when the United States invaded his Caribbean nation.
lead_paragraph: Paul Scoon, who vaulted from the mainly ceremonial post of governor general of Grenada to the role of power broker when the United States invaded his Caribbean nation in 1983, died on Sept. 2 in St. Paul’s, Grenada. He was 78.

headline: Once the Sport of Teenagers, Tennis Grows Older and Stronger
abstract: Teenagers once rose to the top of the professional ranks. But tennis is a sport for adults today, and everyone is benefiting.
lead_paragraph: Arthur Ashe Stadium loomed as a giant and seductive backdrop to a packed Court 11, where the American teenager Alicia Black lost a third-set tiebreaker to Ana Konjuh of Croatia on Sunday in the junior girls’ final of the United States Open. Symbolically, the big stage was more of a distant star twinkling in the sky above the Billie Jean King National Tennis Center.

headline: William C. Campbell, a Leader in Golf, Dies at 90
abstract: Mr. Campbell was a champion of golf’s amateur era who later led his sport’s two most prestigious governing organizations.
lead_paragraph: William C. Campbell, a champion of golf’s amateur era who later led his sport’s two most prestigious governing organizations, died on Aug. 30 at his home in Lewisburg, W.Va. He was 90.

Catsimatidis made their final pitch to Republican voters on Sunday, clashing at a debate on WNBC-TV in which Mr. Lhota sought to leave the impression Mr. Catsimatidis was not a serious candidate, and Mr. Catsimatidis argued that Mr. Lhota was a meanspirited technocrat who lacked big ideas.

headline: Bonding With Beards, the Red Sox Repair Their Clubhouse Chemistry
abstract: Facial hair is running rampant as Boston, one season removed from a miserable 93-loss campaign, is on top of the American League East.
lead_paragraph: The Boston Red Sox take their craft seriously. Catcher David Ross owns a special comb. First baseman Mike Napoli has reached a level of forestation so impenetrable that a family of squirrels could be living on his face. And pitcher Andrew Miller has stayed true enough to the cause that he said his wife had “given up the battle.”

abstract: Bonding with beards, the Red Sox have rediscovered clubhouse chemistry in their return to the top of the American League East.
