headline: On Both Sides, Syrians Make Pleas to U.S.
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Social Media', 'United States International Relations', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)']
abstract: As lawmakers prepare to debate a strike on the Assad government, Syrians on both sides of the issue work to influence Congress and the American public.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The video from Kafranbel, a rebel-held village in northern Syria, has been sent by e-mail to members of the United States Congress and posted repeatedly on their Web sites — often in long strings of comments about Syria that have flooded unrelated posts about health care or the openings of new constituent offices.

headline: Inquiry Finds Inadequate Staffing at Mississippi Veterans Hospital
abstract: Problems at a Jackson, Miss., unit will be among the topics discussed at a special field hearing of the House Committee on Veterans’ Affairs in Pittsburgh on Monday.
lead_paragraph: An internal investigation by the Department of Veterans Affairs has found that one of its hospitals in Jackson, Miss., did not have enough doctors in its primary care unit, resulting in nurse practitioners’ handling far too many patients, numerous complaints about delayed care and repeated violations of federal rules on prescribing narcotics.

headline: Democratic Candidates Urge Supporters to Push Voters to the Polls
abstract: Two days before the citywide primary, candidates reminded supporters that the real work would be to persuade their friends and neighbors to vote Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: They hit the church circuit, fielded questions on street corners, and inhaled too many cups of coffee to count. They traveled to far-flung corners of New York City, promoted plans on education and affordable housing, and took pains in interviews to come across as down-to-earth.

headline: Jets Replay: Week 1
abstract: Geno Smith passed for 256 yards in his debut and Nick Folk hit a long field goal with seconds left, as the Jets beat the Buccaneers, 18-17, at home.
lead_paragraph: Geno Smith passed for 256 yards in his debut and Nick Folk hit a long field goal with seconds left, as the Jets beat the Buccaneers, 18-17, at home.

headline: Embarking on a New Life, Transgender Woman Has It Brutally Taken
abstract: Islan Nettles, 21, who was killed last month in Harlem, had recently transformed from a shy, insecure youth into a radiant young woman who was designing her own fashion line.
lead_paragraph: The transformation of Islan Nettles over the last year was something her friends and relatives discussed with barely concealed awe.

headline: In a More Diverse City, a More Diverse Slate of Mayoral Candidates

lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Like many of the candidates running for mayor here, John Barros attended house party after house party over the weekend.

headline: Led by Golfers From Alabama, U.S. Rolls to Walker Cup Win

lead_paragraph: SOUTHAMPTON, N.Y. — The one-two punch of Bobby Wyatt and Justin Thomas finished their matches in such rapid succession that Jay Seawell, their coach on the University of Alabama golf team, jogged up the 15th fairway to see it.

lead_paragraph: Eighteen people, including 12 children, were injured at a festival in Norwalk, Conn., on Sunday when they fell from a carnival ride that had lost power, the authorities said.

headline: Obama Tests Limits of Power in Syrian Conflict
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Law and Legislation', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)']
abstract: President Obama’s approach to Syria is likely to create an important precedent in the often murky legal question of when presidents or nations may lawfully use military force.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In asking Congress to authorize an attack on Syria over claims it used chemical weapons, President Obama has chosen to involve lawmakers in deciding whether to undertake a military intervention that in some respects resembles the limited types that many presidents — Ronald Reagan in Grenada, Bill Clinton in Kosovo and even Mr. Obama in Libya — have launched on their own.

abstract: The United States, with four new players in camp on Sunday, will look to improve its defense in Tuesday’s World Cup qualifier.

lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — After seven years of playing basketball in five countries, Michelle Campbell, at 29, finally achieved her dream of reaching the W.N.B.A. Campbell, who was cut from her first W.N.B.A. training camp after graduating from Rutgers in 2006, is a 6-foot-2-inch rookie reserve forward for the Chicago Sky, the Eastern Conference regular-season champions.

headline: Life’s Hard Lessons
keywords: ['Medicine and Health', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Seasonal Affective Disorder (SAD)', 'Unemployment']
abstract: A new book by the psychiatrist Norman E. Rosenthal, “The Gift of Adversity,” offers life-changing lessons and insight in how to deal with setbacks.
lead_paragraph: Every so often an especially insightful book prompts me to reflect on or change my behavior, attitudes or both. Years ago, after reading “Type A Behavior and Your Heart” by two San Francisco cardiologists, Dr. Meyer Friedman and Dr. Ray H. Rosenman, I learned to reduce stress and hostility by cramming less into my days and allowing adequate time to accomplish whatever I had to do.

lead_paragraph: Opening Ceremony, the international retailer that is like a hipster factory, decided to have its first runway show this Fashion Week for its signature collection, designed by the owners Carol Lim and Humberto Leon.

headline: What’s on Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 7:30 P.M. (HBO) WYNTON MARSALIS: A YOUNGARTS MASTERCLASS YoungArts, a program of the National YoungArts Foundation, has offered scholarships and mentors to high school artists for more than 30 years. This Season 3 premiere of the Emmy-nominated “MasterClass” series, directed by the Oscar-winning filmmakers Karen Goodman and Kirk Simon and featuring sessions between students and acclaimed artists, focuses on Mr. Marsalis, above, the artistic director of Jazz at Lincoln Center and the first jazz artist to be awarded the Pulitzer Prize in music, for his oratorio “Blood on the Fields.” “Jazz is the only music in the world where four people sit up on a bandstand, and they have to give shape and logic and form to music as they’re making it,” he says as he prepares the saxophonist Patrick Bartley, the pianist Tony Madruga and the bass player Russell Hall for a performance. “What musicians do and artists do is they give form to chaos.”

headline: Grim Debut for Giants as Errors Pile Up
abstract: In a seesaw game befitting what has become an exhilarating if unpredictable rivalry, the Giants were unable to overcome six turnovers in a season-opening loss to the Cowboys.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Tex. — Three possessions into their season-opening game with the Dallas Cowboys on Sunday night, the Giants had thrown two interceptions and lost a fumble.

headline: N.S.A. Spied on Brazilian Oil Company, Report Says
abstract: The latest revelation, based on documents from Edward J. Snowden, does not indicate what information the N.S.A. wanted about Petrobras.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — The National Security Agency spied on Petrobras, Brazil’s giant national oil company, according to a report here on Sunday night by the Globo television network, in the latest revelation of the agency’s surveillance methods that have raised tension between Brazil and the United States.

headline: Jets Close-Up
abstract: Key plays from the Jets-Buccaneers game.
lead_paragraph: KEY/PLAY PERFORMANCE The late hit by Lavonte David on Geno Smith that ushered the Jets into range for the winning field goal was indicative of the Buccaneers’ lack of discipline Sunday. They committed 13 penalties for 102 yards, and four were personal fouls.

abstract: Under tough conditions, Serena Williams desperately needed a rock to lean on in the Open final. That rock was her backhand.
lead_paragraph: When the wind howled around the court and the wolves howled in her head Sunday, Serena Williams desperately needed a rock to lean on in the final of the United States Open against Victoria Azarenka.

lead_paragraph: Jihad Allaham, the speaker of the Syrian People’s Assembly, wrote to Rep. John A. Boehner as Congress prepares to debate a military strike on Syria.

headline: Facebook Offers New Windows Into Social Conversation
abstract: The company is trying to compete aggressively with Twitter by offering tools — first available to select news organizations — that surface the public conversation occurring on its platform.
lead_paragraph: Facebook is releasing two new search tools on Monday designed to give news organizations — and potentially, marketers — more insights into the real-time social conversation occurring on Facebook, particularly around television shows, big news and sporting events.

headline: Shy of Runoff, Challenger Demands Recounts in Moscow Mayoral Race
abstract: Official results showed that the incumbent won outright, but Aleksei A. Navalny accused the authorities of stealing votes and called for a recount.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — A surprisingly strong finish in the Moscow mayoral race by Aleksei A. Navalny, the anti-Putin opposition leader, was convincing enough to assure him new credibility as a mainstream political contender. Falling just short of forcing a second round of balloting also positioned him to continue in his familiar role accusing the authorities of fraud and corruption.

headline: India Sends Security Forces to North After Deadly Clashes
abstract: India deployed thousands of police officers and army troops on Monday, after weekend confrontations between Hindus and Muslims killed at least 30 people.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — India deployed thousands of police officers and army troops to a region in the north of the country on Monday after weekend confrontations between Hindus and Muslims killed at least 30 people and gravely injured many more, according to the police.

headline: A van Gogh’s Trip From the Attic to the Museum
abstract: The work, titled “Sunset at Montmajour,” was painted in Arles in 1888. For decades, it was considered a fake and consigned to an attic.
lead_paragraph: AMSTERDAM — For roughly a century, the painting “Sunset at Montmajour” was considered a fake. It was stored in an attic and then held in a private collection, unknown to the public and dismissed by art historians. But on Monday, the Van Gogh Museum declared the work a genuine product of the master, calling it a major discovery.

headline: Test Yourself | E.L.L. Practice, Sept. 9, 2013
abstract: A sentence-scramble quiz and some related ideas for teaching about Sept. 11, 2001.
lead_paragraph: Note to teachers:  The content of this week’s edition of E.L.L. Practice, a new feature we’ve begun just for English language learners, is in commemoration of the 12th anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks. Please make sure the content is appropriate for your students.

headline: The “Shame of Memory” Haunts a War Photographer
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'News and News Media', 'Photography', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: With the looming crisis in Syria as backdrop, conflict photographers and photo editors of multiple generations debate the value and power of the imagery that emerges from war.
lead_paragraph: PERPIGNAN, France — A 13th-century church is a fitting location for the exhibition of war photographs by Don McCullin, a man intent on paying public penance. Most photographers would be proud of the honors and accolades showered on Mr. McCullin at Perpignan’s Visa Pour l’Image festival this week.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Tokyo to Host 2020 Olympics
abstract: Why was Tokyo chosen to host the 2020 Olympics?

Do you think they are good indicators of future success, as students and then as contributors in one’s chosen field? How would you award scholarships?

headline: A Conversation With: Civil Rights Activist Khurram Pervez
abstract: The moral obligation for the killing of four men on Saturday in Shopian district of Jammu and Kashmir lies on the shoulders of German Ambassador to India Michael Steiner, Mr. Pervez says.
lead_paragraph: A heated political debate accompanied a concert by the world-renowned conductor Zubin Mehta and the Bavarian State Orchestra on Saturday in Srinagar in Indian-administered Kashmir. Several separatist politicians and members of civil society groups were critical of Mr. Mehta’s decision to participate in a concert organized and managed by the German Embassy in India and by the federal and state Indian governments.  In response to the concert, titled “Ehsaas-e-Kashmir” (The Feel of Kashmir), civil society members in Srinagar organized a parallel cultural program, “Haqeeqat-e-Kashmir” (The Reality of Kashmir), in a municipal park.

headline: New York Today: Teachable Moment

headline: Two More Writers for Shakespeare Effort
abstract: Margaret Atwood and Howard Jacobson are the latest authors to be commissioned by Penguin Random House’s Hogarth imprint to write their interpretations of plays by Shakespeare, the publisher is to announce on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Margaret Atwood and Howard Jacobson are the latest authors to be commissioned by Penguin Random House’s Hogarth imprint to write their interpretations of plays by Shakespeare, the publisher is to announce on Monday. Ms. Atwood will tackle “The Tempest,” while Mr. Jacobson has chosen “The Merchant of Venice.” They join Anne Tyler, who will provide her own take on “The Taming of the Shrew,” and Jeanette Winterson, who will reimagine “The Winter’s Tale.” The plays are scheduled to be published in print, digital and audio formats in 2016 to coincide with the 400th anniversary of Shakespeare’s death as part of the Hogarth Shakespeare project. In a news release, Ms. Atwood said that she had selected “The Tempest” because it “has always been a favorite of mine, and working on it will be an invigorating challenge. Is Caliban the first talking monster? Not quite, but close.” Mr. Jacobson also gave his reasons for selecting “The Merchant of Venice”: “For an English novelist, Shakespeare is where it all begins. For an English novelist who also happens to be Jewish, ‘The Merchant of Venice’ is where it all snarls up.” He added: “ ‘Who is the merchant and who is the Jew?’ Portia wanted to know. Four hundred years later, the question needs to be reframed: ‘Who is the hero of this play, and who is the villain?’ ” Hogarth plans to announce more writers for the project in the future.

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Adam Sternbergh on the New Rules of Popularity
abstract: The magazine’s culture editor examines why “Gone Girl” is truly popular but Miley Cyrus’s twerking isn’t; why a film doesn’t need to be a blockbuster anymore; and whether he’s a low-brow snob.
lead_paragraph: Adam Sternbergh, the magazine’s culture editor, wrote the opening essay in this week’s collection of articles on what makes movies, books and music popular. He last wrote for the magazine about the enduring appeal of “Die Hard.”

headline: Russia’s Rigged Election Game
abstract: Was there a right way to vote in Moscow’s mayoral election?
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Election time is special in my family. My partner is an electoral geographer who wrote her dissertation on mapping voting fraud in Russia. Our courtship six years ago involved texting back and forth about the campaign underway then. I was not going to vote; she was. My argument was that Russian elections are a farce — the Kremlin controls who gets on the ballot, who gets air time on television and who wins — and I wanted to play no role in legitimizing them. Darya’s argument was that civic participation, however flawed, should never be forfeited.

headline: Daily Report: Microsoft’s Growth Raises Concerns About Its Focus
abstract: At a time when many people in business believe the number of products at Microsoft should be getting smaller, it is about to become a lot bigger.
lead_paragraph: At a time when many people in business believe the number of products at Microsoft should be getting smaller, it is about to become a lot bigger, Nick Wingfield reports.

headline: Desegregation and the Public Schools
abstract: Retro Report: Three decades after court-ordered busing began in Charlotte and other cities, many plans have come undone and integration has diminished.
lead_paragraph: In many northern cities, the 1974 United States Supreme Court decision Milliken v. Bradley killed any hopes of integrating the public schools. That ruling, involving Detroit and its suburbs, said that a mandatory plan to achieve integration by busing black children from Detroit across district lines to mainly white suburbs was unconstitutional. The result accelerated white flight to the suburbs, leaving the schools in urban centers even more segregated than they had been.

headline: The Battle for Busing
abstract: A story of America’s school integration and what happened when the buses stopped rolling.
lead_paragraph: A story of America’s school integration and what happened when the buses stopped rolling.

headline: Australia’s New Leader May Find Governing Harder Than Criticizing

headline: Here’s What Happened When I Introduced Profit Sharing
abstract: Well, for one thing, the business owner did not get the reaction he was expecting from his workers.
lead_paragraph: About half of my employees had been involved in devising the profit-sharing program I have been writing about the past few weeks, but the other half had heard only rumors. So I made a formal announcement of the program at the end of April. Before the meeting, I taped a large printout of the program, as shown above, to our whiteboard.

headline: Toronto Video: Brad Pitt on ’12 Years a Slave’

lead_paragraph: TORONTO — The red carpet was rolled out for the period drama “12 Years a Slave” here, with several cast members attending a gala screening on Friday. They included the star of the pre-Civil War drama, Chiwetel Ejiofor, who plays a free New Yorker who is kidnapped and sold into slavery in the South, and Brad Pitt, who also served as a producer of the movie. In this video from the Toronto International Film Festival, Mr. Pitt spoke about working with the British director Steve McQueen to make a film about American slavery.

headline: How the S.E.C. Threw In the Towel on Lehman
abstract: The government faces questions about the decision to spare Lehman Brothers executives. | The owners of Neiman Marcus are near a deal to sell the luxury retailer. | Verizon paid dearly for waiting to acquire Vodafone’s stake in its wireless venture. | Harvard Business School conducted a two-year experiment to foster female success.
lead_paragraph: THE END OF THE BID TO PUNISH LEHMAN EXECUTIVES  |  At a closed-door meeting in early 2011, the Securities and Exchange Commission’s eight-member Lehman Brothers team concluded that suing the bank’s executives would be legally unjustified, Ben Protess and Susanne Craig report in DealBook. “The group, noting that prosecutors and F.B.I. agents had already walked away from a parallel criminal case, reached unanimous agreement to close its most prominent investigation stemming from the financial crisis, according to officials who attended the meeting, which has not been reported previously.”

headline: Lessons from Thailand?
abstract: Egyptians should be careful what lessons it learns from Thailand.
lead_paragraph: Contrary to Jonathan Tepperman’s claim in “Can Egypt learn from Thailand?” (Views, Aug. 24), Thailand was not a “virtual wreck” when the current government of Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra took over from the Democrat Party in 2011. Thailand had a record level of foreign reserves and national debt was just over 41 percent of G.D.P., while it’s closer to 45 percent and rising now. Thailand is far from “booming;” the country is in a recession.

headline: Make Japan Chaste and Continent, But Not Yet
abstract: No tax increase now, please.
lead_paragraph: So far, Abenomics has been going really, really well. By signaling that the Bank of Japan has changed, that it won’t snatch away the sake bottle just as the party gets going, that it’s going to target sustained positive inflation — and also by signaling that some fiscal stimulus is forthcoming despite high levels of debt — Japanese authorities have achieved a remarkable turnaround in short-term economic performance.

headline: C’est La V No More
abstract: Postmodern recessions and the 2008 crisis.
lead_paragraph: Dean Baker weighs in on the self-correcting economy discussion — it’s not really a debate — and expresses some skepticism about whether we can expect a recovery even in the Keynesian long run. Fair enough. But a quibble: Dean seems to think that I’m saying that 2008 was unique and completely unlike previous recessions. Actually that was never my view — and my actual view ties in with some of the arguments David Warsh makes in his attack on Larry Summers.

lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase said on Monday that its board intended to elect two new directors.

headline: Toronto Report: The Rebirth of Matthew McConaughey
abstract: A screening of “Dallas Buyers Club” seals the return of Matthew McConaughey.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — One of the great stories right now in movies is the resurrection of Matthew McConaughey. His transformation from a lazily uncommitted prop in throwaways like “Fool’s Gold” to one of the most appealing actors working in American film today began a few years ago, with the likes of “Bernie” and “The Lincoln Lawyer,” and continues with “Dallas Buyers Club,” which had its premiere at the Toronto International Film Festival on Saturday. Directed by Jean-Marc Vallée and written by Craig Borten and Melisa Wallack, this fine movie tracks another rebirth, that of Ron Woodroof, a Texas electrician who, beginning in the mid-1980s, became an accidental AIDS activist.

headline: The Cloud Era Begins for Enterprise Tech

lead_paragraph: Let’s say it: Last summer was the beginning of the end for the old guard in what is still the biggest part of technology – business spending on everything from servers to software. This fall begins a new competition for the hearts and minds of corporate customers.

lead_paragraph: After months of fighting and a seemingly inexhaustible stream of sharp-tongued letters, Carl C. Icahn is ending his battle against Dell’s proposed sale to its founder.

headline: Soda Bread With Walnuts and Golden Raisins

lead_paragraph: This Irish soda bread is inspired by a classic, made with white flour and currants, called “spotty dog.” My whole wheat version proved to be the perfect home for some particularly luscious golden raisins and walnuts that I get from a vendor at my farmers’ market.

headline: Detroit Institute of Arts Amending Policy on Donations
abstract: The Detroit Institute of Arts said it planned to amend its policy for accepting donations to try to provide an extra layer of legal protection.
lead_paragraph: The Detroit Institute of Arts, whose world-class collection has become a target for creditors seeking billions of dollars in Detroit’s municipal bankruptcy case, said it planned to amend its policy for accepting donations of art, to try to provide an extra layer of legal protection against forced sales of work for purposes other than acquiring new art.

headline: On a Bright Morning, New York Students Head Back to School

lead_paragraph: Lugging backpacks, wiping away tears, high-fiving friends not seen in a while, children across New York’s five boroughs flooded into freshly cleaned and decorated classrooms as the nation’s largest school system marked the first day of the academic year.

headline: Fantasy Football: Rating the Rookies, Part 2

lead_paragraph: After analyzing quarterbacks and running backs in our first installment, we are back to break down receivers and tight ends. Opportunities exist at receiver for players to break out, and we rank our top 10 to see who can help your fantasy team at a cheap value.

headline: Justice for Kenya
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: The International Criminal Court case is the first step toward the end of impunity and the beginning of peace.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — ON Tuesday, the eyes of Kenya will be firmly fixed on The Hague, where the trial of the country’s deputy president, William Ruto, and his co-defendant, Joshua arap Sang, an influential radio executive, is set to begin before the International Criminal Court. They have been charged with crimes against humanity for their alleged roles in the violence that rocked Kenya in late 2007 and early 2008. Kenya’s president, Uhuru Kenyatta, will face similar charges in a related case set for trial in November.

headline: First Apartments of Future Rivals
abstract: Mayoral candidates were asked about the first places they lived as young adults, and though some had trouble remembering the addresses, most looked back fondly.

headline: Mayoral Candidates Recall the Days of Tiny and Grimy
keywords: ['Elections, Mayors', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: The people now seeking to live rent-free in Gracie Mansion recalled with fondness the small spaces in Brooklyn, Queens and Manhattan where they started out.
lead_paragraph: One apartment did not have space for a bed. Another had an exposed brick wall that had been left unsealed, and so spread a fine sprinkling of dust around the apartment. A third apartment had a bathtub in the kitchen.

headline: Palmer Mebane’s Combonoku
abstract: Try Combonoku — an original challenge by world puzzle champion Palmer Mebane.
lead_paragraph: This week we present Combonoku — an original creation by Palmer Mebane, a world champion puzzle solver (and expert creator) who currently works as an instructor for Art of Problem Solving. We’ll have the opportunity to take on three versions: easy, medium and hard. Mr. Mebane calls the medium version, which he created for a recent U.S.A. Mathematical Talent Search, “one of the best U.S.A.M.T.S. puzzles I’ve managed to write. It’s not often that you can simultaneously get a nice symmetric-looking pattern of givens and an interesting puzzle at the same time.” The hard version is also beautifully constructed, but was something Mr. Mebane shared with puzzle geeks only, because it is “way too hard to use in any math contest.”

lead_paragraph: Current guidelines require that heart attack victims undergo balloon angioplasty, a procedure for widening a narrowed artery, within 90 minutes of entering the hospital and many hospitals have met that goal.

abstract: With the addition of plump, seared shrimp, a beloved side dish can stand on its own.
lead_paragraph: What’s for Dinner? answers that universal question, offering recipes for simple, relatively quick dishes that use ingredients you can pick up on the way home.

headline: Google Makes New Offer to Settle Its European Union Antitrust Case
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Search Engines', 'Online Advertising']
abstract: The Internet giant said it made a second attempt to settle an antitrust inquiry it faces in Europe over accusations that it abuses its dominance in Internet search and advertising.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Google made a second try last week to settle a three-year-old antitrust case with the European Union, officials said. Neither side released details of the offer, however, and rivals continued to call for the American technology company to cede more control of its Internet search and advertising business.

headline: Image of the Day: September 9
abstract: Ganesh Chaturthi, the birthday of Hindu god Ganesha, was celebrated by devotees in Mumbai, Maharashtra, on Monday.

headline: At Goldman, a Paycheck No Longer Equals an Account
abstract: For years, employees at Goldman Sachs automatically received a brokerage account. But in recent months, the firm has notified several employees, most of whom have assets valued at less than $1 million, that their accounts are being transferred to Fidelity.
lead_paragraph: Getting a job at Goldman Sachs may be a ticket to great wealth, but it no longer comes with an automatic brokerage account at the Wall Street firm.

headline: European Rail Crashes Show Gaps in an Increasingly Precarious System
abstract: A spate of deadly train wrecks has highlighted the patchwork nature of the network, where high-speed 21st-century trains often run on 19th-century rails.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — In the wake of a fiery train crash this summer in northern Spain that killed 79 people, investigators, survivors and passengers are demanding to know why the rail line entrusted the train’s safety to a sole driver who had publicly boasted about past speeding and was talking on a mobile phone seconds before the derailment.

headline: Letting a Child Walk Alone
abstract: My daughter was ready to walk to school alone, but I wasn’t ready to let her go.
lead_paragraph: My oldest child wanted to take the piano lessons her school offered during the time before classes started. I loved the idea, but the needs of my younger kids would make it difficult for me to get her there. The obvious solution — letting her walk by herself, to a school we walked to together daily — threw me into a panic.

headline: Heroes of the Sabine Pass
abstract: How black and white Texans remembered a critical battle of September 1863.

headline: A Data Weapon to Avoid the Next Financial Crisis

lead_paragraph: Many economists see a data revolution that could transform their field, opening a window to seeing and measuring economic behavior in greater detail than ever before. The potential — and limitations — of what can be thought of as Big Data economics was the topic of my column over the weekend.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Public Relations and Publicity', 'Hiring and Promotion']
abstract: Advertising spending in the United States rose 3.5 percent in the second quarter compared with the same period a year ago, according to a report by the Kantar Media unit of WPP.
lead_paragraph: Advertising spending in the United States rose 3.5 percent in the second quarter compared with the same period a year ago, according to a report released Monday by the Kantar Media unit of WPP. For the first half, Kantar Media said, American ad spending rose 2 percent from the first half of 2012. The second quarter’s increase represented the sixth quarterly gain in a row, Kantar Media reported; results for the first quarter, which initially showed a decline of 0.1 percent, were subsequently revised to show a gain of 0.3 percent. Media with growth in ad revenue in the second quarter, according to the report, included outdoor, up 7.4 percent; television, up 6.4 percent; and magazines, up 1.6 percent. Media that lost ad revenue in the second quarter included newspapers, down 3.6 percent, and radio, down 2.2 percent.

headline: Jimmy Carter Seeks to Write Book on Treatment of Women
abstract: A proposal has circulated among major publishers for a book written by the former president.
lead_paragraph: Jimmy Carter, whose prolific postpresidential career as an author has covered aging, his Southern boyhood and the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, is now tackling the treatment of women.

headline: S.&P.’s Counterattack on the Government
keywords: ['Collateralized Debt Obligations', 'Credit Ratings and Credit Rating Agencies', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Mortgage-Backed Securities', 'National Debt (US)', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: In its defense against a Justice Department lawsuit, Standard & Poor’s argues that it was improperly targeted because it lowered the credit rating on federal debt two years ago. How far it will get with that argument is an open question.
lead_paragraph: With the start of the football season, we are sure to hear an analyst trot out the old cliché that the best defense is a good offense. But it certainly applies to the approach McGraw-Hill Companies is taking in defending its Standard & Poor’s unit against the fraud lawsuit filed by the Justice Department. In its defense, the company accuses the government of improperly targeting S.&P. because it lowered the credit rating on federal debt two years ago.

headline: Watching Tennis Can Improve the Games of Pros and Amateurs
abstract: Many amateurs — and professional players — report that seeing tennis played at the highest level provides helpful lessons on the court.
lead_paragraph: The blue skies and brisk breezes of early September mark the end of the United States Open, and its corresponding state of near-total immersion in the shifting fortunes of professional tennis players. For observers who play the sport, this often means an enthusiastic return to the court, after two mostly sedentary weeks on stadium benches and upholstered furniture. This does not mean, however, that they are out of practice: many amateurs report that seeing tennis played at the highest level improves their own games.

headline: Rogge’s Legacy Doesn’t Extend to the Oppressed
abstract: Under Jacques Rogge, 71, who will step down on Tuesday, the International Olympic Committee steered the middle ground on human rights issues.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — Twelve years ago, the International Olympic Committee traded an autocratic style of leadership for one that was considered inclusive, more democratic, less imperious.

headline: Video of the Kerry Remark Russia Seized Upon in Game of Diplomatic Chess
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Video of Secretary of State John Kerry suggesting at a news conference in London on Monday that Syria could avoid an attack by surrendering its chemical weapons this week.
lead_paragraph: Last Updated, 5:48 p.m. | At a news conference in London on Monday, Secretary of State John Kerry was asked by Margaret Brennan of CBS News if there was anything President Bashar al-Assad of Syria “could do or offer that would stop an attack?” As video posted online by Britain’s ITN shows, Mr. Kerry replied: “Sure. He could turn over every single bit of his chemical weapons to the international community in the next week. Turn it over, all of it, without delay, and allow a full and total accounting for that. But he isn’t about to do it, and it can’t be done, obviously.”

headline: Are Wasps Cannibals?
abstract: Some wasps are both carnivores and cannibals, with recent studies indicating that some were observed eating their own adult siblings.
lead_paragraph: Q. Moments after a wasp was squashed on my patio, another wasp sniffed at the body, scooped it up and flew off with it. Are wasps cannibals, or did he carry it off to give it a decent burial?

headline: Voigt Bows Out of ‘Tristan and Isolde’ in Washington
abstract: The soprano Deborah Voigt withdraws from the production a little more than a week before it opens.
lead_paragraph: The soprano Deborah Voigt has withdrawn from the role of Isolde in the Washington National Opera’s production of “Tristan and Isolde,” saying that the “unique challenges” of the part compelled her to bow out.  Ms. Voigt, 53, decided to leave the show a little more than a week before the curtain goes up and has been replaced by Iréne Theorin, a Swedish soprano.

headline: Manhattan Theater Club to Stage New Fierstein Play on Broadway
abstract: “Casa Valentina” will be the Tony winner’s first play on Broadway since 1987.
lead_paragraph: Harvey Fierstein, who won Tony Awards for best play and best actor in 1983 for his landmark gay drama, “Torch Song Trilogy,” but has mostly written musical scripts since then, has a new play coming to Broadway for the first time in nearly 30 years. “Casa Valentina,” a ’60s-era portrait of a Catskills vacation resort where heterosexual men would dress up and act as women, will begin previews on April 1 at Manhattan Theater Club’s Samuel J. Friedman Theater and open on April 23, the theater company announced on Monday.

lead_paragraph: As the 12th anniversary of Sept. 11, 2001, nears, a campaign is getting under way to help build awareness for the memorial museum devoted to what happened that day at the World Trade Center.

abstract: Those predicting a sharp slowdown in China a couple of months ago appear to have underestimated the central government’s determination to keep things on track, the author writes.

lead_paragraph: Bill de Blasio holds a wide lead heading into the Democratic primary for New York City mayor on Tuesday, two new polls find. But whether he will garner enough support to avoid a runoff remains to be seen.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Seashell-Like Updos at Carolina Herrera
abstract: Clean lines and flawless execution were key for this hairstyle by Orlando Pita.
lead_paragraph: “I especially like structured, architectural updos — and not many people let you do that,” the hair wiz Orlando Pita said at the Carolina Herrera show earlier today. Herrera, though, is just the kind of designer who appreciates classic, clean lines, which Pita played up in the sleek, tightly coiled updos seen on her runway. “The shape was inspired by a long seashell with a swirl at the top,” he said. To achieve the effect, he brushed strands straight and generously misted on By Byron Spirulina Hair Spray for grip. Hair was then parted off to the side and divided into two sections at the back, each of which was rolled in toward the scalp, leaving a loop at the top, and pinned in place. “I need it tighter here,” Pita said, cupping the base of a model’s updo and ordering a redo. (Fact: even the pros don’t nail things on the first attempt.) The finished result was entirely right for the Herrera woman. “This isn’t a jeans-and-a-jacket kind of look — it’s cocktails and an event,” Pita noted, as the delicate clouds of hair spray settled around him.

lead_paragraph: They were supposed to be respirator masks, but as a dark post-9/11 joke, some workers at ground zero called them “neck protectors.” The masks were so cumbersome and uncomfortable that many yanked them off and left them hanging around their necks.

headline: Kerry’s Comments on Syria Are a Shift Over Strike

abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry dangled the idea that Syria could avoid military action for the first time, though he was skeptical it could work.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Secretary of State John Kerry dangled for the first time on Monday actions that President Bashar al-Assad of Syria could take to avoid a military strike, it seemed an acknowledgment that Congress, America’s allies and the Russians were all looking for an off-ramp for what a week ago seemed like inevitable military action against Syria.

headline: Diabetes Epidemic Grows in China
abstract: The number of Chinese adults with Type 2 diabetes has risen to 114 million — 11. 6 percent of the population, compared with below 1 percent in 1980.
lead_paragraph: China has the world’s biggest diabetes epidemic, and it continues to get worse, according to the latest study of the disease’s devastating effects on the world’s most populous country, which has risen from poverty to become an economic superpower in 30 years.

headline: Italian Documentary Takes Top Prize at Venice Film Festival
abstract: “Sacro GRA,” by the Italian director Gianfranco Rosi, is named the best film at the Venice Film Festival.
lead_paragraph: “Sacro GRA,” a film by the Italian director Gianfranco Rosi about the unusual characters living around Rome’s ring road, became over the weekend the first documentary to win the Golden Lion for best film at the Venice Film Festival. It was the first year that nonfiction films were admitted to competition and the first time an Italian director had won since Gianni Amelio for “The Way We Laughed” in 1998.

headline: Time to Get the Flu Shots
abstract: At the first available opportunity, the members of my family will be rolling up our sleeves.
lead_paragraph: I just checked online to find out when our health care provider will hold its annual flu vaccine clinics. In early October, we’ll load up in the car and pull into the familiar parking lot with four children (who will by then be 7, 8, 9 and 12) in varying moods of acquiescence, reluctance and resignation. We’ll walk into the building (it’s been a few years since anyone had to be carried), and we’ll fill out our forms.

headline: Penicillin Allergies Overblown
abstract: Though one in 10 Americans avoids the antibiotic, a majority of them have no serious allergy and doctors lack the time to dispel their misunderstanding.
lead_paragraph: The woman with the swollen red leg was selling us one bill of goods after another. She said she had stopped injecting drugs years before; the fresh needle marks on her feet suggested otherwise. She said she had duly taken all the antibiotic pills another hospital had given her, although most people don’t finish those prescriptions.

headline: The Tweet Goes On for Icahn
abstract: Carl Icahn conceded defeat on Dell, but he has had better luck with Apple.
lead_paragraph: Carl Icahn won’t get the last tweet on Dell. The uppity billionaire has conceded defeat in his effort to block Michael Dell’s $24 billion buyout of the eponymous PC maker. Mr. Icahn’s logic never computed. His recent Apple bet is a stronger advertisement for his self-promotional parting shot to Dell shareholders.

headline: Rodman Gives Details on Trip to North Korea
abstract: The former N.B.A. star Dennis Rodman, who says he is trying to “open doors,” said he held Kim Jong-un’s baby daughter and agreed to train the North’s basketball team for the 2016 Olympics.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — The retired N.B.A. star Dennis Rodman said Monday that on his visit to North Korea last week, the country’s leader, Kim Jong-un, trusted him enough to let him hold his baby daughter and asked him to bring a team of former basketball stars for games in Pyongyang and train the North’s basketball team for the next Olympics.

headline: Three’s a Trend | The Spring Runways Serve Up Court-Friendly Looks
abstract: These ensembles were a reminder of the other show happening in New York besides Fashion Week: the United States Open.
lead_paragraph: The United States Open concludes tonight with a heated match between top seeds Rafael Nadal and Novak Djokovic. This of course has not been lost on the fashion set, despite the endless lineup of New York Fashion Week shows, where Lisa Perry, Lacoste and Louise Goldin coincidentally served up tennis-inspired ensembles. The real ace was Goldin’s look, which was accompanied on the runway by the soundtrack of an actual tennis rally. Game, set, match.

headline: Seven Isn’t the Magic Number for Short-Term Memory
abstract: A theory from an influential paper from the 1950s about the limits of short-term memory has been refined, but not supplanted.
lead_paragraph: We have seven deadly sins, seven days of the week, seven seas, seven dwarfs. The recurrence of the number seven so impressed the cognitive psychologist George A. Miller that, in an oft-cited paper in 1956, he wrote, “My problem is that I have been persecuted by an integer.”

headline: An Epitaph for Summer, Etched in the Senses
abstract: Shostakovich’s String Quartet No. 8 in C minor was the main attraction in a performance by the Cassatt String Quartet on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: It is always overpowering to hear a strong performance of Shostakovich’s wrenching and emotionally ambiguous String Quartet No. 8 in C minor. The excellent Cassatt String Quartet opened a program on late Sunday afternoon at Bargemusic in Brooklyn with a bold and probing account of this great piece.

headline: Polio Virus Found in Jerusalem’s Sewers

lead_paragraph: Polio virus has been found in Jerusalem’s sewers for the first time since Israel eliminated the disease, the nation’s Heath Ministry announced on Monday. No children are known to have been paralyzed by the disease.

lead_paragraph: Scientists in Indonesia have discovered a new species of walking shark that lives on the ocean floor and uses its fins to shuffle around, wiggling from side to side as it moves. Named hemiscyllium halmahera, the shark was described in Aqua, International Journal of Ichthyology.

headline: Male Sensitivity Written in the Genes
abstract: A crucial gene on the Y chromosome, SRY, that activates male development in a human embryo is surprisingly sensitive and vulnerable to environmental factors, a study finds.
lead_paragraph: In human development, certain genes act as master switches, ensuring that we are born with similar attributes (one head, two lungs, 10 fingers) in nearly all circumstances. Such genes tend to be highly reliable and resistant to environmental factors.

headline: The Pope Gets on the Line, and Everyone Is Talking
abstract: Pope Francis has taken to calling ordinary citizens without warning to offer comfort and support in difficult times.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Pope Francis already has distinguished himself from his predecessor with a more down-to-earth style. Now he is both unnerving the Vatican and delighting the faithful by picking up the telephone and spontaneously calling people, earning the nickname “the Cold Call Pope.”

lead_paragraph: The odd new play written and directed by Regina Taylor has an awkward title: “stop. reset.” The handle suggests some kind of digital technology, and your hand may, in fact, itch for a remote control at many points during this often bewildering piece, which opened on Sunday night at the Pershing Square Signature Center.

headline: Global Warming’s Impact and Germs That Induce Thinness
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Space and Astronomy', 'Moon', 'Bacteria', 'Computer and Video Games', 'Science and Technology', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: Recent developments in health and science news. This week: NASA’s latest moon mission and games that could help older adults.
lead_paragraph: Though many think the Moon does not have an atmosphere, that is not quite true. There is an atmosphere, but it is extremely thin — and NASA is spending more than a quarter of a billion dollars to study it with a spacecraft launched on Friday. Back on Earth, scientists reported that global warming was changing not just the climate but the weather, intensifying at least some of last year’s extreme weather events.

headline: Target-Date Funds Might Not Hit Your Bull’s-Eye
abstract: Increasingly popular target-date funds may not be suited to every retirement investor, particularly those near or in retirement.
lead_paragraph: TARGET-DATE funds are all intended to do the same thing: reduce stock market risk incrementally the closer you get to your retirement target date. But that does not mean the funds, known as T.D.F.’s, are entirely adequate for every rainy-day situation. They could flip up in a strong financial wind.

headline: 1967 Border Is a Source of Strain in the Israeli-Palestinian Talks
abstract: A Palestinian official said Secretary of State John Kerry had “guaranteed” that talks would start from the 1967 lines, but American officials rejected the claim.
lead_paragraph: RAMALLAH, West Bank — Signs of strain emerged Monday around the nascent Israeli-Palestinian peace talks, as a senior Palestinian official said Secretary of State John Kerry had “guaranteed us in writing” that negotiations would start from the 1967 lines, and American officials suggested he was not telling the truth.

headline: Georgia: Russian Envoy in Rebel Enclave Is Killed
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'International Relations']
abstract: Dmitry Vishernev was shot Monday in Abkhazia, in the former Soviet republic of Georgia, prompting Russian and Abkhaz officials to denounce the assassination as an attempt to disrupt their diplomatic ties.
lead_paragraph: A senior Russian diplomat was shot and killed Monday morning in Abkhazia, a rebel enclave in the former Soviet republic of Georgia, prompting both Russian and Abkhaz officials to denounce the assassination as an attempt to disrupt their diplomatic ties. The diplomat, Dmitry Vishernev, who was first secretary of the Russian Embassy in Abkhazia, was killed as he was leaving the driveway of his residence in Sukhumi, the enclave’s capital, the Abkhaz police told the Interfax News Agency. Abkhazia, a sliver of land along the Black Sea, broke from Georgia in 1992 and is heavily reliant on Russian economic support. The Abkhaz Foreign Ministry called the killing an act “aimed at undermining the strategic and brotherly Russian-Abkhaz relations.” Russia’s Foreign Ministry said the killing threatened “Russian-Abkhaz relations, peace and stability” in the region.

headline: Campbell Bets on the Wisdom of a Child

headline: Pakistan: New President Is Sworn Into Office
abstract: Mamnoon Hussain, an obscure 73-year-old political figure and loyalist for Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif, was sworn in on Monday in Islamabad.
lead_paragraph: Pakistan’s new president, Mamnoon Hussain, an obscure 73-year-old political figure and loyalist of Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif, was sworn in on Monday in Islamabad. Under the previous president, Asif Ali Zardari, the post was returned to mostly ceremonial status after years of serving as the center of power under the military ruler Gen. Pervez Musharraf.

headline: From a Child’s Memory, the Sound of an Organ Is Brought Back to Life
abstract: Joseph A. Vitacco III was a child when he first heard the organ at Our Lady of Refuge in Brooklyn. It changed his life. Now he has brought life back to the organ.
lead_paragraph: Joseph A. Vitacco III remembers what captivated him when he was a child and his grandmother took him to Mass: not the sight of the priests in their robes, not the stained glass windows soaring beyond the arches, but the sound of the pipe organ. “It was rich, powerful and ethereal, all at the same time,” he recalled the other day. “Sort of like an orchestra.”

headline: As Corruption Abates, Hope Amid a Slowdown
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Indian Rupee (Currency)', 'Mines and Mining']
abstract: Some economists say India’s economic boom was based on a toxic “corruption bubble,” and even those who had benefited and are now suffering say they are glad to see a crackdown.
lead_paragraph: HOSPET, India — After a decade of rapid economic growth, India is in the midst of a sudden swoon. The stock market has fallen, the value of the rupee has plunged, and India’s longtime hope of catching up to China appears increasingly distant.

headline: Brazil: Answers Are Sought on N.S.A. Spying
abstract: President Dilma Rousseff said Monday that Brazil would seek an explanation over a news report that the National Security Agency had spied on the national oil company.
lead_paragraph: President Dilma Rousseff said Monday that Brazil would seek an explanation from the Obama administration over a news report that the National Security Agency had spied on Petrobras, Brazil’s giant national oil company. The report added to tension over earlier disclosures that the N.S.A. had spied on Ms. Rousseff and top aides. She called the surveillance of Petrobras, if confirmed, “plainly illegitimate.” Meanwhile, Energy Minister Edison Lobão said an auction of offshore oil licenses scheduled for October would continue as planned, contending there was no risk that data related to the auction had been leaked. Petrobras said in a statement that its internal data protection methods were comparable with those of other large oil companies around the world.

Intelligence officials have a general idea of where they are hiding. And the military has a contingency plan to snatch them if that becomes necessary.

headline: Police Question Zimmerman About a Domestic Dispute
abstract: George Zimmerman, the Florida neighborhood watch volunteer who was cleared of charges in the shooting death of Trayvon Martin, was said to have threatened his wife and his father-in-law.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — George Zimmerman, the man acquitted in the shooting death of Trayvon Martin, was questioned by the police on Monday after his wife, Shellie, reported that he had punched her father and threatened them with a gun, the police said. But Ms. Zimmerman and her father declined to press charges, and Ms. Zimmerman later said she had not seen a gun, the police said.

headline: Drug Deaths Threaten Rising Business of Electronic Music Fests
abstract: A string of drug-related deaths at big music festivals has highlighted the risks not only to fans, but to the businesses looking to profit from the craze.
lead_paragraph: The electronic dance music business, propelled by huge festivals featuring star D.J.’s and psychedelic light shows, has grown to an estimated worth of $4.5 billion, a number that is luring both Wall Street investors and mainstream corporate sponsors. Yet a recent string of drug-related deaths has highlighted the risks not only to fans, but to the businesses looking to profit from the craze.

headline: 4 Major Candidates Vie for New York Public Advocate Job
abstract: Here is a look at the major candidates, who are all Democrats, virtually guaranteeing that the winner of Tuesday’s Democratic primary or a later runoff election will take office.
lead_paragraph: Though New York City’s current public advocate, Bill de Blasio, has fought his way to front-runner status in the race for mayor, the four major candidates battling to succeed him have struggled even to be sure voters know who they are — and what the job is. The least known of the three citywide offices, after mayor and comptroller, the public advocate is an ombudsmanlike post created in 1993 to give voice to residents’ complaints and concerns.

headline: Norway Elects a Conservative as Its Premier
abstract: Voters ousted the center-left government on Monday, paving the way for the new leader, Erna Solberg, nicknamed “Iron Erna,” to assemble a governing coalition that may include an anti-immigration party.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A little more than two years after a far-right, anti-immigrant militant killed 77 people, many of them teenagers, Norwegian voters ousted their center-left government on Monday, paving the way for the conservative leader, Erna Solberg, to assemble a governing coalition that may include an anti-immigration party.

headline: Twitter Plans to Sell Ads for Other Companies With MoPub Acquisition
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Mobile Applications', 'Online Advertising', 'Social Media']
abstract: The microblogging service paid more than $300 million for a start-up that specializes in mobile advertising technology. The deal gives Twitter valuable tools for simplifying the sale of its own ads and a doorway into selling ads on other companies’ mobile applications.
lead_paragraph: Twitter has been focused on building up a business selling advertisements that blend into the flow of 140-character messages that make up its social network.

headline: Russia: Inquiry Focuses on Antics of U.S. Rock Band With Russian Flag
abstract: Russia’s most powerful law enforcement agency has opened a criminal case against the bass guitarist of Bloodhound Gang, who is accused of “inciting hatred” during a show.
lead_paragraph: Russia’s most powerful law enforcement organization, the Investigative Committee, has opened a criminal case against the bass guitarist of the American rock group Bloodhound Gang for “inciting hatred” during a show. During that performance, which took place in neighboring Ukraine, the bassist, Jared Hasselhoff, passed a wadded-up Russian flag through the crotch of his pants. Russian investigators convened a panel of psychological and linguistic analysts to examine the video, and it concluded that the act had been intended to offend. After the contention over its appearance in Ukraine, the band canceled a show in Russia and left the country. The authorities have been sensitive to the political overtones of Western rock performances since Madonna spoke out in support of gay rights and for jailed members of the punk group Pussy Riot at concerts in Russia.

headline: Judges Hear Arguments on Rules for Internet
keywords: ['Net Neutrality', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: In a battle over whether the Web should remain open, judges expressed doubt over a requirement that service providers treat all traffic equally.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a momentous battle over whether the Web should remain free and open, members of a federal appeals court expressed doubt over a government requirement that Internet service providers treat all traffic equally.

headline: Study Sees Benefit in Courses With Nontenured Instructors
abstract: Students in introductory classes taught by untenured faculty were more likely to take a second course in the same discipline and earn a better grade in the next course, a report says.
lead_paragraph: While many higher education experts — and parents — bemoan the fact that tenured professors are a shrinking presence, now making up less than a quarter of the academic work force, a study released Monday found, surprisingly, that students in introductory classes learned more from outside instructors than from tenured or tenure-track professors.

headline: Election Day Stories
abstract: Are you planning to vote in New York’s primaries? We’re looking for stories: Candidate sightings, long lines at the polls, trouble with the machines…
lead_paragraph: Tuesday’s an election day in New York City. The civic-minded types who participate in primaries will use old-fashioned lever machines to vote for their favorite candidates—in races for mayor, public advocate, city comptroller and, depending on their district, city council and district attorney.

headline: Digital Natives: A Defense of the Internet Community
abstract: In a guest column, an educator takes up the debate over higher education online.
lead_paragraph: In my previous column I suggested that new developments in on-line teaching bring with them a loss of community and human interaction. Daphne Koller, co-founder of Coursera, has been invited by the editors and me to reply to my account of her position.

headline: Russian Proposal Could Offer Obama Escape From Bind
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: President Obama found himself in the odd position of relying on his Russian counterpart, Vladimir V. Putin, of all people, to bail him out of a predicament partly of his own making.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama woke up Monday facing a Congressional defeat that many in both parties believed could hobble his presidency. And by the end of the day, he found himself in the odd position of relying on his Russian counterpart, Vladimir V. Putin, of all people, to bail him out.

headline: My Life as a Warrior Princess
keywords: ['ACTORS AND ACTRESSES', 'Women and Girls', 'Models (Professional)', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Television']
abstract: Three years as a teenage model left me feeling powerless. I needed out.
lead_paragraph: EVERY time Fashion Week returns to the city, the subways crowded with long-legged adolescents with stylish shoes and wary eyes, I can’t help but think about myself at age 14. That’s how old I was when I started working in the fashion industry.

headline: Recall Fights in Colorado Grow Fiercer in Last Days
abstract: Voters in two Colorado districts will head to the polls Tuesday after recall campaigns against two Democrats who supported new gun-control laws grew from a novelty into a central political battle.
lead_paragraph: PUEBLO, Colo. — At first, Angela Giron was surprised to find herself in the cross hairs of a campaign to recall Colorado lawmakers who had supported a slate of new gun-control laws. She had won her State Senate seat by a 10-point margin. Her Southern Colorado district is heavily Hispanic and reliably Democratic, hardly ideal terrain to oust a lawmaker with Mexican roots whose mother once worked picking beans.

headline: Survey Reveals Scant Backing for Syria Strike
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'United States International Relations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Exhausted by nearly a dozen years of war and fearful of tripping into another one, Americans are opposed to a military strike on Syria, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A broad majority of Americans, exhausted by nearly a dozen years of war and fearful of tripping into another one, are opposed to a military strike on Syria, even though most say they think Syrian forces used chemical weapons against civilians, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

headline: A Syrian’s Cry for Help
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Terrorism']
abstract: A half-hearted intervention will not stop Assad’s barbarism.
lead_paragraph: THE story is simple. Here in Syria, there is a regime that has been killing its subjects with impunity for the last 30 months. The notion that there is a mysterious civil war that is inextricably linked to the nature of the Middle East and its complicated sectarian divisions is far from the truth.

headline: Nadal Beats Djokovic to Win U.S. Open
abstract: No. 2 Rafael Nadal beat No. 1 Novak Djokovic, 6-2, 3-6, 6-4, 6-1, for his second United States Open singles title. They played for the title for the third time in four years.
lead_paragraph: It was early afternoon on Monday at the Billie Jean King National Tennis Center and Rafael Nadal’s father, Sebastian, and other members of the Nadal clan were wandering through the United States Open Court of Champions snapping photographs of the plaques honoring inductees past.

headline: One Classroom, Two Genders
abstract: Do students learn differently if taught by a man or a woman?
lead_paragraph: BELGRADE LAKES, Me. — MY favorite teacher in high school was a man named Robert Ulysses Jameson, a terrifying, red-faced man whom the students called “Chopper.” Chopper yelled at us if we said things that were stupid. If our stupidity persisted, he’d throw us out of the classroom by pointing to the door and saying, “Out!” Sometimes he threw us out one by one, and on other days he threw us all out at once. One by one was worse.

headline: In Missouri, Governor Turns Tax Cut Debate Against G.O.P.
abstract: Gov. Jay Nixon has argued that lower taxes would hurt education and mental health services, and has found support in the face of an override vote.
lead_paragraph: MARSHALL, Mo. — As a Democrat facing a State Legislature with veto-proof Republican majorities, Gov. Jay Nixon of Missouri has not claimed big victories lately. So when he began stumping the state against a deep Republican tax cut that he had vetoed, he might have seemed to be on a political fool’s errand.

headline: For Richer, for Poorer
abstract: In the tale of this city, Mayor Michael Bloomberg isn’t quite the villain Bill de Blasio sometimes makes him out to be.
lead_paragraph: It’s either part of his peculiar charm or proof of its absence, depending on your feelings about him, which are surely fixed by now. But Mayor Michael Bloomberg has a way of speaking so gruffly that he causes stirs he can’t have meant to. He doesn’t exactly put his foot in his mouth, not all the way. Just the big toe and maybe the index one, too.

headline: The Border Is a Back Door for U.S. Device Searches
keywords: ['Search and Seizure', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: Documents released Monday detail the largely secretive process that lets the government detain an individual at a border crossing and confiscate or copy any electronic devices that person is carrying.
lead_paragraph: Newly released documents reveal how the government uses border crossings to seize and examine travelers’ electronic devices instead of obtaining a search warrant to gain access to the data.

headline: Curbing Rape Behind Bars
abstract: The Justice Department can help by speeding up audits of prisons and jails and fully complying with the Prison Rape Elimination Act.
lead_paragraph: The Prison Rape Elimination Act, signed into federal law 10 years ago this month, requires correctional facilities receiving federal money to develop intensive programs for preventing the sexual violence that has long been endemic behind bars. A crucial provision of the act requires that new programs be audited by examiners who are trained and certified by the Justice Department. But the department has certified nowhere near enough examiners required to inspect the thousands of prisons, jails and other institutions that need auditing.

headline: Obama Backs Idea for Syria to Cede Control of Arms
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: A Russian plan to have international monitors take control of the Syrian government’s chemical weapons offered an exit strategy for President Obama, who had been reluctant to order a military strike.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Monday tentatively embraced a Russian diplomatic proposal to avert a United States military strike on Syria by having international monitors take control of the Syrian government’s chemical weapons. The move added new uncertainty to Mr. Obama’s push to win support among allies, the American public and members of Congress for an attack.

headline: Hillary Rodham Clinton on Syria
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States International Relations']

lead_paragraph: After meeting with President Obama on Monday, former Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton spoke about Syria for the first time.

lead_paragraph: On one hectic day of campaigning, mayoral candidates fanned out across the five boroughs of New York City, chasing votes ahead of Tuesday's primary elections.

headline: Luxury Brands Face Hazards When Testing Lower Costs
abstract: The addition of a cheaper iPhone could help Apple sell tens of millions more phones, but it could also diminish its reputation as a premium brand.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — For upscale brands, there is a fine line between “cheaper” and “cheap.” And for Apple, the premium electronics maker, the key is to avoid crossing it.

abstract: Style.com’s global take on New York Fashion Week is part of its plan to build on the fashion-hungry audience it has been drawing to its site this year.
lead_paragraph: In the heart of New York Fashion Week, it is not just fashion journalists reporting or posting on Twitter steps from the runway about the latest looks.

lead_paragraph: Here are recommendations in some contested races in Tuesday’s primary election. Polling hours are 6 a.m. to 9 p.m.

headline: A Diplomatic Proposal for Syria
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'United States International Relations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Editorials']
abstract: Russia’s idea that President Bashar al-Assad give up gas weapons could be a way out of military action.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State John Kerry may not have expected his casual suggestion that Syria avert American military action by giving up its chemical weapons to be taken seriously. But it may have created a diplomatic way out for President Obama, who has insisted that a military strike is the only way to respond after concluding that the Syrian government used poison gas in its civil war.

headline: The Two Bloombergs
abstract: There’s the farsighted Mayor Bloomberg hailed for his vision and then there’s the tone-deaf Mayor Bloomberg who doesn’t understand the working class.
lead_paragraph: There is the Mayor Michael Bloomberg who is hailed for his vision, for being farsighted in the best sense.

headline: Penalties Reshuffle Nascar Cup Chase
abstract: Ryan Newman will replace Martin Truex Jr. in the Chase for the Sprint Cup championship as part of Nascar’s penalties against Michael Waltrip Racing.
lead_paragraph: CONCORD, N.C. — The Sprint Cup driver Martin Truex Jr. was kicked out of the field for Nascar’s annual 10-race playoff after officials ruled his team deliberately manipulated the results of Saturday night’s race at Richmond International Raceway to help him qualify.

headline: Investors Bet on Olympic Construction Boom
abstract: Contractors, property developers and other ailing construction-related stocks surged, as investors anticipated a construction boom before the 2020 Games.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Ever since a group of out-of-work samurai pooled their pensions to found Onoda Cement 130 years ago, the company has had its ups and downs: industrialization, a crippling war, Japan’s postwar economic miracle.

headline: Back in Queens, Johnson Is Full of Memories and Statistics
abstract: Davey Johnson, taking part in what may be his last managing trip to Queens, is still a man of variables.
lead_paragraph: If Davey Johnson were the nostalgic type, he might get worked up over what might be his last managing trip to Queens, where funky old Shea Stadium used to be.

headline: Long, Stormy Mayoral Primary Hurtles to Finish
abstract: On Tuesday, voters will take the first big step toward choosing a successor to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.
lead_paragraph: There were arguments over dogs and kittens, a minor contretemps about circumcision and a weightier one over antiterrorism efforts, and first-day-of-school promises to improve public education, as New York City’s long and tumultuous mayoral primary campaign raced to an end on Monday.

headline: A Giant’s Fumbles Prompt Running Back Tryouts
abstract: For the second year, Giants running back David Wilson has opened the season by turning over the ball. Last season, Coach Tom Coughlin turned to a veteran player, a move he could make again.
lead_paragraph: When David Wilson fumbled on his second N.F.L. carry in the Giants’ opener against the Dallas Cowboys last season, Coach Tom Coughlin responded by relying on the veteran Ahmad Bradshaw, severely limiting Wilson’s opportunities for weeks after his turnover.

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
abstract: The latest New York Times/CBS News poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Sept. 6 through Sept. 8 with 1,011 adults throughout the United States.
lead_paragraph: The latest New York Times/CBS News poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Sept. 6 through Sept. 8 with 1,011 adults throughout the United States. Interviews were in English or Spanish.

headline: Kenneth Wallis, British Pilot of Bombers and Odder Flying Machines, Dies at 97
abstract: Mr. Wallis was an enthusiastic maker, flier and promoter of autogyros, buglike vehicles similar to helicopters.
lead_paragraph: Kenneth Wallis, a decorated British bomber pilot in World War II who went on to proselytize for the buglike flying machine called the autogyro — and flew one as Sean Connery’s stunt double in the 1967 James Bond film “You Only Live Twice” — died on Sept. 1 in East Dereham, England. He was 97.

headline: Japan: No Indictments Over Fukushima Accident
keywords: ['Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant (Japan)', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Japan Earthquake and Tsunami (2011)']
abstract: Prosecutors have decided not to indict former officials of Tokyo Electric Power, the operator of the stricken nuclear plant at Fukushima, over their roles in the 2011 accident there.
lead_paragraph: Japanese prosecutors have decided not to indict former officials of Tokyo Electric Power, the operator of the tsunami-stricken nuclear power plant at Fukushima, over their roles in the accident there in March 2011, Japan’s public broadcaster reported Monday. Naoto Kan, who was prime minister at the time of the accident, will also not be prosecuted over his inability to prevent the multiple meltdowns and explosions that hit the plant’s reactors, driving 100,000 people from their homes, according to the broadcaster, NHK. Prosecutors said that their decision was based on data provided on a voluntary basis, and on the opinions of experts, who suggested that the scale of the earthquake and tsunami that triggered the accident could not have been predicted. That finding, however, has been contradicted in various studies, including an influential parliamentary report that called the accident a “manmade disaster.” A group of Fukushima residents who had sought indictments told NHK that prosecutors “had failed to respond to the voice of local residents."

headline: Corrections: September 10, 2013
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on September 10, 2013.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK

headline: If You Ask Me
abstract: Zhouqin Burnikel teaches us some delightful new words that we knew already.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — There will be no whining about the foreign language words in today’s puzzle. Some people like them, some people don’t, but I say that this puzzle is an enjoyable foray into learning the etymological origins of words we all know. They just all happen to be derived from CHINESE.

headline: U.S. at Home vs. a Mexican Team That Has Lost Way
abstract: The Mexican soccer team that will meet the United States on Tuesday in Columbus is not playing like the squad that won the 2012 Olympic gold medal.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio — It is natural for any team or competitive individual to keep tabs on a rival, and the players on the United States men’s soccer team, which traveled here this weekend hoping to secure passage to the 2014 World Cup, could not claim to be different.

headline: Zelmo Beaty, All-Star Center in Pro Basketball, Dies at 73
abstract: Beaty was probably about 6 feet 8 inches, but he excelled as a scorer and as a rebounder in his battles with bigger opponents.
lead_paragraph: Zelmo Beaty, a star center in the N.B.A. who left the league to play for its upstart competitor, the A.B.A., where he immediately took the previously mediocre Utah Stars to victory in the 1971 championship series in his first season, died on Aug. 27 at his home in Bellevue, Wash. He was 73.

headline: Sex Films Halted After a String of Positive H.I.V. Tests
abstract: A trade group for the pornography industry called for a moratorium on production after the third performer in less than a month tested positive for H.I.V.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Production of pornographic films has been halted here after the third performer in less than a month tested positive for H.I.V. The Free Speech Coalition, a trade group for the multibillion-dollar pornography industry, called Friday for production to be suspended after it was notified about the most recent positive H.I.V. test. As a rule, the industry voluntarily follows the guidance of the organization until questions are resolved.

headline: Dueling Interviews
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
