lead_paragraph: President Obama and President Bashar al-Assad of Syria spoke to the American news media to gain Congressional and public support for their positions.

headline: Industry Is Angered Over Move by Cuomo
keywords: ['Boats and Boating', 'Conventions, Fairs and Trade Shows', 'Javits, Jacob K, Convention Center (NYC)']
abstract: A decision by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo to have a boat show’s dates changed provides a glimpse into his decision-making style and its unintended consequences.
lead_paragraph: Matthew Barbara, regional president of Marine Max, the largest boat dealer in New York, was contemplating pulling out of the century-old New York Boat Show at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center.

headline: Jeter Is Gauged Daily, but Days Are Few
abstract: The Yankees said there are no plans to shut down Derek Jeter for the rest of the season and his ankle injury is being evaluated daily.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — Derek Jeter walked briskly through the Yankees’ clubhouse Monday afternoon during a break in his treatment for his achy left ankle. He seemed to be moving better through the carpeted room than he did on the infield dirt on Saturday, when he was removed from the Yankees’ game against the Boston Red Sox.

headline: Friends Mourn Man Fatally Assaulted in Possible Random Hate Crime
abstract: Jeffrey Babbitt, 62, of Brooklyn, died on Monday after a random possible hate crime; he was remembered for his gentle nature and love of comic books.
lead_paragraph: For more than a decade, Jeffrey Babbitt traveled two or three times a week from his home in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, to a comic book store called Forbidden Planet just below Union Square in Manhattan. There, he bought the latest copies of “X-Men” or “Doctor Who,” or sometimes just chatted up the employees, who over the years had become good friends.

headline: Lottery Numbers
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Jets, Encouraged by Smith’s Debut, Are Hoping He Can Build on It
abstract: Geno Smith dazzled with his poise, his legs and his presence in Sunday’s victory against the Buccaneers, but will face a tough test Thursday against the Patriots.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — There they were, the Jets — the 1-0 Jets — bantering and smiling and laughing as they finished stretching Monday afternoon, the euphoria produced by a remarkable victory lingering a day later.

headline: How to Run a Successful Writing Workshop for Veterans
abstract: For veteran writing workshops to flourish, Matt Gallagher found that they needed to stress the writing part over the veteran part.
lead_paragraph: “I’ve done a lot of horrible things in my life,” the author Thomas McGuane once said, “but I never taught creative writing.”

headline: Critics of Cycling Group’s Chief Question His Re-election Effort
abstract: Pat McQuaid, the president of the International Cycling Union, has reached out to nations that he has no personal connection to for his nomination and ultimately re-election.
lead_paragraph: Allegations of underhanded dealing, sinister plotting and cheating are nothing new in cycling. For a change, though, the sport is mired in a controversy that has nothing do with doping or racing, at least directly.

headline: California: Delay Sought for Cutting Inmates’ Numbers
abstract: Gov. Jerry Brown will ask a panel of federal judges to extend its year-end deadline to cut the state’s prison population while the states increases rehabilitation programs.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Jerry Brown will ask a panel of three federal judges to extend its year-end deadline to cut the state’s prison population while the state increases rehabilitation programs meant to bring down the number of former inmates who commit crimes after their release. After a decades-long battle, the Supreme Court ruled in 2011 that the state must reduce the number of inmates by Dec. 31.

headline: After Managers Clash, Orioles Get a Key Win Against Yankees
abstract: The Yankees and Orioles emptied the dugouts when Joe Girardi and Buck Showalter argued in the first inning, but Baltimore emerged with an important victory.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — Buck Showalter charged out of the Orioles dugout wagging his finger, spitting tobacco juice and invective in the direction of Joe Girardi, who emerged from his own dugout to confront his enraged counterpart. For a moment, anything was possible: a discussion, an argument, a fight. But before the incident could escalate into something more, Showalter was restrained by two umpires and the managers returned to their respective corners.

headline: Nadal Inspires Awe After His Victory
abstract: Rafael Nadal fits a special mold of athletes, the ones who are gracious winners against their biggest rivals.
lead_paragraph: When they embraced at the net, Rafael Nadal momentarily rested his head on Novak Djokovic’s shoulder. This was classic Nadal, killing another opponent with kindness.

headline: At Toronto Film Festival, Works of Hope and Despair
keywords: ['ACTORS AND ACTRESSES', 'Festivals', 'Movies', 'Space and Astronomy', 'Toronto International Film Festival']
abstract: Two movies with big-name actors explore the fine line between inspiration and emotional annihilation.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — There is a fine line between inspiration and emotional annihilation. And two movies at the Toronto International Film Festival — both with performers who will be an inevitable presence in the race for a best actress Oscar — walk it in very different ways.

headline: Voting Information for Primary Day
abstract: Here are details about the election and how to find out where to cast ballots.
lead_paragraph: New York City on Tuesday is holding party primaries for local offices including mayor, comptroller, public advocate, borough president, district attorney and City Council. You must be enrolled as a member of a political party to vote in its primary.

headline: Spitzer and Stringer Use Differing Strategies to Influence Turnout in a Close Contest
abstract: Political consultants say the contest for New York City comptroller will be between Scott M. Stringer’s larger field operation and Eliot Spitzer’s money and greater name recognition.
lead_paragraph: As Scott M. Stringer and Eliot Spitzer headed into the final hours of their too-close-to-call Democratic primary for New York City comptroller, the difference between their battle plans boiled down to boots on the ground versus data analysis.

headline: On Reed-Thin Evidence, a Very Wide Net of Police Surveillance
abstract: Most people think of New York’s undercover spying as a phenomenon afflicting Muslims, but it has also been connected to the Republican National Convention, bike rides and Occupy Wall Street.
lead_paragraph: A bicycle glides through the perpetual neon glow that suffuses Times Square to the foot of a military recruiting station. The rider dismounts and then bikes away.

headline: Griffin Returns, but Redskins Fans Leave Unhappy
abstract: Exactly eight months after he had reconstructive surgery on his right knee, Robert Griffin III’s return to the field was overshadowed by the unveiling of the Eagles’ up-tempo offense.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Robert Griffin III discovered that dozens of cameramen were awaiting his arrival Monday afternoon at FedEx Field, where the long buildup to his return from surgery for the Washington Redskins registered at a level that felt vaguely radioactive.

lead_paragraph: Over the course of the primary campaign in New York City, mayoral candidates have regularly appeared at campaign forums and met voters at subway stops. But few destinations have been more popular than churches.

headline: Final Appeals Before Primary Day

lead_paragraph: The mayoral candidates greeted potential voters across the city on Monday in a final push of campaigning before the primary election.

headline: A Backdrop Artist Sets the Scene for the Fashionable Set
abstract: Sarah Oliphant's perfectly executed sets have made her a go-to for fashion photographers like Annie Leibovitz and Patrick Demarchelier, as well as for the runway shows of designers like Anna Sui.
lead_paragraph: Step into the cavernous space of Oliphant Studios in Manhattan’s Flatiron District, and colorful chaos reigns: three scraggly mutts — Buddy, Strider and Comet — roam around the paint-splattered loft while an 8-year-old, Theo, entertains himself. That’s the way the backdrop artist Sarah Oliphant likes it. “At one point, I had seven kids in here,” she said — two of her own, plus five belonging to staff members. “It was insane. It’s a miracle my heart pressure didn’t explode.”

headline: Farm Subsidies for Nonfarmers May Continue as Lawmakers Deadlock Again

abstract: Far from the nation’s fields of wheat and corn, more than 18,000 people who live in the 54 largest American cities received millions in farm subsidies last year, a report finds.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — There are no farms in the city of Columbus, the capital of Ohio. Yet nearly 500 people living there received about $1.1 million in farm subsidies last year.

headline: Depreciation’s Place in Tax Policy

abstract: Allowing businesses to depreciate the cost of capital investments makes good economic sense, if enacted with a long-term view rather than an eye on stimulus, an economist writes.

headline: What’s On Tuesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (13) BILLIE JEAN KING She played tennis like a man: muscular, aggressive, fast on her feet. But Billie Jean King, above, was all about girl power, crusading for gender equality on the court and off. And in 1973 — a year in which “Ms.” was added to the United States government’s list of acceptable courtesy titles, and the Supreme Court legalized abortion — she faced Bobby Riggs in the so-called Battle of the Sexes and won. “When he jumped over the net, his first thing he said to me was, ‘I underestimated you,’ ” she recalled. He was perhaps the only one. Ms. King won 39 Grand Slam titles and a record 20 at Wimbledon; founded the Women’s Tennis Association in 1973; became the country’s first openly lesbian major sports figure in 1981; and received a Presidential Medal of Freedom from President Obama in 2009 for championing the rights of women and gay people. In its first profile of a sports figure, “American Masters” recounts the hard-hitting times of Ms. King, 69, whom many consider the most important female athlete of the 20th century.

headline: Our Debt to Society
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'National Debt (US)', 'International Trade and World Market', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Federal Budget (US)']
abstract: Playing chicken with the debt ceiling could make everyone (everywhere) a whole lot poorer.
lead_paragraph: The Daily Treasury Statement, a public accounting of what the U.S. government spends and receives each day, shows how money really works in Washington. On Aug. 27, the government took in $29 million in repaid agricultural loans; $75 million in customs and duties; $38 million in the repayment of TARP loans; some $310 million in taxes; and so forth. That same day, the government also had bills to pay: $247 million in veterans-affairs programs; $2.5 billion to Medicare and Medicaid; $1.5 billion each to the departments of Education and Defense. By the close of that Tuesday, when all the spending and the taxing had been completed, the government paid out nearly $6 billion more than it took in.

headline: Ugly Disagreements
abstract: Singular goes with singular, plural with plural. Sounds easy. Yet agreement problems abound in our prose, between subjects and verbs, between nouns and pronouns. The perils are all familiar: phrases intervening between subject and verb that throw us off track; collective nouns that veer from singular to plural; tricky words like “each”; and, of course, that infamous “one of the people who …” construction that we simply refuse to get right.
lead_paragraph: Singular goes with singular, plural with plural. Sounds easy. Yet agreement problems abound in our prose, between subjects and verbs, between nouns and pronouns. headline: Eagles’ Kelly Shows the N.F.L. How to Run
abstract: In Week 1, N.F.L. defenses shut down rushing attacks, but one of the big exceptions was Philadelphia, which is led by a new coach.
lead_paragraph: The Philadelphia Eagles’ heavily hyped offense did not disappoint in Chip Kelly’s N.F.L. coaching debut Monday night. The Eagles ran 30 plays in the first quarter and 53 in the first half, operating at a dizzying pace against an overmatched Washington Redskins defense in a 33-27 victory. The Eagles had 21 first downs in the first half, using an even faster tempo than the lightning-quick, hurry-up offense the team showed in the preseason. Kelly took his foot off the gas pedal in the second half, but he won over a lot of Eagles fans, and skeptics, in just 30 minutes.

headline: An Offer We Can’t Refuse
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'United States Politics and Government', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: There are no alternatives to taking the Russian offer on Syria.
lead_paragraph: Jeffrey Goldberg has fifteen questions about the proposal, floated as a near-impossible hypothetical by John Kerry and embraced with alacrity by the Russians, to have Bashar al-Assad turn over his chemical weapons stockpile as an alternative to U.S. strikes. They’re good questions! But they aren’t questions that will prevent this strange “peace” plan from going forward, because at this point the Obama White House doesn’t really have any option except to play the card that Vladimir Putin just dealt. A congressional resolution authorizing strikes was on life support even without the Russian option; with the Russian option on the table, the resolution is as dead as a doornail buried six feet under in the local cemetery, and the potential humiliation the administration was facing a few days ago would become a certainty if they decided to turn to the offer down outright. Which means there is no alternative: As Dan Drezner says, you take the deal, you take it now, and you worry about Goldberg’s questions further down the line.

headline: Getting While the Getting Is Good
abstract: Suburbia is no place for a spinster lady.

headline: Thinking Inside the Sandbox
abstract: One of our developers explains his process for building a sandbox.
lead_paragraph: At The New York Times, the tech department has been evolving. I’ve only been here for about a year, but even in that time, I’ve witnessed some big changes. For a large — and very old — organization, I’ve found this company to be rather innovative and willing to take risks to stay on the cutting edge of technology. Internally, however, there are certain areas where we haven’t pushed the envelope, and when it comes to the development environment we use to build our website, we have been behind for a while. When I started at The Times, our dev environment was a combination of mounted file systems from remote servers mixed with a poorly organized Subversion repository that was extremely difficult to work with. All of those systems were put in place for good reasons, but over time the reasons became less relevant and the solutions more outdated.

headline: Course Provider Joins Google to Start Learning Platform
abstract: EdX, the nonprofit online consortium, is joining forces with the Internet corporation on an open-source platform and Web site to help others offer courses to a global audience.
lead_paragraph: In what it expects to become “the YouTube of online learning,” edX, the nonprofit online consortium started by Harvard and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, is joining forces with Google to start a new open-source learning platform, Open edX, and Web site, MOOC.org, that will let individuals, businesses and institutions offer online courses to a global audience. Anant Agarwal, the president of edX, said the financial details and plans for quality control were still being worked out. Google will continue to maintain Course Builder, its year-old Web platform for open online courses, while providing a path to bring those courses to the edX platform. And edX will continue to operate its edx.org site for its university partners.

lead_paragraph: As faithful Apple followers know, September announcements usually mean a new iPhone. And Apple followed the script once again this year.

headline: Sept. 10: Where the Candidates Are Today

lead_paragraph: Planned events for the mayoral candidates, according to the campaigns and organizations they are affiliated with. Times are listed as scheduled but frequently change.

headline: Freed Captives Differ on Claim Syrian Rebels Framed Assad With Gas Attack
abstract: Two Europeans released Monday after five months as prisoners of Syrian rebels disagree on whether an overheard Skype conversation is proof that insurgents used gas to frame the government and provoke intervention.
lead_paragraph: The Italian war correspondent Domenico Quirico, who reported sympathetically on the uprising in Syria before being taken hostage in April by rebel fighters, told reporters on Monday after his release that two years of bloody, armed conflict had changed the nature of the rebellion. “I was a hostage in Syria, betrayed by the revolution that no longer exists and has become fanaticism and the work of bandits,” he said.

headline: I.O.C. Names New President Amid Concern Over Possible Athlete Protests in Sochi
abstract: Thomas Bach, a German lawyer and Olympic gold medal winner, replaces Jacques Rogge, with the Sochi Games facing potential protests as part of widespread criticism of a new Russian law viewed as antigay.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — Shortly after Thomas Bach, a German lawyer, became the first gold-medal winning athlete to be named the president of the International Olympic Committee on Tuesday, he excused himself from a group of reporters.

headline: Rising Up Against the Civil War
abstract: The draft resistance in the Midwest nearly boiled over into an armed rebellion of its own.
lead_paragraph: The draft loomed large in the mind of the Northern public during the Civil War. Supporters of the Union war effort cheered conscription as a tool to help to fill federal armies. But opponents of a coercive war against the Confederate rebels feared compulsory military service, which forced unwilling men to serve an administration and cause they despised. They denounced government intrusion into their lives and wanted nothing to do with the war. Many resorted to violence to avoid it. Throughout the Old Northwest – today’s Midwest – large, organized groups banded together to resist the draft.

headline: A Pension Plan With a Flair for Deal-Making
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Private Equity']
abstract: The Canada Pension Plan Investment Board often flexes its deal-making muscle with direct investments. When it does invest in funds managed by private equity firms, it often chooses to invest in certain “emerging” managers that have the potential to grow, Jim Fasano, the head of private equity funds for the pension plan, said in a video interview.
lead_paragraph: Pension funds typically have a mediated relationship with the private equity industry, investing money with managers that handle the deal-making. But as a $6 billion deal on Monday showed, one pension fund in Canada is a buyout player in its own right.

headline: Playing Chess with Putin
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: In giving terms for avoiding a strike in Syria, John Kerry seems to have played a careless pawn.
lead_paragraph: On the list of principles compiled by the chess strategist Bill Wall, number 21 is “Do not make careless pawn moves. They cannot move back.” This is especially true if you are sitting across the board from Vladimir Putin, who comes from the motherland of chess masters.

headline: Salinger’s Big Appeal: The Life or the Work?

lead_paragraph: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on pressing and provocative questions about the world of books. This week, Francine Prose and Dana Stevens discuss a new film and biography about the private life of J. D. Salinger.

headline: How Fair Was a Story on the President of Hunter College?

headline: Violence Against Women in India
abstract: The men convicted of raping a student in Delhi shouldn’t get the death penalty. A push to make the country safe would be a far greater tribute to the student’s memory.
lead_paragraph: The conviction on Tuesday of four men for the brutal rape and murder of a 23-year-old student late last year in Delhi shows that there is no reason justice cannot be delivered swiftly in India, a country where most legal cases drag on for years. Unfortunately, the case also demonstrates that it takes thousands of people protesting in the streets to put enough pressure on Indian lawmakers to get the wheels of justice moving.

headline: Business Leaders Tell Lawmakers Not to Forget About Immigration

lead_paragraph: While Congress was preoccupied with Syria on Tuesday, more than 100 businesses, including some of the nation’s largest companies, sent a letter to leaders of the House of Representatives reminding them not to forget about immigration.

headline: First Hurricane Brews After Silent First Half to the Atlantic Storm Season
abstract: Forecasters predict that Hurricane Humberto will end the 2013 hurricane drought.
lead_paragraph: There’s been a lot of excellent analysis of the mysterious storm-free first half of this year’s hurricane season in the Atlantic Ocean and, more generally, tropical weather trends in the context of human-driven global warming. So rather than add to it, I’ll direct you to some highlights. This is how networked knowledge works.

The risk of minimalism is boring your audience to tears. So Vera Wang gave herself a big assignment for spring with a collection that was based partly on streamlined athletic attire.

lead_paragraph: LONDON — Pakistan is ready to release Mullah Abdul Ghani Baradar, an imprisoned senior Taliban commander, in a bid to bolster the faltering peace process in Afghanistan, officials in Islamabad said Tuesday.

headline: Dying in the Line of Duty on a Sept. 11 Decades Ago
abstract: On Sept. 11, 1954, Daniel Sullivan died after flying off the back of a fire truck in Queens, so 9/11 has ever since had special meaning to his family.
lead_paragraph: Well before 2001, Sept. 11 was a painful date for the family of one New York City firefighter. His name was Daniel Sullivan, and that was the day he died in the line of duty, in 1954.

headline: The Not-So-Industrial Average
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Corporations', 'Dow Jones Stock Average', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Changes to the Dow Jones industrial average mean that for the first time, half of its 30 companies are not primarily in the business of mining or of making physical objects.
lead_paragraph: When the Dow Jones industrial average was first expanded to 30 companies in 1928, it was almost entirely a list of companies that made or mined things. American Can, General Railway Signal, Victor Talking Machine — it was an era when boys were named Robert, girls were named Mary, and companies were not ashamed to be named for the things they made.

headline: Vodafone Calls Hedge Fund’s Bluff
keywords: ['Cable Television', 'Cellular Telephones', 'Hedge Funds', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: The British wireless giant says it won’t tweak its $10 billion offer for Kabel Deutschland, even as Elliott Management builds a possible blocking stake. That’s sensible, the author contends.
lead_paragraph: Vodafone is right to defy the hedge funds over its $10 billion bid for Kabel Deutschland. The London-listed mobile giant says it won’t alter its agreed offer for the German cable company, even after Elliott Management and Davidson Kempner amassed possible blocking stakes of 10.9 percent and 3.4 percent. Vodafone’s resolve makes sense – a failed deal would hit everyone. But even if the offer succeeds, a fight looms over the remainder of Kabel Deutschland’s shares.

headline: Oh Yes They Can

lead_paragraph: One of the things you have to get used to if you want to debate real economic policies (or real policies in any area, I suppose) is that people will make arguments that leave you floored with their sheer dumbness. The first time you pay attention, you find it hard to believe.

headline: Harvey and Tejada Are Joined by Uncertain Status for 2014

headline: The Turning Point of the Nadal-Djokovic Match
abstract: Rafael Nadal saved three straight break points in the ninth game of the pivotal third set to wrest control from Novak Djokovic in the United States Open final.
lead_paragraph: Rafael Nadal came back from the precipice in the ninth game of the pivotal third set, saving three straight break points to wrest control from Novak Djokovic and turn the match in his favor. It was a stunning reversal of fortune for Djokovic, who was a point away from serving for a two-sets-to-one lead with the wind at his back.

headline: Putting Up Tomato Preserves

Pasta all’arrabbiata, gumbo, chana masala, enchiladas, shakshuka, bouillabaisse: each jar holds a world of possibility.

headline: The Wonk Gap and the Debt Ceiling
abstract: Again, what they don’t know can hurt us.
lead_paragraph: So, are we going to have a crisis over the debt ceiling again? Everyone seems to assume that we won’t, that Republicans have learned their lesson, and that they’ll huff and puff before slinking away into the shadows. But there’s a problem: the GOP leadership has been telling the base to chill on the idea of shutting down the government to defund Obamacare, that they’ll use the debt limit instead. And so far nobody seems to have been willing to admit that this won’t work either.

lead_paragraph: Overview | How should the United States respond to the use of chemical weapons in Syria? Should it use military force or put its faith in diplomacy? Or, is there no need to draw a “red line” at chemical weapons, and should the United States stay out of the Syrian conflict?

headline: The Rich Get Richer Through the Recovery

lead_paragraph: The top 10 percent of earners took more than half of the country’s total income in 2012, the highest level recorded since the government began collecting the relevant data a century ago, according to an updated study by the prominent economists Emmanuel Saez and Thomas Piketty.

In addition to its recently re-designed S-Class sedan line, Mercedes previewed a Concept S-Class Coupé – due next year in production form – an S63 AMG performance sedan and an S500 plug-in hybrid.

headline: America’s Not-Always-Disastrous Middle East Record
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Nineteen Hundred Seventies']
abstract: A semi-defense of American grand strategy since Carter.
lead_paragraph: While we wait to find out if Russia’s offer that we can’t refuse will miraculously defuse the Syrian crisis or somehow turn into a deal designed to fall apart, I thought I would highlight this interview with Andrew Bacevich (via Rod Dreher at the American Conservative), which I found helpful in clarifying why, despite non-interventionist sympathies, I’m not sold on the foreign policy perspective that undergirds the more intellectually-rigorous opposition to any U.S. involvement in Syria. Here’s Bacevich, one of the most distinguished of the dissident-conservative critics of the Iraq War, explaining what he thinks has gone wrong with American efforts in the Middle East:

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Food and Drug Administration on Tuesday announced changes to the labeling requirements for long-acting painkillers, in a further effort to curb prescription drug abuse, which has been on the rise in recent years.

headline: Why Roger Federer Is the Greatest of All Time
abstract: Yes, he has a lousy record against Nadal. But he’s displayed a consistency and durability at a time when the competition is deeper than it has ever been.
lead_paragraph: Roger Federer, who I wrote about in the magazine’s U.S. Open issue, was the big story coming into the Open; the state of his game dominated the conversation for most of the tournament. But the big story coming out of the Open is his longtime nemesis, Rafael Nadal, who won the men’s title last night with an enthralling four-set victory over the world No. 1, Novak Djokovic. The win gives the 27-year-old Spaniard his 13th grand-slam singles title at exactly the same age that Federer won his 13th, which leaves the whole GOAT debate even more unsettled. GOAT? That’s short for greatest of all time and is an acronym that has been tossed around promiscuously during the Federer years. With a record 17 majors highlighting his numerous career achievements, Federer has staked a strong claim to GOAT status. But he has a losing record against Nadal, and a lopsided one at that. The two have played 31 times since 2004, and Nadal has won 21 of those matches. Federer’s record against Nadal is a large blot on an otherwise remarkable résumé. How can you be considered the greatest player ever if you were arguably not even the best player of your own era? When I spoke with Federer at Wimbledon, he didn’t object when I noted that some feel that Nadal ought to be regarded as the finest male player of all time. “I believe we’ll never quite know,” Federer told me.

headline: Divided Society and a Divided Audience
abstract: The director Godfrey L. Simmons Jr., has imposed a provocative twist on Eugene O’Neill’s play “All God’s Chillun Got Wings.”
lead_paragraph: When Eugene O’Neill’s “All God’s Chillun Got Wings” opened in 1924, this play about an interracial marriage inspired angry reactions, generating, as The Brooklyn Daily News review put it, “almost as much publicity as a murder.”

headline: Revealing a Subject Who Holds Back
abstract: The actor Harry Dean Stanton, 87, is guarded in the extreme, but Sophie Huber’s documentary film aims to find his depths.
lead_paragraph: “How would you like to be remembered?” the director David Lynch asks the actor Harry Dean Stanton during the documentary “Harry Dean Stanton: Partly Fiction.” “Doesn’t matter,” is the laconic reply, and you know he means it.

headline: For Two U.S. Open Umpires, a Difficult Trip Home
abstract: Jill and Wayne Spencer of Indio, Calif., worked as line judges in more than 70 matches at the United States Open over more than two weeks, but when the finals came along this weekend, they watched from the hospital.
lead_paragraph: Jill and Wayne Spencer of Indio, Calif., worked as line judges in more than 70 matches at the United States Open over more than two weeks, often standing within a few feet of top 10 players as well as unknown qualifiers.

headline: Frankfurt Motor Show: Audi Unveils a Swank Quattro Concept

lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — When the warm-up band is the Pet Shop Boys, the headliner had better be a knockout. The Audi Nanuk Quattro Concept was, in fact, just that.

abstract: Coming just one day after leaked documents suggested that the National Security Agency is able to hack into smartphones, the unveiling of a new iPhone with a built-in fingerprint scanner prompted dismay and mockery online.
lead_paragraph: Coming just one day after leaked documents suggested that the National Security Agency is able to hack into smartphones, the unveiling of a new iPhone with a built-in fingerprint scanner prompted dismay and mockery online from privacy advocates and journalists.

headline: Butterflied Leg of Lamb
abstract: Melissa Clark hosts a backyard barbecue with leg of lamb and garlicky yogurt sauce, and a punch made by the cocktail expert Dave Wondrich.
lead_paragraph: Melissa Clark hosts a backyard barbecue with leg of lamb and garlicky yogurt sauce, and a punch made by the cocktail expert Dave Wondrich.

headline: Late Summer’s Grilling Sweet Spot
abstract: As the heat and humidity ease, lighting up the grill for leg of lamb becomes less daunting.
lead_paragraph: The calendar may claim September as a summer month, but our national psyche insists that it’s fall. That’s probably because we associate going back to school with crunching leaves underfoot and bundling up in cozy sweaters, even when the temperatures are still in the 70s and the trees still green and full.

headline: Diesel: a Little Bit Rock ’n’ Roll
abstract: Andreas Melbostad, who showed his spring collection at Vanderbilt Hall today, is turning out to be a great choice of designer for Diesel Black Gold.
lead_paragraph: In Monday’s issue of The Daily, the Fashion Week fanzine, Stefano Tonchi, the editor of W, was quoted predicting the demise of everything preppy. “A European rock ’n’ roll look – a little bit dirty, a little bit French, not put together – is in,” he said.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Zebra-Printed Hair at Rodarte
abstract: Custom, hand-painted extensions added a very street-style-esque accent to the relaxed, casual hairstyle on Kate and Laura Mulleavy’s runway.
lead_paragraph: Hair took a wild, animalistic turn at Rodarte earlier today, courtesy of some zebra-patterned extensions, which the French hairstylist Odile Gilbert fastened onto the back of models’ manes. “We worked together to come up with the idea,” Gilbert said of the eye-catching embellishments that were custom created for the designers Kate and Laura Mulleavy and took two days to hand paint and stamp. “My genius assistant and I worked on them in between fittings and shows,” the stylist noted. Having done that work in advance allowed Gilbert to streamline her routine backstage: she applied John Frieda Frizz-Ease Curl Reviver Styling Mousse before blow-drying, curling and parting hair far over to one side. The extensions were then glued in a diagonal band across the head, while the rest of the hair was pulled into a small side knot below the ear. The peekaboo effect of the print was particularly striking on the bleach-blonde model Soo Joo Park, who gave it a thumbs up as far as street-style trends go. “I think Odile is onto something,” she said, glancing in the mirror. “I would definitely wear an animal stripe in my hair.”

headline: Foundation Gets $24 Million in Insurance on Paintings Stolen From Dutch Museum
abstract: The foundation that owned artwork stolen from a Rotterdam museum has collected nearly $24 million in insurance, a move that suggests it has given up on recovering the works.
lead_paragraph: BUCHAREST, Romania — A publicity-shy Dutch foundation that owned artwork stolen from a Rotterdam museum has collected nearly $24 million in insurance and surrendered ownership rights over the missing paintings, defense lawyers said Tuesday during the trial of the confessed thief and his mother, indicating that it has itself given up on recovering intact the works by Picasso, Monet, Matisse and other modern masters.

headline: Wes Gordon: Spring 2014 RTW

lead_paragraph: New York

abstract: Readers discuss the pressure on Syria to give up its chemical weapons to avert a possible American attack.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Albert King and Johnny Cash to Join Memphis Music Hall of Fame
abstract: The hall of fame is a project of the Memphis Rock ’n’ Soul Museum, intended to pay tribute to Memphis musicians.
lead_paragraph: Albert King, the Memphis Jug Band and Johnny Cash are among 13 artists who will be inducted into the Memphis Music Hall of Fame on Nov. 7.

headline: Diesel Black Gold: Spring 2014 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Surprising Enhancements to Apple’s iPhone Line
abstract: A fingerprint reader and an improved camera are among the new features in Apple’s new iPhone 5S.
lead_paragraph: Tuesday morning, Apple caught up to its own rumor mill. It took the wraps off the two new iPhones that everyone had already predicted: the iPhone 5C and the iPhone 5S, which will be available on Sept. 20.

headline: Hammered Chords and Meditative Intensity
abstract: For its first United States concert, at Roulette, the new-music group Dedalus Ensemble mustered a program called “Made in USA.”
lead_paragraph: Not every substantial American debut by an acclaimed European ensemble comes packaged with oversize fanfare, media hype and an obligatory guest appearance by Yo-Yo Ma. When the Dedalus Ensemble, a French group highly regarded among new-music cognoscenti, played its first United States concert at Roulette in Brooklyn on Monday night, the buzz of anticipation probably barely exceeded the unobtrusive murmurings of much of the music included in the program.

headline: Armani Ristorante Fifth Avenue
abstract: Inside Giorgio Armani’s first restaurant in New York.
lead_paragraph: Inside Giorgio Armani’s first restaurant in New York.

headline: Timeless Italian Tailoring
abstract: Armani Ristorante floats above the economic ups and downs.
lead_paragraph: A few opulent restaurants opened right after the economy fell apart in 2008, like guests who pound on the door long after the lights have been turned out and the hosts have gone to bed. The rest of the city looked up from a collective hangover at their flashy outfits and expectant smiles and said, “Um, the party’s kind of over, dude.”

headline: License To Stagnate
abstract: Why we don’t recover from severe shocks.
lead_paragraph: A further thought on this ongoing discussion with Konczal, Baker, and Rowe over whether economies tend to self-correct. I think it’s useful to ask why, as a practical matter, conventional policy-oriented macroeconomists (myself included) used to think we could normally count on a fairly quick return to full employment after a shock — and why we shouldn’t think so anymore.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Syria, Turkey, Washington and the Philippines.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Syria, Turkey, Washington and the Philippines.

headline: Dance Tribute to James Brown Is Among New Apollo Theater Offerings
abstract: The Philadelphia Dance Company will present the world premiere of “James Brown: Get on the Good Foot,” with works from several choreographers.
lead_paragraph: A dance tribute to James Brown, a theatrical work about Richard Pryor and a concert by Janelle Monáe are among the highlights of the Apollo Theater’s fall season, the theater’s programmers announced.

headline: Finding the Right Roadside Rooms
keywords: ['Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Budget Travel']
abstract: Motels can offer charm on the cheap, but how do you track down the best properties for your trip? Some tips.
lead_paragraph: At the tidy, cheerily decorated, $51-a-night Cottonwood Inn in Salem, Ark., a note in the breakfast area alerts guests that the office is closed every Sunday from 9 a.m. to 1:30 p.m. That’s when the owners, Nelson and Kay Bassham, attend services at the Salem Church of Christ, just down meandering U.S. 62 from the motel. And this July, they invited me to come along.

headline: Latin America Lodging, From Panama to Peru
abstract: Go hotel hopping on this five-country tour of notable new properties in the region.
lead_paragraph: Grande dame rehabs. Art-focused urban boutiques. Rain-forest hideaways. There’s no pattern to be found in the latest hotels in Latin America. But the offerings reveal one trend: the broad appeal of the region.

headline: A Museum and a Beacon
abstract: A look inside the Detroit Institute of Arts.
lead_paragraph: A look inside the Detroit Institute of Arts.

headline: Savoring the Pleasures of Puebla, Mexico
abstract: A visit to this city, a two-hour drive from the capital, can cause the author to fantasize about staying indefinitely. Here’s why.
lead_paragraph: There are places to which we travel, and imagine staying. Why not just quit our job, rent a little apartment, tell the folks at home we’ll be back when our money runs out?

headline: In Detroit, a Case of Selling Art and Selling Out
abstract: The recent suggestion that the City of Detroit, which owns the Institute of Arts’ building and collection, should sell some of the art to help cover municipal debts would be a betrayal of public trust and donors’ bequests.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — These days, the message screens above the main ticket desk at the Detroit Institute of Arts regularly flash the phrase “Thank You Voters.” Unusual as it may seem among announcements about exhibitions and events at this world-class museum, it belongs there. On Aug. 7, 2012, the citizens of the three counties that contain and surround Detroit — Wayne, Oakland and Macomb — voted in favor of a 10-year commitment to a small increase in real estate taxes that would guarantee the institute $23 million a year, roughly two-thirds of its annual operating budget.

headline: Election 2013: Rise of the Machines
abstract: New Yorkers who had trouble voting in today’s primary can take comfort in knowing that they are part of a musty old tradition.
lead_paragraph: New Yorkers who had trouble voting in today’s primary elections can take comfort in knowing that they are part of a musty old New York tradition, like drinking an egg cream or riding a carriage through Central Park. The lever-action voting machines that were pulled out of storage for Tuesday’s voting date back to the 1960s. Like humans of that vintage, they are prone to crankiness and mechanical failure.

headline: Inheriting the Family Apron
abstract: A new generation of chefs and entrepreneurs who grew up in the kitchen are shaping American food.
lead_paragraph: There are many routes to a cooking career. Not so long ago, military and prison kitchens were reliable sources of line cooks for American restaurants. Now the siren song of reality television lures many recruits to kitchens and culinary schools.

headline: Han Dynasty to Open in New York, and More Restaurant Openings
abstract: Han Chiang’s fiery Sichuan fare will be served up on Third Avenue.
lead_paragraph: Headliner

headline: He Looks Backward as He Goes Forward
abstract: Arsenio Hall has to work harder to stand out in today’s late-night television landscape than he did when he started in 1989.
lead_paragraph: “Back is beautiful” is how Arsenio Hall framed his return to late- night television after a 19-year hiatus.

headline: Before a ‘Psycho’ Musical, Let’s Get Lost in Some Songs
abstract: Duncan Sheik, who has a coming musical based on “American Psycho,” is playing songs with an ensemble at 54 Below.
lead_paragraph: Late in his show at 54 Below on Monday evening, Duncan Sheik offered a tantalizing preview of his new musical based on Bret Easton Ellis’s novel “American Psycho,” which is scheduled to open in London in December. Mr. Sheik, who is 43, has a history of chastising the kind of rampant materialism satirized in Mr. Ellis’s novel.

headline: A Calamity Tailor-Made for Internet Conspiracy Theories
abstract: In “Bleeding Edge,” Thomas Pynchon returns to favorite themes: alternate realities, secret government doings and the abyss.
lead_paragraph: “A screaming comes across the sky. It has happened before, but there is nothing to compare it to now.

headline: Dear Parent: The Lunch You Packed Was Nutritionally Inadequate.
abstract: The new school food rules: Should your packed lunch fail to meet the school’s standards, a note will be sent home — a “friendly reminder” to do better tomorrow.
lead_paragraph: I have certainly convinced myself that my children’s teachers would judge me by their lunches.

headline: Let’s See What You Think
abstract: “Brains on Trial With Alan Alda” examines how developments in neuroscience are affecting court cases.
lead_paragraph: Plenty of actors are willing to lend their voices to documentaries or informational programs in exchange for a paycheck, but Alan Alda is willing to lend his brain as well. Not just his brainpower. His actual brain.

headline: Frankfurt Motor Show: The Record-Breaking Porsche 918 Spyder Has Arrived
abstract: Porsche introduced the 918 Spyder Tuesday, but not before breaking a lap record at the Nürburgring.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Before the 2015 Porsche 918 Spyder arrived for its debut Tuesday at the Frankfurt Motor Show, it was taken out for a little joy ride at the Nürburgring. The $846,000 hybrid-electric supercar broke a record that had stood for four years on its first attempt.

headline: Taking the Reins, Then Hanging On
abstract: After moving from New York to Oregon to run the Profile Theater in Portland, Adriana Baer faced many challenges, starting with finding the company a new home.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — Like other New Yorkers who fetishize the Pacific Northwest, Adriana Baer thought that life would get easier when she moved here last year to become artistic director of a small, respected stage company, Profile Theater. Sure, there would be challenges: Ms. Baer was 29, female and an outsider in a city — and an industry — where many donors and professional peers were older men. She was also replacing the theater’s founder, often a tricky transition, and taking on a $500,000 annual operating budget that barely covered costs.

headline: A Copyright Victory, 35 Years Later
abstract: Victor Willis, a former member of the Village People, is set to take control of a share of the copyright to songs he wrote for the group.
lead_paragraph: In the lucrative world of music copyright, it may be something of a watershed moment: on Friday, after six years of legal wrangling and decades after he wrote the lyrics to the hit song “YMCA,” Victor Willis will gain control of his share of the copyright to that song and others he wrote when he was the lead singer of the 1970s disco group the Village People.

headline: Frankfurt Motor Show: The Opel Monza Returns
abstract: Opel’s Monza nameplate is back for the first time since 1986, but gone is the 3-liter V-6. Today’s Monza is a hybrid-electric.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — The frantic efforts on the part of Germany’s financially troubled Opel to present new products and convince European buyers that it can design a compelling automobile were on display Tuesday at the Frankfurt motor show.

headline: Power Brokers and the Secrets That They Kept
abstract: “The Presidents’ Gatekeepers,” a four-hour documentary on Discovery Channel, pulls back the curtain on the inner workings of the White House chiefs of staff.
lead_paragraph: Consigliere, enforcer, point guard, battlefield commander, director of traffic, reality therapist, heat shield: each of these descriptions is used at some point during the four-hour documentary “The Presidents’ Gatekeepers” to characterize the job of White House chief of staff. Based on nomenclature alone, this should be a film about heroism and perseverance, a detailing of the muscles that work stealthily so that the body might move unfettered.

headline: Apple Is Challenged to Innovate Its Flagship
abstract: Nick Bilton, technology columnist for The New York Times, examined some of the implications of the updates and changes coming to the iPhone line.
lead_paragraph: Nick Bilton, technology columnist for The New York Times, examined some of the implications of the updates and changes coming to the iPhone line.

headline: Snap Sketch | Zachary Quinto, Zosia Mamet and the Showgoers of New York Fashion Week Spring 2014
abstract: The illustrator Damien Florébert Cuypers shares his impressions of the fashion set around New York City this week.

headline: Off the Runway: Day Six
abstract: Scenes from the sixth day of New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the sixth day of New York Fashion Week.

headline: Sadness, and Bargains, as Mall at South Street Seaport Shuts Down
abstract: After 28 years of operation, the Pier 17 pavilion in Lower Manhattan has closed and will be demolished, but not before giving shoppers some final deals.
lead_paragraph: On an upper level of the Pier 17 pavilion in Lower Manhattan, a shop called Seaport Dollars marketed a stack of “freedom dollars” featuring the face of Gov. Jan Brewer of Arizona. They clustered next to a bobblehead doll of President Obama and the apparently severed head of a bald mannequin. Detached arms, legs and naked torsos were splayed across the floor.

headline: Embracing Wynne Godley, an Economist Who Modeled the Crisis
keywords: ['Economics (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Recession and Depression', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Mr. Godley, a British economist who died in 2010, helped develop formal models that foresaw the financial crisis of the late 2000s, but underestimated its depth.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — With the 2008 financial crisis and Great Recession still a raw and painful memory, many economists are asking themselves whether they need the kind of fundamental shift in thinking that occurred during and after the Depression of the 1930s. “We have entered a brave new world,” Olivier Blanchard, the International Monetary Fund’s chief economist, said at a conference in 2011. “The economic crisis has put into question many of our beliefs. We have to accept the intellectual challenge.”

headline: Betsy Pickering Kaiser Dresses for Auction
abstract: On Wednesday, an auction house, will offer for sale the suits, coats, gowns and accessories amassed in her lifetime by Betsy Pickering Kaiser.
lead_paragraph: Yes, it’s New York Fashion Week, but for some style enthusiasts, the action will be elsewhere. On Wednesday, Leslie Hindman, the Chicago auction house, will offer for sale the suits, coats, gowns and accessories amassed in her lifetime by Betsy Pickering Kaiser, the model, Manhattan social figure and devotee of James Galanos, whose couture designs for Ms. Kaiser, the client he called his favorite muse, will go on the block.

headline: Laotian Banh Mi, Surprising Cupcakes and More
abstract: Recommendations for the week of Sept. 10.
lead_paragraph: To Reminisce: I’ll Have What She’s Reading

headline: Marc by Marc: Fresh From the Oven
abstract: The Marc by Marc show today over at the SuperPier was hot, hot, hot. But the clothes still had some flash.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this year, Robert Duffy, the president and vice chairman of Marc Jacobs, told Women’s Wear Daily that the company’s Marc by Marc Jacobs collection was “getting a little stale.” The 1970s references and lighthearted casual sportswear do tend to become repetitive over the seasons, but isn’t it still so cute?

headline: Behind Time Inc. Purchase of American Express Publishing Lies a Long History
abstract: Years of collaboration between the companies smoothed the way for Time Inc. to add magazines like Food & Wine and Travel & Leisure to its roster.
lead_paragraph: After a two-decade-long relationship between the magazine giant Time Inc. and American Express, Time Inc. plans to close quickly on its purchase of American Express’s publishing division.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Applemania, and a Family Shunning New Technology
abstract: Tuesday’s selections from around the Web include reactions to Apple’s announcement of two new iPhones. Plus, the tale of a family that has been shunning all technology introduced after 1986.
lead_paragraph: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: New York Fashion Week: Rodarte Spring/Summer 2014

lead_paragraph: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.

headline: Government Announces Steps to Restore Confidence on Encryption Standards
abstract: The National Institute of Standards and Technology said it would reopen the vetting process for a controversial encryption standard after reports that the National Security Agency had developed the standard and could break it.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The federal agency charged with recommending cybersecurity standards said Tuesday that it would reopen the public vetting process for an encryption standard, after reports that the National Security Agency had written the standard and could break it.

headline: Opinion in Google Street View Privacy Case
keywords: ['Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Maps']
abstract: A federal appeals court rejected Google’s bid to dismiss a lawsuit accusing it of violating a federal wiretap law when it collected data for its Street View program.
lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court rejected Google’s bid to dismiss a lawsuit accusing it of violating a federal wiretap law when it collected data for its Street View program.

headline: Frankfurt Motor Show: Infiniti Q30 Concept Straddles Line Between Coupe and Crossover
abstract: Based on a Daimler platform shared with Mercedes-Benz compacts, Infiniti’s styling for the Q30 is decidedly un-Teutonic.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Nissan’s upscale Infiniti brand revealed its swoopy Q30 concept car here on Tuesday. What is notable is that the premium compact will share many of its chassis components with Daimler products, including the Mercedes-Benz CLA coupe and the new GLA crossover that Mercedes announced on Tuesday.

headline: You Can’t Look Away From Thom Browne
abstract: A review of Donna Karan, Phillip Lim, Rodarte, Theyskens’ Theory, Thom Browne, Tory Burch and more.
lead_paragraph: As irritating as Thom Browne’s fashion is, it can’t be ignored. His spring collection is a perfect case in point.

headline: Lawyers for Corzine Seek Case’s Dismissal
abstract: Lawyers for Jon S. Corzine argued that “there is no evidence demonstrating that Mr. Corzine knowingly directed unlawful conduct or acted without good faith” in the final days before the collapse of the brokerage firm MF Global.
lead_paragraph: Jon S. Corzine, the former New Jersey governor accused of a failure of leadership at the helm of the brokerage firm MF Global, is fighting back.

headline: Stargazing Day 6: Front-Row Drivers and New Blood
abstract: This fashion weekend closed with a roar – or really, a purr. At the Opening Ceremony show, Maseratis, Ferraris and other exotic imports opened the show.
lead_paragraph: Usually Sunday nights in New York are a quiet affair reserved for relaxed suppers with friends or lazy DVR catch-up. But this fashion weekend closed with a roar – or really, a purr. At the Opening Ceremony show, Maseratis, Ferraris and other exotic imports opened the show. It had guests like Rihanna (who has been “into a punk-Goth mood lately,” she said, pointing to her butch haircut with tail), Justin Bieber and Miguel cheering. Rashida Jones said “it was probably the best setup for a show that I’ve ever seen.” As for giving one of those hot wheels a test drive? “I’m actually a very good offensive driver,” Ms. Jones claimed.

headline: The I.O.C., by the Numbers
abstract: A look at the members and money behind the International Olympic Committee. Thomas Bach of Germany was elected on Tuesday to lead the organization as Jacques Rogge’s tenure ends.
lead_paragraph: A look at the members and money behind the International Olympic Committee. Thomas Bach of Germany was elected on Tuesday to lead the organization as Jacques Rogge’s tenure ends.

headline: New York Fashion Week: Diesel Black Gold Spring/Summer 2014
abstract: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Erin Baiano.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Erin Baiano.

headline: A Lottery in Hard Times Puts Spaniards to Work
abstract: The mayor of Alameda, a village in the south of Spain, has taken a novel approach to hiring for many of the municipality’s jobs: a televised lottery.
lead_paragraph: ALAMEDA, Spain — The day that José Antonio Pérez Zembrana, 32, won the lottery here, he did not jump for joy or shout out.

headline: Making Progress
abstract: The average mileage of new vehicles sold in the United States reached 30.1 miles per gallon in August, as calculated for the federal corporate average fuel economy standard, or CAFE. Automakers are under pressure to reach government targets for fuel economy for 2016 and 2025.
lead_paragraph: The average mileage of new vehicles sold in the United States reached 30.1 miles per gallon in August, as calculated for the federal corporate average fuel economy standard, or CAFE. Automakers are under pressure to reach government targets for fuel economy for 2016 and 2025.

headline: A Trading Frenzy Over Oh-So-Hot LinkedIn Shares
abstract: Did LinkedIn benefit its shareholders with its recent sale of stock worth $1.2 billion at $223 a share?
lead_paragraph: “When the ducks are quacking, feed them.”

headline: Tory Burch’s Metallic Slingbacks
abstract: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway. Today’s pick: shiny sling-backs with block heels.
lead_paragraph: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: Some of  China’s Prominent Internet Voices
abstract: A look at leading microbloggers on Weibo and some of their messages.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Here are some popular people on Sina’s Weibo and some of their recent messages.

headline: California Takes Steps to Ease Landmark Law Protecting Environment
abstract: The law requires rigorous reviews of environmental fallout from construction projects, and is often invoked in lawsuits to block or delay them.
lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO — A landmark law that has been a symbol of California’s tough environmental philosophy for more than 40 years is facing an unlikely challenge from Democrats, including Gov. Jerry Brown, who contend that regulations protecting the environment have been abused and are thwarting legitimate development.

headline: Intel’s Extensive Makeover
abstract: In a low-key way, the world’s largest maker of semiconductors just bid goodbye to the world of PCs and servers, and made a real bid for the cloud. In an exclusive interview, Intel’s president talks about Intel’s cultural transformation, which includes help from Google and Facebook.
lead_paragraph: While Apple talked about a couple of new products on Tuesday, Intel, with much less fanfare, talked about the transformation of a world, and itself.

headline: Proposal to Protect Antarctic Waters Is Scaled Back
abstract: A proposal by the United States and New Zealand to create a huge ocean reserve in Antarctic waters has been sharply reduced after opposition from Russia and other nations with large fishing industries.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A proposal by the United States and New Zealand to create a huge ocean reserve in Antarctic waters has been sharply reduced in scale after opposition from Russia and other nations with large fishing industries. Environmentalists warned that the ambitious project was being badly undermined.

headline: In Venezuela, Surrounded by Dark Plots (Real or Not)
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Sabotage (Crime)', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela has repeatedly blamed conspirators for disasters and Venezuela’s economic doldrums.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — When a sweeping power failure left more than half the country without electricity last week, President Nicolás Maduro wasted no time issuing a verdict. Despite a strained power grid that has gone lacking in basic upkeep for years, he assured Venezuelans that there could be only one cause: sabotage.

headline: With iTunes Radio, Apple Takes Aim at Pandora
keywords: ['Music', 'Audio Recordings and Downloads', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Radio']
abstract: The service could pose a threat to Pandora Media, which dominates Internet radio.
lead_paragraph: A decade ago, Apple transformed the music business with its iTunes store. Now what the music industry expects from Apple is less of a revolution than a helping hand.

headline: G.O.P. Eyes Hard Line Against Health Care Law
keywords: ['National Debt (US)', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: House Republican leaders signaled that they would support an increase in the nation’s debt limit only if President Obama and Democrats delay putting his health program into full effect.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House Republican leadership signaled Tuesday that Republicans would support an essential increase in the nation’s debt limit in mid-October only if President Obama and Democrats agree to delay putting his health insurance program into full effect — a demand that sets the stage for another economically risky confrontation.

headline: Primary Night in New York City
abstract: There were a few glitches, but one way or another, voters managed to make their preferences known in the city.
lead_paragraph: There were a few glitches, but one way or another, voters managed to make their preferences known in the city.

headline: Still No Word From Jeter About His Injured Ankle
abstract: Derek Jeter has not publicly addressed the issue since he was removed from Saturday’s game by Joe Girardi when Girardi sensed Jeter was not moving well.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — For the second straight day Derek Jeter spent the pregame period in the training room, and did not address reporters about his injured left ankle.

headline: Imagining a Cyberattack on the Power Grid
keywords: ['Electric Light and Power', 'Cyberwarfare', 'Books and Literature', 'Power Outages and Blackouts', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers']
abstract: A former North Dakota senator, Byron L. Dorgan, has written a book that he hopes will get people to think about the electricity sector’s vulnerability.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It’s electrifying.

headline: From a New York Art Icon, ‘Free Advice’ Worthy of Lucy Van Pelt
abstract: To kick off “Radical Presence,” a new survey of African-American performance art, the venerable Sur Rodney (Sur) took questions from gallerygoers last night.
lead_paragraph: Last night, the East Village artist, gallerist and archivist Sur Rodney (Sur) arrived at N.Y.U.’s Grey Art Gallery to strike a pose he’s been perfecting in recent years. In the style of Lucy Van Pelt of the comic strip Peanuts, he sat at a desk behind a sign that read “Free Advice.” Sur, who is 59 but looks 20 years younger, wore black slacks and red slippers, his nails painted silver. He wore a little button that read, “I love everybody — and you’re next!”

headline: Court Says Privacy Case Can Proceed vs. Google
keywords: ['Decisions and Verdicts', 'Privacy', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Maps', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods']
abstract: A unanimous decision found little merit in Google’s legal maneuverings, stating at one critical point that the company was basically inventing meanings in an effort to declare its actions legal.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — In a major legal setback for Google, a federal appeals court here said on Tuesday that a lawsuit accusing the Internet giant of illegal wiretapping could proceed.

headline: Talk of a Cooler 2022 World Cup Heats Up
abstract: Sepp Blatter, the top official at FIFA, has signaled that he supports the controversial decision to move the 2022 World Cup in Qatar from the heat of summer to a cooler time of year.
lead_paragraph: Some say it will cause utter chaos. Others say it is necessary. And while on paper it is a possible shift of a few months in scheduling an event that will not take place for nine more years, the idea of moving the 2022 World Cup has already enmeshed the global soccer world in a polarizing debate.

headline: Trimmings NYFW, Day 6
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'New York Fashion Week', 'Shoes and Boots', 'Handbags and Purses']
abstract: Accessories from the spring Rodarte, Marc by Marc, Tory Burch shows and more.
lead_paragraph: Accessories from the spring Rodarte, Marc by Marc, Tory Burch shows and more.

headline: Man Charged in Fatal Park Assault Had Long History of Racial Conflict
abstract: Martin Redrick, accused of fatally punching a man in in Union Square Park, was agitated by white people, relatives and the police said.
lead_paragraph: Throughout his adult life, Martin Redrick bounced from one conflict to the next, frequently showing the potential for violence. He abused drugs, threw bottles and punches at the police and others, struggled with mental illness and was frequently agitated by white people. (Mr. Redrick is black.)

headline: Oscar de la Renta: Spring 2014 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: De Blasio First in Mayoral Primary; Unclear if He Avoids a Runoff
abstract: Bill de Blasio held a wide lead in the Democratic primary for New York City mayor. Joseph J. Lhota, the former Metropolitan Transportation Authority chief, won the Republican primary.
lead_paragraph: Bill de Blasio, whose campaign for mayor of New York tapped into a city’s deepening unease with income inequality and aggressive police practices, captured far more votes than any of his rivals in the Democratic primary on Tuesday.

headline: On 9/11, My Two Cents on Syria
abstract: On a grim anniversary, pondering Syrian intervention.
lead_paragraph: For the last couple of weeks I’ve struggled with forming an opinion about Syria. [1] And what I’ve recognized is that it’s difficult to claim you’re fighting for justice—that you’re this good-natured, caring policeman—while you’re murdering people at the same time. This complicates matters, as does the fraught chemical weapons issue, which may (or may not) be headed toward resolution thanks to the unlikely duo of John Kerry and Vladimir Putin. [2]

headline: At Polls, Return of Levers Brings Problems and Praise
abstract: Some of New York City’s lever machines broke down and even some candidates had to resort to paper ballots Tuesday, but it was not a full-scale electoral disaster.
lead_paragraph: Delightful to some, confusing to others, New York City’s old-fashioned lever voting machines were blamed for a smattering of problems at polling places on Tuesday, but not a full-scale electoral disaster.

headline: Homeland Confusion
keywords: ['September 11 (2001)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Terrorism', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Congress still needs to streamline its oversight of national security.
lead_paragraph: NO single event in the last half-century has had a greater effect on American national security policy than the terrorist attacks that occurred 12 years ago today. When we co-chaired the 9/11 Commission, which was set up in 2002 and issued its report on the attacks in 2004, we investigated the failures that left our country vulnerable and recommended 41 actions to correct them and strengthen our national security.

headline: Loud Voice Fighting Tide of New Trend in Education
abstract: Diane Ravitch has become a folk hero to the left for arguing that fixing schools without addressing the larger context of societal problems is doomed to fail.
lead_paragraph: Diane Ravitch made her name in the 1970s as a historian chronicling the role of public schools in American social mobility. In the 1990s, she went to work in the Bush administration’s Education Department, where she pushed for a rejection of 1960s relativism and a return to basics and standards. After leaving government, she called for the removal of incompetent teachers, for tying school performance to student scores, and for closing failing schools.

headline: Quinn Smiles Gamely, but Primary Wasn’t Supposed to Be This Hard
abstract: Once expected to win the Democratic primary easily, Christine C. Quinn was instead seen by many as a proxy for Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.
lead_paragraph: An eye roll. Lips pursed. Slight shake of the head, a sigh, all gone in an instant. From Christine C. Quinn, this ticked-off scowl, or perhaps simple exasperation, a cloud scudding across her face, is the first break in a full morning of aerobic, sunny cheerfulness.

headline: Threaten to Threaten
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Behind the incredibly messy and confusing situation with Syria.
lead_paragraph: If you’re an average American and are confused and worried about us getting embroiled in a no-win Syrian civil war, you’re right to be concerned. It means you’re paying attention. But if you’re a member of Congress or a senator who’s still wondering whether to grant President Obama the authority to use force to deter Syrian President Bashar al-Assad from again murdering hundreds of his people with poison gas, it now makes sense to take a timeout. That also means you’re paying attention.

headline: A Governor Battles Against Ruinous Tax Cuts
abstract: Cutting taxes and spending at a time of weak economic recovery is a losing strategy. Missouri has a chance to show that there’s a better way forward.
lead_paragraph: Update: On Wednesday afternoon, an attempt to override Governor Nixon's veto of the tax cut bill fell short in the Missouri House. The tax cut will not go into effect.

headline: The Race to Improve Global Health
keywords: ['Millennium Development Goals', 'Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome', 'Children and Childhood', 'Malaria', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Editorials', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: Much progress has been made in the campaign to reduce mortality by 2015, but many gaps still remain.
lead_paragraph: International health programs have greatly reduced death and sickness worldwide over the past two decades but there is still a long way to go. The United Nations General Assembly will meet later this month to assess progress — impressive in some areas, halting in others — toward achieving the United Nations’ Millennium Development Goals, which were adopted in 2000 and are supposed to be reached by the end of 2015.

headline: Pakistan’s Peaceful Transition
abstract: The inauguration of a new president offers some hope for a troubled country.
lead_paragraph: During most of his five years as Pakistan’s president, Asif Ali Zardari was so embattled that there were constant rumors that he would be killed, jailed or ousted in a military coup. On Sunday, he left office after a formal lunch hosted by his political rivals. This was the first time that an elected Pakistani president had completed his term; most others were overthrown or forced to resign. It was a remarkable development in a fragile nation not known for peaceful transitions. On Monday, Mamnoon Hussain, an obscure 73-year-old political figure, was sworn in as his successor.

headline: Piercing the Mystery of Potter’s Field
abstract: New York City has introduced a searchable database for the impoverished dead who have been buried on Hart Island.
lead_paragraph: Since 1869, an estimated 850,000 of New York’s unclaimed, impoverished dead have been interred on Hart Island off the coast of the Bronx. They are the city’s ultimate nobodies, collected and ferried over to the island’s 101-acre potter’s field to be stacked in pine coffins and buried by city-prison inmates.

headline: For the Second Time, a Killer of Two Detectives Is Sentenced to Death
keywords: ['Sentences (Criminal)', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Capital Punishment', 'Attacks on Police']
abstract: Ronell Wilson, whose earlier death sentence was struck down, was sent back to death row for killing Detectives James V. Nemorin and Rodney J. Andrews in 2003.
lead_paragraph: They sat in silent expectation on Tuesday afternoon, scores of people on the long wooden benches in the largest and most hallowed space in the federal courthouse in Brooklyn, all to witness the rare spectacle of a man, Ronell Wilson, being sentenced to death.

headline: In Shift, Syrian Official Admits Government Has Chemical Arms
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: The country’s foreign minister acknowledged for the first time on Tuesday that the Syrian government possesses chemical arms, while fighting continued around the country.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Nearly buried in the diplomatic din over Syria, the country’s foreign minister acknowledged for the first time on Tuesday that the Syrian government possessed chemical arms, something it had never admitted before, and declared that the country aimed to become a signatory to the international convention banning the weapons.

headline: Like Him or Not, Yankees Rely on Rodriguez
abstract: For all their distrust of him personally, for all of their anger at his deceit, the unmistakable truth of this pennant race is that the Yankees need Alex Rodriguez.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — For all their distrust of him personally, for all of their anger at his deceit, the unmistakable truth of this pennant race is that the Yankees need Alex Rodriguez. He is free on bail, essentially, appealing his 211-game drug suspension, and his line-drive doubles helped spark a 7-5 victory over the Baltimore Orioles on Tuesday at Camden Yards.

headline: Russia: Man Who Plotted to Kill Putin Is Sentenced
abstract: A man convicted of plotting to assassinate President Vladimir V. Putin during his recent re-election campaign was sentenced in Moscow on Tuesday to 10 years in prison.
lead_paragraph: A man convicted of plotting to assassinate President Vladimir V. Putin during his recent re-election campaign was sentenced in Moscow on Tuesday to 10 years in prison. The would-be assassin, Ilya Pyanzin, was arrested last year in Ukraine. The authorities said he had planned to set a bomb on Mr. Putin’s motorcade route. Mr. Pyanzin pleaded guilty in exchange for a reduced sentence, Russian news agencies reported. The case was covered extensively during the presidential campaign by state-controlled media.

abstract: In a class-action suit, a federal judge ruled that dancers at Rick’s Cabaret in Manhattan deserved at least the minimum wage.
lead_paragraph: As she shook her bare backside for the sparse afternoon crowd at Rick’s Cabaret, the dancer introduced as Vanessa appeared to be more committed to her work than the typical clock-puncher. But a federal judge ruled on Tuesday that she and her fellow strippers were hourly workers who deserved at least the minimum wage.

headline: France: Four Charged With Ties to Syrian Jihadists
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Robberies and Thefts']
abstract: French judges opened a formal investigation on Monday into four men suspected of links to jihadist activities in Syria, the office of the Paris prosecutor said.
lead_paragraph: French judges opened a formal investigation on Monday into four men suspected of links to jihadist activities in Syria, the office of the Paris prosecutor announced Tuesday. The four suspects, ages 23 to 34, were arrested last week after a robbery at a fast food restaurant in Coignières, a suburb of Paris. The police said the men carried out the robbery to finance a trip by one of the men to Syria. The four were charged with complicity in a terrorist undertaking.

abstract: The Obama administration on Tuesday relaxed restraints on humanitarian activities between Iran and the United States, including athletic exchanges.

It was at least the second American government relaxation of Iranian sanctions this year and came as Iran’s new president, Hassan Rouhani, has signaled his desire to improve relations.

headline: Donal O’Brien, Audubon Leader, Dies at 79

lead_paragraph: Donal C. O’Brien, who was the Rockefeller family’s lawyer for five decades but perhaps had his greatest impact as the longtime chairman of the National Audubon Society, died on Sunday at his home in New Canaan, Conn. He was 79.

Stringer. With 97 percent of the precincts reporting early Wednesday, Mr. Stringer was ahead 52.1 percent to 47.9 percent.

headline: Alvin Eisenman, Graphic Design Educator, Dies at 92

lead_paragraph: Alvin Eisenman, a graphic designer who in 1951 became the first director of Yale’s graduate program for graphic design, the first offered by a major American university, died on Sept. 3 at his home, which he also designed, on Martha’s Vineyard. He was 92.

abstract: An upset victory by Kenneth P. Thompson followed a fierce race that often seemed more a referendum on Charles J. Hynes’s record, and set up a November rematch.
lead_paragraph: Kenneth P. Thompson, a former federal prosecutor, performed the rare feat of defeating a sitting district attorney by beating Brooklyn’s six-term incumbent, Charles J. Hynes, on Tuesday in the Democratic primary.

headline: David Karp Is Tumblr’s Reluctant Technologist
abstract: The Williamsburg loft of David Karp, the founder and chief executive officer of Tumblr, is a minimalist affair, eschewing screens, gadgets, and slickness. It's also a good metaphor for the difference between the New York and Silicon Valley tech scenes.
lead_paragraph: “I DON’T LIKE SCREENS very much,” says David Karp, founder and chief executive officer of Tumblr, the popular microblogging platform. “Big bright monitors drive me nuts”; screens in the bedroom are “gross.” He takes his rule seriously, for in Karp’s newly renovated loft, in south Williamsburg, Brooklyn, screens are scarce, as is, for that matter, anything particularly shiny or smooth. It is, instead, a dedication to all that is aged, rough or both: ancient bricks, weathered concrete, blackened steel and reclaimed oak. While Karp designs the future, his personal aesthetic is worlds apart from the Star Trek flight deck or the Google campus that form our usual idea of what is to come. Karp doesn’t believe, he says, that the next century is necessarily about “more screens covering more surface area.”

headline: The ‘Coase Theorem’ and Labor Unions
abstract: Ronald Coase, in his research and theories, found in labor unions many of the qualities valued by his more liberal colleagues, an economist writes.

The country’s new prime minister, Tshering Tobgay, secured an aid package from India worth 5,000 crore, 50,000 million rupees ($781million) for his nation during his recent visit to New Delhi.

headline: Prosecutors Seek Death Penalty in India Rape Case
abstract: In the Delhi gang rape case, prosecutors on Wednesday appealed for a death sentence for the convicts.

lead_paragraph: Dr. Jock Cobb is 94 years old and lives in an Albuquerque nursing home. He has had a long and fascinating life, yet it all might have been quite different if he had not met a girl, many years ago, and followed her to Mexico.

headline: Rescuing Tartare From the Stuffy, Old Power-Lunchers
abstract: It’s time for home cooks to conquer the raw.
lead_paragraph: In the go-go ’80s, “tartare” pretty much meant a pile of raw, well-seasoned chopped beef topped with a raw egg yolk. It was seen as food for the carnivorous power-lunch crowd — tartare even had a cameo as a status symbol in “Wall Street” — and for old-fashioned people who ate at old-fashioned restaurants.
