keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Emotions', 'Children and Childhood', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Intelligence and Intelligence Tests (IQ)', 'ANGER (EMOTION)', 'Education', 'Empathy']
abstract: If everybody knows that test scores and grades aren’t the keys to success, how do we teach, and measure, the things that are?
lead_paragraph: One day last spring, James Wade sat cross-legged on the carpet and called his kindergarten class to order. Lanky and soft-spoken, Wade has a gentle charisma well suited to his role as a teacher of small children: steady, rather than exuberant. When a child performs a requested task, like closing the door after recess, he will often acknowledge the moment by murmuring, “Thank you, sweet pea,” in a mild Texas drawl.

headline: U.N. Rights Panel Cites Evidence of War Crimes by Both Sides in Syria
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: Investigators say government forces and rebel fighters have killed, tortured and raped on a huge scale.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — As the United States and Russia searched for a diplomatic solution to the crisis over Syria’s chemical weapons, a four-person United Nations rights panel presented detailed evidence on Wednesday of what it said were war crimes and crimes against humanity committed by pro-government forces and, to a lesser extent, rebels in the 30-month-old conflict.

headline: New York Today: Last Candidates Standing
abstract: What you need to know for Wednesday: Bill de Blasio’s win, Eliot Spitzer’s defeat and weather that feels like July.
lead_paragraph: The first leg of a New York election that has been anything but predictable (just ask any pundit) is over.

headline: European Chief Backs Plan to End Roaming Fees
keywords: ['Wireless Communications', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Telephones and Telecommunications']
abstract: José Manuel Barroso’s support for a single telecommunications market seizes on a popular idea at a time of doubt over enhancing the European Union’s powers.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — José Manuel Barroso, the president of the European Commission, called on Wednesday for an end to the high fees charged for making mobile phone calls across national borders, seizing on one of the few truly popular European initiatives at a time of rising skepticism about the European Union.

headline: Daily Report: Privacy Suit Against Google Will Continue
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Privacy', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods']
abstract: In a major legal setback for Google, a federal appeals court said on Tuesday that a lawsuit accusing the Internet giant of illegal wiretapping could proceed.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — In a major legal setback for Google, a federal appeals court said on Tuesday that a lawsuit accusing the Internet giant of illegal wiretapping could proceed, David Streitfeld reports.

headline: Looking to a Wall That Limited the Devastation at the World Trade Center
abstract: Among the heroes of Sept. 11 is the construction supervisor of the slurry wall that held firm at the site, preventing the Hudson from flooding parts of Lower Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Some of the heroes of Sept. 11, 2001, performed their lifesaving work at the World Trade Center many years before the attack.

headline: A Health Insurance Offer for the Busy Start-Up
keywords: ['Entrepreneurship', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Small Business', 'Start-ups']
abstract: Young Entrepreneur Council says it wants to save business owners the time and effort of figuring out health insurance. But there may be a price.
lead_paragraph: Start-ups — hungry, lean, facing an uncertain future — are different from other businesses. So it is reasonable to think that start-ups might have different needs when it comes to health insurance. Now, one organization istrying to profit from this distinction, real or imagined, by marketing health insurance specifically to start-ups almost anywhere in the country.

headline: From Scenic Alpine Golf Course to 5th Women's Major

lead_paragraph: Members of the L.P.G.A. will get one last chance to win a major this week at The Evian Championship in Evian-les-Bains, France.

headline: What Local Problems Do You Think Your Mayor Should Try to Solve?

lead_paragraph: After months in which the candidates debated New York City issues from income inequality and public schools to bike lanes and how to handle kittens who stray onto subway tracks, voters went to the polls on Tuesday to choose Democratic and Republican candidates for the general mayoral election in November.

lead_paragraph: A thematic visual diary of New York Fashion Week inspired by the essential building blocks of fashion and style.

lead_paragraph: Cathy N. Davidson, a professor of English and interdisciplinary studies at Duke University, is answering readers’ questions about how to find and use Massive Open Online Courses (MOOCs) and other online continuing education tools. Part 1 of her answers is here.

headline: New York Fashion Week: Marc by Marc Jacobs Spring/Summer 2014
abstract: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Anna Moller.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Anna Moller.

headline: A Wiseguy, Retooled for Police Work
abstract: In a significant departure from his “Saturday Night Live” days, Andy Samberg plays a police detective in the new Fox comedy “Brooklyn Nine-Nine.”
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — When Andy Samberg reports for work these days, he is often confronted with questions he’s never had to address before. Where should he put his hands when he pulls his gun? Does he need to wear a necktie if he already has a police badge hanging around his collar? How do you spin a criminal suspect to put him in handcuffs?

headline: Corzine Fights Back
abstract: Lawyers for Jon S. Corzine, who was accused of a failure of leadership at the helm of the MF Global, filed a motion to dismiss a civil case against him. | Verizon Communications plans to sell up to $49 billion of bonds in record debt offering. | Deals like LinkedIn’s recent sale of stock may simply feed a trading frenzy.
lead_paragraph: CORZINE SEEKS CASE’S DISMISSAL  |  Lawyers for Jon S. Corzine, the former New Jersey governor accused of a failure of leadership at the helm of the brokerage firm MF Global, filed a motion late Tuesday to dismiss a civil case against him brought by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, the federal agency that regulated MF Global until its demise in 2011, DealBook’s Ben Protess reports. The 30-page motion outlined Mr. Corzine’s defense and leveled a sharp critique of the commission.

headline: On 9/11 Anniversary, Paying Tribute and Taking Stock Amid New Turmoil Abroad
abstract: The memorial ceremonies on Wednesday offered an occasion to pay tribute to those killed in 2001.
lead_paragraph: Michael Ollis was not even in high school when terrorists slammed jetliners into the World Trade Center towers.

headline: Vodafone’s Bid for Kabel Deutschland Awaits Shareholder Approval
abstract: The offer has the backing of Kabel Deutschland’s board, but Vodafone appeared to be far short of the 75 percent of shareholder votes required before Wednesday’s deadline.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British telecommunications giant Vodafone faces a nervous wait on Wednesday as the shareholder voting deadline approaches for its proposed takeover of the German cable operator Kabel Deutschland for 7.7 billion euros, or $10.1 billion.

headline: AMC’s ‘The Killing’ Is Canceled, Again
abstract: The crime drama that was canceled last year and revived in the spring has now been canceled a second, and likely final, time.
lead_paragraph: Choose whichever morbid metaphor you want, but there will be no further stays of execution for “The Killing,” the AMC crime drama that was canceled last year, revived in the spring and has now been canceled a second, and likely final, time.

abstract: While many analysts expected Apple to price the iPhone 5C at about $400, it will actually go for significantly more in China, where the company is struggling.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — With the introduction of a cheaper iPhone on Tuesday, Apple took a step toward catering to China, the world’s largest smartphone market and one that is crucial to the company’s future.

abstract: Among members of Congress and in world capitals, President Obama’s speech on Syria offered some relief about a possible diplomatic solution, but few reassurances.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Members of Congress from both sides of the aisle returned to work Wednesday, relieved that President Obama had called off a vote on military action in Syria, postponing a political confrontation that few in Washington want to have.

headline: What Defunding Means
abstract: Suffering must not be alleviated!
lead_paragraph: As some of us have been saying, financial markets are way too complacent about the debt ceiling — which we’re going to hit in as little as five weeks. Everything Republican leaders are actually saying suggests that they intend to go full-on blackmail, holding America’s full faith and credit hostage to the sacred goal of crippling Obamacare before it gets going. Assumptions that they will in fact blink are entirely faith-based.

lead_paragraph: Apple’s new iPhones took a step closer Wednesday to being offered by the world’s biggest cellphone carrier, China Mobile, when the Chinese government approved the handset to run on the carrier’s next-generation network, Eric Pfanner reports.

headline: Virginia Names Scholar to New Mormon Studies Chair
keywords: ['Mormons (Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints)']
abstract: The Mormon Studies chair at the University of Virginia is the first at a major public university and the first in the East.
lead_paragraph: Kathleen Flake, a scholar of early Mormonism, has been named the first occupant of a new chair in Mormon studies at the University of Virginia. The chair, named for the historian Richard Lyman Bushman and supported by a $3 million endowment from anonymous donors, is the first of its kind at a major public university, and the first in the East.

headline: Money Manager Takes Big Stake in News Corp.

lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: The Next Wireless Revolution, in Electricity
abstract: More than a quarter of the world has no electricity. The good news is it is now possible to buy a small power plant in a box.
lead_paragraph: Gaurav Gupta, the director for Asia of the development consulting firm Dalberg, tells a story about the untethered life. “You want to sit next to a beach and have a laptop on your lap, and you want to be connected to the world,” Gaurav says. “But you don’t want any wires.”

headline: New Devices Mind Pets While Owners Are Away
abstract: Innovative tools help ease pet owners’ concerns about what their animals are doing while home alone.
lead_paragraph: An undercurrent of anxiety lies behind the newest pet products that busy working parents will instantly recognize.

headline: Brooklyn Emerged as Big Winner in Primaries
abstract: Not since 1973 has a Brooklynite been elected mayor of New York, but that may change this fall if Bill de Blasio and Joseph J. Lhota face off.
lead_paragraph: In New York City, few stories have gotten more attention in recent years than the ascendancy of Brooklyn. What was once a national punch line became a catch phrase for urban cool — and very costly urban cool, at that.

headline: Futile Care at Life’s End
abstract: A new study suggests that nearly 11 percent of patients in intensive care units at large medical centers received care that their doctors considered futile.
lead_paragraph: Researchers studying critical care in four intensive care units at large medical centers report that almost 11 percent of patients received care that their doctors considered futile.

headline: Under Investor Pressure, Sotheby’s Weighs Changes
keywords: ['Hedge Funds', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: The company said that it was considering moves like a share repurchase or raising its dividend, taking into account a number of factors, including taking on new debt, the value of its real estate and possible tax issues.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 5:35 p.m. |Sotheby’s announced on Wednesday that it was reviewing its financial policies, after a number of prominent hedge funds built up significant long positions in the auction house.

headline: A Postcard From Jharkhand
keywords: ['Forests and Forestry', 'Land Use Policies', 'Mines and Mining', 'Names, Geographical', 'Roads and Traffic']
abstract: Ranchi’s assortment of social and political problems indicates the health of the nation’s mineral-rich state.
lead_paragraph: RANCHI, Jharkhand— In most small towns across India, men huddle around roadside tea stalls and discuss everything from international politics to whose daughter eloped with whom. Such informal chat sessions are useful indicators of the pulse of the town.

headline: Toronto Video: Nicole Holofcener on ‘Enough Said’
abstract: Nicole Holofcener discusses her film “Enough Said,” featuring Julia Louis-Dreyfus and James Gandolfini.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — A good amount of Nicole Holofcener can be found in a Nicole Holofcener movie. The writer and director, who has made five features, draws from personal thoughts and experiences to build her lived-in, reflective comedies. Her latest, “Enough Said,” which screened here at the Toronto International Film Festival this week and opens in theaters on Sept. 18, stars Julia Louis-Dreyfus as  a single mother whose daughter is going away to college. She begins dating a divorced father (James Gandolfini, in one of his final roles), who is also facing an empty nest. In this video, Ms. Holofcener discusses the themes of her film and the places from which her  ideas spring.

headline: Annie Proulx Writes Libretto for ‘Brokeback Mountain’ Opera
abstract: Annie Proulx, whose short story “Brokeback Mountain” became a highly acclaimed film, has written the libretto for Charles Wuorinen’s opera based on the work.
lead_paragraph: Over the years Annie Proulx has founded a small-town Vermont newspaper, written the Pulitzer prize-winning novel “The Shipping News” and seen her short story “Brokeback Mountain” become a highly acclaimed film. Now she has tackled another, perhaps more unlikely, kind of writing: as an opera librettist.

headline: Retired Wheelchair Player Still Champions the Sport
abstract: Esther Vergeer, a dominant Dutch wheelchair player who retired from competition in February, has remained an active advocate for her sport.
lead_paragraph: After nearly a decade of uninterrupted winning, it was time for a new challenge for Esther Vergeer.

headline: A Fast-Growing Tree Service Considers Selling Franchises
abstract: An owner wants to add more locations, but is not sure whether he wants to own the locations or franchise them.
lead_paragraph: MONSTER TREE SERVICE is a five-year-old tree pruning and removal business based in Fort Washington, Pa., north of Philadelphia. It is owned by Josh Skolnick, 29, an entrepreneur since boyhood, whose outdoor businesses have evolved from lawn mowing to mulching to his current company, which has 15 employees and annual revenue of more than $2 million. Mr. Skolnick, who manages the business, takes pride in the fact that he has “never pulled the cord on a chain saw.”

headline: U.N. Rights Panel’s Report on War Crimes in Syria
abstract: A report dated Aug. 16 and released Sept. 11 by a commission of inquiry on Syria, attributes eight massacres to government forces and one to rebel fighters.
lead_paragraph: A report dated Aug. 16 and released Sept. 11 by a commission of inquiry on Syria, attributes eight massacres to government forces and one to rebel fighters.

headline: The Mistake at McLemore’s Cove
abstract: The South missed a chance to destroy the Union’s Army of the Cumberland.
lead_paragraph: Unlike Robert E. Lee’s Army of Northern Virginia, Confederate armies west of the Appalachians and east of the Mississippi River seldom won major battles. The biggest success, at Chickamauga in late September 1863, was a Pyrrhic victory, costing the Rebel Army of Tennessee more casualties than the defeated federal Army of the Cumberland. Kennesaw Mountain was a sizable Confederate win, but most of the other convincing victories in the region – Chickasaw Bayou, Holly Springs – were strategically small.

keywords: ['Environment', 'Explosions', 'Global Warming', 'Oceans and Seas', 'Railroad Accidents and Safety', 'Science and Technology']
abstract: An in-depth analysis of the recent slowdown in global warming finds lots of theories and few firm facts.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a fresh roundup of notable news and analysis grabbed from the nonstop information fire hose:

headline: 9/11 Through the Emotional Lens of Cantor Fitzgerald
abstract: “Out of the Clear Blue Sky” weaves together interviews with Howard Lutnick, the chief executive of Cantor Fitzgerald; family members of those who were killed on Sept. 11; home video; and rarely seen clips of Cantor executives from the months after the attacks.
lead_paragraph: Howard Lutnick is known best by reputation, for being a ruthless competitor, even by Wall Street’s cutthroat standards.

headline: Is This Business Ready to Open Franchises?
abstract: Josh Skolnick, who has demonstrated a knack for building and selling businesses, is trying to decide the best way to grow his latest venture.
lead_paragraph: We just published a case study about a suburban Philadelphia company called Monster Tree Service. Having grown his two-year-old, 15-employee business to more than $2 million in annual revenue, 29-year-old Josh Skolnick wants to expand beyond the working radius of his Fort Washington, Pa., office.

headline: Let the Blames Begin

lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — If he knew me, Suat Kilic, Turkey’s sports minister, would probably say that I decorate my backside with henna — Turkish vernacular for a naysayer who gloats over the misfortunes of others.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: Video of ‘Mother of George’
abstract: Andrew Dosunmu, the director of “Mother of George,” narrates a scene from the film.
lead_paragraph: A new bride and an intimate conversation are the focus of this anatomy of a scene video. The Nigerian-born director Andrew Dosunmu narrates this scene from his film about a newly married West African immigrant living in Brooklyn. He discusses his choice of music for the scene and his images, shot by the cinematographer Bradford Young.

headline: The Gun Report: September 11, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: For the first time in Colorado’s history, two lawmakers state have been recalled. The reason? Their support for stricter gun control measures.

lead_paragraph: Discussions with Oscar De La Hoya about his sobriety came with a caveat, a disclaimer he provided: he slipped up occasionally.

keywords: ['Credit and Debt', 'Interest Rates', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']

lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:05 p.m. | For companies looking to raise money through the debt markets, and the bankers egging them on, it seems no sum is too large.

headline: Michael Kors Doesn’t Break a Sweat
abstract: Mr. Kors used a lot of natural looking materials with a lot of texture.
lead_paragraph: Ninety degrees and 50-plus percent humidity is a forecast for a fashion disaster. But, amazingly, the audience at the Michael Kors show this morning looked relatively crisp, given that many of his customers are probably rich enough to travel by mobile igloo. The day is young, though.

headline: The Rich Got Richer
abstract: Last year the wealthiest 1 percent of Americans earned more than 19 percent of the country’s household income—their biggest share since 1928.
lead_paragraph: During the 2012 election Republicans accused President Obama of waging “class warfare” because he occasionally mentioned income inequality. This tactic obviously didn’t work very well. Perhaps voters felt that the president was merely acknowledging reality.

abstract: As fall approaches, two new picture books about the dramatic changes made possible by trees.
lead_paragraph: As leaves begin to change color and summer gives way to fall, two books about trees, Christie Matheson’s “Tap the Magic Tree” and “The Tree Lady,” written by H. Joseph Hopkins and illustrated by Jill McElmurry, draw on their dramatic mutability and their ability to transform landscape.

headline: At Airports, Beauty Products Made to Travel
abstract: New airport vending machines from 3floz.com offer travelers beauty and wellness products in sizes approved by the T.S.A.
lead_paragraph: 3floz.com, a New York City-based site founded in 2009 with the premise of offering high-end beauty and wellness products in T.S.A.-approved sizes, is now selling them in vending machines at airports.

headline: Vivendi to Weigh Splitting Up
abstract: The French conglomerate Vivendi said on Wednesday that its board was considering cleaving itself in two, months after it struck deals to sell big holdings in the video game maker Activision Blizzard and a Moroccan phone company.
lead_paragraph: The French conglomerate Vivendi said on Wednesday that its board was considering cleaving itself in two, months after it struck deals to sell big holdings in the video game maker Activision Blizzard and a Moroccan phone company.

headline: Tasting the Flavors of Uruguay’s Melting Pot
abstract: Ignacio Mattos, a Uruguayan chef, talks about the food back home.
lead_paragraph: The food of Uruguay is as heterogeneous as its people: a cross mostly between Spanish and Italian, with some indigenous influences.

headline: Alternatives to a $29 In-Room Burger
abstract: For guests who would rather not spend the money or the time waiting for room service, hotels are offering more fast-food-style, budget-friendly dining choices.
lead_paragraph: Room service is a mainstay at most hotels, but not always the best option for travelers looking for an affordable and quick bite. For guests who would rather not spend the money or the time waiting for room service, hotels are offering more fast-food-style, budget-friendly dining choices (while still offering traditional meals delivered to rooms). The Amway Grand Plaza hotel in Grand Rapids, Mich., noticed its guests frequently ordering pizza from local restaurants and created its own competitively priced pizza delivery service, Piezelli’s.

headline: Teatro Real Names New Artistic Director; Mortier to Step Down Immediately
abstract: Joan Matabosch will succeed Gerard Mortier at the Madrid opera house.
lead_paragraph: MADRID –The opera house Teatro Real put an end on Wednesday to an unusually public and tense leadership dispute by replacing Gerard Mortier as its artistic director with Joan Matabosch.

headline: Tribes Challenge New York’s Authority Over Their Lending
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Consumer Protection', 'Credit and Debt', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Law and Legislation', 'Native Americans', 'Payday Loans', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Two tribes are arguing in Federal District Court in Manhattan that New York’s top financial regulator overstepped his jurisdictional bounds in his efforts to end their online lending operations in the state.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:46 p.m. | Since becoming New York State’s top financial regulator in 2011, Benjamin M. Lawsky has aggressively pursued wrongdoing far beyond the state’s borders, investigating financial consultants in Washington, insurance industry practices nationwide and money laundering overseas.

headline: It’s Your Words Against Others’, in Games for the Mobile Screen
abstract: Besides the popular Words With Friends, app word games can be played with others over the Internet, or alone against the clock.
lead_paragraph: Word puzzles are among the most successful games to make the leap from cardboard and wooden pieces atop the family dining table into apps on the glossy screens of tablets and smartphones. So popular is the Words With Friends app, for example, that an episode of “The Big Bang Theory” revolved around playing the game.

headline: The Moment | Men’s Wear That Isn’t Ready to Grow Up Yet
abstract: Men will be boys — at least, that’s the feeling of many of the latest styles for guys, which convey a feeling of youthful carelessness.
lead_paragraph: There’s a feeling of boyish waywardness to much of men’s dressing right now, from signet rings to rumpled collars and cowlicks.

headline: Steve Martin’s Prize for Bluegrass Goes to Jens Kruger
abstract: Mr. Kruger, a German who grew up in Switzerland and lives in North Carolina, has won the fourth annual Steve Martin Prize for Excellence in Banjo and Bluegrass.
lead_paragraph: As a child growing up in Switzerland, Jens Kruger was so fascinated by a broken tenor banjo owned by his father — actually, just the neck of it — that he nailed strings to it and silently taught himself the fingering for several chords. When his mother bought him a proper banjo at about the age of 10, Mr. Kruger said, “I could finally hear how all these chords sounded.”

headline: An App to Lend an Artsy Blur to Photos
abstract: The Tadaa 3D app offers some embellishments to portraits.
lead_paragraph: The Tadaa 3D app for Apple products adds an arresting effect to your photos, making a foreground object move around when you tilt your phone, like an old postcard with a plastic lenticular 3-D screen.

headline: With CityVille Invasion, a Blend of Destruction and Construction
abstract: Hasbro and Zynga have combined Kre-o brick-building kits with the CityVille digital game.
lead_paragraph: When Hasbro announced its partnership with Zynga last year, the companies had to figure out how to translate Zynga’s digital games into a physical form that Hasbro could stock on store shelves. It turns out that it made more sense to go the other direction.

headline: Abbado, Blaming Health Problem, Cancels Plans for Japan Concerts
abstract: The conductor Claudio Abbado did not say what his health problem is in announcing the cancellation of concerts planned for Japan in the fall.
lead_paragraph: Citing ill health, the Italian conductor Claudio Abbado has canceled plans to conduct a series of concerts in Japan this fall with the Lucerne Festival Orchestra — including one at an inflatable concert hall in Matsushima that was to be dedicated to a region recovering from the 2011 earthquake.

headline: What Really, Seriously Ought to Be Popular, Like, Come On
abstract: An informal survey of things that should be just as popular as Harry Potter, Budweiser or boneless rib-eyes.
lead_paragraph: The magazine’s recent culture package on popularity — “What Was, Is and Will Be Popular” — examined phenomena across a spectrum of cultural pursuits, but didn’t answer one really crucial question: What should be more popular than it already is? For that, we informally surveyed the staff of the magazine; you’ll find their answers below.

headline: Panel Urges France to Drop Plans to Tax Internet Firms
abstract: A report from a government advisory committee said that the introduction of a digital tax “would be both unrealistic and economically devastating.”
lead_paragraph: PARIS — France should abandon its effort to unilaterally enact taxes on global Internet companies and should instead work at the international level to create a level playing field, according to a report from a government advisory committee.

headline: Join Our Video Chat With Fuchsia Dunlop
abstract: This month’s Recipe Lab will feature “Every Grain of Rice,” which translates easy, practical Chinese recipes for a Western audience.
lead_paragraph: Fuchsia Dunlop is a British journalist who enrolled in cooking school in Sichuan almost as a lark — and since then has become a brilliant translator of traditional Chinese food for Western audiences, especially in her books about the regions of Sichuan and Hunan.

headline: Frankfurt Motor Show: In Search of the American Car
abstract: Amid scores of new models from the world’s automakers, American manufacturers’ presence at this year’s Frankfurt Motor Show is looking thin.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — The Frankfurt Motor Show is a bounteous showcase for new models from auto manufacturers around the globe, but American manufacturers seem to have a diminished presence here this year.

headline: Women’s Chess Challenger Moves to Retake Title
abstract: Hou Yifan of China mounted a blistering attack to take the first game from the Women’s World Chess champion, Anna Ushenina of Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: The Women’s World Chess Championship got off to a fast start on Wednesday in Taizhou, China, as the challenger and former champion, Hou Yifan of China, mounted a blistering attack to take the first game from the current champion, Anna Ushenina of Ukraine.

headline: Google’s Stock Settlement May Not Do Much for Shareholders
keywords: ['Initial Public Offerings', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: Google’s settlement of a shareholder lawsuit will most likely clear the way for the company to issue new nonvoting Class C shares. The move will perpetuate the control of Google by its co-founders, Sergey Brin and Larry Page, but may not be in shareholders’ best interests.
lead_paragraph: Google and its co-founders, Sergey Brin and Larry Page, settled a shareholder lawsuit earlier this summer that most likely clears the way for Google to issue new nonvoting Class C shares. The settlement perpetuates the co-founders’ control, which is good for them, but it may not do much for Google’s shareholders, the majority of whom voted to oppose the maneuver.

headline: Proenza Schouler: Pleats and Prints
abstract: The Proenza Schouler collection played with prints and technology.
lead_paragraph: Liv Tyler stepped onto the elevator of a new office building under construction in Midtown where the Proenza Schouler show was taking place and greeted Lisa Love, a Vogue editor who did not have a smartphone or other device at the ready, by saying, “You’re not on Insta-crack.”

headline: Toxic Inequality
abstract: In a surprising place.
lead_paragraph: A couple of days ago the Times published a fascinating portrait of a society being poisoned by extreme inequality. The society in question is, in principle, highly meritocratic. In practice, inherited wealth and connections matter enormously; those not born into the upper tier are, and know themselves to be, at a huge disadvantage. Furthermore, you can clearly see some of the other costs of inequality — for example, expenditure cascades, in which the less well-off feel compelled to go into debt in an attempt to keep up.

headline: Elisabeth Erm Transforms Backstage at Marc by Marc Jacobs
abstract: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Spring 2014 Fashion Week in New York.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Spring 2014 Fashion Week in New York. Here, the model Elisabeth Erm before (left) and after (right) makeup by Dick Page and hair by Guido Palau.

headline: Bringing On the Heartbreak, a Comic Switches Gears
abstract: Ricky Gervais wrote, directed and stars in “Derek,” a show about a volunteer in a small British nursing home, streaming on Netflix.
lead_paragraph: We’ve seen this before: a comedian who can make us laugh until we cry decides he wants to make us cry, period. We’ve been through it with Woody Allen, Robin Williams and Tom Hanks, among others, and now it’s Ricky Gervais’s turn.

headline: U.N. Leader Admits Failure to Halt Syrian Atrocities
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Ban Ki-moon, the secretary general, spoke as diplomatic energy was intensifying over a Russian proposal to secure Syria’s chemical weapons stockpiles.
lead_paragraph: Ban Ki-moon, the secretary general of the United Nations, said Wednesday that the organization was responsible for a “collective failure” to halt more than two years of atrocious violence in Syria, and he expressed hope that the crisis over that country’s chemical weapons stockpile would be a catalyst toward a diplomatic solution.

headline: What's a Fab Lab?
abstract: Paulo Blikstein, an assistant professor at Stanford University, talks about the Fab Lab, an effort to inspire invention and innovation aimed at school-aged youth.
lead_paragraph: Paulo Blikstein, an assistant professor at Stanford University, talks about the Fab Lab, an effort to inspire invention and innovation aimed at school-aged youth.

headline: Cuba: Doing It Your Way
keywords: ['Embargoes and Economic Sanctions', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Travel Restrictions']
abstract: There are a variety of ways for Americans to travel to Cuba, all with varying levels of restrictions. Here’s a cheat sheet.
lead_paragraph: Nearly half a million travelers now go from the United States to Cuba every year, making the once-forbidden island if not familiar, at least far less isolated from its American neighbors than it used to be. But who gets to go and how do they get there?

headline: Cuba: Going With a Tour Company
abstract: What can you expect to see and do when traveling with a tour organizer? Here’s a quick guide.
lead_paragraph: Just two years after the Obama administration relaxed travel restrictions to Cuba, nearly every major tour company is now jockeying for the hearts and wallets of American tourists. And why not? When the Grand Circle Foundation, part of Grand Circle Corporation, offered its first licensed educational exchange trip to Cuba (known as a people-to-people tour) in 2011, it attracted about 1,000 travelers. Last year that figure jumped to 1,900. In 2013, the company expects to take more than 2,200 American tourists to Cuba. And that’s just one agency.

headline: Midtown West: Suitable for the Diplomatic Life
keywords: ['Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: For two men from Brazil, New York was an exciting post, with company expected.
lead_paragraph: After three years as a diplomat based in Port-au-Prince, Haiti, Daniel Guimarães learned he would be posted to New York for a position with the Brazilian mission to the United Nations.

headline: Renounced Ambition: David Schickler Talks About ‘The Dark Path’
abstract: Mr. Schickler’s memoir recounts his struggle to abandon his goal of becoming a Catholic priest.
lead_paragraph: David Schickler’s fiction first made a splash in 2000, when The New Yorker published his story “The Smoker,” which led to a collection called “Kissing in Manhattan.” His new book, “The Dark Path,” is a memoir about his desire as a young man to become a Catholic priest. The book recounts his struggle between serving God and being with women; between trying to communicate with a higher power and giving up out of frustration. In a recent e-mail interview, Mr. Schickler discussed the demands of celibacy, his experience with the inappropriate behavior of a priest, why he prays and more. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation:

headline: Ariana Grande’s Debut Tops Album Chart
abstract: Ms. Grande’s album, “Yours Truly,” is the first debut by a female artist in more than three years to reach No. 1.
lead_paragraph: Ariana Grande, the 20-year-old actress and singer who has been a star on the Nickelodeon shows “Victorious” and “Sam & Cat” and performed on Broadway, has arrived in the music world with a splash.

keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']

lead_paragraph: Greg Smith created a headache for Goldman Sachs last year when he resigned from the firm through a harshly worded Op-Ed article in the pages of The New York Times.

headline: Cultural Preservation Groups Ask Obama to Protect Syrian Heritage Sites
abstract: Cultural preservation groups have written to President Obama, asking that he make sure any military action taken in Syria is mindful of the need to protect important heritage sites.
lead_paragraph: Worried about a possible strike against Syria, American and international cultural heritage organizations are urging President Obama to ensure the protection of that country’s archeological sites, among the oldest on earth, before taking military action.

headline: An 86-Year-Old’s Head-to-Toe Makeover Is Complete
abstract: The renovation of the Park Central Hotel in Midtown is sensitive to the hotel’s long life, according to its general manager.
lead_paragraph: Don Fraser has a long-playing record — something people listened to before everything went digital — that was issued before Eddie Layton became the organist at Yankee Stadium and Madison Square Garden in the 1960s. The album describes Layton as the “tireless star of the exquisite Mermaid Room” in the Park Central Hotel.

headline: Fight Nights With Oscar De La Hoya
abstract: Images from Oscar De La Hoya’s career as a popular boxer and now as a successful promoter.
lead_paragraph: Images from Oscar De La Hoya’s career as a popular boxer and now as a successful promoter.

headline: Buy! Sell! Hold! Analysts Offer Different Views on Apple
abstract: After Apple extended sales of the iPhone to new foreign markets and offered a less expensive iPhone, some analysts downgraded the company’s stock while others came to its defense.
lead_paragraph: The stock market really doesn’t like the new Apple iPhone 5C, or at least the price of it. As Apple’s stock fell more than 5 percent on Wednesday, analysts were all over the map with their reactions to the company’s new phones and sales strategy.

headline: Player Ratings: U.S. (2) vs. Mexico (0)
abstract: Player ratings from the United States team’s victory over Mexico in World Cup qualifying in Columbus, Ohio.
lead_paragraph: For the fourth straight World Cup cycle, the United States national team defeated Mexico by the same score. This 2-0 victory in Columbus, Ohio, was arguably the most impressive as it clinched a spot in the 2014 World Cup and jeopardized the chances for its archrival.

headline: Are Adoptive Parents Who Give Up on Children Uncaring or Unprepared?
keywords: ['ADOPTIONS', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Children and Childhood', 'Orphans and Orphanages', 'Parenting']
abstract: How does an adoptive parent dump a child? Even if the child is not responding to love or seems filled with hate, how do you hand him or her off to a stranger?
lead_paragraph: Last week I received an e-mail from a bereft mother about how she adopted a Russian orphan 13 years ago, and how it all went wrong. In sharp, spare sentences, she told me she has traveled twice to Siberia. She told me how her son has been in and out of a juvenile detention center. At 16, he is now in state custody and wants nothing to do with her. This woman was devastated and could hardly make sense of what has happened. She said after investing everything she has in this boy, both financially and emotionally, she has been left with nothing and no one.

lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Students Have Their Say: Exploring Ideas to Improve Science Education
abstract: In this lesson, students explore suggestions for improving the way science is taught and make their own proposals for new approaches to science teaching.
lead_paragraph: Overview | What does “good” science education look like? What experiences, good and bad, have students had in science classes? In this lesson, students explore suggestions for improving the way science is taught and make their own proposals for new approaches to science teaching.Materials | Computers with Internet access, projection equipment

headline: Slim Can Afford to Raise Bid for Dutch Firm
abstract: There should be room for the billionaire’s América Móvil to pay more for the Dutch telecommunications firm KPN, even if his company is insisting it will not budge, the author writes.
lead_paragraph: The billionaire Carlos Slim Helú can pay more for the Dutch telecommunications firm KPN. Unless the two sides agree on a friendly deal, a poison pill will probably stop Mr. Slim’s América Móvil from buying the 70.2 percent of KPN that it does not already own.

headline: Turn Left, and Head for Queens
abstract: Jonathan Lethem’s tragicomic new novel, “Dissident Gardens,” covers generations of leftists.
lead_paragraph: In “Dissident Gardens,” a novel jampacked with the human energy of a crowded subway car, Jonathan Lethem attempts a daunting feat: turning three generations’ worth of American leftists into a tragicomic tale of devolution. He has couched this as a family story and written it so that someone’s hot breath is always in the reader’s face. One of the two main characters tries to stick the other’s head in a gas oven. And this is as tender a moment as Rose Angrush, gifted with a “hammer of personality,” and her daughter, Miriam, “the maven of Macdougal Street,” ever share.

headline: A Studio Visit With Blaine Halvorson
abstract: The most bizarre creations of Blaine Halvorson – a designer of rugged clothing and a voracious collector of myriad curiosities – are the macabre installations that fill his 4,500-square-foot studio in Culver City, Calif.
lead_paragraph: A Los Angeles designer and collector creates a surreal hangout where taxidermied dogs play chess and Elton John swings by for a chat.

headline: Michelle Obama Visits Wounded Veterans Family Center
abstract: In keeping with her continued focus on the families of wounded veterans, Michelle Obama spent Wednesday afternoon at the new U.S.O. Warrior and Family Center in Virginia, visiting with veterans’ young children.
lead_paragraph: FORT BELVOIR, Va. — Michelle Obama, in keeping with her continued focus on the families of wounded veterans, spent Wednesday afternoon at the new U.S.O. Warrior and Family Center here, visiting with the young children of veterans and touring the facility, which provides care for veterans with traumatic brain injuries and other disorders.

abstract: Christine C. Quinn, the New York City Council speaker, thanked her wife, family members, campaign staff and volunteers.
lead_paragraph: Christine C. Quinn, the New York City Council speaker, thanked her wife, family members, campaign staff and volunteers.

headline: In Peru, a Portrait of Porters
abstract: As part of its “Hidden Lives” series, Fat Rat Films looks at porters who cater to tourists traveling to Machu Picchu.
lead_paragraph: As part of its “Hidden Lives” series, Fat Rat Films looks at porters who cater to tourists traveling to Machu Picchu.

headline: Hidden Lives: Porters of Machu Picchu
abstract: A video segment created by Fat Rat Films examines the routines of porters who assist climbers near Machu Picchu.
lead_paragraph: How do you explore an entire continent? The best approach is piece by piece. For our Latin America issue (which we’re publishing all week in the Travel section), we’ve tried to do that, focusing on the people and the culture that you discover when you’re not distracted by the Big Attraction.

headline: Planting a Flag for Youthful Harmony
abstract: World Peace Orchestra, an international youth ensemble, played its inaugural concert on Tuesday at Avery Fisher Hall, sharing the stage with the violinist Alexander Markov.
lead_paragraph: As a goal, world peace is fairly unobjectionable. But the inaugural concert of World Peace Orchestra, an international youth ensemble, on Tuesday at Avery Fisher Hall felt more like a hostile takeover than like a lesson in harmony.

headline: Jets, Especially the Rookies, Take a Cram Course on the Patriots
abstract: Ready or not, the 2013 draft picks Sheldon Richardson and Dee Milliner will face the Patriots on Thursday night after a compressed week of practice.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Sheldon Richardson, the Jets’ rookie defensive lineman, has this friend back home in St. Louis. They are very close. They have been pals for years. They text all the time, talk when they can. Most weeks. Just not this one: his friend is a Patriots fan.

headline: Ackman Questions Impartiality of Herbalife’s Auditor
abstract: William A. Ackman expanded his campaign against Herbalife on Wednesday, questioning the independence of its auditor, PricewaterhouseCoopers, and warning of “serious accounting” issues at the company.
lead_paragraph: William A. Ackman expanded his campaign against Herbalife on Wednesday, questioning the independence of its auditor, PricewaterhouseCoopers, and warning of “serious accounting” issues at the company.

headline: Frankfurt Motor Show: Daimler and Renault-Nissan Announce Expanded Partnership
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Small Cars (Compact, Subcompact and Microcars)']
abstract: While the companies will expand the number of joint projects to 10, both chief executives tried to tamp down speculation about a merger.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Daimler and Renault-Nissan said Wednesday that they had significantly expanded an alliance that has proved to be one of the most durable in the industry, and would soon begin building additional motors and transmissions together in the United States and elsewhere.

headline: U.S. Officials Growl Back at a Watchdog
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Inspectors General', 'Foreign Aid', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The officials have begun publicly airing their grievances about an inspector general’s aggressive audits of the American campaign to rebuild Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — After months of quietly simmering tension, officials from the State Department and the United States Agency for International Development have begun publicly airing their grievances about the special inspector general for Afghan reconstruction, the government watchdog charged with auditing their work here.

headline: Past Lingers in Present, and the Sorrows Go On
abstract: Jesmyn Ward’s new memoir, “Men We Reaped,” looks at the deaths of five young men in her hometown, DeLisle, Miss.
lead_paragraph: DeLISLE, Miss. — The writer Jesmyn Ward’s brother is buried in a cemetery next to the park where they used to play as children. Graves are beginning to fill up the space between the two, and she says she worries that one day the park will be swallowed up by the headstones of friends and neighbors, too many of them dying too young.

headline: Sydney Reising: An Advanced Degree in Velvet Rope
keywords: ['Parties (Social)', 'Social Media', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'New York Fashion Week', 'Public Relations and Publicity']
abstract: The P.R. wunderkind Sydney Reising left college for the siren call of New York. Now, she has a publicity agency all her own.
lead_paragraph: “I’m a bit delusional from lack of sleep,” the publicist Sydney Reising said at the Tribeca Grand Studios, where she was co-hosting yet another gathering of the young and dance-floor-prone.

headline: Missouri Republicans Fail to Block Vetoes on 2 Bills
abstract: State lawmakers lacked the votes to overturn the governor’s vetoes of a sweeping tax cut and a bill preventing enforcement of federal gun laws.
lead_paragraph: JEFFERSON CITY, Mo. — Missouri’s Republican-dominated state legislature was dealt a stinging blow on Wednesday when lawmakers failed to override the Democratic governor’s vetoes on two emotionally charged measures: one for sweeping tax cuts, and another preventing the enforcement of federal gun laws in the state.

headline: Chair Pitched as Answer to New Ways We Sit on Job
abstract: Steelcase says we need chairs to accommodate the strange new positions we work in these days, but its new model may offer only a slight improvement.
lead_paragraph: The first time I had to buy a mattress, I remember being shocked at how much it cost. “Ah, but just remember,” the sales representative told me, “you’re going to spend a third of your life on it. Isn’t it worth investing in something you’ll use for a third of your life?”

headline: 90 Seconds With Pogue: Steelcase Gesture
abstract: The Times's David Pogue tests out Steelcase's Gesture, a chair that adapts to multiple positions.
lead_paragraph: The Times's David Pogue tests out Steelcase's Gesture, a chair that adapts to multiple positions.

headline: 10 Ways to Ease Your Child’s Preschool Separation Anxiety (and Yours)
abstract: Advice from school officials to help children, and parents, keep preschool separation in perspective and smooth the first weeks at a new school.
lead_paragraph: Like so many parents, I fretted about my preschoolers’ first days of class. Will he think I’m abandoning him? Will he be scarred for life? (“That’s right, Dr. Therapist, she left me there with strangers for three hours every single morning!”)

headline: On Formula One’s Non-Calendar, New Jersey Is Nowhere to Be Seen
abstract: A provisional calendar for the 2014 Formula One season that surfaced last week — without a date for a race in New Jersey — has been disavowed by Bernie Ecclestone.
lead_paragraph: When is a calendar not a calendar?

lead_paragraph: Victoria Beckham stood backstage after her show last Sunday morning, surrounded by reporters asking questions about her spring 2014 collection, while her husband, David Beckham, was off in another part of the room, tending to their toddler, Harper.

lead_paragraph: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: Bridging a Generation Gap at Saint Laurent
abstract: In the store, there’s plenty of room to ponder whether the history is a burden to bear or fuel for a better tomorrow.
lead_paragraph: When Hedi Slimane took over YSL last year and chopped the Yves right out of the brand name, how you felt about the blood on the floor depended on what lens you looked through: either Saint Laurent is upheaval, or Saint Laurent is tradition. The truth is, it’s a little of each.

headline: Tina Brown to Leave The Daily Beast and Publishing
abstract: The magazine editor said she would start a company to build up her Women in the World conferences.

lead_paragraph: Analysis of the vote in the Democratic mayoral primary in New York City.

headline: Huge Aquifers Are Discovered in North Kenya
abstract: The discovery of a potentially enormous underground water supply could improve the lives of generations of people throughout the region.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — The United Nations and Kenyan officials on Wednesday announced the discovery of a potentially enormous underground supply of water, a find they said could improve the lives of generations of people in impoverished northern Kenya, if not the entire nation.

headline: Pictures of the Day: New York and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from New York, Washington, Libya and Syria.
lead_paragraph: Photos from New York, Washington, Libya and Syria.

headline: A.P.C. and Eastpak’s Streamlined Golf Bag
abstract: The French brand’s founder, Jean Touitou, teamed up with the backpack and luggage maker to create a chic, functional, minimalist accessory.
lead_paragraph: Jean Touitou, the quirky perfectionist founder of the cult French brand A.P.C., is known for shearing everything down to its minimalist basics: sneakers, candles, bottles of laundry detergent, quilts, hoodies (with help from collaborator Kanye West) and his signature product, denim. Now he’s streamlining the stuffy old game of golf. “Golf just has this terrible reputation — boring grown-ups, beige pants with pleats,” Touitou said. “But at it’s simplest, it’s supposed to be elegant. The swing is just so elegant.”

headline: Middle-Aged Men, Too, Can Blame Estrogen for That Waistline
abstract: New research has found that estrogen, the female sex hormone, plays a much bigger role in the aging male body than previously thought.
lead_paragraph: It is the scourge of many a middle-aged man: he starts getting a pot belly, using lighter weights at the gym and somehow just doesn’t have the sexual desire of his younger years.

headline: ‘If You Can Do Anything Else, Kids, Do It’
abstract: A Lives essayist shares the best writing advice she has ever received.
lead_paragraph: The author of last weekend’s Lives essay shares the best writing advice she has ever received.

headline: New Turns on That Trip to Ithaca
abstract: Opera Omnia has tightened Monteverdi’s account of “The Odyssey,” in an English production that mingles modern and antiquarian touches.
lead_paragraph: Can this be New York, that notorious backwater of early music?

headline: House G.O.P. Delays Vote on Stopgap Budget Measure
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Republican leaders scrapped a vote this week on legislation that would keep the federal government financed through mid-December while ending financing for President Obama’s health care law.
lead_paragraph: Facing another revolt by the House’s most ardent conservatives, Republican leaders scrapped a vote this week on legislation that would keep the federal government financed through mid-December while ending financing for President Obama’s health care law.

headline: Hush of a Duo and 20-Piece Orchestra
abstract: Goldfrapp, an English band making its only United States appearance this year, showcased its new album, “Tales of Us,” at the Beacon Theater.
lead_paragraph: “You better run for your life,” Alison Goldfrapp sang in “Jo,” the first song of the English band Goldfrapp’s concert at the Beacon Theater on Tuesday night. She crooned the words like a lullaby, over a barely swaying rhythm, with her voice swathed in sustained chords from a string orchestra. In its serenely elusive foreboding, the music was a world away from the pumping, simplistic electronic dance-pop songs, like “Ooh La La,” that gave Goldfrapp its biggest hits.

headline: Astronaut’s Photo of Smoke Over Lower Manhattan on Sept. 11, 2001
abstract: An American astronaut captured a stunning view of Lower Manhattan from the International Space Station after the World Trade Center collapsed in 2001.
lead_paragraph: On a day of somber memorials — for American diplomats killed in Benghazi on this date last year, and for the thousands who died in the terrorist attacks in the United States in 2001 and during the coup in Chile on Sept. 11, 1973 — an American blogger directs our attention to a stunning view of Lower Manhattan from the International Space Station after the World Trade Center collapsed.

headline: Front Row? Box Seat? Decisions
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Tennis', 'United States Open (Tennis)', 'New York Fashion Week']
abstract: For the fashion world, there’s always room for tennis.
lead_paragraph: For much of the fashion flock, the announcement that Marc Jacobs was shifting his New York Fashion Week show this week from Monday to Thursday night was not welcome news. It meant it would be impossible for many attendees to make it to England in time for the start of London Fashion Week the next morning.

headline: Rayman Legends, Total War: Rome II, Plants vs. Zombies 2, Amnesia: A Machine for Pigs and Puppeteer

headline: A Would-Be Usurper Stalks Yet Agonizes
abstract: On Tuesday night, Kendrick Lamar gave his first high-profile New York concert since he laid claim to being king of the city’s rap scene on a guest track last month.
lead_paragraph: The king of the land looked out over the people, thousands of them, and took in their adoration. He wore a crown that identified him as leader of their tribe. It was his first look at his charges — and their first look at him — since he had announced his takeover of the realm. What kind of leader would he be?

headline: In Search of a Gay Aesthetic

lead_paragraph: “I once asked Vivienne Westwood what women have contributed to fashion,” said Valerie Steele, the director of the Museum at the Fashion Institute of Technology. “And she answered, ‘Probably not as much as gay men.’ ”

headline: An Anchor Tells Stories Onstage, but Off Camera

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Jim Lehrer is sitting in the second row of a nearly empty auditorium watching a rehearsal with a pen poised over a script open on his lap. He marks up the text with a newsman’s precision, squinting intently at the page. As the scene onstage comes to an end, he leans back to ponder.

headline: For Male Models, Handsome Is as Handsome Does
abstract: A new generation of male models is parlaying fashion connections and using social media to get noticed, not just for their good looks but also for their original designs.
lead_paragraph: If you’re a top model, becoming a fashion designer may seem like a logical next step — unless you’re a man. While male models have had success in other fields (Mario Sorrenti is a top fashion photographer, and Magnus Berger is a creative director at WSJ Magazine), few have made the jump from runway to design studio. But a new generation of male models is parlaying fashion connections and using social media to get noticed, not just for their good looks but also for their original designs. “These guys have access to all the ingredients of the industry just by being in front of the camera,” said Dan May, the style director at Mr. Porter, the online luxury site. “If they’re shrewd enough, they can easily pick up on how to build a business and evolve it firsthand, from understanding product development, branding, marketing and P.R.” Here are four models who are breaking the mold.

headline: The Champagne of Venetian Glass
abstract: Vintage glass by Napoleone Martinuzzi is on display in Venice.
lead_paragraph: In 1925, Napoleone Martinuzzi became creative director of the Venetian glass company popularly known as Venini. In 1928, inspired by the strength and opacity of ancient glass, he devised a technique called pulegoso that produced a bubbly glass. It can be seen in “Napoleone Martinuzzi: Venini 1925-1931,” an exhibition through Dec. 1 at Le Stanze del Vetro on San Giorgio Maggiore in Venice. A show theme is the friendship between Mr. Martinuzzi and the poet Gabriele D’Annunzio, who commissioned intensely colorful, intricate works, like a pumpkin made of layered glass. “Martinuzzi brought the tradition of Murano glass into the modern era,” said the show’s curator, Marino Barovier, and his work is “rich in energy and saturated with a surprisingly contemporary taste.” Closed Wednesdays. 011-39-041-5229138 or lestanzedelvetro.it.

headline: When Cats and Cubes Collide
abstract: High tech meets fake fur in the Rimula lounge chair.
lead_paragraph: High tech meets fake fur in Rimula, a lounge chair by Guillaume Sonnet that playfully mixes materials. Mr. Sonnet, a 27-year-old Belgian architect introducing his first production piece, combined the geometry of epoxy-coated tubular steel with the fluffy comfort of a synthetic pelt. (He was reaching for the effect of a cat that had jumped up onto a seat, he said.) The chair is a deformed cube — it measures about two square feet — with every angle offering a different perspective. And its continuous line is a literal representation of his pencil sketch, he said. The chair, which is produced by Liparus, a year-old company that promotes young Belgian designers, made its first appearance recently in Paris. It is available for $1,127. Information: 011-32-497-16-46-17 or liparus.be.

headline: A Fresh Look for Persian Carpets
abstract: Stained glass and lilypads inspired the design of a new collection by Orley Shabahan.
lead_paragraph: Geoffrey Orley and Bahram Shabahang met in the bazaars of Isfahan, Iran, in 1972 and started a business together to import antique Persian carpets. Thirty years later, they set out to create new ones, which are produced with techniques the men feared were dying out. All of their rugs are handmade with silk and wool from their own silkworms and sheep. The yarn is handspun, bathed in natural vegetable dyes, rinsed in streams and dried in the sun. Mr. Shabahang, a trained architect from a family that has made rugs for 400 years, creates all the designs. The latest collection, which was woven in Turkey, includes Printemps, shown above at right, inspired by a piece of Art Deco stained glass (4 feet 2 inches by 6 feet 2 inches; $5,500), and Adrift, inspired by a bird’s-eye view of lilypads in a pond (3 by 5 feet; $3,400). Both rugs are wool. Information: (212) 421-5800 or orleyshabahang.com.

They are sturdy laminated plywood in bright colors. “They’re solid enough to last a lifetime, or several,” Mr. van Elten said. “I just hate plastic toys that are played with for five minutes and then end up in a landfill.”

lead_paragraph: On a late summer day, when the undulating lawns of Mauerpark play host to strolling tourists and local children chasing soccer balls, it is hard to believe that this place was ever the death strip, or no man’s land, running between heavily guarded sections of the Berlin Wall. There are reminders, of course. Portions of the wall remain, as do the foundations of houses abandoned in the zone between East and West.

headline: A Rockefeller Who Prefers A Rustic Life
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Rural Areas', 'Books and Literature', 'Gardens and Gardening']
abstract: Of the many homes Eileen Rockefeller describes in her new memoir, she is most fond of the one that she and her siblings built as children.
lead_paragraph: Growing up Rockefeller is not all finger bowls and private islands in Maine, as Eileen Rockefeller writes in her new memoir, “Being a Rockefeller, Becoming Myself,” out this month from Blue Rider Press. (Reader, don’t be dismayed: there are those accouterments, too.) Ms. Rockefeller, the youngest of David and Peggy Rockefeller’s six children, and a great-granddaughter of John D., grew up between a town house in Manhattan, a farm in Tarrytown, N.Y., a house in St. Barts and another in Maine, and struggled with shyness and undiagnosed dyslexia. Yet the star of the memoir may be Ms. Rockefeller’s mother, Peggy, who battled depression and the exigencies of her role as a Rockefeller wife with an antic wit and a passion for rural life, both of which qualities she worked hard to instill in her children. After Peggy bought a 20-acre island in Maine for $300 from a lobsterman (private island alert), she and her three youngest children built a cabin there by themselves, along with an outhouse, stone wall and vegetable garden.

headline: Lettuce and Tomato on That?

headline: May It Please the Audience
abstract: “Arguendo,” a staged re-creation of a 1991 case about the right of strip clubs to feature performers who are totally nude, is being mounted at the Public Theater by the Elevator Repair Service.
lead_paragraph: A disproportionate number of theatergoers are lawyers. I have no empirical proof to support this — surely none that would hold up in court — but it’s an opinion based on a lifetime of seeing shows, talking to audience members and, for that matter, lawyers, who invariably seem more informed about the current theater season than the average person I meet at a party. So an adaptation of a transcript of a Supreme Court argument might have more commercial potential than you’d think. Moreover, “Arguendo,” a staged re-creation of a 1991 case about the right of strip clubs to feature performers who are totally nude, is being mounted at the Public Theater by the Elevator Repair Service, which has a history of imbuing potentially dry material with off-kilter theatrical joy.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Berry Lips (and No Shortage of Bronzer) at Michael Kors
abstract: Backstage, the designer used lipstick and bronzer from his own recently launched makeup collection on the models.
lead_paragraph: “Of course, it’s Michael Kors — there had to be a little bit of glam!” the fashion designer exclaimed, with a laugh, when describing the beauty look at his show this morning. To achieve the necessary oomph, the makeup artist Dick Page slicked on a rich berry lipstick, called Dame, from Kors’s new 18-piece makeup collection. “It’s a color that’s not an obvious color, and that’s what makes it work on so many different complexions,” the designer said of the shade worn by his entire cast of models, including Karolina Kurkova, Joan Smalls and Liu Wen. Page applied the hue, blotted it, and then set it by brushing powder onto one layer of tissue that had been pressed to the lips to “diffuse the color and pull it out of focus,” he explained. The finishing touch? Bronzer. “I’m bronzer obsessed!” Kors admitted, which explains the generously sized compacts of his label’s Sporty Bronze Powder used backstage (“If I had a horse who needed bronzing, there’s enough product in here!” quipped Page). It all came together to create a relaxed, just-back-from-holiday look, which the model Karmen Pedaru easily channeled: she was spotted sitting outside, soaking up a bit of sun, moments before opening the show.

And yet surveying recent offerings in the bookstores, one can’t help but notice a strange echo reverberating behind the esteemed author.

headline: I Know You Are, but What Am I?
abstract: On Twitter, it was hard to tell who fared worse in Lawrence O’Donnell’s interview with Anthony Weiner.
lead_paragraph: Tuesday may have been the last day of Anthony Weiner’s political career, but his interview on MSNBC with Lawrence O’Donnell Monday night was one more memorable moment in a campaign for the ages. With a confrontational opening question that stunned his guest into a temporary (and uncharacteristic) silence (“What is wrong with you?”), Mr. O’Donnell seemed more shrink than journalist, and created seven minutes of TV gold that became even weirder as it progressed. It even proved an irresistible target for the hosts on “Morning Joe” on MSNBC the next day, as they kept asking one another and several of their guests “What is wrong with you?” before bursting into laughter. On Twitter, it was hard to say who people thought came off worse: the beleaguered guest or his prosecutorial host.

headline: As Obama Pauses Action, Putin Takes Center Stage
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin has, at least for now, made Russia indispensable in containing the conflict in Syria.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin has been many things to President Obama: a partner at times, an irritant more often, the host of the elusive Edward J. Snowden and “the bored kid in the back of the classroom” who offered so little on the administration’s foreign policy goals that Mr. Obama canceled plans to hold a summit meeting in Moscow last week.

headline: McIlroy Trying to Salvage a Season of Lost Confidence

lead_paragraph: LAKE FOREST, Ill. — The PGA Tour is a place where unlucky breaks and honest reckoning intersect. If players could coast on their accomplishments, Rory McIlroy would be coming into the BMW Championship with wind at his back instead of his back against the wall.

headline: It’s a Mad, Mad, Mad, Mad World
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']

headline: The Bordello Chic Trend
abstract: Marc Jacobs’s fall Louis Vuitton show popularizes the bordello look.
lead_paragraph: Love his work or loathe it, there is no escaping Marc Jacobs and his persistent sway on the fashion establishment. On his Louis Vuitton fall runway, the designer unveiled a succession of sylphs wearing little more than their sumptuous skivvies and furs. He followed that act with a much-discussed video that captured the likes of Georgia May Jagger and Cara Delevingne soliciting strangers in Parisian alleys, one performing a languid strip in the headlights of a passing car. At around the same time, Vuitton introduced a fall advertising campaign that ushered viewers inside the parlor of a high-end bordello, its occupants lounging in sultry dishabille (above).

headline: Dot Calm
abstract: New sites that makes booking spa and grooming appointments a virtual experience.
lead_paragraph: Many people now make restaurant reservations, plan trips and rent movies online. But book spa and grooming appointments? Borrow cosmetics? Now you can, with these three new sites.

headline: Hard Lessons of the Colorado Recall
abstract: The ouster of two state senators who had supported gun control laws was a disgraceful low point in punitive single-issue politicking by the gun lobby.
lead_paragraph: The Colorado Legislature showed good sense when it voted in March to require universal background checks in the sale of firearms and limits on magazine clips to 15 rounds.

headline: After Taking a Beating Overseas, Tesco Seeks Comfort at Home
abstract: The British supermarket giant is remodeling its larger stores in an effort to create shopping destinations where customers will linger longer and spend more.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — On a recent Wednesday afternoon, Maureen Goodwin sat sipping a cup of coffee and reading a book in a coffee shop. Next to her were a newspaper and some flowers she had just purchased.

headline: More Mistakes at the N.S.A.
abstract: A surveillance court rebuke of the agency in 2009 for violating its own procedures in analyzing phone records shows, again, the dangers in the data sweeps.
lead_paragraph: A fresh trove of previously classified documents released on Tuesday provides further evidence — as if any more were needed — that the National Security Agency has frequently been unable to comprehend, let alone manage, its vast and continuing collection of Americans’ telephone and Internet records. The documents, made available by the agency in response to lawsuits by two advocacy groups, revealed that in 2009 a judge on the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court severely reprimanded the agency for violating its own procedures for gathering and analyzing phone records, and then misrepresented those violations to the court.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — New satellite photographs showing steam emerging from a newly reconstructed nuclear reactor in North Korea suggest that the country may be making good on its promise to resume the production of plutonium for its small nuclear arsenal, six years after it reached an agreement with the Bush administration to dismantle the facility.

lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — The beginning was so glorious, and so unusual. Eighteen years ago, the Yankees promoted four players from the minor leagues who would go on to play, collectively, at least 70 seasons for the team, mostly as superstars. There is no reason to expect such a bounty again.

headline: A Rare Public View of Obama’s Pivots on Policy in Syria Confrontation
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations', 'Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: President Obama’s handling of his confrontation with Syria has been an unusual instance of a commander in chief seemingly thinking out loud and changing his mind on the fly.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President Obama strode into the Rose Garden last month after a week of increasing tension over Syria’s use of chemical weapons, many assumed it was to announce that the attack that had been broadly hinted at by his own aides had begun. Instead, he turned the decision over to Congress. And when Mr. Obama appeared on television Tuesday night, a speech initially intended to promote force made the argument for diplomacy.

lead_paragraph: Need to lose weight, quit smoking, improve your sex life or get a better night’s sleep? There’s an app for that — all of it — and more. Thousands of mobile apps are available to improve your health and fitness.

headline: Ending Remarks
abstract: Lift your eyes toward Ian Livengood’s puzzle.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — What child hasn’t tucked a towel into the back of their collars like a cape, extended their arms and, pretending to soar into the heavens, yell “IT’S A BIRD! IT’S A PLANE! IT’S SUPERMAN!”?

headline: Getting Past the Outrage on Race
abstract: Trayvon Martin became a symbol for opposing moral judgments about the plight of young black men. But the same systemic problem underlies both.
lead_paragraph: George Yancy’s recent passionate response in The Stone to Trayvon Martin’s killing — and the equally passionate comments on his response — vividly present the seemingly intractable conflict such cases always evoke. There seems to be a sense in which each side is right, but no way to find common ground on which to move discussion forward. This is because, quite apart from the facts of the case, Trayvon Martin immediately became a symbol for two apparently opposing moral judgments. I will suggest, however, that both these judgments derive from the same underlying injustice — one at the heart of the historic March on Washington 50 years ago and highlighted in the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.’s speech on that occasion.

headline: What’s Bugging Me? How Much Time You Got?
abstract: In “All the Faces of the Moon,” Mike Daisey performs a brand-new, highly digressive monologue night after night — for 29 nights and a projected 44 hours.
lead_paragraph: The waxing and waning of the moon affects the tides, as we all know, but lunar changes will have little effect on the prodigious flow of words pouring forth from the writer and performer Mike Daisey this month. Every evening, Mr. Daisey is sitting himself down in front of a table on the stage of Joe’s Pub to perform a brand-new monologue. Night after night — for 29 nights through Oct. 3 and a projected 44 hours — Mr. Daisey is making like a modern-day Scheherazade, telling stories of his life and the life of New York City, ranting and railing at any number of contemporary scourges along the way, in an epic series of performances he’s collectively calling “All the Faces of the Moon.”

headline: New York Regulator Sees Abuse Increasing Under New Insurance Rules
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Life Insurance', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Benjamin Lawsky, the New York financial regulator, has left a multistate test of a framework for insurers’ asset reserves, saying industry “gamesmanship” was only getting worse.
lead_paragraph: Several big life insurers are going to have to set aside a total of at least $4 billion because New York regulators believe they have been manipulating new rules meant to make sure they have adequate reserves to pay out claims.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State John Kerry headed late Wednesday to Geneva with a team of arms control experts for intensive talks with his Russian counterpart, Sergey V. Lavrov, to try to reach an agreement on how to secure and ultimately destroy Syria’s chemical weapons.

abstract: Democrats control the state legislature and the governor’s mansion, but a recall campaign exposed the party to popular anger as voters ousted two state senators who supported gun laws.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — When Colorado passed a series of tough gun restrictions last winter, Democrats and gun control advocates hailed it as a sign of changing attitudes in a Western swing state. But moments after a pivotal vote in the state Senate, a Republican lawmaker named Greg Brophy warned that Colorado’s independent-leaning voters would rebel against the new laws.

headline: Giants’ Jacobs Has a New Attitude to Go With His New Number

lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — In his first term with the Giants, Brandon Jacobs was the outspoken, gruff outlier in an understated, even-tempered football family. Jacobs squabbled with fans who booed him, vexed his coaches, lost his starting job and said he looked forward to proving himself elsewhere as an ex-Giant.

lead_paragraph: SANGIN, Afghanistan — Some days, the Afghan soldiers worry that the mud walls around their headquarters in this embattled district are barely enough to keep the Taliban out. Perhaps more problematic is that the crumbling facade appears to be keeping the soldiers in.

headline: For Hynes, History of Making Brooklyn Safer Wasn’t Enough to Survive
abstract: Charles J. Hynes became the first district attorney in the city to lose a re-election bid since 1955 after a challenger swept to victory in the Democratic primary on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Charles J. Hynes, the district attorney who was Brooklyn’s most powerful political figure and top law enforcement officer for more than 23 years, liked to say he would probably die in office. As he instituted programs that changed New York City’s criminal justice system and became a heavyweight in the borough’s insular political world, there seemed to be no part of Brooklyn he had not touched and few members of the bar who had not worked with or against him.

headline: Ballot Measure on Casinos Will Have a Positive Slant

headline: Saul Landau, Maker of Films With Leftist Edge, Dies at 77
abstract: Mr. Landau’s passion for asking what he called “the most intrusive questions” yielded penetrating cinematic profiles of leaders like Fidel Castro and Salvador Allende.
lead_paragraph: Saul Landau, a determinedly leftist documentary filmmaker and writer whose passion for asking what he called “the most intrusive questions” yielded penetrating cinematic profiles of leaders like Fidel Castro and Salvador Allende, died on Monday at his home in Alameda, Calif. He was 77.

headline: Israel: To Avoid Trial, State Pays Family of Prisoner X
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'International Relations', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts']
abstract: Israel has reached a compensation agreement with the family of Ben Zygier, an Australian-Israeli who was jailed in Israel and who died after hanging himself in his cell in 2010.
lead_paragraph: Israel has reached a compensation agreement with the family of Ben Zygier, an Australian-Israeli who was jailed in Israel after apparently getting caught in a web of espionage and who died after hanging himself in his cell in December 2010. The Israeli authorities have concealed the reason for the arrest and secret imprisonment of the man who was known as Prisoner X, citing national security reasons. Israel’s Ministry of Justice said in a statement late Tuesday that negotiations were held after the family claimed the state had been negligent in its treatment of the case. The state will pay the family just over $1.1 million to avoid a court trial that might have revealed details harmful to state security, according to the statement.

headline: Yankees Rally for a Crucial Win; the Loss They Need Comes Later
