lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — A half-hour after their latest important victory, the Yankees showered and changed in the visitors’ clubhouse at Camden Yards as a television set beamed images from Tropicana Field, where the Boston Red Sox were facing the Tampa Bay Rays.

headline: Britain: Politician Leaves a Post After Assault Charges
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Legislatures and Parliaments', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: A deputy speaker of Parliament, Nigel Evans, resigned from the post after he was charged with eight counts of sexual assault, including rape, dating from 2002 until this year.
lead_paragraph: A deputy speaker of Parliament, Nigel Evans, resigned from the post on Wednesday after he was charged with eight counts of sexual assault, including rape, dating from 2002 until earlier this year. Mr. Evans, 55, a Conservative who represents a constituency in Lancashire, said that he would remain an independent member of Parliament while he seeks to prove his innocence in court, where he is scheduled to appear Sept. 18. The Crown Prosecution Service had said Tuesday that the charges would be based on alleged offenses against men, according to The Associated Press.

headline: Canada: Crude Oil in Runaway Train Was Mislabeled
abstract: The runaway train that exploded, killing 47 people and destroying much of Lac-Mégantic, Quebec, was far more volatile than signs on its tank cars indicated, investigators said.
lead_paragraph: The crude oil on a runaway train that derailed, exploded and destroyed much of Lac-Mégantic, Quebec, killing 47 people, was far more volatile than warning signs on its tank cars indicated, investigators said Wednesday. Donald Ross of the Transportation Safety Board of Canada said that the crude had been classified like substances with relatively low flash points, like diesel fuel. But tests on the oil remaining in tank cars that survived the crash found that it belonged in a more explosive category that includes gasoline. Questions had been raised about why the explosion had been so devastating, given the relatively low volatility of most crude oil. Mr. Ross said that accurate labeling would not have required the use of stronger tank cars or altered the actions of firefighters, but investigators are eventually expected to make new safety recommendations based on their findings.

headline: Wheeler Finishing on Strong Note, Unlike Mets’ Offense
abstract: Zack Wheeler, who is nearing his innings limit, held the Nationals in check for seven innings, but the offense managed just three hits.
lead_paragraph: Zack Wheeler will soon reach his innings limit and be shut down for the rest of the Mets’ lost season. He will effectively be placed in storage, in metaphorical Bubble Wrap, to be reopened next spring, as a precaution to protect his young right arm.

headline: Can the Yankees Squeeze In a Few More?
abstract: The Yankees have two and a half weeks to match the record for the most players used by one team in a season at 59.
lead_paragraph: Plagued by injuries since spring training, the Yankees had already used a club-record 54 players (listed in the team logo above, with the size of each name proportional to the number of games played) going into Wednesday night’s game at Baltimore. And the number continued to grow, with the newly acquired shortstop Brendan Ryan making his Yankees debut against the Orioles. For those who are wondering, the Elias Sports Bureau said the record for the most players used by one team in a season is 59, set by the Cleveland Indians in 2002 and the San Diego Padres in 2002 and 2008. The Yankees have two and a half weeks to match that mark. And who knows? They might.

headline: Hospital Confronts Childbirth Deaths in Mumbai Slum
abstract: The efforts of community volunteers and doctors at Chotta Sion hospital toward improving maternal and infant mortality rates in Mumbai’s Dharavi slum are threatened by the rising population.
lead_paragraph: DHARAVI, Maharashtra— Elizabeth Nadumani, 40, pulled up the bottom of her sari as she stepped over a hole filled with milky fluid and floating debris toward the entrance of a shack in Mumbai’s Dharavi slum. Inside the tiny home, a 23-year-old mother named Chaya, who goes by one name, breastfed her one-month-old son. When Ms. Nadumani parted the thin curtain that served as a door, Chaya covered her breasts and straightened her matted hair. In hushed tones, Ms. Nadumani reminded the young mother of her son’s pending appointment for a polio vaccination, and then slipped her a package of government condoms.

headline: No Child Left Untableted
abstract: Rupert Murdoch’s new idea for how to educate America.
lead_paragraph: Sally Hurd Smith, a veteran teacher, held up her brand-new tablet computer and shook it as she said, “I don’t want this thing to take over my classroom.” It was late June, a month before the first day of school. In a sixth-grade classroom in Greensboro, N.C., a dozen middle-school social-studies teachers were getting their second of three days of training on tablets that had been presented to them as a transformative educational tool. Every student and teacher in 18 of Guilford County’s 24 middle schools would receive one, 15,450 in all, to be used for class work, homework, educational games — just about everything, eventually.

headline: Vietnam War Photos That Made a Difference
abstract: Richard Pyle, the last surviving Saigon bureau chief for The Associated Press during the Vietnam War, recounts how the wire service marshaled the talents of a legendary corps of photographers in pursuit of the truth.
lead_paragraph: We highly recommend that you view this slideshow in “full-screen” mode.

headline: What Are Your Favorite Internet Spoofs?
abstract: Were you fooled by the recent “Worst Twerking Video EVER” spoof? What other Internet jokes, parodies or tricks have you enjoyed? Why?
lead_paragraph: By now you’ve probably seen either the viral video “Worst Twerk Fail EVER — Girl Catches Fire!” or the Jimmy Kimmel reveal, which we’ve embedded above. The Times reporter Bill Carter called it “one of the best Internet pranks in recent memory.” Were you tricked?

headline: Kerry Insists That Syria Quickly Give Data on Arms
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT', 'United States International Relations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry said his team would be looking for important signs that Syria and Russia were serious about securing and disposing of Syria’s chemical weapons.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Secretary of State John Kerry set an early test for Syria’s top leader on Thursday by insisting on quick disclosure of data on that country’s arsenal of chemical weapons.

headline: Submersible James Bond Lotus Brings Nearly $1 Million at Auction
abstract: The swimming Lotus from “The Spy Who Loved Me” is an actual submarine, and it sold Monday at an auction in London.
lead_paragraph: RM Auctions of Blenheim, Ontario, sold a white 1977 Lotus Esprit S1 in London on Monday for the astronomical sum of $973,000.

headline: New York Today: Autumn Can Wait
abstract: What you need to know for Thursday: more sticky weather, jockeying to avert a mayoral runoff and the birthday of the American musical.
lead_paragraph: Updated 11:51 a.m. | Perhaps you were thinking that by mid-September you could put your air-conditioners and tank tops in storage.

headline: Mark Cuban Invests in Start-Up to Connect Companies to M.B.A.’s
abstract: The billionaire Mark Cuban is investing in a start-up that offers companies consulting services by M.B.A. students and graduates.
lead_paragraph: It started with a cold call: an e-mail in July to the billionaire investor Mark Cuban, asking him for money.

headline: To the Best of My Memory, It Was Love
abstract: When memories are over 50 years old, can we believe them?
lead_paragraph: Possibly because it’s September, when it has become clear whether a romance will last or has been only the stuff of summer, I am thinking of my older cousin, Ravishing Rachel, who, in the 1950s, could walk down the street in the Catskills resort town of Fleischmanns and make old men weep.

headline: Morgenthaler Partners Hang Out a Shingle With $175 Million Fund
abstract: Three partners at the venture capital firm Morgenthaler Ventures are forming the Canvas Venture Fund, a new fund to make early-stage investments in software companies.
lead_paragraph: Three partners at the venture capital firm Morgenthaler Ventures are striking out on their own, with a new fund to make early-stage investments in software companies.

headline: Debating Whether There’s Still a Place for Advertising
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Blogs and Blogging (Internet)', 'Magazines', 'Online Advertising', 'Small Business', 'Social Media']
abstract: With the decline of print publications, the founder of one start-up said she wouldn’t even consider advertising.
lead_paragraph: At the most recent She Owns It business group meeting, we discussed advertising. Several group members — Alexandra Mayzler, Jessica Johnson and Susan Parker — were unable to attend the meeting, but they offered their thoughts in individual conversations afterward. Additionally, Erica Rosenfeld, co-owner of Bari Jay, provided comments separately.

headline: Daily Report: F.T.C. Raises Questions About Facebook’s New Privacy Policy
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Privacy', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Social Media']
abstract: Facebook, which has repeatedly tripped over its own feet when changing its privacy practices, has stumbled yet again.
lead_paragraph: Facebook, which has repeatedly tripped over its own feet when changing its privacy practices, has stumbled yet again, Vindu Goel and Edward Wyatt report.

headline: North Korea Appears to Restart Nuclear Program
abstract: Satellite photos suggest that North Korea has resumed plutonium production.
lead_paragraph: Satellite photos suggest that North Korea has resumed plutonium production.

headline: In Dell Buyout, a Final Chapter
abstract: After months of boardroom wrangling, the fight over Dell may be drawing to a close. | It seems no sum is too large for companies looking to raise money through the debt markets. | New York State plans to drop out of an agreement over rules for insurers. | Henry M. Paulson Jr. is still troubled by the bailout of Wall Street.
lead_paragraph: IN DELL BUYOUT, A FINAL CHAPTER  |  After months of boardroom wrangling and public accusations, the fight over Dell may be drawing to a close. Shareholders are meeting on Thursday to vote on the $24.9 billion buyout proposal by the company’s founder, Michael S. Dell, and the investment firm Silver Lake.

headline: New York Fashion Week: Reed Krakoff Spring/Summer 2014
abstract: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Anna Moller.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Anna Moller.

headline: A Far-Flung Possibility for the Origin of Life
abstract: A leading expert on the origin of life suggests that based on available evidence, Mars might be a more likely place for life to have started than Earth.
lead_paragraph: “We’re All Martians, Scientist Claims,” The Telegraph wrote on Aug. 28. Similar articles showed up in newspapers and on Web sites around the world.

headline: Taking Himself Out of the Equation
abstract: Sting broke his songwriter’s block by focusing on a show, “The Last Ship,” which he hopes will reach Broadway.
lead_paragraph: Early in May, a few hundred people received hush-hush invitations to the Signature Theater in Midtown. They arrived for a staged reading, a spartan workshop production assembled in under 29 hours of rehearsal as a preview for potential backers and other interested parties.

headline: Prince William to Leave the British Military
keywords: ['Royal Family', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Endangered and Extinct Species']
abstract: After more than seven years of service, mainly as a helicopter search-and-rescue pilot, the royal family said the prince would focus on charitable work and conservation.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — After more than seven years of service as a guards officer and pilot, Prince William will end his military service and focus on charitable work and conservation issues, the royal family announced Thursday.

headline: An Anchorless World
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States International Relations', 'Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: “The ogre does what ogres can,” wrote W.H. Auden. Yet no ogre, least of all in Syria, trembles today after Obama’s wavering.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — At dinner the other night, perusing the debacle that is Syria, a German friend observed: “It’s the post-American world — and that means chaos.” We were joined by John Kornblum, the former U.S. ambassador to Germany, whose verdict was similar: “What you’re seeing is the steady break-up of the postwar system.”

headline: Xiao Wen Ju Transforms Backstage at Anna Sui
abstract: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Spring 2014 Fashion Week in New York.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Spring 2014 Fashion Week in New York. Here, the model Xiao Wen Ju before (left) and after (right) makeup by Pat McGrath and hair by Garren.

headline: In Hilton I.P.O., a Losing Deal Turns Around
abstract: If successful, the Hilton initial public offering would be a powerful vindication of Blackstone’s real estate strategy and prove that even some seemingly doomed deals can yield generous returns given enough time.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 7:14 p.m. | In early 2009, it looked as if Blackstone, the investment firm, had struck one of the worst deals ever. Two years earlier, Blackstone had acquired Hilton Hotels for $26 billion, one of the largest buyouts of all time.

headline: Fashion Week: Elements | Silhouette
abstract: A thematic visual diary of New York Fashion Week inspired by the essential building blocks of fashion and style.
lead_paragraph: A thematic visual diary of New York Fashion Week inspired by the essential building blocks of fashion and style.

headline: The Cult of Sisi
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Amid all the ambient chauvinism, few Egyptians are questioning the military’s actions or intentions.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — At a chocolate store around the corner from my home, one of the most popular items are boxes of chocolates decorated with tiny portraits of Gen. Abdel Fattah el-Sisi. The head of the armed forces, defense minister and deputy prime minister who deposed President Mohamed Morsi on July 3 is the object of hero worship and many quirky commercial tie-ins. The Tumblr feed “Where else have you seen Sisi today?” includes posters of him as “the lion of the Egyptian Army,” military-themed wedding parties and a Sisi sandwich.

headline: The Many Mysteries of Air Travel
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Airport Security', 'Aviation Accidents and Safety']
abstract: Air turbulence won’t crash a plane, and nothing happens when lightning hits a plane. A pilot and blogger answers the questions that many fliers have.
lead_paragraph: Technology and air travel have always gone hand in hand, and they’re only getting more intertwined. From security at the airport to the rules about using electronics in flight to the final resting place of the plane’s toilet contents, airplanes and tech are a constant source of conflict, passion — and questions.

headline: European Lawmakers Expand Power of Central Bank Over Top Lenders
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Law and Legislation', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The European Parliament agreed to put about 130 of the euro zone’s largest banks under the scrutiny of the European Central Bank.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — European Union legislators overwhelmingly approved a law on Thursday that puts about 130 of the euro zone’s largest banks under the direct scrutiny of the European Central Bank.

headline: KPN and América Móvil Still in Talks
abstract: América Móvil, the Latin American telecommunications company, confirmed on Thursday that it remained in talks with the Dutch cellphone company KPN about a potential bid worth $9.6 billion despite its earlier announcement that it was considering dropping its bid.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Carlos Slim Helú still has his sights set on Europe.

headline: Peter Ackroyd’s London Calling
abstract: The astoundingly prolific author Peter Ackroyd has maintained a hermetic lifestyle in the city whose lore he knows best. But he hasn’t done so without some controversy.
lead_paragraph: Up close and personal with Peter Ackroyd, England’s insanely prolific, controversial and eccentric novelist and historian.

headline: Remembering a Lift From Grandmother
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A woman watched her sister being helped off a bus by a stranger.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: A Comeback on His Own Terms
abstract: Isaiah Washington is back on screen with “Blue Caprice” after a six-year hiatus during which he focused on aiding Sierra Leone.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Isaiah Washington was talking about goats. At Hal’s Bar & Grill here on Abbot Kinney Boulevard, he was recounting how he had recently bought 15 of them for a village in Sierra Leone, where he has been a chief, known as Gondobay Manga II, since 2006.

headline: Latinos Among New Kennedy Center Honorees
abstract: After a revamped selection process, Martina Arroyo and Carlos Santana join Herbie Hancock, Billy Joel and Shirley MacLaine in this year’s selections.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Herbie Hancock learned he was one of the five artists to be honored this year by the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, the surprise, he said, brought him to the verge of tears. “And that doesn’t happen to me very often.”

headline: India Restarts Battle Against Leprosy
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Doctors', "Leprosy (Hansen's Disease)", 'Volunteers and Community Service']
abstract: India has declared that it has leprosy under control, but the numbers are showing a slow but clear rise in new cases.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, Maharashtra— At a referral center in Mumbai, a 19-year-old college student rolls up the sleeve of her tunic to reveal an inch-long red lesion surrounded by a negligible skin discoloration on her arm. She pinches the pigmented patch, then prods at it with an accusing finger.

headline: Ode to the Undergarment
abstract: Andrew Ross Sorkin tried everything in a quest for the perfect undershirt, and found out that men of all stripes care a lot more about undergarments than one might think.
lead_paragraph: Even men who don’t conjure Channing Tatum when stripped to their skivvies still feel passionate about their underpinnings. One man’s quest to find perfection.

headline: With Subsidies, Frito-Lay Buys Chargers and More Electric Trucks
abstract: Using state and federal grants, Frito-Lay hopes to bring its nationwide fleet of electric trucks to 269 by the end of the year.
lead_paragraph: Frito-Lay, one of the first companies to put modern electric delivery trucks on the road in New York State, is now following up by adding more vehicles and, working with state government, the charging stations to go with them.

headline: Ralph Steadman on His Work
abstract: Ralph Steadman, an illustrator and the subject of the film “For No Good Reason,” speaks about his creative process.
lead_paragraph: Ralph Steadman, an illustrator and the subject of the film “For No Good Reason,” speaks about his creative process.

headline: Image of the Day: September 12
abstract: A worker at a carpet manufacturing factory in Jammu city, Jammu and Kashmir.

headline: Richard Dawkins: By the Book
abstract: The author of “The God Delusion” and “An Appetite for Wonder” doesn’t care for “Pride and Prejudice”: “I can’t get excited about who is going to marry whom, and how rich they are.”
lead_paragraph: The author of “The God Delusion” and “An Appetite for Wonder” doesn’t care for “Pride and Prejudice”: “I can’t get excited about who is going to marry whom, and how rich they are.”

headline: Toronto Video: Ralph Steadman Discusses His Art
abstract: Ralph Steadman, an illustrator and the subject of the film “For No Good Reason,” speaks about his creative process.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — The lively political drawings of Ralph Steadman have been capturing attention for decades. The illustrator and cartoonist may be known for teaming up with the writer Hunter S. Thompson in 1969, but he has racked up his fair share of interesting life experiences as well. They are chronicled in Charlie Paul’s documentary about Mr. Steadman, “For No Good Reason,” which screened this week at the festival.

headline: Long Battle for Dell Ends in Victory for Founder
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: Dell shareholders voted on Thursday to approve the computer company’s $24.9 billion sale to its founder, ending a monthslong slog that included fierce opposition from some investors.
lead_paragraph: After months of hurdles, Michael S. Dell is finally poised to buy full control of the company that bears his name, in his biggest move yet to turn around the computer maker’s fortunes as its industry goes through tectonic shifts.

headline: Republicans Who Meddle With Profit-Making Business
abstract: Bob Corker said Volkswagen would be a “laughingstock” if it let the U.A.W. set up shop in its Chattanooga factory.
lead_paragraph: It’s no secret that many Republican lawmakers dislike labor unions, which are big supporters of Democrats. But it’s unusual to see a politician willing to castigate an employer in his state just for talking to union officials about setting up a union at its factory.

headline: Uncertain at the OECD
abstract: Pay no attention to the austerity behind the curtain.
lead_paragraph: One of the distinguishing features of economic discourse since 2008 has been the remarkably destructive role played by most, though not all, international technocrats. In the face of high unemployment and low inflation, key institutions — the European Commission, the Bank for International Settlements, the OECD — have consistently called for policies that would depress advanced economies even more.

headline: Day 8 at NYFW: Ralph Lauren, Calvin Klein, Marc Jacobs
abstract: Three powerhouses show their collections today, wrapping the spring 2014 season of New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: Three powerhouses show their collections today, wrapping the spring 2014 season of New York Fashion Week.

headline: Boehner Seeking Democrats’ Help on Fiscal Talks
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'National Debt (US)', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: As Speaker John A. Boehner sought a deal to avert a government shutdown and raise the debt ceiling, a bloc of Republicans demanded a delay in the federal health care law, which the White House called “a nonstarter.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With Congress momentarily freed from the Syrian crisis, lawmakers plunged back into their bitter fiscal standoff on Thursday as Speaker John A. Boehner appealed to the Obama administration and Democratic leaders to help him resolve divisions in the Republican ranks that could lead to a government shutdown by month’s end.

headline: Good Times at the Top
abstract: The top 0.01 percent are richer than ever.
lead_paragraph: Inequality wonks wait eagerly for the latest update of the Piketty-Saez data, which estimate concentration of income at the top using income tax returns. The latest edition does not disappoint: it shows, as one might expect but needed confirmed, that the very rich have recovered just fine from the Great Recession, even as the great majority of Americans continue to struggle. In fact, the super-elite — the top 0.01 percent — actually had higher incomes in 2012 than they did at the height of the bubble.

headline: Photos: A Test of Will, With a View
abstract: The Ultra-Trail du Mont-Blanc, a 104-mile marathon through France, Switzerland and Italy, tests runners’ endurance with numerous passages in high altitude.
lead_paragraph: A race that compiles a breakdown of the athletes who abandoned the competition cannot be kind.

headline: Warner and J.K. Rowling Reach Wide-Ranging Deal
abstract: The studio said Ms. Rowling would become a screenwriter, working on an adaptation of her “Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them.”
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Warner Brothers is doubling down on the J. K. Rowling business. The studio, whose blockbuster “Harry Potter” films have generated billions of dollars for the company, announced on Thursday that it had concluded a deal with Ms. Rowling that will include new movies, distribution rights to a television mini-series and new theme park attractions.

headline: Mayor Defends Record Amid Campaign Attacks
abstract: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg offered a spirited case for his stewardship of the city and warned that his hard-fought accomplishments could be lost.
lead_paragraph: For months, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has been ignored and maligned by many of those seeking to succeed him.

headline: Today in Small Business: Burt’s Buzz
abstract: New home sales soften. “Phablets” take off. Are higher wages actually good for a fast-food business?
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Poetry Pairing | ‘Trees’
abstract: We ring in the new school year with “Trees” by Joyce Kilmer paired with The New York Times Book Review essay “A Tree Grows, and Grows.”
lead_paragraph: We ring in the new school year with the return of our Poetry Pairing series.

headline: The Story Behind the Putin Op-Ed Article in The Times
abstract: The editorial page editor calls the piece fascinating and newsworthy.
lead_paragraph: A Times reader, Lawrence DeVine, has a few questions about The Times’s publication of an Op-Ed article in Thursday’s paper by Vladimir V. Putin, the president of Russia. He asks: “Did he call up the editorial page editor and say, hey, how would you like 800 words on you, us and Syria, I’ll have it in by Wednesday night deadline, no sweat, I’ll take your usual freelance rates?”

headline: A Little Slip of a Thing
abstract:
First cousin of the fainting couch, the slipper chair has
broken out of the boudoir and proven remarkably versatile.
lead_paragraph: Chuck Chewning lowered his tall, lean frame into a petite slipper chair at David Duncan Antiques on the Upper East Side. Both he and the chair were elegant, but his height and the chair’s diminutive size made this an amusing exercise to witness.

headline: Fantasy Football: Week 2 Matchup Breakdown
abstract: Fantasy owners may panic after seeing some of their top picks struggle to start the season. We emphasize patience in Week 2.
lead_paragraph: After months of preparation, it is understandable that fantasy owners tend to panic after seeing some of their top draft picks struggle to start the season.

headline: American Jihadist Is Believed to Have Been Killed by His Former Allies in Somalia
abstract: Omar Hammami, who grew up in Alabama, was known for his rap-infused propaganda videos for the Shabab, a brutal Islamist group.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — A young man from Alabama who traveled to Somalia and became an infamous Islamist militant, commanding guerrilla forces and earning a $5 million American bounty on his head, was believed to have been killed by his former extremist allies on Thursday, according to news reports and Islamist Web sites.

headline: Fool for Being Fooled
abstract: Why do we love being fooled? A look at why people get a thrill out of misdirection in puzzle cluing and sleight-of-hand.
lead_paragraph: I’ve long been fascinated with the concept of misdirection in crossword cluing and the feeling of wonder in general when something beautiful and unexpected happens. I was also curious about why we seem to love being fooled so much, so I’m presenting the following as a think piece.

headline: Another Set of Beatles’ BBC Recordings Is on the Way
abstract: A follow-up to the 1994 “The Beatles Live at the BBC” is due out Nov. 11.
lead_paragraph: When Capitol Records released “The Beatles Live at the BBC” to great fanfare in 1994, Beatles collectors lamented that the two-disc set barely scratched the surface of the vast trove of recordings the band made for the BBC between March 1962 and June 1965. Many of those radio recordings were already on a 10-disc bootleg set, after all, and in the 19 years since then, bootleggers have come up with another three discs’ worth of material.

headline: Hilton Is Ready to Go Public, but Other Buyouts Are Still Waiting
abstract: Some of the biggest of companies of the buyout era, including First Data and Clear Channel Communications, remain in the hands of their private equity buyers, which are reshaping the companies with varying degrees of success.
lead_paragraph: With Hilton Worldwide Holdings filing on Thursday to go public, it appears that one of the biggest deals of the buyout boom is headed toward a successful completion.

headline: Footsteps of Kings (Like Olivier and Gielgud)
abstract: “The Hollow Crown,” a co-production of the BBC and PBS, uses a British cast to retell four of Shakespeare’s history plays.
lead_paragraph: “Uneasy lies the head that wears a crown,” Shakespeare wrote some 400 years ago, and although crowns are far less abundant now, uneasy heads are everywhere on the world stage. So the audience for the new series “The Hollow Crown” should understand exactly what Henry IV of England means when he speaks that famous line. That, at least, is the hope of the BBC and PBS, the co-producers of the four-part series, which was shown in Britain last year and is to be broadcast on “Great Performances” in the United States, beginning on Friday, Sept. 20.

headline: The Gun Report: September 12, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.

headline: Letting Lips Do What Hands Do
abstract: A veteran British voice coach helped Orlando Bloom and Condola Rashad rehearse for the new Broadway production of “Romeo and Juliet.”
lead_paragraph: Sometimes love arrives like a thunderbolt. Sometimes it arrives with a bonk on the head with a balloon.

headline: Classically Innovative
abstract: Adrian Lester and Rory Kinnear, two leading British theater actors, discuss their current play, “Othello,” and others.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Does Shakespeare ever get stale for experienced Shakespeareans? In Nicholas Hytner’s contemporary production of “Othello” at the National Theater here, two leading British theater actors, Adrian Lester and Rory Kinnear, have drawn acclaim for the fresh clarity and credibility of their performances as Othello and Iago — characters whose ultimately lethal actions can sometimes strain belief.

headline: An Off Broadway Rarity: ‘Buyer & Cellar’ Turns a Quick Profit
abstract: “Buyer & Cellar” becomes one of the few Off Broadway shows to turn a profit.
lead_paragraph: The critically acclaimed play “Buyer & Cellar,” an Off Broadway show starring Michael Urie (“Ugly Betty”) as a struggling actor who goes to work for Barbra Streisand, recouped its $500,000 capitalization in just nine weeks of performances at the Barrow Street Theater, the producers announced Thursday.

headline: Youngest Djokovic Is Adjusting to Life as a Pro
abstract: Djordje Djokovic, 18, is the youngest of Novak’s two tennis playing siblings, and has long been marked as a special talent. But he has only two wins in his first full season on the professional circuit.
lead_paragraph: On Monday afternoon the eyes of the tennis world were fixated on Flushing Meadows, Novak Djokovic played the 37th installment of his rivalry with Rafael Nadal. Several thousand miles away in Banja Luka, a picturesque city in northern Bosnia, another Djokovic watched from his hotel room, living every moment and dreaming that one day he too might experience the adrenaline rush of competing on such a grand stage.

headline: Lessons From the Dell Deal
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism']
abstract: The tortuous Dell buyout is essentially over. Now, it’s time to step back, be introspective and draw some lessons.
lead_paragraph: The tortuous Dell buyout is essentially over after shareholders approved the company’s purchase by its chief executive, Michael S. Dell, and the private equity firm Silver Lake. Now, it’s time to step back, be introspective and draw some lessons.

headline: Wheelies: The Papal Beater Car Edition
abstract: Pope Francis gets a 29-year-old Renault, and Harley-Davidson may bring lower-cost motorcycles to India.
lead_paragraph: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: From Sketch to Stage: A Season of Shakespeare
abstract: A look at  costume sketches from Shakespeare productions in the new season.
lead_paragraph: A look at  costume sketches from Shakespeare productions in the new season.

headline: At the End of Eden, Rustic Tranquillity
abstract: The San Blas Islands, off the coast of Panama, may not offer your average Caribbean escape. But, that may be exactly why you’d want to go.
lead_paragraph: The street was empty when I locked the door at the inn and plopped myself down on the curb. It was 4:30 a.m., the air as still as slack water: a great time to be in Panama City. On the quiet, empty sidewalk I took inventory of everything I would need for the next few days: bug spray, sunscreen, snacks, bathing suit, shorts and lots and lots of water.

headline: As They Liked It
abstract: Performers recall the Shakespeare moment they still can’t shake.
lead_paragraph: Actors, directors and others in Shakespeare-themed productions this fall recall the Shakespeare moment they still can’t shake.

headline: Brush Up Your ... Oh, You Know
abstract: A selective guide to Shakespeare-based productions in New York this season.
lead_paragraph: A selective guide to Shakespeare-based productions in New York this season.

headline: Triple Play: Make Your Picks for Week 25
abstract: Put your predictive skills to the test each week of the baseball season.
lead_paragraph: The Bats blog again tests our readers’ predictive skills with three questions about the coming week. Feel free to lean on research, tea leaves, your gut instinct or maybe just dumb luck.

headline: A Hallucinatory Blaze, via Tibetan Ritual
abstract: “Poppy Fields,” a solo show opening on Friday at Pace Gallery, will be a showcase for Zhang Huan’s brightly colored paintings of skulls, a shift from his somber tones of earlier years.
lead_paragraph: Damien Hirst once encrusted a skull with diamonds, and Takashi Murakami has turned out canvases with cartoon versions of skulls. But when the artist Zhang Huan addresses similar iconography, he creates paintings in a style all their own. Sitting in his Shanghai studio one day recently amid dozens of Tibetan death masks, he was busy preparing for the opening on Friday of “Poppy Fields,” an exhibition of new works at the Pace Gallery in Chelsea.

headline: What if a Teacher Doesn’t Like a Parent?
abstract: Dear Mrs. Lahey: Do you treat our kids differently if you like their parents? Alternately, are you nicer to the parents if you like the kids?
lead_paragraph: The very first question for the Parent-Teacher Conference comes from A. J. Jacobs, editor-at-large at Esquire magazine, author and father of three: a 9-year-old and 7-year-old twins. A. J. plays the role of guinea pig in his writing, whether he is following the Bible as literally as possible in his book “My Year of Living Biblically” or striving to be the healthiest man in the world in “Drop Dead Healthy.” Consequently, when I needed a guinea pig for my first installment of the Parent-Teacher Conference, A. J. was a willing subject. In the coming weeks, I’ll be answering questions about the parent-teacher relationship in this space on alternating Thursdays. Have a question? E-mail me at teacherlahey@gmail.com.

headline: Caring for a Mind in Crisis
abstract: Of all the afflictions that fall upon us, few remain as misunderstood and stigmatized as those that affect the mind.
lead_paragraph: One afternoon at a school not far from the hospital where I was working, a teacher opened a utility closet and found a staff member passed out on the floor. He was clutching a small bloody mass in one hand, a sharp knife in the other, she reported, a red stain spreading rapidly at his middle.

headline: Senate Panel Approves Journalist Shield Legislation
abstract: The Senate Judiciary Committee on Thursday passed legislation to provide greater protections against reporters being fined or imprisoned if they refuse to identify confidential sources.
lead_paragraph: The Senate Judiciary Committee on Thursday passed legislation to provide greater protections against reporters being fined or imprisoned if they refuse to identify confidential sources. The bill, the Free Flow of Information Act of 2013, passed by 13 to 5, after lawmakers agreed on an amendment defining who qualifies as a journalist.

headline: Looking for the Anti-Bloomberg
keywords: ['Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Elections, Mayors', 'Gun Control', 'Liberalism (US Politics)']
abstract: A pro-rich, socially liberal authoritarianism is not the only form of political centrism imaginable.
lead_paragraph: With Dave Weigel calling Tuesday’s outcome in New York’s mayoral primary (which turned on liberal angst about stop and frisk and economic inequality) and Colorado’s recall elections (which turned on conservative backlash against gun control) a defeat for the “ethos of Bloombergism,” this seems like a good time to highlight Jonathan Chait’s excellent New York Magazine essay on Michael Bloomberg’s worldview and (deluded) presidential ambitions. Chait does a fine job of capturing the essential elements of Bloombergism, from the authoritarian governing style to the distinctive “pink police state” approach to social policy (sexual freedom and bike lanes for me, stop and frisk and soda bans for thee), and he cuts to the heart of why Bloomberg’s overall agenda wasn’t really perfectly calibrated to the median voter’s allegedly post-partisan desires, as so many of the mayor’s Acela Corridor fans wanted to believe:

headline: All the Rage | Men’s Wear Collections for Speed Racers and Getaway Guys
abstract: It’s almost as though the movie “Drive” influenced spring runways, from the venues to the clothes.
lead_paragraph: In a welcome contrast to the bare-bones runways that have set the scene for most women’s shows during New York Fashion Week, men’s wear designers have played up the masculine, visual references. From the venues to the clothes, it’s almost as though “Drive,” the 2011 visual thriller starring Ryan Gosling, influenced it all. General Idea presented its sleek separates inside the Classic Car Club, where models walked in front of a pair of antique roadsters that set the tone for the label’s mesh and reflective jackets. Tim Coppens took his collection to the track, outfitting his crew — whose members carried racing helmets as the accessory du jour — in long and short sleeveless jumpsuits and classic racing leathers. Backstage at Siki Im, models dressed amid parked cars before the show began inside an old garage. Opening Ceremony showed both men’s and women’s looks in its very first runway, but the setting and presentation was decidedly masculine: an army of models flooded the vast space at the SuperPier, all at once, chauffeured by a stream of shiny cars. And the satin bomber jackets, like the one Gosling wears in “Drive,” were in no short supply either. Bespoken, J. Crew, Marc by Marc Jacobs and Porsche Design all showed metallic and satin versions of the short zip-front blouson, many with models wearing expression-concealing shades like Gosling’s deadpan character.

headline: A Heady Cocktail of Books and Booze
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Book Trade and Publishing', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: The Lit Crawl — like a pub crawl, but with authors — returns to Manhattan this weekend, offering lesser-known New York writers a turn in the spotlight.
lead_paragraph: LET the publishing industry fret about the future of print. In an ever more digitized age, literature as live event appears to be thriving.

headline: My Tragic Encounter With James Taylor’s Pig
abstract: A battle of blue-ribbon pets in the summer of 1971.
lead_paragraph: The summer of 1971 was drawing to a close, and I had a large and growing problem: Kosher, my pet pig. I was 16, and the pig had been a poorly-thought-through joke gift from my father. When he brought her home to our Manhattan apartment in June, Kosher — the name was also his idea — was a (sort of) cuddly pinkish-white football who fit into a shoe box and drank from a bottle.

headline: Ralph Lauren: Black, White and Red All Over
abstract: Mr. Lauren’s collection was clean and white as well, divided roughly into three sections.
lead_paragraph: New York Fashion Week wraps up today with the three majors: Ralph Lauren, Calvin Klein and Marc Jacobs. Mr. Lauren kicked things off this morning with a collection shown at the St. John’s Center Studios over on Washington Street, where the designer had built an especially spare set this season: a white glass runway with a black backdrop at the end. No fancy chandeliers. No antlers. Just an enormous bouquet of white lilies that scented the entrance.

headline: Putin’s Plea: Sampling the Reviews
abstract: Readers react to an Op-Ed essay by the Russian president.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Hewitts Prepare to Leave
abstract: Mr. Hewitt says goodbye to a neighbor in the settlement.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Hewitt says goodbye to a neighbor in the settlement.

headline: Living With Cancer: A Rainbow Coalition
abstract: Important as advocacy ribbons are, can their use inadvertently set advocates against one another? What would it mean to form a rainbow coalition to support people dealing with every type of cancer?
lead_paragraph: Everyone recognizes the pink ribbon of breast cancer, but fewer know the color of testicular (orchid), uterine (peach), lung (white), pancreatic (purple), or head and neck (burgundy/ivory) cancers. Given current research and treatment, as well as a commitment to equity, is it time to imagine a rainbow coalition?

headline: Bowie Among Nominees for Britain’s Mercury Prize
abstract: David Bowie’s first album in a decade, “The Next Day,” is among the nominees for this prize honoring British or Irish performers.
lead_paragraph: David Bowie has been nominated for Britain’s prestigious Barclaycard Mercury Prize, along with several younger artists who were not even born when he first emerged as a star in the early 1970s.

headline: After Frustration, Winslow Embraces Fresh Start With Jets
abstract: Tight end Kellen Winslow, who spent nine days with the Patriots last year and sat out most of the season, will return to New England on Thursday night.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — When tight end Kellen Winslow sought and received his release from the New England Patriots last September, ending his stint with the team after only nine days, it was as amicable a parting as there can be in the N.F.L.

headline: Live Stream | Calvin Klein’s Spring 2014 Collection at New York Fashion Week
abstract: The latest women’s collection from Calvin Klein at New York fashion week.
lead_paragraph: The latest women’s collection from Calvin Klein at New York fashion week.

headline: Raucous Scene Grips Afghan Capital: Soccer Euphoria
abstract: A stadium once used by the Taliban for public executions was overtaken for a celebration rife with symbolism after the Afghan national team won a South Asian title match.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Olympic Stadium in Kabul has not seen this big a crowd since the Taliban used the place for public executions, with attendance mandatory.

headline: Senator Asks Cellphone Carriers: What Exactly Do You Share With Government?
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'USA PATRIOT Act', 'Wireless Communications']
abstract: Senator Edward J. Markey sent a letter to carriers asking what kind of information law enforcement officials seek from them, including location data and the content of text messages.
lead_paragraph: Last year, Edward J. Markey, then a member of the House of Representatives, asked the country’s major cellphone carriers to disclose how many data requests they received from federal and local law enforcement agencies. More than one million in 2011 alone, they said, revealing for the first time how ubiquitous cellphone records had become in criminal investigations.

headline: Modern Love | Falling in Love at 71
abstract: Nora Johnson, long divorced, wasn't looking for love when she met George, a widowed 83-year-old. It just happened.
lead_paragraph: Nora Johnson, long divorced, wasn't looking for love when she met George, a widowed 83-year-old. It just happened.

headline: In a Breathtaking First, NASA’s Voyager 1 Exits the Solar System
keywords: ['Voyager Project', 'Space and Astronomy', 'Stars and Galaxies', 'Solar System']
abstract: Voyager 1, launched back in 1977, has become the first man-made object to pass into the unknown vastness of interstellar space.
lead_paragraph: PASADENA, Calif. — By today’s standards, the spacecraft’s technology is laughable: it carries an 8-track tape recorder and computers with one-240,000th the memory of a low-end iPhone. When it left Earth 36 years ago, it was designed as a four-year mission to Saturn, and everything after that was gravy.

headline: Age Is No Obstacle to Love, or Adventure
abstract: What astonished us was that the electricity we generated was as strong and compelling as love had been 50 years before, that it scrambled the brain every bit as much.
lead_paragraph: I used to think that elder love, if it even existed, was confined to rocking chairs or golf carts, that it had to be a dull business because of the physical limitations of age.

headline: Simon Anderson, on Creating a Culture of  Shameless Honesty
abstract: Simon Anderson, C.E.O. of DreamHost, a Web host and domain name registrar, says that corporate culture is a full-contact sport, and it can be messy.
lead_paragraph: This interview with Simon Anderson, chief executive of DreamHost, a Web hosting provider and domain name registrar, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Ackermann to Resign From Board of Siemens
abstract: Josef Ackermann, the former chief executive of Deutsche Bank, plans to resign as a deputy chairman of Siemens, a decision that comes shortly after he abruptly resigned as chairman of Zurich Insurance Group last month.
lead_paragraph: Josef Ackermann, the former chief executive of Deutsche Bank, plans to resign as a deputy chairman of Siemens, a decision that comes shortly after he abruptly resigned as chairman of Zurich Insurance Group last month.

headline: Too Much Shakespeare? Be Not Cowed
abstract: A theater critic (and frequent fan) tries to sell a skeptic on this season’s full slate.
lead_paragraph: The feast of Shakespeare on New York stages this season represents a boon for those who cannot get enough of his work. But there are many who will be happy to leave this banquet entirely untasted. Shocking but true: There walk among us a solid bloc of the Shakespeare-averse.

headline: Havens Found Off the Treadmill
abstract: The New York Access PassBook provides 600 passes to more than 165 health and fitness clubs in the five boroughs.
lead_paragraph: AFTER running on the same treadmill at the same gym at the same time every night for almost a year — research showing that a regular routine can bring promising results — I wondered if this was all there could be to my fitness life.

keywords: ['ACCOUNTING AND ACCOUNTANTS', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Ethics (Institutional)', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: A regulatory ruling that British accountants must serve the public interest could put a crimp in a lucrative new business for auditing firms: putting together corporate finance deals.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a novel concept: Accountants have an obligation to always work in the public interest.

lead_paragraph: Secretary of State John Kerry speaks about the situation in Syria from Geneva, Switzerland, where he is meeting with Russian Foreign Minister Sergey V. Lavrov.

headline: Spinning a Ballot Measure on Gambling
abstract: A New York ballot question about whether or not to allow casino gambling includes its own advertisement for adding seven Las Vegas-style casinos in the state
lead_paragraph: Generally speaking, proposals for constitutional amendments on the ballot in New York State are written in carefully dull, straightforward language. The idea is to ask voters if they want to make a more permanent change to the way the state government operates, yes or no. That’s all. The phrasing should not nudge voters in either direction, in favor or against.

headline: After Mayoral Primaries, a Sharp Divide
abstract: Joseph J. Lhota and Bill de Blasio embraced the role of fierce rivals on Thursday, even as thousands of ballots from New York City’s mayoral primary had yet to be counted.
lead_paragraph: Joseph J. Lhota and Bill de Blasio embraced the role of fierce rivals on Thursday, displaying the testy tenor and deep ideological divide of a general election matchup even as thousands of ballots from New York City’s mayoral primary had yet to be counted.

headline: An Interview With John Kerry About Syria
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: In a Google+ Hangout, the Secretary of State John Kerry speaks with the Op-Ed columnist Nicholas D. Kristof, the executive editor of Syria Deeply, Lara Setrakian, and Andrew Beiter, a school teacher.
lead_paragraph: In a Google+ Hangout, the Secretary of State John Kerry speaks with the Op-Ed columnist Nicholas D. Kristof, the executive editor of Syria Deeply, Lara Setrakian, and Andrew Beiter, a school teacher.

headline: Cape Verde Disqualified From World Cup Playoffs
abstract: The team fielded an ineligible player in a match Saturday, the latest error to embarrass African soccer in the 2014 World Cup qualifying cycle.
lead_paragraph: Cape Verde, a tiny group of islands off West Africa bidding to become the smallest nation ever to qualify for the World Cup, was thrown out of the competition Thursday for fielding an ineligible player in a qualifying match last Saturday.

headline: A Family Says ‘Enough’
abstract: The long, unlikely struggle to get a pacemaker disconnected.
lead_paragraph: The story ran more than three years ago in The New York Times Magazine, but fairly often I come across people who remember it.

headline: Jason Bateman on ‘Bad Words’
abstract: The actor discusses his directorial debut, and the pros and cons of directing himself.
lead_paragraph: The actor discusses his directorial debut, and the pros and cons of directing himself.

headline: Teaching Children the ‘Easy’ Lesson of Syria
abstract: That the only thing certain about any of the ways forward is the uncertainty of the result is among the most important lessons our children should carry with them.
lead_paragraph: We should be talking to our children about what is happening and what is being considered in Syria. Because while it may be counterintuitive, there are “easy” lessons in both the Syrian conflict, and the conflict over whether the United States and other nations should or should not intervene. They are not necessarily easy to understand, but they are easy to convey; so easy that they can be captured in cliché: Uncertainty is the only certainty, and only hindsight is 20/20.

headline: Vodafone Says Shareholders Clear Kabel Deutschland Bid
abstract: Vodafone says it has received sufficient investor support to win approval of its 7.7 billion euros ($10.2 billion) takeover of the German cable operator Kabel Deutschland.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Vodafone announced on Thursday that it had received sufficient investor support to win approval of its 7.7 bilion euros ($10.2 billion) takeover of the German cable operator Kabel Deutschland.

headline: From the Best Seller List to Your Classroom Library | Creating Student Book Lists
abstract: In this lesson, students use The New York Times Best Sellers lists as a model to create their own book lists, book summaries and “inside the list” short essays for their school or classroom libraries.
lead_paragraph: Overview | What is The New York Times Best Sellers list and how is it compiled? What do best-seller lists tell us about our culture? How can they be models for student-created reading lists?

headline: Seeking Connections on Independence Day
abstract: “Four,” based on Christopher Shinn’s play, chronicles the assignations of two secretive for-a-night couples.
lead_paragraph: The quietly desperate characters in “Four” are driven by the piercing loneliness that goads people into pursuing risky couplings with strangers in the night. June (Emory Cohen), a closeted, baby-faced teenager, steals out of his parents’ house during a Fourth of July celebration and hooks up with Joe (Wendell Pierce), a stocky, middle-aged African-American college professor he met online. Joe picks up June in his car as the boy waits beside a pay phone at an abandoned strip mall. For the next few hours, they drive around as Joe tries to get to know the evasive, sulky June. Eventually, they stop at a motel.

lead_paragraph: The genre-crossing singer K.D. Lang will make her Broadway debut in February in “After Midnight,” the musical about Harlem’s legendary Cotton Club that opens at the Brooks Atkinson Theater in October.

headline: Where the Past Is Never Left Behind
abstract: The battle re-creations at Fort Ticonderoga have grown more elaborate, but in addition to the re-enactments, there are now canoe tours, walking tours,  concerts and seminars.
lead_paragraph: FIVE Septembers ago, my 8-year-old son returned from a trip to Fort Ticonderoga with my husband, euphoric from a weekend of war re-enactments. My 5-year-old daughter had stayed behind with me in Brooklyn, neither of us interested in watching grown men pretend to shoot one another.

headline: How We Captured a Crowd
abstract: The evolution of our culture issue cover design.
lead_paragraph: Creating the cover for last weekend’s culture issue was a fun challenge; there are countless ways to approach the topic of popularity. We generally present three or four rounds before deciding on a final direction. The first round is typically a brainstorming session. Then as we move forward, the presentations become more focused. Below are some of the designs — and discussions — that emerged from that process.

lead_paragraph: The actor talks about the relationship society has with Shakespeare’s tragedy.

abstract: Flash floods in Colorado have killed at least three people near Boulder and Estes Park, cutting off mountain towns and washing away homes, bridges and parts of highways.
lead_paragraph: Video from KCNC-TV in Colorado of rescue crews saving a motorist near Lafayette.

abstract: Westin, as part of a partnership with a marathon series, is offering guests a running concierge.
lead_paragraph: Westin Resorts & Hotels announced this week that the running coach and marathoner Christopher Heuisler, 34, will be its first running concierge, as part of the brand’s partnership with the Rock ‘n’ Roll Marathon Series.

headline: Attorney General’s Office Voices Concern About Sale of Hudson River School Painting

lead_paragraph: The New York Attorney General’s office has voiced its concern over the possible sale of a large oil painting by Thomas Cole that once hung in the Seward House Historic Museum in Auburn, N.Y.

headline: Insurance Company With An Army Blogging
abstract: About that government spending.
lead_paragraph: A short piece on yours truly in Bloomberg Businessweek online, in which I learn that I’m a gnome. Also, that Jeff Sachs, whose analysis and motives become increasingly mysterious, thinks that I don’t pay enough attention to wasteful government spending. And that calls, I think, for a couple of reminders.

headline: Toronto Video: Jason Bateman on ‘Bad Words’
abstract: Jason Bateman discusses his feature directorial debut, “Bad Words.”
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — In the comedy “Bad Words,” Jason Bateman stars as a man who enters a children’s spelling bee. It’s also Mr. Bateman’s directorial debut. In this video, Mr. Bateman discusses the bitter character he plays, and also talks about the overseeing his first feature.

headline: ‘Italian Futurism’ Is Coming to the Guggenheim
abstract: An exhibition at the Guggenheim Museum will focus on the Italian avant-garde from 1909 to 1944, a period that Sotheby’s will also highlight in a Nov. 6 auction.
lead_paragraph: The future is on its way at the Guggenheim and at Sotheby’s.

headline: The Story of Chagall, as Told by His Granddaughters
abstract: A Marc Chagall retrospective at the Jewish Museum tells the story that Bella Meyer and her twin sister, Meret, heard as children in France.
lead_paragraph: Strolling through a museum, two sisters stopped at a painting, a fantasy scene of faces and rooftops and a huge ox hanging upside down. They remembered it from childhood — it had hung in their parents’ living room, not because their parents were wealthy art patrons with an impressive collection, but because the painting had been made by their grandfather, the artist Marc Chagall.

headline: China’s Plan to Curb Air Pollution Sets Limits on Coal Use and Vehicles
abstract: The plan represents the most concrete response yet to growing criticism for allowing the country’s air, soil and water to degrade to abysmal levels.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The Chinese government announced an ambitious plan on Thursday to curb air pollution across the nation, including setting some limits on burning coal and taking high-polluting vehicles off the roads to ensure a drop in the concentration of particulate matter in cities.

headline: Atomic Gaffes
abstract: Eric Schlosser examines the history of nuclear risk, including many accidents and near-disasters.
lead_paragraph: A little over 50 years ago a South Carolina doctor (and the grandfather of this reviewer) treated a family for injuries sustained when a sudden, inexplicable explosion tore through their backyard. The injuries were not serious, and after spending the night at the doctor’s house they returned home to discover that the object in the 50-foot crater left behind their house was an atomic bomb that had fallen from a passing Air Force plane. The bomb had not been “armed” with its nuclear core; the blast came from the explosives intended to trigger a chain reaction. The crater can still be seen today.

headline: What Becomes of the Lost Estates?
abstract: Their wines are to be savored wistfully or sold at auction for outlandish prices born of increasing scarcity.
lead_paragraph: Recently I attended two extraordinary dinners in New York, one featuring the precise, focused red Burgundies of René Engel and the other the exquisite Côte-Rôties of Marius Gentaz.

abstract: A reader responds to a recent review of Teddy Getty Gaston’s “Alone Together.”
