headline: Adrian Lester on ‘Othello’
abstract: The actor discusses the play’s place in the 21st century.
lead_paragraph: The actor discusses the play’s place in the 21st century.

headline: Something I Said?
abstract: Advice on when to keep mum on your friend’s boyfriend, how to treat a bereaved colleague and the obligations of “rain check.”
lead_paragraph: I’ve put off writing to you because I’m afraid you will yell at me. My best friend had a really lousy boyfriend. He was cheap, took her for granted, and I’m pretty sure he cheated on her. But I kept quiet about him, as I suspect you recommend. (He wasn’t abusive or anything.) Even after they broke up, I vowed to say nothing. But one night, after a couple of glasses of wine, I told her exactly what I thought of him. Surprise! They’re back together again, and now my friend will barely look at me. What can I do? Lisette

headline: Rory Kinnear on ‘Othello’
abstract: The actor talks about the differences in how audiences interpret a character.
lead_paragraph: The actor talks about the differences in how audiences interpret a character.

headline: Riding the Waves of a Memorial
abstract: Bargemusic’s free concert on Wednesday night remembered the Sept. 11 attacks and its founder, Olga Bloom.
lead_paragraph: Olga Bloom, the Bargemusic founder, liked to wake up early and go to the barge not long after daybreak. She would tune her violin or viola and play some music, often her beloved Bach, as she looked through the big windows at the back toward the rushing currents of the East River and the skyscrapers of Lower Manhattan, the view her audience had during concerts.

headline: Works From Earliest Photographers Are on Display and on Sale
abstract: Archives and pictures from some pioneers in the medium have stayed together and are headed to the National Gallery and Sotheby’s.
lead_paragraph: Archives and favorite works from a few of the earliest photographers have stayed together and are headed for public view and sale.

headline: Calvin Klein in Full Color
abstract: The Calvin Klein collection was expansive in range, with a surprising amount of color and texture that still fit neatly within the label’s minimalist box.
lead_paragraph: There were five black models in the 35-look Calvin Klein show this afternoon. Five models is a significant number in a collection that in recent seasons has included only one or no black models, the most prominent example in New York of a general trend of whitewashing the runways.

headline: Richard Stengel to Leave Time for the Obama Administration
abstract: Managing editor at the magazine since 2006, Mr. Stengel will now handle public affairs in the State Department.
lead_paragraph: Richard Stengel, the managing editor of Time magazine, is leaving to become under secretary of state for public diplomacy and public affairs at the State Department, according to people with knowledge of the appointment.

headline: ‘X-Factor’ Hits a New Ratings Low in Its Season Premiere
abstract: The tepid ratings for Simon Cowell’s two-year-old show are yet more evidence that singing competitions are not the blockbusters they once were.
lead_paragraph: The days of the singing competition blockbuster on television may be coming to an end.

headline: Pynchonopolis
abstract: Thomas Pynchon’s latest shaggy-dog novel, set in 9/11-era New York, features a conspiracy typically dazzling and ludicrous.
lead_paragraph: Are you ready for Thomas (Screaming Comes Across the Sky) Pynchon on the subject of Sept. 11, 2001? On the one hand, his poetry of paranoia and his grasp of history’s surrealist passages make a perfect fit. Yet his slippery insouciance, his relentless japery, risk being tonally at odds with the subject. Either way, and despite his sensibility’s entrenchment in ’60s Californian hippiedom, Pynchon is a New Yorker, with an intimate license to depict the sulfurous gray plumes and tragic tableaus of that irreconcilable moment: “On the way home she passes the neighborhood firehouse. They’re in working on one of the trucks. . . . She threads among the daily bunches of flowers on the sidewalk, which will be cleared in a while. The list of firefighters here who were lost on 11 September is kept back someplace more intimate, out of the public face, anybody wants to see it they can ask, but sometimes it shows more respect not to put such things out on a billboard. . . . What makes these guys choose to go in, work 24-hour shifts and then keep working, keep throwing themselves into those shaky ruins, torching through steel, bringing people to safety, recovering parts of others, ending up sick, beat up by nightmares, disrespected, dead?”

headline: U.S. Jumps to No. 13 in FIFA Rankings
abstract: The United States moved up six places in the latest world rankings, released on Thursday by FIFA.
lead_paragraph: It is fitting that the game that counts the most for the United States men’s soccer team — a World Cup qualifier against Mexico — also counts in the latest edition of FIFA’s world rankings, released Thursday.

headline: Singing ‘Soprano’ in Normandy
abstract: Robert De Niro and Michelle Pfeiffer uproot their children and export their mobster ways to Normandy in “Family.”
lead_paragraph: Mobsters can’t help themselves. It’s in their nature to solve problems the family way — with baseball bats, explosives and anything at hand that leaves an opponent dead or writhing in agony. Sadistic violence is a reflexive response to having grown up in households where fathers regularly beat their sons senseless for no reason.

headline: Republicans Say Documents Show Abuse of Power at I.R.S.
keywords: ['Internal Revenue Service Political Profiling', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: House Republicans on Thursday released what they said was further evidence that the Internal Revenue Service acted on political impulses when it targeted conservative groups for special scrutiny.
lead_paragraph: House Republicans on Thursday released what they said was further evidence that the Internal Revenue Service acted on political impulses when it targeted conservative groups for special scrutiny.

headline: In a Cultural and Sexual Netherland, Gaudy and Unsettling
abstract: “The Last Time I Saw Macao,” a Portuguese-language film, explores the themes of contested territory and fragmentation.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after “The Last Time I Saw Macao” opens, a bosomy blonde begins lip-syncing to Jane Russell crooning “You Kill Me.” This lip-syncer isn’t just any ordinary chanteuse, but Candy (Cindy Scrash), a transsexual with a square jaw and breasts that look ready for liftoff. Howard Hughes — who fretted about how Russell’s bust should be deployed in “Macao,” an amusing 1952 Hollywood noir made by his studio — might have approved. Candy, dressed in a cheongsam with a peekaboo front, performs the song in a pool of light against a tall fence, a couple of lions frolicking on the other side. Like Russell, Candy may be from planet Earth, but she’s also from another world.

headline: Loveless Marriage on a Lovely Island
abstract: “And While We Were Here,” a drama set in Ischia, Italy, follows a couple and a stranger who enters their lives.
lead_paragraph: While watching Kat Coiro’s dour marital drama, “And While We Were Here,” I realized with a mixture of sadness and relief that adultery and erotic discontent, at least in the movies, are not what they used to be. They’ve lost any frisson of the exotic and forbidden.

headline: A Modern Warrior (and a Meat Sack)
abstract: Nate Jackson, a former professional football player, tells of his six years in the N.F.L. in “Slow Getting Up.”
lead_paragraph: We’re in the middle of a boomlet of superb, satire-minded writing about professional football. That screaming you hear coming across the sky? It’s a wobbly spiral.

headline: Federal Judge Approves American Airlines’ Plan to Exit Bankruptcy
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Bankruptcies', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: Judge Sean H. Lane approved the carrier’s plan nearly two years after its bankruptcy filing, contingent on Justice Department approval of its merger with US Airways.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge approved American Airlines’ bankruptcy plan on Thursday but ruled that the decision was contingent on Justice Department approval of the carrier’s merger with US Airways.

headline: Doomed Blond Bombshell Not Really Included
abstract: “Jayne Mansfield’s Car” is a family drama that, despite its name, isn’t about the actress who died young in a car accident in the late 1960s.
lead_paragraph: The misleading title of “Jayne Mansfield’s Car” suggests that this meandering family drama, set in Morrison, Ala., in 1969, relates to the blond, buxom Hollywood star who died in 1967 in a traffic accident in Louisiana. But the only thing this loquacious multigenerational family history has to do with Mansfield is a brief scene of her wrecked vehicle on display as a traveling sideshow.

headline: Horrors With Lighthearted Bookends
abstract: “Chagall: Love, War, Exile” focuses on the artist’s works immediately before, during and after World War II, when he fled France for the United States.
lead_paragraph: At the risk of sounding like a crank: Love is the problem with “Chagall: Love, War, and Exile” at the Jewish Museum.

headline: A Strange Bond Between Killers
abstract: “Blue Caprice” recalls the terror of the Beltway sniper case but focuses on the father-son relationship of the murderers.
lead_paragraph: “I’ve created a monster,” John says to Lee, with a satisfied smile. John is proud of his protégé, and proud of himself for being such an effective mentor. He is also speaking the literal truth.

headline: An All-Too-Human Federal Reserve
abstract: In the documentary “Money for Nothing,” Federal Reserve officials are shown as having great influence, if not great insights.
lead_paragraph: If “Money for Nothing: Inside the Federal Reserve” seeks to demystify that organization, it doesn’t really succeed. But the documentary, by Jim Bruce, does leave you with the impression that however the Fed does what it does, it is often just guessing or willfully acting against the best long-term interests of the economy.

headline: Trying to Be a Parent, for Better or for Worse
abstract: “Mother of George,” Andrew Dosunmu’s new drama, is not only an assimilation story, but also a keenly observed tale of two people seeking guidance in painful and complicated circumstances.
lead_paragraph: There is something irresistible about a movie that begins with a wedding (think of “The Godfather”), and there are few movie weddings as beautiful as the one at the start of “Mother of George,” Andrew Dosunmu’s gorgeous and delicate new drama. The party, a swirl of color, music and sentiment, observed with an eye for telling details of behavior, sets the tone — exuberant, dignified, a little bit anxious — for what is to follow.

headline: A Couple Flees a House of Death but Can’t Escape the Ghosts
abstract: “Insidious: Chapter 2” delves into a couple’s history and why they’re terrorized by ghosts.
lead_paragraph: A mess from start to finish — though, judging by the ending, this story won’t be over any time soon — “Insidious: Chapter 2” is the kind of lazy, halfhearted product that gives scary movies a bad name. From its robotic acting to its generic props (enough already with the self-motivated children’s toys), this shoddy sequel, tacked together with the cynicism of a carnival barker, suggests that the director, James Wan, is long overdue for a vacation.

headline: Pakistani’s Iron Grip, Wielded in Opulent Exile, Begins to Slip
abstract: A British murder investigation has been closing in on Altaf Hussain, who has run his brutal Karachi political empire by remote control, shrouded in luxurious exile in London.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — For two decades, Altaf Hussain has run his brutal Pakistani political empire by remote control, shrouded in luxurious exile in London and long beyond the reach of the law.

headline: From Welded Worshipers, a Joyful Pneumatic Noise
abstract: Chico MacMurtrie has fashioned his robot sculptures into an orchestra that will perform what he calls a “mass” in his “Robotic Church” installation.
lead_paragraph: CHICO MacMURTRIE, a Brooklyn-based artist, has been building robots for nearly three decades. His creations do not vacuum the house, teach foreign languages to children or try to take over the world; they were designed to play music, mainly syncopated rhythms, and perhaps evoke some thought about humanity.

headline: When Appraisals Come in Low
abstract: The subprime mortgage crisis resulted in a much more rigid appraisal process, leaving some prospective borrowers out in the cold.
lead_paragraph: One consequence of the subprime mortgage crisis is a far more rigid home appraisal process. Borrowers can complain about lower than expected appraisals — which may mean they can’t borrow enough to meet an agreed-upon sale price, or can’t refinance — but lenders very rarely reconsider.

headline: Microscope on the U.S. Food Supply
abstract: “GMO OMG,” a documentary from the director Jeremy Seifert, tries to inform viewers about food in America.
lead_paragraph: “GMO OMG,” Jeremy Seifert’s plain-folks primer on genetically modified food, is pitched somewhere between the high school student and the helicopter parent. Its central concern — that Americans are inadequately informed about the corporate manipulation of the food supply — may be valid, but its reliance on cute-kiddie silliness does little to fill that void. Even children as photogenic as Mr. Seifert’s are no substitute for rigorous research.

headline: A Little Ditty That Became an Anthem of Hip-Hop
abstract: “Sample This,” from Dan Forrer, revisits the birth of hip-hop through “Apache,” by the Incredible Bongo Band.
lead_paragraph: Opens on Friday.

headline: Family Reunion With a Party Under the Clouds
abstract: In “Naked as We Came,” from the director Richard LeMay, a mother makes amends (and smokes marijuana).
lead_paragraph: It has been a long time since a marijuana high has been romanticized like this in the movies. Right in the middle of Richard LeMay’s “Naked as We Came,” a terminally ill woman, her daughter, her son and her handsome young housemate (with whom the son has just spent the night) share a joint on a glorious green lawn — and the universe’s whitest clouds float by, casting a spell, in the bluest sky of all time.

headline: Silly Girl, You Want to Race a Boy?
abstract: Haifaa al-Mansour’s “Wadjda” is the story of a spirited 10-year-old Saudi girl discovering the severe limitations placed on women in the name of custom, Islam and family honor.
lead_paragraph: You can tell that Wadjda is a rebel by looking at her feet. The other students at her all-girls madrassa in Saudi Arabia accessorize their long, shapeless gray dresses with black Mary Janes and frilly socks, but Wadjda, a lanky 10-year-old with big eyes and an easy smile, favors black Converse high-tops, a small gesture of spirited individuality in a world that seems organized to suppress any such expression.

headline: The March on Washington, in Harlem
abstract: The Schomburg Center presents free programs on landmark events in the civil rights movement; Snug Harbor celebrates the fall to come.
lead_paragraph: By the end of 1963, Medgar Evers had been murdered, four young black girls had perished in the bombing of an Alabama church, and Nina Simone had had enough. The next year, she put her career on the line by releasing “Mississippi Goddam,” her defiant response to these deaths and an anthem for the civil rights struggle.

headline: To Table, From a Farm of Their Own
abstract: The owners’ dairy supplies Arethusa al Tavolo with cheese, butter and ice cream.
lead_paragraph: Farm to table has a ring of authenticity at Arethusa al Tavolo in Bantam, which is owned by George Malkemus and Anthony Yurgaitis, the proprietors of Arethusa Farm in Litchfield; they are also president and vice president of Manolo Blahnik in North and South America. Al Tavolo, which opened in June, is adjacent to the dairy farm’s retail shop, the two businesses occupying brick buildings separated by a narrow courtyard.

headline: F.D.A. Panel Backs Pre-Surgery Drug for Breast Cancer
abstract: Perjeta, a Genentech drug already approved for late-stage breast cancer, could be used in patients before surgery to remove tumors if the F.D.A. approves it.
lead_paragraph: A federal advisory committee cleared the way on Thursday for the first approval of a cancer drug that would be used to treat patients before surgery to remove their tumors.

headline: 20% Turnout in New York Primaries
abstract: A total of 700,000 voters took part in city elections this week, according to incomplete returns.
lead_paragraph: Bill de Blasio took first place in the Democratic mayoral primary on Tuesday with the votes from only about 3 percent of all New Yorkers. If that percentage seems small, consider that the number and share of votes received by Joseph J. Lhota, the Republican nominee, was only about one-tenth that amount.

headline: Friars Club Proposed for Landmark Status
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Real Estate (Commercial)']
abstract: 57 East 55th Street began life as a mansion and is now the Friars Club. It has been proposed for landmark status.
lead_paragraph: To most owners, landmark designation is no joke. Repairs must be at a high level, time is spent in review, major changes are barred — that’s nothing to laugh at.  Now it looks as if the 1909 town house of the Friars Club, at 57 East 55th Street, may come before the Landmarks Preservation Commission. Will the Friars be happy if their monastery is protected, or would the commissioners get the next roast?

headline: A Short Post, a Big Splash: #TwitterIPO
abstract: The company, which has more than 200 million active users, announced that it had filed paperwork with regulators to eventually sell shares in an initial public offering.
lead_paragraph: Twitter, which began as a side project in a small but failing start-up seven years ago and grew into one of the world’s largest platforms for public conversation, is about to take its biggest step yet into maturity: selling stock to the public.

headline: Calvin Klein: Spring 2014 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Sharing the Bounty of Priceless Art
abstract: “Herb & Dorothy 50x50” visits some of the museums given artworks from the Vogel collection.
lead_paragraph: Films about caped avengers, Hobbits and young wizards are often packaged as franchises. Sequels are less expected, though, for documentaries about working-class patrons of Minimal and Conceptual art. But “Herb & Dorothy 50x50” is just that: Megumi Sasaki’s follow-up to her 2009 film about Herbert and Dorothy Vogel — him a postal clerk, her a school librarian in New York City — who accumulated an enormous and trailblazing art collection.

headline: The Brilliance of His Universe
abstract: “Hawking” chronicles the life and impact of the cosmologist Stephen Hawking.
lead_paragraph: Opens on Friday in Manhattan.

headline: Brahms Rising: Echoes of a First Impression
abstract: Ian Hobson began a 14-part survey of the complete chamber works for and with piano by Brahms on Tuesday at the DiMenna Center.
lead_paragraph: Brahms was 20 when he first played for Robert and Clara Schumann at their home in Düsseldorf on Oct. 1, 1853. In her diary entry that night, Clara gushed about the handsome young musician whom God appeared to have placed, fully formed, on earth. Equally gushing but more important for Brahms’s career was the article Robert published in his journal of music criticism, in which he imagined “heroes and graces” standing watch over the infant Brahms’s cradle.

headline: The Activist Who Worked for the F.B.I.
abstract: “Informant,” a profile of an activist who turned government informer, raises questions about identity and perspectives.
lead_paragraph: Opens on Friday.

headline: Absolutely, Paul; Right Away, Ringo
abstract: “Good Ol’ Freda” chats with Freda Kelly, the onetime secretary for the Beatles, but she’s not dishing much.
lead_paragraph: Sweet but far from juicy, “Good Ol’ Freda” offers a gobsmackingly tame profile of Freda Kelly, the Beatles’ longtime secretary and fan club manager. Now an amiable, still-typing grandmother in her late 60s, Ms. Kelly sits on a nondescript sofa and delivers nostalgic observations on a time when her life was a great deal more exciting.

headline: Disney Infinity Game Has Strong Early Sales
abstract: Disney sold 294,000 starter kit units of the game  in August, normally a slow sales month for video games.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES – — Disney’s new Infinity video game is a hit out of the gate, but it is too early to say whether the release will deliver the kind of blockbuster holiday sales that the company’s struggling interactive division needs for a turnaround.

headline: Boldly Deciding to Stay Sunny, Sweet and Upbeat
abstract: Sutton Foster’s cabaret show at Café Carlyle is marked by her song selection and resolute optimism.
lead_paragraph: Utter simplicity: a fresh breeze blowing through a meadow as a barefoot country girl skips through the grass under a blue sky dotted with a few puffy clouds. That describes the aura around the irresistible Sutton Foster on Tuesday evening at Café Carlyle, where she opened her new cabaret show.

headline: A Brass-Filled Tribute Does Not Hold Back
abstract: A tribute to Henry Brant and Butch Morris was part of the Festival of New Trumpet Music.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to imagine that a work consisting of 52 trumpets could be a “chamber” version of anything, but Henry Brant’s imagination was large scale. He originally wrote “Flight Over a Global Map” for 100 trumpets, one of several works — including “Orbits” for 80 trombones, soprano and organ — that he composed for vast brass or wind forces.

headline: Zoi Gaitanidou: ‘Risk Aversion’
abstract: The New York debut of Ms. Gaitanidou, a Berlin-based Greek artist, has a definite bounce.
lead_paragraph: Scaramouche Gallery

headline: Mary Mattingly: ‘House and Universe’
abstract: After exhibiting eco-science-fiction photographs early in her career, Ms. Mattingly started experimenting with real-life situations.
lead_paragraph: Robert Mann

headline: Images Propelled Beyond Pictures
abstract: Work by eight artists who share a certain iconoclastic attitude about photographic images make up this show of 62 recent works at MoMA.
lead_paragraph: Among the works by eight artists in “New Photography 2013” at the Museum of Modern Art is a series of prints by Josephine Pryde showing guinea pigs bustling about in what appears to be studio detritus. Viewers who know that Ms. Pryde uses photography to explore ideas about social issues will surely assume that these are not just affectionate pictures of her cute little pets. A wall label explains that the guinea pig, native to South America, was so named when it was brought to Europe on slave ships known as “Guineamen.”

headline: Charline von Heyl
abstract: Ms. von Heyl is one of the more intriguing, and least predictable, abstract painters working right now; there are few repetitions to be found in her current show.
lead_paragraph: Petzel Gallery

headline: Leslie Hewitt
abstract: Artists like Leslie Hewitt are making art that evokes latter-day Pictures Generation work, but also addresses the omissions of their predecessors.
lead_paragraph: Sikkema Jenkins & Company

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Glass App Dazzles, and a Hacker Target Speaks Out
abstract: Thursday’s highlights from around the Web include a dazzling video for a forthcoming Google Glass app that shows how the device could augment a live sporting event. Plus, the victim of a well-known hacker and Web provocateur recalls her experience being targeted online.
lead_paragraph: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: ‘Interwoven Globe’
keywords: ['Art', 'Textiles', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: Images from the Met’s sweeping new exhibition about the textile trade.
lead_paragraph: Images from the Met’s sweeping new exhibition about the textile trade.

headline: Threads of Many Cultures, Embroidering a World
abstract: “Interwoven Globe: The Worldwide Textile Trade, 1500-1800,” opening on Monday at the Met, surveys a cross-cultural pollination of styles, materials and techniques.
lead_paragraph: Mind your footwear. Few New York art seasons are fully under way until the Metropolitan Museum of Art rolls out a fall exhibition with enough visual thrills and historical insights to knock your socks off. Yet this year’s offering may be even more outstanding than usual.  “Interwoven Globe: The Worldwide Textile Trade, 1500-1800,” opening on Monday, is a staggering overview of more than three centuries of art, commerce, craft and cross-cultural fertilization.

headline: Overdoses of ‘Molly’ Led to Electric Zoo Deaths
abstract: The New York City Medical Examiner confirmed that two young people who died at the Electric Zoo festival over Labor Day weekend took fatal doses of drugs sold on the street that are known as “molly.”
lead_paragraph: The New York City Medical Examiner has confirmed that two young people who died at the Electric Zoo festival on Randalls Island over Labor Day weekend took fatal doses of drugs sold on the street that are known as “molly.”

headline: Finally, One Madison Is Back
abstract: A vacant skyscraper on Madison Square Park is ready for buyers.
lead_paragraph: It’s been a long, strange ride for the pencil-thin building that towers over the south side of Madison Square Park.

headline: Bolshoi Artistic Director to Return to Moscow Months After Acid Attack
abstract: Sergei Filin, the artistic director of the Bolshoi Ballet who was nearly blinded in January in an acid attack, will return to Moscow this weekend.
lead_paragraph: Sergei Filin, the artistic director of the Bolshoi Ballet who was nearly blinded in January in an acid attack that was sparked by professional jealousies, will return to Moscow this weekend after spending eight months receiving medical treatment in Germany, Reuters reported on Thursday.

headline: Comedy Listings for Sept. 13-19
abstract: A selected guide to stand-up, improv and comedy shows in New York.
lead_paragraph: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Four in Audience Are Shot at a Club in SoHo
abstract: A witness said the gunfire had been aimed at the crowd as an opening act was performing at S.O.B.’s.
lead_paragraph: Four men were wounded early Thursday when a gunman opened fire during a performance at a crowded music club in Manhattan.

headline: Readers Debate Colorado Recall Vote
abstract: New York Times readers posted more than 1,600 comments on the recall of two Colorado Democrats who supported new restrictions on firearms.
lead_paragraph: After the recall of two Colorado Democrats who supported new restrictions on firearms, New York Times readers posted more than 1,600 comments, which encompassed spirited debates between those celebrating the recalls and others dismayed by the backlash against what many called “common-sense” gun regulations. The ousted Democrats, Angela Giron of Pueblo and John Morse of Colorado Springs, will be replaced by Republican state senators.

headline: Theater Listings for Sept. 13-19
abstract: A guide to theater productions in New York, with a special note of shows in previews or about to open.
lead_paragraph: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: 36 Hours in Buenos Aires
abstract: Dine in a private supper club, tour a renowned opera house and soak up some nature by the Río de la Plata during a weekend in Argentina’s capital.
lead_paragraph: Sure you can have a tango-filled, steak-fueled weekend in Buenos Aires. But Argentina’s capital and largest city also has a much more contemporary side that has been emerging from its traditional roots and European influences for years now. Blame it on a creative class of Porteños, as the locals are known, who have turned the Latin metropolis into a vibrant, cosmopolitan community. And it’s a movement that keeps evolving. From hidden supper clubs to bankrolled art galleries to buzzing boutiques, the sprawling city is a study of sophistication on the rise. But that doesn’t mean you should bypass the old timey cafes and parrillas. Partly what makes the city so irresistibly alive right now is its checkered past peeking through its new personality.

headline: A Steakhouse Amid a World of Tastes
abstract: Downtown Mount Kisco’s variety of foods now includes prime dry-aged beef.
lead_paragraph: In the last few years, Mount Kisco has enjoyed a rush of restaurants drawn to its buzzing downtown. Joining the long-appreciated Thai Angel’s and the Spanish restaurant La Camelia, newcomers have been filling other ethnic niches. There’s Neo with its creative New World spins on Asian fare; Bonnie Saran’s Indian and French places, Little Kebab Station and Little Crepe Street; the Ethiopian spot Lalibela; the trattoria and cafe Via Vanti!; and Taverna Pandesia, a Greek restaurant — to mention just a few. It was only a matter of time until a steakhouse threw its hat into the ring.

headline: From Culture to Cuisine in Buenos Aires
abstract: Take a tour of Argentina’s capital city.
lead_paragraph: Take a tour of Argentina’s capital city.

headline: Movie Listings for Sept. 13-19
abstract: A critical guide to movies playing in New York, including film series.
lead_paragraph: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

headline: Pop & Rock Listings for Sept. 13-19
abstract: A selected guide to performances of indie rock, R&B, country, folk-metal and psychedelic rock in the New York area.
lead_paragraph: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Bahrain and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Bahrain, Syria, Kashmir and the Philippines.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Bahrain, Syria, Kashmir and the Philippines.

headline: Jazz Listings for Sept. 13-19
abstract: A selected guide to jazz performances in New York.
lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Classical Music and Opera Listings for Sept. 13-19
abstract: A selected guide to classical music performances in the New York area.
lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Dance Listings for Sept. 13-19
abstract: A selected guide to dance performances in the New York area.
lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings for Sept. 13-19
abstract: A critical guide to the visual arts in New York and the region.
lead_paragraph: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Cruz Tries to Claim the Middle Ground on Immigration
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Citizenship and Naturalization', 'Tea Party Movement', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Hispanic-Americans']
abstract: Senator Ted Cruz has made it clear that he opposes giving citizenship to law-breakers. But he also supports legal status for millions of people here already.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to immigration reform, Senator Ted Cruz has made it abundantly clear what he opposes: giving citizenship to people who broke the law to come here.

headline: Stargazing: The Final Day
abstract: As New York Fashion Week entered its final day, with Ralph Lauren, Calvin Klein and Marc Jacobs, front row regulars were already planning their next steps.
lead_paragraph: As New York Fashion Week entered its final day, with Ralph Lauren, Calvin Klein and Marc Jacobs closing out the calendar, front row regulars were already planning their next steps. “I have Yom Kippur starting tomorrow night and then I’m off to London,” said Ariel Foxman, editor of InStyle, on Thursday morning while waiting for the Ralph Lauren show to begin.

headline: Jim Nutt, Jennifer Wynne Reeves, Donald Roller Wilson: ‘Will There Be Any Stars in My Crown?’
abstract: This enchanting little show organized by the collector Todd Levin presents three works each by three artists in a chapel-like installation.
lead_paragraph: Storefront Bushwick

headline: Spare Times for Children for Sept. 13-19
abstract: A listing of cultural events for children, teenagers and families.
lead_paragraph: 92Y Street Festival

headline: Daily Reminder of Texas State Budget Cuts
abstract: The latest transportation idea in the state shows the trouble of meeting the demands of growth when voters believe government already costs too much.
lead_paragraph: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

headline: Boardwalk Fire Erases Months of Rebuilding at Jersey Shore
abstract: Flames that began in an ice cream shop quickly engulfed businesses along a stretch of boardwalk rebuilt after Hurricane Sandy left the area devastated.
lead_paragraph: Nearly a year after Hurricane Sandy devastated the Jersey Shore, a boardwalk that was just rebuilt was ravaged by fire on Thursday, as a blaze that began at an iconic ice cream shop quickly engulfed businesses along a stretch of beach in two towns.

headline: This Week’s Movies: Sept. 13, 2013
abstract: The New York Times film critics on “Blue Caprice,” “Mother of George” and “The Family.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics on “Blue Caprice,” “Mother of George” and “The Family.”

headline: Spare Times for Sept. 13-19
abstract: A listing of walking tours, speaking engagements, cultural events, parades, street fairs and more in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Celebrate Mexico Now

headline: What I Love | Derek McLane
abstract: The Tony Award-winning set designer decorated his West Village apartment from scratch.
lead_paragraph: The Tony Award-winning set designer decorated his West Village apartment from scratch.

headline: A Scenic Designer’s West Village Home
abstract: The décor of Derek McLane’s West Village apartment calls to mind his sets for Broadway plays.
lead_paragraph: There is nothing remotely funny about Derek McLane’s West Village apartment. Still, the first time Mr. McLane’s three children walked into his elegant living room, they burst out laughing.

headline: Election Math Works in Favor of de Blasio
abstract: Bill de Blasio, who finished first in the Democratic mayoral primary, would need to capture about one-third of the votes left to be counted to avoid a runoff against William C. Thompson Jr.
lead_paragraph: It is not rocket science. The odds favor Bill de Blasio.

headline: Saving Summer in a Jar
abstract: More and more classes, workshops and lectures on canning and preserving fruits and vegetables are available to gardeners on Long Island.
lead_paragraph: Debra Kawaller, 58, of Northport went to a canning workshop because of a predicament familiar to many gardeners: She had a peach tree full of fruit that was ready to be harvested.

headline: With Doubled Fees, Tennis Court Permit Sales Plunge
keywords: ['Tennis', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: After doubling the seasonal fee, to $200, the city’s Department of Parks and Recreation saw a drop even more significant than expected.
lead_paragraph: Watching the dazzling United States Open play of Rafael Nadal at Arthur Ashe Stadium on Monday, the majestic Manhattan skyline in the background, could inspire even the most casual tennis player to grab a racket and head out to the park.

headline: Italy’s Far Right Salutes Putin for Anti-Gay Law and Support for Assad
abstract: “I’m With Putin” posters have appeared around the Italian capital in the past week, saluting the Russian president for his opposition to homosexuality, the Syrian rebels and the European Union.
lead_paragraph: As the Reuters Rome correspondent Naomi O’Leary reported, “I’m With Putin” posters have appeared around the Italian capital in the past week, saluting the Russian president for his opposition to homosexuality, the Syrian rebels and the European Union.

headline: It’s Not Just the Heat
abstract: Brick Lane Curry House serves British-style Indian cuisine, which is spicier than is customary in most Indian restaurants in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Feel free to ignore, as I did, the sign on the sidewalk in front of Brick Lane Curry House in Upper Montclair: “3 Steps to the Phaal Hall of Fame — Order it. Finish it. Win a Free Mango Lassi.” It is a stunt, a culinary dare to brave what is described on the menu as “an excruciatingly hot curry, more pain than flavor.”

headline: Reaction on Twitter to Twitter’s I.P.O. Plans
abstract: The microblogging service posted a development of its upcoming initial public offering on its platform, leading to a flurry of reactions from its users.
lead_paragraph: Twitter said Thursday that it had filed the preliminary paperwork for its long-awaited initial public offering of stock. It made the announcement on Twitter, naturally:

headline: GTT ★
keywords: ['Art', 'Rap and Hip-Hop', 'Horses', 'Conventions, Fairs and Trade Shows', 'Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'Music']
abstract: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.
lead_paragraph: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

headline: Carolina Thaler Transforms Backstage at Ralph Lauren
abstract: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Spring 2014 Fashion Week in New York.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Spring 2014 Fashion Week in New York. Here, the model Carolina Thaler before (left) and after (right) makeup by Tom Pecheux and hair by Guido Palau.

headline: Verizon Backing Off Plans for Wireless Home Phones
abstract: Amid complaints from residents of Fire Island, the company said it would start laying fiber optic cable to restore service in areas ravaged by Hurricane Sandy.
lead_paragraph: After facing numerous complaints from residents of Fire Island, Verizon has backed away from its plan to use a wireless device to replace traditional phone service in areas where it would rather not repair its old copper wires.

headline: After 32 Years, a Protester (Briefly) Loses Her Spot Near the White House
abstract: The United States Park Police temporarily removed the tent and signs Concepcion Picciotto, 77, had long used across the street from the White House to protest war and nuclear proliferation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Concepcion Picciotto held a vigil for 32 years across the street from the White House, protesting war and nuclear proliferation. Her small encampment never left the edge of Lafayette Square, her tent surrounded by signs with slogans like “Read My Lips, No New Wars.”

headline: Frankfurt Motor Show: Nismo Introduces Smart Watch to Monitor Vehicle and Driver
abstract: Although it is still a concept, Nissan’s motorsports-inspired wristwatch measures driver parameters and vehicle performance characteristics.
lead_paragraph: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=v4Wjpe0ZOxY

headline: Reader Reactions to Putin’s Op-Ed
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Biological and Chemical Warfare']
abstract: In response to an Op-Ed by Russian President Vladimir V. Putin, published by The New York Times on Wednesday, Sept. 11, readers responded to multiple aspects of his argument: that a former head of the KGB seemed to snatch the mantle of peace while supporting Bashar al-Assad’s beleaguered Syrian government; that President Obama may have been outmaneuvered on the global stage; and at what they saw as Mr. Putin’s gall for championing dialogue on this issue while suppressing dissent in his own country.
lead_paragraph: In response to an Op-Ed by Russian President Vladimir V. Putin, published by The New York Times on Wednesday, Sept. 11, readers responded to multiple aspects of his argument: that a former head of the KGB seemed to snatch the mantle of peace while supporting Bashar al-Assad’s beleaguered Syrian government; that President Obama may have been outmaneuvered on the global stage; and at what they saw as Mr. Putin’s gall for championing dialogue on this issue while suppressing dissent in his own country.

headline: Events in Connecticut
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut.

lead_paragraph: ALLIANCE, Ohio — Football practices at the University of Mount Union are technically closed to the public, but often, former coaches and players, and even their parents, will stop by. Family is always welcome.

keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: Negotiators for the United States are urging European officials not to think of the trans-Atlantic trade talks as a panacea for their region’s ills.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — American trade officials said in interviews this week that trans-Atlantic trade talks should not be seen as a panacea for Europe’s economic ills, and they continue to resist the idea of including financial service regulations in the discussions.

headline: Tax Filings Hint at Extent of Koch Brothers’ Reach
abstract: Tax returns show that a nonprofit group linked to Charles G. and David H. Koch, billionaire industrialists who support Republican causes, has given away a staggering amount of money in recent years.
lead_paragraph: A single nonprofit group with ties to Charles G. and David H. Koch provided grants of $236 million to conservative organizations before the 2012 election, according to tax returns the group is expected to file Monday, underscoring the broad reach of the political movement the two business executives and their advisers have built in recent years.

headline: Fred Katz, Who Married Cello to Jazz, Dies at 94
abstract: Mr. Katz was a classically trained cellist who quite by accident helped elevate his instrument to unlikely stardom in jazz.
lead_paragraph: Fred Katz, a classically trained cellist who quite by accident helped elevate his instrument to unlikely stardom in jazz, died on Saturday in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 94.

headline: In Libya, Unrest Brings Oil Industry to Standstill
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots']

lead_paragraph: Two years after local militias overthrew the Libyan dictator Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, many of those same fighters have brought Libya’s critical oil industry to a halt, as a challenge to the latest in a series of that country’s interim governments.

headline: Women’s Groups Rally for Immigration Reform
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Women and Girls', 'Capitol Building (Washington, DC)']
abstract: More than 100 women were arrested on Capitol Hill after they blocked an intersection to press the House of Representatives to move on immigration legislation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — More than 100 women were arrested on Capitol Hill on Thursday after they blocked a busy intersection to press the House of Representatives to move on immigration legislation in a protest that rallied national women’s groups to the cause.

headline: Defection Hurts Polish Premier Amid Protests
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Organized Labor', 'Legislatures and Parliaments', 'Labor and Jobs', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots']
abstract: A country that enjoyed growth through Europe’s debt crisis is now feeling the pain of a slowing economy.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — While thousands of Polish labor union members marched through Warsaw on Thursday, a member of the governing party defected, pushing the center-right government of Prime Minister Donald Tusk to the brink of losing its parliamentary majority amid intensifying popular discontent.

headline: A ‘GameDay’ Extravaganza, Minus the Game
abstract: The popular ESPN program “College GameDay” has set up camp in College Station, Tex., but the showdown between No. 1 Alabama and No. 6 Texas A&M is not on the network’s television schedule.
lead_paragraph: The ESPN traveling circus known as “College GameDay” set up camp this week in College Station, Tex., where top-ranked Alabama will play No. 6 Texas A&M on Saturday. ESPN’s trucks, stages, video walls and sponsor tents, as well as the Home Depot Bus, have taken up nearly one-third of the drill field where the Aggies’ corps of cadets holds formal reviews. And starting with reports Thursday afternoon and running through its three-hour show Saturday morning, “GameDay” and other ESPN shows will spend hours analyzing the matchup.

abstract: The number, the government said, was skewed by upgrades on two state computer systems that caused those states to underreport claims.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Initial jobless claims fell to their lowest level last week since the spring of 2006, the Labor Department said on Thursday. Or not.

headline: Surge in Independent Spending Is Reshaping City’s Elections
abstract: The Supreme Court’s decision in Citizens United, which lifted most restrictions on independent expenditures in political campaigns, has helped spur the increase, a city spokesman said.
lead_paragraph: Call it an offer, a threat, a promise: in late winter, an aide to the speaker of the City Council was asked to meet on the street with a political consultant for a group that wanted a bill passed.

headline: Colorado Towns Are Left Stranded in Deadly Floods
abstract: The flooding killed at least three people and cut off major highways, isolated towns and forced the closing of the main campus of the University of Colorado.
lead_paragraph: BOULDER, Colo. — Walls of water cascading down hillsides caused flash floods across Colorado on Thursday, killing at least three people. The flooding cut off major highways, isolated mountain towns and closed the main campus of the University of Colorado, the authorities said.

headline: Orioles Zip Around but Need On-Field Surge
abstract: Many of the Orioles ride bikes to the ballpark and some even use motorized contraptions, but this season has been a bumpier experience for the team in comparison to the joy ride of 2012.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — The wheels whirring beneath outfielder Steve Pearce’s feet propelled him along the concave underbelly of Oriole Park at Camden Yards. As if on cue, a stadium attendant opened the clubhouse door, and Pearce rode into the inner sanctum aboard his motorized skateboard.

headline: A Brilliant Mess
abstract: The world’s oldest constitutional democracy, in all its inconsistent, incoherent cacophony, is there for the world to watch in the standoff with Syria.
lead_paragraph: After a staggering display of mush, muddle and miscues by the world’s lone superpower, a rogue nation appears ready to give up the chemical weapons it supposedly never had. Without a shot’s being fired. This, of course, is a miserable failure in the eyes of the gaseous class, amateur hour in real time, because, well — it wasn’t planned.

headline: How We Learned Not to Guzzle
abstract: Over the past 40 years, we have found so many innovative ways to save energy that we more than doubled the economic productivity of our oil, natural gas and electricity.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — FOR as long as most of us can remember, the nation’s energy news has trended from bad to worse, starting with the oil crises of the 1970s. But today, the good news is that our energy productivity and security are better than they have been in decades.

headline: With Chase Starting, a Dispute Lingers About Unwritten Rules
abstract: The first race of the Chase for the Sprint Cup championship is Sunday, but a report suggesting one driver allowed another to pass him has stoked anger over last week’s race.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — The Chase for the Sprint Cup championship begins Sunday at Chicagoland Speedway, with the first of 10 races that will cap Nascar’s season and determine its champion. The lead-up to the race, though, has been marred by cheating allegations and questions about the integrity of the 12-driver field.

headline: Godfrey Sperling, Who Made Eggs for Press, Dies at 97
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Deaths (Obituaries)']
abstract: Mr. Sperling, a journalist with The Christian Science Monitor, organized breakfast meetings that became a Washington institution, bringing newsmakers together with news reporters.
lead_paragraph: “We’re on the record.”

headline: Rich Man’s Recovery
abstract: While the great majority of Americans are still living in a depressed economy, the rich at the very top are doing just fine.
lead_paragraph: A few days ago, The Times published a report on a society that is being undermined by extreme inequality. This society claims to reward the best and brightest regardless of family background. In practice, however, the children of the wealthy benefit from opportunities and connections unavailable to children of the middle and working classes. And it was clear from the article that the gap between the society’s meritocratic ideology and its increasingly oligarchic reality is having a deeply demoralizing effect.

headline: For Turkey’s Leader, Syria’s War Worsens His Problems at Home
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Biological and Chemical Warfare']
abstract: The American decision to delay a military strike on Syria left Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan, a strong advocate for military intervention in the conflict, more politically vulnerable at home.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Sitting in his son’s wedding gown shop in a conservative neighborhood here, Sabah Bakirci heaped praise on Turkey’s prime minister, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, with swagger matched only, perhaps, by Mr. Erdogan’s own.

headline: The Marijuana Muddle
abstract: States that have legalized the drug need practical guidelines for staying within federal rules.
lead_paragraph: On marijuana policy, there’s a rift between the federal government and the states. It started with California’s allowing marijuana for medical use in 1996, widened as several other states followed suit, and became too big to ignore 10 months ago, when voters in Colorado and Washington decided to legalize the drug for recreational use. Under federal law possession is still a crime.

headline: Who Will Be Left in Egypt?
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Editorials', 'Foreign Aid']
abstract: After crushing the Muslim Brotherhood, the generals in Cairo who are running the government are now going after liberals and journalists.
lead_paragraph: Two years after thousands of Egyptian protesters risked their lives to bring down the dictator Hosni Mubarak, the military-controlled government in Cairo is expanding a repressive system that may ultimately be worse than the one Mr. Mubarak built and managed.

headline: NBC Announces a Face-Lift, and One New Face, for ‘Today’
abstract: NBC outlined changes for its morning program, “Today,” which has lost about a quarter of its audience and is stuck in second place behind “Good Morning America.”
lead_paragraph: Tired of waking up in second place, the “Today” show is hoping that a new studio, a new logo, a new mission statement and a new cast member will help it regain the ratings ground it lost last year when Ann Curry was unceremoniously dismissed from the NBC morning show.

headline: Kindergarten Applications Going Digital
abstract:
Next year, New York City parents will be able to submit one
electronic form for multiple schools.
lead_paragraph: They line up in the predawn chill, clutching original birth certificates and passports, utility bills and lease agreements, all for the chance to enter their children into one of New York City’s most agonizing lotteries: the kindergarten application process.

headline: Trounced in Primary, Quinn Returns to Council, Seeking the Old Normal
abstract: Seeming weary of requests to explain her third-place finish in the Democratic mayoral primary, Christine C. Quinn turned back to the business of legislating.
lead_paragraph: Her colleagues hugged and kissed her, greeting her with “Hey!” and “I called you!” She responded brightly, congratulated one councilwoman on her re-election, and then prefaced her prepared remarks by telling reporters that two members of the City Council were absent because they had just had “beautiful, healthy babies.”

headline: In California, Stronger Workers’ Rights
abstract: Gov. Jerry Brown should sign a bill that requires paid overtime for many domestic workers.
lead_paragraph: The California Senate on Wednesday passed a bill to extend basic rights to an overlooked segment of the labor force: domestic workers, mostly immigrant women, who toil in private homes without the protection of most labor laws. The bill, a scaled-back version of a measure that passed the State Assembly, is expected to land on Gov. Jerry Brown’s desk within a week. He should sign it, allowing California to join New York and Hawaii as the states that have gone furthest to bring fairness to an industry notorious for low wages, long hours and grueling conditions.

headline: Mismanagement and Death in a Coal Mine
abstract: It is heartening that a former executive with Massey Energy was sentenced to three-and-a-half years in prison.
lead_paragraph: For the sake of coal miners’ lives and livelihood, it is heartening that the federal investigation into the West Virginia disaster that killed 29 men in 2010 continues forward. It gained momentum this week when a former executive with Massey Energy, which ran the Upper Big Branch mine at the time of the deadly explosion, was sentenced to three-and-a-half years in prison.

headline: An Initial Filing, in Fewer Than 140 Characters

lead_paragraph: Did you read about Twitter’s initial public offering filing?

lead_paragraph: LAKE FOREST, Ill. — As he exited the scoring area at Conway Farms Golf Club, Jason Kokrak came upon a group of autograph seekers. He had no illusions about whose signature they coveted.

lead_paragraph: On the campus of the University of Alabama, accusations that traditionally white sorority chapters had turned down an apparently impeccable candidate simply because she was black hardly came as a surprise.

headline: Making Administration’s Case, Kerry Finds Six Words That Spell Trouble
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Critics on the left and the right have seized on Secretary of State John Kerry’s use of “boots on the ground” and “unbelievably small.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the last three weeks, Secretary of State John Kerry has uttered tens of thousands of words about Syria — in Congressional hearings, on Sunday news programs, from the State Department and the British Foreign Office, and now in a Geneva hotel, where he and the Russians are hashing out a plan that could avert a military strike.

headline: Cup Turning Into Rout as Kiwis Win Twice More
abstract: Emirates New Zealand, winners of six of the first seven races, needs three more victories in the best-of-17 series to wrest the trophy from Oracle Team USA.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The persistent zigzag tacks into the wind have hypnotically turned Oracle Team USA’s high-speed catamaran into little more than a tourist junket during the America’s Cup, its sailors and supporters left searching for the flotsam of the defending champion’s diminished hope and dignity.

headline: An Early Start on Promoting a Mini-Series Spoof Set for January
abstract: Ads will begin to run on Friday for “The Spoils of Babylon,” a six-part series about a wealthy oil family that will parody mini-series of the 1970s and ’80s.
lead_paragraph: AS viewers are inundated with promotions for the new fall television series, which start appearing next week, the IFC cable channel is beginning to beat the drum for a show that does not make its debut until January.

headline: Islanders Glimpse Future Home, Then Get to Work
abstract: After 41 years — and still with two seasons remaining — at Nassau Coliseum, the Islanders took the ice at their next home, Barclays Center.
lead_paragraph: Like many thousands of daily commuters Thursday morning, the Islanders arrived at their destination via the Long Island Rail Road. But for them, the journey from Long Island to Brooklyn represented more than the 40-minute ride from Garden City station to Atlantic Terminal.

headline: 2 Consultants to Banking Industry Come Under Scrutiny
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Consultants', 'Money Laundering', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Promontory Financial Group and PricewaterhouseCoopers, two firms that received subpoenas in recent months, are among the Wall Street consulting industry’s biggest names.
lead_paragraph: They are known as Wall Street’s shadow regulators. And after years of guiding banks through problems like money laundering and foreclosure abuses, their influence has soared.

headline: Drinking, Smoking and Misbehaving in Small-Town Texas
abstract: In Horton Foote’s “Old Friends,” a clutch of “Mad Men”-era swingers find their lives becoming unmoored when a local beauty returns home after a long absence.
lead_paragraph: A gentle bossa nova, the kind Petula Clark extolled in the 1964 hit “Downtown,” bubbles through the opening moments of “The Old Friends,” stirring a ripple of disorientation in the audience. For this drama, which opened on Friday night at the Pershing Square Signature Center in a lively potboiler of a production, is a Horton Foote play.

headline: One Boxed Himself In, One Boxed His Way Out
abstract: Black stars from two very different generations, Muhammad Ali and Stepin Fetchit, meet for advice and conflict in “Fetch Clay, Make Man.”
lead_paragraph: Plenty of verbal punches are thrown in “Fetch Clay, Make Man,” a drama by Will Power that opened on Thursday at New York Theater Workshop in an eye-poppingly sleek production directed by Des McAnuff. This intriguing play, about the meeting between two men who achieved renown during different eras in the thorny history of race in America — Muhammad Ali and the actor Stepin Fetchit — has more rounds of combat than an epic prize fight. Yet the dramatic adrenaline necessary to create a powerful play does not entirely materialize. Mr. Power tosses interesting ideas and contrasting characters into the ring, but doesn’t quite succeed in shaping a compelling narrative.

headline: It’s Not Fair
abstract: A brain-bending Friday by Patrick Berry.

headline: Experts’ Report to U.N. on Syrian Mass Killing Is Expected Within a Few Days
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Although the report’s authors are only to say whether such weapons were used, not who used them, their evidence appears likely to implicate the Syrian government.
lead_paragraph: The secretary general of the United Nations could receive a widely awaited report on Monday, or possibly earlier, on last month’s mass killing in Syria that is believed to have involved chemical weapons, diplomats said Thursday. Some said they expected the findings would point unambiguously to Syrian government culpability.

headline: Clear Channel-Warner Music Deal Rewrites the Rules on Royalties
abstract: Clear Channel will pay royalties for the first time to performers and a record label when songs are played on its radio stations. In return for the record label, Warner Music, will discount the high cost to stream music online.
lead_paragraph: For decades, Clear Channel Communications and other big radio companies have fought fiercely to avoid paying record companies for songs they played on the air. But with the business going digital, Clear Channel is now eager to make a trade.

headline: Listing Demands, Assad Uses Crisis to His Advantage
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'United States International Relations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: In exchange for giving up control of his chemical arsenal, President Bashar al-Assad of Syria said he would require the United States to stop arming the opposition, using President Obama’s own “red line” against him.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Not long ago, President Bashar al-Assad of Syria seemed a remote and embattled figure, with the United States threatening airstrikes and other Arab leaders denouncing him for having used chemical weapons against his own people.

headline: Senate Committee Approves Protections for Journalists
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Law and Legislation', 'News Sources, Confidential Status of']
abstract: The Senate Judiciary Committee on Thursday approved legislation to provide greater protections against fines or imprisonment for reporters who refuse to identify confidential sources.
lead_paragraph: The Senate Judiciary Committee on Thursday approved legislation to provide greater protections against fines or imprisonment for reporters who refuse to identify confidential sources. The bill, the Free Flow of Information Act of 2013, passed 13 to 5 after lawmakers agreed on an amendment defining who qualifies as a journalist. Three Republicans, including the panel’s ranking member, Charles E. Grassley of Iowa, joined Democrats to pass the bill. The panel rejected amendments from Republicans that would have stripped protections for reporters who reveal classified information, limited the bill’s protections to American members of the news media and exempted grand jury leaks. Opponents said it did not protect national security interests and unconstitutionally allowed the government to decide who is a journalist. But supporters said it was important to establish parameters for the news media as the Justice Department grapples with leak cases.

headline: Massachusetts: Former F.B.I. Official Is Charged in Ethics Case
abstract: Kenneth W. Kaiser, 57, was charged with violating a law that prohibits senior government personnel from professionally contacting their old agencies for a year after they leave.
lead_paragraph: A retired F.B.I. official was charged Thursday with violating an ethics law that prohibits senior government personnel from professionally contacting their old agencies for a year after they leave them. The former official, Kenneth W. Kaiser, 57, led the agency’s Boston office from 2003 to 2006; he then served as the assistant director for the F.B.I.’s criminal investigative office until his retirement in 2009. Shortly after that, according to an information filed in Federal District Court in Boston, Mr. Kaiser contacted individuals at the F.B.I. regarding an investigation into his employer, LocatePlus, a Massachusetts technology company. The information also says that he tried to sell them his new company’s services. If convicted, Mr. Kaiser would face up to a year in prison and a maximum fine of $100,000.

headline: Opposition Leader Asserts Broad Problems in Moscow Race
abstract: Aleksei A. Navalny gave a court evidence of irregularities in Sunday’s mayoral contest in Moscow, but had little hope of changing the results.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The Russian opposition leader, Aleksei A. Navalny, on Thursday submitted to a court more than 50,000 pages of documents illustrating what he said were irregularities in Sunday’s voting in the Moscow mayor’s race in an attempt to prove that he won enough votes to force a runoff against the incumbent, Sergei S. Sobyanin.
