headline: Marc Jacobs: Separate States
abstract: The clothes looked wintery, there were dark, bulky sweatshirts with shorts; more jackets tossed with braid and taffeta.
lead_paragraph: Even if Marc Jacobs were not the most successful American designer working on two continents, he would be described in terms of a separate country. People talk about New York Fashion Week — and Mr. Jacobs. They say, “Let’s see what Marc does on Thursday night.”

headline: Honduras Grants Land to Indigenous Group, in Bid to Help It Protect Forests
abstract: A title agreement gives the indigenous people ownership of nearly 4,000 square miles of their traditional land.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — The Honduran government has granted almost 7 percent of its territory to the indigenous Miskito communities who live on the land, an initiative intended to help them protect their forests.

headline: F.B.I. Plans to Close Offices for 10 Days to Cut Costs
abstract: On furlough days, the Federal Bureau of Investigation will have only a skeleton crew on hand, which raises questions about how effectively the agency can respond to crime.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After months of agonizing about how to deal with the effects of government spending cuts, senior F.B.I. officials in Washington have decided how they will reduce the bureau’s spending: they will shut down its headquarters and offices across the country for roughly 10 weekdays over the next year.

headline: Fed Prepares for Change in Policy, and in Policy Makers
abstract: The Federal Reserve is trying to reassure investors about its effort to stimulate the economy as it prepares a shake-up of its policy-making committee.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Federal Reserve officials, who have made clear that they intend to cut back on the Fed’s monthly asset purchases by the end of the year, must decide next week whether it is time to tap the brakes or better to wait another month or two.

headline: A Group in Flux
abstract: Next year, the Federal Open Market Committee is expected to undergo an unusually large change in membership, making it harder to predict how the Fed will act in the future.
lead_paragraph: Next year, the Federal Open Market Committee is expected to undergo an unusually large change in membership, making it harder to predict how the Fed will act in the future.

headline: Nova, Saying His Elbow ‘Feels Good,’ Is Expected Make His Start Sunday
abstract: Ivan Nova, who was removed from his start Tuesday after reporting tightness in his right elbow, threw a bullpen session Thursday afternoon.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — Ivan Nova did not sound very convincing Thursday when he said it, but he claimed that his elbow felt fine and that he would be able to pitch in his next scheduled start Sunday against the Boston Red Sox.

headline: Ray Dolby, Who Put Moviegoers in the Middle of It, Is Dead at 80
abstract: Dr. Dolby, who founded Dolby Laboratories, transformed cinema and home entertainment with the development of Dolby digital surround sound.
lead_paragraph: Ray Dolby, the sound pioneer who revolutionized the recording industry with the invention of the Dolby noise-reduction system and transformed cinema and home entertainment with Dolby digital surround sound, died on Thursday at his home in San Francisco. He was 80.

headline: Tina Brown to Write Memoir
abstract: The acclaimed editor, who said Wednesday she was leaving journalism to start her own conference company, will write about her career in magazines.
lead_paragraph: Tina Brown, the veteran editor who announced on Wednesday that she is departing The Daily Beast and magazine journalism, has struck a deal to write a memoir, she said in an interview on Thursday.

headline: The Restoration of a French Country Estate, 20 Years in the Making
abstract: The furniture designer and artisan André Dubreuil has filled his family’s 18th-century estate in France’s Dordogne region with an eclectic array of carefully chosen objects, including his own metal sculptures.
lead_paragraph: With his characteristic wit and humble charm, the artist André Dubreuil has devoted decades to breathing life back into his family’s grand 18th-century chateau.

headline: The Artist With the Race Car in His Studio
abstract: Matthew Day Jackson’s unapologetically masculine, profoundly American work often grapples with speed, power and technology. So it’s hardly surprising that when he’s not at work in Brooklyn, he can often be found at the track.
lead_paragraph: Rigorously considered, unapologetically masculine and over-the-top ambitious, Matthew Day Jackson’s art breaks all boundaries: collaborator and employee, home and work, life and death.

headline: A Tiny Nation With a Big Appetite
abstract: Singapore has a reputation for stodgy sterility, but its adventurous food culture, driven by a wave of chef-driven restaurants, is gaining international prominence.
lead_paragraph: In food-rich Singapore, where even the cabbies are obsessive gourmands, a new wave of chef-driven restaurants are changing the face of dining.

headline: Word of the Day | embryonic
abstract: This word has appeared in 62 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: embryonic •\ˌem-bre-ˈä-nik\• adjective

headline: Waste vs. Value in American Health Care
keywords: ['Doctors', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicine and Health', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: Just what value is derived from the exceedingly high administrative costs of American health care is far from clear, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton. He has some financial interests in the health care field.

headline: Blaze Is Treated Like a Wildfire in the Forest
abstract: With the wind whipping along the shore, firefighters decided to make a firebreak by gouging a hole in the wooden Boardwalk.
lead_paragraph: The flames were racing up the Boardwalk, leaping from the flat, tarred roof of one small business to the neighboring one faster than the growing platoon of firefighters could douse them.

headline: Yankees Survive Late Rally and Stay Within Striking Distance of Rays
abstract: As the Yankees were battling their way to a 6-5 victory, they could see that the Tampa Bay Rays had won, meaning the Yankees would to wait at least one more day to catch them, if they ever do.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — The multicolored out-of-town scoreboard that sits atop the right-field wall at Camden Yards is a constant reminder, beaming scores of relevant games directly into the Yankees’ dugout.

headline: Jets Have Opportunity but Fall to Patriots
abstract: Though New England’s defense swarmed and the offense sputtered, the Jets’ hopes of capturing the division lead faded with each of Geno Smith’s three interceptions in the fourth quarter.
lead_paragraph: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. — Through the rain and through the wind, the Jets could see first place in the A.F.C. East. They saw their defense swarm. They saw New England’s offense sputter. They saw an end zone that, if breached, would catapult the Jets to a place that defied logic and good sense and anyone’s expectations but their own.

headline: As Patriots Are Tested, Brady Shows His Frustration
abstract: Tom Brady and his young receiving corps struggled against the Jets, but the Patriots still found a way to win.
lead_paragraph: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. — He threw a touchdown pass for the 50th straight game. He passed his former teammate Drew Bledsoe for seventh place on the list for career completions. His team beat the Jets, again.

headline: The American League’s Traffic Jam
abstract: With two and a half weeks to go in the season, only two teams seem to have playoff spots nailed down, leaving seven teams in the league’s wild-card fray.
lead_paragraph: With two and a half weeks to go in the season, only two teams — Boston and Detroit — would seem to have playoff spots nailed down. Detroit has a comfortable lead in the American League Central, while Boston’s margin in the A.L. East is borderline luxurious. Meanwhile, five other teams — Tampa Bay, the Yankees, Baltimore, Cleveland and Kansas City — are in the battle for the league’s two wild-card spots. And two more teams, Texas and Oakland, are in that scrum, too, although one of them will ultimately emerge as the A.L. West winner and be able to step away from the wild-card fray.

headline: What’s On Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (CMT) CMT CROSSROADS: STEVIE NICKS AND LADY ANTEBELLUM Ms. Nicks, the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame inductee, and Lady Antebellum, the Grammy- and Academy of Country Music Award-winning trio, collaborate for the first time in a concert recorded last spring in Los Angeles. The playlist features Ms. Nicks’s “Edge of 17,” “Landslide,” “Rhiannon” and “Stop Draggin’ My Heart Around” and Lady Antebellum’s “Need You Now,” “Love Don’t Live Here” and “Golden.” (Above, Hillary Scott of Lady Antebellum, left, and Ms. Nicks.)

headline: News Quiz | September 13, 2013
abstract: See what you know about the news of the day.
lead_paragraph: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: 37 Reported Dead After Fire in a Russian Hospital
abstract: Fires in state-run institutions, which are often poorly maintained, have been a persistent problem in Russia.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — A fire early on Friday in a psychiatric hospital in northwestern Russia killed 37 people, including a nurse who was trying to save patients, local investigators said.

headline: Ex-White House Aide to Be Economic Adviser
abstract: President Obama has chosen Jeffrey D. Zients, who twice was the president’s acting budget director, to succeed Gene B. Sperling as chief White House economic adviser.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama has chosen Jeffrey D. Zients, an entrepreneur who twice was the president’s acting budget director and a past candidate for two cabinet positions, to succeed Gene B. Sperling as the chief White House economic adviser.

headline: South Korean Fisherman’s Escape From North Is Confirmed
abstract: Chun Wook-pyo escaped from North Korea last month, more than four decades after his abduction at sea.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A South Korean fisherman who was kidnapped and taken to North Korea four decades ago has fled his captors and returned home, government officials confirmed Friday.

headline: Firefight at U.S. Consulate in Western Afghanistan
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'United States International Relations', 'Terrorism', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Bombs and Explosives']
abstract: The once relatively peaceful city of Herat is now embroiled in the violence that has bedeviled Afghanistan, a situation underscored by a deadly attack on the American Consulate.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — An attack in the western city of Herat that killed seven people and wounded 20 on Friday morning underscored the continued fragility of the security situation in the country, even in pockets of Afghanistan long considered peaceful.

headline: Test Yourself | Editing Practice, Sept. 13, 2013
abstract: Can you identify the correct number of commas needed to complete a sentence from the article?
lead_paragraph: Take the Quiz

headline: Attack U.S., Qaeda Chief Tells Muslims in a Speech
abstract: Ayman al-Zawahri was quoted as saying that Muslims should “bleed America economically” and carry out “a few disparate attacks” on American soil.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In an audio speech a day after the 12th anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks on the United States, Ayman al-Zawahri, the leader of Al Qaeda, called on Muslims to carry out a “a few disparate attacks” on American soil and to “bleed America economically,” according to a translation on the American SITE monitoring service on Friday.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | NASA’s Voyager I Leaves the Solar System
abstract: Why does the article refer to Voyager I as the “Little Spacecraft That Could?”
lead_paragraph: In the article “In a Breathtaking First, NASA Craft Exits the Solar System,” Brooks Barnes writes about Voyager I’s unique accomplishment among man-made objects.

headline: Reimagining a Tragedy, 50 Years Later
keywords: ['Baptist Churches', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Bombs and Explosives', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Photography', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Dawoud Bey explores the relationship of past to present with diptychs of people the same age as the victims of the 1963 Birmingham church bombing — both at the time of the bombings and in the present day.
lead_paragraph: As a youngster living in Queens, the photographer Dawoud Bey was traumatized by a picture he encountered in a civil rights photography book. In the stark black-and-white image, a 12-year-old African-American girl, Sarah Jean Collins, lies severely wounded in a hospital bed, her eyes covered by bandages. Blinded in one eye, Ms. Collins was one of the survivors of the deadly bombing by white supremacists of the 16th Street Baptist Church in Birmingham, Ala., on Sept. 15, 1963.

headline: Should Tablet Computers Become the Primary Way Students Learn in Class?
abstract: What would be the benefits of students using tablet computers to do all their classwork and homework? What might be the downsides?
lead_paragraph: From Secretary of Education Arne Duncan to corporate stakeholders like Rupert Murdoch, powerful voices are clamoring to get tablet computers into the hands of students in every classroom. Tablet technology — with its capability to connect students, individualize instruction and engage youth — is seen as the next big thing in education. So long textbooks, hello iPads.

headline: Many Doubt Death Sentences Will Stem India Sexual Attacks
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Capital Punishment', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Four men convicted of brutally raping and murdering a 23-year-old woman were sentenced to die by hanging, a sentence that drew cheers from some but skepticism from others.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — There was no mistaking the whoop of joy that rose outside Saket District Court on Friday, when word got out that four men convicted in last December’s horrific gang rape and murder had been sentenced to death by hanging. People burst into applause. They hugged whoever was beside them. They pumped the air with their fists.

headline: Syria Talks Yield Plan to Discuss Peace Conference
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Friday’s talks followed Secretary of State John Kerry’s insistence that Syria quickly disclose data about its chemical arsenal and that Russia show its seriousness about securing the weapons.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Secretary of State John Kerry planned to meet Friday evening with his Russian counterpart, as the two sides sought to forge an agreement on how to disarm Syria’s chemical weapons program.

headline: 4 Sentenced to Death in Rape Case That Riveted India
abstract: A Delhi court on Friday announced death sentence for four men convicted of raping and murdering a 23-year-old woman last year.
lead_paragraph: Four men convicted of a brutal gang rape were sentenced Friday to die by hanging, “a decision met with grim satisfaction from the victim’s parents and triumphant cheers” from the crowd outside the courthouse in Delhi, where some held up pictures of bodies in nooses, Ellen Barry wrote in The New York Times.

headline: U.N. Reports Syria Uses Hospital Attacks as a ‘Weapon of War’
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Hospitals', 'Doctors', 'Civilian Casualties', 'Torture', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: A new report says government forces are targeting medical personnel, denying treatment to patients from rebel-held areas and using hospitals as torture centers.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Syrian government forces are systematically attacking hospitals and medical staff members and denying treatment to the sick and wounded from areas controlled or affiliated with the opposition, United Nations investigators said Friday in a new report that also detailed the use of hospitals as torture centers by military intelligence agencies.

headline: New York Today: Checking It Twice
abstract: What you need to know for Friday and the weekend: tallying the mayoral vote, beautiful weather ahead and a pub crawl with authors.
lead_paragraph: Updated 3:05 p.m. | For William C. Thompson Jr., it’s all over but the counting.

headline: Daily Report: Twitter Announces Intention to Sell Shares
abstract: Twitter, which began as a side project in a small but failing start-up seven years ago and grew into one of the world’s largest platforms for public conversation, plans a public stock offering.
lead_paragraph: Twitter, which began as a side project in a small but failing start-up seven years ago and grew into one of the world’s largest platforms for public conversation, is about to take its biggest step yet into maturity: selling stock to the public, Vindu Goel, Nick Bilton and David Gelles report.

headline: New York Fashion Week: Calvin Klein Spring/Summer 2014
abstract: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Barbara Anastacio.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Barbara Anastacio.

headline: It’s O.K. to Sell Your Business to the Highest Bidder
abstract: You want to believe that the buyers will treat your employees, customers and vendors with the same respect you did. But they probably won’t.
lead_paragraph: I recently helped a restaurant owner sell his business. He priced it at an attractive level and had several interested buyers, one of whom seemed especially eager to take good care of the restaurant’s employees and continue to provide the same level of food and service.

headline: New York Fashion Week: Marc Jacobs Spring/Summer 2014
abstract: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.

headline: Twitter’s I.P.O. Plans
abstract: Twitter is about to take a big step into maturity by selling stock to the public. | Investors, for now, are not able to take a look at Twitter’s financials. | Regulatory scrutiny of consultants to the banking industry is intensifying. | The Securities and Exchange Commission is asking the nation’s stock exchanges to introduce “kill switches” and other technological updates.
lead_paragraph: #TWITTERIPO  |  Twitter, the microblogging service that has grown into one of the world’s largest platforms for public conversation, is about to take a big step into maturity by selling stock to the public. The company announced on Thursday — in a tweet, naturally — that it had filed paperwork with regulators to eventually sell shares in an initial public offering, Vindu Goel, Nick Bilton and David Gelles report in DealBook.

headline: India’s Electoral Politics Reignites Religious Hatreds
abstract: A comparison of economic and sectarian strife in India during the early 1990s and the country today.
lead_paragraph: Sectarian violence between Hindus and Muslims has killed more than 38 and displaced over 10,000 people in the past week in Muzaffarnagar district of the northern state of Uttar Pradesh. The state government led by Chief Minister Akhilesh Yadav of Samajwadi Party failed to respond swiftly to the violence and restore order. Indian army had to be deployed to control the violence and impose a curfew.

headline: Syria, Through a Screen
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: As thousands of Syrians flee the war every day, many have become indefinitely separated from their families and from a country that is increasingly becoming divided and unstable.
lead_paragraph: As thousands of Syrians flee the war every day, many have become indefinitely separated from their families and from a country that is increasingly becoming divided and unstable.

abstract: Metropolitan Diary: An Australian heard a New York woman’s claim that she had done something foolhardy, and he wondered if they are all like that.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: A Russian Take on Syria
abstract: Putin takes center stage.
lead_paragraph: Putin takes center stage.

headline: Margin of Terror
abstract: The British government is doing little to help Muslims — particularly recent converts among blacks — resist the draw of extremism.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — On most mornings, Brixton — a traditionally Afro-Caribbean neighborhood in south London — echoes with the cries of Christian evangelists, the clapping of sidewalk gospel choirs and hymns blaring from stereos at CD stalls. A newcomer to the area may not guess that this is one of London’s most vibrant Muslim communities: Its Muslim population has quadrupled since the early 1990s, according to several members of the congregation.

headline: Death By Tweet
abstract: And why I don’t.
lead_paragraph: I don’t tweet. But, you may ask, what about that Twitter account? That’s a robot — it’s just tweeting the titles of blog posts. And I do blog a lot:

headline: Drinking Milk in Pregnancy May Lead to Taller Children
abstract: A new study suggests that the amount of milk a woman drinks during pregnancy may affect the adult height of her offspring.
lead_paragraph: A new study suggests that the amount of milk a woman drinks during pregnancy may affect the adult height of her offspring.

headline: A Three-Year Pledge That Holds Still
keywords: ['Baby Boomers', 'Homosexuality', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Whatever the issue, Jack Connelly and Bob Gaither have found their relationship strengthened by talking it out.
lead_paragraph: Booming’s “Making It Last” column profiles baby boomer couples who have been together 25 years or more. Send us your story and photos through our submission form.

headline: German Candidates Compete in Battle of Magazine Covers
abstract: Some Germans raised eyebrows when the Social Democrat challenger to Chancellor Angela Merkel was shown gesturing with his middle finger while Ms. Merkel was depicted as Europe’s leader.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Nine days before Germany’s widely watched national election, the two main candidates made contrasting waves with magazine covers on Friday.

headline: Hip-Hop, Tolerance and a D.J.’s Bared Soul: He’s Tired of Denial
abstract: Mister Cee discussed some of the particulars of his indiscretions with a frankness that has virtually been unheard of in the genre.
lead_paragraph: It was early Thursday morning and Mister Cee, a D.J. on the hip-hop station Hot 97 and a prominent figure in New York hip-hop history, was in tears. The day before, an audio clip was released in which he appeared to solicit a sexual act from a transgender person, the latest in a string of incidents, including arrests, revolving around Mister Cee’s sexual activities. During his Wednesday afternoon show he had announced his resignation, saying he didn’t want to draw negative attention to his employer and colleagues because of his actions.

headline: Bloomberg Decides Not to Endorse a Successor
abstract: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, dissatisfied with his potential replacements and unsure his political blessing would be beneficial, ended weeks of speculation with his surprising announcement.
lead_paragraph: Michael R. Bloomberg, dissatisfied with his potential successors and unsure his political blessing would help anyone, on Friday ruled out making an endorsement in the general election for New York City mayor.

headline: September Subjects: Hispanic Heritage, Constitution Day, Banned Books Week and More
abstract: Some resources for celebrating events this month, along with a fill-in activity about historical events that took place in the month of September.
lead_paragraph: Just like last school year, on most Fridays in this space we’ll be publishing a lesson written by two New Jersey humanities teachers, Sarah Gross and Jonathan Olsen. Because they need a few weeks to meet their new students and settle in, however, that feature won’t resume until later this month.

headline: Water, Now Fire, and Shore Nightmare Goes On
abstract: The day after a beachfront blaze destroyed dozens of businesses on the Jersey Shore, owners struggled to summon what it would take to start over so soon after starting over.
lead_paragraph: Nick Dionisio is a third generation Boardwalk guy. Having peeled shrimp as a 7-year-old in his grandfather’s clam bar, he decided to go into banking, but when the markets collapsed came back to what he knew, pulling his father out of retirement to help him start a fried-fish place, and then another a little more upscale.

headline: Tobin and the Taper (Wonkish)
abstract: A few incomprehensible diagrams for your reading pleasure.
lead_paragraph: An interesting article by Matthew Klein in Bizweek about why Mike Woodford is in favor of a Fed taper, even as he calls for much more aggressive forward guidance to the effect that short-term rates will stay low for a long time. What’s that about?

headline: On Twitter’s Big Day, Tweeting About Twitter
abstract: Perhaps not unexpected, legions of Twitter users took to Twitter, dashing off hundreds of tweets, full of jokes and serious analysis about the company’s planned initial public offering.
lead_paragraph: Twitter couldn’t have promoted its services any better.

headline: Ophelie Guillermand Transforms Backstage at Marc Jacobs
abstract: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Spring 2014 Fashion Week in New York.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Spring 2014 Fashion Week in New York. Here, the model Ophelie Guillermand before (left) and after (right) makeup by Francois Nars and hair by Guido Palau.

headline: Resurrecting Triumph’s Glory Out on the Salt
abstract: The Triumph-powered Castrol Rocket was built to bring glory back to the name of a motorcycle company with notable successes at the Bonneville Salt Flats.
lead_paragraph: BONNEVILLE, Utah – There can be only one “fastest motorcycle in the world.” The Castrol Rocket, with a pair of outrageously powerful Triumph Rocket III engines fitted to a motorcycle cloaked in streamlined Kevlar-carbon bodywork, might just be able to grab that title.

headline: Adding the Right Amount of RAM
abstract: How to upgrade the memory on a MacBook pro laptop and other OS X computers, and resizing the tiles on the Windows 8 start screen.
lead_paragraph: Q. I want to add more memory to my MacBook Pro laptop before I upgrade from OS X 10.8 to OS X 10.9. How can I tell if it’s possible to add more without opening up the computer?

headline: Colorado Floodwaters Force Thousands to Flee
abstract: Many residents marveled at how swiftly the rains had swamped their homes and carved up the mountainsides, transforming picturesque towns and vacation communities into scenes of devastation.
lead_paragraph: LONGMONT, Colo. — “Get up!” Abe Mares was jolted awake. It was 2:30 a.m., a swollen river was pouring into his home in the mountains of Colorado’s Front Range, and his roommate was scrambling.

headline: When Nurses Bond With Their Patients
abstract: As nurses we are taught that we are professionals and must maintain a certain emotional distance. But sometimes the line between a professional and personal relationship with a patient can become blurred.
lead_paragraph: As nurses we are taught that we are professionals and we must maintain a certain emotional distance with our patients. It’s a boundary that encompasses the therapeutic relationship: nurses as caregivers, patients as the recipients of the care. But now, working as a nurse, I have found that while most of my professional boundaries are well defined, sometimes the line between a professional and personal relationship with a patient can become blurred.

headline: Off the Charts: Confidence Returns In Europe
abstract: European investors’ confidence has risen into positive territory, according to the Sentix euro zone investor confidence index.
lead_paragraph: European investors’ confidence has risen into positive territory, according to the Sentix euro zone investor confidence index.

headline: How to Get a Job With a Philosophy Degree
keywords: ['Careers and Professions', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Humanities']
abstract: No, liberal-arts majors aren’t necessarily doomed to lives of poverty. But why not add a minor in entrepreneurship just in case?
lead_paragraph: On a Friday in late August, parents of freshmen starting at Wake Forest University, a small, prestigious liberal-arts school in Winston-Salem, N.C., attended orientation sessions that coached them on how to separate, discouraged them from contacting their children’s professors and assured them about student safety. Finally, as their portion of orientation drew to a close, the parents joined their students in learning the school song and then were instructed to form a huge ring around the collective freshman class, in a show of support.

headline: Who Made That Built-In Eraser?
abstract: And why it didn’t make him rich.
lead_paragraph: In 1858, a stationer named Hymen Lipman patented a newfangled pencil with a rubber plug embedded in one end of its wood shaft. An entrepreneur named Joseph Reckendorfer guessed that the pencil-plus-eraser would become a blockbuster product and bought the patent from Lipman for $100,000, about $2 million in today’s dollars. Had that patent held up, Reckendorfer might have become a titan of industry. By the 1920s, almost all of the pencils sold in America included erasers.

headline: Caveat Donor
abstract: Cross-campaign finance; government-sanctioned charity.
lead_paragraph: Is it ethical for a candidate who has solicited funds to run for one political office to use those same funds if he decides to drop out of that race and run for a different office? AARON KENEDI, NEW YORK

headline: The Real-Life ‘Glee’ in Levittown, Pa.
abstract: How one high-school theater teacher transformed generations of students.
lead_paragraph: Harry S. Truman High School, set on a slight incline, is a monument to utility, neither inviting nor forbidding. Buffered on three sides by athletic fields, the school, in Levittown, Pa., rises to just one story. Its exterior is brick — not red but a dull yellow, the color of putty. Inside the front entrance, several trophy cases filled with pictures and other mementos commemorate mostly unsuccessful athletic teams, and a big bulletin board lists the colleges where the current seniors have been admitted. An energetic janitorial staff buffs the floors each afternoon to a high gloss. The classroom clocks tell the right time.

headline: The 9.1.13 Issue
abstract: Readers respond.

headline: Earl Sweatshirt: ‘Canadians Are Weirdos’
abstract: The member of Odd Future on senioritis, his parents and how Toronto is “like a city full of grandmas.”
lead_paragraph: The rap collective you’re a member of, Odd Future, became famous very rapidly after you were sent by your mother to a school for troubled youth in Samoa. Did missing out on that success further your resolve to sort through the behavior issues that got you there? Hell, no. Not initially, and not the way that Odd Future was coming out — it was like a temper tantrum. It was perfect. But throwing a temper tantrum in a residential treatment facility is so much less cool than throwing a temper tantrum on TV.

headline: Mario Batali’s Recipe for Red Greyhounds
abstract: Plus: Johnny Manziel vs. Johnny Rotten; does Dick Cheney want your heart?
lead_paragraph: Plus: Johnny Manziel vs. Johnny Rotten; does Dick Cheney want your heart?

headline: The Fear That Dare Not Speak Its Name
abstract: “Blue Jasmine” touches on an aging woman’s clammiest fear: You’ll wind up as a bag lady. Now, which female filmmaker will step up and make the definitive bag-lady movie?
lead_paragraph: Jasmine-née-Jeanette, the wilting flower at the center of Woody Allen’s Age-of-Madoff fable, “Blue Jasmine,” is in extremis. Her husband’s income once supported her, opulently. But now the money is gone, and so is the husband. Jasmine never finished college, and she has no practical ambitions or employable skills. The simplest principles of computer use confound her. She has lost her friends and alienated her family; her working-class sister, who has temporarily housed her, wants her gone. Jasmine is also losing her mind, the disintegration hastened by drink and pills. And in a bravura performance — all smudged eyes, pale sheen of flop sweat and nervous hand gestures of self-delusion — Cate Blanchett makes Jasmine a riveting spectacle of disintegration, last seen nattering to herself on a park bench. She’s so bedraggled that the stranger on the bench next to her, smelling crazy in the air, picks up and leaves.

headline: The Boy Genius of Ulan Bator
abstract: How a kid from Mongolia found his way to M.I.T.
lead_paragraph: Days before I was to meet Battushig Myanganbayar at his home in Mongolia, he sent me an e-mail with a modest request: Would I bring him a pair of tiny XBee wireless antennas? Electronic parts are scarce in Mongolia (he used components from old elevators for some of his projects), and packages ordered online take weeks to show up.

headline: Financing Start-Up Dreams With Retirement Savings
abstract: You can use 401(k) money to create a new business, but beware: the rules are complicated and the Internal Revenue Service will be watching closely.
lead_paragraph: BOHNNE JONES had always dreamed of being an architect or interior designer. Suzie Ford wanted to know if the home-brewed beer her husband, Todd, made was as good as people said it was, while Jan Morris figured owning a distillery would be more fun than being a divorce lawyer.

headline: Narendra Modi Is Opposition Party’s Prime Ministerial Candidate
abstract: Gujarat Chief Minister Narendra Modi was declared the prime ministerial candidate for the Bharatiya Janata Party on Friday in New Delhi.
lead_paragraph: Narendra Modi, 62, the chief minister of the western Indian state of Gujarat has been nominated as the leading opposition party, Bharatiya Janata Party’s prime ministerial candidate for the 2014 national elections, the party chief said Friday evening.

headline: Today in Small Business: Rainbow Loom’s Patent Fight
abstract: Rainbow Loom is battling a competitor. Twelve questions to ask yourself before firing an employee. A toilet-fan scam.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Happy at Last
abstract: J. Robert Lennon’s novel “Happyland” is being published in its entirety after being hung up for years due to legal concerns.
lead_paragraph: In 2005, W. W. Norton almost published J. Robert Lennon’s novel “Happyland.” But according to Lennon, the company feared potential legal action and canceled its plans. A satirical novel, the book was inspired, in part, by the real-life actions of Pleasant Rowland, who founded the American Girl doll empire and whose efforts to renovate and revitalize Aurora, N.Y., home of her alma mater, Wells College, drew vocal supporters and detractors. Even after Harper’s Magazine serialized a truncated version of “Happyland” in 2006 without legal repercussion, publishers remained wary.

headline: International Thrillers
abstract: New books by Frederick Forsyth, Nicholas Mennuti, Adam LeBor, David Downing and James Reich.
lead_paragraph: THE KILL LISTBy Frederick Forsyth  G. P. Putnam’s Sons, $27.95.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: PANORAMA CITY,  by Antoine Wilson. (Mariner/Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, $14.95.) Shot through with Christian symbolism, Wilson’s delightfully oddball novel is a picaresque tale of self-determination. From his hospital bed in a small California town, with only one night left to live (according to him), 28-year-old Oppen Porter dictates his life story to his unborn son, a story highlighted by his 40-day journey from “slow absorber” to man of the world.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: DISSIDENT GARDENS,  by Jonathan Lethem. (Doubleday, $27.95.) Spanning 80 years and three generations, Lethem’s novel realistically portrays an enchanted — or disenchanted — garden of American leftists in Queens.

headline: Selling High Holy Days Tickets Is a Dilemma for Synagogues
keywords: ['Jews and Judaism', 'Synagogues', 'Rosh Hashana', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Yom Kippur']
abstract: While some Jews worry that requiring expensive tickets for High Holy Days services keeps newcomers away, congregations face the reality that large communal events carry costs.
lead_paragraph: Let’s say that your religion considers one day a year to be especially holy. On that day, people complete a 10-day period of self-examination and making amends. Meanwhile, God decides what is in store for the coming year. Members of the community — even many who rarely attend services — gather to chant special prayers.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Delia Ephron’s Essays
abstract: This week, Delia Ephron discusses her new essay collection; Eric Schlosser talks about “Command and Control,” his new book about nuclear weapons; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.
lead_paragraph: This week, Delia Ephron discusses her new essay collection; Eric Schlosser talks about “Command and Control,” his new book about nuclear weapons; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: Philip Levine Is Awarded $100,000 Poetry Prize
keywords: ['Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'Poetry and Poets', 'Pulitzer Prizes']
abstract: Philip Levine, the former United States poet laureate and Detroit autoworker, has been awarded the Academy of American Poets’ Wallace Stevens Award for lifetime achievement.
lead_paragraph: Philip Levine, the former United States poet laureate who spent his early years writing verse between shifts as a Detroit autoworker, has been awarded the Academy of American Poets’ Wallace Stevens Award for lifetime achievement.

headline: A Dual Review of What’s New, Starring Tom Dixon and Brian Eno
abstract: Tom Dixon, the celebrated British designer, and Brian Eno, the legendary record producer, weigh in on skin care, fleece shorts and the documentary “Muscle Shoals.”
lead_paragraph: Tom Dixon, the celebrated British designer, who created iconic pieces like the S Chair for Cappellini before founding his own furniture and lighting company, and Brian Eno, the ambient-music pioneer and groundbreaking record producer, and the founding member of Roxy Music, weigh in on skin care, fleece shorts and the documentary “Muscle Shoals.”

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Delia Ephron’s Essays
abstract: This week, Delia Ephron and Eric Schlosser.
lead_paragraph: This week, Delia Ephron and Eric Schlosser.

headline: Wynne Godley and the Hydraulics
abstract: Back to the macro future.
lead_paragraph: A slightly belated reaction to Jonathan Schlefer’s interesting piece on the revived influence of Wynne Godley. There will, I’m sure, be a lot of argument about whether Godley’s approach was actually superior to somewhat more mainstream approaches. But I was struck by Schlefer’s characterization of Godley’s approach:

headline: Sister Act
abstract: Delia Ephron’s essays on pets, religion and “sibling stuff.”
lead_paragraph: Who wouldn’t want to be a spy in the house of Ephron, where writing is the family business and essays can feel like confidences of the gossipy but upright, trustworthy kind?

headline: Living Apart Together
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Families and Family Life', 'Marriages']
abstract: Some couples, both married and in longtime relationships, swear by separate homes.
lead_paragraph: With housing in New York City an increasingly scarce and costly commodity, and under the hoary “two can live as cheaply as one” rule, logic would seem to dictate that couples would move heaven and earth to place themselves under a single roof.

headline: Investors in Europe See a Glass Half Full and Rising
abstract: It remains to be seen whether optimism in the face of negatives like high unemployment is rooted in complacency or a belief that the worst is over.
lead_paragraph: THE skies above Europe are getting much brighter.

headline: Jets Will Have to Let Top Rookies Show What They Can Do
abstract: The rookie quarterback Geno Smith had his moments against the Patriots on Thursday before three fourth-quarter interceptions short-circuited the Jets’ rallies.
lead_paragraph: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. — At halftime of Week 2 of what could be his farewell season as coach of the Jets, Rex Ryan benched a first-round draft pick, Dee Milliner, the Alabama cornerback who was brought in to replace the irreplaceable Darrelle Revis.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Delia Ephron’s Essays
abstract: Ms. Ephron discusses her new collection, “Sister Mother Husband Dog (Etc.).”
lead_paragraph: In The New York Times Book Review, Elinor Lipman reviews “Sister Mother Husband Dog (Etc.),” the new collection of essays by Delia Ephron, sister of the late essayist and screenwriter Nora Ephron. Ms. Lipman writes:

headline: Four Seasons Plans Hotel in Seoul
abstract: Four Seasons Hotels plans to open a property in Seoul in 2015.
lead_paragraph: Four Seasons Hotels & Resorts is venturing into South Korea with a property scheduled to open in Seoul in May 2015. The 317-room, 25-story high-rise with seven levels of underground floors is being built in the Central Business District on a 44,000-square -foot site that is close to the city’s fashion district.

headline: Party Animals
abstract: In three picture books, characters draw different lessons from the promise of a social bash, from inclusion to manners.
lead_paragraph: For some adults (including this reviewer), there are few more stressful words than “party.” Just being invited to one stirs up all kinds of anxiety: Who will be there? What should I wear? Must I attend? And of course: How long am I required to stay? Children, however, have no such ambivalence. For the under-12 set, all parties are equally wonderful. I have never met a child who expressed anything other than unalloyed enthusiasm when invited to one. They never ask who will be in attendance or what will be served. Except in the case of costume parties, sartorial questions are rarely fretted over.

headline: Disappearing Act
abstract: In Cynthia Voigt’s middle-grade novel, a Victorian-era boy’s highly theatrical parents vanish.
lead_paragraph: Within 10 pages of beginning “Mister Max: The Book of Lost Things,” the first volume in a new series by the Newbery Medal winner Cynthia Voigt, we recognize the familiar moves of what is, in no bad sense, a very familiar kind of story. Here is a colorful setting in a slightly burnished, early-modern past (as in “Hugo Cabret”); a mysterious invitation from an exotic source to propel the narrative (as in “Harry Potter”); and a preadolescent boy hero, with several eccentric friends and a single trusty, if grumpy, older person to consult (as in . . . well, as in too many tales, old and new, to enumerate).

headline: Holding Down the Home Front
abstract: In Suzanne Collins’s picture book, a little girl awaits her father’s return from war.
lead_paragraph: Suzanne Collins, author of the famously bloody “Hunger Games” trilogy, has written a picture-book memoir about what life at home is like for a child whose father has gone away to war. Collins’s own father went to Vietnam the year she turned 6, and she’s said the experience had a profound effect on him. But though post-traumatic stress disorder is often spoken of these days, the more subtle effects of war on the children of men and women serving abroad are less well known.

headline: Charming Billy
abstract: A 7-year-old recovering from a summer accident approaches second grade with trepidation in Kevin Henkes’s novel.
lead_paragraph: True to its 7-year-old protagonist’s world and his way of experiencing it, Kevin Henkes’s “Year of Billy Miller” begins with school and with anxiety: “It was the first day of second grade and Billy Miller was worried. He was worried that he wouldn’t be smart enough for school this year.”

headline: Here, There Be Monsters
abstract: In Victorian London, a girl learns to hunt creatures with a knack for snatching children.
lead_paragraph: The twin monsters of modern-day parenting are, on the one side, the cloying hoverer, who suffocates innocent babes when they try to take an independent step, and on the other, the screeching separatist, who dispatches small children onto the nearest public transport system with no coat and the wrong change. How do you navigate between them? Nobody knows. But as you wrestle with the mystery, hand your child a copy of Catherine Jinks’s “How to Catch a Bogle.” Let your darling wander unsupervised down the streets of Victorian London for a change.

headline: Super Squirrel
abstract: An encounter with a vacuum run amok leaves a rodent with unusual perspective and powers.
lead_paragraph: When I meet a new character in a children’s book, I often ask myself: Is this a child I would want to drive to a birthday party? The answer is most often a resounding no.

headline: Sunila Abeysekera, Sri Lankan Human Rights Activist, Dies at 61
abstract: Ms. Abeysekera ran the Inform Human Rights Documentation Center, bringing attention to the violence in Sri Lanka as well as to women’s rights issues throughout South Asia.
lead_paragraph: Sunila Abeysekera, a prominent human rights advocate who sought to bring the world’s attention to myriad acts of violence in her country, Sri Lanka, despite threats against her own life, died of cancer on Monday in Colombo, the Sri Lankan capital. She was 61.

headline: On the Waterfront and Elsewhere
abstract: Kevin Baker’s novel depicts the temptations of power in midcentury New York.
lead_paragraph: The members of the “big crowd” referred to in the title of Kevin Baker’s rewarding new novel are, more or less, the bad guys of the story: the pols, mobsters, union goons and grasping business types who fend off reformers and joust for control of New York in the middle of the 20th century. The struggle is especially fierce along the waterfront, where a shadowy Mr. Big oversees the extraction of tribute, sometimes brutally, from everyone who wants to work on or move goods across the docks at a time, before the advent of airfreight, when the port was the main gateway to the city.

headline: Her Own Woman
abstract: Molly Haskell recounts her brother’s transformation from male to female.
lead_paragraph: Read Molly Haskell’s reappraisal of “Gone With the Wind” in her 2009 book “Frankly, My Dear,” and you will never look at Scarlett O’Hara in quite the same way. She deftly deconstructs that iconic Southern coquette and reveals her to be an ur-feminist of surprising complexity. As a reviewer and critic, Haskell has skillfully dissected celluloid characters, mining one-dimensional archetypes for insights. However, real people (herself included) prove to be more elusive targets in her new memoir, “My Brother My Sister.” As a result, the book — a chronicle of her brother’s transformation from male to female — is more of a surface skim than one might expect. Although much is revealed, little is revelatory.

headline: Community
abstract: Tom Perrotta’s stories explore family and neighborhood life in the suburbs.
lead_paragraph: In Norman McLaren’s classic short film “Neighbours,” two well-dressed suburban men come to blows over a flower on their property line, the fight soon descending into meaningless savagery and mutual destruction. A parable of cold war violence, “Neighbours” shows how quickly peace devolves into chaos when people lose their heads: nobody wins.

headline: In Their Prime
abstract: Jesmyn Ward chronicles the death of four friends and her brother during a four-year period.
lead_paragraph: Steve Martin’s opening lines in “The Jerk” — “I was born a poor black child. I remember the days, sittin’ on the porch with my family, singin’ and dancin’ down in Mississippi” — amuse precisely because there is nothing funny about them. Mississippi, the nation’s poorest state, was where 14-year-old Emmett Till was lynched in 1955 and the civil rights workers James Chaney, Andrew Goodman and Michael Schwerner were murdered in 1964. It’s come to represent American racism at its most brutal — never mind that James Byrd Jr. was chained to a truck and dragged to death in Texas in 1998 or that Sean Bell and Oscar Grant III lost their lives in New York in 2006 and California in 2009, respectively. As Nina Simone belted: “Everybody knows about Mississippi Goddam.”

headline: San Francisco Treats
abstract: A walking tour of Gary Kamiya’s hometown takes him from the familiar to the unknown.
lead_paragraph: About four years ago, I ran into Gary Kamiya at a San Francisco Public Library sale of volumes deemed too dog-eared, outdated or infrequently checked out to continue occupying shelf space. My family and I walked off with a couple of armfuls of books. Kamiya exited with a wagon­load, a Radio Flyer stacked perilously high with novels, poetry collections, books on art and architecture and regional history and botany and God knows what else. I remember feeling a mix of bemusement and literary inadequacy — and noting his irregular gait. What had happened, I wondered, or had he always limped? But I didn’t ask, and we instead exchanged the brief pleasantries of people in the same industry. After we parted, I spotted him going back for (at least) one more load.

headline: In an Old House in Paris
abstract: This novel’s heroine moves into a decaying mansion and embarks on an adventure.
lead_paragraph: At the beginning of “It’s Not Love, It’s Just Paris,” Patricia Engel’s wise and accomplished first novel, Lita del Cielo arrives at the House of Stars, a decaying mansion converted into an upscale hostel or downscale boutique hotel (depending on your point of view), the day Princess Diana dies. The house is run by Séraphine, a countess in her 80s who seems more or less a prop — not unlike the rugs “darkened with age, spotted with cigarette stains, worn with high-heel holes.”

headline: How She Left
abstract: Women can’t escape the trappings of heritage in Chinelo Okparanta’s stories, set in Nigeria and the United States.
lead_paragraph: The stories in Chinelo Okparanta’s first collection are quiet, often unnervingly so, in the manner of a stifled shriek. Hints of menace — a reference to a robbery, an illness, a drop of blood on peeling linoleum — are delivered blandly, matter-of-factly, as if resisting the urge to dramatize were a kind of survival mechanism.

headline: Beyond Borscht
abstract: A love of food unites the generations of a Russian family.
lead_paragraph: The culinary memoir has lately evolved into a genre of its own, what is now known as a “foodoir.” But Anya von Bremzen is a better writer than most of the genre’s practitioners, as this delectable book, which tells the story of postrevolutionary Russia through the prism of one family’s meals, amply demonstrates.

headline: For Mayweather, Peace of Mind Weighs 1,470 Pounds
abstract: The boxer Floyd Mayweather Jr. employs four very large men — the largest is 7-foot-1 and 430 pounds — to stand between him and any problems out of the ring.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — The boxer Floyd Mayweather Jr. travels everywhere surrounded by 1,470 pounds of bulk, the combined weight of four men so large that when they stand close to him, he disappears.

headline: Three Global Health Successes That I Witnessed Firsthand
abstract: On his homecoming, an aid worker shares the lessons he learned working in public health on the ground in Africa for 25 years.
lead_paragraph: Somewhere bumping along the back roads in Mali, Nick Kristof challenged me to reflect on lessons learned from my 25 years working in Africa first as a Peace Corps volunteer in the 1980s and most recently on public health and nutrition programs for Helen Keller International.

headline: Image of the Day: September 13
abstract: A fisherman on the Marina Beach in Chennai, Tamil Nadu.

headline: Miso, for So Much More Than Just Soup
abstract: Miso is a healthy fermented food that is a good source of protein, and great in salad dressings, dips and spreads.
lead_paragraph: I’ve been expanding my repertoire of fermented foods lately. I’ve always eaten lots of yogurt, but if you opened my refrigerator today you would also find kimchi and miso paste. The miso paste usually gets hidden in the back, because up until recently I would buy a container for a recipe I was working on (often a soup) and then forget about it for months.

headline: The Gun Report: September 13, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Gun owners in Chicago, where more than 1,000 people were shot in the first six months of this year, no longer have to register their firearms with the local authorities, in accordance with a new state law that will make Illinois the last in the nation to allow people to carry concealed weapons in public. The loss of control over the city’s 45-year-old gun registry is a major setback for gun control proponents.

headline: Twitter’s Magic Recs Experiment Personalizes What You Follow
abstract: Twitter is working on a new way to show its users new and interesting Twitter accounts. But so far only a tiny number of Twitter users know about it.
lead_paragraph: A few months ago, a mysterious account called “Magic Recs” appeared on Twitter.

headline: When ‘More, Bigger, Faster’ Is Not Better
abstract: For many leaders, growing means building bigger companies. But it also includes spiritual and psychological growth, for personal benefit as well as serving as a role model for others, the author writes.
lead_paragraph: DALIAN, China — What quality ought we value most in leaders?

headline: A Winter World Cup? Gulati Says Not So Fast
abstract: Sunil Gulati of the United States says three weeks is too soon to have an educated vote on whether to change the dates of the 2022 World Cup in Qatar.
lead_paragraph: The 2022 World Cup in Qatar is about nine years away. A vote on whether to change the dates for that tournament — which is, by the way, about nine years away — has been scheduled for three weeks from now. If that timing seems abrupt, it is because it is.

headline: The F.B.I.’s Forced Vacation
abstract: Due to the sequester, the nation’s law enforcement agency will be off duty for 10 workdays over the next year.
lead_paragraph: For 10 workdays over the next year, the nation’s law enforcement agency will be off duty. Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation will stay home, leads will not be followed, crime will not be fought. Only a skeleton crew will be on duty — because the government doesn’t have enough money to meet the bureau’s payroll.

headline: Divisive Nationalist to Lead Opposition in Indian Vote
abstract: The opposition party’s choice of Narendra Modi could pit him against the governing party’s Sonia Gandhi, scion of India’s first family of politics.
lead_paragraph: AHMEDABAD, India — India’s leading opposition party on Friday officially anointed a prominent Hindu nationalist, considered one of the most divisive politicians in Indian history, as its candidate for prime minister in next year’s national elections.

headline: China Detains a Billionaire for Activism
keywords: ['Political Prisoners', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: Wang Gongquan, a venture capitalist who has been outspoken in his liberal views, was detained by more than 20 officers from the Beijing police.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — A Chinese billionaire venture capitalist who has strongly advocated more liberal political and social policies was detained Friday by Beijing police officers, friends of the businessman said.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Stephen King, whose new novel, “Doctor Sleep,” is a sequel to “The Shining,” once told a critic of his work: “Sales aren’t all-important. We all want to be nominated for a National Book Award.”
lead_paragraph: ‘Shining’ Star: “Doctor Sleep,” Stephen King’s much-­anticipated sequel to “The Shining,” isn’t on the hardcover list yet — its official release date is Sept. 24 — but back in 1977, “The Shining” did spend time there on its way to becoming a cultural touchstone. (It also sold well in paperback, especially after Stanley Kubrick’s 1980 film adaptation.)

headline: Cheerleaders, at Risk of Concussion, Hide Symptoms
abstract: New research suggests that cheerleading accounts for 66 percent of catastrophic injuries in female athletes. And the ones who are being injured are not accurately reporting their symptoms.
lead_paragraph: Cheerleaders underreport concussions, according to a new study published in the Journal of Pediatrics.

headline: In China, the Dangers of Due Diligence
abstract: Background checks, audits and other investigations are just part of doing business in most countries, but in China those jobs can pose big risks.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — When Peter Humphrey and his wife, Yu Yingzeng, appeared on Chinese national television recently, handcuffed and wearing orange prison vests, it was the first time in more than a month that family and friends had seen the British-American couple, well-known figures in the foreign business world here.

headline: Square Roots | The Making of a Proenza Schouler Runway Look
abstract: Click the image to see the path of one of Jack McCollough and Lazaro Hernandez’s ideas for their spring/summer 2014 collection, from the page to the stage.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the back story behind some of the most popular pieces to appear on the runway this season, showing their trajectory from the designer’s own sketch to a fully realized look. Just begin clicking on the image above to transform it into a thick, embroidered coat worn over a sleek crepe dress from Proenza Schouler’s spring/summer 2014 collection.

headline: Hong Kong Drops Shark Fin From Official Menus
keywords: ['Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Sharks', 'Fishing, Commercial', 'Cruelty to Animals']
abstract: The authorities, yielding to years of pressure from environmental groups, also applied the curbs to bluefin tuna and black moss, a type of algae.
lead_paragraph: Hong Kong bowed Friday to years of pressure from environmental groups, saying it would no longer allow shark fin to be served at official functions.

headline: Calendar: Coming Events in Traverse City, Mich.; Philadelphia; Düsseldorf, German
abstract: A weekly capsule of events around the globe curated by our writers and editors.
lead_paragraph: Midwest Space Fest, Traverse City, Mich. The wonders of the night sky will be celebrated at the Midwest Space Fest on Oct. 4 and 5 in Traverse City, Mich. The first-time event will include films, talks, exhibitions, music with space themes and, of course, ample sun, moon and star gazing; it is timed to coincide with World Space Week. Magnetic North, the nonprofit organization that is hosting the festival, said the wide vistas and comparative lack of city lights in the northern Michigan skies are ideal for astronomy enthusiasts of all levels.

headline: After U.S. Open, Stephens Stays for Fashion Week
abstract: Sloane Stephens walked the runway Thursday night in the Just Dance With Boy Meets Girl fashion show, modeling the designs of Stacy Igel.
lead_paragraph: Most of the players who participated at the United States Open have already left New York and have scattered across the globe, with some of the men playing Davis Cup ties this weekend and the women off to play tournaments in Quebec City and Tashkent, Uzbekistan.

headline: At $17.9 Million, Michael Feinstein’s Home
abstract: A pair of Upper East Side brownstones were combined to form a singular grand home.
lead_paragraph: A pair of Upper East Side brownstones were combined to form a singular grand home.

headline: Feinstein’s Home: Isn’t It Romantic?
abstract: An 18-room town house created from a pair of Upper East Side brownstones is owned by the cabaret singer Michael Feinstein and his spouse.
lead_paragraph: An uncommon property created from a pair of bow-front Upper East Side brownstones that, 120 years after they were built around 1886, were combined to form a singular town house of grand and gracious dimensions earmarked for entertainment, is about to enter the market for the first time. The sellers are the cabaret singer, pianist, and Great American Songbook archivist Michael Feinstein and his spouse, Terrence Flannery. The asking price is $17.9 million, which does not include the wall-size Hirschfeld mural, populated by stars like Liza Minnelli, Fred Astaire, Woody Allen and Barbra Streisand, that sets the tone in the foyer.

headline: Why Lehman Wasn’t Rescued
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Bankruptcies', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Emergency Economic Stabilization Act (2008)', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis']
abstract: The Lehman Brothers crisis was different in nature than the failures of Bear Stearns and A.I.G., and the Treasury and the Fed responded appropriately, an economist and former Treasury official writes.
lead_paragraph: Phillip Swagel is a professor at the School of Public Policy at the University of Maryland and was assistant secretary for economic policy at the Treasury Department from 2006 to 2009.

headline: Vikram Seth’s ‘Suitable Boy’ Sequel Finds a New Home
abstract: After a deal with another publisher fell through, Vikram Seth’s sequel, “A Suitable Girl,” has been acquired by an imprint of the British publisher Orion.
lead_paragraph: Weidenfeld and Nicolson, an imprint of the British publisher Orion, has acquired “A Suitable Girl,” the sequel to Vikram Seth’s gargantuan 1993 novel “A Suitable Boy,” after a deal with another publisher fell through this summer when Mr. Seth failed to deliver the manuscript on time.

headline: Fashion Week: Elements | Character
abstract: Explore character through a thematic visual diary of New York Fashion Week inspired by the essential building blocks of fashion and style.
lead_paragraph: Explore character through a thematic visual diary of New York Fashion Week inspired by the essential building blocks of fashion and style.

headline: Twitter vs. Facebook: A Tale of Two Sites
abstract: All eyes are on Twitter as it prepares for an initial public offering of stock, and many are comparing it to Facebook, which went public last year. How do the two social networking sites actually compare?
lead_paragraph: All eyes are on Twitter as the company prepares for a highly anticipated initial public offering of stock. Twitter’s announcement on Thursday that the company had filed paperwork with regulators to eventually sell shares  immediately had analysts and potential shareholders wondering how the company would fare after Facebook’s public offering last year, which was turbulent, to say the least.

headline: When Your Child Doesn’t Want to Go to School
abstract: Find a solution. Offer a “Get Out of School Free” day. Solutions for the parent whose child doesn’t want to go to school.
lead_paragraph: Last Friday, we introduced New Parent, Old Parent, a feature bringing together readers of Motherlode and Booming to discuss the often humbling challenges of raising children. Our first question was pegged to the new school year: How do you deal with a child who won’t go to school?

headline: Long Island City: From Locomotives to Living Rooms
keywords: ['Area Planning and Renewal', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Efforts to remake Hunters Point, in Long Island City, Queens, come to fruition, with most of the envisioned residential buildings going up, as promised.
lead_paragraph: Many of the rail yard conversion projects championed by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg over the last decade have taken time to come to fruition.

headline: An Adage Adjustment for Investors at Retirement
abstract: A study found that holding as little as 20 percent in stocks at retirement, and adding more over time, could make a portfolio last longer.
lead_paragraph: It’s the kind of advice that people approaching retirement long to hear: you may not need to keep as much of your hard-earned savings in stocks.

headline: Cranked Gears for Leaping
abstract: Scientists used advanced high-speed video to track the incredibly fast, mechanically powerful jump of a plant-hopping insect called Issus coleoptratus.
lead_paragraph: Scientists used advanced high-speed video to track the incredibly fast, mechanically powerful jump of a plant-hopping insect called Issus coleoptratus.

headline: The Dell Deal Showed How Deals Aren’t Supposed to Work
abstract: Overconfidence and delay got the better of both sides in the bid by Michael Dell and an investment firm to take Dell private. Speculators, too, succumbed to their overactive imaginations.
lead_paragraph: The months of torment in taking Dell private have at last ended. But the lessons will probably go unlearned.

headline: Big Ticket | Gramercy Park Penthouse for $42 Million
abstract: A 6,300-square-foot penthouse duplex was bought by the owner of the Houston Rockets and was the week’s most-expensive residential sale in New York City.
lead_paragraph: The duplex penthouse at 18 Gramercy Park South, the luxuriously upgraded former Salvation Army rooming house for women, sold for its full asking price of $42 million and was, by a landslide, the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Bookshelf: The Wild West
abstract: New picture books about cowboys, ranches, sheriffs, coyotes and more.
lead_paragraph: New picture books about cowboys, ranches, sheriffs, coyotes and more.

headline: Iquitos, Peru: Wet and Wild
abstract: From sinkholes and snake oil to echoes of Eiffel and Herzog,  the surreal is simply real in the “Capital of the Amazon” — and you don’t even need a local hallucinogen to experience it.
lead_paragraph: Before we begin, a disclaimer: In Iquitos, Peru, your correspondent did not consume the shamanic hallucinogen ayahuasca. This is despite having seen candy-colored motorcycle-pulled carriages, Volkswagen-size sinkholes, the lost jungle Eiffel Tower, the gentleman pushing a life-size red-and-gold merry-go-round horse up a lime neon-lit edge of an avenue and the woman stopping traffic at midnight with a pompom routine, and heard the tinny soundtrack of cuckoo-clock church bells straight out of the Twilight Zone marking every quarter-hour.

headline: Gearlike Legs Propel a European Jumper
abstract: A plant-hopping insect has joints that work like interlocking gears, a new study reports, the first known instance of coglike wheels in nature.
lead_paragraph: A plant-hopping insect has joints that work like interlocking gears, a new study reports, the first known instance of coglike wheels in nature.

headline: Out of the Past in Lively Old Rio
abstract: Peek beyond the preparations for the World Cup and Olympics and you’ll find a historic area humming with attractions.
lead_paragraph: As Rio de Janeiro undergoes a face-lift in preparation for next year’s World Cup and the 2016 Summer Olympics, what was old is once again new.

headline: Bookshelf: The Wild West
abstract: New picture books about cowboys, ranches, sheriffs, coyotes and more.
lead_paragraph: THE CASE OF THE MISSING DONUT  By Alison McGheeIllustrated by Isabel Roxas  32 pp. Dial. $16.99. (Picture book; ages 3 to 6)

headline: Rooney Mara’s Pared-Down, All-Black Ensemble
abstract: The actress attended the Calvin Klein show yesterday, the final day of New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: The Girl: On the last day of New York Fashion Week, the actress (and T’s women’s issue cover star) attended the Calvin Klein show with sleek hair and minimal accessories that balanced out her voluminous coat and all-black look.

headline: Would You Start a Business With 401(k) Money?
keywords: ['401(k), 403(b) and 457 Plans', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Small Business']
abstract: For many, it can be a very tempting strategy for all sorts of reasons.
lead_paragraph: Paul Sullivan, who writes the Wealth Matters column for The Times, is writing about the strategy of using retirement money to finance the start of a business. It’s especially tempting for those who have substantial 401(k) accounts and who have lost their jobs in recent years, and Mr. Sullivan finds several examples of people who have given it a shot:

headline: Red Bulls Encounter Cleared the Air
abstract: After last week’s impressive victory at Houston, the Red Bulls return home to face struggling Toronto on Saturday night.
lead_paragraph: It is hard to know if Red Bulls Coach Mike Petke is a disciple of the philosopher Friedrich Nietzsche, though he certainly subscribes to the quotation, “That which does not kill us makes us stronger.”

headline: Obama Names Zients as Chief Economic Adviser
abstract: President Obama named Jeffrey D. Zients, a candidate in the past for two cabinet positions, to replace Gene B. Sperling next year.
lead_paragraph: President Obama on Friday officially named Jeffrey D. Zients, an entrepreneur who twice was the president’s acting budget director and a candidate in the past for two cabinet positions, to succeed Gene B. Sperling as the chief White House economic adviser.

headline: U.N. Chief Says Report Will Confirm Gas Massacre
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: An apparently off-the-cuff remark by Secretary General Ban Ki-moon caught his press office by surprise.
lead_paragraph: Ban Ki-moon, the United Nations secretary general, said Friday that he believed that an impending report he had commissioned on the massacre of Syrian civilians last month would be “overwhelming” in showing that chemical weapons were used.

headline: Casey Dunn Talks About How CreatureCast Got Started
abstract: The Brown University professor on the translating biology into animation.
lead_paragraph: The Brown University professor on the translating biology into animation.

headline: My Jewish Daughter, Mary
abstract: Aside from “Christina,” perhaps, there’s no name that shouts “Jesus is my Lord and Savior” as much as “Mary.” In the view of the religious teachers who educated me, “Moon Unit'” would be a better choice.
lead_paragraph: When I was pregnant with my second child, my husband and I told our 3-year-old son, Cai, that he could name the baby. This would help him feel like an important family member before his universe collapsed. “O.K.,” Cai said. “Her name is Mary.”

headline: Free to Marry, and Not Bound by Rites
keywords: ['Weddings and Engagements', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Customs, Etiquette and Manners']
abstract: Same-sex couples choose traditions meaningful to them, often tossing out parts of the ceremony adhering to gender roles.
lead_paragraph: No wedding rule book exists for gay men and lesbians who find themselves in equal measure confused and liberated by the etiquette free-for-all that has accompanied the expanding legalization of same-sex marriage. Evan Wolfson, the president of Freedom to Marry, an advocacy group based in New York, argues that while it’s tempting to say, “Our weddings are the same as everyone else’s, only gayer,” the truth is more complex.

headline: New Magazine Celebrates ‘Rust Belt Chic,’ With a Wink
abstract: Belt Magazine, a new weekly online magazine of essays and reportage based in Cleveland, officially started publishing this week.
lead_paragraph: The decaying cities of the post-industrial Midwest can sometimes seem like a museum of things America used to make: cars, refrigerators, steel, televisions.

headline: Sicilian Summer on the Mainland
abstract: A fragrant stovetop lamb stew called spezzatino di agnello has a definite southern Italian sensibility.
lead_paragraph: I had planned to spend a week at the end of the summer on an island off the Sicilian coast. Sunny skies and blue waters were to be followed by a night or two in Palermo and a few days in the countryside visiting Fabrizia Lanza, director of the Anna Tasca Lanza cooking school, where the main activity is picking and cooking vegetables from the garden for every meal.

headline: Backstage Beauty | The Eyes Have It at Marc Jacobs
keywords: ['Cosmetics and Toiletries', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Models (Professional)', 'New York Fashion Week']
abstract: François Nars used green pencil and cobalt liner to accomplish the statement eye makeup on last night’s runway.
lead_paragraph: It was all about aqua eyes backstage at the Marc Jacobs runway last night. “The colors we used made the eyes look really intense,” explained the makeup artist François Nars of the shades that riffed off the collection’s richly saturated, floral-strewn pieces. To achieve the effect, artists traced around the perimeters of eyes with either a green pencil (Nars Eyeliner Pencil in Kalisté) or cobalt liner (Nars Blue Dahlia Larger Than Life Eyeliner; available in November), extending their ultra-fine strokes just beyond the inner and outer corners to provide graphic impact. Smudges and smears were cleaned up with a simple cotton swab while an eyebrow comb was used to sweep away any fallen particles from skin. “Marc loves when I do eyes,” Nars said of the feature he’s most known for enhancing, which often anchors the designer’s beauty look. The model Cara Delevingne was eager to try things out as she sat in the makeup chair. “I love a colored eye,” she said, pushing her tousled hair off her face. “It just adds a touch of something.” Her backstage cohort, Georgia May Jagger, concurred, saying: “People can get quite boring, so it’s good to add something different.”

lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

lead_paragraph: The actress discusses how she approached her role in her upcoming film, “The Disappearance of Eleanor Rigby.”
