headline: Obamacare Doublethink
abstract: Is the danger that it will fail, or that it will succeed?
lead_paragraph: I’m sure someone else has pointed this out, but there’s a fundamental contradiction at the heart of the right’s anti-Obamacare strategy — I mean, aside from the fact that it isn’t going to work, and may do immense damage both to America and to the Republican brand.

headline: 40 Years After War, Israel Weighs Remaining Risks
keywords: ['Yom Kippur', 'War and Revolution', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Biological and Chemical Warfare']
abstract: The anniversary of the surprise attack on Yom Kippur by Egypt and Syria comes amid new regional tensions, stirring latent questions about the reliability of intelligence assessments.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — It was 1 p.m. on Saturday, Oct. 6, 1973, the day of Yom Kippur, the holiest in the Jewish calendar, and Israel’s military intelligence chief, Maj. Gen. Eli Zeira, had called in the country’s top military journalists for an urgent briefing.

headline: It’s Not ‘Mess.’ It’s Creativity.
abstract: Need inspiration? Make a mess.
lead_paragraph: MESSY or tidy — which is better?

headline: A Big Job: Protecting Floyd Mayweather Jr.
abstract: Floyd Mayweather Jr.’s safety is ensured by 1,470 pounds of bulk spread over four men.
lead_paragraph: Floyd Mayweather Jr.’s safety is ensured by 1,470 pounds of bulk spread over four men.

headline: Been Down So Long, It Looks Like Up to Me
abstract: Is it good news if fewer people are working? In the euro zone, the answer seems to be yes, so long as the rate of decline is slowing.
lead_paragraph: “Employment down by 0.1% in euro area”

headline: Devils’ Brodeur Gets Butterflies as His Son Gets Playing Tips
abstract: Having goalie Martin Brodeur’s 18-year-old son, Anthony, who was selected as the 208th overall pick in the draft, in training camp was odd for both of them, they said.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — Seeing Anthony Brodeur around Devils training camp is not anything new.

headline: Every Reason to Be Afraid
abstract: In “The Beautiful Dark,” Erik Gernand has created complicated, recognizable people who are, like most of us, victims of their own flaws.
lead_paragraph: Thunder is the first sound the audience hears in Erik Gernand’s drama “The Beautiful Dark.” Then a heavy rain falls. Then a spotlight comes up on a young man in a hoodie, standing on what looks like a school desk. He delivers a monologue about nature, hurricanes and why destruction is good, even deserved.

headline: They Like Being in the Same Scene
abstract: The couple are married at a family retreat in the Catskills that the groom’s father, the actor Raul Julia, had loved.
lead_paragraph: It was about 30 years ago that the actor Raul Julia sat upon a hilltop in the Catskills, gazed down on the rolling hills, woods and meadows below, and instantly and completely fell in love.

headline: Quick Breads Packed With Flavor
abstract: Sweet and savory quick breads can make great snacks or side dishes to a meal.
lead_paragraph: If you are craving home baked goods but don’t have time for traditional bread, try making a sweet or savory quick bread, writes Martha Rose Shulman in this week’s Recipes for Health.

headline: Toronto Video: Jessica Chastain on ‘The Disappearance of Eleanor Rigby’
abstract: Jessica Chastain discusses her role in a movie that shows two sides of a relationship in two separate films: “Him” and “Her.”
lead_paragraph: In “The Disappearance of Eleanor Rigby: Him and Her,” the details and struggles of a marriage are portrayed from two perspectives in essentially two separate films. “Him” tracks that relationship through the eyes of Conor (James McAvoy), while “Her” makes Eleanor (Jessica Chastain) its focus. This week, the Toronto International Film Festival has been screening the movie, occasionally in reverse order, putting “Her” first. In this video, Ms. Chastain speaks about her role and the dual requirements of playing her character in one film, and Conor’s impressions of her character in another.

headline: A Cruise With a Focus on World War II
abstract: Crystal Cruises will offer trips with an emphasis on World War II and the Pacific Theater.
lead_paragraph: Crystal Cruises will explore history with a cruise that will visit major battlegrounds and historic sites of World War II’s Pacific Theater. On Jan. 18, the Crystal Serenity will depart from Los Angeles with ports of call in Hilo, Honolulu, Guam, Okinawa, Saipan and Tokyo’s port of Yokohama.

headline: The Days of Flapper Chic and Illicit Drink
abstract: The East Hampton Historical Society tells the lively story of the Jazz Age on the East End.
lead_paragraph: At the entrance to “Jazz Age East Hampton (1919-1933): Clothes, Clubs and Contraband,” the exhibition at the East Hampton Historical Society’s Clinton Academy Museum, stand mannequins of two elegant women dressed in sleeveless drop-waist dresses of the 1920s. Between them is a small bamboo table holding an ice bucket, a cocktail shaker and two glasses. Behind them hangs a 1922 pastel portrait of a flapper.

headline: Spider, New York’s Oldest Cabby, Dies at 94
abstract: Johnnie Footman, known widely as Spider, stopped driving a cab in recent months, but continued to show up most days at the cab depot he worked out of for many years.
lead_paragraph: It’s the end of the line for New York City cabdriver 016337 – that’s the hack license number of Johnnie Footman, who turned 94 last month and was the oldest licensed yellow-cab driver in the city.

headline: Pentagon in Back Seat as Kerry Leads Charge
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Biological and Chemical Warfare']
abstract: The defense secretary and the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff share a reluctance to use military might overseas, in contrast to the Pentagon in the George W. Bush years.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the weeks of sometimes bewildering debate in Washington about what to do in Syria, one truth has emerged: President Obama has transformed his relationship with the Pentagon and the military.

headline: American Ballet Theater Announces Diversity Program
abstract: American Ballet Theater has begun a partnership with the Boys and Girls Clubs of America and regional ballet companies aimed at increasing the number of dancers from minority groups.
lead_paragraph: American Ballet Theater has begun a partnership with the Boys and Girls Clubs of America and regional ballet companies across the country aimed at increasing the meager number of minority dancers, the troupe announced on Friday. The program, called Project Plié, will offer scholarships to talented young dancers of color and train dance teachers who work in underrepresented communities.

headline: Weekend Reading: Dollars Trump Caution in Twitter I.P.O.
abstract: Investors’ current yearning for the speedy growth of mobile advertising revenue at social media companies has overcome their wariness following the dreadful initial public offering of Facebook last year.
lead_paragraph: Investors’ current yearning for the speedy growth of mobile advertising revenue at social media companies has overcome their wariness after the dreadful initial public offering of Facebook last year.

headline: High Seriousness, Low Humor
abstract: The Red Grooms show at Yale, with roots in pictorial art, is big, rowdy and entertaining.
lead_paragraph: There’s a wild, wild party going on at the Yale University Art Gallery these days. And I don’t mean the happy celebration of painting that can be ascribed to most any art museum. This particular bash — calling it wild is probably understating things — rounds up Rembrandt and Leonardo, Picasso and Stravinsky, cancan girls and the New York Knicks and lets them all loose in a big room with plenty of booze, cigarettes and a large, extremely entertaining bowl of grapes.

headline: Behind Microsoft Deal, the Specter of a Nokia Android Phone
abstract: A team within Nokia had Android up and running on the company’s Lumia handsets well before Microsoft reached a deal to buy Nokia’s phone business, according to people briefed on the effort.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Before Microsoft reached a deal to buy Nokia’s phone business, there was a possibility that Nokia could have switched its smartphones to Google’s Android operating system sometime after late 2014.

headline: Broccoli Salad With Hazelnut Romesco
abstract: Melissa Clark makes a romesco sauce that can hold its own against the strong flavor of broccoli.
lead_paragraph: Melissa Clark makes a romesco sauce that can hold its own against the strong flavor of broccoli.

headline: From Battlefield to Ballfield
abstract: By 1863, baseball was the Union’s favorite diversion from the Civil War.
lead_paragraph: The fratricidal struggle between the Union and the Confederacy had a profound and often tragic impact on Northern society, but after the initial shock, people began to return to some semblance of a normal life – including sports. Although membership in baseball and cricket clubs and the number of games declined sharply during the first year of combat, a revival of baseball (but not yet of cricket) began in 1862. Most of the men on the first nines of the premier clubs were able to avoid military service, but a few of them risked their lives by enlisting in state regiments. Still, by the second year of the war championship competition among the leading clubs of Manhattan, Brooklyn and northern New Jersey attracted large crowds of spectators and increased coverage by daily newspapers and weekly sporting journals.

headline: A Jazz Logic in Intricate Puzzles
abstract: The guitarist Miles Okazaki, performing with his band at Seeds in Brooklyn, is an unusually calculating musical thinker, drawn to numerical puzzles and structural designs.
lead_paragraph: The last tune that Miles Okazaki offered up at Seeds in Brooklyn on Wednesday night was “Dozens,” which opened with a syncopated stutter, like combinations thrown against a punching bag. Mr. Okazaki, playing his hollow-body Gibson guitar, then sidled into the song’s main theme, a complex melody sluicing through the standard chord changes of Gershwin’s “I Got Rhythm.”

headline: New Metric for Colleges: Graduates’ Salaries
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Graduation Rates', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: PayScale offers an alternative to the U.S News rankings of universities, listing them by the average earnings of their graduates. Not everyone agrees with that approach.
lead_paragraph: U.S. News & World Report released its eagerly anticipated annual rankings of universities and colleges this week, and two of the usual suspects — Princeton University and Williams College — came out on top. Prospective students and their parents can evaluate these institutions on a variety of measures deemed important by U.S. News.

headline: Mismatched Rankings
abstract: A comparison of the widely read U.S. News & World Report annual ranking of the best colleges and universities with a ranking by PayScale of the midcareer salaries of graduates.
lead_paragraph: A comparison of the widely read U.S. News & World Report annual ranking of the best colleges and universities with a ranking by PayScale of the midcareer salaries of graduates.

headline: A Romesco Sauce That Earns Top Billing
abstract: Romesco can be hearty, smoky and open to fresh ideas.
lead_paragraph: Before I ate my way around Catalonia, I assumed that the great (and sadly, late) Penelope Casas’ recipe for romesco sauce, from her book “The Foods and Wines of Spain” was the only one I would ever need.

headline: Fashion’s Latest Muse? Instagram
abstract: Designers are using Instagram to get into the heads of their fans, and vice versa.
lead_paragraph: A compulsive snapper of all things stylish, kitschy or arcane, Susanna Lau, the blogger known as Susie Bubble, wandered earlier this summer through the Meiji Park flea market in Tokyo taking pictures of vintage Hawaiian shirts, toy robots and tiny Minnie Mouse dolls to upload to her phone.

headline: Wall Street Gears Up for a Twitter I.P.O.
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Initial Public Offerings', 'Social Media']
abstract: Four big banks — with Goldman Sachs taking the lead — are said to have secured roles in Twitter’s highly anticipated initial public offering, according to people briefed on the matter.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 6:12 p.m. |

headline: Sublime Jumbles, Reverently Reassembled
abstract: The Institute of Contemporary Art in Philadelphia readies a solo survey of the work of Jason Rhoades, known for seemingly chaotic yet painstakingly constructed environments.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Since the death of the Los Angeles artist Jason Rhoades in 2006 from an accidental drug overdose and heart disease at 41, his exuberant life has always threatened to overshadow his short career. But Rhoades, a canny student of pop culture, seemed to have anticipated that idea almost from the beginning.

headline: Reports Point to an Overlooked Massacre in Syria
abstract: According to a forensic examination of video and witness accounts collected by Human Rights Watch and Britain’s Channel 4 News, forces loyal to Syria’s president executed at least 248 people in May in two neighboring towns.
lead_paragraph: While the debate over Syria’s use of chemical weapons continues to be the focus of international diplomacy, a Human Rights Watch report released on Friday concluded that forces loyal to President Bashar al-Assad, armed with just guns and knives, “executed at least 248 people in the towns of al-Bayda and Baniyas on May 2 and 3,” many of them women and children.

headline: Defense’s Strong Start Doesn’t Surprise Jets
abstract: The Jets held Tom Brady to 185 passing yards and the Patriots to 54 rushing yards, and were equally impressive in their season-opening victory against Tampa Bay.
lead_paragraph: When Jets Coach Rex Ryan praised his revamped defense in training camp and spoke of fielding a unit that would rank in the top five in the N.F.L., it was immediately labeled more of his trademark braggadocio.

headline: A Seductive Dance of Horn and Voice
abstract: Crowds filled Trinity Church on a stormy afternoon for Britten’s Serenade for Tenor, Horn and Strings.
lead_paragraph: Benjamin Britten’s Serenade for Tenor, Horn and Strings is one of the wonders of 20th-century vocal music. Set to a collection of English poems on the subject of evening and night as a kind of inner dialogue between singer and solo horn, it marries an Impressionist visual allure with a northern pensive melancholy and morbid fascination with death.

headline: Fashion Week Parties: Night 8
abstract: Two perfume parties — for Downtown Calvin Klein and Estee Lauder Modern Muse — close out Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: Two perfume parties — for Downtown Calvin Klein and Estee Lauder Modern Muse — close out Fashion Week.

headline: Meghan McCain: Sexter, Truth Teller and Now, Talk-Show Host
abstract: The host of “Raising McCain” talks about digital regrets and why she will never run for office.
lead_paragraph: Who’s the biggest troublemaker in the McCain family? There are some days it could be argued that it’s still Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, but more frequently that title falls to his daughter Meghan McCain. A 28-year-old author, blogger, media personality and proud nonconformist, Meghan is about to take center stage in her own television series, “Raising McCain.” The program, which makes its debut on the Pivot cable channel on Sept. 14, is a hybrid talk show and reality show in which she and her friends and colleagues tackle a different issue each week, including the loss of privacy in an increasingly online world, and the abundance of sex — but lack of romance — in the lives of twenty-somethings.

headline: Citing Sport’s Integrity, Nascar Adds Gordon as 13th Chase Driver
abstract: Nascar expanded the field to 13 drivers because of possible efforts last week to manipulate the results of the season-ending race in Richmond.
lead_paragraph: Cheating accusations, an unprecedented penalty to a race team and a reshuffling of the field for Nascar’s Sprint Cup playoff turned the past week into one of the most bizarre in the sport’s history.

headline: Fashion Week Beauty: The Scarf Bun
abstract: After eight-days of shows, one of the standout hairstyles we’ve seen, not to mention one of the most easy-going, was at Sophie Theallet.
lead_paragraph: After reading Bee Shapiro’s Fashion Week beauty roundup in yesterday’s Thursday Styles, you may be eager to try a new look. Why wait until spring? With the weather in flux and fall around the corner, there can never be enough hair options.

headline: Primer | Tools and Tips for Surviving London Fashion Week
abstract: Everything you need to survive the next five days in style, from can’t-miss exhibitions to a good workout to a speakeasy for hiding out between shows.
lead_paragraph: London Fashion Week begins today, and fashion industry insiders and locals alike are making their final preparations. Here, a guide to surviving (and enjoying) the festivities.

headline: National Pride on the Screen
abstract: Canadian cinema, after three consecutive nominations for the Oscar for best foreign-language film, is a force to be reckoned with.
lead_paragraph: MONTREAL — As the executive director of Telefilm Canada, a government entity that finances some 60 movies a year, Carolle Brabant naturally goes to festivals all over the world to promote those films and advance what she calls “the branding of Canada” as a force in global cinema. Lately, she can’t help noticing that she gets a much more respectful and enthusiastic reception than she used to.

headline: Upon Reflection, Anne Fontaine’s Feminine Touch
abstract: The French writer and director carries a Guerlain lipstick that comes in a clever metal compact with its own mirror inside to feel fully composed behind the camera.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes it has seemed that feminism was consumed with achieving the same tedious manly traits it often derided: political power, coldblooded careerism, hard hearts and functional fashion. The baby (anything regarded as feminine, aesthetic, domestic or even ambivalent) was often tossed out with the bath water and bra.

headline: At Labor Group, a Sense of a Broader Movement
abstract: After decades of decline, the energy and focus at this week’s A.F.L.-C.I.O. convention signaled, as one union president put it, “our need to put some movement back in the labor movement.”
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — As soon as the delegates to the A.F.L.-C.I.O.’s convention entered the hall, they encountered a booth where three 20-somethings were teaching labor leaders more than twice their age how to use Facebook and Twitter. Behind the booth was a sign saying, “Online Strategies that Rock the Movement.”

headline: Furyk Ties Tour Mark With a 59
abstract: Jim Furyk became the sixth golfer to break 60 in a competitive PGA round with a 12-under 59 in the second round of the BMW championship.
lead_paragraph: LAKE FOREST, Ill. — Ten days after finding out in a text message that he was being left off the U.S. Presidents Cup team, Jim Furyk transmitted his reply in 59 strokes.

headline: Where a Bicycle Is Sweetly Subversive
abstract: Haifaa al-Mansour has directed and written the first feature film shot entirely in Saudi Arabia.
lead_paragraph: Early this year, King Abdullah of Saudi Arabia issued a decree allowing women to be appointed to the Shura, an assembly that advises the king on laws and other issues and has been traditionally all male. For the first time, too, women may  vote in the next municipal elections, in 2015. Both decisions represent steps for a conservative country where women still cannot drive and lack other basic rights.

headline: Review: 2014 Subaru Forester
abstract: In this week’s Driven, Tom Voelk takes the 2014 Subaru 2.0XT to the trails to see how capable its Symmetrical All-Wheel Drive really is.
lead_paragraph: In this week’s Driven, Tom Voelk takes the 2014 Subaru 2.0XT to the trails to see how capable its Symmetrical All-Wheel Drive really is.

headline: U.S.-Russia Talks on Syria’s Arms Make Progress
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States International Relations', 'Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: American and Russian negotiators meeting in Geneva on Friday moved closer to an agreement that would seek to ultimately strip Syria of its chemical weapons.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama will not insist on a United Nations Security Council resolution threatening Syria with military action, senior administration officials said Friday, as American and Russian negotiators meeting in Geneva moved closer to an agreement that would seek to ultimately strip Syria of its chemical weapons.

headline: A Master Grafter, Conjuring Hybrids
abstract: Angelin Preljocaj has choreographed a new work for New York City Ballet, his first collaboration with the company since 1997.
lead_paragraph: “Let’s divide into blonds and brunets,” Angelin Preljocaj told the group of male dancers with whom he was working out the timing of a sequence. The dark-haired men — Robert Fairchild, Amar Ramasar and Sean Suozzi — stepped forward and began a long, complicated section of a new work by Mr. Preljocaj that is to have its premiere on Thursday at New York City Ballet’s fall gala.

headline: Video: A Fresh Look at Subaru’s Forester, the Toast of the North Woods
abstract: The closer you get to Canada, the more Subarus you’ll see. The 2014 Forester is a capable utility vehicle that could have broader appeal.
lead_paragraph: It’s an automotive phenomenon like no other in North America – the closer you travel toward the border with Canada, the more Subarus you’ll see. Symmetrical All-Wheel Drive has helped the Japanese brand carve out a fiercely loyal following wherever roads are rough and snowfall is significant.

headline: A Studio Luxuriating in Louche and Lurid
abstract: Warner Archive has released DVD versions of smoldering melodramas and Charlie Chan movies issued by the low-budget studio Monogram in the ’40s.
lead_paragraph: When Jean-Luc Godard dedicated his first feature, “Breathless,”  to Monogram Pictures, he was thumbing his nose at the critical establishment of 1960. For most of the Anglo-American film writers of the time, it was a self-evident truth that nothing but trash could come from a cash-starved studio like Monogram, with its constant flow of micro-budgeted genre pictures. An important movie required major stars, an acclaimed director, an epic scale and a socially significant subject, qualities conspicuously — almost aggressively — absent in Monogram productions.

headline: Pictures of the Day: New Jersey and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from New Jersey, Colorado, Russia and Syria.
lead_paragraph: Photos from New Jersey, Colorado, Russia and Syria.

headline: Uptown Trendsetters Reflect
abstract: Under the leadership of George Steel, from 1997 until 2008, and, now, Melissa Smey, the Miller Theater at Columbia University has carved out a place at the vanguard of the arts in New York.
lead_paragraph: In the 25 years since its opening concert, the Miller Theater at Columbia University has had a transformative impact on musical culture in New York City. The theater itself is modest, with just 700 seats and an operating budget that is a fraction of what larger institutions enjoy. But with the bold programming initiatives enacted by George Steel, the executive director from 1997 until 2008, and expanded by his collaborator and successor, Melissa Smey, Miller has exerted an oversize influence on tastes and trends. Marking the anniversary, Mr. Steel (who is now the general manager and artistic director of New York City Opera) and Ms. Smey spoke with Steve Smith about Miller’s metamorphosis, with additional perspective from a handful of longtime associates. Here are excerpts from the interviews:

headline: Gov. Chris Christie Gives Update on Fire
abstract: Gov. Chris Christie held a news conference Friday morning to give an update on the fire that seriously damaged the boardwalk and several structures in Seaside Park, N.J.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Chris Christie held a news conference Friday morning to give an update on the fire that seriously damaged the boardwalk and several structures in Seaside Park, N.J.

headline: Marc Jacobs: Left Undernourished By the Final Course
abstract: The collection included chunky leaf-patterned tops and darkly colored sweatshirts with beaded skirts.
lead_paragraph: Even if Marc Jacobs were not the most celebrated American designer working on two continents, he would be described in terms of a separate country. People hold him apart from Fashion Week. They say, “Let’s see what Marc does on Thursday night.”

headline: An Intervention for Malibu
keywords: ['Therapy and Rehabilitation', 'Alcohol Abuse', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Law and Legislation', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: The growth of high-profile rehabilitation centers has Malibu residents seeking relief.
lead_paragraph: MALIBU, CALIF. — Cliffside, Summit, Milestones, Seasons. The names suggest New Age spas or, perhaps, recent-vintage vineyards. They sprawl across the scrubby foothills of this storied coastal town and survey its expensive, eroding beaches, their comforts rivaling those of world-class resorts.

headline: Listen Up | Deer Tick Pays Tribute to Its Fallen Idols
abstract: The Providence-based folk rockers preview their deeply-personal new record with the prison ballad “Mr. Sticks,” which premieres here.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Sticks by Deer Tick

headline: Frankfurt’s Debutantes
abstract: The 65th Frankfurt Motor Show was, not surprisingly, dominated by European automakers. Here are some notable models from the show floor.
lead_paragraph: The 65th Frankfurt Motor Show was, not surprisingly, dominated by European automakers. Here are some notable models from the show floor.

headline: The Twitter I.P.O: Investor Beware
abstract: Due to the JOBS Act, Twitter does not immediately have to release information about its finances or its operations.
lead_paragraph: The excitement around Twitter’s impending I.P.O. is misplaced. That’s not a prediction about the company’s prospects. Twitter’s backers and bankers are all likely to become rich(er) in the I.P.O., otherwise they wouldn’t be doing an I.P.O. For all I know, the company’s new public investors will also make money on the stock.

headline: Toward a Go-To Gershwin Edition
abstract: The University of Michigan is planning a critical edition of Ira and George Gershwin’s work under an agreement with their estates.
lead_paragraph: Is it to-may-to or to-mah-to? That question may be unanswerable, but an agreement between the estates of George and Ira Gershwin and the University of Michigan, to be announced on Sunday, aims to create the first definitive edition of the Gershwins’ entire joint body of work, including such landmark pieces as “Rhapsody in Blue,” “Porgy and Bess” and “An American in Paris.”

headline: Cesar Conde of Univision Leaves for NBCUniversal
abstract: Mr. Conde, who has been the president of Univision’s networks division since 2009, is joining a rival, the parent of Telemundo.
lead_paragraph: Cesar Conde, who has been the president of Univision’s networks division since 2009, on Friday jumped to one of the Spanish-language broadcaster’s rivals, NBCUniversal.

headline: Variations on Famed Variations
abstract: The jazz pianist Dan Tepfer offered improvisations on Bach’s “Goldberg” Variations in an adventurous performance at Le Poisson Rouge.
lead_paragraph: The jazz pianist Dan Tepfer first heard Bach’s “Goldberg” Variations when he was a teenager and a friend played him a recording. He was instantly awe-struck by the music. He also recognized in Bach a fellow spirit, a fellow improviser.

headline: Exploring Topography in Varied Skins and Tones
abstract: Leimay presented “Becoming-Corpus” on Thursday night at the Fishman Space at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
lead_paragraph: Seven bodies stand in near darkness. A stripe of light falls across them, then another and another until the human shapes are stratified, like the Grand Canyon, with straight lines bending along the bodies’ curves. The stripes are like skin, a zebra’s pelt, but also like slices, and as they spread, the bodies seem to be stretched, pulled apart.

headline: Couplings, Ogling and Separation
abstract: Oui Danse brought love of the Brice Mousset type to Danspace Project on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: “French Amour,” judging by what the company Oui Danse staged on Thursday at Danspace Project, is a mad, not a groovy, kind of love.

headline: Floods Inundate Colorado
abstract: Video shows the extent of flash flooding in parts of Colorado after record rainfalls.
lead_paragraph: Video shows the extent of flash flooding in parts of Colorado after record rainfalls.

headline: 25 Years at Miller Theater
abstract: A look at some notable performances and events from the history of the Miller Theater at Columbia University.
lead_paragraph: 1988: The Kathryn Bache Miller Theater officially opens on the site of Columbia University’s former McMillin Theater on Sept. 15.

headline: Twitter’s I.P.O., by the Numbers
abstract: A look at the messages, users and revenue behind the global information network. Twitter announced on Sept. 12 that it had filed for an initial public offering.
lead_paragraph: A look at the messages, users and revenue behind the global information network. Twitter announced on Sept. 12 that it had filed for an initial public offering.

headline: Sculptures Big and Small, and All in the Open
abstract: “The Farm Project 2013” comprises 52 installations on 140 acres in Putnam County.
lead_paragraph: At the top of a hill on the western edge of Saunders Farm in Garrison, three life-size concrete figures sit together on the ground. Their knees jut up toward their chests; their feet rest in the grass. Featureless, armless, their rough-hewed surfaces flesh-toned and blotchy, they seem timeless and serene. Behind them, in a vista through the trees, Storm King Mountain rises across the Hudson River.

headline: NPR Plans Buyouts  to Cut Staff 10%
abstract: The public radio organization’s board approved the buyout plan while also naming an interim chief executive, Paul G. Haaga Jr.
lead_paragraph: In an effort to balance its budget, NPR said on Friday that it would try to reduce its staff about 10 percent through voluntary buyouts.

headline: Four Centuries, Countless Influences
abstract: A six-part PBS series charts the experiences of Hispanics in America, from the arrival of a Spanish admiral in Florida in 1565 to the immigration issues confronted today.
lead_paragraph: In 1944, when Americans were fighting for the Pacific island of Saipan, a feisty young Mexican-American Marine named Guy Gabaldon ventured on his own behind Japanese lines, defying the orders of his commander. With a few phrases of Japanese he had learned as a boy in Los Angeles, Mr. Gabaldon coaxed enemy soldiers from caves where they were hiding, making them believe a regiment was close behind.

headline: Pro-Am Bridge Event for BackStoppers
abstract: A pro-am bridge event last Sunday raised money for BackStoppers, a nonprofit charity in St. Louis.
lead_paragraph: The BackStoppers is an admirable nonprofit charity in St. Louis. It gives money to the families of police officers, firefighters and emergency medical personnel who have been killed in the line of duty.

headline: Legal Tussle Over Statue Turns Nasty
abstract: Accusations of unethical behavior fly in a court battle over an ancient statue from Cambodia.
lead_paragraph: The fight between Sotheby’s and federal lawyers over the fate of an ancient sandstone statue that Cambodia wants returned took a bitter turn in court on Thursday after each side filed papers accusing the other of acting unethically.

headline: Jolt of Films and Crowds in Toronto
abstract: Attendees at the Toronto International Film Festival could choose from 288 features and 78 shorts from 70 countries, but head-scratching scheduling pitted hot title against hot title.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — How big is too big? That was the question that faced the tide of humanity as it flowed into this year’s Toronto International Film Festival, filling theaters and spilling into halls. For decades, the festival, which wraps up this weekend, has served as one of the year’s essential film events because of its mix of new-season offerings and titles cherry-picked from earlier festivals. It’s where you can admire Matthew McConaughey’s continuing career rehabilitation in “Dallas Buyers Club”; giggle through “The Liberator,” a hair-in-the wind adventure about the 19th-century Latin American hero Simón Bolívar; and sit in stone-silence through “12 Years a Slave,” a coolly intellectual look at slavery in America.

headline: Finding Satisfaction in Second Best
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Magazines', 'Careers and Professions', 'Education (K-12)', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: In her new book, the president of Barnard College says women have to stop trying to be flawless professionals, mothers, homemakers, cooks and athletes.
lead_paragraph: Debora Spar is the president of Barnard College and the mother of three children, and yet in her spare time she wrote a book — about how women are trying to do far too much at once, using herself as a prime case study. In “Wonder Women: Sex, Power, and the Quest for Perfection,” which will be published on Tuesday, Ms. Spar argues that at every stage of life, from childhood to old age, women are straining to reach impossible standards.

headline: Man on Fire | Matthew Day Jackson
abstract: Most Wednesday evenings in summer, the artist Matthew Day Jackson races a Super Comp dragster on a quarter-mile track in New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: Most Wednesday evenings in summer, the artist Matthew Day Jackson races a Super Comp dragster on a quarter-mile track in New Jersey.

headline: An Insider’s View for Tourists
abstract: UrbanBuddy pairs visitors with locals who answer questions, giving those unfamiliar with an area the scoop on what’s happening.
lead_paragraph: Knowledge is most precious to those who know the least. In New York City, where tourists are derided for clogging the streets of Midtown while locals hail the latest water-tower nightclub, getting an insider’s scoop on what’s happening can feel like the first step toward belonging.

headline: Casual Swagger, Cracked Hearts and Earnest Guitars
abstract: New albums by Lil Silva, Sampha, Rico Love, Austin Lucas, Diarrhea Planet and D’Banj.
lead_paragraph: Lil Silva, SamphaDISTANCE DUAL

headline: Bill Cunningham | Sunset
abstract: Joyous sunflower colors were a favorite of many women during Fashion Week, on shoes and print dresses.
lead_paragraph: Joyous sunflower colors were a favorite of many women during Fashion Week, on shoes and print dresses.

headline: From Zoo Kid to Heartthrob
abstract: Archy Marshall (better known as King Krule or, years ago, as Zoo Kid) discusses how he’s growing into his voice.
lead_paragraph: The Londoner Archy Marshall, better known by his latest stage name, King Krule, recorded his first demo at the age of 8. “I wrote about escaping the city,” he said, “living in the countryside, on a farm,” and about animals. “That’s kind of how Zoo Kid,” as he was called when he released his first single, “came about.” Music he composed at 12 was eventually posted online. “If someone dug hard enough, they could find my voice, unbroken, over like a speed-garage-indie track,” Mr. Marshall, now 19, said, laughing.

headline: Welcoming Friends to Help Make Music
abstract: The British saxophonist Evan Parker, 69, has been a major figure in free improvisation since the late 1960s.
lead_paragraph: The British saxophonist Evan Parker, 69, has been a major figure in free improvisation since the late 1960s. That’s not only because of his sound and style, which starts from late Coltrane and pushes ahead — turning the process of circular breathing into a supercollider of tones and overtones — but also because of his sociability. The best free improvisers are drawn to him, and he to them, and his weeklong residency at the Stone corrals the best of the New York-based ones across three generations.

headline: Sisters Are Two of a Kind, Like Those 1960s Cousins
abstract: Fifty years after Patty Duke played identical cousins, “Liv and Maddie” gives Dove Cameron a role as identical twins, but times have definitely changed.
lead_paragraph: Two television series, a half-century apart. In each, one young actress plays two separate look-alike characters. But here’s a difference you gotta love. In the older series, “The Patty Duke Show,” several episodes revolved around the teenage Patty Lane’s relationship with a star basketball player. In the newer show, “Liv and Maddie,” Maddie is a star basketball player.

headline: War Is Over, but Enemies Are Afoot in London
abstract: In the new season of “Foyle’s War,” starting Sunday on PBS, the detective-hero works for the MI5 intelligence agency in London.
lead_paragraph: “Foyle’s War” returns to PBS on Sunday night with the same Foyle but a new war.

headline: The Car of Your Fantasies? It Comes With Caveats
abstract: Collectors are buzzing about the 50 Lambrecht vehicles that are still considered new, with, in some cases, plastic on their seats and stickers on their windows.
lead_paragraph: PIERCE, NEB. — Ray Lambrecht made collectors wait decades for a chance at his cars, but his auctioneer is moving faster.

headline: Chevys That Time Forgot
abstract: The Ray Lambrecht collection, which goes on sale later this month, includes American classics from the 1950s, ’60s and ’70s.
lead_paragraph: The Ray Lambrecht collection, which goes on sale later this month, includes American classics from the 1950s, ’60s and ’70s.

headline: They Only Look Mismatched
abstract: The sketches on “Key & Peele,” a Comedy Central series that begins its third season on Wednesday, are often caustic, but they’re also usually smart.
lead_paragraph: The sketches on “Key & Peele,” a Comedy Central series that begins its third season on Wednesday, are often caustic, but they’re also usually smart. The season premiere includes a sketch that begins with a “battle rap” — two rappers go at it in an exchange of insults — but ends by invoking Steinbeck.

headline: Testing an Odd Beauty Procedure for the Red Carpet
abstract: How to prepare for an awards show? Ellen DeGeneres got shrink-wrapped and slathered in an odd liquid and then bounced on a trampoline.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — What’s a nice guy like me doing on a trampoline like this?

headline: New Work Now on These Shores
abstract: Crossing the Line, a rich multidisciplinary festival produced annually by the French Institute Alliance Française, opens on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Crossing the Line, a rich multidisciplinary festival produced annually by the French Institute Alliance Française, opens on Thursday with the United States premiere of “Systema Occam,” a richly sensual work by the French composer Éliane Radigue and the visual artist Xavier Veilhan. Ms. Radigue, an electronic-music pioneer whose elemental works reach New York far too infrequently, has recently turned her attention to creating intensely focused pieces for acoustic instruments. “Systema Occam” involves Rhodri Davies, an arresting Welsh harpist.

headline: The New New Bond Street
keywords: ['Shopping and Retail', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']
abstract: Merchants worry that, as it caters more and more to “high net worth individuals,” Bond Street is losing its chronicled charm.
lead_paragraph: The new Chanel store in London, which opened in June at 158-159 New Bond Street, spans 12,600 square feet and boasts a three-story dangling strand of Coco-inspired glass “pearls.” On a Saturday several weeks ago, a group of Muslim women in silky white headscarves entered the V.I.P. fitting room after a pot of tea in the lounge and a tour of a series of rooms decorated to replicate the Paris apartment of the famous designer.

headline: One Artist, Several Scenes
abstract: The artist Robert Ryman moved to New York in the early 1950s to play jazz, spent seven years as a guard at the Museum of Modern Art and came to realize that painting was his calling.
lead_paragraph: The artist Robert Ryman moved to New York in the early 1950s to play jazz, spent seven years as a guard at the Museum of Modern Art and came to realize that painting was his calling. White-on-white paintings became his signature, but Mr. Ryman is also known for works consisting of multiple panels. Now a series of these are on view at Pace’s Chelsea gallery in New York through Oct. 26. The show, “Recent Paintings,” includes nine works from 2010 and 2011 as well as a 10-panel painting, “No Title Required 3” (2010). Pace calls Mr. Ryman’s “No Title Required” series his “most monumental multiple panel work to date.” (508 West 25th Street, 212-989-4258, pacegallery.com)

headline: A Study of Failure in Black and White
abstract: Museum of Modern Art presents films by Douglas Sirk on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Douglas Sirk said of his wide-screen black-and-white melodrama “The Tarnished Angels” that it had, like his “Written on the Wind,” a “mood of desperation, drinking and doubting the values of life, and at the same time almost hysterically trying to grasp them, grasping the wind.” In “The Tarnished Angels,” adapted from Faulkner’s “Pylon,” the wind is the element of Roger Shumann (Robert Stack), a World War I flying ace turned barnstormer who scrapes by in the Depression doing dangerous stunts. Rock Hudson plays a New Orleans reporter drawn to Roger and, even more so, to his wife, LaVerne (Dorothy Malone) — peripatetic daredevils whose workaday confrontation with death makes them seem a breed apart.

headline: Maître d’ for the Mind
abstract: Andrew Johnson has been selling used books for eight years on the streets outside the Queensbridge public housing project, telling his customers, “You got to feed your mind like you feed your body.”
lead_paragraph: “Books are my mistress — I’m enamored of books,” Andrew Johnson, 57, said while leaning back in his office chair, here on the eastern edge of the Queensbridge public housing project, which, with roughly 3,000 units, is the city’s largest public housing development.

headline: Four Troupes Play in the Park
abstract: Fall for Dance is giving audiences more to fall for.
lead_paragraph: Fall for Dance is giving audiences more to fall for. This annual celebration opens its 10th year on Sept. 25 at City Center, and heralding it are free performances hosted by the Public Theater at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park this week. Fall for Dance resembles the New York Dance Festival, which from the 1960s to the ’80s regularly followed Shakespeare in the Park there.

headline: Obama Aide Hospitalized Twice Last Week
abstract: Dan Pfeiffer, President Obama’s 37-year-old chief strategist and one of his longest-serving advisers, was hospitalized twice last week after suffering “stroke-like symptoms,” White House officials confirmed on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Dan Pfeiffer, President Obama’s 37-year-old chief strategist and one of his longest-serving advisers, was hospitalized twice last week after suffering “stroke-like symptoms,” White House officials confirmed on Friday.

headline: Taiwan Tries to Revive Its Banana Export Industry
keywords: ['Bananas', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Consumer Behavior', 'Pineapples']
abstract: As farmers struggle to make a living, the future of the industry may hinge on finding a hit product that will increase demand and raise prices.
lead_paragraph: KAOHSIUNG, Taiwan — The problem with bananas, for the Taiwanese farmers who grow them, is that they are not pineapples.

headline: ‘Rush’: The Drama Is Off the Track
abstract: Ron Howard’s film, which chronicles the duel between Niki Lauda and James Hunt for the 1976 Formula One driver championship, has racing greats fired up.
lead_paragraph: Hollywood has long tried to make films about auto racing that would strike a chord with general audiences. So far, the commercial successes have been few — and, with rare exceptions, the racing has served as little more than a noisy background that fed speed and thrills to another story line.

headline: In Nebraska, a Field of Low-Mileage Dreams
abstract: The Lambrecht collection, featuring hundreds of American classics hidden for decades in a field in Pierce County, Neb., will go on sale this month.
lead_paragraph: PIERCE, NEB. — For decades, a 10-acre tangle of trees in the corner of a corn and soybean field did its best to hide the legends of Pierce County.

headline: The Surround Sound Is $321,080, Supercar Included
abstract: The retractable-hardtop McLaren 12C Spider offers a symphony of howls and gurgles from its mid-mounted, twin-turbocharged V-8, and a staggering 616 horsepower.
lead_paragraph: WHAT IS IT? A retractable hardtop version of McLaren’s ferocious 12C.

headline: Letter From Germany: Passengers Wanted
abstract: Dozens of automakers revealed new cars and features at the Frankfurt Motor Show, hoping to stir the European market from its doldrums.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — A sprawling array of new production models and blue-sky design studies — from humble econocars and all manner of hybrid configurations to $3 million supercars — made their debuts last week during two hectic days of press previews for the 65th Frankfurt Motor Show.

headline: For Developers, a Downside to a Public Twitter
abstract: For the many developers who built services on top of Twitter, and helped the service become popular, a Twitter I.P.O. could mean a bleak future for their products.
lead_paragraph: Twitter’s public offering will lead to a lot of changes, including for its investors, executives and early employees, who stand to make a lot of money.

headline: The Doctor Is Back, on a House Call
keywords: ['Doctors', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Preventive Medicine', 'Emergency Medical Treatment']
abstract: Doctors respond to an Op-Ed article by Dr. Ezekiel J. Emanuel.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Movie Review: 'Mother of George'
abstract: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews "Mother of George."
lead_paragraph: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews "Mother of George."

headline: Movie Review: 'The Family'
abstract: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews “The Family.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews “The Family.”

headline: Movie Review: 'Blue Caprice'
abstract: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews "Blue Caprice."
lead_paragraph: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews "Blue Caprice."

headline: A Biennial Moves Indoors
abstract: The Istanbul Biennial, which organizers had hoped to install in public spaces, opens to the public in indoor spaces on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: The Istanbul Biennial, which organizers had hoped to install in public spaces, opens to the public in indoor spaces on Saturday.

headline: A Canvas of Turmoil During Istanbul Biennial
abstract: The exhibition, which opens Saturday, planned to focus on public spaces long before the angry protests in May about how the government was developing the city.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Back in January, Fulya Erdemci, the curator of this year’s Istanbul Biennial, decided to focus the exhibition on art in public spaces. The city was booming, but at what cost, and for whose benefit? It had become the central question there. Ms. Erdemci wanted artists to engage with the issue, and citizens to engage with public art.

headline: Week in Pictures for Sept. 13
abstract: Watch a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the first day of school, election night parties in the mayoral race, and the 12th anniversary of Sept. 11.
lead_paragraph: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the first day of school, election night parties in the mayoral race, and the 12th anniversary of Sept. 11.

headline: To Raiders Fans’ Relief, a Sight Worth Tuning in
abstract: Terrelle Pryor, who nearly led the Raiders to a win over the Colts last Sunday, has helped excite a waning fan base that will watch a sellout game against the Jaguars.
lead_paragraph: Jaguars (0-1) at Raiders (0-1)

headline: Friday Night Music: Elephant Revival, Old Rogue River
abstract: A bit of joy to end the week.
lead_paragraph: A bit of a tough choice this week. Arcade Fire — who are the group that started me on indie music — has a single from their upcoming album; it’s kind of alarmingly different in style from their previous work, but grows on you after several listens (although I still hate the video.) On the other hand, they had more than a million views last time I looked, so they don’t need boosting. Lucius will have a new album soon, and there’s an official release of Tempest; beautiful song, but I still think they’re best in live performance.

headline: Jews Make a Pilgrimage to a Grand Rebbe’s Grave
abstract: The grave of Rabbi Menachem Mendel Schneerson, the seventh grand rebbe of the Lubavitcher group of Hasidic Jews, has evolved into a spiritual touchstone of the religious movement he spawned.
lead_paragraph: At midnight on Wednesday, Gaby Danieli stepped into the warm night on Francis Lewis Boulevard in Queens, the locks of hair flowing from each temple still sopping wet. He had just dunked in a Jewish ritual bath built beneath a modest house, and was ready for a visit to the grave of Rabbi Menachem Mendel Schneerson, the seventh grand rebbe of the Lubavitcher group of Hasidic Jews.

headline: Judge in Spain Partitions Home of Feuding Couple
keywords: ['Divorce, Separations and Annulments', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )']
abstract: With Spain’s economic crisis forcing feuding couples to stay together, a judge in Seville ordered a divorcing couple to split their apartment into two independent abodes.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The economic crisis in Spain has had the unintentional consequence of forcing warring couples who cannot afford divorces to remain together. Now, a judge in Seville has ordered a divorcing couple to split their 2,700-square-foot apartment down the middle.

headline: 5 Reasons That Innovation at Twitter Might Take a Hit
abstract: A Stanford researcher has found that innovation steeply declines after a company goes public. What does that mean for Twitter?
lead_paragraph: When a company takes itself public, it can function like a shock to the internal system, especially at companies accustomed to operating in start-up mode. Money rushes in, some longtime employees cash out, and new pressures loom over management to increase revenue.

headline: Gardner Likely to Be Sidelined for Rest of Regular Season
abstract: The Yankees’ injury list grows with Brett Gardner, found to have a strained oblique muscle on the left side of his ribcage.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Brett Gardner played in 145 of 147 games this season, but even he could not overcome the injury epidemic that has afflicted the Yankees. On Friday, Gardner was given a diagnosis of a strain of his oblique on the left side of his rib cage.

headline: If You Sell Them, Buyers Will Come: A Small Plains Town Becomes a Car Lovers’ Mecca
abstract: After decades of buying cars and never selling them, an elderly owner of a Nebraska General Motors dealership is finally getting rid of his now-prodigious collection.
lead_paragraph: PIERCE, Neb. — Unless you happen to be headed to Plainview, Neb., the world’s “Klown Kapital,” the small town of Pierce (population 1,700) isn’t on the way to anywhere. You have to jog off the main four-lane (U.S. 81) and take a state road northwest, past farms and fields, and then more farms and fields.

headline: German Magazine Said to Glorify Nazis Will End
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: Der Landser said it was just offering tales of ordinary soldiers in World War II but was the subject of complaints by an American Jewish group.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — The German publisher of InTouch and numerous other magazines said Friday that it would stop publishing a pulp magazine criticized by an American Jewish group for heroic portrayals of German war criminals in World War II.

headline: California: Changes Made to Environment Measure
abstract: The Legislature has approved changes to an environmental statute that has been broadly criticized as encouraging needless litigation and construction delays.
lead_paragraph: The Legislature has approved changes to an environmental statute that has been broadly criticized as encouraging needless litigation and construction delays. The rewrite of the law, forwarded to Gov. Jerry Brown, is a scaled-back version of what some lawmakers had sought. Among other things, the changes would exempt some urban projects from including parking and aesthetics as part of mandatory environmental reviews, one of many goals of business leaders. At the pressing of Darrell Steinberg, a Democrat who is Senate leader, the measure exempts a sports arena being built in Sacramento that was central to getting the Kings basketball team to agree not to move to Seattle.

headline: The Chic Meter | An Offer Kristen Stewart Couldn’t Refuse, Kim Kardashian’s Engagement Ring and More
abstract: How much did a Middle Eastern prince offer Kristen Stewart for a casual conversation? What was the fate of the wedding ring Kris Humphries gave Kim Kardashian? We’ve got the numbers from the week in style and culture.
lead_paragraph: ALL THE NUMBERS THAT MATTER FROM THE WEEK IN STYLESept. 7 – 13

headline: How to Improve Oversight of Homeland Security
abstract: Former counsel to the Department of Homeland Security agree with an Op-Ed essay on streamlining Congressional oversight.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
