keywords: ['National Parks, Monuments and Seashores', 'Minorities', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas']
abstract: The president of the largest forest preserve in the country sees that Chicago-area treasure as a steppingstone to greater adventures.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Tough Talk With Unions
abstract: A deputy mayor of New York City says the city’s attempts to reach a labor deal have been rebuffed.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Eyes Closed in the G.O.P.
abstract: A reader responding to a column by Paul Krugman says that willful blindness is the culprit.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Weekly Wheels Calendar
abstract: From the Jalopnik Film Festival in New York to the Cars and Copters show in Massachusetts, there’s plenty going on this week to keep automotive enthusiasts enthused.
lead_paragraph: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lzNbGH1oZJc

headline: Yale Tries to Clarify What Sexual Misconduct Is in a New Guide
abstract: The university released a document this week that includes a series of sketches in which characters navigate sexual encounters, sometimes respecting each other’s right to consent, and sometimes not.
lead_paragraph: Sex is rarely a straightforward matter on college campuses, but in recent years it has been a particularly fraught issue at Yale University. Two years ago a federal complaint described a “hostile sexual environment on campus,” and more recently an accounting of sexual misconduct complaints prompted protests that the university was not punishing wrongdoers aggressively enough.

headline: Near Union Square Greenmarket and a Playground, Methadone Alley
abstract: A fatal attack has brought new scrutiny to a strip, beside a popular Manhattan park, where clients of drug treatment clinics hang out.
lead_paragraph: “This is where most of the degenerates hang out,” Old Man Tom said. “People with no money. Panhandlers, hustlers.”

headline: After Cosmo’s Bark, a Walk and a Duet
abstract: Sunday is the only day off for the soprano Sarah Joy Miller, who is to star in an opera based on the life of Anna Nicole Smith, but she still manages to get some singing in.
lead_paragraph: Anna Nicole Smith, who died in 2007 at the age of 39, was a jeans model, a pinup and a tragic figure, and is now the subject of an opera, “Anna Nicole,” composed by Mark-Anthony Turnage, which will have its American premiere at the Brooklyn Academy of Music from Sept. 17 to 28, in a coproduction with the financially troubled New York City Opera. For the soprano Sarah Joy Miller, 34, that’s one big bustier to fill. “I think that she’s really not all that different from a Violetta or a Manon,” Ms. Miller said, referring to the heroines of “La Traviata” and “Manon.” Ms. Miller, who also has a debut solo album, “A Glorious Dream,” coming out this month, lives less calamitously in the financial district with her husband, David Miller, an opera singer and a member of the group Il Divo; and their dog, Cosmo, a Maltese-Havanese mix.

headline: Sanctions on Iran Extend to YouTube
abstract: Iran’s state-owned channel Press TV has been engaged in a battle of wits with YouTube in recent months over whether access to the video-sharing site violates American sanctions.
lead_paragraph: Last Updated, Saturday, 3:33 p.m. | As my colleague Michael Schwirtz reported, Iran’s new foreign minister, Mohammad Javad Zarif, addressed the crisis in Syria in an English-language interview this week on Press TV, a state-owned satellite channel that exists to put Tehran’s spin on the news.

headline: Overpopulation Is Not the Problem
abstract: There really is no such thing as a human carrying capacity on the earth.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — MANY scientists believe that by transforming the earth’s natural landscapes, we are undermining the very life support systems that sustain us. Like bacteria in a petri dish, our exploding numbers are reaching the limits of a finite planet, with dire consequences. Disaster looms as humans exceed the earth’s natural carrying capacity. Clearly, this could not be sustainable.

headline: Two Votes for the Caesar Salad
abstract: Flat Top, in Morningside Heights, goes for safe, rib-sticking comfort staples, with a small menu that includes burgers, chicken, salmon and duck breast.
lead_paragraph: Going out to eat in Morningside Heights is a lot like voting. You hope for the best, but when it comes to pulling the lever, you may not be thrilled with your choices. Good restaurants here are as rare as Republicans. On Primary Day, as the neighborhood threw its liberal weight behind Bill de Blasio, some locals also voted with their palates for Flat Top, a New American restaurant on 121st Street and Amsterdam Avenue that was opened in July by the owners of the popular Jin Ramen on Broadway.

headline: The Duty to Protect, Still Urgent
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Civilian Casualties', 'Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Humanitarian Aid', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'International Relations']
abstract: Humanitarian intervention is facing a crisis of legitimacy.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — PRESIDENT OBAMA’S failure to get Congress to support airstrikes in Syria, coupled with the vote against military action in the British House of Commons, brings home a key fact about international politics: when given a choice, democratic peoples are reluctant to authorize their leaders to use force to protect civilians in countries far away.

headline: E.P.A. Is Expected to Set Limits on Greenhouse Gas Emissions by New Power Plants
abstract: Experts predict separate caps for gas-fired and coal-burning plants, something the coal industry would be likely to challenge.
lead_paragraph: Following up on President Obama’s pledge in June to address climate change, the Environmental Protection Agency plans next week to propose the first-ever limits on greenhouse gas emissions from newly built power plants.

headline: U.S. Coal Companies Scale Back Export Goals
keywords: ['Coal', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Mines and Mining']
abstract: American mining companies confront a global coal glut and a price slump, along with persistent environmental opposition.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — The ailing American coal industry, which has pinned its hopes on exports to counter a declining market at home, is scaling back its ambitions as demand from abroad starts to ebb as well.

headline: With Facebook’s Tumultuous I.P.O. in Mind, Twitter Tries to Value Its Shares
abstract: Twitter has fewer users, but it must nevertheless try to convince advertisers that those users are as valuable as those on Facebook.
lead_paragraph: It has more than 200 million active users. It played a central role in the protests against governments in the Middle East a couple of years ago. And it appeals to a generation of Internet users who relish publicly expressing themselves in short bursts of 140 characters or less.

headline: About Last Night | Calvin Klein’s Star-Studded Party for Francisco Costa
abstract: Famous faces from all walks of life braved a wet night to pay tribute to the brand’s women’s creative director, who was celebrating a decade on the job.
lead_paragraph: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Priest in Zanzibar Is Burned in Another Attack on Clergy
abstract: The attack on a Roman Catholic priest was the latest aimed at Christian clergy members and churches in the last year on the Tanzanian island, which has a Muslim majority.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In another sign that religious tensions are on the rise in Zanzibar, a Roman Catholic priest was burned in an acid attack on Friday.

headline: Rift Deepens Over Latest Plan for Europe’s Banks
abstract: A senior European Central Bank official took a jab at the German finance minister, accusing him of blocking revisions to the ’s troubled banking system.
lead_paragraph: VILNIUS, Lithuania — A senior European Central Bank official took a jab on Friday at a crucial member of the conservative party of Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany, just days before Germany’s national election, accusing him of blocking revisions to Europe’s troubled banking system.

headline: Fraud Investigation Unsettles Mental Health Care in New Mexico
abstract: The state is in the midst of a sweeping criminal investigation into 15 of its largest mental health providers, suspected of defrauding Medicaid of $36 million over three years.
lead_paragraph: SANTA FE, N.M. — For weeks now, New Mexico has been in the midst of a sweeping criminal investigation into 15 of its largest mental health providers, suspected of defrauding Medicaid of $36 million over three years. Arizona companies have been hired to fill in, but many patients are struggling without regular treatment. The state behavioral health system is in turmoil, with the administration of Gov. Susana Martinez under sharp attack.

headline: California Inland Empire Still in Housing Tailspin
abstract: Five years after the collapse of Lehman Brothers, the Inland Empire, where it financed hundreds of subprime loans, is still a long way from recovery.
lead_paragraph: RIVERSIDE, Calif. — The one-story home that Scott and Summer Gieser just moved into is a far cry from the new two-story, four-bedroom house they owned before the great mortgage collapse.

headline: Answers to Questions About New York
abstract: A question about the draining of the Croton Distributing Reservoir.
lead_paragraph: Q. How was the Croton Distributing Reservoir, that giant 19th-century storage tank in Midtown Manhattan, emptied when it was taken out of service?

headline: As Vote Verification Begins, Thompson Stays Hopeful
abstract: Election workers on Friday began recanvassing lever voting machines used in New York City’s mayoral primary, as William C. Thompson Jr. continued to contest the race.
lead_paragraph: Election workers on Friday began the monotonous job of double-checking the results from more than 5,000 lever voting machines used in New York City’s mayoral primary, as William C. Thompson Jr. clung to hope that revised vote totals might make Bill de Blasio face him in a runoff.

headline: Oops. 40,000 Federal Workers Miss a Payday.
abstract: A mistake by the payroll center that serves 23 federal agencies meant that paychecks were not deposited into bank accounts on Friday as they usually are.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Everyone looks forward to payday. But for about 40,000 federal employees, Friday’s regular payroll deposits never materialized.

headline: Judge Blocks Shipment of Oil Equipment Through Idaho Forest
keywords: ['Forests and Forestry', 'Conservation of Resources', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Native Americans']
abstract: The move came in response to a lawsuit filed by the Nez Perce tribe and an environmental group, which charged that the Forest Service failed to enforce its own rules to protect the environment through the corridor.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — A federal judge ordered a halt on Friday to more shipments of immense loads of oil field equipment through a national forest in north-central Idaho, pending a broad review of effects on the route.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Tracking Your E-ZPass Toll Transmitter, and Zynga’s Tale of Woe
abstract: Friday’s selections from around the Web include the story of a hacker who found out that his E-ZPass transmitter, which he uses to electronically pay tolls, was being tracked outside of tollbooths. Plus, a tale of Zynga’s rise and fall.
lead_paragraph: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: How a Pop-Up Store Pops Up
keywords: ['Pop-Up Stores and Restaurants', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: To refresh its brand, Dockers opened a temporary shop in SoHo, offering free coffee, tattoos and haircuts to lure in coveted 18- to 34-year-old customers.
lead_paragraph: When people think of Dockers, the khaki pants, they may well think: Beige. Oxford shirt. Striped tie. Blazer. Loafers — with socks.

headline: A High-Powered A&M Offense With a Low-Profile Quarterback
abstract: He is the quarterback of a high-powered A&M offense in College Station, Tex. But the high school player Kobe Miller is charting his own course.
lead_paragraph: He wears a maroon-and-white jersey manufactured by Adidas, leads a hyperactive offense with title aspirations and is the starting quarterback at A&M.

headline: Editor’s Letter | Talented Men
abstract: In an age when, for better or worse, the very idea of the male hero has been displaced from its traditional role in American culture, T’s Fall Men’s Fashion Issue features many men of great talent, style, and grace.
lead_paragraph: IN OUR LEAD SIGN OF THE TIMES ESSAY, the novelist Joshua Ferris writes about how the idea of the male hero has been irreparably severed from that of the icon. On magazine covers, where heroes quaintly once resided, our icons now run the gamut from those famous for being famous through the complexly tortured stars of TV to terrorist suspects if they happen to be young and photogenic.

headline: As Comics Say, ‘These Kids Today! I Tell Ya!’
abstract: Those less-liberated college days of long ago look pretty bad from here.
lead_paragraph: Many and many a year ago, in the kingdom of ABC, Woody Allen was one of my very first guests. And we consented to take questions from an eager audience of mostly young people. Like ourselves.

headline: Deceptive Practices in Foreclosures
keywords: ['Foreclosures', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Editorials']
abstract: A lawsuit filed by the state of Illinois describes the latest abuses against homeowners.
lead_paragraph: In early 2012 when five big banks settled with state and federal officials over widespread foreclosure abuses, flagrant violations — including the seizure of homes without due process — were supposed to end.

headline: A Step to Curb Painkiller Abuses
keywords: ['Pain-Relieving Drugs', 'Labeling and Labels', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Editorials']
abstract: The Food and Drug Administration’s new labeling rules leave consumers safer, but not safe enough.
lead_paragraph: Consumers will be less apt to overdose on prescription painkillers — but still less safe than they should be — under new labeling rules announced by the Food and Drug Administration on Tuesday for a class of drugs known as opioid analgesics.

headline: Collusion in the Potash Market
keywords: ['Potash', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Fertilizer', 'Editorials']
abstract: A dispute between two obscure mining companies demonstrates why the World Trade Organization needs the power to look into anticompetitive partnerships.
lead_paragraph: A dispute between two obscure mining companies in the former Soviet Union has ended, at least temporarily, a cartel that artificially propped up the price of potash, an important fertilizer needed by farmers around the world.

headline: The Gipper and the Deep Blue Sea
keywords: ['Names, Geographical', 'Oceans and Seas', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Monuments and Memorials (Structures)', 'Editorials']
abstract: House Republicans take action on he biggest, wettest and most ambitious memorial to President Ronald Reagan.
lead_paragraph: Of all the more than 3,000 landmarks named for President Ronald Reagan — from scores of schools and highways to an aircraft carrier and a mountain — nothing comes close to this: designating 3.4 million square nautical miles of ocean as the biggest, wettest and most ambitious Reagan memorial yet imagined.

headline: Judge Urges U.S. to Consider Releasing N.S.A. Data on Calls
keywords: ['Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA)', 'Privacy']
abstract: Judge F. Dennis Saylor IV, who sits on the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court, said that release of classified court opinions on National Security Agency requests would add to “informed debate” on privacy.
lead_paragraph: A judge on the nation’s intelligence court directed the government on Friday to review for possible public release the court’s classified opinions on the National Security Agency’s practice of collecting logs of Americans’ phone calls.

headline: Syrian Refugee Spillover Into Europe Surges
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'International Relations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: The United Nations refugee agency reported that 3,300 Syrian refugees crossed the Mediterranean and came ashore in southern Italy in the past 40 days.
lead_paragraph: The refugees streaming out of Syria have put severe stress on neighboring Middle Eastern countries, which have absorbed more than two million of them since the Syrian conflict began 30 months ago. Now Europe is beginning to feel the effects of the refugee crisis.

headline: Big Game Doesn’t Stop Recruiting by Saban
abstract: A matchup between Alabama and Texas A&M, with Johnny Manziel, has not stopped Crimson Tide Coach Nick Saban from doing what he has done best: recruiting.
lead_paragraph: This week, as the biggest game of the college football season loomed, Alabama’s coaches turned their attention away from Texas A&M to look forward, toward players who may or may not help them in future seasons. This is Nick Saban’s process.

headline: Fighting Over the Rock
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: A dispute among Spain, Britain and Gibraltar threatens an economic lifeline for 7,000 Spaniards who cross the border daily to work in the tiny territory.
lead_paragraph: GIBRALTAR — Since Spain introduced tighter border checks as part of a tit-for-tat feud over the sovereignty of this British territory at the tip of Spain, Lola Ballesteros Benítez’s commute has become a lot harder.

headline: Back to Boehner
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Federal Budget (US)']
abstract: The budget crisis is looming, people! So many important dates are coming up. Here is a rundown for you.
lead_paragraph: Back to Congressional gridlock. Back to watching John Boehner provide exciting updates like “we’re continuing to work with our members.” Maybe, if the stalemate goes on long enough, he will once again tell reporters: “If ands and buts were candy and nuts, every day would be Christmas.” I always enjoy that part.

headline: Building Blocs, Not Lofts
abstract: It was evident in two City Council districts in Brooklyn that New York’s immigrant communities helped shape the results of the primary elections.
lead_paragraph: During the Bloomberg era, which it now officially seems appropriate to talk about in the past tense, the term global city came into wide use to describe a New York not where strivers from around the world come to settle, but where the wealthy from London or Moscow or Mumbai merely pass through in a fever of luxury acquisition.

headline: Nonrent Fees for Bronx Tenants Are Focus of Advocates’ Report
keywords: ['Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Landlords', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Some Bronx landlords, nonprofit groups say, are using nonrent fees to drive up housing costs and push out longtime residents, a charge building owners dispute.
lead_paragraph: When Doris Attah complained about mold in her bathroom in 2010, the building manager came to take photos and noticed an air-conditioner in the living room. The manager snapped a photo of that, too.

headline: Lottery Numbers
abstract: Lottery numbers for Sept. 13 for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: The Payday at Twitter Many Were Waiting For
abstract: Twitter’s public offering will not be nearly as large as Facebook’s $16 billion offering, but it will still create dozens of multimillionaires.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — In June 2007, Evan Williams was looking for investors for a quirky Internet communications service called Twitter that he had co-founded.

headline: Ideas of Federal Panel on Long-Term Care Don’t Include Costs
keywords: ['Disabilities', 'Elderly', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Home Health Care', 'Long-Term Care Insurance', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: The federal Commission on Long-Term Care issued new recommendations on Friday, but stopped short of endorsing any new program to help families pay for services.
lead_paragraph: The federal Commission on Long-Term Care on Friday issued more than two dozen recommendations meant to bolster services for older Americans and people with disabilities, but stopped short of endorsing a new public or private program to help families pay for home health care, custodial care, assisted living or nursing home services.

headline: Season, if Not a Yankee Tenure, Ends With September
abstract: Brendan Ryan made his third start Friday in place of the injured Derek Jeter, who has vowed to return next season. But the Yankees could bring back Ryan if they like what they see.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — When he got the call to the pennant race on Tuesday, Brendan Ryan was studying a lineup. Not the batting order of the Houston Astros, the team his Seattle Mariners would be facing that night at Safeco Field. His fantasy football team.

headline: The Gibraltar Commute
abstract: A dispute among Spain, Britain and Gibraltar threatens an economic lifeline for Spaniards who work in the tiny territory.
lead_paragraph: A dispute among Spain, Britain and Gibraltar threatens an economic lifeline for Spaniards who work in the tiny territory.

headline: The Scourge of the South
keywords: ['Civil War (US) (1861-65)', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: Champ Ferguson was one of the Civil War’s most vicious war criminals.
lead_paragraph: At the end of the Civil War, our nation’s bloodiest struggle, only two men were tried and executed for war crimes. Both had served the Confederacy. One was Henry Wirz, commandant of the notorious prisoner-of-war camp at Andersonville, Ga.; the other was the guerrilla leader Champ Ferguson.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, September 14, 2013
abstract: Quotation of the day for Saturday, September 14, 2013.
lead_paragraph: “Everything has been a bad dream already. To have this happen, it hasn’t even hit me yet. This sums up how awful this year has been. It doesn’t get any worse than what it is right now.”

headline: Giants’ Amukamara Clears Tests and May Face Broncos
abstract: The cornerback, who left last Sunday’s loss to the Dallas Cowboys with a concussion, passed the N.F.L.-mandated concussion protocol of tests and evaluations.
lead_paragraph: Giants cornerback Prince Amukamara, who left last Sunday’s loss to the Dallas Cowboys with a concussion, was cleared to practice Friday and will probably play Sunday when the Giants face the Denver Broncos. The Giants said Amukamara had passed the N.F.L.-mandated concussion protocol of tests and evaluations. Coach Tom Coughlin said Amukamara would play, “barring any setbacks.”

headline: The Two Wills of the Heiress Huguette Clark
abstract: The relatives of Huguette Clark, who died in 2011 at 104, are contesting the disposition of her estimated $300 million estate after she executed a second will that excluded her family.
lead_paragraph: With flawless etiquette, every year from 1977 to 2010, Katherine Hall Friedman sent a Christmas card to the home of her distant relative Huguette Clark, a copper heiress whose father was once one of the richest men in America. She never got an answer.

headline: Filmmaker Giving Voice to Acts of Rage in Today’s China
abstract: Reports of ordinary Chinese being driven to violence persuaded the director Jia Zhangke to put aside his first big-budget martial arts film and tell their story instead.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — JIA ZHANGKE, China’s most prominent art house director, had been preparing to make his first big-budget martial arts film, set in dynastic China, when reality intruded in the form of the Internet.

headline: Corrections: September 14, 2013
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on September 14, 2013.
lead_paragraph: BUSINESS DAY

headline: Lets Go Through
abstract: A Saturday sizzler by Jeff Chen.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — To open a puzzle with PIZZA JOINT and then to admit that you are lactose-intolerant (see below) is tantamount to a tragedy, in my opinion. Poor Jeff Chen can’t enjoy a good slice without suffering, although I highly recommend the chain California Pizza Kitchen for some excellent low- to no-cheese pizzas.

headline: From Netscape to Twitter
abstract: Some Internet companies have become global behemoths. Others have traced the trajectories of shooting stars — going from concept to scrap heap in only a few years.
lead_paragraph: Some Internet companies have become global behemoths. Others have traced the trajectories of shooting stars — going from concept to scrap heap in only a few years.

headline: T Fall Men’s Fashion Issue
abstract: T’s fall Men’s Fashion issue is all about talent, so it’s only appropriate that the cover bears the ultimate multi-hyphenate performer, Justin Timberlake.
lead_paragraph: T’s fall Men’s Fashion issue is all about talent, so it’s only appropriate that the cover bears the ultimate multi-hyphenate performer — Justin Timberlake — who is reinventing the role of all-around entertainer for a new generation. But talent takes many specific forms: Jody Rosen interviews the English historian and novelist Peter Ackroyd, who is as prolific as he is erudite, and Mark Healy profiles the boundary-breaking artist Matthew Day Jackson, whose work explores the very boundaries it transcends. We hear from the handsome young actors Dane DeHaan and Jamie Dornan, who, each in their own way, are interested in deviating from the entertainment industry’s script. And the Tumblr founder, David Karp, takes you on a tour of his home, while Andrew Ross Sorkin waxes poetic about his $40 undershirts. See all from the issue >>

headline: Protest by Mexican Teachers Is Ended
keywords: ['Teachers and School Employees', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Education (K-12)']
abstract: The police moved to reclaim a historic square in Mexico City two days before the nation’s Independence Day celebration is to be held there.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — The federal police moved into this city’s historic central square on Friday to retake the space from thousands of teachers who had been occupying it for the past month to protest an overhaul of nation’s education policies.

headline: After Blaze, a Two-Carousel Boardwalk Comes Full Circle
abstract: A fire that tore through six blocks in Seaside Heights, N.J., on Thursday left the Boardwalk with just one carousel.
lead_paragraph: SEASIDE HEIGHTS, N.J. — In the beginning, there was a carousel.

headline: Coalition Governing Could Be Britain’s New Normal Despite Liberal Democrats’ Troubles
abstract: Before 2010, Britons had largely dismissed political alliances, like the Liberal Democrats’ coalition with the dominant Conservatives, as chaotic and messy.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Their poll ratings are terrible and their leader is widely mocked, but the Liberal Democrats, the traditional minnows of British politics, have chalked up one striking success: they have stayed part of a durable coalition government.

headline: Occupy Wall Street Legacy
abstract: Eventually, the 99 percent will demand better.
lead_paragraph: When Occupy Wall Street sprang up in parks and under tents, one of the many issues the protesters pressed was economic inequality. Then, as winter began to set in, the police swept the protesters away. All across the country the crowds thinned and enthusiasm waned, and eventually the movement all but dissipated.

headline: Mayoral Primary: Double-Checking Votes
abstract: In warehouses across New York City, election workers have begun the painstaking task of verifying the results from more than 5,000 lever machines.
lead_paragraph: In warehouses across New York City, election workers have begun the painstaking task of verifying the results from more than 5,000 lever machines.

headline: Girl’s Suicide Points to Rise in Apps Used by Cyberbullies
keywords: ['Bullies', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Social Media']
abstract: Rebecca Ann Sedwick, 12, leaped to her death from a platform at an abandoned cement plant near her home in Florida, in a case that highlights the growing use of cellphone apps for cyberbullying.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — The clues were buried in her bedroom. Before leaving for school on Monday morning, Rebecca Ann Sedwick had hidden her schoolbooks under a pile of clothes and left her cellphone behind, a rare lapse for a 12-year-old girl.

headline: Scorer’s Call: Rivera Gets Win, Not Save
abstract: After the Yankees’ victory Thursday in Baltimore, the official scorer at Camden Yards invoked a rule that allowed him to take the win away from an ineffective pitcher — here, Dave Robertson — and give it to another.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — As Mariano Rivera walked off the field in Baltimore on Thursday night, thinking he had just secured another save for the Yankees, he heard the public-address announcer call him the winning pitcher.

headline: Italy: Former C.I.A. Chief Requests Pardon for 2009 Rendition Conviction
abstract: A former C.I.A. station chief is seeking a pardon from Italy’s president for his 2009 kidnapping conviction in the “extraordinary rendition” of a Muslim cleric off the streets of Milan.
lead_paragraph: A former C.I.A. station chief is seeking a pardon from Italy’s president, Giorgio Napolitano, for his 2009 kidnapping conviction in the “extraordinary rendition” of a Muslim cleric off the streets of Milan. An Italian court convicted the former officer, Robert Seldon Lady, and 22 other American intelligence officials for a 2003 operation in which the cleric, Hassan Mustafa Osama Nasr, was swept up and turned over to the authorities in Egypt. The case brought international attention to the controversial Bush administration practice of abducting suspected Islamic terrorists and transporting them for interrogation in countries that allow torture. Mr. Lady was convicted in absentia. In July he was briefly arrested in Panama, before being released. He has said he was doing his duty in the global war on terrorism.

headline: Grand Slam Foils Yankees Again
abstract: Another big seventh-inning blast by Boston spoiled a comeback by the Yankees, who are battling for the second wild-card spot in the American League.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — On Sept. 6 in the Bronx, the Yankees were leading the Red Sox by four runs in the seventh inning until Mike Napoli hit a seventh-inning grand slam off Boone Logan that helped Boston win an emotionally draining game.

headline: A Wet and Deadly Month
abstract: Total rainfall so far this month is the highest monthly total ever seen in the Boulder area and includes 9.08 inches on Sept. 12 alone.
lead_paragraph: Total rainfall so far this month is the highest monthly total ever seen in the Boulder area and includes 9.08 inches on Sept. 12 alone.

headline: Administration Rejects Union Pleas on Health Law
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Organized Labor']
abstract: The decision denies federal tax credits to workers who receive health coverage under plans sponsored by more than one employer.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The federal government on Friday rejected pleas from labor unions for a dispensation from President Obama’s health care law.

headline: After the Delhi Gang Rape
abstract: The brutal rape of a young woman in New Delhi in December 2012 has led Indians to ask why women are so unsafe in public spaces. Daily travels are often filled with a sense of insecurity.
lead_paragraph: The brutal rape of a young woman in New Delhi in December 2012 has led Indians to ask why women are so unsafe in public spaces. Daily travels are often filled with a sense of insecurity.

headline: Boardwalk Businesses Destroyed by Jersey Shore Fire
abstract: An overview of the boardwalk area destroyed by fire in two Jersey shore towns.
lead_paragraph: An overview of the boardwalk area destroyed by fire in two Jersey shore towns.

headline: Feeling the Pain of the Fight for a Playoff Berth
abstract: David Robertson watched from the bullpen as the game slipped away from the Yankees, whose pitching staff has endured wear and tear.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — David Robertson knew he would not pitch for the Yankees on Friday, so he watched the first five innings against the Boston Red Sox on television in the stuffy visitors’ clubhouse at Fenway Park. After that, he said, he had to get out.

headline: What’s on Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (HBO) PARENTAL GUIDANCE (2012) Billy Crystal and Bette Midler star as Artie Decker, a recently canned minor-league baseball announcer, and his wife, Diane. Summoned to care for their three grandchildren, they prepare to take control, or rather, loosen the grip of the helicopter parents, played by Marisa Tomei and Tom Everett Scott (both above, with Mr. Crystal, left, and Kyle Harrison Breitkopf). The grandparents arrive with “inappropriate gifts (Artie gives out bobblehead figures of himself), life lessons and a hands-on parenting philosophy that encompasses criminal negligence and Dr. Spock-style common sense,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. “Does it work? You betcha. There are smiles and tears, love and affirmations, a few funny jokes and a lot of easy sentimentality.” But “while this may nominally be a family affair,” she added, “don’t be fooled for a second: this is Mr. Crystal’s show from opening to close, and he is not especially good about sharing.”

headline: U.S. and Russia Reach Deal to Destroy Syria’s Chemical Arms
keywords: ['ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT', 'United States International Relations', 'Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: The announcement by Secretary of State John Kerry and the Russian foreign minister, Sergey V. Lavrov, set the stage for one of the most challenging undertakings in the history of arms control.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The United States and Russia reached a sweeping agreement on Saturday that called for Syria’s arsenal of chemical weapons to be removed or destroyed by the middle of 2014 and indefinitely stalled the prospect of American airstrikes.

headline: Philippine Leaders Descend on Strife-Torn City as Hopes of Cease-Fire Fade
abstract: Top Philippine leaders discussed strategies Saturday for dealing with violence that has killed at least 55 people, displaced more than 62,000 and crippled a once peaceful trading enclave.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — Fighting intensified in the embattled southern Philippine city of Zamboanga on Saturday as hopes for a quick cease-fire with Muslim rebels evaporated amid some of the most serious violence to strike the troubled region in years.

headline: Radnor Hunt Concours Attracts Top-Shelf Samples of Automotive History
keywords: ['Antique and Classic Cars', 'ART DECO', 'Automobiles', 'Le Mans Auto Race']
abstract: Held outside Philadelphia last weekend, the Radnor Hunt Concours d’Elegance featured a rich assortment of racecars, Art Deco vehicles and motorcycles.
lead_paragraph: MALVERN, Pa. – Held each September in the Main Line horse country outside Philadelphia, the Radnor Hunt Concours d’EÉlégance ranks in the top 10 Concours-type car shows nationwide, according to its organizers. That’s surely a subjective measure, but the sheer number of entrants and spectators at the show, and the provenance of its cars and motorcycles, are nonetheless impressive.

headline: Connecting Hindu Gods and Humans
abstract: Manjari Sharma has been recreating elaborate tableaux of Hindu gods in a continuing project that recalls her childhood encounters with the divine.
lead_paragraph: Growing up in India, Manjari Sharma spent vacations with her parents experiencing the vivid sounds, sights and smells of Hindu temples throughout the country. She remembers all of her senses being engaged, and the anticipation of encountering paintings or statues of Hindu deities as she entered temples that were centuries or even millennia old.

headline: Snap Sketch | Cecilia Dean, Anna Dello Russo and the Stylistas of New York Fashion Week
abstract: The illustrator Damien Florébert Cuypers shares his impressions of the fashion set around New York City this week.

headline: London Fashion Week: J. JS Lee Spring/Summer 2014
abstract: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Louise Damgaard.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Louise Damgaard.

headline: Is Suburban Sprawl on Its Way Back?
abstract: Does the return of the housing market mean the return of suburban sprawl?
lead_paragraph: THIRTY miles from downtown Minneapolis is the small city of Otsego, defined by its proximity to two highways and its investment in two wastewater treatment plants. Its one grocery store is a SuperTarget. Its walkability score, on a scale of 1 to 100, is 3.

headline: Variety: Cryptic Crossword
abstract: A tricky cryptic crossword by Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — I’m a bit rusty, so it took me a while to get started on this one by Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon. But it’s like riding a bicycle: once I made my way through 14 Across’s easy CABARET for “Stripped inside a hipster nightclub” [that’s BARE inside CAT: CABARET], I was off and solving.

headline: Secret Society Dips Toe in City Politics, Prompting Lawsuit
keywords: ['Fraternities and Sororities', 'Elections', 'Voting and Voters', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Segregation', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Education (K-12)']
abstract: At the University of Alabama, a longtime political secret society has run into trouble after becoming involved in an off-campus election.
lead_paragraph: TUSCALOOSA, Ala. — The college students began arriving a little before lunch at Calvary Baptist Church, far more than usual for a local election. The poll workers knew immediately: the Machine was here.

headline: An Unassuming Stenson Leads a Summer Surge by Swedish Golfers
abstract: Led by Henrik Stenson, first in the European Tour’s Race to Dubai and the PGA Tour’s FedEx Cup standings, Swedish golfers, male and female, have surged.
lead_paragraph: LAKE FOREST, Ill. — In this year of the endless midsummer in Sweden, the country’s populace is dancing around the human maypole that is Henrik Stenson, reveling in the international golf success of a few of its own.

headline: But Where’s My Phoenix?
abstract: Some sudden stops are worse than others.
lead_paragraph: Olivier Accominotti and Barry Eichengreen look at the crisis in Europe, and tell us something new. I knew that it was best viewed as a balance-of-payments crisis, not a debt crisis — a case in which large capital inflows to Europe’s periphery suddenly went into reverse. What I didn’t know was that something quite similar happened in Europe from 1919 to 1933, with huge inflows to Austria, Hungary and Germany suddenly shifting to huge outflows, and with similarly disastrous results.

headline: Reshaping Brazil’s Retail Scene, Inspired by Vegas and Vanderbilt

lead_paragraph: FORT QU’APPELLE, Saskatchewan — From the tee box of the fourth hole, Mark McMorris could spot the small green hill in the distance where, as a young boy, he spent most of his winter weekends snowboarding. Mission Ridge Winter Park has 292 vertical feet of terrain. The stripe up the side was a new triple-chair lift, but it used to be a T-bar.

lead_paragraph: Updated | Sunday, 12:40 p.m. As my colleagues, Dan Frosch and Jack Healy reported, Colorado’s worst flooding in years has killed at least four people, washed away homes and roads and forced thousands of residents from Pueblo to Fort Collins to flee.

lead_paragraph: Readers suggest changes to how Medicare reimburses for care.

headline: Two-State Illusion
abstract: The idea of a state for Palestinians and one for Israelis is a fantasy that blinds us.
lead_paragraph: THE last three decades are littered with the carcasses of failed negotiating projects billed as the last chance for peace in Israel. All sides have been wedded to the notion that there must be two states, one Palestinian and one Israeli. For more than 30 years, experts and politicians have warned of a “point of no return.” Secretary of State John Kerry is merely the latest in a long line of well-meaning American diplomats wedded to an idea whose time is now past.

headline: When Complexity Is Free
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', '3-D Printers', 'Science and Technology', 'Research']
abstract: The world of work is changing. If you want to see some American exceptionalism, visit a research lab.
lead_paragraph: NISKAYUNA, N.Y. — IT’S easy to be depressed about America these days. We’ve got messes aplenty abroad and the Republican-dominated House of Representatives is totally paralyzed. Indeed, the G.O.P.-led House has become a small-minded, parochial place, where collaboration is considered treason, where science is considered a matter of opinion, where immigration is considered a threat, where every solution is a suboptimal compromise enacted at midnight and where every day we see proof of the theory that America is a country that was “designed by geniuses so that it could be run by idiots.”

headline: Identity Politics, in a Brand-New Form
abstract: After the mayoral primary, students of New York politics already pronounced identity politics dead. But is it?
lead_paragraph: ARGUABLY, New York’s identity politics peaked in 1945. That year, William O’Dwyer, the Democratic Party machine’s mayoral favorite, was Irish and from Brooklyn. Lazarus Joseph, the candidate for comptroller, was Jewish and from the Bronx. Party leaders balanced their citywide ticket with a candidate for City Council president by plucking the name of Vincent R. Impellitteri, an obscure legal secretary to a Manhattan judge, from the index to the official city directory.

headline: Civil Rights Justice on the Cheap
abstract: The 50th anniversary of a church in Birmingham, Ala., offered an opportunity for truth and reconciliation. But it has ended up a ceremonial affair.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — VICTIMS often absorb the shame that should belong to the perpetrators. For most of her 62 years, Sarah Collins Rudolph has confronted that misplaced emotion every time she looks in the mirror at a glass substitute for the eye she lost 50 years ago today, when members of the Ku Klux Klan bombed the 16th Street Baptist Church in Birmingham, Ala. The same ambulance (colored) that took young Sarah to the hospital subsequently transported the corpse of her 14-year-old sister, Addie Mae Collins, who perished along with three other girls. The morning’s Sunday school lesson was on “The Love That Forgives.”

headline: What War Means
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: When we talk about future interventions, we must own up to the heavy price some Americans paid in past ones.
lead_paragraph: IN the feverish debate about a strike against Syria, there was a phrase that rankled, a shorthand that shortchanged the potential consequences and costs of military engagement.

headline: The Delicate Handling of Images of War

abstract: The British photographer on pictures of skies and dead-animal sculptures.
lead_paragraph: John Rankin Waddell, known popularly as “Rankin,” is a British celebrity portrait and fashion photographer whose subjects have included Kevin Spacey, Kate Moss and the queen of England.

keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Biological and Chemical Warfare']
abstract: Americans are asking good questions about whether we should intervene in Syria. Here are some answers.
lead_paragraph: COLUMNY is often a kind of dodge ball, in which we avoid counterarguments and bluster past contrary views. So, since I’ve obviously offended many readers by supporting missile strikes on Syria if it doesn’t give up chemical weapons, let me try to confront directly your objections.

keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Biological and Chemical Warfare']
abstract: The Russian president, Vladimir Putin, savors his moment.
lead_paragraph: WHEN I came into my office, he was in my chair, feet up, shirt off, an AK-47 propped against the desk.

headline: My So-Called C.I.A. Life
abstract: C.I.A. Chief John Brennan explains the heavy mantle of protecting the homeland to the “Homeland” C.I.A. chief, Mandy Patinkin.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — CARRIE MATHISON may be banished from the fictional C.I.A. on “Homeland,” but she was welcomed with open arms at the real one on Monday.

headline: Caught in the Hipster Trap
abstract: Sneakers? Can’t wear them. Plaid? No way. Now, my new glasses are making me look like a slavish adopter of trends.
lead_paragraph: AFTER resisting for years, I finally gave in and began wearing glasses, mostly when I watch movies or drive (the rest of the time I go around in a tolerable fog). More upsetting than this small sign of physical decay was the acquaintance who took note of my newly bespectacled profile and said that I looked like a hipster. Mind you, the glasses are ordinary brown frames, not retro black. Architects would scoff. Yet I’d been linked to the tattooed, headphone-clad, hirsute rulers of youth culture, and insulted, because anyone who believes he is genuinely cool would never want to be called a hipster, that slavish adopter of trends.

headline: Not to Be, Um, Trifled With, Texas Guards Its Slogans
abstract: “Don’t Mess With Texas,” the trademarked slogan, has become something far bigger: an identity statement, and the state is touchy about who uses it and how.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Don’t mess with Texas. In fact, don’t even mess with “Don’t Mess With Texas.”

headline: Was Salinger Too Pure for This World?
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Writing and Writers', 'Movies']
abstract: Does genius justify exploitative, predatory behavior?
lead_paragraph: IN the 50 years since J.D. Salinger removed himself from the public eye and stopped publishing, he has been viewed — more accurately, worshiped — as the human embodiment of purity, a welcome antidote to phoniness. To many, he was a kind of god.

lead_paragraph: This interview with   Bob Moritz, chairman and senior partner of PricewaterhouseCoopers, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

abstract: Mr. Tripucka’s seven children were all athletes; his son Kelly was an all-American basketball player for the Fighting Irish.
lead_paragraph: Frank Tripucka, a star quarterback for Notre Dame’s unbeaten 1948 team and one of the leading passers in the early years of the American Football League with the Denver Broncos, died on Thursday in Woodland Park, N.J. He was 85.

headline: In Time, Big Numbers Stand Out as the Context Fades
abstract: If Alex Rodriguez were to play for the Yankees in 2014, he could reach an impressive number of statistical milestones.
lead_paragraph: What if Alex Rodriguez were allowed to play for the Yankees in 2014? What if, through maneuvering by his legal dream team, he avoided his 211-game drug suspension and got to pick up where he is leaving off in 2013, having regained his batting stroke and his confidence?

lead_paragraph: MARANELLO, Italy – On an extended visit to the home of Ferrari ahead of last weekend’s Italian Grand Prix at Monza, it hardly required a crystal ball to foresee the Ferrari grand prix team’s driver lineup for 2014.

headline: After a Financial Flood, Pipes Are Still Broken
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'United States Economy', 'Mortgage-Backed Securities']
abstract: Five years after the Lehman Brothers bankruptcy, the $4.6 trillion wholesale funding market — the plumbing of the financial system — is a big liability as it operates on trust.
lead_paragraph: IT’S been five years since the bankruptcy filing of Lehman Brothers set off the worst economic crisis in the United States since the Great Depression. With the perspective that distance provides, it’s worth asking: Is our financial system safer and sounder today than it was back then?

headline: Doing Business in Bangladesh
keywords: ['Rana Plaza Building Collapse, Bangladesh (2013)', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Editorials', 'Accidents and Safety']

lead_paragraph: The owner of a clothing factory in Dhaka, Bangladesh, was at New York University last week to meet with clothing industry executives, labor activists and American and European government officials to talk about the Bangladeshi garment industry, the world’s second-biggest exporter of clothes after China.

headline: Tips and Poverty
keywords: ['Restaurants', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Waiters and Waitresses', 'Tips and Tipping', 'Minimum Wage', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials']
abstract: The minimum wage for tipped workers has not been raised since 1991.
lead_paragraph: When The Times’s restaurant critic, Pete Wells, recently called tipping “irrational, outdated, ineffective, confusing, prone to abuse and sometimes discriminatory,” he was referring mainly to mid- to high-priced restaurants that are considering an end to the practice in favor of surcharges or service-included pricing.

headline: Celebrities With Their Hands Out
abstract: Celebrities have been showing up on Kickstarter, but that doesn’t mean smaller names will be lost in the crowd.
lead_paragraph: Since 2009 the crowdfunding Web site Kickstarter has matched artists and entrepreneurs struggling to finance creative projects with people on the Internet willing to contribute a little cash. The earliest adopters of the technology, on the pitching side, were small-time musicians, unestablished filmmakers and others with no clear access to capital.

headline: Birmingham Sunday
keywords: ['Bombs and Explosives', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Terrorism', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Editorials']
abstract: The city has planned a full day of remembrance to commemorate the deaths of four young girls: Addie Mae Collins, Denise McNair, Carole Robertson and Cynthia Wesley.
lead_paragraph: Nineteen sixty-three, the year of the March on Washington and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.’s greatest speech, was as pivotal in American history as 1863, the year of Gettysburg and the Emancipation Proclamation. It is easy, gazing backward, to see that year as a great milestone in an inexorable march toward justice and equality, from Emmett Till to Rosa Parks to Barack Obama.

headline: The Annual Republican Crisis
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Editorials', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Tea Party Movement']
abstract: Extremists on the right are ready to shut down government if they can’t cripple health reform.
lead_paragraph: The fiscal year is about to end, so the annual awakening of Tea Party Republicans in the House and Senate is about to begin. Most of the time they sit around and do virtually nothing but gripe (they have made the current Congress the least productive ever), but a new fiscal year finally gives them a chance to govern the only way they know how: by creating a false crisis in order to tear down a piece of the government.

headline: Russia Is Persuaded to Alter Statement to Call for Inclusion
abstract: The Olympic Truce, a good-will gesture that usually draws little notice or debate, caused an outcry at the United Nations when language drafted by Russia did not mention gay or transgender people.
lead_paragraph: Every two years, the United Nations adopts a resolution called the Olympic Truce, a perfunctory statement that invokes the ancient Greeks and celebrates friendly competition and “the cause of peace.”

headline: Ronald Coase, a Pragmatic Voice for Government’s Role
keywords: ['Economics (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'United States Economy', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: The late Nobel laureate was revered by free-market enthusiasts who saw his arguments as favoring limited government. But an economist says their perspective was mistaken.
lead_paragraph: THE Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science is not awarded posthumously. So I was relieved when my longtime intellectual hero, Ronald H. Coase, won it in 1991, just a few months before his 81st birthday.

headline: Athletes Send Fans a Video Challenge
abstract: Through an app called OverDog, athletes and fans can face off in online games, including Call of Duty, Madden and FIFA.
lead_paragraph: Ray Rice, the Baltimore Ravens running back, will take care of family matters at home at night, and then settle on the couch for some video gaming. Texts and calls will come in from teammates asking, “Who’s on Call of Duty?” The same ones who were yapping at him during practice want to yap some more on popular video games like Call of Duty, Madden and FIFA.

headline: On Campus, a Faculty Uprising Over Personal Data
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Privacy', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: Faculty members at Penn State University are objecting to an employee wellness plan that asks them to disclose medical and other personal information.
lead_paragraph: IMPROVING health while holding down health care costs is the kind of having-your-cake-and-eating-it combination that most people can get behind. In fact, both ideas are embedded in the Obama administration’s Affordable Care Act. But an uprising among faculty members at Pennsylvania State University over a new employee wellness plan is challenging at least some of the methods designed to achieve those aims.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Sept. 15
abstract: President Obama leads discussion on the crisis in Syria and the anniversary of the 2008 financial meltdown, which is also a topic for the former Treasury secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr.
lead_paragraph: President Obama leads the lineup on the Sunday talk shows this week, as he and others discuss the challenges in Syria and looming battles between the White House and Congress over the federal budget and his health care law.

headline: Embrace Your Age, and Conquer the World
abstract: As baby boomers grow older, they finally have the numbers to tackle popular misconceptions about older workers.
lead_paragraph: IN March, I celebrated my 60th birthday, which brought with it the expected mix of disbelief and angst. I got over the worst of it, thanks to three days of festivities and reassurance from kind friends. But soon I began to notice that I was avoiding mentioning my age around clients and colleagues.

headline: Sanchez Out for 8 Weeks So Shoulder Can Recover
abstract: The Jets placed quarterback Mark Sanchez on short-term injured reserve, a day after Coach Rex Ryan said he was “doing a great job in rehab.”
lead_paragraph: The Jets’ handling of quarterback Mark Sanchez’s shoulder injury took another curious turn Saturday when they placed him on short-term injured reserve, a move that will sideline him for the next eight weeks.

headline: Banana Republic’s President, From Choir to C-Suite
abstract: The global president of the clothing chain says he learned early on that a balance of creativity, analytics and leadership was vital to a fulfilling career.
lead_paragraph: I GREW up in Lafayette, Ind., the youngest of five in a family of modest means. I had big dreams and was ready to do the hard work to achieve them. My first job was in a busy ice cream store. I remember the owner saying, “If you can lean, you can clean.” I learned that there’s always something to do in a business, and that hard work is rewarded.

headline: Drawn Back From the Diamond, a Running Back Leads Stanford
abstract: Tyler Gaffney, a fifth-year senior, rushed for 132 yards and a touchdown and added a touchdown catch in Stanford’s victory against Army.
lead_paragraph: WEST POINT, N.Y. — A little more than a year ago, Stanford did not have Tyler Gaffney, and Gaffney did not want Stanford. He wanted baseball, not football. He wanted to play center field for the Pittsburgh Pirates.

headline: Russia Preparing Patrols of Arctic Shipping Lanes
abstract: The military said the regular patrols are meant to protect the thousands of miles of coastline suddenly open to other countries’ ships on a regular basis.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russia on Saturday announced an initiative to address climate change. But it had nothing to do with smokestacks.

headline: Mannings Spin More Than Spirals
abstract: Eli and Peyton Manning have collectively said nearly 15,000 words to the news media this week about Sunday’s Giants-Broncos game.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday, Eli and Peyton Manning oppose each other as starting quarterbacks for the third time when the Giants meet the Denver Broncos.

headline: Taste-Testing a Second Career, With a Mentor
abstract: Is that dream job all that it seems? Hire-a-mentor services want to help you decide — whether you want to become a coffeehouse owner, a D.J. or an Episcopal priest.
lead_paragraph: GOD, as we know, works in mysterious ways. Back in the spring of 2011, Gerry Owen, an assistant pastor at a megachurch in Garland, Tex., was reading through the comment cards that worshipers drop in a box at the back of the church after Sunday services. He came across a card from a worshiper who also happened to be the owner of Generator Coffee, the coffee shop where Mr. Owen, who is 55, and his second wife, Melissa, had married just several months before.

headline: A Hire-a-Mentor Sampler
abstract: A look at a few mentors who offer their advice to prospective career-switchers, via the PivotPlanet site.
lead_paragraph: PivotPlanet connects prospective career-switchers with experienced pros, who — by phone, by Skype, or in person — can tell them what their dream jobs are really like. Such advisers can be hired for all kinds of fields, including these:

headline: Readers Answer Me Answering Them
abstract: In my column, I try to tackle head-on reader concerns about Syria–and here’s your chance to push back.
lead_paragraph: My Sunday column is an attempt to answer reader objections to my take on Syria, which has outraged many of my readers. People tend to think of me as a dove because of my positions on Iraq, Afghanistan and Iran, and so they’re aghast that I’m fine with missile strikes on Syria if the chemical weapons deal falls apart. So this column is an attempt to address some of those specific concerns.

headline: Injuries Keep Piling Up; Yanks Fall Further Behind
abstract: The Yankees were forced to reconfigure their lineup with Alfonso Soriano scratched before the game with a thumb injury. The Red Sox then beat the Yankees for the fifth time in their last six games.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — The way the Boston Red Sox have been playing recently, especially against the Yankees, they do not need any extra help to win. But they got some just before the first pitch Saturday.

headline: 3 Democrats Say They Will Oppose Summers for Fed
abstract: Three key Democratic senators signaled in recent days that they would oppose the nomination of Lawrence H. Summers as chairman of the Federal Reserve.
lead_paragraph: Lawrence H. Summers’s prospects of becoming chairman of the Federal Reserve have become murkier since three key Democratic senators signaled in recent days that they would oppose his nomination.

headline: That Girl
abstract: Joe DiPietro introduces us to that girl.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — I’m going to preface this post by saying that I’m a big fan of Joe DiPietro’s puzzles, in particular this one, this one and, oh yes, this one.

headline: When Good Things Happen to Bad Ideas
abstract: About austerity and politics.
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Chait has a rather discouraging post to the effect that the opponents of austerity have won a decisive intellectual victory, and it has made no difference. Yes, I’d noticed.

headline: Heads They Win, Tails We Lose
abstract: Life as a failed plutocrat ain’t bad.
lead_paragraph: Many years ago MIT’s Andy Lo made a simple point (weirdly, I haven’t been able to track down the paper) about the distortion of incentives inherent in financial-industry compensation. Suppose you’re a hedge fund manager, getting 2 and 20 — fees of 2 percent of investors’ money, plus 20 percent of profits. What you want to do is load up on as much leverage as possible, and make high-risk, high return investments. This more or less guarantees that your fund will eventually go bust — but in the meantime you’ll have raked in huge personal earnings, and can walk away filthy rich from the wreckage.

headline: Lehman Brothers Goes to War
abstract: The storied investment bank that went under five years ago almost didn’t survive the Civil War.
lead_paragraph: The storied investment bank Lehman Brothers filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy in the early morning hours of Sept. 15, 2008. Overleveraged in vulnerable mortgage-backed securities and at the mercy of short sellers, Lehman’s shares had plummeted precipitously during the summer. Later efforts to sell the company failed when the chief executive, Dick Fuld, maintained too high a valuation of the firm even as the real estate chasm opened beneath it. Lehman would become one of several financial casualties of the global crisis of 2008, and it remains the single largest bankruptcy in American history.

headline: Proudly Private, a Wall Street Brokerage Firm Marches On
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Private Equity', 'September 11 (2001)']
abstract: The investment bank Sandler O’Neill, one of the last major private partnerships on Wall Street, also takes fewer risks than others in the industry.
lead_paragraph: On Wall Street, most bankers are paid a convoluted formula of cash and stock that’s determined by committee. At the boutique brokerage firm Sandler O’Neill, it’s old school: Everyone gets cash and one opinion matters most: Jimmy Dunne’s.

headline: Richard Nicoll: Spring 2014 RTW
abstract: London
lead_paragraph: London

headline: Lifelines for Poor Children
abstract: While education is a great equalizer of opportunity, American programs don’t start early enough. Nor do they produce the skills that matter most for personal and societal prosperity.
lead_paragraph: What’s missing in the current debate over economic inequality is enough serious discussion about investing in effective early childhood development from birth to age 5. This is not a big government boondoggle policy that would require a huge redistribution of wealth. Acting on it would, however, require us to rethink long-held notions of how we develop productive people and promote shared prosperity.

headline: Chemical Disarmament Amid Conflict
abstract: A chemical weapons plant in Al-Safira exemplifies the challenges of securing Syria’s stockpile, military experts say. While the plant remains under Syrian military control, rebels in the countryside harass the site and the roads leading to the town. The site is surrounded by rebel-held territory and areas of active conflict.
lead_paragraph: A chemical weapons plant in Al-Safira exemplifies the challenges of securing Syria’s stockpile, military experts say. While the plant remains under Syrian military control, rebels in the countryside harass the site and the roads leading to the town. The site is surrounded by rebel-held territory and areas of active conflict.

headline: Biden and Clinton: Friends With Awkward Twist
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The bond of affection and regard between the vice president and the former secretary of state is by all accounts genuine and of long standing, but it has also endured many strains.
lead_paragraph: In December 2011, pollsters working for President Obama’s re-election campaign asked voters in battleground states a question: Would you be more likely to vote for Mr. Obama if Hillary Rodham Clinton were to campaign for him?

headline: Christie Pledges Support for Fire-Ravaged Towns
abstract: Reprising his role after Hurricane Sandy, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey met with residents reeling from another disaster on the Shore.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Chris Christie, who garnered national attention one year ago as he raced up and down the Jersey Shore visiting areas ravaged by Hurricane Sandy, reprised that role on Saturday — but this time it was just two communities that were left reeling.

headline: Even if Federer’s Game Wanes, His Moneymaking Potential May Not
abstract: Roger Federer has long been the most popular player on the Tour, but how will his marketability fare when he is no longer an elite player?
lead_paragraph: Perhaps no sportsman alive has elicited such effusive testimonials as Roger Federer in the last few weeks. His poor summer, which included losses to players who would once have struggled to take a set off him, culminated in a fourth-round loss at the United States Open. Instead of playing for the title, he became a devoted fan of his Swiss countryman Stanislas Wawrinka, who reached the semifinals.

headline: The Risks and Rewards of Defying the Basics
abstract: The Bulgarian grandmaster Ivan Cheparinov ignored several principles of the game in a recent tournament, with widely different results.
lead_paragraph: There are certain basic principles that beginners are taught to follow: try to control the center of the board, develop pieces as quickly as possible, castle to get the king to safety, and protect your pieces. Players can get into trouble when these fundamentals are violated or forgotten.

headline: Harris County May Control Water Plans
abstract: When Texans go to the polls in November to consider $1.1 billion for water projects, Houston, relatively unaffected by drought, could account for one-third of the votes.
lead_paragraph: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

headline: An Ace Tries to Limit the Damage as Time Starts to Run Out
abstract: The Yankees need three more starts from C. C. Sabathia to be nothing like Saturday’s, when he looked tired and his pitches looked easy for the Red Sox to hit.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — C. C. Sabathia escaped the second inning on Saturday at Fenway Park, allowing one run and stranding two runners he had put on base with walks. With that, he reached 200 innings for the seventh season in a row. Soon enough, he also reached 13 losses, extending a career high.

headline: If History Is Any Measure, the Clock Is Ticking

abstract: Weapons experts and diplomats say that if President Bashar al-Assad is serious about giving up his arsenal, he will have to take dramatic action in the coming weeks.

headline: Amid Drought, a Water Fight Spills Into Legal Territory

headline: Syrian Opposition Group Elects New Prime Minister
abstract: Ahmad Tomeh ran unopposed and was said to be a consensus candidate accepted by a secular-leaning coalition within the Syrian National Council.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — The main Syrian opposition coalition on Saturday elected Ahmad Tomeh, a dentist and longtime dissident, to be the opposition’s provisional prime minister, in the group’s latest effort to improve its standing inside the country and attract greater support from foreign nations.

headline: Merkel's Moment in Germany
abstract: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany is running for a third and perhaps final term.
lead_paragraph: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany is running for a third and perhaps final term.

headline: A Campaign in Germany, an Influence Far Beyond It
abstract: Seeking a third term as chancellor, Angela Merkel is saying little about the future of Europe, while the rest of the world scours the election race for clues to her intentions.
lead_paragraph: RECKLINGHAUSEN, Germany — Angela Merkel shows up right on time outside the sun-splashed old town hall here. The 59-year-old chancellor works the crowd of 5,000, gives three or four waves from the stage, then settles in for local small talk and — despite hecklers — a 30-minute stump speech. She mixes folksy expressions with statistics and worldly observations, and assures listeners that their affairs, at home and farther afield, are safe in her hands.

headline: Amid Madness, Alabama Sticks to Its Method
abstract: The Crimson Tide machine overcame Johnny Manziel’s highlight-reel performance (562 total yards and 5 touchdowns), but Coach Nick Saban’s focus lingered on the schedule ahead.
lead_paragraph: COLLEGE STATION, Tex. — Johnny Manziel turned and scrambled backward, then turned again and scrambled farther backward, then eluded a defender and spun around and heaved a pass off his back foot toward, well, toward somewhere. The play was ridiculous, the toss reckless, so naturally, it went for a first down.

headline: Disabled Man Dies in a Fire in the Bronx

headline: In State Records, Little Evidence to Back Stricter Abortion Law

lead_paragraph: In their successful push this summer for strict new regulations on abortion facilities and the doctors performing them, proponents said the legislation was needed because conditions at existing facilities made it unsafe for women seeking to terminate pregnancies.

headline: Furyk Can’t Explain His 59, or Repeat It

headline: Robert F. Capon, Who Wrote of God and Food, Dies at 87

Capon, an Episcopal priest, author, theologian and food writer best known for “The Supper of the Lamb,” a sui generis book about cooking and metaphysics that has remained in print almost continuously since it was first published in 1969, died on Sept. 5 in Greenport, N.Y. He was 87.

headline: Maybe This Is Why Warhol Stuck to Soup Cans
keywords: ['Art', 'Trademarks and Trade Names', 'Traffic Signals and Signs']
abstract: Prada Marfa is an art installation, not a retail store, but the Texas Department of Transportation has declared it an “illegal outdoor advertising sign.”
lead_paragraph: Prada, the Italian luxury-goods house, has plenty of impressive stores — in Milan, Paris, around the world. But its most exclusive is a 15-foot-by-25-foot adobe building in the Chihuahuan desert, 35 miles northwest of Marfa. It contains six bags (without bottoms, to discourage theft), 20 shoes (the rights only, for the same reason), and hundreds of dead flies (thieves, help yourselves). Since opening in 2005, it has also drawn thousands of tourists, including, last summer, Beyoncé. She was not allowed entrance. This store is so exclusive that its door is always locked.
