headline: What’s on Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (13, 49) FOYLE’S WAR, SERIES VII: THE ETERNITY RING This “Masterpiece Mystery!” stalwart, starring Michael Kitchen as the tenacious detective Christopher Foyle and on hiatus since 2010, picks up in 1946, when one war has ended and a new one looms as the Iron Curtain falls across Europe. Foyle, now retired, has been recruited by the British intelligence agency MI5 and must investigate the possibility of a Soviet spy network in the heart of London. In the process he learns that his former driver, Sam (Honeysuckle Weeks, above, speaking to Mr. Kitchen), has been working for one of the suspects. “As a quiet man who makes a religion of honor, responsibility and competence, Mr. Kitchen gives a performance that is, by current standards, miraculously understated,” Mike Hale wrote in The New York Times. And though the series has advanced chronologically by only a year, “it’s a different world,” he said. “This grayer, chillier ‘Foyle’s War’ may not suit everyone, but it’s admirable, and a bit remarkable,” that its creator and writer Anthony Horowitz “has moved the show forward in a way that makes historical and dramatic sense. It wouldn’t work, of course, if Mr. Kitchen did not remain at the center, communicating an entire worldview in the way he says ‘Oh, I see’ or tells a weaselly major, ‘I’ve come to give you another opportunity to tell me the truth.’ ”

headline: In Wake of Syria Deal, Kerry Emphasizes Iran
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Nuclear Weapons']
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry sought to send the message that the deal to eliminate Syria’s chemical weapons did not signal a weakening of the Obama administration’s stance on Iran.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — In a whirlwind trip to allied capitals, Secretary of State John Kerry sought to send the message that the agreement struck Saturday to eliminate Syria’s chemical weapons did not signal a weakening of the Obama administration’s stance on Iran.

headline: The Blurred Lines of Song Ownership
abstract: Ben Ratliff and Larry Rohter discuss charged music-copyright developments surrounding both classic songs like “Money (That’s What I Want)" and current hits.
lead_paragraph: Ben Ratliff and Larry Rohter discuss charged music-copyright developments surrounding both classic songs like “Money (That’s What I Want)" and current hits.

headline: Popcast: ‘Money,’ ‘Y.M.C.A.’ and the Blurred Lines of Song Ownership
abstract: Ben Ratliff and Larry Rohter discuss charged music-copyright developments surrounding both classic songs like “Money (That’s What I Want)” and current hits.
lead_paragraph: This week, Larry Rohter, a culture reporter for The Times, talks to host Ben Ratliff about two potentially precedent-setting music-copyright cases in recent news, involving the bid to recapture rights by the authors of “Money (That’s What I Want)” and “Y.M.C.A.” They also discuss the matter of Robin Thicke vs. the heirs of Marvin Gaye over the rhythmic feel of “Blurred Lines” vis-à-vis “Got To Give It Up.”

headline: Settlement Leaves Fans at a Moral Crossroads
abstract: The recent settlement of a concussion lawsuit against the N.F.L. has put fans on a moral hot seat. Will they continue to watch a game that they know is damaging its players?
lead_paragraph: During the familiar drive to the Jets-Patriots showdown in Foxborough, Mass., on Thursday, I contemplated various ways out of a moral quandary: how to continue to cover these weekly N.F.L. spectacles, knowing that in 15 to 20 years some of the participants will probably be disabled, or worse.

headline: Disruptions: Minecraft, an Obsession and an Educational Tool
abstract: Teachers and parents are using Minecraft, a video game popular with children, to help teach science, history, languages and ethics.
lead_paragraph: If you were to walk into my sister’s house in Los Angeles, you’d hear a bit of yelling from time to time. “Luca! Get off Minecraft! Luca, are you on Minecraft again? Luca! Enough with the Minecraft!”

headline: Video of Helicopter Rescue Crews Airlifting 85 Schoolchildren to Safety
abstract: Trapped while on a field trip, 85 schoolchildren and their chaperones were among the hundreds of people evacuated by helicopter this weekend amid severe flooding.
lead_paragraph: Updated | 8:05 p.m. As my colleague, Jack Healy reported, heavy rain prevented military helicopters on Sunday from continuing efforts to airlift people to safety in the aftermath of the state’s worst flooding in years. Four people have been killed, two people are presumed dead and hundreds of others remain unaccounted for, meaning they have not communicated with friends or relatives, officials said.

headline: Paul Smith: Spring 2014 RTW
abstract: London
lead_paragraph: London

headline: ‘Insidious: Chapter 2’ Has Strong Start
abstract: The film sold an estimated $41.1 million in tickets at North American theaters over the weekend, one of the strongest results ever for a September release.
lead_paragraph: In a brute display of the continued box-office power of micro-budgeted horror movies, “Insidious: Chapter 2” (FilmDistrict) sold an estimated $41.1 million in tickets at North American theaters over the weekend, one of the strongest results ever for a September release. Blumhouse Productions spent about $5 million to make the movie, which was directed by James Wan and starred Rose Byrne and Patrick Wilson. To compare, the first “Insidious,” made for about $1.5 million and released in April 2011, took in $13.3 million over its first three days and went on to sell $97 million in tickets worldwide.

headline: Excerpt: 'Mr. Burns'
abstract: A scene from Anne Washburn's "Mr. Burns, a Post-Electric Play," at Playwrights Horizons.
lead_paragraph: A scene from Anne Washburn's "Mr. Burns, a Post-Electric Play," at Playwrights Horizons.

headline: Toronto Video: Errol Morris on ‘The Unknown Known’
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Toronto International Film Festival']
abstract: The documentary filmmaker Errol Morris discusses his film “The Unknown Known,” about the former secretary of defense Donald Rumsfeld.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — In his latest feature, the veteran documentary filmmaker Errol Morris points his camera at Donald Rumsfeld. “The Unknown Known” is a film-length interview with Mr. Rumsfeld, a longtime official in Washington who served as defense secretary under the George W. Bush administration. By asking difficult questions, Mr. Morris tries to gain a better understanding of the man and the decisions he made throughout his career. Mr. Morris brought the film here after it premiered in Venice, and in this video, he discusses why he decided not to interview others for the film and instead focused solely on his subject.

headline: Red Bulls Rewind: Alone in First Place
abstract: Saturday night’s 2-0 win against visiting Toronto put the Red Bulls into sole possession of the top spot in the Eastern Conference.
lead_paragraph: HARRISON, N.J. — In one aspect, the Red Bulls were on the road at home Saturday night against Toronto.

headline: ‘Murder for Two’ Finds a New Home
abstract: In the show, Brett Ryback plays a police officer investigating a murder, and Jeff Blumenkrantz portrays a collection of prime suspects.
lead_paragraph: The new musical comedy “Murder for Two,” which drew praise from theater critics this summer at Second Stage Uptown, will transfer to another Off Broadway space, New World Stages, with performances resuming Oct. 23, the producers announced on Sunday.

headline: Egypt Reports Gains Against Militants in Sinai
abstract: The army has taken the upper hand in a drive to rid Sinai of Islamist militants, repairing a “security collapse” after the revolution of January 2011, a spokesman said.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — A spokesman for the Egyptian military said Sunday that it had taken the upper hand in a two-month-old campaign to rid Sinai of Islamist militants, repairing a “security collapse” after the revolution of January 2011.

headline: Pontiac’s Rough Road to Recovery Could Foreshadow Detroit’s Path
abstract: The financially troubled city north of Detroit is no longer under the control of an emergency manager, but that does not mean elected officials are in charge.
lead_paragraph: PONTIAC, Mich. — When Gov. Rick Snyder declared this city’s financial crisis resolved last month, officially ending the tenure of the state-appointed emergency managers who have controlled it for four years, the elected municipal leaders thought they were getting their jobs back. But they may not be in charge anytime soon.

headline: Senior Pakistani General Is Killed in Insurgent Attack
abstract: The bombing, for which the Pakistani Taliban claimed responsibility, struck a vehicle carrying Maj. Gen. Sanaullah Khan Niazi as he returned from visiting troops.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — A senior Pakistani general was killed in an insurgent bombing in the northwest of the country on Sunday, bringing into sharp focus the government’s recent overtures toward the Taliban for peace talks.

headline: Mayweather Adds Flair as Promoter to Dominance in Ring
abstract: Floyd Mayweather Jr., 36, showed little signs of slowing against Saúl Álvarez, but he also seems to be embracing a potential life after boxing as a promoter.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — There was a time when Floyd Mayweather Jr. would strut into his postfight news conferences, declare his brilliance as a boxer and rave that no one could touch him.

headline: Mary Katrantzou: Spring 2014 RTW
abstract: London
lead_paragraph: London

headline: Japan Celebrates New Home Run King
abstract: The former major leaguer Wladimir Balentien, who plays for the Tokyo Yakult Swallows, hit his 56th homer, sending him past Sadaharu Oh, Tuffy Rhodes and Alex Cabrera.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — It was a day few thought would arrive. Japan’s single-season home run record had fallen — to a foreigner.

headline: Video Offers Glimpse of Syria’s War Through Eyes of Iranian Military Advisers
abstract: Footage of Iranian military advisers in Syria offers a rare glimpse of what the war in Syria looks like to these mostly unseen participants.
lead_paragraph: Iranian military advisers have reportedly been operating in Syria for some time, training forces loyal to Iran’s ally, President Bashar al-Assad. Until recently, however, there was little tangible evidence of their presence. That changed when Syrian rebels overran troops trained by Persian-speaking advisers and captured what looks like footage of the Iranians recorded by a cameraman embedded with their unit.

headline: At Frankfurt Automobile Show, the Driver Began to Take a Back Seat
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Frankfurt Auto Show', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects']
abstract: At the Frankfurt motor show last week, there was a palpable sense that technology for autonomous driving was moving quickly from laboratories to dealers.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — A wide grin beneath his bushy mustache, Dieter Zetsche, the chief executive of Daimler, did as car executives often do at auto shows, cruising onto the stage in the company’s newest model. But at the Frankfurt motor show last week, Mr. Zetsche added a surprise: he sprang from the back of a Mercedes S-Class that had no one in the driver’s seat.

headline: The Banality of Systemic Evil
keywords: ['Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Ethics (Personal)', 'Philosophy', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Whistle-Blowers']
abstract: A recent poll showed that 70 percent of people aged 18 to 34 thought Edward Snowden “did a good thing.” Has the younger generation lost its moral compass?
lead_paragraph: In recent months there has been a visible struggle in the media to come to grips with the leaking, whistle-blowing and hacktivism that has vexed the United States military and the private and government intelligence communities. This response has run the gamut. It has involved attempts to condemn, support, demonize, psychoanalyze and in some cases canonize figures like Aaron Swartz, Jeremy Hammond, Chelsea Manning and Edward Snowden.

headline: Summers Pulls Name From Consideration for Fed Chief
abstract: Facing growing opposition in Congress, Lawrence H. Summers, the former Treasury secretary and a top contender for Federal Reserve chairman, told President Obama that he didn’t want to be considered for the job.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For Lawrence H. Summers, President Obama’s preferred candidate to lead the Federal Reserve, the messy debate over a military attack in Syria was the final sign.

headline: Matthew Williamson: Spring 2014 RTW
abstract: London
lead_paragraph: London

headline: U.S. Has Strong Teams at World Bridge Championships in Bali
abstract: The United States has two teams in each of the three main events at the World Bridge Championships, and each will be among the favorites to win.
lead_paragraph: The World Bridge Championships start on Monday in Bali, Indonesia, and end on Sept. 29. The 12-hour time difference between Bali and New York will make watching the play live on Bridge Base Online (bridgebase.com) suitable for night owls.

headline: 3 Vie to Build Culture Center at Presidio in San Francisco
abstract: The Presidio in San Francisco must decide whether to approve a museum for illustration art, a shared center for local groups or an interactive-science building.
lead_paragraph: By 5 p.m. Monday, three proposals are expected at the office of the Presidio Trust in San Francisco. They come from the finalists competing for the chance to build what the trust calls a “cultural institution of distinction” on one of the most cherished bits of parkland in the country, a maximally scenic swath of green overlooking the bay and the Golden Gate Bridge.

headline: In Giving Petraeus an Honor, an Institution Gets Some Buzz
abstract: The New-York Historical Society plans to honor David H. Petraeus, a decision that has raised some eyebrows because of his past.
lead_paragraph: David H. Petraeus ended his first day as a visiting professor at the City University of New York last Monday listening to the shouts of protesters calling him a “murderer” and “war criminal” as he walked nearby down Central Park West. But that same day, just a few blocks away, the New-York Historical Society was notifying members that it planned to honor Mr. Petraeus at its black-tie gala in December.

headline: Still Shining and Spooked, but Hopeful
abstract: In “Doctor Sleep” Stephen King offers a sequel to “The Shining.”
lead_paragraph: In the author’s note that accompanies “Doctor Sleep,” Stephen King explains some of the obstacles he faced in writing this follow-up to “The Shining.”

headline: An Ichabod Crane With Backbone (but Can He Use an iPad?)
abstract: In “Sleepy Hollow,” a TV series beginning Monday on Fox, Ichabod Crane and the headless horseman are transported to the 21st century.
lead_paragraph: Is it a new entry in the fantasy-come-to-life genre, or is it making a play for the more than 10 million viewers who watched each episode of the History channel series “The Bible”?

headline: Make It Snappy
abstract: Humming along in this puzzle by Ed Sessa.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — We have a special set of puzzles for the first part of our solving week, and it’s always a pleasure to see how something as ordinary as a crossword puzzle can be used to help people. Will Shortz’s Westchester crossword tournament, for example, coming up on Friday, Sept. 27, raises money for the Pleasantville Learning Fund, and spots are still available if you are in the New York area. Walk-ins are perfectly welcome.

headline: K-Pop’s Antic Emissary Raids the Cupboard
abstract: “Coup D’Etat,” the new album from the K-Pop star G-Dragon, has America heavily on its mind and in its credits.
lead_paragraph: In the video for “Crooked,” the K-pop star G-Dragon — effortlessly lissome, his hair Warhol-white — does a lot of running, some staggering, some mean-mugging, some dancing and a little aggressive flirting.

headline: Binding the Sounds of the Earth
abstract: The composers Pauline Oliveros and Olivia Block, who have a propensity for unconventional sounds, shared a concert program at Issue Project Room in Downtown Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: In practical terms, the two compositions presented in a concert on Saturday night at Issue Project Room shared little common ground. Pauline Oliveros, in “Primordial/Lift,” engaged with a small ensemble in a lengthy process akin to collective meditation. Olivia Block, seated at a table filled with amplified gadgets and electronics for “Dissolution,” produced a discursive field of sound constantly in flux.

headline: In an Old Factory Space, Artists Make Festive New Statements
abstract: Basilica Soundscape, a two-day festival in Hudson, N.Y., featured music, literature and conceptual art.
lead_paragraph: HUDSON, N.Y. — I’m about to say some very nice things about Basilica Soundscape, the small-scale, big-idea music and art festival inside a beautiful converted factory here that had its second annual edition on Friday and Saturday nights. So one objection out front.

headline: Basilica Soundscape
abstract: Scenes from a two-day festival in Hudson, N.Y., that featured music, literature and conceptual art.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from a two-day festival in Hudson, N.Y., that featured music, literature and conceptual art.

headline: Where Choreography Can Be Thoroughly Intense or Wholly Nonexistent
abstract: The BEAT Festival hosted two dance artists, Yanira Castro and Storyboard P, at the Brooklyn Museum over the weekend.
lead_paragraph: Downtown Brooklyn is the hub for the BEAT Festival, a site-specific performance series that hosted two dance artists at the Brooklyn Museum over the weekend. It was more than a little random. Yanira Castro’s choreography is tight, contained and orderly; in “Nancy” she offered four interpretations of the same solo, which was inspired by Nancy Ellis, a longtime collaborator.

headline: A Descent Chronicled With Care
abstract: In “First Cousin Once Removed,” Alan Berliner looks at Edwin Honig’s life as Alzheimer’s took its toll.
lead_paragraph: “Recalling who I was, I see somebody else” begins a poem by Fernando Pessoa, quoted in Alan Berliner’s “First Cousin Once Removed.” In Mr. Berliner’s moving and mysterious documentary, the poet and translator Edwin Honig picks his way through his mind and memories in the falling shadow of Alzheimer’s. It’s the latest of Mr. Berliner’s dogged investigations into identity and family, and his strongest work yet, elevated by the presence of another artist in Mr. Honig, playfully insightful and eloquent even as his powers wane.

headline: Nomads Looking for Leftovers, the Precious Kind
abstract: In “Price of Gold,” filmmakers follow Mongolian nomads as they seek gold in the Gobi Desert.
lead_paragraph: Opens on Monday in Manhattan.

headline: Bavarian Voting Gives German Chancellor’s Re-election Hopes a Mixed Blessing
abstract: One week before the national election, Angela Merkel’s conservative allies won a majority in the state vote, but her liberal partners in the government had a disastrous showing.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Chancellor Angela Merkel got good and bad news on Sunday from Germany’s economically powerful state of Bavaria: her conservative allies captured an absolute majority in elections for the regional Parliament, but her current liberal partners in the national government failed to make the cut.

headline: 10-Book Deal for Terry Pratchett
abstract: Terry Pratchett, the best-selling fantasy author, has struck a 10-book deal with Doubleday and Anchor Books, the publisher said on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Terry Pratchett, the best-selling fantasy author, has struck a 10-book deal with Doubleday and Anchor Books, the publisher said on Sunday. The first book, “Raising Steam,” will be released in March as part of a seven-figure deal. Mr. Pratchett, whose books have sold more than 80 million copies, is known for his satirical series “Discworld.” Edward Kastenmeier, executive editor at Vintage Anchor, is the acquiring editor. “Terry’s work has a huge following and an enormous footprint in the fantasy world, as they were the first adopters of his enthralling, hilarious fiction,” Mr. Kastenmeier said. “With mainstream readers warming to the work of Neil Gaiman and George R. R. Martin, we see this as a crossover moment for Terry, an opportunity to expand his audience.”

headline: Will Woody Allen Show Up This Time?
abstract: Mr. Allen will be the recipient of the 2014 Cecil B. DeMille Lifetime Achievement Award, which is given annually during the Golden Globes in January.
lead_paragraph: The Hollywood Foreign Press Association has given Woody Allen another reason not to attend an awards ceremony, after it was announced that he would be the recipient of the 2014 Cecil B. DeMille Lifetime Achievement Award, which is given annually during the Golden Globes in January. Mr. Allen, 77, does not normally attend awards events: his most recent absence was during the 2012 awards season, when his film “Midnight in Paris,” won an Oscar and a Golden Globe for best screenplay. A tribute to Mr. Allen’s career will also be included in the live broadcast of the Golden Globes, scheduled for Jan. 12. The actress Jodie Foster received this year’s DeMille Award, giving a semi-confessional speech concerning privacy and Hollywood celebrity.

headline: Jonathan Saunders: Spring 2014 RTW
abstract: London
lead_paragraph: London

headline: Philippine Clashes Continue as Troops Set Sights on Muslim Rebels
abstract: Government forces pushed ahead in an offensive aimed at driving the militants out of communities outside Zamboanga, where they have been holding hostages since Monday.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — Government troops pushed ahead in an offensive aimed at driving Muslim rebels out of the poor coastal communities outside the southern city of Zamboanga, where they have been holding hostages since Monday. Officials said that nearly 100 rebels had been killed or captured.

headline: Ex-Champion Takes Solid Lead in Fight for Chess Title
abstract: Hou Yifan, 19, of China has a significant edge over the reigning world champion, Anna Ushenina, 28, of Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Hou Yifan, a Chinese grandmaster, may soon be the former and future queen of chess.

headline: Lands’ End Ad Campaign for Dress Shirts Salutes White-Collar Workers
abstract: In television commercials and online videos, real men describe their professions and laud Lands’ End dress shirts.
lead_paragraph: ADVERTISING for work clothes often features tradesmen, like recent marketing videos by Dickies showing workers outfitted in its clothing while forging knives and building hot rods, to highlight durability and fire-resistance. Now Lands’ End, a 50-year-old brand, is taking the unusual approach of promoting men’s dress shirts as work wear for jobs where the work is white-collar.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
abstract: A collection of pithy sayings about those brands you love to hate.
lead_paragraph: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

headline: News From the Advertising Industry
abstract: Account assignments, executive appointments and miscellaneous news from advertising agencies.
lead_paragraph: Accounts

headline: Lawrence H. Summers’s Letter to President Obama
abstract: Lawrence H. Summers pulled his name from consideration to become chairman of the Federal Reserve.
lead_paragraph: Lawrence H. Summers pulled his name from consideration to become chairman of the Federal Reserve.

headline: New Course for ‘Weekend Update,’ and All of ‘SNL’
abstract: Cecily Strong will become an anchor on the “Saturday Night Live” “Weekend Update” desk, and six performers will join the cast for this next season.
lead_paragraph: With his cast depleted of some of its most talented and most loved performers of recent vintage, Lorne Michaels had an exceptionally busy summer vacation from “Saturday Night Live,” the show he created and still produces.

headline: McIlroy’s Season, Full of Swings in Fortune, Ends on a Rainy and Positive Note
abstract: Rory McIlroy finished at seven-over 291 before pounding rain led to two lengthy suspensions at the BMW Championship, setting up a Monday finish.
lead_paragraph: LAKE FOREST, Ill. — Rory McIlroy’s 2013 PGA Tour finale was a microcosm of his year. In defense of his title at the BMW Championship, McIlroy opened with his worst 36-hole score of the season and closed with his first back-to-back rounds under 70.

headline: Vows: Joe and Thos
keywords: ['Weddings and Engagements', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: As the mayor of his hometown, Joseph Delorio was hesitant to come out of the closet as gay — until he fell in love with jazz singer Thos Shipley.
lead_paragraph: As the mayor of his hometown, Joseph Delorio was hesitant to come out of the closet as gay — until he fell in love with jazz singer Thos Shipley.

headline: The New Yorker Spruces Up a Stalwart of Print, Subtly
abstract: The magazine is updating a number of sections and redrawing its typeface, though the magazine says it will still be identifiable to longtime readers.
lead_paragraph: For decades, fans of The New Yorker have been drawn to its pages for its meticulous prose, its enterprising journalism and its predictable typeface and layout.

headline: How the Shooting Near Times Square Unfolded
abstract: Cellphone videos caught the final seconds of the confrontation Saturday night between the police and an apparently deranged man on a crowded street. Here is a schematic of the events depicted on the videos.
lead_paragraph: Cellphone videos caught the final seconds of the confrontation Saturday night between the police and an apparently deranged man on a crowded street. Here is a schematic of the events depicted on the videos.

headline: An Unusual Public Battle Over an Energy Nomination
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Coal', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Energy and Power']
abstract: Ronald J. Binz, nominated to lead the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, is opposed by the coal industry because of his efforts to promote renewable energy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The coal industry, feeling threatened by federal efforts to promote wind and solar power, has opened a counterattack by opposing President Obama’s nomination of a renewable electricity advocate to head the federal agency with jurisdiction over power lines.

headline: Freedom’s Just Another Word For Nothing Left To Lose
abstract: It’s a wonderful life.
lead_paragraph: So Larry Summers has withdrawn from the Fed race. No profound thoughts here, except that it’s really, really hard to see how Obama can justify not picking Janet Yellen at this point. Nobody else is as qualified; any other choice would look like spite.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
abstract: Bentley Motors has chosen a Minneapolis agency, Solve, to lead its marketing in the Americas.
lead_paragraph: Bentley Motors, Crewe, England, selected Solve, Minneapolis, as agency of record for North, Central and South America. Billings were not disclosed. Bentley had previously used work created in other countries for its marketing efforts in the Americas. Solve will work with another Minneapolis agency, Akquracy, which specializes in customer relationship management and database marketing. The assignment will include existing models as well as a sport utility vehicle that Bentley plans to introduce in 2016.

headline: Online Music Service Rdio in Deal With Cumulus
keywords: ['Music', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Radio']
abstract: The agreement will give an online outlet to Cumulus Media, which operates 525 radio stations, and help Rdio, a subscription music service, compete against players like Spotify.
lead_paragraph: As radio broadcasters go digital and online music services try to stand out in a crowded market, both are finding ways to scratch each other’s backs.

headline: What’s Needed in the Next Fed Chief
abstract: Whoever succeeds Ben Bernanke will need to be attentive and proactive in steering the economy away from bubbles and fostering full employment, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: Shrugging Off Allegations and Going About Business as Usual
abstract: In a season plagued by accusations of wrongdoing, many college football fans are simply turning a blind eye and enjoying the games, like Alabama’s victory over Texas A&M on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: COLLEGE STATION, Tex. — In the hours before Alabama clashed with Texas A&M on Saturday, overflow crowds clogged University Drive. The Dixie Chicken restaurant served its famous Death Burger. Patrons clad in crimson and maroon swayed to country music. (The best line: “My long hair just can’t cover up my redneck”).

headline: Reach of Turmoil in Egypt Extends Into Countryside
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Rural Areas']
abstract: In rural communities, where tradition has long been inviolable, the political crisis is tearing communities apart.
lead_paragraph: AGA, Egypt — Rami Abdel Aal’s body was gently washed and then wrapped tight in a white death shroud, all in accordance with Islamic mandates for preparing the dead for burial. But for Mr. Abdel Aal and his family, that is where ritual and tradition ended.

headline: Retailers Fight Exile From Gmail In-Boxes
abstract: Google introduced five new folders for its Gmail service over the summer, including one for promotions that puts retailers’ e-mail under a separate heading.
lead_paragraph: Even in an age of Twitter posts and Instagram photos, e-mail is still the way marketers reach the hearts — and wallets — of consumers. And that is why retailers are up in arms about Google’s latest tweak to Gmail.

headline: Newcomers Challenge Leadership in the House
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Tea Party Movement', 'Libertarianism (US Politics)']
abstract: Representative Justin Amash of Michigan is among the cadre of young, libertarian-leaning Republican House members who have repeatedly hijacked the party’s agenda.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative Justin Amash, a sophomore Republican from Michigan, is not one to mince words.

headline: Rebel Rifts on Island Confound Philippines
abstract: Despite a 2012 deal with the largest group of Muslim insurgents, factionalism complicates peace efforts on Mindanao, experts say.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — In August 2011, President Benigno S. Aquino III flew secretly to Tokyo to meet with the leader of the Philippines’ largest Muslim separatist group. The meeting, with the chairman of the Moro Islamic Liberation Front, Al Haj Murad Ebrahim, led to a landmark October 2012 framework agreement for peace.

headline: More Rain in Colorado Frustrates Rescue Efforts
abstract: After a week of record-breaking storms in Larimer and Boulder Counties, many people were still reported unaccounted for, but officials said they hoped those people had simply lost contact.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — Efforts to reach hundreds of people still stranded in the flooded mountains of Colorado ran headlong into another day of pelting rain on Sunday, the authorities said.

headline: Hollywood Wants Numbers on the Digital Box Office
abstract: As digital distribution takes off, some players in the film business are chafing about a lack of open information on how movies perform in on-demand channels.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The movie industry is whooshing toward its digital future, but some players are worried about getting stuck in an informational void along the way.

headline: A New Spider-Man on Broadway
abstract: Justin Matthew Sargent will be the next actor to don Spider-Man’s costume in the musical “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark.”
lead_paragraph: Justin Matthew Sargent will be the next actor to don Spider-Man’s costume on Broadway in the musical “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark,” the producers announced on Sunday.

headline: Storytelling Ads May Be Journalism’s New Peril
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'News and News Media', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Native advertising is advertising that wears the uniform of journalism, mimicking the storytelling aesthetic of the host site. Some say it could dilute the power of a brand over time.
lead_paragraph: When the guy who ruined the Internet with banner ads tells you that a new kind of advertising might destroy journalism, it tends to get your attention.

headline: As Deadline Nears, Taxi of Tomorrow Faces Court Fight and Reluctant Owners
abstract: Beginning Oct. 28, virtually every new non-hybrid taxi is required to be a Nissan NV200, an order dreaded by many fleet owners.
lead_paragraph: His green livery cabs finally patrol the streets outside Manhattan. His army of blue bicycles is well entrenched.

headline: In New Home, Wilson Continues to Push Boundaries
abstract: Reliever Brian Wilson is coming back from arm surgery as a member of the Dodgers after being let go by the Giants, the team he helped lead to a World Series title.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — When the baseball season began, Brian Wilson was far removed from the rituals that he had come to live by: batting practice, conditioning runs, group stretches, dominoes in the clubhouse and, often enough at the end of the workday, the opening of the bullpen gates.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week of Sept. 16
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Company Reports']
abstract: The financial markets will be awaiting the Federal Reserve’s decision this week on the future of its economic stimulus program.
lead_paragraph: The financial markets will be awaiting the Federal Reserve’s decision this week on the future of its economic stimulus program. The Federal Open Market Committee is meeting on Tuesday and Wednesday, and a decision is expected by many on Wall Street on when the central bank will begin winding down its purchases of $85 billion a month in Treasury and mortgage-backed securities and how quickly it will do so.

headline: A Befuddling Game Show Slides, Despite ‘Synergies’
abstract: A strategy known as “symphony” — in which NBC liberally salts its broadcasts with promotions — seems to have had little effect in drawing viewers to “The Million Second Quiz.”
lead_paragraph: Before NBC introduced the game show “The Million Second Quiz,” there were so many corporate cross-promotions — part of a Comcast strategy it calls “symphony” — that the NBC executive Paul Telegdy said “the symphony has graduated into a philharmonic.”

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
keywords: ['Credit and Debt', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'States (US)', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions']
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Thompson Still Dispensing Handshakes and Smiles
abstract: William C. Thompson Jr., still hoping for a runoff in the Democratic mayoral race, courted the public at the African-American Day Parade in Harlem.
lead_paragraph: He is still hopeful. And when you are a political aspirant and are still hopeful, you of course do the parades.

headline: White House Warns Against Threats of Debt Default
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'National Debt (US)']
abstract: The National Economic Council, advisers to the Obama administration, said in a report that Congressional tussles over raising the federal debt ceiling could harm the economy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Five years ago, the investment bank Lehman Brothers declared bankruptcy. The credit markets seized. The unemployment rate soared. Small and large financial institutions shook, and some fell, as the economy plunged into the deepest recession since the Great Depression.

headline: Lottery Numbers
abstract: Lottery numbers for Saturday, Sept. 14 for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: How to Fall in Love With Math
abstract: Contemplate the elegance of infinity. Don’t ask “When will I use this?”
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — EACH time I hear someone say, “Do the math,” I grit my teeth. Invariably a reference to something mundane like addition or multiplication, the phrase reinforces how little awareness there is about the breadth and scope of the subject, how so many people identify mathematics with just one element: arithmetic. Imagine, if you will, using, “Do the lit” as an exhortation to spell correctly.

headline: Vision for Speed on Display as Kiwis Inch Closer to Victory
abstract: Lead changes and speeds exceeding 40 knots downwind during an America’s Cup race on Sunday thrilled the crowd and the visionaries for this year’s race.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When Larry Ellison and Russell Coutts sketched out their vision of their new-age America’s Cup, the final draft must have looked very much like Sunday’s second race.

headline: Give Jobs a Chance
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Quantitative Easing', 'Interest Rates', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Unemployment']
abstract: It’s not time for the Federal Reserve to take its foot off the gas pedal.
lead_paragraph: This week the Federal Reserve’s Open Market Committee — the group of men and women who set U.S. monetary policy — will be holding its sixth meeting of 2013. At the meeting’s end, the committee is widely expected to announce the so-called “taper” — a slowing of the pace at which it buys long-term assets.

headline: Politico Plans for New York Are Drawing Some Doubt
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Some wonder if there is room in the city for another political and media Web site, even if it is made in the image of successful Politico.
lead_paragraph: Until last week, Capital New York was an obscure Web publication that covered New York City culture and politics with a handful of staff members. It produced long, thoughtful pieces on topics like the Metropolitan Opera and the finances of the New York Mets and had some media and political scoops, but it also struggled to pay freelancers on time and to get the credit the editors thought they deserved.

headline: Looking to Twitter to Reignite Tech I.P.O.’s
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Initial Public Offerings', 'Social Media', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: Now investors and deal makers hope that Twitter’s stock sale will help the once-soaring tech sector take flight again.
lead_paragraph: Beginning in 2011, the market for technology initial public offerings exploded with a number of blockbuster offerings — but went quiet soon after Facebook’s $16 billion stock sale last year.

headline: How Syria Media Advisers Decided Who Would Speak to President Assad
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'News and News Media', 'Public Relations and Publicity']
abstract: After Charlie Rose broadcast an hourlong talk with Bashar al-Assad on PBS, George Stephanopoulos of ABC was invited to do the same, but the rug was pulled out from under him.
lead_paragraph: Last Monday, ABC’s George Stephanopoulos got the call that virtually every journalist wanted to get this week. Come to Syria, he was told, and President Bashar al-Assad will talk to you about the country’s civil war and the West’s threats to attack.

headline: A Little Brother Learns a Lesson as the Giants Sputter to 0-2
abstract: Peyton Manning efficiently led a multifaceted, diverse offense in the Broncos’ victory as Eli Manning and a one-dimensional Giants offense sputtered and other components of the team failed.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — It was billed as the Manning Bowl, and halfway through the game, it was a mostly even, if desultory, duel between the quarterbacking brothers, Eli and Peyton.

headline: Progress on Predatory Lending
abstract: State efforts have curbed some payday loan abuses, but federal regulators should do more
lead_paragraph: Payday loans have long been huge financial traps for cash-strapped, low-income borrowers. Several states have tightened regulations to clamp down on these “quick fix” loans, which sometimes carry annual interest rates of 400 percent or more. But a lot more needs to be done, particularly since the federal Consumer Financial Protection Bureau has not yet formulated rules governing these loans.

headline: E-Smoking Among Teenagers
keywords: ['Smoking and Tobacco', 'Youth', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Editorials']
abstract: A survey shows a notable increase of electronic cigarettes in middle school and high school, making a strong case for regulation.
lead_paragraph: The case for regulating electronic cigarettes grew even stronger this month when the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported a notable increase in their use by high school and middle school students. A national survey found that the percentage of high school students who had ever smoked e-cigarettes jumped to 10 percent in 2012 from 4.7 percent in 2011; for middle school students (grades six to eight), the figure rose to 2.7 percent from 1.4 percent.

headline: Seeking the Riches of Gay Marriage
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Homosexuality', 'Editorials']
abstract: Eyeing a lucrative sales market, Mayor R. T. Rybak of Minneapolis is urging same-sex couples to wed in his city.
lead_paragraph: Fast as two people can say “I do,” Mayor R. T. Rybak of Minneapolis opened the doors of City Hall to gay couples on Aug. 1, just as the state’s new same-sex marriage law took effect. He married 46 couples that first day, couples who had been together a collective 734 years by their accounts. But that wasn’t bliss enough for the mayor, who began roaming the Midwest, inviting gay and lesbian couples in areas without legal same-sex marriage to visit his city and take the plunge.

headline: If You Like Music, There May Be a Ford in Your Future
abstract: “The Rider Challenge,” an online marketing campaign produced by Live Nation Entertainment, pits teams competing in Ford Fiestas.
lead_paragraph: As viewers get ready for another new television season, they are also being asked to look beyond the traditional sources for new series and watch shows online.

headline: Rivera Hoping This Send-Off Isn’t a Farewell
abstract: Mariano Rivera received a goodbye tribute from the Red Sox in Boston on Sunday, but he’d like to visit there as a player again.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Mariano Rivera has grown used to ceremonies in his farewell season. He got a surfboard in Oakland, a bicycle in San Diego, a gold record in Cleveland. The Dodgers gave him a fishing pole, the Rangers a cowboy hat and boots, the Twins a rocking chair made of broken bats. Rivera has collected several oversized checks for his foundation.

headline: The Syrian Pact
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Editorials']
abstract: Aiming to destroy chemical weapons, the process might open the way to a broader settlement.
lead_paragraph: The United States-Russian agreement to dismantle Syria’s chemical weapons arsenal is remarkably ambitious and offers a better chance of deterring this threat than the limited military strikes that President Obama was considering.

headline: Finding Love in Iowa, but Maybe Not Votes
abstract: At Senator Tom Harkin’s annual steak fry fund-raiser, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. might have unofficially kicked off a third presidential campaign, but Iowans are reluctant to support a bid.
lead_paragraph: INDIANOLA, Iowa — It was not difficult to find Iowa Democrats here on Sunday who just think the world of Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. But it was considerably harder to locate one at Senator Tom Harkin’s annual steak fry fund-raiser, where Mr. Biden gave the keynote address, who was willing to fully commit support to the vice president at what may have been the unofficial kickoff of his third presidential campaign.

headline: Stubborn Cycle of Runaways Becoming Prostitutes
keywords: ['Prostitution', 'Runaway Children', 'Sex Crimes', 'Children and Childhood', 'Homeless Persons', 'Teenagers and Adolescence']
abstract: With shelter beds for homeless youths scarce in New York, the problem of children trapped in prostitution remains intractable.
lead_paragraph: At the age of 14, Ann ran away from home. She had been living with her aunt and uncle in the South Bronx, a situation made untenable, she said, because she was frequently being raped by her cousin.

headline: The Missing Partner
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: If you really want peace in Syria, talk to Iran.
lead_paragraph: I sincerely hope Vladimir Putin, the Russian president, calculating showman (and now my fellow Op-ed writer), wants to play peacemaker in Syria. I’m skeptical of his intentions, as I wrote last week, and my skepticism was compounded when Putin began imposing preconditions for the surrender of Syria’s poison gas, starting with an American vow not to back up diplomacy with the threat of force. I look forward to being proved wrong.

headline: Rehabilitation or Surgery? Ligament’s Stability Is Key in Harvey’s Choice
abstract: Mets pitcher Matt Harvey, weighing his decision about the partially torn ulnar collateral ligament in his right elbow, is scheduled to see the orthopedic surgeon Dr. James Andrews on Monday for a second opinion.
lead_paragraph: About two years ago, David Aardsma faced a similar decision to what Matt Harvey does now. Aardsma had a 50 percent tear of his ulnar collateral ligament, and his doctor, Lewis A. Yocum, told him he could rehabilitate, continue to pitch and hope it held up, or have Tommy John surgery. Yocum, who died in May, said it was too close for him to call.

headline: In Gun Debate, Divide Grows as Both Sides Dig In for Battle
abstract: Losses have tempered the gains supporters of tougher gun laws have made, and now those on both sides of the debate are focusing on potential battles in at least six states.
lead_paragraph: The weeks after a gunman killed 20 schoolchildren in Newtown, Conn., were characterized by a new optimism about a goal that had seemed elusive for almost a decade: tougher gun laws. The shooting was called on more than one occasion “a game changer.”

headline: Stand Up, Survivors; Homer Is With You
abstract: “Mr. Burns, a Post-Electric Play,” by Anne Washburn at Playwrights Horizons, imagines a postdisaster world where the retelling of a “Simpsons” episode helps create security and culture.
lead_paragraph: When was the last time you met a new play that was so smart it made your head spin? Not in years, huh? Well, get ready to reel, New York. Anne Washburn’s downright brilliant “Mr. Burns, a Post-Electric Play” has arrived to leave you dizzy with the scope and dazzle of its ideas.

headline: Deal Represents Turn for Syria; Rebels Deflated
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The accord on chemical arms is seen as a major turning point by both sides in Syria, leaving the rebels deflated and government supporters jubilant.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Both sides in Syria’s civil war see the deal to dismantle President Bashar al-Assad’s chemical weapons stockpiles as a major turning point. It left rebels deflated and government supporters jubilant. And both sides say it means the United States knows Mr. Assad is not going anywhere anytime soon.

headline: Desperation Wins Out As Soriano Plays Hurt
abstract: One day after missing an important game because of his injury, Alfonso Soriano was doing everything he could to get back on the field at Fenway Park.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — About three hours before the Yankees took the field at Fenway Park on Sunday, Alfonso Soriano grabbed a bat and walked to the indoor batting cage underneath the left-field stands. He had a splint on his right thumb and tape wrapped around the splint. He then wedged a batting glove over the tape with a piece of gauze padding attached to the glove for added protection.

headline: Deadline Passes With No End to Orchestra Labor Dispute
abstract: As the scheduled season approaches, Minnesota Orchestra management and the locked-out musicians seem willing to continue negotiations.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — A deadline from management to settle a nearly yearlong lockout of the Minnesota Orchestra players expired on Sunday, but both sides appeared willing to continue negotiations.

headline: Trading Privilege for Privation, Family Hits a Nerve in South Africa
abstract: A white middle-class family’s decision to move to a poor black township for a month had many debating whether it was about empathy or slum tourism.
lead_paragraph: MAMELODI, South Africa — Regina Matshega was gossiping with a neighbor over a fence between their shacks in the Phomolong squatter camp last month when a very unexpected sight suddenly popped into view: two ruddy-cheeked white South Africans, a man and a woman, with two towheaded toddlers running at their heels.

headline: Labeled a Cheat, but He Has a Story
abstract: Don Ramos, who holds several weight-lifting world records for his age group, has had a Forrest Gumpian odyssey, 80 years of life that were nullified by one drug test.
lead_paragraph: COLORADO SPRINGS — Don Ramos is 80. His square jaw looks chiseled from rock, and his biceps, when flexed, looks as if it swallowed a softball. He holds several weight-lifting world records for his age group and can still lift more than 160 pounds off the ground and raise it over his head.

headline: Rituals of Retail’s Past, Kept Alive on Lower East Side in the Digital Era
abstract: With tag-team sales pitches and an online presence, Nick & Son Clothing is a throwback to the last century with an eye on the future.

lead_paragraph: A few months ago, an anonymous letter was sent to the board of directors of one of the city’s most venerable nonprofit institutions, the Metropolitan New York Council on Jewish Poverty.

headline: Marshall Berman, Philosopher Who Praised Marx and Modernism, Dies at 72

headline: Vietnam Legacy: Finding G.I. Fathers, and Children Left Behind
keywords: ['Veterans', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Parenting', 'Vietnam War', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: For veterans longing to salve the scars of an old war and their half-Vietnamese children wanting to know their roots, the need to find one another has become more urgent than ever.
lead_paragraph: SALTILLO, Miss. — Soon after he departed Vietnam in 1970, Specialist James Copeland received a letter from his Vietnamese girlfriend. She was pregnant, she wrote, and he was the father.

headline: Dick Newick, Sailboat Design Visionary, Dies at  87
abstract: Mr. Newick designed boats with two and three hulls that would beat conventional yachts in major races. The AC72 catamarans competing for the America’s Cup descend from concepts he helped develop.
lead_paragraph: Nathanael Greene Herreshoff, one of the greatest yacht designers, shocked the genteel sailing world in 1876 by entering a catamaran in the Centennial Regatta off Staten Island. He won easily. The New York Yacht Club gave him a certificate declaring his Amaryllis the world’s fastest boat, then it banned boats like it — with more than one hull — from competitions.

headline: Veterans and Vietnam Offspring Reach Out, Racing Time
keywords: ['Veterans', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Vietnam War']
abstract: There is an urgency to reunite as former servicemen age and the children they left behind grow ever more eager to know their American roots.
lead_paragraph: There is an urgency to reunite as former servicemen age and the children they left behind grow ever more eager to know their American roots.

headline: Brief Respite for President, but No Plan B on Syria
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Biological and Chemical Warfare']
abstract: The Russian-American deal to destroy Syria’s chemical weapons gives President Obama some breathing space, but the list of things that could still go wrong is daunting.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Russian-American deal to destroy Syria’s chemical weapons arsenal gives President Obama some breathing space after a politically damaging few weeks. But the list of things that could still go wrong is extensive and daunting.

headline: Lansing Lamont, Journalist and Historian of Atomic Bomb, Dies at 83

lead_paragraph: Lansing Lamont, a journalist who was credited with writing the first popular account of the building and testing of the atomic bombs used in the attacks on Hiroshima and Nagasaki, died on Sept. 3 in Manhattan. He was 83.

headline: At 41, American Cyclist Is Oldest Champion of Vuelta a España
keywords: ['Vuelta a Espana (Bicycle Race)', 'Cycling, Road', 'Bicycles and Bicycling']

lead_paragraph: MADRID — The American cyclist Chris Horner became the oldest champion of one of Europe’s grand tours, winning the Vuelta a España on Sunday a month before turning 42.

headline: U.S.C. Coach Has Support From Boss, if Not the Fans
abstract: U.S.C. Athletic Director Pat Haden reiterated his backing of Coach Lane Kiffin, who has been booed by restless crowds and has found himself in the middle of another controversy.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — When Southern California quarterback Cody Kessler took the first snap of the game, faked a handoff and launched not a bubble screen, but a long pass that landed just out of the reach of a diving Marqise Lee, the crowd at Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum rose and cheered.

headline: Lee Tanner, Jazz Performance Portraitist, Is Dead at 82
abstract: Mr. Tanner’s often ethereal images, which graced album covers, magazines, exhibitions and books, included subjects like Duke Ellington, Dizzy Gillespie and Thelonious Monk.
lead_paragraph: Lee Tanner, a photographer whose evocative and sometimes ethereal images of Duke Ellington, Dizzy Gillespie, Thelonious Monk and other stars of jazz helped define the genre visually on scores of album covers and in magazines, exhibitions and books, died on Sept. 7 in San Andreas, Calif. He was 82.

headline: A Much-Loved Family Business Meets Disaster Again on the Shore
keywords: ['Fires and Firefighters', 'Family Business', 'Ice Cream and Frozen Desserts', 'Hurricane Sandy (2012)']
abstract: Many landmarks of the Jersey Shore burned to ashes Thursday, including Kohr’s Frozen Custard, which had already endured the tremendous destruction wrought by Hurricane Sandy.
lead_paragraph: Fierce winds whipped the flames down the wooden Boardwalk in Seaside Heights, N.J., as firefighters struggled to control the blaze. When it was all over, more than 80 buildings across three blocks of Boardwalk lay destroyed, including a Jersey Shore institution called Kohr’s Frozen Custard.

headline: Jacobs Gets Into End Zone, but Giants’ Running Game Goes Nowhere
abstract: In his return to the Giants, Brandon Jacobs added to his franchise-record touchdown total. But he gained only 4 yards in his seven carries, a performance that underscored the team’s rushing woes.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — When Brandon Jacobs bulled into the end zone from a yard out late in the third quarter Sunday, he jumped to his feet and pounded his chest with all of the jubilation of a rookie who had scored his first touchdown.

headline: Day’s Best in the N.F.L.
abstract: The top performers and key injuries in Week 2 of the N.F.L. season.
lead_paragraph: Aaron Rodgers was sacked on consecutive plays on the Packers’ first series against the Redskins, and Green Bay had to settle for a field goal. Things looked shaky again on the team’s third series, but on fourth down at the Washington 35, Rodgers found Randall Cobb for a score and got the offense on track. He had 335 passing yards by halftime and finished with a career-high 480, as well as four touchdown passes.

headline: When Teams Lose, Fans Tackle Fatty Foods
abstract: Football fans’ saturated-fat consumption increased by as much as 28 percent following defeats and decreased by 16 percent following victories, a new study reports.
lead_paragraph: When Vinnie Richichi started watching the Pittsburgh Steelers’ home opener against the Tennessee Titans last Sunday, he was feeling great. After all, the Steelers had won their first home game six years in a row.

(Fox) BONES At the end of Season 8, the serial killer Christopher Pelant (Andrew Leeds) forced Special Agent Booth (David Boreanaz) to call off his engagement to Brennan (Emily Deschanel, above, with Mr. Boreanaz), but not tell her why. headline: Yanks’ Last Crack at Red Sox Leads Only to Dull Thud

lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Joe Girardi could barely disguise his anger. He has spent almost every day of a challenging season staunchly defending his players, whether it has been an embattled superstar like Alex Rodriguez or an unheralded rookie like David Adams.

lead_paragraph: JOLIET, Ill. — For the week leading up to the first race of the Chase for the Sprint Cup championship, Nascar ducked, dodged and answered questions about the sport’s integrity. The field for the Chase, a 10-race playoff, was changed twice after investigations into race manipulation by several teams during last weekend’s race in Richmond, Va.

headline: Frankfurt Motor Show: ‘Why Can’t I Have That?’

headline: Jointly Run Factory Park in North Korea Resumes Production
abstract: South Korean managers returned Monday to the Kaesong industrial complex in the latest sign of a thaw on the divided Korean Peninsula.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — In the latest sign of a thaw on the divided Korean Peninsula, hundreds of cars and trucks streamed across the border on Monday to take South Korean managers and raw materials back to a jointly operated industrial park in North Korea, where factories resumed production after a 166-day hiatus.

headline: Many Doubt Death Sentences Will Stem India Sexual Attacks
abstract: Many in India are still skeptical whether death sentences handed over to the four convicts in the Delhi gang rape case will stem further sexual violence in the country.
lead_paragraph: “There was no mistaking the whoop of joy that rose outside Saket District Court in New Delhi on Friday, when word got out that four men convicted in last December’s horrific gang rape and murder had been sentenced to death by hanging,” Ellen Barry and Betwa Sharma wrote in The New York Times.

headline: Female Afghan Police Commander Dies After Shooting

abstract: The outspoken lieutenant in southern Helmand Province was killed by gunmen on a motorcycle, the authorities said. It was the third such attack on a female officer since July.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — An outspoken female police commander in southern Helmand Province died Monday, a day after being shot by two gunmen, the authorities said. It was the third such attack on a female officer since July.

headline: Crews Right Cruise Ship in Waters Off Italy
abstract: The Costa Concordia, has been lying on its side off Giglio Island since it ran aground last year, killing 32 people.
lead_paragraph: GIGLIO, Italy — After a costly, painstaking and potentially perilous operation to raise the battered hull of the cruise ship Costa Concordia, engineers said early Tuesday that they had succeeded in righting the ship, removing it from two granite reefs where it ran aground last year, killing 32 people.
