headline: A Historian on a Film Set
keywords: ['ACTORS AND ACTRESSES', 'Books and Literature', 'Movies', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: A historian writes a Bollywood movie and explores the differences in non-fiction writing and filmmaking.
lead_paragraph: On July 28, I flew to Colombo, the capital of Sri Lanka, to join the filmmaker Anurag Kashyap,  the actors Ranbir Kapoor and Anushka Sharma, and a massive crew making the movie “Bombay  Velvet.” In 2004, drawing on my research on the history of Mumbai, I had written the outline for a retro film noir  aimed at capturing the momentous transformation of Mumbai’s milieu of jazz clubs and industrial society in the 1960s. I had seen and admired Mr. Kashyap’s first film, “Paanch,” a dark tale set in Mumbai that has never been released commercially but was screened at Princeton University. I told my story to him because he had a reputation as an independent-minded and talented scriptwriter and director. When I finished, he said, “Like James Ellroy! Great! We’ll make it.”

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Thousands Flee Rising Flood Waters
abstract: Why did thousands of people in Colorado have to evacuate their homes recently?
lead_paragraph: In the article “Colorado Floodwaters Force Thousands to Flee,” Daniel Frosch and Jack Healy write about the dangerous conditions caused by heavy rains.

headline: Everyday Nigeria — Not Idealized, Not Debased
abstract: A Nigerian writer has teamed up with photographers to provide words and pictures of daily life that challenge stereotypes about the country and the continent.
lead_paragraph: Helon Habila grew up in northern Nigeria and has written vividly about it, most recently in “Oil on Water,” a novel that explores the oil industry’s effects on the Niger Delta. A former newspaper editor as well, he now lives in Virginia and teaches at George Mason University.

headline: Does Keeping a Messy Desk Make People More Creative?
abstract: How does a tidy or messy work space affect creativity?
lead_paragraph: The environment where we do our work provides a glimpse into our creative process. Or does it?

headline: Jonathan Saunders: Turning the Fashion Page
abstract: This season, Jonathan Saunders departed from his well-composed outfits that occasionally bordered on the tastefully conventional.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — If you think of Jonathan Saunders as a freewheeling colorist, you’re in the right ballpark. But this season he departed from his well-composed outfits that occasionally bordered on the tastefully conventional. I liked this collection very much. Mr. Saunders opened his show on Sunday night at the Tate Modern museum with tricolor suede jackets over Western-cut, sheer embroidered blouses and satin shorts with sandals.

headline: L’Wren Scott: Leaving an Impression
abstract: Ms. Scott found a natural context for her fashion in Japanese folding screens from the late 16th century known as Tagasode.
lead_paragraph: In one way or another, clothes designed by women reflect their personalities and body types, but this seems especially true of L’Wren Scott, a former model and stylist. Season in, season out, she designs a long-legged pantsuit, a pencil skirt for a frilled blouse or one of her (widely copied) cardigans, a gown primed for snaking down red carpets. And prints have become a specialty, too. Her sense of femininity feels very self-contained, and so can be rattling to others. But it has become her signature look.

headline: Bavarian Voting Gives German Chancellor’s Re-election Hopes a Mixed Blessing
abstract: Seeking a third term as chancellor, Angela Merkel is saying little about the future of Europe, while the rest of the world scours the election race for clues to her intentions.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Chancellor Angela Merkel got good and bad news on Sunday from Germany’s economically powerful state of Bavaria: her conservative allies captured an absolute majority in elections for the regional Parliament, but her current liberal partners in the national government failed to make the cut.

headline: New York Today: Damn Yankees
abstract: What you need to know for Monday: dwindling playoff hopes, chilly rain ahead and questions following a Times Square police shooting.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 12:01 p.m. | Do the beaten, battered Yankees still stand a chance?

headline: British Agency Appoints New Chief to Oversee Bailout Investments
abstract: The British government agency in charge of managing the holdings in the country’s bailed-out banks has appointed James Leigh Pemberton, a former Credit Suisse banker, as its new chief executive.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The British government agency in charge of managing the holdings in the country’s bailed-out banks appointed a new chief executive on Monday to oversee the pending share sale in the part-nationalized firms.

headline: In London, Faith in Handmade Eyewear
abstract: Many top fashion names have called on Cutler and Gross to execute their designs because of the company’s skill in custom frames.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In an old church annex in northwest London, the walls of the Cutler & Gross offices are lined with colored eyewear that looks like fragments of stained-glass windows.

headline: Freeing Willy
abstract: After the 1993 hit movie “Free Willy,” activists and fans campaigned to release the movie’s star – a captive killer whale named Keiko — and launched a story Hollywood couldn’t invent.
lead_paragraph: After the 1993 hit movie “Free Willy,” activists and fans campaigned to release the movie’s star – a captive killer whale named Keiko — and launched a story Hollywood couldn’t invent.

headline: The Whale Who Would Not Be Freed
keywords: ['Whales and Whaling', 'AMUSEMENT AND THEME PARKS', 'Baby Boomers', 'ANIMALS', 'Fish and Other Marine Life']
abstract: This Retro Report video lays out the lavish attempt to release Keiko the killer whale, star of the 1993 film “Free Willy,” into the wild.
lead_paragraph: If there is a lesson in this week’s Retro Report video about a famous whale, it’s mess with nature at your own peril. In this case we are talking about the man-made peril that comes from confining a wild killer whale in a theme park and the economic peril of trying to recreate through nurture what, it turns out, can often be taught only through nature.

headline: Daily Report: Twitter I.P.O. May Set Stage for Resurgence in Tech Offerings
abstract: Investors and deal makers hope that Twitter will inspire the technology sector, which exploded beginning in 2011 but went quiet after Facebook’s $16 billion stock sale last year, once more into action.
lead_paragraph: Beginning in 2011, the market for technology initial public offerings exploded with a number of blockbuster offerings — but went quiet soon after Facebook’s $16 billion stock sale last year. Now, investors and deal makers are hoping that Twitter’s coming stock sale will help the once-soaring technology sector take flight again, Michael J. de la Merced and David Gelles report.

headline: South Korean Troops Kill Man Trying to Cross Border
abstract: A man dressed in civilian clothes was shot as he attempted to cross a river into North Korea.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — South Korean soldiers shot and killed a man who was making a rare attempt to enter North Korea from the South, the Defense Ministry said Monday.

headline: ‘I Did Not Want to Raise My Prices’
abstract: It took a personal bankruptcy to get David Geslak, founder of the Exercise Connection, to change his mind about his prices.
lead_paragraph: A couple of years ago, I was reading an article about a guy in his 30s, David Geslak, who had started a company in Chicago, Exercise Connection, that works with children who have autism. Reading the article, it became obvious to me that he must have his hands full, trying to teach, to develop programs and to give speeches while also building his business. In part because his mission is dear to me — I have a nephew who is on the autism spectrum — I decided to call him to see if I could offer any entrepreneurial advice.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Sept. 16, 2013
abstract: On Mondays we publish a New York Times photo without a caption, headline or other information about its origins. Join the conversation by posting about what you see, and why. Live moderation is offered from 9 a.m. to 3 p.m. Eastern
lead_paragraph: Update: Sept. 17, 2013

headline: Vaclav Havel Refused 1991 Nobel Peace Prize Nomination, Says Daw Aung San Suu Kyi
abstract: Vaclav Havel, the former Czech president whose potent critique of communist rule helped foment revolutions that brought down the Berlin Wall, never won the Nobel Peace Prize.
lead_paragraph: Vaclav Havel, the former Czech president whose potent critique of communist rule helped foment revolutions that brought down the Berlin Wall, never won the Nobel Peace Prize, a source of disappointment to his legion of ardent supporters who felt he deserved the prize given his outsize contribution to recent history.

headline: Roksanda Ilincic: Spring 2014 RTW
abstract: London
lead_paragraph: London

headline: London Fashion Week: Mary Katrantzou Spring/Summer 2014
abstract: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Louise Damgaard.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Louise Damgaard.

headline: Sherman Puts on Show as Seahawks Rout 49ers
abstract: Seattle’s defense was too much for Colin Kaepernick and San Francisco in a highly anticipated showdown of N.F.C. powers.
lead_paragraph: Right now, the Seahawks’ Richard Sherman is the best cornerback in football. Sherman, a third-year pro who also talks a good game, normally plays exclusively on the left outside. But Sunday night in a resounding 29-3 home victory against San Francisco, he frequently moved around to shadow Anquan Boldin, who was fresh off a 200-yard debut for the 49ers. Sherman held Boldin to one catch, which was as many as Sherman had himself (he celebrated the interception by dancing with cheerleaders and later patted his former coach at Stanford, Jim Harbaugh, on the behind).

headline: When Tech Turns Nouns Into Verbs
abstract: It started with smartphones that downloaded new operating systems, or became maps or cameras. Now cars, actual cameras, thermostats and computers are changing their look and functionality on a near-constant basis. We’re making a world where all objects change to create the experience of the moment.
lead_paragraph: We’re remaking the world so quickly that our language is breaking down.

headline: What Putin Doesn’t Have to Say About Syria
abstract: The master of double-speak is certain to sabotage the only measures that would give the chemical-disarmament project any hope of succeeding: a strong enforcement mechanism.
lead_paragraph: As he lay dying in a London hospital in November 2006, the Russian secret-police whistleblower Alexander Litvinenko dictated his final statement, addressed to President Vladimir Putin: “You have shown yourself to be as barbaric and ruthless as your most hostile critics have claimed. You have shown yourself to have no respect for life, liberty or any civilized value. You have shown yourself to be unworthy of your office, to be unworthy of the trust of civilized men and women.”

headline: U.S. and Allies Push for Strong U.N. Measure on Syria’s Arms
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: France and Britain joined Secretary of State John Kerry in warning Damascus of “consequences” if it delays disarmament.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Secretary of State John Kerry and the foreign ministers of France and Britain said on Monday that they would not tolerate delays in dismantling Syria’s chemical weapons and would press ahead with a strong resolution in the United Nations Security Council to enforce the disarmament plan.

headline: Hoping Twitter I.P.O. Leads to More
abstract: Investors and deal makers hope Twitter’s stock sale will help the market for tech I.P.O.’s take flight. | Lawrence H. Summers, President Obama’s preferred candidate to lead the Fed, pulled his name from consideration. | Sandler O’Neill is a throwback to a different era. | Some say a market in ethanol credits has been exploited.
lead_paragraph: LOOKING TO TWITTER TO REIGNITE TECH I.P.O.’S  |  Investors and deal makers are hoping that Twitter’s coming stock sale will help the market for technology initial public offerings take flight again, after a period of reduced activity in the wake of Facebook’s I.P.O., Michael J. de la Merced and David Gelles report in DealBook.

headline: Emmys Watch: Anna Chlumsky on ‘Veep’
abstract: Anna Chlumsky talks about her Emmy-nominated role on “Veep.”
lead_paragraph: In HBO’s “Veep,” Anna Chlumsky plays Amy Brookheimer, the chief of staff to Vice President Selina Meyer (Julia Louis-Dreyfus), who is often the lone voice of reason among a team of bumbling misfits. In this role, Ms. Chlumsky has shown a knack for the verbal sparring and quick wit that are essential to the political universe created by Armando Iannucci. She first displayed this touch in Mr. Iannucci’s 2009 film “In the Loop.” Now that dexterity has led to her first Emmy nomination, for supporting actress in a comedy series.

headline: Christopher Kane: Spring 2014 RTW
abstract: London
lead_paragraph: London

headline: London Fashion Week: Jonathan Saunders Spring/Summer 2014
abstract: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Columbine Goldsmith.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Columbine Goldsmith.

headline: In Front of Their Noses
abstract: On learning nothing from events.
lead_paragraph: Antonio Fatas, like me, is boggled by the OECD’s apparent inability even to contemplate the possibility that Europe’s poor economic performance is the result of fiscal austerity.

headline: Dueling in the Newspaper
abstract: So long as the superpowers duel in the newspaper, the prospects for both peace and the press would appear to have brightened.
lead_paragraph: Throughout my youth, the superpowers battled each other via proxies in regional wars or via their respective secret services. On Friday, I awoke to find them battling each other on your Views pages in the form of an article by President Vladimir Putin, “A plea for caution from Russia.” There will always be wars. And we’re likely to see more efforts to attain and deploy weapons of mass destruction. But, so long as the superpowers duel in the newspaper, the prospects for both peace and the press would appear to have brightened.

headline: Don’t Arm Syria’s Rebels
abstract: Our choice isn’t between bad and good, dictatorship and democracy; it’s between bad and worse.
lead_paragraph: In “That threat worked” (Sept. 13), Nicholas D. Kristof suggests a three-track strategy in Syria that includes expanded support of “moderate” rebels. That is precisely the wrong strategy. It is not in America’s interest to see a rebel victory, which will bring either Islamic militants to power or chaos.

headline: When Parents Need Nurturing
abstract: Many people feel a moral obligation to assist aging parents, which can leave adult children feeling overburdened and neglectful of their own families, personal needs and goals.
lead_paragraph: “Growing old is not for sissies.”

headline: The Political Economy of Bloombergism
abstract: New York is not America.
lead_paragraph: Via Mark Thoma, Daniel Little has a nice survey essay on Saskia Sassen’s concept of the global city (pdf). These are cities that concentrate high-level coordination functions for the global economy — finance, in particular — and exhibit extraordinary concentrations of wealth as a consequence. New York and London are the prime examples; Tokyo also shows up on Sassen’s list, although I’d say that it’s a lot less global than the others, thanks to the continuing insularity of Japanese culture. If I had to make a guess, I wouldn’t be surprised if Seoul, rather than Tokyo, ends up becoming the true global city of East Asia.

headline: Weather Grounds Copters in Colorado Rescue
abstract: Officials waited to get helicopters grounded by rain and fog back into the air to rescue hundreds of people who remain cut off by floodwaters.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — As rain continued to fall Monday along Colorado’s Front Range, officials waited for a clearing in the weather so National Guard helicopters grounded by rain and fog could resume searching for hundreds of people who remain cut off by floodwaters.

headline: Authorities Say No Radiation Leaked in Russian Sub Fire
keywords: ['Submarines and Submersibles', 'Nuclear Energy', 'Maritime Accidents and Safety']
abstract: Two nuclear reactors were aboard a submarine when it caught fire in Russia’s Far East early Monday, but they had been shut down before the fire started.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — A Russian nuclear submarine caught fire and was spewing smoke into the air at a port city in Russia’s Far East early Monday, but fire crews extinguished the blaze, and the authorities said no radiation leaked.

headline: Live Stream | Burberry Prorsum’s Spring 2014 Collection at London Fashion Week
abstract: The latest women’s collection from Burberry Prorsum at London fashion week.
lead_paragraph: The live stream has ended; there will be more coverage from Burberry Prorsum at London Fashion Week later today.

headline: Gunman and 12 Victims Killed in Shooting at D.C. Navy Yard
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Washington Navy Yard Shooting (2013)']
abstract: A former Navy reservist killed at least 12 people on Monday in a mass shooting at a naval office building in Washington, and then was killed by the police, officials said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A former Navy reservist killed at least 12 people on Monday in a mass shooting at a secure military facility that led the authorities to lock down part of the nation’s capital — even after the gunman was killed — in a hunt for two other armed men spotted by video cameras, officials said.

headline: Stocks Soar on Summers Withdrawal
abstract: Wall Street rallied as investors bet that the exit of Lawrence H. Summers as a candidate for chief of the Fed could mean a slower scaling back of monetary stimulus.
lead_paragraph: Stock and bond markets around the world jumped on Monday, after Lawrence H. Summers withdrew from consideration as chairman of the Federal Reserve.

headline: A Display of Democratic Unity as Thompson Cedes to de Blasio
abstract: After William C. Thompson Jr. exited the mayoral race, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and other Democratic leaders rallied around Bill de Blasio, who faced attacks from his Republican rival, Joseph J. Lhota.
lead_paragraph: Bill de Blasio, completing a stunning political turnaround, assumed the role of standard-bearer of New York City’s Democratic Party on Monday, as his last remaining primary rival exited the mayoral race and he turned his attention to a fight against a Republican opponent with a starkly different vision.

headline: Marios Schwab: Spring 2014 RTW
abstract: London
lead_paragraph: London

headline: An Ecologist Explains His Contested View of Planetary Limits
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Biodiversity', 'Earth', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Factory Farming', 'Global Warming', 'Planets', 'Sustainable Living']
abstract: An embattled ecologist defends his upbeat view of a human-dominated Earth.
lead_paragraph: It’s no surprise that Erle C. Ellis, an ecologist at the University of Maryland, Baltimore County, faced resistance when The Times published his Op-Ed article titled “Overpopulation is Not the Problem.” After all, his views clash with decades of assertions that we’re in “overshoot” as a species, sucking up far more resources than the planet can continue to offer. His answer to my enduring question here — “Which Comes First, Peak Everything or Peak us?” — is the latter. We are different than bacteria on agar, he contends.

headline: Grand Theft Auto V Is a Return to the Comedy of Violence
abstract: Grand Theft Auto V involves three main characters with less soul searching on their minds than their predecessor had.
lead_paragraph: As video game players have gotten older, as antiheroes have become routine across the culture, as sex and violence have permeated prestige television, the controversies that once surrounded the Grand Theft Auto games have begun to seem like sepia-toned oddities from another age. Sure, the new installment, to be released on Tuesday, contains plenty that might offend those who enjoy taking offense, and it is still disturbing to see parents giving these games to preteenage children. Among the interactive pastimes Grand Theft Auto offers — alongside pursuits like yoga, sky diving, tennis, scuba and golf — are bong hits and lap dances.

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Jennifer Kahn on Emotional-Intelligence Education
abstract: The writer discusses the questions raised by a seductive theory.
lead_paragraph: Jennifer Kahn, a contributing writer for the magazine, wrote this week’s cover story on teaching emotional intelligence at school. She last wrote for the magazine on pre-psychopathic children.

headline: KPN Books Loss on Sale of German Unit
abstract: The Dutch cellphone operator KPN announced on Monday that it would book a $4.9 billion loss on the sale of its German unit E-Plus to the Spanish giant Telefónica, possibly making KPN more valuable to América Móvil, which is seeking to acquire it.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The Dutch cellphone operator KPN announced on Monday that it would book a loss of 3.7 billion euros, or $4.9 billion, on the sale of its German unit E-Plus to the Spanish giant Telefónica.

headline: Erdem: Spring 2014 RTW
abstract: London
lead_paragraph: London

headline: A Conversation With: Hollywood Producer Ashok Amritraj
abstract: Ashok Amritraj, the tennis player who turned Hollywood producer three decades ago, on his journey from Chennai, Tamil Nadu to Hollywood.
lead_paragraph: Ashok Amritraj was born in Chennai, Tamil Nadu into a family of tennis players. He went on to play the Wimbledon and the U.S. Open championship, but his passion for cinema found him a second career. He began producing Hollywood movies in 1984, and has more than a hundred movies to his credit.

headline: Behavior Therapy Aids Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder
keywords: ['ANTIDEPRESSANTS', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Therapy and Rehabilitation']
abstract: Adding cognitive behavioral therapy may be more effective than an antipsychotic drug for treating obsessive-compulsive disorder, a new study found.
lead_paragraph: Five antidepressant drugs are approved by the Food and Drug Administration for treating obsessive-compulsive disorder. But they are sometimes ineffective, and guidelines suggest adding an antipsychotic drug to the regimen. Now scientists have found that adding cognitive behavioral therapy, or C.B.T., may be more effective than an antipsychotic.

headline: How Does Hurricane Sandy Affect Your Life Today?
abstract: Have you struggled financially after property damage? Have you been forced to relocate? The Times wants to hear your stories.
lead_paragraph: The lights turned back on, the floodwaters receded, and many people whose lives were disrupted by Hurricane Sandy were eventually able to return to normalcy.

headline: Today in Small Business: Frauds and Cyberattacks
abstract: Another blow to dozens of businesses on the Jersey Shore. Updates on the looming financial crises. And a Home Depot wedding proposal.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: A Bahraini Activist’s Message From Prison
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Political Prisoners']
abstract: Zainab al-Khawaja, an opposition activist in Bahrain who charted the uprising there on her Twitter feed until she was detained this year, has sent an audio message to supporters from prison.
lead_paragraph: Zainab al-Khawaja, an opposition activist in Bahrain who charted the uprising in the country on her @AngryArabiya Twitter feed until she was detained this year, has sent an audio message to her supporters from prison.

headline: The iPhone 5C and the Allure of Shownership
abstract: For better or worse, getting Apple’s new line of iPhones isn’t just about ownership — it’s about inspiring desire and jealousy in those around you that you’ve got the latest device.
lead_paragraph: When Apple introduced its less expensive version of the iPhone last week, many techies and tech followers — including me — groaned and poked fun at the shiny, toy-like designs. To me, the candy-colored bodies looked like a cheap marketing gimmick, a lazy throwback to iBook laptops from a decade or so ago. It seemed like a drastic diversion from the minimalistic, streamlined look that has become the norm for Apple’s current line of hardware products. I thought no one would want to buy them.

headline: 5 Years After Financial Collapse, Obama Says House G.O.P. Could Reverse Gains
abstract: The president warned that House Republicans would reverse the gains made and willfully cause “economic chaos” with their uncompromising stands on looming budget deadlines.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Monday seized on the fifth anniversary of the 2008 financial collapse to warn that House Republicans would reverse the gains made and willfully cause “economic chaos” with the uncompromising stands they have staked out on looming budget deadlines.

headline: Forensic Details in U.N. Report Point to Assad’s Use of Gas
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: The report provided incriminating new evidence of Syrian government culpability in the Aug. 21 attack, in which banned chemical weapons were used.
lead_paragraph: A United Nations report released on Monday confirmed that a deadly chemical arms attack caused a mass killing in Syria last month and for the first time provided extensive forensic details of the weapons used, which strongly implicated the Syrian government.

headline: A Look Back at Thompson’s Candidacy
abstract: William C. Thompson Jr. ended his campaign for the Democratic nomination for mayor, closing the latest chapter of a long political career in New York City.
lead_paragraph: William C. Thompson Jr. ended his campaign for the Democratic nomination for mayor, closing the latest chapter of a long political career in New York City.

headline: Since Lehman’s Collapse, Companies More Forthcoming on Compliance
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Securities and Commodities Violations']
abstract: Since the collapse of Lehman Brothers, companies are committing a lot more time, money and resources to comply with a host of regulatory requirements.
lead_paragraph: In the five years since Lehman Brothers filed for bankruptcy, Wall Street and regulators have had plenty of time to reflect on what could – and should — have been done.

headline: Shalom Yoran, Jewish Resistance Fighter, Dies at 88
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: Mr. Yoran and his brother escaped their occupied town in Poland, days before their parents were killed, to wreak vengeance on the Nazis.
lead_paragraph: For three years, Shalom Yoran survived the German occupation of Poland even as he saw his fellow Jews slaughtered by the Nazis. When he and his family inevitably became targets themselves, his mother knew she would not escape.

headline: Barclays Faces Fine in Qatar Deal
keywords: ['Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis']
abstract: Barclays said on Monday that Britain’s financial regulator had concluded the bank acted “recklessly” when it raised emergency money from Qatari investors during the financial crisis and could be fined $79 million.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Barclays said on Monday that Britain’s financial regulator had concluded the bank acted “recklessly” when it raised emergency money from Qatari investors during the financial crisis and could be fined $79 million.

headline: Robert Torrence’s Lights Out
abstract: Can you press the correct series of buttons to create Lights Out?
lead_paragraph: This week’s challenge was created by Robert Torrence, who is an undergraduate math major at The College of William and Mary. The challenge involves turning off a network of connected lights. As the network becomes more complicated, the game becomes very difficult — but Mr. Torrence recently discovered a simple strategy for winning these more complicated games. Mr. Torrence will share this winning strategy with us on Friday, but before he does — can you figure it out?

headline: A Young Fan Dies of an Apparent Overdose at Music Festival in Australia
abstract: The 23-year-old man is the latest in a string of drug-related injuries that have marred dance festivals this year.
lead_paragraph: A 23-year-old man died and at least 14 others were suspected to have overdosed on drugs at a dance music festival near Sydney, Australia, over the weekend, the latest in a string of drug-related injuries that have marred the growing dance craze this year.

headline: Weekend Gun Report: September 13-15, 2013
abstract: A weekend in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: This week, the California State Assembly is set to vote on a measure requiring anyone who wants to purchase ammunition to obtain a permit requiring that they pass a background check. Similar bills have been proposed—then-Governor Arnold Schwarzenegger even signed an ammunition control bill into law in 2007, only for it to be stymied on appeal—but have failed, thanks to the National Rifle Association’s financial backing. State Senator Kevin de León, who represents areas of Los Angeles, points out that a criminal can walk into a Big 5 or Wal-Mart and purchase ammunition, no questions asked. In fact, it’s easier to purchase a pallet of ammunition in California than a pack of cigarettes or allergy medicine.

headline: Questions Swirl After Summers Drops Out of Consideration for Fed
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Economists and pundits weighed in on the news, and on social media, about the president’s next move.
lead_paragraph: With Lawrence H. Summers having withdrawn from consideration to lead the Federal Reserve, Wall Street and Washington are analyzing possible outcomes and trying to prepare for what’s next.

headline: Burberry Prorsum: Spring 2014 RTW
abstract: London
lead_paragraph: London

headline: Anthony Vows Allegiance to Knicks, but Things Change
abstract: “I’m not going nowhere,” Carmelo Anthony said in a recent television interview. But the specter of his free agency will shadow the Knicks all season.
lead_paragraph: The question was about the future, and Carmelo Anthony responded with four words of practiced reassurance.

headline: Box Adds Document Writing to Its Cloud
abstract: Box, the online storage service, has announced it is getting into the content-creation business. The first product is a stripped-down, word-processing program. If you miss the bells and whistles of Microsoft Word, you may also be missing the new aesthetic — build it to work quickly, from anywhere, with sharing.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft just got another little kick in the shins from the world of cloud-computing software.

headline: Full Text of U.N. Report on Chemical Attack in Syria
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Rockets armed with the banned chemical nerve agent sarin were used in an Aug. 21 mass killing near Damascus, United Nations chemical weapons inspectors reported Monday.
lead_paragraph: Last Updated, 3:52 p.m. | As my colleagues Rick Gladstone and Nick Cumming-Bruce report, rockets armed with the banned chemical nerve agent sarin were used in an Aug. 21 mass killing near Damascus, United Nations chemical weapons inspectors reported Monday.

headline: Updates From Washington Navy Yard Shootings
keywords: ['Military Bases and Installations', 'Washington Navy Yard Shooting (2013)']
abstract: Live updates on the shootings at a naval headquarters in Washington that killed 13 people, including the gunman and a police officer.
lead_paragraph: As our colleagues reported, 13 people were killed, including a gunman, at the Washington Navy Yard on Monday. At least three others were seriously injured. F.B.I. officials have identified the gunman as Aaron Alexis, 34, a former full-time Navy reservist working as a defense contractor on information technology projects.

headline: Image of the Day: September 16
abstract: Onam being celebrated by young women in Bangalore, Karnataka.

headline: Antibiotic-Resistant Infections Lead to 23,000 Deaths a Year, C.D.C. Finds
abstract: At least two million people also fall ill each year, officials found in research that was the first to quantify a growing public health problem.
lead_paragraph: Federal health officials reported Monday that at least two million Americans fall ill from antibiotic-resistant bacteria every year and that at least 23,000 die from those infections, putting a hard number on a growing public health threat. It was the first time that federal authorities quantified the effects of organisms that many antibiotics are powerless to fight.

headline: Britain Sells Stake in Lloyds for $5.1 Billion
abstract: Britain has sold a 6 percent stake of Lloyds Banking Group stock for $5.1 billion, which reduces the government holding in the firm to 33 percent.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 3:43 a.m. | The British government raised £3.2 billion, or $5.1 billion, on Tuesday after it sold part of its stake in the Lloyds Banking Group.

headline: 3-D Printed Gun Goes on Display at London Museum
abstract: A pistol made entirely of parts built with a 3-D printer is now on display at the Victoria and Albert Museum as part of its permanent collection.
lead_paragraph: The first functional gun created entirely with a 3-D printer has become more than an object of curiosity and outrage: two prototypes of the weapon and one disassembled gun are now on display at the Victoria and Albert Museum in London.

headline: A Snowboarder From the Prairie
abstract: Images of Mark McMorris, 19, the favorite to win the gold medal in the inaugural Olympic snowboarding slopestyle event.
lead_paragraph: Images of Mark McMorris, 19, the favorite to win the gold medal in the inaugural Olympic snowboarding slopestyle event.

headline: Street Style: Shades of Gray
abstract: The best of readers’ photos from the week of Sept. 9.
lead_paragraph: The best of readers’ photos from the week of Sept. 9.

headline: Chipotle Returns to Animation to Support Sustainable Farming
abstract: The company’s new video, which has been viewed four million times on YouTube, picks up where an earlier one left off.
lead_paragraph: Two years after Chipotle Mexican Grill introduced to widespread acclaim an animated commercial with a pointed message about sustainable farming, the company is back with another animated spot on the subject of food production.

headline: The Site of the Washington Navy Yard Shooting
keywords: ['Washington Navy Yard Shooting (2013)', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: A gunman opened fire Monday morning in and around a Navy facility building in Washington, killing at least 12 people.
lead_paragraph: A gunman opened fire Monday morning in and around a Navy facility building in Washington, killing at least 12 people.

headline: Twitter’s Plans May Run Into China’s Attitudes Toward the Internet

headline: Burberry: Cuddle Up
abstract: In new dandy Burberry collection, the creative director Christopher Bailey chose “English Rose” as his theme.
lead_paragraph: The aptly named Harry Styles of the band One Direction was in Burberry’s front row on Monday, dressed in jeans and a leopard-print T-shirt, his hair a seemingly wind-whipped bouffant with curls framing his face. It was such a hair scene at Burberry, with candy-haired Paloma Faith on the same bench, as well as Sienna Miller and Suki Waterhouse, in black leggings, chunky boots and a brown shearing jacket. England is like the land of the It people. They looked adorable.

headline: A More Compact Camper Van
abstract: Jucy Rentals, based in New Zealand, has introduced compact camper vans to the United States, with a long list of amenities.
lead_paragraph: Jucy Rentals, a travel company based in Auckland, New Zealand, recently introduced customized camper vans for rent in the United States that it said are smaller and more compact than many larger recreational vehicles, but offer essentially the same equipment and amenities.

headline: AMC Announces a Companion Series to ‘Walking Dead’
abstract: The new show, which is expected to begin in 2015, will be developed by Robert Kirkman, whose comic book inspired “The Walking Dead.”
lead_paragraph: AMC wants more “Dead” and who could be surprised?

headline: Booker Prize Panel Is Said to Consider Allowing Americans to Be Eligible

lead_paragraph: For more than four decades, the Man Booker Prize for Fiction has been a uniquely British award, seeking to identify the best novel by authors from Ireland and the Commonwealth.

headline: Robert Gates to Write ‘Duty,’ About His Time as Defense Secretary

headline: Male Orangutans Found to Share Travel Plans
abstract: The males make plans up to 24 hours in advance and tell them to nearby orangutans through long, loud calls that can be heard more than a half-mile away.
lead_paragraph: After several years tracking orangutans in the Sumatran swamplands, researchers made some surprising discoveries, they report in the journal PLoS One: males make travel plans up to 24 hours in advance and share them with nearby orangutans by emitting long, loud calls that can be heard more than a half-mile away.

headline: In D.C., Where Universal Free Preschool Is Becoming the Norm
keywords: ['Charter Schools', 'Child Care', 'Day Care Centers', 'Education (Pre-School)', 'Parenting', 'Teachers and School Employees']
abstract: Five days a week, for nearly 10 months a year, from 8 to 3:15, my taxes pay for my toddler’s education.
lead_paragraph: Last winter, my husband and I almost moved back to Brooklyn with our only child. We got as far as hiring movers and boxing up our home. Instead, we stayed in Washington, D.C., and achieved my long-nagged-at dream of having child No. 2. A big reason for this turnaround? Universal preschool.

headline: Dancing With Black Widow Spiders
abstract: A professional outdoorsman gets to know some of the black widow spiders near his home, first as a shy, retiring pet, then as a venomous threat.
lead_paragraph: I lay on my back with my teeth clenched and my hands gripping the sides of a hospital bed. A crowd of strangers in white coats filled the tiny room. Waves of pain lapped from my abdomen into my chest as the venom worked its way toward my heart.

headline: Nureyev Foundation Grant to Support Joffrey Ballet
abstract: The Joffrey Ballet in Chicago has been awarded a $500,000 challenge grant from the Rudolf Nureyev Dance Foundation to help create and produce full-length story ballets.
lead_paragraph: The Joffrey Ballet in Chicago has been awarded a $500,000 challenge grant from the Rudolf Nureyev Dance Foundation for an endowment to help create and produce full-length story ballets, officials of the Joffrey announced Monday. The new endowment, to be called the Rudolf Nureyev Fund at the Joffrey Ballet, is among the foundation’s biggest grants to a single cultural institution. The challenge is now for the Joffrey Ballet to raise an additional $1 million for the fund.

headline: A Time to Splurge, and a Time to Pinch Pennies
abstract: People make their own choices on what they are willing to spend extra for. The important thing is having good reasons for these choices.
lead_paragraph: A friend of mine never understood why his neighbors spent a lot of money on things he didn’t care about, like houses and cars. To him, these things weren’t worth the money. So one time when he was being particularly grumpy about it, I asked him about his family’s spending habits.

headline: Marchionne Still Low-Balling Chrysler
abstract: A Chrysler initial public offering would cost Fiat time and money better spent on integrating the companies. It’s time for the chief executive, Sergio Marchionne, to increase his offer for the remaining stake.
lead_paragraph: Fiat’s chief executive, Sergio Marchionne, passes for a tough and canny negotiator. These skills have brought him control of 58.5 percent of Chrysler at a bargain basement price of less than $2 billion. However, in his attempt to buy the remaining 41.5 percent owned by VEBA, a health care trust affiliated with the United Auto Workers, Mr. Marchionne may over-egg the pudding.

headline: Spain on Track to Meet Budget, an Official Says
abstract: Luis de Guindos, the economy minister, also said Spain should emerge from recession before the end of the year.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Spain is on track to meet the 2013 budget deficit target it agreed on with its European Union partners and should emerge from recession before the end of the year, the economy minister said on Monday.

headline: Guardian Story on Israel and N.S.A. Is Not ‘Surprising’ Enough to Cover
abstract: What some readers called an “explosive” development in the N.S.A. leaks story was not followed by The Times.
lead_paragraph: Many Times readers have been writing to me for several days about a story The Guardian broke last week, describing how the United States routinely shares with Israel intelligence information that the National Security Agency gathers on American citizens.

headline: McQueen Film Takes Top Award at Toronto Festival

lead_paragraph: The director Steve McQueen won the BlackBerry People’s Choice Award at the Toronto International Film Festival for his drama “12 Years a Slave,” based on the story of Solomon Northup, who was kidnapped and sold into slavery in 1841. The award, voted on by audiences, is the festival’s top prize.

lead_paragraph: “Who plants flowers on this crummy street?” protested Carlos, the hero of a young adult novel called “The Street of the Flower Boxes,” which told of the rejuvenation of a trash-strewed, gang-infested block in Manhattan of the 1960s: West 94th Street between Central Park West and Columbus Avenue.

headline: A Step Up for Brooklyn Bridge Park
abstract: A viewing platform and landscape designs would add to the allure of Brooklyn Bridge Park, on the Brooklyn waterfront.
lead_paragraph: Brooklyn Bridge Park has plenty going for it already: the waterfront promenades, the little corners where you escape into nature, the playgrounds and soccer fields. But it could use more wide-open green space, places to picnic or throw a Frisbee, the kinds of free-for-all gathering spots synonymous with the exercise of democracy and the flirtations of sunbathers. And another architectural landmark in the city never hurts.

headline: H&M’s Capsule Collection of Rugged Weekend Gear
abstract: This week, the Swedish retailer unveils the Mauritz Archive, a range of outdoor clothing inspired by the brand’s early days in Stockholm.
lead_paragraph: Before H&M became the fast-fashion behemoth it is today, it was known simply as Hennes, a Swedish chain of women’s boutiques. In 1968, looking to expand one of his Stockholm outlets, the owner Erling Persson acquired the store next door, Mauritz Widforss, along with its back stock of gentlemen’s outdoor clothing and sporting goods. This excess woolly weekend gear, the initial offering for men in the new company called Hennes & Mauritz, served as the inspiration for the Mauritz Archive Collection, a new H&M capsule collection hitting stores Sept. 19. The designer Petter Klusell unearthed old store catalogs and advertisements to serve as authentic guides for interpreting the original pieces that create a wardrobe fit for a woodsman. Think long johns tucked into hiking boots, removable orange jacket liners in quilted nylon and chunky Shetland sweaters with leather patches. The period-perfect woolens and waxed cotton were sourced from Abraham Moon & Sons and British Millerain, fabric mills based in Britain, for that extra trad touch.

headline: JPMorgan Chase Is Said to Admit Fault in Settlement of Trade Loss
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Fines (Penalties)', 'Securities and Commodities Violations']

headline: Gone but Not Forgotten: Suzuki Issues 194,000-Vehicle Air Bag Recall
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Automobiles', 'Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']

lead_paragraph: Following an investigation by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, Suzuki is recalling almost 194,000 vehicles — Grand Vitaras from the 2006-11 model years and SX4s from 2007-11 — because a passenger-side air bag problem could result in a child or small adult being injured. The safety agency is also investigating reports of 2012-13 Ford Focus electric vehicles stalling, as well as brake problems on 2013 BMW 328i models.

headline: Triple Play: Week 24 Results
abstract: Put your predictive skills to the test each week of the baseball season.
lead_paragraph: The two least popular answers to Question No. 1 this week turned this into a two-man race. Jose Ramirez, a second baseman with the Indians, went 4 for 10 with a triple and three runs scored in six games. Marcus Semien, a White Sox infielder, went 7 for 19 with a double, a run batted in, a stolen base and two runs scored. Nick Castellanos, Michael Choice and Billy Hamilton, all on teams either headed to the postseason or trying to get there, received very little playing time. And it was the fact that Cleveland is battling for a wild card spot that had the Bats blog’s crack baseball committee choose Ramirez as the correct answer.

headline: The Rational Choices of Crack Addicts
keywords: ['Research', 'Cocaine and Crack Cocaine', 'Methamphetamines', 'Addiction (Psychology)', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Brain', 'Therapy and Rehabilitation', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Scientists have long known how drugs act on the brain’s reward center, but a researcher shows that societal factors play a large role in addiction, too.
lead_paragraph: Long before he brought people into his laboratory at Columbia University to smoke crack cocaine, Carl Hart saw its effects firsthand. Growing up in poverty, he watched relatives become crack addicts, living in squalor and stealing from their mothers. Childhood friends ended up in prisons and morgues.

headline: DNA Double Take
keywords: ['DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid)', 'Genetics and Heredity', 'Forensic Science', 'Research', 'Human Genome Project', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: Your DNA and identity are not as entwined as once thought. In fact most people have multiple genomes floating around, from mutations and remnants of pregnancies or twins.
lead_paragraph: From biology class to “C.S.I.,” we are told again and again that our genome is at the heart of our identity. Read the sequences in the chromosomes of a single cell, and learn everything about a person’s genetic information — or, as 23andme, a prominent genetic testing company, says on its Web site, “The more you know about your DNA, the more you know about yourself.”

headline: For Furyk, Another One Lips Cup
abstract: Zach Johnson shot a six-under 65 and birdied three of the last seven holes to finish 16 under to win the BMW Championship, snatching victory from Jim Furyk, who shot a 71 and finished 13 under.
lead_paragraph: LAKE FOREST, Ill. — When he tied a PGA Tour record by shooting a 59 on Friday, Jim Furyk had difficulty explaining how he had managed such a feat, caught among luck, skill and sheer happenstance. After he let his latest final-round lead slip away at the BMW Championship at Conway Farms on Monday, there was no mystery.

headline: Gazing Into Their Past Through Their Bellybuttons
abstract: In Norman Rush’s latest novel, “Subtle Bodies,” college friends gather after the death of their onetime leader.
lead_paragraph: The premise of this tiresome new novel by the critically acclaimed author Norman Rush sounds as if it had been lifted straight from “The Big Chill”: a group of now middle-aged college friends reunite to commemorate the death of one of their own. The result not only lacks that movie’s humor and groovy soundtrack but is also an eye-rollingly awful read.
