keywords: ['Fires and Firefighters', 'Maritime Accidents and Safety', 'Ships and Shipping', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: Seventy-one years ago, as the Normandie was being converted into a troopship for World War II, a fire left it on its side at a Manhattan pier.
lead_paragraph: The last name painted on the grand liner, christened the S.S. Normandie in 1932 and being converted into a troopship called the U.S.S. Lafayette a decade later, was Lipsett, in large white letters.

headline: Parents Who Make No Apologies
abstract: Two comedies about coping with parents are making their debuts: “Dads,” Tuesday night on Fox, and “Mom,” Monday night on CBS.
lead_paragraph: It seems obvious that a comedy about a mother-and-daughter team of recovering addicts would be harder-edged than one about meddling elderly fathers who won’t pick up a check.

headline: New Hope for H.I.V. Vaccine
keywords: ['Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome', 'Monkeys and Apes', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Research']
abstract: A new vaccine tested in monkeys generated a muted immune response that effectively wiped out cells infected with simian immunodeficiency virus, a close relative of H.I.V.
lead_paragraph: “Kafkaesque” is not a word normally used to describe immune responses, but it’s how Dr. Louis J. Picker described what his experimental vaccine did to his rhesus monkeys: “It’s like their T-cells were turned into the East German secret police, hunting down infected cells until there were none left.”

headline: Sex in Spoonworms
keywords: ['Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Worms', 'ANIMATED FILMS', 'Oceans and Seas', 'Science and Technology', 'Biology and Biochemistry']
abstract: What if you had a tiny husband, about the size of a breath mint, that lived in a chamber within your body and produced sperm on an as-needed basis? This is how mating works in the green spoonworm.
lead_paragraph: What if you had a tiny husband, about the size of a breath mint, that lived in a chamber within your body and produced sperm on an as-needed basis? This is how mating works in the green spoonworm.

headline: The Hidden History of a Substantial Minority
abstract: “Latino Americans,” a six-hour PBS documentary that begins on Tuesday night, reveals this group’s longstanding roots.
lead_paragraph: Have you ever heard about the American pilot who took off from an aircraft carrier on Dec. 7, 1941, for a routine check of its next port, Pearl Harbor? His last words were a desperate “Hold your fire” message, just before he was shot down — no one is sure by which side — as one of the first American casualties of World War II. That was Ensign Manuel Gonzales, as viewers will learn through “Latino Americans,” an important and enlightening three-part, six-hour PBS documentary that begins on Tuesday night.

headline: Creatures, Strange and Complex, in Colorful Detail
keywords: ['ANIMATED FILMS', 'Biology and Biochemistry', 'Oceans and Seas', 'Fish and Other Marine Life']
abstract: This week, we start a new video partnership with CreatureCast, a video podcast project from Brown University that uses animation to show the evolutionary range of the natural world.
lead_paragraph: The famous Nobel-winning scientist, Marie Curie, once said: “A scientist in his laboratory is not only a technician: he is also a child placed before natural phenomena which impress him like a fairy tale.”

headline: Watching the Detectives, for a Laugh
abstract: “Brooklyn Nine-Nine,” new from Fox, is a loose, jokey police squad room comedy.
lead_paragraph: Andy Samberg and Andre Braugher, man-child and man’s man, make their debuts as sitcom leads in Fox’s new cop comedy, “Brooklyn Nine-Nine,” on Tuesday night. That the show isn’t nearly as distinctive as its two stars is a disappointment, but, in a way, it’s also a virtue. Mild, affable and familiar, “Brooklyn Nine-Nine” is a show the whole family can snicker at.

headline: Recipe Lab | Gong Bao Chicken
abstract: Julia Moskin cooks gong bao chicken with hot chiles and crunchy peanuts from Fuchsia Dunlop’s “Every Grain of Rice.”
lead_paragraph: Julia Moskin cooks gong bao chicken with hot chiles and crunchy peanuts from Fuchsia Dunlop’s “Every Grain of Rice.”

headline: Three’s a Trend | Graphic Sweatshirt Dressing Goes Upscale
abstract: Designers in New York and London are pairing crew-neck sweatshirts with unexpected separates for a decidedly cozy yet chic look.
lead_paragraph: In New York and now in London, designers have ushered in an attractive lot of not-so-standard-issue crew-neck sweatshirts, emblazoned with bold, eye-catching graphics, in their spring collections. These statement pieces have been paired with unexpected separates, like patterned skirts at Christopher Kane and Marc Jacobs and voluminous graphic shorts at Alexander Wang, for looks that are cozy yet chic.

headline: Gong Bao Chicken With Peanuts From ‘Every Grain of Rice’
abstract: Make this pop classic from Fuchsia Dunlop’s latest cookbook, then join the author and Julia Moskin in a live video chat.
lead_paragraph: Recipe Lab, a monthly feature, invites you to cook with the Dining section. Try the recipe below, from Fuchsia Dunlop’s cookbook “Every Grain of Rice,” then join us for a live video chat with Julia Moskin, Ms. Dunlop and fellow Dining readers on Monday, Sept. 23, 3 p.m. Eastern time, at nytimes.com/dining. If you’re interested in participating in the chat, please fill out this form.

headline: Jeering at Gender Roles in Victorian England
abstract: The Pearl Theater Company is reviving George Bernard Shaw’s “You Never Can Tell,” a subversive comedy of errors about men and women’s negotiations over independence and marriage.
lead_paragraph: Mrs. Clandon is the very model of an independent 21st-century woman. Too bad she lives at the turn of the 20th century.

headline: Update on Navy Yard Shooting
abstract: At a news conference Monday afternoon, officials discussed the latest developments in a deadly shooting at the Washington Navy Yard.
lead_paragraph: At a news conference Monday afternoon, officials discussed the latest developments in a deadly shooting at the Washington Navy Yard.

headline: A Home With Demons That Have No Place to Go
abstract: “Carcass” is a severe and unrelentingly grim play from around 1905 that centers on an embittered family, and this cunning production intensifies every angry scene.
lead_paragraph: It’s been a long time since I’ve seen a play as brutal as “Carcass.” It may be even longer before I can scrub its residue from my mind. Severe and unrelentingly grim, the piece is often difficult to watch; several audience members flinched during its most vicious moments. Yet “Carcass” is also tough to look away from, especially in this cunning production that intensifies every angry scene.

headline: HBO Leads, as Usual, in Emmys Creative Arts Awards
abstract: HBO’s “Behind the Candelabra” and “Boardwalk Empire” took early leads in the annual Emmy race when the Academy of Television Arts and Sciences handed out its Creative Arts awards on Sunday in categories like casting and directing.
lead_paragraph: HBO’s movie “Behind the Candelabra” and its series “Boardwalk Empire” took early leads in the annual Emmy race when the Academy of Television Arts & Sciences handed out its Creative Arts awards on Sunday in categories like casting and camera work.

headline: Hoping to Raise Awareness, 2 Leading Groups for the Blind Plan a Merger
abstract: Lighthouse International and Jewish Guild Healthcare, both based in Manhattan, are joining forces to improve advocacy efforts and increase affiliations with similar groups.
lead_paragraph: Two venerable nonprofit organizations based in Manhattan that provide health care and rehabilitation services for blind and visually impaired people are merging, with the top officials of both groups raising the possibility of broad affiliations among similar local groups around the country.

headline: U.N. Chief Condemns Syrian Use of Sarin
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: The United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, called the chemical weapons attack in Syria the “worst use of W.M.D. in the 21st century.”
lead_paragraph: The United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, called the chemical weapons attack in Syria the “worst use of W.M.D. in the 21st century.”

headline: A Solar System First and Sizing Down a Mountain
keywords: ['Voyager Project', 'Ice', 'Chinese Food (Cuisine)', 'DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid)', 'Medicine and Health', 'Science and Technology']
abstract: Recent developments in health and science news. This week: That lip tingling from Sichuan cuisine and good news for the Arctic’s ice.
lead_paragraph: Voyager 1 has left the solar system, while back on Earth, the tallest mountain in North America turns out to be a bit shorter. Also, there was news of gustatory trickery, in the form of Sichuan peppercorns; a climate surprise, in the refreezing of Arctic ice; and some competition for the entrepreneur Elon Musk in the world of commercial space exploration.

headline: A Chef in the Field | Melons
abstract: Labor Day may have marked the unofficial end of summer, but you can still savor the flavors of the season in the form of the sweet, refreshing melons that are ripe right now.
lead_paragraph: This series by the chef Jeff Schwarz and the photographer Greg Kessler traces the trajectory of seasonal food — from its original source to a place on your table.

headline: Britain Is Pulled, Reluctantly, Into Debate Over Wearing Full-Face Veils in Public
abstract: Two cases test the country’s pride in protecting individual liberty even as other European nations have taken stands on the issue.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The vexing debate over the wearing of full-face veils in public has come to Britain, a country that prides itself on the protection of individual liberty.

headline: Complying With U.S. Tax Evasion Law Is Vexing Foreign Banks
abstract: Concerns have been raised about the cost and effort required to comply with the Foreign Account Tax Compliance Act, among other issues.
lead_paragraph: A sweeping new federal law has a seemingly simple goal — curbing offshore tax evasion by Americans through foreign banks, trusts and shell companies. But behind the scenes, foreign banks and financial firms are increasingly finding that complying with the law is a major headache.

headline: Moto Guzzi’s Faithful Surprise It With a Visit
keywords: ['Factories and Manufacturing', 'Motorcycles, Motor Bikes and Motorscooters']
abstract: Although the motorcycle maker had canceled an annual event, 5,000 enthusiasts showed up anyway.
lead_paragraph: An estimated 5,000 motorcyclists converged on the Moto Guzzi headquarters in Mandello del Lario, Italy, over the weekend to participate in the traditional celebration of G.M.G., or Guzzi World Days.

headline: Tom Ford’s Elaborate, Bondage-Inspired Lace-Up Boots
abstract: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway. Today’s pick: corsetlike boots that are bound to amp up the sex appeal of their wearer.
lead_paragraph: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: In Performance: Joe Manganiello
abstract: Joe Manganiello plays Stanley in the Yale Repertory Theater’s revival of the Tennessee Williams drama “A Streetcar Named Desire.”
lead_paragraph: Joe Manganiello plays Stanley in the Yale Repertory Theater’s revival of the Tennessee Williams drama “A Streetcar Named Desire.”

headline: Not Even a Window Seat Can Get You This View
keywords: ['Stars and Galaxies', 'Hubble Space Telescope', 'Space and Astronomy']
abstract: A view of a galaxy cluster, in new detail.
lead_paragraph: In an image that meshes both visible and infrared data, the Hubble’s Advanced Camera for Surveys, or A.C.S., showed Abell 1689, a galaxy cluster, in more striking detail than in previous observations. The picture has a combined exposure time of more than 34 hours.

headline: Iranians Gain Access to Facebook and Twitter
abstract: The government’s longtime firewall had forced Iranians to use special software to access the sites, and it was unclear whether the opening Monday was the result of an official decision or a glitch.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — Internet users in Iran were surprised on Monday to find that they could access Facebook and Twitter without having to evade the government’s firewall, which had blocked direct access to the Web sites for years.

headline: Navy Yard Shooting: 6 P.M. Update
abstract: At a news conference Monday evening, officials discussed the latest developments in a deadly shooting at the Washington Navy Yard.
lead_paragraph: At a news conference Monday evening, officials discussed the latest developments in a deadly shooting at the Washington Navy Yard.

headline: U.S. Bans Import of Generic Drugs From Indian Plant
keywords: ['Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Recalls and Bans of Products', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Generic Brands and Products']
abstract: The Food and Drug Administration cites concern over drug quality for banning imports from the Ranbaxy’s new plant in Mohali, India.
lead_paragraph: Citing concerns about drug quality, the Food and Drug Administration on Monday announced a ban on imports of any products made at the generic drug maker Ranbaxy’s newest factory in India.

headline: A Giant Aims to Give New Life to Its Smallest Network
abstract: WPP, the largest agency holding group in advertising, is seeking to revive United Network, its smallest agency network.
lead_paragraph: THE largest agency holding group in advertising is seeking to revive its smallest agency network.

headline: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
abstract: The Department of Defense has identified 2,255 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations.
lead_paragraph: The Department of Defense has identified 2,255 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

headline: Summers Seen as Costly in Political Terms
abstract: The horse-trading needed to get Lawrence H. Summers approved in the Senate Banking Committee alone was too much for Democrats.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On Friday, Senator Jeff Merkley, an Oregon Democrat, tried to phone Denis McDonough, the White House chief of staff, with some bad news: as many as five Democrats on the Senate Banking Committee were “no” votes for Lawrence H. Summers, the White House’s favored candidate for the position of chairman of the Federal Reserve.

headline: In Geneva, Russia’s Foreign Minister Still Claimed Chemical Attack Was ‘Fabricated’
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Sergey V. Lavrov insisted, even during negotiations in Geneva last weekend, that the chemical attack outside Damascus on Aug. 21 “was clearly fabricated” by rebels intent on provoking Western intervention.
lead_paragraph: Last Updated, Tuesday, 1:30 p.m. | Russia’s foreign minister continued to insist that the deadly chemical attack outside Damascus on Aug. 21 “was clearly fabricated” by rebels intent on provoking Western intervention, even as he met with his American counterpart in Geneva last weekend to hammer out a deal to take Syria’s chemical weapons out of the hands of President Bashar al-Assad’s generals.

headline: Rhapsody Cuts Staff as New Investor Arrives
keywords: ['Music', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: The digital music service on Monday said it laid off its president, Jon Irwin, along with 15 percent of its staff.
lead_paragraph: Rhapsody, a digital music service that pioneered the subscription model now dominated by Spotify, has laid off its president, Jon Irwin, along with 15 percent of its staff, as the service struggles to remain competitive in a crowded market.

headline: Students Accused of Cheating Return Awkwardly to a Changed Harvard
abstract: Forced to take a year off in the university’s worst cheating scandal in memory, some of the about 70 students involved are back on a campus that has been changed by their actions.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — Dozens of Harvard students who were forced to take a year off in the university’s worst cheating scandal in memory are returning this month to some painful moments on a campus that has been changed by their actions.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Kenseth Prevails in Rainy Chicagoland
abstract: Nascar reviews last week’s chicanery, shuffling the lineup for the Chase for the Championship; Jorge Lorenzo wins his second Moto GP series race in a row.
lead_paragraph: Top seed Matt Kenseth claimed the opening race Sunday of Nascar’s 10-race Chase for the Sprint Cup. The race, held at Chicagoland Speedway near Joliet, Ill., finished near midnight after multiple rain delays.

headline: Massachusetts: Attorney General Joins the Race for Governor
abstract: Martha Coakley announced Monday that she was running for governor in 2014. The race has drawn four other Democrats.
lead_paragraph: Martha Coakley, whose defeat as the Democratic candidate for the Senate in 2010 led to the election of Scott P. Brown and threatened President Obama’s health care bill, announced Monday that she was running for governor in 2014. Chastened by her loss, Ms. Coakley, the state’s attorney general, has said she has learned from her mistakes. The race has drawn four other Democrats. In a video announcing her candidacy, she is shown talking with voters, suggesting a more personable campaign than the one she conducted in 2010 and one with a strong populist pitch. She also planned a three-day announcement swing to 18 cities. Gov. Deval Patrick is stepping down.

headline: A Town-Gown Clash Over the Costs of Public Services
keywords: ['Water', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: In financial straits, Alfred, N.Y., asked Alfred University and Alfred State College to pay more for water. When one institution balked, the village gave an ultimatum: Pay up or go thirsty.
lead_paragraph: ALFRED, N.Y. — It was just about the time they were going to turn off the water that this village recognized it might have a college problem.

headline: Giants’ Chain Reaction of Woe Begins With the Handoff
abstract: Because the Giants’ running game has been such a flop, the offense has faced numerous third-and-long situations in which play-action fakes have been pointless.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — There was an excess of negative statistics to cull from the Giants’ 41-23 loss to the Denver Broncos on Sunday, but there is one measurement — viewed with a twist — that is more illustrative than any other.

headline: A Way of Life Moves With a Market
abstract: Tokyo is spending $4.5 billion to relocate a 78-year-old fish market to accommodate modern truck traffic — a move critics call another blow to a vanishing way of life.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Each day before dawn, the world’s largest fish market comes to life in frantic activity, a last holdout of an older, quainter Japan.

headline: In Pursuit of Tastier Chickens, a Strict Diet of Four-Star Scraps
abstract: In an experiment, chickens are being fed prized scraps from acclaimed New York restaurants to rediscover what, aficionados say, a chicken should taste like.
lead_paragraph: EPHRATA, Pa. — They may be the most pampered chickens on the planet.

headline: Initial Focus of Research in Brain Project Is Chosen
abstract: An advisory group said to focus on systems and circuits involving thousands to millions of brain cells, not the entire brain or individual cells and molecules.
lead_paragraph: In the first hint of how the Brain Initiative announced by President Obama in April could take shape, an advisory group on Monday recommended that the main target of research by the National Institutes of Health should be systems and circuits involving thousands to millions of brain cells — not the entire brain or individual cells and molecules.

headline: Two-Name Race Drops to One, but Guessing Continues
abstract: Janet Yellen has emerged as the leading candidate to take over the Fed, but some are speculating that the president may still choose Donald L. Kohn.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON – What if Janet L. Yellen doesn’t get the job?

headline: Chin Peng, Malaysian Rebel, Dies at 88
abstract: Mr. Peng pitted himself against Japanese invaders, British colonialists and his own government in a bloody struggle for an independent Communist country.
lead_paragraph: Chin Peng, a Communist guerrilla leader whose tenacious, bloody struggles for an independent Communist Malaysia pitted him against Japanese invaders, British colonialists and finally the government of what had become his own newly sovereign nation, died in exile on Monday in Bangkok. He was 88.

headline: Google Buys Bump, Maker of Apps for Sharing Photos and Files
keywords: ['Android (Operating System)', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Google Phone', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Software']
abstract: Bump, which struggled to find its footing, provides Google with mobile and photo-sharing expertise.
lead_paragraph: Remember 2008, when people at conferences and cocktail parties would bump their phones together to exchange digital business cards? Ever wondered what happened to that app, called Bump?

headline: For Bloomberg, a Day to Celebrate Successful Schools
abstract: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and other officials visited nearly two dozen schools that had excelled on state reading and math exams.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg; the schools chancellor, Dennis M. Walcott; and senior education officials took a victory lap of sorts on Monday, visiting 22 New York City public schools that ranked among the state’s top 25 in reading and math exams given last spring.

headline: For Twitter, Key to Revenue Is No Longer Ad Simplicity
abstract: Virtually all of Twitter’s revenue, estimated to be $583 million this year, currently comes from three basic ad formats.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When it comes to making money, Twitter is all about keeping it simple. There are no banner ads, no dancing animations, no ads inserted between screens that you must click to get past.

headline: President’s Speech and Online Army Video Point to Iran’s Dueling Interests in Syria
abstract: A speech by President Hassan Rouhani of Iran and an online video showing his commanders appearing to fight rebels in Syria point to Iran’s dual tracks in the civil war.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — Iran’s new president, Hassan Rouhani, told Revolutionary Guards commanders on Monday that Iran would support whomever Syrians want as their leader even if it is not the country’s staunch ally, President Bashar al-Assad of Syria.

headline: Push for Yellen to Lead at Fed Gathers Steam
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: After Lawrence H. Summers withdrew from consideration, Janet L. Yellen became the presumptive nominee for the top job at the Fed.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Janet L. Yellen told friends in recent weeks that she did not expect to be nominated as the next chairman of the Federal Reserve. Although she had been the Fed’s vice chairman since 2010 and would make history as the first woman to hold the job, President Obama’s aides made clear throughout the summer that he wanted Lawrence H. Summers, his former chief economic adviser.

headline: Reiko Douglas, Entertainer on TV Talk Shows, Dies at 77
abstract: Ms. Douglas was a Japanese-born entertainer who became a popular guest on American talk shows in the 1960s and ’70s even though she appeared to speak little English.
lead_paragraph: Reiko Douglas, a Japanese-born entertainer who became a popular guest on American talk shows in the 1960s and ’70s despite the fact that she appeared to speak little English, died on Sept. 9 in Los Angeles. She was 77.

headline: Is Angela Merkel Too Boring for Germany?
abstract: Is Angela Merkel, who has succeeded through an iron commitment to consensus and harmony, too boring for Germany?
lead_paragraph: MUNICH — IT is election season in Germany, and Angela Merkel, the chancellor, is living through her worst nightmare. The allegedly most powerful female politician on the planet hates campaign politics.

headline: The Opposite of Bloomberg? Not So Fast
abstract: Though Bill de Blasio has taken pains to frame himself as anti-Bloomberg, a de Blasio administration is likely to deepen and extend some of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s policies.
lead_paragraph: Our billionaire mayor has seen his golden touch turn to dross of late, and so he decided that he would not bestow his endorsement on a successor.

headline: Let the Poor Have Fun
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Third World and Developing Countries']
abstract: Don’t underestimate the power of entertainment to transform developing countries like India.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — THEY can’t do without the farmer story. When people who wish to transform India through the Internet talk about their plans, they tend to tell a story that goes something like this: A poor farmer is about to sell his crop very cheap when someone, often a smart adolescent granddaughter, checks the market price online, and the farmer makes a more informed decision.

headline: Lottery Numbers
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Hard Truths About Our Soft Bodies
abstract: Studies and theories about everything from additives to air-conditioning cloud the bigger-is-better ethos that definitely contributes to America’s weight problem.
lead_paragraph: I was steering my cart through Costco the other day, wondering whether to waddle to the aisle where they sell cashews by the quarter-ton or to the one with thousand-piece packs of chicken thighs, when an epiphany pierced the fog of my gluttony.

headline: Germany: Knut’s Trademark Is Upheld
abstract: A British company cannot sell merchandise under the name “Knut — Der Eisbär” (German for “Knut — the polar bear”), a European court ruled Monday.
lead_paragraph: A British company cannot sell merchandise under the name “Knut — Der Eisbär” (German for “Knut — the polar bear”), a European court ruled Monday, closing yet another chapter in the unusual saga of the Berlin Zoo’s late animal celebrity, who enjoyed a cult-like following around the world until his death last year. The General Court of the European Union in Luxembourg upheld an earlier claim by the zoo that the proposed brand was too similar to the registered trademark “Knud,” which the zoo already holds. Marketing the bear has proved especially lucrative for the zoo, which has raked in millions of euros with its Knut-themed trinkets and souvenirs.

headline: 56 Ways of Saying I Don’t Remember
abstract: Alan Berliner explores memory and forgetting in this short experimental documentary about his cousin Edwin Honig — a poet, translator and professor — and his journey through Alzheimer’s disease.
lead_paragraph: Alan Berliner explores memory and forgetting in this short experimental documentary about his cousin Edwin Honig — a poet, translator and professor — and his journey through Alzheimer’s disease.

headline: ‘56 Ways of Saying I Don’t Remember’
abstract: Alan Berliner explores memory and forgetting in this short experimental documentary about his cousin Edwin Honig – a poet, translator and professor — and his journey through Alzheimer’s disease.
lead_paragraph: This Op-Doc is part of a suite of short films collectively titled “Translating Edwin Honig: A Poet’s Alzheimer’s,” completed in 2010. The films form a portrait of the distinguished poet, translator, critic and Brown University professor Edwin Honig — who was my cousin, friend and mentor — and his journey through the depths of Alzheimer’s disease. It is the chronicle of a man who, though he may have lost his memory, his relationship to the past and his command of language, still retained his wit, his sense of humor, his scholarly demeanor and the bearings of a deeply poetic soul.

headline: Perelman’s Daughter Leads a Nasty Legal Brawl
abstract: A dispute between Ronald O. Perelman and his ex-in-laws has moved into the next generation as his daughter argues her uncle blocked her inheritance.
lead_paragraph: Samantha Perelman, a 23-year-old student at Columbia University, will be at the center of a nasty family battle in a New Jersey courtroom this week.

headline: Amid Revolt Over Fiscal ‘Gimmicks,’ Options Dwindle for G.O.P.
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'National Debt (US)']
abstract: With a possible government shutdown and debt default on the horizon, conservatives are rallying to prevent their leaders from using the maneuvers that have warded off fiscal crises in the past.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — First came the “supercommittee,” tasked in 2011 with finding a bipartisan deficit reduction plan but doomed to fail. Then came the “McConnell plan,” a way for Congress to raise the government’s debt limit without actually voting to do so. And in January there was “no budget, no pay,” a measure coupled with the last debt ceiling increase to deny paychecks to lawmakers if they did not pass a budget.

headline: Russia: Shooting in Philosophical Clash
abstract: An argument over the teachings of the philosopher Immanuel Kant ended when one man shot another with a gun loaded with rubber bullets, the state RIA news agency reported.
lead_paragraph: An argument over the teachings of the philosopher Immanuel Kant between two men standing in line for beer at an outdoor festival in southern Russia ended when one man shot the other in the head with gun loaded with rubber bullets, the state RIA news agency reported on Monday, citing the police. Though the wound was not critical, the attacker faces up to a decade in prison if convicted on assault charges. Among educated Russians, including those who drink, classical literature and philosophy are sometimes debated in casual social settings, the way sports often are in Western countries.

headline: A Court Just for Juveniles in N.Y.
abstract: New York should create a special court for children under 18 charged with nonviolent crimes.
lead_paragraph: Teenagers prosecuted in adult courts or who do time in adult jails fare worse in life and can go on to commit more violent crimes than those who are handled by the juvenile justice system. Neuroscience research has found that these young offenders don’t weigh risks the way adults do, making them prone to rash judgments that can land them in trouble with the law.

headline: Giving Up on Antarctica
keywords: ['Oceans and Seas', 'Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Conservation of Resources', 'Editorials']
abstract: Creative marine reserves in the south polar region would seem like a no-brainer. So why are plans being scaled back?
lead_paragraph: The idea of creating extensive marine reserves in the Southern Ocean, around Antarctica, seems like a no-brainer. The reserves would protect what is still the most pristine aquatic ecosystem in existence, and they would extend to the ocean some of the international protection that the continent enjoys: the recognition that the south polar region is a world treasure, off limits to the frenzy of resource extraction playing out across the rest of the planet.

headline: Thompson Bows Out
abstract: Bill Thompson made a gracious exit from the New York mayor’s race, but he called the lack of official results a disgrace. He’s right.
lead_paragraph: William Thompson Jr. made a gracious exit from the race for mayor of New York on Monday, throwing his support to Bill de Blasio, who probably got slightly more than 40 percent of the vote in last Tuesday’s Democratic primary, which he needed to avoid a runoff with Mr. Thompson.

headline: End Mandatory Life Sentences
abstract: Mandatory life without parole still applies to some juveniles.
lead_paragraph: Young people are different. The Supreme Court has delivered that message repeatedly over the last decade in limiting or flatly prohibiting the most severe criminal punishments for those under 18 at the time of their crime.

headline: Time to Write? Go Outside
abstract: Nothing coaxes jumbled thoughts into coherent sentences like sitting under a shade tree on a pleasant day.
lead_paragraph: Fall promises crisp days with ample sunlight, a lifting of the humidity and ideal temperatures for being outdoors. This also means my writing will be getting better.

headline: Suspect in Shooting Had Problems With the Law
keywords: ['Washington Navy Yard Shooting (2013)', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: Aaron Alexis, identified as the gunman in the Washington Navy Yard shooting, had been arrested twice on firearm-related charges.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Aaron Alexis, 34, the man killed by police officers and identified as the gunman in the deadly rampage at the Washington Navy Yard on Monday, served his country as a Navy reservist, had an abiding interest in Buddhism and Thai culture, and had problems with the law, records and interviews show.

abstract: Mayor Steven M. Fulop of Jersey City responds to a Sunday Review news analysis.

abstract: A reader suggests that Voyager 1 turn its cameras back on the planet it has left far, far behind.

keywords: ['Millennium Development Goals', 'Poverty', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Third World and Developing Countries']
abstract: Two international experts respond to an editorial.

headline: A Two-State Critic, and His Critics
abstract: Readers mostly defend the idea of separate Israeli and Palestinian states, disagreeing with a Sunday Review writer.

headline: Groups Want Bad Image of Penn State to Go Away
abstract: Current and former faculty, alumni and fans are upset about how they feel the Jerry Sandusky scandal has come to define Penn State unfairly.
lead_paragraph: STATE COLLEGE, Pa. — During the first week of classes at Penn State last month, John Nichols sat in his office in the old wing of the Willard Building, across the lawn from Old Main, fuming about what people have been saying, for two years now, about the university he loves.

headline: Week After a Fire, Three Bodies Are Found in the Ruins of a Bronx House
abstract: The victims’ names and ages were unknown, and it was not immediately clear whether they had died in the fire.
lead_paragraph: On Sept. 9, a raging blaze in an abandoned three-story house in the Bronx drew more than a hundred firefighters, took nearly three hours to bring under control and left a charred structure in place of what had been an unloved neighborhood eyesore.

headline: M.T.A. Plan Envisions a Nicer Status Quo
abstract: A Metropolitan Transportation Authority presentation outlined a $106 billion list of possible investments over 20 years, including a need for a successor to the MetroCard.
lead_paragraph: By 2034, the Second Avenue subway will wind through Manhattan, the MetroCard will be long dead and few riders will remember an age without countdown clocks.

headline: Gas Leaks in Fracking Disputed in Study
abstract: Hydraulic fracking appears to cause smaller leaks of methane, a greenhouse gas, than the federal government estimates, according to a study released Monday.
lead_paragraph: Drilling for shale gas through hydraulic fracturing, or fracking, appears to cause smaller leaks of the greenhouse gas methane than the federal government had estimated, and considerably smaller than some critics of shale gas had feared, according to a peer-reviewed study released on Monday.

headline: For Thompson, a Disappointing End to a Not-Quite-Compelling Quest
abstract: In his campaign for mayor of New York City, William C. Thompson Jr. could not concoct the right recipe to parlay his two terms as city comptroller into something grander.
lead_paragraph: Maybe it was not that surprising that William C. Thompson Jr. would come up just shy.

headline: Next Cup Battle: To Decide What Representing a Country Means
abstract: The Kiwis’ chief executive wants to restore a nationality rule to the next America’s Cup. The question is how strong the rule should be.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — With Emirates Team New Zealand holding a huge lead heading into the final stages of the America’s Cup, it remains unclear just what the team will do with the competition if it goes on to defeat Oracle Team USA.

headline: Asking for Help, Then Killed by an Officer’s Barrage
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: The family of Jonathan Ferrell, who while searching for help after an accident was shot to death by a Charlotte, N.C., officer, applauded the city for charging the officer.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — A former college football player shot to death while searching for help after a car accident was killed by 10 bullets fired by a Charlotte, N.C., police officer, officials said Monday.

headline: Sheldon Hackney, Leader in Humanities, Dies at 79
abstract: Mr. Hackney was an educator and chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities who organized  “national conversations” during the culturally fractious 1990s.
lead_paragraph: Sheldon Hackney, an educator and chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities who organized a series of “national conversations” aimed at restoring civility and civic-mindedness during the culturally fractious 1990s, died on Thursday on Martha’s Vineyard in Massachusetts. He was 79.

headline: Alabama: Sororities Told to Increase Diversity
keywords: ['Fraternities and Sororities', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Discrimination']
abstract: The University of Alabama said on Monday that its traditionally white sororities had been ordered to extend their recruitment efforts and increase diversity.
lead_paragraph: The University of Alabama said on Monday that its traditionally white sororities had been ordered to extend their recruitment efforts after the school came under withering criticism for racial bias by its Greek organizations. The university said in a statement that President Judy L. Bonner had told the social groups to use a process that allows the organizations to accept new members after the traditional sorority rush as part of a push “to remove barriers in order to increase diversity in our sororities.” The university drew attention last week after a member of the Tuscaloosa campus’s Alpha Gamma Delta chapter told the student newspaper, The Crimson White, that the sorority had considered race when it denied admission to a black woman with a sterling academic record and close familial ties to Alabama. Members of other sororities recounted similar experiences, though they did so anonymously.

headline: Corrections: September 17, 2013
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on September 17, 2013.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Inviting Him Over for More Than He’s Expecting
abstract: “Women or Nothing” is a comedy about a lesbian couple who want to trick a man into helping them have a baby.
lead_paragraph: “Women or Nothing,” the new comedy by the filmmaker Ethan Coen, feels like a short play that has been heavily padded. (Perhaps this should not be a surprise: Mr. Coen has written several one-acts, but this is his first full-length stage work.) Somewhere inside this bloated comedy, about two lesbians in search of some viable sperm, there may be a skinny sex farce struggling to break free.

headline: Late-Night Party
abstract: Peter A. Collins gets romantic.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — I honestly had no idea that Peter A. Collins was such a romantic, but here he is, suggesting a few DATE movies for us all to go on with him. We probably won’t all fit in the car, so let’s meet at the theater, shall we?

headline: In A.L. Wild-Card Race, Yankees Are on Outside Looking for a Miracle
abstract: If the Yankees secure one of the two American League wild-card spots, it will probably require one of baseball’s greatest multiteam collapses.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — The history of baseball is full of famous collapses that enabled teams to qualify for the playoffs against all expectations. The 1978 Red Sox, the 1964 Phillies and the 2007 Mets are but a few whose collapses paved the way for more fortunate teams.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, September 17, 2013
abstract: Quotation of the day for Tuesday, September 17, 2013.
lead_paragraph: “The report makes for chilling reading. The findings are beyond doubt and beyond the pale. This is a war crime.”

headline: Outburst Highlights Conundrum for Twitter
abstract: Twitter flowed with disparaging comments about the new Miss America, raising a question about the company’s future: Will Wall Street follow a platform for trash talk, or will Twitter have to police its users more aggressively?
lead_paragraph: One of Twitter’s greatest values, which its investors are hoping to capitalize on soon, is as a real-time global bullhorn that lets users make their voices heard about anything under the sun.

headline: Pile of Gold to Use for Bail? Seems ‘Fishy,’ a Judge Says
abstract: At a court hearing in Manhattan, prosecutors sought to challenge the provenance of gold jewelry a family sought to use as collateral for a man’s $50,000 bail.
lead_paragraph: There were Liberty gold coins and Krugerrands, and a gold chain so thick that had it been used as a restraining device, it might have done a fair job of keeping Tom Eli behind bars.

headline: Germany’s Political Fragmentation May Pose Challenge for Merkel
abstract: Chancellor Angela Merkel’s Christian Democratic Party could win this Sunday’s national election but fall short of an outright majority.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — The real political drama in Germany this year may get under way only after Chancellor Angela Merkel faces the voters.

headline: Shooting at the Washington Navy Yard
abstract: A gunman was killed Monday after a shooting that left at least 12 people dead at a naval office building in Washington.
lead_paragraph: A gunman was killed Monday after a shooting that left at least 12 people dead at a naval office building in Washington.

headline: Returning to Rangers After Injury, and Loss
abstract: Defenseman Marc Staal and center Dominic Moore are approaching the season from dramatically different perspectives of redemption.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Rangers defenseman Marc Staal and center Dominic Moore are approaching the season from drastically different perspectives of redemption.

headline: Jets Rookie Cornerback Learned All About the Bench in College
abstract: The Jets’ top draft pick, Dee Milliner, who was pulled from Thursday’s game in New England for poor play, received similar treatment as an Alabama freshman before becoming a standout.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Dee Milliner made a few mental miscues, and his coach, infuriated, yanked him from the game. This occurred Thursday night against the Patriots. It also happened three years ago, in Milliner’s freshman season at Alabama.

headline: Complex Science at Issue in Politics of Fetal Pain
abstract: New laws further restricting abortions have been driven by the contention that fetuses can feel pain at 20 weeks after conception. The science is far less clear on the issue.
lead_paragraph: It is a new frontier of the anti-abortion movement: laws banning abortion at 20 weeks after conception, contending that fetuses can feel pain then.

headline: Foggy Bottom and the Fog of War
abstract: What is gained or lost when the secretary of defense takes a back seat to the secretary of state in pursuing military interventions?

headline: Primary Field Clears Abruptly for Illinois Governor’s Bid
abstract: With William M. Daley, a former White House chief of staff, dropping out, the most serious challenge to Pat Quinn, the Democratic incumbent, may come from the Republicans.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — William M. Daley, a former White House chief of staff and a member of one of Chicago’s best-known political families, is dropping his bid to become governor of Illinois, an aide said Monday evening.

headline: In Islamist Bastions of Egypt, the Army Treads Carefully, and Christians Do, Too
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Christians and Christianity', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: Two months after the ouster of President Mohamed Morsi, the Egyptian government is struggling to control the Islamist strongholds in rural southern regions of the country.
lead_paragraph: DALGA, Egypt — A convoy of more than a dozen armored police and army vehicles arrived here just before dawn on Monday, rolling into the rural village that has witnessed the most horrific sectarian violence in Egypt since the military’s ouster two months ago of President Mohamed Morsi of the Muslim Brotherhood. Among the damage, a 1,650-year-old monastery, its two churches and as many as 35 homes belonging to Christians have all been burned or ransacked.

headline: South of Cairo, Fear and Tension After Violence Toward Christians
keywords: ['Christians and Christianity', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Two months after the ouster of President Mohamed Morsi, the Egyptian government is struggling to contain his supporters in some parts of the country.
lead_paragraph: Two months after the ouster of President Mohamed Morsi, the Egyptian government is struggling to contain his supporters in some parts of the country.

headline: Harvey’s Injury Shows Pitchers Have a Speed Limit
abstract: Matt Harvey’s injury exposes the fraility of ligaments and tendons, already stretched by the pitching motion. As a biomedical engineer says, “Velocity itself is a risk factor for injury.”
lead_paragraph: BIRMINGHAM, Ala. — Glenn Fleisig’s rather unusual laboratory has a pitcher’s mound and a home plate, and when he rigs people up to throw a baseball, their motion is analyzed with sensors feeding into computers.

headline: Melissa Aldana, Saxophonist, Wins Monk Competition
abstract: Melissa Aldana, a tenor saxophonist originally from Santiago, Chile, has been a working bandleader in New York since 2009 and won the Thelonious Monk competition with the song “I Though About You” and an original work, “Free Fall.”
lead_paragraph: The winner of the 2013 Thelonious Monk International Jazz Saxophone Competition is Melissa Aldana, 24, a tenor saxophonist originally from Santiago, Chile. She has been a working bandleader in New York since 2009 and has released two albums on the Inner Circle label.

headline: Tracing Flight Directions
abstract: The United Nations report released Monday identified the direction from which two of the rockets carrying chemical weapons were fired.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations report released Monday identified the direction from which two of the rockets carrying chemical weapons were fired.

headline: Philippine Forces Free Scores Held by Muslim Rebels
abstract: Three soldiers were killed in the operation, which was a major breakthrough in a battle that has paralyzed an important southern city for more than a week.
lead_paragraph: The Philippine military on Tuesday rescued almost 80 of the 100 hostages being held by Muslim rebels, a major breakthrough in a battle that has paralyzed an important southern city for more than a week.

headline: Veteran Diplomat Fond of Cigars, Whiskey and Outfoxing U.S.
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'International Relations']
abstract: Sergey V. Lavrov, the Russian foreign minister who pushed for the Syria chemical arms pact, has spent a career trying to keep the United States in check.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Secretary of State John Kerry had just made an offhand remark about how President Bashar al-Assad of Syria could avoid a military strike — and now Sergey V. Lavrov, Russia’s hard-charging foreign minister, was on the phone.

headline: Domingo and Coppola Among Winners of Praemium Imperiale Awards
abstract: The Praemium Imperiale awards recognize lifetime achievement in the arts in categories not covered by the Nobel Prize.
lead_paragraph: The tenor and conductor Plácido Domingo and the film director Francis Ford Coppola are among the 2013 winners of the Praemium Imperiale awards from the Japan Art Association. The awards, which bring about $150,000 for each recipient, recognize lifetime achievement in the arts in categories not covered by the Nobel Prize. They are scheduled to be presented Oct. 16 at a ceremony in Tokyo.

headline: Taxing Medicare Benefits
abstract: Medicare systematically pays out far more in aggregate benefits than beneficiaries pay for, and the tax on Social Security benefits may provide a model for how to close the gap, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of “The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform – Why We Need It and What It Will Take.”

abstract: This word has appeared in four New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: hireling •\ˈhi(-ə)r-liN\• noun

headline: What’s on Tuesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 7 P.M. (SNY) MAJOR LEAGUE BASEBALL: NEW YORK METS VS. SAN FRANCISCO GIANTS After receiving rave reviews for his first stint announcing from the SNY broadcast booth, on June 23, 2010, Jerry Seinfeld, right, will once again call a game alongside Keith Hernandez, Ron Darling and Gary Cohen. “Four guys who love to talk, sharing one broadcast booth, sounds like a bad idea on its face,” Mr. Seinfeld said in an SNY statement. “I don’t even know if the chairs will fit. But to spend an evening with Keith, Ron and Gary, I will stand if I have to.” Mr. Seinfeld will team up with Bob Ojeda, the lead studio analyst, and the host Chris Carlin on “Mets First Pitch,” at 6.

headline: Rick Casares, 82, a Bear Who Got Yards With Grit, Dies
abstract: Casares led the National Football League in rushing in 1956 and is third on the Chicago Bears’ career rushing list.
lead_paragraph: Rick Casares, a fullback for the Chicago Bears in the 1950s and ’60s who bulled through defensive lines to become, for a time, the leading rusher in team history, and who once led the National Football League in rushing, died on Friday at his home in Tampa, Fla. He was 82.

headline: News Quiz | September 17, 2013
abstract: See what you know about the news of the day.
lead_paragraph: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Crews Right Cruise Ship in Waters Off Italy
abstract: The 19-hour, highly complicated salvage operation rotated the Costa Concordia upright, leaning it on an underwater platform.
lead_paragraph: GIGLIO, Italy — Salvage workers righted the scarred and discolored hull of the cruise ship Costa Concordia early Tuesday after coaxing it from two granite reefs it ran aground on just off this tiny tourist island 20 months ago, killing 32 people.

headline: U.N. Official Presses Karzai on Rights Panel Appointees
abstract: The top United Nations human rights official, Navi Pillay, is concerned that the Afghan president, Hamid Karzai, is stacking a human rights panel with political appointees.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The top United Nations human rights official emerged from a meeting here with President Hamid Karzai on Tuesday without hoped-for assurances that he would reverse his decision to pack the country’s human rights commission with political appointees.

headline: Tough Calls Are Paying Off for the Bears
abstract: Chicago is 2-0 after an off-season in which it let go of Coach Lovie Smith and Brian Urlacher, the face of the franchise.
lead_paragraph: In January 2012, the Chicago Bears were looking for a new general manager. That search ended with the hiring of Phil Emery, a relative unknown who was the Kansas City Chiefs’ director of college scouting. Emery did not make any immediate splashes, but one year later, he made two bold decisions that could have easily turned the Chicago faithful against him.

headline: Test Yourself | History, Sept. 17, 2013
abstract: Answer this question about the history of apartheid in South Africa.
lead_paragraph: Take the Quiz

headline: How Robots Can Trick You Into Loving Them
abstract: The secret to robots with better social skills? Exploiting human nature.
lead_paragraph: I like to think of my Roomba as cute and industrious. He makes noises while he cleans that make me feel as if he’s communicating with me, which contributes to the fact that I have assigned him a sex. He exists in a liminal space between animate and inanimate, but once he’s done cleaning my floors, I don’t mind putting him in the closet until I need his services again — he’s a rolling disc, after all.

headline: What Is More Important: Our Privacy or National Security?
abstract: Do you feel the government is striking the right balance between protecting national security and our right to privacy? Why?
lead_paragraph: Earlier this year, Edward J. Snowden, a government contractor, leaked classified documents to the news media that revealed the existence of top-secret government surveillance programs.

headline: Turning Point: Light, Composition, Revelation
abstract: A young multimedia journalist discusses his inspiration, Tomás Munita, who marries light, color and storytelling to deliver complicated ideas succinctly and beautifully.
lead_paragraph: Jake Naughton, 25, is enrolled at the City University of New York’s Graduate School of Journalism and is an intern at the Lens blog. He has an undergraduate degree in journalism from the University of Wisconsin at Madison, where he also studied fine arts photography and African studies. He lived in Washington, D.C., for three years, pursuing photography while working as the multimedia projects coordinator at the Pulitzer Center on Crisis Reporting. He left that position because he felt he needed “a framework to drill down my skills as a photographer and videographer.”

headline: Iran Bars Social Media Again After a Day
abstract: Iranian officials said a technical glitch allowed people to access social media sites that had been blocked for years in Iran.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — Iranians lost unrestricted access to Facebook and Twitter on Tuesday almost before they knew they had it, leaving many people wondering whether the opening was deliberate or the result of some technical glitch.

headline: New York Today: De Blasio and Occupy Wall Street
abstract: What you need to know for Tuesday: Occupy Wall Street’s anniversary, more lovely autumnal weather and an opera about Anna Nicole Smith.
lead_paragraph: Updated 12:00 p.m. | Two years ago today, demonstrators gathered in the financial district to protest income inequality and the influence of money on politics.

headline: Go East Old Man: The Pumps Are On, but There’s Nobody Home
abstract: In the penultimate installation of “Go East Old Man,” Dexter Ford chronicles his ride across Wisconsin and Michigan’s Upper Peninsula into the wilds of southern Ontario.
lead_paragraph: Dexter Ford is traveling from Southern California to upstate New York along mostly obscure roads, on a motorcycle that, by American standards, is quite tiny. This is the fifth of his occasional reports from the paths less traveled.

headline: Daily Report: Twitter Makes Plans to Increase and Enrich Advertising Channels
abstract: As Twitter prepares to sell stock to the public, the company is planning initiatives that will add complexity to its advertising business while also diversifying its revenue stream.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to making money, Twitter is all about keeping it simple. There are no banner ads, no dancing animations, no ads inserted between screens that you must click to get past, Vindu Goel reports.

headline: Auto Sales in Europe Fall Again, but Tumble Is Thought to Be Ending
abstract: New passenger-car sales in Europe in the first eight months of this year were the lowest ever tracked for the period.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — European auto sales declined again in August, an industry group reported on Tuesday, erasing a rare gain in July.

headline: Dishes to Help Tackle Part-Time Veganism
abstract: Mark Bittman shares recipes for what you might call A Vegan Day.
lead_paragraph: Mark Bittman shares recipes for what you might call A Vegan Day.

headline: Debating the Merits of a Profit-Sharing Plan
abstract: A business owner responds to reader questions about his plan to share profits with his employees — and promises to report back if the plan fails.
lead_paragraph: I’d like to thank everyone who commented on my series of posts about implementing a profit-sharing plan. The posts were published over a relatively long time period, five weeks, and generated a lot of feedback: 100 comments so far. Many of the earlier posts elicited questions that were answered in later installments. But apparently a lot of you would have done things differently.

headline: Going Vegan, if Only for a Day
abstract: Farmers’ markets are making it easy to be an occasional vegan.
lead_paragraph: It’s not worth trying to persuade anyone to become vegan, for a couple of very good reasons: one, it’s a losing battle, and two, it’s far from certain that a diet with no animal products is best for everyone. It’s increasingly evident, however, that a part-time vegan diet — one that emphasizes minimally processed plant food at the expense of everything else — is the direction that will do the most to benefit human health, increase animal welfare and reduce environmental impact. The remaining challenge, an undeniably big one, is to figure out how to make such a diet, which you might also call “flexitarian,” the standard.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Shooting at D.C. Navy Yard
abstract: What is known about the gunman?
lead_paragraph: In “Gunman and 12 Victims Killed in Shooting at D.C. Navy Yard,,” Michael D. Shear and Michael S. Schmidt write about the mass shooting:

headline: Inspired by Denise
keywords: ['Baby Boomers', 'Sex Crimes', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Tumors', 'Brain Cancer', 'Marriages', 'Emotions']
abstract: When my wife battled a brain tumor, her courage gave me what I needed to get past living with childhood abuse, and enjoy the rest of our time together.
lead_paragraph: If the M.R.I. scan that the neurosurgeon was pointing to was, as it appeared to me, a map of South America, the tumor in the brain of my wife, Denise, was the size of Brazil. Enormous, imposing, bulging all its borders, not to be denied.

headline: JPMorgan’s Settlement Over Trading Loss
abstract: JPMorgan Chase has agreed to pay about $800 million and make a groundbreaking admission of wrongdoing. | Samantha Perelman, the 23-year-old daughter of Ronald O. Perelman, will be at the center of a nasty family battle in court. | What if Janet L. Yellen doesn’t get the Federal Reserve job? | Complying with a tax evasion law is vexing foreign banks and financial firms.
lead_paragraph: JPMORGAN CHASE IS SAID TO ADMIT FAULT IN SETTLEMENT  |  JPMorgan Chase has agreed to pay about $800 million to government agencies in Washington and London, and to make a groundbreaking admission of wrongdoing, to resolve allegations stemming from its London Whale trading loss last year, Ben Protess and Jessica Silver-Greenberg report in DealBook. The settlements, expected this week, will help the bank move beyond the $6 billion loss and mend frayed relationships with regulators. In a victory for the bank, senior JPMorgan executives avoided charges in the case.

headline: Intersection: Laid-Back in Paris
abstract: In the Canal Saint-Martin neighborhood of Paris, Mehdi Attar draws style inspiration from rap music.
lead_paragraph: In the Canal Saint-Martin neighborhood of Paris, Mehdi Attar draws style inspiration from rap music.

headline: ‘Going to California’: Led Zeppelin’s and Martin Sexton’s
abstract: “Going to California” is this week’s cover trip by Val Haller, who matches tracks from her generation to those of her 20-something sons’ generation.
lead_paragraph: Val Haller, a music-obsessed baby boomer and the founder of the Web site Valslist.com, matches tracks from her generation to those of her 20-something sons’ generation.

headline: In Performance: Joe Manganiello of ‘A Streetcar Named Desire’
abstract: The actor performs a scene from the Yale Repertory Theater revival of the Tennessee Williams drama.
lead_paragraph: In the HBO series “True Blood,” Joe Manganiello plays Alcide, a sensitive but strong-minded Louisiana werewolf. Now he’s starring as a very different kind of wolf, the brutish Stanley Kowalski, in the Yale Repertory Theater revival of Tennessee Williams’s 1947 drama “A Streetcar Named Desire.” In this scene, Stanley talks to his wife, Stella, about how their life will return to normal once her Southern belle sister, Blanche, who has been staying with them at their New Orleans apartment, finally leaves. The production opens on Sept. 26 and continues through Oct. 12.

headline: Emmys Watch: Matt LeBlanc on ‘Episodes’
abstract: Matt LeBlanc, nominated for best actor in a comedy, talks about playing a character named Matt LeBlanc on “Episodes.” They’re both divorced and share custody with their exes, but he says that’s where the similarities end.
lead_paragraph: Matt LeBlanc is not Matt LeBlanc.

headline: U.N. Panel Urges International Action on North Korean Human Rights Abuses
abstract: An investigation of conditions in the nation’s gulags has been aided by information from people have escaped the police state over the years.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The United Nations experts investigating human rights conditions in North Korea said Tuesday that the “shocking” evidence they had collected from defectors and others suggested “large-scale” patterns of abuse that demanded an international response.

headline: Iran Moves to Mend Ties With West
abstract: In calling for “heroic leniency” in diplomacy, the supreme leader of Iran appeared to put his authority behind the nation’s moderate new president.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — Iran’s supreme leader seemed to put his authority behind Iran’s moderate new president on Tuesday, calling for “heroic leniency” in navigating the country’s diplomatic dispute with the West.

headline: China Internet Giant Buys Stake in Search Engine
abstract: Tencent Holdings, the biggest Internet company in China, said Monday that it had invested $448 million for a 36.5 percent stake in Sogou, a search engine, in a bid to keep pace with its rivals.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Another big investment has deepened a struggle for primacy among China’s online giants.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A month before a murderous rampage at the Washington Navy Yard, Aaron Alexis called the police in Rhode Island to complain that he had changed hotels three times because he was being pursued by people keeping him awake by sending vibrations through the walls.

To mark the conclusion of New York Fashion Week, we catalog the bows — some proud, some playful, some humble, some all of the above — of 14 fashion visionaries.

headline: How to Survive a Mass Extinction – Even One Caused by Us
keywords: ['Asteroids', 'Disasters and Emergencies', 'Earth', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Global Warming', 'Planets', 'Synthetic Biology', 'Volcanoes']
abstract: Handy tips for surviving the next mass extinction — even if it’s our own doing.
lead_paragraph: Scatter. Adapt. Remember. This is how the upbeat new apocalyptic book by science writer Annalee Newitz, the lead editor of the engaging tech/science/entertainment Web site io9, summarizes the strategies that could allow the human species to persist if faced with the kind of epic disruptions to Earth’s environment that have periodically erased the majority of living things.

headline: Eiji Toyoda, Promoter of the Toyota Way and Engineer of Its Growth, Dies at 100
abstract: Mr. Toyoda, the nephew of the Toyota group’s founder, was the architect of the company’s “lean manufacturing” method, which helped turn the automaker into a global powerhouse.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Eiji Toyoda, who as a member of Toyota Motor’s founding family and an architect of its “lean manufacturing” method helped turn the automaker into a global powerhouse and changed the face of modern manufacturing, died on Tuesday in Toyota City, Japan, where the company has its headquarters. He was 100.

headline: Fear and Loathing in North India’s Sugar Cane Town
keywords: ['Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Hinduism', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: More than 44 people have been killed and 42,000 people displaced in sectarian violence in the Muzaffarnagar district in Uttar Pradesh, about 80 miles from New Delhi.
lead_paragraph: BASSI KALAN, Uttar Pradesh— Zareena Khatun, 45, covered her head and part of her anguished face in a white scarf and her sun-battered hands worried a string of white prayer beads. Ms. Khatun sat on the floor of a madrasa in Bassi Kalan in Shamli district of the northern Indian state of Uttar Pradesh, which had been converted into a refugee camp.

The cause of the suit: the leftists equated the organization with “fascism” on a Facebook page. The main cause of rejection: freedom of speech, even blunt speech, is essential for political debate.

And Tuesday night they will also have to deal with R.A. Dickey’s knuckleball, which is usually not easy.

headline: A Run of Luck in Illinois for Its Embattled Governor

lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — It is hard to dream up a more auspicious series of events for Pat Quinn, Illinois’s governor, whose re-election hopes had appeared shaky enough that a line of fellow Democrats had been salivating over his job for ages.

headline: The Father of the 14th Amendment
keywords: ['Bill of Rights (US)', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Civil War (US) (1861-65)', 'Slavery', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The Civil War-era politician John Bingham wrote one of America’s most important documents.
lead_paragraph: In September 1863, the Ohio politician John Bingham was at the lowest point of his career. He had once been among the fastest-rising stars in American politics. Nine years earlier, he was among the first group of Republicans elected to the House of Representatives. Shortly after arriving in Washington, he established himself as one of the leading congressional voices against slavery. He was one of the new President Lincoln’s most steadfast supporters and a key member of the House’s pro-war caucus.

headline: What’s More Unpopular Than Health Care Reform?
abstract: Americans don’t want lawmakers to sabotage the Affordable Care Act.
lead_paragraph: A new Pew Research Center / USA Today poll indicates that Americans still haven’t embraced the Affordable Care Act, President Obama’s signature domestic policy measure. Fifty-three percent disapprove of the law, while 42 percent approve. That’s a decline in the level of support since last July, when, in the wake of the Supreme Court decision upholding the law, 43 percent disapproved and 47 percent approved.

headline: U.S. to Include Home Care Aides in Wage and Overtime Law
keywords: ['Wages and Salaries', 'Minimum Wage', 'Home Health Care', 'Elder Care', 'Overtime']

headline: Budget Office Warns That Deficits Will Rise Again Because Cuts Are Misdirected
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'National Debt (US)']
abstract: The nonpartisan office says that lawmakers are focused on the wrong kind of spending and that annual deficits will begin rising in 2016 as baby boomers age.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the White House and Congress careen toward another fiscal showdown, the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office warned on Tuesday that President Obama and lawmakers have been cutting the wrong kind of federal spending as they try to avoid the unsustainable buildup of debt that is projected in the coming decades.

headline: Tourists, Not Conventions, Feed Chicago Hotel Boom
keywords: ['Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Building (Construction)', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Travel and Vacations']

lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — After a drought in new construction dating back to the 2008 financial crisis, downtown Chicago is suddenly awash in new hotel projects.

headline: Netanyahu to Focus on Iranian Nuclear Threat at U.N.
abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel said he would discuss his proposal to halt Tehran’s nuclear program before the General Assembly and in a meeting with President Obama.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel said Tuesday that he would focus on halting Iran’s nuclear program in a meeting with President Obama in Washington at the end of the month and in his annual speech before the United Nations General Assembly, using the Syria situation to increase pressure for a “credible military threat.”

headline: Through Five Men’s Lives, a Memoirist Illuminates Her Own
abstract: In Jesmyn Ward’s memoir, “Men We Reaped,” she uses the downfall of others to tell her own story.
lead_paragraph: Jesmyn Ward, who won a National Book Award in 2011 for her novel “Salvage the Bones,” grew up in rural Mississippi, mostly in a series of single-wide trailers. Her mother was a maid; the family was on food stamps. Her father raised pit bulls he bred for fighting. He trained them with deflated bike tires.

lead_paragraph: PARIS — The Dutch defense ministry said on Tuesday that it had selected the F-35 fighter jet from Lockheed Martin to replace its aging fleet of F-16s, bringing an end to years of uncertainty over the Netherlands’ commitment to a program that has been plagued by technical delays and mounting development costs.

headline: Give I.V.F. a Chance

headline: Percentage of Americans Lacking Health Coverage Falls Again
abstract: The proportion of uninsured people fell to 15.4 percent in 2012, even though real household income and the poverty rate were not significantly different from their 2011 levels.

T caught up with the faces of the season to find out their secrets.

headline: Would I Let My Son Play Football?
abstract: The writer lobbied his parents for a chance to play tackle football when he turned 8, but, he says, because it worked out well for him does not mean it will work out well for everyone.
lead_paragraph: In 1987, shortly after I turned 8, I began to lobby my parents for a chance to play tackle football. My father was the coach of a high school freshman team, so in a way, I had been raised around the game.

headline: Still Recovering From Acid Attack, Artistic Director Returns to Bolshoi

lead_paragraph: MOSCOW – The Bolshoi Ballet artistic director, Sergei Filin — who was injured early this year in an acid attack that nearly blinded him — made a happy, if temporary, return to the historic Moscow theater on Tuesday as the company officially opened its 238th season.

headline: Improving the Big Data Toolkit
abstract: The next version of Hadoop, the open-source software used in Big Data analysis, is planned for next month. But it remains uncertain whether the fast-moving marketplace being built around the software will yield a clear winner.
lead_paragraph: Open source software tends to march into the marketplace step by step, a quiet but steady strategy compared with the grand marketing events of the commercial software world. And Hadoop, the bedrock software of the fast-growing Big Data business, is on the march.

headline: The Sound of Consolidation
abstract: Pandora’s stock sale will give it a war chest of more than $200 million to pursue smaller rivals.
lead_paragraph: Pandora looks as if it’s spinning a new theme song: The Consolidator. The $4.3 billion Internet radio firm is still losing money and the industry’s growth is slowing. Yet the stock has been on a tear, up more than 150 percent since the start of the year. Selling shares prudently shores up the balance sheet. It also gives the new boss – who knows about M.&A. – a chance to buy smaller rivals nipping at Pandora’s heels.

headline: Firms to Pay $14 Million to Settle
keywords: ['Hedge Funds', 'Short Selling', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']

lead_paragraph: The Internal Revenue Service recently decided that for same-sex couples filing federal income taxes, married means married — regardless of where you and your spouse live. The Social Security Administration, however, hasn’t officially come to the same determination yet regarding potentially valuable spousal benefits.

headline: Brazil’s Leader Postpones State Visit to Washington Over Spying
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: President Dilma Rousseff, angered over revelations of N.S.A. spying on her and her aides, delivered a sharp rebuke to the Obama administration.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Brazil’s president, Dilma Rousseff, said Tuesday that she was postponing a state visit to the United States, delivering a sharp rebuke to the Obama administration over revelations that the National Security Agency had spied on her, her inner circle of top aides and Brazil’s largest company, the oil giant Petrobras.

headline: Taking Ride-Share Services for a Spin
keywords: ['Budget Travel', 'Car-Pooling and Ride-Sharing', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Road Trips']
abstract: In an attempt to save money on a long drive this summer, the Frugal Traveler posted his route on three ride-share sites. Here’s what he learned.
lead_paragraph: If you followed my summer road trip from Baton Rouge, La., to Fargo, N.D., you may have wondered how I got from New York to my starting point in the first place. I drove 20 hours. Alone. It was far cheaper than flying into Louisiana — then having to rent a car, pay a (huge) drop-off fee in North Dakota and fly home.

headline: American Theater Wing Gala Sets Fund-Raising Record
abstract: The American Theater Wing raised $700,000 on Monday night at the Plaza Hotel, where 450 guests gathered to honor the director and producer Harold Prince.
lead_paragraph: The American Theater Wing, a nonprofit organization that helps oversee the Tony Awards, raised a record-breaking $700,000 on Monday night at its annual gala, where 450 guests gathered at the Plaza Hotel to honor the director and producer Harold Prince. The previous gala record was about $600,000, set last year.

headline: Tightening the  Wording on Results of Web Flight Searches
abstract: The Department of Transportation has told ticket agency Web sites to use more precise language for flight searches.
lead_paragraph: Messages like “no flights are available” or “no flights match your search criteria” will no longer be permitted on ticket agency Web sites when consumers search online for flights, even if no results are produced.

headline: Remembering Route 9 Roots

lead_paragraph: The chef Bill Telepan goes on a culinary journey back to New Jersey, the territory of his youth.

headline: Yet More Gun Violence
abstract: The answer is not more firearms.
lead_paragraph: Three days, two very different shootings. The first is an example of why the answer to gun violence isn’t more guns; the second illustrates the out-of-control nature of our firearm culture.

headline: Ex-JPMorgan Trader Slams Government’s Case
abstract: A lawyer for Julien Grout, a former JPMorgan Chase trader indicted on charges that he hid losses to protect his bonus, contends his client is being used as a scapegoat.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors have portrayed Julien Grout as the quintessential Wall Street criminal, accusing the former JPMorgan Chase trader of “systematically and fraudulently” masking losses to protect his bonus.

headline: The Brand of Me, as Seen on TV

lead_paragraph: Nobody is really expecting to be the next Oprah Winfrey because that’s not going to happen, not even for Ms. Winfrey. But this fall, new aspirants are jostling for a perch on daytime television, and they seek a talk show less to cap a career than to expand their marketing horizons.

headline: Indulging His Inner New Jersey Child
abstract: The chef Bill Telepan revisits the hair metal and onion rings of his youth.
lead_paragraph: SOUTH AMBOY, N.J. — “I was thinking maybe we should get some Def Leppard going,” Bill Telepan said, nodding toward the tabletop jukebox at the Peterpank Diner on Route 9. He was recalling the nights he spent here in the 1980s, with “that feathered Jersey hair and big glasses,” joking around with friends, listening to tunes and consuming plate after plate of onion rings.

headline: South Huntington, L.I., Defined by Its Famous Resident
abstract: Homes in this Town of Huntington hamlet range from bungalows on tiny plots to colonials on an acre or more.
lead_paragraph: In 1994, just before they were married, Mary Beth Kraese, who runs a marketing and social media business from her home, and her husband, Phillip, a steamfitter, bought a home in the community of South Huntington. Mr. Kraese had grown up in the neighborhood and she had spent her youth just to the north in Huntington Station.

headline: Charting a Path to Shared Prosperity

headline: Remembering the Victims of the Washington Navy Yard Shootings
abstract: Friends, family, co-workers and neighbors shared memories of the 12 people who were killed on Monday at the Washington Navy Yard.

To honor the 12 people killed in the Washington Navy Yard mass shooting, the secretary of defense and the secretary of the Navy placed a wreath at the United States Navy Memorial on Tuesday morning as police officials released the identities of the victims.
