headline: Discrimination Claim Against El Museo del Barrio Is Dismissed
abstract: A claim of gender discrimination filed by Margarita Aguilar, the former director of El Museo del Barrio, was dismissed after a state investigation.
lead_paragraph: A claim of gender discrimination and a hostile workplace filed by the former director of El Museo del Barrio has been dismissed following an investigation by New York State human rights officials. Museum officials had always contended that Margarita Aguilar, the former director, was dismissed for poor performance.

headline: Harvey Will Put Off Surgery, at Least for Now
abstract: Mets pitcher Matt Harvey has decided to try to rehabilitate his partly torn ulnar collateral ligament, then attempt to throw, rather than undergo surgery right away.
lead_paragraph: Matt Harvey’s right elbow felt fine Tuesday. He did not have the numbness, the tingling, the shooting pain often associated with elbow issues. He did not feel any pain.

headline: More Details Released on Aaron Alexis
abstract: At a news conference on Tuesday, officials provided additional information about the Navy Yard shooting suspect’s arrival in Washington and the weapons he used.
lead_paragraph: At a news conference on Tuesday, officials provided additional information about the Navy Yard shooting suspect’s arrival in Washington and the weapons he used.

headline: Concern Over Drug Costs
keywords: ['Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Many people worry that they will have to pay much more for their prescriptions, while some of the chronically ill fear they’ll have to pay thousands for their expensive drugs.
lead_paragraph: Among the most troubling questions facing consumers as they shop for insurance under the Obama administration’s new health care law is whether the plans will cover the drugs they take — and how much they will have to pay for them.

headline: ‘Mad Men’ to Split Final Season Into Two Parts
abstract: AMC is following the strategy it took with “Breaking Bad” in dividing up a final season into two installments, and it will be waiting a full year between arcs.
lead_paragraph: AMC is having a hard time separating from its hit series. On Tuesday the network announced that instead of a final season of “Mad Men,” as was planned for next spring, the much-acclaimed series will divide in two, pushing off the finale for another year.

headline: Red Bulls Coach Is Low-Tech
abstract: The Red Bulls will be seeking their fourth straight win when they face visiting Dallas on Sunday evening.
lead_paragraph: Take a gander at Twitter and initiate a search for Red Bulls Coach Mike Petke and you find pages like Mike Petke’s Sweater, Mike Petke’s Suit and Mike Petke (not official).

headline: Where to Draw the Line: Balancing Government Surveillance With the Fourth Amendment
abstract: In this lesson students will research new surveillance technologies, like facial scanning and domestic drones, and try to figure out whether their use should ever be prohibited as unconstitutional.
lead_paragraph: Overview | Sept. 17 is Constitution Day, and we are using this lesson and our related Student Opinion question to take a closer look at the Fourth Amendment and what it says about new government surveillance techniques.

headline: Few Gains Despite Better Economy
abstract: After several years of decreasing household income and increasing poverty in the United States, both measures were largely unchanged from 2011 to 2012.
lead_paragraph: After several years of decreasing household income and increasing poverty in the United States, both measures were largely unchanged from 2011 to 2012.

headline: City Plans Redevelopment for Vacant Area in Lower Manhattan
keywords: ['Area Planning and Renewal', 'Affordable Housing', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Mixed-Use Developments']
abstract: A mixed-use complex that includes 500 low-to-moderate income housing units is proposed for the Seward Park urban renewal area.
lead_paragraph: A corner of New York City, by Delancey and Essex Streets on the Lower East Side, has been a vacant, bitterly contested area for decades, as community groups and politicians battled to a standstill over what would replace tenements that were demolished in 1967.

headline: Now That’s Shrill
abstract: I defer to my superior.
lead_paragraph: I was pretty tough on Wolfgang Schäuble. But Ambrose Evans-Pritchard shows us how it’s really done.

headline: Snowden Among Nominees for a European Human Rights Prize
keywords: ['Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: The European Parliament included the fugitive former N.S.A. contractor on its list of potential recipients of the 2013 Sakharov Prize for Freedom of Thought.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The Sakharov Prize for Freedom of Thought, considered Europe’s top human rights award, has been bestowed on luminaries like Daw Aung San Suu Kyi and Nelson Mandela. This year, in a slap against Washington, the award could go to Edward J. Snowden, known as either the N.S.A. whistle-blower or a traitor, depending on one’s perspective.

headline: Fox News Unveils New Prime-Time Lineup
abstract: Greta Van Susteren will move to 7 p.m. from 10, making way for Sean Hannity. Megyn Kelly will host “The Kelly File” in Mr. Hannity’s old slot at 9.
lead_paragraph: The Fox News Channel on Tuesday announced a new lineup of hosts for its weeknight schedule, moving Greta Van Susteren to 7 p.m. from her current spot at 10 and moving Sean Hannity into the 10 p.m. hour from his present 9 o’clock slot.

headline: Justin Case Offers More Than a Play on Words
abstract: The Justin Power Case can charge an iPad and other gadgets, including iOS, Android and BlackBerry devices, at the same time.
lead_paragraph: When considering backup power for mobile devices, consumers typically have two choices: a portable battery that can charge multiple devices or a charging case, which is more convenient but usually works with only a single device.

headline: Security Council Returns to Role in Syria Conflict
abstract: Major differences over a draft resolution emerged, with Russia resisting Western pressure for strong language on enforcing a chemical arms ban.
lead_paragraph: Thrust back into a central role in resolving the Syrian conflict, the five permanent members of the United Nations Security Council met on Tuesday to negotiate a draft resolution that would hold Syria to its pledge of identifying all chemical weapons under government control for destruction, but diplomats said major differences over a draft quickly emerged.

headline: Eggplant Marinara Sandwich
abstract: Melissa Clark visits Frankies Spuntino in New York, where its owners share some culinary “grandma tricks” for making a memorable eggplant sandwich.
lead_paragraph: Melissa Clark visits Frankies Spuntino in New York, where its owners share some culinary “grandma tricks” for making a memorable eggplant sandwich.

headline: Content Creators Use Piracy to Gauge Consumer Interest
abstract: Both Netflix and HBO have expressed a more forgiving stance toward online piracy Web sites.
lead_paragraph: You would think that Netflix, HBO and the like don’t think too highly of video piracy Web sites. After all, two of the biggest hits on Netflix — Orange Is the New Black, a show about a women locked up in prison, and House of Cards, about a conniving politician — are among the most pirated content online. HBO’s Game of Thrones was the most pirated show of 2012.

headline: With Bose, Hear What You Want and Block the Rest
abstract: Bose designed its QuietComfort 20 in-ear headphones with a control module that actively cancels unwanted noise.
lead_paragraph: When Bose decided to build a pair of in-ear headphones with a noise-canceling feature, it faced a quandary: how to stuff that technology into a tiny package.

headline: Man on Fire | Matthew Day Jackson
abstract: Most Wednesday evenings in summer, the artist Matthew Day Jackson races a Super Comp dragster on a quarter-mile track in New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: Most Wednesday evenings in summer, the artist Matthew Day Jackson races a Super Comp dragster on a quarter-mile track in New Jersey.

headline: Three Strikes And You’re, Well, Still Playing The Same Game
abstract: On being wrong again and again and again and again and ….
lead_paragraph: Steve Benen notes that Republicans have been completely wrong about the U.S. economy three times in the past two decades — about Clinton, Bush, and Obama — but haven’t changed their doctrine a bit.

headline: The Secret to a Crisp and Tender Eggplant Sandwich
abstract: Frankies Spuntino’s fried eggplant sandwich is based on recipes brought over from Italy by the owners’ grandmothers.
lead_paragraph: The Restaurant Takeaway column is devoted to restaurant dishes you can make in your own kitchen, tested and tweaked for home cooks.

headline: Time Magazine Names Its First Female Managing Editor
abstract: Nancy Gibbs, 53, is a prolific writer for the 90-year-old newsweekly and was its most recent deputy managing editor.
lead_paragraph: Nancy Gibbs, 53, was named the new managing editor of Time magazine on Tuesday, the first woman to become the top editor at the newsweekly in its 90-year history.

headline: Israel Weighs Response to a Ruling Limiting Detentions of Migrants
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Illegal Immigration']
abstract: An emotional public debate was reignited after Israel’s Supreme Court overturned a law allowing the government to detain migrants and asylum seekers for up to three years without trial.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israeli lawmakers grappled on Tuesday with new questions of how to deal with the tens of thousands of migrants from Africa who have entered the country illegally, now that Israel’s Supreme Court has overturned a law allowing the government to detain migrants and asylum seekers for up to three years without trial.

headline: Can Minecraft Be Educational? Readers Respond
abstract: Parents and even a few children responded positively to a column on Minecraft and its benefits for kids as an educational tool — albeit one they are obsessed with.
lead_paragraph: When I published my Disruptions column this weekend about Minecraft, a relatively simple computer game that children today are utterly obsessed with, I was fully prepared for a barrage of angry e-mails and comments from readers. After all, I wasn’t just writing about the game, I was noting that a video game could actually be a good thing for children.

headline: Wi-Fi and Cellphone Service on Subway Trains? M.T.A. Leader Says It May Happen
abstract: The chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, Thomas F. Prendergast, said the agency’s ambitions for wireless service went beyond station platforms, but questions remain.
lead_paragraph: A New York City subway ride remains, for many, an exercise in gaze aversion. Maps are inspected. Advertisements are read in their entirety. A staring contest with an empty seat can prove preferable to even the briefest human interaction.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Pretty in Pink at Burberry Prorsum
abstract: The models’ makeup matched the runway, which was littered with rose petals that fell from the sky at yesterday’s show in London.
lead_paragraph: Think pink! That was the makeup artist Wendy Rowe’s modus operandi before the Burberry Prorsum runway show yesterday in London. “Of course, Burberry is about the English Rose, but instead of being twee, our girl is the cooler version,” she said while Cara Delevingne slinked into her makeup chair. “There’s something just a little bit off about her.” Rowe groomed eyebrows and left lashes mascara-free, then swiped Burberry Tea Rose eye shadow, a petal pink shade, around the eyes. She then used blush to even complexions and contour cheekbones for a feline effect. “We’re not show-offs here, are we?” Wendy asked Delevingne, who shook her head the firmest no. The final touch: a splatter of pink Burberry lipstick in Trench Kiss (out this fall). “I do love a trench kiss,” sighed Delevingne, before offering a pout.

headline: Ilili Box Will Serve Middle Eastern Fast Food
abstract: The Lebanese chef Philippe Massoud is serving takeout from a stand just outside Madison Square Park, and more restaurant openings.
lead_paragraph: Headliner

headline: Living in South Huntington, L.I.
abstract: The birthplace of Walt Whitman offers homes from $220,000 to $925,000, and reasonable commute.
lead_paragraph: The birthplace of Walt Whitman offers homes from $220,000 to $925,000, and reasonable commute.

headline: ‘Sleepy Hollow’ Ratings Offer Hopeful Sign for Network TV
abstract: Fox’s new series about a reincarnated Ichabod Crane had a big audience for its premiere; and ABC’s “Dancing With the Stars” showed some life.
lead_paragraph: The network television season got off to an early and swinging start on Monday thanks to the ax wielded by the Headless Horseman on the Fox network.

headline: Familiarity Breeds Content
abstract: Frank Bruni, a former Times restaurant critic, praises the virtues of visiting a favorite spot again and again.
lead_paragraph: What a cad I used to be, constantly ditching the bistro that had opened only four months ago for the week-old trattoria with an even dewier complexion, callously trading in the yellowtail sashimi that had been so good to me for a hot tamale of unproven charms.

headline: Campaign for Prime Minister in India Gets Off to Violent Start
abstract: The candidacy of Narendra Modi, one of India’s most divisive politicians, for prime minister raises the prospect that next year’s national elections could be the deadliest in decades.
lead_paragraph: AHMEDABAD, India — India’s most important election in a generation began in earnest this month the same way consequential elections nearly always start here — with a proclamation and a deadly riot.

headline: When Obese Children Develop Eating Disorders, Doctors Often Don’t Notice
abstract: Obese adolescents are at significant risk of developing eating disorders, and health professionals, focused on weight loss, may be at significant risk of not diagnosing them, according to a new report.
lead_paragraph: Obese adolescents are at significant risk of developing eating disorders, according to a report due in the October issue of Pediatrics. And the two case studies highlighted in the paper suggest that health professionals may be at significant risk of not diagnosing them.

headline: Spike Lee Wins $300,000 Gish Prize
abstract: The filmmaker Spike Lee will receive the Dorothy and Lillian Gish Prize, one of the largest in the arts.
lead_paragraph: The filmmaker Spike Lee is this year’s recipient of the $300,000 Dorothy and Lillian Gish Prize, one of the largest in the arts, the Gish Prize Trust announced. Mr. Lee will receive the award on Oct. 30 at a private event at the Museum of Modern Art.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Syria, Indonesia, Mexico and Washington.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Syria, Indonesia, Mexico and Washington.

headline: Bangladesh Orders Death for Islamist in Killings
keywords: ['Sentences (Criminal)', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: A Supreme Court decision increased the punishment of Abdul Quader Mollah, an Islamist leader, who had received a life sentence in February.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — Bangladesh’s Supreme Court on Tuesday condemned a senior Islamist leader, Abdul Quader Mollah, to death by hanging — increasing his punishment for a mass murder conviction from the life sentence he received from a special tribunal in February, and sparking demonstrations.

headline: Estela
abstract: Inside the intimate dining room on Houston Street.
lead_paragraph: Inside the intimate dining room on Houston Street.

headline: The Woman Who Knew Too Much
abstract: Nicole Holofcener’s “Enough Said” stars Julia Louis-Dreyfus, James Gandolfini and Catherine Keener.
lead_paragraph: “I’m tired of being funny,” says Eva, the Los Angeles massage therapist whose midlife travails are the subject of “Enough Said,” a small miracle of a movie written and directed by Nicole Holofcener. It is possible to sympathize with Eva and also to marvel at her curious sense of timing. Happily — or at least not miserably — divorced, with nice friends and a gratifyingly nondysfunctional teenage daughter, Eva, played by the reliably hilarious Julia Louis-Dreyfus, uses her sense of humor as a social tool and an emotional defense. She’s a good sport, a designated joker, which is fine except that it means that she never has to be taken seriously, even by herself.

headline: After Navy Yard Shooting, a New Look at Gun Control
abstract: Even more modest measures to address gun violence, including ones with bipartisan support, seemed unlikely to go anywhere.
lead_paragraph: Even among those who fought hardest to pass an ill-fated gun control bill earlier this year, the political reality was undeniable: If the Newtown, Conn., massacre could not persuade Congress to pass tougher laws, a mass shooting less than a mile away from Capitol Hill was not going to either.

headline: Having Dinner With a Mild Eccentric
abstract: At Estela, the little differences keep boredom at bay.
lead_paragraph: If you wanted to take the measure of Ignacio Mattos’s cooking at Estela, which opened on East Houston Street in June, you might look at the burrata on the menu and think: no, too easy. Anyone can slap burrata on a plate and wait for the moaning to start. But order it anyway, so you can see what happens when Mr. Mattos puts this louche, voluptuous cheese on a juice cleanse.

headline: Lofty Bids Emerge for a Piece of New York’s Skyline
keywords: ['Empire State Building (Manhattan, NY)', 'Initial Public Offerings', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Historic Buildings and Sites']
abstract: Malkin Holdings may move ahead as early as this week with plans to sell shares to the public through a real estate investment trust.
lead_paragraph: After months of contentious behind-the-scenes battles, the public may finally get its chance to own a piece of a New York City landmark — the Empire State Building.

headline: State Law Prevented Sale of Assault Rifle to Suspect Last Week, Officials Say
keywords: ['Washington Navy Yard Shooting (2013)', 'Firearms', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Gun Control']
abstract: The suspect in the Washington Navy Yard shooting was stopped from buying an assault rifle last week by a Virginia law prohibiting such sales to out-of-state buyers, officials said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The suspect in the killing of 12 people at the Washington Navy Yard on Monday test-fired an AR-15 assault rifle at a Virginia gun store last week but was stopped from buying one because state law there limits the sale of such weapons to out-of-state buyers, according to two senior law enforcement officials.

headline: Comic Bits Stitched Together With Irreverence
abstract: The sketch-comedy series “Key & Peele” begins its third season Wednesday night on Comedy Central.
lead_paragraph: If you haven’t watched “Key & Peele,” Keegan-Michael Key and Jordan Peele’s sharp and periodically hilarious show on Comedy Central, you’ve got time before the premiere of Season 3 on Wednesday night to catch up. YouTube and comedycentral.com offer collections of their greatest hits, from “Das Negros” (Mr. Key and Mr. Peele in whiteface placating a Nazi played by Ty Burrell of “Modern Family”) to the original, sidesplitting “Substitute Teacher” (Mr. Key as an inner-city disciplinarian taking roll in a suburban classroom: “Where is A-A-Ron right now?”).

headline: Framed by the Sky, Lighted by the Moon
abstract: A celebratory prelude to the Fall for Dance festival brought back choreography to the Delacorte Theater for free shows on Monday and Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Decades ago, each fall dance season began in Central Park. From 1962 to 1980 (except for gaps caused by financing in 1968 and 1973), an annual festival drew crowds to the Delacorte Theater. First it was called the Rebekah Harkness Foundation Dance Festival and then, from 1969 on, the New York Dance Festival, a name befitting its place in the civic fabric. Always it was free and eclectic, its program mixing established and little-known artists, its audiences mingling connoisseurs and first-timers. New Yorkers loved it, and after the financing collapsed, and it was gone, it was spoken of as “much-missed.”

headline: Classical Saxophone, an Outlier, Is Anointed by John Adams Concerto
abstract: The soloist Timothy McAllister and the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra will give the United States premiere of John Adams’s Saxophone Concerto on Friday.
lead_paragraph: The saxophone is the most ambiguous of instruments. Though ubiquitous in jazz and pop, it has long remained on the fringes of classical music, brought in for the occasional “Bolero,” but rarely afforded the spotlight. When it finds its way into the orchestra, it often functions as a jazzy outsider, an ambassador of pop.

headline: Model Diary | Meet Ben Allen, the New Kid on the Block
abstract: The 17-year-old newcomer to big-name runways, now the star of a Jil Sander campaign, is suddenly the guy that every men’s wear designer wants to cast.
lead_paragraph: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Veggies Jumping into Yogurt, Anchovies from Italy and More
abstract: Recommendations for the week of Sept. 17.
lead_paragraph: To Spoon: Fresh Vegetables Join the Yogurt Crowd

headline: Crying the Same Salty Tears: Despair Over the Tenuous Future of a Species
abstract: “Sacred Elephant,” at La MaMa, elevates the creature and despairs over its fate.
lead_paragraph: “Maybe we never outgrow the imaginary animal kingdom of childhood. Maybe it’s the one we are trying to save.”

headline: Kerry’s Remarks on Syria Ahead of Senate Briefing
abstract: Following is the text of remarks to reporters by Secretary of State John Kerry before a closed Senate briefing on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Following is the text of remarks to reporters by Secretary of State John Kerry before a closed Senate briefing on Tuesday, as transcribed by Federal News Service:

headline: This Debt Ceiling Fight Isn’t About Spending
abstract: Hard-line conservatives are narrowly focused on achieving one impossible thing: The end of health care reform.
lead_paragraph: Senator Mitch McConnell said today that raising the debt ceiling represents an opportunity to demand that President Obama “do something about the debt.” He said that was the “view of virtually every Republican.”

headline: Playing Well With Others, What They Do Best
abstract: Elvis Costello and the Roots gave an extended lesson in collaborative thrift during a concert at Brooklyn Bowl on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Elvis Costello and the Roots began their encore at Brooklyn Bowl late Monday night with a wry lamentation, as churning and ominous as a gathering storm on the plains. The song was “Wise Up Ghost,” which provides both a title and a centerpiece for their trenchant new album on Blue Note. Its delivery was impassioned, unruly, a bit grandiose — gripping, but in a crucially different way from the rest of the show.

headline: Fall for Dance
abstract: The festival brought back choreography to the Delacorte Theater for free shows on Monday and Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: The festival brought back choreography to the Delacorte Theater for free shows on Monday and Tuesday.

headline: Trimmings: London Fashion Week
keywords: ['London Fashion Week', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Shoes and Boots', 'Handbags and Purses', 'Jewels and Jewelry']
abstract: Accessories from the Burberry, Preen, Simone Rocha spring shows, and more.
lead_paragraph: Accessories from the Burberry, Preen, Simone Rocha spring shows, and more.

headline: A Sound, Then Silence (Try Not to Breathe)
abstract: The “Monotone-Silence” Symphony, an eccentric 1960 work by the conceptual painter Yves Klein, will finally get a hearing in New York on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: The sound, a D major chord produced by an orchestra and a chorus, begins abruptly, full force, and fills the air for 20 minutes, like a sonorous foghorn with a stuck switch. It ends as suddenly as it begins, but there is no applause because the orchestra is only half finished — its members sit without playing or even moving, “performing” silence for just as long.

headline: What, No Kick Line? A Novelty From the Rockettes
abstract: A section of “Heart & Lights,” the Rockettes’ first spring production at Radio City Music Hall since 1997, will be unveiled on Wednesday on “America’s Got Talent.”
lead_paragraph: As the director of the Rockettes, Linda Haberman knew it was time to leave Santa behind. As she put it, “Christmas is kind of a safe place to live.”

headline: Ideas From Near and Far Meet in Intimate Scale
abstract: Johnny Gandelsman brought his solo violin and wide-ranging tastes to his New York recital debut at Le Poisson Rouge.
lead_paragraph: The busy violinist Johnny Gandelsman was supposed to have made his New York recital debut on Aug. 13 at Le Poisson Rouge. But fate intervened; announcing the concert’s cancellation on Twitter, he compressed into a hashtag the saying, “If you want to make God laugh, tell him your plans.”

headline: Proclaiming Sacred Mysteries
abstract: Patriarch Tikhon Choir, a new ensemble devoted to music of the Orthodox Church, made its debut on Monday at St. Malachy’s.
lead_paragraph: The Patriarch Tikhon Choir, a mixed-voice professional ensemble of 35 American, Canadian and Russian singers, was formed recently to focus on Orthodox Christian sacred music, a tradition it hopes to nurture in the United States.

headline: Occupy Has Mellow 2nd Birthday, With Appearance From the Hipster Cop
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Police']
abstract: The smaller turnout on Tuesday for the second anniversary of Occupy Wall Street caused some private grumbling among protesters, but they said the reasons for their movement remained relevant.
lead_paragraph: A sea of police officers formed around Zuccotti Park in Lower Manhattan on Tuesday morning, prepared to keep the peace.

headline: The Outlook for Federal Spending
abstract: While Congress and the White House have trimmed federal spending since deficits peaked in 2009, they have not made reductions in areas that are projected to drive future debt — chiefly Medicare and Medicaid.
lead_paragraph: While Congress and the White House have trimmed federal spending since deficits peaked in 2009, they have not made reductions in areas that are projected to drive future debt — chiefly Medicare and Medicaid.

headline: He’s Dead, but Not Quite Gone
abstract: “The Life and Sort of Death of Eric Argyle,” a play about a man’s immediate afterlife, is having its American premiere at 59E59 Theaters.
lead_paragraph: One minute, you’re going about your business, absent-mindedly walking into a head-on collision with a bus; the next, you’re stuck in a room, subject to the whims of a rather officious middle manager. That’s life — and whatever it is that comes immediately after it, as imagined in “The Life and Sort of Death of Eric Argyle.”

headline: Spokesman and Social Media Activist for Muslim Brotherhood Arrested in Cairo
abstract: Security forces on Tuesday arrested Gehad el-Haddad, a senior Muslim Brotherhood official who handled the group’s communication with the foreign news media, Egyptian officials said.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Security forces on Tuesday arrested Gehad el-Haddad, a senior Muslim Brotherhood official who handled the group’s communication with the foreign news media, Egyptian officials said. His arrest was part of a continuing roundup of hundreds or thousands of Brotherhood leaders in the two months since the military ouster of President Mohamed Morsi, an ally of the group.

headline: Safeway Puts Up Defense After Hedge Fund Amasses Stake
keywords: ['Hedge Funds', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Supermarkets and Grocery Stores']
abstract: The $6 billion hedge fund Jana Partners has disclosed a 6.2 percent stake in Safeway and has begun agitating for changes at the grocer.
lead_paragraph: The grocer Safeway has gone on the defense days after the activist hedge fund Jana Partners declared a 6.2 percent stake in the company.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Modern Warfare, and What Facebook Ads Say About You
abstract: Tuesday’s highlights from around the Web include an image of Syrian rebels fighting with the aid of an iPad. Plus, an investigation into what Facebook ads say about you, or why Facebook thinks you need to lose belly fat.
lead_paragraph: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: China Finds Resistance to Oil Deals in Africa
abstract: Some cash-starved African states are showing an assertiveness that suggests the days of China’s unbridled influence as a mega-investor may be waning.
lead_paragraph: NIAMEY, Niger — In Niger, government officials have fought a Chinese oil giant step by step, painfully undoing parts of a contract they call ruinous. In neighboring Chad, they have been even more forceful, shutting down the Chinese and accusing them of gross environmental negligence. In Gabon, they have seized major oil tracts from China, handing them over to the state company.

headline: De Blasio Has Huge Lead Over Lhota, Poll Finds
abstract: Bill de Blasio, the Democratic nominee for mayor, leads his Republican rival, Joseph J. Lhota, by over 40 points, a new public opinion survey shows.
lead_paragraph: Bill de Blasio opens the final phase of his bid for New York City mayor with a daunting lead over his Republican opponent, Joseph J. Lhota, who appears to face a tougher path to victory than even his most pessimistic supporters imagined.

headline: French Teacher Killed in Cairo Jail as Detained Canadians Begin Hunger Strike
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Prisons and Prisoners']
abstract: A French citizen arrested for violating an army curfew was beaten to death in an Egyptian jail cell late Monday night, on the same day that two Canadians held without charge for more than a month began a hunger strike.
lead_paragraph: A French citizen arrested for violating an army curfew was beaten to death in a Cairo jail cell late Monday night, on the same day that two Canadians held without charge for more than a month began a hunger strike — a grim pairing of events that drew attention both to the dysfunctional Egyptian police force and to rising xenophobia in a country whose economy once relied largely on its booming tourism sector.

headline: In a Faded Literary Capital, Efforts at a Revival
abstract: In a city long famous as a big market for Arabic writers, there is growing worry that the collapse of book culture is a direct mirror of Sudan’s overall decline.
lead_paragraph: KHARTOUM, Sudan — On the corner of an old colonial building in downtown Khartoum sits the city’s oldest bookstore, Sudan Bookshop. It was established in 1902, three years after Britain established control over Sudan, and for a long time it was a magnet for the city’s civil servants, politicians and intellectuals.

headline: New Rules Could Strip Pensions From Politicians Convicted of Corruption
abstract: The policies, aimed at stopping jailed politicians from collecting public money, were detailed Tuesday by Preet Bharara, the United States attorney for the Southern District of New York.
lead_paragraph: Any public officials convicted of federal corruption charges could lose their government pension under new policies announced on Tuesday night by the top federal prosecutor in Manhattan.

headline: Tom Ford: Spring 2014 RTW
abstract: London
lead_paragraph: London

headline: Egypt Arrests Brotherhood Figure Who Handled News Media
abstract: Gehad el-Haddad, a senior official of the Muslim Brotherhood who dealt with the foreign news media, was the latest of the group’s spokesmen to be apprehended.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Security forces on Tuesday arrested Gehad el-Haddad, a senior official of the Muslim Brotherhood who handled the group’s communication with the foreign news media, security officials said. His arrest was part of a continuing roundup of thousands of Brotherhood members in the two months since the military ouster of President Mohamed Morsi, an ally of the group.

headline: Dole Food’s Buyout in 2013 Looks a Lot Like One in 2003
abstract: In the latest buyout, many of the same people are involved and the regulatory filings have been nearly identical.
lead_paragraph: Once is apparently not enough for David H. Murdock, the chief executive of the Dole Food Company.

headline: Newport, R.I., Police Report on Aaron Alexis
abstract: Two officers detailed an encounter with Mr. Alexis at a Marriott in which he said that after an argument at a Virginia airport, the person “had sent three people to follow him and to keep him awake by talking to him and sending vibrations to his body” via a microwave.
lead_paragraph: Two officers detailed an encounter with Mr. Alexis at a Marriott in which he said that after an argument at a Virginia airport, the person “had sent three people to follow him and to keep him awake by talking to him and sending vibrations to his body” via a microwave.

headline: Robert A. Knakal
abstract: Mr. Knakal is the chairman of Massey Knakal Realty Services, a commercial real estate brokerage firm in New York. He started the company in 1988 with Paul Massey, the chief executive.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Knakal, 51, is the chairman of Massey Knakal Realty Services, a commercial real estate brokerage firm in New York. He started the company in 1988 with Paul Massey, the chief executive.

headline: PGA to Discuss Reducing Viewers’ Impact on Penalties
abstract: Tour Commissioner Tim Finchem expressed concern Tuesday about the format’s fairness, in part because some players, like Tiger Woods, tend to get more TV time than others.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — A clamorous football crowd can induce visiting squads into committing penalties by drowning out the signal calls.

headline: A Week Later, No End in Sight for Primary Vote Count
abstract: Despite stinging criticism of New York City’s Board of Elections, the executive director, Michael J. Ryan, said the board had compressed its usual vote-counting schedule.
lead_paragraph: The Board of Elections acknowledged on Tuesday that, a week after the primary election for mayor of New York City, it still did not know when it would be able to release official results.

headline: Tourist-Hungry New York to Put Visitor Center in Macy’s
abstract: Visitors to the center in the department store will be able to get directions, make dinner reservations and buy tickets to other attractions.
lead_paragraph: In debates among the New York City mayoral candidates, there has been plenty of discussion about those responsible for the state of city schools, or the tactics of the Police Department. The name of George A. Fertitta, the man credited with luring millions of free-spending tourists to the city, has not come up.

headline: Firm That Sent 42 Million Texts Settles in Spam Case
abstract: Rentbro and its principals, Daniel Pessin and Jacob Engel, agreed to turn over all remaining assets and to repay up to $377,321.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Trade Commission said on Tuesday that it had settled charges against a Florida company and its two top executives for sending more than 42 million unwanted and deceptive text messages to consumers.

headline: Judge Throws Out Officers’ Convictions in Killings After Hurricane Katrina
keywords: ['Hurricane Katrina (2005)', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: The judge harshly criticized federal prosecutors for making anonymous comments on the Web site of a New Orleans newspaper before and during the trial.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — Citing “grotesque prosecutorial misconduct” on the part of federal lawyers here and in Washington, a judge on Tuesday threw out the 2011 convictions of five former police officers who had been found guilty in a momentous civil rights case of killing two citizens and engaging in an extensive cover-up in the days after Hurricane Katrina.

headline: Deadline Approaching, U.S. Is Weighing More Charges in Madoff Case
abstract: Among those still under scrutiny in connection with the Ponzi scheme are Shana Madoff Swanson, Mr. Madoff’s niece, and Paul J. Konigsberg, an accountant.
lead_paragraph: With federal prosecutors in Manhattan facing a December deadline to bring additional charges connected to Bernard L. Madoff’s multibillion-dollar Ponzi scheme, they are weighing criminal charges against several people connected to the case, said people briefed on the investigation. Among those still under scrutiny are Shana Madoff Swanson, a senior executive at the firm, and Paul J. Konigsberg, a longtime accountant in Mr. Madoff’s inner circle.

headline: At Northwestern, ‘Caught Napping’ Can Be a Positive
abstract: The Northwestern Wildcats are not only undefeated this year, they are well-rested thanks to a regimen that emphasizes good sleeping habits.
lead_paragraph: Northwestern is 3-0 heading into Saturday’s game against Maine, with an offense averaging more than 43 points a game and a roster that is getting the right amount of sleep.

headline: S.&P. Bond Deals Are on the Rise Since It Relaxed Rating Criteria
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Credit Ratings and Credit Rating Agencies', 'Mortgage-Backed Securities', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis']
abstract: As banks began reviving the market for bonds tied to home loans, S.& P.’s tough stance was hurting the bottom line.
lead_paragraph: During a meeting at Standard & Poor’s New York offices in the summer of 2012, analysts responsible for rating bonds tied to home loans were informed that their unit had sustained big losses in the previous quarter.

headline: Mexico: Stranded Tourists Airlifted From Acapulco
abstract: Mexico began airlifting hundreds of stranded tourists to Mexico City from Acapulco after a tropical storm flooded highways, the airport and some hotels.
lead_paragraph: Mexico began airlifting hundreds of stranded tourists to Mexico City from Acapulco on Tuesday after a tropical storm flooded highways, the airport and some hotels at the faded and violent Pacific resort town. It was another blow to the city, once a playground for the Hollywood set but now struggling to overcome organized crime violence and a passé reputation. Days of heavy rain from the storm, as well as another on the Gulf Coast, have sent rivers of mud cascading through scores of cities and villages on both coasts, leaving an estimated 47 people dead and thousands homeless, one of the highest storm tolls in Mexico in recent years. Although many hotels in Acapulco were undamaged, some began rationing food and other provisions because of power failures and the inability of workers or trucks to get through flooded streets on the outskirts to supply them.

headline: China: Accused Bomber Claims Explosion Was Unintentional
abstract: A man accused of detonating a bomb this summer in Beijing Capital International Airport pleaded not guilty on Tuesday. No one was injured in the blast.
lead_paragraph: A man accused of detonating a bomb this summer in Beijing Capital International Airport pleaded not guilty on Tuesday. The man, Ji Zhongxing, had not intended to set off an explosive, his lawyer said, according to online reports of the trial. No one was injured in the blast, which took place on July 20, except Mr. Ji, and he was wheeled into the courtroom on Tuesday on a stretcher. Mr. Ji had been trying to call attention to grievances against officials in the southern city of Dongguan, whom he accused of having beaten him. Police officers tried to stop Mr. Ji from carrying out his protest, which unfolded in Terminal 3, before the explosion took place. Mr. Ji’s case elicited widespread sympathy among Chinese Internet users, who accuse the government of hassling rather than helping petitioners like Mr. Ji.

headline: In New York, Having a Job, or 2, Doesn’t Mean Having a Home
keywords: ['Homeless Persons', 'Affordable Housing', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Public and Subsidized Housing', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Unemployment', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']
abstract: Affordable-housing advocates say the homeless work force is proof of the widening gap between wages and rents and the difficulty in escaping the shelter system.
lead_paragraph: On many days, Alpha Manzueta gets off from one job at 7 a.m., only to start her second at noon. In between she goes to a place she’s called home for the last three years — a homeless shelter.

headline: Cuban Slugger Brings Promise and Risk to the Plate
abstract: Jose Dariel Abreu recently left Cuba and is expected to sign a lucrative contract, though it remains to be seen if he can hit major league pitching.
lead_paragraph: During this year’s World Baseball Classic, Cuba’s Jose Dariel Abreu hit a grand slam against China that was positively jaw-dropping. Abreu, a powerfully built right-handed hitter, loaded up on his back leg, waited on a curveball and hit a towering drive halfway up the outfield stands. Thirty major league front offices were surely paying attention.

headline: Extended Ruling by Secret Court Backs Collection of Phone Data

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court on Tuesday offered its most extensive public explanation for why it has allowed the government to keep records of all Americans’ phone calls, releasing a previously classified  opinion in which it said the program was constitutional and did not violate Americans’ privacy rights.

headline: The Mismeasure of Poverty
abstract: Lowering poverty means both recognizing the successes of safety net programs we now have and devising new policies that can spread the wealth created by economic growth.
lead_paragraph: THE Census Bureau reported yesterday that the poverty rate in America held stable between 2011 and 2012, at about 15 percent. According to the official measure, poverty today is higher than it was in 1973, when it reached a historical low of 11.1 percent.

headline: The Man With Pink Hair
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Nuclear Weapons']
abstract: See what dealing with the Middle East can do to your hair?
lead_paragraph: I was at a conference in Bern, Switzerland, last week and struggling with my column. News of Russia’s proposal for Syria to surrender its poison gas was just breaking and changing every hour, forcing me to rewrite my column every hour. To clear my head, I went for a walk along the Aare River, on Schifflaube Street. Along the way, I found a small grocery shop and stopped to buy some nectarines. As I went to pay, I was looking down, fishing for my Swiss francs, and when I looked up at the cashier, I was taken aback: He had pink hair. A huge shock of neon pink hair — very Euro-punk from the ’90s. While he was ringing me up, a young woman walked by, and he blew her a kiss through the window — not a care in the world.

headline: The Antibiotic Resistance Crisis
abstract: A federal health report issues the first solid numbers on the extent of the problem.
lead_paragraph: The overuse of antibiotics in medicine and agriculture has long been known to foster the emergence of germs that are resistant to drugs. On Monday, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention issued the first solid numbers on the extent of the problem. It said that at least two million Americans fall ill from antibiotic-resistant infections each year, of whom at least 23,000 die from the infections, a very conservative estimate.

headline: Online Classes Move Closer to Degree Programs
abstract: Coursera and edX, the two largest providers of massive open online courses, are inching closer to offering degree programs, although the courses so far carry no academic credit.
lead_paragraph: Coursera and edX, the two largest providers of massive open online courses, or MOOCs, are inching closer to offering degree programs, although the courses so far carry no academic credit. Coursera is now offering courses from the University of Pennsylvania’s Wharton School, covering most of its MBA program’s first year curriculum. And Edx is starting two “sequences,” linked courses in a particular discipline. Both are from MIT: Foundations of Computer Science, a set of undergraduate courses that will begin this fall, and Supply Chain and Logistics Management, a set of graduate level courses that will begin in fall 2014.

headline: New Chief Nominated for Justice Dept. Division
abstract: President Obama on Tuesday nominated Leslie R. Caldwell, a defense lawyer specializing in white-collar cases, to be assistant attorney general for the Justice Department’s criminal division.
lead_paragraph: President Obama on Tuesday nominated Leslie R. Caldwell, a defense lawyer specializing in white-collar cases, to be assistant attorney general for the Justice Department’s criminal division. From 2002 to 2004, Ms. Caldwell, a former federal prosecutor, was the director of the Justice Department’s task force that handled prosecutions related to the 2001 collapse of Enron. Ms. Caldwell is a graduate of Penn State and George Washington University Law School and has worked in the United States attorney’s offices in the Northern District of California and the Eastern District of New York.

headline: What’s On Wednesday

lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (Lifetime) JULIE & JULIA (2009) In yet another of her Oscar-nominated performances, Meryl Streep, above, plays the chef Julia Child in this film written and directed by Nora Ephron. Amy Adams is Julie Powell, who for one year works her way through “Mastering the Art of French Cooking” (Child was the principal author) and blogs about it. “By now this actress has exhausted every superlative that exists, and to suggest that she has outdone herself is only to say that she’s done it again,” A. O. Scott, writing in The New York Times, said of Ms. Streep. “Her performance goes beyond physical imitation, though she has the rounded shoulders and the fluting voice down perfectly.” And though Ms. Adams may have been outmatched by Ms. Streep, Mr. Scott called Stanley Tucci, as Child’s husband, Paul, impeccable.

headline: Daily Report: Rentbro, Sender of 42 Million Texts, Settles in Spam Case
abstract: The Federal Trade Commission settled charges against a Florida company and its two top executives for sending more than 42 million unwanted and deceptive text messages to consumers.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Trade Commission said on Tuesday that it had settled charges against a Florida company and its two top executives for sending more than 42 million unwanted and deceptive text messages to consumers, Edward Wyatt reports.

headline: Verdict for Bo Xilai to Be Announced on Sunday
abstract: Political analysts said they expected a lengthy prison sentence for Mr. Bo, a former high-ranking Chinese official whose downfall shook the Communist Party.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — A verdict and sentence in the case of Bo Xilai, the former high-ranking official whose downfall shook the Communist Party, will be announced Sunday, Chinese authorities said on Wednesday.

headline: Why the Owner of Monster Tree Decided to Sell Franchises
abstract: Josh Skolnick explains why he thinks franchising is the way to grow — and why he is proud that he never pulls the cord on a chain saw.
lead_paragraph: Last week, we published a case study about the founder of a suburban Philadelphia tree-trimming and -removal business. Having built his five-year-old company, Monster Tree Service, to 15 employees and more than $2 million in annual revenue, Josh Skolnick, 29, debated how best to expand: With corporate-owned locations or with franchises?

headline: Free-Spirited Designs in London
abstract: Suzy Menkes speaks with the Scottish designer Jonathan Saunders about his latest collection at London Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: Suzy Menkes speaks with the Scottish designer Jonathan Saunders about his latest collection at London Fashion Week.

headline: Review Roundup: The iPhone 5S and iPhone 5C
abstract: A small number of technology journalists have had their hands on Apple’s new iPhones for about a week. This time they had two phones to evaluate instead of one. The consensus among reviewers was generally positive.
lead_paragraph: A small number of technology journalists have had their hands on Apple’s new iPhones for about a week. And this time they had two phones to evaluate instead of one.

headline: A Sensitive Rap Star Toughens Up
abstract: On his new album, “Nothing Was the Same,” Drake adopts a tougher stance toward perceived antagonists than on his previous effort, “Take Care.”
lead_paragraph: Let it be known that the Tough Drake era begins not this week, with the release of “Nothing Was the Same,” the first official Tough Drake album, but rather began all the way back on Jan. 6, 2012. That day saw the release of the video for “Stay Schemin,” a Rick Ross song featuring Drake and French Montana. The clip is a fuzzy Michael Mann rip-off, nighttime Miami reduced to blacks, grays and electric blues, oozing sinister energy.

headline: Live Stream | Gucci’s Spring 2014 Collection at Milan Fashion Week
abstract: The latest women’s collection from Gucci at Milan Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: The latest women’s collection from Gucci at Milan Fashion Week.

headline: Associates of Madoff May Face Charges
abstract: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan face a December deadline to bring additional charges connected to Bernard L. Madoff’s Ponzi scheme. | Standard & Poor’s won more business after relaxing its ratings criteria. | JPMorgan’s chief executive told employees about the bank’s compliance efforts. | Shareholders of the Dole Food Company are challenging the latest buyout proposal.
lead_paragraph: ASSOCIATES OF MADOFF MAY FACE CHARGES  |  Federal prosecutors in Manhattan, facing a December deadline to bring additional charges connected to Bernard L. Madoff’s Ponzi scheme, are considering criminal charges against several people connected to the case, DealBook’s Peter Lattman reports. Among those under scrutiny are Shana Madoff Swanson, a senior executive at the firm, and Paul J. Konigsberg, a longtime accountant in Mr. Madoff’s inner circle.

headline: Breathing Room for Emerging Markets Watching Money Flee
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Quantitative Easing', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Third World and Developing Countries']
abstract: While previous exoduses by investors from emerging markets have caused bank failures, bankruptcies and layoffs, the latest retrenchment has been much milder.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — When the Asian financial crisis hit in 1997, sales plummeted 95 percent and stayed down for six months at the IGP Group, Indonesia’s dominant manufacturer of car and truck axles. Four-fifths of the company’s workers lost their jobs.

headline: Taking Questions on Causes and Effects of Sleep Deficiency
abstract: Orfeu Marcello Buxton, a neuroscientist, is taking reader questions about sleep deficiency in middle age.
lead_paragraph: This week’s Ask an Expert features Orfeu Marcello Buxton,  a neuroscientist who will answer questions about the causes and health consequences of sleep deficiency, particularly in middle age. He researches chronic sleep deficiency in the workplace and home and how it contributes to disorders like obesity, diabetes and cardiovascular disease.

headline: Getting a Clearer Picture of College Costs
abstract: A calculator being introduced by Wellesley will give students and their families a clearer sense — perhaps less daunting — of the prospective out-of-pocket costs at top colleges.
lead_paragraph: For high-achieving, low-income students, some of the cheapest places to attend college are the ones with the highest list prices. Thanks to their endowments, these elite colleges often award large scholarships to poor and even many middle-class students. For example, despite Harvard’s published annual cost of about $60,000, parents of Harvard students making less than $65,000 are expected to make no contribution; parents making $65,000 to $150,000 typically pay no more than 10 percent of their income.

headline: Emmys Watch: Morena Baccarin on ‘Homeland’
abstract: Morena Baccarin talks about being nominated for her performance as Jessica Brody on “Homeland” and what viewers can expect in Season 3.
lead_paragraph: With her otherworldly aura, Morena Baccarin seemed a natural for science-fiction roles like Inara Serra, a 26th-century courtesan from the planet Sihnon in Josh Whedon’s “Firefly,” and Anna, the leader of the alien Visitors in “V” on ABC. But it is Showtime’s “Homeland” that has allowed Ms. Baccarin to run the gamut of human emotions. As Jessica Brody — the wife of a Marine turned terrorist — Ms. Baccarin’s character has morphed from a military widow, whose life is upended when her husband returns from the dead after eight years, to the spouse of a congressman with ulterior motives.

headline: Mixing Crime and Politics in Argentina
abstract: The focus on crime this election season has revealed how President Kirchner’s power is waning.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner is scrambling. Since her party, Frente Para la Victoria (Front for Victory), lost by a surprisingly wide margin in the country’s five largest districts in last month’s primaries, Kirchner and her allies are struggling to find a formula to gain support before the Oct. 27 midterm elections.

headline: Wheelies: The 3-Million-Mile Edition
abstract: A man who has owned his 1966 Volvo since new has now driven it more than three million miles, and Consumer Reports gives the 2014 Chevrolet Silverado top honors.
lead_paragraph: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Starbucks Seeks to Keep Guns Out of Its Coffee Shops
abstract: Starbucks, reversing a policy that had allowed customers to openly carry guns in states that allow it, is asking customers not to bring firearms into its stores.
lead_paragraph: Tired of being thrust onto the front lines of the nation’s debate over guns, Starbucks is asking customers to leave firearms behind when they are in its stores and its outdoor seating areas.

headline: London Fashion Week: Meadham Kirchhoff Spring/Summer 2014
abstract: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Sarah Aubel.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Sarah Aubel.

headline: With Help, Teradata Speeds Up
abstract: Teradata, the big business analytics company, is speeding up. Working with two younger firms, its new release offers a kind of fast and supple Big Data product that hasn’t been seen before from a large incumbent. It shows a change in what customers want answered: not “what happened?” but “What’s next?”
lead_paragraph: Teradata, the venerable data analytics company, is about to offer capabilities in data analysis that seem to be fast, powerful, versatile and accessible. It is a somewhat cobbled-together approach, involving other companies, but it is a start.

headline: Former Defense Secretaries Criticize Obama on Syria
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: In a joint appearance, Robert M. Gates and Leon E. Panetta were critical of President Obama for asking Congress to authorize the use of force against Syria in retaliation for its use of chemical weapons.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s first two defense secretaries publicly questioned the administration’s handling of the Syrian crisis on Tuesday night and expressed skepticism about whether Russia can broker a deal to remove Syria’s chemical weapons.

headline: Celebrating the Top Women in Banking, but Noting a Lack
abstract: American Banker Magazine’s annual ranking of the most powerful women in banking revealed a continued lack of women in top jobs.
lead_paragraph: American Banker Magazine released on Wednesday its annual ranking of the most powerful women in banking. But the list, even as it celebrated the accomplishments of the honorees, revealed a lack of women in top jobs.

headline: Will a ‘Black’ Name Brand My Son With Mug Shots Before He’s Even Born?
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Names, Personal', 'Parenting', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: My unborn son, a seven-month old fetus, could already have all the world’s unspoken markings of a criminal — the wrong skin color and the wrong name.
lead_paragraph: My son will look like Trayvon Martin.

headline: Unfinished Business From the Financial Crisis
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Commercial Paper (Finance)', 'Government Bonds', 'Money Market Mutual Funds', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis']
abstract: Problems arising from money market mutual funds are viewed as a crucial channel through which the financial crisis spread from Wall Street to Main Street, and reforms are still needed, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Phillip Swagel is a professor at the School of Public Policy at the University of Maryland and was assistant secretary for economic policy at the Treasury Department from 2006 to 2009.

headline: An Opera Plot Ripped From the Tabloids
abstract: The New York City Opera, which faces financial distress, began its season on Tuesday night with the American premiere of Mark-Anthony Turnage’s story of Anna Nicole Smith.
lead_paragraph: New York City Opera opened its season on Tuesday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music with the eagerly anticipated American premiere of the brilliant British composer Mark-Anthony Turnage’s “Anna Nicole.” Yes, that Anna Nicole. This audacious, entertaining and, in its strange way, wrenching opera tells of the real-life Playboy Playmate, reality television star and fortune hunter Anna Nicole Smith.

headline: Dsquared2: Spring 2014 RTW
abstract: Milan
lead_paragraph: Milan

headline: In Queens, Now May Not Be Time for an Old House of the Future
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Residents oppose a proposed apartment complex in Sunnyside Gardens that would include a spaceshiplike house that was built long ago.
lead_paragraph: This isn’t a case of Nimby, the neighbors in Sunnyside Gardens, Queens, say. It’s more a matter of namby.

headline: The Gun Report: September 18, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Whenever there’s a mass shooting in America, a press conference with police and hospital officials usually follows, in which we get updates on the suspects and the condition of the victims. But the one following Monday’s Washington Navy Yard shooting was different than most. In her remarks, Dr. Janis Orlowski, the chief medical officer at MedStar Washington Hospital Center, which treated three of the wounded, struck a surprisingly emotional note.

headline: Board Book Roundup
abstract: ‘Barnyard Baby,’ by Elise Broach, and more.
lead_paragraph: ‘Barnyard Baby,’ by Elise Broach, and more.

headline: Board Book Roundup
abstract: The season’s crop of board books includes a toddler’s adventures on a farm, animals eating their favorite foods and the antics of a very bossy baby.
lead_paragraph: BARNYARD BABYBy Elise BroachIllustrated by Cori Doerrfeld14 pp. Little, Brown & Company. $7.99. (Board book; ages 3 months to 3 years)

headline: At Photoville, Hicks’s Photographic Year
abstract: At the Photoville photography exhibition in Brooklyn, shipping containers house picture presentations, including one that showcases a year’s worth of assignments from The Times’s staff photographer Tyler Hicks.
lead_paragraph: What’s contained in a year? For Tyler Hicks, a staff photographer for The New York Times, it’s trips to places like Gaza or Syria and photographing the longstanding yet reliably devastating conflicts there. Or to the Gulf of Oman, where the aircraft carrier he was on, covering a different story with C. J. Chivers, changed course suddenly to pursue and capture Somali pirates.

headline: Keep Those Due Dates From Sneaking Up on You
abstract: Mobile devices can be powerful personal finance tools, with apps that make managing and paying bills easier, if not more enjoyable.
lead_paragraph: Bills, bills, bills. They always seem to be multiplying, and adding digital devices like smartphones and tablets to our lives only makes the pile bigger. Thankfully, those same smartphones and tablets can also help track and manage all of the bills in one place.

headline: Love and Paranoia in Brooklyn: Yes, They Inhale. Repeatedly.
abstract: In “Newlyweeds,” a man and a woman in Brooklyn love the pot they smoke as much as they love each other.
lead_paragraph: Promoted as a hip stoner comedy, “Newlyweeds” sustains an amiable, jocular tone, even when its characters flirt with self-destruction. This portrait of a cannabis-using couple living in the Bedford-Stuyvesant neighborhood of Brooklyn puts on the appearance of a happy-go-lucky romp. But under its nonchalance is a cautionary story about potentially wasted lives that feels as close to “The Panic in Needle Park” as it does to a Cheech and Chong movie.

headline: Medicine’s Search for Meaning
abstract: Doctors willing to heal themselves can help the medical profession recover from its own illness.
lead_paragraph: Every day, we are reminded that the health care system is in crisis. We are going bankrupt. There are too many lawsuits. We practice defensive medicine. We restrict access. But surveys of doctors indicate a problem that penetrates much deeper than this. Today, almost 50 percent of doctors report symptoms of burnout — emotional exhaustion, low sense of accomplishment, detachment.

headline: Faith Healing on the Train
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A rider with his foot in a cast was surprised when a woman offered to give him a hands-on prayer.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Today in Small Business: Is ‘Obamacare’ Working?
abstract: Why women should skip business school. Consumer prices up 0.1 percent. A slew of tax breaks are set to expire.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: And the Winner of the Big Four Popularity Contest Is … Murray?
abstract: According to one celebrity marketing index, Andy Murray is the most appealing of the so-called Big Four in men’s tennis.
lead_paragraph: Last week, for the 12th time in the last 13 Grand Slam events, two members of the so-called Big Four met for the men’s singles championship, as No. 2 Rafael Nadal defeated No. 1 Novak Djokovic to win the United States Open.

headline: Pressed From His Right, Speaker Yields on a Budget Showdown
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'National Debt (US)', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Speaker John A. Boehner surrendered to demands that he tie money to keep the government open after Sept. 30 to stripping President Obama’s health care law of any financing.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After three years of cajoling, finessing and occasionally strong-arming his fitful conservative majority, Speaker John A. Boehner waved the white flag on Wednesday, surrendering to demands from his right flank that he tie money to keep the government open after Sept. 30 to stripping President Obama’s health care law of any financing.

headline: U.N. Treaty Governing Headquarters’ Establishment in United States
abstract: As the host country of the United Nations, the United States has an obligation to issue visas for members of delegations, regardless of any disputes with individual countries.
lead_paragraph: As the host country of the United Nations, the United States has an obligation to issue visas for members of delegations, regardless of any disputes with individual countries.

headline: Salesforce and Workday Form Cloud Alliance
abstract: Salesforce.com and Workday, which between them offer enough cloud-based software to run much of a business, announced a deep and pervasive alliance. All the details aren’t available yet, but it’s the biggest step yet by cloud providers to go after the big incumbents.
lead_paragraph: Attention big software incumbents: Your newfangled competitors just became more of a threat. Salesforce.com and Workday, two of the largest cloud-based enterprise software companies, have announced a strategic alliance.

headline: U.S. Is Asked to Hold Sudan Leader if He Visits U.N.
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Visas']
abstract: President Omar Hassan al-Bashir of Sudan, who has been charged with genocide, is seeking a visa to attend the United Nations General Assembly.
lead_paragraph: The president of Sudan, wanted for years by the International Criminal Court on charges of genocide and other crimes in the Darfur conflict, set off a growing storm of anger on Wednesday with his plan to attend the United Nations General Assembly, as human rights advocates urged governments to oppose the visit and the court’s judges asked the United States to arrest him if he dares to come.

headline: Four Questions for the Fed
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Interest Rates', 'Quantitative Easing', 'United States Economy']
abstract: What the Federal Reserve says Wednesday afternoon — particularly the details — will offer insight into the Fed’s plans.
lead_paragraph: Here are the four most important questions that the Federal Reserve will answer Wednesday afternoon after the latest meeting of its policy-making committee:

headline: Gucci: Spring 2014 RTW
abstract: Milan
lead_paragraph: Milan

headline: Smithsonian Director to Step Down
abstract: G. Wayne Clough, the director of the Smithsonian Institution, announced that he will step down from his position in October 2014.
lead_paragraph: G. Wayne Clough, the director of the Smithsonian Institution and its sprawling network of museums and research centers, announced that he would step down from his position in October 2014. Mr. Clough, whose official title is secretary, has headed the billion-dollar institution since 2008, and said he was announcing his decision to retire now in order to give the Smithsonian plenty of time to find a successor.

headline: Test of Alzheimer’s Drug Gets Large Federal Grant
abstract: The $33.2 million grant will help finance a clinical trial to test a treatment on people 60 to 75 who have no symptoms of the disease, but do have two copies of a gene known to greatly increase the risk of getting it.
lead_paragraph: In the most significant sign yet of a broad shift in the focus of Alzheimer’s research from treating to preventing the disease, the federal government announced on Wednesday its largest grant so far to test an Alzheimer’s drug on healthy people at greatest risk for the most common form of the disease.

headline: Francona’s Approach Draws Raves in Cleveland
abstract: After a bitter exit from Boston and then a year off from managing, Terry Francona is comfortable with Cleveland’s front office and has the Indians vying for a wild card.
lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — When Terry Francona spent last season away from the dugout, as an analyst for ESPN, he expected to gain perspective on life. He needed the break after eight seasons of exhilaration and exhaustion as manager of the Boston Red Sox, but his mind rarely strayed from the only life he has known.

headline: Look Who’s Catching the Drakewave
abstract: Artists in the hip-hop-R&B continuum are demonstrating Drake’s influence.
lead_paragraph: Three years ago, one of the debates that preoccupied a certain stripe of hip-hop obsessive was the one over hashtag rap. That style, now a relic, referred to the phenomenon of rappers concluding a series of lines each with a single word — as if it were a hashtag — that served as an implied wink. Drake was maybe its highest-profile proponent, but Big Sean was generally credited with injecting the style into hip-hop’s DNA.

headline: Q. & A. | The French Culinary Legend Anne Willan Dishes on the Changing Food Landscape
abstract: The founder of the famed French cooking school La Verenne has a new memoir out this week. Here, she remembers her good friend Julia Child and early days at Le Cordon Bleu.
lead_paragraph: Anne Willan found her footing in the male-dominated world of French cuisine long before female chefs became commonplace. Raised in Yorkshire, England, she studied at Le Cordon Bleu in Paris before going on to cook for American socialites, British royalty and French artists, also working as an editor at Gourmet magazine and the Washington Star. In 1975, backed by Sofitel, her dear friend Julia Child and James Beard, she founded the Parisian cooking school La Varenne, where she played a major role in the popularization of French cuisine. In May, she was inducted into the James Beard Foundation’s Cookbook Hall of Fame for her “body of work,” which includes 40 cookbooks and a 26-part PBS program. Now, she shares her adventures in life, love and cheese balls in the delectable memoir “One Soufflé at a Time” (St. Martin’s Press, $28), which also comes peppered with her favorite recipes. Here, Willan remembers her early days and talks about how the food world has changed.

headline: Dsquared Gets an Early Start in Milan
abstract: Now the real fashion party begins, and organizers of the Milan shows are doing their best to put a dynamic spin on the week, starting with Dsquared.
lead_paragraph: Shuffling along the Via della Spiga early this morning, having arrived at Malpensa shortly after 6 a.m., a tired traveler could not escape the signs of a fashion party missed. In the shop windows and on the street were torn posters and detritus from Fashion’s Night Out, the annual Vogue-choreographed shopping event that skipped New York this year, but must have carried on in Milan on Tuesday night before all the editors and retailers descended upon the city.

headline: Blankfein Says Fed Should Ease Stimulus
abstract: Lloyd C. Blankfein, the chief executive of Goldman Sachs, said on Wednesday that the Federal Reserve should begin scaling back its huge economic stimulus efforts.
lead_paragraph: Lloyd C. Blankfein, the chief executive of Goldman Sachs, said on Wednesday that the Federal Reserve should begin scaling back its huge economic stimulus efforts.

headline: U.S. to Host Britain in First Round of Davis Cup
abstract: The United States learned on Wednesday that it would host a first-round tie with Britain for the 2014 Davis Cup.
lead_paragraph: In the draw ceremony for the 2014 Davis Cup in London on Wednesday morning, the United States team learned it would host a first-round meeting with Britain, a matchup that harks back to when the tournament and the overall map of the sport were considerably smaller.

headline: Things Come to a Head
abstract: The crazies get their moment.
lead_paragraph: A decade ago, in the introduction to my collection The Great Unraveling, I argued that the modern Republican party was a “revolutionary power” in the sense once defined by, of all people, Henry Kissinger — a power that no longer accepted any of the norms of politics as usual, that was willing not just to take radical positions but to act in ways that undermined the whole system of governance people thought they understood.

headline: Exploring Málaga, from the Phoenicians to Picasso
abstract: Joe Diaz, a travel magazine founder, talks about discovering the rich history of this Spanish city along the Mediterranean.
lead_paragraph: Growing up, Joe Diaz, a founder of the travel magazine and Web site Afar, visited his father’s birthplace, Málaga, the Spanish port city along the Mediterranean, nearly every year. And yet conversations with his grandmother never progressed beyond, “Te quiero mucho, yaya.”

headline: Filmmaker Susan Lacy Leaves PBS for HBO
abstract: Ms. Lacy,  the creator and executive producer of “American Masters,” has signed a multiyear deal to produce documentaries for the pay cable channel.
lead_paragraph: One of the most prolific and honored filmmakers in television is moving from PBS to HBO.

headline: Now Checking In: Pampered Pets
abstract: Pet-icure? Puppy purse? Pooch minibar? These days, hotels are rolling out the amenities to make sure pets, and their owners, feel right at home.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after arriving at the new Viceroy Riviera Maya in Mexico, dogs are blessed by a shaman as he circles them with burning incense. Afterward, the dog receives a garland of shells and flowers and can retire to a miniature palapa.

headline: High-Altitude Andorra Aims Higher
abstract: The tiny principality, wedged between Spain and France, tries to extend its appeal to all seasons.
lead_paragraph: As Andorra’s snowcapped peaks dissolved into waterfalls this summer, the warm mountain air filled with unfamiliar sights and sounds. Cirque du Soleil was in town in July and August, the latest effort by this tiny principality, sandwiched between France and Spain, to position itself as a year-round destination for vacationers.

headline: Britney Spears Confirms a Long Stand of Concerts in Las Vegas
abstract: The pop star will perform 50 shows over two years at the Planet Hollywood Resort & Casino.
lead_paragraph: In a world of declining album sales, a residency in Las Vegas is an easy paycheck for pop stars. But some use the announcement of a long-term stand there as a way to generate publicity as well.

headline: Republicans Say State Dept. Meted Out No Discipline Over Benghazi Attack
abstract: At a hearing, lawmakers said the State Department had failed to hold senior officials accountable for lapses that contributed to a deadly attack on an American mission.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senior House Republicans on Wednesday accused the State Department of failing to hold senior department officials accountable for security failures that contributed to the attack on the American diplomatic mission in Benghazi, Libya, last year in which four Americans were killed.

headline: Lee Broom
abstract: Mr. Broom recently opened a shop in the East End to sell his cut crystal light bulbs and Art Deco-inspired furniture.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Broom recently opened a shop in the East End to sell his cut crystal light bulbs and Art Deco-inspired furniture.

headline: Catterton, a Private Equity Firm, Closes Two Funds at $2.1 Billion
abstract: Catterton Partners, a private equity firm focused on consumer companies, said on Wednesday that it had closed on its latest two funds after having raised $2.1 billion.
lead_paragraph: Catterton Partners, a private equity firm focused on consumer companies like Restoration Hardware, said on Wednesday that it had closed on its latest two funds after having raised $2.1 billion.

headline: Health Plan Penalty Ends at Penn State
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: The university had proposed a $100 monthly penalty for employees who failed to provide personal data in a wellness questionnaire.
lead_paragraph: After weeks of vociferous objections by faculty members, Pennsylvania State University said on Wednesday it was suspending part of a new employee wellness program that some professors had criticized as coercive and financially punitive.

headline: Real Estate in Montreal
abstract: A three-bedroom Victorian mansion, on Mount Royal in Westmount, is on the market.
lead_paragraph: A three-bedroom Victorian mansion, on Mount Royal in Westmount, is on the market.

headline: House Hunting in ... Westmount, Montreal
abstract: Home-sale activity has slipped, because of slower economic growth, giving buyers more negotiating power in certain areas of Montreal, including Westmount.
lead_paragraph: A HISTORIC VICTORIAN MANSION IN WESTMOUNT, MONTREAL

headline: Broad Art Museum in Los Angeles to Offer Free Admission
abstract: The Broad, the contemporary art museum being built by the billionaire collector Eli Broad and his wife Edythe in Los Angeles, will be free to the public, Mr. Broad announced.
lead_paragraph: The Broad, the contemporary art museum being built by the billionaire collector Eli Broad and his wife, Edythe, and which is scheduled to open late next year in Los Angeles, will be free to the public, Mr. Broad announced Tuesday.

headline: Iran Frees Political Prisoners on Eve of President’s Visit to U.S.
abstract: Analysts said the release of 11 prominent prisoners was a significant step in President Hassan Rouhani’s efforts to repair Iran’s relationship with the West.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — On the eve of a visit by Iran’s moderate president, Hassan Rouhani, to the United States, the Iranian authorities on Wednesday unexpectedly freed 11 of Iran’s most prominent political prisoners, including Nasrin Sotoudeh, a human rights lawyer.

headline: The Moroccan Front
abstract: When the Civil War came to the shores of North Africa.
lead_paragraph: The Civil War arrived in Morocco in February of 1862, when two Confederate naval officers took a walk in Tangier. The men, Henry Myers and Thomas T. Tunstall, were on an errand to buy coal and bring it back to their ship, the Sumter, which was laid up for repairs nearby in Gibraltar, a British territory near the southern tip of Spain. Myers and Tunstall hoped to find coal in the Spanish city of Cádiz, but the steamer they took to Spain made a quick stop in Tangier en route.

headline: Reuters Ends Plans for Ambitious Direct-to-Reader Service
abstract: The project, Next, missed deadlines and had cost overruns, but also generated a lot of interest as a new way to distribute news. Instead, the company will focus on Reuters.com.
lead_paragraph: Two years after Thomson Reuters announced an ambitious effort to reach out to news consumers directly through a program called Next, the company has decided to change direction and work through its Web site, Reuters.com.

headline: Rooms With a Burberry
abstract: The Claridge’s, Connaught and Berkeley hotels in London will put complimentary Burberry coats in suites for guests to use during their stays.
lead_paragraph: An umbrella stocked in the hotel closet? Passé, according to the Maybourne Hotel Group in London. The company, which manages the high-end Claridge’s, Connaught and Berkeley hotels in a city known for its rain, has made a deal with the fashion brand Burberry to stock each suite with a designer trench coat for guests to use throughout their stay.

headline: Mulling on Molly: Investigating the Dangers of a Club Drug
abstract: What are the risks of using this club drug, also known as ecstasy or MDMA? In this lesson, students learn about a string of fatalities associated with the drug and research how it adversely affects the body.
lead_paragraph: Overview | What is Molly and why has it been in the news lately? What are the risks of using this club drug, also known as ecstasy or MDMA?
