In this lesson, students learn about a recent string of fatalities associated with the drug and research how it adversely affects various body systems, like electrolyte balance and temperature regulation. Finally, they create minidocumentaries to present their findings to others.

headline: Why a Summer as a Chambermaid Can Be More Valuable Than an Internship
abstract: How a non-résumé-building job set my writing career on track.
lead_paragraph: I was the kind of undergraduate who probably would have loved a career-planning program like the one I wrote about at Wake Forest. When I started college, I already knew that I eventually wanted to go into publishing. Determined to start building my résumé, I managed, by pulling every string I could find, to talk myself into an internship at a prestigious literary magazine, right after my freshman year. Then I languished in its offices all summer, tasked with retyping Rolodex cards and pained at being indoors for hours on end. Many kind people went out of their way to find interesting work for me to do, but the truth was that I was too young to be there, or just too immature. I pined for the outdoors and despaired of a future working in an office, any office.

headline: The Hero of ‘Breaking Bad’
abstract: The importance of heroism to cable television’s dark masterpiece.
lead_paragraph: A spoiler-rich post on television’s best drama follows below the fold:

headline: City Opera’s ‘Anna Nicole’
abstract: The opera’s new season opened with the American premiere of this work by the composer Mark-Anthony Turnage.
lead_paragraph: The opera’s new season opened with the American premiere of this work by the composer Mark-Anthony Turnage.

headline: Under New Guidelines, Man Booker Prize to Be Open to Americans
abstract: Beginning in 2014, the award will be open to all novels originally written in English and published in Britain no matter where the author is from.
lead_paragraph: In a break from tradition that has already rankled purists, the Man Booker Prize will be open to all novels originally written in English and published in Britain, the administrators of the prize announced on Wednesday. Previously, the prize had been open to novels written by authors from Britain, the other countries in the Commonwealth, and Ireland. The change is planned to begin in 2014.

headline: Homes for $900,000
abstract: Homes include a Dutch Colonial in New York; an adobe in Santa Fe, N.M.; and a three-story condo in Chicago.
lead_paragraph: Homes include a Dutch Colonial in New York; an adobe in Santa Fe, N.M.; and a three-story condo in Chicago.

headline: What You Get for ... $900,000
abstract: This week’s properties include a Dutch Colonial in New York; an adobe in Santa Fe, N.M.; and a three-story condo in Chicago.
lead_paragraph: NEW PALTZ, N.Y.

headline: Outsource Your Memory, With an App
abstract: Memoir, a new start-up, wants to take the place of that scrapbook on your smartphone by offering a way to store and organize photos, notes and more.
lead_paragraph: Like GPS units, alarm clocks and watches, scrapbooks are largely things of the past, relics of an era before the smartphone. Mementos we once might have pasted in a scrapbook are now largely stored on our phones and scattered between apps like Facebook, Instagram, Foursquare and Twitter.

headline: Another Promising Night for Fox and Its Early Start to TV Season
abstract: The network got the jump on its competitors and for two nights has had generally positive ratings to show for it, including the premiere of “Brooklyn Nine-Nine.”
lead_paragraph: On its second night of jump-starting the new television season a week before its network competition, the Fox network again got some positive results.

headline: Photo/Essay | How My Picture of a Guy on a Diving Board Wound Up on the Cover of an Elton John Album
abstract: The photographer Tim Barber recalls the moment he captured the ethereal image, and explains how the British pop star found out about it.
lead_paragraph: The photographer and curator Tim Barber has shot work for publications ranging from Vice to Vogue, and for brands like Nike, Levi’s and Opening Ceremony. But his most famous client is undoubtedly Sir Elton John, who used a decade-old photo of Barber’s as the cover of his 31st studio album, “The Diving Board,” out Sept. 24. Here, Barber relates the story of the image:

headline: Officials Never Learned of Police Doubts on Gunman’s Stability
keywords: ['Washington Navy Yard Shooting (2013)', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: Naval police in Rhode Island did not alert superiors to evidence pointing to Aaron Alexis’s mental instability.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Naval police in Rhode Island did not alert superiors in Washington to evidence pointing to the mental instability of the former Navy reservist who the police say killed 12 people at a Washington Navy base, Pentagon officials said.

headline: Image of the Day: Sept. 18
abstract: Celebrations on the streets of Mumbai on the closing day of the 10-day Ganesh festival.

headline: Marcel Reich-Ranicki, Literary Critic, Is Dead at 93
keywords: ['Writing and Writers', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Mr. Reich-Ranicki, a Polish Jew who grew up in Berlin, became a powerful cultural figure in postwar Germany as a literary critic and a television talk show host.
lead_paragraph: Marcel Reich-Ranicki, a survivor of the Warsaw ghetto who left Poland to become a powerful cultural figure in postwar Germany as a distinguished literary critic and a popular television talk show host, died on Wednesday in Frankfurt. He was 93.

headline: The Vital Long View in Tracking Diminishing Arctic Sea Ice
abstract: Sea ice around the North Pole retreated less this year than last, but the trend toward an open-water Arctic Ocean in summers remains.
lead_paragraph: With the annual pullback of Arctic Ocean sea ice at an end, it’s clear that this year’s retreat is nowhere near the satellite-era record set in 2012, but it’s also clear that there is still a long-term trajectory toward a largely open-water Arctic in summers in coming decades.

headline: Updates on the Fed Announcement
abstract: Times correspondents offer updates and insights on the Federal Reserve’s monetary policy announcement at 2 p.m. and the news conference by Ben Bernanke, the Fed chief.
lead_paragraph: Annie Lowrey, Nathaniel Popper and other contributors covered the developments after the Fed’s announcement that it will not yet start ratcheting down its bond purchases — a transition that has come to be known as the “taper” — including the news conference of the Fed chairman, Ben S. Bernanke.

headline: Russia Calls U.N. Chemical Report on Syria Biased
abstract: Saying the report was biased and incomplete, Russia hardened its stance even as it pressed ahead with a plan to disarm Syria’s government of its chemical arsenal.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russia sharply criticized the new United Nations report on Syria’s chemical arms use on Wednesday as biased and incomplete, hardening the Kremlin’s defense of the Syrian government even while pressing ahead with a plan to disarm its arsenal of the internationally banned weapons.

headline: Gunman’s Family Left Shocked, Saddened, Mystified
abstract: “I am so so very sorry that this happened,” the mother of Aaron Alexis said in a statement at her Brooklyn home.
lead_paragraph: The family of the gunman.

headline: Right-Wing Friendly Regulation
keywords: ['Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: The Michigan attorney general argued that the state’s ban on same-sex marriage is necessary to “regulate sexual relationships.”
lead_paragraph: Regulation’s a bad word in some circles. Regulations kill jobs and hold back the economy. They’re nothing but red tape. “The biggest obstacle we’re having about jobs is regulation and regulatory overreach,” said Republican Rep. Marsha Blackburn of Tennessee in 2011. Innumerable conservative Republicans might have uttered the exact same phrase that year, or last year, or this year.

headline: Gucci’s Opulent Gym
abstract: A tracksuit and the ornamental drawings of Erte seem an odd couple, but Frida Giannini brought them together.
lead_paragraph: A tracksuit and the ornamental drawings of Erte seem an odd couple, but Frida Giannini brought them together at Gucci on Wednesday, as the Italian spring collections began. She made a complete collection out of the sports theme, and she made a fairly good case for it, because it was never literal. She started off with a loose, sheer black top over cropped silk print pants (more like shorts, really) and moved into an array of skimming halter dresses with black mesh bras, black track pants, flowing tunics with deep side slits, and lots of pretty kimono jackets.

headline: Tech Titans Form Biotechnology Company
abstract: Calico, a new start-up focusing on aging and illness, is run by Arthur D. Levinson, the former chief executive of Genentech, and financed by Google.
lead_paragraph: Silicon Valley has an obsession with immortality, and not just as science fiction. Many people here say they believe that the day when technology makes it possible to live forever is just around the corner.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: 'Prisoners'
abstract: The director Denis Villeneuve narrates a scene from his film featuring Jake Gyllenhaal and Hugh Jackman.
lead_paragraph: The director Denis Villeneuve narrates a scene from his film featuring Jake Gyllenhaal and Hugh Jackman.

headline: Milan Fashion Week: Gucci Spring/Summer 2014
abstract: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Columbine Goldsmith.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Columbine Goldsmith.

headline: Alberta Ferretti: Spring 2014 RTW
abstract: Milan
lead_paragraph: Milan

headline: Putin’s Dubious Opinion
abstract: He said there was “every reason to believe” that the chemical weapons attack in Syria was carried out by rebel forces.
lead_paragraph: President Vladimir Putin of Russia said in an Op-Ed article that we published last week that “there is every reason to believe” that the chemical weapons attack in Syria on Aug. 21 was carried out by the rebel forces in a crafty plan to provoke the United States into bombing Syria and unleashing all kinds of mayhem.

headline: In Surprise, Fed Decides to Maintain Pace of Stimulus
abstract: In a reversal that stunned economists and investors, the Federal Reserve said it would continue to buy bonds to encourage growth, at least for another month and quite possibly into next year.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It turns out that the Federal Reserve is not quite ready to let go of its extra efforts to help the economy grow.

headline: Clintons, in Statement, Back de Blasio for Mayor
abstract: The endorsement was hardly a surprise given that Bill de Blasio served as Hillary Rodham Clinton’s campaign manager in her successful 2000 campaign for Senate.
lead_paragraph: Bill de Blasio now has the endorsement of not one, but two potential contenders for president.

headline: Blankfein Discusses Goldman’s Support of SAC Capital
abstract: The chief executive of Goldman Sachs said that if his firm and other banks withdrew their support from SAC, that “would vaporize” the firm.
lead_paragraph: Just a few days after the indictment of the hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors on insider trading charges, Gary Cohn, the president of Goldman Sachs, appeared on CNBC and issued a public statement of support for the firm.

headline: Air France Plans to Cut 2,800 More Jobs
abstract: The staff reductions, to be made by the end of 2014, come after initial cuts failed to deliver sufficient savings in a struggling European economy.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Air France informed union representatives Wednesday that it planned to eliminate an additional 2,800 jobs, or 5 percent of its work force, by the end of next year, as the carrier scrambles to return to profitability.

headline: S.E.C. Proposes Greater Disclosure on Pay for C.E.O.’s
keywords: ['Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Executive Compensation']
abstract: The regulator is nearing adoption of a rule that would require chief executives to compare their pay to the median paid to employees.
lead_paragraph: The gap in pay between chief executives and rank-and-file employees has been growing steadily, and now regulators want companies to tell investors just how wide it is.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: Video of ‘Prisoners’
abstract: The director Denis Villeneuve narrates a scene from his film featuring Jake Gyllenhaal and Hugh Jackman.
lead_paragraph: Rain turns into snow in this scene from the drama “Prisoners,” featuring Hugh Jackman as Keller Dover, whose daughter has gone missing and Jake Gyllenhaal as Loki, the detective on the case. In this video, the director Denis Villeneuve narrates a sequence where Loki follows Keller, considering him a suspect. Mr. Villeneuve discusses decisions around the scene’s gray and blue color palette, as well as how he relays the action of the scene from a distinct point of view.

headline: A New BlackBerry Phone, but Maybe Too Late
abstract: The new phone, the BlackBerry Z30, has a 5-inch touchscreen and has a bigger battery and a faster processor. But questions about the company’s survival, not the phone’s technical specifications, may be at the top of buyers’ minds.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — With its future as a business in doubt, BlackBerry introduced on Wednesday a new flagship model for the line of phones that were supposed to revive the company.

headline: Jefferies’ Results Reflect the Hazards of Fixed Income
abstract: The revenue that the investment bank Jefferies Group generated from trading bonds, currencies and commodities slumped 85 percent in the three months before September, a far bigger drop than its larger rivals across Wall Street are expecting.
lead_paragraph: The Jefferies Group shows that fixed income isn’t necessarily for everyone. The revenue that the investment bank generated from trading bonds, currencies and commodities slumped 85 percent, to just $33 million, in the three months to September. That’s a far bigger drop than its larger rivals across Wall Street are expecting. As a relative newcomer, Jefferies appears to be struggling with volatility. The same may prove true for others that are downsizing their fixed-income businesses.

headline: Yankees Can’t Match 41-Year-Old Pettitte’s Energy
abstract: All of the Yankees except pitcher Andy Pettitte appeared lifeless against the Blue Jays on Tuesday night in what was virtually a must-win game.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO – After watching the Yankees’ offense go down meekly in 2 hours 25 minutes Tuesday night, one had to wonder if Andy Pettitte was the only member of the team still trying to make the playoffs.

headline: A Mom Turns Her Sons’ Awkward Adolescence Into Art
abstract: The photographer Martine Fougeron shows images documenting her two sons’ journey into adulthood at the Hermès flagship store in New York.
lead_paragraph: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Live Commercials Coming to ‘Late Night’
abstract: The advertisements for Lexus will run during Jimmy Fallon’s taped talk show. A comedy troupe will come up with the commercials based on audience suggestions.
lead_paragraph: For almost four decades now, a late-night NBC show has begun with the words, “Live from New York, it’s Saturday night.” Beginning late Thursday night — early Friday morning, to be technical — another late-night NBC show will revisit a popular concept from long-ago television, live commercials.

headline: Assad’s Office Promotes Fox News Interview With Kucinich
abstract: Syrians who take their cues from President Bashar al-Assad’s office were advised to stay up late Wednesday, so they can watch “a television dialogue” on the Fox News Channel between their leader and Dennis Kucinich.
lead_paragraph: Last Updated, 5:47 p.m. | Syrians who take their cues from President Bashar al-Assad’s office were advised to stay up late Wednesday, so they can tune into the Fox News Channel at 1 a.m. local time (6 p.m. Eastern) to watch “a television dialogue” between their leader and Dennis Kucinich, the former Democratic representative from Ohio who is now a Fox News contributor.

headline: Injured ‘Spider-Man’ Actor Blames Equipment Malfunction
abstract: A young actor who was injured during a performance of “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” has filed court papers contending that his accident was caused by an equipment malfunction, not human error.
lead_paragraph: Daniel Curry, a young actor who was badly injured last month while performing in the Broadway musical “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark,” has filed court papers contending that his accident was due to malfunctioning equipment in the show, and not to human error, as the show’s producers have maintained.

headline: Facebook Removes Dating Ads Featuring Photo of Dead Girl
abstract: The social network apologized for ads placed by a dating service that featured photos of Rehtaeh Parsons, a Canadian girl who committed suicide in April after she had been cyberbullied over an alleged rape.
lead_paragraph: Facebook has apologized for dating ads that recently appeared on its service that featured a photo of a Canadian teenager, Rehtaeh Parsons, who hanged herself in April.

headline: Nadja Bender Transforms Backstage at Gucci
abstract: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Spring 2014 Fashion Week in Milan.
lead_paragraph: (function($) {var data = chameleonData[0];var beforeAfterContainer = $('#nytmm_beforeAfter_wrapper122 .nytmm_beforeAfter_container');var options = {leftImage: data.images.left.leftImage,rightImage: data.images.right.rightImage,showFooter: data.footer.showFooter,leftCredit: data.images.left.leftCredit,rightCredit: data.images.right.rightCredit,caption: data.footer.caption,startPoint: data.images.startPoint,showButton: data.footer.button.showButton,leftButtonText: data.footer.button.leftButtonText,rightButtonText: data.footer.button.rightButtonText}beforeAfterContainer.BeforeAfter(options);})(jQuery||NYTD.jQuery);

headline: Tracy Antonopoulos: Just Her Friends, Goofing Around
abstract: After making short films for Opening Ceremony, Ms. Antonopoulos formed a noisy guitars-and-electric-beats duo called Cable.
lead_paragraph: AGE 27

headline: Bills Rookie Hopes to Close a Revolving Door
abstract: The Bills’ E J Manuel, who has a passer rating of 95.9, and the Jets’ Geno Smith (55.2), the first two quarterbacks taken in the 2013 draft, will face each other on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: E J Manuel was 25-6 as a starter at Florida State. He led the Seminoles to four consecutive bowl victories and ended his career with a 66.9 completion percentage, the best in the storied program’s history.

headline: Dropping Anchor on the Upper East Side
abstract: Lauren Strachan found the one-bedroom she was seeking in the East 70s.
lead_paragraph: After Lauren Strachan graduated from Rutgers University, where she studied acting, she rented briefly in New York. She waited tables, auditioned and “basically lived the life of a starving artist,” she said.

headline: Taking a Tank for a Spin
abstract: Drive a Tank in Minnesota has seven armored vehicles that customers can drive.
lead_paragraph: The urge to get behind the wheel of a fantasy vehicle has driven everything from Indy car racing schools to vintage convertible rentals. Now one Minnesota outfitter militarizes the dream with tanks for rent.

headline: A Bartender Nursing His Broken Heart
abstract: A cross-country trip is still fresh in the mind of an Irish immigrant in “The Compass Rose,” part of the 1st Irish Festival.
lead_paragraph: Before Ronan Noone’s play “The Compass Rose” begins, you wait to see if life will subtly transform into theater. You look around the bar that is its site-specific setting and take note of the details. Will the bartender who can flip a shot glass in the air and catch it behind his back become a character? Will the atmosphere in the room shift from cozily humdrum to ritually charged?

headline: Court Gives a Victory to Pandora Over Licensing Streaming Music
abstract: A federal judge ruled against Ascap, saying it must make its entire publishing catalog available for licensing by Pandora.
lead_paragraph: Pandora Media won a battle in its continuing war with the music industry over royalties when a federal judge ruled on Tuesday that the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers, which represents thousands of members, cannot prevent Pandora from licensing all the songs in its catalog.

headline: Better Smartphone Typing Is Just a Tap Away
abstract: Apps and tips to help ease your virtual keyboard frustrations.
lead_paragraph: TOUCH-SCREEN phones have become so astonishingly good at some tasks they have all but replaced landline phones, pocket cameras and printed maps. But there is one feature that they still struggle to get right — the keyboard. The flexibility of the full touch screen has won out over tactile, physical buttons, leaving us with a keyboard that is just an image on glass and small keys that sometimes get cranky around big thumbs.

headline: ‘Salinger’ to Add Details on Relationships With Young Women
abstract: The Weinstein Company said that it planned to release a “special edition” of the film about J.D. Salinger with the additions. Also, the company plans a dramatic film based on the writer’s life.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — “Salinger,” Shane Salerno’s documentary about the secret life of J. D. Salinger, is set to reveal some more secrets.

headline: Lafayette 148 Is Growing Up
abstract: The women’s wear company is opening a store in the same building as its SoHo headquarters.
lead_paragraph: The latest designer store to join the bustling retail scene that surrounds Howard Street in SoHo, an area pioneered by Opening Ceremony, is around the corner at 148 Lafayette Street. If the address rings a bell, that is because it has appeared for 17 years on the label of one of fashion’s quietest success stories.

headline: Decoding the Fed’s Statement
abstract: A statement from the policy-making group of the Federal Reserve offers its assessment of current economic conditions — and insights into its decision not to pull back yet from its policy of bond purchases to stimulate the economy.
lead_paragraph: A statement from the policy-making group of the Federal Reserve offers its assessment of current economic conditions — and insights into its decision not to pull back yet from its policy of bond purchases to stimulate the economy.

headline: Chevrolet Talks Bold Colors for Small Cars
abstract: Pink cars are nothing new, but where its Chevrolet Spark and Sonic models are concerned, General Motors seems bent on turning heads.
lead_paragraph: Although most consumers tend to buy white, silver and black vehicles, Chevrolet is bringing more splashes of bright color to its Spark and Sonic models. Color was the theme du jour at a presentation last week at the Manhattan headquarters of Stylesight, a fashion-trend analysis and forecasting firm that helps designers choose market-worthy colors, fabrics and other materials.

headline: Miley Cyrus Hits No. 1
abstract: The popularity of Ms. Cyrus’s latest music video, “Wrecking Ball,” has helped her reach No. 1 on Billboard’s singles chart.
lead_paragraph: It may not have been “Harlem Shake,” but the popularity of Miley Cyrus’s latest music video has helped her reach No. 1 on Billboard’s singles chart. Ms. Cyrus’s song “Wrecking Ball” made headlines last week for racking up 19.3 million views in its first 24 hours on the video service Vevo, which most people view through YouTube.

headline: The Tense Soundscape of Hitchcock Thrillers
abstract: The New York Philharmonic’s Film Week begins with “Hitchcock!,” featuring live accompaniment to excerpts from films like “Psycho” and “Vertigo.”
lead_paragraph: Brilliant or foolhardy? There were times during Tuesday night’s fabulously entertaining New York Philharmonic concert at Avery Fisher Hall when I found myself debating the pros and cons of the conceit behind “Hitchcock!,” the first of two programs in “The Art of the Score: Film Week at the Philharmonic.”

headline: Taking Stock at the London Fashion Shows
abstract: England is home to some world-conquering fashion brands that derive a lot of their success from retail expertise.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — This week, Tom Ford opened his 89th store, in London, where his company has its headquarters. “We’re in Baku,” he said, as he reeled off cities that, presumably, will carry his mirror-spangled dresses next spring. For its show, Burberry invited the impossibly cute Harry Styles of One Direction and the It girl Suki Waterhouse.

headline: Everything Is Explored, Though Little Is Voiced
abstract: “Dream River,” the newest album by Bill Callahan, finds that musician putting everything in his songs: love, death, fear, patience, transfiguration.
lead_paragraph: Bill Callahan may be easiest to describe by what he isn’t quite: a folkie; a country singer; a cloistered, primitivist weirdo with a four-track recorder; a poet or some other kind of words-only artist. Over the last 23 years, on a string of records made almost exclusively for the Chicago label Drag City, you sense that he’s walked past those doors, revising his ideas, waiting, looking for something.

headline: On View | Olivo Barbieri’s Awe-Inspiring Images of the Alps
abstract: The Italian photographer, known for his surreal aerial photographs of cities like Las Vegas and Rome, applies his trademark style to Europe’s most rugged mountains.
lead_paragraph: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Joseph E. Granville, Stock Market Predictor, Dies at 90
abstract: Mr. Granville was a famous market forecaster who made his own fortune in the less risky newsletter business.
lead_paragraph: When the stock market prognosticator Joseph E. Granville talked, his subscribers listened.

headline: Science, Evidently, Was in His Genes
abstract: In “An Appetite for Wonder,” the evolutionary biologist Richard Dawkins looks back at his childhood in Africa and the roots of his interest in how animals act.
lead_paragraph: “An Appetite for Wonder” is only the first half of Richard Dawkins’s projected two-volume memoir about his life in science. With typical unsentimental pragmatism, he notes that “the companion volume should follow in two years — if I am not carried off by the unpredictable equivalent of a sneeze.” No one will ever accuse this highly opinionated ethologist and evolutionary biologist, whose books include “The Selfish Gene” and “The God Delusion,” of a rosy attitude.

headline: Tying Music to Works on the Museum Wall
abstract: The Grand Tour is part of a series that links period music to the Met’s exhibitions.
lead_paragraph: This week I discovered the best new performance space in New York. It isn’t in a downtown basement or a converted factory by the Gowanus Canal. It goes by a pretty banal name: Gallery 634.

headline: The Grand Tour at the Met
abstract: Musical performances set in the museum’s galleries.
lead_paragraph: Musical performances set in the museum’s galleries.

headline: Moving Anew, Now at ‘Glacier’ Speed
abstract: Peak Performances is opening its season with a new work by the abstract choreographer Liz Gerring.
lead_paragraph: “No drama.” That’s how Jedediah Wheeler, the executive director of Peak Performances at Montclair State University in New Jersey, describes working with Liz Gerring, the on-the-rise choreographer he has chosen to open his fall series on Thursday. “Without drama” is how Ms. Gerring has described her own athletic, abstract dances. In both statements, the lack was meant as a positive.

headline: Face-Lift for a Gilded Age Beauty
abstract: A panoramic look at the newly renovated Board of Officers Room at the Park Avenue Armory, part of a $200 million restoration of the facility.
lead_paragraph: A panoramic look at the newly renovated Board of Officers Room at the Park Avenue Armory, part of a $200 million restoration of the facility.

headline: Disney Shuffles Schedule Over Delays to ‘Good Dinosaur’
abstract: For the first time in nine years, Disney will not release its annual Pixar movie. The gap has led to a flurry of new opening dates for Disney movies.
lead_paragraph: Walt Disney Studios on Wednesday announced a flurry of movie release date changes prompted by delays on “The Good Dinosaur” from Pixar, a movie originally scheduled to arrive in theaters in May.

headline: Just Peachy
abstract: During New York Fashion Week, Justin Bieber showed up with an unexpected accessory: a wispy smudge above his upper lip.
lead_paragraph: Hair today, gone tomorrow? During the most recent New York Fashion Week, Justin Bieber showed up in the front row of several shows, including Opening Ceremony (below), with an unexpected accessory: a wispy smudge above his upper lip that sharp-eyed observers eventually identified as a mustache. A few days later, in an expression, perhaps, of boredom (or even defeat), the 19-year-old pop star had shaved off all trace of facial hair, returning to the baby-face visage that has a place of honor on the bedroom walls of preteen girls around the world. The dabbling with adulthood (like his earlier public barings of surprisingly well-defined pecs) did not go unnoticed on Twitter.

headline: The Company He Keeps, Virtuosic to Endearing
abstract: “Roberto Bolle and Friends,” a dance gala organized as part of a year of Italian culture, was presented Tuesday night at City Center.
lead_paragraph: Who is Roberto Bolle? Indubitably, he is a handsome man, an exemplary ballet dancer. In his home country of Italy, he is a celebrity bordering on national hero. As a member of American Ballet Theater, he is a reliable leading man and a sterling partner. Since 2000 he has also been something of an impresario, organizing all-star performances under the title “Roberto Bolle and Friends.” On Tuesday at City Center, he showed one to New York.

headline: Uncertain Times in India, but Not for a Deity
abstract: Tributes to the Hindu god Ganesh have grown more lavish, even as Indians feel increasingly insecure about the economy and social problems.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — As this year’s monsoon season receded, onions were selling for an eye-popping 58 cents a pound, and inflation had accelerated to a six-month high. It has been a period of belt-tightening in India’s financial capital, a slow but sure blunting of hopes.

headline: Nets’ Williams Sprains Ankle in Workout
abstract: Point guard Deron Williams is in a walking boot, but the Nets expect him to be ready for the start of training camp on Oct. 1.
lead_paragraph: Nets point guard Deron Williams sprained his right ankle and bruised a bone while working out in Utah, the team said Wednesday, hardly the kind of news the Nets wanted to announce with the start of training camp on Oct. 1.

headline: Costume Designers for TV Have a Big Impact on Fashion
abstract: As television has gained more respect as a medium, there has been a coattail effect on some of its costume designers.
lead_paragraph: When the costume designer Mandi Line was interviewing for a job on the ABC Family show “Pretty Little Liars,” she had a case to make. “I said, “If you let me make fashion the fifth character on this show, people will watch it just for the clothes,’ ” she said.

headline: Ornate Peek at a Refreshed Gilded Age
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Park Avenue Armory (NYC)', 'Restoration and Renovation']
abstract: The reopening of the Board of Officers Room will offer the public a look at the Park Avenue Armory restoration process, and a preservation philosophy that accepts flaws and signs of age.
lead_paragraph: When the ambitious refurbishing of the landmark Park Avenue Armory is complete, New York will have an alternative arts center unlike any in the world: a national treasure that carefully weaves together historical and new design while encompassing industrial austerity and Belle Époque excess.

headline: Badgley Mischka Opens in New York
abstract: A design team long known for embellishment opens its first boutique in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: ON A DAMP AFTERNOON in the second-tier dressing room of the new Badgley Mischka boutique, I happened upon a clear cellophane packet containing perhaps the most brilliant retail innovation since the escalator: the Disposable Fashion Mask. Manufactured by a company called True Fit Try On, which also does a brisk business in “hygienic liners” for bathing suits, this translucent mask, sort of a Ped for the face, with holes only for the eyes, enables the wearer to try on expensive clothing without worrying that her makeup will soil the neckline.

headline: An Approach Embodying Complexity, Not Formality
abstract: A small ensemble from Benjamin Millepied’s L.A. Dance Project performed an evening of recent works at the Maison de la Danse in Lyon, France.
lead_paragraph: LYON, France — The buzz around Benjamin Millepied’s L.A. Dance Project is undoubtedly fueled by an aura of glamour that emanates from Mr. Millepied — former New York City Ballet principal, future artistic director of the Paris Opera Ballet, sought-after choreographer and husband of Natalie Portman. Only one year old, the L.A. Dance Project has already found international success, and on Tuesday night the troupe opened the Maison de la Danse’s season, filling every one of its 1,160 seats.

headline: A Groomer Polishes the Looks of Male Celebrities
abstract: Diana Schmidtke, a groomer for male celebrities, takes handsome men and makes them look even better.
lead_paragraph: When the nine-time Emmy nominee and widely acknowledged dreamboat Jon Hamm sails down the red carpet on Sunday, chances are you will notice his date’s dress, makeup and hairstyle more than the particulars of his appearance.

headline: Traditional Staple Has a Few Twists, While Dancers Give It a Spin
abstract: The New York City Ballet production of “Swan Lake” was shaped by the company’s artistic director, Peter Martins, in the 1990s, and it hasn’t changed.
lead_paragraph: The New York City Ballet production of “Swan Lake,” shaped by the company’s artistic director, Peter Martins, in the 1990s, is no simple experience. Especially as performed on Tuesday, it keeps tugging its audience in different directions. The designs by Per Kirkeby turn it into a pencil cartoon sketch of “The ‘Swan Lake’ Show” that’s then been daubed by a paint-by-numbers beginners’ class: the prince is all blue, the villagers are green, the jester orange and so on. Tchaikovsky’s tempos are taken at a terrific lick: no Romantic lingerings here. Often the music — Andrews Sill conducted the company’s orchestra on Tuesday — rushes past without deepening the action; yet in some central passages we’re swept urgently into its vortex.

headline: Scene City: Art Circus Comes to Town
abstract: Galerie Perrotin opens on the moneyed Upper East Side, with fun and games at the Russian Tea Room.
lead_paragraph: Galerie Perrotin opens on the moneyed Upper East Side, with fun and games at the Russian Tea Room.

headline: Q. & A. | Jeff Koons on His New Champagne-Filled Balloon Sculpture and the DNA of Art History
abstract: The superstar artist discusses his limited-edition collaboration with Dom Pérignon, what motivates him as an artist and how he feels about having the last show ever at the Whitney Museum’s uptown site.
lead_paragraph: This fall, an incredibly rare, highly valuable object created by Jeff Koons will become available for purchase. Two, actually. It’s up to you to decide whether to spend tens of millions on “Balloon Dog (Orange),” the massive sculpture being sold by the collector Peter Brant in November at a Christie’s auction (where it is expected to fetch between $35 million and $55 million), or the somewhat more reasonable figure of $20,000 on “Balloon Venus for Dom Pérignon,” the artist’s limited-edition Champagne-filled collectible made for the luxury brand. T spoke with Koons about the project and his forthcoming 2014 career retrospective at the Whitney, which will be the museum’s final exhibition in the iconic Marcel Breuer building on Madison Avenue.

headline: Galerie Perrotin Opens on Madison Avenue With a Splash
abstract: The art world’s latest temple opens as Champagne flows.
lead_paragraph: In the basement of Galerie Perrotin, a powerhouse gallery from Paris that opened in New York on Tuesday night, a dollar bill shot out of a towering blue box and drifted onto a floor littered with bills and coins. A sign explained the work by Paola Pivi, an Italian artist: “Caution: Money is spit out everywhere.”

headline: Global Pop, Now Infused With Country
abstract: The Swedish D.J.-producer Avicii has released his debut album, “True.”
lead_paragraph: Two years ago the Swedish D.J., producer and denim model Avicii released “Levels,” a clangorous and joyful club anthem that was a global hit so vast that it reinforced the fact that the United States isn’t really the center of global pop, at least not the way it once was.

headline: World Championships in Indonesia
abstract: The world championships are under way in Bali, Indonesia, where there are 22 teams in each of the three events: the Venice Cup, Bermuda Bowl and d’Orsi Senior Trophy.
lead_paragraph: The world championships are under way in Bali, Indonesia. There are 22 teams in each of the three events: the Venice Cup, Bermuda Bowl and d’Orsi Senior Trophy. After a round robin of 16-board matches, eight will qualify for the knockout matches, which begin on Tuesday.

headline: Swaddle Blankets: Baby’s Own Fashion Statement
abstract: Swaddle blankets are increasingly becoming ways for new mothers to make design statements.
lead_paragraph: Britt Levine, 33, who lives in Los Angeles and works in media sales for Clear Channel, has a 2-month-old baby boy and says that the colorful blankets she uses to wrap him, made by a company based there named Munchkin, are a way to extend her love of fashion to her newborn. Her regular afternoon promenades with her son at the Grove, an upscale mall, are a sea of strollers with colorful swaddle blankets draped over them.

headline: Gay Theaters Now Struggle to Evolve
abstract: Gay theater companies like About Face in Chicago find that the mainstream success of gay plays has some unintended side effects.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — At a time of rapid change in the gay-rights movement, from marriage to the military, the purpose of a strictly gay theater company isn’t the same as it was 10 years ago. Andrew Volkoff, now in his fourth month as the artistic director of About Face Theater, is about to discover what it might turn out to be.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Lebanon and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Lebanon, Syria, Washington and Greece.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Lebanon, Syria, Washington and Greece.

headline: Zachary Quinto: A Playwright’s Home, an Actor’s Muse
abstract: An actor in “The Glass Menagerie” finds inspiration in a visit to the playwright Tennessee Williams’s last home.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after a downpour hit Manhattan last Thursday, Zachary Quinto abandoned his car and driver to the gridlock on Madison Avenue and walked up to the Hotel Elysée on East 54th Street. As he apologized for being late, the actor looked up at the red and gold flag emblazoned with the name of the hotel, took out his iPhone and snapped a shot.

headline: N.W.S.L.’s First Season From the Outside Looking In
abstract: U.S. international Yael Averbuch on watching the inaugural season of the National Women’s Soccer League.
lead_paragraph: GOTHENBURG, Sweden — Last month, I lay in bed in Sweden with my computer tuned to the inaugural championship game of the National Women’s Soccer League. It was 2 a.m., and through sleepy eyes I watched the starting lineups walk out in Sahlen’s Stadium in Rochester. I couldn’t help but reminisce about my last professional game in the United States — played in that same stadium — the 2011 championship game of Women’s Professional Soccer.

headline: Noted Rockwells Coming to Auction
abstract: In December, three of Norman Rockwell’s best-known paintings will be auctioned at Sotheby’s.
lead_paragraph: In December, three of Norman Rockwell’s best-known paintings will be auctioned at Sotheby’s.

headline: Norman Rockwell’s America, Newly Up for Bid
abstract: Sotheby’s will auction three of Norman Rockwell’s best-known cover paintings for The Saturday Evening Post, including “Saying Grace.”
lead_paragraph: They are three of Norman Rockwell’s best-known paintings of homey, small-town America published on the covers of The Saturday Evening Post — “Saying Grace,” “The Gossips” and “Walking to Church.”

headline: JPMorgan Set to Pay More Than $900 Million in Fines
abstract: JPMorgan Chase is also expected to make a rare admission of wrongdoing to government authorities in Washington and London.
lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase is expected to pay more than $900 million in fines to government authorities in Washington and London and make a rare admission of wrongdoing on Thursday, a pact that will settle a range of investigations over a multibillion trading blunder the bank suffered last year, according to people briefed on the matter.

headline: France Debates Self-Defense as Robbery Victim Faces Murder Charge
abstract: A jeweler in Nice is being praised as a hero and criticized as a vigilante after prosecutors said he fatally shot in the back a teenager who had robbed him.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Early on the morning of Sept. 11, a 67-year-old jeweler in Nice, France, raised his unlicensed semiautomatic pistol and shot a teenager in the back as he and an accomplice sped away on a motor scooter with gems they had stolen at gunpoint, prosecutors said. The body of the youth, Anthony Asli, 19, was discovered on a nearby street lined with small grocery markets; the jeweler, Stephan Turk, was arrested last week and charged with murder.

headline: Asked to Reflect, Bloomberg Grumbles Instead
abstract: At a news conference on the Lower East Side, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg seemed annoyed with questions about the end of his tenure leading the city.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg does not want to talk about the race to succeed him. He does not want to talk about his legacy. And, thanks very much, he is not particularly impressed with those questions.

headline: Shopping Highlights in New York Starting Sept. 19
abstract: Sales on Elizabeth Street, the Gap x GQ Best New Menswear Designers in America collection and a pop-up shop for charity.
lead_paragraph: Openings and Events

headline: Bernanke on Fed Stimulus Decision
abstract: The Federal Reserve chairman, Ben Bernanke, explained his decision not to retreat from the agency’s stimulus campaign.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve chairman, Ben Bernanke, explained his decision not to retreat from the agency’s stimulus campaign.

headline: The Spa Experience
abstract: There is a sense of luxury to bathing and a ritual to a spa experience that we can recreate in the home, says designer Stephan Jaklitsch.
lead_paragraph: There is a sense of luxury to bathing and a ritual to a spa experience that we can recreate in the home, says designer Stephan Jaklitsch.

headline: Soft Rock for Your Linens
abstract: Keehnan Konyha’s black-and-white bedding collection, some of which looks like marble, was designed for the urban male.
lead_paragraph: When Keehnan Konyha, a 32-year-old Brooklyn designer, surveys the landscape of bedding, he sees “a lot of florals” and “a lot of birds,” he said, but not much that appeals to young men with the least bit of urban in their souls. Into this void Mr. Konyha has dropped black-and-white bedding, the inaugural collection from his new company, Safe House USA. The duvet sets and throw pillows have windowpane grids, flecks lifted from the covers of composition notebooks and even the look of marble (shown, $35). The demands of printing these patterns required Mr. Konyha to use synthetic fabric (he chose a soft polyester poplin), but the upside is that the bedding is a dream to clean. “I just came from a photo shoot where somebody spilled split pea soup on a pillow,” he said. “A little soap and water and it came right off.” Information: safehouseusa.com.

headline: Should I Convert My Alcove Into a Bedroom?
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
abstract: Advice on whether a home owner should renovate before selling.
lead_paragraph: Q. There’s a dining alcove off the kitchen in my one-bedroom apartment. Should I turn it into a second bedroom?

headline: Shopping for Bathtubs
abstract: A search for the perfect soak.
lead_paragraph: A search for the perfect soak.

headline: Just Add Rubber Duck
abstract: When being up to your neck in hot water is a beautiful thing.
lead_paragraph: In many bathrooms, the tub seems like an afterthought, a soulless scoop of white-enameled cast-iron or acrylic. Stephan Jaklitsch thinks that’s a missed opportunity. A more-interesting tub, he said, could “make your bathroom feel a little more special, and like a real retreat.”

headline: Antique Fabrics Breathe Again
abstract: A shop selling vintage textiles is revived on the Upper East Side.
lead_paragraph: Virginia DiSciascio Antique Textiles was a fixture on the Upper East Side for more than a quarter-century, until Ms. DiSciascio retired last year. Six months later, Ms. DiSciascio’s daughter, Audrey, and her assistant designer, Perla Nuñez, bought the inventory and added to it. They traveled to estate sales, auction houses and private collections in Europe and bought 17th-century Italian vestments, Ottoman Empire robes decorated with needlepoint, and Japanese ikat. In January, they opened their own shop, Antique Textiles Collection, where their clients include the interior designers David Easton and Michael Smith. An 18th-century Italian chandelier from a Paris flea market is the centerpiece of the 400-square-foot boutique. In addition to selling rare fabrics, the women use them to make room dividers and sofa cushions. A pillow starts at $800. The shop is at 32 East 68th Street, Suite A, (212) 535-0055.

headline: Changing Perspectives
abstract: The Monks Garden at the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum gets a makeover by Michael Van Valkenburgh.
lead_paragraph: A meander through a small, precious setting describes the experience of visiting the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston. And now Michael Van Valkenburgh, the landscape architect, has replicated that experience in a pocket-size garden next to the original museum building and near its new Renzo Piano-designed addition.

headline: Discounts at D’Apostrophe, Ligne Roset and Ann Gish
abstract: Bargains on sofas, beds and other home furnishings.
lead_paragraph: D’Apostrophe is offering discounts of up to 80 percent Thursday through Oct. 4 (the EZ lounger by Royal Botania, regularly $1,895, is about $948); 394 Broadway (White Street), (212) 334-5045, dapostrophe.net.

headline: French Senate Approves Ban on Pageants for Young Girls
keywords: ['Beauty Contests', 'Women and Girls', 'Law and Legislation', 'Legislatures and Parliaments', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: The move stems from concerns about the “hypersexualization” of young girls, though contests in France are far less intense than those in the United States.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Facing growing fears of “hypersexual” young girls, the French upper house of Parliament voted Wednesday to end beauty pageants for those younger than 16.

headline: Calming a Child’s Fears After Another Mass Shooting
abstract: There have been 20 mass shootings since my son turned 4, and in one way or another, he seems to have become aware of all of them. Yesterday, as I shopped, he cowered in the back of the store.
lead_paragraph: My 9-year-old son Zane has developed a gripping fear of death, a fear born on the heels of the Newtown school shooting. I didn’t tell him about it — a choice my husband and I made together, hoping he would never hear, but it seems clear now that he did. That knowledge has not only made my very sensitive child afraid, but also raised his antennas to the horrors that sometimes seem to surround us.

headline: A Conran Steps Up
abstract: Sebastian Conran designs 78 pieces of kitchenware, including a stool, for West Elm.
lead_paragraph: Sebastian Conran, the elder son of the British designer and retailer Sir Terence Conran, has created award-winning housewares for almost three decades. And although he introduced a few of those pieces under his own name, Mr. Conran, who is 57, never had what he calls a “real complete collection where I take full responsibility for the design choices” until now. Universal Expert, a 78-piece range of small kitchen appliances and tabletop accessories, will be introduced at West Elm next week. They are products, Mr. Conran said, “that do more than one job, and do the job better.” His favorites include the stainless steel Box Grater, which folds flat for storage ($30) and the wood-and-stainless Step-Up storage stool ($80). “I’ve always wanted to be a foot taller,” Mr. Conran said of the stool. The pepper and salt mills, shown, are $70 for the set. Information: (888) 922-4119 or westelmmarket.com.

headline: Let’s Be Honest About Israel’s Nukes
keywords: ['ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT', 'United States International Relations', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Biological and Chemical Warfare']
abstract: How an obstacle of America’s own making stymies talks over weapons of mass destruction in the Middle East.
lead_paragraph: THE recent agreement between the United States and Russia on Syria’s chemical weapons made clear what should have been obvious long ago: President Obama’s effort to uphold international norms against weapons of mass destruction in the Middle East will entangle the United States in a diplomatic and strategic maze that is about much more than Syria’s chemical arsenal.

headline: New Products for Tans, Teeth and Talons
abstract: A cover stick for tan lines, a breath freshener, and art for your nails.
lead_paragraph: A roundup of products for tans, teeth and talons.

headline: Sleek, Boutique and Not Crazy Expensive
abstract: This 2,000-square-foot house in Sonoma County cost $360 a square foot to custom build.
lead_paragraph: This 2,000-square-foot house in Sonoma County cost $360 a square foot to custom build.

headline: Bespoke for the People
keywords: ['ARCHITECTURE', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Prefabricated Buildings', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
abstract: An architect builds a case against prefab.
lead_paragraph: Neal Schwartz, a San Francisco architect, is eager to share what he has learned about how to get the look for less.

headline: Python Flats at No. 21 That Are Perfect for Hitting the Town
abstract: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway. Today’s pick: embellished flats that feel nighttime ready.
lead_paragraph: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: An Osmond Offers Up a Bit of Home
abstract: Donny Osmond  on the new housewares collection he created with his wife, Debbie.
lead_paragraph: Those who remember Donny Osmond singing “You Are My Sunshine” on the Andy Williams show in 1963 have probably become so inured to life’s little curve balls that they won’t be surprised to learn that the popular entertainer, now 55 and a grandfather several times over, is about to release a housewares collection with his wife, Debbie. Everyone else, take a moment to compose yourself.

headline: New York Fashion Week Styles to Wear Now
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'New York Fashion Week', 'Leather and Leather Goods']
abstract: A few take-aways from the shows and street style include off-the-shoulder looks, logos, and leather (also in vegan form).
lead_paragraph: Giving Them the Hot Shoulder

headline: Be Careful What You Wish For
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Historic Buildings and Sites']
abstract: A woman who dreamed of owning a Newport mansion is knee-deep in its renovation. Luckily, she’s dating the contractor.
lead_paragraph: A woman who dreamed of owning a Newport mansion is knee-deep in its renovation. Luckily, she’s dating the contractor.

headline: Ghosts Be Gone
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Restoration and Renovation']
abstract: A Gilded Age dowager in Newport gets a makeover that may finally put its troubled past to rest.
lead_paragraph: NEWPORT, R.I. — The house formerly known as Belcourt Castle now has a Twitter account, a Facebook page and an American flag planted on its meticulously restored Pennsylvania slate roof. Gone are the sidewalk placards announcing the ghost and murder-mystery tours. These are some of the most visible signs that the once-derelict, nearly 40,000-square-foot folly designed by Richard Morris Hunt is under new management.

headline: De Blasio Remains Above Threshold for Runoff in Updated Primary Results
abstract: The New York City Board of Elections released updated numbers that showed Bill de Blasio remaining above the 40 percent needed to avoid a mayoral runoff with William C. Thompson Jr.
lead_paragraph: Eight days after the primary for mayor of New York City, the Board of Elections released updated results on Wednesday that showed Bill de Blasio remaining above the threshold that would prompt a runoff election.

headline: Video of Heavily Armed Starbucks Customer Thanking Staff Before Policy Change
abstract: Last month, a pastor named Terry Holcomb visited a Starbucks in Huntsville, Tex., carrying a loaded AR-15 Bushmaster rifle to thank the company for serving armed patrons in its stores.
lead_paragraph: As my colleague Stephanie Strom reports, Starbucks on Tuesday announced a change in policy regarding guns. In a blog post and a video statement, Howard Schultz, the chief executive, made “a respectful request that customers no longer bring firearms into our stores or outdoor seating areas.”

headline: Harvey Apologizes for Awkward Interview
abstract: This season, at 24, Matt Harvey proved he was among the best pitchers in the game. But perhaps he still must learn the finer points of being a star, as evidenced Wednesday, when his radio appearance with Dan Patrick turned awkward.
lead_paragraph: This season, at 24, Matt Harvey proved he was among the best pitchers in the game. But perhaps he still must learn the finer points of being a star, and how to act in the spotlight, as evidenced Wednesday, when his radio appearance with Dan Patrick turned awkward.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: The Release of iOS 7, and the Constitutional Protection of the ‘Like’
abstract: Wednesday’s highlights from around the Web include an opinion from a federal judge that concluded that a Facebook “like” was protected under the First Amendment. Plus, Apple’s mobile operating system was released to the general public.
lead_paragraph: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: Brix Smith-Start Has a Second Life as a Fashion Retailer
abstract: The ex-musician has taken her retailing know-how to the small screen.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Brix Smith-Start was trailed through her store by a mother-daughter fashion duo.

headline: Grand Theft Auto V Muscles Its Way to Sales Record
abstract: Grand Theft Auto V, one of the most anticipated video games of the year, has beaten sales records for the edgy and violent adventure game series, earning more than $800 million in sales for its first day on store shelves.
lead_paragraph: Grand Theft Auto V, one of the most anticipated video games of the year, has beaten sales figures posted by previous installments in the violent and controversial adventure game series. The new game generated more than $800 million in sales Tuesday on its first day on store shelves.

headline: Till Death (or Decorating Disputes) Do Us Part
abstract: A group of friends decided to grow old together 20 years ago, and today they say their experiment in communal living has had its rewards but is not for the stubborn.
lead_paragraph: Mendocino County, Calif. — Twenty years after they embarked on an experiment in communal living, the members of Cheesecake gathered for an anniversary celebration over Labor Day weekend. Nearly 100 people — the seven who live here full time, six who are here part time, and assorted children, grandchildren and friends, including Laura Hartman, one of the architects who designed the complex — spent two days barbecuing, talking, hiking through the redwoods and competing to see who could bake the best cheesecake. (The competition was in honor of the community’s name, which is derived from a loose translation of Casada, the surname of the family who owned the 20-acre property at the turn of the 19th century.)

headline: Aging Together
abstract: Members of the Cheesecake community, in Mendocino County, celebrate 20 years of shared living.
lead_paragraph: Members of the Cheesecake community, in Mendocino County, celebrate 20 years of shared living.

headline: Goodbye, Albert (Personal)
abstract: A small but painful loss.
lead_paragraph: No taper, at least yet. Government shutdown and maybe debt ceiling crisis looming. Obamacare rollout begins in a couple of weeks. There are a lot of important things happening in the world.

headline: Bette Midler Will Bring One-Woman Show to Los Angeles
abstract: “I’ll Eat You Last: A Chat with Sue Mengers” will run for three weeks at the Geffen Playhouse in December.
lead_paragraph: Sue Mengers is coming home.

headline: America’s Sinking Middle Class
abstract: The standard of living of most Americans has fallen in the last 25 years; last year, the typical household made $51,017, roughly the same as in 1988.
lead_paragraph: In some respects, 1988 has the feel of an alien, distant era. There was no such thing as the World Wide Web then. The Soviet Union was still around; the Berlin Wall still standing. Americans elected a Republican president who would raise taxes to help tame the budget deficit.

headline: Standing Still?
abstract: The typical American household enjoys a standard of living no higher today than its counterpart 25 years ago, and the level of poverty is about the same as well.
lead_paragraph: The typical American household enjoys a standard of living no higher today than its counterpart 25 years ago, and the level of poverty is about the same as well.

headline: The Sailors and Their Flying Machines
abstract: This year’s America’s Cup vessels are more flying machines than yachts.
lead_paragraph: This year’s America’s Cup vessels are more flying machines than yachts.

headline: A Promise to Protect Pensions Will Test Greece’s Red Line on Austerity
keywords: ['Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Strikes', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )']
abstract: Greece has pledged to make no further cuts to its disgruntled citizens’ pensions, but a gaping hole in its finances may force its hand.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — With a fresh inspection by Greece’s foreign creditors looming next week and labor unions leading a new wave of strikes, the government here has drawn a red line: it will keep pushing economic reforms but vows to impose no more austerity measures on Greeks already battered from three years of tax increases and pension cuts.

headline: Former Women’s Chess Champion Close to Regaining Title
abstract: Hou Yifan, a Chinese grandmaster, defeated the reigning champion, Anna Ushenina of Ukraine, in Game 6 of their match, which is being held in Taizhou, China.
lead_paragraph: Hou Yifan, a former women’s world chess champion, took a big step toward regaining the title on Wednesday as she won Game 6 of her title match with Anna Ushenina, the reigning champion. The match is being held in Taizhou, China.

headline: Berlusconi Stakes a Claim for Relevance, but Avoids Threats
abstract: In a televised address on Wednesday, Silvio Berlusconi tried to claim a continued place at the heart of Italian politics, but did not mention his party’s threats to bring down the coalition government.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Ever the unpredictable showman, Silvio Berlusconi used a special televised address on Wednesday to defiantly stake a claim for a continued place at the heart of Italian politics. Perhaps, though, it was what he did not say that spoke loudest: not once did he discuss his party’s earlier threats to bring down Italy’s fragile coalition government.

headline: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
abstract: The Department of Defense has identified 2,256 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations.
lead_paragraph: The Department of Defense has identified 2,256 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

headline: Syria Releases Video of Fox News Interview With Assad
abstract: Speaking to Fox News, President Bashar al-Assad compared his use of force in Syria to American efforts to quell the Los Angeles riots in 1992.
lead_paragraph: President Bashar al-Assad’s office, which promoted his “television dialogue” with the Fox News contributor Dennis Kucinich online before the channel even acknowledged that it had taken place, posted video of the complete interview on its YouTube channel as soon as the broadcast began Wednesday night.

headline: Morsi Speaks With Family by Phone, Lawyer Says
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots']
abstract: Mohamed Morsi, the ousted Egyptian president, had his first contact with his family since he was held in military custody and said he was in good health, his lawyer said.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Mohamed Morsi, Egypt’s ousted president, has spoken by telephone with his family twice in recent days, their first contacts since he was detained by the military on July 3, his lawyer told The Associated Press on Wednesday.

headline: Brazilian Court Allows Appeals for Political Figures Convicted of Corruption
abstract: The court ruling allowing the reopening of crucial aspects of the trial suggested that senior political figures convicted in a vast vote-buying scheme may not get any hard jail time.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Brazil’s highest court on Wednesday allowed a new round of appeals in a trial over a vast vote-buying scheme, a decision that may allow senior political figures in the ruling Workers Party to maneuver out of hard jail time for their actions in what may be Brazil’s biggest corruption scandal.

headline: Businesses Manage Medical Bill Payment Plans
keywords: ['Hospitals', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Credit and Debt', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Payment services let patients pay bills over time and let hospitals get paid for care immediately.
lead_paragraph: It used to be that if you could not afford to pay a big medical bill, your doctor or hospital might let you pay it over time, a little bit each month.

headline: Mexico: Shops Looted as Acapulco Recovers From Flood
abstract: Looters plundered stores on Wednesday as Acapulco struggled to recover from a flood wrought by a tropical storm that is also threatening Cabo San Lucas.
lead_paragraph: Looters plundered stores in Acapulco on Wednesday as it struggled to recover from a flood wrought by a tropical storm that has moved up the coast and is threatening another resort area, Cabo San Lucas. The death toll from the storm, and another this week on the Gulf coast, which is also threatened by yet another storm, reached at least 80 people. But a full accounting is yet to come from several towns cut off by mudslides; in Atoyac de Álvarez, a small municipality in Guerrero State, about 50 people remained unaccounted for. An airlift of thousands of tourists stranded in Acapulco continued Wednesday.

headline: Anti-Hunger Advocates Put Pressure on Lawmakers Over Food Stamp Bill
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Crop Controls and Subsidies', 'Food Stamps', 'Farm Bill (US)']
abstract: The efforts came as the Republican-controlled House was expected to take up the measure this week.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — More than 50 New Yorkers active in anti-hunger efforts, including leaders of food banks and soup kitchens, made their way to Washington last week for a day of lobbying. On Tuesday, the celebrity chef Tom Colicchio, a board member of the group Food Policy Action, met with House Democrats to highlight the need for programs to address hunger.

headline: Spot Shares Moments of Better Cruise Memories
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Cruises', 'Social Media', 'Maritime Accidents and Safety', 'Public Relations and Publicity', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: Carnival Cruise Lines has created a new campaign it hopes will put behind it the incident that stranded passengers last February.
lead_paragraph: CARNIVAL CRUISE LINES is introducing a new advertising campaign on Monday that it hopes will help it recover from the negative publicity it received when its ship, the Triumph, caught fire last February and stranded passengers and crew in the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: Questions Swirl After Bus Plows Into Train in Canada
keywords: ['Buses', 'Railroad Accidents and Safety', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: Speculation was widespread that the driver of a double-decker bus in Ottawa had suffered a medical emergency before the bus crashed into a train, killing six passengers and the bus driver.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Commuters were shocked and investigators were at a loss to explain why a double-decker transit bus drove past a warning light in Ottawa on Wednesday morning, crashed through safety barriers and plowed into a passenger train, killing six bus passengers and injuring 34 others.

headline: Fanciful Adieu for Victim Who Saw World’s ‘Hidden Magic’
keywords: ['Funerals and Memorials', 'Hate Crimes', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: Jeffrey Babbitt, who died after he was attacked, loved steam locomotives, comic books, Goth art and winged fairies; a rabbi at his grave site called his killing senseless.
lead_paragraph: They quietly buried the man who had no business dying.

headline: Brand Suffers Most From Spat Between Owner and Hollywood Blogger
abstract: Nikki Finke, the blogger who squeezed Hollywood with her rabid trade reporting for Deadline.com, is in a standoff with Jay Penske, the media entrepreneur who bought her Web site in 2009.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — For her detractors, and there are many, the turnabout is delicious: Nikki Finke, the blogger who squeezed Hollywood with her rabid trade reporting for Deadline.com, is now being squeezed. Jay Penske, the media entrepreneur who bought her Web site in 2009, has Ms. Finke in a difficult spot.

headline: Police Raid Golden Dawn Office in Athens After a Killing
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots']
abstract: The raid at the office of the Greek far-right party on Wednesday came after the fatal stabbing of an antifascist activist set off widespread protests.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — The police raided the offices of Greece’s far-right Golden Dawn Party on Wednesday, and government officials scrambled for ways to clamp down on the group after thousands of demonstrators took to the streets in several Greek cities to protest the killing of an antifascist activist that the police attributed to a Golden Dawn sympathizer.

headline: After Fed’s Announcement, Confusion and Relief on Wall Street
keywords: ['Interest Rates', 'Quantitative Easing', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'United States Economy']
abstract: The Federal Reserve’s apparent change of heart left investors wondering how they got it so wrong, with several pointing an accusing finger at Ben S. Bernanke, the chairman.
lead_paragraph: Ben S. Bernanke and the markets are having a hard time understanding each other.

headline: Germany’s Effort at Clean Energy Proves Complex
keywords: ['Energy and Power', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Wind Power', 'Coal', 'Nuclear Energy', 'Electric Light and Power', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions']
abstract: Germany’s plan to convert to renewable energy sources is running into problems in execution that are forcing Germans to face the costs of sticking to their principles.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — It is an audacious undertaking with wide and deep support in Germany: shut down the nation’s nuclear power plants, wean the country from coal and promote a wholesale shift to renewable energy sources.

headline: Winds of Change
keywords: ['Cocaine and Crack Cocaine', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Eighth Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Mandatory Sentencing', 'State Legislatures']
abstract: Will shifts in public attitudes on mandatory minimum sentences, stop-and-frisk, privacy and civil liberties influence the Supreme Court?
lead_paragraph: Back in 1991, the Supreme Court upheld a Michigan man’s prison sentence of life without the possibility of parole for possessing more than 1.5 pounds of cocaine. The sentence did not represent the third strike of a three-strikes law: the prisoner, Ronald A. Harmelin, 45, had no previous criminal record. The police found the drugs when they stopped him for running a red light. Since simple possession was enough to trigger Michigan’s mandatory life-without-parole sentence, the prosecution didn’t even have to bother trying to prove that Mr. Harmelin intended to sell the cocaine.

headline: Science’s Humanities Gap
abstract: Steven Pinker has charged humanists with a failure to embrace science. But the greater problem is scientists’ failure to embrace the humanities.
lead_paragraph: In his recent sermon to humanists, “Science Is Not Your Enemy,” the psychologist Steven Pinker makes an impressive plea for humanists to pay more attention to science and urges them to an interdisciplinary approach that he thinks has been sadly lacking. His general point is surely right: specialists in any area are likely to benefit from acquaintance with relevant work beyond their disciplinary boundaries. But it seems to me that Pinker mistakes his audience. On this issue, it’s humanists who are the choir and scientists who need a call to grace.

headline: At Alabama, a Renewed Stand for Integration
keywords: ['Fraternities and Sororities', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Discrimination', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: Hundreds of University of Alabama students and faculty members held a demonstration to demand an end to racial bias in the university’s fraternities and sororities.
lead_paragraph: TUSCALOOSA, Ala. — For this rendition of Stand in the Schoolhouse Door, there were no National Guard troops or presidential edicts.

headline: Bring Back the Lyme Vaccine
abstract: How a marketing fiasco derailed an important medical development.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — IN August 2005 my son Alec, then 39 years old, collapsed into unconsciousness while walking his dog in the suburbs of Philadelphia. By the time he arrived at the hospital, his heart rate had slowed to 30 beats per minute. Fortunately, an experienced physician recognized that Alec was having a cardiac complication of Lyme infection. Installation of a pacemaker and an infusion of antibiotics saved his life.

headline: A Ghastly Ritual Repeats Itself
keywords: ['Washington Navy Yard Shooting (2013)', 'Gun Control', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: We are stuck in a cycle of savagery as one shooter after another catches us in his sights.

lead_paragraph: These weeks after the passing of my husband, Stuart, I often think of Joan Didion and her book “The Year of Magical Thinking,” and about how her beloved husband, John Gregory Dunne, died suddenly of cardiac arrest while sitting in his living room.

Mr. Saylor suffocated on the floor, on his stomach, hands cuffed behind him. His death was ruled a homicide.

headline: Staying the Course at the Fed

lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve did the right thing when it decided on Wednesday not to begin reducing the monthly, multibillion-dollar bond purchases that are a pillar of its efforts to spur the economy. To do otherwise would have violated the Fed’s own criteria for gradually withdrawing the support measures.

headline: The March to Anarchy
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'National Debt (US)', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Editorials', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: House Republicans hasten a government shutdown later this month and a default with a no-win plan to end health reform.
lead_paragraph: Until now, the only House Republicans pushing for a government shutdown and debt crisis were a few dozen on the radical right, the ones Senator Harry Reid, the majority leader, referred to as “the anarchists.” On Wednesday, however, the full Republican caucus, leadership and all, joined the anarchy movement, announcing plans to demand the defunding of health care reform as the price for keeping the government open past Sept. 30.

lead_paragraph: If Mets pitcher Matt Harvey has Tommy John surgery on his right elbow, it will be paid for, partly, with workers’ compensation insurance. A partly torn ulnar collateral ligament like Harvey’s is considered a workplace injury, just as if he were a truck driver hurt on a loading dock.

headline: Russia: Greenpeace Members Held at Arctic Oil Rig
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Offshore Drilling and Exploration', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']
abstract: Russian border guards detained two activists from the environmentalist group Wednesday morning after they boarded an oil rig to protest drilling in the Arctic.
lead_paragraph: Russian border guards detained two activists from the environmentalist group Greenpeace early Wednesday morning after they boarded an oil rig to protest drilling in the Arctic by a state gas company. Border guards fired a warning shot from an automatic rifle by the ship that ferried the protesters to the oil rig in the Pechora Sea in Russia’s Arctic waters, the Federal Security Service said in a statement. The statement said that the warning shot was fired for the protesters’ failure to “cease illegal activity” and “the real danger to the gas and oil complex.” Maria Favorskaya, a Greenpeace Russia representative, said the organization was in contact with Russian law enforcement but had not spoken with the activists, Sini Saarela of Finland and Marco Polo of Switzerland, since they were detained Wednesday morning.

headline: Griner and Other Rookies Rejuvenate W.N.B.A.
abstract: With the W.N.B.A. heavily promoting the top rookies Brittney Griner, Elena Delle Donne and Skylar Diggins, the league has seen increases in ticket sales, TV audiences and Web site traffic.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — The eager fans waited for Brittney Griner. They waited to marvel at her 6-foot-8-inch frame. They waited to give her a hug. They waited to give her gifts, like a white bow tie with rhinestones. They waited to ask her questions, about her first dunk, about her advice for younger players.

headline: European Plan Aims to Curb Rate-Rigging
abstract: The proposed rules would tighten oversight of financial instruments and create new powers to investigate possible manipulation of benchmarks like the Libor.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The European Union’s top financial regulator proposed tougher rules for market benchmarks, new oversight that comes after a wave of interest rate-rigging scandals at big banks.

headline: California Court Upholds Emissions Curbs
abstract: A federal appeals court upheld California’s transportation fuel standards, which are designed to help reduce greenhouse gas emissions from fuel to 1990 levels by 2020.
lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court on Wednesday upheld California’s transportation fuel standards, which are designed to help reduce greenhouse gas emissions from fuel to 1990 levels by 2020. The district court in 2011 had ruled that the state’s low carbon fuel standards discriminated against fuels produced outside California, violating Congress’s power to regulate interstate trade. Wednesday’s appeals court decision lifted a partial injunction on the state’s program. The standards were the first of their kind in the country, and regulated the carbon emitted during the production, transportation and use of fuel. Other states have since considered adopting their own limits. American Fuel and Petrochemical Manufacturers, one of the organizations that challenged the law, said it was “evaluating its options.”

headline: Hynes Is Said to Be Weighing a G.O.P. Run for District Attorney
abstract: People close to Charles J. Hynes, the incumbent in Brooklyn who lost the Democratic primary last week, say that he is reconsidering his resolution not to campaign as a Republican.
lead_paragraph: After losing the Democratic primary last week by a wide margin, District Attorney Charles J. Hynes of Brooklyn promised a smooth transition to his opponent, even though he was still on the Republican ticket. But now his political future has become murkier: while Mr. Hynes says on the record that he is not running as a Republican, three people close to him are saying that he is, indeed, considering it.

A chain of 13 crystalline lakes and ponds teems with bass and lake trout. A 10-mile stretch of the Hudson River gorge winds through dense stands of hemlock, white pine and red maple.

abstract: Mr. Taylor, a former Border Patrol agent, was regarded as a legend in the art of tracking people in the wild and helped develop a program to teach children how to increase their chances of being found.
lead_paragraph: Albert Taylor, a former United States Border Patrol agent who came to be regarded as a legend in the art of tracking in the wild — sensing in shifting sand or broken twigs the sparest of signals that someone had passed that way — died on Sept. 9 in Alpine, Calif. He was 88.

headline: Sectarian Violence Reignites in an Iraqi Town

lead_paragraph: MUQDADIYA, Iraq — The orange archway at the entrance to this farming community welcomes visitors in “peace.” The lush palm groves are heavy with ripe dates. For generations, Shiite and Sunni families worked the land, earning a living from their sheep and cows, their wheat fields and lemon trees.

The price was reported to be $10.

He gets around in a white Bentley Flying Spur, a car so luxurious it is akin to steering a cloud, which is not as comfortable as it sounds for the grounded Woodland.
