abstract: Mental health experts say that barring the rare few people who declare their intentions, picking out those who are likely to commit murder can be extremely difficult.
lead_paragraph: In hindsight, it may seem clear that Aaron Alexis, who went on a shooting rampage at the Washington Navy Yard on Monday, posed a threat long before the attack, but most mental health experts say that barring the rare few who declare their intentions, it can be extremely difficult to pick out people who are likely to commit murder.

headline: Poverty Rate Is Up in New York City, and Income Gap Is Wide, Census Data Show
abstract: New data from the Census Bureau showed that 1.7 million New Yorkers were poor, while the 2012 mean income of the highest-earning 5 percent was $436,931.
lead_paragraph: Bill de Blasio’s path to the Democratic nomination for mayor was built in large part around his theme that New York has become a tale of two cities. New data being released on Thursday by the Census Bureau lend support to that argument, showing that even as the recession has ended, the city’s poverty rate continues to inch up and the gap between the rich and poor remains stubbornly large.

headline: What’s On Thursday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (Bravo) INSIDE THE ACTORS STUDIO James Lipton interviews Jake Gyllenhaal about growing up in a Hollywood family and his relationship with his sister, Maggie Gyllenhaal; collaborating with Anne Hathaway on Ang Lee’s “Brokeback Mountain,” for which he received an Oscar nomination for best supporting actor as a cowboy in love with another man; and his work on films like “October Sky,” “Donnie Darko,” “End of Watch” and the forthcoming “Prisoners,” in which he plays a detective to Hugh Jackman’s father, desperate to find his abducted daughter. “The way you behave with everybody is more important than the work that you do,” says Mr. Gyllenhaal, above right with Mr. Lipton. “It’s essential. It is everything. Generosity and kindness and patience will get you so far. That’s the biggest lesson I’ve learned.” After 16 nominations, “Inside the Actors Studio” just won its first Emmy, for outstanding informational series.

abstract: A draft legislation aimed at reform in the pension sector, does not address the core objectives of pension — “reducing uncertainty, vulnerability and poverty in old age,” expert says.
lead_paragraph: Ashwini Kumar Sharma, 60, a data processing assistant with India’s Ministry of Home Affairs, is about to retire after 41 years of working with the government. He will get to withdraw the money that a mandatory government program made him set aside during his working years, along with the interest it accrued in a savings account.

lead_paragraph: With another high school football death on Monday after a helmet-to-helmet hit, and with more attention being paid to the risk of head injuries in football, some parents are beginning to wonder whether the game is too dangerous for their children to play.

headline: Looking at Our Hometowns
abstract: A 21st-century portrait of America by high school students is unveiled today in an interactive, searchable slide show of more than 4,000 user-submitted images.

headline: A Family Affair at London Fashion Week
abstract: Suzy Menkes speaks with the London-based designer Simone Rocha about working with her father, John Rocha, and her latest collection that mixes craft, hypermodern fabrics and pearls.
lead_paragraph: Suzy Menkes speaks with the London-based designer Simone Rocha about working with her father, John Rocha, and her latest collection that mixes craft, hypermodern fabrics and pearls.

headline: Study Affirms Benefit of Back Braces as Scoliosis Treatment
abstract: Physicians have recommended bracing to treat scoliosis in adolescents for more than 50 years, but until now, research on its effectiveness had produced mixed results.
lead_paragraph: A new study provides the best evidence yet that wearing a back brace will slow the progression of the most common form of scoliosis in adolescents, helping them avoid painful spine surgery.

headline: Chinese Dairy Company Raises $1.3 Billion in I.P.O.
abstract: Strong demand from investors for shares of China Huishan Dairy gave a boost to Hong Kong’s biggest new share sale since May, raising hopes that the market for I.P.O.’s may be staging a comeback.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Hong Kong’s market for new stock listings may be emerging from a summer slump after a Chinese dairy company raised more than $1 billion on Thursday in the city’s biggest offering since May.

headline: Obama Finds a Pen Pal in Iran
abstract: At the core of Iran’s recent diplomatic charm offensive is an exchange of letters between President Obama and President Hassan Rouhani.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Few American presidents have held a deeper belief in the power of the written word than President Obama. And in few ways has that belief been more tested than in his frustrating private correspondence with the leaders of Iran, a country with which the United States has had no diplomatic ties for 34 years.

headline: Fashion Designers Customize Two Infiniti Q50s
abstract: Nissan’s luxury brand commissioned Thom Browne and Zac Posen to each customize an Infiniti Q50 as part of a marketing tour and charity fund-raiser.
lead_paragraph: To stand out from the cars that share its nameplate, a special edition car really has to shine. In the case of the Infiniti Q50 customized by Thom Browne, the fashion designer, the car’s shininess is literal as well as figurative. Like the Fisker Karma Justin Bieber once owned, the Q50 is covered end to end in chrome.

headline: New York Today: Back to the Polls
abstract: What you need to know for Thursday: weighing the cost of runoff elections, still more sunshine and a memorial service with fairy wings.
lead_paragraph: Updated 12:08 p.m. | There might not be a runoff in the mayoral primary. But if you can’t wait until November to vote again, your chance may come in just 12 days, in the Democratic runoff for public advocate.

headline: Daily Report: Pandora Wins Court Victory Over Licenses to Stream Music
abstract: A federal judge has ruled that the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers cannot prevent Pandora Media from licensing all the songs in its catalog.
lead_paragraph: Pandora Media won a battle in its continuing war with the music industry over royalties when a federal judge ruled on Tuesday that the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers, which represents thousands of members, cannot prevent Pandora from licensing all the songs in its catalog, Ben Sisario reports.

headline: The Myspace Alumni That Left L.A. to Start Businesses
abstract: Gogobot and Mango Health emerged from the decline of Myspace but chose to locate in Silicon Valley.
lead_paragraph: In our recent article about the surprising number of Silicon Beach start-ups that have emerged from Myspace’s tortured decline, there were two start-ups that we chose not to include, Gogobot, and Mango Health. Both were started by Myspace alumni and both have interesting missions, but these entrepreneurs headed north to Silicon Valley instead of staying in Los Angeles’s Silicon Beach.

headline: Medicine Is More Than Carrots and Sticks
abstract: In today’s medical schools, words like “provider” and “consumer” are used as frequently as “healer” and “patient.” But no arsenal of incentives alone will ever produce the kind of compassion and attention to detail every patient wants and deserves.
lead_paragraph: “Did you take it out yet?” my supervising physician asked me, referring to the urinary catheter I placed in a patient several days before. “You know they’re keeping tabs on that now?”

headline: Saying He’s Pro-Russia, McCain Criticizes Putin
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Biological and Chemical Warfare']
abstract: In an online essay in Pravda, Senator John McCain delivered a blistering attack against President Vladimir V. Putin.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — In a combative essay published Thursday in the online newspaper Pravda.ru, Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, declared himself to be “pro-Russian” but delivered a blistering attack on President Vladimir V. Putin, describing him as presiding over a failed petro-state and as a quasi dictator who rules “by corruption, repression and violence.”

headline: Fed Catches Wall St. by Surprise
abstract: The Federal Reserve announced that it would postpone any retreat from its monetary stimulus program. | JPMorgan Chase is expected to pay more than $900 million in fines. | Goldman Sachs’s chief explained the decision to keep SAC Capital Advisors as a client. | Regulators proposed a rule that would require greater disclosure on pay.
lead_paragraph: CONFUSION AND RELIEF AFTER FED’S SURPRISE MOVE  |  The Federal Reserve stunned Wall Street on Wednesday by announcing that it would postpone any retreat from its monetary stimulus program for at least a month and possibly until next year. Stocks jumped and the 10-year Treasury yield fell after the 2 p.m. statement from the central bank, which flew in the face of the widespread expectation that the Fed would start to withdraw its economic stimulus this month.

headline: 6 Ways to Overcome Anxiety and Talk Money With Your Children
abstract: Many parents would rather talk to their children about sex than about money, but far too few have stopped to figure out why — and how to get over it.
lead_paragraph: Many parents would rather talk to their children about sex than about money, but far too few have stopped to figure out why — and how to get over it.

headline: At 81, Still a Master of Reinvention
abstract: The pioneering filmmaker Melvin Van Peebles, whose home is filled with artworks like a file cabinet disguised as a giant hot dog, is making his public debut as a visual artist.
lead_paragraph: THREE-QUARTERS of an hour before sunrise, Melvin Van Peebles glided up the sleeping West Side, a slender man in an orange hoodie, leading a reporter on his five-times-a-week morning run. His legs were toned and without blemish, his hair and beard a gentle white. He had a story about why he was tired on this September morning, but it is not suitable for publication, and might not be true, anyway.

headline: When Your Family Is My Family Much Too Often
keywords: ['Divorce, Separations and Annulments', 'Marriages', 'Baby Boomers', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: Winifred M. Reilly, a Berkeley-based therapist, suggests what to do when it seems as if a spouse is still married to extended family.
lead_paragraph: In the best of worlds, before marrying, people would discuss their feelings about extended family, like: How many barbecues a month do I really want to spend with my in-laws?

abstract: Jim Carter, who plays the butler on “Downton Abbey,” discusses his Emmy nomination and what viewers can expect in Season 4.
lead_paragraph: Jeeves in P.G. Wodehouse books. Hobson in “Arthur.” Hudson in “Upstairs, Downstairs.”

headline: Fed to Continue Stimulus Campaign
abstract: The U.S. economy still needs a push.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. economy still needs a push.

headline: Ladies and Gentlemen, Delhi Police Are Not With You If You Are Poor
keywords: ['Crime and Criminals', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Police', 'Robberies and Thefts']
abstract: A former crime reporter explains how the Delhi police criminalizes the poor.
lead_paragraph: I returned to Delhi in winter.  I had been away for five years. The city was in turmoil in those early months of 2010, physically and morally. The Commonwealth Games were around the corner and Delhi was a city of broken culverts, dug-up roads, half-built bus stops and hurriedly whitewashed public spaces. Revelations of corruption followed. It was hard to count the zeros in the amount of money that had been pilfered by the politicians and contractors. I had left Delhi as a young man who had worked here for several years as a police beat reporter. I was returning as an anthropologist to research the city and its press.

headline: Disappointments in ‘Happily Ever After’
keywords: ['Divorce, Separations and Annulments', 'Marriages', 'Families and Family Life', 'Baby Boomers', "Huntington's Disease"]
abstract: A couple who divorced after 18 years of marriage speak of opposites attracting, his closeness to his family, her decision to separate and their new lives.
lead_paragraph: One-quarter of all divorces now involve people over 50. In Unhitched, longtime couples tell the story of their relationships, from romance to vows to divorce to life afterward.

headline: Constitutional Disorder
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Constitutional Amendments', 'Constitutions', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: Egypt’s new constitution is being drafted much like the last: to enshrine a particular imbalance of power, rather than reflect the aspirations of all citizens.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The divisive constitution that the Muslim Brotherhood pushed through last year — over howls of indignation from the opposition — was one of the great mistakes of the Islamist organization’s short time in power. The Brothers and other Islamist parties were determined to give the country a more Islamic charter, and in doing so they ran roughshod over the concerns of many non-Islamists and their own promises of inclusiveness.

headline: Backstage Drama at the Met, Worthy of Opera
abstract: The new production of “Eugene Onegin,” which opens the Metropolitan Opera’s season, features Anna Netrebko along with a last-minute replacement director and a political protest.
lead_paragraph: “It needs more psychic atmosphere,” said Fiona Shaw, the distinguished actress and, as of last month, the director of the Metropolitan Opera’s new production of Tchaikovsky’s “Eugene Onegin.” She was standing in an aisle in the Met’s auditorium during a rehearsal break one recent Friday, staring up at the stage like it was a gifted child having trouble fulfilling its potential.

headline: Why Greece Is Not Weimar
abstract: Extremism rises in a humiliated nation, but the E.U. saves Greece from the worst.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — The perfect political storm for violent extremism has descended on Greece. It consists of national humiliation, economic disaster, high immigration, political division and international tutelage. Look no further than Weimar Germany to understand its ingredients.

abstract: Mr. Lomax, who played with the Undertakers and the Lomax Alliance, never made it as big as his fellow Liverpool rockers, the Beatles, did.
lead_paragraph: Jackie Lomax, a British rock singer and guitarist who recorded with his Liverpool neighbors George Harrison, Paul McCartney and Ringo Starr but never achieved the stardom that many had predicted, died on Sunday while visiting the Wirral, a peninsula on the Irish Sea near Liverpool. He was 69 and lived in Ojai, Calif.

keywords: ['Homosexuality', 'ABORTION', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']

lead_paragraph: Six months into his papacy, Pope Francis sent shock waves through the Roman Catholic church on Thursday with the publication of his remarks that the church had grown “obsessed” with abortion, gay marriage and contraception, and that he had chosen not to talk about those issues despite recriminations from critics.

lead_paragraph: Updated, 7:33 p.m. |  China, which has been gradually opening up its financial system, is about to let foreign hedge funds stick a small toe in.

headline: Happenings | Brooklyn Folkies Invade Big Sur and the Mojave
abstract: With the Woodsist Festival, today’s psych and folk troubadours are connecting with the bohemian legacy of California’s central coast and the Mojave Desert.
lead_paragraph: For generations, the rugged mountains and towering redwoods of Big Sur, the 90-mile stretch of central California coastline, have attracted bohemian spirits like Jack Kerouac, Hunter S. Thompson and Edward Weston. Today, the mist-shrouded Henry Miller Memorial Library — a nonprofit bookstore and arts center on the Pacific Coast Highway that opened in 1981 as a tribute to the legendary writer, who lived nearby for two decades — is the cultural heart of the region. Among its annual calendar of musical acts, film festivals and literary workshops is the Woodsist Festival, started in 2009 by the folk rock band Woods, which begins its two-day program on Sept. 22. Woodsist’s roughly 300 festivalgoers can expect jangly mellow tunes from up-and-coming and established acts represented by the Woodsist record label in an appropriately forested setting that recalls the legendary (though much larger) Monterey Pop Festival, which was held not far to the north in 1967.

headline: Poetry Pairing | ‘Eros Turannos’
abstract: Today’s Poetry Pairing presents Edwin Arlington Robinson’s “Eros Turannos,” a century-old poem about a failing relationship and the 2011 article “How Divorce Lost Its Groove” by Pamela Paul.
lead_paragraph: This Poetry Pairing presents Edwin Arlington Robinson’s “Eros Turannos,” a century-old poem about a failing relationship, and the 2011 article “How Divorce Lost Its Groove” by Pamela Paul.

headline: Poetry After Politics
abstract: For years, the vague language of poetry was one of the only ways for writers in Myanmar to criticize the country’s military rulers. But now that censorship has ended, poets are writing more freely.

lead_paragraph: Enrollment is rising at the Aung Thawada Nunnery School on the northern border of Yangon. The nuns, whose ages range from 9 to 94, join for a variety of reasons, including to escape poverty or abuse.

headline: Preserving Yangon
keywords: ['ARCHITECTURE', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Area Planning and Renewal']
abstract: Myanmar’s former capital is home to a large number of British colonial buildings, many of which are in danger of being destroyed amid gentrification as the isolated country opens up to the world.
lead_paragraph: Myanmar’s former capital is home to a large number of British colonial buildings, many of which are in danger of being destroyed amid gentrification as the isolated country opens up to the world.

headline: The Storm Before the Calm: Strange Sounds Emerge From ‘Monotone-Silence Symphony’
abstract: The “Monotone-Silence Symphony” by the artist Yves Klein is performed in New York for the first time.
lead_paragraph: I thought I heard bagpipes. I thought I heard snippets of Philip Glass’s “1000 Airplanes on the Roof.” Toward the end, I could have sworn I heard someone near me crying. But I didn’t really hear any of those things, because the only music filling the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church was a D major chord, sustained with great effort for precisely 20 minutes by a group of almost 70 singers and instrumentalists.

headline: Yangon, Once Frozen in Time, Inches Forward
abstract: Myanmar’s halting political progress is reflected in Yangon, a city that swells with new opportunity despite numerous problems. Three videos explore these shifts.
lead_paragraph: Yangon’s skyline, punctuated by golden pagodas and the steel skeletons of new development, is a scene of picturesque disrepair and halting progress as Myanmar emerges from decades of military rule that seemed to freeze the country in time. Colonial facades crumble next to new buildings painstakingly constructed mostly by men, not machines. Recently imported cars idle on congested, often flooded, streets. And the Internet — largely unrestricted since 2011 — remains hobbled by frequent and unpredictable outages.

headline: National Book Awards Releases Nominees
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Poetry and Poets', 'National Book Awards', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors']
abstract: Ten nominees for the categories of fiction, nonfiction, poetry and young people’s literature were announced, and winners will be revealed Nov. 20.
lead_paragraph: In a bid to generate more excitement for its annual National Book Awards, the foundation that administers the prize has released four long lists of nominees for the first time this year.

headline: Defeat in Victory at Chickamauga
abstract: The Confederacy came out victorious in one of the Civil War’s bloodiest battles, but it was a hollow win.
lead_paragraph: On Sept, 11, 1863, the Confederates lost a crucial opportunity to destroy Brig. Gen. James Negley’s exposed division at Dug Gap, south of Chattanooga, Tenn. Negley’s division was part of William Rosecrans’s Army of the Cumberland, which was on a relentless campaign to push the rebels out of Tennessee. Even though Negley’s men somehow survived destruction, Rosecrans was shaken. The Confederates, having recently abandoned Chattanooga, had looked to be on the run. Now they had turned and fought, and almost won. Rosecrans realized that his grand pursuit had gone tragically awry – his forces were divided into three widely separate corps, and if he failed to unite them rapidly, he might well find himself the pursued.

lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Filippo Mutani.

headline: Magnets Fail to Relieve Arthritis Pain
abstract: Many people use copper bracelets and magnetic wrist straps to alleviate the pain of arthritis, but a rigorous new study concludes they do not work.
lead_paragraph: Many people use copper bracelets and magnetic wrist straps to alleviate the pain of arthritis, but a new randomized, double-blinded, placebo-controlled study concludes they do not work.

headline: Shaking Up Shakespeare: Reaching the Shakespeare-Averse With Adaptations
abstract: In this lesson, students will examine their preconceptions about Shakespeare and his work. After reading one critic’s case for reading and seeing Shakespeare this year, they will use The Times to explore adaptations of a Shakespearean play they are studying.
lead_paragraph: Overview | Why study Shakespeare? What role can his work play in teaching us about ourselves in the 21st century? In this lesson, students will examine their preconceptions about Shakespeare and his work. Then, after reading one theater critic’s case for reading and seeing Shakespeare this year, they will use The Times to explore adaptations of a Shakespearean play they are currently studying. Finally, they will use these as a springboard for staging their own scenes from the play in a new way, using an adaptation they have read about as a model.

headline: A New Andaz Hotel in Costa Rica
abstract: The Andaz Papagayo hotel is scheduled to open in Costa Rica in December.
lead_paragraph: Andaz, the upscale hotel chain managed by Hyatt Hotels & Resorts, recently announced that it will open its first Latin American property, Andaz Papagayo on Península Papagayo in Costa Rica’s northwest Pacific Coast on Dec. 15.

headline: The Great Wrecking-Ball Search of Summer 2013
abstract: To properly illustrate our Education issue cover, we looked far and wide for just the right doomed school.
lead_paragraph: Last weekend’s Education issue highlighted several ongoing experiments in rethinking education — what we teach (emotional intelligence, career planning), how (tablets) and even where (enormous open online courses). To evoke that idea on the cover, the magazine’s editor, Hugo Lindgren, suggested in late August that we photograph a school being demolished and add a headline like “Your Idea Here.” As the photo editor overseeing the issue, it fell to me to find some schools facing the wrecking ball.

headline: Into the Wildfire
abstract: What science is learning about fire and how to live with it.
lead_paragraph: Lassen Volcanic National Park, in Northern California, consists of more than 100,000 acres of wilderness and woodlands surrounding Lassen Peak, a volcano named for a pioneer and huckster who guided migrants through the area, that last blew its top in 1915, before anybody knew it was an active volcano. Last summer the park, like much of the West, was in the midst of a yearlong drought — which could be more accurately described as the continuation of a decade-long drought that had merely been less severe for a couple of years.

headline: Image of the Day: Sept. 19
abstract: A 10th-century sculpture stolen from Uttar Pradesh and shipped to France was recently returned to India.

abstract: Stanley Crouch discusses his new book about Charlie Parker’s early life and social world.
lead_paragraph: Stanley Crouch discusses his new book about Charlie Parker’s early life and social world.

headline: Collision Course, as Rivals Follow Their Drives
abstract: Ron Howard’s “Rush” tells the story of James Hunt and Niki Lauda, Formula One titans and rivals who, in 1976, helped push racing into mainstream consciousness.
lead_paragraph: Several times in “Rush,” Ron Howard’s excitingly torqued movie set in the Formula One race world, the camera gets so close to a driver’s eye that you can see each trembling lash. It’s a startlingly beautiful but also naked image, partly because there’s no hiding for an actor when the camera gets that close. In moments like these, you’re no longer watching a performance with its layers of art and technique: you’ve crossed the border between fiction and documentary to go eye to eye with another person’s nervous system. Mr. Howard doesn’t just want you to crawl inside a Formula One racecar, he also wants you to crawl inside its driver’s head.

headline: Popcast: Early Bird and ‘Kansas City Lightning’

headline: ‘Willy Wonka’ Shadows a Stage Candy Man
abstract: The West End musical “Charlie and the Chocolate Factory” faces an uphill climb toward Broadway.
lead_paragraph: London — The song arrives late in the new musical “Charlie and the Chocolate Factory,” but when that familiar lilting melody begins, audiences come alive as at no other point in the show. During one performance this summer, several people hummed softly while others smiled broadly as the mysterious chocolatier, Willy Wonka, stepped into his glass elevator and sang “Pure Imagination,” the immensely tuneful number from the 1971 film “Willy Wonka & the Chocolate Factory.”

headline: Triple Play: Make Your Picks for Week 26
abstract: Put your predictive skills to the test each week of the baseball season.
lead_paragraph: The Bats blog tests our readers’ predictive skills one last time this season with three questions about the coming week. Feel free to lean on research, tea leaves, your gut instinct or maybe just dumb luck.

headline: The Lives Lived Outside History
abstract: “Not What Happened,” by the playwright and performance artist Ain Gordon, opens on Wednesday as part of the Next Wave Festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
lead_paragraph: The playwright and performance artist Ain Gordon haunts the margins of history. Main events featuring famous people, the kind recorded with unblinking authority in encyclopedia entries, have never been his primary interest. In works like “In This Place ...” and “A Disaster Begins,” Mr. Gordon conjures the sort of distant lives that don’t make it into textbooks, processed into oblivion by what he calls history’s “ruthless editing machine.”

headline: Looking at Our Hometowns
abstract: A 21st-century portrait of America by high school students is unveiled today in an interactive, searchable slide show of more than 4,000 user-submitted images.
lead_paragraph: A 21st-century portrait of America by high school students is unveiled today in an interactive, searchable slide show of more than 4,000 user-submitted images.

headline: Sting’s Musical to Open on Broadway After Chicago Tryout
abstract: “The Last Ship” will open in Chicago next summer, before a planned Broadway opening that fall.
lead_paragraph: “The Last Ship,” a new musical from Sting about family and labor strife in working-class Britain, will come to Broadway in the fall of 2014, after a tryout run in Chicago next summer, the producers announced on Thursday.

headline: Today in Small Business: The Business Lessons of Walter White
abstract: Gender balance is good for business. Lessons from the death of a start-up. The Super Bowl’s first marijuana commercial?
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: 36 Hours in Reykjavik
abstract: See the city’s award-winning new architectural landmark, stay up (very) late on a pub crawl, find peace on a nearby island and far more during a weekend in Iceland’s capital.
lead_paragraph: The major news out of Iceland in recent years has not been good. First a banking collapse crippled the economy in 2008, and then a year and a half later, the volcanic eruption at Eyjafjallajokull halted air travel across the Atlantic and in Europe, frustrating millions. But signs of an upswing — economic and otherwise — can be spotted in Reykjavik, where this year the capital’s impressive new concert hall won the prestigious Mies van der Rohe Award, the European Union’s top prize for contemporary architecture. In other parts of town, new restaurants are embracing fresh local fare, and the bacchanalian night life is thumping with a crop of new bars and clubs. This winter has been predicted to be a particularly favorable time to observe the aurora borealis dancing across the night sky, but already Reykjavik is shining.

headline: Above and Beyond in Reykjavik
abstract: Climb, dine and drink during a quick weekend in Iceland’s capital.
lead_paragraph: Climb, dine and drink during a quick weekend in Iceland’s capital.

headline: On Martha’s Vineyard, Celebrating the Local Bounty
abstract: Resorts give way to pastures, farmland and wildlife in a pocket of the island around Chilmark and Menemsha.
lead_paragraph: It was late August in Martha’s Vineyard, a bright, sunny day perfect for a farmers’ market. I arrived at 9 a.m. with Chris Fischer — chef, farmer, guy who knows everyone. Mr. Fischer, who grew up on a farm here and has had a job since he was 9, looks as if he grew up on a farm here and has had a job since he was 9. His dark, weathered skin, wrinkly eyes, graying beard and cracked, calloused hands belie a mere 33 years.

headline: Along a Stretch in Brooklyn, Moving Beyond the Bars
abstract: Stylish boutiques, antiques dealers and upscale restaurants now mix with local watering holes on the western end of Atlantic Avenue.
lead_paragraph: Stylish boutiques, antiques dealers and upscale restaurants now mix with local watering holes on the western end of Atlantic Avenue.

headline: Patrik Ervell’s Sci-Fi Moment in the Northern California Redwoods
abstract: In this video premiere, the designer presents his fall/winter 2013 men’s wear collection in a natural setting that imbues the clothes with a sense of fantasy.
lead_paragraph: In one season after another, the New York-based men’s wear designer Patrik Ervell has presented precise, impeccably tailored collections that frequently feature futuristic textures and technical fabrics inspired by the outdoors. For the video to promote his fall/winter 2013 men’s wear collection, which was shot by Luke Gilford and has its premiere here, Ervell bucked trends as surely as he does with his clothes, choosing to set his looks against the backdrop of the redwood forests in the mountains above Santa Cruz, south of his childhood home of San Francisco. “For me, it’s refreshing to see fashion video shot in a natural setting,” he said. “Most people approach this fashion video format like they would a shoot. It’s just a girl walking around, which I think ends up being a bit boring. For others it’s a long-winded thing, like an art project, which I also see as a misfire.”

headline: Texas Court Overturns Conviction of DeLay
keywords: ['Campaign Finance', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Money Laundering']
abstract: An appeals court ruled that Tom DeLay, a Texas Republican who was the House majority leader, did not violate state laws by laundering corporate contributions to divert money to elect Republicans.
lead_paragraph: Tom DeLay was the very symbol of Congressional power and, in the view of his detractors, excess. His political career collapsed in 2005 when Mr. DeLay, a Texas Republican who was the House majority leader, was indicted on money-laundering charges that resulted in a three-year prison sentence.

headline: New Approach to Explaining Evolution’s Big Bang
abstract: Two scientists take a fresh look at the hypotheses about the Cambrian explosion, one of the most important phases in the history of life.
lead_paragraph: The name Myllokunmingia may not ring a bell, but it is worth knowing. This 520-million-year-old creature was the size of a guppy, with a tiny swordfish-like fin running high over its back. The fossils it has left behind preserve traces of a skull.

headline: Life on Mars? Well, Maybe Not
abstract: In more than a year on Mars, Curiosity has found no evidence of methane, a gas that is considered a possible calling card of microbes, NASA announced Thursday.
lead_paragraph: In findings that are as scientifically significant as they are crushing to the popular imagination, NASA reported Thursday that its Mars rover, Curiosity, has deflated hopes that life could be thriving on Mars today.

headline: A Writer’s Life Measured in Movies
abstract: Anticipating the release of the first film adaption of his work, “C.O.G.,” the writer David Sedaris discussed some of his favorite movies.
lead_paragraph: “In a way you have to forgive people of a certain age,” the writer David Sedaris said recently. “Like when you watch the movie ‘Into the Wild.’ There were times when I just wanted to take that kid and shake him, but then I thought, he’s 20. That’s what 20-year-olds do, and you just have to forgive him that.”

headline: A Weekend of Old-Fashioned Chivalry and Combat
abstract: “The Middle Ages on Film: Knights of the Roundtable,” a 10-day series at Anthology Film Archives, starts this weekend.
lead_paragraph: The Miser likes to quip that his appreciation of high culture stems from a more prosaic youthful pursuit: hours spent playing Dungeons & Dragons. Among the many worlds a player could compete in, this player was invariably drawn into realms replete with castles, knights, wizards and damsels.

headline: Fantasy Football: Week 3 Matchup Breakdown
abstract: Marshawn Lynch offered fantasy owners a valuable lesson in Week 2. He is among our favorable matchup picks for Week 3.
lead_paragraph: Marshawn Lynch offered fantasy owners a valuable early lesson in Week 2.

headline: Double Duty: Guarding the Art, and Explaining It
abstract: During the day, Jeffrey Martinez, a guard at the Guggenheim Museum, watches over masterpieces and gently helps baffled viewers. At night, he creates his own art.
lead_paragraph: “Are you the person that we can ask questions? Or are you just a guard?” If the visitor’s words sting Jeffrey Martinez, he doesn’t show it. After a summer protecting works by the artist James Turrell at the Guggenheim Museum, he has grown accustomed to roving throngs of the baffled.

headline: Hiroshi Yamauchi, Who Steered Nintendo to Dominance, Dies at 85
abstract: At 22, Mr. Yamauchi became president of his family’s playing-card company and later steered it into the growing game business, developing hits like Donkey Kong and the original Mario Brothers franchises.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Hiroshi Yamauchi, who transformed his great-grandfather’s playing-card company, Nintendo, into a global video game powerhouse, died on Thursday in Kyoto, Japan. He was 85.

headline: Taliban Are Said to Attack Afghan Police
abstract: The reports were a sign of growing casualty rates among forces in Afghanistan, but they were disputed by the government.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Taliban insurgents have reportedly captured or killed large numbers of Afghan government forces in the remote and usually quiet northeastern corner of the country for the second time this year, officials said Thursday.

headline: Milan Fashion Week: Fendi Spring/Summer 2014
abstract: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

headline: New Getty Atlas to Preserve Data on Nondigital Photography
abstract: The Getty Conservation Institute in Los Angeles will collect and publish information about pre-digital photography to aid scholars and preservationists.
lead_paragraph: Analog photography may be going the way of the dinosaurs. But for the museums, archives, galleries and collectors who own and care for millions of pictorial artifacts bequeathed by more than 150 years of pre-digital photography, information about how film, paper, chemicals and metals worked to create pictures for all those years remains extraordinarily valuable.

headline: Greek Killing Raises Fears of Extremism
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: European officials expressed concern about a rise in hate-fueled violence after Greek demonstrators protested the killing of an antifascist activist that the police blamed on a supporter of the right-wing Golden Dawn party.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — European officials expressed concern on Thursday about a rise of extremism in Greece, a day after thousands of demonstrators took to the streets in several Greek cities to protest the killing of an antifascist activist. The Greek police said the killer was a supporter of the right-wing Golden Dawn party.

headline: NBC Plans a Mini-Series on Life of Johnny Carson
abstract: The special will be based on the long-awaited biography by Bill Zehme, “Carson the Magnificent: An Intimate Portrait.”
lead_paragraph: NBC will feature one of its icons, Johnny Carson, in an ambitious biopic mini-series, the network announced on Thursday.

headline: Lessons for H.P. From Its Offspring
abstract: Agilent Technologies was considered the producer of nerdy scientific equipment when it was spun off from Hewlett-Packard in 1999, while H.P. was expanding. But Agilent has outperformed H.P. and is now splitting to create yet more value.
lead_paragraph: The old Hewlett-Packard has set a breakup example for the new Hewlett-Packard. Spun off in 1999 with the company’s original testing products and research DNA, Agilent Technologies is considered by Silicon Valley veterans to be the “real H.P.” It has outperformed its former parent and is now splitting to create yet more value. H.P. can learn from its progeny.

headline: In Auction of Koch’s Possessions, a Trove of Letters
abstract: A gallery is holding an auction of former Mayor Edward I. Koch’s possessions, including a letters from presidents and famous public officials, celebrities, and literary and entertainment figures.
lead_paragraph: For those who couldn’t get enough of former Mayor Edward I. Koch while he was alive, Doyle Galleries will hold an auction on not one, but two days for those interested in his possessions, including letters, books, ephemera and furniture from his Greenwich Village apartment.

headline: With a Swimmer’s Honesty Questioned, The Times Should Follow Up
abstract: With the focus shifting to more technical matters in Diana Nyad’s 52-hour, 110-mile swim, the larger questions should be settled.
lead_paragraph: Jason Stallman, the sports editor at The New York Times, describes an article that questioned Diana Nyad’s record-breaking swim to Florida from Cuba as “a tricky one from the start.”

headline: Prada: Working Girl
abstract: If Miuccia Prada’s spring men’s show, in June, led people astray with its “Menacing Paradise” theme, her women’s collection on Thursday night was a slap in the face, Cher style.
lead_paragraph: If Miuccia Prada’s spring men’s show, in June, led people astray with its “Menacing Paradise” theme, set in the tropics, her women’s collection on Thursday night in Milan was a slap in the face, Cher style. It put across a strong physical attitude, not merely a tough-girl snarl.

headline: Bad Guy as Hero: Happy Ending?
abstract: Showtime’s “Dexter” ends on Sunday, and the question is, Will Michael C. Hall’s serial killer head off to happy retirement in Argentina or end up in some kind of hell?
lead_paragraph: As “Dexter” reaches its final episode on Showtime on Sunday night, the question is, will he go or will he go?

headline: Prada: Spring 2014 RTW
abstract: Milan
lead_paragraph: Milan

headline: In JPMorgan Settlement, Testing the Lines of Admitting Wrongdoing
abstract: JPMorgan walked a careful line when it settled with one regulator but not another in the London Whale case, the author writes.
lead_paragraph: The settlements announced on Thursday by JPMorgan Chase over the “London Whale” trading included a much-anticipated admission of wrongdoing in its resolution with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: General Motors Looks to Cut Battery Prices and Increase E.V. Range
abstract: Announcing its plans to build an affordable electric vehicle with a 200-mile range, General Motors appears to be answering the challenge leveled by Tesla’s proposed car of similar dimensions.
lead_paragraph: The range of the battery-powered Chevrolet Spark is 82 miles, but although General Motors says that’s enough for most daily commuters, the company isn’t stopping there.

headline: As German Vote Nears, No Guarantees for Merkel’s Coalition
abstract: Polls showed the difficulties Chancellor Angela Merkel faced building a winning coalition as her Social Democratic challenger, Peer Steinbrück, urged his party to make the most of Ms. Merkel’s collapsing support.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Germany’s race for Parliament tightened Thursday, three days before elections, with fresh polls underlining the difficulty that even the popular chancellor, Angela Merkel, faces in building a winning coalition.

headline: U.S. Orders More Steps to Curb Stiff Drug Sentences
abstract: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. said prosecutors were ordered to refile charges in certain drug cases to avoid triggering mandatory minimum sentencing laws.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Thursday expanded its effort to curtail severe penalties for low-level federal drug offenses, ordering prosecutors to refile charges against defendants in pending cases and strip out any references to specific quantities of illicit substances that would trigger mandatory minimum sentencing laws.

headline: Same Firm Did Checks on Snowden and Gunman
keywords: ['Washington Navy Yard Shooting (2013)', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: USIS, which conducted a background check of the former contractor Edward J. Snowden, said that it had also run a check on the former Navy reservist who killed 12 people Monday.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A company that conducted a background check of Edward J. Snowden, the government contractor who leaked national security secrets, said on Thursday that it had also run a check on the former Navy reservist who killed 12 people at the Washington Navy Yard on Monday.

headline: A Rutgers Walk-On Rushes to the Top
abstract: The Scarlet Knights have two nonscholarship athletes starting in the backfield: running back Paul James and fullback Michael Burton.
lead_paragraph: PISCATAWAY, N.J. — Two years ago, Paul James could not get a single Division I football program to notice him. He spent college signing day in 2011 sitting in class at Glassboro High School, in South Jersey. His coaches worked the phones furiously, hoping for a late break. The fax machine stayed silent.

headline: Cochran Makes a Fund-Raising Push as He Eyes Re-election
abstract: While it is unclear whether longtime Senator Thad Cochran will seek another term next year, fund-raising efforts remain a high priority for the Mississippi Republican.
lead_paragraph: Senator Thad Cochran, a Republican of Mississippi and one of the Senate’s longest-serving members, is increasing his fund-raising efforts amid speculation that he might retire instead of run for re-election next year.

headline: Events in Connecticut
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Once Again, Punishing the Bank but Not Its Top Executives
abstract: Reports from the Securities and Exchange Commission and the British Financial Conduct Authority reveal how the bank’s senior management operated in the crucial days before a shareholder filing on May 10.
lead_paragraph: It’s an outcome that has vexed the public since the financial crisis of 2008.

headline: Google Is Exploring an Alternative to Cookies for Ad Tracking
abstract: Google is considering an anonymous identifier for Chrome users, as advertisers fear that traditional methods of tracking users across the Web no longer work.
lead_paragraph: Google, the biggest online advertising company, is considering a new way to help advertisers track people across the Web and consolidate its power in the industry.

headline: Kerry Talks to China’s Foreign Minister
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty', 'United States Politics and Government', 'International Relations']
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry met with Foreign Minister Wang Yi to discuss the issues of Syria and North Korea.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State John Kerry met with Foreign Minister Wang Yi to discuss the issues of Syria and North Korea.

headline: Honda Recalls 374,000 Minivans and S.U.V.’s for Air Bag Problem
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Automobiles', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: Blaming electrical interference as the cause, Honda is issuing a recall for vehicles in which the air bags could deploy spontaneously in a noncrash scenario.
lead_paragraph: Honda will recall about 374,000 Honda minivans and Acura sport utility vehicles because the air bags may deploy without the vehicle being in an accident, the automaker informed the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. Honda said electrical interference was the cause of the problem.

headline: Despite Early Criticism, Apple’s iOS 7 Quickly Gains Traction
abstract: Despite harsh criticism from some designers, app developers and tech journalists about iOS 7, Apple’s redesigned mobile operating system, people are downloading the software in droves.
lead_paragraph: Consumers are downloading Apple’s latest mobile operating system in droves, despite some harsh criticism from designers, app developers and journalists who had tried early versions of the software.

headline: Events in Westchester
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Behind the Counter, Working the Room
abstract: At Kura in the East Village, Norihiro Ishizuka prepares sushi with a genial smile and a generous hand.
lead_paragraph: At the sushi counter at Kura, there is no sentinel in white; no silent, coolly appraising overlord. Norihiro Ishizuka, 70, stands alone, wearing not a crisp chef’s coat but a samue, traditionally a monk’s work robe, that slouches at his waist like a dressing gown.

headline: Kura
abstract: Inside the tiny East Village sushi restaurant with an austere exterior.
lead_paragraph: Inside the tiny East Village sushi restaurant with an austere exterior.

headline: Elizabeth Gilbert Stirs Strong Reactions
abstract: What writers, celebrities, fans and haters have said about the beloved and despised author of “Eat, Pray, Love.”
lead_paragraph: Since Elizabeth Gilbert rocketed to fame, fueled in part by appearances on “Oprah” and a movie based on her book “Eat, Pray, Love,” people have been broadcasting their opinions of her in reviews, blog posts and tweets. To some, Gilbert, whom Steve Almond profiles in this week’s magazine, is like the cool, free-spirited aunt they never had who doles out wisdom in punchy verses. (Search #EatPrayLove on Twitter for tweets and retweets like “A true soulmate is a mirror” and “Balance is not letting anyone love you less than you love yourself.”) To others, she is self-indulgent and undeserving of her success. Here’s a sampling of some of the more extreme reactions to her (and you can see a bunch more in the comments section of Almond’s article).

headline: Lhota, Behind in Another Poll, Wants More Debates With de Blasio
abstract: A Quinnipiac survey of New York’s mayoral race gives Bill de Blasio a 41-point lead over Joseph J. Lhota.
lead_paragraph: Joseph J. Lhota, faced on Thursday with another poll showing him far behind Bill de Blasio in New York’s mayoral race, proposed holding weekly debates, hoping they might alter the dynamics of the contest.

headline: A Year After Storm, Travel Deals in New Jersey
abstract: New Jersey inns will offer discounts on rooms in a campaign to promote tourism a year after Hurricane Sandy.
lead_paragraph: Inns throughout New Jersey will observe the coming anniversary of Hurricane Sandy with discounts on rooms. Twenty-six member inns of the New Jersey Bed and Breakfast Association will offer 10 percent off weeknight rates during October in a campaign called Back Inn Business.

headline: Goldman to Expand Small-Business Program
abstract: The ideal candidate for the program, a spokeswoman said, is a company in business for two years, with at least four employees and from $150,000 to $4 million in annual revenue.
lead_paragraph: In the last five years, officials from Goldman Sachs have been familiar faces on Capitol Hill, frequently defending the firm’s actions in the years leading up to the financial crisis. But on Thursday, the investment firm used a friendly hearing as an opportunity to go on offense: testifying before a Republican-led House committee, Goldman Sachs’s director of corporate engagement, Dina Powell, announced that her organization was expanding 10,000 Small Businesses, its program to assist entrepreneurs.

headline: Questioning Steroid Shots for Back Pain
abstract: A new review of studies suggests that injecting any liquid, even plain saline solution, works just as well as steroid injections for back pain.
lead_paragraph: Injecting steroids into the area around the spinal cord, known as an epidural, is the most commonly used treatment for back pain, but a new review of studies suggests that injecting any liquid, even plain saline solution, works just as well.

headline: The Messy-Kitchen, Parking-Spot War
abstract: Not wanting to be like my mother, I let my college-age daughter and her boyfriend live with me without any rules. That was a mistake.
lead_paragraph: The day my daughter arrived home from her first year in college, her boyfriend moved in. They didn’t consult me.

headline: A Brother, Long Gone, Is Painfully Present
abstract: Jhumpa Lahiri’s new novel, set in India and America, explores the relationship between two brothers whose paths diverge.
lead_paragraph: Jhumpa Lahiri first made her name with quiet, meticulously observed stories about Indian immigrants trying to adjust to new lives in the United States, stories that had the hushed intimacy of chamber music. The premise of her new novel, “The Lowland,” in contrast, is startlingly operatic. Udayan, an idealistic student in Calcutta in the 1960s, is drawn into Mao-inspired revolutionary politics. After his violent death (which happens fairly early in the novel), his devoted, dutiful brother, Subhash, marries his pregnant widow, Gauri, and brings her to America in hopes of giving her a new start in a new country. Their marriage, though, will remain haunted by their memories of Udayan and a terrible secret Gauri keeps to herself.

headline: Playful Throwback Sandals from Prada
abstract: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway. Today’s pick: an upscale twist on one of the ubiquitous shoes of the ’90s.
lead_paragraph: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: Reconstructing the Music of Roman Jews
abstract: It being the first night of Sukkot, naturally we went to hear Roman-Jewish liturgical melodies and World War II Italian Resistance anthems set to avant-rock arrangements by an art-house band in Greenwich Village.
lead_paragraph: It being the first night of Sukkot on Wednesday, naturally we went to hear ancient Roman-Jewish liturgical melodies and World War II Italian Resistance anthems set to avant-rock arrangements by an art-house band in Greenwich Village.

headline: Not Even the Pope Likes the Church’s Obsession with Abortion
abstract: Pope Francis said the church had grown “obsessed” with abortion, gay marriage and contraception, to its detriment.
lead_paragraph: Many Catholics in the United States, especially younger ones, women and those with a more liberal outlook, have long wondered why their church is so focused on divisive political issues such as abortion, homosexuality and contraception.

headline: Portrait Miniatures Flow Out of the Attic
abstract: Shows of portrait miniatures are regaining their allure, partly because of detailed research into the lives (and the foibles) of the sitters.
lead_paragraph: Displays of antique miniature portraits can serve as giant diagrams of connections among families, their fortunes and the artists who painted the works. Sometimes there’s a whiff of scandal.

headline: From the Page to the Stage, a Confession Receives an Operatic Turn
abstract: Patricia Racette performs the title role in an adaptation of “Dolores Claiborne” at the San Francisco Opera.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — This was already going to be a banner season at the San Francisco Opera for the American soprano Patricia Racette. Her performances always thoughtful and touching, Ms. Racette has long been a favorite here and she was scheduled to star in no fewer than three of the year’s eight productions.

headline: There’s a Big City Out There Called Milan
abstract: It is not often you see this many Italian designers in the same room, let alone speaking to one another.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of editors travel here twice a year and never stop to smell the roses. That is, they never step foot outside the circuit of fashion shows and shopping binges (well, back before the euro) to see anything else. Ask a fashion person for directions to “The Last Supper” and you’re likely to wind up in front of Da Giacomo.

headline: Another Cubist Gift for the Met, and New Art at MetroTech
abstract: The philanthropist Leonard A. Lauder, who donated $1 billion worth of art to the Metropolitan Museum last spring, has expanded his gift with a newly purchased Léger painting.
lead_paragraph: A BIG GIFT TO THE MET GROWS EVEN BIGGER

headline: After Two Children Vanish, Agony Begets Recklessness
abstract: In “Prisoners,” a father takes matters into his own hands after his young daughter and her friend disappear.
lead_paragraph: Violence against children strikes most people as a uniquely terrible phenomenon, which may be why filmmakers are so fond of it. Nothing sparks a revenge plot, or allows a director to trade intellectual nuance for visceral feeling, quite as efficiently as a child in peril. When dealing with people who gratuitously cause the innocent to suffer, no retribution seems too extreme, and the history of movies is full of good men (and a few women) driven to righteous brutality against predators, kidnappers and abusers.

headline: Confronting Long Island’s Rental Shortage
keywords: ['Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: A new report finds that more than half of all 20- to 34-year-olds on Long Island still live with their parents.
lead_paragraph: Steve Murphy swears he has nothing against his parents.

headline: Taking Over a Seller’s Loan
abstract: Mortgages from the F.H.A. and Department of Veterans Affairs have a little-known feature: assumability.
lead_paragraph: Homeowners with a mortgage insured by the Federal Housing Administration or the Department of Veterans Affairs should consider using their loan terms as a marketing tool when it comes time to sell.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Egypt, Syria, Sri Lanka and Pakistan.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Egypt, Syria, Sri Lanka and Pakistan.

headline: Back to ‘Made in America’
abstract: After years of decline, one of the hardest hit industries in the United States might be making a comeback. But while textile manufacturing might return to the Carolinas, the jobs probably will not.
lead_paragraph: After years of decline, one of the hardest hit industries in the United States might be making a comeback. But while textile manufacturing might return to the Carolinas, the jobs probably will not.

headline: No Easy Answers on Financing Long-Term Care
abstract: The full report from the federal Long-Term Care Commission offers few ideas about how Americans should pay for long-term care.
lead_paragraph: The federal Long-Term Care Commission published its full report on Wednesday, but it did little to change the perception that substantial relief for caregivers will be a long time coming.

headline: New York Times Company to Pay a 4-Cent Dividend
abstract: The president and chief executive of The Times, Mark Thompson, said that while the company would maintain a cautious financial strategy, the strength of the balance sheet justified a dividend.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Company announced on Thursday that it would pay a quarterly dividend to its shareholders for the first time in five years.

headline: Labour Party Finding Fault With Its Leader
abstract: Ed Miliband, who became the leader of the British Labour Party three years ago after its election defeat, has failed to convince the public that he is prime ministerial material.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Ed Miliband, the leader of the opposition Labour Party, appeared to have Prime Minister David Cameron on the ropes. Mr. Cameron had just lost a vote in Parliament on a nonbinding motion to consider military action in Syria over chemical weapons, the first time in at least a century that a prime minister had not gotten parliamentary support for such a response. Mr. Cameron threw in the towel.

headline: Canada to Set Up New Securities Regulator
abstract: Thwarted by a court ruling blocking it from unilaterally establishing a national securities regulator, the government of Canada joined with two provinces to form a “cooperative” agency on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Thwarted by a court ruling blocking it from unilaterally establishing a national securities regulator, the government of Canada joined with two provinces to form a “cooperative” agency on Thursday.

headline: If What You Fancy Is Simplicity
abstract: The restaurant, opened by Angelo Bongiovanni and Steven Botta in mid-July, offers the simple rustic fare that its name suggests, as well as indulgent service.
lead_paragraph: Don’t go looking for fancy Italian at Osteria Cucina Rustica in Marlboro. Despite the imposing facade of this restaurant in a former bank, the fare is indeed rustic, as the name suggests. Flavors are simple.

headline: This Week’s Movies: Sept. 19, 2013
abstract: The New York Times film critics on “Rush,” “Prisoners” and “Enough Said.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics on “Rush,” “Prisoners” and “Enough Said.”

headline: What to Eat With Bierzo Wines
abstract: Beef with peppers echoes the flavors in these Spanish wines.
lead_paragraph: The last time we tasted mencías from Bierzo, Spain, my recipe included rosemary, the wines’ dominant herbal note. Consistency may be someone else’s hobgoblin, but it’s nice to see it in wines; there was that rosemary again.

headline: In the New World, Trappings of a New Social Order
abstract: “Behind Closed Doors: Art in the Spanish American Home, 1492-1898,” at the Brooklyn Museum, examines the conspicuous consumption of Spanish colonials.
lead_paragraph: “Behind Closed Doors: Art in the Spanish American Home, 1492-1898,” at the Brooklyn Museum, leaves us in the strange position of marveling at the opulence of domestic life in the Spanish colonies while pondering some of the ugliest aspects of colonialism. This is awkward, to be sure, but also enlightening.

abstract: A reader responds to a recent review of Norman Rush’s “Subtle Bodies.”
