headline: Laura Parnes: ‘County Down’
abstract: Ms. Parnes’s 70-minute horror movie, “County Down,” looks like it was made by an enterprising but not exceptionally talented high school student.
lead_paragraph: Fitzroy

headline: Michael Buthe: ‘Secrets’
abstract: The German artist Michael Buthe was gay, Roman Catholic, and sought sources for art outside his own culture.
lead_paragraph: Alexander and Bonin

headline: Milan Fashion Week: Prada Spring/Summer 2014
abstract: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.

headline: Joanna Malinowska: ‘A Hawk From a Handsaw’
abstract: Although heavy-handed in its symbolism, Ms. Malinowska’s latest solo is a high-spirited exploration of the North American frontier.
lead_paragraph: Canada

headline: Carol Bove: ‘RA, or Why is an orange like a bell?’
abstract: Ms. Bove continues to cultivate her extraordinary garden, operating in the gaps between art and design, modernism (especially Minimalism) and nature.
lead_paragraph: Maccarone

headline: Virginia Poundstone: ‘Total Meltdown’
abstract: The Victorian pastime of flower pressing looks decidedly contemporary in Ms. Poundstone’s latest solo, which makes it difficult to separate nature and artifice.
lead_paragraph: Kansas

headline: Barbad Golshiri: ‘Curriculum Mortis’
abstract: Mr. Golshiri is part of a generation of young Iranian artists who, working primarily at home, are distancing themselves from the easy exoticisms that sell well abroad.
lead_paragraph: Thomas Erben Gallery

headline: Beguiling Reds from Bierzo
abstract: Even with some problems in balance, this Spanish region has tremendous potential with wines that are distinctively its own.
lead_paragraph: Few wine notions are tossed around as frequently and as randomly as “balance.” Often it’s stated axiomatically, as in, “Good wines must be balanced.” Who can argue with that?

headline: As Oil Thieves Bleed Nigeria, Report Says, Officials Profit
abstract: Thieves in Nigeria steal an estimated 100,000 barrels of oil a day, and the country’s politicians and security officials are among those profiting, a report said.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — Oil is being stolen on an “industrial scale” in Nigeria, the world’s 13th largest producer, and the country’s politicians and security officials are among those profiting, according to a new report from a prominent British research group.

headline: Professor in Chief
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)']
abstract: When Woodrow Wilson moved from the university to the White House, he faced a host of domestic and international challenges.
lead_paragraph: No American president was more improbable than Thomas Woodrow Wilson. None better embodied how we like to think of ourselves in the greater world.

headline: Minnesota Orchestra Plans Gala; Dissonance Is Expected
abstract: Locked-out players plan to protest outside the orchestra’s annual fund-raising ball at Orchestra Hall on Friday.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — It promises to be a bizarre scene.

headline: Stylish Italian Food, Modestly Priced
abstract: Bianco Rosso has style, flair and a short, compelling menu, featuring a two-course prix fixe lunch of excellent value.
lead_paragraph: Another Italian restaurant? Well, yes and no. Bianco Rosso Wine Bar and Restaurant in Wilton, which opened in January 2012, does indeed serve Italian food. But Bianco Rosso is not just another Italian restaurant. It has style, flair and a short, compelling menu devised by Jacob Hamilton, the chef, who formerly worked for Todd English in New York. It is owned by two brothers, Mario and Jaime Lopez, and their partner Gustavo Jaramillo.

headline: Shine On
abstract: “Doctor Sleep” picks up the story of Danny, the little boy with psycho-intuitive powers from Stephen King’s 1977 novel “The Shining.”
lead_paragraph: “Doctor Sleep” is Stephen King’s latest novel, and it’s a very good specimen of the quintessential King blend. According to Vladimir Nabokov, Salvador Dalí was “really Norman Rockwell’s twin brother kidnapped by gypsies in babyhood.” But actually there were triplets: the third one is Stephen King.

headline: In China, Living With Choices Made Years Ago
abstract: Directed and starring Robert Lepage, “The Blue Dragon,” at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, revisits characters first created in “The Dragons’ Trilogy.”
lead_paragraph: Feisty young women chasing around Sweden tracking down killers are by no means the only people with dragons tattooed on their flesh. The middle-aged French-Canadian gallery owner at the center of Robert Lepage’s slight but moving work “The Blue Dragon,” at the Brooklyn Academy of Music’s Harvey Theater through Sunday, has a similar creature snaking across his back, an emblem of his reverence for Chinese culture and his adopted home.

headline: Sharing, With a Safety Net
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'Privacy', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Social Media', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: A privacy bill for young people passed by California’s Legislature has put the state in the middle of a debate over how to protect those who share without thinking.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Kids. The reckless rants and pictures they post online can often get them in trouble, by compromising their chances of getting into a good college or even landing them in jail. What to do about such lapses vexes parents, school officials, the Internet companies that host their words and images — and the law.

headline: Goldman Settles Lawsuit Over eToys I.P.O.
abstract: Goldman is poised to leave behind a long-running lawsuit over the 1999 initial public offering of eToys — an online toy retailer whose rise and fall became a symbol of the dotcom boom and bust — by paying $7.5 million to eToys creditors.
lead_paragraph: As JPMorgan Chase works its way through its own legal morass, it can look to Goldman Sachs for an example of how long litigation can haunt a bank.

headline: Buffett Wants to Keep Bernanke Atop Fed
abstract: Asked about Janet Yellen, President Obama’s expected choice to lead the Federal Reserve, Warren Buffett said that he didn’t know her at all.
lead_paragraph: Janet who?

headline: Demo of “Far Far Away”
abstract: A song by Garland Jeffreys
lead_paragraph: A song by Garland Jeffreys

headline: Money Funds Are Circling the Wagons on Rules
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis', 'Credit and Debt', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Money Market Mutual Funds']
abstract: As proposed rules are weighed, the industry is fighting vigorously to avoid even weak regulation.
lead_paragraph: Bank regulators around the world are forcing banks to hold more capital than they did before the financial crisis revealed just how inadequate their capital truly was. But one set of American banks appears to be on the verge of keeping the right to have no capital at all.

headline: Schubert, Underground
abstract: The pianist Shai Wosner brought a Schubert-inspired program of works to his show at SubCulture.
lead_paragraph: In the not-so-distant past, the recently opened SubCulture, an intimate subterranean space with a bar, cinema-style seats with cup holders and a purple-lighted brick wall framing the piano, might have seemed an unlikely site for classical music concerts.

headline: Oozing Sludge, Gregor, Is Never a Good Sign
abstract: “The Metamorphosis,” Arthur Pita’s dance-theater adaptation of Franz Kafka’s novella, opens the Joyce Theater’s fall season.
lead_paragraph: Before “The Metamorphosis,” Arthur Pita’s dance-theater adaptation of Franz Kafka’s novella, officially begins, the stage tells a story. On one side is a kitchen where a mother dries silverware, a father hunches over a newspaper and a pigtailed daughter lies on the floor checking her homework. On the other is Edward Watson, recumbent in bed with a white sheet pulled up to his chest. Eerily, his body seems trapped. Even as he lifts his head off the pillow and slowly rolls it side to side, he remains otherwise still.

headline: “Far Far Away”
abstract: The final version of the song by Garland Jeffreys
lead_paragraph: The final version of the song by Garland Jeffreys

headline: Questions to Ask a King Before You Are Beheaded
abstract: “The Hollow Crown” is a four-part serving of Shakespeare that begins on Friday on PBS’s “Great Performances.”
lead_paragraph: If you want an interesting perspective on a police procedural, watch it with a real police officer. If you want insights into the accuracy of a medical drama, watch it with a doctor. It’s too bad there are no late-14th- or early-15th-century British kings around with whom to watch “The Hollow Crown,” a four-part serving of Shakespeare that begins on Friday on PBS’s “Great Performances.” Think of the questions you could ask:

headline: When a Host Nods Off, and In-Laws Botch Your Name (for Years)
abstract: Guests are puzzled by a sleepy host, and why can’t the in-laws get her name right?
lead_paragraph: A newly engaged couple has had us to dinner at their place a few times. We have lovely meals with wine, then retire to sofas in the living room. At around 10:30 or 11 p.m., the woman cuddles up to her fiancé, pulls a blanket over herself and falls asleep. Meanwhile, the fiancé is happily awake and offers us nightcaps. We feel hugely awkward. My husband is good friends with the guy, and we’d love to stick around and chat, but the sleeping body makes it less enticing. How should we handle this?

headline: Atop the Puck Building
abstract: The SoHo beacon, built in 1885, is going to be a residential destination for the first time in its history.
lead_paragraph: The SoHo beacon, built in 1885, is going to be a residential destination for the first time in its history.

headline: Penthouses for the Puck Building
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Restoration and Renovation']
abstract: Six loft-style homes, priced from $21 million to $60 million, will be the first residences in the building.
lead_paragraph: The Puck Building, the inimitable epicenter of SoHo industrial swank even before there was a SoHo, has been around for 128 years but defies its age with the tenacity of an uptown socialite. All it takes is good bone structure, tons of money and a winning personality — the first supplied by Henry Baerer’s two saucy statues of Shakespeare’s mischievous Puck on the building’s exterior, the last by the genius of the Puck’s original architect, Albert Wagner. The essential contemporary attribute in the middle, a bottomless bankroll, is traceable to Jared Kushner, 32, a scion of the family that owns the Puck.

headline: Rocket Fuel Prices I.P.O. at Top of Revised Range
abstract: Rocket Fuel, an advertising technology company that relies on artificial intelligence, priced its initial public offering on Thursday at the top of its expectations, garnering $116 million in proceeds.
lead_paragraph: Rocket Fuel, an advertising technology company that relies on artificial intelligence, priced its initial public offering on Thursday at the top of its expectations, garnering $116 million in proceeds.

headline: Idyllic Setting for Flavors of Portugal and Brazil
abstract: Aquario is just steps from Silver Lake in West Harrison, but its owners try to stir thoughts of the Tagus River.
lead_paragraph: They don’t make them like this anymore: genteel, old-fashioned restaurants with beautiful tiles and intricate, carefully maintained murals framed by rich dark wood; with enough space among tables that conversations can remain private; where music doesn’t boom and blare; where service is calm and patrons unrushed. Aquario is such a place. That may explain why, even though the kitchen has its ups and downs, the restaurant has enjoyed two decades across the road from Silver Lake in West Harrison.

headline: Comedy Listings for Sept. 20-26
abstract: A selected guide to stand-up, improv and comedy festivals  in New York.
lead_paragraph: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Movie Listings for Sept. 20-26
abstract: A critical guide to movies playing in New York, including film series.
lead_paragraph: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

headline: Beyond ‘LOVE’
abstract: A look at the work of the artist Robert Indiana.
lead_paragraph: A look at the work of the artist Robert Indiana.

headline: An Artist’s LOVE-Hate Relationship
abstract: As the Whitney Museum of American Art opens “Robert Indiana: Beyond LOVE,” the artist regards his most famous work ruefully.
lead_paragraph: VINALHAVEN, Maine — Visit Robert Indiana’s remote Maine mansion — arch, beautiful and borderline bizarre — and you’ll find a man, and an artist, surrounded, and haunted, by LOVE.

headline: Pop & Rock Listings for Sept. 20-26
abstract: A selected guide to performances of indie rock, electro-pop, country-pop and R&B in the New York.
lead_paragraph: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Living a Day in Half an Hour
abstract: “T. J. Wilcox: In the Air,” at the Whitney Museum, features a filmed, sped-up panorama of a day in Lower Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: “In the Air,” T. J. Wilcox’s dazzling panoramic film installation at the Whitney Museum, is an ode to New York and to film, and to their mutually enhancing entwining. Mr. Wilcox is equally enamored of both. His new work makes you realize anew that the metropolis and the moving image were made for each other.

headline: Jazz Listings for Sept. 20-26
abstract: A selected guide to jazz performances in New York.
lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Opera and Classical Music Listings for Sept. 20-26
abstract: A selected guide to classical music performances in the New York area.
lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Riffs on Race, Role and Identity
abstract: “Radical Presence: Black Performance in Contemporary Art” is an entertaining and philosophically stimulating exhibition at New York University’s Grey Art Gallery.
lead_paragraph: In “Kevin and Me,” a video by the black performance artist Dave McKenzie, the camera focuses downward on the artist’s legs and feet as he walks along a wood-planked pedestrian bridge. One of his legs is twisted, causing him to limp. As he advances he begins to walk more naturally until he’s moving normally, at which point he stops to doff his sneakers and puts on a pair of tap shoes awaiting him at a steel joint in the walkway. He then executes a series of precise dance steps along the narrow metal band.

headline: Dance Listings for Sept. 20-26
abstract: A selected guide to dance performances in the New York area.
lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: A Gilded Trove
abstract: A look at “Medieval Treasures From Hildesheim” at the Met.
lead_paragraph: A look at “Medieval Treasures From Hildesheim” at the Met.

headline: Treasures for the Glory of God and Kings
abstract: “Medieval Treasures From Hildesheim,” an exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, is a well-preserved glimpse of the city’s art that advertised God’s glory.
lead_paragraph: Smack in the middle of the Metropolitan Museum, there’s a nugget of compressed light called “Medieval Treasures From Hildesheim.” Visually, the show is eminently graspable: a one-room cluster of 50 objects, many jewel-encrusted or covered in gold. In other ways, the art is almost beyond reach, being about the power politics of spirituality in a distant age, a subject that today’s drive-by museumgoer would seem to know little, or care little, about.

headline: House Republicans Pass Deep Cuts in Food Stamps
keywords: ['Food Stamps', 'Law and Legislation', 'Farm Bill (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: House Republicans narrowly pushed through a bill on Thursday that slashes billions of dollars from the food stamp program, over Democrats’ objections.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — House Republicans narrowly pushed through a bill on Thursday that slashes billions of dollars from the food stamp program, over the objections of Democrats and a veto threat from President Obama.

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings for Sept. 20-26
abstract: A critical guide to the visual arts in New York and the region.
lead_paragraph: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: City Greenery
keywords: ['Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Flowers and Plants', 'Gardens and Gardening']
abstract: New York City’s inventory of small parks and gardens is more varied than many locals realize.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s inventory of small parks and gardens is more varied than many locals realize.

headline: In Defiant Flower, a Host of Plucky Plots
keywords: ['Gardens and Gardening', 'Flowers and Plants', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas']
abstract: New York City teems with small, unsung parks tended by experts who continually adjust the botanical mix.
lead_paragraph: THE official New York color is gray. The materials are concrete and stone. That is the image.

headline: Theater Listings for Sept. 20-26
abstract: A guide to theater productions in New York, with a special note of shows in previews or about to open.
lead_paragraph: Theater

headline: Spare Times for Children for Sept. 20-26
abstract: A listing of cultural events and other activities for children, teenagers and families.
lead_paragraph: World Maker Faire

headline: Addicts With Cause to Fear Closeness
abstract: “Thanks for Sharing” centers on three mutually supportive men coping with sex addiction.
lead_paragraph: As the camera ogles the shapely legs of women in high heels strutting down the sidewalks of New York in “Thanks for Sharing,” it is easy to see why such stimulus is more than some men can handle. Neil (Josh Gad), one of three male characters in the film who belong to the same 12-step program for sex addiction, has a habit of spotting an attractive woman in a subway car, sidling up to her and pressing his lower body against hers.

headline: Spare Times for Sept. 20-26
abstract: A listing of parades, street fairs, walking tours, literary events and more in New York.
lead_paragraph: In Celebration of the Written (and Spoken) Word (Friday through Sunday) This is a perfect weekend for those who love a good story. The Brooklyn Book Festival on Sunday, from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m., will feature indoor and outdoor readings, discussions and other events for adults and children at various locations, including Borough Hall and its plaza, at 209 Joralemon Street, Downtown Brooklyn. (Above, visitors at a previous event.)

headline: A Bronx Tale by Way of Ireland, Step Dancing Included
abstract: “McGoldrick’s Thread” is a musical about immigrants who’ve settled in New York in 1995.
lead_paragraph: If I had anything harsh to say about “McGoldrick’s Thread,” I probably wouldn’t say it. This charming musical, featuring a troupe of talented teenage and preteenage dancers, wants nothing more than to show you a nice time, and it does. Anyone criticizing it sharply should be branded a sourpuss.

headline: A Loner Finds Bad Company
abstract: In “A Single Shot,” a loner living in a trailer finds — and throws himself into — a world of trouble when he has to deal with a dead woman and found cash.
lead_paragraph: During its initial quiet stretch, when about the only things on the screen are a man, his gun and the kind of lonely feeling meant to gnaw at the soul, “A Single Shot” drifts along on its woodsy scenery and vaporous promise. The man, John Moon (a fine Sam Rockwell), lives his spartan existence in a beat-up trailer in the middle of Nowhere, U.S.A. It’s the kind of atmospherically desolate place where, at least in fiction, men and their destinies are rarely alone for long. And so it is for Moon, who soon has to deal with a dead woman and a stash of cash.

headline: Heroes or Killers? Can We Try to Discuss?
abstract: The documentary “After Tiller” tells the story of four doctors who it says are the only ones in the United States openly performing third-trimester abortions.
lead_paragraph: “After Tiller,” a new documentary by Martha Shane and Lana Wilson, is a partisan document in the culture wars. It could hardly be otherwise, since the film’s subject, abortion, is one where common ground is elusive, if not philosophically untenable. The four doctors interviewed and observed on screen, who the film says are the only ones in the United States openly performing third-trimester abortions, are heroic figures in the filmmakers’ eyes, but are condemned as murderers by those on the other side. It would be nice to believe that a movie like this could provoke civil and respectful dialogue about an intensely polarizing issue, but let’s not kid ourselves.

headline: A Return to Duty for the Brooklyn Navy Yard Hospital
abstract: Steiner Studios plans to spend $400 million to take over and restore the magnificent, slightly sagging Navy Yard Hospital.
lead_paragraph: The Brooklyn Navy Yard is known for its muscular collection of industrial architecture. Here, the battleship Missouri and other warships were built and repaired until the yard closed five decades ago. The regular weekend tours of the Navy Yard cover that and more, but at the end comes an unexpected treat: the magnificent, slightly sagging Naval Hospital, a ghostly marble temple built in 1838 and empty for two decades. A new plan may sweep away the cobwebs.

headline: Former Congresswoman Lauds Syria’s ‘Free Health Care’ After Meeting Assad
abstract: Writing on Facebook from Damascus, Cynthia McKinney, a Georgia Democrat, also saluted Syrians who offered themselves as human shields to protect government military installations in the event of American air strikes.
lead_paragraph: Writing on Facebook from Damascus, Cynthia McKinney, a former Democratic Congresswoman from Georgia, praised Syria for its “free health care.”

headline: At Every Corner, From Deaf Man to Danger, Hints of a Colorful Past
abstract: Caracas, the Venezuelan capital, is a traffic-choked, graffiti-smeared city where hints of its past character can still be read in the descriptive names of street corners.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — In Caracas, you can live between Danger and Keep Your Eyes Peeled. Or between Hope and Faith, just a short walk from Eternity. At Restaurante Gallegos, one of several restaurants with similar names, prospective diners often call to ask, “Are you the one on Dead Man’s Corner?”

headline: Front Seat on a Stage of 1960s New York
abstract: Grace Cosgrove summoned the spirit of 1960s New York with the songs of Laura Nyro at the Metropolitan Room.
lead_paragraph: To enter the world of the singer-songwriter Laura Nyro is to open a time capsule evoking the concentrated sounds, sights and turbulence of New York City in the late 1960s. The voice behind them was the wail of an emotionally unguarded young woman touched with genius, who was still in her teens when she composed many of her most famous songs.

headline: Charged Interactions in an Abstract Universe
abstract: In “Flutter,” a new work by Megan V. Sprenger presented at the Chocolate Factory, dancers undergo sometimes bruising encounters.
lead_paragraph: With its radiators and unadorned brick, the small Chocolate Factory theater can be a stark, impersonal setting. For Megan V. Sprenger’s “Flutter,” which had its debut on Wednesday, the designer Brad Kisicki has softened the place up a bit. A white panel floats in front of the back wall, and wide bands of white gauze arch up the sides of the room and across the ceiling. There’s a suggestion of a wedding, and also of bandages. The hard facts are only partly hidden.

headline: Revelers, Pause to Meet Yourselves
abstract: A bawdy college kegger has a possible extraterrestrial mystery in “+1.”
lead_paragraph: Randy singles and body doubles drive the party-down plot of “+1,” a fleet and frenzied sci-fi tale with more on its mind than alien gate-crashers.

headline: U.S. Textile Plants Return, With Floors Largely Empty of People
keywords: ['Textiles', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Series']
abstract: Textile factories are bustling again in the United States, but the savior was automation, meaning few of the jobs lost since the ’90s came back with the plants.
lead_paragraph: GAFFNEY, S.C. — The old textile mills here are mostly gone now. Gaffney Manufacturing, National Textiles, Cherokee — clangorous, dusty, productive engines of the Carolinas fabric trade — fell one by one to the forces of globalization.

headline: Blasting Through the Dance Wars
abstract: A bawdy college kegger has a possible extraterrestrial mystery in “+1.” The 3-D “Battle of the Year” has a dance team preparing for competition.
lead_paragraph: The miracle of the new 3-D dance film “Battle of the Year” is how it can be so relentlessly boring while there is so much frenetic activity on screen. Despite the break-dance spins and disorienting strobe lights in the performance scenes, the movie feels sluggish throughout.

headline: ‘Creepy Uncle Sam’ Is Anti-Health Care Law Mascot
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Political Advertising']
abstract: The group Generation Opportunity released a series of advertisements as part of a six-figure campaign to discourage people aged 18 to 29 from enrolling in insurance exchanges under the Affordable Care Act.
lead_paragraph: A group seeking to persuade young people to “opt out” of President Obama’s health care law posted videos on YouTube Thursday that show young patients on exam tables recoiling in fear as a character the group is calling “Creepy Uncle Sam” appears out of nowhere and looms over them.

headline: An Ivy Leaguer Among Rustics
abstract: In “C.O.G.,” starring Jonathan Groff, a naïve Yale student decides to spend his summer working on an apple farm in Oregon.
lead_paragraph: In the world of “C.O.G.,” the first movie adaptation of a David Sedaris essay, self-knowledge is best gained among simple folks, preferably those defined by outsize quirks and nutty pronouncements. At least that’s what David (Jonathan Groff), an arrogant Yalie, learns when he boards a bus to Oregon to bury his fingers — and his unacknowledged homosexuality — in the soil.

headline: Mired Below Ground in an Endless Winter
abstract: The sci-fi thriller “The Colony” focuses on a struggling underground colony on a perpetually wintry Earth of the future.
lead_paragraph: “The Colony” is two-thirds of a pretty good sci-fi suspense movie. But it eventually takes a disappointing turn and becomes yet another run-from-the-ghouls exercise, cheapening decent work by a good cast.

headline: Joy Covey, Top Executive in Amazon.com’s Early Days, Dies at 50
abstract: Joy Covey was the retailer’s first chief financial officer. She helped take the company public and played an important role in convincing Wall Street that it would be managed for long-term growth, not quarterly numbers.
lead_paragraph: Joy Covey, an executive who joined Amazon.com when it was a new company with big ideas and played a major role in turning those ideas into reality, died on Wednesday after the bicycle she was riding struck a delivery van in a remote stretch of San Mateo County, Calif. She was 50.

headline: Rivera’s Farewell Tour Reaches Toronto
abstract: The Blue Jays honored the soon-to-retire Mariano Rivera, who admits to feeling a bit fatigued at this point in the season, in a pregame ceremony.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — The Toronto Blue Jays honored Mariano Rivera in a brief pregame ceremony Thursday night (and didn’t rehash his blown saves against them, the way the Boston Red Sox did).

headline: A Guide to Dharavi
abstract: Mumbai’s notorious Dharavi slum draws filmmakers and journalists, many of whom rely on the expertise of Rajesh Prabhakar, who is a researcher and fixer.
lead_paragraph: Mumbai’s notorious Dharavi slum draws filmmakers and journalists, many of whom rely on the expertise of Rajesh Prabhakar, who is a researcher and fixer.

headline: Love’s Eternal Masquerade
abstract: In “Jewtopia,” a young man asks a childhood friend to help him “act Jewish” so he can romance the girl of his dreams.
lead_paragraph: Did you hear the one about the gentile and the Jew? The gentile guy, he’s drawn only to Jewish women, see, so he has his childhood buddy — who’s Jewish! — help him fit the skullcap, so to speak, the better to find romance. First a play, now a movie, it’s “Jewtopia”!

headline: Will Islamic Stand-Up Play in Peoria?
abstract: “The Muslims Are Coming” documents a road trip by Muslim-American comedians whose goal is to counter anti-Islamic prejudice.
lead_paragraph: “Every single solitary Butterball turkey in the United States of America has been sacrificed to Allah,” a conservative commentator says of halal meat in the montage that opens “The Muslims Are Coming!” Directed by the comedians Negin Farsad and Dean Obeidallah, the documentary begins strongly with this collection of absurd hatemongering, cobbled from television clips. Unfortunately, the film peaks in those first few minutes.

headline: New York City’s Jobless Rate Increased to 8.6% in August Despite Hiring Gains
abstract: The rate increased despite stronger than usual hiring at the end of the summer, according to newly released reports.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s unemployment rate rose to 8.6 percent in August, despite stronger than usual hiring at the end of the summer, according to reports released on Thursday.

headline: Diversifying a Wine Portfolio
abstract: In its 40th year, the regional industry’s versatility is gradually broadening, grape by grape.
lead_paragraph: Winery by winery, grape by grape, Long Island’s overall portfolio and versatility are gradually broadening.

headline: Candace Pert, 67, Explorer of the Brain, Dies
abstract: As a Johns Hopkins graduate student, Dr. Pert helped discover a key to brain chemistry. She went on to become a neuroscientist and a major proponent of alternative medicine.
lead_paragraph: Candace Pert, a neuroscientist who helped discover a fundamental element of brain chemistry as a graduate student and went on to become a major proponent of alternative medicine, died on Sept. 12 at her home in Potomac, Md. She was 67.

headline: Taking the Place of an Old Favorite
abstract: Maru Asian Cuisine in St. James, which has taken over the space formerly occupied by Lotus East, serves a menu featuring Chinese and pan-Asian dishes.
lead_paragraph: A couple of decades ago, Chinese restaurants were as ubiquitous as Italian ones. Nearly every town on Long Island had at least one. Today, Japanese, fusion and pan-Asian spots have taken their place. Maru Asian Cuisine in St. James is a recent example of the trend, in name at least.

headline: Moved to Tears at the Cloisters by a Ghostly Tapestry of Music
abstract: A sacred composition of Renaissance England is reworked by the multimedia artist Janet Cardiff and carried through 40 speakers in “The Forty Part Motet.”
lead_paragraph: Wobbling, blissed out, a few in tears, people emerged every 12 minutes or so from the remnant of a 12th-century Spanish chapel tucked into the Cloisters museum.

headline: Vaulting From Doodling to Derring-Do
abstract: In “My Lucky Star,” a cartoon artist is swept up in a romantic spy adventure of her own invention.
lead_paragraph: “My Lucky Star,” a spy-caper romance from China, is sweet and harmless, but it’s also a little disorienting. After watching it, you may need a few moments to remember which decade this is, because the film has the tone and silliness of a “Pink Panther” movie or an episode of the 1960s sitcom “Get Smart.”

headline: A Mean Swing, Between the Cuddles and Flatulence Jokes
abstract: “The Short Game” is a documentary about 7- and 8-year-olds competing in an international junior-golf championship.
lead_paragraph: On a cuteness scale — where 10 is a fuzzy kitten yawning in a hammock — the chattily uninhibited 7- and 8-year-old golfers of “The Short Game” score high. One moment, these skilled children are tirelessly practicing swings, rain or shine; another moment, they’re saying that Dad should marry Lady Gaga, or beaming over a book about breaking wind. Discipline exists alongside child’s play, on and off the green.

headline: The Warrior as Nurturer
abstract: “Arise” turns a lens on women battling environmental ills around the world.
lead_paragraph: The documentary “Arise,” which celebrates women around the world leading movements in environmental protection, might reach a broader audience were its filmmaking more vibrant. A shame, because its message is worthy. Starhawk, from the San Francisco area, perhaps best captures the spirit of this gentle film when she speaks of women’s natural role in finding a “mosaic of solutions” to a planetary crisis.

headline: Jets Are Taking a Pass on the Running Game
abstract: The Jets’ offensive coordinator Marty Mornhinweg is well known for his pass-first approach, and Rex Ryan appears to welcome that.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — When Rex Ryan was hired to coach the Jets in 2009, he insisted on running effectively, a philosophy that he captured in the catchphrase “ground and pound.” Even as the Jets develop Geno Smith, a rookie quarterback who understandably lacks polish, that is no longer Ryan’s mantra.

headline: Don’t Help Injured Baby Raccoons? Alabama Edict Angers Those Who Love Them
abstract: The state conservation agency has told raccoon protectors in Alabama to stop rehabilitating the animals, a decision that has angered many.
lead_paragraph: WOODVILLE, Ala. — There are at least two types of Alabamian you don’t want to anger. One is a wild raccoon. The other is a person who rehabilitates wild raccoons.

headline: Latvian Adventures
abstract: Are there any lessons for the rest of us?
lead_paragraph: The paper by Blanchard, Griffiths, and Gruss is here (pdf). Some bemusement among the non-international-macro types about why a long session devoted to a country roughly the same size as either Nebraska or Brooklyn, take your pick. But a good discussion all the same. My take:

headline: 11 Men on a Girder, Unknowable Yet Not
abstract: “Men at Lunch” investigates the identity of the 11 construction workers photographed in 1932 while sitting atop a girder during the construction of Rockefeller Center.
lead_paragraph: On Sept. 20, 1932, 11 workers sat on a beam 69 floors above Manhattan during the construction of Rockefeller Center. The photograph of this moment, one of the most famous images of New York, is called “Lunch Atop a Skyscraper” (even though a cigarette and a liquor bottle in the hands of these workmen are as noticeable as any sandwiches).

headline: Russia Cuts Budget to Try to Spur Growth
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: It was the clearest sign yet that officials do not expect the nation’s economy to revive soon and are ready to try a new policy.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The Russian government on Thursday approved across-the-board budget cuts over the next two years in the clearest sign yet that officials do not expect its economy, the world’s eighth-largest, to revive soon, and that the Kremlin is ready to try a new policy to spur growth.

headline: Signs of Distress Multiplied on Killer’s Path to Navy Yard
keywords: ['Washington Navy Yard Shooting (2013)', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: A call to a hotel where the Navy Yard gunman was staying before the shooting suggests that his employer had deep concerns about his state of mind and raises questions about his clearance to work at bases.
lead_paragraph: In the days before Aaron Alexis called the police in Newport, R.I., to complain that he was hearing voices sent by a “microwave machine,” employees at the Residence Inn in nearby Middletown were struggling to cope with his behavior.

headline: JPMorgan, by the Numbers
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Securities and Commodities Violations']
abstract: With JPMorgan paying $1 billion in fines, The Times takes a closer look at the figures behind the story.
lead_paragraph: With JPMorgan paying $1 billion in fines, The Times takes a closer look at the figures behind the story.

headline: Computer Flaws Get Wry Smile From Humans Displaced
abstract: The technology that virtually eliminated the job of stock market specialist has been the source of expensive, disruptive errors, including the “flash crash” of 2010.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:50 p.m. | After a technological breakdown froze the Nasdaq stock market for three hours last month, investors across Wall Street wrung their hands.

headline: Red State Pain
abstract: The Republican Party’s animus toward the poor is hurting its own voters.
lead_paragraph: Rick Santorum is right. Not far right, crazy right, piously right or, on most issues, never right. He is all of those things. But under the rubric that even a blind pig can find an acorn every now and then, the moral scourge of the Republican Party is on to something — a greater truth.

headline: Buffed and Toned Up for a Beauty Contest
abstract: “Generation Iron,” directed by Vlad Yudin, follows professional bodybuilders in their quest to become Mr. Olympia.
lead_paragraph: Early in Vlad Yudin’s new documentary, “Generation Iron,” Phil Heath is weighing whether he’s prepared to defend his Mr. Olympia title. “Can I get better than I just did?” he asks. It’s more of a challenge than a question, since the answer for him and the other bodybuilders profiled here — ahead of and during last year’s Mr. Olympia contest — is always an unequivocal yes. They may have 23-inch necks and who-knows-how-many-inch thighs, but they are indefatigable in their quest for the perfectly sculptured body.

headline: Scratching Their Heads, Investors Start Revising Expectations for the Fed
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Dow Jones Stock Average', 'Inflation (Economics)', 'Interest Rates', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Mortgages', 'Nasdaq Composite Index', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', "Standard & Poor's 500-Stock Index", 'Unemployment', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Wall Street is furiously revising expectations about the role the Federal Reserve will play in the economy in the months ahead.
lead_paragraph: For investors, it’s back to the drawing board.

headline: Kerry Presses Security Council to Act on Syrian Arsenal
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry is trying to overcome differences with Russia that call into question whether the agreement on Syria will ever be carried out.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Putting down a marker before his coming trip to the United Nations, Secretary of State John Kerry said Thursday that it was essential for the United Nations Security Council to pass a resolution next week to eliminate Syria’s chemical arsenal.

headline: Standing in Merkel’s Shadow
abstract: The German Social Democratic Party will most likely lose to Angela Merkel, but if it can finally own up to its success, it can use a coalition role to build on that record.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — A FEW weeks ago, Germany’s left-leaning Social Democratic Party threw a lavish campaign event for more than 200,000 people next to the Brandenburg Gate in the middle of Berlin. There were bratwurst, balloons and songs, but the party never quite took off.

headline: The Violence in Our Heads
keywords: ['Washington Navy Yard Shooting (2013)', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Schizophrenia', 'Hallucinations', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: Schizophrenic Americans hear more threatening voices.
lead_paragraph: STANFORD, Calif. — THE specter of violence caused by mental illness keeps raising its head. The Newtown, Conn., school killer may have suffered from the tormenting voices characteristic of schizophrenia; it’s possible that he killed his mother after she was spooked by his strange behavior and tried to institutionalize him. We now know that Aaron Alexis, who killed 12 people at the Washington Navy Yard on Monday, heard voices; many observers assume that he, too, struggled with schizophrenia.

headline: The Crazy Party
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: At the moment, it seems highly likely that the Republican Party will force a shutdown of the U.S. government next month. How did we get here?
lead_paragraph: Early this year, Bobby Jindal, the governor of Louisiana, made headlines by telling his fellow Republicans that they needed to stop being the “stupid party.” Unfortunately, Mr. Jindal failed to offer any constructive suggestions about how they might do that. And, in the months that followed, he himself proceeded to say and do a number of things that were, shall we say, not especially smart.

headline: M.L.S. Tries to Mute Fans’ Vulgar Chants
abstract: Some teams in Major League Soccer have been trying, with mixed success, to stop off-color taunting of opposing goalkeepers that at times is audible over TV broadcasts.
lead_paragraph: For decades, soccer officials in the United States simply wanted some fans in their stadiums. Now they have them, and some of those fans have brought an unexpected problem: a vulgar chant, in the vein of more notoriously rabid soccer fans in other countries.

headline: Where Medieval Armor Meets the Aquatic
abstract: The Glyndor Gallery at Wave Hill is presenting an exhibition inspired by fish, suits of armor and intersections of the two.
lead_paragraph: Underwater creatures and medieval knights might seem unlikely themes for an exhibition of contemporary art, but the Glyndor Gallery at Wave Hill is filled with works inspired by fish, suits of armor and intersections of the two. “Tandem Pursuits: Armor & Ichthyology” presents pieces in a range of media, from intricate watercolors of fanciful fish, to aluminum sculptures suggestive of codpieces, to a video documenting a dress that inflates like a blowfish when its wearer feels threatened.

headline: 2 Top Technology Writers Are Leaving Dow Jones
abstract: Walt Mossberg and Kara Swisher, co-editors of the All Things Digital news site, will depart at the end of the year.
lead_paragraph: Dow Jones confirmed on Thursday evening that the company would part ways with Walt Mossberg and Kara Swisher, the co-editors of the very popular All Things Digital news site, at the end of the year when their contracts expire.

headline: The President’s Chef vs. the Food Snobs
abstract: Christian Vincent’s “Haute Cuisine” recounts the tenure of a private chef to President François Mitterrand.
lead_paragraph: Resembling a Francophile fantasy yet based on actual events, “Haute Cuisine” recounts Danièle Mazet-Delpeuch’s tenure as private chef to President François Mitterrand. Plucked from the Périgord region of France, Ms. Delpeuch — here renamed Hortense Laborie — yields to no one in cooking the grandmotherly comfort food desired by her country’s patrician leader. As flatly directed by Christian Vincent, “Haute Cuisine” is a reserved, très simple tale that raises the occasional smile and tummy rumble but keeps hiccuping because of the drawn-out parallel story about her subsequent tour of duty.

headline: Kicking the Chant
abstract: Major League Soccer teams like the Red Bulls have provided fans with incentives to stop vulgar chants directed at opposing teams.
lead_paragraph: Major League Soccer teams like the Red Bulls have provided fans with incentives to stop vulgar chants directed at opposing teams.

headline: Where Water Is Gold
abstract: The discovery of five new aquifers in Kenya promise relief for a parched nation.
lead_paragraph: Some rare good news has offset the usual grim predictions about the planet’s dwindling natural resources. Kenya, one of Africa’s most important countries, has uncovered a potentially huge new water source. Now comes the challenge of managing it fairly and transparently.

headline: Blocking Health Care Reform in Florida
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Editorials']
abstract: In the latest outrage, the state has ordered health agencies to bar counselors who inform people on how to enroll in insurance plans from their premises.
lead_paragraph: Florida’s  destructive efforts to sabotage health care reform has drawn a much-needed response from the Obama administration. Kathleen Sebelius, the secretary of health and human services, has been visiting the state to encourage private groups to help residents understand what insurance policies and federal subsidies will be available to them when the enrollment period opens Oct. 1.

headline: Another Insult to the Poor
keywords: ['Food Stamps', 'Poverty', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials']
abstract: House Republicans passed a bill that would drastically cut federal food stamps and accelerate a long slide for low-income Americans.
lead_paragraph: In what can be seen only as an act of supreme indifference, House Republicans passed a bill on Thursday that would drastically cut federal food stamps and throw 3.8 million Americans out of the program in 2014.

headline: Funny Money in New Jersey
abstract: Though the state has tough pay-to-play laws, donors have found a backdoor way to support Gov. Chris Christie’s campaign for re-election.
lead_paragraph: New Jersey has some of the strongest pay-to-play laws in the country, aimed at regulating the awarding of contracts and other favors in exchange for campaign contributions. That has made little difference this year for some New Jersey players who have found a backdoor way to support Gov. Chris Christie’s campaign for re-election.

headline: A Gender Gap as Ballot Spots Start to Fill
abstract: In a year when their liberal opponents are accusing them of waging a war on women, Texas Republicans could end up with very few women at the top of their ticket.
lead_paragraph: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

headline: Iran Said to Seek a Nuclear Accord to End Sanctions
keywords: ['Embargoes and Economic Sanctions', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Seizing on a perceived flexibility in a letter from President Obama to President Hassan Rouhani, Iran’s leaders are focused on getting quick relief from crippling sanctions, a top adviser to the Iranian leadership said.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — Iran’s leaders, seizing on perceived flexibility in a private letter from President Obama, have decided to gamble on forging a swift agreement over their nuclear program with the goal of ending crippling sanctions, a prominent adviser to the Iranian leadership said Thursday.

headline: Autumn of a Martial Arts Patriarch
abstract: Herman Yau’s “Ip Man: The Final Fight” catches up with that martial arts grandmaster in his twilight years as a teacher in postwar Hong Kong.
lead_paragraph: Don’t expect to see the rise of Wing Chun martial-arts legend Ip Man recounted in Herman Yau’s “Ip Man: The Final Fight.” (That would be Mr. Yau’s 2010 film, “The Legend Is Born: Ip Man.”) Instead, this straightforward social drama, written by Erica Li, catches up with Ip Man in his twilight years as a teacher in postwar Hong Kong. Mr. Yau and Ms. Li’s Ip Man is a far cry from the hero popularly portrayed by Donnie Yen in two earlier hit movies, or by Tony Leung as the smoldering fighter in Wong Kar-wai’s film “The Grandmaster.”

headline: GTT ★
abstract: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.
lead_paragraph: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

headline: Prospects for Mideast Peace
abstract: A Middle East expert is more sanguine than a Sunday Review writer about the viability of a two-state solution.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Ethanol Credits
abstract: The Union of Concerned Scientists responds to an article about Wall Street and the rising price of the credits.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Deciding When to Use Force for Humane Reasons
abstract: Readers respond to an Op-Ed essay about how the “responsibility to protect” concept is imperiled.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Can the Earth Support More of Us?
abstract: Responding to an Op-Ed article, population and sustainability experts say no.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Twitter’s Fibs and a Pinterest Baby Step
abstract: Thursday’s highlights from around the Web include the discovery that Twitter inflated some of its statistics. Plus, promoted pin ads offer a glimpse of monetization for Pinterest.
lead_paragraph: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: A Maverick Tries to Stay in the Picture
abstract: Four years after emerging as a Tea Party darling in Texas, Debra Medina is eyeing the comptroller race. But she knows that donations from grass-roots supporters take a candidate only so far.
lead_paragraph: In 2009, Debra Medina began an underdog bid for governor of Texas, delivering one fiery speech after another to any Republican club or Tea Party group that would let her make the case for a platform focusing on state sovereignty, gun rights and eliminating the property tax. For nearly a year, until her appearance in a televised debate drew national attention and energized her fund-raising, the campaign sustained itself on a shoestring budget.

headline: Texas, Where Oil Rules, Turns Its Eye to Energy Efficiency
abstract: A diverse coalition is racing to institute a plan to increase energy and water efficiency upgrades that supporters say could help Texas improve its conservation record.
lead_paragraph: In Texas, where oil lubricates the economy the same way it does pickup trucks, energy consumption is no exception to the state’s everything-is-bigger reputation. The nation’s leading energy producer also uses more energy by far than any other state.

headline: Door to U.S. May Be Closing for Iraqis Who Helped the American Military
keywords: ['Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Translation and Interpreters', 'Visas', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Iraqis who worked for the American military during the war, many of whom face discrimination and danger at home, could lose their chance at American visas if Congress doesn’t act.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — As a former interpreter for the American military, and as a gay man, Hassan says he is a focus of frequent discrimination by his fellow Iraqis.

headline: Blood Enemies, Lugging an Olive Branch
abstract: A friendship develops between a downed Israeli pilot and a Palestinian boy in “Zaytoun,” directed by Eran Riklis.
lead_paragraph: Adversity makes for unlikely allies in “Zaytoun,” an odd-couple road movie set in 1982 as Israel is preparing to invade Lebanon.

headline: For Mets, Another Year at the Same Address
abstract: If the Mets’ season ended Friday, they would wind up fourth in the National League East for the fifth straight season, a franchise record for consecutive finishes in the same spot.
lead_paragraph: When the Mets moved into Citi Field five years ago, they were also, as it turned out, settling into fourth place in the National League East and making themselves comfortable. If their season ended Friday, they would finish in that very undistinguished spot for the fifth straight season. It would be a franchise record, dubious as it might seem, for never in their uphill history have they ended up staying in the same place for so long.

headline: Judge Overturns Firing of Teacher Who Faced Drug Charge
keywords: ['Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Heroin', 'Education (K-12)']
abstract: Damian Esteban, a New York City public school teacher, had been dismissed after being arrested and charged with bringing 20 small packets of heroin into a courthouse last year.
lead_paragraph: A judge overturned New York City’s firing of a tenured public school teacher who was arrested and charged with bringing 20 small packets of heroin into a Manhattan courthouse last year.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Friday, September 20, 2013
abstract: Quotation of the day for Friday, September 20, 2013.
lead_paragraph: “This church with which we should be thinking is the home of all, not a small chapel that can hold only a small group of selected people. We must not reduce the bosom of the universal church to a nest protecting our mediocrity.”

headline: At Tour Championship, Stenson Funnels His Aggression Into Stellar Play
abstract: Henrik Stenson, who damaged his driver and a locker after last week’s FedEx Cup event, stayed calm and breezed through his first round in six-under-par 64.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — On Monday, Henrik Stenson beheaded his driver at the 18th hole and damaged a locker while venting over a 74, the sixth-worst final-round score at the BMW Championship.

headline: Monuments of a Postindustrial Landscape
abstract: “An Artificial Wilderness,” now at the Wadsworth Atheneum Museum of Art, showcases a different vision of nature, marked by human intervention.
lead_paragraph: The first-floor galleries at the Wadsworth Atheneum Museum of Art were home until recently to the heart of the collection: 19th-century landscape paintings by Thomas Cole, Frederic Church and Albert Bierstadt, members of the Hudson River School, which were collected by and commissioned directly from the artists by the museum’s founders and earliest patrons. Removed last fall for the installation of a new heating and cooling system, they have been replaced by an exhibition of contemporary photographs that show a very different version — and vision — of nature.

headline: De Blasio Causes Stir by Saying He Would Fire Taxi Commissioner
abstract: Bill de Blasio drew a stern response from a coalition of cabbies and set off a Twitter battle when he said that if elected mayor, he would replace David S. Yassky.
lead_paragraph: In the Democratic primary campaign for mayor, Bill de Blasio’s refusal to retain Raymond W. Kelly as police commissioner was framed as a cornerstone of his candidacy. His thoughts on who might run the Taxi and Limousine Commission would appear less likely to affect vote tallies in November.

headline: Staten Island Man Is Accused of Planting Bombs to Stop a Wedding
abstract: The authorities said Omar Duran, 54, made the devices to frame his neighbor’s fiancé because he was worried that the man would replace him as a father figure.
lead_paragraph: The little girl first came into Omar Duran’s life as a baby. As the years went by, Mr. Duran, 54, who lived above her and her mother in a tidy brick apartment house on Staten Island, watched her grow, played with her and taught her to ride her first bike.

headline: Hurdles Are Still High for a New Fed Front-Runner
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Quantitative Easing', 'Unemployment', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: The White House is worried that Janet L. Yellen could be a target for criticism before a formal nomination, and if she does lead the Federal Reserve, she must manage a stimulus easing in a weak job market.
lead_paragraph: As the favorite to succeed Ben S. Bernanke to lead the Federal Reserve, Janet L. Yellen faces no shortage of hurdles.

headline: Private Schools Are Expected to Drop a Dreaded Entrance Test
keywords: ['Tests and Examinations', 'Private and Sectarian Schools', 'ADMISSIONS STANDARDS', 'Education (K-12)']
abstract: A group representing New York City private schools said it would no longer recommend using the test because of concerns that test-preparation courses rendered it meaningless.
lead_paragraph: For generations, families have dreaded and despised the exam used to determine the fate of 4- and 5-year-olds seeking entry into the elite world of New York City private schools.

headline: Who Is Janet Yellen?
abstract: The vice chairwoman of the Federal Reserve, a leading candidate to replace Ben Bernanke as head of the agency, is favored by Democrats and economists alike.
lead_paragraph: The vice chairwoman of the Federal Reserve, a leading candidate to replace Ben Bernanke as head of the agency, is favored by Democrats and economists alike.

headline: The Season When Golf and Football Collide
abstract: The FedEx Cup playoffs have provided great theater, but the start of autumn brings back college football and the N.F.L., and the playoffs may not be delivering a new audience.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Jason Dufner walked off East Lake Golf Club’s ninth green on Thursday after making an eight-foot birdie putt with his shoulders slouched, his cap pulled over his eyes, his gaze directed downward. Dufner, the reigning P.G.A. champion, is known for his impassivity, but his posture straightened and his lips nearly curved into a smile when a fan in the crowd shouted, “War Eagle!”

headline: Two Queens Officers Are Accused of Giving Out Accident Reports for Bribes
keywords: ['Frauds and Swindling', 'Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: Two police officers, working independently, provided information to so-called runners for insurance frauds, prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: For the insurance industry, they are a familiar bugaboo: the people who stalk accident scenes and emergency rooms seeking patients to deliver to medical clinics for costly treatment.

headline: Positive Thinking Pioneer
abstract: A smooth debut by Mangesh Ghogre, with his collaborator Doug Peterson.
lead_paragraph: Administrivial Win Valuable Prizes Alert! The Sunday puzzle will be a special contest puzzle. The crossword itself can be solved in all the usual online formats. However, to solve the bonus contest element, you will need to see some heavy outlines in the grid, which cannot be reproduced electronically. Thus, if you plan to enter the contest, please print out the PDF version of the puzzle, which will be made available at the same time as the electronic version. Good luck!

headline: Corrections: September 20, 2013
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on September 20, 2013.
lead_paragraph: NATIONAL

headline: Such Sweet Sorrow
abstract: David Leveaux’s production of “Romeo and Juliet,” with Orlando Bloom and Condola Rashad, has opened at the Richard Rodgers Theater.
lead_paragraph: A sense of divine justice seizes us whenever two of the world’s prettiest people find each other. This was true when Taylor met Burton, when Brad met Angelina, when Paris met Helen, or even when Narcissus met his reflection. We just can’t help sighing over the glory of separate souls wrapped in the luxury of shared beauty. Then there’s that other part of us that thinks, both fearfully and hopefully, “It can’t last.”

headline: Quick Turn of Fortunes as Diplomatic Options Open Up With Syria and Iran
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Embargoes and Economic Sanctions', 'Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Nuclear Weapons']
abstract: President Obama is facing two unexpected diplomatic initiatives with the United States’ biggest adversaries in the Middle East, Syria and Iran, each fraught with opportunity and danger.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Only two weeks after Washington and the nation were debating a unilateral military strike on Syria that was also intended as a forceful warning to Iran about its nuclear program, President Obama finds himself at the opening stages of two unexpected diplomatic initiatives with America’s biggest adversaries in the Middle East, each fraught with opportunity and danger.

headline: Wind Delay Takes Air Out of America’s Cup for Third Consecutive Day
abstract: Team New Zealand still needs one more victory to secure the 34th America’s Cup. A win by Oracle Team USA, followed by a delay because of wind limits, prevented it on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — After a 10-year wait, Emirates Team New Zealand and its skipper, Dean Barker, had to wait at least one more day as they attempted to win back the America’s Cup.

headline: A Book Award Without Borders
abstract: Should the Man Booker Prize be open to all writers of English, not just those from the Commonwealth and Ireland?

headline: Parking Rules
abstract: Because of Sukkot, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Friday. Other regulations will remain in effect.
lead_paragraph: Because of Sukkot, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Friday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

headline: In Boston, Mayor Builds a Legacy With Construction Cranes
keywords: ['Building (Construction)', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Elections', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: As Mayor Thomas M. Menino’s time in City Hall runs out, the pace of development is accelerating, in part because developers expect a change in administration to slow the process.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — No one seemed happier the other day than Mayor Thomas M. Menino as he joined in the ceremonial groundbreaking for a high-rise tower at the site of the old Filene’s department store in downtown Boston.

headline: Residents of Detroit Go to Court for Pensions
abstract: In an emotional hearing, protesters of the city’s bankruptcy filing pleaded with a federal judge to protect employee pensions and essential services from cuts.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — In an emotional hearing, Detroit residents protesting the city’s bankruptcy filing pleaded on Thursday with a federal judge to protect employee pensions and essential services from cuts they said would be devastating.

headline: Voice of Yanks Is Maddening and Memorable
abstract: John Sterling’s baritone bombast, mistakes, creative home run calls and unalloyed joy at Yankees victories have made him an odd but solid part of the Yankees brand.
lead_paragraph: John Sterling’s quarter-century of baritone bombast, mistakes, bizarrely creative home run calls and unalloyed joy at Yankees victories (“Thuuuuuh Yankees win!”) has made him an odd but solid part of the Yankees brand. A singular, divisive, much-debated personality, Sterling seems likely to move with the Yankees’ radio rights next season from WCBS-AM to WFAN, which will simulcast the games at 660 AM and 101.9 FM.

headline: 3 Queens E.M.T.’s Are Held in Theft
abstract: Three board members of the Corona Community Volunteer Ambulance Corps were accused of stealing more than $325,000 from the Queens squad.
lead_paragraph: Three emergency medical technicians were arrested on Thursday and accused of stealing more than $325,000 from their nonprofit volunteer ambulance service in Queens, according to court documents filed by the state attorney general.

headline: U.S. Revives Aid Program for Clean Energy
keywords: ['Federal Aid (US)', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation', 'Coal', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']
abstract: A controversial federal loan-guarantee program intended to support greener energy technologies will shift to supporting development of cleaner oil and coal technology.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration has decided to revive a controversial loan guarantee program at the Energy Department, administration officials said on Thursday, even as the program remains under Congressional scrutiny after losing hundreds of millions in taxpayer money on investments in failed green energy start-ups like the solar module maker Solyndra.

headline: New York’s Top Recruit Selects Seton Hall
abstract: Isaiah Whitehead, the 12th-best prospect in the country, according to Scout.com, had whittled his choices to Indiana, Pittsburgh, Minnesota, Seton Hall and St. John’s.
lead_paragraph: In the sandy brick gymnasium at Abraham Lincoln High School, in Coney Island in Brooklyn, foldout chairs were laid out, and a podium was in place for an announcement by yet another basketball prodigy who had decided to leave home.

headline: Conservatives Take Turns Standing Up to the Speaker
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Tea Party Movement', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: A cast of characters, elected on a Tea Party wave, is challenging Speaker John A. Boehner at every turn, empowered by the fact that Republicans hold a narrow majority in the House.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Those in the circle of fiery House conservatives who are spearheading a fiscal showdown that threatens to shut down the government see themselves in vaunted company.

keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Soil', 'Defoliants and Herbicides', 'Weeds', 'Corn', 'Biotechnology', 'Science and Technology']

lead_paragraph: ALTON, Iowa — The puny, yellow corn stalks stand like weary sentries on one boundary of Dennis Von Arb’s field here.

headline: For Nets, a Sore Ankle and a Little Trash Talk
abstract: The Nets’ Deron Williams is in a walking boot after spraining his ankle two weeks ago, and his teammate Paul Pierce scoffed at comments from a Knicks guard.
lead_paragraph: Deron Williams was not deemed healthy enough to play dodgeball Thursday, but he still expects to be on the court Oct. 1, when the Nets begin training camp.

headline: Administration Presses Ahead With Limits on Emissions From Power Plants
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Coal', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Electric Light and Power']
abstract: The limits, to be announced Friday, are an aggressive move to bypass Congress on climate change, and a sign that the White House is not backing down from a confrontation on emissions.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A year after a plan by President Obama to limit greenhouse gas emissions from new power plants set off angry opposition, the administration will announce on Friday that it is not backing down from a confrontation with the coal industry and will press ahead with enacting the first federal carbon limits on the nation’s power companies.

headline: With Stakes at a High, the Yankees Near a Low
abstract: The Yankees needed a win to keep up the momentum after an emotional victory Wednesday night, but instead they endured a loss to the last-place Blue Jays on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — There may be some complex equations and intricate algorithms that prove the Yankees still have a mathematical chance to reach the playoffs. But the visible evidence tells a different story.

lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The Walt Disney Company and Jerry Bruckheimer said on Thursday that they would end a movie deal under which Mr. Bruckheimer has produced hits like the “Pirates of the Caribbean” series, and a notable flop in “The Lone Ranger.”

headline: Goalie Helps Others With Multiple Sclerosis
abstract: Josh Harding, now back on the ice at the Minnesota Wild’s training camp, spent the off-season establishing a charity benefiting M.S. patients struggling to afford medication and treatment.
lead_paragraph: EDINA, Minn. — The 95-degree heat on a late August day made Josh Harding hasten from his Cadillac Escalade pickup truck into an air-conditioned coffee shop. A few minutes after buying a lemonade, Harding — in a white T-shirt, dark blue shorts, flip-flops and a backward Minnesota Twins ball cap — felt so cold he grasped his shoulders for warmth.

lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Brooklyn has rejected a request by prosecutors to sequester a jury in a murder and racketeering trial, citing the impact that federal budget cuts are having on the judiciary.

headline: Wrong Signal
abstract: Ben S. Bernanke has said that the Federal Reserve might stop buying bonds as soon as the unemployment rate fell to 7 percent. But he backed away from that position this week.

headline: Cornell Men Punished for Hazing
abstract: Cornell canceled all fall competitions for its men’s lacrosse team for what the university described as “a team hazing incident.”
lead_paragraph: Cornell canceled all fall competitions for its men’s lacrosse team Thursday for what the university described as “a team hazing incident.” Cornell penalized the team as a whole, not individual players, it said in a news release.

headline: What’s On Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (Hallmark) THE WATSONS GO TO BIRMINGHAM (2013) In the summer of 1963, Daniel and Wilona Watson (Wood Harris and Anika Noni Rose) of Flint, Mich., decide that the antics of their son Byron (Harrison Knight) are too much to bear. So they load him and their two younger children, Kenny (Bryce Clyde Jenkins) and Joetta (Skai Jackson), into their 1948 Plymouth Brown Bomber and head to the home of the no-nonsense Grandma Sands (LaTanya Richardson Jackson) in Birmingham, Ala. That’s where, with the help of Grandma’s friend Mr. Robert (David Alan Grier, second from left in foreground above, with, from left, Mr. Harris, Mr. Knight, and Mr. Jenkins), they discover that life is different — and get caught up in events that will change them and the country forever. Kenny Leon directed this adaptation of Christopher Paul Curtis’s Newbery Medal- and Coretta Scott King Author Award-winning novel. Tonya Lewis Lee, Stephen Glantz and Caliope Brattlestreet wrote the screenplay.

abstract: See what you know about the news of the day.

headline: Task Force Backs Changes in Legal Education System
abstract: A task force of the American Bar Association is calling for sweeping changes that support more liberal standards and offer opportunities for people without law degrees.
lead_paragraph: Faced with rising student debt and declining applications to law schools, a task force of the American Bar Association is calling for sweeping changes in legal education, including training people without law degrees to provide limited legal services and opening the bar to those who have not completed four years of college and three years of  law school.

headline: India Adjusts Short-Term Interest Rates
abstract: The changes were aimed at maintaining control of inflation while also making credit somewhat more available to the country’s troubled industrial sector.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA — India’s central bank announced on Friday a complex series of changes to its interest rate policies, aimed at maintaining control of inflation while also making credit more available to the troubled industrial sector.

headline: Violence Flares Anew on Chicago’s South Side
abstract: The attack Thursday night — which left three people in critical condition, including a 3-year-old boy — came amid the city’s recent progress in cracking down on gang violence.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — A gunman involved in a shooting that wounded 13 people at a South Side park on Thursday night was armed with an assault-style rifle equipped with a high-capacity magazine, the police said on Friday.

headline: With Festival, Paris Seeks to Reclaim Literary Reputation
keywords: ['Libraries and Librarians', 'Books and Literature', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: Paris is reaching out to the global literary world to recapture its place on the cutting edge of culture with a new festival of international writers.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — There was a time when Paris was an obligatory way station for aspiring foreign writers on the Grand Tour through Europe as they strove to burnish their reputations as cosmopolitan sophisticates. But in recent years, the city seems to have lost some of its edge. Now Paris has reached out to recapture its place as a center of literature with a new festival of international writers that began on Friday and ran through the weekend.

headline: I.P.O. in New Zealand Would be a Record
abstract: The government’s plan to sell 49 percent of Meridian Energy, New Zealand’s biggest electricity producer, would raise $1.6 billion or more.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The government of New Zealand said on Friday that the partial privatization of Meridian Energy, the country’s biggest electricity company, could raise close to $2 billion.

headline: A Conversation With: Filmmaker Richie Mehta
abstract: Mr. Mehta on his recent film “Siddharth”, which traces a father’s journey for his missing son.
lead_paragraph: In the spring of 2010, the Toronto filmmaker Richie Mehta was stuck. A Disney project he had been working on for six months in India fell through. And he couldn’t book a flight back to Toronto because the Icelandic volcano Eyjafjallajokull had erupted, disrupting air travel. While he bided time in New Delhi, a chance conversation with an auto-rickshaw wallah unwittingly gave Mr. Mehta the inspiration for his latest film, “Siddharth.”

headline: Does Gym Help Students Perform Better in All Their Classes?
abstract: Have your physical education classes helped you do better, over all, in school?
lead_paragraph: Some financially struggling school districts have chosen to cut their physical education programs to save money. But new studies suggest that being physically fit doesn’t just make children healthier; it actually helps them learn more. What do you think?

headline: The Italian-Americans of Mulberry Street, Long Before ‘The Godfather’
abstract: A pastor at St. Patrick’s Old Cathedral deployed huge banners of photographs from a time when Little Italy was a little more Italian to refocus the neighborhood’s San Gennaro festival.
lead_paragraph: Strolling along Mulberry Street in Little Italy during this year’s Feast of San Gennaro, visitors passed stands selling zeppole and sausage and peppers as vendors hawked “Fuggedaboudit” T-shirts and “Godfather”-themed trinkets. But when they reached St. Patrick’s Old Cathedral at the corner of Prince Street, the atmosphere changed, the booths thinned and visitors encountered large banners with historical photographs of the neighborhood hanging on the church cemetery walls.

headline: New York Today: Harvest Time
abstract: What you need to know for Friday: bounteous greenmarkets, a sunny day but a rainy weekend, and a Queens native’s success with inane ditties.
lead_paragraph: Updated 12:09 p.m. | As summer makes way for fall (4:44 p.m. on Sunday, if you’re keeping score), the best place to watch the seasons change, or at least the yummiest, may be your local greenmarket.

headline: Jumping Into the ‘Shark Tank’
abstract: Josh Brooks, a Myspace founding team member, can be seen pitching his start-up, On The Run Tech, Friday night on the ABC reality show.
lead_paragraph: Josh Brooks, one of the entrepreneurs in our recent story about the many Silicon Beach companies started by Myspace’s founding team, will appear on ABC’s “Shark Tank” Friday night. Mr. Brooks will be pitching his start-up, On the Run Tech, to the show’s “sharks” — a group of well-known entrepreneur-investors.

headline: Daily Report: A Proposed Reset Button for Children Online
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Law and Legislation', 'Privacy', 'Social Media']
abstract: A piece of legislation in California has put the state in the middle of a turbulent debate over how best to protect children and their privacy on the Internet.
lead_paragraph: California legislators, faced with the problem of reckless online behavior by children, and of the sometimes outsize and life-changing repercussions from that behavior, are trying to solve the problem with the first measure in the country to give minors the legal right to scrub away their online indiscretions. The legislation puts the state in the middle of a turbulent debate over how best to protect children and their privacy on the Internet, and whether states should even be trying to tame the Web, Somini Sengupta reports.

headline: A Regulatory Punching Bag
abstract: JPMorgan Chase paid $1 billion in fines to resolve investigations into a trading loss as well as an inquiry into credit card products. | Technological mishaps have led former specialists to reflect on the days before machines took over the market. | Two technology companies priced I.P.O.’s Thursday evening. | Wall Street is furiously revising expectations about the Federal Reserve.
lead_paragraph: JPMORGAN LOSES FAVOR  |  The board members of JPMorgan Chase had a pressing question earlier this week when they met to approve $1 billion in fines: are we done yet? The answer, in short, was no, Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Ben Protess report in DealBook. The fines, announced on Thursday, resolve investigations into the bank’s big trading loss in London as well as an inquiry into its credit card products.

headline: Emmys Watch: Jimmy Kimmel on ‘Jimmy Kimmel Live’

headline: Is This the Face of a Lothario?
abstract: The actor Joseph Gordon-Levitt is directing his first feature film, an edgy romantic comedy he stars in and also wrote.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — On Friday, Joseph Gordon-Levitt enters the ranks of first-time feature directors with “Don Jon,” an edgy romantic comedy he stars in and also wrote. But in a way, it’s the culmination of a directing education that stretches back to his appearance in Robert Redford’s 1992 big-screen adaptation of the fly-fishing-brothers-in-Montana tale, “A River Runs Through It.”

headline: The Fixers of Dharavi
abstract: The success of “Slumdog Millionaire,” created an industry of fixers for the increasing number of photographers, filmmakers, and journalists visiting the Dharavi slum in Mumbai.
lead_paragraph: DHARAVI, Maharashtra— The success of “Slumdog Millionaire,” which sent an increasing number of journalists, documentary filmmakers, and photographers to the Dharavi slum in Mumbai, created an industry of fixers, researchers, and line producers who specialize in finding a cast of characters the visitors demand.
