lead_paragraph: The Times has published several letters responding to “Overpopulation Is Not the Problem,” an Op-Ed article by the ecologist Erle C. Ellis (who expanded on that piece here).

headline: A Different Way for Republicans to Handle Tea Party Zeal
keywords: ['Tea Party Movement', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The Tea Party helped cost Democrats control of the House in 2010, but its political energy can put Republicans in difficult positions, too.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The extraordinary zeal of the Tea Party has been a signature development during Barack Obama’s presidency — with dangers for both Republicans and Democrats.

headline: Soldiers in Yemen Are Killed in Attacks on 2 Military Targets
abstract: Suspected members of Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula were believed to be responsible for attacks that killed at least 21 soldiers, although the government and witnesses gave varying death tolls.
lead_paragraph: SANA, Yemen — At least 21 government soldiers were killed on Friday in what appeared to be coordinated attacks by people suspected of being Qaeda militants on two military targets in the south of Yemen, government officials said. Earlier in the day, witnesses and local security officials gave a higher death toll, saying at least 33 soldiers were killed.

headline: Nielsen Will Add Mobile Viewership to Ratings
abstract: The company’s program, which would begin in fall 2014, should soothe television executives eager to get credit for fans who don’t use ordinary TVs.
lead_paragraph: Nielsen, playing catch-up, has a plan to start incorporating some viewership of television shows on phones and tablets into its industry-standard TV ratings system in the fall of 2014.

headline: Amid Economic Stress, Differing Strategies Emerge
abstract: Indonesia must get used to higher interest rates, its vice president said Friday, while India’s central bank decided it needed to lower its rates.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA — Indonesia and India, the two emerging markets hardest hit in recent weeks by falling currencies and other financial troubles, took opposite tracks on Friday as both countries struggled to balance growth with the threat of inflation.

headline: How Did You Handle Grandparents’ Unsolicited Parenting Advice?
abstract: There is nothing like the arrival of a baby to crystallize the child-rearing views of everyone around a new parent — especially the views of that parent’s own parents, or parents-in-law.
lead_paragraph: “You’re picking him up too much.”

headline: Savoring the End of Breast-Feeding as Infancy Slips Away
abstract: One night when the baby woke up crying and I went into his room to nurse him, it hit me: This could be my last breast feed — ever.
lead_paragraph: I breast-fed my first child exclusively for seven months, and I couldn’t wait to be done. It’s not that I didn’t enjoy it or acknowledge the health benefits, but he refused to take a bottle, and as a first-time mother, I felt that I would have to nurse him forever – or, as some of my “helpful” friends pointed out, at least until he was 2. That seemed endless, and after seven months of nighttime feeds, leaky breasts and the appearance of small, razor-sharp teeth — not to mention feeling occasionally smothered that I was the only one who could take care of my child — I was done.

headline: As It Makes Overtures to Iran, U.S. Strives to Reassure Israel
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'Embargoes and Economic Sanctions', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: As the United States reaches out to Iran’s new president, White House officials are trying to convince skeptical Israelis that they will not prematurely ease pressure on Tehran to curb its nuclear program.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the Obama administration embarks on a highly visible diplomatic overture to Iran, White House officials are engaged in a quieter, behind-the-scenes effort to reassure Israel that they will not fall for the charms of Iran’s new president by prematurely easing pressure on his government to curb its nuclear program.

headline: Administration to Press Ahead With Carbon Limits
abstract: The proposed rules are an aggressive move by President Obama to bypass Congress on climate change with executive actions.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Friday announced that it was not backing down from a confrontation with the coal industry and that it would press ahead with enacting the first federal carbon limits on the nation’s power companies.

headline: New Feature: Weekly Classroom-Tested Skills Lessons
abstract: Sarah Gross and Jonathan Olsen, the teachers with whom we collaborated for Common Core Practice last year, will return to the blog Sept. 27. This year, we’ll focus on a skill a week and offer many ways to teach it — with The Times, of course.
lead_paragraph: Remember Common Core Practice, last year’s weekly feature co-written by the New Jersey teachers Sarah Gross and Jonathan Olsen?

headline: Movers and Shapers
abstract: A roundup of the dancers, choreographers and designers to watch for this season.
lead_paragraph: The energy that characterizes New York City finds artistic release in dance. Other cities around the world have important dance scenes, but for diversity and vitality this one has no match. Here ballet and modern mingle with tap and jazz. Here ethnic and experimental mixed media works find devoted audiences. Here it’s natural to find the formal colliding with the forward-looking. And during the main season, from September to June, it’s not unusual to find a dozen dance productions opening in a week.

headline: Hedge Fund Drops Opposition to Smithfield Deal
abstract: Starboard Value, the activist hedge fund that was seeking to block Smithfield Foods’ $4.7 billion sale to a Chinese meat processor, dropped its fight on Friday, saying that it could not formalize an alternative takeover bid.
lead_paragraph: Starboard Value, the activist hedge fund that was seeking to block Smithfield Foods’ $4.7 billion sale to a Chinese meat processor, dropped its fight on Friday, saying that it could not formalize an alternative takeover bid.

lead_paragraph: LONDON — Three of the biggest British department store chains were accused Friday of colluding on prices with a maker of sports bras.

headline: Green Cabs Appear as Bloomberg Prepares to Depart
keywords: ['Taxicabs and Taxicab Drivers', 'Car Services and Livery Cabs']
abstract: The innovation of the green cab fleet was meant to help solve the problem of an unequal distribution of taxis in the city.
lead_paragraph: The waning days of any political administration are typically given over, in large part, to a trumpeting of its successes, real and perceived, and so it has been in New York, as Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg prepares to depart with all the reluctance of a 6-year-old leaving Great Adventure.

headline: A Night for Swiss Pride, Minus Tax Talk
abstract: At a party at the Swiss Embassy on Wednesday night in Washington, discussion about bank secrecy took a back seat to a celebration of other Swiss pursuits.
lead_paragraph: Absinthe, chocolate and raclette cheese are helping Switzerland to banish its private-banking blues.

headline: The Gun Report: September 20, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: As we head into the last weekend of summer, here is a roundup of gun news:

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Sue Grafton, whose latest novel featuring Kinsey Millhone, “W Is for Wasted,” is No. 1 on the hardcover fiction list, began writing mysteries after a bitter divorce.
lead_paragraph: W Is for Woo-Woo: “Meet a new private eye — Kinsey Millhone.” That’s how the Book Review’s former crime columnist, Newgate Callendar, greeted readers on May 23, 1982, introducing Sue Grafton’s resourceful, virtuous, unlucky-in-love sleuth, who made her debut that spring in “A Is for Alibi” and has since gone on to star in 22 more alphabet novels. (The latest, “W Is for Wasted,” enters this week’s hardcover fiction list at No. 1, providing an emphatic answer to Callendar’s question, “Will the series take hold?”)

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: THE SCIENTISTS: A Family Romance,  by Marco Roth. (Picador, $15.) Roth was still in his teens when his father, a New York hematologist with pitilessly highbrow cultural and intellectual standards, died in 1993 after a long struggle with AIDS. In this memoir Roth, a founder of the literary journal n+1, investigates his father’s troubled life through the novels he cherished: Turgenev, Goncharov, Mann and others.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: BLEEDING EDGE,  by Thomas Pynchon. (Penguin Press, $28.95.) Airliners crash not only into the twin towers but into a shaggy-dog tale involving a fraud investigator and a white-­collar outlaw in this vital, audacious novel.

headline: Criminal Record
abstract: Marilyn Stasio has been covering crime fiction in the Book Review for 25 years.
lead_paragraph: Marilyn Stasio has now been on the case for 25 years. In the Sept. 18, 1988, issue of the Book Review, Stasio took over the Crime column from her predecessor, Newgate Callendar (the pen name for Harold C. Schonberg, who covered classical music for The Times). She’s been grading detective work ever since.

headline: Etro: Spring 2014 RTW
abstract: Milan
lead_paragraph: Milan

headline: Square Roots | The Making of an Alberta Ferretti Runway Look
abstract: Click the image to see the path of one of Alberta Ferretti’s ideas for her spring/summer 2014 collection, from the page to the stage.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the back story behind some of the most compelling pieces to appear on the runway this season, showing their trajectory from the designer’s own sketch to a fully realized look. Just begin clicking on the image above to transform it into the floral, asymmetrical dress that Alberta Ferretti showed on Wednesday in Milan as part of her spring/summer 2014 collection.

headline: Alessandro Dell’Acqua Heading to Rochas?
abstract: Italian designer Alessandro Dell’Acqua is in line to be named the new designer of Rochas in Paris, replacing Marco Zanini after his show next week.
lead_paragraph: A fashion season would not be complete these days without a round of gossip about which designer is about to go where. On Friday, the front rows were abuzz with fresh reports that the Italian designer Alessandro Dell’Acqua is in line to be named the new designer of Rochas in Paris, replacing Marco Zanini after his show next week.

headline: House Bill Links Health Care Law and Budget Plan
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'National Debt (US)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Without a resolution, large swaths of the government could shut down Oct. 1, and a first-ever default on federal debt could follow weeks later.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — House Republicans muscled through a stopgap bill Friday that would fund the government only if all spending for President Obama’s health care law is eliminated. Senate Democrats and President Obama quickly made it clear they had no intention of going along, putting the government on a course toward a shutdown unless one side relents.

headline: After a Crisis of Faith, a Former Minister Finds a New, Secular Mission
abstract: The path for a minister who loses faith in God can be murky. But for one lapsed Methodist, fate — or something — intervened.
lead_paragraph: Nine days before Easter in 2012, the Rev. Teresa MacBain sent a letter to the congregants she had pastored for three years at a Methodist church in Tallahassee, Fla. For much of that time, she had preached the Gospel every Sunday, only to slip each Monday into tormented doubt.

headline: New York Life Suspends Chief Executive of Its Lending Unit
abstract: New York Life is said to have suspended Madison Capital’s chief executive, Trevor J. Clark, and another one of its senior executives, Christopher G. Williams, over violations in company policies.
lead_paragraph: Madison Capital Funding, a lending unit of the insurance giant New York Life, has been on a roll. It attracted a new business partner in the private equity giant Apollo Global Management. The trade publication Mergers & Acquisitions named it the 2012 lender of the year.

headline: Etro Gets an Assist From Grandma
abstract: Veronica Etro got the idea for her spring Etro collection while visiting her grandmother’s country home.
lead_paragraph: Veronica Etro got the idea for her spring Etro collection while visiting her grandmother’s country home, where she noticed the textiles on a patterned bookshelf and decided to bring them back to life. These she combined with metalwork from the Ottoman Empire and a touch of Eastern dressing, along with some signature Etro paisleys for a strong show on Friday. The colors veered from soft, iridescent pastels to vivid yellows with a black vine print on scarf dresses and wraps. The hits were the long paisley halters worn with with gold-fringed scarves loosely tied around the neck.

headline: Today in Small Business: Saying No to Starbucks
abstract: Leading indicators post gains. Jobless claims hit a six-year low. Does your start-up have a chef?
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Sarah Jessica Parker’s Ballerina-Inspired Ensemble
abstract: The actress wore an outfit created by Prabal Gurung and Olivier Theyskens, two of the three designers who created custom costumes for the New York City Ballet’s Fall Gala.
lead_paragraph: The Girl: The actress glided across the red carpet in a pastel bustier and full skirt last night at the New York City Ballet‘s Fall Gala in New York.

headline: Looking for a Bandit Who Took 3 Handbags, and Never Left His Chair
abstract: A man in a wheelchair stole women’s bags at some of the city’s finer hotels and restaurants, according to the police.
lead_paragraph: In the restaurants, where he managed to thread his way through the well-fueled crowds at the bar, no one wondered why he did not order a drink. In the hotel, where he acted the same as any other guest, no one wondered why he never went upstairs to his room.

headline: V-8 Expats Roll Into England
abstract: There is a growing classic-car movement in England to collect what are called Yank Tanks, big American cars made after World War II.
lead_paragraph: STRATFORD-UPON-AVON, ENGLAND — Visitors to Shakespeare County Raceway during the annual Yanks Weekend could be forgiven for thinking they had stumbled into a regular Sunday meet at a typical American dragstrip — were it not for the British accents and license plates, that is, and the track name’s incongruous association with the playwright, born a few miles down the road.

headline: Cherry Jones, at the Peak of Her Powers
abstract: One of the great theater actresses talks about stage fright, vanity and her pre-performance rituals.
lead_paragraph: Cherry Jones is one of the greatest stage actresses of her generation. Though she is probably best known for her Emmy-winning portrayal of President Allison Taylor on “24,” watching her on television is nothing like watching her in the theater, her sweep unconstrained by a camera.

headline: Who Made That T-Shirt?
abstract: From the “bachelor undershirt” to everyday outerwear.
lead_paragraph: In 1904, the Cooper Underwear Company ran a magazine ad announcing a new product for bachelors. In the “before” photo, a man averts his eyes from the camera as if embarrassed; he has lost all the buttons on his undershirt and has safety-pinned its flaps together. In the “after” photo, a virile gentleman sports a handlebar mustache, smokes a cigar and wears a “bachelor undershirt” stretchy enough to be pulled over the head. “No safety pins — no buttons — no needle — no thread,” ran the slogan aimed at men with no wives and no sewing skills. Someone in the U.S. Navy must have seen the logic in this, because the following year, the quartermaster’s office specified that sailors should wear undershirts with no buttons under their uniforms; soon thousands of men became acquainted with the comfort of the cotton pullover.

headline: The Grand Mufti Of Google
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Names, Personal']
abstract: An international soap opera landed in my inbox — what was I to do?
lead_paragraph: “Reply me its very imported,” the subject line demanded, bossy and impatient. Before I even opened the message, blinking over my morning coffee, I knew where this was going.

headline: Garage-Sale Arbitrage
abstract: The $1,000 comic book with the 25-cent price tag.
lead_paragraph: Is it ethical to buy something at a yard sale or a flea market at the seller’s asking price if you know the value of the item to be significantly higher than what is being asked? Let’s say, for example, someone is selling an old comic book worth thousands of dollars but asks for only a quarter because he or she does not know the true value. Is it incumbent on the seller to do his or her research? If the seller does not, is it fair game? RYAN ATLAS, BOSTON

headline: No Comments
abstract: Online comment sections are famously full of vitriol. But if we rethink the way comments function, can we reform their tone and content as well?
lead_paragraph: Dip into the comments, the American text genre of the moment, and you can sense the currents that move American life. “The comments are where the real America is,” someone once wrote in a comment thread. Comments also may be the most obnoxious development of the Web, the wild back alleys where people sound their acid yawps. Their tenor is now so bad that last November a game designer, Shane Liesegang, set up a Twitter feed, @avoidcomments, where he tweets things like “I once showed a comments section to a man in Reno, just to watch him cry.” He now has 27,000 followers.

headline: Are We Ready For Urinal-Sinks?
abstract: The wig Amy Sedaris let get away; Jenny McCarthy vs. Joseph McCarthy.
lead_paragraph: The wig Amy Sedaris let get away; Jenny McCarthy vs. Joseph McCarthy.

headline: Old-School Pong
abstract: Vintage table-tennis snapshots collected by the photographer Alec Soth.
lead_paragraph: Vintage table-tennis snapshots collected by the photographer Alec Soth.

headline: The 9.8.13 Issue
abstract: Readers respond.
lead_paragraph: WHAT WAS, IS AND WILL BE POPULAR

headline: Comments on Comments
abstract: A Q. & A. with Bassey Etim, the community manager at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: In this week’s Riff, Michael Erard recounts the history of Web site comments and explains how their technical origins has shaped the actual commentary we’ve come to expect as usual today. When it comes to the comments sections of newspapers, he writes that they “have mistakenly treated comments as the digital equivalents of letters to the editor.” I wanted to get Bassey Etim’s take on all this. As the community manager at The Times, Etim oversees 13 comment moderators and thinks way more about Web comments than most people would ever want to.

headline: A-Rod’s Defender Knows How to Tap Dance
abstract: The lawyer Joseph Tacopina on mobsters, the Yankees and the art of skirting questions.
lead_paragraph: As a criminal-defense lawyer, you’ve represented a notorious roster of clients. You’ll take pretty much anyone except for mobsters.  I wouldn’t say I’d take any client. If I had a client I believed were guilty of pedophilia, for instance, it’s just not the right case for me. It doesn’t mean that person is not entitled to representation. That being said, I don’t take organized-crime cases. My parents were Italian immigrants, and my dad’s parents had run-ins with organized crime in Red Hook.

headline: Rocket Fuel and FireEye More Than Double in Market Debut
abstract: The successful initial public offerings of Rocket Fuel, an advertising technology company, and FireEye, a cybersecurity services provider, point to a resurgence of technology I.P.O.’s by year end.
lead_paragraph: Shares of Rocket Fuel and FireEye hewed close to their names on the first day of trading, taking off to atmospheric heights in their initial public offerings.

headline: YA Crossover
abstract: New books by Rainbow Rowell, Sara Farizan, Elizabeth Wein, Robin Wasserman and Ursula Dubosarsky.
lead_paragraph: FANGIRLBy Rainbow Rowell  St. Martin’s Griffin, $18.99.

headline: Pettitte Up Next as Dynasty Nears End
abstract: Andy Pettitte said he struggled with the timing of his announcement because he did not want to take away from Mariano Rivera’s final home game on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: If Hall of Fame starters are supposed to be durable, dominant winners, then Andy Pettitte just misses the cut. But he pitched a long time and won a lot, and that made him an indelible Yankee great.

headline: Russia Seizes Greenpeace Ship and Crew for Investigation
keywords: ['Ships and Shipping', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Offshore Drilling and Exploration']
abstract: The Federal Security Service said it would tow the ship, the Arctic Sunrise, to port in Murmansk and conduct an inquiry after Greenpeace activists scaled an offshore oil rig in the Arctic Ocean.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russia’s Federal Security Service announced on Friday that it had seized a Greenpeace International ship and its crew after a series of protests at an offshore oil rig in the Arctic Ocean and that it would tow the ship to port in Murmansk to conduct an investigation.

headline: Our Towns
abstract: The past shapes the present, and fiction melds with fact, in Peter Orner’s stories.
lead_paragraph: For the past 12 years, since his lauded “Esther Stories,” Peter Orner has been engaged in a strange, quiet and wonderful experiment. He has written four works of fiction — two novels and two story collections — all composed of canny snippets that build with subtle accumulative power to create books autobiographical in feel, if not necessarily in fact. In all but his first novel, “The Second Coming of Mavala Shikongo,” the books return to the same characters from startling vantage points; Orner is writing in spirals, moving restlessly out to embody imagined characters, but always returning to the Chicago and Fall River, Mass., family of his most frequent first-person narrator, a young man who is roughly his age. In each of his books, Orner’s crystalline sentences and his ability to pay close and sustained attention to small moments transform the ordinary elements of each story into an even more astonishing whole.

headline: The Sorcerer’s Mistress
abstract: A schoolteacher takes an unusual lover in Kathryn Davis’s novel of fantastical suburbia.
lead_paragraph: “Like most writers, I have one particular thing I can’t stop thinking about, wondering about, and in my case it’s the animating spirit of a thing, what we also call the soul.”

headline: An Aggregator for Rides, Lodging and Guides
abstract: The site Outpost.Travel offers listings from peer-to-peer categories like lodging, transportation, and trip guides.
lead_paragraph: By several estimates, the peer-to-peer rental market, which includes travel-related sites like Airbnb and Vayable, will generate more than $3.5 billion in revenues this year. So how does a traveler navigate the increasingly crowded territory?

headline: Red and Black
abstract: Three women artists, all sympathetic to the left, illuminate Harlem’s culture in the years around World War II.
lead_paragraph: In the national consciousness, Harlem has usually been defined by two eras: the artistic and cultural explosion of the 1920s, known as the Harlem Renaissance, and the drug-fueled devastation that began in the 1950s and peaked in the late ’80s. The Harlem Renaissance has been well documented by its poets, novelists and essayists, as well as by a legion of scholars in the decades since. The long, depressing ghetto years were recounted most eloquently by James Baldwin, and by lesser mortals like sociologists, memoirists, politicians, Hollywood screenwriters and rappers. Today’s whiter Harlem of multimillion-­dollar brownstones and flashy eateries is already the subject of books, blogs and innumerable magazine travel articles.

headline: Uptown Girls
abstract: White women participated in the Harlem Renaissance as philanthropists, activists, authors and patrons.
lead_paragraph: Time hasn’t been kind to the white women who participated in the Harlem Renaissance. As philanthropists and activists, authors and patrons, they sought a place for themselves in that remarkable outpouring of African-American art during the 1920s and ’30s. Some, constrained by social expectations, effaced the records of their work. Others made it difficult for historians to treat them with much seriousness. What, after all, can we do with someone like Nancy Cunard, a British steamship heiress raised on a remote English estate, who felt no shame in proclaiming “I speak as if I were a Negro myself”?

headline: The Unquiet Americans
abstract: Bob Shacochis’s novel of conflict and corruption spans five decades and four countries.
lead_paragraph: Like most serious American novels about war, “The Woman Who Lost Her Soul” wants to explain the country in its entirety. Of course, that’s a tall order, but Bob Shacochis doesn’t lack for ambition — his novel is about not one but two contemporary wars, both of them endless: the war on terror and the war on drugs. It’s a novel about the United States that takes place largely outside the United States, if you discount the many scenes set on various world-renowned American golf courses. Although the book strives to paint a full portrait of its panoply of complicated characters — both in warrior mode and on the home front — the problem with endless war in a narrative is that the writer ends up not with “War and Peace” but with war and . . . more war. One follows from battle to battle, from firefight to firefight, from political assassination to terror attack to revenge-taking, without resolution, because the endless war can conceive of no resolution: resolution, which makes a narrative complete, is not part of this story.

headline: Down and Out
abstract: In Sue Grafton’s “W Is for Wasted,” a homeless man is found dead on the beach and the sleuth Kinsey Millhone meets his three disinherited children.
lead_paragraph: Instead of dreading the day Sue Grafton reaches the end of the alphabet, her faithful readers should be concerned about her plans for a new decade. It’s still the materialistic 1980s in W IS FOR WASTED (Marian Wood/Putnam, $28.95), so Kinsey Millhone, the well-nigh immortal sleuth in this enduring series, still has time to play her rebel role simply by living a spartan existence in a world of greedy narcissists. How sweet it is to see the California private eye back in her garage apartment, hanging out with her 88-year-old landlord, wearing jeans and boots and pulling out a single dress to get her through formal occasions. It’s also fun to watch her at work, taking notes on index cards, typing reports on a Smith-Corona and — here’s what really matters — communicating with people face to face.

headline: Her Story
abstract: The woman raped by Roman Polanski when she was 13 tells what happened then and in the long aftermath.
lead_paragraph: Samantha Geimer says she really wants you to leave her alone. Really. She’s a 50-year-old woman now, dividing her time between Hawaii and Nevada with her husband and three sons. But 36 years ago in Hollywood, when she was only 13, she was plied with Champagne and a quaa­lude, photographed topless, and raped by the 43-year-old Roman Polanski. And ever since, her privacy has been busted. Any time Polanski is in the news, Geimer is once again thrown back into reliving her invaded girlhood, an unwilling principal player in a story never satisfactorily concluded. And Polanski is in the news often, since the artistically impressive, Oscar-winning, Polish-French director who made “Chinatown,” “Rosemary’s Baby” and “The Pianist” fled the United States in 1978 before final sentencing. The wrath of American justice, affronted as much by his defiance as by his crime, awaits him if he ever returns. It’s a story that has become grimy with symbolism about Hollywood privilege, 1970s California indulgence, imperfect parenting, judicial pandering and inconsistency, tortured creative temperament, and the rights of rape victims.

headline: Latitudes of Grief
abstract: Julian Barnes discusses life after the loss of his wife.
lead_paragraph: Julian Barnes has disregarded the conventional boundaries between literary genres for as long as he’s been publishing books. So it should come as no surprise that “Levels of Life,” a putative grief memoir about the loss of his wife, the literary agent Pat Kavanagh, is part history, part meditative essay and part fictionalized biography. The pieces combine to form a fascinating discourse on love and sorrow.

headline: Guilt Trip
abstract: In Ben Dolnick’s novel, a young man heads to India in search of a former friend.
lead_paragraph: Ben Dolnick’s first two novels, “Zoology” and “You Know Who You Are,” were intelligent, amiable books, about the coming-of-age of middle-class male protagonists. They were warmhearted and strikingly perceptive about their heroes’ feelings, the petty as well as the generous. But their painstaking rendering of childhood and adolescent struggles felt at moments overly wide-eyed, almost twee.

headline: And Then Everything Changed
abstract: At the center of Paul Harding’s follow-up to the Pulitzer-winning “Tinkers” is a man coming to terms with personal tragedy.
lead_paragraph: Truly memorable experiences — whether they involve a lover, a pinot noir or a novel so good you have to keep putting it down just to savor the afterimage of a particular phrase — tend to generate a certain anticipatory tension. Will the follow-up repeat the magic? Or will the lover be distracted the next time around, the wine underwhelming?

headline: Losing Her Religion
abstract: Nicole Hardy examines her wavering Mormon faith.
lead_paragraph: Augustine famously asked God to grant him chastity but not yet. In “Confessions of a Latter-day Virgin,” her account of remaining chaste and Mormon well into her 30s, Nicole Hardy pleads with God to just take it from her already — because if he wants her to wait until marriage for sex, as her church demands, he’s going to have to toss her something she’s been unable to find on her own. As she writes in typically winking fashion after a grueling bout of online Mormon dating: “If the kind of man I want exists within the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, he is rare, not unlike the endangered red panda of the Himalayas. Show me an LDS man who’s wickedly funny, politically liberal, brighter than the average bear and uncommitted to 1950s gender roles, and I will show you the shaggy tail and waddling gait of the Ailurus fulgens, its mischievous mouth rife with bamboo.”

headline: Original Gangsters
abstract: Two books recount the criminal careers of Frank and Jesse James.
lead_paragraph: Jesse James, the young Confederate guerrilla turned outlaw, rose to fame and descended into infamy in less than two decades — from the mid-1860s to his death in 1882 — in the crucible of a frontier struggling to establish law and order, in circumstances that birthed the very notion of the Wild West.

headline: Poor in the Land of Plenty
abstract: For Sasha Abramsky, poverty is not an aberration but an inherent part of the American system as it operates today.
lead_paragraph: Virtually everything worthwhile written about American poverty is essentially about moral failure. It is the failure of the society (according to liberals) or of the poor themselves (according to conservatives) or of institutions and individuals together in a complex combination (according to centrists). Poverty violates core American values. It challenges the American dream’s promise of prosperity for anyone who works hard, a faith central to the national ethic. Richard Wright called this faith “the truth of the power of the wish.”

headline: Off the Charts: World Population Could Peak by 2055
abstract: The United Nations population division this summer released its 2012 population forecasts, predicting that there are likely to be 10.9 billion people in the world by 2100, up from 6.9 billion in 2010.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations population division this summer released its 2012 population forecasts, predicting that there are likely to be 10.9 billion people in the world by 2100, up from 6.9 billion in 2010.

headline: Image of the Day: Sept. 20
abstract: A passing out parade of Border Security Force personnel in Srinagar, Jammu and Kashmir.

headline: Milan Fashion Week: Emporio Armani Spring/Summer 2014
abstract: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

headline: For Your Ears Only
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Real Estate Brokers', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']
abstract: In New York City, homes are selling as “whisper listings,” without ever being put on the market.
lead_paragraph: No open houses, no advertising and not a single online photo. And yet a $27 million town house on the Upper East Side and an $850,000 two-bedroom co-op in Lower Manhattan had no problem finding buyers in the past six months. Neither home was listed on the open market.

headline: Vodafone Wins Approval for Takeover of German Cable Operator
abstract: The approval by the European antitrust authorities was the last hurdle in Vodafone’s $10.4 billion acquisition of Kabel Deutschland.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British telecommunications giant Vodafone received approval on Friday from European antitrust authorities for its proposed takeover bid of 7.7 billion euros, or $10.4 billion, for the German cable company Kabel Deutschland.

headline: Judge Opens Lid on Deal Companies Would Prefer Stay Shut
abstract: A ruling by a Delaware judge has thrown the sale by Vivendi of most of its stake in Activision Blizzard into turmoil, with the parties grappling with what to do next.
lead_paragraph: Vivendi and Activision Blizzard have been tripped up on their new deal by their old one, creating a possible “wreck,” as one participant representing Activision put it.

headline: Two Table Tennis Obsessives Go Back and Forth
abstract: A conversation with the photographer Alec Soth about ping pong.
lead_paragraph: This week’s Look features table-tennis pictures collected by the photographer Alec Soth, an avid player of the game. The images appear in the book “Ping Pong,” which Soth’s publishing enterprise, Little Brown Mushroom, put out this month. We asked Will Shortz, the crossword editor of The New York Times — and the owner of the Westchester Table Tennis Center, in Pleasantville, N.Y., who says he has played in tennis table clubs in 43 of the country’s states — to interview Alec about the book and their shared love of the game.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: A. Scott Berg’s ‘Wilson’
abstract: This week, A. Scott Berg discusses his new biography of Woodrow Wilson; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Carla Kaplan talks about “Miss Anne in Harlem”; Sasha Abramsky on “The American Way of Poverty”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.
lead_paragraph: This week, A. Scott Berg discusses his new biography of Woodrow Wilson; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Carla Kaplan talks about “Miss Anne in Harlem”; Sasha Abramsky on “The American Way of Poverty”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: Cooking With Miso
abstract: Many people know and love miso soup. But this week Martha Rose Shulman goes beyond soup and explains how miso can be used for glazes, dips and dressings.
lead_paragraph: Many people know and love miso soup. But this week Martha Rose Shulman takes miso beyond soup and explains how it can be used for glazes, dips and dressings. She writes:

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: A. Scott Berg’s ‘Wilson’
abstract: This week, A. Scott Berg, Carla Kaplan and Sasha Abramsky.
lead_paragraph: This week, A. Scott Berg, Carla Kaplan and Sasha Abramsky.

headline: HondaVac Sucks Up Rubbish and Hollywood Talent
abstract: Honda knew it had an ingenious device with the detritus-devouring HondaVac in its Odyssey minivans. But using the right voice-over talent in advertising has proved invaluable.
lead_paragraph: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4qcLXt_Ivzw

headline: Joe on WNYC’s “Money Talking”: Sept. 20, 2013
abstract: Is this the end of employee-based healthcare?
lead_paragraph: October 1 is a watershed moment for Obamacare, because that’s the day people can start signing up for health insurance, online, through public exchanges. But against this backdrop, there are also signs of a sea change in how private employers will offer health insurance.

headline: Population Growth Forecast From the U.N. May Be Too High
abstract: The United Nations sees the world population at nearly 11 billion by the year 2100, but an expert at Deutsche Bank predicts much slower growth.
lead_paragraph: DEMOGRAPHY may, as they say, be destiny. But demography is anything but a sure thing.

headline: Advice for New Parents Who Get Too Much Advice
abstract: The arrival of a baby can provoke conflict, as brand-new grandparents want to share what they learned in decades of child-rearing, while new parents are looking to find their own way.
lead_paragraph: In the second installment of the New Parent, Old Parent collaboration between Booming and the Motherlode blog, I (representing the New Parent) ask the question, on Booming: What’s a new parent to do when the grandparents give too much advice about the baby?

headline: Fox Contest Offers 30-Second Super Bowl Pregame Ad as a Prize
abstract: The contest is meant to tap into public interest in the advertising for the game by using social media to pick a winner. The entry fee is $150,000, however.
lead_paragraph: From time to time, Super Bowl advertisers have sponsored contests, among them brands like Chevrolet and Doritos. Now, for what may be the first time, the network broadcasting the Super Bowl is planning an ad contest of its own.

headline: Watching Memories Slip From the Mind
abstract: Alan Berliner’s documentary “First Cousin Once Removed” follows Edwin Honig and his struggles with Alzheimer’s disease.
lead_paragraph: Some years ago the documentarian Alan Berliner was going to make a movie about a California woman with superabundant autobiographical memory. “She remembered everything in her past,” Mr. Berliner said. “The neurologists studied her at UC Irvine for five years, and she was the real deal. No tricks. Extraordinary.”

headline: Evoking Mali, Appalachia and the Twilight of the 1970s
abstract: Notable new music includes an English electronic trio, a modern twist on Appalachia, stripped-down Malian singing and more.
lead_paragraph: Factory Floor

headline: Life on the Battlefield
abstract: What can Ambrose Bierce’s short story “Chickamauga” tell us about how civilians suffered during the Civil War?
lead_paragraph: In Ambrose Bierce’s short story “Chickamauga,” a young boy emerges from his home, wooden sword in hand, and proceeds to kill imaginary enemies. He is unaware that a real battle – the namesake blood bath that gives the story its title – is taking place just a short distance away. He is deaf, and therefore can’t hear the approaching gunfire or the groans of dying soldiers.

headline: How She Got the Mother, of All Roles
abstract: From the Girl in “Once” to the Mother in “How I Met Your Mother” — with a stint in a Martin Scorsese movie thrown in — Cristin Milioti is having a pretty good year.
lead_paragraph: For the record, Cristin Milioti is not engaged. “No, I swear to you I’m telling the truth!” she nearly shrieked upon hearing a morsel of Internet gossip. “My boyfriend’s going to get such a kick out of that.” She grinned conspiratorially. “But we’re very happy,” she said of the man in question, the furniture maker Jesse Hooker.

headline: Big Ticket | A Charming Corner for $12.3 Million
abstract: A fully renovated prewar duplex, with five bedrooms and a separate guest suite, features open city views to the north and east.
lead_paragraph: A graciously proportioned prewar duplex at 125 East 72nd Street, a corner combination situated to capture open city views to the north and east, ignited an uptown bidding war and sold for $12,315,000, the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Calendar: Coming Events in North Carolina; England; California
abstract: A weekly capsule of events around the globe curated by our writers and editors.
lead_paragraph: World of Bluegrass, North Carolina Some of the top stars in traditional and new-school bluegrass, including Sam Bush, Bela Fleck, Punch Brothers, the SteelDrivers and the actor and musician Steve Martin (above) and his band, the Steep Canyon Rangers, will appear in Raleigh Sept. 24 to 28 for the International Bluegrass Music Association’s World of Bluegrass 2013. Events open to the public include ticketed shows at the Red Hat Amphitheatre and a showcase called the Bluegrass Ramble, held at various downtown clubs. A free outdoor event on Sept. 27 and 28 includes three music stages, a dance tent and a barbecue cook-off.

headline: Emmys Watch: Michelle MacLaren on Directing ‘Breaking Bad’
abstract: A director of “Breaking Bad,” Michelle MacLaren, explains how to shoot fake cash and other feats that led to her Emmy nomination.
lead_paragraph: The director Michelle MacLaren may not be a household name, but her work has been seen in many a home: her credits include episodes from popular television dramas like “Game of Thrones,” “The Walking Dead” and “NCIS.”

headline: Crafty Character. The Actor, Too.
abstract: James Spader plays an intense criminal mastermind in “The Blacklist,” a new drama on NBC.
lead_paragraph: The set, inside the cavernous studio on Chelsea Piers in Manhattan, is meant to represent the bunkerlike headquarters of a polished Chinese techno-gangster who has a relationship with the criminal mastermind Raymond Reddington, now — for murky reasons unknown to both the gangster and the audience — aligned with the F.B.I.

headline: And Now, Trying Their Hand at Condos
abstract: High land prices prompted Glenwood Management to go for a new business model.
lead_paragraph: The next generation of a prominent New York real estate family business, Glenwood Management, has taken up the mantle at the company and begun its first condominium project.

headline: John A. Boehner’s Remarks After Vote
keywords: ['Farm Bill (US)', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Speaker John A. Boehner held a rally after the House vote on the continuing resolution that would strip funding for President Obama’s health care law.
lead_paragraph: Speaker John A. Boehner held a rally after the House vote on the continuing resolution that would strip funding for President Obama’s health care law.

headline: A Loner, Playing With the Crowd
abstract: The pianist and composer Muhal Richard Abrams performs  in concert on Thursday at Roulette in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: The pianist and composer Muhal Richard Abrams, who just turned 83, has always had roughly equal use for communion and solitude. Nearly 50 years ago he laid the groundwork for the Association for the Advancement of Creative Musicians, one of the great collectivist institutions in African-American music. And yet his own creative metabolism suggests a rugged self-containment, impervious to outside influence.

headline: A Smorgasbord of Tasty Twirls
abstract: It is 10 years since Fall for Dance burst upon the New York fall season with its eclectic programs and — most important — its movie-ticket prices.
lead_paragraph: It is 10 years since Fall for Dance burst upon the New York fall season with its eclectic programs, its international mix of the well-known and the undiscovered and — most important — its movie-ticket prices. That price has sneaked up, to $15 from $10, but it’s still a steal for the caliber of work you can see at any of the five programs.

headline: An Actor Seeks Answers
abstract: Kirk Cameron’s “Unstoppable” is booked for a one-night showing in almost 700 theaters on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Some former child stars have stayed in the spotlight by being arrested or doing vulgar dances on national awards shows. Kirk Cameron has done it with his religious beliefs. Mr. Cameron, who played Mike Seaver on the sitcom “Growing Pains” in the 1980s and early ’90s, is an outspoken conservative Christian who has angered some with his views, particularly comments last year about homosexuality, which he called “detrimental and ultimately destructive to so many of the foundations of civilization.”

headline: Three Fanfares for a Local Hero
abstract: Who are the musicians who define New York? For the last four decades, one of the most indefatigable has been John Zorn.
lead_paragraph: Who are the musicians who define New York? For the last four decades, one of the most indefatigable has been John Zorn, the composer, saxophonist, impresario and all-around macher of the city’s arts scene. He has founded a record label (Tzadik) and a performing space (the Stone, in the East Village). Perhaps most impressive, he has managed to retain an edge of enfant-terrible cred while making the transition from downtown stalwart to uptown respectability. Institutions all over the city are honoring Mr. Zorn, who turned 60 on Sept. 2.

headline: A Surrealist Under Scrutiny
abstract: “Magritte: The Mystery of the Ordinary, 1926-1938,” opening on Saturday at the Museum of Modern Art, is sure to be a crowd-pleaser.
lead_paragraph: “Magritte: The Mystery of the Ordinary, 1926-1938,” opening on Saturday at the Museum of Modern Art, is sure to be a crowd-pleaser: among its 80 works are well-known canvases like “The Treachery of Images” (better known for its declaration, “This is not a pipe”) and “The Lovers,” with its eerie image of a kiss stymied by drapery.

headline: Stuff Guys Like, Like Cooking Shows
abstract: What do men want? According to Esquire magazine, they want their own cable network.
lead_paragraph: What do men want? According to Esquire magazine — for eight decades a hot line to the male psyche — they want their own cable network that caters to a more sophisticated but no less masculine viewer than those currently in thrall to tattoo parlors, pawnshops and hillbillies. So now they’ve got it. “You only live once,” a male voice intones in ads for the Esquire Network, which makes its debut Monday on what was Style. “But if you really live, once is all you need.”

headline: A Closer Look at ‘Metallica Through the Never’
abstract: Using one performance image, the makers of Metallica’s new concert movie describe their process.
lead_paragraph: Using one performance image, the makers of Metallica’s new concert movie describe their process.

headline: Responding to Reader Comments on War Photographs and Drone Victims
abstract: The public editor follows up on questions and comments from readers, after a Sunday column on images of war.
lead_paragraph: I’m appreciative of the reader response to my column last Sunday on photographic images from Syria. A few of those responses have made me realize that some further explanation is in order, on two points.

headline: With Neighbors Like These
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Mosques', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Religion-State Relations', 'Sunni Muslims', 'Terrorism']
abstract: Syria’s problems are exposing Turkey’s own challenges with its Alevi minority.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — If countries had mission statements, Turkey’s would be the 1931 dictum of its founder, Mustafa Kemal Ataturk: “Peace at home, peace in the world.” It appears on public monuments everywhere.

headline: Late on Her Schoolwork? Well, She’s a Titan of Chess
abstract: Hou Yifan, of China, defeated Anna Ushenina, 28, a grandmaster from Ukraine, in a match in Taizhou, China.
lead_paragraph: By her own definition, 19-year-old Hou Yifan is an average student. She is a sophomore at Peking University, one of China’s top colleges, and says she constantly falls behind on her work.

headline: SNAP Notes
abstract: A program doing what it’s supposed to do.
lead_paragraph: Just out of conference, and probably not much posting. But I wanted to tie together two of this week’s stories: the new Census numbers on income and poverty, and the GOP vote to throw several million people off food stamps.

headline: As Fierce as She Is Fragile: Elaine Stritch in Michigan
abstract: Ms. Stritch, who made a dramatic exit from her home at the Carlyle Hotel this spring, is settling into her new life in Birmingham, Mich., cosmos and all.
lead_paragraph: BIRMINGHAM, Mich. — Even at 88, and in what might be called spectacularly frail health, Elaine Stritch can still make a theatrical entrance.

headline: A Silents Gold Mine From Down Under
abstract: “Lost and Found: American Treasures From the New Zealand Film Archive” offers a dozen newly restored American silent features and shorts that were unearthed abroad.
lead_paragraph: A dozen long-vanished films again see the light of day in the new DVD anthology from the National Film Preservation Foundation, “Lost and Found: American Treasures From the New Zealand Film Archive.” A few have big names attached to them — John Ford, Alfred Hitchcock, Mabel Normand — but every movie here has its own fascination, some for social and historical reasons, others as entertainment pure and simple.

headline: Grilled Ratatouille With Goat Cheese
abstract: Melissa Clark avoids heating up her kitchen by making ratatouille on the grill.
lead_paragraph: Melissa Clark avoids heating up her kitchen by making ratatouille on the grill.

headline: Visuals: Paper Goods
abstract: As publishers move ever closer to the screen-based library, enjoy these tactile books while they’re still here.
lead_paragraph: As publishers move ever closer to the screen-based library, enjoy these tactile books while they’re still here.

headline: BMW to Recall 134,000 Vehicles for Electrical Malfunction
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Automobiles', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: BMW’s 5 Series is the subject of a recall stemming from a defect that can cause brake lights, turn signals, tail lights and backup lights to fail.
lead_paragraph: BMW will recall about 134,000 5 Series models from 2008-10 because the tail lights may not work, the automaker told the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration in a report posted Friday on the agency’s Web site.

headline: Why ‘Million Second Quiz’ Didn’t Work: A Multiple-Choice Answer
abstract: NBC’s game-show “event” didn’t draw big ratings but it did raise questions about the format.
lead_paragraph: Andrew Kravis, a 25-year-old law school graduate from Michigan, won $2.6 million as the clock finally ran down on NBC’s 10-night game show “The Million Second Quiz” on Thursday. That’s a nice number for him — NBC claimed it was the largest payout in game-show history.

headline: Younger Generations’ Approach to Investing
keywords: ['Personal Finances', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Youth', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: Three reports by big financial institutions show how the younger generations want to set themselves apart from the baby boomers.
lead_paragraph: TRYING to glean differences among the generations makes for an interesting parlor game. But this week, three reports by big financial institutions offered insights into how investors in their 40s and 20s — known as Generation X and Generation Y — think about their personal finances in the broadest way.

headline: Ratatouille That Takes a Delicate Touch
abstract: Grilling adds a smoky nuance to the finished dish without overpowering the essential flavors of vegetables, olive oil and herbs.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to ratatouille, there is no shortage of recipes. There’s the traditional, time-consuming kind in which you sauté all the vegetables separately, then stew them together slowly in a casserole. There’s the shortcut method of simmering everything at once. There’s roasted ratatouille, microwaved ratatouille and even steamed ratatouille, though that one doesn’t tempt me at all.

headline: The House Republicans’ Ghoulish Defunding Rally
abstract: The party atmosphere was boisterous. It was easy to forget everyone in the room had just voted to keep millions of people from getting health insurance.
lead_paragraph: There was something ghoulish about the rally that House Republicans held today in the Rayburn Room after they voted to defund health care reform. The party atmosphere was so boisterous, the cheers and laughter so loud, that it was easy to forget everyone in the room had just voted to keep tens of millions of people from getting health insurance.

headline: The Week in Pictures for Sept. 20
abstract: Subjects include a fire on the Jersey Shore, prayers at the grave of the Lubavitcher Rebbe in Queens, and vote counting in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Subjects include a fire on the Jersey Shore, prayers at the grave of the Lubavitcher Rebbe in Queens, and vote counting in Brooklyn.

headline: Opting to Blow the Whistle or Choosing to Walk Away
abstract: Many employees are using their companies’ ethics procedures to report misdeeds, but the outcome is sometimes not what they expected or hoped.
lead_paragraph: WHISTLE-BLOWERS have been big news lately — from Chelsea Manning, formerly known as Pfc. Bradley Manning, to Edward J. Snowden. Yet, for most people, the question of whether to expose unethical or illegal activities at work doesn’t make headlines or involve state secrets.

headline: Morgan Museum to Make Its Entire Collection of Drawings Available Online
abstract: The Morgan Library and Museum said Friday that it planned to digitize its entire drawings collection, containing more than 10,000 images, including works by Michelangelo, Leonardo and Dürer.
lead_paragraph: The Morgan Library and Museum announced Friday that it planned to digitize its entire drawings collection, one of the most important in the world, containing works from the 14th through the 21st centuries by masters like Michelangelo, Leonardo, Dürer, Rembrandt and Cézanne.

headline: A Wonderland Indeed
abstract: “Beauty in Wonderland” is an event coordinated by Italian Vogue and P&G Global Prestige, with a show that was ostensibly designed to highlight beauty products and their connection to nature.
lead_paragraph: “Ooh, it’s chiaroscuro,” said Cate Blanchett, her face half lighted by a television camera in an otherwise dark atrium of the 15th-century Palazzo Casa degli Atellani. She was wearing a fitted white dress with a skirt of red feathers from Prabal Gurung’s latest resort collection (look No. 37, actually), for the opening of a very short-term exhibition here called “Beauty in Wonderland.” (It is open to the public only on Friday.)

headline: The Arsenic in Our Drinking Water
abstract: Long famed for its homicidal toxicity at high doses, a number of studies suggest that arsenic is an astonishingly versatile poison, able to do damage even at low doses.
lead_paragraph: The baby with the runny nose, the infant with a stubborn cough — respiratory infections in small children are a familiar family travail. Now scientists suspect that these ailments — and many others far more severe — may be linked in part to a toxic element common in drinking water.

headline: When Trying to Follow Rules Isn’t Enough
keywords: ['Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: As JPMorgan’s general counsel, Stephen Cutler tried to create a culture of compliance. The effort couldn’t stop the “London whale” matter and other regulatory woes.
lead_paragraph: As the Securities and Exchange Commission’s chief of enforcement from 2001 to 2005, the era of landmark fraud settlements with Enron, WorldCom and Tyco, Stephen M. Cutler earned a reputation as a tough and, at times, feared regulator. He was particularly dismayed by chief executives, chief financial officers, general counsels and compliance officials who, even if not directly implicated in wrongdoing, created a culture in which it was ignored, tolerated, or even worse, tacitly encouraged.

headline: Anglicans Name First Female Bishop in Ireland
abstract: The Rev. Pat Storey, 53, a married mother of two, will serve as the bishop of Meath and Kildare, in the Church of Ireland.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Anglicans on Friday appointed their first female bishop in the United Kingdom and Ireland. The Rev. Pat Storey, 53, a married mother of two, will serve as the bishop of Meath and Kildare, in the Church of Ireland. Born in Belfast, she previously served as rector of St. Augustine’s Church in Londonderry, Northern Ireland. Anglican churches in Wales and Scotland, like the Church of Ireland, have the power to appoint women as bishops but have not yet used it; the Anglican Church of England is expected to permit the appointment of female bishops soon.

headline: Shooting a Story on a Window Cleaner
keywords: ['Photography', 'Video Recordings and Downloads', 'Windows', 'Cleaning Services', 'Cleansers, Detergents and Soaps']
abstract: David Frank, a New York Times videojournalist, gives a glimpse of what he went through in shooting a story about a window cleaner in New York City.
lead_paragraph: David Frank, a New York Times videojournalist, gives a glimpse of what he went through in shooting a story about a window cleaner in New York City.

headline: In Conversation | Pharrell Williams and Daniel Arsham on Memory, Creativity and the Casio MT-500 Keyboard
abstract: In a partnership of talented multihyphenates, the musician-producer and the artist-architect teamed up on a sculptural project that, in its own way, bends time.
lead_paragraph: Besides being a preternaturally gifted songwriter, musician and producer, Pharrell Williams is one of the great collaborators of our time. Perhaps most famously, there’s his partnership with Chad Hugo as the Neptunes, the production duo that defined the sound of hip-hop and R&B in the late ’90s and early ’00s. He has also designed accessories for Louis Vuitton, created sculpture with Takashi Murakami and teamed with Nigo, the founder of A Bathing Ape, on several clothing lines. And of course Williams teamed up with other musicians on two of the biggest songs of the summer — “Get Lucky” with Daft Punk and “Blurred Lines” with Robin Thicke.

headline: Life and Death in New Orleans: Sheri Fink Talks About ‘Five Days at Memorial’
abstract: Ms. Fink’s book is a detailed look at the chaos in a New Orleans hospital during and after Hurricane Katrina.
lead_paragraph: One of the most compelling stories to emerge from the devastation in New Orleans after Hurricane Katrina involved the death of several patients at the city’s Memorial Medical Center, which had lost power during the storm. Authorities investigated whether some of those patients, who were found to have elevated levels of morphine, had been euthanized by desperate and exhausted doctors. Sheri Fink won a Pulitzer Prize for her coverage of the events at Memorial in a 2009 joint assignment for ProPublica and The New York Times Magazine. In “Five Days at Memorial,” Ms. Fink greatly expands the story, reconstructing the crisis at the hospital and the complicated legal and ethical questions that followed in its wake. In his review for The Times, Jason Berry called the book “social reporting of the first rank.” In a recent e-mail interview, Ms. Fink discussed the chaos at Memorial, how she pieced her story together, whether we’re better prepared for the next disaster, and more. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation:

headline: Emmys Watch: Robert Carlock on ’30 Rock’
abstract: Robert Carlock, nominated for an Emmy for writing “30 Rock,” explains why he’s better heard and not seen on TV.
lead_paragraph: Say “30 Rock” and odds are that most viewers think about Tina Fey. But where would she be without Robert Carlock: friend, writer, show runner and self-described setup man?

headline: Inter Milan Said to Near Sale of Big Stake
abstract: The Italian soccer club says it is about to sell a stake to the Indonesian businessman Erick Thohir, who also owns part of the Philadelphia 76ers and the United States soccer team D.C. United.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — To compete against each other, the world’s most powerful soccer clubs have to be willing to spend big.

headline: How to Take a Compliment Like a Rock Star
abstract: Oasis demonstrates rock attitude in Thomas Beller’s memorable 1997 article in Spin magazine.
lead_paragraph: Among the many pleasures of Russell Brand’s diatribe in The Guardian against the fashion-media industrial complex is the Noel Gallagher cameo. (Appraising Brand’s wardrobe, Gallagher says to him, “Does Rod Stewart know you’re going through his jumble?”) It brought back to mind the excellent quotability of the Gallagher brothers (here’s an interview we did with Noel in 2011) and in particular a memorable profile of their former band Oasis that Tom Beller wrote for Spin magazine in 1997, at the height of their fame. Traveling around with a rock band hardly rates as a tough journalistic assignment, but Beller more than had his hands full dealing with their stratospheric rock attitude, best exemplified by this classic exchange:

headline: Nothing Like a Fight Song at Nebraska
abstract: Nebraska’s marching band is a big part of the game-day experience in Lincoln.
lead_paragraph: Nebraska’s marching band is a big part of the game-day experience in Lincoln.

headline: Divorce After 50 Grows More Common
keywords: ['Divorce, Separations and Annulments', 'Weddings and Engagements', 'Baby Boomers']
abstract: For the first time, more Americans 50 and older are divorced than widowed.
lead_paragraph: So much for “till death do us part.” For the first time, more Americans 50 and older are divorced than widowed, and the numbers are growing as baby boomers live longer. Sociologists call them gray divorcees.

headline: Weekend Wheels Calendar
abstract: From a gathering of Chevrolet Corvairs in Long Island to a cruise along a California stretch of Route 66, there will be plenty going on this weekend to keep automotive enthusiasts busy.
lead_paragraph: A bite-size sampling of concours, cruise nights, auctions, club races and other upwellings of car culture happening across America this weekend.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Professor in Chief
abstract: A. Scott Berg discusses his new biography of Woodrow Wilson.
lead_paragraph: In The New York Times Book Review, Kevin Baker reviews A. Scott Berg’s new biography of Woodrow Wilson. Mr. Baker writes:

headline: Seeing Nebraska Football Anew, Behind a Trombone
abstract: Weeks of practice prepared him for the marching band’s performance, but not for playing in front of that crowd.
lead_paragraph: I waited in the mouth of a tunnel beneath the concrete bleachers of Nebraska’s Memorial Stadium. Rocking side to side on the soles of my shoes, I focused on the rhythm of my breathing and scanned the stands, watching them fill, one red pixel at a time. A dream of mine was about to come true.

headline: Navy Hearing in Rape Case Raises Alarm
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Courts-Martial', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: A case at the Naval Academy illuminates what critics say is wrong with trying sexual assault cases in the current military justice system, which is under scrutiny in Congress.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For roughly 30 hours over several days, defense lawyers for three former United States Naval Academy football players grilled a female midshipman about her sexual habits. In a public hearing, they asked the woman, who has accused the three athletes of raping her, whether she wore a bra, how wide she opened her mouth during oral sex and whether she had apologized to another midshipman with whom she had intercourse “for being a ho.”

headline: Why We Like Sad Music
abstract: The emotions that we feel when listening to sad music differ from those that we perceive, a study shows.
lead_paragraph: SADNESS is an emotion we usually try to avoid. So why do we choose to listen to sad music?

headline: Pakistan to Free a Taliban Commander
abstract: Pakistani officials portrayed the release of one of the founding members of the Taliban as a good-will gesture that would help bring the Taliban and Afghanistan to the negotiating table.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — The Pakistani government said Friday that it would release a senior Taliban commander on Saturday to facilitate peace talks in neighboring Afghanistan.

headline: Swaggering Up to the Barista
abstract: At Starbucks guns aren’t welcome, but they’re not banned outright, either.
lead_paragraph: The Starbucks coffee chain, facing increased complaints for tolerating customers who are openly and legally packing guns, is trying a different policy blend: Guns are not welcome, yet they’re not banned outright either. Kindly don’t tote them into the stores, goes the new approach, but if you do, we’ll serve you as ever with a smile.

headline: A Celebration of Fermentation
abstract: The Fermentation Fest in Wisconsin will include classes, beekeeping advice, and a driving tour with art installations and performances.
lead_paragraph: “Fermentation is transformation, whether it’s from grain to beer, or cabbage to kimchi, or one sort of community to another,” said Donna Neuwirth, the founder with her partner, Jay Salinas, of the Fermentation Fest — A Live Culture Convergence in Reedsburg, Wis.

headline: Events in New Jersey
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: On the Market in New York City
abstract: A two-bedroom in Central Harlem; a three-bedroom Upper West Side condop; and a one-bedroom in Carroll Gardens.
lead_paragraph: A two-bedroom in Central Harlem; a three-bedroom Upper West Side condop; and a one-bedroom in Carroll Gardens.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Luminous and Tanned Skin at Etro
keywords: ['Cosmetics and Toiletries', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Milan Fashion Week']
abstract: Charlotte Tilbury created the slightly sun-kissed look, an ode to the supermodel Gisele Bundchen, with a minimal amount of products but a healthy dose of tinted powder.
lead_paragraph: Lightly tanned and luminous skin was the makeup artist Charlotte Tilbury’s main goal backstage at Etro’s spring show this morning in Milan. “It’s a healthy, glowy feeling,” said Tilbury, likening the effect to Gisele Bundchen’s skin tone. “To create it, we applied a little bit of concealer where needed, lip conditioner by M.A.C. Cosmetics on the lips and a brown creamy eye shadow all around the eyelids with a little bit of eye gloss.” She finished the face with a touch of brown mascara on the top lashes and a healthy brushing of M.A.C.’s mineralize powder in a warm shade all over the face.

headline: Events on Long Island
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Auto Leases Entice, but They’re Still Costly
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Consumer Behavior', 'Used Cars', 'Automobile Renting and Leasing']
abstract: A car lease may seem like a steal, but it still costs several thousands more than buying a new car, not to mention a newish used car.
lead_paragraph: When you can drive a car off the lot with that new car smell for a mere $199- or $299-a month-lease, many consumers can’t help asking: How can I afford not to take this deal?

headline: BlackBerry to Cut 40% of Work Force After Big Loss
abstract: The embattled smartphone maker said it would report a quarterly loss between $950 million and $995 million next week, mainly the result of a writeoff of unsold phones and restructuring charges.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — At their peak, just a few years ago, BlackBerry smartphones were symbols of corporate and political power. When President Obama took office he made keeping his BlackBerry a personal priority, and when BlackBerry service had a hiccup so did business on Wall Street.

headline: Fear, Pain and Loneliness Have Their Place in Children’s Books
abstract: Danger, whether real or metaphorical, will always appeal to children. As hard truths are expressed, the characters find resilience.
lead_paragraph: When my 9-year-old son picked up Guy Delisle’s graphic novel “Jerusalem” at Brooklyn’s Bergen Street Comics, I first said no. Wouldn’t it be too disturbingly realistic, showcasing the region’s turmoil and bloodshed? “Any sex?” I asked the guy at the counter. “No,” he said. I flipped through the book. The minimalist illustrations and the gentle man (Mr. Delisle) living a year abroad were understated. The turmoil was expressed through the insidiousness of security checkpoints, closed border crossings and distant bombings. Sold.

headline: Clever Quips? Better Left Unsaid to Celebrities
abstract: It’s impolite to stare at celebrities, and it’s dangerous to try to separate yourself from the herd by saying something memorable.
lead_paragraph: I WAS WALKING ALONG a twilit Hudson River the other night, distracted by how gobs of blackened chewing gum can make a sidewalk look leopard-spotted, when an even more vivid sight caught my eye. I saw a flutter of excitement ripple through a row of 15 or so people sitting on park benches along the water. The flutter was like a seated, nonstadium version of the “Wave,” and led to isolated pockets of chittering and simulations of postcoital languor.

headline: On the Market in the Region
abstract: A Tudor in Yonkers with five bedrooms and a contemporary home in Suffolk County set on the Long Island Sound.
lead_paragraph: A Tudor in Yonkers with five bedrooms and a contemporary home in Suffolk County set on the Long Island Sound.

headline: S.E.C. Charges Ex-Akamai Executive in Galleon Insider Trading Case
abstract: Federal securities regulators on Friday identified the employee inside Akamai Technologies who was the source of a tip to the hedge fund manager Raj Rajaratnam of the Galleon Group.
lead_paragraph: In July 2008, Danielle Chiesi called her friend and fellow hedge fund manager Raj Rajaratnam. She could barely contain her excitement about a tip she had gotten about Akamai Technologies.

headline: Ale to the Chief
keywords: ['Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'Bars and Nightclubs', 'Restaurants', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: Touring East Coast spots on a presidential pub crawl makes for a history lesson that goes down easy.
lead_paragraph: Presidents Kennedy, Nixon and Clinton walked into a bar. This is no joke. The bar is Martin’s Tavern in Washington, and it serves an above-average pot roast.

headline: It’s Not What You Wear, It’s How You Dance in It
abstract: New York City Ballet’s Fall Gala paired each of its choreographers with a different fashion designer.
lead_paragraph: For the second year in a row, New York City Ballet has allied with high fashion for its fall gala. Last time, the costume designs were by Valentino, and the reviews of the event mostly described it as an artistic fiasco or insignificant. (I missed it.) By those standards, this recent program, at the David H. Koch Theater on Thursday, was a vast improvement. Only one part of the evening was apt to give you bad dreams.

headline: Eating in Silver City, N.M.
abstract: Though the town is small and relatively isolated, its food scene has become a draw.
lead_paragraph: Though the town is small and relatively isolated, its food scene has become a draw.

headline: Looking for Big Flavors in a Small New Mexico Town
abstract: Silver City, an old mining town in the southwestern corner of the state, has seen its creative spirit extend to the local food scene.
lead_paragraph: You know you’re in for something good when a man with a tiny plastic spoon asks conspiratorially: “Have you tried the cherries jubilee? It’s what got me into the biz.”

headline: Obama Criticizes Congress After Vote
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Speaking at a Ford plant hours after House Republicans passed a stopgap bill that would strip funding for his health care law, the president said Congress was focused on politics and not on Americans.
lead_paragraph: Speaking at a Ford plant hours after House Republicans passed a stopgap bill that would strip funding for his health care law, the president said Congress was focused on politics and not on Americans.

headline: Greenpeace Turns Arctic Face-Off Into Instant Ad
abstract: Just hours after the arrest of two Greenpeace activists for boarding an oil rig in Russia’s Arctic waters, the environmental group was using footage of the confrontation in a Web advertisement.
lead_paragraph: As my colleagues Steven Lee Myers and Andrew Roth reported, Russian security forces seized a ship owned by Greenpeace in remote northern waters on Thursday, a day after two of the environmental group’s activists were detained for boarding an oil rig to protest drilling in the Arctic by the state-controlled energy giant Gazprom.

headline: As the Camera Is My Witness
abstract: Legal experts say that it is legal to record others with a dashboard cam, but there are exceptions.
lead_paragraph: In the event of a traffic accident, a dashboard video recorder could save you a hefty repair bill — provided you’re not at fault.

headline: Found, a Soul Mate
abstract: Two yoga teachers marry in a ceremony overlooking the sea, in Montauk, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: People describe Erika Halweil, a longtime yoga teacher in the Hamptons, as someone who has a lot of backbone in every way. She has great posture. She rarely gets upset over things like parking tickets or bad-hair days. (Naturally pretty, she probably doesn’t have many.) She is sometimes stern but never shy.

headline: 3 Favorite Journeys on a Bike
abstract: Cycle around western Ireland, Paris and Lake Champlain as three writers take you along on their favorite bike rides.
lead_paragraph: For many cyclists, riding a bike is a kind of heaven. You’re simply a body breathing clean air and having very few thoughts. That’s the meditative side. It does not hurt that the sport is kind to the knees. That’s the non-load-bearing, exertive side. Then there are the fans who like to mosey, the leisurely bike riders. No spandex or clocking speed for them. They don’t pay attention to the miles. It’s just the wind in their faces, and the tranquillity and peace that they feel. With the advent of fall, three writers tell us about their favorite bike journeys, from a beloved route along rolling fields and Lake Champlain in Vermont and upstate New York to a ride in the wild green countryside of western Ireland and a night ride in Paris.

headline: Weekend Reading: For JPMorgan, Trouble Still Looms
abstract: Even after approving $1 billion in fines and an admission of wrongdoing, the board of JPMorgan Chase is confronting more regulatory problems.
lead_paragraph: Even after approving $1 billion in fines and an admission of wrongdoing, the board of JPMorgan Chase is confronting more regulatory problems.

headline: Oracle Charges Past Kiwis
abstract: Team New Zealand needed one more victory to defeat Oracle Team USA in the America’s Cup, but the wind was not on their side.
lead_paragraph: Team New Zealand needed one more victory to defeat Oracle Team USA in the America’s Cup, but the wind was not on their side.

headline: The Measure of Our Poverty
abstract: While the official formula for measuring the number of Americans in poverty may be outdated, alternative methods would put the share of Americans in poverty even higher.
lead_paragraph: How poor have we become?

headline: Hate-Reading: Love to Loathe You, Baby
abstract: Making yourself feel better by hate-reading over-the-top postings on social media.
lead_paragraph: Jillian Sanders frequently visits the Facebook page of a high-school classmate she hasn’t talked to in years. But these drop-ins, more like recon missions, are not entirely pleasant.

headline: The Defunct Westbury Theater Gets a Makeover
abstract: The Space at Westbury, the renovated former Westbury Theater, is outfitted with plush seating, massive chandeliers, Italian tile and six bars.
lead_paragraph: Cyrus Hakakian has a soft spot for ’80s rock.

headline: Tools & Toolkits
abstract: Last night, we hosted three great talks on tools and toolkits.
lead_paragraph: Last night, we hosted three great talks on tools and toolkits. Adam Lehman gave us an overview of Adobe’s open source code editor Brackets and encouraged everyone in the room to contribute.

headline: Daria Strokous Transforms Backstage at Versace
abstract: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Spring 2014 Fashion Week in Milan.

headline: Breaded and Fried Cutlets Can’t Miss
abstract: A slice of meat or poultry coated in bread crumbs and fried is delicious by any name: cutlet, chicken-fried steak, schnitzel or Milanesa.
lead_paragraph: What is it about a breaded and fried slice of meat that is so cross-culturally endearing? Call it a cutlet, call it chicken-fried steak. Call it schnitzel or Milanesa or cotoletta alla Milanese; everybody loves it the world around. Use beef, veal or pork. Or use chicken or turkey. It’s all good.
