abstract: The American car scene is growing in England, on the streets and on the track.
lead_paragraph: The American car scene is growing in England, on the streets and on the track.

headline: Press Release of the Week: Posted Without Comment
abstract: Wonder Bread is back. Yay?

headline: Syria Meets First Test of Accord on Weapons
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: The government of President Bashar al-Assad made an “initial declaration” of the chemical weapons it possesses.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A senior Obama administration official said Friday that the United States was encouraged by the initial inventory that the Syrian government had submitted of its chemical weapons arsenal.

headline: Review: 2014 Honda Odyssey
abstract: A Shop-Vac that retails for $45,280? Fortunately, a new 2014 Honda Odyssey Touring Elite van is included. Tom Voelk discovers that the built-in vacuum has the power to keep up with 5-year-old twins.
lead_paragraph: A Shop-Vac that retails for $45,280? Fortunately, a new 2014 Honda Odyssey Touring Elite van is included. Tom Voelk discovers that the built-in vacuum has the power to keep up with 5-year-old twins.

headline: The Best Way to Drink at a Tailgate
abstract: Beer is obvious. But why not add a thermos of Brandy Alexanders?
lead_paragraph: First, a confession: I’ve never tailgated. Not once. The closest I’ve come, I guess, is another quintessentially American experience: hanging out for hours in stadium parking lots before Grateful Dead shows. But the ubiquitous veggie chili and falafel and, yes, tofu hot dogs I ate back in those days bear little resemblance to Sam Sifton’s meaty brisket-and-brats feast.

headline: That Trail of Crumbs Ends at the Minivan
abstract: Fuel economy and safety are improved in the new Honda Odyssey, but exterior changes to the fourth-generation minivan are so subtle they practically fall into the “if you say so” category.
lead_paragraph: WOLFEBORO, N.H. — When it came time to update its popular Odyssey minivan for 2014, Honda opted not to make a clean sweep: it just tidied up around the edges.

headline: Real Estate Q & A
keywords: ['Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Condominiums']
abstract: Subjects include co-op rules about visitors; lease renewal; and the rights of renters when buildings convert to condominiums.
lead_paragraph: When Family and Friends Visit

headline: Versace: Spring 2014 RTW
abstract: Milan
lead_paragraph: Milan

headline: Not So Much Math as Chemistry
abstract: “Proof,” at the McCarter Theater Center, is more concerned with the value of trust in relationships than with proving some mind-boggling equation that changes the world’s understanding of the cosmos.
lead_paragraph: The math-averse may not be drawn initially to “Proof,” the David Auburn play that is being presented by McCarter Theater Center in Princeton. It is, at least superficially, about advanced math and mathematicians.

headline: Oh, the Vanity: Left-Right Divide Persists in Interior Mirrors
abstract: Vanity mirrors have become common, and most vehicles have them. But why do some cars have them only above the passenger seat?
lead_paragraph: Once marketed “for milady” and available only for passengers, vanity mirrors now come on both the left and right sunvisors of most vehicles sold in the United States. Among the 2,192 trim levels offered on 2013-model cars and trucks, dual visor mirrors are standard on 81 percent, according to Chrome Data Solutions, a Portland, Ore., company that provides vehicle descriptions for online shopping tools.

headline: A Just-in-Case Provision for Incidents on the Road
abstract: Dashboard video cameras can protect drivers in the event of a crash by recording who was at fault.
lead_paragraph: Runaway 18-wheelers, death-defying motorcyclists and vehicular acrobatics that seem to defy the laws of physics have become a staple of YouTube, in large part a result of the availability of dashboard video cameras. It’s all entertaining, but there are also practical reasons for recording while driving.

headline: No Retrial in ’95 Bronx Killing for 3 Freed From Prison
abstract: One of two cases in which the men were convicted fell apart after others confessed, and some evidence in the other was contaminated by Hurricane Sandy flooding.
lead_paragraph: Three men convicted of murdering a Federal Express executive in 1995 have been free since January, when a judge in the Bronx ordered them released from prison after  vacating their sentences. But it was not until Friday, when a prosecutor said her office would not seek to retry them in the case, that they learned that they were truly rid of the charge.

headline: Wake Up, Be Funny, Do It Again 999 Times
abstract: The comedian Sammy Obeid has performed for 1,000 consecutive days. Is this the way to get good at telling jokes?
lead_paragraph: If Sammy Obeid has learned one thing from performing stand-up for 1,000 consecutive days, it’s to embrace his inner robot.

headline: Characters on ‘Veep’ Become Shorthand for Washington Types
abstract: The on-screen characters in “Veep” have managed to capture a subset of Washington’s striving population.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When a friend invited Teal Pennebaker to a party in the nation’s capital, Ms. Pennebaker had just one question: “I asked her, ‘Will there be a lot of Jonahs there?’ ” she said.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Gaza and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from the Gaza Strip, the Philippines, Germany and South Africa.
lead_paragraph: Photos from the Gaza Strip, the Philippines, Germany and South Africa.

headline: And BlackBerrys Make 6
abstract: On Sundays, John Feinblatt and Jonathan Mintz, whom Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg married in a ceremony at Gracie Mansion in 2011, try to give their BlackBerrys a rest and savor family time together.
lead_paragraph: Couples who work together can sometimes find themselves with an excess of togetherness. For John Feinblatt, 62, and Jonathan Mintz, 49, who have both worked for Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg since 2002 — Mr. Feinblatt is his chief policy adviser, Mr. Mintz is the city’s commissioner of consumer affairs — that is hardly an issue. They see each other only occasionally during work hours. On Sundays, Mr. Feinblatt and Mr. Mintz (in glasses in photographs), whom Mr. Bloomberg married in a ceremony at Gracie Mansion in 2011, shortly after New York legalized same-sex marriage, try to give their BlackBerrys a rest (at least for short spells) and savor family time together. They live in a house in the West Village with their two daughters, Maeve, 10, whose nickname is Maisie, and Georgia, 8, and two dogs, a golden retriever, Tully, and a Havanese, Molly.

headline: Head of NBC Entertainment Extends Contract to 2017
abstract: Robert Greenblatt, who was put in charge by Comcast in 2011,  has had some successes like “The Voice” as well as fallow periods.
lead_paragraph: NBC quietly renewed the contract of its chief entertainment executive, Robert Greenblatt, extending his deal with the network until 2017.

headline: Icy White Synapses in a Crackling Heat
abstract: Liz Gerring’s “Glacier” had its world premiere on Thursday at Montclair State University’s Alexander Kasser Theater.
lead_paragraph: MONTCLAIR, N.J. — “Glacier,” an enthralling and important new dance work lasting 60 minutes, by the choreographer Liz Gerring, abounds in arresting contradictions. The dancers look relaxed and galvanized. They hurl themselves into impetuous slides, skim across the stage in nimble footwork, push their way urgently backward on all fours, shimmer in turning or bobbing jumps — and yet, amid the formal structures, always keep an informal quality, never letting the steps acquire any veneer of academicism. Steps look natural, athletic and exploratory — even when they then come around a second or third time with other dancers. The work has wit without quirkiness, passion without emotionalism: its moods change like the weather, and its ebbs and flows carry aspects of poetry and excitement.

headline: Beauty Pageants Draw Social Media Critics
abstract: The pageants once again are platforms for protest, some of it inflammatory.
lead_paragraph: “Miss America victory marred by racist slurs.” — Time, Sept. 16

headline: Amid Violence, Returning to Elections in Sri Lanka After a Void
abstract: The house of a Tamil candidate in the first provincial elections in 25 years was attacked on Thursday, according to the accounts of several witnesses.
lead_paragraph: JAFFNA, Sri Lanka — The thugs first appeared around 11:20 on Thursday night, a dozen or so men lurking outside her house. Two wore army uniforms.

headline: A Jazzman Swinging to Rhapsody and Back
abstract: For “Ahmad Jamal and Wynton Marsalis” at Jazz at Lincoln Center, Mr. Jamal, 83, a jazz pianist, had a broad repertory to choose from.
lead_paragraph: As the pianist Ahmad Jamal and the members of the Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra took their bows at the Rose Theater on Thursday night, someone in the crowd filed a simple but urgent request. “Poinciana!” he shouted against the applause. “Poinciana!” he shouted again, hoarsely. “Poinciana! Poinciana! Poinciana!” Eventually reality set in: the house lights went up, and the audience began to file toward the doors.

headline: Iconic Driving Moccasins From Tod’s, With Playful New Detailing
abstract: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway. Today’s pick: classic shoes from the venerable Italian brand, updated to incorporate one of the season’s hottest trends.
lead_paragraph: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: The Backlash to the American Invasion of the Booker Prize
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Man Booker Prize', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: Next year, the Man Booker Prize will be open to any work originally written in English and published in Britain, bringing concerns that American novels will dominate.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Americans are coming, and the British literary world is not happy.

headline: Pretty but Unwelcome
abstract: The Oriental Bittersweet, a nonnative vine covered in beautiful orange and yellow berries, looks at home in autumn centerpieces but wreaks havoc upon habitats.
lead_paragraph: Thick, twining and handsome, Oriental bittersweet (Celastrus orbiculata) has been introduced into countless gardens since the mid-19th century. In the wet dark weather of fall, the vine covers itself with orange and yellow berries. Some sources claim it is these strongly contrasting berries from which bittersweet derives its name. Whatever the source, every autumn I find myself lamenting that “bittersweet” more perfectly describes the ecological havoc that this beautiful nonnative plant wreaks upon habitats so far from its home in China, Japan and Korea.

headline: Online Book Clubs: Talk That Stays on the Page
keywords: ['Book Clubs', 'Books and Literature', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Once thought impersonal, online book clubs may be more serious than get-togethers in somebody’s living room.
lead_paragraph: When NBC announced recently that “Today” would host a book club featuring online discussion groups, I thought it was a fine idea.

headline: Two New Wars on Terror on the ‘Homeland’ Front
abstract: Two of the better new network dramas this season — “Hostages” on CBS, and “The Blacklist” on NBC, both starting on Monday — center on government secrets, betrayal and a heroine.
lead_paragraph: It could be because of Edward J. Snowden. But it’s more likely the influence of “Homeland.”

headline: Tim Russert, 1950-2008
abstract: The longtime host of “Meet the Press” died at the age of 58.
lead_paragraph: The longtime host of “Meet the Press” died at the age of 58.

headline: John Baldessari on Tom Waits, Rodarte and a Yodeling Pickle From Damien Hirst
abstract: On the eve of a new show at the Garage Center for Contemporary Art in Moscow, the conceptual art master recounts some of his greatest influences and inspirations.
lead_paragraph: In 1970, when he was already an acclaimed young artist, John Baldessari famously collected and then burned all of his early work, before embarking on a career of radical simplicity. A painting of pure beauty could be just that: a painting of the words “PURE BEAUTY.” Just try to prove him wrong.

headline: Emmys Highlight a Changing TV Industry
abstract: With its first nomination, for “House of Cards,” Netflix makes its mark on the Emmys, but “Breaking Bad” has the most buzz.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The Emmy Awards have witnessed many new players on the red carpet over the years, but there has never been a gate-crasher quite like Netflix.

headline: Williamsburg Waterfront, 1:25 P.M.
abstract: N.Y. See: Guilherme Santos, a resident of Brooklyn for 50 years, relaxed in a park near the East River in Williamsburg on Friday.

headline: With Antonio Monda, It’s Dine, Drink, Discuss
abstract: In his Upper West Side apartment, the Italian writer and filmmaker reigns as host of the city’s liveliest cultural salon.
lead_paragraph: Enough, please, about the cultural “elite,” that all-but-useless category, so baggy it now seems to include practically everyone. No, what we really want to know about are the cultural elect — the famous people other famous people connive to meet.

headline: World Championships in Bali, Indonesia
abstract: The round-robin stage of the world championships in Bali, Indonesia, is just past the halfway mark, 12 of 21 rounds.
lead_paragraph: The round-robin stage of the world championships in Bali, Indonesia, is just past the halfway mark, 12 of 21 rounds. With eight teams to qualify for the quarterfinals, five of the six United States teams are in the top eight.

headline: Pipeline Reopens in Libya, Bolstering Oil Production
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: A striking militia opened the valves on a pipeline between two major western oil fields and Mediterranean port terminals.
lead_paragraph: More than one-third of Libya’s oil production has come back on line in recent days after a striking militia opened the valves on a critical pipeline between two major western oil fields and Mediterranean port terminals outside the capital, Tripoli.

headline: Step Away From the Phone!
abstract: Smartphone addicts are starting to curb the habit.
lead_paragraph: Whenever Michael Carl, the fashion market director at Vanity Fair, goes out to dinner with friends, he plays something called the “phone stack” game: Everyone places their phones in the middle of the table; whoever looks at their device before the check arrives picks up the tab.

headline: Milan Fashion Week: Versace Spring/Summer 2014
abstract: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.

headline: The Mr. Fix-It of Greenwich Village
abstract: Colin Ryan, a Vietnam veteran, is a freelance carpenter in the Village. “I don’t need no pot of gold,” he said, “just enough for beer and cigarettes and subway fare.”
lead_paragraph: He is the Famous Greenwich Village Leprechaun Handyman, or so the small sign on Colin Ryan’s toolbox proclaims.

headline: A Concert Suited for the Kitchen (Watch Out for the Knives, Though)
abstract: Karbido, a band from Wroclaw, Poland, use rudimentary tools to create percussive sounds with international influences at the Brooklyn Academy of Music’s Next Wave Festival.
lead_paragraph: Karbido means “free choice” in Polish, according to the musicians performing in “The Table,”  part of the Brooklyn Academy of Music’s Next Wave Festival. And it’s an appropriate name for this group from Wroclaw, Poland, which at first glance seems to use rudimentary tools — knives, coins, wineglasses, a metal bowl — to create percussive sounds. For visual flavor, a candle appears.

headline: Mao Didn’t Show Up, but Many Other Stars Did
keywords: ['Poetry and Poets', 'Books and Literature', 'Writing and Writers', 'Archives and Records']
abstract: As part of its 75th-anniversary celebration, the 92nd Street Y’s Unterberg Poetry Center digs deep into its archive of rare photographs and correspondence.
lead_paragraph: Almost since its opening in 1939, the 92nd Street Y’s Unterberg Poetry Center has been the Carnegie Hall of American literary life, host to just about everybody who was anybody, and site of more than one dramatic evening. But who knew that the Y once tried to book a poetry reading by Mao Zedong?

headline: What Happened to the Maxim Man?
abstract: Maxim made its name exploiting the market for a kind of adolescent mind-set but has seen some if its success fade.
lead_paragraph: Mark Golin was in his office at the Time-Life Building recently, reflecting on his go-go days as the editor of Maxim magazine in the late 1990s.

headline: White Women in Harlem’s Renaissance
abstract: Books about the white female supporters of Harlem’s cultural renewal; paintings of Central Park; and Fritz Kuhn, the New York Nazi.
lead_paragraph: Carla Kaplan, a professor of American literature at Northeastern University, offers a joint biography of six largely forgotten women (winnowed down from five dozen whom she researched) in “Miss Anne in Harlem: The White Women of the Black Renaissance” (Harper, $28.99).

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: As iPhones Go on Sale, Tim Cook Tweets
abstract: Friday’s highlights from around the Web include reactions to the new iPhones go on sale. Plus, Google revamped its logo, but did anyone notice?
lead_paragraph: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: Friday Night Music: Build Me Up From Bones
abstract: More Sarah Jarosz.
lead_paragraph: I had a good time at the Brookings Panel, which I haven’t attended for a while. But I have to say that in a way it made me feel old. The first panel I attended was to help present this paper (pdf). Back then they didn’t even have individual microphones, and didn’t record the proceedings. Instead, in the middle of the table sat a secretary wearing what looked like a gas mask, repeating everything that was said into a tape recorder.

headline: Answers to Questions About New York
abstract: Questions about the historic significance of Substation 7, and the length of a dog’s leash.
lead_paragraph: Q. The unusual building at 1782 Third Avenue, at 99th Street, is listed as “Substation 7” on the National Register of Historic Places, but I can’t find any information about it. Why is it historic?

headline: Tips for Making the Change to iOS 7
abstract: For many, switching to iOS 7, Apple’s latest operating system, is a shock. Here are a couple of simple tips that will help make the transition easier.
lead_paragraph: In the television show Extreme Home Makeover, people go away for a nice quiet weekend with their family and return to discover that their house has been completely renovated. Their favorite old, ragged, puffy couch has now replaced with a sleek designer slab of gray foam. Their favorite lamp has been swapped out for an obscure designer lighting system. Usually, it’s a shocking transition.

headline: After Hours | A Starry, Stilted Tribute to Édith Piaf
abstract: At the first stateside edition of the popular French festival Francofolies, on the Upper West Side, performers like Harry Connick Jr. and Beth Ditto tried to capture the spirit of the legendary chanteuse.

headline: Stuart Weitzman Likes to Think Big
keywords: ['Milan Fashion Week', 'Shoes and Boots', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: When he decided to open an “international flagship,” Mr. Weitzman wanted it to make a statement, that he was right up there with Gucci and Prada.
lead_paragraph: MILAN — When Stuart Weitzman decided to close his shoe box of a store on the Via della Spiga here and open a fancy new “international flagship” in the heart of Milan’s shopping district, he had three architects in mind: Frank Gehry, Santiago Calatrava or Zaha Hadid.

headline: Green Parking: Not Just a Concept Anymore
abstract: New technology is making vehicle parking faster, more compact and less harmful to the environment.
lead_paragraph: Parking, whether in lots or garages, is benefiting from some fresh thinking these days, thanks to new technology and creative ideas that can both save operators money and reduce carbon footprints. Parking operators are also addressing the need for publicly available electric vehicle charging in New York and other cities, though it’s not widely installed yet.

abstract: The right-leaning United Kingdom Independence Party has removed Godfrey Bloom as its whip.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The right-leaning populist party that has sent tremors through British politics sustained a self-inflicted setback on Friday when a senior official was disciplined after jokingly referring to women as “sluts” and hitting a television reporter on the head with a party document.

headline: BlackBerry Co-Founder Is Said to Consider Bid for Company
abstract: Mike Lazaridis, a co-founder of BlackBerry, has separately approached the Blackstone Group and the Carlyle Group about making an offer, according to people familiar with the matter.
lead_paragraph: Mike Lazaridis, the co-founder of BlackBerry who stepped down as co-chief executive in 2012, has reached out to private equity firms about a possible bid for the troubled company.

headline: Furs, Worthy of Their Close-Up
abstract: The exhibition “Making Dreams: Fendi and the Cinema” illuminates Fendi’s long history of making furs for the movies, but also leaves you feeling that you have been inside a movie.
lead_paragraph: Fendi is based in Rome, where the legendary movie studio Cinecittà is. And many directors have lived or worked in Rome. So it makes sense that the house of Fendi, which turns 90 in 2015, should have a long history of making furs for the movies.

headline: The Final Data Report of Bloomberg’s Tenure
abstract: Among the varied statistics noted in the Mayor’s Management Report is the roughly one-third decrease in civilian fire fatalities.
lead_paragraph: The number of civilian fire fatalities in New York City dropped drastically last year, with roughly one-third fewer deaths than in the previous year, according to a report issued by the Bloomberg administration on Friday.

headline: Witness for the Prosecution
keywords: ['Mental Health and Disorders', 'Witnesses', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Courts and the Judiciary']
abstract: Dr. William B. Barr, a psychologist, has worked for the prosecution in more than 100 cases, frequently testifying that defendants have exaggerated mental impairments.
lead_paragraph: After hours of harsh questioning from a defense lawyer, the psychologist testifying for prosecutors twisted ever so slightly in the witness stand.

headline: With His Remarks on Sexual Morality, a Surprise Pope Keeps on Surprising
abstract: Some think Pope Francis may be trying to shake up the Vatican hierarchy and prepare the ground for a more fundamental shift in the direction of the church.
lead_paragraph: ROME — From the moment he was introduced to the huge crowds waiting for a new pope in the rain at St. Peter’s Square, Pope Francis has been a surprise. People gasped when his name was called out. He was 76, seemingly another rigid conservative, not the younger, dynamic figure many Catholics had hoped for.

headline: American Resistance Member Is Honored in Berlin
keywords: ['World War II (1939-45)', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era']
abstract: Arvid Harnack and Mildred Fish-Harnack — the latter the only American civilian executed on the direct order of Hitler — fought far-right extremism in Germany.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The man in the floppy hat and khaki vest was on his knees, pounding two small, brass-plated bricks into the wet sidewalk. One bore the name Arvid Harnack, the other of Mr. Harnack’s wife, Mildred Fish-Harnack — the only American civilian to be executed on the direct order of Adolf Hitler.

headline: Showdown in Arizona Over ‘Most Western’ Motto
abstract: In a modern-day Western showdown, residents of Cave Creek, Ariz., are challenging its neighbor, Scottsdale, for the title of the West’s most Western Town.
lead_paragraph: CAVE CREEK, Ariz. — A baby buffalo stood guard outside Town Hall, snorting at the approach of three mounted police officers from nearby Scottsdale who had towed their horses here on a trailer.

headline: Pictures From the Week in Business
keywords: ['Empire State Building (Manhattan, NY)', 'Hedge Funds', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: More trouble hit JPMorgan Chase, a possible I.P.O. loomed for the Empire State Building, and the Fed stunned the economic world by delaying its plan to ease its stimulus efforts.
lead_paragraph: More trouble hit JPMorgan Chase, a possible I.P.O. loomed for the Empire State Building, and the Fed stunned the economic world by delaying its plan to ease its stimulus efforts.

headline: U.S. Denies Trying to Bar Venezuelan President From Airspace
abstract: American officials gave permission for President Nicolás Maduro to fly over Puerto Rico  and denied that they had tried to bar Mr. Maduro from United States airspace.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — In the latest diplomatic dispute between the United States and Venezuela, American officials late Thursday gave permission for President Nicolás Maduro to fly over Puerto Rico on his way to a state visit in China and denied angry accusations from Venezuelan officials that the United States had tried to bar Mr. Maduro from its airspace.

headline: Arctic Ice Makes Comeback From Record Low, but Long-Term Decline May Continue
abstract: The sea ice coverage in the Arctic Ocean is 50 percent greater than last year at this time.
lead_paragraph: Sea ice in the Arctic Ocean underwent a sharp recovery this year from the record-low levels of 2012, with 50 percent more ice surviving the summer melt season, scientists said Friday. It is the largest one-year increase in Arctic ice since satellite tracking began in 1978.

headline: To Buy or to Lease
abstract: Over the course of 6 years, the costs of leasing a new car can be almost one-third again as much as buying the same model outright.
lead_paragraph: Over the course of 6 years, the costs of leasing a new car can be almost one-third again as much as buying the same model outright.

headline: Anti-Euro Party Gaining Steam in Germany
abstract: An upstart party, Alternative for Germany, is threatening to shake up the country’s consensus politics with a conservative message.
lead_paragraph: BAD HOMBURG, Germany — Europe has barely been mentioned in the German election campaign. But in the final days before Sunday’s vote, a fringe party that wants to scrap the euro is gaining in the polls, threatening to scramble the country’s consensus politics with a message that has echoes of the Tea Party in America and rightist movements elsewhere in Europe.

headline: A Very Violent Gentleman
keywords: ['Civil War (US) (1861-65)', 'News and News Media', 'Prisoners of War']
abstract: The life and times of Brig. Gen. Daniel W. Adams, who moved between the rarified aristocracy and the violent world of the 19th Century South.
lead_paragraph: On Sept. 20, 1863, the 105th Ohio was advancing through thick woods on the Chickamauga battlefield when one of the regiment’s lieutenants heard loud cries for help interspersed with angry curses. He soon found a blood soaked and exhausted Confederate officer leaning against a tree, trying to fend off several Union soldiers who were apparently robbing him. Years later, the regiment’s historian reported that the rebel “was loading them with imprecations of unique and vigorous character.” Seeing the lieutenant, the thieves retreated, and the Union officer was surprised to discover that he had come to the aid of none other than Brig. Gen. Daniel W. Adams, commander of the Army of Tennessee’s Louisiana Brigade.

headline: Lagerfeld, Analog and Digital
abstract: A review of Milan collections: Fendi, Gucci, Prada, Tod’s, Versace, MaxMara.
lead_paragraph: MILAN — Not too long from now, Karl Lagerfeld will pass a milestone in fashion. He will have spent 50 years at Fendi, designing its fun furs and cerebral ready-to-wear.

headline: A Turnabout at Traditionally White Sororities, in Nine Days at Alabama
keywords: ['Fraternities and Sororities', 'Discrimination', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: After a campus newspaper’s report on discrimination, the president of the University of Alabama said that traditionally white sororities have accepted six minority students.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Nine days after the University of Alabama’s campus newspaper detailed chronic racial discrimination within the campus’s Greek system, the university’s president said on Friday that six minority students had accepted offers of admission to traditionally white sororities.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Getting Real
abstract: The contrast between the commerce of Fashion Week and the imaginatively dressed crowds, armed with cameras, added a festive touch.
lead_paragraph: The contrast between the commerce of Fashion Week and the imaginatively dressed crowds, armed with cameras, added a festive touch.

headline: A Late-Career Legal Niche After the Hussein Trial
abstract: Since presiding over the trial of Saddam Hussein, Munir Haddad has had an unlikely trajectory in private law, and has gotten rich in the process.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — ON a recent afternoon, a pistol lay on Munir Haddad’s coffee table. A television, sound off, played professional wrestling. As a visitor entered he told an assistant to remove the gun, embarrassed by its presence, but then said he is never without a weapon, even in the bathroom.

headline: Israel Should Annul the Oslo Accords
abstract: The government of Israel should declare that the Oslo process has failed. Only then will we have the opportunity to lay the foundations for a more realistic peace.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — THIS month marks 20 years since the signing of the first of the Oslo Accords between the State of Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization. Two decades after Yitzhak Rabin and Yasir Arafat stood on the White House lawn with President Bill Clinton, Israelis and Palestinians are again in the midst of the umpteenth round of negotiations.

headline: Ensuring Team Items Are Just a Click Away
abstract: Fanatics is the nation’s largest online seller of licensed sports merchandise. It includes more than one million items for professional and college teams, conferences and leagues.
lead_paragraph: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. — To measure the popularity and financial heft of the N.F.L., one need only look at the record amounts paid for franchises, the league’s ever-rising television ratings and the astronomical prices for Super Bowl tickets.

headline: Knowing When to Worry
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Federal Budget (US)']
abstract: The government shutdown is only days away, people! Here’s a rundown of what’s to come for you to print out and put on the refrigerator.
lead_paragraph: I know you’re worried about the government shutting down on Oct. 1. Who wouldn’t be? Services suspended, the nation’s credibility damaged in the eyes of the rest of the world. What serious person would want to let that happen?

headline: Oracle’s Next Cloud Moves
abstract: Oracle, the large enterprise software company, will kick off one of the industry’s biggest customer conferences with a lot of news.
lead_paragraph: In a couple of days, Oracle is going to go all in on the cloud, with many new products and features, and a “the customer gets to choose” strategy for how rapidly its buyers make the biggest step in tech in over the last two decades.

headline: Tape No. 54
abstract: The process of writing songs is still mysterious — the tune, the words are rattling around inside me and I just need to locate them.
lead_paragraph: In my song “Ghost Writer” there’s a line “Been writing down these old stories now / about 18 years or so.” Even though I was exaggerating for effect at the time, I wrote the song in 1976, so do the math.

headline: Stricker Is Playing Less but Performing Just as Well
abstract: Steve Stricker made fewer PGA Tour starts in 2013 so he could spend more time with his family, but he still qualified for the Tour Championship and is in seventh place after 36 holes.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Steve Stricker cut his PGA Tour playing schedule nearly in half this year so he could be a more attentive husband and father, and he found that a balanced life was worth pursuing.

headline: In Mexico, Critics Say Political Corruption Worsened Impact of Dual Storms
keywords: ['Hurricanes and Tropical Storms', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Floods']
abstract: The twin storms that tore through the country this week renewed criticism that corruption and political shortsightedness made the damage even worse.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — The twin storms that tore through the country this week, unleashing rains that sent mud crashing down hillsides, buckling roads and flooding coastal cities, have renewed criticism that corruption and political shortsightedness made the damage even worse.

headline: At NPR, a New Host and a Move Westward
abstract: NPR officials have billed a move west as a chance for a legacy radio program, previously based in Washington, to rethink what it is and what it does.
lead_paragraph: CULVER CITY, Calif. — The weekend broadcasts of “All Things Considered” are heading West.

headline: Kamikaze Congress
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Federal Budget (US)']
abstract: For far-right House Republicans, in their fight against Obamacare, it’s their way or no way, all or nothing.
lead_paragraph: Delay and defund. And default.

headline: Distant Violence Shatters a Texas Buddhist Group’s Quiet
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Buddhism', 'Washington Navy Yard Shooting (2013)']
abstract: The man who the authorities say killed 12 people at the Washington Navy Yard once prayed, volunteered and lived among a community of Thai immigrants in Texas.
lead_paragraph: WHITE SETTLEMENT, Tex. — People still gather nightly at the Buddhist temple here, slipping off their shoes and kneeling on the floor of what was once someone’s living room. Their chanting voices slip out the screen door into the muggy Texas night, like the misty sprays of water that keep the patio cool outside.

headline: Jamie Dimon’s Long Day
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Fines (Penalties)']
abstract: How JPMorgan went from hero to goat with government regulators.
lead_paragraph: Thursday was quite the day for JPMorgan Chase and its chief executive, Jamie Dimon.

headline: A Craigslist Ad: Will Pay for Poem
abstract: The ad on Craigslist was eye-catching: $10,000 for a single poem, if it impressed an anonymous lover (lovers?) of the arts.
lead_paragraph: A little while ago, I was browsing Craigslist during one of my many daily breaks from writing. Every sentence or so, I have to do something else. I’m not a Craigslist frequenter, and I wasn’t entirely sure where to look, so I typed in “writer,” and looked at the daily job postings.

headline: Tracking Stolen Art, for Profit, and Blurring a Few Lines
abstract: One of the world’s largest databases of stolen art is held by a private London company that is praised by some and criticized by others for its tactics in trying to recover the works.
lead_paragraph: Early in the morning of May 11, 1987, someone smashed through the glass doors of the Museum of Modern Art in Stockholm, removed a Matisse from a wall and fled.

headline: Biometric Technology Takes Off
keywords: ['Privacy', 'Biometrics', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials']
abstract: Privacy protections lag as business and government use of fingerprinting and facial recognition expands.
lead_paragraph: The use of biological markers like fingerprints, faces and irises to identify people is rapidly moving from science fiction to reality. Apple’s latest iPhone, which went on sale this week, can be unlocked with a fingerprint. Users of Android smartphones can unlock their devices with a glance. And the Department of Homeland Security is developing facial recognition technology that would allow it to pinpoint criminals and suspects in large crowds of people with closed-circuit cameras.

headline: F.B.I. Tries to Trace Last Weeks of Gunman
keywords: ['Washington Navy Yard Shooting (2013)', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: Investigators are parsing the final conversations of Aaron Alexis’s life for any clues to a motive for the Navy Yard shootings.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — F.B.I. analysts are poring through the cellphone and e-mail accounts of Aaron Alexis, the former Navy reservist who the police say killed 12 people at the Washington Navy Yard on Monday.

headline: Stenson Loses Club but Increases Lead
abstract: Henrik Stenson held a four-stroke lead after two rounds of the PGA Tour Championship, despite playing with less than a full complement of clubs.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — This time, Henrik Stenson’s golf bag contained less than a full complement of clubs for 18 holes, rather than just on the final hole.

headline: Ivory Coast: Former First Lady’s Warrant Is Rejected
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: Ivory Coast has decided it will not send Simone Gbagbo, the wife of former President Laurent Gbagbo, to the International Criminal Court to stand trial.
lead_paragraph: In the latest snub to the International Criminal Court by an African government, Ivory Coast has decided it will not send Simone Gbagbo, left, the wife of former President Laurent Gbagbo, to the court in The Hague to stand trial with Mr. Gbagbo on charges of crimes against humanity.

headline: More Gun Deaths, Less Resolve in Washington
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: Both the mayhem and the ritual that follows seem all too predictable.
lead_paragraph: In the aftermath of the gun rampage at the Washington Navy Yard that killed 12 Americans just blocks from Capitol Hill, President Obama expressed dismay that “this becomes a ritual that we go through every three, four months.”

headline: A Lack of Full Accountability
keywords: ['Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Fines (Penalties)', 'Editorials', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Bankers go unnamed and unpunished in JPMorgan Chase’s recent settlements.
lead_paragraph: Having agreed this week to pay $920 million in fines to resolve federal and international investigations into its $6 billion “London Whale” trading loss, JPMorgan Chase has reportedly reached “some closure” in the case and is ready, in the words of its chief executive, Jamie Dimon, to move forward in a process of “simplifying” the bank.

headline: A Literary Club Opens Its Doors
keywords: ['Man Booker Prize', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'Books and Literature', 'Editorials']
abstract: The Man Booker Prize will soon be open to all authors writing in English, regardless of nationality.
lead_paragraph: Lionel Shriver, an American novelist who lives in England, told a reporter recently that she was considering applying for citizenship in her adopted country, in part to be eligible for the Man Booker Prize, which historically has been limited to citizens of the Commonwealth. She may be relieved to learn that she needn’t take the trouble.

headline: Saved by Light Breeze, Oracle Will Race Again
abstract: Oracle Team USA kept the America’s Cup for one more day, pulling away from Emirates Team New Zealand in Race 13. The Kiwis lead, 8-3.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — With a huge lead and the rival skipper Jimmy Spithill swearing at the helm of Oracle Team USA’s yacht, Emirates Team New Zealand looked as if it had finally managed to end a decade of frustration and collective soul-searching to bring the America’s Cup back to the island nation where sailors are superstars.

headline: California Gives Expanded Rights to Noncitizens
keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'Drivers Licenses', 'Citizenship and Naturalization', 'State Legislatures', 'Jury System', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: California is challenging the status of citizenship with measures to let noncitizens sit on juries and monitor polls for elections.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — California is challenging the historic status of American citizenship with measures to permit noncitizens to sit on juries and monitor polls for elections in which they cannot vote and to open the practice of law even to those here illegally. It is the leading edge of a national trend that includes granting drivers’ licenses and in-state tuition to illegal immigrants in some states and that suggests legal residency could evolve into an appealing option should immigration legislation fail to produce a path to citizenship.

headline: Challenges Await Plan to Reduce Emissions
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Law and Legislation', 'Carbon Capture and Sequestration', 'Coal', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'Factories and Manufacturing']
abstract: A proposal from the Obama administration to limit carbon emissions might be curtailed in a legal quagmire if the required technology does not meet current standards.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration’s potentially pathbreaking proposal for carbon emission limits on new power plants will face political and legal challenges from opponents who argue that the technology needed has not been close to being proven as the law requires.

headline: Lottery Numbers
abstract: Lottery numbers for Sept. 20 for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Pick a Team, Pick a Color and Then Click Away
abstract: Fanatics, an online seller of licensed sports merchandise, operates the online shops of many colleges and professional teams and their leagues.
lead_paragraph: Fanatics, an online seller of licensed sports merchandise, operates the online shops of many colleges and professional teams and their leagues.

headline: Cattle Hides Out West, and Suspected Check Rustling Back East
keywords: ['Robberies and Thefts', 'Postal Service and Post Offices']
abstract: A $37,080 payment sent from Bellingham, Wash., to Vancouver, British Columbia, ended up in a Brooklyn bank, and a suspect has been charged.
lead_paragraph: A company that buys cattle hides, just outside Bellingham, Wash., has been doing business with one of its Canadian suppliers, West Coast Reduction, for decades. One particular transaction this summer went awry and far afield.

headline: Food Workers in Hunts Point Criticize a Commission’s Scrutiny
abstract: Background checks of hundreds of workers by the Business Integrity Commission, which combats organized crime, are raising concerns.
lead_paragraph: The day after Jonathan Sanchez was released from prison in 2010 after serving three years for a burglary, he walked into Down East Seafood in Hunts Point in the South Bronx and asked for a job, and a second chance. He got both.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, September 21, 2013
abstract: Quotation of the day for Saturday, September 21, 2013.
lead_paragraph: “A military-grade weapon on the streets of Chicago is simply unacceptable.”

headline: Hacking U.S. Secrets, China Pushes for Drones
abstract: A two-year hacking operation by a group linked to China’s army is the latest sign of Beijing’s ambitious plans to be at the forefront of drone manufacturing.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — For almost two years, hackers based in Shanghai went after one foreign defense contractor after another, at least 20 in all. Their target, according to an American cybersecurity company that monitored the attacks, was the technology behind the United States’ clear lead in military drones.

headline: Santa Monica Bets on Electric Cars, but Consumers Are Slow to Switch
abstract: For automakers, reluctance in Santa Monica, Calif., underscores how difficult it will be for them to meet strict federal and state mandates on fuel efficiency and pollution.
lead_paragraph: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — It would seem to be a good time to own an electric car in Santa Monica. From the charging stations dotted around town to the dedicated public parking spaces — all provided at no cost by the city — Santa Monica has rolled out the welcome mat for electric cars.

headline: Corrections: September 21, 2013
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on September 21, 2013.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Now Making Money for the Yankees ...
abstract: More than 20 licensees have signed up to make about 150 items to commemorate Mariano Rivera’s retirement. Here are some other ways the Yankees could honor his final season.
lead_paragraph: THE YANKEES and Major League Baseball are running out of time to make some money off Mariano Rivera’s retirement. With only eight games left in the regular season, more than 20 licensees have signed up to make about 150 retirement items, according to ESPN. On Sunday, the Yankees will begin wearing jerseys and hats and using balls adorned with patches that commemorate Rivera’s retirement. Here are some other ways the Yankees could honor Mariano Rivera’s Final Season™ as it enters the home stretch:

headline: Round Trip for One
abstract: A pretty grid from Tim Croce.
lead_paragraph: Administrivial Win Valuable Prizes Alert! The Sunday puzzle will be a special contest puzzle. The crossword itself can be solved in all the usual online formats. However, to solve the bonus contest element, you will need to see some heavy outlines in the grid, which cannot be reproduced electronically. Thus, if you plan to enter the contest, please print out the PDF version of the puzzle, which will be made available at the same time as the electronic version. Good luck!

headline: De Blasio Has Early Advantage in Fund-Raising
abstract: Joseph J. Lhota, the Republican mayoral nominee, conceded he is behind Bill de Blasio, the Democrat, in fund-raising, but said that would soon change.
lead_paragraph: As the race for New York City mayor turns toward November’s general election, Bill de Blasio has a modest fund-raising advantage over Joseph J. Lhota, according to new campaign finance filings.

headline: Giants Hope for U-Turn on Familiar Trip
abstract: The Giants hope their game against the Carolina Panthers can provide the same turning point in their season as it did last year. But they may be without cornerback Corey Webster.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The 0-2 Giants found a ray of hope this week in the knowledge that their last such start came in 2007, when they swept their next six games and went on to win Super Bowl XLII. The belief that they can repeat such a turnaround could hinge on how they fare Sunday against quarterback Cam Newton and the Carolina Panthers, an opponent they are meeting at a familiar time and place.

headline: On Fulton Street, Worries About Change
abstract: As trendy stores move in to the Fulton Street bazaar in Downtown Brooklyn, some worry about the potential loss of the market’s distinctive stores and atmosphere.
lead_paragraph: First came Aeropostale, the clothing store chain that caters to teenagers. Then Shake Shack, the trendy Manhattan fast-food chain, started flipping hamburgers on a prime corner. Last year the Gap opened with its Factory Store, and an Armani Exchange followed. In July, lines snaked around the block for a new steel-and-glass H&M, the chain known for its modestly priced clothing inspired by fashion runways. Nordstrom Rack, Century 21 and Swarovski are on the way.

headline: D. J. R. Bruckner, Columnist and Critic, Dies at 79
abstract: Mr. Bruckner, who was a longtime editor for The New York Times Book Review, landed on Nixon’s enemies list over his syndicated columns for The Los Angeles Times.
lead_paragraph: D. J. R. Bruckner, a retired book and theater critic for The New York Times who was previously a nationally syndicated political columnist for The Los Angeles Times, died on Friday in Manhattan. He was 79.

headline: Devils Recharge by Loading Lineup With Fresh Faces
abstract: The Devils acquired new and experienced talent in the off-season to fill holes left by Ilya Kovalchuk and David Clarkson, two of their top scorers.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — When the Devils acquired forward Ilya Kovalchuk in 2010 and later signed him to a 15-year contract, he was expected to one day own the team’s offensive records.

headline: Peter K. Leisure, Judge Who Oversaw Football Antitrust Case, Dies at 84
abstract: Judge Leisure also presided over a Gambino crime family trial and ordered the release of secret grand jury testimony in the investigation of Alger Hiss, which included testimony by Richard M. Nixon.
lead_paragraph: Peter K. Leisure, a federal judge in Manhattan who in 26 years on the bench oversaw high-profile business disputes, trials of Mafia chieftains and political controversies, died on Sept. 17 in Manhattan. He was 84.

headline: Rabbi Philip Berg, Who Updated Jewish Mysticism, Dies at 86
abstract: Rabbi Berg’s Kabbalah Center International attracted celebrities like Madonna and Britney Spears but also drew criticism over spiritual and financial matters.
lead_paragraph: Rabbi Philip Berg, whose Kabbalah Center International put a modern spin on an ancient Jewish mystical tradition, attracting celebrities like Madonna, Demi Moore and Britney Spears but also incurring criticism on spiritual and financial matters, died Monday in Los Angeles. He was 86, according to the center, although some news reports put his age at 84.

headline: Tentative Deal in Feud Over Will of an Heiress
abstract: A tentative settlement has been reached in the dispute over the $300 million fortune of the copper heiress Huguette Clark, lawyers for several parties said Friday night.
lead_paragraph: A tentative settlement has been reached in a dispute over the $300 million fortune of the copper heiress Huguette Clark, a recluse who lived for two decades in a hospital room though she owned several mansions, lawyers for several parties said Friday night.

headline: In One Swing, Rodriguez Helps Put Focus Back on the Field
abstract: Alex Rodriguez, hours after Andy Pettitte announced this would be his last season, kept the Yankees’ playoff hopes alive with his 24th grand slam, sending him to first on the career list.
lead_paragraph: Alex Rodriguez arrived at Yankee Stadium on Friday afternoon to a throng of reporters waiting to ask him for a comment.

headline: Homering in His Return, Wright Leads Mets to a Win
abstract: Third baseman David Wright hit a two-run home run in his first at-bat after missing seven weeks because of a hamstring injury, and the Mets went on to beat the Phillies.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Each spring, Mets Manager Terry Collins talks with his young players about their expectations for spring training and the season ahead. He tells them: if you want to know what it takes, watch David Wright — do what he does.

headline: The Left-Handed Complement
abstract: A look at Andy Pettitte’s career, by the numbers.
lead_paragraph: Always formidable but rarely a big star, Andy Pettitte, at age 41, says he will retire for good at the end of the 2013 season. A look at his career, by the numbers:

headline: North Korea Postpones Family Reunion Program
abstract: Pyongyang abruptly postponed a humanitarian program that would have allowed hundreds of family members on both sides of the Korean Peninsula to meet for the first time since the Korean War six decades ago.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL — North Korea on Saturday postponed an emotionally charged humanitarian program that would have allowed hundreds of family members on both sides of the divided Korean Peninsula to meet for the first time since the Korean War six decades ago.

headline: Sunday Dialogue: The Office vs. the Home
abstract: Readers discuss the pros and cons of telecommuting.
lead_paragraph: Readers discuss the pros and cons of telecommuting.

headline: Bonita Spence, a Referee Who Had a Cheering Section, Dies at 52
keywords: ['Officiating (Sports)', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Public Defenders and Court-Appointed Lawyers (Criminal)', 'NCAA Basketball Championships (Women)']
abstract: Well known in the world of basketball, Ms. Spence also worked as an investigator in the public defender’s office in Newark, N.J.
lead_paragraph: Bonita Spence, an investigator for public defenders whose second job as a basketball referee took her to the sport’s highest level, working at N.C.A.A. tournament games, Women’s National Basketball Association games and the first men’s professional game to be officiated entirely by women, died on Sept. 15 in West Orange, N.J. She was 52.

headline: What’s On Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (HBO) HITCHCOCK (2012) Anthony Hopkins, buried in a fat suit and facial prosthetics, summons the spirit of Alfred Hitchcock during the making of “Psycho” in this biopic, directed by Sacha Gervasi and based on a book by Stephen Rebello. But Hitchcock isn’t merely taken with the inspiration behind his perverse shocker: Robert Bloch’s 1959 novel about the crimes of Ed Gein, a serial killer in Wisconsin who adorned his home with human body parts and walked around in the skin of his female victims. Hitchcock becomes possessed, enduring sleepless nights and, at the same time, marital troubles with his wife and adviser, Alma (Helen Mirren, above with Mr. Hopkins), who is dramatically unhappy about his fixation on blondes — in this case, Janet Leigh (Scarlett Johansson). “The real Hitchcock’s great flaw, apparently, was that he was at once a genius and a private man, a combination that has allowed some writers and filmmakers to have their insultingly imaginative way with him,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. And while “The Girl,” on HBO, “painted him as a pathetic sexual predator,” this film “takes a lighter, more strenuously comic if patronizing approach to the director,” she said. “It’s fluff. But while its dim fantasies about Hitchcock and the association of genius with psychosis can be written off as silly, they also smack of spiteful jealousy.”

headline: Strong Typhoon Nears China, Putting Hong Kong on Alert
abstract: The storm caused landslides in the Philippines and flooding in Taiwan as it prepared to hit the densely populated Pearl River Delta area of China.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The strongest typhoon to hit Asia this year caused landslides in the Philippines and flooding in Taiwan on Saturday as it appeared headed toward the densely populated Pearl River Delta area of China, with the financial center of Hong Kong preparing for possible business shutdowns at the start of the workweek.

lead_paragraph: Milan

headline: Gunmen Kill Dozens in Terror Attack at Kenyan Mall
keywords: ['Nairobi, Kenya, Westgate Mall Shootings (2013)', 'Terrorism', 'Shopping Centers and Malls', 'Hostages', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
abstract: Two squads stormed into a Nairobi mall Saturday, killing at least 39 people. Hours later, police officers dashed through corpse-strewn corridors, trying to find the assailants. A Somali militant group is suspected in the attack.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — Masked gunmen stormed into a fancy, crowded mall in Nairobi on Saturday and shot dead at least 39 people and wounded more than 150 in one of the most chilling terrorist attacks in East Africa since Al Qaeda blew up two American embassies in 1998.

headline: Stella Jean: Spring 2014 RTW
abstract: Milan
lead_paragraph: Milan

headline: Fendi: From Fur to Film
abstract: Suzy Menkes reports on the people behind the exhibition “Making Dreams: Fendi and the Cinema” in Milan.
lead_paragraph: Suzy Menkes reports on the people behind the exhibition “Making Dreams: Fendi and the Cinema” in Milan.

headline: The Wild English Ponies of Dartmoor Travel to London
abstract: The artist Patricia Heal has created a multimedia exhibition dedicated to the indigenous ponies of Devon, England, which she has spent years photographing.
lead_paragraph: The British artist Patricia Heal grew up in Devon, England, home to Dartmoor National Park, where indigenous ponies roam free. “I’ve been photographing them for centuries, it seems,” said Heal, now based in New York, who likens the romantic, mysterious animals to “mythical creatures.” Two years ago, she decided to do something with her archive of images, which led to a multimedia exhibition called “The Dartmoor Photographs,” consisting of images on canvas, a video installation and sculpture, at New York’s Robin Rice Gallery. Heal has brought the show closer to home at the Stone Theatre Gallery in London.

headline: Roberto Cavalli: Spring 2014 RTW
abstract: Milan
lead_paragraph: Milan

headline: Alabama Primary Puts a Wide Spectrum of Republican Views on Display
keywords: ['Elections, State Legislature', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Tea Party Movement']
abstract: The outcome in the state’s First Congressional District may provide some hints on how much further the Republican lurch to the right might go.
lead_paragraph: FAIRHOPE, Ala. — Judging from the questions submitted by the audience, everyone attending the Eastern Shore Republican Women candidates’ forum shared some basic assumptions.

headline: Marvin Rainwater, 88, Twangy Country Singer, Dies
abstract: Mr. Rainwater was a classically trained pianist who turned to country music, then wrote and recorded the hits “Gonna Find Me a Bluebird” and “Whole Lotta Woman.”
lead_paragraph: Marvin Rainwater, a classically trained pianist who improbably turned to country music after an accident in a garage, then wrote and recorded the hit songs “Gonna Find Me a Bluebird” and “Whole Lotta Woman,” died on Tuesday in Minneapolis. He was 88.

headline: Yankees’ Fond, and Not So Fond, Farewells
abstract: The glorious send-off for Mariano Rivera stands in contrast to other departures by Yankees through the years.
lead_paragraph: Mariano Rivera is a rare Yankees icon. As he approaches retirement, his career and character will be celebrated Sunday at the Stadium with fans cheering and bands playing. But in the often cruel culture of baseball, in the past, many of the most famous Yankees departed unhappily, if not sadly.

headline: John Kennell, Advocate of Infant Bonding, Dies at 91
abstract: Dr. Kennell’s research in the 1960s helped end a common practice of keeping newly born infants and their parents apart in the first hours of life.
lead_paragraph: When Dr. John H. Kennell was a hospital pediatrician in the 1950s, newborns were typically whisked away within minutes of delivery, washed, weighed, blood-tested and plunked into bassinets under the nursery’s fluorescent lights. Their mothers would not be permitted to hold them for 12 hours, sometimes longer.

headline: Jil Sander: Spring 2014 RTW
abstract: Milan
lead_paragraph: Milan

headline: Variety: A Charming Acrostic
abstract: A charming acrostic by Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — Some people just know how to make small talk and how to draw people into conversation. The character of Edward in “RAMEAU’S NIECE” a parody of Diderot’s “Rameau’s Nephew,” is one such person and, according to Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon (and humorist Dave Barry) below, so is Bill Clinton.

headline: Batting Averages, Too, Tend to Climb Higher in Colorado
abstract: A Colorado batter has hit .330 or higher 16 times, leading to seven batting titles since the club’s inaugural season in 1993.
lead_paragraph: Michael Cuddyer has never hit .300 in a major league season. A .271 career batter coming into 2013, Cuddyer, an outfielder for the Colorado Rockies, hit a career-high .284 in 2006 with Minnesota. The last time he hit higher than .300 in a full season on any level was 2001, when as a 22-year-old he hit .301 for Class AA New Britain. If you include his 4-for-18 performance in a brief call-up to the majors that season, his average drops to .298.

headline: Giants’ Myers Turned Corner in College to Reach N.F.L.
abstract: Brandon Myers signed a one-year free-agent contract hoping he could become the latest in a long succession of lesser-known Giants tight ends who had big roles in the offense.
lead_paragraph: It was 2005, and Brandon Myers, then a little-used second-year tight end at Iowa, went home for a weekend in the off-season.

headline: Jews Challenge Rules to Claim Heart of Jerusalem
abstract: Tensions are growing as more mainstream Jews seek to visit and pray at the Temple Mount in Jerusalem, a sacred site controlled for centuries by Muslims, who call it the Noble Sanctuary.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Small groups of Jews are increasingly ascending the Temple Mount in Jerusalem’s Old City, a sacred site controlled for centuries by Muslims, who see the visits as a provocation that could undermine the fragile peace talks started this summer.

headline: Honor for Jets Rookies, if Only They Knew It
abstract: The Bill Hampton Award is presented to the rookie “who best exemplifies a ‘Pro’ in the locker room.” The winner’s jersey hangs for a year, and in plain view of players milling about their lockers.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Against the back wall of the Jets’ equipment room hangs a green No. 82 jersey. It rests on a green hanger and dangles from a silver hook, and it does not belong to Mickey Shuler or Rob Carpenter, who wore that number with pride, or, for that matter, to anyone on the current roster.

headline: When Rivera Started, and Pettitte Relieved
abstract: A role reversal of two rookie pitchers in June 1995 changed the Yankees’ fortunes and baseball history
lead_paragraph: In the spring of the 1995 major league baseball season, a rookie named Andy Pettitte was pitching in relief for the Yankees. Another rookie, named Mariano Rivera, was starting and not doing well.

headline: 3 Coalition Soldiers Are Shot Dead in Afghanistan
abstract: A man in an Afghan National Army uniform killed the soldiers on or near an American base, Afghan officials said, in the first suspected insider attack since July.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — A man in an Afghan National Army uniform killed three coalition soldiers on or near an American base on Saturday, according to Afghan officials.

headline: Israeli Soldier Is Lured to West Bank and Killed
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Kidnapping', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Palestinians']
abstract: A Palestinian man had hoped to use the soldier’s body as leverage to lobby for the release of his brother from an Israeli prison, military officials said on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — A Palestinian man lured an Israeli soldier he worked with at a sandwich shop outside Tel Aviv to the West Bank on Friday, and killed him in hopes of using the body as leverage to lobby for the release of his brother from an Israeli prison, military officials said Saturday.

headline: In the Market for Another Liriano
abstract: As teams begin to survey the free-agent market for starting pitchers, the hope is for another turnaround story like Francisco Liriano’s in Pittsburgh.
lead_paragraph: Teams hoping to bolster their pitching rotation this winter will have a final look at most of their free-agent options this week, and all are hoping for the kind of success the Los Angeles Dodgers and the Pittsburgh Pirates had last off-season.

headline: Pakistan Releases Taliban Commander to Help Afghan Peace Efforts
abstract: News of the release was met with a mixed reception in Afghanistan, amid questions about the extent of his influence over the Taliban or his intent toward peace talks.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Acquiescing to years of Afghan government demands, Pakistan released a senior Taliban commander on Saturday in a bid to help kick-start peace talks in Afghanistan.

headline: In Milan, Frills and Riddles
abstract: Neutral palettes from Bottega Veneta and some simple, feminine classics from Jil Sander.
lead_paragraph: Tomas Maier made two basic points at Bottega Veneta on Saturday morning. The first was his anti-decorative use of pleated ruffles on dresses and skirts. That sounds like a contradiction, but the flat, almost offhand treatment of the monochromatic frills seemed to be used for texture and unexpected volume on his classically shaped cotton dresses. The ruffles appeared a lot, but they were not sweet.

headline: German Campaign, Amid Fiery Debate Abroad, Shuffles Toward Consensus
abstract: Germany’s inclination toward consensus could yield something nearly unfathomable anywhere else: a power-sharing pact between the main parties of the left and right.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — It would be easy to mock the political campaign that ends with Sunday’s national elections in Germany as a version of fiddling while Rome burns. It has lacked any heated debate over the nation’s role in maintaining the common European currency or addressing the crippling levels of unemployment among its southern neighbors.

headline: Rakesh Kapoor on Accepting Bitter Pills
abstract: Mr. Kapoor, chief executive of Reckitt Benckiser, says employees and leaders should not “keep complaining about how life should be.”
lead_paragraph: This interview with Rakesh Kapoor, chief executive of Reckitt Benckiser, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Nuns', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']

lead_paragraph: ADONIS, Lebanon — When Russia’s foreign minister, Sergey V. Lavrov, wanted to bolster his argument that rebels had carried out the poison gas attacks near Damascus on Aug. 21, he pointed to the work of a 61-year-old Lebanese-born nun who had concluded that the horrifying videos showing hundreds of dead and choking victims, including many children, had been fabricated ahead of time to provide a pretext for foreign intervention.

lead_paragraph: After scoring goals in consecutive games, there is no telling what kind of celebration Red Bulls striker Thierry Henry has in his bag of tricks.

abstract: Mr. Molyneux, head of Sony Electronics in San Diego, says he has been given freedom to innovate, create and build.

headline: Once Suicidal and Shipped Off, Now Battling Nevada Over Care
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Homeless Persons', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Abuse of the Disabled']
abstract: A lawsuit on behalf of a group of homeless and mentally ill people claims they were bused out of Nevada and left on the streets of San Francisco with little or no medication.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — David Theisen keeps his legal papers in a frayed yellow envelope in his tiny transients’ hotel room, a toilet down the hall, the covers of his beloved comic books, with titles like “Dark Mysteries” and “Vault of Horror,” lining the drab walls.

headline: It’s Quinoa’s World. We Just Live in It.
abstract: After establishing that quinoa is comfortable, instruct onions, carrots and squash that they are not to disturb quinoa before cooking begins.

headline: Was This Whistle-Blower Muzzled?
keywords: ['Emergency Economic Stabilization Act (2008)', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Whistle-Blowers']
abstract: Thanks to political pressure and the revolving door between Washington and Wall Street, the events leading up to the financial crisis remain obscured.
lead_paragraph: THE fifth anniversary of Lehman Brothers’ bankruptcy has occasioned one legacy-spinning defense after another. We’ve heard from Ben S. Bernanke, chairman of the Federal Reserve; Henry M. Paulson Jr., the Treasury secretary at the time; and Timothy F. Geithner, then the New York Fed president and later Mr. Paulson’s successor at Treasury, about their historic decisions to use trillions of dollars of taxpayers’ money to bail out the banking system.

headline: America’s Billionaire
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Federal Budget (US)']
abstract: Trapped in the capital with the Republican gargoyles preaching nihilism, one yearns for the grandfatherly Warren Buffett preaching optimism.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — WHEN you’re trapped in a city with House Republican gargoyles who don’t understand math or history, much less reality, sometimes you crave a dose of grandfatherly wisdom.

headline: When I Moved Online ...
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Parenting', 'Families and Family Life', 'Social Media']
abstract: In endearingly impulsive ways, my parents have begun to interact with the Internet.
lead_paragraph: I WAS born in 1983. My parents, in the mid-1990s, briefly knew more than I did about the Internet, I think (the bill from AOL must have required a credit card). But, as adults, with settled understandings of the world, they didn’t integrate the Internet into their lives. For around five years, they seemed to use it mostly to check stock prices. The Internet remained nonessential and separate for them, like a vacation destination.

headline: The Pope’s Radical Whisper
abstract: The Catholic leader’s tone and words are a counterpoint to the arrogance and self-aggrandizement that define so much of modern life.
lead_paragraph: IT’S about time. The leader of the Roman Catholic Church has surveyed the haughty scolds in its ranks, noted their fixation on matters of sexual morality above all others and said enough is enough. I’m not being cheeky with this one-word response. Hallelujah.

headline: Dinner Is Printed
keywords: ['3-D Printers', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Food', '3-D Devices and Effects']
abstract: Will 3-D printing save the world? Bring in the apocalypse? Or is it just a gadget that spits out cheap plastic trinkets? An investigation.
lead_paragraph: THE hype over 3-D printing intensifies by the day. Will it save the world? Will it bring on the apocalypse, with millions manufacturing their own AK-47s? Or is it all an absurd hubbub about a machine that spits out chintzy plastic trinkets? I decided to investigate. My plan: I would immerse myself in the world of 3-D printing. I would live for a week using nothing but 3-D-printed objects — toothbrushes, furniture, bicycles, vitamin pills — in order to judge the technology’s potential and pitfalls.

headline: Good Populism, Bad Populism
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Tea Party Movement', 'Federal Budget (US)']
abstract: The most innovative ideas in the Republican Party are coming from the same contingent that’s pushing the pointless budget brinkmanship.
lead_paragraph: HERE’S the good news for Republicans: The party now has a faction committed to learning real lessons from the 2012 defeat, breaking with the right’s stale policy consensus and embracing new ideas on a range of issues, from foreign policy to middle-class taxes, the drug war to banking reform.

headline: The Evangelical Orphan Boom
abstract: The craze for adoption among evangelical Christians has contributed to a boom-and-bust market for children around the world.
lead_paragraph: IF you attend an evangelical church these days, there’s a good chance you’ll hear about the “orphan crisis” affecting millions of children around the world.

headline: Mother Nature and the Middle Class
keywords: ['Environment', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Global Warming', 'Population']
abstract: Here’s why the same old, same old is gone for good in Iran and Egypt.
lead_paragraph: IF you fell asleep 30 years ago, woke up last week and quickly scanned the headlines in Iran and Egypt you could be excused for saying, “I didn’t miss a thing.” The military and the Muslim Brotherhood are still slugging it out along the Nile, and Iranian pragmatists and ideologues are still locked in a duel for control of their Islamic Revolution.

headline: The Boy Who Stood Up to Syrian Injustice
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Children and Childhood', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: After suffering extreme conditions at home, refugees are fleeing Syria and straining its neighbors. There are steps we can take to help.
lead_paragraph: MAFRAQ, Jordan — AS in the fairy tale, in Syria it was the children who pointed out that the emperor had no clothes.

headline: The Importance of the Afterlife. Seriously.
abstract: The assumption that the human race will survive plays an underappreciated role in our lives.
lead_paragraph: I believe in life after death.

headline: You Didn’t Get the Job? Maybe It’s a Good Thing
abstract: Someone who is solicited for a job with a former employer, then gets only silence, might want to find out what went wrong.

abstract: Downward economic mobility helps explain our polarization and mistrust.
lead_paragraph: Not long ago I was walking toward an airport departure gate when a man approached me.

headline: The Lost Slumgullions of English
abstract: Look to the past for a dragon’s pile of linguistic loot.
lead_paragraph: A “slumgullion” is a stew of leftovers, and while the dish has been described as “watery,” the word itself is delectably unusual and juicily descriptive. Alas, you won’t find many people cooking up anything with that name these days, so we’re denied the pleasure of rolling the lovely sounds of slumgullion — let alone its more questionable flavors — on the tongue.

headline: Lobbyists Look for a Euphemism
keywords: ['Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Campaign Finance', 'Editorials']
abstract: They are trying to rebrand themselves, possibly doing away with the “L” word.
lead_paragraph: The American League of Lobbyists, a powerful institution that defends and defines the role of Washington’s booming influence industry, is surveying its members to see whether it should drop what would seem to be the existential word “lobbyist” from its identity. The term “Government Relations Professionals” is used in some of the leading choices for a new name, according to The Hill newspaper, which first reported the league’s “rebranding” plans.

headline: Silencing Scientists
keywords: ['Oil Sands', 'Science and Technology', 'Research', 'Politics and Government', 'ACADEMIC FREEDOM', 'Editorials', 'Global Warming', 'Fish and Other Marine Life']
abstract: The Canadian government is making it harder for scientists to do their work.
lead_paragraph: Over the last few years, the government of Canada — led by Stephen Harper — has made it harder and harder for publicly financed scientists to communicate with the public and with other scientists.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | A Healthy Dose of Moisture at Roberto Cavalli
abstract: Nourishing products that left the skin looking dewy and fresh were key backstage at today’s show in Milan.
lead_paragraph: “I just wanted the girls to be naturally beautiful,” said the makeup artist Diane Kendal, who used nourishing products to give models a healthy glow for Roberto Cavalli’s show today in Milan. “The skin is well moisturized with a very light foundation.” Kendal then used her fingers to apply M.A.C.’s creamy blush in improper copper to the contours of the face before dusting a pink powder blush on the cheeks. She continued with M.A.C.’s moisturizing lip pencil for a soft pucker, and topped the fresh-faced look off with a thin line of black liner close to the lashes.

headline: Close the N.S.A.’s Back Doors
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Computer Security', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Editorials', 'Cyberwarfare']
abstract: The National Security Agency undermines confidence in communication by weakening encryption.
lead_paragraph: In 2006, a federal agency, the National Institute of Standards and Technology, helped build an international encryption system to help countries and industries fend off computer hacking and theft. Unbeknown to the many users of the system, a different government arm, the National Security Agency, secretly inserted a “back door” into the system that allowed federal spies to crack open any data that was encoded using its technology.

headline: The Quest for a Lyme Vaccine
abstract: There are glimmers of hope that newer, more effective Lyme vaccines can be developed.
lead_paragraph: People who spend time outdoors in wooded or grassy areas where black-legged ticks are abundant would welcome a vaccine to protect them from Lyme disease and other dangerous pathogens that the same ticks can transmit simultaneously. Past efforts to develop and market a Lyme vaccine ended in failure, but now there are glimmers of hope that newer, more broadly effective vaccines can be developed.

headline: A Rare Plea to the Court
abstract: The Supreme Court has a chance to save a life and clarify how it views its power to stop unjust executions.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court’s next term is full of big-ticket issues — from campaign finance to affirmative action to the separation of powers — but a largely overlooked death-penalty appeal the court hasn’t agreed to hear yet could clarify how broadly it views its ultimate power to stop unjust executions.

headline: President Rouhani Comes to Town
abstract: The new president of Iran has sent encouraging signals that could mean the beginning of real change.
lead_paragraph: All eyes at this week’s United Nations General Assembly will be on Iran’s new president, Hassan Rouhani. Since taking office in August, he has sent encouraging signals about his willingness to engage more constructively with the West than his predecessor, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, who insisted on proceeding with Iran’s nuclear program, denied the Holocaust and seemed unconcerned as his country slipped into deeper economic distress. Mr. Rouhani’s assembly address on Tuesday gives him a chance to provide concrete evidence that his talk of change is real.

lead_paragraph: The computer billionaire Michael S. Dell and two executives of his private investment firm have agreed to donate an archive of nearly 200,000 prints from the Magnum photo collective to the University of Texas at Austin, the school announced on Friday.

lead_paragraph: After 155 games, nobody can be quite sure how the final moments of the Yankees’ season will unfold. The end is near but not clear. They may have celebrations or disappointments, or simply goodbyes to Mariano Rivera and Andy Pettitte, the stalwarts who are spending their last days in pinstripes.

headline: The Simple Test That Saved My Baby
keywords: ['Babies and Infants', 'Tests (Medical)', 'Heart', 'Birth Defects', 'Medicine and Health', 'Pulse Oximetry']
abstract: A simple test can determine whether a newborn has heart defects, yet more than a dozen states still do not require it.
lead_paragraph: ON July 10, my wife gave birth to a seemingly healthy baby boy with slate-blue eyes and peach-fuzz hair. The pregnancy was without complications. The delivery itself lasted all of 12 minutes. After a couple of days at Greenwich Hospital in Connecticut, we were packing up when a pediatric cardiologist came into the room.
