headline: Reader Comments on my Column About the Boy Who Defied the Syrian Regime
abstract: A bit more background on my visit to Syrian refugees in Jordan.
lead_paragraph: My Sunday column is from the Syria/Jordan border area, focused on the story of the children who helped launch the Syria uprising and the extraordinary courage they showed. I confess I’m feeling increasingly pessimistic about this conflict (that’s why I keep writing about it, in hopes that the world will do more to try to ease this unfolding tragedy). Unfortunately, the world doesn’t seem inclined to do much, and most of the trends are bad. I think there’s a good chance that this war will continue for years to come, will claim hundreds of thousands of lives, will lead to the toppling of King Abdullah’s government in Jordan, and will result in an extension of the fighting in Lebanon and Iraq. In other words, we’re on course toward a catastrophe.

lead_paragraph: A YOUNG woman with hearing loss wrote to me recently about being interviewed for a senior position in a major library system. She was well qualified for the job, and as her interviews progressed through the day, she sensed that she was about to be offered the job.

headline: Roaring Waters, Deep Scars: ‘It Chewed Us Up’
abstract: After flooding hit 17 counties in Northern Colorado earlier this month, affected communities are facing the prospect of a slow and expensive recovery.
lead_paragraph: JAMESTOWN, Colo. — In the Colorado mountains, the floodwaters struck Jamestown like an invading army. Houses tumbled into the churning Little James Creek. A torrent of rocks and mud crushed Joey Howlett, 72, in his home. People rushed into the rain in pajamas, children in their arms, to shouts of “Get out! Get out!”

headline: Security Officer Is Charged With Setting 8 Fires at 2 Manhattan Hotels

headline: Please Hold, for a Week or So

headline: An Israeli Sergeant Is Shot Dead in the West Bank as a Second Is Remembered
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Palestinians']
abstract: The soldier, identified as Sgt. Gabriel Koby, was shot and killed in Hebron, apparently by a Palestinian sniper, in the second deadly attack on the Israeli military this weekend.
lead_paragraph: BAT YAM, Israel — An Israeli soldier was fatally shot in the West Bank city of Hebron on Sunday, apparently by a Palestinian sniper, in the second deadly attack on the Israeli military this weekend. Killings of Israelis have become relatively rare in the Israeli-occupied West Bank. While there appeared to be no direct link between the two latest episodes, they jolted Israeli complacency, fed popular distrust of Palestinians and deepened skepticism about the recently resumed Israeli-Palestinian peace negotiations.

headline: Hating On Food Stamps
abstract: Looking for takers in all the wrong places.
lead_paragraph: Tyler Cowen wonders why Republicans have chosen to go after the food stamp program, which he concedes is actually pretty good. He suggests that it’s a sign of weakness, because the GOP isn’t willing or able to go after the big items like Medicare. But this begs the question, why does the inability to go after programs that really are problems (although the disability story isn’t nearly as problematic as he thinks) mean that you should go after a program that isn’t a problem? There’s no significant money to be saved — if and when the economy recovers, SNAP will be back down to something like 0.25 percent of GDP.

headline: Diane Dorsey, Ronald Helman
abstract: The couple plan to start an online business together.
lead_paragraph: Diane L. Dorsey and Ronald Dale Helman are to be married Sunday. Alice C. Buros, a Universal Life minister, is to officiate at the Plaza Blanca Badlands in Abiquiu, N.M.

headline: Carly Sharon, Christopher Wimpfheimer
abstract: The bride works at UBS in portfolio construction and investment strategy; the groom is an investment adviser at JPMorgan Chase.
lead_paragraph: Carly Elizabeth Sharon, the daughter of Nanci B. Sharon and Douglas A. Sharon of Fisher Island, Fla., was married Saturday to Christopher Anthony Wimpfheimer, the son of Melinda E. Wimpfheimer and Andrew T. Wimpfheimer of Southampton, N.Y. Johanna Bard Richlin, a friend of the bride who received a one-day solemnization certificate from Massachusetts, officiated at the Wauwinet, an inn on Nantucket.

headline: Jacqueline Erb, Robert Cornell Jr.
abstract: The couple met at Vanderbilt.
lead_paragraph: Jacqueline Ashley Erb and Robert Tuxford Cornell Jr. were married Saturday at St. James’s Church in Manhattan. The Rev. Craig D. Townsend, an Episcopal priest and the vicar of the church, performed the ceremony.

headline: Susannah Geltman, Yuriy Prilutskiy
abstract: The bride is an associate in the litigation department of Simpson Thacher & Bartlett; the groom is an associate at a venture capital firm.
lead_paragraph: Susannah Sidney Geltman, a daughter of Deborah S. Geltman and Dr. Richard L. Geltman of New York, was married Saturday evening at her parents’ summer home in Millbrook, N.Y., to Yuriy Arkadiyevich Prilutskiy, a son of Galina A. Prilutskiy and Arkadiy M. Prilutskiy of Princeton, N.J. Rabbi Laurie Gold officiated.

headline: ‘Prisoners’ Captures Top Spot at Box Office
abstract: “Prisoners,” starring Hugh Jackman and Jake Gyllenhaal, raked in about $21.4 million over the weekend.
lead_paragraph: The adult drama “Prisoners” (Warner Brothers) was the No. 1 film at North American theaters over the weekend, taking in about $21.4 million, far ahead of “Insidious: Chapter 2” (FilmDistrict), which dropped sharply from its debut last week to place second with $14.5 million. The strong performance for “Prisoners” – which cost Alcon Entertainment about $46 million to make according to Boxofficemojo.com and stars Hugh Jackman and Jake Gyllenhaal – was particularly impressive given its dark subject matter centered around a child-kidnapping plot and the movie’s long running time.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Full, Dark Eyebrows Take the Stage at Marni
abstract: Under the models’ visors hid statement eyebrows: full, grey and slightly glittery.
lead_paragraph: Beneath those sculpted visors on Marni’s spring/summer 2014 runway was a return to the bold, caterpillar-like eyebrow — with a twist. “We started with a transparent skin with no powder, and we created a contrast filling the eyebrows with a grey shadow, like a dusty cloud, with a little bit of fine glitter to get a touch of light,” the makeup artist Tom Pecheux said. For what looked like a less extreme version of the all-pink eyes on the runway earlier this season at Burberry, Pecheux first covered eyelids with a soft veil of pearl white eyeshadow, then added a peach tone near the lashes. Combined with simple rosy cheeks, the subtle eyeshadow let the full, grey eyebrows steal the show — backstage, anyway.

headline: At Milan Fashion Week, in With the Young Energy
abstract: Marco de Vincenzo and Fausto Puglisi were among those showing collections at Milan Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: There is a renewed focus on young designers at Milan Fashion Week, where the city is looking for new energy to keep the fashion audience engaged.

headline: In the Shadow of ‘Old Smokey,’ a Toxic Legacy
keywords: ['Waste Materials and Disposal', 'Soil', 'ARSENIC', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances']
abstract: Years after a trash incinerator stopped operating in the West Grove neighborhood in Miami, its legacy might be more ominous than soiled laundry: contaminants like arsenic remain in the soil.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — When she was little, Elaine Taylor remembers rushing home whenever Old Smokey fired up. Clouds of ash from the towering trash incinerator would fill the air and settle on the ramshackle houses and the yards of the West Grove neighborhood.

headline: Meanwhile, Elsewhere in The New York Times …
abstract: Puzzle master Will Shortz pops up on the 6th Floor blog to talk about table tennis and going head-to-head on winning collectibles on eBay.
lead_paragraph: … Will Shortz interviews photographer Alex Soth for the 6th Floor Blog about his book and their mutual obsession with the sport of table tennis (that’s ping-pong to us casual players.)

headline: Fausto Puglisi: Spring 2014 RTW
abstract: Milan
lead_paragraph: Milan

headline: What’s on Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (ABC) THE 65TH PRIMETIME EMMY AWARDS Neil Patrick Harris (rolling out the red carpet, above, flanked by two television executives) hosts this ceremony honoring the best in television, broadcast live from the Nokia Theater in Los Angeles. Michael Douglas and Matt Damon, who are nominated this year for their portrayal of Liberace and his lover Scott Thorson in HBO’s “Behind the Candelabra,” will present, along with the celebrity pairs Kerry Washington and Diahann Carroll; Tina Fey and Amy Poehler; Emily and Zooey Deschanel; and Allison Janney and Anna Faris. Other presenters include Jimmy Fallon, Tim Gunn and Jon Hamm. Elton John will perform in a tribute to Liberace. The “In Memoriam” segment will feature remembrances of James Gandolfini by Edie Falco; of Gary David Goldberg by Michael J. Fox; of Cory Monteith by Jane Lynch; of Jean Stapleton by Rob Reiner; and of Jonathan Winters by Robin Williams. Don Cheadle will honor television’s role in covering the assassination of President John F. Kennedy on Nov. 22, 1963, and the Beatles’ appearance on “The Ed Sullivan Show” on Feb. 9, 1964; Carrie Underwood will sing music from the era. Preceremony coverage begins at 5 on E!; an after-party special is at 11.

headline: A Final Bow for Rivera
abstract: The Yankees and fans honored Mariano Rivera with an emotional, 50-minute retirement ceremony before their game against the Giants.
lead_paragraph: Sunday afternoon at Yankee Stadium was undoubtedly Mariano Rivera’s moment — the gifts, the recorded tributes, the standing ovations — although it might have also been a day to remember and to wistfully say goodbye to a great Yankees era that slowly, and inevitably, is coming to an end.

headline: ‘Breaking Bad,’ ‘Modern Family’ Take Top Honors in a Tribute-Heavy Emmy Awards
abstract: Dave Itzkoff and Jon Caramanica live blogged the 65th Primetime Emmy Awards.
lead_paragraph: Dave Itzkoff and Jon Caramanica live blogged the 65th Primetime Emmy Awards on Sunday night.

headline: Unauthorized Bike Lanes Created in Midtown
abstract: Inspired by an accident in which a cabdriver, after arguing with a bicyclist, crashed into a young British tourist, severing her leg, activists painted bicycle corridors on a stretch of Avenue of the Americas.
lead_paragraph: As night fell on Saturday, about a half-dozen bicyclists emerged from a huddle outside the New York Public Library and began pedaling north. They rode through crowded Midtown blocks where tour buses passed slowly and tourists walked along sidewalks, carrying cameras or copies of Playbill from Broadway theaters.

headline: Giants Go From Bad to Worst Start Since ’96
abstract: In Tom Coughlin’s most lopsided loss as the Giants’ coach, Eli Manning was sacked seven times as the team fell to 0-3 for the first time since 1996.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — A lopsided shutout defeat and an 0-3 record signify a conclusive and comprehensive level of ineptitude. But there were still innumerable ways to define a complete, and perhaps foreboding, collapse by the Giants in a 38-0 thrashing by the previously winless Carolina Panthers on Sunday.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Sept. 23
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'States (US)', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Government Bonds']
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: 2013 Emmy Award Winners and Nominees
abstract: A list of the 2013 prime time Emmy Award winners and nominees.
lead_paragraph: A list of winners and nominees for the 2013 Primetime Emmy Awards. Winners are denoted in bold.

headline: Mumford & Sons Taking a Break
abstract: Mumford & Sons completed their latest tour on Friday, and it will be the band’s last appearance for an extended period of time, members said.
lead_paragraph: Mumford & Sons completed their latest tour on Friday in Bonner Springs, Kan., and it will be the band’s last appearance for an extended period of time, members said, as the group will begin an open-ended hiatus. “There won’t be any Mumford & Sons activities for the foreseeable future following Friday’s show,” the keyboardist Ben Lovett, below right, said in an interview with Rolling Stone last week. The announcement concludes an eventful period for the group. Its latest record, “Babel,” was named album of the year at the Grammy Awards in February, and the bassist Ted Dwane was hospitalized in June with a blood clot in his brain. Mr. Dwane has recovered, but “we’re just going to rest up,” Mr. Lovett told Rolling Stone. “I don’t think we’ve had actually much time in the process to be with other people and living a life outside of the band. I think that’s what’s in place at the moment, to do very little — especially when it comes to Mumford & Sons.”

headline: Ancient Greeks and Romans, Alive Again in Manhattan
abstract: Salon Sanctuary opened its new season with “The Heirs of Tantalus,” a concert of Baroque opera arias.
lead_paragraph: The concept behind Salon Sanctuary is seductive. Each program devised by its artistic director, the soprano Jessica Gould, presents pre-Romantic music in the context of other art forms in unusual locations across Manhattan that are tailored to the evening’s theme.

headline: A Museum Works to Reinvent Itself, as Well as the American West
abstract: The Autry National Center in Los Angeles, based on the collection of the singing cowboy Gene Autry, is fine-tuning its mission and message.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — You don’t hear shootouts at the Autry National Center of the American West any more, and the gunslingers at the O.K. Corral have been put out to pasture. Hollywood’s singing cowboy Gene Autry, whose fortune helped establish this institution in 1988, a decade before his death, is still cast in bronze out front, but his guitar and memorabilia have been retired to a modest display case. Even the museum’s central mural, “Spirits of the West,” which exultantly portrays that realm’s history, from Spanish missionaries to Clint Eastwood, has curtains that can be drawn to shield visitors from its out-of-sync sensibilities.

headline: A Woman’s, Like, Life Continues as, Um, Art
abstract: Episodes 4.5 and 5 of “Life and Times,” from Nature Theater of Oklahoma, continued over the weekend, in film and with a book modeled on early medieval illuminated manuscripts.
lead_paragraph: Oh, my God, like, no way.

headline: Challenging the Notion That Franco Wholly Succeeded in Quashing Dissent
abstract: Mr. Treglown, a former editor of The Times Literary Supplement, challenges the idea that Spanish dissidents were completely stifled under Franco.
lead_paragraph: Can anything worthwhile come out of a shabby dictatorship like Franco’s in Spain? In “Franco’s Crypt,” the British biographer Jeremy Treglown, a former editor of The Times Literary Supplement, challenges the notion that Spanish intellectual life from the Civil War in 1936 to Franco’s death in 1975 was a cultural wasteland.

headline: With Feet on the Ground, the Orchestra Travels Through Space
abstract: The New York Philharmonic performed music from “2001: A Space Odyssey” on Friday as part of a new initiative, “The Art of the Score.”
lead_paragraph: When Alan Gilbert, the music director of the New York Philharmonic, announced a new initiative this past January, “The Art of the Score: Film Week at the Philharmonic,” he said he thought the programs could be exciting and enjoyable. The idea was to screen some classic films at Avery Fisher Hall and have the orchestra play the scores live.

headline: The Dawn of a World, Dreamlike Yet Chaotic
abstract: The Lyon Opera Ballet presented a rare run of performances of William Forsythe’s pathbreaking ballet “Limb’s Theorem.”
lead_paragraph: LYON, France — The curtain rises on an almost entirely dark stage. A giant white panel tilted from one corner looms dimly over the dark space. A ticking sound is heard; time is passing. Then, very slowly, movement becomes apparent. As the light brightens almost imperceptibly, arms and legs begin to emerge from a knot of bodies so entwined and tangled that it appears to be a single organism, a shifting, breathing amoeba.

headline: A Middle East Mourned and Celebrated in Suites
abstract: Bargemusic’s Here and Now Series offered a program of works by Mohammed Fairouz, including pieces dedicated to Egypt and addressing an event in Syria.
lead_paragraph: In the early afternoon of May 25, 2012, trucks pulled up in the village of Taldou near the town of Houla, Syria. Armed men, some in army uniforms, others in civilian clothes, fanned out and entered the houses. Witnesses cowering behind buildings heard screams and gunshots. When it was all done, over a hundred civilians were dead, including 49 children.

headline: Family Tree: Digging Up Those Roots
abstract: “Genealogy Roadshow” takes an “Antiques Roadshow” approach, inviting ordinary viewers’ questions about their ancestry.
lead_paragraph: “Genealogy Roadshow,” which begins on Monday on PBS, is a poor man’s “Who Do You Think You Are?” in several ways, and fans of tree-tracing may find it tepid. It occasionally uncovers interesting genealogical nuggets, but the search for them isn’t very sexy.

headline: Home Turf for a Band With Global Reach
abstract: Vampire Weekend, promoting its latest album, brought its brand of rock to the Barclays Center.
lead_paragraph: That arena in Brooklyn doesn’t feel like the monument it was intended to be, or the rude intrusion it seemed destined to be. It sits there, more or less quietly, taking in several thousand people on game or show nights, then expelling them with little fanfare. Post-event, the crowds tend to dissipate quickly. After Jay Z played eight shows to open the Barclays Center last fall, it became just another local landmark. It can be hard to remember what all the fuss was about.

headline: Yankees’ Costly Loss Puts a Damper on Rivera’s Party
abstract: On Mariano Rivera Day in the Bronx, the Yankees’ offense fell flat as the team dropped four games back in the wild-card chase with six to play.
lead_paragraph: Gifts surrounded Mariano Rivera’s locker, besieging his little alcove in the clubhouse. Framed posters and plaques, bags of T-shirts, bats, trophies, bins of mail, all of it piled like presents around a Christmas tree.

headline: Total Recall: Reconstructing Memory, for Better or Worse
abstract: John J. Zullo and dancers explored perspective and perception in a memory triptych at Danspace Project.
lead_paragraph: The choreographer John J. Zullo opened his program at Danspace Project last week with one of three dances delving into memory. In “ALL what THIS do HAS you HAPPENED see? BEFORE” — simply string together the capital or the lowercase words to create alternative and more logical titles — he explored perspective and perception by constructing dance phrases that were repeated, deconstructed and rearranged.

headline: Schumer Seeks Action on Drug Molly
abstract: Senator Charles E. Schumer said on Sunday that he was urging the federal government to increase the regulation of chemicals that can be used to make the drug molly, according to The Associated Press.
lead_paragraph: Senator Charles E. Schumer said on Sunday that he was urging the federal government to increase the regulation of chemicals that can be used to make the drug molly, according to The Associated Press. Overdoses of the drug, which is a form of MDMA, or ecstasy, have caused a string of deaths at dance festivals this year, including two at the Electric Zoo festival on Randalls Island over Labor Day weekend. Another man died this month at a festival near Sydney, Australia. Senator Schumer, Democrat of New York, said that MDMA dealers are getting around federal law by slightly tweaking the chemical composition of banned substances and that he had asked the New York and New Jersey High Intensity Drug Trafficking Area task force to shift its focus to molly labs. A related incident occurred on Saturday at a dance concert in Quassy Amusement Park in Middlebury, Conn., where seven people were treated for suspected overdoses of a hallucinogenic drug called 2C-P. About 1,200 people attended the event, which was shut down after four concertgoers collapsed around the same time.

headline: With Official’s Conviction, China Calls Attention to Its Crackdown on Corruption
abstract: With Bo Xilai banished to life in prison, the Communist Party stepped up its efforts to convince the public that his trial proved that leaders were serious about rooting out corruption.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — With one of China’s most divisive politicians, Bo Xilai, banished to life in prison on Sunday, the Communist Party stepped up its efforts to convince a scandal-weary public that the spectacle of his trial proved that national leaders were serious about rooting out official corruption.

headline: Let’s Go
abstract: Start your solving week with Susan Gelfand’s moving grid.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Welcome to another solving week here at Wordplay. Just a reminder: the Sunday puzzle contest is still going on, so please avoid discussing that puzzle in your comments. The contest closes Tuesday, Sept. 24 at 6:00 p.m. Eastern time, and you will be able to comment on it then, as well as on the Friday wrap-up post where Will Shortz will announce the winners.

headline: Youth’s Disappointments Etched Deep
abstract: “The Cure” follows a working-class Irishman on a bender in Cork, Ireland.
lead_paragraph: Michael Mellamphy is the right man to play the unnamed working-class narrator of “The Cure,”  part of Origin’s 1st Irish theater festival. For one thing, he was raised in Cork, Ireland, the setting of this one-man show, and, for another, he has the tousled look of the protagonist, who’s spent three days “on the ran-tan” (roaring drunk) after getting his holiday bonus at work.

headline: Salvatore Ferragamo Python Heels from a Desert-Inspired Collection
abstract: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway. Today’s pick: python heels from a desert-inspired collection, fit for an urban landscape.
lead_paragraph: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: Americans Approach Knockouts in Indonesia
abstract: At the world championships in Bali, Indonesia, there are three more 16-board matches to be played before the quarterfinals begin on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: At the world championships in Bali, Indonesia, there are three more 16-board matches to be played before the quarterfinals begin on Tuesday.

headline: With Third Victory in Row, Mets Climb Out of Fourth
abstract: Mets starter Carlos Torres and Wilfredo Tovar, a 22-year-old shortstop prospect, helped the Mets top the Phillies and tie Philadelphia for third place in the National League East.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — The Mets have been asked for weeks to assign meaning to their games.

headline: President Obama Honors Navy Yard Victims
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Funerals and Memorials']
abstract: President Obama spoke at a memorial service for the victims of the Washington Navy Yard shooting.
lead_paragraph: President Obama spoke at a memorial service for the victims of the Washington Navy Yard shooting.

headline: Philadelphia Raises Stakes With Plan to Reverse Blight
keywords: ['Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Abandonment (Property)', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: With an estimated 40,000 abandoned buildings, Philadelphia wants to consolidate its inventory of distressed real estate by creating a “land bank” to make purchase more attractive to buyers.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — With an estimated 40,000 abandoned houses, lots and commercial buildings, Philadelphia wants to consolidate its inventory of distressed real estate by creating a “land bank” to make purchase more attractive to potential buyers.

headline: Small Fry Feed Off Merger of Big Fish
abstract: Is big actually better or is small beautiful? Small is at least funnier, in the hands of rivals of the soon-to-merge Omnicom and Publicis.
lead_paragraph: SOME people love collecting sayings that seemingly contradict each other, like “Many hands make light work” versus “Too many cooks spoil the broth.” In the advertising business, those who believe that “Bigger is better” find themselves at odds with those who believe that “Small is beautiful.”

headline: Milan Fashion Week: Missoni Spring/Summer 2014
abstract: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.

headline: Wintour’s Reign Extends Beyond Vogue
abstract: Anna Wintour has always been a big deal, but her influence within Condé Nast is now on the march in ways that are not just reshaping the magazines but the organization.
lead_paragraph: Anna Wintour created a bit of an international incident in 2010, when she cut short her visit to Milan Fashion Week. Designers scrambled, fashion journalists pondered its deeper meaning and local officials took grave offense.

headline: A Plan to Revamp Subway Entryways Has Elements of Disneyland and Feng Shui
abstract: The changes, part of a roughly $900,000 project, have drawn on observations of train riders’ entering and exiting behaviors.
lead_paragraph: For the first time since at least the era of token fares, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority is redecorating its stations, rethinking its systemwide network of turnstiles to match ridership trends amid wide-scale demographic shifts in the city.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
abstract: Governments reports will include durable goods orders and sales of new homes for August, and companies reporting earnings will include KB Home, Bed Bath & Beyond, Nike and BlackBerry.
lead_paragraph: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data to be released will include home prices in July for 20 cities and the Conference Board’s report on consumer confidence in September (Tuesday); durable goods orders for August and sales of new homes for August (Wednesday); the final revision of the nation’s gross domestic product for the second quarter, initial applications for unemployment benefits, and pending home sales for August (Thursday); and personal spending and income for August and the University of Michigan’s consumer confidence index for September (Friday).

headline: Brooklyn Botanic Garden Defends Decision to Suspend Science Program
keywords: ['Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Flowers and Plants', 'Gardens and Gardening']
abstract: The garden, which has faced criticism for temporarily closing its science center and laying off three employees last month, cited the disrepair of the building and a $750,000 budget gap.
lead_paragraph: At Brooklyn Botanic Garden’s Science Center, a short walk from the garden’s main campus, inch-wide cracks snake across concrete floors and up walls. Hallway floors rise and fall, in fun-house fashion, and doors no longer fit in doorjambs. “This is where you really get vertigo,” said Scot Medbury, the garden’s president, moving through the stacks in the science library, which is lined with books and journals like “Compendium of Grape Diseases,” “Desert Plants” and “Starter Vegetable Gardens.”

headline: Cutting Through the Cloud
abstract: Corporate technology buyers are looking at a growing number of new and old tech companies to manage their systems.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Over the next few years, what happens to the several trillion dollars that businesses spend on technology will be decided by executives like Jeff Allen.

headline: F.A.A. Nears New Rules on Devices
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Wireless Communications', 'Handheld Computers', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Faced with the flood of personal electronics on airplanes, the government has spent the last year looking for ways to modify its policy and keep passengers safe.
lead_paragraph: The rules on when to turn off electronic devices on airplanes have long been a sour, and sometimes contentious, point for travelers. But faced with a surge of electronics on airplanes and under pressure from a growing number of tech-savvy — and increasingly tech-dependent — passengers, the Federal Aviation Administration recognized that change was inevitable.

headline: Rebels View Coalition Leadership Outside Syria as Detached From the Suffering
abstract: While the main opposition group’s leaders shuttle among fancy hotels, they seem increasingly powerless to affect the course of the war.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — With empty pockets and clothes smudged with dirt, the Syrian rebel fighter smuggled himself across the border and traveled 18 hours by bus to plead with Syrian opposition leaders meeting in a luxury hotel here to send help back home.

headline: Bale Has Setback, but His New Team Is Surging Ahead
abstract: Two goals by Cristiano Ronaldo helped Real Madrid defeat Getafe, 4-1, but Gareth Bale sat out after sustaining an injury during warm-ups at Madrid’s Santiago Bernabéu stadium.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Gareth Bale’s long-awaited home debut for Real Madrid was delayed Sunday after he injured himself warming up.

headline: Networks Go to Extremes to Promote New Shows for the Fall Season
abstract: Broadcast networks have been challenged by a continuing decline in ratings, so marketing executives have left no stone unturned in the pursuit of promotional ideas.
lead_paragraph: With a phalanx of new series to make their debuts this week against an increasingly dominant cable television lineup, broadcast television executives this summer turned to diverse promotional ideas.

headline: Candidates in Boston Struggle to Stand Out on Eve of Mayoral Vote
abstract: This is the first open mayor’s race in a generation, and no fewer than a dozen candidates are running; the top two finishers on Tuesday will face each other on Nov. 5.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Cara and Michael McGrath, both 36-year-old lawyers here, are torn over their choice for mayor. They live in affluent Beacon Hill, where Michael P. Ross, one of the mayoral candidates, is a city councilman who, they say, has done a lot for the community. But they are also drawn to John R. Connolly, a councilman at large, who has made education the centerpiece of his campaign.

headline: Milan Fashion Week: Salvatore Ferragamo Spring/Summer 2014
abstract: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Filippo Mutani.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Filippo Mutani.

headline: Path to Manning Slices Through Offensive Line, Again and Again
abstract: Giants center David Baas said he was “embarrassed, disgusted” after the offensive line allowed seven sacks of Eli Manning, six of them in the first half.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Frustrated Giants fans looking to place blame for a 38-0 loss to the Carolina Panthers at Bank of America Stadium on Sunday could find fault with just about any player on the roster.

headline: On the Red Carpet at the Emmys
abstract: Looks from the red carpet at the 65th Primetime Emmy Awards.
lead_paragraph: Looks from the red carpet at the 65th Primetime Emmy Awards.

headline: An Escape From Slavery, Now a Movie, Has Long Intrigued Historians
abstract: Solomon Northup told a story of escaping from slavery in 1853, and for decades scholars have been trying to untangle the truth of his account.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In the age of “Argo” and “Zero Dark Thirty,” questions about the accuracy of nonfiction films have become routine. With “12 Years a Slave,” based on a memoir published 160 years ago, the answers are anything but routine.

headline: Detroit Is Now a Charity Case for Carmakers
abstract: General Motors, Ford and Chrysler are investing heavily in plants from Mexico to China. Yet their operations in Detroit remain a fraction of what they were a half-century ago.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Four years after the recession and a government bailout, Detroit’s hometown automakers are riding high on strong sales and big profits.

headline: Kenya Mall Carnage Shows Shabab Resilience
abstract: The Shabab could be signaling a wider offensive, despite losses in recent years at the hands of the African Union and Kenyan troops in their home country.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — The ferocious armed political movement known as the Shabab is on the ropes in Somalia, losing territory and influence in its home country.

headline: America’s Cup Turns Into Battle as Oracle Wins Fourth Straight Race
abstract: Team New Zealand’s lead, once a seemingly impregnable 8-1, has been whittled to 8-5, and this regatta, originally scheduled to end no later than Sunday, is now extending into uncharted waters.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The loud groans that emanate from the high-tech America’s Cup catamarans as they sail on San Francisco Bay under heavy structural loads are now a good acoustic match for the groaning New Zealand fans on shore.

headline: Short of a Deal, Containing Iran Is the Best Option
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'United States International Relations', 'ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT']
abstract: Without a diplomatic deal, we will have to choose between using force to prevent Iran from acquiring a nuclear arsenal, or containing a nuclear Iran. The latter is the less-bad option.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — THIS week, Iran’s new president, Hassan Rouhani, will address the United Nations General Assembly. His message is likely to be a sharp change from the adolescent belligerence of his hard-line predecessor, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad. Mr. Rouhani is a genuine reformer — but his desire to move Iran in a new direction should not blind the United States to the difficulties of achieving a diplomatic solution.

headline: Lottery Numbers
abstract: Lottery numbers for for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Nigeria’s Long Emergency
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']
abstract: The leader of a violent religious sect might be dead, but that matters little for a country torn by regional conflict.
lead_paragraph: LAGOS, Nigeria — Last month, we Nigerians received some startling news from the army: Abubakar Shekau, the leader of the militant Islamist group Boko Haram, which has killed some 3,000 people in northern Nigeria over the last four years, “might have died.”

headline: Free to Be Hungry
keywords: ['Food Stamps', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Conservatives’ obsession with food stamps is just plain cruel.
lead_paragraph: The word “freedom” looms large in modern conservative rhetoric. Lobbying groups are given names like FreedomWorks; health reform is denounced not just for its cost but as an assault on, yes, freedom. Oh, and remember when we were supposed to refer to pommes frites as “freedom fries”?

headline: Jets Overcome Their Mistakes With One Long Pass
abstract: A 69-yard touchdown pass from Geno Smith to Santonio Holmes in the fourth quarter helped the Jets, who committed 20 penalties, defeat the Bills and improve their record to 2-1.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — On game days, Santonio Holmes wears orange-tinted contact lenses. “I can stand here and look right into this light,” Holmes said, “and I don’t have to worry about breaking my eyes.”

headline: A Jury of Whose Peers?
abstract: Why should jury duty be for citizens only?
lead_paragraph: TODAY let’s take a short break from the dismaying spectacle of everything Washington and celebrate one feature of American democracy that still pretty much works. I refer to jury duty, which, since the abolition of the draft and aside from taxes, is the most arduous chore that comes with government by the people.

headline: Citing Family for Furlough From Jail
abstract: Inmates, but especially mob suspects, have pleaded over the years with federal judges in Brooklyn for passes to attend weddings, funerals and all manner of family activities.
lead_paragraph: They were in jail on charges of murder, robbery, extortion and, of course, racketeering, but the inmates, accused of being members of La Cosa Nostra, wanted out. At least for a little while.

headline: An Important Step on Global Warming
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'Coal', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Editorials', 'Global Warming']
abstract: Despite howls by the coal industry, the Obama administration will limit power plant carbon pollution.
lead_paragraph: On Friday, in a move that has already caused dismay in industry and among Congressional Republicans, the Obama administration proposed the first-ever federal limits on power plant emissions of carbon dioxide, which account for nearly 40 percent of the greenhouse gases America contributes to a gradually warming climate.

headline: Scandalous Pensioners
abstract: The top federal prosecutor in Manhattan is right to move to seize state pensions from lawmakers convicted on corruption charges.
lead_paragraph: The top federal prosecutor in Manhattan is right to move to seize state pensions from lawmakers who are convicted of corruption charges, instead of waiting for the New York Legislature to act.

headline: Don’t Fear the Squeegee Man
abstract: In New York’s mayoral race, doomsaying is all the rage.
lead_paragraph: The New York mayor’s race is barreling toward November. The once-crowded primary bus now has just one Democrat and one Republican, Bill de Blasio and Joseph Lhota, grappling for the wheel. (An independent, Adolfo Carrión Jr., is in there, but a few rows back.)

headline: Law Opens Financing of Start-Ups to Crowds
keywords: ['Start-ups', 'Crowdfunding (Internet)', 'Law and Legislation', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Entrepreneurship']
abstract: On Monday, federal legislation goes into effect to allow small start-ups to ask for equity investments publicly without having to register the shares for public trading.
lead_paragraph: Entrepreneurs looking to the crowd to finance their big ideas just got a little extra help from the government.

headline: Humble Chinese Village Basks in Legacy of Three Kingdoms Era
abstract: Residents take pride in descending from an ancient king, and a connection with one of the towering classics of Chinese literature.
lead_paragraph: LONGMEN, China — In the shadow of a lush mountain and near a slow-moving river in southeast China sits this village, whose name means Dragon Gate.

headline: Stenson Gains an Edge From Losing a Big Lead
abstract: Sweden’s Henrik Stenson shot a final-round two-under-par 68 to finish ahead of Jordan Spieth and Steve Stricker, winning the Tour Championship and the FedEx Cup points championship.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Henrik Stenson relished the sight of a clear sky when he peeked outside his window Sunday morning.

headline: The ‘Tale of 2 Cities’ Mayoral Candidate Who Lost
abstract: Sal F. Albanese’s 1997 campaign for the Democratic mayoral nomination used the Dickens theme that Bill de Blasio adopted this year in defeating Mr. Albanese and seven other Democrats.
lead_paragraph: It became a refrain for one Democrat seeking his party’s nomination for mayor, how New York was “a tale of two cities” under the incumbent, elected on the Republican line. The man running City Hall had favored business interests over neighborhoods, this Democrat said, and had made us “more divided than ever.”

headline: Top Award Would Be Just One of Woods’s Consolations
abstract: Tiger Woods did not win a major tournament or the Tour Championship this year, but he seems likely to be voted the player of the year.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — After signing his scorecard Sunday, Tiger Woods lifted his daughter, Sam Alexis, who had run out to greet him after he putted out at No. 18 for a three-under-par 67. Woods’s par 280 finish left him tied for 22nd in the 30-man field at the Tour Championship, meaning he would not lift the FedEx Cup trophy or receive the $10 million bonus check. Both were snatched by Henrik Stenson, who overtook Woods, the leader in the playoff standings, with a three-stroke victory at East Lake Golf Club.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Monday, September 23, 2013
abstract: Quotation of the day for Monday, September 23, 2013.
lead_paragraph: “It ought to be a shock to all of us, as a nation and a people. It ought to obsess us. It ought to lead to some sort of transformation.”

headline: Chinese Titan Takes Aim at Hollywood
abstract: Wang Jianlin, reputed to be China’s richest man, announced plans to build a movie-themed real estate development in what he billed as China’s effort to become the world leader in filmmaking.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Los Angeles has film studios and the best-known movie industry award ceremonies. Orlando has amusement parks and resort hotels. Now, one of China’s richest men wants to copy them with a movie-themed real estate development in his country’s most fashionable beach city.

headline: Netanyahu Is Said to View Iran Deal as a Possible Trap
abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel plans to warn the United Nations next week that a nuclear deal with the Iranian government could be a trap, according to an Israeli official.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, stepping up his effort to blunt a diplomatic offensive by Iran, plans to warn the United Nations next week that a nuclear deal with the Iranian government could be a trap similar to one set by North Korea eight years ago, according to an Israeli official involved in drafting the speech.

headline: Shots Ring Out in Footage Recorded During Kenya Mall Attack
abstract: Video recorded during the militant attack in a Kenyan mall showed terrified customers taking cover as shots rang out.
lead_paragraph: The Chinese state television network CCTV broadcast video it said was recorded by one of its reporters inside Nairobi’s Westgate shopping mall as it came under attack from Islamist militants Saturday.

headline: The Rock of Chickamauga
keywords: ['Civil War (US) (1861-65)', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The life of Gen. George Thomas, who saved the Union Army from disaster in one of the Civil War’s bloodiest battles.
lead_paragraph: The Battle of Chickamauga, which took place in northwest Georgia on Sept. 19 and 20, 1863, was one of the bloodiest battles of the war, and a near disaster for the Union. Indeed, what might have been a game-changing defeat for the North was averted largely thanks to the battlefield leadership of a single man, Gen. George Thomas. While the Union ultimately fled the field, Thomas’s stalwart stand against an overwhelming Confederate assault saved thousands of men, who were then able to regroup and continue the Union push into Georgia.

headline: The Sun Sets on Forever
abstract: On an afternoon that felt like Old-Timers’ Day and a Hall of Fame induction, Mariano Rivera was honored by the Yankees, who were unable to deliver a victory.
lead_paragraph: Summer is over. It ended on Saturday, the day before the Yankees honored Mariano Rivera, who brought a sense of calm to their tense empire as no other pitcher has. When Rivera took the mound Sunday, just a sliver of sunlight remained on the back slope of the hill.

headline: Secret Recordings Reveal Mubarak’s Frank Views on a Range of Subjects
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States International Relations', 'Audio Recordings and Downloads']
abstract: The recordings offer a rare glimpse into former Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak’s attitudes about Washington, Israel, Jews, the Muslim Brotherhood and himself.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Hosni Mubarak looked like a stalwart American ally but worried for years that Washington was trying to oust him as president of Egypt, he confided to a doctor recently in surreptitiously recorded conversations that came to light here last week.

headline: Taylor, Proud of His Hits on the Field, Regrets the Pain He Caused Off It
abstract: The Hall of Famer Lawrence Taylor criticized rules intended to increase safety in the N.F.L., but he acknowledged mistakes that embarrassed his family and the Giants.
lead_paragraph: In the debate about safety and football, Lawrence Taylor, the original L. T., lines up squarely on the side of old-time, old-school, rough-and-tumble football. Taylor, a Giants Hall of Fame linebacker, is no fan of the new N.F.L.

headline: A Glittering Runway, as Stars Sashay Into Top Couture Ranks
abstract: In the realm of high fashion, the Emmys have long played in the minor leagues. Well, times change.
lead_paragraph: In the realm of high fashion, the eye-popping kind that has branded the Oscars as the style-world equivalent of the Super Bowl, the Emmys have long played in the minor leagues. A modest event, the show was mostly disdained by blue-chip designers, who wrote off television’s night of nights as a dreary also-ran.

headline: Robert McCabe Jr., a Kidney Donation Specialist, Dies at 88
abstract: After having a donor kidney flown to Moscow in 1979 when no domestic recipients were found, Dr. McCabe used the episode to improve the transplant donor system.
lead_paragraph: The clock was ticking. The kidneys of a 14-year-old girl who had died in a Virginia hospital had been removed from her body with her parents’ consent, in the hope that the organs might extend the life of others. But with only a rudimentary computer network available to help them in 1979, officials at the hospital, Norfolk General, could not find a suitable recipient for one of the kidneys, and they knew they had only 72 hours, at most, to do so.

headline: Day’s Best in the N.F.L.
abstract: The top performers and key injuries in Week 3 of the N.F.L. season.
lead_paragraph: Cowboys defensive end DeMarcus Ware matched Harvey Martin’s 30-year-old franchise record by recording his 114th career sack in the first half against the Rams. He got to Sam Bradford again in the third quarter to surpass Martin, with Dallas recording six sacks in total against a St. Louis team that had not allowed one in four games dating to last season. Ware’s teammate DeMarco Murray had success against the Rams, too: he ran for 175 yards two years after setting a franchise rushing record with 253 against St. Louis as a rookie.

headline: Lower Health Insurance Premiums to Come at Cost of Fewer Choices
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Doctors', 'Hospitals']
abstract: With insurance marketplaces set to open next month under the new health care law, consumers may find that insurers have put big limits on their choices.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Federal officials often say that health insurance will cost consumers less than expected under President Obama’s health care law. But they rarely mention one big reason: many insurers are significantly limiting the choices of doctors and hospitals available to consumers.

headline: A Mayoral Hopeful Now, de Blasio Was Once a Young Leftist
abstract: As a fresh-faced activist, Bill de Blasio was influenced by a socialist movement in Nicaragua that strengthened his view that government should protect and enhance the lives of the poor.
lead_paragraph: The scruffy young man who arrived in Nicaragua in 1988 stood out.

headline: Give Yourself 5 Stars? Online, It Might Cost You
keywords: ['Consumer Protection', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Online Advertising', 'Computers and the Internet', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']
abstract: A yearlong investigation by New York regulators has resulted in the most comprehensive crackdown to date on deceptive reviews on the Internet.
lead_paragraph: “I celebrate myself, and sing myself,” wrote Walt Whitman, America’s great bard of self-promotion. As the world goes ever more digital, quite a few businesses are adopting that philosophy — hiring a veritable chorus of touts to sing their nonexistent praises and lure in customers.

headline: Dolan Calls Pope’s Tone on Sexual Morality a ‘Breath of Fresh Air’
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Three days after Pope Francis chastised the Roman Catholic Church for adhering too rigidly to dogma, Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan, the archbishop of New York, conveyed his approval.
lead_paragraph: Three days after Pope Francis set a new tone for the Roman Catholic Church, Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan, the archbishop of New York, embraced the “magnificent interview” in which the pope chastised the church for its obsession with sexual morality, and called him “a breath of fresh air.”

abstract: Juan Perez, a Giants rookie who nabbed Robinson Cano in the eighth inning, trained as a teenager next to the old Yankee Stadium.
lead_paragraph: As a teenager growing up in the Bronx, Juan Perez spent many nights training at a running track adjacent to the old Yankee Stadium.

lead_paragraph: When AMC’s “Breaking Bad” comes to an end next week, you can finally breathe again.

headline: Strong Chinese Manufacturing Data Points to Turnaround
abstract: The initial HSBC purchasing managers index for September shows expansion accelerating to a six-month high.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A China manufacturing index hit its highest level in six months on Monday, offering the first important measure of how the country’s economy performed in September and showing that a tentative reacceleration has continued as government support and firmer demand for Chinese exports have gained traction.

abstract: The Yankees and their fans celebrated the 19-year run of the career saves leader.
lead_paragraph: The Yankees and their fans celebrated the 19-year run of the career saves leader.

keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Biological and Chemical Warfare']
abstract: Samantha Power, the American ambassador to the United Nations, will be on the spot as her performance at the General Assembly this week will help determine the country’s future course in Syria.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — Nearly a year before the world woke up to images of Syrians dying in a large-scale chemical weapons attack, Samantha Power was quietly pushing President Obama for a military strike to stop what she calls the “grotesque tactics” of President Bashar al-Assad. For a fleeting moment this month, it seemed she had prevailed.

lead_paragraph: From time to time, the Center for Science in the Public Interest, a Washington-based advocacy group, prepares an updated “report card” on changes in the American diet. The latest, collated by the nutritionist Bonnie Liebman and published in the September issue of the center’s Nutrition Action Newsletter, is not one Americans should be especially proud of.

lead_paragraph: Nancy Folbre is professor emerita of economics at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst.

headline: Collectors of Royalties for Music Publishers May See Better Results
abstract: Broadcast Music Inc. will report a 5 percent uptick in revenues to around $944 million for the year ended in June.
lead_paragraph: The music industry is used to bad news. When the International Federation of the Phonographic Industry announced that record sales in 2012 had their first yearly uptick since 1999, for example, there was jubilation in the record business — even though the gain was only 0.3 percent.

headline: What’s on Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (CBS) HOSTAGES Toni Collette stars as Dr. Ellen Sanders, whose husband (Tate Donovan) and children are taken captive by a rogue F.B.I. agent (Dylan McDermott, above with Ms. Collette), who then orders her to kill the president of the United States (James Naughton) during surgery. The show is “suspenseful and artfully layered,” Alessandra Stanley wrote in The New York Times, featuring lead characters who “are enemies with a special connection.” But, she added, “the premise that pits them against each other is almost impossible to prolong.” Once the mystery is solved, and the crisis is over, she said, “any prolongation turns into soap opera — and not the fun, campy kind on ‘Scandal’ or ‘Revenge.’ ”

headline: The Old Guard Keeps Its Grip
abstract: Despite all the fear and anxiety, Netflix didn’t steal Emmy night in the end as established series like AMC’s “Breaking Bad” and “Modern Family” on ABC took top awards.
lead_paragraph: Despite all the fear and anxiety, Netflix didn’t steal the night in the end. “Modern Family” on ABC won the Emmy for best comedy, which was almost a surprise because it has won so many times before and because other shows, like “Veep” of HBO, have gained ground. “Breaking Bad,” on the other hand, is about to end its run, so it was almost inevitable that that AMC hit would get yet another standing ovation.

headline: Honors for ‘Breaking Bad’ and ‘Modern Family’
abstract: It was a night of upsets at the 65th Primetime Emmy Awards, in which several HBO series won unexpected victories.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — On Sunday, a mere seven days before its very last episode, AMC’s “Breaking Bad” finally earned the outstanding drama Emmy award that it had been denied for years.

headline: James Levine at the Metropolitan Opera
abstract: Mr. Levine returned to the Met to conduct Mozart’s “Così Fan Tutte” in 2013, after two years’ absence.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Levine returned to the Met to conduct Mozart’s “Così Fan Tutte” in 2013, after two years’ absence.

headline: Met’s Maestro Heading Back to His Podium
abstract: James Levine is to return to the podium of the Met after an absence of more than two years brought on by health problems.
lead_paragraph: When James Levine comes home on Tuesday night for his first performance at the Metropolitan Opera since he fell and damaged his spine more than two years ago, he will conduct Mozart’s “Così Fan Tutte” from a wheelchair-accessible orchestra pit, with new lifts and ramps to help him steer his chair to the rising mechanical podium that stagehands call the “maestro lift.”

headline: Behind the Scenes With James Levine, in Full Preseason Swing
abstract: James Levine has been his old, larger-than-life self in rehearsals leading up to his return to the Met podium on Tuesday, after more than two years.
lead_paragraph: As James Levine prepared to return to the Metropolitan Opera House to conduct his first performance there since he was sidelined by a severe spinal injury two years ago, he invited a reporter to watch how he gets ready for the season. He rehearsed the Met Orchestra for a future Carnegie Hall concert. He held a sitzprobe — an unstaged rehearsal with the cast of Mozart’s “Così Fan Tutte” — in a large rehearsal room on C Level, three floors below the Met’s vast stage. He then held a piano rehearsal for singers in List Hall, the small hall off the Met’s main auditorium, where latecomers are sometimes sent to wait for the next intermission.

headline: Kenya Forces Said to Be Securing Mall After Long Standoff
abstract: The bloody standoff at a Kenyan shopping mall edged closer to a conclusion on Monday night, with Kenyan officials saying that there were no more civilians trapped inside.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — The bloody standoff at a Kenyan shopping mall edged closer to a conclusion on Monday night, with Kenyan officials saying that their troops were securing the building and that there were no more civilians trapped inside.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Terror at a Nairobi Shopping Mall
abstract: What group is responsible for the siege of a shopping mall in Kenya?
lead_paragraph: In “Kenyans Move to End Siege of Mall In Nairobi,” Nicholas Kulish and Jeffrey Gettleman write about the events that occurred in the past few days in Nairobi, Kenya.

headline: Re-election in Hand, Merkel Moves to Form New German Government
abstract: Fresh off a commanding election victory, Chancellor Angela Merkel and her Christian Democrats took early steps toward forming a new government.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Chancellor Angela Merkel took steps on Monday to form a new government, a day after she scored a stunning personal triumph in German national elections that cemented her position as the most powerful politician in Europe.

headline: A Haitian State of Mind
abstract: Paolo Woods sought out Haiti as a place to ponder the meaning of the state and statehood, taking photographs that eschew the jarring visual tropes of misery, grime and violence.
lead_paragraph: Growing up in Italy as the child of a Dutch mother and a Canadian father, Paolo Woods was fascinated by the notion of the state. How does where you live, and how you live, shape individual and national identity? To find out, he moved to a country most often described as anything but a state: Haiti.

headline: Do You Always Have Your Phone or Tablet at Your Side?
abstract: Student Opinion | Do you set limits on being accessible via phone and social media?
lead_paragraph: “Disconnecting is a luxury that we all need,” says one of the people quoted in an article about cutting down on cellphone and other device use.

abstract: What you need to know in New York for Monday: U.N. traffic mess, splendid weather and a vigilante bike lane.
lead_paragraph: Updated 12:01 p.m. | As the United Nations General Assembly convenes in the city this week, tempers will flare. Progress will be slow. As the hours drag on, hopelessness may set in.

headline: Why Not Keep Your Favorite Car Forever?
abstract: Grace Braeger has had her ’57 Chevy since it was new, and Irv Gordon just drove the ’66 Volvo he bought new past the 3 million mile mark. So what about the rest of us?
lead_paragraph: Cars can be like significant others. If the relationship is tumultuous, you can emerge from it with more gray hair than when it began. But when you’ve found “the one,” there’s a chance you’ll know immediately.

headline: Euro Zone Business Activity Rises
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Economic growth in the 17 members of the euro zone appears to have accelerated modestly in the third quarter, according to a survey of purchasing managers.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Economic growth in the 17 European Union states in the euro zone appears to have accelerated modestly in the third quarter from the previous three months, according to a private sector report released on Monday.

lead_paragraph: In the 1950s, thalidomide cut a wide swath of destruction across the world, leaving behind thousands of deformed infants, but that was only the beginning of the story.

headline: Daily Report: With Cloud Computing, Companies Face a Glut of Tech Choices

lead_paragraph: As big business hitches its computer systems to the latest technology wave, Jeff Allen and executives like him will have the tricky job of ensuring that old systems work with the many new systems finding their way into his company, Quentin Hardy reports.

headline: The Death and Afterlife of Thalidomide
keywords: ['Thalidomide (Drug)', 'Birth Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Morning Sickness', 'Cancer', "Leprosy (Hansen's Disease)", "Crohn's Disease"]
abstract: This Retro Report video revisits the horrors that followed use of thalidomide by pregnant women in the 1950s and the drug’s startling re-emergence.
lead_paragraph: The story of thalidomide, told in this week’s Retro Report video, is one of the most shameful in the history of the modern pharmaceutical industry.

headline: Singapore to Give Citizens Priority for Job Openings
abstract: A new policy requires job openings to be posted in the city-state before they are offered to overseas workers.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The government of Singapore announced measures on Monday that will compel companies to give priority to local residents in the job recruitment process, a move that could create more challenges for multinational firms doing business in the Southeast Asian city-state.

headline: Four Things to Remember When You’re Feeling Spent
abstract: First of all, it’s important to understand that — under certain circumstances — it’s O.K. to quit.
lead_paragraph: A few months ago I was talking to a 31-year-old entrepreneur, Aalap Shah, who is a co-founder of SoMe, a social media consulting company in Chicago. I have known him for a couple of years now, and this time he didn’t seem to be his usual chipper self.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Sept. 23, 2013

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Paul Tullis on Understanding Wildfires
abstract: How the Tunnel fire of 1991 ignited the writer’s interest in fires.
lead_paragraph: Paul Tullis, a contributing writer for the magazine and the features editor of TakePart, is the author of this week’s cover story about how a new understanding of the way wildfires spread might be able to help us manage them better, make forests healthier and keep people and property safer. His last article for the magazine was about restorative justice.

headline: Week 3 Quick Hits: Takeaways on Steelers and Bears
abstract: The Steelers still may have the stingiest defense in football, but they’re 0-3 and the Bears are 3-0.
lead_paragraph: Despite a 40-23 loss to the Bears that dropped the Steelers to 0-3 Sunday night, Pittsburgh still may have the stingiest defense in football. But it’s a unit that has failed to generate turnovers. Pittsburgh is the only N.F.L. team not to have any take-aways through three games.

headline: Human Trafficking Continues to Ravage Jharkhand
keywords: ['Human Trafficking', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Police', 'Sex Crimes', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: More than 100,000 girls, mostly from tribal communities, are trafficked from the eastern Indian state of Jharkhand every year, according to the state government statistics.
lead_paragraph: BHOOT, Jharkhand— Suman Tutti, 11, a frail, shy girl from Bhoot village, around 35 kilometers, or 21 miles from Ranchi, the capital of the eastern state of Jharkhand, is one of the 100,000 girls who are trafficked from the state every year, according to the state government statistics.

headline: Life in a Russian Prison
abstract: Nadezhda Tolokonnikova of the punk group Pussy Riot has given up her struggle to keep the peace and has declared war on her jailers. But only after they threatened to kill her.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — “I am declaring a hunger strike starting Sept. 23. I refuse to take part in slave labor in the camp until the penal colony authorities start to conduct themselves in accordance with laws and start treating women inmates like people rather than cattle.” After a year-and-a-half behind bars, Nadezhda Tolokonnikova has given up her struggle to keep the peace and has declared war on her jailers.  But only after they threatened to kill her.

headline: Under Fire From Investors, CommonWealth to Change Its Ways
keywords: ['Boards of Directors', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Real Estate Investment Trusts', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism']
abstract: The real estate investment trust CommonWealth said on Monday that it was updating its corporate governance structure and compensation model after months of pressure from activist investors.
lead_paragraph: The real estate investment trust CommonWealth has finally decided to listen to its shareholders. But not all investors feel as if they are being heard.

headline: BlackBerry’s Prospects Are Muddied
abstract: A BlackBerry co-founder is weighing a possible bid for the troubled company. | JPMorgan Chase’s general counsel once called for more corporate accountability when he worked as a regulator. | Vivendi and Activision Blizzard have been tripped up on their new deal by their old one.
lead_paragraph: Mike Lazaridis, the co-founder of BlackBerry who stepped down as co-chief executive last year, has contacted private equity firms about a possible bid for the troubled company, David Gelles and Michael J. de la Merced report in DealBook. He has separately approached the Blackstone Group and the Carlyle Group about making an offer, according to people familiar with the matter, who cautioned that the talks were preliminary and might not lead to any bids.

headline: Asia at Risk as Economies Put Off the Inevitable
abstract: The Fed’s decision to continue its stimulus program is a temporary reprieve — one that could tempt Asian policy makers to put off structural changes.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Economists say the Federal Reserve’s decision to keep pumping money into the American economy is only a temporary reprieve for Asia — one that could tempt policy makers in the region to put off the structural changes they believe are essential to improve long-term growth prospects across the region.

headline: Giorgio Armani: Spring 2014 RTW
abstract: Milan
lead_paragraph: Milan

headline: Typhoon Kills at Least 25 People in China, Reports Say
abstract: A powerful typhoon that had threatened Hong Kong brushed past, but crashed into a mountainous area of Guangdong Province, according to the local news media.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — A powerful typhoon that had threatened Hong Kong brushed past the southern Chinese city on Sunday night and crashed into Guangdong Province. The local news media said at least 25 people were killed.

headline: Apple Sells Nine Million New iPhones in First Weekend
abstract: That compares to five million iPhone 5 smartphones sold last year in the first weekend that device went on sale. But this year, for the first time, two models went on sale at once.
lead_paragraph: For Apple, the release of two new iPhone models has already resulted in nearly double the sales of previous releases.

headline: Where Are The Austerian Economists?
abstract: Does it even matter?
lead_paragraph: I’ve been part of a discussion over the direction of economic policy debate — as opposed to the direction of actual economic policy — in which an interesting question has been raised: which prominent economists are now making the best case for fiscal austerity? It’s a tough question to answer, because at this point it’s hard to find any prominent economists making that case.

headline: Modern Applied Macro
abstract: Some reading for the wonkish.
lead_paragraph: I’ve mentioned David Romer’s nice formulation of modern applied macro — the way people actually think, as opposed to the intertemporal maximization with whipped cream that’s respectable. David now informs me that he has a set of publicly available class notes (pdf) that have been regularly updated, covering that ground even better — with an extensive section on the liquidity trap.

headline: History Is On Sale at a Venerable Paris Hotel
abstract: About to undergo a renovation, the Hotel Plaza Athénée Paris will hold an auction of collectibles, some vintage and some not.
lead_paragraph: For those inspired by hotel design, there is now a chance to take some of it home, legally. The 100-year-old Hotel Plaza Athénée Paris will hold its first auction of vintage and not-so-old collectibles as it prepares to close for a seven-month renovation.

headline: In Supreme Court Opinions, Web Links to Nowhere
abstract: According to a new study, 49 percent of the hyperlinks in Supreme Court decisions no longer work.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Supreme Court opinions have come down with a bad case of link rot. According to a new study, 49 percent of the hyperlinks in Supreme Court decisions no longer work.

headline: Video: Watching the Finale of ‘Dexter’
abstract: Mike Hale, a television critic for The Times, breaks down Sunday’s series-ending episode of “Dexter” on Showtime.
lead_paragraph: Mike Hale, a television critic for The Times, breaks down Sunday’s series-ending episode of “Dexter,” the Showtime serial killer drama starring Michael C. Hall. There are spoilers.

headline: On ‘Breaking Bad,’ a Shout-Out to Sorkin
abstract: In Sunday night’s episode of AMC’s “Breaking Bad,” Charlie Rose, portraying himself, cites a fictional column by Andrew Ross Sorkin about a $28 million charitable donation that is made after news linking a drug company’s founders to a meth dealer.
lead_paragraph: In Sunday night’s episode of AMC’s “Breaking Bad,” Charlie Rose, portraying himself, cites a fictional column by Andrew Ross Sorkin about a $28 million charitable donation that is made after news linking a drug company’s founders to a meth dealer.

headline: Weekend Gun Report: September 20-22, 2013
abstract: A weekend in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: What will Wayne LaPierre will say after each mass shooting, and how long will he wait to say it? It’s a question that’s turned into something of a media parlor game. On Sunday, LaPierre, the executive vice president of the National Rifle Association, went on “Meet the Press” and blamed last Monday’s shooting at the Washington Navy Yard not on the ease with which someone so obviously mentally ill could legally purchase guns, but on a lack of security at the shooting site.

headline: Free Cable for Building Managers, but With Fine Print
keywords: ['Cable Television', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Building Service Employees', 'Television']
abstract: In recent years, concerns have bubbled up that Time Warner’s contracts with apartment building employees are deputizing them to carry out the company’s business, thus creating a conflict.
lead_paragraph: Tom Hogan misses the History Channel.

headline: Today in Small Business: JOBS Act
abstract: It may now be cheaper to manufacture in China. The price of writing a fake review. Why Microsoft will keep making Surface tablets.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Turkey’s Chief European Union Negotiator Acknowledges Turkey May Never Join Bloc
abstract: Turkey’s European Union affairs minister, Egemen Bagis, said Saturday that Turkey would probably never join the union, the world’s biggest trading bloc.
lead_paragraph: It has been an open secret for years that Turkey, a majority Muslim country with a strong dose of national pride, would reject joining the European Union rather than waiting for the bloc to deny it entry.

headline: ScienceTake: How a Dragonfly Hunts
abstract: Marveling at the efficiency of the dragonfly, a stone-cold killer in the skies.
lead_paragraph: Marveling at the efficiency of the dragonfly, a stone-cold killer in the skies.

headline: ScienceTake: The Cheetah’s Agility
abstract: They are the fastest animals on land, but new research shows that much of cheetahs' predatory success is based not on sprinting, but on stopping and starting with extraordinary agility.
lead_paragraph: They are the fastest animals on land, but new research shows that much of cheetahs' predatory success is based not on sprinting, but on stopping and starting with extraordinary agility.

headline: ScienceTake: Tiny Bat, Long Tongue
abstract: How does Pallas's long-tongued bat collect nectar midflight? By using a long, barb-lined tongue, of course.
lead_paragraph: How does Pallas's long-tongued bat collect nectar midflight? By using a long, barb-lined tongue, of course.

headline: ScienceTake: A Thresher's Deadly Tail
abstract: The tail of the thresher shark is not just for show -- it's for hunting.
lead_paragraph: The tail of the thresher shark is not just for show -- it's for hunting.

headline: ScienceTake: How Dolphins Know Who’s Who
abstract: We all know that dolphins are smart animals, but scientists have found that these creatures create their own names and respond when they are called.
lead_paragraph: We all know that dolphins are smart animals, but scientists have found that these creatures create their own names and respond when they are called.

headline: Johnson Controls Introduces a Dual-Voltage System for Mild Hybrids

lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT – Johnson Controls used the car show here last Wednesday to introduce its Micro Hybrid battery system, which is designed to help mild hybrid cars achieve better fuel economy.
