abstract: The first of our new ScienceTake series examines how a kind of bacteria can organize coordinated, wavelike attacks on prey using a stealth communication system.
lead_paragraph: The first of our new ScienceTake series examines how a kind of bacteria can organize coordinated, wavelike attacks on prey using a stealth communication system.

headline: For 2nd Generation of Surface, Tweaks From Microsoft
abstract: The Surface, which has sold poorly compared with the Apple iPad, will undergo only subtle adjustments, a sign that Microsoft still believes in its vision for the device.
lead_paragraph: REDMOND, Wash. — Weak reaction to important new Microsoft products rarely discourages the company — instead, it usually tweaks the products over and over.

headline: Scans More Likely if Doctors Have Financial Stake
abstract: A new study suggests that doctors with a financial interest in M.R.I. machines may be more likely to order the scans even when clinical findings suggest they are unnecessary.
lead_paragraph: A new study has found that patients are more likely to have magnetic resonance imaging scans that indicate nothing is wrong if they are referred by a doctor who owns the machine. The scientists conclude that doctors with a financial interest in the machines may be more likely to order M.R.I.s even when clinical findings suggest they are unnecessary.

headline: LDF Highlights
abstract: Some of the thousands of designs that were on display from South Kensington to Shoreditch.
lead_paragraph: Some of the thousands of designs that were on display from South Kensington to Shoreditch.

headline: Its Main Mission: Forever Stamps
abstract: The new stamp gallery at the Smithsonian National Postal Museum, which opened on Sunday, has innovative displays devoted to an object on the brink of extinction.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It could easily be a glorious Pharaonic tomb, stocked with all the sustenance a philatelist might require for the afterlife. The William H. Gross Stamp Gallery, which opened on Sunday here at the Smithsonian National Postal Museum, includes an $18 million array of display spaces, artifacts, trays and touch screens. Its 20,000 items have been culled from more than 6 million at the museum, one of the world’s great collections. And the gallery’s 12,000 square feet are devoted to a single object that seems on the brink of extinction: the postage stamp.

headline: Aftermath of Pakistani Church Attack
abstract: A suicide bombing at All Saints Church in Peshawar, Pakistan, killed at least 78 people.
lead_paragraph: A suicide bombing at All Saints Church in Peshawar, Pakistan, killed at least 78 people.

headline: ‘String Bean’ Is Not a Compliment
abstract: The men who affectionately tease my daughter for being skinny know better than to tease a girl for being overweight. But what’s probably intended as praise can still make a girl feel small.
lead_paragraph: It’s 1981, I’m in seventh grade, and my father is trying to guess how much my friend weighs.

headline: On JPMorgan and What Makes a Criminal Case
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Securities and Commodities Violations']
abstract: The decision to charge two lower level JPMorgan employees, but not top executives, in the case of the so-called London Whale underlines the fact that prosecutors and the police have enormous discretion over whether to bring charges.
lead_paragraph: The case of the so-called London Whale presents an interesting contrast in how the government pursues corporate wrongdoing. While two lower-level employees of JPMorgan Chase were formally indicted last week for their role in the credit derivatives trading that caused over $6 billion in losses, the bank itself faced only civil charges that it settled by paying $920 million. No higher level individuals were accused of violations.

headline: Image of the Day: Sept. 23
abstract: Stephan Winkelmann, chief executive officer of Lamborghini, during the inauguration of a new dealership in New Delhi.

headline: Remembering Sister Nora, a Nun Fiercely Devoted to Children of the Bronx
abstract: Sister Nora McArt, who spent four decades teaching at St. Martin of Tours in Crotona and fought to keep the school open, died on Friday at 68.
lead_paragraph: Septembers have been cruel to the people of Crotona ever since St. Martin of Tours grammar school closed in 2011. Last year, it brought the death of the Rev. John C. Flynn, the longtime pastor and “people’s priest,” who fought to save the doomed Bronx school. This year it brings the passing of Sister Nora McArt, the silver-haired nun who spent four decades teaching the children of that parish.

headline: The Pyramid Problem
abstract: In 1980 Daniel Lowen outwitted a national merit exam administered by the National Testing Service. Can you find the same mistake that he did?
lead_paragraph: We’ve got something a little different this week — a two-part puzzle we’ll be revealing over two consecutive days. Come back tomorrow to find Part 2 included as an update to this blog post.

headline: Video Chat on Chinese Cooking at Home
abstract: Fuchsia Dunlop, the author of “Every Grain of Rice,” joined Julia Moskin and three home cooks to discuss everyday Chinese cooking.
lead_paragraph: Today, Julia Moskin and the author Fuchsia Dunlop joined three home cooks for a live Recipe Lab video chat to discuss healthful, everyday Chinese cooking, and the gong bao chicken with peanuts from Ms. Dunlop’s newest book, “Every Grain of Rice.” You can watch a replay of the chat above.

headline: Number of Illegal Immigrants in U.S. May Be on Rise Again, Estimates Say
abstract: The new information comes as Congress debates an immigration overhaul that could include a pathway to legal status or citizenship.
lead_paragraph: About 11.7 million immigrants are living in the United States illegally, a population that has not varied much over the last three years but may recently be increasing again, according to new estimates published Monday by the Pew Research Center Hispanic Trends Project.

headline: When There’s No Family
abstract: For elderly adults without relatives, it’s hard to implement advance directives.
lead_paragraph: I rarely write about advance directives and end-of-life discussions without a few readers asking, sometimes plaintively: What if you don’t have a family?

headline: 6 Days, 6 Teams: A.L. Wild-Card Intrigue
abstract: The Orioles could be eliminated from wild-card contention on Tuesday night in the American League race.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 1:06 p.m. Sept. 24 |

headline: Food Matters | Stockholm’s New Casual Bistros
abstract: In the midst of the New Nordic food movement, Stockholm’s top chefs are resurrecting the traditional bakficka, or “back pocket” bistro, offering menus that tend to be both innovative and casual.
lead_paragraph: Swedes pride themselves on egalitarianism, but memorable midpriced meals have remained elusive even as the New Nordic food movement spawns innovative fine dining all over Stockholm. To fill the void, the city’s top chefs have resurrected the traditional bakficka, or “back-pocket” bistro, which offers a more casual menu.

headline: McConnell’s Deal-Making Yields to Politicking
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, Senate', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: As Congress nears another budget abyss, Senator Mitch McConnell is balancing leadership demands with re-election ones.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At the climax of each of the fiscal crises that have paralyzed the nation’s capital since the Republican landslide of 2010, Senator Mitch McConnell, the wily Kentuckian who leads the Senate Republicans, has stepped in to untangle the seemingly hopeless knots threatening the economy.

headline: When Labeling Yourself Middle Class Can Hold You Back
keywords: ['Income', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Financial Planners']
abstract: Investing and financial planning should be on the agenda of middle class families, not just wealthy people.
lead_paragraph: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah, and is the director of investor education at the BAM Alliance. His sketches are archived on Your Money.

headline: Ruth Patrick, a Pioneer in Science and Pollution Control Efforts, Is Dead at 105
abstract: Dr. Patrick, one of the country’s leading experts in the study of freshwater ecosystems, or limnology, was an innovator of a number of environmental practices and principles.
lead_paragraph: Ruth Patrick, a pioneer in studying the health of freshwater streams and rivers who laid the scientific groundwork for modern pollution control efforts, died on Monday in Lafayette Hill, Pa. She was 105.

headline: Fade to BlackBerry
abstract: Once the device of choice for a rich and mobile class, the BlackBerry is now seen as little more than a mark of white-collar servitude.
lead_paragraph: The dawn of the new millennium brought a gadget like no other. More than a cellphone, the BlackBerry offered users something novel in the blossoming age of e-mail: liberation from the desk. This made it the device of choice for a rich and mobile class, eventually spawning an aspirational market beyond Wall Street. Fittingly, BlackBerry’s demise is occurring with the device as little more than a mark of white-collar servitude.

headline: 11 Officers Killed as Taliban Strike Afghan Border Post
abstract: The attack, in which the Taliban used heavy weapons, took place against a series of border check posts in the Shorabak District of Kandahar Province.
lead_paragraph: LASHKAR GAH, Afghanistan — A Taliban ambush on a border post in southern Afghanistan killed 11 police officers, an Afghan police official said on Monday.

headline: Science Events: Live Radio and Kepler on Stage
abstract: October events at the intersection of science and culture.
lead_paragraph: October events at the intersection of science and culture.

headline: Easing Into Fall, Taking Eggplant With You
keywords: ['Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Recipes', 'Eggplants', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: Five recipes for putting the final summer bounty of “meaty,” delicious eggplant to good use.
lead_paragraph: Even though it’s officially autumn, the summer crop of eggplant is still in full swing at farmers’ markets across the country. I’ve been buying them in all shapes and sizes — small, delicate Italian eggplants and paler Asian eggplants that I buy both at farmers’ markets and at my local Iranian market, as well as the familiar globe eggplants that are widely available in both farmers’ markets and supermarkets.

headline: Balkan Eggplant and Chile Purée
abstract: A delicious spread that works well with warm pita bread or toasted pita triangles.
lead_paragraph: This is an eggplant-centric version of ajvar (pronounced “eye-var), the Balkan red pepper and eggplant relish. Serve it with toasted pita triangles or warm pita bread. It differs from other eggplant purées because once the eggplant is cooked and puréed with the other ingredients, the purée itself is simmered until thick.

headline: North Korea Learning to Make Crucial Nuclear Parts, Study Finds
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT']
abstract: Scientists have learned how to produce components of gas centrifuges inside the isolated country, undermining sanctions, according to an analysis by two American arms control experts.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korean scientists have learned to produce crucial components of gas centrifuges inside their isolated country, undermining years of export controls and sanctions intended to stop the country’s enrichment of uranium for nuclear weapons, according to an analysis by two American arms control experts made available on Monday.

headline: Merkel Wins Big in German Election
abstract: Chancellor Angela Merkel scored a stunning personal triumph Sunday in the national elections in Germany.
lead_paragraph: Chancellor Angela Merkel scored a stunning personal triumph Sunday in the national elections in Germany.

headline: A Vexing Season Is Ending Early for Sabathia
abstract: C. C. Sabathia, who was 14-13 with a 4.78 earned run average this year, with one more start to go, will require a recovery period of about eight weeks, the Yankees said.
lead_paragraph: In a season plagued by injuries, it probably came as no surprise to the Yankees that one of their best players was hurt in the final days. C. C. Sabathia became the latest victim of the Yankees’ yearlong injury epidemic during his last start Friday when he sustained a left hamstring strain, the Yankees announced Monday.

headline: Sabotaging Health Care
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Political Advertising']
abstract: Wildly misleading ads aim to discourage young people from signing up for health insurance exchanges.
lead_paragraph: A Koch-brothers funded conservative group, Generation Opportunity, is out with a wildly misleading, pernicious set of ads aimed at sabotaging the Affordable Care Act by discouraging young people from signing up for health insurance exchanges.

abstract: In a statement released by Bill de Blasio’s campaign, President Obama said Mr. de Blasio’s platform of “progressive change” would make him “a great mayor.”
lead_paragraph: What a difference four years makes.

lead_paragraph: HARRISON, N.J. — Red Bulls goalkeeper Luis Robles is first to admit his play early in the season did little to engender confidence from his coach, teammates and fans.

headline: France Sets Conditions for Including Iran, an Assad Ally, in Syria Peace Talks
abstract: Iran’s new foreign minister is to meet with the five permanent Security Council members and Germany this week at the United Nations, according to their envoy.
lead_paragraph: In a softening of the Western stance on Iran, France’s foreign minister said on Monday that Iran could be included, under certain conditions, in a Geneva conference that would seek to negotiate an end to Syria’s bloody civil war.

headline: Guantánamo Hunger Strike Is Largely Over, U.S. Says
abstract: The military said the number of hunger strikers had dropped significantly since mid-July, and a lawyer for the detainees said they had largely achieved their goals.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The military on Monday effectively pronounced the end of a mass hunger strike among detainees at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba — a six-month protest that at one point swept through a majority of the inmate population, refocused global attention on the prison, and pushed the Obama administration to revive the effort to shutter it.

headline: Walkabout: F.A.A. Nears New Rules on Devices; A Blow to Kenya’s Tourism
abstract: A weekly capsule of travel news curated by our writers and editors.

lead_paragraph: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

headline: BlackBerry Buyout Offer Raises Array of Questions
abstract: BlackBerry said on Monday that it had reached an agreement to sell the company for $9 a share to a group led by Fairfax Financial Holdings. The proposed deal values the faltering smartphone maker at about $4.7 billion.
lead_paragraph: An offer to take BlackBerry private does not end the uncertainty surrounding the ailing smartphone maker.

headline: Jailed Member of Pussy Riot Announces That She’s on a Hunger Strike
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Hunger Strikes', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Russian Orthodox Church', 'Sentences (Criminal)']
abstract: In an open letter, Nadezhda Tolokonnikova, a member of Pussy Riot, the group known for staging “punk protests” in brightly colored balaclavas, described harsh and punitive prison conditions.
lead_paragraph: One of two members of a female punk rock collective jailed for staging a protest against Russian President Vladimir V. Putin in an Orthodox church announced a hunger strike on Monday, citing brutal conditions and threats of violence from guards in a prison camp in the remote Russian region of Mordovia.

headline: Breaking Bad: The Gray Matter of Charity
abstract: The column everyone is talking about: Elliott and Gretchen Schwartz vs. Walter White.
lead_paragraph: On “Breaking Bad” on Sunday night, Charlie Rose referred to a column by Andrew Ross Sorkin in The New York Times. Here is an excerpt from that fictional column:

headline: A Dream River in Iceland Rich With Salmon
abstract: The Midfjardara River in northwest Iceland required only a single-handed rod for salmon fishing.
lead_paragraph: MIDFJARDARA RIVER, Iceland — Along this river in Iceland’s cold northwest, the world is reduced to its bare components: rocks, grass, water and fish. The view is as uncomplicated and as beautiful as a well-constructed haiku. The scale of the river is inviting and intimate. Its twisting course cuts through black lava canyons and tumbles over numerous waterfalls, pausing only to collect itself in the deep runs and deeper holding pools in which its salmon wait.

headline: Attack of the Killer Hipsters
abstract: Democrats, Republicans, and the battle of the exchanges.
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Chait has an excellent survey of the current state of the battle for health reform. Among other things, it drives home the extent to which — despite all the glitches likely in the first few months — this is now being fought on favorable terrain for the reformers.

headline: Austen’s Ring to Stay in Britain
abstract: A gold and turquoise ring once owned by Jane Austen and purchased by the singer Kelly Clarkson at auction last year will be staying in Great Britain, thanks to a successful fund-raising campaign by the Jane Austen’s House Museum in Hampshire.
lead_paragraph: A gold and turquoise ring once owned by Jane Austen and purchased by the singer Kelly Clarkson at auction last year will be staying in England, thanks to a successful fund-raising campaign by the Jane Austen’s House Museum in Hampshire.

headline: Triple Play: Week 25 Results
abstract: Put your predictive skills to the test each week of the baseball season.
lead_paragraph: The feisty Royals took two of three games from both the Indians and the Rangers last week, and yet they begin the final week of the season three and a half games out of the last wild-card spot with seven games to play. The Bats blog’s crack baseball committee gathered and decided that since those seven games are against the lowly Mariners (3) and White Sox (4), the Royals are still in the race.

headline: Weekly News Quiz | Sept. 17 – 23, 2013
abstract: Answer the 10 questions below to see what you know about the people and events that are making news this week.
lead_paragraph: Answer the 10 questions below to see what you know about the people and events that are making news this week.

headline: Scientific Discovery, Frame by Moving Frame
keywords: ['Video Recordings and Downloads', 'Research', 'Science and Technology', 'ANIMALS', 'Flowers and Plants', 'Bacteria']
abstract: This week, we begin a new video series that will take you inside the labs and give you a narrated view of research as it happens.
lead_paragraph: How does a bat take a drink midflight? Why is a cheetah so good at bringing down its prey? Are the bacteria in the soil beneath our feet able to act like more than the sum of their single cells when attacking prey?

headline: All the Rage | Bright, Cheerful Colors at the London Design Festival
abstract: This year’s edition of the annual mega-fair found designers using an unexpectedly playful color palette that included a smorgasbord of neons and pastels.
lead_paragraph: The international news might be grim right now, but at this year’s London Design Festival, the sprawling, eclectic event consisting of fairs, exhibitions, installations and parties that wrapped over the weekend, designers eschewed darkness, showing off products in a rainbow of bright shades, including feminine pastels, candy-colored hues and accessible neons. There must be something in the air: similar colors, pastels especially, were recently also on display in the spring/summer presentations in both London and New York, from Phillip Lim and Prabal Gurung to Christopher Kane and Burberry Prorsum.

headline: Egyptian Court Shuts Down the Muslim Brotherhood and Seizes Its Assets
abstract: The court issued an injunction dissolving the Brotherhood and confiscating its assets, escalating a broad crackdown on the group less than three months since the military ousted its ally, President Mohamed Morsi.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — An Egyptian court on Monday issued an injunction dissolving the Muslim Brotherhood and confiscating its assets, escalating a broad crackdown on the group less than three months since the military ousted its ally, President Mohamed Morsi.

headline: Chemical Disarmament Won’t Be Easy
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The United States has been working to dispose of its chemical weapons for decades, a process complicated by concerns about public health and the environment.
lead_paragraph: Four miles from the White House, Army specialists are digging very cautiously into an empty lot where a brick house once stood in one of the district’s toniest neighborhoods, on the edge of the American University campus.

headline: ‘Venus in Fur’ to Dominate in American Theaters This Season
abstract: David Ives’s dark sexual comedy “Venus in Fur” will be the most-produced play of the 2013-14 season, according to the Theater Communications Group.
lead_paragraph: What has fur, four legs and a leather collar? If you guessed a dog, you probably haven’t yet seen David Ives’s dark sex comedy “Venus in Fur.” But you should have plenty of chances, as the play is set to be the most-performed play in American theaters in the 2013-14 season, with 22 productions across the country, more than any other play, according to American Theater magazine. The rankings were compiled through surveys of over 500 member theaters of the Theater Communications Group, an umbrella organization of regional and nonprofit theaters, and the publisher of the magazine. “Venus in Fur” opened on Broadway in 2011 with Hugh Dancy and Nina Arianda in a Tony Award-winning performance.

headline: Kerry Washington’s Emmy Beauty Look
abstract: An interview with Carola Gonzalez, Kerry Washington’s long-time makeup artist, on her red carpet look.
lead_paragraph: For the first-time Emmy nominee Kerry Washington, the red carpet rigmarole has become a sort of exercise in fashion’s master class. (For the awards show, she wore a romantic Marchesa runway gown plucked from the recent spring 2014 show.) But what about beauty? Last night, after Ms. Washington walked the Emmy red carpet, I spoke with her longtime makeup artist, Carola Gonzalez, who also works with Naomie Harris and Padma Lakshmi, on how Ms. Washington’s look comes together.

headline: Street Style: Leather Weather
abstract: The best of readers’ photos from the week of Sept. 16.
lead_paragraph: The best of readers’ photos from the week of Sept. 16.

headline: Evolution’s Big Bang Revisited, A New Science Video Series, Finding Alzheimer’s Before It Takes Hold
abstract: A new theory to explain the Cambrian explosion; “Science Take” brings you cool science videos straight from the lab; a new tack in the fight against dementia — treat it long before it appears.
lead_paragraph: A new theory to explain the Cambrian explosion; “Science Take” brings you cool science videos straight from the lab; a new tack in the fight against dementia — treat it long before it appears.

headline: Getting the Most Out of Sleep
abstract: While duration is important, experts say the quality and timing of sleep are critical to a good night’s rest.
lead_paragraph: Q. To get the health benefits of a good night’s sleep, is it just the number of hours that counts? What if sleep is induced by a sleeping pill or is stressful because of a nightmare?

headline: A Deal for BlackBerry That’s Not Yet a Deal
abstract: The “letter of intent” between Blackberry and Fairfax Financial Holdings is not a binding deal, and a lot of things need to happen before the company is actually acquired for $9 a share.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 4:30 p.m. |

headline: Russia Sells Stake in Maker of AK-47s to Investors
abstract: A Russian government-owned conglomerate said it would sell to two private investors just under half of the company that makes Kalashnikov assault rifles.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — A Russian government-owned conglomerate announced plans on Monday to sell to two private investors just under half of the company that makes Kalashnikov assault rifles.

headline: Four Ways to Improve the Culture of Commenting
abstract: Online comments may be, as one reader said, “where the real America is.” But connoisseurship, awards and searchability could make the comments section a more robust place.
lead_paragraph: In my Riff for this past weekend’s magazine, I write about the history of online comments and how they came to often take such an off-putting form. Here are some things we could adopt to help build a better commenting environment:

headline: For a Better Way to Prosecute Corporations, Look Overseas
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Deferred Prosecution Agreements', 'Law and Legislation', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: American prosecutors have used deferred prosecution agreements in cases of great public importance without any meaningful oversight, the authors write.
lead_paragraph: Brandon L. Garrett is a professor at University of Virginia School of Law. David Zaring is an assistant professor of legal studies at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania.

headline: First Class for the Bat; Its Bearer Tags Along
abstract: Jeff Idelson, president of the National Baseball Hall of Fame, was once greeted by mobs of fans wanting to see Mark McGwire’s record-breaking bat.
lead_paragraph: I’VE worked in baseball most of my career. When I was in junior high and high school I worked as a vendor at Fenway Park. After college, I was with the Yankees for about five years and now for about the past 19 years I’ve been with the National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum. Most of my travel involves seeing sponsors, fund-raising, meeting with the Hall of Fame players and collecting artifacts for the museum.

headline: Designer’s Boyfriend Is Sentenced in Killing at Soho House
abstract: Nicholas Brooks, the son of a Grammy Award-winning songwriter, received the maximum term of 25 years to life in prison for killing Sylvie Cachay in 2010.
lead_paragraph: To make clear the pain that her daughter’s former boyfriend had visited upon her family, Silvia Panizo Cachay rose at his sentencing on Monday to describe her last moments with the daughter he was convicted of killing.

headline: Crisp White Wines for a Crisp Pork Cutlet
abstract: Try Champagne, a fizzy gift to savory fried foods, with bubbles that lift up the nutlike flavors of the breaded meat.
lead_paragraph: These crisp, lemony cutlets set out a pork-flavored welcome mat, inviting any number of crisp white wines to the meal. Start with Champagne, a fizzy gift to savory fried foods, with bubbles that lift up the nutlike flavors of the breaded meat. Or maybe grüner veltliner from Austria, with peppery citrus flavors that echo the main course. Riesling, of course, is a brilliant match, particularly dry versions from Austria, Alsace or Germany.

headline: After Cancer, Fertility Is Often Within Reach
abstract: Oncologists are increasingly making a point of bringing up the subject of fertility at the time of a cancer diagnosis in children, discussing various options before treatment.
lead_paragraph: Like many adults who survived childhood cancer, Karen Cormier always assumed she would never get pregnant.

headline: Is Maker Faire Made for Kids?
keywords: ['Computer and Video Games', 'Conventions, Fairs and Trade Shows', 'Do It Yourself', 'Inventions and Patents', 'Robots and Robotics']
abstract: At the New York Maker Faire, children were everywhere. Should adults even bother anymore?
lead_paragraph: At New York’s Maker Faire this weekend, an event that has built a following by showcasing the tinkering of homespun inventors, children were front and center at every booth, touching, playing and asking the exhibitors how their inventions work.

headline: Panzanella With Chicken and Capers
abstract: Toss roasted chicken into this Tuscan tomato salad, and spend an extra few minutes crisping up the skin first.
lead_paragraph: What’s for Dinner? answers that universal question, offering recipes for simple, relatively quick dishes that use ingredients you can pick up on the way home.

headline: Scene City: Partying With HBO After the Emmys
abstract: HBO might not have swept the Emmys, but it was a winner among the after parties.
lead_paragraph: HBO might not have swept the Emmys, but it was a winner among the after parties.

headline: Emmys Draw 17 Million Viewers, Up From Recent Shows
abstract: The audience was the largest in almost a decade and, notably, had competition from the big winner of the night, AMC’s “Breaking Bad.”
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Bucking downward network-television ratings trends, the Emmy Awards on Sunday evening earned the biggest audience for an Emmys show in almost a decade.

headline: Arsenic Contamination Threatens Water in Hanoi
abstract: Aggressive pumping is draining aquifers, creating an opening for arsenic-contaminated water to leach into a major drinking-water aquifer that serves Hanoi, Vietnam, researchers say.
lead_paragraph: Arsenic-laden sediment that washed down from the Himalayas eons ago underlies vast stretches of Asia, from Pakistan to China. When it gets into underground aquifers, as has happened in Bangladesh, it can contaminate public water supplies and cause illness and death.

headline: The Sun That Did Not Roar
abstract: The Sun appears to slack off at the height of the solar cycle, the solar maximum, usually a time of roiling activity as the star’s magnetic fields reverse.
lead_paragraph: This is the height of the 11-year solar cycle, the so-called solar maximum. The face of the Sun should be pockmarked with sunspots, and cataclysmic explosions of X-rays and particles should be whizzing off every which way.

headline: Rethinking Motion Sickness
abstract: Thomas Stoffregen, a kinesiologist, believes that motion sickness is connected to posture and gait, not imbalances in the inner ear.
lead_paragraph: In a cavernous basement laboratory at the University of Minnesota, Thomas Stoffregen thrusts another unwitting study subject — well, me — into the “moving room.” The chamber has a concrete floor and three walls covered in faux marble. As I stand in the middle, on a pressure sensitive sensor about the size of a bathroom scale, the walls lurch inward by about a foot, a motion so disturbing that I throw up my arms and stumble backward. Indeed, the demonstration usually throws adults completely off balance.

headline: Feeling For | An Artisanal Fragrance Brand From Florence
abstract: For one-of-a-kind scents, head to Aqua Flor in Florence to sample concoctions made of raw materials sourced from all over the world.
lead_paragraph: Many visitors to Florence make a routine pilgrimage to Officina Profumo-Farmaceutica di Santa Maria Novella, but those in the know now head to Aqua Flor, where the master perfumer Sileno Cheloni concocts small-batch fragrances distilled from obscure raw materials — like Himalayan musk and Damascus rose — that he travels the world to collect.

headline: A Change in iTunes Radio
abstract: Adjusting to shifts in iTunes after the arrival of iOS7, and locking a Nexus 7 screen into place.
lead_paragraph: Finding Stations

headline: Pakistan Christians Issue Call for Protection
abstract: The death toll from a suicide attack rose to 85 as government critics said the atrocity highlighted the failure of the state to protect minorities.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — With its Muslim-style minarets topped by a large black cross, the All Saints Church in Peshawar has for more than a century offered a daring architectural expression of Muslim-Christian harmony and cohabitation.

headline: Stopping Alzheimer's Before It Starts
abstract: The Times's Pam Belluck reports on a federal clinical trial that could lead to a treatment that prevents Alzheimer's Disease.
lead_paragraph: The Times's Pam Belluck reports on a federal clinical trial that could lead to a treatment that prevents Alzheimer's Disease.

keywords: ['Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Methamphetamines', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: How much sympathy does the lost soul of “Breaking Bad” deserve?

headline: Now Arriving at Your Seat: The In-Flight Storefront
abstract: Airlines are looking to expand in-flight sales beyond food and drinks, to such things as hotels, rental cars and package trips.
lead_paragraph: SEEING a flight attendant trudging down the airplane aisle peddling boxed meals, or perfume off the duty-free cart, reminds me of a movie image: Mia Farrow as the cigarette girl lugging that tray of smokes through a nightclub in Woody Allen’s 1987 movie “Radio Days.”

headline: Hostels Gain Popularity With Business Travelers
abstract: Hostels, long associated with backpackers and students, have gone upscale and now attract business travelers, especially young ones on tight budgets.
lead_paragraph: Ferdi van ‘t Wout, a manager for a global electronics manufacturer in the Netherlands, frequently stays in hostels when traveling for work, an option he discovered last year by accident.

headline: Timeline of the Kenya Mall Shooting
abstract: A day-to-day look at the events that have occurred since Saturday's deadly shooting and hostage situation at an upscale mall in Nairobi, Kenya.
lead_paragraph: A day-to-day look at the events that have occurred since Saturday's deadly shooting and hostage situation at an upscale mall in Nairobi, Kenya.

headline: Making a Case for a Timber Tower
abstract: Engineers are developing ways to build skyscrapers largely of timber, which would reduce construction-related carbon dioxide emissions compared with conventional structures of concrete and steel.
lead_paragraph: Engineers are developing ways to build skyscrapers largely of timber, which would reduce construction-related carbon dioxide emissions compared with conventional structures of concrete and steel.

headline: Towers of Steel? Look Again
keywords: ['Building (Construction)', 'Wood and Wood Products', 'ARCHITECTURE', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Forests and Forestry', 'Sustainable Living']
abstract: Skidmore, Owings & Merrill has developed a proposed structural system that uses timber to build tall buildings as an environmentally friendlier alternative to steel and concrete.
lead_paragraph: The movement to construct tall buildings largely with wood as an environmentally friendlier alternative to steel and concrete has received a boost from an unusual source — a leading architectural firm known for its towers of steel and concrete.

headline: Cocaine Haul on French Jet Raises Concern
keywords: ['Cocaine and Crack Cocaine', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Search and Seizure']
abstract: The authorities are investigating how more than a ton of cocaine in suitcases was sent from Venezuela in an Air France cargo hold.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A record haul of cocaine, found in suitcases here on an Air France flight arriving from Venezuela, is raising a multitude of questions about the security of the baggage scanning system and the possibility of collusion by either airport or airline staff members both in Venezuela and France.

headline: Easing a Difficult Passage
abstract: ‘Knocking on Heaven’s Door’ examines the struggles in caring for an aging parent, and facing a medical system that favors a reflexive postponing of death, no matter quality of life.
lead_paragraph: Whoever tucked “in sickness and in health” into the marriage vows was quite the poet, compressing into six little syllables a whole strange, sad parallel universe of grievous obligation. But at least spouses know on some level what they may be in for. Not so children, who take no premonitory oaths in the matter of sick parents but are suddenly hurled around that same alternate universe by primal forces — love and conscience, guilt and resentment.

headline: Go East Old Man: In the Wet of the Night
abstract: In the final episode of Dexter Ford’s chronicle of his travels across the continent on a tiny motorcycle, he rides through more lakes and takes more insects in the face shield.
lead_paragraph: Dexter Ford is traveling from Southern California to upstate New York along mostly obscure roads, on a motorcycle that, by American standards, is quite tiny. This is the last of his occasional reports from the paths less traveled.

headline: Striving to Have It All, and Then Recalculating
abstract: Debora L. Spar’s “Wonder Women” joins the public conversation about women’s success and the work-life balance.
lead_paragraph: “Wonder Women: Sex, Power, and the Quest for Perfection,” by Debora L. Spar, is the latest offering from a high-profile woman with advice for her educated, middle- and upper-class sisters on the possibility of having it all. Publishing a book on a current debate is like riding a wave. Catch it too early, and the wave will sweep out in front, leaving you behind. Catch it too late, and you miss the force needed to carry you to shore.

headline: Shutdown vs. Default: The Relative Impact
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'National Debt (US)', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Economists warn against equating the prospects of a budget impasse and a failure to raise the debt ceiling, saying the latter would be much worse for the economy.
lead_paragraph: At the moment, Congress is figuring out how to avoid two forms of chaos of its own making: a government shutdown and a public default.

headline: New App to Highlight Recordings of John Lennon at Sea
abstract: John Lennon’s June 1980 visit to Bermuda, where he composed some of the songs that became “Double Fantasy,” will be the subject of a new iPad and iPhone app.
lead_paragraph: John Lennon’s June 1980 visit to Bermuda, where he composed some of the songs that became “Double Fantasy,” his final album, will be the subject of “John Lennon: The Bermuda Tapes,” an iPad and iPhone app scheduled to be released on Nov. 5. The app will include some the rough composing recordings that Lennon made during the trip, as well as visual materials that include his handwritten lyric sheets and photographs taken during the trip.

headline: Genetic Treatment Aims for a Workaround
abstract: Experimental drugs use a technique called exon skipping  to try to counteract genetic errors that cause muscular dystrophy.
lead_paragraph: Experimental drugs use a technique called exon skipping  to try to counteract genetic errors that cause muscular dystrophy.

abstract: Gunshots and explosions emanated from the Westgate mall in Nairobi after Kenyan forces moved in for a major assault against heavily armed Islamist militants.
lead_paragraph: Gunshots and explosions emanated from the Westgate mall in Nairobi after Kenyan forces moved in for a major assault against heavily armed Islamist militants.

headline: New Offer for BlackBerry Gives Buffett’s Favorite Banker Another Assignment
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: BDT & Company, the investment bank run by the former Goldman Sachs rainmaker Byron D. Trott, is one of the primary advisers to Fairfax in its pursuit of BlackBerry. A deal would give the firm another prominent assignment in a year full of them.
lead_paragraph: Fairfax Financial Holdings’ $4.7 billion offer to take BlackBerry private has once again thrust Byron D. Trott into the spotlight.

headline: Lottery Winners Switch Old Woes for New
abstract: “Lucky 7,” a new drama on ABC, shows the problems of no money, and of sudden wealth.
lead_paragraph: If we are so lazy that we have to steal a lottery-pool TV series from Britain, couldn’t we at least Americanize it a bit? Couldn’t we supersize the jackpot into something Americans would be proud and pleased to win?

headline: Guy, His Bride and His 2 Exes
abstract: “Trophy Wife” is an ABC comedy revolving around the latest spouse of a man who has already been married twice.
lead_paragraph: The sitcom chefs at ABC have fired up the Cuisinart in an effort to create another blended-family winner on a par with “Modern Family,” but the result, “Trophy Wife,” is forced-frivolity mush.

headline: Union Push for I.P.O. Forces Filing at Chrysler
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Initial Public Offerings', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Organized Labor', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: Chrysler is taking the step toward an offering only under pressure from its second-largest shareholder, a trust set up to provide medical coverage for 115,000 retired auto workers and family members.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Chrysler filed for a public stock offering on Monday, acting only under pressure from its second-largest shareholder, a trust set up to provide medical coverage for 115,000 retired autoworkers and their relatives.

headline: The Lit Set’s Day in the Sun
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Brooklyn Book Festival', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: Authors, publishers and readers came together Sunday for the eighth annual Brooklyn Book Festival.
lead_paragraph: Several participants in the eighth annual Brooklyn Book Festival on Sunday were thrown by their surroundings. Sitting near the altar of St. Ann & the Holy Trinity on Montague Street, Cristina García paused while reading a vivid description of a man’s naked body from her novel “King of Cuba”: “I just realized I’m in a church, so perhaps I should have chosen something else.”

headline: In Latin America, Brazilian Banks Fill Void Left by Global Giants
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Initial Public Offerings', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: As the big international investment banks pull back from Latin America, BTG Pactual and Itaú BBA are expanding there.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — The erratic performance in Latin American markets in recent months is leading some global banks to shy away from volatile regions and rethink their strategies.

headline: Gene Therapy With a Difference
abstract: An experimental drug for Duchenne muscular dystrophy failed in a large clinical trial recently, but the technique of counteracting mutated genes holds promise.
lead_paragraph: Terri Ellsworth is convinced that her 12-year-old son Billy, who has Duchenne muscular dystrophy, is being helped by an experimental drug that counteracts the genetic mutation causing his disease.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Kenya and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Kenya, Pakistan, Israel and the West Bank.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Kenya, Pakistan, Israel and the West Bank.

headline: Action, Yes, Just No Superhero This Time
abstract: In “Marvel’s Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D.,” on ABC, Joss Whedon tries to transfer the Marvel Universe to television.
lead_paragraph: There may never have been a television show as hard to address on its own terms as “Marvel’s Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D.,” beginning on Tuesday night on ABC. That’s what happens when you’re a cog in the Marvel Cinematic Universe, the interlocking entertainment machine that encompasses comic books and megabudget movies. “Agents,” the franchise’s first TV property, picks up the story after the superheroes-versus-aliens battle that leveled much of Midtown Manhattan in the $1.5 billion-grossing film “Marvel’s The Avengers.”

headline: Back to His Working-Class Roots
abstract: Christopher Abbott, formerly of HBO’s “Girls,” has found a milieu closer to his working-class roots in the play “Where We’re Born,” at Rattlestick Playwrights Theater.
lead_paragraph: With his fuller beard and his longer hair slicked back under a Yankees cap, Christopher Abbott is hardly recognizable as the character he played on “Girls”: Charlie, the sweet, docile boyfriend of Allison Williams’s Marnie. Shortly after the Season 2 finale in March, Mr. Abbott abruptly announced that he was leaving the show.

headline: Squabble Disrupts a Refuge for the Rich
abstract: The group that runs the Breakers, the Vanderbilt “cottage” in Newport, R.I., wants to build a visitors center on the grounds, a proposal that has provoked outrage from neighbors.
lead_paragraph: NEWPORT, R.I. — Change has rarely been welcomed in this seaside haven of the uber-rich, where the famously over-the-top mansions of the Gilded Age are still called “cottages.” Longtime residents weren’t happy when the America’s Cup defected, or when Bob Dylan went electric at the Folk Festival, or when Maya Lin designed a contemporary memorial to honor the heiress Doris Duke in the village green.

headline: After Hours | The Origin Story of Midler and Manilow, in Music and Words
abstract: The Bette Midler impersonator Donna Maxon paid tribute to the diva’s early days when she performed at a gay bathhouse in Manhattan, with Barry Manilow accompanying her on piano.

headline: Former F.B.I. Agent to Plead Guilty in Press Leak
keywords: ['Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Terrorism', 'Search and Seizure', 'News and News Media', 'Child Pornography']
abstract: Donald Sachtleben, a former bomb technician, agreed to plead guilty to leaking classified details about a foiled bomb plot in Yemen, the Justice Department announced.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A former F.B.I. agent has agreed to plead guilty to leaking classified information to The Associated Press about a foiled bomb plot in Yemen last year, the Justice Department announced Monday. In a twist, the former agent had already been under investigation in a separate child pornography case, and he has also agreed to a guilty plea in it.

headline: Small, Slimy and See-Through
abstract: Scientists have discovered a tiny snail with a translucent shell living half a mile below the surface in Croatia.
lead_paragraph: Scientists have discovered a snail with a glasslike, translucent shell living half a mile below the surface in Croatia. Just a millimeter across and practically immobile, the snail, Zospeum tholussum, makes its home in a hot, humid cave within the Lukina Jama-Trojama cave system.

headline: Decoy Protein Boosts Bone Growth
abstract: Mice with dwarfism characteristics, caused by a gene mutation, resumed normal bone growth after injection of a decoy protein.
lead_paragraph: Injections of a decoy protein can restore normal bone growth in mice with dwarfism characteristics, according to a new study, suggesting a possible treatment for humans with the condition.

headline: Research May Point to Treatment for Cold Sores
abstract: Insight about a mutated gene in people who got cold sores suggests a possible research route for both cold sores and other infections caused by herpes simplex virus type 1.
lead_paragraph: If you are among the roughly 20 percent of people who regularly get cold sores, you can now blame your genes, researchers say.

headline: Mexico’s New Arrivals Mix Praise and Criticism
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Readers responding to an article in The Times said that while they wished the world would focus more on Mexico’s strengths, they also wished the country would do more to tackle its flaws.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Can Mexico ever ascend to its proper place in the world economy without tackling corruption and crime head on? When will the country, with its rising potential, stop being held down by weak government?

headline: Reviewing the Review Reviewers
abstract: Monday’s article about a crackdown on fake reviewing prompted many responses from readers indicating that the problem is even worse than regulators think.
lead_paragraph: There was a voluminous response to my article Monday morning that said Eric T. Schneiderman, the New York attorney general, had gone after 19 companies for fake online reviews. His investigation was the largest such action by regulators to date, indicating how the problem is now becoming a law enforcement issue.

headline: A Composer, Not Easy to Peg, Is Heard Through Others
abstract: Éliane Radigue’s music was featured in two concerts in New York last week and influenced a third.
lead_paragraph: “It’s like looking at the surface of a river,” the French composer Éliane Radigue said of her music in a short 2009 video portrait produced by the Austrian Institute for Media Archaeology. “There’s an iridescence around the reefs, but it’s never completely the same. According to the way in which you look, you can see the golden flashes of the sun, or the depths of the water.”

headline: Rethinking the Poker Face and Plans for a Cat in Space
keywords: ['Poker (Card Game)', "Alzheimer's Disease", 'Mars (Planet)', 'Water Pollution', 'Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Science and Technology', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: Recent developments in health and science news. This week: A molasses spill has been killing marine life and a $33.2 million grant will go toward Alzheimer’s research.
lead_paragraph: Seldom does the Boston Molasses Disaster of 1919 come up these days, but a recent spill that is wreaking havoc on the environment in Hawaii brought that long-ago tragedy back into the news.

headline: A Century of Chemical Weapons
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Nations have fought for a century to stop the scourge of chemical weapons. But their use continues, as evidenced by the recent sarin gas attack in Syria.
lead_paragraph: Nations have fought for a century to stop the scourge of chemical weapons. But their use continues, as evidenced by the recent sarin gas attack in Syria.

headline: When Stores Outshine the Clothes at Milan Fashion Week
abstract: Cathy Horyn finds a subpar season in Milan, with many designers either playing to the cameras or to mass tastes.
lead_paragraph: MILAN — Everything in Milan feels a little hyperbolic these days, or more than usual. Not only was there a big Condé Nast-sponsored evening at La Scala, the opera house, but there were also several store openings. When asked what made the new Prada and Fendi stores different, a Milanese publicist thought a minute and replied, “They’re more luxury.”

headline: As ‘Normal’ as Rabbits’ Weights and Dragons’ Wings
abstract: In this week’s CreatureCast we look at a common pattern used to statistically describe of the world — the so-called “normal distribution” — with some familiar and fanciful examples.
lead_paragraph: Statistics are used to describe the world. The average height of women in the United States, for example, is 63.8 inches. Statistics are also used to test our ideas. If your friend told you he is 130 pounds, and you also know that 98 percent of healthy adult males weigh more than this, you might have reason to be concerned about his health. This is because you would expect few men sampled at random from the healthy population to weigh this little.

headline: Bunnies, Dragons and the ‘Normal’ World
abstract: The normal distribution crops up many places in nature. The central limit theorem explains how it provides a near-universal expectation for averages of measurements.
lead_paragraph: The normal distribution crops up many places in nature. The central limit theorem explains how it provides a near-universal expectation for averages of measurements.

headline: No Quick-Fix Recipe for the Giants
abstract: Coach Tom Coughlin realizes there are not many personnel options that will help turn around the Giants, who have been outscored by 115-54 to start the season.
lead_paragraph: Minutes after his team’s 38-0 thumping at the hands of the Carolina Panthers, Giants Coach Tom Coughlin had the look of a man facing a new reality.

headline: A Playwright’s Later Years, Rowdy and Dissolute
abstract: A Belfast production of “Brendan at the Chelsea,” Janet Behan’s play about Brendan Behan, her uncle, is at the Acorn Theater in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: The alcoholic dimming of a literary light is rendered in “Brendan at the Chelsea,” a fascinating if fanciful account of the late life of Brendan Behan, now at the Acorn Theater. Behan — the Irish poet, short-story writer, novelist, memoirist and playwright, who died of complications from alcoholism in 1964 — lived at the Chelsea Hotel in the early 1960s, after the New York premiere of his play “The Hostage.”

headline: Live Video From The New York Times
abstract: A live video stream from The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: A live video stream from The New York Times.

headline: Twitter Adds CBS to Its Stable of Big Advertising Partners
abstract: As the social network prepares to sell stock to the public, it is trying to show sustained revenue growth. Under Twitter’s Amplify program, CBS and other broadcasters can pair video clips with ads and distribute them on the service.
lead_paragraph: Twitter has been furiously adding partners to its Amplify advertising program ever since it began informally last year with a partnership between the social network, ESPN and the Ford Motor Company. In those initial ads, ESPN sent out clips of football games, wrapped in a Ford Fusion ad, as short messages on the service.

headline: Answers to Readers’ Questions About Electronics on Planes
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Laptop Computers']
abstract: With an F.A.A. advisory panel expected to recommend relaxing restrictions on electronic devices during flights, reporters Jad Mouawad and Nick Bilton answered questions on what changes could mean for travelers with gadgets.
lead_paragraph: As Jad Mouawad and I reported, a Federal Aviation Administration advisory panel will meet this week to complete its recommendations to relax restrictions on electronic devices during flights.

headline: Gay Rights Protest Greets Opening Night at the Met
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Homosexuality', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: A Russian-themed gala at Lincoln Center to celebrate Tchaikovsky’s “Eugene Onegin” has become a lightning rod for critics of Russia’s antigay laws.
lead_paragraph: After the lights dimmed for the Metropolitan Opera’s Russian-themed opening night gala on Monday evening, the first solo voice that rang out in the house was not of a tenor or soprano, but of a protester criticizing the recent antigay laws signed by President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Zuckerberg in a Suit, and Claims of an iPhone Fingerprint Scanner Hack
abstract: Monday’s highlights from around the Web include a critique of a suit that Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook’s co-founder, wore as he met with members of Congress. Plus, hackers claim to have broken the iPhone 5S’s new fingerprint recognition system.
lead_paragraph: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: China Gains New Friends in Its Quest for Energy
abstract: A Chinese presence at a vast new oil field in Kazakhstan is another indication that China’s influence has eclipsed even Russia’s across the former Soviet republics of Central Asia.
lead_paragraph: ATYRAU, Kazakhstan — On the northern reaches of the Caspian Sea, not far from this old Soviet town known for its oil and sturgeon, lies a vast new oil find, the biggest outside the Middle East. China was rebuffed when it asked for a stake 10 years ago.

headline: Despite a Deadly Crash, Rail System Has Good Safety Record
abstract: Statistics suggest that China’s high-speed trains have actually proved to be one of the world’s safest transportation systems so far.
lead_paragraph: CHANGSHA, China — The crash happened in an instant two years ago, ending 40 lives, injuring 192 people and casting a lasting shadow over the reputation of China’s high-speed rail system.

headline: Speedy Trains Transform China
abstract: Just five years after the high-speed rail system opened, it is carrying nearly twice as many passengers as the country’s domestic airline industry.
lead_paragraph: CHANGSHA, China — The cavernous rail station here for China’s new high-speed trains was nearly deserted when it opened less than four years ago.

keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )']

headline: Civilian Planes Led Away as U.N. General Assembly Meets
abstract: F-16 fighter jets escorted at least three aircraft from New York City’s airspace because they had violated a “temporary flight restriction,” an official said.
lead_paragraph: It is no secret that when world leaders gather in New York City, security gets tighter — both on the ground and above it.

headline: China’s Crackdown Prompts Outrage Over Boy’s Arrest
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: After a public outcry, the authorities on Monday released Yang Zhong, 16, who was among the first people charged under new rules that criminalize the spreading of online rumors.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — In their widening campaign against online “rumormongers” and other putative purveyors of social disorder, Chinese authorities have netted influential rights activists, freelance anticorruption sleuths and even a billionaire entrepreneur who championed the rights of poor migrants. Many of those detained in recent weeks remain in police custody.

headline: Boston’s Police Chief Plans to Step Aside
abstract: Edward Davis, who rose to national prominence after the marathon bombings, said he was leaving voluntarily, but critics pointed to a lack of diversity among commanders on the force.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Edward Davis, the Boston police commissioner who rose to national prominence after the marathon bombings in April, said Monday that he was stepping down from his job in the next month or two.

headline: Inside Matadero Madrid
abstract: A closer look at the arts complex.
lead_paragraph: A closer look at the arts complex.

headline: In Madrid, Art Finds New Friends
abstract: Matadero, a Madrid arts complex, shows the results of a new kind of corporate and artistic cooperation.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Bloodstains mixed with graffiti mark the walls of this city’s old slaughterhouse and its vast compound of arched neo-Moorish pavilions. They are signs of an eclectic history: over the last century, the complex, called Matadero Madrid, has changed from an abattoir to a homeless squat to an outpost for contemporary art, theater and documentary films.

headline: Ask a Question on Hiring New Employees
abstract: Choosing a candidate that fits both a specific position and the culture of a business  often proves challenging.
lead_paragraph: Hiring the best people can be one of the most important parts of an entrepreneur’s job. But choosing a candidate that fits both a specific position and the culture of the business often proves challenging.

headline: Ask a Question About Job Hunting
abstract: In many ways, looking and applying for a job just isn’t what it used to be.
lead_paragraph: In many ways, looking and applying for a job just isn’t what it used to be. Many job seekers have replaced their old paper résumés with online portfolios. Networking remains valuable, but it now includes maximizing the potential of social networks like LinkedIn and Facebook. And new online tools make researching a potential employer even more beneficial when trying to make a good impression.

headline: Mayoral Rivals Attack de Blasio on Past Support of Sandinistas
abstract: Joseph J. Lhota, the Republican nominee for New York City mayor, was among those expressing alarm over Bill de Blasio’s young enthusiasm for Nicaraguan socialists.
lead_paragraph: Bill de Blasio, on the defensive two weeks after winning the Democratic primary for mayor of New York, found himself on Monday explaining his long-ago support for Nicaragua’s Sandinista party, as two of his opponents expressed alarm about his political worldview.

headline: Cambodian Prime Minister Extends Reign Amid Opposition Boycott of Parliament
abstract: Hun Sen, the authoritarian prime minister who has ruled the country for 28 years, appears willing to govern without the cooperation of the opposition.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — Cambodia’s long-serving, authoritarian prime minister, Hun Sen, was elected to another five-year term in office on Tuesday despite a deadlock with the opposition, which has refused to attend the National Assembly in protest over alleged electoral cheating.

headline: Carolyn Cassady, Beat Writer and Muse, Dies at 90
abstract: Ms. Cassady was the former wife of Neal Cassady and a character in Jack Kerouac’s “On the Road.” She later chronicled her life in the Beat Generation.
lead_paragraph: Carolyn Cassady, a writer who entered the American consciousness in 1957 as a character in Jack Kerouac’s novel “On the Road,” and decades later chronicled her life as a member of the Beat Generation, died on Friday near her home in Bracknell, England. She was 90.

headline: 200 Years After Battle, Some Hard Feelings Remain
abstract: Preparations are under way to mark the 200th anniversary of Napoleon’s defeat at Waterloo, but sometimes it seems the battle has not really ended.
lead_paragraph: WATERLOO, Belgium — The region around this Belgian city is busily preparing to commemorate the 200th anniversary in 2015 of one of the major battles in European military history. But weaving a path through the preparations is proving almost as tricky as making one’s way across the battlefield was back then, when the Duke of Wellington, as commander of an international alliance of forces, crushed Napoleon.

headline: Detroit’s Casino-Tax Dollars Become Big Issue in Bankruptcy Case
abstract: An insurer has filed a lawsuit, trying to block a deal Detroit reached over interest-rate swaps.
lead_paragraph: Detroit had a bit of rare good fortune as it hurtled toward bankruptcy last summer — a couple of banks were willing to let it out of some expensive financial contracts, called interest-rate swaps, without paying in full the usual steep termination fees.

headline: Arguments Begin in a Bitter Family Brawl Over a Media Mogul’s Estate
abstract: Samantha Perelman is suing her uncle James Cohen, the head of the Hudson Media empire, over what she says is her rightful $700 million share in her grandfather Robert Cohen’s fortune.
lead_paragraph: Robert B. Cohen, the founder of the Hudson Media empire, whose last wishes are at the center of nasty legal battle here, was either a gravely ill old man unable to speak in his final years, or an opinionated octogenarian who enjoyed attending family bar mitzvahs. Those were the clashing portraits presented in state court on Monday of the man, who died in 2012, leaving behind a fortune that is now the subject of a bitter fight that has drawn in some of the ultrawealthy of New York society.

headline: As JPMorgan Settles Up, Shareholders Are Hit Anew
abstract: The $920 million JPMorgan Chase agreed to pay to settle S.E.C. civil allegations sounded like a lot, but the money is actually coming from the firm’s shareholders, who already took a $6 billion hit.
lead_paragraph: Last week, JPMorgan Chase agreed to pay $920 million to settle civil allegations brought by the Securities and Exchange Commission and other regulators in connection with a multibillion-dollar trading loss that’s come to be known as the London Whale case.

headline: Victims Push Laws to End Online Revenge Posts
keywords: ['Cyberharassment', 'Dating and Courtship', 'Law and Legislation', 'Privacy', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'First Amendment (US Constitution)']
abstract: Posting explicit images of former sexual partners can ruin lives, yet mostly goes unpunished. But the law may be catching up with technology.
lead_paragraph: He was a muscular guy with “kind of a nerdy kind of charm,” Marianna Taschinger recalled, a combination that proved irresistible to an 18-year-old girl in a small Texas town.

headline: Deeper Than God: Ronald Dworkin’s Religious Atheism
abstract: A final book grapples with a vexing question: to what extent and on what basis should constitutional protection be afforded to religious activities?
lead_paragraph: Ronald Dworkin, a professor of law and philosophy at New York University, was arguably the most influential legal philosopher of the past 50 years. Dworkin, who died in February, was (and will continue to be) known for his critique of positivism, a view of law that locates its authority in what is “on the books” — what has been enacted by those who are in a position to back up their pronouncements with sanctions and penalties, including the loss of property and life. Dworkin argued that here must be more than that; there must be an underlying or overarching set of values in relation to which legal particulars are intelligible and have meaning.

headline: E.P.A. Rules on Emissions at Existing Coal Plants Might Give States Leeway
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Coal', 'Clean Air Act', 'Global Warming', 'States (US)', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Electric Light and Power']
abstract: The states might be given latitude on how to reach carbon limits. Some states are already well on their way; others don’t see global warming as a pressing problem.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Four years ago, Congress rejected the idea of a cap-and-trade system to reduce carbon dioxide emissions by putting a price on them. But the plan announced by the Environmental Protection Agency on Friday to regulate emissions from existing coal-fired power plants could foster creation of such a system, at least on a regional basis, and a push for renewable energy and energy efficiency in states that so far have embraced neither.

headline: An Education in Equality
abstract: Filmed over 13 years, this short film presents a coming-of-age story of an African-American boy who attends an elite Manhattan prep school.
lead_paragraph: Filmed over 13 years, this short film presents a coming-of-age story of an African-American boy who attends an elite Manhattan prep school.

headline: The West Need Not Fear Its Young Muslims
abstract: Even as jihadis set off bombs in Mogadishu, exile Somali communities offer a lesson about helping their homeland rebuild.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — It has been five years since Shirwa Ahmed, a 26-year-old from Minneapolis, blew himself up in northern Somalia, and sent shivers up American spines about young immigrants from war-torn Muslim countries who were turning into terrorists. Unconfirmed reports that American Muslims might have been among the gunmen who stormed Nairobi’s Westgate shopping mall over the weekend will no doubt revive fears of the “enemy within.”

headline: ‘Those Are Our People’
abstract: Watching terrorists attack a mall just miles from my home in Nairobi.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — I WAS watching the 1 o’clock news at home on Saturday when the Westgate mall story broke. Young, casually dressed men — carrying very sophisticated weapons — had opened fire on shoppers in Nairobi’s luxury mall, killing dozens, and taking an unknown number hostage.

headline: ‘An Education in Equality’
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Education (K-12)', 'Private and Sectarian Schools', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: Filmed over 13 years, a coming-of-age story of an African-American boy who attends an elite Manhattan prep school.
lead_paragraph: When our son Idris was 4 years old, he was accepted to the Dalton School, a prestigious private school in Manhattan. Idris would become one of only a few black boys in a kindergarten class of about 90 students, where tuition rivaled that of private colleges. We decided to document this new world, following Idris over 13 years through graduation. (The story of Idris and one of his close friends became our feature-length documentary “American Promise,” from which this Op-Doc video is adapted.) What began as an exploration of diversity in New York’s elite private-school world grew into a story that touches on larger themes of identity, race and class in American society.

headline: After Shooting Rampage, Navy Seeks New Policy in Reviews of Security

abstract: The recommendation, disclosed Monday, came after the Navy completed a detailed review of the military career of Aaron Alexis, who is suspected in the Washington Navy Yard massacre.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The secretary of the Navy has recommended that future security reviews include any available police reports, even if they did not result in charges or convictions, after the shooting deaths of 12 Navy personnel by a gunman who had an honorable discharge, a Secret-level clearance and at least two firearms incidents in law enforcement files.

headline: After Setting a Team Record, the Jets Start a Penalty-Prevention Plan
abstract: For every penalty in practice, everyone present — players and coaches, front-office personnel and trainers — will perform 10 push-ups. Everyone that is, except the culprit himself.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Here in the realm of hunter green and white, the Jets saw yellow, and lots of it on Sunday. Yellow as in the penalty flags that parachuted from all corners of MetLife Stadium during the Jets’ 27-20 victory against the Buffalo Bills, that registered every hold, every false start, every infuriating infraction — all 20 of them.

headline: A Climate Change Showdown as Global Officials Meet
abstract: The world’s transport ministers are gathering this week to tackle the growing problem of greenhouse gases emitted by airliners, a contentious issue with no easy solution.
lead_paragraph: Transportation ministers from governments around the world will gather on Tuesday to tackle the growing problem of greenhouse gases emitted by airliners. As they assemble, many will be bracing for the political tumult that has wrecked previous international efforts to address climate change.

headline: That Chicken in Your Soup

lead_paragraph: Senator Charles Schumer of New York last week offered a long list of horror stories of contaminated food in China — ranging from eggs with toxic levels of melamine to rat labeled as lamb in Shanghai. And then there is the threat of another bird-flu outbreak, one of the reasons the United States still does not import chickens grown and slaughtered in China.

headline: Angela Merkel’s Next Challenge

lead_paragraph: Angela Merkel’s resounding re-election in Germany on Sunday is a personal triumph, but it still leaves unanswered questions about the direction she will lead Germany and the European Union over the next four years.

headline: New York Legislators’ Secret Income
abstract: The state anticorruption commission must press for details about outside money sources that lawmakers have kept hidden for decades.
lead_paragraph: Considering the scandals in the New York State Legislature, one would think that battered lawmakers would be eager to clean up their reputation. Instead, they’ve hired lawyers to fight a new anticorruption commission’s efforts to find out precisely where they earn outside income. This fight, they insist, is all about maintaining a separation of powers and protecting the Legislature from an intrusive executive. The real reason is that revealing income sources could also uncover conflicts of interest.

headline: Home Care in the Home Stretch
abstract: A strong new rule that entitles these workers to the minimum wage and overtime pay is a victory in word, not deed, because it does not take effect until 2015.
lead_paragraph: For nearly 40 years, home-care workers, wrongly labeled “companions,” have been denied basic federal labor protections, including the right to be paid at least the minimum wage and time and a half for overtime.

headline: Global Spending to Fight AIDS Has Grown Slowly, Report Finds
abstract: Global financing to fight AIDS has remained essentially flat since the 2008 financial crisis, according to a new report.
lead_paragraph: Global financing to fight AIDS has remained essentially flat since the 2008 financial crisis, according to a report by the Kaiser Family Foundation and the United Nations AIDS-fighting agency. About $7.9 billion from donors went to poor and middle-income countries last year. The amount has grown slowly after inflation for the past four years. Spending soared from 2002 to 2008 with the creation of the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Malaria and Tuberculosis and the Bush administration’s President’s Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief. The United States contributes almost 64 percent of the money. Britain gives 10 percent, France 5 percent, Germany 4 percent and Japan 3 percent. Measured as a percentage of gross national product, Denmark is the largest donor. Speeding up the disbursement of previously approved money increased the American contribution in 2012 to $5 billion from $4.5 billion. The report was released as world leaders met at the United Nations to review progress on fighting poverty and disease.

headline: Catholic College Rescinds Invitation to Speaker Defending Same-Sex Marriage
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Homosexuality']

lead_paragraph: Providence College, a Roman Catholic school in Rhode Island, has canceled a lecture in support of same-sex marriage on Thursday by a gay philosophy professor, citing a church document that says that “Catholic institutions should not honor those who act in defiance of our fundamental moral principles.”

headline: Where Bettors Go to Lose, Some Doubts
abstract: The way the New York Racing Association is overseen raises questions about Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s plan to add seven casinos in the state.
lead_paragraph: I took a stroll through a glowing forest of slot machines — past a hospital aide who fed ragged dollars into them and a retired transit worker who peered into his empty wallet and a security guard who eyed me, wondering when I was going to sit down and start losing money.

headline: Debate Offers 2 Similar Public Advocate Rivals a Chance to Stand Out
abstract: Letitia James and Daniel L. Squadron, both Democrats who have similar political positions, will face off in a televised debate on Tuesday night.
lead_paragraph: Letitia James and Daniel L. Squadron are both liberal Democrats, critics of stop-and-frisk police tactics who boast about fighting on behalf of homeless families and public housing residents. But over the next week, they have to convince a tiny fraction of New York City voters that one of them is better suited to the office of public advocate, a little-known post that offers a bullhorn on city policy and a potential steppingstone to City Hall.

headline: Vote for Merkel Seen as Victory for Austerity
abstract: For months, Europe waited for German elections, hoping that a re-elected Chancellor Angela Merkel would ease austerity measures. The wait is over, and so, too, is any hint of a new approach.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — As Angela Merkel savored the results of Germany’s national elections, newspapers on the left and right in Greece on Monday gave the same mournful assessment of what the result means beyond German borders. “Victory for the Queen of Austerity,” declared the front page of Ta Nea, a center-left daily. “Merkel victory atop the ruins of the South,” said the conservative Dimokratia.

headline: In Bronx River, Helping Oysters Stage Comeback

abstract: The city that calls itself the capital of Silicon Valley is planning to cut pensions and other benefits to fight its escalating fiscal woes, and other municipalities are watching.
