lead_paragraph: “We’re Silicon Valley, we’re not Detroit. It shouldn’t be happening here. We’re not the Rust Belt.”

headline: F.D.A. to Regulate Some Health Apps
abstract: The Food and Drug Administration said it would oversee mobile applications that function as medical devices, like ultrasounds, but not apps that count calories.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration said Monday that it would regulate only a small portion of the rapidly expanding universe of mobile health applications, software programs that run on smartphones and tablets and perform the same functions as medical devices.

headline: 2 Black Lawmakers Voted to Parliament in Germany
abstract: Karamba Diaby, of the Social Democrats, and Charles M. Huber, from the Christian Democratic Union, will take seats in the Bundestag after being elected through so-called party lists.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — When Karamba Diaby finished third in his party’s state primaries last February, the result catapulted him into the national spotlight. Now, after Sunday’s federal elections here, Mr. Diaby’s place in German history is guaranteed.

headline: Study Sees a Higher Risk of Storms on the Horizon
abstract: Rising temperatures and the atmospheric changes they spawn are most likely to generate more severe-weather days in the eastern and central parts of the nation by midcentury, scientists concluded.
lead_paragraph: The eastern and central United States likely will see a greater risk of severe weather by the middle of this century as rising temperatures trigger atmospheric changes that favor storms, a new study by climate scientists from Stanford and Purdue universities concludes.

headline: Developer Wins Approval to Renovate Nassau Coliseum
abstract: The Nassau County Legislature voted for a $229 million bid by the owner of the Barclays Center to turn the arena into a modern sports and entertainment complex.
lead_paragraph: The Nassau Coliseum, the suburban home of four straight Stanley Cups and of concerts by Elvis Presley, Bruce Springsteen and the Grateful Dead, will be getting a head-to-toe makeover.

headline: Georgia: Atlanta’s Use of Grant Is Questioned
abstract: Atlanta could be forced to repay  nearly $400,000 after a Justice Department review found that the city had breached the terms of grants intended to improve its neighborhoods.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department’s inspector general has found that Atlanta breached the terms of grants intended to improve its neighborhoods and fight crime. According to the Justice Department’s review, which questioned nearly $400,000 in spending, Atlanta officials used flawed accounting practices and insufficiently documented some expenses. The city, which could be forced to repay the money, disputed parts of the audit, but its chief financial officer acknowledged discrepancies.

headline: Orioles, Deflated and Battered, Face Cruel End to Their Season
abstract: The Orioles lost a two-run lead, suffered two injuries, and saw their wild-card chances nearly evaporate in a demoralizing loss to the Rays.
lead_paragraph: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — Every noise was amplified amid the anguish in the Baltimore Orioles clubhouse. Trunks filled with gear closed with a startling slam. Hair dryers could be heard at full throttle from the bathroom. Monday was a travel date, and after being swept by the Tampa Bay Rays, the Orioles packed up in mostly stunned silence and disbelief.

headline: Enigmatic Leader of Iran Backs Overture, for Now
abstract: Iran’s new president, Hassan Rouhani, is getting all the attention, but Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, the supreme leader, remains the man behind the curtain.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — This is Hassan Rouhani’s moment. The toast of the United Nations, the new Iranian president is busy granting interviews to select audiences and possibly cramming in a meeting with President Obama — the first such high-level get-together since the 1979 revolution. But when he stands before the world to speak on Tuesday, he will do so as the loyal representative of Iran’s supreme leader, the ultimate authority behind the country’s recent diplomatic charm offensive.

headline: Cargo Ship Docking at Space Station Is Delayed
abstract: A commercial cargo spacecraft, which was to dock at the International Space Station on Sunday, will not make its second attempt until at least Saturday.
lead_paragraph: A commercial cargo spacecraft, which was to dock at the International Space Station on Sunday, will not make its second attempt until at least Saturday. It is the first flight of the unmanned Cygnus cargo ship built by Orbital Sciences of Dulles, Va. Orbital said it fixed the software glitch that aborted the approach, but a traffic jam — three astronauts are to arrive on a Russian Soyuz on Wednesday — will delay the docking.

headline: Senators Call for Surveillance Inquiry
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A bipartisan group of senators on Monday signed a letter asking the inspector general for the intelligence community to carry out a “full accounting” of the government’s surveillance powers.
lead_paragraph: A bipartisan group of senators on the Judiciary Committee on Monday signed a letter asking the inspector general for the intelligence community, I. Charles McCullough III, to carry out a “full accounting” of how the government is carrying its surveillance powers. The letter — signed by the committee’s Democratic chairman and ranking Republican, Senators Patrick J. Leahy of Vermont and Charles E. Grassley of Iowa, among others — cited the debate that has arisen since leaks by Edward J. Snowden, the former National Security Agency contractor, although it did not mention his name. It requested that the investigation cover government activities between 2010 and 2013 and that it be completed by the end of 2014. The letter asked that the inquiry focus on surveillance that affects “the privacy rights of U.S. persons” and “any improper or illegal use” of the programs.

headline: After Rewarding Merkel, Germans Seek Focus at Home
abstract: The German election showed that above all, the country appreciates the stable, safe course that Chancellor Angela Merkel charted during her first two terms.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — If the German election campaign came across as staid — and it would be hard to argue it was anything but— Sunday’s vote showed that above all, the country appreciates the stable, safe course that Chancellor Angela Merkel charted during her first two terms, so much so that they awarded her a third.

headline: The Virtues of Fine in the Age of Awesome
abstract: In an age of superlatives, vacation runs the risk of becoming a space reserved for extreme adventure and alienating exclusivity. Whatever happened to things being simply good enough, or even simply enjoyable?
lead_paragraph: In an era of extreme travel and desperately competitive bucket lists, it’s worth recognizing that ‘good’ is often good enough.

headline: Word of the Day | fray
abstract: This word has appeared in 314 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: fray •\ˈfra\• verb and noun

headline: Mets Lose to Reds, but Eye the Future
abstract: In an address to the team, General Manager Sandy Alderson discussed young pitchers and said Terry Collins had done “exceptionally well” as manager.
lead_paragraph: CINCINNATI — The Mets arrived in the middle of a playoff race, with the Cincinnati Reds vying to win the National League Central Division, and in the heart of their own race with the Philadelphia Phillies to finish third in the East. General Manager Sandy Alderson even joined the team for its final road trip.

headline: Charity’s Fired Chief to Face Grand Larceny Charges
abstract: William E. Rapfogel, the former head of the Metropolitan New York Council on Jewish Poverty, turned himself in to authorities on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: A longtime Jewish community leader who headed one of the city’s most influential social service organizations until he was fired amid accusations of financial improprieties was expected to face grand larceny charges on Tuesday, according to a person with knowledge of the matter.

headline: World Cup Stadium in the Amazon
abstract: Despite delays, cost increases and design changes, construction of Arena Amazonia in Manaus, Brazil, is expected to be completed late this year.
lead_paragraph: Despite delays, cost increases and design changes, construction of Arena Amazonia in Manaus, Brazil, is expected to be completed late this year.

headline: What’s On Tuesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (Esquire) KNIFE FIGHT The Esquire Network, which was formerly Style, unveils its programming lineup with this underground cooking competition refereed by Ilan Hall, the Season 2 winner of “Top Chef.” In each episode, two chefs meet at Mr. Hall’s Los Angeles restaurant, the Gorbals, where they go head-to-head to determine who can make at least two dishes from unusual ingredients. A rotating roster of celebrities and food specialists serves as the judges and timekeepers; the photographer Giovanni Reda is the master of ceremonies. The show begins as David Feau of Le Ka and Brendan Collins of Waterloo & City (above left, with Mr. Hall, center, and Mr. Feau) face off over razor clams and live catfish, with the comedian Eric Wareheim, the food writer Jeanne Kelley and the actress Bijou Phillips as the judges. At 9:30, C. J. Jacobson of Girasol and Kris Morningstar of Ray’s & Stark Bar tackle white truffles, kohlrabi and ridgeback shrimp, with Lou Amdur of Los Angeles magazine and Brett Gurewitz of Bad Religion weighing in. In “Brew Dogs,” at 10, the Scottish-malt rebels James Watt and Martin Dickie journey across the United States on a mission to convert new craft beer fans by celebrating local brews and devising their own, using regional ingredients. They begin in San Diego, where they mastermind a Southern California-style beer using kelp and the world’s hottest chili while traveling on a train up the Pacific coast.

headline: Chinese Conglomerate Plans $1.8 Billion Reverse Takeover in Hong Kong
keywords: ['Initial Public Offerings', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: Cofco, whose operations include slaughtering livestock and selling life insurance, said it would place 12 property projects in mainland China into a subsidiary, the Hong Kong Parkview Group.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG – Cofco, a sprawling, state-owned Chinese conglomerate began a reverse takeover bid on Tuesday worth 14.2 billion Hong Kong dollars ($1.8 billion) that would result in a Hong Kong listing for its commercial property business in mainland China.

headline: News Quiz | September 24, 2013
abstract: See what you know about the news of the day.
lead_paragraph: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Before Kenya Attack, Rehearsals and Planting of Machine Guns
abstract: The plot to attack the Westgate mall was hatched weeks or months ago, with militants studying the building’s blueprints and hiding powerful machine guns in a shop, officials said.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — The plot was hatched weeks or months ago on Somali soil, by the Shabab’s “external operations arm,” officials say. A team of English-speaking foreign fighters was carefully selected, along with a target: Nairobi’s gleaming Westgate mall.

headline: National Health Costs vs. Your Health Costs
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicine and Health', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'United States Economy']
abstract: A study shows why many individuals are feeling an ever-greater burden in health costs even as hospitals and insurers have wrung billions of dollars out of the system.
lead_paragraph: Health care spending growth has plummeted to the lowest levels ever recorded. But many Americans insist that they are paying more and more.

headline: Test Yourself | History, Sept. 24, 2013
abstract: Answer this question about the 1998 Qaeda embassy bombings in East Africa.
lead_paragraph: Take the Quiz

headline: Ethical Design at Milan Fashion Week
abstract: Giorgio Armani opens the theater in his Milan headquarters for a fashion show by the emerging ethical designer Stella Jean.
lead_paragraph: Giorgio Armani opens the theater in his Milan headquarters for a fashion show by the emerging ethical designer Stella Jean.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Mexico Is the New Land of Opportunity for Many Migrants
abstract: What happened to Mexico’s documented foreign-born population between 2000 and 2010?
lead_paragraph: In “For Migrants, New Land of Opportunity Is Mexico,” Damien Cave writes about how broad changes in the global economy have created new migration patterns, as well as new opportunities for Mexico.

headline: Freebies for the Rich
abstract: Why are colleges giving away money to rich kids who don’t need it? They might value their rankings more than the economy.
lead_paragraph: Max Russell had always been a conscientious student, but when his father died during his junior year of high school, he had to take on a 25-hour-per-week job to help his family pay the bills. The gig inevitably ate into the time he spent on homework, and Russell’s G.P.A. plummeted from 3.5 to 2.5, which complicated his ability to get the aid he needed to attend a four-year college. So he ended up at Ivy Tech Community College in Indianapolis. Last year, after finally qualifying for student loans and cobbling together some grant money, he transferred to Purdue University, one of the state’s top public schools.

headline: Photos, Like Life, Blurred and Re-Envisioned
abstract: Brian Nice traveled the world as a fashion photographer until a traumatic brain injury in 2009. He has since made images that reflect his double vision, and this week begins a road trip to continue that work.
lead_paragraph: Brian Nice traveled the world as a fashion photographer for 25 years creating technically precise images reflecting his clients’ concepts of beauty.

headline: How Much Do You Trust Online Reviews?
abstract: Do you read online reviews to help you make decisions — about movies, books, stores or music?
lead_paragraph: The Internet has democratized the ability to review. No longer do we have to wait for a select group of experts to declare “two thumbs up” — instead, anybody can read or write what he or she thinks online. But some businesses are trying to exploit that freedom by posting phony reviews.

headline: China Bans Items for Export to North Korea, Fearing Their Use in Weapons
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'International Trade and World Market', 'ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT']
abstract: The ban on exports of military-like hardware and chemicals is a sign of China’s increasing concern about the North’s nuclear abilities.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — In a sign of growing concern about North Korea’s nuclear ambitions, China published a long list on Tuesday of equipment and chemical substances to be banned from export to North Korea for fear they could be used in adding to its increasingly sophisticated nuclear weapons programs.

headline: Senator Persists Battling Health Law, Irking Even Many in His Own Party
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Many Republicans abandoned Senator Ted Cruz in his fight over the health care law, which stretched into the early hours Wednesday morning on the Senate floor.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Facing an increasingly likely defeat in his tangled procedural fight over funding the government, Senator Ted Cruz took to the Senate floor on Tuesday and declared he would speak “until I cannot stand” to rally voters against the health care law.

headline: 50 Years After the House Vote for the Kennedy Tax Cut
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'Law and Legislation', 'Taxation', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Fifty years ago, a president was able to win a compromise on tax policy in a very different Congress from the current one, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of “The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform — Why We Need It and What It Will Take.”

headline: New York Today: Small-Screen City
abstract: What you need to know for Tuesday: Brooklyn’s moment in the TV spotlight, the president weighs in on the mayor’s race, and Yankees playoff tickets — get them while you can.
lead_paragraph: Updated 12:03 p.m. | Time was when the Brooklyn of television shows was a pretty Bensonhurst kind of place. That was where Ralph Kramden and the rest of the Honeymooners cracked wise.

headline: Auction House C.E.O. Moves to Hong Kong
abstract: The move by the head of Spink & Sons, a small auction house founded in London in 1666, reflects Asia as a growing market for anything from fast cars to fine wines.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — In a move that underscores the growing importance of Asia as a market for goods as varied as fast cars, fine wines and postage stamps, Spink & Sons, a small auction house founded in London in 1666, announced on Tuesday that its chief executive had relocated to Hong Kong.

headline: A Conversation With: Environmental Activist Akhil Gogoi
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Forests and Forestry', 'Hydroelectric Power', 'Levees and Dams', 'Volunteers and Community Service', 'Water']
abstract: Natural disasters, similar to the floods that killed several thousand people in the northern state of Uttarakhand in June, could also occur in India’s northeastern states if the construction of big dams and highways goes unchecked, says Akhil Gogoi, an environmental activist.
lead_paragraph: Akhil Gogoi, an environmental activist, has been campaigning against the construction of the big dams and highways in the mountainous northeastern state of Arunachal Pradesh bordering China. Mr. Gogoi believes that natural disasters like the floods that hit the northern state of Uttarakhand and killed several thousand could also happen in Arunachal Pradesh if dam and road constructions go unchecked.

headline: Daily Report: Questions Arise From BlackBerry Buyout Offer
abstract: An offer to take BlackBerry private does not end the uncertainty surrounding the ailing smartphone maker.
lead_paragraph: An offer to take BlackBerry private does not end the uncertainty surrounding the ailing smartphone maker, Ian Austen and David Gelles report.

headline: Selling Sunbeam Road
keywords: ['Baby Boomers', 'Nineteen Hundred Sixties', 'Suburbs', 'Families and Family Life', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Moving to Long Island was  a step up on the economic ladder, but over the years, I was the one in my family to have the most peaceful relationship with the house.
lead_paragraph: When we first arrived on Long Island in the summer of 1965, my mother hated the house on Sunbeam Road. A split-level with a two-car garage, it sat on a patch of unnaturally green grass framed by hot-pink azalea bushes. In the backyard, a fiberglass awning shaded a concrete patio painted green.

headline: Milan Fashion Week: Giorgio Armani Spring/Summer 2014
abstract: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.

headline: U.S. Manufacturer of Chip-Making Equipment Buys Japanese Rival
abstract: Applied Materials of California is buying Tokyo Electron in a deal valued at $9 billion that will create a big new player in the semiconductor industry.
lead_paragraph: With the chip-manufacturing industry facing more pressure, Applied Materials is aiming to shore up its business in a big way by striking a big takeover of a Japanese company.

headline: How to Introduce a Married Gay Couple
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Homosexuality', 'Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Baby Boomers', 'Defense of Marriage Act (1996)', 'Marriages', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: An Army sergeant asks how to introduce his girlfriend to a married gay couple, one of whom is an officer.
lead_paragraph: Every other Tuesday, Steven Petrow, the author of “Steven Petrow’s Complete Gay & Lesbian Manners” (Workman, 2011), addresses questions about gay and straight etiquette for a boomer-age audience. Send questions for Civil Behavior to stevenpetrow@earthlink.net.

headline: Celebrity-Inspired Fashion in the Bronx
abstract: Chaveli Gil, who grew up in the Bronx, says her style is inspired by Rihanna, Nicki Minaj, and sometimes Kim Kardashian.
lead_paragraph: Chaveli Gil, who grew up in the Bronx, says her style is inspired by Rihanna, Nicki Minaj, and sometimes Kim Kardashian.

headline: Close but Not Quite
abstract: These aren’t the usual homophone missteps — bare for bear, or palate for palette. But in each case we seemed to have mixed up two vaguely similar words. Working too fast? Dictionary shelf too far away?
lead_paragraph: These aren’t the usual homophone missteps — bare for bear, or palate for palette. But in each case we seemed to have mixed up two vaguely similar words. Working too fast? Dictionary shelf too far away?

headline: Two Artists Make Cash’s ‘Folsom Prison Blues’ Their Own
abstract: Brandi Carlile, out of Seattle and Keb’ Mo’, out of Nashville, add fresh twists on Johnny Cash’s signature song.
lead_paragraph: Val Haller, a music-obsessed baby boomer and the founder of the Web site Valslist.com, matches tracks from her generation to those of her 20-something sons’ generation.

headline: In Performance: Matthew Maher of ‘Mr. Burns, a Post-Electric Play’
abstract: The actor performs a scene from Anne Washburn’s post-apocalyptic play at Playwrights Horizons.
lead_paragraph: Anne Washburn’s generation-spanning “Mr. Burns, a Post-Electric Play” imagines a post-apocalyptic world in which an episode of “The Simpsons” becomes a piece of cultural mythology. In this scene from the first act, set around a fire in the woods with a group of survivors, Matt (Matthew Maher) tries to recall details from the “Cape Feare” episode of “The Simpsons.” The show continues through Oct. 20 at Playwrights Horizons.

headline: S.E.C. Advances New JOBS Act Rule, but Not Crowdfunding
keywords: ['Crowdfunding (Internet)', 'Private Placements (Non-Public Offerings)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Small Business']
abstract: The JOBS Act set the end of last year as the deadline for final rules on crowdfunding, but the S.E.C. has not yet proposed those regulations, much less completed them.
lead_paragraph: Over the last few months, the messages have piled up in The Agenda’s in-box, heralding a new securities regulation that, our correspondents say, will usher in a new era of crowdfunded financing. That new regulation took effect on Monday, but equity crowdfunding — at least as most people understand it — remains a long way off.

headline: Riverstone Holdings Plans $2.4 Billion I.P.O. of New Company in London
abstract: Riverstone Holdings, an American private equity fund, is planning an initial public offering of a new energy investment company called Riverstone Energy, aiming to raise up to $2.4 billion.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Riverstone Holdings, an American private equity fund, said on Tuesday that it was planning an initial public offering of a new energy investment company in late October on the London Stock Exchange.

headline: More Legal Woes to Come for JPMorgan
abstract: JPMorgan Chase’s biggest battles with federal authorities may lie ahead. | An offer to take BlackBerry private does not end the uncertainty. | When Chrysler filed for an I.P.O. on Monday, it was acting under pressure from a big shareholder. | In Detroit’s bankruptcy case, a fight is brewing over casino-tax dollars.
lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase paid $1 billion last week to resolve a number of government investigations, but the bank’s biggest battles with federal authorities may lie ahead, Ben Protess and Jessica Silver-Greenberg report in DealBook.

headline: A Fight for Love, in the Met and Out
abstract: The Met’s new “Eugene Onegin,” directed by Fiona Shaw, opened on Monday in a drab production upstaged by critics protesting Russian laws intolerant of gays.
lead_paragraph: By tradition the gala opening night of a Metropolitan Opera season is a fashionable and pricey affair. But during his tenure as general manager of the company, Peter Gelb has also made opening night a statement of artistic purpose, as it was on Monday when the Met began the season with a new production of Tchaikovsky’s “Eugene Onegin,” a landmark Russian opera based on the novel in verse by Pushkin.

headline: On Beauty | Clever Twists on Classic Hairstyles
abstract: T offers a short primer on how to get the best hairstyles from the fall collections.

headline: Shirtless on a Solemn Day
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A sweltering jogger, going topless past the Firemen’s Monument, realized too late what day it was.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Juries, a Postscript
abstract: The author responds to feedback from his Monday column: Is a “jury of one’s peers” a right? Must jurors speak English?
lead_paragraph: One of these days (I hope) the tech wizards of The Times will transform the “Comments” feature to make it more conducive to a real-time, post-column conversation between columnists and readers. For now, I’ll settle for a next-day follow-up.

headline: Saving Shalit, Killing Hazan
abstract: The price Israel pays for boosting public morale over sending a strong message to would-be kidnappers.
lead_paragraph: TEL AVIV — Last Friday, an Israeli soldier was killed by a Palestinian co-worker from the restaurant where he worked when he was off duty. The Palestinian, Nidal Omar, convinced the soldier, Tomer Hazan, to come with him to a place near his village in the West Bank. Omar then murdered Hazan and hid his body in a well. He was soon captured by Israeli forces.

headline: Using Religion as an Excuse to Discriminate
keywords: ['Freedom of Religion', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: The Marriage and Religious Freedom Act is an invitation to unfairness and bureaucratic chaos.
lead_paragraph: A pernicious measure just introduced in the House, the Marriage and Religious Freedom Act, provides the latest example of political conservatives trying to use religion as an excuse to discriminate.

headline: As World Leaders Speak at United Nations, Iran Sends More Friendly Signals
abstract: A Twitter message by the new foreign minister of Iran spoke of a “historic opportunity” to resolve the nuclear issue.
lead_paragraph: As world leaders began speaking at the United Nations General Assembly on Tuesday, Iran extended its optimistic pronouncements on possible progress over the country’s nuclear dispute, with the new foreign minister proclaiming in a Twitter message that “we have a historic opportunity.”

headline: Art Comes to the Interstate
abstract: “The Manifest Destiny Billboard Project” is a cross-country exhibition of roadside posters stretching from Jacksonville to Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: This month, the cross-country art exhibition “The Manifest Destiny Billboard Project” starts with the artist Shana Lutker’s ethereal cloudscapes on billboards posted on Interstate 10 in Jacksonville, Fla. The installation, which was curated by Zoe Crosher and Shamim M. Momin, will eventually include roadside posters by artists like Crosher and Mario Ybarra Jr. at stops all the way to Los Angeles. “Instead of talking about the trip west,” Crosher says, “the idea is to physically move through the very landscape being fantasized.”

headline: Building a World Cup Stadium in the Amazon
abstract: Organizers face extraordinary hurdles, from humidity to bureaucracy, in the construction of a 42,000-seat stadium in Manaus, a city in the midst of the rain forest.
lead_paragraph: MANAUS, Brazil — The most challenging aspect of building a World Cup soccer stadium in the middle of the Amazon is debatable. Some might say it is figuring out how to get oversize cranes and hundreds of tons of stainless steel and concrete into a city surrounded by a rain forest that stretches for about 2.1 million square miles. Others might mention the need to put most of those materials together before the rainy season floods the entire construction site. Then, of course, there are those who might point to the need to install the special chairs.

headline: Getting a Foothold
abstract: CB Made in Italy shoes include styles with colors and patterns, including a good-looking suede style with a contrasting leather strip hand-stitched across the top
lead_paragraph: When I first checked in with Cecilia Bringheli, in September 2011, she was trying to get her shoe business going, using her Milan apartment as a showroom and office. Ms. Bringheli’s slipper flats go under the label CB Made in Italy. Last week, I noticed quite a few slipper styles around Milan, including Charles Philip, which got started in 2010 with a blue and white striped flat produced by a cobbler in Shanghai, and which produces in China. Charles Philip sells at Corso Como 10, where Dior has a special slipper style made with Surrealist motifs from the fall ready-to-wear show. So Ms. Bringheli was on the right track.

headline: Germany and Europe
abstract: Angela Merkel escorts Europe to the altar.
lead_paragraph: Angela Merkel escorts Europe to the altar.

headline: What’s It All About Then
abstract: Austerity arguments were never honest.
lead_paragraph: Simon Wren-Lewis writes with feeling about the “austerity deception“; what sets him off is a post that characterizes the whole austerity debate as being about “big-state” versus “small-state” people.

headline: The Human Behind a Favorite Spambot, Horse_eBooks
abstract: Jacob Bakkila, a 29-year-old artist and Buzzfeed employee, said he had been operating the Twitter account for the last two years. “The goal was not to appropriate the account but to become the account,” he said.
lead_paragraph: For months, the Internet was captivated by the mysterious and strangely poetic Twitter spam account Horse_ebooks. The account spat out comical snippets of speech, including: “Unfortunately, as you probably already know, people,” and the occasional link to a Web site advertising e-books about horses. It was an Internet phenomenon that spawned legions of fans, who created Web comics and jewelry devoted to memorializing its bizarre existence and even led to a hunt to unearth the people behind it.

headline: Political Battles Intensify in Andhra Pradesh After Jailed Politician Gets Bail
abstract: Y.S. Jaganmohan Reddy, a leading politician in the southern state of Andhra Pradesh, who was in prison on graft charges was released on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: HYDERABAD, Andhra Pradesh— Massive crowds gathered in Hyderabad, the capital of the southern state of Andhra Pradesh, to welcome Y.S. Jaganmohan Reddy, a leading politician of the state, who was released from a local prison on bail on Tuesday. Mr. Reddy, who founded the Y.S.R. Congress Party in 2009, spent 485 days in prison after being arrested over corruption charges. A court of India’s premier federal investigative agency, Central Bureau of Investigation (C.B.I.) granted him bail Monday after being ordered by the Supreme Court of India.

headline: Obama Defends U.S. Engagement in the Middle East
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: President Obama declared that the United States would use all its levers of power to defend its interests in the Middle East, but acknowledged a limited ability to influence global events.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — President Obama on Tuesday laid down a retooled blueprint for America’s role in the strife-torn Middle East, declaring that the United States would use all of its levers of power, including military force, to defend its interests, even as it accepted limits on its ability to influence events in Syria, Iran and other countries.

headline: Elance Pairs Hunt For Temp Work With Cloud Computing
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Freelancing, Self-Employment and Independent Contracting']
abstract: The ranks of temporary online workers, apparently filling mostly humanities-type jobs like design and writing, continue to grow. Now an online job site, Elance, is setting up virtual private networks of trusted freelancers that companies can call on as needed. Elance says these are “fractional” workers who otherwise wouldn’t get jobs.
lead_paragraph: Cloud computing does not move computing power to small phones and big data centers. It is rearranging how we allocate work — maybe to a state of permanent, temporary work, for the mostly nontechnical ranks of the work force.

headline: Greenpeace Activists May Face Russian Piracy Charges
keywords: ['Piracy at Sea', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Offshore Drilling and Exploration', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots']
abstract: Russian officials have opened a piracy investigation against Greenpeace members who scaled a Gazprom offshore oil platform in the Arctic.
lead_paragraph: SALEKHARD, Russia — Russia announced on Tuesday that it had opened a piracy investigation against the crew of a Greenpeace ship after its activists scaled an offshore oil platform in the Arctic last week. The step signaled that the authorities intended to act decisively to thwart more protests against Russia’s ambitious plans to expand energy exploration in the region.

headline: What Congress Must Do to Avoid a Shutdown
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Federal Budget (US)']
abstract: Flowchart of the steps Congress needs to take.
lead_paragraph: Flowchart of the steps Congress needs to take.

headline: The Depressed Economy Is All About Austerity
abstract: Doing the dismal math.
lead_paragraph: Right now the official unemployment rate is 7.3 percent. That’s bad, and many people — myself included — think it understates the true badness of the situation. On the other hand, there are some reasonable people (like Bob Gordon) arguing that at this point, possibly thanks to long-run damage from the Great Recession, “full employment” is now a number north of 6 percent. So there’s considerable uncertainty about just how depressed we are relative to potential.

headline: Raising Its Stake in Telecom Italia, Telefónica Eyes Latin America
abstract: The Spanish telecommunications giant Telefónica agreed to raise its stake in the struggling Telecom Italia to 66 percent through a $437 million share issue in an attempt to gain greater control of the Italian operator’s assets in Latin American markets.
lead_paragraph: MADRID – The Spanish telecommunications giant Telefónica agreed on Tuesday to raise its stake in the struggling Telecom Italia in an attempt to gain greater control of the Italian operator’s assets in important Latin American markets.

headline: The Gun Report: September 24, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Do you live in a state that doesn’t allow concealed-carry? No problem! Utah is there for you.

headline: Six Follicles of Anticipation
abstract: I can’t believe that the doctor will take my eggs, Solomon’s sperm and actually place our embryo inside of me. That science can mimic biology like this is so incredible. Suddenly it’s hard to believe something so complex actually happens naturally.
lead_paragraph: I have six follicles.

headline: Text of Obama’s Speech at the U.N.
abstract: Following is a transcript of President Obama’s speech at the United Nations General Assembly on Tuesday in New York, provided by the White House.
lead_paragraph: Following is a transcript of President Obama’s speech at the United Nations General Assembly on Tuesday in New York, provided by the White House.

headline: Three’s a Trend | Tropical Prints Get a Serious Upgrade
abstract: In the spring/summer 2014 collections, designers have given kitschy warm-weather patterns a forward-thinking makeover with unexpected materials and surprising styling choices.
lead_paragraph: The bold, mixed tropical prints Miuccia Prada showed over the summer in her 2014 resort collection turned out to be a preview of coming attractions. In the spring/summer 2014 shows, designers have brought new life to these classic floral patterns — which were once relegated to kitschy Hawaiian shirts but will soon be a warm-weather wardrobe staple — by introducing unexpected materials, like this acid trip of a coat in mink by Prada; artistry, as in the abstract shapes on this jacket by Marni; and far-out styling, like this Victorian-surfer look by Marc Jacobs. Next spring, you can be sure we’ll be feeling the heat of this tropical wave.

headline: Today in Small Business: Holiday Hiring
abstract: Leasing of business equipment declines. E-mail marketing isn’t improving. Is the out-of-office auto-response message dying?
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

lead_paragraph: No, they were not on a hiking trip in the Carpathians.

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: Viewing Violent Media
abstract: The National Coalition Against Censorship disputes claims that fantasy violence leads to antisocial behavior. Readers are invited to respond.

headline: House Democrats Crafting Immigration Proposal
abstract: Though no final decisions have been made on the immigration proposal, a topic that has been languishing in the Republican-controlled House, Democratic leadership hopes to introduce the bill in the next few weeks.
lead_paragraph: House Democratic leaders are working on a broad immigration proposal that they hope will reinvigorate the debate on Capitol Hill and pressure their Republican counterparts to pass legislation that includes a pathway to citizenship for the 11 million undocumented immigrants already in the country.

headline: Married Cancer Patients Live Longer
abstract: The burdens of cancer treatment take a greater toll on single patients than married patients, a new study shows.
lead_paragraph: Married cancer patients live longer than single people who have the disease, suggesting that logistical and emotional support from a loved one may be far more critical to cancer care than previously recognized.

headline: Dozens Killed in Earthquake in Pakistan
abstract: The magnitude 7.7 earthquake struck in a remote area of Baluchistan Province, killing at least 80 people.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — A powerful earthquake killed at least 80 people when it struck a remote area of western Pakistan on Tuesday afternoon, according to Pakistani government officials.

headline: Robert Johnson’s Family Fights in Court Over Photo Rights
abstract: The son of the blues guitarist Robert Johnson and more distant relatives are fighting in court over ownership of the two known photographs of him.
lead_paragraph: There are only two known photographs of the great Delta bluesman Robert Johnson, whose songs like “Cross Road Blues” and “I Believe I’ll Dust My Broom” are classics. One is a studio shot of him in a wide-lapeled suit and a slick fedora, hands resting on the strings of a flat-top guitar; the other shows Mr. Johnson in a photo booth, a cigarette hanging from his lips as he fingers a chord.

headline: N.C.A.A. Begins to Ease Penn State Penalties
abstract: Pleased with Penn State’s progress toward athletic integrity, the N.C.A.A. said on Tuesday that five football scholarships would be restored next year and more would be phased in afterward.
lead_paragraph: When the N.C.A.A. levied significant penalties last year against Penn State and its football program, there was a general sense among many at the university that the national association was punishing the innocent, those left behind after the Jerry Sandusky scandal, those left to rebuild the university’s reputation and start anew.

headline: A Spring Fashion Gridlock

lead_paragraph: Few trends are to be found among clothing styles, with fashion houses now more interested in promoting an individual look or a brand image. But common themes do surface in colors and textiles. One that stands out is so-called optical patterns: grids, checks, stripes. At Fendi, Karl Lagerfeld took the idea to the max, with pieces of shaved fur arranged in grid patterns on organza.

headline: A Slave’s Service in the Confederate Army

Chandler began his memoir of fighting at Chickamauga with utilitarian prose that belied the horrible, bloody waste that the battle wrought on northwest Georgia in September 1863. “I was engaged in the battle of Chickamauga, belonged to the Forty-fourth Mississippi Regiment, Patton Anderson’s Brigade, Hindman’s Division,” he wrote for an 1894 article in Confederate Veteran magazine.

As a result, few Americans (not to mention New Yorkers) know that just across the Hudson River, on the hills and shores of New Jersey, this small beast ranges freely, with a welter of variations and a certain abandon.

headline: How I Hire: Got Any Questions?
keywords: ['Careers and Professions', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Small Business']

lead_paragraph: You’re the Boss and The New York Times are participating in a LinkedIn feature called “How I Hire.” If you go to the site, you can read the thoughts of more than 80 LinkedIn “Influencers” who have written about their hiring experiences. For example, Tony Fernandes, chief executive of AirAsia Group, says he takes just 10 seconds to make a decision. Steve Blank, co-author of the “Startup Owner’s Manual,” compares candidates with the help of a pie chart. Kevin Chou, chief executive of Kabam, devised a case-study interview as a screening exercise to try to break through the noise of the application process.

headline: Bharara Acknowledges That Budget Issues Are Straining His Office

headline: The Ambitions of Ted Cruz
abstract: The contrasting approaches of the junior senator from Texas and his right-wing rivals.
lead_paragraph: The perhaps not-so-subtle subtext of my Sunday column, which considers the ways in which the Republican Party’s populist flank has jump-started important policy discussions while also pointlessly strewing the budget process with unexploded bombs, is that out of the core group of Tea Party-affiliated senators Ted Cruz has thus far stood out for the, shall we say, purity of his theatrics. (Some of which are ongoing on the Senate floor at the moment.) The others in that group — Rand Paul, Mike Lee, Marco Rubio — have tried to initiate real policy debates and shift the party’s stance on major issues: Rubio with immigration, Paul (and Lee) with foreign policy and civil liberties, Paul with drug policy and criminal justice, and now Lee with family policy and tax reform. But not Cruz: He’s defining himself as a national figure not by taking positions on questions that divide his party, but by picking issues where the party is basically united — Obamacare, gun control, taxes — and playing the maximalist while promising the moon. (Tellingly, on the specific fronts where the others have staked out some legitimately bold stances, the Texas senator has mostly tap-danced — he’s “somewhere between Rand Paul and John McCain” on foreign policy, somewhere in the middle of his party on immigration, and so on.) Paul, Rubio and now Lee are all trying to move the party, and conservatism, in a particular direction; Cruz is telling conservatives to fight harder, but otherwise to stay exactly where they are.

abstract: In the documentary “Shepard & Dark” two writers — one who operates amid fame, one who doesn’t — discuss their craft and their intertwined lives across the years.
lead_paragraph: “Shepard & Dark,” a new documentary by Treva Wurmfeld, begins with two writers at work. In Deming, N.M., a silver-haired man touch-types at the keyboard of a far-from-new desktop, chuckling to himself between bong hits, flanked by bookshelves bearing volumes by Tolstoy and Gurdjieff. Meanwhile, on a ranch somewhere around Los Angeles, another fellow pecks at a portable typewriter, transcribing densely lettered blocks of prose from a worn Moleskine notebook.

headline: Obama and Clintons Share Stage for Health Care Talk

lead_paragraph: After delivering a much-anticipated speech to the United Nations General Assembly in the morning and meeting with world leaders in the afternoon, President Obama turned to health care on Tuesday evening, sharing center stage with the Clinton family at an event to highlight the rollout of the Affordable Care Act.

headline: Bayside: A City Suburb With Enclaves
abstract: An upper-middle-class community in Queens with a suburban feel: predominantly single-family homes, excellent schools and ample parks.
lead_paragraph: There was a time in the early 20th century when Bayside rivaled nearby Long Island havens for the affluent and celebrated — for instance Sands Point, a North Shore enclave often associated with Fitzgerald’s “Great Gatsby.”

headline: Remote Controls, Without the AAA Batteries
abstract: A company in San Diego, Maxwell Technologies, says it has developed a power system for remote controls that stores electricity without chemicals and can recharge in minutes.
lead_paragraph: Smartphones, tablets and other portable devices that need electricity rely on batteries that use a chemical reaction. But Maxwell Technologies, a company in San Diego, announced Tuesday that it was providing devices for television remote controls that store electricity without chemicals.

headline: Finding Echoes of Bach Afresh
abstract: The violinist Gil Morgenstern planned his latest Reflections Series program as a mandala, with Bach at the center.
lead_paragraph: You have to appreciate any artist’s attempts to breathe new life into the classical concert format. And the violinist Gil Morgenstern has done more than his share of rethinking with his Reflections Series, which opened its seventh season on Thursday at Avenues: The World School in Chelsea. But there was something a little pretentious in the conception of this program, “The World According to Bach: A Musical Mandala,” and something a little smug in its presentation.

headline: Miraval Plans a Resort in New Jersey
abstract: The luxury resort Miraval is scheduled to open a location in New Jersey in 2015.
lead_paragraph: Miraval Resort and Spa, the luxury resort in Tucson, Ariz., is coming to the East Coast with Miraval at Natirar projected to open in early 2015. The 86-room hotel will be situated on the Natirar estate in Somerset County, N.J., a 500-acre property with a river that was once owned by the king of Morocco.

headline: Sowing a Change in Kitchens
abstract: Luminaries from the world of food gathered in Westchester to discuss using seeds to explore a new frontier of flavor.
lead_paragraph: POCANTICO HILLS, N.Y. — It used to be that chefs believed their work began in the kitchen, where knives and fire and skill would convert good ingredients into a great meal. During the last few decades, a number of top chefs started to focus on an earlier element of the process: the farm, where so many of those ingredients come from.

headline: Venus Williams Tops No. 2 Azarenka in Tokyo

lead_paragraph: Seizing an opportunity, Venus Williams struck while her opponent was hot, beating a feverish Victoria Azarenka, 6-2, 6-4, in the second round of the Pan Pacific Open in Tokyo on Tuesday night. Azarenka is ranked No. 2.

abstract: Three sitcoms with different angles on parent-child relationships have their premieres: “The Goldbergs,” “Back in the Game” and “The Crazy Ones.”
lead_paragraph: Children are so ungrateful.

headline: For Some Songs, the Audience Is Included
abstract: The Cuban pianist Roberto Fonseca worked with a six-piece combo at his show at the Highline Ballroom on Monday.
lead_paragraph: During his encore at the Highline Ballroom on Monday night, the pianist Roberto Fonseca did what any gracious Cuban entertainer typically does with a New York audience: he struck a note of inclusion. Leading his band into a traditional son cubano, he earned a welcoming murmur. Then, steering his solo toward an ageless bolero, “Bésame Mucho,” he elicited cheers. For a while he played the theme with one hand; with the other he directed a singalong, holding the crowd in an outstretched palm.

headline: Adorable Baby, Doubting Dad, Teachable Moment
abstract: A memorable episode of “The Dick Van Dyke Show” from 1963 shows how television used a daring subject to help alter the racial landscape.
lead_paragraph: Fifty years ago Wednesday, Rob Petrie opened the front door of his home in New Rochelle, N.Y., and admitted two visitors. Their arrival collapsed a studio audience in laughter and, amid the watershed year of 1963, perhaps nudged the needle of social change toward integration and inclusiveness.

headline: Dilapidated Mansion Has Had Many Occupants, Maybe Even a Ghost
abstract: Chaonei No. 81, in central Beijing, has housed missionaries, Red Guards and perhaps the spirit of a woman scorned.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — It was 1949, and the Communists had just defeated the Nationalists in the civil war. Legend has it that during the losing army’s rushed retreat to Taiwan, a high-ranking Kuomintang official living in Beijing abandoned his wife, leaving her to fend for herself as the Communists marched into the city. Devastated, the wife (some say she was his concubine) hanged herself from the rafters of their three-story French Baroque-style home.

headline: Labour Leader Tries to Energize Party for Britain’s Next Election
abstract: Ed Miliband, who has faced leadership questions from within his party, attacked the government of Prime Minister David Cameron.
lead_paragraph: BRIGHTON, England — Hoping to woo disillusioned voters after three years in the opposition, Ed Miliband, the leader of the Labour Party, promised on Tuesday to freeze energy bills and cut taxes on small companies by squeezing more from big business.

lead_paragraph: SPECIAL POST — So what did you think? Pretty wild, right?

headline: New York City Passes Law Defending Rights of Pregnant Workers
abstract: No one benefits from effectively forcing a pregnant woman to choose between protecting her baby’s health and looking out for that child’s future economic interests.
lead_paragraph: The New York City Council has passed the Pregnant Workers Fairness Act, which states that employers cannot penalize a pregnant woman who needs a minor job modification to continue working during pregnancy or requires time off to recover from childbirth. Employers with four or more employees must provide a reasonable accommodation for pregnancy, childbirth and related medical conditions — something many women working in retail and service jobs have found their employers to be reluctant to do.

headline: A Call for New Laws in New York to Fight High-Tech Crime
abstract: A white-collar crime task force made proposals, including strengthening the laws against identity theft and the theft of computer code, in a report unveiled on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: New York State, failing to keep pace with technological change and increasingly sophisticated economic crimes, needs to update its laws to help authorities prosecute white-collar wrongdoing, according to a report released on Tuesday by the Manhattan district attorney, Cyrus R. Vance Jr.

headline: Iran’s New President Preaches Tolerance in First U.N. Appearance

lead_paragraph: In what may have been the most widely awaited speech at the United Nations, Iran’s new president, Hassan Rouhani, preached tolerance and understanding on Tuesday, decried as a form of violence the Western sanctions imposed on his country and said nuclear weapons had no place in its future.

headline: Pentagon Denies Money for Guantánamo Overhaul
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: A lack of Congressional support doomed a bid to renovate the prison in Cuba that the Obama administration has been trying to close, an official said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Pentagon has rejected a military request that it spend $195.7 million to renovate the prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, an official with the United States Southern Command said on Tuesday. The Obama administration has been trying to close the prison, but Congress has prevented it from doing so.

headline: In Which a Young Man Learns His Limitations
abstract: “Philip Goes Forth” is the first New York revival of George Kelly’s 1931 play.
lead_paragraph: Philip doesn’t want to go into his father’s business. He feels he’s made of more artistic stuff. He’d like to go to New York to write plays — plays that avoid the obvious, and even dare to have happy endings.

headline: Groomed for Greatness | A Simple Line That Promises to Thicken Guys’ Hair
abstract: Martial Vivot’s elegant styling aids rely on an enzyme used in anti-aging products, to fortify men’s strands.
lead_paragraph: The well-heeled clients who flock to Martial Vivot’s luxe men’s salon on West 54th Street are a diverse lot, including actors, C.E.O.s and bankers. But all have one thing in common (besides wealth): “Men, 98% of the time, want more hair, thicker hair,” Vivot said. It was with this desire in mind that he developed the new product line Martial Vivot Grooming Line for Hair, which launched exclusively at his salon and on his Web site today.

headline: Stance on Peace Talks Suggests Syria and West Differ on Tactics
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'International Relations']
abstract: In an interview in Damascus, Syria’s deputy foreign minister, Fayssal Mekdad, exuded confidence as he dismissed the Western-backed opposition as having little influence on the ground.
lead_paragraph: DAMASCUS, Syria — Syria’s deputy foreign minister, Fayssal Mekdad, said Tuesday that his government aimed to negotiate an end to the country’s civil war by talking with a broad range of Syrians, from religious and community leaders to peaceful opposition groups, dismissing the main Western-backed exile opposition as having little influence on the ground.

headline: Internet Pioneer RealNetworks Seeks Revival
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Software', 'Video Recordings and Downloads']
abstract: The company has reinvented its venerable RealPlayer software as a cloud service that it says will make it easier to privately share personal videos between mobile devices, television sets and computers.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — When a ground-breaking product called RealPlayer was released in its earliest form in 1995, Steven P. Jobs had yet to return to Apple, Google’s future founders had only just met and Mark Zuckerberg was 10 years old.

headline: Losing Is Good for You
abstract: Awards can be powerful motivators, but nonstop recognition does not inspire children to succeed. Instead, it can cause them to underachieve.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — AS children return to school this fall and sign up for a new year’s worth of extracurricular activities, parents should keep one question in mind. Whether your kid loves Little League or gymnastics, ask the program organizers this: “Which kids get awards?” If the answer is, “Everybody gets a trophy,” find another program.

headline: JPMorgan May Settle With Group of Agencies

lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase, seeking to avert a wave of litigation from the government, is negotiating a multibillion-dollar settlement with state and federal agencies over the bank’s sale of troubled mortgage securities to investors in the run-up to the financial crisis.

headline: Is Natural Gas ‘Clean’?
abstract: Embarking on a huge push to real zero-carbon-producing renewables is the only responsible path to take.
lead_paragraph: The question is whether the natural gas “revolution,” which is a real thing — production is up about a third since 2005 — is also a good thing.

headline: A Republican Calls Another a ‘Fraud’
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Representative Peter King, a Long Island Republican, spoke out against what he saw as a cynical maneuver by Senator Ted Cruz to delude Republicans into thinking that the new health care law could be repealed.
lead_paragraph: When Peter King is going to give you a sound bite, he lets you know ahead of time, so as not to insult your intelligence or, for that matter, waste your time if you’re not that interested in the details.

headline: The End of Poverty, Soon
abstract: The evidence for eradication of poverty worldwide is on the side of optimists.
lead_paragraph: Appealing for peace 50 years ago, President John F. Kennedy told the Irish Parliament, “The problems of the world cannot possibly be solved by skeptics or cynics, whose horizons are limited by the obvious realities. We need men who can dream of things that never were and ask, why not?”

headline: Fiat Chief Rolls Dice on Market and Chrysler Merger

lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Sergio Marchionne cemented his reputation as a master negotiator four years ago, when he persuaded the Obama administration to turn over control of Chrysler to his company, the Italian automaker Fiat.

headline: Yankees Can Only Wish to Spend as Wisely as Rays
abstract: The Yankees have asked themselves why they must spend so much for players, while other teams, such as the Tampa Bay Rays, can win for much less by making hard choices.
lead_paragraph: The Tampa Bay Rays are probably headed to the playoffs for the fourth time in six seasons. The Yankees, who spend about $167 million more on their payroll, will probably be eliminated in the next few days. Very reasonably, the Yankees have asked themselves why they must spend so much for players, while other teams can win for much less.

headline: Jeffrey I. Sussman

lead_paragraph: Mr. Sussman, 70, is the founder and president of the Property Group Partners, which develops and manages office buildings. The company is developing an office building at 860 Washington Street in Manhattan’s meatpacking district in partnership with Romanoff Equities.

headline: Greece, in Anti-Fascist Crackdown, Investigates Police

lead_paragraph: ATHENS — The photo splashed on the cover of a Greek newspaper this weekend shocked a nation: Pavlos Fyssas, a Greek rapper whose music inveighed against far-right groups, lay dying in a pool of his own blood as his girlfriend cradled him in her arms, moments after he was stabbed in the heart.

lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The America’s Cup has produced no shortage of strange scenes in its 162 years. There have been capsizings, shattered masts and shattered spirits, but it has never produced a reversal of fortune quite like this year.

headline: Atomic Goal: 800 Years of Power From Waste

lead_paragraph: BELLEVUE, Wash. — In a drab one-story building here, set between an indoor tennis club and a home appliance showroom, dozens of engineers, physicists and nuclear experts are chasing a radical dream of Bill Gates.

headline: Hundreds of Storm Evacuees in Hotels Face Evictions
keywords: ['Hurricane Sandy (2012)', 'Evacuations and Evacuees', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Evictions', 'Federal Aid (US)', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Lawyers for New York City are trying to transition about 350 people uprooted by the storm into shelters, saying the federal government was ending reimbursements for the program.
lead_paragraph: Almost a year after Hurricane Sandy, hundreds of displaced New Yorkers living in hotels face eviction.

headline: Clemens to Be Part of Rivera’s Game 162 Farewell
abstract: Unless the Yankees find a way to sneak into the postseason, Mariano Rivera’s final goodbye ceremony will come in Houston, with Roger Clemens on the field with him.
lead_paragraph: Mariano Rivera has had a distinguished farewell season. Not only has he pitched impeccably at age 43, with 44 saves and a 2.15 earned run average, but he has also displayed class in the way he is saying goodbye, meeting with behind-the-scenes workers and fans in various major league stadiums as a way to express his appreciation for the love and commitment they give to the game.

headline: No Brief Encounter
abstract: President Obama can’t catch a break, or even a hand.
lead_paragraph: The man formerly hailed as a messiah was having a bad day.

headline: Unchained Cellphones
abstract: The Federal Communications Commission should make it easier for consumers to unlock their cellphones once their contracts are completed.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration is pushing the Federal Communications Commission to make it easier for consumers to “unlock” their cellphones and tablet computers once their wireless contracts are completed. The F.C.C. should do so quickly.

headline: Exposing the Pay Gap
keywords: ['Executive Compensation', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Editorials']
abstract: Chief executives should have to justify their pay to shareholders, employees and the public.
lead_paragraph: Of all the provisions in the vast and complex Dodd-Frank financial reform law, one of the most far-reaching is also the most direct and easily understood. It requires public companies to compute and disclose the ratio of a chief executive’s pay to that of a typical employee.

headline: The Embarrassment of Senator Ted Cruz
keywords: ['Tea Party Movement', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Editorials', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: The Texas politician might think people want to hear about his ideas for getting rid of the new health law, but he really is only speaking to himself.
lead_paragraph: Senator Ted Cruz of Texas, the public face of the aimless and self-destructive Tea Party strategy to stop health care reform, began an endless floor speech on Tuesday with the theme of “make D.C. listen.” But even his Republican colleagues had long since stopped paying attention to his corrosive bombast, tired of his pious insults to his own party and unimpressed with his eagerness to shut down the government in pursuit of an ideological dream.

headline: President Obama at the United Nations
abstract: Iran topped the agenda in the president’s address to the General Assembly, but he acknowledged other challenges as well.
lead_paragraph: In his address to the United Nations General Assembly, President Obama gave some coherence to his foreign policy vision, which acknowledges both America’s role in the world and its limited ability to determine events inside other nations. He also set important, if incomplete, priorities for the rest of his term. Mr. Obama is well known for giving good speeches, so the question is whether he can implement a consistent, effective strategy to achieve his goals.

headline: Bloomberg Is Unlikely to Testify in Fraud Trial, Judge Says
abstract: The judge said he was not convinced that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s testimony was relevant in a trial over what prosecutors call a scheme to defraud New York City through a payroll project.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Manhattan indicated on Tuesday that he was unlikely to approve a defense lawyer’s request that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg be compelled to appear and testify as a defense witness in a fraud trial starting next month.

headline: The Way We Were
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'Research', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Tea Party Movement', 'United States Economy']
abstract: While productivity on Capitol Hill grinds to a halt, research and innovation in the country suffers.
lead_paragraph: Countries that don’t plan for the future tend not to do well there. When you watch the reckless behavior of the Tea Party-driven Republicans in Congress today, you can’t help but fear that we’ll be one of those. What makes it all the more frustrating is that in so many ways we have the wind at our back, if only we’d pull together to take advantage of it.

headline: With Simple Protest, Players Join Push for N.C.A.A. Reform
abstract: The National College Players Association, the group that organized the protest, said 28 players from three universities — Northwestern, Georgia and Georgia Tech — participated.
lead_paragraph: The protest took the form of three words, or three letters, scribbled onto equipment tape or actual equipment last Saturday during college football games. All Players United, or A.P.U., it read.

keywords: ['National Debt (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: Residents of northwestern Arkansas see the turmoil over a possible debt default as the new normal of Washington rather than a seminal political moment likely to affect their lives.
lead_paragraph: BENTONVILLE, Ark. — The apocalypse may or may not be looming in Washington in the form of a possible government shutdown or debt default.

headline: Full-Frontal Justice, a Matter of Redress
keywords: ['Theater', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Strip Clubs and Strippers']
abstract: “Arguendo,” which brings together strippers and Supreme Court justices, is an argument for the right to free expression within an argument for the right to free expression.
lead_paragraph: A cool, obsessive genius animates the ever more fevered proceedings of “Arguendo,” the Elevator Repair Service’s foray into the hallowed mazes of American jurisprudence. Come to think of it, jurisprudence doesn’t describe what’s happening here. “Jurisfolly” would be closer. In this anatomy of a 1991 legal case, now being re-enacted at the Public Theater, order in the court — the Supreme Court, no less — is not an option.

headline: It’s More Useful When It’s Busted
abstract: The return of Vic Fleming and Bonnie Gentry.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — I happen to like themes where the two-word phrases can have a word before or after them, because they tend to hold their secrets until the very last minute, although I tend to agree with Will Shortz when he says, “‘Word before’ and ‘word after’ sorts of themes have become overdone, I think.”

headline: Levine Returns to the Met
abstract: James Levine was greeted to a thundering ovation as he returned to the conductor’s podium at the Metropolitan Opera after a two-year absence because of injury.
lead_paragraph: He’s back.

headline: Increase in Jihadi Attacks in Africa May Reflect Movement’s Weakness
abstract: Some terrorism experts say an uptick in violence has occurred because Islamist militants are making a statement as they feel themselves threatened.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — A bloody mall siege in Kenya, mass hostage-taking in Algeria, brazen attacks on government facilities in Niger, routine killings of civilians in Nigeria, an aggressive military push toward the capital in Mali: have Islamist militants found their chosen soft spots on the African continent?

headline: O’Neal, New Partner in the Kings, Is Not Silent
abstract: Shaquille O’Neal apologized for calling the Kings “the Queens” a decade ago and said he saw no conflict of interest with his job as an analyst on the TNT program “Inside the N.B.A.”
lead_paragraph: In a city where Kevin Johnson, a former N.B.A. star, is the mayor, an even bigger retired star with a crateful of nicknames, Shaquille O’Neal, announced Tuesday that he had bought a piece of the Sacramento Kings. He promptly rechristened the city “Shaqramento.”

headline: Obama and Iranian Leader Miss Each Other, Diplomatically
abstract: The near miss between President Obama and President Hassan Rouhani of Iran illustrates the political sensitivities that will affect both leaders as they try to embark on a diplomatic path.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — It was the handshake that never happened.

lead_paragraph: Update: I see someone arguing that live music is too expensive for many families. Just to say, we’re not talking Taylor Swift here — tickets for last night were $15.

headline: For Obama, an Evolving Doctrine on Foreign Policy
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Palestinians']
abstract: President Obama told world leaders on Tuesday that he was devoting the rest of his presidency to a negotiated end to the Iran confrontation, and creating a separate state for the Palestinians.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For five years, President Obama has publicly struggled with the question of when America is willing to act as the world’s policeman, and when he will insist that others take the lead, or at least share the risks, costs and resentments it engenders.

headline: How Did Conservatives Get This Radical?
abstract: Showdowns, shutdowns and meltdowns.
lead_paragraph: Whether they did so out of conviction or fear, House Republicans bent to the will of the dominant Tea Party faction of their party and voted 228 to 1 on Sept. 20 to make continued financing of the federal government contingent on defunding the Affordable Care Act.

headline: After Hints of Guilty Plea, Lawmaker Opts for Trial
abstract: William F. Boyland Jr., a Brooklyn assemblyman facing corruption charges, was expected to plead guilty Tuesday, but at the last moment, he decided to go to trial.
lead_paragraph: The anticipation inside the courtroom was building: top officials from the United States attorney’s office in Brooklyn were there, along with the parents and supporters of William F. Boyland Jr., an assemblyman facing a host of corruption charges.

headline: Bitter Tone in Debate Between Public Advocate Rivals
abstract: The televised debate between Letitia James and Daniel L. Squadron was fiercely negative as the candidates sought to win over the tiny number of undecided voters.
lead_paragraph: Her steely gaze wavered only once.

headline: Extended America’s Cup Leaves Some High, Dry and Homeless
abstract: With the America’s Cup’s spilling into a third week, crews, commentators, fans and journalists have scrambled to change flight itineraries and find hotel rooms after their planned stays expired.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The only people scrambling more than the sailors aboard the America’s Cup yachts over the past 10 days have been those trying to figure out when the series of races would end.

headline: A Star Architect Leaves Some Clients Fuming
abstract: The architect Santiago Calatrava is collecting critics as buildings develop problems.
lead_paragraph: VALENCIA, Spain — For a while, this sprawling Mediterranean city embraced Santiago Calatrava’s architecture with gusto. In a dried-up riverbed, Mr. Calatrava built and built, eventually filling 86 acres with his radical, and some say awe-inspiring, designs.

headline: Will Hurricane Lull Blunt Coastal Shifts?
keywords: ['Disasters and Emergencies', 'Hurricane Sandy (2012)', 'Hurricanes and Tropical Storms', 'Weather']
abstract: As the sleepy hurricane season continues, will folks relax their guard or sustain shifts in coastal norms?
lead_paragraph: This Twitter item that I posted a short while ago says what needs to be said as the New York region heads toward the anniversary of the devastating surge from Hurricane Sandy:

headline: Former Justice Department Official Is Nominated to Appeals Court
abstract: President Obama on Tuesday nominated David Barron to be a federal appeals court judge in Boston.
lead_paragraph: President Obama on Tuesday nominated David Barron, who as acting head of the Justice Department’s Office of Legal Counsel at the start of the administration evaluated some of its most contentious legal policy questions, to be a federal appeals court judge in Boston. Mr. Barron, a Harvard Law School professor, led the agency from 2009 to 2010 and took a leading role in reviewing and writing legal policy memorandums about the war against Al Qaeda, along with domestic legal questions like how the TARP bailout fund could be used. Mr. Barron also signed two secret memorandums declaring that it would be lawful for the United States to kill Anwar al-Awlaki, a United States citizen suspected of plotting terrorist attacks,  if it were not feasible to capture him. Mr. Awlaki died in a drone strike in Yemen 2011. Mr. Barron is married to Juliette Kayyem, who is running in the Democratic Party primary for governor of Massachusetts.

headline: Christopher Koch, Writer of ‘Year of Living Dangerously,’ Dies at 81
abstract: Mr. Koch was widely regarded as one of Australia’s finest novelists. His best known book became even better known as a film.
lead_paragraph: Christopher Koch, who was widely regarded as one of Australia’s finest novelists and whose best-known book, “The Year of Living Dangerously,” became even better known as a film, died on Monday in Hobart, Australia. He was 81.

headline: Sabathia Promises to Adapt
abstract: After a subpar season that was ended last Friday by a hamstring injury, the Yankee’s left-handed ace acknowledged he will have to make changes for next season.
lead_paragraph: Throughout his baseball career, C. C. Sabathia has not watched much video of himself, or of opposing hitters. If his mechanics were off, the pitching coach would see the video evidence and tell Sabathia what needed to be corrected.

headline: Tradition Trumps Diversity in Boston Mayoral Vote
abstract: Two white men of Irish descent topped the balloting on Tuesday in the crowded race for mayor of Boston, and they will face off in November.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Two white men of Irish descent topped the balloting on Tuesday in the crowded race for mayor of Boston, dashing the hopes of many that this would be the year an African-American woman might have a shot at the top job in City Hall.

headline: David Hubel, Nobel-Winning Scientist, Dies at 87
abstract: Dr. Hubel was half of a team that studied how the brain processed information from the retina. The findings led to a better understanding of how to treat certain birth defects.
lead_paragraph: Dr. David Hubel, who was half of an enduring scientific team that won a Nobel Prize for explaining how the brain assembles information from the eye’s retina to produce detailed visual images of the world, died on Sunday in Lincoln, Mass. He was 87.

headline: Paul Dietzel, Coach Who Led L.S.U. to Its First National Title, Dies at 89
abstract: In Louisiana State’s 1958 championship season, Dietzel  used a platoon system famous for a scrappy defensive unit known as the Chinese Bandits.
lead_paragraph: Paul Dietzel, who in the first of three head coaching jobs in college football led Louisiana State to its first national championship, in 1958, using a platoon system famous for a scrappy defensive unit known as the Chinese Bandits, died on Tuesday at his home in Baton Rouge, La. He was 89.

headline: Rays All but Crush Yankees’ Wild-Card Hopes
abstract: With a shut-out loss, the Yankees were eliminated from the American League’s first wild-card spot Tuesday as they fell six games behind the Rays with five to play.
lead_paragraph: The Yankees’ inexorable march toward elimination inched closer to its conclusion, in typically maddening fashion and with very little resistance.

headline: 49ers on Edge of Falling Apart or Snapping Back
abstract: San Francisco has fallen short of expectations — defined as the point spread — by an average of 17.5 points this season.
lead_paragraph: From the moment Coach Jim Harbaugh arrived in San Francisco in 2011, the 49ers have been one of the N.F.L.’s best teams.

headline: 24 Recipients of MacArthur ‘Genius’ Awards Named
keywords: ['Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'Culture (Arts)', 'Writing and Writers', 'Science and Technology']
abstract: The dancer-choreographer Kyle Abraham, who recalled relying on food stamps three years ago, is among the 24 MacArthur fellows who will each receive a $625,000 stipend.
lead_paragraph: The dancer-choreographer Kyle Abraham, who recalled relying on food stamps just three years ago, was among the 13 men and 11 women officially named MacArthur fellows on Wednesday. Besides the imprimatur of achievement and future promise, the 2013 fellowships from the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation come with a sweetened stipend of $625,000 paid over five years.

headline: 5 Days, 5 Teams: Wild-Card Race Moves Toward Finish
abstract: The Orioles’ loss to the Blue Jays, which combined with the Rays’ 7-0 shutout victory over the Yankees, knocked them out of contention in the American League’s wild-card race.
lead_paragraph: The American League wild-card race, an egalitarian affair that includes teams more used to winning divisions and others more used to finishing under .500, began to narrow on Tuesday night.

headline: Medicare’s Lessons for the Affordable Care Act
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicare', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: The creation of Medicare in the 1960s may offer some insights for how the Affordable Care Act will go into effect, but the demographics of those eligible are quite different, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago. He is the author of “The Redistribution Recession: How Labor Market Distortions Contracted the Economy.”

headline: Why Runners Don’t Get Knee Arthritis
abstract: One of the most entrenched beliefs about running is that it can ruin knees by causing arthritis. But a new study finds that distance running is unlikely to contribute to the development of arthritis.
lead_paragraph: One of the most entrenched beliefs about running, at least among nonrunners, is that it causes arthritis and ruins knees. But a nifty new study finds that this idea is a myth and distance running is unlikely to contribute to the development of arthritis, precisely and paradoxically because it involves so much running.

headline: Officials Detail Premium Costs of Health Plan
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'States (US)']
abstract: The Obama administration highlighted premiums for consumers in states where the federal government will run new insurance markets starting next week, with costs it said were generally lower than prior estimates.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Tuesday provided the first detailed look at premiums to be charged to consumers for health insurance in 36 states where the federal government will run new insurance markets starting next week, highlighting costs it said were generally lower than previous estimates.
