lead_paragraph: DETROIT — To help prevent the deaths of children hit by cars that are backing up, the Transportation Department said Tuesday that it would add rearview cameras to its list of recommended safety measures.

headline: Unilever to Buy Oil Derived From Algae From Solazyme
abstract: Unilever plans to buy about three million gallons of the algae-produced oil as part of its aim to double the size of its business while reducing its environmental footprint.
lead_paragraph: In a sign of the growing mainstream acceptance of products derived from algae, Unilever, the consumer products giant, has agreed to buy large amounts of oil from Solazyme, a start-up that bioengineers algae to produce oils, proteins and complex sugars, executives said Tuesday.

headline: What’s On Wednesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (NBC) LAW & ORDER: SPECIAL VICTIMS UNIT After days with no word, the squad takes drastic measures to track down Detective Benson (Mariska Hargitay) and her abductor (Pablo Schreiber), both above, in this two-hour 15th-season premiere. But a trail of murders and rape victims causes her colleagues to worry that it’s already too late. Later, an abandoned boy leads the detectives to the house where his family lives — and where a locked basement reveals victims that could help solve cases that have been cold for decades.

headline: A Career With the Yankees
abstract: Mariano Rivera, who has pitched in relief for five World Series-winning teams and has been the Yankees’ closer since 1997, spent 19 seasons with the team, during which he became baseball’s career saves leader.
lead_paragraph: Mariano Rivera, who has pitched in relief for five World Series-winning teams and has been the Yankees’ closer since 1997, spent 19 seasons with the team, during which he became baseball’s career saves leader.

abstract: King Juan Carlos of Spain underwent hip surgery on Tuesday, his fifth operation in 18 months.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — King Juan Carlos of Spain underwent hip surgery on Tuesday, his fifth operation in 18 months, which has helped fuel the debate over whether the 75-year-old monarch is fit enough to remain on the throne.

headline: Toll in Quake in Pakistan Rises Past 300
abstract: Soldiers and rescue workers scrambled to reach victims in one of the country’s remotest areas, frequently troubled by unrest and natural calamities.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — The death toll from a devastating earthquake in western Pakistan rose to 327 on Wednesday, as soldiers and rescue workers scrambled to reach victims in one of the country’s remotest areas.

lead_paragraph: In “Scientific Discovery, Frame by Moving Frame,” James Gorman introduces ScienceTake, a new regular series on the Science pages. Watch the above video and then read the article to answer the questions below.

headline: Japanese-Brazilians: Straddling Two Cultures
abstract: Exploring crosscurrents of reverse migration, Nadia Shira Cohen and Paulo Siqueira photographed Japanese-Brazilians, who in Brazil are considered Japanese and in Japan are considered Brazilian.
lead_paragraph: Paulo Siqueira grew up in São Paulo, Brazil, going to school in the 1980s with friends whose grandparents had immigrated from Japan earlier in the 20th century to work on coffee plantations. Inside their homes, Japanese language, culture and cuisine prevailed. His friends, he thought, were an interesting mix.

headline: Can a Gay, Catholic Leftist Actually Squelch Corruption in Sicily?
abstract: Rosario Crocetta is a reform-minded leader in a highly corrupt place that hates change. And that’s only one reason his life is in danger.
lead_paragraph: Rosario Crocetta smokes two to three packs of cigarettes a day, lighting them without putting them to his lips, often glancing at the three cellphones arrayed before him as he does so. If you are speaking to him, as an emissary from Turin named Antonio Saitta was on the day I first met Crocetta, he often picks up one of the phones in midconversation, without apology, and urgently begins reading text messages.

headline: Would You Most Want to Live in a City, a Suburb or the Country?
abstract: What best describes where you live now: a city, a suburb, a small town or the country? Where do you want to live as an adult? Why?
lead_paragraph: A recent Sunday Review article looked at how attitudes and patterns are changing in terms of where Americans prefer to live.

abstract: What you need to know for Wednesday: the Second Avenue Subway advances, power outages on Metro-North and the president compliments Dante’s hair.

headline: Do You Have Any Grey Poupon? Rolls-Royce and Bentley Owners Cruise Tuxedo Park
keywords: ['Antique and Classic Cars', 'Automobiles', 'Historic Buildings and Sites']
abstract: Tuxedo Park, N.Y., one of America’s first gated communities, played host to a gathering of Rolls-Royce owners who also took part in a tour of local mansions.
lead_paragraph: About 40 vintage Rolls-Royce and Bentley automobiles descended on one of America’s most exclusive private communities, Tuxedo Park, N.Y., for “Gates and Estates,” an event held on Sunday. Sponsored by the Atlantic Region of the Rolls-Royce Owners’ Club and hosted by Peter Regna, the noted car collector and entrepreneur, and his wife, Barbara, the gathering took guests on a four-mile drive through “The Park” and featured walking tours of three luxurious homes along the way.

headline: Attention Switches to Investigation of Kenyan Mall Siege
abstract: Investigators began sifting through rubble, studied closed-circuit television footage and brought in more resources to identify the militants who laid siege to an upscale mall in Nairobi.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — Kenyan and American investigators began a sweeping inquiry on Wednesday into a shopping mall massacre here that killed scores of people, sifting through rubble, studying closed-circuit television footage and bringing in more resources to identify the attackers.

headline: A New Senator Stops Talking, and a Vote on Spending Nears
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Tea Party Movement', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Filibusters and Debate Curbs', 'Federal Budget (US)']
abstract: Senator Ted Cruz’s verbal assault on the health care law ended when the Senate voted 100 to 0 to end debate and move to consider legislation that keeps the government open through Dec. 15.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate on Wednesday moved toward approving legislation to keep the government open without gutting the health care law after Senator Ted Cruz’s 21-hour-and-19-minute verbal assault on it ended with a 100-to-0 vote that is likely to lead to an outcome that Mr. Cruz had tried to stop.

headline: Levine Is Impressive in Return to Met With ‘Così Fan Tutte’
abstract: The Met’s maestro, James Levine, conducted Mozart’s “Così Fan Tutte” Tuesday night at the Metropolitan Opera, with a bright young cast.
lead_paragraph: When James Levine conducted the orchestra of the Metropolitan Opera in a triumphant concert at Carnegie Hall in May, I wrote that, against all odds, he was back in action. Injuries and multiple health problems had incapacitated Mr. Levine for two years. But with rehabilitation and surgery, he finally returned to a podium. Well, a special kind of podium: a rotating platform with an elevator mechanism, named the “maestro lift,” that can accommodate the motorized wheelchair he has taken to using.

headline: Street Vendor’s Execution Stokes Anger in China
abstract: Some compared the fate of Xia Junfeng, who stabbed two officials to death four years ago, with that of another convicted killer, Gu Kailai; she was spared the death penalty.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — There was never any doubt that Xia Junfeng was a killer: Four years ago, in a flash of panic and fear, he stabbed to death two urban enforcement officials who had sought to punish him for operating an unlicensed shish kebab stall.

headline: Poll Shows Disapproval of Threat of   Government Shutdown
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'National Debt (US)', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Tea Party Movement']
abstract: Republicans, Democrats and independents alike object to the threat of a shutdown during budget negotiations, a poll says.
lead_paragraph: Eight in 10 Americans find it unacceptable for either President Obama or members of Congress to threaten to shut down the government during budget negotiations in order to achieve their goals, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll. Fewer than 1 in 5 think the stalemate between Mr. Obama and the Republicans in Congress is acceptable.

headline: How I Hire: Don’t Tell Me You Work Too Hard and Care Too Much
abstract: How do you get candidates to talk usefully about their weaknesses?
lead_paragraph: Editor’s Note: Adam Bryant writes the Corner Office for the Times. This column was written as part of LinkedIn’s “How I Hire” feature.

headline: Aguirre, the Wrath of God
abstract: When natural catastrophes are pitfalls for Mexican politicians.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Hurricanes and politics don’t mix. Just think about that photo of George W. Bush looking down on New Orleans after Katrina in 2005 from a seat on Air Force One.

headline: Advice About  Sleep Deficiency in Midlife, Part 1
abstract: Orfeu Marcello Buxton, a neuroscientist, addresses questions about “normal sleep” in midlife, sleep apnea and other aspects of sleep deficiency.
lead_paragraph: More than 200 people sent questions (most can be read here) about sleep to Orfeu Marcello Buxton, a neuroscientist who studies chronic sleep deficiency in the workplace and home and how it contributes to disorders like obesity, diabetes and cardiovascular disease.

headline: A Seven-Hour Documentary About a Horror Franchise? The Director Explains
abstract: The director of a new seven-hour documentary about the horror film “Friday the 13th” talks about the franchise’s history and popularity.
lead_paragraph: It takes almost 10 hours to watch the landmark Holocaust documentary “Shoah.” If you have 24 hours to spare you can spend it with Christian Marclay’s movie-clip art film “The Clock.” Now horror fans have their own chance for marathon movie-watching with the release of “Crystal Lake Memories,” a seven-hour documentary about the highly successful “Friday the 13th” franchise.

headline: Daily Report: Alibaba Is Said to Shift I.P.O. Focus to U.S.
abstract: The Chinese Internet company Alibaba has ended talks with the Hong Kong stock exchange over an initial public offering and is now moving forward with plans to list in New York, a person close to Alibaba said on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: The Chinese Internet company Alibaba has ended talks with the Hong Kong stock exchange over an initial public offering and is now moving forward with plans to list in New York, a person close to Alibaba said on Wednesday.

headline: SAC in Settlement Talks
abstract: Federal prosecutors and SAC Capital Advisors are said to be in settlement talks. | Alibaba has shifted its initial public offering plans to New York from Hong Kong. | JPMorgan Chase is negotiating a multibillion-dollar settlement with state and federal agencies over its sale of troubled mortgage securities before the financial crisis.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors have begun talks with the hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors to settle criminal insider trading charges against the firm, DealBook’s Peter Lattman reports. The settlement talks are at an early stage, and the two sides are far from any agreement, people briefed on the case said. The government is seeking a guilty plea from SAC and a financial penalty of as much as $2 billion, they said.

headline: Quick Change in Williamsburg
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A security camera caught a woman changing out of her Hasidic clothing into an outfit more appropriate for secular entertainment.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Key Syrian Rebel Groups Abandon Exile Leaders
abstract: As diplomats push for a peace conference to end Syria’s conflict, a collection of some of the country’s most powerful rebel groups have publicly abandoned the opposition’s political leaders.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — As diplomats at the United Nations push for a peace conference to end Syria’s civil war, a collection of some of the country’s most powerful rebel groups have publicly abandoned the opposition’s political leaders, casting their lot with an affiliate of Al Qaeda.

headline: Putin Defends Seizure of Activists’ Ship but Questions Piracy Charges
abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin appeared intent on defending Russia’s decision to seize a Greenpeace International ship last week, while defusing potential diplomatic tensions if the crew members are charged with piracy.
lead_paragraph: SALEKHARD, Russia — President Vladimir V. Putin said Wednesday that the Russian authorities were justified in seizing a Greenpeace International ship at an offshore oil platform in the Arctic last week, but he questioned whether the activities of the ship’s 30 crew members warranted the piracy charges that Russian authorities said they would pursue.

headline: Bowser, Stay! (Forever)
abstract: Pet owners in New York State can now be interred with their pets. Do you really want to go there?
lead_paragraph: I heard on the news that New York State will now permit animal owners to share burial plots in their deceased pets’ cemeteries, and my first thought was: “Why wait, guys? Jump in with them right now.”

headline: Another Pass at Revitalizing Abandoned Warehouse Space on the Waterfront
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Real Estate (Commercial)']
abstract: A redevelopment plan for the Empire Stores, seven red-brick buildings in Brooklyn on the East River, has faced decades of delay, but a new team was designated this month.
lead_paragraph: Even in their name, Empire Stores, the seven adjoining red-brick warehouses on the East River conjure the mercantile might and reach of the City of Brooklyn in the 19th century. Through their arched openings passed coffee, sugar, molasses and hides from Africa, South America and the Caribbean.

headline: Stryker to Buy MAKO Surgical for $1.65 Billion
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Robots and Robotics', 'Surgery and Surgeons']
abstract: The price of $30 a share represents a huge 86 percent premium for MAKO, which makes tools for robotic assisted surgery in orthopedics.
lead_paragraph: The Stryker Corporation, the medical technology company based in Kalamazoo, Mich., said on Wednesday that it would pay $1.65 billion for the MAKO Surgical Corporation.

headline: Visit to Washington Ends Era in U.S.- India Relations
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Elections', 'Indian-Americans', 'United States Economy', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The past and the future of the U.S. – India relationship.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Manmohan Singh of India, who is on a visit to the United States, will meet President Obama in Washington on Friday.

headline: U.S. and British Officials Fine ICAP in Libor Case
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Fines (Penalties)', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Libor (London Interbank Offered Rate)']
abstract: The Justice Department also brought criminal charges against three former ICAP employees on Wednesday over their roles in manipulating the benchmark London interbank offered rate.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:55 p.m. | LONDON — American and British authorities moved a step further on Wednesday in their investigation into the manipulation of the benchmark interest rate known as Libor, fining the British financial firm ICAP a combined $87 million for its role.

headline: Fox Grabs ‘Gotham’ Series, About the City Before Batman
abstract: “Gotham,” written by the “Mentalist” creator Bruno Heller, will be a one-hour crime drama exploring the origins of Commissioner James Gordon and the villains that made Batman’s hometown famous.
lead_paragraph: If you’re of the opinion that the movies have become dominated by reboots and adaptations of comic books, well, you won’t find much refuge on television, either. On Tuesday evening, while ABC was showing the debut episode of “Marvel’s Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D.,” its action series spun off from the superhero blockbuster “The Avengers,” Fox was making its own commitment to “Gotham,” a new show set in the stomping grounds of Batman, the caped-and-cowled DC Comics champion.

headline: Power Failure Disrupts Metro North’s New Haven Line; May Last Days
abstract: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority said that the problem was caused by the loss of a feeder cable, and that the disruptions could persist for at least a few days.
lead_paragraph: Hours after a predawn power loss shut down much of Metro-North Railroad’s New Haven Line early on Wednesday, officials warned that service could be imperiled for several days, and possibly longer, upending commutes for tens of thousands of travelers.

headline: Feeling For | A Hong Kong Neighborhood That’s a Lot Like Brooklyn
abstract: The laid-back area of Tai Hang is proving that Hong Kong’s night life scene is about more than fancy hotel bars and ostentatious clubs.
lead_paragraph: The remarkably easygoing Tai Hang neighborhood feels a little like, well, Brooklyn.

headline: See the Abortion Documentary ‘After Tiller’
abstract: The new film about third-trimester abortions takes a complicated subject beyond the familiar talking-points.
lead_paragraph: “After Tiller,” a new documentary focused on the four doctors in the United States openly performing third-trimester abortions, takes a complicated subject beyond the familiar muck of abstract and often ill-informed talking points to deliver a frank portrayal of the real life situations of the physicians and their desperate patients.

headline: A Nudge to Poorer Students to Aim High on Colleges
abstract: Seniors with high SAT scores are receiving packets from the College Board encouraging them to apply to top colleges, part of a new outreach effort.
lead_paragraph: The group that administers the SAT has begun a nationwide outreach program to try to persuade more low-income high school seniors who scored high on standardized tests to apply to select colleges.

headline: With Special Courts, State Aims to Steer Women Away From Sex Trade
abstract: In an initiative believed to be the first of its kind in the nation, a system announced by New York State’s chief judge will use social services and specially trained court officers to help victims.
lead_paragraph: New York State is creating a statewide system of specialized criminal courts to handle prostitution cases and provide services to help wrest human- and sex-trafficking victims from the cycle of exploitation and arrest, the state’s chief judge announced on Wednesday. The initiative is believed to be the first of its kind in the nation.

headline: Escaping the Cycle of Scarcity
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Credit and Debt', 'Poverty', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: The bad decisions of the poor, says a new book, are not a product of bad character or low intelligence. They are a product of poverty itself.
lead_paragraph: “Scarcity” is a new book that does something that I didn’t think possible: it says something new about why people are poor — and what to do about it.

headline: A Report Card on Education Reform
abstract: A discussion with Education Secretary Arne Duncan; Mitch Daniels, the president of Purdue University; and John Engler, the head of the Business Roundtable, about the state of the education system.
lead_paragraph: I sat down last week in Washington with Arne Duncan, the secretary of education, and Mitch Daniels, the former Indiana governor and current Purdue University president, after they had met with several dozen chief executives of big companies to talk about education. Their meeting was at the office of the Business Roundtable, the corporate lobbying group, and joining us for the conversation was John Engler, the former Michigan governor who runs the Business Roundtable.

headline: Treasury Puts a Date on When Cash May Run Out: Oct. 17
abstract: Treasury Secretary Jacob J. Lew warned in a letter to Speaker John A. Boehner on Wednesday that the government might not be able to pay its bills in mid-October unless a budget deal was made.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Treasury has handed Congress an urgent deadline: Oct. 17.

headline: Kids’ Menu
abstract: In four new picture books, three of them bilingual, the pleasures of gathering and preparing food are paramount.
lead_paragraph: Apple trees heavy with fruit, fat pumpkins waiting to be chosen at the farm; autumn harvests, with their reckless abundance and promise of feasts to come, suggest an enduring North American heritage more than those of any other season. In four new children’s books, three of them bilingual, the pleasures of gathering and preparing food are paramount.

headline: A Candidate’s Attack on a ‘Marxist’ Strategy
abstract: Gotham Extra: Joseph J. Lhota expressed his concern that years ago, Bill de Blasio joined what was known as a solidarity group supporting the Sandinistas in Nicaragua, though the history of the movement is complicated.
lead_paragraph: Joseph J. Lhota’s office sent out an e-mail on Tuesday, purportedly from the Republican candidate for mayor. It concerned his grave alarm at the “news” that more than two decades ago, Bill de Blasio, his Democratic rival, had joined what was known as a solidarity group supporting the Sandinistas in Nicaragua.

headline: App Smart: Best Apps for iOS7
abstract: Now that Apple has rolled out its latest mobile operating system, iOS 7, several apps take advantage of the new look and feel of iPhones.
lead_paragraph: Now that Apple has rolled out its latest mobile operating system, iOS 7, several apps take advantage of the new look and feel of iPhones.

headline: Kacey Musgraves’s Arrow Is Pointing Up
abstract: The country music scene was wary of her lyrics about same-sex desire a few months ago. But soon, “Follow Your Arrow” — which some found controversial — will air as a radio single.
lead_paragraph: When the magazine profiled Kacey Musgraves in March, her record label had just decided that country radio wasn’t ready for her song “Follow Your Arrow” to be released as a single. While the mainstream country music coming out of Nashville sounds more and more like what’s on pop stations, where pretty much anything goes as long as everyone’s wearing glitter, country radio’s gatekeepers still try to enforce a moralizing wholesomeness founded on church values, patriotism and a calculated intolerance that has more to do with focus groups and corporate branding than with the lived experience of regular folks.

headline: Part II: Lessons From Post-Soviet Afghanistan Haunt Debate on Syria
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'International Relations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Translation and Interpreters', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Kristen L. Rouse, a captain in the Army National Guard, says the all-consuming flames of civil war are unforgiving, and the damage can never be undone.
lead_paragraph: Since President Obama began weighing the possibility of military strikes against the government of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, many veterans have been discussing the pros and cons of another armed intervention so soon after the Iraq war ended, and at a time when American troops are still engaged in Afghanistan. One theme often heard in that debate is that policy makers in the White House and Congress should listen to the voices of veterans in calculating the cost of another war. With the United Nations expected to debate Syria — and the possibility of resolving the crisis — through diplomacy this week, At War offers two essays by former soldiers, one a veteran of the war in Iraq, one of the war in Afghanistan, below, on the issue.

headline: Part 1: Idealism or Realism When It Comes to Syria?
abstract: Dan Savage, a former infantry officer, analyzes the debate over Syria through his perspective as a veteran.
lead_paragraph: Since President Obama began weighing the possibility of military strikes against the government of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, many veterans have been discussing the pros and cons of another armed intervention so soon after the Iraq war ended, and at a time when American troops are still engaged in Afghanistan. One theme often heard in that debate is that policy makers in the White House and Congress should listen to the voices of veterans in calculating the cost of another war. With the United Nations expected to debate Syria – and the possibility of resolving the crisis – through diplomacy this week, At War offers two essays by former soldiers, one a veteran of the war in Iraq, below, and one of the war in Afghanistan, on the issue.

headline: Apps That Make the Most of iOS 7
abstract: Apple’s mobile operating system has undergone a radical, huge redesign, and several apps have been updated to match the new look and feel.
lead_paragraph: Consumers have been lining up worldwide to buy Apple’s new iPhones, even braving a typhoon in Japan.

headline: We Need Better Infrastructure, Personal Whining Edition
abstract: Testing my affection for rail travel.
lead_paragraph: Update: Progress! We’re no longer sitting motionless underground in Manhattan! We’re now sitting motionless in bright sunlight somewhere in the Bronx! I should add that by and large I still find Amtrak — and NJ Transit, which I use a lot — relatively reliable and convenient, especially compared with either driving or air travel.

headline: ‘Yo, I’m Driving. I’ll Text You When It’s Safe.’
keywords: ['Driver Distraction and Fatigue', 'Parenting', 'Smartphones', 'Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Text Messaging']
abstract: I couldn’t help but wonder, if he went for his phone with me right there, what would he do when he had his license and I was no longer in the car, watching his every move?
lead_paragraph: His newly minted learner’s permit in hand, my 15-year-old son, Nathaniel, sat behind the wheel the other day when his mobile phone rang. We were just pulling onto the street in front of our house, and as if on autopilot, his hand reached for the phone. “Are you kidding?” I said, incredulous that he would even consider it.

headline: Default Notes
abstract: Known unknowns, unknown unknowns, and markets.
lead_paragraph: Add me to the chorus of those puzzled by the lack of market alarm over the possibility of U.S. default, induced by failure to raise the debt ceiling. The best story I’ve heard came from a government official who put it something like this: “Business types come to Washington, and they talk to Boehner, or Paul Ryan, or Eric Cantor – all of whom are very hard line, but not insane. So they go home reassured. What they don’t realize is that those guys aren’t in control, and that they’re running scared of a large faction of the party that is indeed insane.”

headline: On YouTube, ‘Lyrics Videos’ Mark a New Genre
abstract: Once a kind of fan tribute, “lyrics videos” have become so successful on YouTube that major musicians like Katy Perry and the Rolling Stones are now producing their own.
lead_paragraph: If you had searched for a “lyrics video” on YouTube in 2008, you might have found a touching homegrown tribute from a fan who urgently wanted to share the poetical lyricism of their favorite song with the world.

headline: Newest Hotel Perk: Baristas in the Lobby
abstract: The lobbies at Le Méridien hotels will feature coffee experts who also can offer recommendations for what to do around town.
lead_paragraph: There are hotel chains for pet lovers (Kimpton Hotels) and art lovers (21c Museum Hotels). Now there’s one for coffee lovers. Le Méridien aims to position itself as the lodging of choice for those who love java with its new Master Barista initiative, placing a dedicated coffee expert at each of its 100 hotels globally by year end.

headline: The Gun Report: September 25, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: In my column on Tuesday, I mentioned that it has been the rabid gun supporters—rather than those trying to stop gun violence—who have been galvanized in recent months. Here is another example: A group called the Armed Citizen Project has proposed giving away shotguns to residents of a neighborhood in Orlando, Fla., called Sunshine Gardens. It is a little unclear why the leaders of the gun giveaway chose this neighborhood, since it is not especially high-crime, but Ron Ritter, the organization’s “state director,” told reporters that he is looking for gun owners to donate arms that can be distributed to people in the neighborhood.

headline: New Beauty Goal: Plumper Cheeks
abstract: Round, plump cheeks look young. Saggy, sunken ones look old. Dermatologists now focus on increasing volume for a more youthful look.
lead_paragraph: Like many people, Christina Conti, 44, a personal assistant from Wantagh, N.Y., was seeking a more youthful appearance. “I have a very thin face, and with that signs of aging come much faster,” she said. “I lost volume in my face over the years.”

headline: Market Report | World-Class Watches for International Travelers
abstract: These stylish timepieces for men and women, which can keep track of up to 24 time zones, cater to the world’s most serious journeyers.
lead_paragraph: Serious travelers deserve a world-class watch that can seamlessly keep track of up to 24 time zones.

headline: Highlights and Analysis: Oracle Team USA Wins America’s Cup
abstract: Live updates, winds permitting, as the rivals from different hemispheres contest one final race Wednesday at 4:15 p.m. Eastern, winner take all.
lead_paragraph: Ken Read, NBC Sports’ sailing commentator, may have summarized Oracle Team USA’s amazing comeback at the America’s Cup best during the final sprint to the finish Wednesday.

headline: A Harlem Suite for Three Women
abstract: Farah Jasmine Griffin discusses her new book, “Harlem Nocturne: Women Artists & Progressive Politics During World War II.”
lead_paragraph: In the book “Harlem Nocturne: Women Artists & Progressive Politics During World War II,” Prof. Farah Jasmine Griffin breathes life into three prominent women who lived and flourished in a New York brimming with clubs like Café Society and with anti-Jim Crow protests: Ann Petry, the novelist; Mary Lou Williams, the pianist and composer; and Pearl Primus, the dancer and choreographer.

headline: Image of the Day: Sept. 25
abstract: A herd of goats on a flooded street in Ahmedabad, Gujarat.

headline: Luciano Vincenzoni, Screenwriter, Dies at 87
abstract: Mr. Vincenzoni, who worked with prominent filmmakers like Billy Wilder and Dino De Laurentiis, was most associated with “For a Few Dollars More” and “The Good, the Bad and the Ugly.”
lead_paragraph: Luciano Vincenzoni, an urbane Italian screenwriter who worked with Billy Wilder, Dino De Laurentiis and other giants of film but to his dismay was best known for helping to write two spaghetti westerns starring a young Clint Eastwood, died on Sunday in Rome. He was 87.

headline: The Boyhood Tides That Formed Baseball’s Sandman
abstract: The best playing surface in Puerto Caimito, Panama — Yankees closer Mariano Rivera’s boyhood village — was the hard, white sand that revealed itself at low tide.
lead_paragraph: Children do not play ball on the beach at Puerto Caimito the way they did when Mariano Rivera was a boy. Erosion and construction have changed the dimensions of the beach, and a new field nearby actually has grass.

headline: Dries Van Noten: Spring 2014 RTW
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: Today in Small Business: The Cocoa Shortage
abstract: Doubts about crowdfunding. Home prices continue to rise. Explaining Google’s search rankings. And George W. Bush is on Instagram.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Getting Online Products to Their New Owners
abstract: Speedy delivery of orders often poses a challenge for owners of small online businesses.
lead_paragraph: Like many small-business owners, Hanna and Mark Lim gave little thought to fulfillment until they had no choice.

headline: Collaboration, From the Beginning to the Final Box
abstract: Andrea Miller of Gallim Dance prepares her newest work, “Fold Here,” for its world premiere on Thursday at the Alexander Kassaer Theater.
lead_paragraph: In the high-ceilinged parish hall of a Brooklyn church on a warm August afternoon, nine members of Gallim Dance worked intensely, mostly alone or in pairs, exploring intricate movement phrases as Louis Armstrong’s “Kiss to Build a Dream On” played over and over. One by one, all of the dancers came forward to offer Andrea Miller, the highly pregnant choreographer, their specific phrases and gestures, as she surveyed, suggested and prodded. Trying to make a point to Francesca Romo, who was maneuvering around a cardboard box, Ms. Miller made a reference to Mister Rogers. Ms. Romo, who was born in Britain, responded with a blank stare.

headline: ‘Our Yankee Stadium’
abstract: Images from Puerto Caimito, Panama, the boyhood home of Yankees closer Mariano Rivera.
lead_paragraph: Images from Puerto Caimito, Panama, the boyhood home of Yankees closer Mariano Rivera.

headline: Things Traders Say, ICAP Edition
abstract: Curry meals, Champagne and steaks were among the rewards promised to ICAP brokers, according to documents released on Wednesday by authorities in a Libor manipulation case.
lead_paragraph: Curry meals, steaks, Champagne and a Ferrari.

headline: Helen Gurley Brown Trust Donates $15 Million for College Prep at New York Libraries
abstract: The five-year program, called NYPL BridgeUP, will provide academic and social support to eighth graders at five library branches in the Bronx and Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Helen Gurley Brown didn’t care only about the Cosmo girl.

headline: In JPMorgan Case, a Missed Opportunity to Charge Its Executives
keywords: ['Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Securities and Commodities Violations']
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission wrung an admission of wrongdoing out of the bank, but it did not charge any top executives with misleading disclosure.
lead_paragraph: Both the Securities and Exchange Commission and JPMorgan Chase won great public relations victories last week. But the public lost — and in ways that go far beyond this one spat.

headline: A Statue Is Removed, and Fans Are Thrilled
abstract: A statue of Michael Jackson, installed by the Fulham team’s former owner, stood outside Craven Cottage in London for more than two years.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — For decades, Michael Jackson was known for his elaborate entrances and glittery stage shows. On Wednesday, the King of Pop was hauled away in air-bubble packaging by four burly stonemasons.

headline: Text to Text | ‘Where Do Your Genes Come From?’ and ‘DNA Double Take’
abstract: In our new lesson format, Text to Text, we match a Times article with often-taught scientific, historic, cultural or literary material. This edition is about new findings in genetics.
lead_paragraph: This week we introduce a new lesson plan format we’re calling Text to Text. In each lesson, we’ll match a Times article, past or present, with often-taught literary, cultural, historical, scientific or mathematical material. Read more about the format, and consider submitting your own ideas.

headline: One Dies in Shooting Near Long Island Mall
abstract: The gunman, who fled, was identified by the police as Sang Ho Kim, 63, of  Queens; the authorities said he had been angry over a business deal.
lead_paragraph: One person was killed and another was seriously wounded in Nassau County on Wednesday after being shot by a gunman who was angered over a business deal gone bad, the authorities said.

headline: Once Again, California Eases Harsh Sentencing Laws
abstract: “Hangover” producer Scott Budnick was a prime mover in a campaign to help juvenile offenders get out on parole early.
lead_paragraph: For the third time in a year, California has changed its laws to show more leniency  toward the state’s most harshly punished prisoners.

headline: Iran’s New President Condemns Holocaust as a Crime
abstract: An interview with CNN was part of an energetic effort by President Hassan Rouhani of Iran to distinguish himself from his bombastic predecessor.
lead_paragraph: President Hassan Rouhani of Iran, visiting the United Nations this week for the first time, intensified efforts on Wednesday to dispel suspicions about his country’s intentions, asserting in a CNN interview that he condemned the Holocaust and that he bore “greetings to the people of America who are very dear and near to the hearts of the Iranian people.”

headline: The Cost of Climate Change
abstract: Some scholars assert that estimates of the long-term cost of a rise in atmospheric temperatures are greatly understated.
lead_paragraph: How much will climate change cost?

headline: An Elite Public School Is the Saddest Spot in Manhattan, a Study Says
abstract: Hunter College High School, filled with many of the city’s top performing students, was labeled the saddest place in Manhattan, based on a study that gauged the emotions of New Yorkers by their Twitter messages.
lead_paragraph: Hunter College High School is a highly rated school whose coveted spots are filled with many of the city’s top performing students. It feeds Ivy League colleges and provides a free education that supporters believe surpasses what is offered at many of the elite private high schools in New York City.

headline: Wheelies: The Harley Sting Ray Edition
abstract: A custom ’63 Corvette Sting Ray built for G.M. the design chief Harley Earl goes up for auction next month, and Fiat delays introduction of Alfa Romeo to the United States.
lead_paragraph: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Does Fulfillment Have to Be a Headache?
abstract: Laura Zander of Jimmy Beans Wool sees it as a competitive advantage.
lead_paragraph: Laura Zander, co-founder of Jimmy Beans Wool, has a different way of looking at what’s known as fulfillment — the packing and shipping of online orders (and the topic of an article we’ve just published).

headline: At Rochas, Dessert Is Served
abstract: The Rochas show was like swallowing a many-tiered cake, or a chandelier, and having the sugar crystals come through your pores.
lead_paragraph: The Rochas show was like swallowing a many-tiered cake, or a chandelier, and having the sugar crystals come through your pores. Everything was seemingly coated in sequins, or the fabrics looked like spun sugar. Actually, in his press notes for what is expected to be his last Rochas show, Marco Zanini described a literal interpretation of “The Glass Menagerie.”

headline: A Vacation Rental Platform for Jet-Setters
abstract: Onefinestay, an up-and-coming service in the mold of Airbnb and HomeAway, offers properties and perks for guests used to four-star hotels.
lead_paragraph: For those who appreciate the advantages of services like Airbnb and HomeAway, but want something more like the Four Seasons treatment, there’s Onefinestay. The platform, which started in London three years ago (where it now boasts 1,000 homes), offers travelers curated, upscale residences, with a variety of perks, like a “front desk” number that is staffed around the clock and the free usage of a local iPhone preloaded with the homeowner’s favorite neighborhood spots. The actual homeowners, happily, stay out of sight. Onefinestay manages all bookings, sending staffers to greet visitors with gift packs and to clean up for them after they leave.

headline: The Bronx, Home for Me and Mom
abstract: Judy Sheridan needed a house in the Bronx where she could live with her elderly mother.
lead_paragraph: As the years passed, Judy Sheridan’s mother, Helen Stoltz, became less and less able to care for herself.

headline: J.W. Anderson Named to Loewe
abstract: The designer will be creative director of the Spanish leather house and received a major injection of funding from LVMH Moët Hennessy Louis Vuitton for his brand.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — “I love Paris. It’s the most sophisticated city,” Jonathan Anderson said as he stood on the Champs-Élysées — and on top of the fashion world.

headline: Before Artisanal Everything Arrived in Brooklyn, There Was This
abstract: A diner in Williamsburg with a killer pork chop.
lead_paragraph: Wythe Avenue was dark as pitch at night in the early part of the century, Williamsburg empty around it, save for prostitutes working the corners and the occasional carpenter kid slogging home from the L train.

headline: Rochas: Spring 2014 RTW
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: Britain Sues to Stop Cap on Bonuses for Bankers
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Bonuses', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: Britain said on Wednesday that it had filed a lawsuit at the European Court of Justice contesting a proposed cap on bankers’ bonuses.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:26 p.m. | Britain said on Wednesday that it had filed a lawsuit at the European Court of Justice contesting a proposed cap on bankers’ bonuses.

headline: It’s Time for Gates to Part Ways With Microsoft
abstract: Bill Gates’s many talents don’t include effectiveness as chairman. Under his leadership, Microsoft’s board left Mr. Ballmer in place too long, the author writes.
lead_paragraph: Maybe Bill Gates should follow Steven Ballmer out of Microsoft.

headline: Steal My Vacation: Norma Kamali’s Provence
abstract: The designer always returns to Provence because of the quality of its olive oil, which she considers the best in the world. Here’s her take on getting a taste of the region.
lead_paragraph: As anyone who has donned a coat inspired by sleeping bags or a dress made of parachutes knows, Norma Kamali is the New York designer behind decades of pioneering trends. But one need not care a whit about fashion to know her work. Remember that 1970s poster of Farrah Fawcett in a red one-piece bathing suit? Those itty-bitty fringe shorts on Beyoncé in her “Run the World (Girls)” video? The vintage wedding dress Lady Gaga wore in her “You and I” video? All Kamali.

headline: 2 Restaurants, 2 Former Spouses. The Winner?
abstract: A number of connections knit a pair of recently opened restaurants together in Burgundy. For diners, however, the best part of the story may be on the plate.
lead_paragraph: Restaurant openings in the Burgundy region of France, where a mix of beloved Michelin-star recipients and calcified institutions generally reign, aren’t an everyday event, so the debut of two spots within a few months of each other might be news enough. But it’s their link to the nearly two-decades-old Le Gourmandin — and to each other — that makes their story that much more noteworthy.

headline: Statins Tied to Cataract Risk
abstract: In one of the largest studies ever done on the subject, researchers have found that taking statins, the widely used cholesterol-lowering drugs, is associated with an increased risk for cataracts.
lead_paragraph: In one of the largest studies ever done on the subject, researchers have found that taking statins, the widely used cholesterol-lowering drugs, is associated with an increased risk for cataracts. Previous studies had mixed results.

headline: Homes for $800,000
abstract: This week’s properties are in Massachusetts, Washington State and downtown Columbus, Ohio.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties are in Massachusetts, Washington State and downtown Columbus, Ohio.

headline: What You Get for ... $800,000
abstract: Valley views in Massachusetts, waterfront in Washington State and downtown living in Columbus, Ohio.
lead_paragraph: BERNARDSTON, MASS.

headline: Antonia Fraser Steps Down From Booker Prize Role
keywords: ['Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'Books and Literature', 'Man Booker International Prize', 'Man Booker Prize']
abstract: Ms. Fraser has resigned as an adviser to the Man Booker International Prize, after the related Man Booker Prize for Fiction recently loosened its eligibility requirements.
lead_paragraph: The award-winning historian and writer Antonia Fraser has resigned as an adviser to the Man Booker International Prize, after the related Man Booker Prize for Fiction recently and controversially loosened its eligibility requirements.

headline: ‘Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D.’ Gains a Big Audience While ‘The Voice’ Keeps Rolling
abstract: The ratings Tuesday night again show that the networks, this time ABC, can introduce a new show and get a big audience to watch it.
lead_paragraph: The networks on Tuesday night again demonstrated that they can successfully introduce a series to the public, as ABC’s much-hyped new comic-book drama, “Marvel’s Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D.,” posted the best numbers for a new drama in almost four years.

headline: Real Estate in South Africa
abstract: The market in the affluent beachfront suburbs of Cape Town, like Camps Bay and nearby Clifton, has improved over the last year.
lead_paragraph: The market in the affluent beachfront suburbs of Cape Town, like Camps Bay and nearby Clifton, has improved over the last year.

headline: Bubbles, Regulation, and Secular Stagnation
abstract: The weirdness may run deep and long.
lead_paragraph: Looking at current macroeconomic policy, the obvious question is, stupid or evil? And the obvious answer is, why do we have to choose?

headline: Model-Morphosis | Marina Nery at Rochas
abstract: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Spring 2014 Fashion Week in Paris.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Spring 2014 Fashion Week in Paris. Here, the model Marina Nery before (left) and after (right) makeup by Lucia Pieroni and hair by Eugene Souleiman.

headline: A Whole New Idea: Half a Camera
abstract: Married to a big-screen smartphone, Sony’s QX cameras turn out great pictures, but the cameras themselves have flaws.
lead_paragraph: Sony’s concept for the new QX100 is among the most brilliant in its history.

headline: A Camera That Looks Like a Lens
abstract: The Sony QX100, which is meant to be used with a smartphone, may look like just a lens, but it’s a complete camera minus the flash and screen.
lead_paragraph: The Sony QX100, which is meant to be used with a smartphone, may look like just a lens, but it’s a complete camera minus the flash and screen.

abstract: The Times’s David Pogue checks out the Sony QX camera, which adapts to smartphones.
lead_paragraph: The Times’s David Pogue checks out the Sony QX camera, which adapts to smartphones.

headline: Singapore Looks Below for More Room
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Buildings (Structures)', 'Caves and Caverns', 'Shopping Centers and Malls', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Building (Construction)', 'Data Centers']
abstract: The city-state is looking at the possibility of an Underground Science City containing 40 interconnected caverns for data centers and research labs.
lead_paragraph: SINGAPORE — Singapore, with a little less land mass than New York City, is running out of room for its 5.4 million people.

headline: Video of Washington Navy Yard Gunman
abstract: The F.B.I. released closed-circuit video of Aaron Alexis inside the Navy Yard on Sept. 16, 2013.
lead_paragraph: The F.B.I. released closed-circuit video of Aaron Alexis inside the Navy Yard on Sept. 16, 2013.

headline: Washington Mayor Deems Entire City Government ‘Essential’ to Avoid Shutdown
abstract: District of Columbia Mayor Vincent C. Gray on Wednesday declared all D.C. government operations “essential,” and told the White House that all employees will continue to work even if Congress can’t reach an agreement on a stopgap spending bill.
lead_paragraph: A shutdown of the federal government, which could come next week if Congress does not pass a stopgap budget measure, would also require the government of the District of Columbia to discontinue its nonessential spending and send some employees home.

headline: Guy Laroche: Spring 2014 RTW
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: Detroit Spent Billions Extra on Pensions
abstract: Detroit’s municipal pension fund made undisclosed payments for decades to retirees, active workers and others above and beyond normal benefits, costing the struggling city billions of dollars, according to an outside actuary hired to examine the payments.
lead_paragraph: Detroit’s municipal pension fund made payments for decades to retirees, active workers and others above and beyond normal benefits, costing the struggling city billions of dollars and helping push it into bankruptcy, according to people who have reviewed the payments.

headline: Growing Into Larger-Than-Life Ali
abstract: The actor Ray Fisher plays Muhammad Ali in Will Power’s “Fetch Clay, Make Man,” at New York Theater Workshop.
lead_paragraph: Ray Fisher wouldn’t call himself “the greatest” or “the prettiest.” Asked to choose a superlative, the 26-year-old actor — friendly of face, huge of bicep — bashfully settles on “most dedicated.”

headline: Researchers Build a Working Carbon Nanotube Computer
abstract: The achievement was reported in the journal Nature on Wednesday. Carbon nanotubes are viewed as having the potential to extend the limits of silicon.
lead_paragraph: PALO ALTO, Calif. — A group of Stanford researchers has moved a step closer to answering the question of what happens when silicon, the standard material in today’s microelectronic circuits, reaches its fundamental limits for use in increasingly small transistors.

headline: Two Big Voices Back From Grave
abstract: Janis Joplin and Billie Holiday are coming to life anew for temporary, theatrical visits to the corporeal world.
lead_paragraph: Sadly, there seems to be no shortage of troubled performers who sing with unbridled passion, succumb to addiction and die early, leaving behind a collection of hits. Currently at least two of them, Janis Joplin and Billie Holiday, are coming to life anew for temporary, theatrical visits to the corporeal world.

headline: China’s Basketball Giant Again Presses Case for Elephant Conservation
keywords: ['Conservation of Resources', 'Elephants', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Wildlife Sanctuaries']
abstract: A basketball giant revisits an orphanage for tiny victims of the ivory trade.
lead_paragraph: Yao Ming, the 7-foot-6-inch N.B.A. veteran, is on the road again pressing the case for curbing the ivory trade and the relentless poaching of elephants. With the help of the conservation group WildAid, he paid a fresh visit to the Daphne Sheldrick Elephant Orphanage abutting Nairobi National Park in Kenya. On his blog (translated to English) he describes how a particularly tiny elephant that he walked with in 2012 had died:

headline: Primer | Tools and Tips for Surviving Paris Fashion Week
abstract: Everything you need to survive in style, from can’t-miss exhibitions to a good workout to a heated pool for hiding out between shows.
lead_paragraph: Paris Fashion Week began yesterday, and fashion industry insiders and locals alike are in the full swing of things. Here, a guide to surviving (and enjoying) the festivities.

headline: Gunman Said Electronic Brain Attacks Drove Him to Violence, F.B.I. Says
keywords: ['Washington Navy Yard Shooting (2013)', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: Aaron Alexis believed he was being controlled by “extremely low frequency” electromagnetic waves, said the official overseeing the investigation into the Navy Yard shootings.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The man who killed 12 people at the Washington Navy Yard 10 days ago left behind electronic documents saying that the government had been attacking his brain for the past three months using “extremely low frequency” electromagnetic waves created by the Navy, and that was the reason he needed to lash out, senior law enforcement officials said on Wednesday.

headline: GT6: How Video Games Can Influence Sports Car Design
abstract: Gran Tourismo, a Sony PlayStation game, is known for crisp graphics, stunning detail and a large following. But it’s also attracting the attention of sports car manufacturers.
lead_paragraph: Not everyone is into video games, but the Gran Turismo series, which, according to Sony, is the best-selling game of its PlayStation brand, is worth even nongamers taking a look at because of its level of detail.

headline: A Surge in Growth for a New Kind of Online Course
abstract: Three major sites have emerged in the last couple of years to offer massive open online courses, greatly expanding the opportunity to take college classes.
lead_paragraph: ONLINE course work has been a staple of American higher education for at least a decade. But over the last few years, a new, more ambitious variant known as a MOOC — massive open online course — has challenged traditional assumptions of what an online course can be. MOOCs have exploded in that short time, redefining who can enroll in college courses, as well as where, when and even why people take online classes.

headline: France Takes Modest Steps on Changes in ’14 Budget
abstract: President François Hollande’s spending plan seeks moderate spending cuts and tax increases but comes without the radical changes that many economists say the country needs.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Hoping to nurture the fragile beginnings of economic growth without running afoul of either the European Union or the financial markets, the French government presented a 2014 budget plan on Wednesday that included modest spending cuts and tax increases, but not the radical changes that many economists say the country needs.

headline: From Carnival Cruise Lines, a New Guarantee Policy
abstract: A new guarantee policy from Carnival Cruise Lines offers passengers full refunds and an additional 10 percent if they are dissatisfied.
lead_paragraph: Carnival Cruise Lines is offering guests a full refund of their cruise fares plus an additional 10 percent if they are unhappy or dissatisfied for any reason.

headline: Wartime Composition by Britten to Receive Public Performance
abstract: Music that Benjamin Britten wrote in 1942 for a radio series about conditions in wartime Britain will be performed in public for the first time next month in Manchester, England.
lead_paragraph: Music that Benjamin Britten wrote in 1942 for a radio series intended to inform American audiences about conditions in wartime Britain will be performed in public for the first time next month by the Halle Orchestra in Manchester, the BBC reported.

headline: Undercover: Spring 2014 RTW
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: Majority of Americans Doubt Benefits of Fed Stimulus
abstract: Only one in three Americans has confidence in the Federal Reserve’s ability to promote economic growth.
lead_paragraph: Only one in three Americans has confidence in the Federal Reserve’s ability to promote economic growth, while little more than a third think the Fed is spinning its wheels, according to a New York Times/CBS News poll.

headline: Climate Change Has Reached Our Shores
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Global Warming', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy']
abstract: My country, the Marshall Islands, is in terrible danger. But we can do something about it — and you can help.
lead_paragraph: MAJURO, Marshall Islands — AS the world barrels toward a climate crisis of its own making, my country stands at the precipice. In the Marshall Islands, like elsewhere in the Pacific, climate change is no longer a distant threat, nor at the doorstep. Climate change is here.

headline: Curtain Call | The Designers of Milan Fashion Week Take Their Bows
abstract: We say goodbye to the spring/summer runway collections with this video that compiles the post-show farewells of 14 designers.
lead_paragraph: Designers project their personalities not only through their collections but also in their appearances at the end of their runway shows. To mark the conclusion of Milan Fashion Week, we catalog the bows — some proud, some playful, some humble, some all of the above — of 14 fashion visionaries.

headline: Original Review: ‘The Glass Menagerie’
abstract: The New York Times’s 1945 review of the Tennessee Williams drama on Broadway.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times’s 1945 review of the Tennessee Williams drama on Broadway.

headline: John McCain Versus Ted Cruz
abstract: Mr. McCain reminded Mr. Cruz that, no matter how much he dislikes health care reform, “the people spoke” and “they re-elected the president.”
lead_paragraph: It’s no secret that Senator John McCain doesn’t much like Senator Ted Cruz, whom he once called a “wacko bird.” His main grievance is that Mr. Cruz isn’t interested in the business of governing, which requires compromise. If Mr. Cruz can’t get what he wants, he’d rather muck up the Senate than give in.

headline: The ‘Genius’ of Carrie Mae Weems
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Gender', 'Photography', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Scholarships and Fellowships', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Carrie Mae Weems, who was named a MacArthur fellow — often known as the “genius” grant — on Wednesday, discusses kitchen tables, notions of family and “activating” her community.
lead_paragraph: Among the recipients of the 2013 MacArthur fellowships is Carrie Mae Weems, whose varied interests and skills encompass photography, film and activism. Though known for work that tackles questions of race and gender, she says it addresses “unrequited love” and the human condition. Her conversation with James Estrin has been edited.

headline: A New Director for the New York Musical Theater Festival
abstract: Dan Markley, a management consultant with experience as a producer, will succeed Isaac Robert Hurwitz in the post.
lead_paragraph: There’s a new leading man at the New York Musical Theater Festival (NYMF). The organization announced on Wednesday that Dan Markley has been named its new executive director and producer. Mr. Markley succeeds Isaac Robert Hurwitz, a festival founder who stepped down earlier this year to become a consultant on development projects for 20th Century Fox’s new Broadway venture.

headline: Update on Navy Yard Shooting
abstract: Officials discussed details of their investigation of the Sept. 16 shooting at the Washington Navy Yard.
lead_paragraph: Officials discussed details of their investigation of the Sept. 16 shooting at the Washington Navy Yard.

headline: A Post-Mayoral Role for Bloomberg in London
abstract: Michael R. Bloomberg next year will become the chairman of the Serpentine Gallery, for which he has long been a benefactor.
lead_paragraph: There is life after City Hall — and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s version of it is already looking rather glam.

headline: Want to Write Better? Watch ‘Columbo’
abstract: He was polite. He was relentless. And he never stopped asking questions until everything was cleanly sorted in his head.
lead_paragraph: The author of this last weekend’s Lives essay shares an insight about writing.

headline: Peacock Feet
abstract: View embellished sneakers from Pierre Hardy, Christian Louboutin, Maison Martin Margiela and more.
lead_paragraph: View embellished sneakers from Pierre Hardy, Christian Louboutin, Maison Martin Margiela and more.

headline: Kaleidoscopic Sneakers for Men
abstract: Sneakers that prove men are as shoe-crazy as women.
lead_paragraph: Economists are always looking for ways to gauge the economy, from housing starts to underwear sales. Before they start inspecting tea leaves, or sales thereof, someone might want to high-tail it over to the men’s shoe department of Saks Fifth Avenue or Barneys New York, where designer sneakers festooned with more colors, materials, studs and doodads than a Las Vegas showgirl are, against all odds, doing a remarkably brisk business.

headline: The Williamsburg Divide
abstract: Glitz and grit: a tale of two Williamsburgs, as different as glass and brick.
lead_paragraph: On Wythe Avenue near North Third Street in Brooklyn, in the shadow of million-dollar condominiums, is the Brooklyn Oenology tasting room, for those who know their dornfelder from their cabernet franc. Nearby is the Brooklyn Denim Company, which sells $295 dungarees, and Pilgrim Surf and Supply, a high-end surf shop whose other shop is in the Hamptons.

headline: 'The Downtown Loop'
abstract: An excerpt of video from "The Downtown Loop," an immersive theater piece written by Ben Gassman, with video design by Jared Mezzocchi, at 3LD Art & Technology Center.
lead_paragraph: An excerpt of video from "The Downtown Loop," an immersive theater piece written by Ben Gassman, with video design by Jared Mezzocchi, at 3LD Art & Technology Center.

headline: New Beauty Product: Baked Makeup
abstract: Manufacturers say baked cosmetics are easier to blend and are longer wearing.
lead_paragraph: “Baked” is a new buzzword referring to cosmetics that start out as liquids, rather than being milled and compressed into compacts. They promise denser and truer pigmentation, longer wear and easier blending. Like bread, some of the best baked makeup (including the three brands here) is made in Italy.

headline: Eastwood, a Homey Bar on the Lower East Side
abstract: Eastwood is a friendly local bar mixing Scotland and Israel.
lead_paragraph: “Two way traffic ahead,” declares the amber street sign outside Eastwood, a homey bar at a still-gentrifying corner of the Lower East Side. It’s an apt description: tattooed tastemakers, longtime neighbors and young families mingle in this cross between a Scottish pub and a Tel Aviv cafe.

headline: Shopping Highlights in New York Starting Sept. 26
abstract: Alexander McQueen goes uptown, and a night at the Whitney.
lead_paragraph: Store Openings

headline: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Syria, Kenya, Pakistan and Spain.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Syria, Kenya, Pakistan and Spain.

headline: A Tiny Village With Its Very Own Princess
abstract: Haroué, in northeastern France, has fewer than 500 residents, but it does have royalty — the princess Minnie de Beauvau-Craon, who presides over the town’s cultural life from her 82-room chateau.
