headline: The Beast, Not the Beauty
abstract: She isn’t a comedian, but the artist Amy Sillman is funny and dirty.
lead_paragraph: She isn’t a comedian, but the artist Amy Sillman is funny and dirty.

headline: New Releases Top Chart
abstract: The top five albums on the Billboard 200 chart this week are all fresh releases, led by Jack Johnson’s “From Here to Now to You.”
lead_paragraph: The top five albums on the Billboard 200 chart this week are all fresh releases, led by Jack Johnson’s “From Here to Now to You,” which sold 117,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan.

headline: Mom’s Van Is Called Uber
keywords: ['Parenting', 'Mobile Applications', 'Taxicabs and Taxicab Drivers', 'Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: Parents are turning to Uber, a company that connects passengers and drivers of luxury vehicles, to have their children conveyed around the city.
lead_paragraph: On the first, fine Tuesday in autumn, Guy Parkin, 13, was sitting outside on the steps of the Salk School of Science on East 20th Street. He had stayed late to attend a Specialized High School Admissions Test group study session, so it was nearing 5 p.m. when a black S.U.V. pulled up, dispatched through his mother’s account on the Uber app.

headline: Uber-Practical: Using the Private Car Service App to Transport Teens
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Children and Childhood', 'Parenting']
abstract: Parents are using the Uber car service app to help older children navigate the city safely.
lead_paragraph: I should say it up front: I’m an Uber car user. When I’m in outer Boston or the outer boroughs of New York City, where yellow cabs can be hard to hail, I use the Uber app to call a car — especially if I’m pushed for time. If I were a city parent, I could see the practicality of using an Uber to take a child from Point A to Point B.

headline: An Arm-Twister in the Oval Office
abstract: Bryan Cranston is Lyndon B. Johnson in “All the Way,” a play set immediately after President Kennedy’s assassination.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — The crowds excitedly filing in to the American Repertory Theater here are not, I am willing to bet, panting at the prospect of hearing words like “filibuster” and “cloture” tossed into their laps. Nor are they eager to watch politicians fulminating and pontificating in front of microphones. For such diversions, after all, we have cable news, and with the government slouching toward yet another partisan smackdown, it’s showtime 24/7.

headline: 7 Paratroopers and Paths They Took Through an Israel at a Crossroads
abstract: “Like Dreamers” focuses on Israel’s near-defeat in the 1973 war as the catalyst for the settler movement and much else that has shaped Israel in the past 40 years.
lead_paragraph: Much has been made over the years, and rightly so, of the messianic fervor that swept Israel after its spectacular victory in the 1967 war. The conquest of Sinai from Egypt, the Golan Heights from Syria, and the West Bank and East Jerusalem from Jordan, all in a biblically epic six days, seemed to religious Israelis — and many secular ones — like a miracle, a sign that God wanted to reunite his people with their promised land. Not long afterward, settlement beyond the 1967 borders began.

headline: A Shop on Land Is Focused on the Water
abstract: Captain Mike’s Diving Services on City Island in the Bronx is just a stroll away from Long Island Sound.
lead_paragraph: Captain Mike’s Diving Services on City Island in the Bronx is just a stroll away from Long Island Sound.

headline: HBO’s Party Celebrates Its Domination on Emmy Night
abstract: HBO’s party was especially celebratory and drew winners from beyond its overflowing stable of statue holders.
lead_paragraph: HBO did not sweep this year’s Emmy Awards, but it still had plenty of reason to celebrate Sunday night.

headline: Newly Released Books
abstract: The novel “Enon,” by the Pulitzer Prize winner Paul Harding, is among the new novels and story collections touching on mortality.
lead_paragraph: Writers this month are preoccupied with lost youth. Multiple characters in two short-story collections confront growing old while three novels and a nonfiction oral history reflect on lives cut short.

headline: Iran’s Leader, Denouncing Holocaust, Stirs Dispute
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'United States International Relations', 'Nuclear Weapons']
abstract: President Hassan Rouhani’s condemnation of the Holocaust has set off a political storm, landing him in precisely the kind of tangled dispute he had hoped to avoid.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As he conducts a high-profile good-will visit to New York this week, Iran’s new president, Hassan Rouhani, says he is bringing a simple message of peace and friendship. But on Wednesday, Mr. Rouhani set off a political storm here and in Iran, with an acknowledgment and condemnation of the Holocaust that landed him in precisely the kind of tangled dispute he had hoped to avoid.

headline: Thursday’s Matchup: 49ers (1-2) at Rams (1-2)
abstract: The 49ers and Rams have a historical rivalry, but on Thursday their meeting could be one-sided.
lead_paragraph: 8:25 p.m. Eastern

headline: U.K. Utility Shares Fall After Pledge to Freeze Rates
keywords: ['Electric Light and Power', 'Natural Gas', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The head of Britain’s opposition Labour Party said that if his party won the election in 2015, it would freeze gas and electric rates for two years.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Party loyalists applauded. Investors blanched.

headline: Milan Fashion Week | Curtain Call
abstract: To mark the conclusion of Milan Fashion Week, we catalog the bows of 14 of its visionary designers and capture how the gesture can subtly reveal a hint of their personalities, whether outsize or not.
lead_paragraph: To mark the conclusion of Milan Fashion Week, we catalog the bows of 14 of its visionary designers and capture how the gesture can subtly reveal a hint of their personalities, whether outsize or not.

headline: The Fashion Week Sports Report
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'New York Fashion Week', 'Milan Fashion Week', 'London Fashion Week']
abstract: Athletic looks are the winners at the Milan spring shows.
lead_paragraph: VERA WANG WAS ONTO the sports trend back in New York. Marc Jacobs, too, had the right shoes for it with his Teva-style sandals. But if there was one unifying theme of the Milan collections that ended on Monday (and let’s admit it, they were a bit all over the place), it was sports.

headline: If Father Doesn’t Know Best, He’s Willing to Learn
abstract: Michael J. Fox, who has made a series of prominent guest appearances since he revealed in 1999 that he had Parkinson’s disease, is back with his own sitcom on NBC.
lead_paragraph: It doesn’t take long to realize that something is off in “The Michael J. Fox Show,” the new NBC sitcom in which Mr. Fox plays a variation of himself: Mike Henry, a network news anchor reviving his career after a hiatus because of Parkinson’s disease.

headline: A Giant of Dance, Seizing on Musicality to Weave His Spell
abstract: New York City Ballet’s program “Black and White” includes four Balanchine pieces: “The Four Temperaments,” “Episodes,” “Duo Concertant” and “Symphony in Three Movements.”
lead_paragraph: Amid a fall dance season richly packed with significant events across the New York dance map, a single program at New York City Ballet stands out like a summit. All of its four items are by George Balanchine, and all are well known — and yet who ever knows any Balanchine ballet?

headline: Giving Drug Advice Along With Music
abstract: Following a European trend in the wake of overdose deaths, an electronic dance music festival near Atlanta will offer advice on safer practices for the use of party drugs like Ecstasy.
lead_paragraph: When the TomorrowWorld festival opens outside Atlanta on Friday, concertgoers can expect to see safety measures that have become common at European electronic dance music festivals but have yet to catch on in the United States: a nonprofit drug education group will be giving advice, not only on the dangers of drug abuse, but also on how those who choose to take party drugs can use them more safely.

headline: Look Good in Ways You Can Afford
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Shoes and Boots', 'Jewels and Jewelry', 'Handbags and Purses', 'Leather and Leather Goods']
abstract: Over-the-knee boots, plated jewelry, leather jackets and fanny packs that are all sensibly priced.
lead_paragraph: Boots That Go Over the Knee for Under $1,000

headline: Olivier Zahm Brings Purple Jeans to Closed Label
abstract: The jeans are just one element of a plan to reinvigorate the label, which was popular in the 1970s and ’80s.
lead_paragraph: OLIVIER ZAHM, THE EDITOR of Purple magazine, is a fixture on the fashion circuit but probably not someone who would likely wind up on a best-dressed list. Has anyone ever seen him wearing anything besides a denim jacket and jeans that are two sizes too small?

headline: From Art to T. Rex, Shutdown Stirs Worry
abstract: Federally financed cultural institutions are scurrying to come up with contingency plans ahead of a possible government shutdown.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Hope Diamond, all 45.5 carats of it, will remain securely guarded here at the Smithsonian National Museum of Natural History. The Japanese giant salamanders of the National Zoo need not worry if the HVAC systems keeping their habitat just right break down — a maintenance crew will be on call.

headline: Garde Robe: High-End Clothes Storage
abstract: A nondescript warehouse in Long Island City, Queens, houses pieces like Gwyneth Paltrow’s couture gowns and Iman’s cashmere car coats.
lead_paragraph: Secreted away in a nondescript warehouse in Long Island City, Queens, may be one of the most valuable collections of contemporary fashion in the world. Few know of its existence. There are no signs on the building. To get there, you take an elevator to the second floor and enter an unmarked door.

headline: Sudan’s President, Wanted by International Court, Cancels Visit to U.N.
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: The United Nations said that President Omar Hassan al-Bashir, who is wanted on genocide charges, has canceled his visit to the General Assembly, amid protests in Sudan’s capital.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations said Wednesday that President Omar Hassan al-Bashir of Sudan, who is wanted by the International Criminal Court in The Hague on genocide charges, has canceled his visit to the General Assembly, amid protests in Sudan’s capital.

headline: ScienceTake: A Frog’s Secret to Sticking
abstract: Nature is full of animals with amazing abilities that scientists are trying to understand, and the torrent frog is one of them. True to its name, it lives stuck to waterfalls.
lead_paragraph: Nature is full of animals with amazing abilities that scientists are trying to understand, and the torrent frog is one of them. True to its name, it lives stuck to waterfalls.

headline: Pinpricks, but No Dagger in Putinland
abstract: The Moscow Biennale of Contemporary Art steers cautiously between its ambition to promote that city as a cutting-edge art center and a concern about drawing the wrath of officialdom.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — There were some complications when the Conceptual artist John Baldessari brought his latest works to Russia as part of the fifth Moscow Biennale of Contemporary Art. First, the title of his project, “Double Take,” did not translate easily into Russian.

headline: Art Matters | Miuccia Prada, Jane Fonda and Some Models Wearing Latex
abstract: All factor into a new short film by Luke Gilford with a score by Jake Shears of Scissor Sisters, which makes its premiere here.
lead_paragraph: With looks that made references to the fist-in-the-air energy of the early-’90s riot grrrls and Britney Spears’s “Work Bitch” on the soundtrack, Miuccia Prada’s spring 2014 show once again explored the paradoxes of dressing the women of today — and tomorrow. For years now, collections like this latest have been inspiring artists across disciplines and generations to ponder the intersections of the beauty industries and feminist ideals.

headline: USA-2 Moves to Semifinals in Venice Cup
abstract: The world team championships in Bali, Indonesia, have reached the semifinal stage.
lead_paragraph: The world team championships in Bali, Indonesia, have reached the semifinal stage.

headline: Keeping It Fake
abstract: The experimental comedian Kate Berlant demonstrates how the comedy tent is getting bigger.
lead_paragraph: It was a typical stand-up show, with embarrassing personal stories and observational gripes, until Kate Berlant strutted onstage in the East Village bar Niagara. She was wearing a backpack and an expression out of a TED talk.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Oracle’s Sailing Success, and an Apple Maps Oops
abstract: Wednesday’s highlights from around the Web include reactions to Oracle Team USA’s victory in the America’s Cup, and a tale of air travel gone awry because of a flaw on Apple’s Maps app.
lead_paragraph: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: Learning From the ‘Black Lumberjack’
abstract: Robert Rising hosts furniture-making workshops in his yard in Ardsley, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: Robert Rising is a self-taught lumberjack and furniture maker who came to his profession 10 years ago because he was building a house in upstate New York and wanted, he said recently, “some cool wood for counter tops and furniture.” Since last spring, he has been hosting D.I.Y. Fridays at his yard in Ardsley, N.Y. For $200, plus the cost of the wood, which can range from $350 to $3,500, participants make their own furniture.

headline: Liberty’s Fields of Flowers
abstract: The storied British company introduces its Nesfield collection of botanically inspired fabrics, wallpaper and paint.
lead_paragraph: The London company Liberty began selling textiles for furnishings in 1874, but a century later it licensed out the interiors side of the business to put more energy into fashion. Now that the license is expired, Liberty has been reeling home décor back with collections like Nesfield, new coordinated fabrics, wallpaper and paint that reflect the company’s heritage of elaborate prints and vibrant colors. Named for William Nesfield, a 19th-century English landscape architect, the collection draws from Liberty’s archive of some 43,000 designs. Patterns include “classic chintzy small flora” and “some quite big abstract paisleys and geometrics,” said Kirstie Carey, managing director of Liberty Wholesale. Though Nesfield “is not going to be for the faint of heart,” Ms. Carey added, those who fear a festival of flowers do have the option of picking one or two elements. “All the styles work together,” she said. Information: liberty.co.uk.

headline: Discounts at Michele Varian, Peter Harrison and Sferra
keywords: ['Shopping and Retail', 'Beds and Bedding', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
abstract: Bargains on knickknacks, benches and bedding.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday only, Michele Varian is taking 20 percent off all items, in store and online (recycled porcelain bottles, regularly $24 to $48, are about $19 to $38). Some discontinued or damaged items at the store will be up to 85 percent off from 5 p.m. to 8 p.m.; 27 Howard Street (Crosby Street), (212) 343-0088, michelevarian.com. Use code Stoopsale if shopping online.

headline: Looking for Beauty, Finding Soul
abstract: “The Inspired Home” features the interiors of artists and designers who attend to the laws of nature.
lead_paragraph: “The Inspired Home: Interiors of Deep Beauty” (Harper Design, $35) sounds like yet another gorgeous coffee table book. But its author, Karen Lehrman Bloch, was determined to show homes that are not merely perfect; they also have a soul.

headline: Paris Fashion Week: Rochas Spring/Summer 2014
abstract: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Kasia Bobula.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Kasia Bobula.

headline: What’s the Best Way to Give Our Shower a High-End Look?
keywords: ['Bathrooms and Toilets', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Brick and Tile', 'Restoration and Renovation']
abstract: Advice for repairing or redecorating a home before selling it.
lead_paragraph: Q. There’s an ugly plastic shower stall in our bathroom. If we decide to replace it, what’s the best way to give the shower a high-end look?

headline: Soaked, Not Welded
abstract: OverNight lamps are made of stained glass panels immersed in a copper plating bath.
lead_paragraph: For a lighting collection called OverNight, Els Woldhek and Georgi Manassiev, London designers known as Odd Matter, coat stained-glass panels in conductive paint and immerse them overnight in a copper bath. The copper builds up on the edges to form a tightfitting frame, eliminating the need for welding.

headline: Musings on a Structure for Heaven
abstract: The architect Alexander Gorlin on his new book, “Kabbalah in Art and Architecture.”
lead_paragraph: The architect Alexander Gorlin, 58, has kept files full of arcane references to kabbalistic principles during two decades of designing projects, from public schools and synagogues to palatial Hamptons houses. Although not a terribly devout Jew, he has studied ancient Jewish texts and modern interpretations by scholars including Gershom Scholem and Daniel C. Matt. He has looked for buildings and artworks related to the texts’ themes of shattering, repair, voids and heavenly structure. His fifth book, “Kabbalah in Art and Architecture” (Pointed Leaf Press, $60), compares Herzog & de Meuron’s steel lacework of the Bird’s Nest Olympic stadium in Beijing to “the radiance of the Bird’s Nest” mentioned in the Zohar and Rothko paintings to Exodus descriptions of deep colors bleeding into one other.

headline: You Are What You Stack
abstract: In the aspirational space known as the living room, coffee table books tell the world what kind of person you want to be.
lead_paragraph: It is publishing season for decorators, and scores of them have new books out. The monograph, an expository form once reserved for architects, seems to have become the preferred form of publicity for interior designers as well, even those with just a few years of work under their belts.

headline: When a House Falls in the Forest
abstract: Remembering a childhood home that led to a lifelong appreciation of modernism.
lead_paragraph: Not long ago, I learned that the house I grew up in had been razed to the ground. This was no ordinary house, certainly not to me. It had walls of glass that overlooked a wood we called the Forest. There was a skylight that turned the rain into a thunderous clatter, and acorns thudded down on it from the overhanging oaks. The spiral staircase to the lower level had real rocks in it — the bedrock left standing when the house was settled onto its perch on the hill. Light filled every room, and the shadows of trees and leaves floated in and out.

headline: Bookends: Embracing Literature
abstract: They don’t necessarily have to begin their lives that way.
lead_paragraph: The Haslegrave brothers, who own a design firm called hOmE, have amassed an impressive collection of books and magazines. Anyone visiting their loftlike studio in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, will notice stray periodicals stashed in nooks and crannies, and volumes stacked in corners and lining makeshift shelves. Yet not a single proper bookend.

headline: What Lurks Beneath the Linoleum in Columbia County
keywords: ['Restoration and Renovation', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
abstract: Namely, wide-plank pine floors and square-head nails.
lead_paragraph: Namely, wide-plank pine floors and square-head nails.

headline: Scraping Away the Decades
keywords: ['Restoration and Renovation', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'ARCHITECTURE']
abstract: Somewhere under all the ugly 20th-century additions was the simple 1850s-era home two Brooklyn designers had been searching for.
lead_paragraph: The restoration began with a valiant swing of the sledgehammer. Robert Highsmith and Stefanie Brechbuehler knew that somewhere inside the house they had bought was a quaint 1850s structure, but the 20th-century additions made it almost impossible to see.

headline: The Water’s Murky. Come On In!
abstract: A dive shop in the Bronx offers equipment and instruction, as well as plenty of stories.
lead_paragraph: Most people, when they imagine scuba diving, probably picture crystalline waters and exotic locations like the Bahamas, Bermuda and Belize. Few would think of the Bronx.

headline: Roll Over? Fat Chance
abstract: More than half the dogs in America are overweight, giving rise to diet and exercise programs.
lead_paragraph: She has been in at least three fitness programs. She runs on the treadmill. She swims in a lap pool. Her trainers shout encouragement. And although her target weight still eludes her, Lolita remains optimistic, smiling gamely during her workout and snacking on carrots.

headline: Doggie Weight Watchers

lead_paragraph: With waistlines expanding, some chubby dogs are being sent to fitness programs to get slim and trim.

lead_paragraph: With another fiscal deadline looming in Washington, The New York Times and CBS News asked Americans for their opinion on the federal budget, government spending and President Obama’s job performance.

keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'National Debt (US)', 'United States Economy', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: President Obama’s standing among the public has dropped significantly, with 49 percent disapproving of his job performance and 43 percent approving, a poll says.
lead_paragraph: President Obama’s standing with Americans has slumped significantly, as the public remains skeptical about his health care law and unsure about the economy, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

headline: ‘Breaking Bad’ Creator Gilligan in Deal for CBS Show, ‘Battle Creek’
abstract: Vince Gilligan wrote the new series, a police drama, for CBS 10 years ago, and it will begin next fall.
lead_paragraph: Vince Gilligan, the creator and producer of one of the most-talked-about series in recent years, “Breaking Bad,” is the hottest name in television. “Breaking Bad” is fresh off an Emmy win for best drama and drawing huge audiences as it builds toward the final episode of its five-season run on AMC on Sunday.

headline: West Says U.N. Nears Syria Resolution
abstract: Two diplomats said they had reached a consensus on the broad elements, including “a reference” to sanctions should Syria fail to comply with its obligations.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — After months of crippling deadlock, members of the United Nations Security Council have inched closer to the details of a binding resolution on Syria, Western diplomats said Wednesday, though Russia, one of Syria’s strongest allies, denied that a consensus had been reached.

headline: Day Devoted to Hoisting Guinness Starts to Leave a Bitter Taste
abstract: Critics say Arthur’s Day, which began in 2009 to mark the 250th anniversary of Guinness, is nothing but an excuse for binge drinking.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — Bars across Ireland will be thronged on Thursday with early evening drinkers. Groups of inebriated young people will be staggering around the streets, and hospital emergency rooms will be packed.

headline: The Yankees’ Farewell Sundays of 2008 and 2013
abstract: In the rare instances of not making the playoffs, the end of two disappointing seasons featured goodbyes to big pieces of the Yankees’ legend.
lead_paragraph: Because the Yankees, in most seasons, roll out of bed and stroll right into the postseason, it stands out when they actually do not get there.

headline: A Big Week for the Advertising Industry, in Many Ways
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Conventions, Fairs and Trade Shows']
abstract: For Advertising Week, 90,000 people, at more than a dozen locations, are attending 198 events featuring 798 speakers.
lead_paragraph: A REVEALING picture can be painted by the numbers of the 10th annual Advertising Week in New York. An estimated 90,000 people are attending the conference this week, with events taking place at more than a dozen locations. And according to Matt Scheckner, executive director of Advertising Week, 798 speakers will have participated in 198 panels, presentations and seminars.

headline: Fund to Let Investors Bet on Price of Bitcoins
abstract: SecondMarket is expected to begin raising money for an investment fund that will hold only bitcoins, giving wealthy investors exposure to the virtual currency.
lead_paragraph: The upstart stock exchange SecondMarket has made a name for itself allowing investors to buy shares of hot private companies like Twitter. Now that those companies are going public, SecondMarket is turning its attention to the next new thing — bitcoin.

headline: Pursuing Graft Cases at Higher Levels, Chinese Leader Risks Unsettling Elites
abstract: While President Xi Jinping may help consolidate his power in targeting corrupt officials, zeroing in on higher targets may unleash risky instabilities within the political elite.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Shortly before his retirement late last year, Zhou Yongkang, the longtime chief of China’s domestic security apparatus, visited an office of the state oil company where he had started his ascent in the Communist Party hierarchy. He spoke of his undimmed devotion to the company, China National Petroleum Corporation, and to his fellow oilmen.

lead_paragraph: A look at how the final race in the America’s Cup unfolded, with Oracle Team USA beating Emirates Team New Zealand by 44 seconds.

headline: Jane Connell, Agnes Gooch of ‘Mame,’ Is Dead at 87
abstract: Ms. Connell appeared in musicals, TV and movies, but was best known for her Agnes Gooch in the musical “Mame,” on Broadway and on screen.
lead_paragraph: Jane Connell, a character actress best known for her portrayal of Agnes Gooch, the mousy secretary to the title character in the musical “Mame,” died on Sunday in Englewood, N.J. She was 87.

headline: Oscar Espinosa Chepe, Cuban Economist and Castro Critic, Dies at 72
abstract: Mr. Espinosa Chepe, who advocated the limited restoration of capitalist principles, remained in Cuba despite enduring harassment and imprisonment.
lead_paragraph: Oscar Espinosa Chepe, a high-ranking Cuban economist and diplomat who became a vocal critic of Fidel Castro in the 1990s but chose to remain in Cuba, despite enduring harassment and imprisonment, died on Monday in Madrid, where he was undergoing medical treatment. He was 72.

headline: U.S. Sees Direct Threat in Attack at Kenya Mall
keywords: ['Nairobi, Kenya, Westgate Mall Shootings (2013)', 'Terrorism', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Dozens of F.B.I. agents are investigating the wreckage, hoping to glean every piece of information possible to help prevent such a devastating attack from happening again, possibly even on American soil.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — Viewing the deadly siege at a shopping mall in Kenya as a direct threat to its security, the United States is deploying dozens of F.B.I. agents to investigate the wreckage, hoping to glean every piece of information possible to help prevent such a devastating attack from happening again, possibly even on American soil.

headline: Trailer: Hers to Lose
keywords: ['Mayors', 'News and News Media', 'Politics and Government', 'Political Advertising', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Primaries and Caucuses', "Women's Rights", 'Homosexuality', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare']
abstract: Christine C. Quinn, the longtime front-runner in the New York City mayoral race, lost in the 2013 Democratic primary. This behind-the-scenes documentary captures the final month of her campaign.
lead_paragraph: Christine C. Quinn, the longtime front-runner in the New York City mayoral race, lost in the 2013 Democratic primary. This behind-the-scenes documentary captures the final month of her campaign.

headline: Fight Over Energy Finds a New Front in a Corner of Idaho
keywords: ['Nez Perce Indians', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Energy and Power', 'Environment', 'Native Americans']
abstract: The Nez Perce Indians were drawn into the national brawl over the future of energy last month when they tried to stop a load of oil-processing equipment from moving through their lands.
lead_paragraph: LAPWAI, Idaho — In this remote corner of the Northwest, most people think of gas as something coming from a pump, not a well. But when it comes to energy, remote isn’t what it used to be.

headline: Jets Lineman Crosses to the Other Side
abstract: Will Campbell, a sixth-round draft choice who played on the defensive line at Michigan, is making the transition to being an offensive guard for the Jets.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Will Campbell loved football, and he loved Warren Sapp, and he stood 6 feet 5 inches and weighed over 300 pounds. So he played on the defensive line. He was a top talent in Michigan, among the best tackles in the nation, a cornerstone of the Wolverines’ formidable 2009 recruiting class.

headline: Cruz, Tea Party Hero, Rankles Senate G.O.P. Colleagues
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Tea Party Movement', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Many Republicans see Senator Ted Cruz’s campaign against the new health care law as self-interested and potentially damaging to the party’s electoral efforts.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Ted Cruz’s crusade to dismantle President Obama’s health care law has helped cement his status as an emerging hero of the Tea Party and conservative grass roots. But it is stoking resentment and derision from many other Republicans, including his own Senate colleagues, who see his campaign as impractical, self-interested and potentially damaging to the party’s electoral efforts in 2014 and beyond.

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'United States Economy', 'United States International Relations', 'National Debt (US)', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: The latest New York Times/CBS News poll is based on phone interviews conducted Sept. 19 through Sept. 23 with 1,014 adults throughout the United States.
lead_paragraph: The latest New York Times/CBS News poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Sept. 19 through Sept. 23 with 1,014 adults throughout the United States. Interviews were in English or Spanish.

headline: In Indonesia, a Governor at Home on the Streets
abstract: As Indonesians look to their next presidential election, many are talking about a local governor who has demonstrated an unusually common touch with the people.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — Each day, Joko Widodo, the governor of Jakarta, does something practically unheard-of among Indonesia’s political elite: he ventures into the streets to speak with the people who elected him.

headline: NBC Gets More Than It Expected
abstract: NBC got a great deal, it paid nothing for the America’s Cup races, and it also got lucky, televising a remarkable comeback.
lead_paragraph: When NBC Sports Group made a deal last year to carry the America’s Cup races from San Francisco Bay, it had modest hopes about viewership. The television heyday of the Cup, the premier yachting regatta, ended more than 20 years ago. By 2010, the Cup’s profile in the United States had declined enough so that live coverage that year was available only on what is now ESPN3, a digital network.

headline: Sri Lanka: U.N. Official Calls for War Crimes Inquiry
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Civilian Casualties']
abstract: The official said she “detected no new or comprehensive effort to independently or credibly investigate the allegations” that civilians were killed by the military.
lead_paragraph: In a review of human rights in Sri Lanka, the United Nations top human rights official on Wednesday called for an international investigation of war crimes accusations if the government does not start a credible national process “with tangible results” in the next six months. The official, Navi Pillay, the high commissioner for human rights, said she “detected no new or comprehensive effort to independently or credibly investigate the allegations” that tens of thousands of civilians were killed by the military during the closing months of the war. The government also offered “no satisfactory responses to concerns over high levels of harassment of journalists, lawyers and human rights defenders,” Ms. Pillay said, citing widespread fears over “the degree to which the rule of law and democratic institutions in Sri Lanka are being undermined and eroded.” Sri Lanka’s ambassador to the United Nations in Geneva, Ravinatha Aryasinha, rejected Ms. Pillay’s views as “not the result of an objective assessment.”

headline: Turkish Protesters Are Still Said to Be Ailing From Tear Gas
keywords: ['Tear Gas', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Police', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: Almost 40 percent of protesters surveyed by a Turkish medical group complained of continuing repercussions from their exposure to the tear gas used in last spring’s antigovernment demonstrations, the group says.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Almost 40 percent of protesters surveyed by a Turkish medical group complained of continuing repercussions from their exposure to the tear gas that security forces used to quell last spring’s antigovernment demonstrations, the group says.

headline: Arms Treaty Now Signed by Majority of U.N. Members
keywords: ['ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Arms Trade', 'Treaties']
abstract: The United States and 17 other countries officially signed the treaty aimed at regulating the global trade in conventional weapons.
lead_paragraph: A pioneering United Nations treaty aimed at regulating the global trade in conventional weapons surpassed a symbolically important threshold on Wednesday when 18 countries, most notably the United States, officially signed the document, pushing the total number to more than half of the organization’s member states.

headline: A Pause, Not an End, to Warming
abstract: The lull is consistent with historic temperature variability.
lead_paragraph: BERKELEY, Calif. — THE global warming crowd has a problem. For all of its warnings, and despite a steady escalation of greenhouse gas emissions into the atmosphere, the planet’s average surface temperature has remained pretty much the same for the last 15 years.

headline: How Do You Say ‘Blog’ in German?
abstract: The editors of the German Duden dictionary added 5,000 words to the 26th edition, many of them English or of English origin. Some Germans aren’t happy.
lead_paragraph: WE Germans owe the English language a debt of gratitude. If English didn’t lend us one or two little words every once in a while, we would probably call blogs “digitale Netztagebücher” and apps “Anwendungen für mobile Endgeräte.” Even for German speakers, those don’t exactly roll off the tongue.

headline: Oracle Completes Voyage to History, Winning America’s Cup
abstract: Pulling off the greatest comeback in America’s Cup history, Oracle Team USA won eight straight races, dashing the title hopes of Emirates Team New Zealand.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Many regattas ago, when Jimmy Spithill had not yet won the grandest prize in yachting, one of his mentors, the Australian Syd Fischer, gave him words to sail by.

headline: Meet Dilly and Dither
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Tea Party Movement']
abstract: The pope makes sense. Iran seems a little more reasonable. The Russians were quite helpful. And Congress is crazy.
lead_paragraph: This month, the pope made some sensible remarks about sex, and the president of Iran made some reasonable comments about nuclear weapons. Also, the Russians proved to be extremely helpful during an international crisis. Meanwhile, on the home front, our Congress appears too crazed by internal conflict to keep the lights on.

headline: Suffocating Echo Chamber
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'News and News Media', 'Tea Party Movement']
abstract: Who is the right-wing echo chamber damaging most of all? Conservatives themselves.
lead_paragraph: When Senator Ted Cruz of La Mancha jumped on his trusty steed and charged the windmills, he explained: “Everyone in America knows Obamacare is destroying the economy.” He added that accepting the Affordable Care Act would be like appeasing the Nazis.

headline: Lasting Damage From the Budget Fight
abstract: The quiet continuation of the sequester has been lost amid the noise about health reform.
lead_paragraph: The budget crisis manufactured by Congressional Republicans will never succeed at halting health care reform, but it has already caused long-lasting harm. It will preserve the deeply damaging spending cuts, known as the sequester, that are costing jobs and hurting the lives of millions.

headline: Fed Up in Bangladesh
keywords: ['Wages and Salaries', 'Minimum Wage', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Editorials', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Factories and Manufacturing']
abstract: Millions of workers earning less than $40 a month need higher wages and union protection.
lead_paragraph: Tens of thousands of workers in Bangladesh’s garment factories have been protesting in recent days to demand an increase in the minimum wage for their industry, which the government last increased three years ago. The government has answered by ordering police to shoot tear gas and rubber bullets at protesters rather than addressing the real grievances of the workers.

headline: A Bold Plan to Aid Sex-Trafficking Victims
abstract: An important initiative in New York aims to treat those charged with prostitution as abused victims, rather than criminals.
lead_paragraph: As understanding of the cruel dynamics of sex-trafficking has grown in recent years, a consensus has emerged among criminal justice professionals that it makes more sense to treat people charged with prostitution as the exploited and abused victims a vast majority are, rather than as criminals. An important new initiative by New York State’s chief judge, Jonathan Lippman, aims to put that humane insight into practice.

headline: Marta Heflin, Actor, Dies at 68; Waif Seen in Altman Films
abstract: Ms. Heflin appeared in New York stage musicals like “Fiddler on the Roof” and “Jesus Christ Superstar,” and later in a string of Robert Altman movies that capitalized on her waifishness.
lead_paragraph: Marta Heflin, an actress who appeared in New York stage musicals like “Fiddler on the Roof,” “Hair” and “Jesus Christ Superstar” in the 1960s and ’70s, and later in a string of Robert Altman movies that capitalized on her waifishness, died on Sept. 18 in Manhattan. She was 68.

headline: Brooklyn Man Is Charged With Role in 2 Deaths in Pakistan
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Visas', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Citizenship and Naturalization']
abstract: Mohammad Ajmal Choudhry is accused of conspiring to kill relatives of people who he believed had helped his daughter flee an arranged marriage.
lead_paragraph: The arranged marriage had already cleaved the family in two: on one side was a Brooklyn-born bride, in hiding after she escaped her new husband’s home in Pakistan, where she said she was held captive by her relatives. On the other was her father, now jailed in Brooklyn, who was so furious over his daughter’s departure that he threatened to kill those who had helped her flee.

abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: For the U.N., Syria Is Both Promise and Peril
keywords: ['International Relations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Biological and Chemical Warfare']
abstract: The American-Russian agreement to rid Syria of chemical weapons should please — and terrify — anyone hoping to see the United Nations return to relevance in global security.
lead_paragraph: THE agreement between the United States and Russia to rid Syria of chemical weapons should please — but also terrify — anyone hoping to return the United Nations to relevance. After the ugly, ignominious train crash of the United Nations’ inspections process in Iraq a decade ago, the question is whether the United Nations can deliver both international legitimacy and a genuine prospect for peace.

headline: The End of Quiet Music

An American microfinance organization had sent me there to gather rosy statistics and uplifting stories about how their loans had improved the lives of this new crop of entrepreneurs.

headline: Tension, Not Joy, in Texas Playoff Chase
abstract: The Rangers, who lost out on a division title after a slump in early September, are scrambling for a wild-card spot.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Tex. — Four empty bottles of Champagne stand proudly in a row on the back shelf of Ron Washington’s office in the Texas Rangers’ clubhouse. They represent the division titles and American League pennants the team won under Washington, their manager, in 2010 and 2011.

headline: Missing Parts

lead_paragraph: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — When I cracked the theme of this puzzle, I thought not of how clever it was (even though it was), or how much I enjoyed solving it. I thought of Mountain Time.

keywords: ['Inventions and Patents', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Law and Legislation']

headline: Your 4-Year-Old Scored a 95? Better Luck Next Time
abstract: For the parents of some preschoolers in New York, a score below 99 on the admission test used by elite private schools can be a cause for concern.
lead_paragraph: When other preschool parents bragged that their children had aced the admission test for New York City private schools with a top score of 99 in every section, Justine Oddo stayed quiet. Her twin boys had not done as well.

headline: Cheers, Hugs, Flags and Brooms Fill Victory Party at Unlikely Host Club
abstract: The Golden Gate Yacht Club, with its working-class roots, was wrapped in a mix of joy and disbelief as Oracle Team USA completed its astounding comeback.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The corner table on the small deck overlooking the bay was marked “Spithill,” and the parents, wife, sister and brother of the Oracle Team USA skipper alternated their anxious gaze from the boats on the water to the tiny screens of iPads in front of them.

headline: Minor Crime Leads to Fatal Cycle of Revenge, Police Say
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Marijuana', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic']
abstract: The police said that a botched marijuana deal between a peddler of bootleg DVDs and a building superintendent bred a fury that might have led to two killings.
lead_paragraph: On a Saturday last October, Terrence Davis Sr., a peddler of bootleg DVDs, sold some marijuana to Lee Smith Sr., according to the charges. The deal did not go smoothly. Officials said a police officer saw the transaction and arrested both men.

headline: Now Revealed by Stripper: Booker’s Twitter Messages
abstract: A 26-year-old woman from Oregon on Wednesday revealed her correspondence with Cory A. Booker, the mayor of Newark, who is running for the United States Senate.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Cory A. Booker has a high schooler’s affinity for Twitter, reveling in its ceaseless flow of affirmation and infinite space for self-promotion.

headline: Giants Are in Dire Spot, but You Wouldn’t Know It by Talking to Them
abstract: Despite starting 0-3 and ranking last in key offensive and defensive categories, the Giants remained undaunted about reaching their goals for the season as they prepared for the 3-0 Chiefs.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — History suggests that the Giants, 0-3 and off to their worst start since 1996, should be all but bereft of hope. Since 1990, when the current playoff format began, only 3 of the 115 teams to drop their first three games have reached the playoffs.

headline: Ground Gives Way, and a Louisiana Town Struggles to Find Its Footing
abstract: Almost nothing in Bayou Corne has been the same since a voracious sinkhole opened up in 2012, and a year later it’s still growing, swallowing trees and belching methane.
lead_paragraph: BAYOU CORNE, La. — It was nearly 16 months ago that Dennis P. Landry and his wife, Pat, on a leisurely cruise in their Starcraft pontoon boat, first noticed a froth of bubbles issuing from the depths of Bayou Corne, an idyllic, cypress-draped stream that meanders through swampy southern Louisiana. They figured it was a leaky gas pipeline. So did everyone else.

headline: In New Zealand, Jitters Yield to Cheers, Then Sighs
abstract: At the Royal Port Nicholson Yacht Club, disappointed fans expressed pride in the performance of Emirates Team New Zealand.
lead_paragraph: WELLINGTON, New Zealand — New Zealand’s yachting fans have had a turbulent two weeks, and the culmination came Thursday morning. Nervous faces were everywhere at the Royal Port Nicholson Yacht Club as members and their friends gathered to watch the winner-take-all 19th America’s Cup race between Emirates Team New Zealand and Oracle Team USA.

headline: BlackBerry Cancels Call to Discuss Its Results
abstract: The company said the call was canceled because of a conditional takeover bid by its largest shareholder.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — The management of the ailing smartphone maker BlackBerry canceled a conference call scheduled for Friday to discuss the company’s quarterly financial results.

abstract: A video shot by John Boudreaux shows the destructive power of a giant sinkhole in Bayou Corne, La.
lead_paragraph: A video shot by John Boudreaux shows the destructive power of a giant sinkhole in Bayou Corne, La.

headline: Yankees’ Dim Playoff Hopes Flicker Out
abstract: For only the second time in the last 19 years, the Yankees were eliminated from playoff contention on a night they were unable to muster enough offense against the Rays.
lead_paragraph: There was a somber inevitability Wednesday night in the Bronx: from the brief pregame ceremony honoring Andy Pettitte to Tampa Bay’s crushing back-to-back home runs in the sixth inning to the decisive final out, which actually came more than 400 miles away in Cleveland.

headline: Lhota Backers Challenge Cap on Spending
keywords: ['Elections, Mayors', 'Political Action Committees', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Campaign Finance', 'Citizens United v Federal Election Commission (Supreme Court Decision)']
abstract: A “super PAC” supporting Joseph J. Lhota, the Republican mayoral nominee, sued New York election officials over a limit on contributions to independent political groups.
lead_paragraph: A new Republican group supporting the mayoral candidacy of Joseph J. Lhota sued New York election officials in federal court Wednesday to allow individuals to contribute more than the current $150,000 annual maximum to independent political groups.

headline: More Sway for F.D.A. Is Object of New Bill
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Meningitis']
abstract: A bill would give the Food and Drug Administration greater control over compounding pharmacies, which lawmakers say would help prevent another crisis like a meningitis outbreak traced to a Massachusetts pharmacy.
lead_paragraph: A bipartisan committee of lawmakers from the Senate and the House reached a compromise on Wednesday on legislation that would give the Food and Drug Administration greater control over compounding pharmacies. But analysts said it was still unclear whether the law would actually make drugs safer.

headline: Rhode Island: College Reschedules Speaker
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: Providence College has rescheduled an event it canceled last weekend with John Corvino, a philosopher at Wayne State University in Detroit, speaking in support of gay marriage.
lead_paragraph: Providence College has rescheduled an event it canceled last weekend with John Corvino, a philosopher at Wayne State University in Detroit, speaking in support of gay marriage. The Roman Catholic college said he would contradict Catholic teaching, but faculty and students protested the cancellation as a violation of academic freedom. The college said Wednesday that Dr. Corvino has been invited for next spring to debate Sherif Girgis, a nationally known opponent of gay marriage. The canceled event had included a theology professor to debate Dr. Corvino, but the college said she was unprepared because she is not a philosopher and had been invited only a week before the event.

headline: Matsuzaka Stars Again for Mets
abstract: Daisuke Matsuzaka shut out the Reds for seven and two-thirds innings to continue his strong turnaround.
lead_paragraph: CINCINNATI — Last season, Daisuke Matsuzaka flamed out with the Boston Red Sox. Last month, he was pitching with the Cleveland Indians’ Class AAA team in Columbus when he asked for his release.

headline: Knicks and Nets, Growing Rivals, Will Work Together to Host All-Star Events
abstract: The All-Star Game will be held at Madison Square Garden. Barclays Center will host the dunk contest, the 3-point shooting contest and the skills challenge.
lead_paragraph: The Knicks’ owner, James L. Dolan, broke his long streak of silence about his team Wednesday.

headline: Free Tickets Offered After Bobble in Rivera Doll Giveaway
abstract: The Yankees, mindful that fans were unhappy with how the Mariano Rivera bobblehead dolls were distributed Tuesday night, announced that they would offer a free ticket to a 2014 regular-season game.
lead_paragraph: Bobblehead peace reigned at Yankee Stadium on Wednesday, one day after Mariano Rivera dolls did not quite show up on time, creating long lines when they finally did arrive and plenty of grumbling fans.

headline: Tory Burch Introduces an Appealingly Pared-Down Beauty Line
abstract: The designer's new fragrance, makeup collection and bath-and-body range adhere to a "less is more" philosophy.
lead_paragraph: There’s been a wave of designers starting beauty collections of late, including Marc Jacobs, Jason Wu and Michael Kors. Tory Burch is the latest, with a new fragrance, makeup collection and bath-and-body range. Unlike Jacobs, who released enough products to fill one of his oversize satchels and then some, Burch took a “less is more” approach. “I’m not into a heavy beauty regimen,” she admitted, with a laugh.

headline: Economic Statecraft, Women and the Fed
abstract: Janet Yellen’s nomination to head the Federal Reserve would reflect her qualifications and also create a role model in a world short of opportunity for women, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Simon Johnson, former chief economist of the International Monetary Fund, is the Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of “White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.”

headline: A New Survey Finds a Drop in Arts Attendance
abstract: A new report from the National Endowment for the Arts finds that the number of Americans visiting an art exhibition or attending a performing arts event fell from 2008 to 2012.
lead_paragraph: You might not know it from the sold-out crowds at Broadway’s big-budget musicals like “The Book of Mormon” or “Wicked,” but theater is the artistic discipline in America that is losing audience share at the fastest rate in recent years.

headline: 4 Days, 3 Teams: Wild-Card Race Moves Toward Finish
abstract: As the days in the regular season dwindled to a precious few, the Yankees were eliminated from the playoff hunt.
lead_paragraph: One day after the Baltimore Orioles exited the complicated wild-card race in the American League, the Yankees followed right behind.

headline: Easing Doctor Burnout With Mindfulness
abstract: Two-thirds of doctors experience the emotional, mental and physical exhaustion characteristic of burnout. New research points to mindfulness, the ability to be fully present and attentive in the moment, as a possible remedy.
lead_paragraph: According to the nurse’s note, the patient had received a clean bill of health from his regular doctor only a few days before, so I was surprised to see his request for a second opinion. He stared intently at my name badge as I walked into the room, then nodded his head at each syllable of my name as I introduced myself.

headline: What’s On Thursday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (CBS) THE BIG BANG THEORY Sheldon (Jim Parsons, fresh from his third Emmy win for outstanding lead actor in a comedy series) and Penny (Kaley Cuoco, above with Mr. Parsons) bond while Leonard (Johnny Galecki) is at sea. But it’s Sheldon’s feelings that are crushed when Leonard returns home in this hourlong Season 7 premiere. In “The Crazy Ones,” a new series at 9, Robin Williams stars as a childlike advertising genius whose behavior might normally earn him a pink slip — if he weren’t a boss. Sarah Michelle Gellar is Sydney, his daughter, partner and grounding force who, in this premiere episode, helps him persuade Kelly Clarkson to record a familiar jingle, with a twist, for their client. “Watching Mr. Williams return to the kind of improvisation-style routines that made him famous in the 1970s is bittersweet, like watching Jimmy Connors play tennis again: they are still impressive, but audiences can’t help recalling how much more elastic and powerful they were at their peak,” Alessandra Stanley wrote in The New York Times. In “Two and a Half Men,” at 9:30, Alan (Jon Cryer) is shocked when Charlie’s long-lost 25-year-old daughter, Jenny (Amber Tamblyn), shows up at the beach house of Walden (Ashton Kutcher) and reveals that she likes everything her father liked, including women.

headline: News Quiz | September 26, 2013
abstract: See what you know about the news of the day.
lead_paragraph: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Chinese Court Sentences Celebrity Singer’s Son to 10 Years for Rape
abstract: Li Tianyi, 17, and four other defendants were convicted in a case that stirred discussion about the reckless lives of some offspring of China’s elite.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A court in Beijing sentenced the teenage son of a celebrity military singer to 10 years in prison on Thursday after finding him and four other young men guilty of gang-raping a woman. The case has galvanized discussion in China about the reckless lives of some offspring of the Communist Party elite.

lead_paragraph: In “After 21-Hour Cruz Speech, Senate Votes to Take Up Budget,” Jonathan Weisman writes about the drama unfolding in Congress this week as the Senate and House inch closer to a possible government shutdown.

headline: Can Urban Planning Help India’s Cities Reduce Sexual Violence ?
keywords: ['Area Planning and Renewal', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Sex Crimes', 'Urban Areas', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Urban planners and designers argue that apart from better policing, gender-sensitive city planning and design can help make India’s cities safer for women.
lead_paragraph: Janaki Sharma, 24, a producer with a radio station, commutes for about 40 kilometers, or 25 miles, from her home in West Delhi to work across the city. Ms. Sharma uses multiple forms of public transport — subway, bus and shared auto-rickshaw, to get to her office. And the last stretch of her commute is a mile-long walk on a desolate stretch to reach her office.

headline: Report Warns of Chinese Municipal Debt Risks
abstract: Nomura analysts say local governments increased their debt by nearly 40 percent in 2011 and 2012, creating systemic dangers.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A report by Nomura said Thursday that Chinese municipal debt, a focal point of major concern about the country’s economy, had grown at an alarming 39 percent clip in recent years.

headline: 50-Year Sentence Upheld for Ex-President of Liberia
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Sentences (Criminal)']
abstract: Charles G. Taylor, the former president of Liberia, had appealed a sentence imposed last year in a case seen as a watershed for modern human rights law.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — An international panel of appeals judges unanimously upheld a 50-year prison sentence on Thursday given to Charles G. Taylor, the former president of Liberia, for committing war crimes and crimes against humanity in a case cast as a watershed for modern human rights law.

headline: ‘Carrie’ Is Back. So Is Kimberly Peirce.
abstract: The director of “Boys Don’t Cry” on the career she’s had and the one that might have been.
lead_paragraph: “I don’t know if I believe in the supernatural, but Brandon Teena’s story entered me in a weird way,” Kimberly Peirce told me. “From the day that I read that story, it was always my responsibility.” Peirce was a graduate student at Columbia’s film school when a friend gave her an article about Teena, who, though born a woman, passed as a man for years, until his biological sex was discovered and he was raped and murdered. “Maybe it’s because I’m a queer person, or maybe it’s because I’m a human being, but I love Brandon so much.”

headline: Chaos and Harmony in Old Dhaka
abstract: The Bangladeshi photographer Munem Wasif describes his love/hate relationship with Old Dhaka, where a sense of belonging is strong because its residents “don’t have any other choice.”
lead_paragraph: If you’re having trouble viewing the audio slideshow, please click here.

headline: Do We Give Children Too Many Trophies?
abstract: Have you ever gotten a trophy you didn’t think you deserved? How did the award make you feel?
lead_paragraph: Have we gone trophy-crazy as a society, bestowing trophies on children for almost anything, even just showing up? Are we afraid children will be hurt by losing, so we make everyone a winner? Or are awards an effective way to raise children’s self-esteem and keep them motivated to do better?

abstract: Jet design influenced many automobile designs in the 1950s, perhaps none more than the Supersonic bodies built by Carrozzeria Ghia.
lead_paragraph: The 1950s are now remembered as a golden age, a time when aristocrats in Northern Italy turned into weekend racers. They had the budgets to hire Italian coachbuilders who created hand-built bodies for new chassis and motors. But the cars that were fast on road courses and at the purpose-built racetracks also had to look good cruising the boulevard.

lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Why are smartphone makers paying so much attention to developing countries? That is where the growth, and the potential for more of it, is concentrated. A new report from the United Nations Broadband Commission demonstrates this in considerable detail.

headline: A Fund for Bitcoins
abstract: The stock exchange SecondMarket is turning to the next new thing: bitcoin. | Regulators missed an opportunity in going after JPMorgan, a columnist writes. | Detroit’s municipal pension fund made payments for decades above and beyond normal benefits. | Larry Ellison’s Oracle Team USA achieved victory in the 34th America’s Cup.
lead_paragraph: The upstart stock exchange SecondMarket, which made a name for itself allowing investors to buy shares of private companies, is turning to the next new thing: bitcoin. On Thursday, SecondMarket is expected to begin raising money for an investment fund — the first of its kind in the United States — that will hold only bitcoins, allowing wealthy investors to bet on the future price of the trendy but much debated virtual currency, Peter Lattman and Nathaniel Popper report in DealBook. The fund will be called the Bitcoin Investment Trust.

headline: New York Film Festival Is Still Sober, but Hardly Dry
abstract: The 51st New York Film Festival, which sometimes feels like a punishingly stern event, features tough dramas, more comedies than usual, as well as a Godard tribute.
lead_paragraph: Ladies and gentlemen, clear your calendars and chug those double espressos: the 51st New York Film Festival is about to begin. Newly recharged, this venerated annual event has reigned supreme since 1963 as the city’s premier cinematic happening, and its lofty position remains secure.

headline: Population Control Is Called Big Revenue Source in China
abstract: Nineteen local governments in China collected a total of $2.7 billion in fines last year from parents who had violated family planning laws, a lawyer who had requested the data said.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Nineteen province-level governments in China collected a total of $2.7 billion in fines last year from parents who had violated family planning laws, which usually limit couples to one child, a lawyer who had requested the data said Thursday.

headline: Please Call Me Miss, Not Ma’am

headline: An Interview With Kent Jones of the New York Film Festival
abstract: The director of programming and selection committee chair of the New York Film Festival discusses this year’s program.
lead_paragraph: The New York Film Festival’s 51st edition will begin Friday, and for the first time in 25 years, under new leadership. But Kent Jones, who has succeeded Richard Peña as the festival’s director of programming and selection committee chairman, doesn’t come in blindly. He spent 11 years on the staff of the Film Society of Lincoln Center and seven of those on the festival selection committee before departing in 2009. His return represents the next chapter in the life of the 17-day festival, which will screen dozens of  features from around the world, along with retrospectives, revivals, shorts, gala tributes for two actors and more.

headline: Between Martyrdom and Diplomacy
abstract: Iran’s embrace of “prudent moderation” has raised guarded hopes for U.S.-Iran talks.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — The Middle East is a place of fast-changing fortunes these days. Just ask the Turkish prime minister, Recep Tayyip Erdogan. Not so long ago neo-Ottomanism was the vogue phrase to describe Turkey’s expanding regional influence, pursued under a catchy dogma of “zero problems with neighbors.”

headline: EBay Buys Braintree, a Payments Start-Up
abstract: EBay said Thursday it would pay $800 million for Braintree, a Chicago start-up that provides technology to process online payments.
lead_paragraph: EBay said Thursday that it was acquiring Braintree, a Chicago payments start-up, for $800 million in cash. The company plans to combine it with its payments division, PayPal.

headline: Rage of the Privileged
abstract: It’s not Ayn Rand, it’s Ancien Régime.
lead_paragraph: Mark Thoma has an excellent column at the Fiscal Times linking the fight over the debt ceiling to the larger issue of extreme inequality. (By the way, I start my day, every day, with a quick skim of the Times followed by Thoma’s blog Economist’s View, which is the best place by far to keep up with the latest in economic discourse.) I’d like, however, to suggest that the reality is even worse than Thoma suggests.

headline: Ahead of India-Pakistan Talks, Militants Kill as Many as 12 in Indian-Controlled Kashmir
keywords: ['Attacks on Police', 'Civilian Casualties', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Terrorism']
abstract: Three men dressed in Indian Army uniforms attacked a police station and an army base, officials said, just days before a planned meeting between leaders of India and Pakistan.
lead_paragraph: Militants dressed in Indian Army uniforms killed up to a dozen people in attacks on Thursday on an Indian police station and army base in Indian-controlled Kashmir, officials said. The attacks, near the disputed border with Pakistan, came a day after the Indian prime minister, Manmohan Singh, said he would hold talks in New York with his Pakistani counterpart.

headline: Ban of Brothers
abstract: Cracking down on the Muslim Brotherhood isn’t the way to hold political Islam accountable for its crimes or force it to face its contradictions.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — When after only one year in office, Egypt’s first Islamist president was driven from his post by millions of protesters, it seemed that the country was ready for a reckoning with the shortcomings of political Islam.

headline: Frustration Mounts Over Metro-North Line’s Woes
abstract: Gov. Dannel P. Malloy of Connecticut said service on Metro-North’s New Haven line could return incrementally in the coming days as alternative power sources were tested.
lead_paragraph: One day after a power failure scrambled service on the New Haven line of the Metro-North Railroad, travelers on Thursday negotiated the patchwork system assembled in its place, or simply avoided the rails altogether, as officials warned that a full restoration remained a long way off.

headline: Different Priorities for Cano and Rays’ Longoria
abstract: Evan Longoria has pledged his allegiance to the Tampa Bay Rays, but the Yankees must wonder what Robinson Cano wants most from his next contract.
lead_paragraph: There was a time Evan Longoria would have been the ideal young veteran star to save the tumbling Yankees. For much of the last four decades, spanning the Steinbrenner era, someone like Longoria — charismatic, skilled and strong — would have filled the gap likely to be left at third base next season by the diminished Alex Rodriguez.

headline: Alfresco Sculpture Comes to Oslo
abstract: Already a surprisingly rich art destination, the Norwegian capital is adding to its appeal with the Ekeburg Sculpture Park, a 68-acre property boasting works by artists ranging from Salvador Dalí to James Turrell.
lead_paragraph: For those for whose impressions of Norway are limited to gravlax, skiing and Edvard Munch, Oslo’s vibrant contemporary art scene, which has been garnering international buzz lately, may still come as some surprise. The latest chapter in the Norwegian capital’s development is the ambitious new Ekeberg Sculpture Park that opens Sept. 26, the passion project of Christian Ringnes, a local real estate tycoon who bought the adjacent Ekeberg restaurant and donated tens of millions to create the park.

headline: Poetry Pairing | ‘Avalon’
abstract: Journeys and destinations are the focus of this Poetry Pairing. It features a poem about San Francisco by Simon Armitage entitled “Avalon” and Emily Brennan’s interview with Mr. Armitage, “Walking ‘That Long Trailing Leg of Britain.'”
lead_paragraph: Journeys and destinations are the focus of this Poetry Pairing. It features a poem about San Francisco by Simon Armitage, “Avalon,” and Emily Brennan’s interview with Mr. Armitage, “Walking ‘That Long Trailing Leg of Britain.’”

headline: Could a Republican Health Care Reform Ever Happen?
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Why conservative reform options might look better to Republicans once Obamacare is actually implemented.
lead_paragraph: Now that it seems that the sheer force of Ted Cruz’s (genuinely remarkable!) physical stamina won’t be enough to bring Obamacare to its knees, it’s worth stepping back and saying something about the current prospects for an actual conservative replacement for/reform of Obamacare. Two recent pieces on this subject recommend themselves: One is in the latest National Affairs, where Thomas Miller offers an extended “reality check” on the pressing need for and current unreadiness of Republican health care alternatives; the other is over at Bloomberg View, where Ramesh Ponnuru presents a gentle critique of one such alternative, from the Republican Study Committee, praising some of its features while suggesting (correctly) that it would need to include an actual tax credit for the purchase of insurance to represent a plausible replacement for the president’s health care law.

headline: Industry Still Churns, Even as Cleanup Plan Proceeds for a Canal
keywords: ['Water Pollution', 'Superfund', 'Waste Materials and Disposal', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances']
abstract: A $500 million plan will focus on the decades-old toxic muck at the bottom of the canal, though nearby businesses are still being cited for sometimes treating the canal like a waste dump.
lead_paragraph: The federal government is about to release its final, $500 million cleanup plan for the Gowanus Canal, one of New York City’s two Superfund sites, a long-awaited moment in the effort to cleanse more than a century of environmental abuse.

lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: To Renovate or Not to Renovate?
abstract: Is it more effective to cloak Shakespearean text in contemporary imagery, or to hew to a more “classical” line?
lead_paragraph: Wherefore art thou riding a motorcycle, Romeo?

headline: Today in Small Business: Too Many Start-Ups?
abstract: How to find a cheap flight. Using Google Plus for contests. Health insurance premiums come in lower than expected.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: House G.O.P. Raises Stakes in Debt-Ceiling Fight
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'National Debt (US)', 'Federal Budget (US)']
abstract: With no serious negotiations in sight, a disorderly and divided Congress slipped closer to a double-barreled fiscal crisis.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With no serious negotiations in sight, a disorderly and divided Congress slipped closer to a double-barreled fiscal crisis on Thursday as House Republican leaders tried to shift the budget dispute to a fight over raising the government’s borrowing limit.

abstract: According to a recent report by the local authorities in New Delhi, cases of dengue fever are on a rise in the city.

lead_paragraph: Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, arrived at the Justice Department on Thursday amid reports that the bank was negotiating a multibillion-dollar settlement over the sale of distressed mortgage securities ahead of the financial crisis.

headline: The Gun Report: September 26, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: In 2011, more than 1,700 women were murdered by men in America, and more than half of those murders were committed with firearms, according to a new report by the Violence Policy Center, which used data from the F.B.I.’s Supplementary Homicide Report. When the victim’s relationship to the shooter could be identified, 94 percent of these women were murdered by a man they knew, and of those, 61 percent were wives or intimate acquaintances. Handguns were used in two-thirds of the murders.

headline: Bladder and Urethral Repair
abstract: A slide show depicting bladder and urethral repair.
lead_paragraph: A slide show depicting bladder and urethral repair.
