lead_paragraph: A slide show explaining ERCP.

headline: Federal Contractors, Low Wages
abstract: Workers who serve food and sell mementos in federal buildings want better pay. They deserve it.
lead_paragraph: In a speech last July, President Obama vowed that “whatever executive authority I have to help the middle class, I’ll use it.” On Wednesday, an estimated 175 workers who serve food, sell mementos or do maintenance work in federal buildings in Washington D.C. went on strike for the day. Instead of showing up at their jobs, they showed up in front of the White House, where they urged President Obama to live up to his word.

headline: Yankees and Cano Are Said to Be Far Apart on Contract
abstract: Second baseman Robinson Cano is said to be asking for a 10-year, $310 million contract, while the Yankees are said to be offering about seven years at about $23 million a year.
lead_paragraph: As the Yankees come to terms with the disappointment of 2013 and their failure to make the playoffs, the focus shifts to 2014 and a future that may not include Robinson Cano, their best and most durable player.

headline: Kel Markey Transforms Backstage at Carven
abstract: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Spring 2014 Fashion Week in Paris.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Spring 2014 Fashion Week in Paris. Here, the model Kel Markey before (left) and after (right) makeup by Nina Havercamp and hair by Romina Manenti.

headline: No Want for Laurels
abstract: Over a six-decade career on Broadway, Harold Prince has won 21 Tony Awards, more than any other individual.
lead_paragraph: Over a six-decade career on Broadway, Harold Prince has won 21 Tony Awards, more than any other individual.

headline: A Prince With No Fairy Godmother
abstract: After repeated delays, Hal Prince’s musical “Prince of Broadway” remains stalled because of a shortage of investors.
lead_paragraph: They may have been celebrating the Prince of Broadway, but they didn’t want to talk about “Prince of Broadway.”

headline: Soldiers on the Home Front: David Finkel Talks About ‘Thank You for Your Service’
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Mr. Finkel’s new book follows soldiers returned from Baghdad and struggling to adjust.
lead_paragraph: In his book “The Good Soldiers,” David Finkel, a Pulitzer Prize-winning reporter for The Washington Post, vividly recounted the experience of a United States Army battalion in Baghdad in 2007 and 2008. In The New York Times Book Review, Doug Stanton called it a “ferociously reported, darkly humorous and spellbinding book.” Now, in “Thank You for Your Service,” Mr. Finkel follows several of those same soldiers back home in the United States, where they struggle with their memories of the war and the transition back to domestic life. In a recent e-mail interview, Mr. Finkel discussed his reporting methods, the military’s suicide rate, how being so close to the suffering of soldiers has changed him and more. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation:

headline: Sister of ‘Into the Wild’ Protagonist Is Writing Memoir
abstract: Carine McCandless, the sister of Chris McCandless, will publish her memoir through HarperOne, an imprint of HarperCollins.
lead_paragraph: The story of Chris McCandless has been immortalized in print and in film: a disaffected wanderer who swore off material comforts, hitchhiked to Alaska and eventually died in the wilderness, alone and starving.

headline: In Crete, a Historic Feast (and a Lesson or Two)
abstract: The Blue Palace resort in Crete has teamed up with a group called Minoan Tastes to offer a re-creation of a feast from 1600 B.C.
lead_paragraph: From the birthplace of the Mediterranean diet comes a historic recipe for dinner, slow cooked in clay pots.

headline: Renée Fleming Sings an Operatic Top Ten for David Letterman
abstract: Ms. Fleming performed the “Top 10 Opera Lyrics” on “Late Show With David Letterman.”
lead_paragraph: Beverly Sills used to make regular television appearances with Johnny Carson, Carol Burnett, and even the Muppets. Another American diva took up the mantle on Wednesday night: Renée Fleming sang an operatic “Top Ten” list on “Late Show With David Letterman.”

headline: A Troupe Thrives, After Disasters
abstract: 3-Legged Dog is outrunning adversity thanks to its innovations in technology.
lead_paragraph: 3-Legged Dog is outrunning adversity thanks to its innovations in technology.

headline: My Son Calls School a ‘Waste of Time’
abstract: Should I tell his teacher that my son is complaining at home, ask for more challenging work or just recognize this as a stage that may pass when he gets to the challenges of high school?
lead_paragraph: Dear Mrs. Lahey,

headline: The Job Situation Looks a Little Worse
keywords: ['Freelancing, Self-Employment and Independent Contracting', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Unemployment']
abstract: Revisions in government employment figures, superficially positive, actually reflect a reduction in gains reported for the 12 months that ended last March.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 2:37 p.m. | with comment from Bureau of Labor Statistics.

headline: Sleeping at the Bauhaus
abstract: The influential German design school has converted its studio building into a dorm-style hotel, with rooms outfitted with Marcel Breuer’s steel tube furniture.
lead_paragraph: The Walter Gropius-designed Bauhaus Dessau in Germany has converted its studio building, once housing for architecture students, into a dorm-style boutique hotel. Book one of the 20 rooms fitted with Marcel Breuer’s steel tube furniture. Or, beginning in late October, stay in spaces personalized to reflect a notable former inhabitant — like a Josef Albers room, with replicas of a bed, a table and a cupboard the artist made while living there; or one dedicated to the architect Franz Ehrlich, with pieces he created for the German Democratic Republic in the 1950s. Doubles from about $55.

headline: Trends to Watch For in Employer Health Plans
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Personal Finances']
abstract: As health insurance changes approach, higher costs for covering a spouse and children and higher deductibles are likely to affect more Americans covered on the job.
lead_paragraph: A lot of attention has been given to the health insurance exchanges opening next month. But if you’re like most Americans, you’ll still get your insurance through an employer. And that means the annual open enrollment season, when you choose your benefits for the coming year, will soon be upon you.

headline: First-Round Bidding to Begin in Auction of IMG Talent Agency
abstract: First round bids for the IMG, which represents athletes and entertainers including Peyton Manning and Justin Timberlake, are due on Monday, according to people familiar with the matter.
lead_paragraph: The auction for IMG Worldwide, the sports, fashion and media talent agency, is finally kicking off.

headline: A Shaken Kenya Is Hit Again in 2 Deadly Attacks by Militants
abstract: Three people were killed in attacks on police officers near the border with Somalia. The Kenyan authorities blamed the Shabab militant group, which has taken responsibility for the mall siege.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — Only days after heavily armed assailants stormed a crowded mall and killed scores of people in the capital, militants killed three people near the border with Somalia, Kenyan officials said Thursday, putting this country even further on edge.

headline: The iPhone 5s’s Fingerprint Scanner Was Hacked, but I’m Not Worried
abstract: Yes, Apple’s Touch ID can be fooled — by a determined attacker with the time and resources to do it.
lead_paragraph: Well, that didn’t take long. Only a couple of days after Apple’s iPhone 5s went on sale, somebody managed to fool its fingerprint sensor.

headline: Avoiding an Ink-Stained Child
abstract: Keeping tattoos off a daughter, ungrateful neighbors and confusion over names.
lead_paragraph: My 18-year-old daughter is determined to get a tattoo. My husband and I are equally determined that she not. She keeps telling us that she’s an adult. But in reality, she is a full-time college student, and her father and I pay her tuition and virtually all her living expenses. A great deal of screaming has already been done. Can you help us navigate a more peaceful pathway?

headline: The Fed’s Confusing Search for Clarity
abstract: Jeremy Stein, a Federal Reserve governor, says the Fed needs to speak more clearly, but he may have contributed to confusion about the Fed’s intentions.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve wasn’t trying to surprise investors last week, it’s just not doing a good job of communicating clearly, Jeremy C. Stein, a Fed governor, said Thursday.

headline: Obama Scorns G.O.P. ‘Blackmail’ on Health Law
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Tea Party Movement', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Days before the law’s main elements take effect, President Obama mocked opponents for “crazy” arguments and accused them of trying to “blackmail a president” to stop the law.
lead_paragraph: LARGO, Md. — President Obama mounted a passionate, campaign-style defense of his health care program on Thursday, just days before its main elements take effect, mocking opponents for “crazy” arguments and accusing them of trying to “blackmail a president” to stop the law.

headline: Knicks Dip Into Past and Bring Back Mills as President and General Manager
abstract: Steve Mills, a former high-level executive at Madison Square Garden before departing in 2009, will replace Glen Grunwald, who will remain as an adviser.
lead_paragraph: In an unexpected move just days before the opening of training camp, the Knicks disclosed Thursday that they were bringing back one of their former executives to serve as team president and general manager.

headline: Getting Out the Word on Twitter
abstract: How to post public and private replies on Twitter, and security software for Windows 8.
lead_paragraph: Posting Public and Private Replies on Twitter

headline: In Fragmented Forests, Rapid Mammal Extinctions
keywords: ['Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Biodiversity', 'Levees and Dams', 'Science and Technology']
abstract: A man-made reservoir in Thailand has given biologists the opportunity to measure the speed of mammal extinctions and to watch them happen, quickly.
lead_paragraph: In 1987, the government of Thailand launched a huge, unplanned experiment. They built a dam across the Khlong Saeng river, creating a 60-square-mile reservoir. As the Chiew Larn reservoir rose, it drowned the river valley, transforming 150 forested hilltops into islands, each with its own isolated menagerie of wildlife.

headline: 36 Hours in Hampstead, London
abstract: Pack a picnic for the Heath, stroll through chapters of history and even take a bracing dip during a weekend in London’s worst-kept, high-altitude secret.
lead_paragraph: Start with Montmartre. Add a cupful of Beacon Hill, a shot of vintage West Village and a splash of Hollywood. Combine with London’s most beautiful hill, and garnish with one unwelcome McDonalds. Here in Hampstead, London’s worst-kept, high-altitude secret, the ghosts of Sigmund Freud, T. S. Eliot and Robert Louis Stevenson mingle with Ricky Gervais, Ridley Scott and more Madonna-accented American expats than you can shake a Land Rover key at. But we’re all equal when it comes to losing ourselves in the charming lanes of Hampstead Village and the joyfully directionless expanse of the Heath, a metropolitan mini-wilderness that may be Europe’s finest city park. Welcome to Hampstead, as serene, green and lovely as ever.

headline: In London, Big Views and Peaceful Picnics
abstract: Pack your provisions for this tour of the Hampstead neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: Pack your provisions for this tour of the Hampstead neighborhood.

headline: Rouhani, Blunt and Charming, Pitches a Moderate Iran
abstract: Amid his fervent diplomatic theater this week, it was at times hard to tell whether Iran’s president, Hassan Rouhani, was a genuinely transformative leader.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — Descending on New York this week in a Shiite cleric’s traditional fine wool robes, Iran’s president, Hassan Rouhani, turned himself into a high-speed salesman offering a flurry of speeches, tweets, televised interviews and carefully curated private meetings.

headline: Chrysler’s Owners Are Racing for the Cliff
abstract: The preliminary prospectus filed by the automaker suggests that the company’s chief executive is willing to go to extremes to scuttle its proposed I.P.O.
lead_paragraph: What do you call the man who is trying to sabotage Chrysler’s initial public offering by threatening to harm the company, perhaps fatally, if the offering is completed?

headline: Hiking Hut-to-Hut in the Presidential Range
abstract: Soaking climbs, sweeping views and hospitable huts are all part of a trek through the White Mountains in New Hampshire.
lead_paragraph: A young man was draped, heroically, across the Valley Way trailhead. “How far ya going?” he said as I approached with trekking poles, a light pack and a goofy sun hat suggesting that I’d never drunk my own urine to survive, much less seen a star-choked sky.

headline: A Taste of Childhood, With a Cherry on Top
abstract: A family trip on the Staten Island Ferry to visit the city’s only Dairy Queen franchise triggers a cascade of memories.
lead_paragraph: At the beginning of each summer, when I have the fantasy of time on my hands, I make a list of all the fabulous places I want to eat in New York. This year I included the new Park Slope branch of L’Albero dei Gelati, a cafe based in Lombardy, Italy.

headline: On the Lookout for Quirky Places to Stay
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Bed-and-Breakfast Lodgings']
abstract: Meghan McEwen, a travel writer, has reviewed dozens of family-owned inns, and now has opened one of her own in Detroit.
lead_paragraph: Meghan McEwen, a travel writer, has always been on the lookout for interesting, design-oriented places to stay.

headline: Boutiques Emerge in a Santiago Barrio
abstract: Several locally owned shops have opened in the Lastarria neighborhood of the Chilean capital, becoming go-to places for one-of-a-kind finds.
lead_paragraph: The Lastarria neighborhood in downtown Santiago used to be a leafy and tranquil residential area favored by retirees, but with its easy access to the city center and its many finance and consulting companies, the small barrio is drawing a more caffeinated younger set. This recent influx has led to the opening of several locally owned boutiques that have become the go-to places for one-of-a-kind finds. Though the main avenue, also called Lastarria, is mostly lined with bustling restaurants, these shops are tucked away on side streets in old buildings that are a mix of neo-Classical and colonial architecture.

headline: Why Not Greet the Shutdown With a Boycott?
abstract: Mayor Vincent Gray plans to ignore Congress and keep his city open.
lead_paragraph: During past government shutdowns, our capital city has stopped various local services, including garbage pickup, and closed scores of buildings across Washington, D.C.

headline: HBO Orders Fifth Season of ‘Boardwalk Empire’
abstract: “Boardwalk Empire,” the period crime-drama, was recently rewarded with five Emmys for its 2012 season, including the award for outstanding supporting actor in a drama, which went to Bobby Cannavale.
lead_paragraph: HBO subscribers can look forward to at least one more year of Nucky (Thompson): the cable network said Thursday that it was ordering a fifth season of “Boardwalk Empire,” its Emmy Award-winning period drama starring Steve Buscemi as a crime boss in 1920s-era Atlantic City. “Boardwalk Empire,” created by the “Sopranos” alumnus Terence Winter, began its fourth season on Sept. 8 and has drawn about 2 million viewers each week for first-run broadcasts of new episodes, though HBO said in a news release that the average gross audience was 7.5 million viewers over multiple showings. The series was recently rewarded with five Emmys for its 2012 season, including the award for outstanding supporting actor in a drama, which went to Bobby Cannavale for his portrayal of the violent and vengeful mobster Gyp Rosetti.

headline: Text to Text | ‘The Scarlet Letter’ and ‘Sexism and the Single Murderess’
abstract: In the third example of our new Text to Text feature, we pair a passage from “The Scarlet Letter” with a recent Op-Ed article that, together, invite discussion on societal attitudes toward female sexuality.
lead_paragraph: This week we’re introducing a new lesson plan format we’re calling Text to Text. In each lesson, we match a Times article, past or present, with often-taught literary, cultural, historical, scientific or mathematical material. Read more about the format, and consider submitting your own ideas.

headline: A History of Pollution in the Gowanus Canal
abstract: The Gowanus Canal continues to support industrial activities.
lead_paragraph: The Gowanus Canal continues to support industrial activities.

headline: Seeking Tacos in Their Purest Form
abstract: A quest for the kind of tacos you might find on any corner of Mexico City.
lead_paragraph: A quest for the kind of tacos you might find on any corner of Mexico City.

headline: Jennifer Lawrence to Star in ‘East of Eden’ Remake
abstract: The “Hunger Games” director Gary Ross plans to make two movies based on the John Steinbeck novel.
lead_paragraph: Remakes continue to be big business in Hollywood, the latest example coming from Universal Pictures and Imagine Entertainment, which are planning a two-part adaptation of the classic John Steinbeck novel “East of Eden.” The film will star Jennifer Lawrence and will be directed by her “Hunger Games” collaborator, Gary Ross.

headline: New York, All Wrapped Up in a Tortilla
abstract: Every cart, truck and bodega holds a promise of taco greatness.
lead_paragraph: Let’s set the record straight: New York has great tacos, tacos that can go mano a mano with the best of Los Angeles. That city may have us outnumbered, but not outgunned.

headline: Selig Says ’14 Season Will Be His Last
abstract: Bud Selig, 79, has been the commissioner of Major League Baseball since 1992, after the ouster of Fay Vincent.
lead_paragraph: Bud Selig, who has presided over Major League Baseball as commissioner for 21 years, formally announced Thursday that he planned to retire in January 2015. Selig will finish his career with the second-longest tenure of any commissioner, trailing only the first, Kenesaw Mountain Landis, who held the job from 1920 to 1944.

headline: Harvard University Press Defends Controversial Book on Hollywood and Hitler
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era']
abstract: Ben Urwand’s book, “The Collaboration: Hollywood’s Pact with Hitler,” which argues that studio bosses censored their movies at the request of Nazi officials, has generated intense response since its contents were reported this summer.
lead_paragraph: Harvard University Press has issued a statement defending its publication of a book on the relationship between Hollywood studios and the Nazi regime, following a long critique from the New Yorker film critic David Denby charging the author, Ben Urwand, with “omissions and blunders” and suggesting that something “broke down” in the press’s system of scholarly review.

headline: Companies Admit They Fixed Prices of Car Parts
abstract: The companies, all based in Japan, agreed to pay $740 million in fines on federal charges of fixing prices on parts like radiators sold to automakers in the United States.
lead_paragraph: In an expanding global antitrust investigation, nine Japanese automotive suppliers, along with two former executives, have agreed to plead guilty to conspiracy and pay more than $740 million in criminal fines for fixing the price of auto parts sold in the United States and abroad, the Justice Department said Thursday.

headline: Paris Fashion Week: Nina Ricci Spring/Summer 2014
abstract: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Filippo Mutani.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Filippo Mutani.

headline: Following a High-Tech Survival Script
abstract: 3LD has confronted a lot of adversity and survived, thanks to its earned-revenue model, and has a full season ahead.
lead_paragraph: When Ben Gassman’s play “The Downtown Loop” opens at 3LD Art & Technology Center on Oct. 15, audiences will climb aboard a decommissioned double-decker tour bus parked inside the theater, while immersive videos of a gritty, non-idealized tour of New York City are projected around them and actors interact live with a video feed of offstage performers.

headline: Living With Cancer: Feeling Older Than My Age
abstract: Sometimes cancer and its treatments make me feel as if I have entered a time machine that accelerates aging.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes cancer and its treatments make me feel as if I have entered a time machine that accelerates aging.

headline: Bernadette Peters Will Star in Sondheim-Marsalis Collaboration
abstract: She will be one of the performers in “A Bed and a Chair,” which features Mr. Sondheim’s songs reimagined and arranged for a jazz orchestra.
lead_paragraph: The Tony Award winner Bernadette Peters, a longtime interpreter of the musicals of Stephen Sondheim, will star this November in his new jazz project with Wynton Marsalis, “A Bed and a Chair: A New York Love Affair,” New York City Center announced on Thursday.

headline: A Proposal to Freeze Pensions in Detroit
abstract: Detroit’s emergency manager wants to freeze the city’s pension system for public workers, in light of evidence it was operated in an unsound manner for many years, contributing to the city’s financial downfall.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:42 p.m. | Detroit’s emergency manager wants to freeze the city’s pension system for public workers in light of mounting evidence that it was operated in an unsound manner for many years, contributing to the city’s downfall.

lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: A Steakhouse With Theatrical Flair
abstract: Stone Manor 101, in Hawthorne, pays exquisite attention to detail without going over the top.
lead_paragraph: It was one of the last miserably hot days of summer the first time I visited Stone Manor 101 in Hawthorne, but I did not feel sweaty and uncomfortable for long. Sitting on the steakhouse’s cushioned seats, enjoying the air conditioning, we looked out the big back windows and saw an open-pit fire being started outside. A few sips of a cool pepper margarita, made with a jalapeño-infused tequila, fresh lime juice and mint leaves, and I was transported to a whole different environment. The mugginess was gone; I actually felt cozy.

headline: Nissan and Toyota Issue Recalls for About 1.5 Million Vehicles Worldwide
abstract: Nissan said it would recall about 98,000 of its 2006-10 Infiniti M models in the United States because of a loss of power. Toyota will recall 615,000 Sienna minivans for a transmission problem.
lead_paragraph: Toyota will recall about 615,000 of its Sienna minivans in the United States, while Nissan will recall about 98,000 Infiniti sedans, the automakers have informed the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

headline: Strategies, Rules and Assists
abstract: Vijay Iyer says his new composition, “Open City,” has the same mix of rules and in-the-moment improvisation that one sees on the court.
lead_paragraph: The jazz composer and pianist Vijay Iyer said he often reached for a sports analogy to explain his new work, “Open City,” which has its premiere on Oct. 4 and 5 at the Alexander Kasser Theater at Montclair State University.

headline: Better Pay — Maybe — for Home Care Aides
abstract: Home care aides will receive federal wage and overtime protections, but there are important caveats.
lead_paragraph: For the groups who had spent years insisting that home care aides should be covered under the federal Fair Labor Standards Act, giving them the same wage and hour protections as other workers, last week’s action by the Labor Department has brought jubilation.

headline: It Wasn’t All He Needed, or All He Did
abstract: Robert Indiana, the artist behind the popular “Love” stamp, has a new retrospective at the Whitney Museum of American Art.
lead_paragraph: Success for an artist can be a dangerous thing. Just ask Robert Indiana. In the early 1960s, he was a leading light of the new Pop Art trend, along with Andy Warhol, Claes Oldenburg and Roy Lichtenstein. Then came disastrous mega-success. His 1966 images of big, blocky letters spelling the word “Love” — the “o” suggestively tilted — went viral. In the subsequent decade, his overproduction of the image in two and three dimensions, including his design for a 1973 United States postage stamp, eventually ruined his reputation in the serious New York art world. Disheartened, in 1978 he exiled himself to the island of Vinalhaven in Maine, where, at 85, he continues to live.

headline: Christian Wijnants: Spring 2014 RTW
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: Christie’s Opens for Business in Mainland China With Its First Auction
abstract: Christie’s took in nearly $25 million at the first auction in mainland China by an international auction, a sale that included the first work by Picasso to be sold at auction in that country.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI – Christie’s held its first auction in mainland China Thursday, a modest affair by international standards that brought $24.9 million for 39 paintings, sculpture, jewelry, watches, and wine.

headline: A Peaceful Voyage
abstract: The artists Ilya and Emilia Kabakov, with the help of schoolchildren, launch a boat/art installation inspired by the Sept. 11 attacks.
lead_paragraph: ON a crisp, sunny fall day at the Miller’s Launch shipyard on Staten Island, a crew of shipbuilders from Manchester, England, was putting the finishing touches on a boat called “The Ship of Tolerance.” All that was missing was its sail: a collage of about 150 paintings executed not by the celebrated married artists who conceived of this wooden vessel,  Ilya and Emilia Kabakov, but by scores of local schoolchildren charged with expressing its message of acceptance and understanding. The aesthetic was decidedly primary-color happy, with rainbows, smiley faces, multihued people holding hands and carefully lettered imperatives like “Peace on Earth.”

headline: Feeling For | A Reed Krakoff Clutch that Travels Well
abstract: The designer explains why he created this document pouch, which can double as a chic clutch, for women on the go.
lead_paragraph: “My wife is very organized, but too many times I’ve watched her dig deep into her handbag for travel documents at the airport. I thought it would be great to make a document pouch for her. It slips nicely into a handbag, and it can double as a chic clutch.” $490; reedkrakoff.com.

headline: Not O.K.
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Books and Literature', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder']
abstract: Soldiers interviewed by David Finkel faced their greatest challenges once they came home.
lead_paragraph: Several years ago David Finkel, a reporter for The Washington Post and a 2012 MacArthur fellow, wrote what might be thought of as a post-heroic “Iliad” for the Iraq war. Now, in “Thank You for Your Service,” he has written an equally cogent “Odyssey.”

headline: The Botany of Desire
abstract: Elizabeth Gilbert’s novel “The Signature of All Things” is about a botanist whose hunger for explanations carries her through the better part of Darwin’s century.
lead_paragraph: My most influential college course began with an assignment from the Book of Genesis: we read the two different creation stories that coexist there. If we wanted a secondary source to explain life’s existence, the professor said, we were free to spend extracurricular angst reconciling those conflicting reports. But hereafter in class, as scientists, we would look to life itself as primary source. As for the organisms in our purview, his credo was: It takes a superior mind to appreciate a plant. By “superior” I believe he meant “uncommonly patient.” Plants do everything animals do, but slowly. They migrate, communicate, deceive, stalk their food and, with an ostentation of styles and perfumes to put the animal kingdom to shame, they make love. It’s just that catching them in flagrante delicto might require time-lapse photography.

headline: This Is Only a Test
abstract: Diane Ravitch attacks the effort to replace public schools with the market system.
lead_paragraph: Over the past 20 years, a rising tide of voices in the world of public policy has been telling us that public education has fallen into an abyss of mediocrity. Our schools are “broken,” the mantra goes. Principals and teachers — their lack of “rigor” and “low expectations” for their students — are the primary offenders. The problem can be “fixed” only if schools are held to strict accountability. “No excuses” are to be permitted.

headline: For City Opera, the Talk Turns to a Shutdown
abstract: It appears increasingly unlikely that the New York City Opera, founded 70 years ago, will be able to meet its stated fund-raising goal of $7 million by early next week.
lead_paragraph: It may very well be all over for New York City Opera after the buxom lady sings.

headline: Give Children a Chance to Lose — and Win
keywords: ['Athletics and Sports', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'Children and Childhood', 'Parenting']
abstract: By age 4 or 5, children are not fooled by all the trophies. They are surprisingly accurate in identifying who excels and who struggles.
lead_paragraph: How many participation trophies and medals do you have displayed in your home or discarded somewhere in the mud room? We’ve got assorted skiing and soccer medals, hockey trophies, and certificates of achievement galore, and now is perhaps a good time to say that of my four sports-playing children, only one has ever really won something, because only one is old enough to have ever really competed — and he has lost far more often than he has won.

headline: Gerard Mortier Named Artistic Adviser of Teatro Real Opera House in Madrid
abstract: The Teatro Real said on Wednesday that it had created a new advisory post for Gerard Mortier, two weeks after abruptly ousting him as artistic director of the opera house in Madrid.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — The Teatro Real said Wednesday that it had created a new advisory post for Gerard Mortier, two weeks after abruptly ousting him as artistic director of the opera house here.

headline: E.A. Sports Settles Lawsuit With College Athletes
keywords: ['Football (College)', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Computer and Video Games', 'College Athletics']
abstract: The settlement in the suit filed by student-athletes seeking to be paid included the Collegiate Licensing Company, and the court filing came after E.A. Sports announced it would not publish a college football video game in 2014.
lead_paragraph: Two of the three targets of a high-profile lawsuit seeking payment for student-athletes settled the closely watched case Thursday, leaving the N.C.A.A. as the lone remaining defendant.

headline: Hold the Russian Vodka: ‘Great Comet’ Producers in Protest Against Anti-Gay Bias
abstract: The producers of “Natasha, Pierre and the Great Comet of 1812″ said vodkas with ties to Russia would no longer be served to audience members.
lead_paragraph: The Russian-themed musical “Natasha, Pierre and the Great Comet of 1812,” a critically acclaimed show that begins performances on Friday in Times Square, will no longer serve vodkas that have any ties to Russia to audience members, the musical’s lead producers said on Thursday. The action is meant as a protest against recent instances of bias and violence against gay people in Russia, according to the producers, Howard and Janet Kagan. In addition, they are donating $10,000 to Human Rights Watch, which has been trying to combat antigay bias in Russia; the producers will also donate revenue from all food and drink sales at the Friday performance and party afterward.

headline: Plucking Sounds From South American Skies
abstract: Alan Gilbert conducted his fifth opening gala as music director of the New York Philharmonic on Wednesday night.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday night, Alan Gilbert conducted his fifth opening gala concert as the music director of the New York Philharmonic. You would think that devising a program for this occasion would be easy. But there are conflicting imperatives at work, and Mr. Gilbert has never quite gotten the balance right.

headline: With Tastes Growing Healthier, McDonald’s Aims to Adapt Its Menu
keywords: ['Fast Food Industry', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Obesity', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: The fast-food chain said it would increase its offerings of fruits and vegetables and promote more nutritional options to children.
lead_paragraph: Under pressure to provide healthier meals, McDonald’s announced on Thursday that it would no longer market some of its less nutritional options to children and said it also planned to include offerings of fruits and vegetables in many of its adult menu combinations.

headline: One Fine Stay Expands to Los Angeles and Paris
abstract: One Fine Stay, the house rental service, now offers homes in Paris and Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: The house rental service One Fine Stay has just added homes in Paris and Los Angeles to its roster.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Pakistan, Kenya, the Philippines and Spain.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Pakistan, Kenya, the Philippines and Spain.

headline: Gunman in Afghan Army Uniform Kills Coalition Soldier
abstract: Though insider attacks are down, it was the second time in a week that a person thought to be an Afghan soldier turned his weapon on foreign troops.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — A person wearing an Afghan Army uniform shot and killed a service member from the American-led coalition in eastern Afghanistan on Thursday before being shot dead himself, Afghan and coalition officials said.

headline: Close-Up Grief After a Parent’s Worst Nightmare
abstract: “Morning” is a portrait of a upper-middle-class couple in California mourning the sudden death of their beautiful only child.
lead_paragraph: Acute emotional honesty and a frustrating narrative coyness coincide in “Morning,” a portrait of a middle-aged couple, Alice (Jeanne Tripplehorn) and Mark (Leland Orser), mourning the sudden death of their beautiful only child.

headline: A Republic’s Last Stand, Sublimely Sketched
abstract: “Tiepolo, Guardi, and Their World: Eighteenth-Century Venetian Drawings,” at the Morgan Library & Museum, summons Venice in the late stages of its republic.
lead_paragraph: Venice in the 18th century was a city of highs and lows, a flourishing art capital that happened to be in the late stages of a long political decline. A new exhibition at the Morgan Library & Museum captures something of the wild, up-and-down nature of life during the last gasp of the Venetian Republic.

headline: Newcomb Pottery Will Go on View at Tulane
abstract: “Women, Art and Social Change: The Newcomb Pottery Enterprise,” an exhibition opening at Tulane, tells the story of the Southern women who once toiled on exquisitely designed wares there.
lead_paragraph: Young Southern women flocked to the New Orleans classrooms of the Newcomb Art School in the early 1900s to learn how to mold clay teacups, carve vases, embroider tablecloths and hammer silver chalices. The results of their grueling work at the school, which was part of Tulane University, appealed to tastemakers like Louis Comfort Tiffany, museum curators and retail distributors from Boston to Los Angeles, and they ended up in elite collections.

headline: Gallery | The Sunset Strip, Before It Was Tamed
abstract: The Hollywood photographer Brad Elterman’s candid late-’70s shots of everyone from Joan Jett to Michael Jackson to Bob Dylan are collected in the book “Dog Days.”
lead_paragraph: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: After the Floods in Colorado, a Deluge of Worry About Leaking Oil
abstract: As waters recede from Colorado’s drilling epicenter, the sight of drowning oil wells has inflamed the debate over the environment.
lead_paragraph: WELD COUNTY, Colo. — When floodwaters surged into Colorado’s drilling center, they swamped wells, broke pipes and swept huge oil tanks off their foundations. The state has counted a dozen “notable” spills stemming from the catastrophic floods this month.

headline: Interpreting History, Any Which Way
abstract: “Not What Happened,” by Ain Gordon, looks at how we interpret the past.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a surprise. It appears that in rural America, way back in the early 19th century, the template for pretentious late-20th-century performance art had already been discovered and perfected. Who knew?

headline: A Coach’s New Playbook Is a Menu
abstract: Geno Auriemma, the University of Connecticut women’s basketball coach, has opened a restaurant just off the main campus.
lead_paragraph: Few Connecticut public figures evoke warmer admiration than Geno Auriemma, whose University of Connecticut women’s basketball teams have won eight national championships. Italy-born and Philadelphia-bred, Mr. Auriemma loves Italian cooking, and with Geno’s Grille, his restaurant in Storrs Center, a glossy new mixed-use development next to the main campus, he has set out to present Italian food “the way it used to be,” as he put it on the phone after my visits.

headline: ‘Actions!’ at the Kitchen Explores Performance Art
abstract: Events this weekend include the performance of a piece called “Actions!” and a series of concerts by Orchestra of Saint Luke’s Chamber Ensemble.
lead_paragraph: If early performance art — Allan Kaprow’s protopsychedelic “happenings,” the Dadaist provocations of Fluxus, the nightmarish nihilism of the Viennese Actionists — was mostly aesthetic, successors like Ron Athey and Karen Finley took an explicitly political turn. Artists came to scrutinize and protest the very conditions and institutions under which art is produced, and married the aesthetic charge of their performances to forthright political action.

headline: Sometimes, Food Bites Back
abstract: “Cloudy With a Chance of Meatballs 2,” an animated sequel, finds its goofy characters in a quandary involving living food products.
lead_paragraph: Opens on Friday.

headline: Looking for Sparks From Old Flames
abstract: A woman goes searching for a husband in “Baggage Claim,” a comedy directed by David E. Talbert and based on his novel.
lead_paragraph: Opens on Friday.

headline: Wheelies: The ‘No More Mr. Nice Guy’ Edition
abstract: Alice Cooper’s ’65 Ford Mustang fastback goes up for auction, and Volkswagen opens a new factory in China.
lead_paragraph: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Go Deeper Into Mexico With Mezcal
abstract: Tequila’s more-assertive cousin is working its way into many cocktails.
lead_paragraph: Mezcal, tequila’s brash, more rustic cousin, is crashing the cocktail party, showing up in the kind of mixed drinks normally made with more-refined spirits.

headline: Both Sides of a Crime, Each Imperfect
abstract: The crime thriller “On the Job,” set in Manila, puts an assassin and a federal agent on a collision course.
lead_paragraph: Opens on Friday.

headline: Tracking the Affordable Care Act
abstract: To coincide with the rollout of the Affordable Care Act, The Times is starting a new feature that will track the law’s implementation through articles, graphics, Q. and A.’s, explanatory items and other elements contributed by Times reporters and editors.
lead_paragraph: On Oct. 1, Americans can begin to sign up for health coverage through the online insurance marketplaces, or exchanges, created under the Affordable Care Act.

headline: Afghan Television, Behind the Scenes
abstract: Afghanistan’s first independent TV operation is the subject of the documentary “The Network.”
lead_paragraph: Opens on Friday in Manhattan.

headline: Late Nights? Please, Dear, It’s Science
abstract: “Masters of Sex” is a romantic look at the lives of the sex researchers William H. Masters and Virginia Johnson.
lead_paragraph: “Masters of Sex” isn’t everything you wanted to know about Masters and Johnson but were afraid to ask.

headline: In This Battle Arena, Warriors Are Armed With Algorithms
abstract: BattleFin, a recruitment firm for hedge funds, stages tournaments to find math whizzes who can apply their knowledge of other fields to the financial world.
lead_paragraph: Michael Chang, 30 years old, is the sort of guy that BattleFin, a recruitment firm searching for hedge fund talent, wants to attract.

headline: Another Stop on Rivera’s Farewell Tour
abstract: At a luncheon at the New York Athletic Club, Mariano Rivera looked forward to his final Yankee Stadium appearance Thursday night and looked back on his 19-year career.
lead_paragraph: Mariano Rivera’s major league career is slowly winding down. He will jog from the bullpen to the mound accompanied by “Enter Sandman” for the final time at Yankee Stadium on Thursday night against the Tampa Bay Rays.

headline: Can You Tell an Up-and-Coming Neighborhood by Its ‘Emergent Energy’?
abstract: Some claim to have felt a special vibe in the Lower East Side before it became what it is today. Which place is next?
lead_paragraph: In this weekend’s issue, Sam Sifton provides a recipe for a pork chops dish that used to be served at Relish, a now-shuttered diner in North Williamsburg, Brooklyn, and describes it as “a taste of Brooklyn on the cusp of its move into full food mania.” (The diner’s space, a silver-colored boxcar, is now occupied by La Esquina, a restaurant higher on the trendy scale.) The article calls to mind an earlier one from 2002, written by Jim Nelson and titled “Hip-ification.” Nelson, who is now the editor of GQ, examined the role that new restaurants play in a neighborhood’s mutation. Here’s how he characterized culinary newcomers to the Lower East Side during the late ’90s:

headline: Obama Discusses Health Care Law
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Before a crowd in Maryland on Thursday, President Obama discussed the benefits of the Affordable Care Act, as well as criticism from the Republican Party.
lead_paragraph: Before a crowd in Maryland on Thursday, President Obama discussed the benefits of the Affordable Care Act, as well as criticism from the Republican Party.

headline: In Los Angeles, a Struggle Over Water Quality
abstract: The 35-year-old federal law regulating tap water is so out of date that the water Americans drink can be both dangerous and legal.
lead_paragraph: The 35-year-old federal law regulating tap water is so out of date that the water Americans drink can be both dangerous and legal.

headline: As Some Companies Turn to Health Exchanges, G.E. Seeks a New Path
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Seeking to cut costs and improve care for its employees, General Electric has taken a hands-on approach with hospitals and doctors.
lead_paragraph: CINCINNATI — Although the new federal health care law is designed to help people buying individual policies, even people with employer-provided policies are beginning to see changes in their coverage as companies rethink health care for their workers, discontinuing it in a few cases and redesigning it in many others.

headline: De Niro to Replace James Gandolfini in HBO Drama
abstract: Robert De Niro, the Oscar-winning actor, has agreed to take over the part played by Mr. Gandolfini in the pilot of “Criminal Justice.” Mr. Gandolfini died in June.
lead_paragraph: HBO and the producers of a promising new television pilot faced a dilemma: How to replace James Gandolfini, the pilot’s star and probably the person most identified with the pay cable network, to keep the project going after the actor’s sudden death last June.

headline: Minnesota Orchestra Makes Contract Offer to Musicians
abstract: The Minnesota Orchestra said Thursday that it had made a fourth contract offer to its players, who have been locked out since Oct. 1 and missed an entire season of concerts.
lead_paragraph: The Minnesota Orchestra announced Thursday that it had made a fourth contract offer to its players, who have been locked out since Oct. 1 and missed an entire season of concerts.

headline: Google Alters Search to Handle More Complex Queries
abstract: Google made one of the biggest-ever changes in its search engine, as part of a shift away from matching keywords on Web pages to understanding the meaning of search queries.
lead_paragraph: Google on Thursday announced one of the biggest changes to its search engine, a rewriting of its algorithm to handle more complex queries that affects 90 percent of all searches.

headline: Rangers Stumble Against a Familiar Face After Signing a Key Player
abstract: Derek Stepan ended his holdout by signing a two-year deal with the Rangers on Thursday, when the team faced its former coach, John Tortorella, in Vancouver.
lead_paragraph: VANCOUVER, British Columbia — A preseason hockey game hardly ever generates buzz. But two N.H.L. clubs hardly ever swap head coaches, as the Rangers and the Vancouver Canucks did this off-season.

headline: Farm Waste in Wisconsin
abstract: Residents in Brown County, Wis., say that farm waste from dairy cows has contaminated their tap water.
lead_paragraph: Residents in Brown County, Wis., say that farm waste from dairy cows has contaminated their tap water.

headline: Survivor Stories
abstract: The documentary “The Time Is ... Now” focuses on people who have survived catastrophes and violence.
lead_paragraph: Opens on Friday in Manhattan.

headline: A Stage Buckling With New-Music Luminaries Has Space for Orchestral Scores
abstract: Members from New York’s current wave of hyper-versatile, independent new-music groups performed to honor the composer John Zorn as part of his 60th birthday celebration.
lead_paragraph: Last year the seasoned conductor Gerard Schwarz made news for assembling the All-Star Orchestra, an ad hoc team of players gathered from elite ensembles across the United States to tape an educational television series. On Wednesday night, a comparably starry aggregation gathered on the stage of the Miller Theater at Columbia University — and on a four-foot platform erected in front of the stage, too. Present were members from New York’s current wave of hyper-versatile, independent new-music groups: the International Contemporary and Talea ensembles; the JACK, FLUX, Mivos and Momenta string quartets; and more.

headline: Five Years Later, Poll Finds Disapproval of Bailout
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Emergency Economic Stabilization Act (2008)', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis']
abstract: Nearly 6 in 10 Americans express dissatisfaction with the government’s 2008 rescue of financial institutions, and only about a third approve, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.
lead_paragraph: At the fifth anniversary of the recession and bailout package for the nation’s banks and financial institutions, nearly 6 in 10 Americans express disapproval of the 2008 bailout, and only about a third approve, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

headline: Friendly Sculptures Derived From Scary Weather
abstract: The artist Nathalie Miebach creates whimsical pieces that represent complex scientific data related to unusual weather patterns.
lead_paragraph: When you look at the colorful, fanciful sculptures of the Boston artist Nathalie Miebach, you’re probably not thinking of, say, hurricanes. But Miebach’s work, as seen in “Nathalie Miebach: Changing Waters,” an exhibition that opens on Sept. 29 at the Craft and Folk Art Museum in Los Angeles, is a visual manifestation of complex scientific data related to astronomy, ecology and meteorology.

headline: Exclusive | 415 Washington Street
abstract: A combination of two units at the Fairchild condominium, built on the site of a former soap warehouse, yielded this 4,000-square-foot triplex.
lead_paragraph: A combination of two units at the Fairchild condominium, built on the site of a former soap warehouse, yielded this 4,000-square-foot triplex.

headline: Opulent and Quirky TriBeCa Town House
abstract: A combination of two units at the Fairchild condominium, built on the site of a former soap warehouse, yielded this 4,000-square-foot triplex.
lead_paragraph: An opulent TriBeCa town house carved out of a condominium in 2008 and rendered even grander by a personalized renovation in 2010 that included the replacement of a supermodern scissor stairway with a sweeping marble-and-wrought-iron Baroque confection is poised to enter the market at $9.5 million.

headline: Lanvin: Spring 2014 RTW
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: On and Off the Menu, an Eclectic Transformation
abstract: After a 14-month renovation and expansion, Tullulah’s — a contemporary, small-plates restaurant — has reopened with new dishes and décor.
lead_paragraph: There’s something slightly discombobulating about walking into Tullulah’s, a contemporary, small-plates restaurant in Bay Shore that recently reopened after a 14-month renovation and expansion with an eclectic, almost whimsical, new menu, and décor to match.

headline: So Full of Himself, Yet Running on Empty
abstract: Joseph Gordon-Levitt portrays a man hooked on pornography in “Don Jon,” which he also wrote and directed.
lead_paragraph: Once upon a time “Don Jon” had the unhappy title “Don Jon’s Addiction.” That was in January at the Sundance Film Festival, where the movie had its premiere. But addiction, which conjures up drunks, druggies and roads to recovery taken 12 steps at a time, felt at odds with the skittering, upbeat cadences and feel of “Don Jon,” an often exuberant movie about a man hooked on pornography who can’t deal with the breathing, desiring women who end up in his bed.

headline: Poor Richard’s Sister: What Jane Thought
abstract: In “Book of Ages: The Life and Opinions of Jane Franklin,” Jill Lepore reconstructs a history of Ben Franklin’s favorite sister.
lead_paragraph: Growing up in Boston at the start of the 18th century, Benjamin Franklin and his sister Jane were known as Benny and Jenny. Their parents had 17 children. He was the youngest boy, she the youngest girl.

headline: Sting Sings, Knowing There’s Much at Stake
abstract: Sting is promoting his new album and musical, “The Last Ship,” in a series of concerts at the Public Theater.
lead_paragraph: Sting told a choice anecdote near the close of his concert at the Public Theater on Wednesday night, reaching back to his boyhood in an English shipbuilding town. It was the day of a launching, he recalled, and amid the festive pomp, a Rolls-Royce cruised down the street, bearing the queen. Planted curbside with his mother in his Sunday best, frantically waving a little Union Jack, he was certain that Her Majesty spotted him.

headline: Headbanging After Therapy
abstract: “Metallica Through the Never,” a 3-D concert film, shows the rockers in robust middle-age form.
lead_paragraph: The last time I saw them in my professional capacity as a film critic, the members of Metallica were in therapy, working out their issues in the fascinating documentary “Metallica: Some Kind of Monster.” Nearly 10 years later, they seem to be doing well. “Metallica Through the Never,” a new concert film directed by Nimrod Antal (“Kontroll,” “Predators”), shows the band — three decades after the release of its first album — in vigorous middle age. Lars Ulrich, the drummer, is still a kinetic master of tricky time signatures, and his partner, the singer James Hetfield, bellows with undiminished authority. The fans, chanting along and giving devil-horn salutes, are as passionate as ever.

headline: U.N. Deal on Syrian Arms Is Milestone After Years of Inertia
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Nuclear Weapons']
abstract: In the most significant diplomatic initiative of the Syrian civil war, five key nations have agreed on a resolution saying Syria must give up its chemical weapons, but the statement lacks the threat of force.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — The five permanent members of the United Nations Security Council have agreed on a resolution that will require Syria to give up its chemical weapons, but there will be no automatic penalties if the Syrians fail to comply, officials said Thursday.

headline: Celebrating the Eclectic, the New, the Joyous
abstract: The opening program of Fall for Dance, at City Center, featured a new work by Justin Peck as well as a world premiere tango.
lead_paragraph: An old-fashioned but excellent line of thought proposes that dance is singularly and naturally equipped to express joy. Let other emotions be conveyed by other body movements or other arts, but dance and joy go together, wedded by high energy and continuous, ebullient rhythm.

headline: For Cicely Tyson and Kerry Washington, Roles of a Lifetime
abstract: Cicely Tyson and Kerry Washington discuss race, role models and overcoming parental disapproval.
lead_paragraph: It was the meal where nobody ate. On a recent Sunday morning, Cicely Tyson and Kerry Washington — one an Oscar nominee in 1972 for “Sounder” and a Tony Award winner this year for “A Trip to Bountiful” (which ends its Broadway run Oct. 9), the other a 2013 Emmy nominee for “Scandal” and a newlywed after her marriage this summer to the San Francisco 49ers cornerback Nnamdi Asomugha — met for brunch in the dining room of the Carlyle Hotel on the Upper East Side. As soon as Miss Tyson entered the room and greeted Ms. Washington with a tight embrace and the words “Don’t get up, don’t you dare get up” to their third table  companion, the two began an animated, breakneck conversation about race, role models, overcoming parental disapproval and why Olivia Pope wears so much white.

headline: Visual Artists, Choosing to Play by Ear
abstract: The exhibition “Music,” at the Aldrich Contemporary Art Museum in Connecticut, lets five visual artists engage with another form.
lead_paragraph: RIDGEFIELD, Conn. — THE first thing you see when you walk into the Aldrich Contemporary Art Museum is a 13-foot-wide poster of six men, mostly middle-aged and overweight, in coveralls and baseball caps. They are fans of the country singer Merle Haggard and were photographed by the British artist James Mollison at a concert in Huntsville, Ala., in 2006 as part of “The Disciples,” his series showing fans of 59 pop groups.

headline: Rallying to Keep the Game Alive
abstract: Deciding to get divorced can be the key to staying married.
lead_paragraph: When I took up tennis, my husband was happy to play with our two children and me, as long as we didn’t have to play by the rules. As Denis repeatedly explained to us, playing by the rules placed him at an unfair disadvantage because he didn’t know the rules, and he didn’t know how to serve.

headline: Uninsured Americans Divided on Impact of Health Care Law
abstract: Less than a week before the new health insurance markets established by 2010 health care law can begin accepting customers, a new New York Times/CBS News poll finds that there is some support among uninsured Americans for President Obama and his law, but also a wariness and lack of understanding about what the new law will mean for them.
lead_paragraph: Less than a week before the health insurance marketplaces established by the 2010 health care law begin accepting customers, a New York Times/CBS News poll has found that there is some support among uninsured Americans for President Obama and his law, but also a wariness and a lack of understanding about what the law will mean for them.

headline: Love, Forbidden and Persecuted
abstract: A Palestinian student from the West Bank falls for an Israeli lawyer he meets in Tel Aviv in “Out in the Dark.”
lead_paragraph: “I don’t care about the Jews, the Palestinians, Fatah or Hamas,” Nimr (Nicholas Jacob), a closeted gay Palestinian, declares to his thuggish older brother, Nabil (Jameel Khouri), in “Out in the Dark.”

headline: Citing New Evidence, Urging a Posthumous Pardon in 1992 Case
abstract: The Innocence Project will ask Gov. Rick Perry to order an investigation into a pardon for Cameron Todd Willingham, who was executed in 2004.
lead_paragraph: Armed with what it says is new evidence of wrongdoing in the prosecution of Cameron Todd Willingham, the Innocence Project on Friday will ask Gov. Rick Perry to order the Texas Board of Pardons and Paroles to investigate whether the state should posthumously pardon Mr. Willingham, whose 2004 execution has become a lightning rod of controversy over the Texas justice system.

headline: Carrying Debt After Retirement
abstract: A much higher proportion of households over the age of 65 is carrying mortgage debt compared with past generations.
lead_paragraph: If college debt is a hindrance to young adults, mortgage debt is the drag on homeowners heading into retirement.

headline: Infatuations, Female and Feline
abstract: An exhibition on the French painter Balthus at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, focusing on his somewhat disturbing predilection for girls and cats, is a rather strange, even refreshing exercise.
lead_paragraph: The French painter who called himself Balthus was infatuated with his medium’s rich history and with girls. He painted alluring, disturbing pictures of nubile adolescents more than he painted anything else, making images that conjured Courbet, Ingres, Piero della Francesca and Seurat and were charged with suggestive undercurrents. Occasionally he included cats in these scenes, increasing their erotic frisson.

headline: There’s More Than Meets the Eye
abstract: “The Mystery of the Ordinary, 1926-1938,” a René Magritte survey at the Museum of Modern Art, zeros in on a decade when he was inventing the artist he wanted to be.
lead_paragraph: Oh, no, I thought when I heard that the Museum of Modern Art’s big fall show was a René Magritte survey. Dozens of undersung modernist painters, many of them women, on at least five continents, have never had a New York moment, and here we’re getting an artist we practically can’t avoid. The pipe; the giant eye; the choo-choo in the fireplace.

headline: At Midterm, Every Campaign Is About Obama
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Elections, Senate']
abstract: Texas’ 2014 primary elections are five months off (candidates can’t even officially file for office yet), but the campaign against President Obama is well under way.
lead_paragraph: Texas Democrats are trying to put together a ticket to run against the Republicans in 2014. But Texas Republicans don’t care whose names appear on the other ballot; they already know the name of the candidate they’re running against:

headline: The Hits Flowed From a Famous Studio
abstract: The documentary “Muscle Shoals” looks at a studio where musicians including Aretha Franklin, Percy Sledge and the Rolling Stones recorded hit songs.
lead_paragraph: If you want to bob your head along to a jukebox sampler of glorious American songs, then “Muscle Shoals” is the documentary for you. But if you want to learn how the area near the small Alabama city of Muscle Shoals, which hugs the south bank of the Tennessee River, became a renowned music center — the place where Percy Sledge’s Civil Rights-era chartbuster “When a Man Loves a Woman” was born and where Aretha Franklin poured sweat and tears into “I Never Loved a Man (the Way I Love You)” — then you will need to look and listen elsewhere.

headline: Plenty of Jobs, Not Enough Shelter
abstract: An oil boom is creating a strain on housing in small towns across the western part of North Dakota.
lead_paragraph: An oil boom is creating a strain on housing in small towns across the western part of North Dakota.

lead_paragraph: Stephan Stoyanov Gallery

abstract: Mr. Gaines is having what amounts to a mini-survey of recent wor  k at Paula Cooper Gallery right now. It’s really something.

abstract: The multitasking artist Brian Belott organized “Draw Gym,” a raucous show of drawings by 75 young or youngish artists.
lead_paragraph: KnowMoreGames

headline: It’s Not the Rare Birds They Mind So Much. It’s the Watchdogs.
abstract: Texas ranchers are crucial to the protection of the declining lesser prairie chicken, but they must set aside their deep suspicion of government efforts.
lead_paragraph: LUBBOCK — An odd-looking grouse with an intricate mating dance is at the center of an intense battle over wildlife conservation among energy companies, Texas officials and environmental advocates and the federal government.

abstract: Mr. Douglas makes dreamlike paintings by means of an improbable, laborious technique.
lead_paragraph: Andrew Edlin 134 10th Avenue, near 18th Street,

abstract: Promoters of the Rock the Bells hip-hop festival have canceled two shows in Washington this weekend and two at the Meadowlands Racetrack in New Jersey next weekend because of lackluster ticket sales.
lead_paragraph: Promoters of the Rock the Bells hip-hop festival have canceled two shows in Washington this weekend and two in the New York City area next weekend because of lackluster ticket sales.

headline: The Traditional (and Inner) Rhythms of Kabul
abstract: Ariana Delawari mined her Afghan heritage for an album in 2009 and now a film, “We Came Home.”
lead_paragraph: In “We Came Home,” Ariana Delawari documents her father’s role in helping his home country, Afghanistan, modernize its financial system after the fall of the Taliban. But this intimate film, Ms. Delawari’s first, is about so much more: her family’s history (seen in home movies and photographs), the resilience of the Afghan people, and her own story of self-discovery as a musician.

headline: Enrollment to Be Delayed for Small-Business Marketplaces
abstract: President Obama’s administration on Thursday announced another minor delay in the implementation of the Affordable Care Act, saying that the insurance marketplaces for small businesses would not be fully open for enrollment until a month later than it had planned.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Thursday announced another minor delay in the implementation of the Affordable Care Act, saying that the insurance marketplaces for small businesses would be fully open for enrollment a month later than it had planned.

headline: It’s More Than What’s for Dinner
abstract: The director Jim Mickle takes on Jorge Michel Grau’s 2011 creep-out, “We Are What We Are.”
lead_paragraph: If the director Jim Mickle has a signature style, it’s to approach horror and hideousness with the elegiac rhythms and lyrical imagery of the best westerns, his mournful tone suggesting deep empathy for his disturbed characters. So when he took on Jorge Michel Grau’s marvelous 2011 creep-out, “We Are What We Are,” he didn’t so much remake as reimagine. Retaining the title but moving the action from Mexico City to the Catskills, Mr. Mickle transforms a politically charged allegory of social decay into a dreamy commentary on the ravages of extreme religious observance.

headline: Opera and Classical Music Listings for Sept. 27-Oct. 3
abstract: A selected guide to classical music performances in the New York area.
lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Minister Admits Overstating Her Credentials
abstract: Teresa MacBain, a former Methodist minister hired by a Harvard humanist group, falsely claimed she had a master of divinity degree.
lead_paragraph: A Methodist minister who resigned her pulpit last year after deciding that she was no longer a believer, and who was recently hired by a humanist group based at Harvard to help build congregations of nonbelievers throughout the country, has acknowledged fabricating aspects of her educational background.

lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.
