lead_paragraph: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: ‘The Mystery of the Ordinary’
abstract: A look at the René Magritte survey at the Museum of Modern Art.
lead_paragraph: A look at the René Magritte survey at the Museum of Modern Art.

headline: Free-Range Herds, in the Broadest Sense
abstract: A shepherd and his young apprentice spend a winter outdoors escorting 800 sheep on a traditional season of free grazing in “Winter Nomads.”
lead_paragraph: Cattle drives in westerns have taught moviegoers the beauty of the herd, a rippling organic mass spreading across the landscape like a bestial cloud. The documentary “Hiver Nomade” (“Winter Nomads”) shares that sense of peace as it shadows two French shepherds wrangling and coaxing their 800 sheep in search of green pasture across the snow-covered Swiss countryside.

headline: Paris Fashion Week: Rick Owens Spring/Summer 2014
abstract: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.

headline: A Nuptial Curse in the Finest Korean-American Tradition
abstract: Wedding Palace,” directed by Christine Yoo, contrasts South Koreans in Seoul with supertraditional Korean-Americans.
lead_paragraph: The romantic comedy “Wedding Palace,” Christine Yoo’s feature directing debut, is swimming in color, clichés and stereotypes, recalling Baz Luhrmann’s “Strictly Ballroom” and other films of that highly stylized ilk. While the story is a bit weak, the film does a good job of contrasting Korean-Americans who steadfastly adhere to the traditions of their homeland with South Koreans who have renounced old customs.

headline: Spare Times for Children for Sept. 27-Oct. 3
abstract: A selected guide to noteworthy events for children, families and teenagers.
lead_paragraph: The Medieval Festival

headline: From Korea With Love
abstract: In “The Spy: Undercover Operation,” a Korean comedy, the agent’s wife may be his most formidable challenge.
lead_paragraph: Can you imagine what James Bond would do with Google Glass? He’d probably use his specs to undress young women digitally while also rescuing the free world. The secret agent in the new South Korean film “The Spy: Undercover Operation” instead uses modern gadgets like this to monitor his wife. In many ways this action-comedy is similar to Roger Moore-era Bond films, but with a henpecked husband instead of a playboy as the hero.

headline: Pakistani General Attacked in Quake Zone
abstract: Militants shot two rockets at a helicopter carrying Maj. Gen. Saeed Aleem, the Pakistani general in charge of disaster relief for the devastating earthquake this week.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Militants on Thursday shot two rockets at a helicopter carrying the Pakistani general in charge of disaster relief for the devastating earthquake this week, officials said.

headline: Spare Times for Sept. 27-Oct. 3
abstract: A listing of street fairs, walking tours, author discussions and other cultural events.
lead_paragraph: ‘Swingin’ With the All Stars: Louis Armstrong & Baseball’ (closes on Sunday) Local baseball fans disappointed by the playoff elimination of the Mets and the Yankees can still find something to cheer about with this exhibition at the Louis Armstrong House Museum, 34-56 107th Street, Corona, Queens. A devoted baseball fan — he followed the Dodgers and the Mets and had ties to the Yankees — Armstrong also had a special interest in a sandlot team in New Orleans, which he named Armstrong’s Secret 9. So devoted was he that he bought the team’s uniforms and equipment.

headline: Texas’ Davis Is Expected to Enter Race for Governor
abstract: Wendy Davis, the Democratic state senator who gained prominence for a filibuster in June against an abortion bill, has reportedly told supporters she is entering the race.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Wendy Davis, the Texas state senator whose filibuster in June against an abortion bill backed by the state’s powerful Republicans catapulted her to national political prominence, has told supporters and potential donors that she plans to announce next week that she will run for governor, according to Democrats in Texas and Washington.

headline: Mariano Rivera, Center Fielder
abstract: Joe Girardi is considering letting his team’s peerless closer play center field during the Yankees’ season-ending series in Houston.
lead_paragraph: Mariano Rivera will pitch one last time in Yankee Stadium on Thursday, and it could be the last relief appearance of his 19-year career. With the Yankees eliminated from the postseason, Rivera could accomplish one more thing in the final three games of the season against the Houston Astros: playing center field.

headline: Little Girl at the Center of Spooky Mayhem
abstract: “Dark Touch” centers on a young girl, who may be the victim or instigator of the supernatural mayhem around her.
lead_paragraph: Part revenge fantasy, part psychological horror, “Dark Touch” owes something to the writings of Stephen King and even more to the jaggedly atmospheric cinematography of John Conroy (who worked most recently on the British television series “Luther” and “Silk”). Wielding his camera with jumpy precision, Mr. Conroy infuses even chaotic motion with stabilizing elegance.

headline: Alienated, From His First Day in the U.S.A.
abstract: “The Citizen” is about a Lebanese immigrant to the United States who arrives on Sept. 10, 2001, only to find his American dream quickly turn into a series of nightmares.
lead_paragraph: As Ibrahim, the unflappably upbeat and disastrously unlucky Lebanese immigrant at the center of “The Citizen,” the Egyptian actor Khaled Nabawy is invaluable. Resembling a duskier Benjamin Bratt, Mr. Nabawy adds much-needed weight and authenticity to a character whose cascade of misfortunes threatens to turn drama into farce at every moment.

headline: Birthday Gift Comes With Unusual Attachments
abstract: In “Hôtel Normandy” a widow is sent on a resort holiday by her girlfriends, who have also secretly arranged for a man to romance her.
lead_paragraph: In the French comedy “Hôtel Normandy,” Alice, a widow of five years with no interest in another love, is given a 40th-birthday gift by her girlfriends at the bank where they work: a stay at a luxe resort in Deauville during its art biennale. What her chums don’t say is that they have also arranged for a man to romance her. (No professional escort, mind you, just a client who owes a favor.)

headline: Fighting for a Cat’s Right to Scratch
abstract: Jennifer Conrad, a California veterinarian, tackles the touchy subject of declawing cats in her documentary, “The Paw Project.”
lead_paragraph: The innocuous title may create the impression that “The Paw Project” is a cutesy compilation of YouTube cat videos, but it’s actually a heartfelt documentary about a subject that inflames cat lovers everywhere: declawing.

headline: Finding a Suitable Match for a School Nerd
abstract: A nerd who lusts after the hottest girl in high school is reluctantly paired with another social outcast in “The Secret Lives of Dorks.”
lead_paragraph: There’s no way to prepare yourself for how awful “The Secret Lives of Dorks” is.

headline: Ray Charles Songs, Mason Jars and Mussels
abstract: Park and Sixth is a restaurant and bar with a retro feel where diners are apt to linger.
lead_paragraph: Had I known that Tuesday was all-you-can-eat mussels night at Park and Sixth, I never would have dined there then. I like mussels but not enough to visit on an evening when mussels, along with items from the lunch menu, are served in place of the larger dinner menu.

headline: Chasm Between the Very Rich and Everybody Else
abstract: In “Inequality for All,” Robert Reich, labor secretary under President Bill Clinton, explains America’s economic woes.
lead_paragraph: The concentration of our country’s wealth among the very rich has gone from being an unsettling factoid to a rallying cry, and Jacob Kornbluth’s “Inequality for All” hands the bullhorn to Robert Reich, the labor secretary under President Bill Clinton. Rather than through a harangue or a lament, Mr. Reich ties together his talking points with a reasonable-sounding analysis and an unassuming warmth sometimes absent from documentaries charting America’s economic woes.

headline: Paris Doesn’t Need a Sideshow
abstract: A review of the Balenciaga, Dries Van Noten, Rick Owens, Rochas, Undercover shows.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — None of the big names on the bill for the opening of the Paris spring shows is French. There’s Jun Takahashi of Undercover (Tokyo), Alexander Wang of Balenciaga (New York) and Dries Van Noten (Antwerp). Rick Owens has lived in Paris for years, but we Americans still claim him as a California guy.

headline: The Broker-Free Sale
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'E-Commerce', 'Online Advertising', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']
abstract: Selling a home without a broker has become easier because of all the real estate information online, but it still involves a lot of work.
lead_paragraph: With inventory hitting new lows, the housing market in New York City has taken a dramatic turn in favor of sellers. Buyers face fewer options and stiffer competition. And that can get homeowners thinking about the value of their increasingly expensive broker.

headline: Events in Westchester
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Nostalgia Burns Bright in a City Renewed
abstract: While Astana, Kazakhstan’s capital, is a fully contemporary city, some residents still express nostalgia for ancient traditions in sports and architecture of the 1950s.
lead_paragraph: ASTANA, Kazakhstan — This city of contemporary buildings recalls a mini-Dubai, but is planted in the middle of the Asian steppe and mixes cutting-edge architecture with traditional pastimes.

headline: Senators Push to Preserve N.S.A. Phone Surveillance
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: The Senate Intelligence Committee appears to be moving quickly to pass a bill aimed at building public confidence in a once-secret  National Security Agency call log program.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate Intelligence Committee appears to be moving toward swift passage of a bill that would “change but preserve” the once-secret National Security Agency program that is keeping logs of every American’s phone calls, Senator Dianne Feinstein, the California Democrat who leads the panel, said Thursday.

headline: Virginia Dwan’s Big Gift to the National Gallery
abstract: Ms. Dwan, a dealer and philanthropist, talks about her donation of 250 modern works — including pieces by Martial Raysse, Robert Smithson, Yves Klein and Carl Andre.
lead_paragraph: Since the late 1960s, the dealer and philanthropist Virginia Dwan has quietly donated art to museums all over the country. Among her gifts are Duchamp’s famed “L.H.O.O.Q.,” a reproduction of the Mona Lisa with a mustache and beard in pencil, which has gone to the Norton Simon Museum in Los Angeles, and “Double Negative,” one of Michael Heizer’s monumental pieces of land art in Nevada, which she has given to the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles. Ms. Dwan also donated six photographic images by Mr. Heizer to the Whitney Museum of American Art, and works by Robert Smithson and Sol LeWitt to the Museum of Modern Art in New York, the Art Institute of Chicago and the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis.

headline: Judge Orders Pay for Illinois Lawmakers
keywords: ['State Legislatures', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans']
abstract: Gov. Pat Quinn had suspended the state legislators’ pay over the summer after they ignored a deadline he set to address the state’s pension problems.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — A Cook County judge, in a ruling made public Thursday, held that Gov. Pat Quinn’s order this summer to withhold state legislators’ wages was unconstitutional.

headline: Mayoral Rivals Entangled in Debate on City’s Rules for a Circumcision Rite
abstract: Bill de Blasio and Joseph J. Lhota have seemed to embrace changing positions on a policy requiring parental consent on a  procedure common among ultra-Orthodox Jews.
lead_paragraph: There are the predictable issues facing the candidates running for mayor of New York: jobs, education, crime.

headline: Events in Connecticut
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: A Promising Start at Air Products
abstract: The activist hedge fund manager William A. Ackman has dislodged the company’s underperforming boss, John McGlade. For bigger, more lasting success, however, a painstaking transformation of the company is now needed
lead_paragraph: Activist investor William A. Ackman has quickly dislodged Air Products and Chemicals’ underperforming boss, John McGlade. The win brought him a sharp gain of $100 million on his 10 percent holding in the natural gas firm as investors initially reacted to the news.

headline: New York’s Air Is Cleanest in 50 Years, Survey Finds
abstract: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said the city estimates that the reduction in pollution is preventing 800 deaths and 2,000 emergency room visits and hospitalizations each year.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said on Thursday that his administration’s efforts at reducing air pollution had resulted in New York City’s having the best air quality in more than 50 years.

headline: Events on Long Island
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Italy: Bones Found Amid Shipwreck
abstract: Divers involved in the recovery of the cruise ship Costa Concordia found several bones on the seabed on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Divers involved in the recovery of the cruise ship Costa Concordia found several bones on the seabed on Thursday, but the authorities cautioned that DNA tests would be necessary to determine whether they were the remains of the last two unrecovered bodies from the shipwreck that killed 32 people last year. The search for the two missing victims resumed Monday, a week after the capsized ship was righted during a complex salvage operation 20 months after the liner crashed into two granite reefs just off the tiny Tuscan island of Giglio. Experts have yet to go inside the parts of the ship that remained submerged for months after the shipwreck in January 2012. The captain, Francesco Schettino, went on trial this month on charges of multiple manslaughter, causing a shipwreck and abandoning the vessel before all of the ship’s 4,229 passengers and crew members were safe.

headline: Events in New Jersey
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: As Merkel Is Showered in Glory, Hollande Trudges Through Drizzle
abstract: President François Hollande of France is struggling at home, while across the border in Germany, Chancellor Angela Merkel is having a much nicer time of it these days.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — It has been a hard week to be François Hollande.

headline: Unlikely Debate on Gay Rights in California Town
abstract: The issue of a gay pride month arose in June and has split the Central Valley farming community of Porterville ever since.
lead_paragraph: PORTERVILLE, Calif. — The mayor of Porterville did not give it much thought when a local gay activist in this remote Central Valley farming town asked her to proclaim June a month of gay pride. But when the mayor, Virginia R. Gurrola, settled into her seat at City Hall to sign the proclamation, people were pouring out of the chambers and into the hallways, citing Scripture in opposition to what she had thought of as a simple ceremonial gesture. Her four fellow City Council members announced they would not join her in signing the document.

headline: Panthers Hope for Fresh Phase With New Owners
abstract: After only four playoff berths in 19 seasons, the Florida Panthers will seek to reverse their fortunes behind a new owner and a combination of veterans and young stars.
lead_paragraph: CORAL SPRINGS, Fla. — It was 90 degrees outside as the Florida Panthers skated through training camp drills at their practice rink this week. Such temperatures are common here during the season, which, according to some theories, is why the Panthers have been so bad for so long, and why so many N.H.L. careers came here to die.

headline: S.E.C. Sues Former Chairman in Looting of Educational Company
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission has accused the former chairman and chief executive of the ChinaCast Education Corporation of stealing $41 million in company funds.
lead_paragraph: The Securities and Exchange Commission on Thursday accused the former chief executive and chairman of an American-listed Chinese education company of stealing $41 million from investors.

headline: Chile Hunt for Justice Winds Up as Enigma
keywords: ["Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat", 'Extradition', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: A former American Navy captain accused of involvement in the murders of two Americans after the 1973  coup may have been right under the noses of the investigators seeking his extradition.
lead_paragraph: SANTIAGO, Chile — The Chilean courts have long been after Ray E. Davis, a former American Navy captain, accusing him of being involved in the murder of two Americans decades ago that inspired the award-winning 1982 film “Missing.”

headline: Time-Shifted Viewing, Plans for Las Vegas and Bossy Little Girls
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Video Recordings and Downloads', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Highlights of the 10th annual Advertising Week, including a panel discussion on a TV network’s advertising plans and a conversation with Sheryl Sandberg, of Facebook.
lead_paragraph: HERE is a look at highlights, lowlights and sidelights of the 10th annual Advertising Week, which took place this week in New York.

headline: Republicans Facing a Test of Unity
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Tea Party Movement', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: As the Congressional showdown over the health care law threatens to shut down the government, conservative advocacy groups have emerged as central players, pitting Republicans against one another.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the Congressional showdown over President Obama’s health care law threatens to shut down the government, conservative advocacy groups have emerged as central players — exerting outsize influence, investing tremendous time and resources, and turning the long-shot budget fight into a do-or-die battle that has pitted Republicans against one another.

headline: Reporting Iran’s News, but Speaking for One Side
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era']
abstract: In Iran’s news media landscape, which is divided into two camps, the hard-liners and reformists, the semiofficial Fars agency has emerged in recent years as the most influential conservative voice.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — So there was Iran’s semiofficial Fars News Agency, once the dedicated defender of the Israel-bashing, Holocaust-denying former Iranian president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, being singled out for praise on Thursday by The Wall Street Journal’s staunchly conservative, Israel-defending, Iran-distrusting editorial page.

headline: Why Conservatives Should Reread Milton Friedman
keywords: ['Capitalism (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Philosophy', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Even a major intellectual hero of the right acknowledged the need for government interventions to keep capitalism on the right track.
lead_paragraph: It’s easy to think that our continuing impasses over the federal budget stem from deep differences in principle between conservatives and progressives over the role of capitalist enterprises in our society. Progressives favor substantial constraints, through taxation and other sorts of regulation, whereas conservatives think that, as Milton Friedman put it in his classic “Capitalism and Freedom,” “there is one and only one social responsibility of business — to use its resources and engage in activities designed to increase its profits.” But if we look more deeply into Friedman’s view, the difference between his conservative economics and progressive views shrinks considerably.

headline: Fishless in Seattle
abstract: I’ve always wanted to save the salmon so I can eat them, in season, on a whim, after grilling them, rubbed with olive oil.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Not long ago, dispirited by national politics mired in mean and a hopeless hometown baseball team, I sought a long day’s refuge in the natural world. But it was not a frozen flank of Mount Rainier or an island in the inland sea that gave me the break I was looking for. It was an overcrowded perch in the heart of a metro area of nearly three million people.

headline: Have a Nice Day, N.S.A.
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: How Brazilians are using humor to fight back against American surveillance.
lead_paragraph: AT the opening of the United Nations General Assembly on Tuesday, Dilma Rousseff, the president of my country, Brazil, delivered a scolding speech in response to reports that the National Security Agency has monitored electronic communications of Brazilian citizens, members of government and private corporations. Like a displeased school principal, Ms. Rousseff seemed to speak directly to President Obama, who was waiting in the wings to deliver his own speech.

headline: My State Needs Obamacare. Now.
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Medicaid', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Kentucky couldn’t afford not to implement Obamacare.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFORT, Ky. — SUNDAY morning news programs identify Kentucky as the red state with two high-profile Republican senators who claim their rhetoric represents an electorate that gave President Obama only about a third of its presidential vote in 2012.

headline: Is Obamacare Working?
abstract: The law is starting to take effect. Were the dire predictions correct, or is it lowering costs and expanding access?

headline: Massachusetts: Fishery Group Limits Herring Catch
abstract: According to the rules, the Atlantic herring fleet can incidentally catch no more than 311.4 metric tons of river herring and shad.
lead_paragraph: The New England Fishery Management Council on Thursday approved the region’s first cap on the amount of river herring that can be caught by industrial trawlers. According to the rules, which must be approved and put into place by the National Marine Fisheries Service, the Atlantic herring fleet can incidentally catch no more than 311.4 metric tons of river herring and shad. The cap, which is the median of what managers estimate it caught over the past five years, will be implemented by zone and gear type. River herring and shad, whose populations are at historic lows, spend part of their lives at sea and run up rivers to spawn; hundreds of millions of dollars have been spent on dam removal projects to foster a revival of the runs, but fishermen and conservationists have long warned the species also need protection at sea. The council also discussed the National Marine Fisheries Service’s decision this summer not to implement all of the measures the council approved last year to protect Atlantic herring, citing funding issues; the group tabled a motion to prohibit midwater trawling in the region until those rules are put into place.

headline: Another 100-Loss Year, but Astros Have Hope
abstract: To judge by their thriving farm system, the Houston Astros are getting better. But this was their third consecutive season with at least 106 losses.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Tex. — You might think that Manager Bo Porter, after watching his Houston Astros stagger to 108 losses, might enjoy some time away from the team this winter. The Astros, whose season mercifully ends at home against the Yankees this weekend, have set a franchise record for defeats.

headline: Whose Cheatin’ Heart Came First?
abstract: “La Dispute,” an entertaining 70-minute comedy now at Hartford Stage, asks: Who committed the first infidelity, mankind or womankind?
lead_paragraph: Sometimes a war has a clear culprit: Paris takes Helen to Troy; Japan bombs Pearl Harbor. But when it comes to what we used to call “the battle of the sexes,” it’s not easy to fix the blame. Leave it to the 18th-century French playwright Pierre Carlet de Chamblain de Marivaux to give it a go in “La Dispute,” the entertaining 70-minute comedy that opened Hartford Stage’s 50th anniversary season last week.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Sept. 26, 2013
abstract: Lottery numbers for Sept. 26, 2013 for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Answers to Readers’ Questions About Job Hunting
keywords: ['Hiring and Promotion', 'Careers and Professions', 'Age, Chronological', 'Discrimination', 'Social Media']
abstract: The Times invited readers to ask Eilene Zimmerman, who wrote a career column for six years, their questions about job hunting.
lead_paragraph: The Times invited readers to ask Eilene Zimmerman, a You’re the Boss blogger, questions about job hunting. Ms. Zimmerman wrote The Times’s Career Couch column for six years. This Q&A is part of “How I Hire,” a LinkedIn Influencer feature in which The Times’s Business section is participating.

headline: What Iran’s President Said, Is Said to Have Said and Says He Said
abstract: In an interview broadcast by CBS News on Thursday, Iran’s new president, Hassan Rouhani, rejected accusations that he had not clearly acknowledged the historical reality of the Holocaust in remarks to CNN earlier this week.
lead_paragraph: In an interview with Charlie Rose of CBS News broadcast on Thursday, Iran’s new president, Hassan Rouhani, rejected accusations that he had not clearly acknowledged the historical reality of the Holocaust in remarks to CNN earlier this week.

headline: Answers to Readers’ Questions About Hiring the Right Candidate
keywords: ['Hiring and Promotion', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: The Times invited readers who work as managers or own their own businesses to ask Jay Goltz, a columnist for You’re the Boss, questions about hiring candidates.
lead_paragraph: The Times invited readers who work as managers or own their own businesses to ask Jay Goltz, a columnist for You’re the Boss, questions about hiring. Mr. Goltz employs more than 100 people at his five Chicago businesses. This Q&A is part of “How I Hire,” a LinkedIn Influencer feature in which The Times’s Business section is participating.

headline: Boss’s Kindness Repaid With a Burst of Violence
abstract: John Choi, a Long Island business owner, gave a job to Sang Ho Kim, who is accused of shooting Mr. Choi and killing a co-worker.
lead_paragraph: It was at church where John Choi met the man accused of shooting him.

headline: The Cup May Stay, but There’s No Going Back on Speed
abstract: After beating Team New Zealand to retain the America’s Cup, Oracle Team USA may be facing a challenge from the Hamilton Island Yacht Club of Queensland, Australia.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The future of the America’s Cup was one victory from becoming Emirates Team New Zealand’s responsibility: one victory from returning to New Zealand, with the Italian team Luna Rossa Challenge expected to be its challenger of record.

headline: Sudan Erupts in Deadly Protests as Gas Prices Rise
abstract: The police and activists differed on how many Sudanese were killed in protests this week after the government lifted gasoline subsidies, raising the price of gas and other commodities.
lead_paragraph: KHARTOUM, Sudan — This time, it was not the organizing by activists on Facebook and Twitter that made people take to the streets in such numbers. They did not need it. The anger was already widespread enough.

headline: Rabbi Linked to Kickback Scheme at Charity
abstract: Two people briefed on the investigation into William E. Rapfogel said that Rabbi David Cohen was one of the unnamed co-conspirators referred to in the criminal complaint.
lead_paragraph: In August, the board of one of New York City’s most respected social services organizations drew widespread attention when it fired its executive director, William E. Rapfogel, because it believed he had been taking large kickbacks from its insurance broker.

headline: JPMorgan Urged to Pay More in Mortgage Deal
keywords: ['Mortgage-Backed Securities', 'Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis']
abstract: Jamie Dimon, the chief executive, met with the attorney general for nearly an hour on Thursday in Washington to discuss a deal that would involve a fine of more than $7 billion, plus $4 billion in relief for struggling homeowners.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department is moving closer to striking a multibillion-dollar settlement with JPMorgan Chase over questionable mortgage practices, after authorities urged the bank to raise its offer and the bank’s chief executive took the rare step of meeting with Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. in Washington to discuss the deal.

headline: Food Stamp Regression in the Statehouse
abstract: At least a half-dozen states are moving on their own to punish the poor by changing rules governing food stamps.
lead_paragraph: While Congress is making up its mind on how much to slash from the food stamp program, some states are moving on their own to punish the poor by changing eligibility and other rules governing food stamps in ways that could deny vital assistance to needy people.

headline: Some Progress on Syria
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Editorials']
abstract: Belatedly, the United Nations is beginning to rein in President Bashar al-Assad.
lead_paragraph: The resolution to rid Syria of its chemical weapons, agreed to by the five permanent members of the United Nations Security Council, is a useful, if imperfect, step toward a credible international response to a bloody war that has killed more than 100,000 Syrians.

headline: A Republican Ransom Note
keywords: ['National Debt (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials', 'Federal Budget (US)']
abstract: The House leaders are threatening economic disaster with an absurd list of discredited demands.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, Treasury Secretary Jacob Lew sent the House a very serious warning that, for the first time, the United States would be unable to pay its bills beginning on Oct. 17 if the debt ceiling is not lifted. House leaders responded on Thursday with one of the least serious negotiating proposals in modern Congressional history: a jaw-dropping list of ransom demands containing more than a dozen discredited Republican policy fantasies.

headline: Prison-Based Gerrymandering
abstract: The Census Bureau should change the wrongful practice of counting inmates at their correctional institutions as “residents.”
lead_paragraph: The Census Bureau has steadfastly resisted calls to end the practice of counting inmates as “residents” of their prisons instead of the cities and towns where they lived and to which they typically return. The bureau’s new director, John Thompson, seems at least open to ending this wrongful practice.

headline: James van Sweden Dies at 78; His Designs Urged Lawns to Grow
abstract: Mr. van Sweden helped lead a revolt against the well-manicured lawn, creating naturalistic, colorful gardens inspired by master painters.
lead_paragraph: James van Sweden, an influential landscape architect who drew inspiration from the grand masters of painting to create vivid, naturalistic landscapes that seemed to explode with grasses and wildflowers, died last Friday at his home in Washington. He was 78.

headline: Plutocrats Feeling Persecuted
abstract: Have you heard the latest about how bad the richest of the rich have it these days? It is reason to fear the wrath of the .01 percent!
lead_paragraph: Robert Benmosche, the chief executive of the American International Group, said something stupid the other day. And we should be glad, because his comments help highlight an important but rarely discussed cost of extreme income inequality — namely, the rise of a small but powerful group of what can only be called sociopaths.

headline: $300 Million in Detroit Aid, but No Bailout
keywords: ['Bankruptcies', 'Federal Aid (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Federal Budget (US)']
abstract: The Obama administration’s proposal for federal and private aid for Detroit, only a fraction of the billions the city owes, reflects President Obama’s fiscal and political limits.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Two months after Detroit became the largest city ever to file for bankruptcy, top Obama administration officials will be there on Friday to propose nearly $300 million in combined federal and private aid toward a Motown comeback — only a fraction of the billions the city owes and a reflection of the budget and political limits on President Obama.

headline: Iranian President Softens Condemnation of Holocaust
abstract: President Hassan Rouhani appeared to walk his condemnation of the Holocaust back a notch on Thursday, one day after he provoked a politically fraught uproar.
lead_paragraph: President Hassan Rouhani of Iran appeared to walk his condemnation of the Holocaust back a notch on Thursday, one day after he provoked a politically fraught uproar in the United States and at home with a qualified castigation of one of history’s best-documented genocides.

abstract: Readers respond to a Sunday Review article.

abstract: A reader says the junta in Cairo is the most repressive government there in memory.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

abstract: Two readers react to an essay on how the existence of others after our deaths gives meaning to our lives.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: 19 Are Charged in a Plot to Cheat on Commercial Driver’s License Tests
abstract: Would-be commercial drivers tapped into a network of cheaters who used secret codes to provide answers to test-takers in exam rooms.
lead_paragraph: They wanted to drive school buses or trucks with heavy loads but had not passed the commercial driver’s license exam. So these would-be drivers tapped into a network of cheats who used secret codes to provide answers to test-takers in exam rooms where security guards were bribed to look the other way, according to a complaint filed on Wednesday in Federal District Court in Brooklyn.

headline: Swimmer Is Fighting a Ruling: She Is Not Disabled Enough
abstract: Paralympic officials have ruled Victoria Arlen ineligible for competition over questions about the permanence and severity of her impairment.
lead_paragraph: EXETER, N.H. — Racked by sudden spasms in her shoulders, back and hands — the things she most relies upon to offset her paralyzed legs — the American swimmer Victoria Arlen failed to qualify for the final in the 100-meter breaststroke at the Paralympics last summer. But she persevered in the freestyle, going on to become one of the competition’s breakout stars. When Arlen returned home to New Hampshire with four medals and a world record, Exeter threw her a parade.

headline: Wounded by Broken Memories
abstract: John Tiffany’s stunning production of Tennessee Williams’s “Glass Menagerie” promises to be the most revealing revival of a cornerstone classic for many a year to come.
lead_paragraph: How can something be this delicate and this strong, so elusive and yet so tenacious? That question radiates from John Tiffany’s stunning production of Tennessee Williams’s “Glass Menagerie,” which opened on Thursday night at the Booth Theater and promises to be the most revealing revival of a cornerstone classic for many a year to come.

headline: Begin and End
abstract: Friday fun with Peter A. Collins.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — It’s not often that we see a Friday puzzle with a theme, even a mini-theme. Sometimes the constructor, say, Peter A. Collins, for example, goes in with the intention of giving the solver something extra to find, and sometimes unearthing a mini-theme is just serendipity. And the collective minds of the constructor, Will Shortz and Frank Longo, who helps Will with some of the grid fixes.

headline: On Governors Island, 30 Acres of Open Space Are Becoming a True Park
abstract: This weekend visitors will be able to get a preview of the park which includes a grove of hammocks, two ball fields, a formal garden and play areas.
lead_paragraph: As one strolls through the 30-acre park now taking shape on Governors Island, the face of the Statue of Liberty keeps peeking over a newly made knoll or poking through a recently planted grove of trees.

headline: Giants’ Battered Line Faces a Tough Test
abstract: Over three games, the Kansas City Chiefs have recorded 15 sacks while the New York Giants have surrendered 11. The teams meet on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The Giants’ beleaguered offensive line will face a difficult task Sunday against a relentless Kansas City Chiefs defense that leads the N.F.L. with 15 sacks.

headline: Where Mets Go Deep
abstract: The Mets’ fantasy football league, which this year has 12 teams, builds relationships and allows players to stay in touch in the off-season, when the trash-talking generally picks up.
lead_paragraph: The Mets held the annual draft for their fantasy football league a few weeks ago, after a day game in Atlanta. Participants gathered at the team hotel, ordered food and placed a big draft board at the front of the room. One by one, each team went up, announced its pick and placed a sticker with the pick’s name on the board. It was an ordeal, and now the board is on display in the team’s training room.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Friday, September 27, 2013
abstract: Quotation of the day for Friday, September 27, 2013.
lead_paragraph: “He had no friends, and no job, and my parents said let’s give him a second chance.”

headline: Closing Scene: Hugs and Tears in Rivera’s Last Home Game
abstract: Mariano Rivera made a memorable and emotional farewell appearance at Yankee Stadium, breaking down in tears on the mound in the embrace of Andy Pettitte.
lead_paragraph: It was supposed to be a meaningless game, the first at Yankee Stadium in 20 years, but there was nothing meaningless about it for Mariano Rivera or the announced crowd of 48,675 that came to say goodbye to an icon.

headline: Wright, Week After Returning, Is Hit in the Helmet by a Pitch
abstract: David Wright, plunked by a changeup from the Brewers’ Johnny Hellweg in the third inning, got up and walked off on his own, but was removed from the game as a precaution.
lead_paragraph: The Mets could not have imagined a scarier sight: a pitch thrown up and in, hurtling toward David Wright’s head. In the third inning Thursday night, in the first game of the last series of the season, Wright was plunked in the helmet with a changeup.

headline: When It Comes to Brows, Thin Is Not In
abstract: Say goodbye to overly pruned, barely-there crescents, and hello to a fuller look that is more natural and more discreetly groomed.
lead_paragraph: After years of manicured arches, eyebrows are making a thicker, fuller, more discreetly groomed return to their natural state.

headline: A Health Care Fight That Punishes Federal Workers
keywords: ['Government Employees', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The Affordable Care Act was not intended to deny a employer contribution to Congressional employees’ health coverage, and accusations that Congress is acting hypocritically in sponsoring such coverage are unfounded, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Updated | to clarify the contentions of critics about the law’s application to Congressional staff members, and with a postscript correcting the legislative history of the Grassley amendment.

headline: Ask Well: Is It Safe to Eat Soy?
abstract: Concerns have been raised about possible health risks from eating soy. Anahad O’Connor responds.
lead_paragraph: Question:

headline: Jack Ma to Join Tech Moguls in Backing Medical Research Prize
abstract: Jack Ma, the executive chairman of the Internet giant Alibaba, and his wife, Cathy Zhang, are joining some of Silicon Valley’s biggest names as sponsors of the world’s richest prize for medicine and biology.
lead_paragraph: Yuri Milner, the Russian entrepreneur and investor, attracted some of Silicon Valley’s biggest names to join him in starting a life sciences prize this year. Now, he has wooed a titan from China: Jack Ma.

headline: U.S. and Turkey to Create Fund to Stem Extremism
abstract: The $200 million fund aims to undercut the ideological and recruiting appeal of jihadists in places like Somalia, Yemen and Pakistan, State Department officials said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States and Turkey on Friday will announce the creation of a $200 million fund to combat violent extremism by undercutting the ideological and recruiting appeal of jihadists in places like Somalia, Yemen and Pakistan, State Department officials said Thursday.

headline: Word of the Day | doff
abstract: This word has appeared in 13 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: doff •\ˈdäf, ˈdȯf\• verb

headline: 3 Days, 3 Teams: A.L. Wild-Card Race Stays Tough
abstract: On a night when Mariano Rivera created a lot of teary eyes across baseball, the three American League wild-card contenders didn’t blink.
lead_paragraph: On a night when Mariano Rivera created a lot of teary eyes across baseball, the three American League wild-card contenders didn’t blink. Well, the Indians almost did, but we’ll get to that in a moment.

headline: Last Call at Yankee Stadium
abstract: Mariano Rivera pitched one and a third innings at Yankee Stadium in front of a huge crowd, with many of the fans attending specifically to say goodbye.
lead_paragraph: Mariano Rivera pitched one and a third innings at Yankee Stadium in front of a huge crowd, with many of the fans attending specifically to say goodbye.

headline: What’s on Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (Fox) MASTERCHEF JUNIOR Twenty-four budding chefs, ages 8 to 13, face the fiery Gordon Ramsay and his colleagues Joe Bastianich and Graham Elliot for a chance to win $100,000 and the title in this “MasterChef” spinoff. (Above, Mr. Ramsay with a contestant.) The competition begins as the youngsters concoct their best seafood, pasta and dessert dishes, after which the 12 most impressive will earn a white “MasterChef” apron and advance to the finals, where challenges involve cupcakes, beef Wellington and a restaurant takeover.

headline: News Quiz | September 27, 2013
abstract: See what you know about the news of the day.
lead_paragraph: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page. Good luck!

headline: Alibaba Chastises Hong Kong Exchange
abstract: A top executive at the company, which bypassed Hong Kong for its possible I.P.O., says the Asian exchange is in danger of being overtaken by other markets.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Alibaba, the Chinese Internet company whose potential initial public offering is one of the most fervently awaited in the world, has fired back at Hong Kong’s exchange, saying its stance on Alibaba’s unusual management structure puts the exchange at risk of being overtaken by the rest of the world.

headline: Editors’ Note: September 27, 2013
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on September 27, 2013
lead_paragraph: The On Religion column on Saturday examined the crisis of faith of a minister, Teresa MacBain, who resigned her pulpit after concluding that she no longer believed in God. After the article was published, questions were raised about her educational background. Although her résumé says she earned a master of divinity degree from Duke University, she now acknowledges that she received no degree from Duke.

headline: U.N. Climate Panel Endorses Ceiling on Global Emissions
abstract: Top climate scientists on Friday embraced an upper limit on greenhouse gases while warning that it is likely to be exceeded within decades if efforts to curb emissions are not rapidly accelerated.
lead_paragraph: STOCKHOLM — The world’s top climate scientists on Friday formally embraced an upper limit on greenhouse gases for the first time, establishing a target level at which humanity must stop spewing them into the atmosphere or face irreversible climatic changes. They warned that the target is likely to be exceeded in a matter of decades unless steps are taken soon to reduce emissions.

headline: Scores Feared Trapped in Collapse of Mumbai Building
abstract: A five-story residential building fell early Friday morning in the Indian city, where many structures are visibly crumbling.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — Scores of people were feared trapped or dead after a five-story residential building collapsed early Friday morning, the fifth deadly collapse this year in and around Mumbai, a city with crumbling housing infrastructure and poor building standards. At least 11 people were confirmed dead.

headline: Test Yourself | Editing Practice, Sept. 27, 2013
abstract: Can you put the sentences from the article in the correct order?
lead_paragraph: Take the Quiz

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Giant Sinkhole Continues to Grow, Unsettling a Small Town
abstract: Watch the video above showing the destructive power of a giant sinkhole in Bayou Corne, La. What is your reaction? How would you feel if you lived there or nearby?
lead_paragraph: In “Ground Gives Way, and a Louisiana Town Struggles to Find Its Footing,” Michael Wines writes about a giant sinkhole and the worry it is causing nearby residents.

headline: Valerie Plame Is the Master of Her Own Universe
abstract: The former C.I.A. officer created a “younger, smarter” version of herself in the spy novel “Blowback.”
lead_paragraph: You’re publishing a book this month called “Blowback,” a spy novel written with Sarah Lovett. Why fiction?  I’ve always been really dismayed at how female C.I.A. officers were portrayed in fiction. They’re always these cartoonish, cardboard characters, big on sexuality, big on gunplay. I wanted to depict something more realistic but still entertaining.

headline: Do Schools Provide Students With Enough Opportunities to Be Creative?
abstract: How often does your school encourage you to do something creative? To design, invent and imagine new ideas? Tell us about a creative activity or project you have worked on.
lead_paragraph: With the increasing pressure on schools to prepare students for high-stakes tests, and a growing dependence on Google and gadgetry for quick answers, is creativity endangered?

headline: Elliott Erwitt, Coloring Outside the Lines
abstract: On the occasion of the release of a new, huge collection of his color work, the Magnum photographer Elliott Erwitt sat down with his photographer son to discuss Kodachrome film, Marilyn Monroe and coaxing horses into hotel rooms.
lead_paragraph: “Elliott Erwitt’s Kolor,” a weighty and lavish collection of the photographer’s color work dating back to the 1950s, mostly on Kodachrome but also some Ektachrome, is being published by teNeues this month in Germany and next month in the United States.

headline: British Postal Service Valued at $5.3 Billion in I.P.O.
abstract: Royal Mail, Britain’s 360-year-old postal service, is to be valued as much as $5.3 billion in its initial public share sale scheduled for next month, the government said on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Royal Mail, Britain’s 360-year-old postal service, could be worth as much as $5.3 billion, based on the value of its initial public share sale scheduled for next month, the government said on Friday.

headline: New York Today: Baby Boom
abstract: What you need to know for Friday and the weekend: a time to be born, plenty of sunshine and an Interceltic Fest-Noz alert.
lead_paragraph: Updated 12:20 p.m. | If the air seems to be filled with the cries of newborns lately, it’s not your imagination.

abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: Shutdown Looms as Senate Passes Budget Bill
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: After a series of Senate votes that sent the stopgap spending measure back to the House, fissures appeared in the badly divided Republican ranks.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate on Friday approved stopgap spending legislation to keep the federal government open without gutting President Obama’s health care law, putting new pressure on Speaker John A. Boehner to find a way out of an impasse that had the government on a steady course to a shutdown at midnight Monday.

headline: Week 4 N.F.L. Matchups
abstract: Arizona has a veteran quarterback, Carson Palmer, to get the ball to wide receiver Larry Fitzgerald. Tampa Bay has a revamped secondary that should hamper the Cardinals’ passing attack.
lead_paragraph: Cardinals (1-2) at Buccaneers (0-3)

headline: How an Internal Combustion Engine Works
abstract: If you don’t know how the engines in most cars and trucks work, there is an animated infographic does a pretty good job of explaining it.
lead_paragraph: As automotive technology becomes more diverse, it’s good to reflect on the technology most of us rely upon. Although cars powered by hydrogen fuel cells, electric motors and whatever else anyone can dream up are certainly something we should take note of, most car owners rely up the same four-stroke internal combustion piston engines that have been in use for well over a century.

headline: Beats Gets Infusion of Capital From Carlyle Group
keywords: ['Headphones and Headsets', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Private Equity', 'Speakers (Audio)']
abstract: The company, known for its headphones, is said to be receiving $500 million from the private equity firm, which will take two seats on the Beats board. Beats also cut ties with HTC.
lead_paragraph: Beats Electronics has already drawn in huge numbers of fans of its colorful, expensive headphones. Now, the audio company, founded by the music impresarios Dr. Dre and Jimmy Iovine, has attracted the support of a top private equity firm.

headline: Bus Bombing in Pakistan Kills at Least 17 Government Employees
abstract: The bombing, which left more than 40 people wounded, was the second major attack in a week in the Peshawar area in northwestern Pakistan.
lead_paragraph: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — A bomb exploded on a crowded bus carrying government officials north of Peshawar on Friday, killing 17 people and wounding more than 40 in the second major attack in or near the northwestern Pakistani city in a week.

headline: Making Their Vows, Without a Stamp of Approval
keywords: ['Marriages', 'Baby Boomers', 'Camps and Camping', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: Ray and Kathleen Quinn married in 1967 against her parents’ wishes and stayed together even when they were getting  “a hard dose of life.”
lead_paragraph: Booming’s “Making It Last” column profiles baby boomer couples who have been together 25 years or more. Send us your story and photos through our submission form.

headline: Obtaining a Loan From Lenders Who Review Your Tweets Along With Your Books
abstract: Kabbage, a lender based in Atlanta, looks at information that a traditional banker would not consider, including social media metrics.
lead_paragraph: Last year, after being denied a traditional loan, Mitch Rezman, founder of Windy City Parrot, decided to apply for a line of credit with an alternative lender, Kabbage, that says it considers a business’s social media contacts when making a loan.

headline: Feeling For | The Enduring Appeal of the Patagonia Fleece
abstract: The California sportswear brand has enjoyed a resurgence of popularity among the fashion set simply by sticking to its utilitarian roots.
lead_paragraph: The more Patagonia remains the same, the more cool it becomes.

headline: A Predicament of the Mainstream
abstract: Religious intolerance is no longer the preserve of extremist groups in Pakistan. It is endemic throughout the country.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — On Sunday, 85 people were killed and more than 100 wounded when two suicide bombers attacked worshipers leaving mass at the All Saints Church in Peshawar, in northwestern Pakistan. The attack was the largest to date against Pakistan’s Christian minority, which comprises less than 2 percent of the population.

headline: Residential Building Collapses in Mumbai
abstract: The scene Friday was a chaotic pile of broken steel and concrete rubble, with more than two dozen fire trucks and at least 15 ambulances on the streets.
lead_paragraph: The scene Friday was a chaotic pile of broken steel and concrete rubble, with more than two dozen fire trucks and at least 15 ambulances on the streets.

headline: K.K.R. to Buy Panasonic Health Care Unit for $1.67 Billion
abstract: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts has agreed to buy the health care unit of Panasonic for 165 billion yen, or $1.67 billion, as the Japanese company attempts to streamline its operations after two years of steep losses.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Kohlberg Kravis Roberts agreed on Friday to buy the health care unit of Panasonic for 165 billion yen, or $1.67 billion, as the Japanese company tries to streamline its operations after two years of steep losses.

headline: BlackBerry’s Future in Doubt, Keyboard Lovers Bemoan Their Own
abstract: BlackBerry could soon be leaving the phone business, which is worrying its loyal users who have refused to give up its devices and their tiny buttons for touch-screen models.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — What is a BlackBerry user to do?

headline: ‘Breaking Bad': Your Series Finale Predictions
abstract: We asked readers to predict on Twitter how they believed the five-season run of “Breaking Bad” would come to an end. It turns out that a lot of theories can be packed into 140 characters, especially when so many of them boil down to two simple words: “Everyone dies.”
lead_paragraph: It is an understatement to say that this post contains spoilers. So consider yourself alerted if you haven’t been binge-watching your way through AMC’s “Breaking Bad” in preparation for the show’s final episode on Sunday night, when  millions of fans  are expected to tune in and view it in real time.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Hashtag Live, and a Gushing Example of Google Fiber
abstract: Thursday’s highlights from around the include Jimmy Fallon and Justin Timberlake talking in hashtags. Plus, the city of Provo, UT., promotes the new high-speed Google Fiber Internet service to its residents in an unconventional way.
lead_paragraph: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: Daily Report: Buying Out HTC’s Stake, Beats Secures Investment From Carlyle
abstract: Beats Electronics said that it has secured a minority investment from the Carlyle Group for $500 million and that it will buy back the 25 percent stake in itself held by HTC, the Taiwanese smartphone company.
lead_paragraph: Beats Electronics, the audio company, founded by music impresarios Dr. Dre and Jimmy Iovine, has attracted the support of a top private equity firm, Michael De La Merced reports for DealBook.

abstract: Beats Electronics has attracted the support of the Carlyle Group. | Authorities urged JPMorgan Chase to raise its offer in a multibillion-dollar settlement over its mortgage practices. | Amid mounting concerns, J.C. Penney said it planned to raise cash in a stock offering. | Chrysler’s own chief executive is trying to sabotage the company’s initial public offering.

abstract: The New York Times film critics on “Metallica Through the Never,” “Muscle Shoals” and “Don Jon.”

headline: Rahul Gandhi Opposes Ordinance Seeking to Protect Convicted Lawmakers
abstract: Rahul Gandhi, Congress Party’s vice president, opposes an ordinance seeking reprieve for convicted lawmakers prepared by India’s governing coalition led by his party.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI— An ordinance prepared by India’s governing coalition to allow Indian lawmakers convicted of a crime to contest election while appeals against their conviction are pending in higher courts received a serious political setback Friday afternoon.

headline: Daily Report: BlackBerry Reports Nearly $1 Billion Quarterly Loss
abstract: Facing an uncertain future and a highly conditional takeover bid, BlackBerry said on Friday that it lost $965 million on sales of $1.6 billion during its fiscal second quarter.
lead_paragraph: Facing an uncertain future and a highly conditional takeover bid, BlackBerry said on Friday that it lost $965 million on sales of $1.6 billion during its fiscal second quarter, Ian Austen reports.

abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: South Korea Returns to Fighter Jet Conundrum
abstract: After deciding against Boeing's F-15 Silent Eagle for its next generation of fighter jets, South Korea is restarting the tender process.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL — After South Korea decided this week that Boeing’s F-15 Silent Eagle was not good enough for its next generation of fighter jets, the country returned to the quandary it has been grappling with for the past two years.

headline: In Store | A New York Flagship for the Maker of the Ultimate American Motorcycle Jacket
abstract: To celebrate its centennial, Schott NYC — manufacturer of the Perfecto, worn by everyone from James Dean to Lady Gaga — is opening a store and staging a special exhibit.
lead_paragraph: The Perfecto, a zippered leather motorcycle jacket with a distinctive single star stud on each epaulet (it is sometimes referred to as the “One Star”), might be the most iconic piece of American outerwear there is. Bruce Springsteen, the Ramones, Andy Warhol, the Beastie Boys and Lady Gaga have all worn the jacket, which was invented by the American outerwear manufacturer Schott NYC. James Dean wore his everywhere, helping get the jacket banned in some American high schools for its rebellious connotations. But nobody is more identified with the garment than Marlon Brando, who paired his with faded Levi’s and a scowl in “The Wild One.”

headline: What I Love | Peter Asher
abstract: The New York home of the ’60s pop-star-turned-record-producer is a sleek Midtown pied-à-terre.
lead_paragraph: The New York home of the ’60s pop-star-turned-record-producer is a sleek Midtown pied-à-terre.

headline: An Off-Road Retreat for a ’60s Pop Star
abstract: Peter Asher, the ’60s pop-star-turned-record-producer, filled his Manhattan home with books and decorated with lots of red.
lead_paragraph: Peter Asher smiled beatifically as he sat in the sleek living room of his Midtown pied-à-terre, and flashed back almost 50 years to his very first trip to the United States. It involved a gig at the 1964 World’s Fair when he was half of the mop-topped British pop duo Peter and Gordon. Mr. Asher was — and is — the pixieish one with the glasses and the carrot-colored hair.

abstract: Metropolitan Diary: Asked by a prospective tenant, a man described the many sounds coming into his office from the theater district.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:
