abstract: One of Asia’s premier banking, trading and logistics centers is a difficult place for low-income residents to live.
lead_paragraph: One of Asia’s premier banking, trading and logistics centers is a difficult place for low-income residents to live.

headline: Have-Nots Squeezed and Stacked in Hong Kong
keywords: ['Poverty', 'Affordable Housing', 'Public and Subsidized Housing', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: In a city with some of the highest living costs in the world, those at the bottom of the income ladder increasingly resort to cupboardlike living spaces, a dozen or more to an apartment.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — On the first floor of a hulking residential building, at the end of a dimly lighted corridor, a narrow door opens up into Hong Kong’s economic underbelly.

headline: U.N. Rights Panel Increases Pressure on Syria
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: The Human Rights Council on Friday stepped up pressure on President Bashar al-Assad to allow greater access for humanitarian aid and for war crimes investigators.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — As the United Nations Security Council moved toward a resolution enforcing the destruction of Syria’s chemical weapons arsenal, the Human Rights Council stepped up pressure Friday on President Bashar al-Assad to allow greater access for humanitarian aid and for war crimes investigators.

headline: The Cunning Plot of the Rt. Honorable Saboteur
abstract: Austerity: It feels so good when you stop.
lead_paragraph: Once upon a time there was a government official with a plan. He had become convinced that the way to fix the economy was to send out teams of saboteurs, who would systematically disrupt production around the country. Why did he believe this? Never mind; for some reason it was what all the Very Serious People were saying.

headline: A Stranger on Lenox Avenue
keywords: ['Discrimination', 'Hate Crimes', 'Minorities', 'Muslim-Americans', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Sikhs and Sikhism']
abstract: The attack on Prabhjot Singh, an assistant professor at Columbia University, is jarring because Harlem has a deep history of solidarity between various communities.
lead_paragraph: On the evening of Sept. 21, Prabhjot Singh, an assistant professor in the International and Public Affairs program at Columbia University in New York and the co-director of a community health care program in Harlem, was walking near his house in Harlem. Mr. Singh is a Sikh man of Indian origin and wears a long flowing beard and a turban. Around 8 p.m., a group of young black men on bicycles confronted Mr. Singh on Lenox Avenue and shouted racist slurs at him, shouting, “get Osama” and “terrorist.” The young men proceeded to punch his face and upper body.

headline: Climate Panel’s Fifth Report Clarifies Humanity’s Choices
keywords: ['Environment', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'UNITED NATIONS', 'United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change']
abstract: The pace of global warming beyond 2050 is ours to choose, a new climate report says.
lead_paragraph: Updates below, 10:03 a.m. | To my eye, perhaps the most important line in the summary of the new report on global warming science from the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change is this:

headline: Germany As Currency Manipulator
abstract: Maybe I spoke too soon.
lead_paragraph: Update: And it was, in fact, Ian Fletcher. I’m not endorsing his overall views, but this was a good point.

headline: Janet Yellen’s Confirmation
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Glass-Steagall Act (1933)', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Quantitative Easing', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The prospective nominee to head the Federal Reserve is not a one-dimensional monetary dove, as some portray her, but has taken positions that cut across the partisan divide, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Phillip Swagel is a professor at the School of Public Policy at the University of Maryland and was assistant secretary for economic policy at the Treasury Department from 2006 to 2009.

headline: Video Reviews of ‘Don Jon,’ ‘Muscle Shoals’ and ‘Metallica Through the Never’
abstract: Times critics on “Metallica Through the Never,” “Muscle Shoals” and “Don Jon.”
lead_paragraph: In this week’s video, Times critics look at the music documentary “Muscle Shoals,” the concert movie-narrative hybrid “Metallica Through the Never” and Joseph Gordon-Levitt’s directorial debut “Don Jon.” See all of this week’s reviews.

headline: In Venice, a New Perfume Museum
abstract: The 18th-century palazzo will include galleries highlighting the city’s role in the origins of the perfume industry.
lead_paragraph: VENICE — Italy will have a new perfume museum on Nov. 1, when the Palazzo Mocenigo reopens after a 10-month renovation.

headline: A Move for the Essex Street Market
abstract: Plans call for the relocation of the city-run Essex Street Market from one side of Delancey Street, on the Lower East Side, to the other.
lead_paragraph: There’s a point at which even the most emphatic preservationist must acknowledge the indulgence of nostalgia. Not every building is in every instance worth saving; not every vanished way of life is worth enshrining. If you believe that cities ought to maximize their options for affordable living space rather than accommodate the best-off, then arguments for keeping things as they are often remain incompatible with arguments for how things ought to be. And yet, mourning is so often the reflex that overcomes us, whenever we hear that a certain patch of land in New York will dramatically alter, a certain structure will go to dust.

headline: Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change Report Summary
abstract: The panel of experts unveiled its latest assessment of climate research, reinforcing its earlier conclusions that global warming is real and that it is caused primarily if not exclusively by man-made emissions.
lead_paragraph: The panel of experts unveiled its latest assessment of climate research, reinforcing its earlier conclusions that global warming is real and that it is caused primarily if not exclusively by man-made emissions.

headline: R.B.S. to Sell Stake in Bank Branch Network
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Initial Public Offerings', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: The Royal Bank of Scotland agreed on Friday to sell a stake in its branch network for £600 million, or $966 million, to a consortium of investors led by Corsair Capital and Centrebridge Partners.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The Royal Bank of Scotland agreed on Friday to sell a stake in its branch network for £600 million, or $966 million, to a consortium of investors led by Corsair Capital and Centerbridge Partners.

headline: The Gun Report: September 27, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: “I’m the type of person who would not be questioned when purchasing a firearm in America,” Afghan vet Jay Kirell wrote in an essay last week entitled “Take my Guns, Please.” “I’m white. I’m male. I’m educated. I’m an honorably discharged military veteran.”

headline: Real Estate Q & A
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Condominiums', 'Electric Light and Power']
abstract: Topics include disclosure of shareholders who are in arrears; when rent includes electricity; and condo boards that fail to have annual meetings.
lead_paragraph: Exposing Shareholders in Arrears

headline: Moncler Party Brings the Editors
abstract: Thursday night was a big party night for Paris Fashion Week, and the multitudes of editors made their way through St.-Germain from the Lanvin show to the Moncler dinner.
lead_paragraph: Thursday night was a big party night for Paris Fashion Week, and the multitudes of editors made their way through St.-Germain from the Lanvin show to the Moncler dinner in hopes of finding a morsel of food: An hors d’oeuvre. An amuse-bouche. Anything! This is France!

headline: In Culture Shift, Evangelical College Lifts Alcohol Ban
keywords: ['Evangelical Movement', 'ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Christians and Christianity']
abstract: The new policy is symbolic of a shift in evangelical attitudes away from teetotaling and the theological desirability of strict systems of rules.
lead_paragraph: Last Saturday, Michael McDuffee had his first beer since 1994. It was a cold beer, refreshing. It was a long time coming.

headline: In Ratings War, ‘G.M.A.’ Beats ‘Today’ for Full Season
abstract: According to the final viewership figures for the 2012-13 season, “Good Morning America” on ABC has taken a decisive lead among total viewers.
lead_paragraph: As he pushed “Good Morning America” through a heated ratings competition with NBC’s “Today” show, Ben Sherwood, the president of ABC News, had three goals: first, to win just one week; second, to win one of the television industry’s so-called sweeps months; and third, to win for a full television season. He called it “the trifecta” in conversations with colleagues.

headline: Judging an Actor by His Cover
abstract: James Franco’s appearance on the cover of a William Faulkner novel set off a brief flurry of sarcasm and outrage online.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps it was audacious of James Franco to co-write, direct and star in an adaptation of William Faulkner’s fractured classic “As I Lay Dying.” But Franco’s real gumption, it seems, came when he appeared alone on the cover of the movie tie-in edition of the book. The Time Out New York film critic Keith Uhlich brought the cover to wide attention on Twitter, where he posted an exasperated expletive along with a photo of the book and his own agonized, palm-covered face. Nearly 350 people retweeted Uhlich’s image, one of them writing: “At least they didn’t change the title to ‘As I, James Franco, Lay Dying.’ ”

headline: Debut Novels
abstract: New books by Ethan Hauser, John Van Kirk, Sarah Bruni and Koren Zailckas.
lead_paragraph: THE MEASURES BETWEEN USBy Ethan Hauser  Bloomsbury, $26.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Nicholas Sparks, whose “Longest Ride” enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 1, is receiving help promoting the book from professional bull riders.
lead_paragraph: Captain Kleenex: If you had to guess which novelist would be first to team up with the P.B.R. — that’s Professional Bull Riders Inc., as if you didn’t know — you might not put your money on Nicholas Sparks. The best-selling author of Hollywood-friendly love stories like “The Notebook” and “Message in a Bottle,” Sparks is so reliable a tear-jerker that one Irish newspaper reviewed his latest book under the evergreen headline “A New Weepie From Captain Kleenex.” But the book in question, “The Longest Ride” — which enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 1 — happens to feature a cowboy in one of its two romantic plotlines: “Bull riders,” a character realizes early on, “oozed sex appeal.” So this summer the P.B.R. announced a cross-marketing effort to promote both the book and the sport. “Nick did an awesome, awesome job,” Ellen Newberg, the group’s vice president of event marketing, told me. “The depiction of professional bull riding and, clearly, the amount of research he did, it’s amazing. The story is very relatable to what actually happens on the tour.”

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: DOCTOR SLEEP,  by Stephen King. (Scribner, $30.) Now grown up, Danny, the boy with psycho-intuitive powers in “The Shining,” helps another threatened magic child in a novel that shares the virtues of King’s best work.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: SPILLOVER: Animal Infections and the Next Human Pandemic,  by David Quammen. (Norton, $16.95.) Sixty percent of the infections that plague humankind — influenza, H.I.V. and Lyme disease, to name a few — are “zoonoses,” which jump from wildlife to humans. Quammen’s sprawling scientific adventure tracks these diseases from the jungles of Central Africa to the rooftops of Bangladesh and the caves of southern China, and warns that such crossovers are bound to occur with more frequency, and possibly greater virulence.

headline: Family Compounds, by Elevator
keywords: ['Families and Family Life', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Grandparents']
abstract: Its expensive in New York City, but a lucky few are building multigenerational compounds in the sky.
lead_paragraph: Some parents dream of owning a home where their adult children and grandchildren also can live. For those with the means, that translates into a family compound, with several generations living in their own houses within the same property line. But here in New York City, creating such expansive homes can be prohibitively expensive. Nevertheless, a lucky few are building multigenerational compounds in the sky.

headline: Young Catcher Can Help Tell Ending to Rivera’s Story
abstract: Mariano Rivera’s goodbye to home fans was especially memorable for J. R. Murphy, 22, who caught the closer’s last pitches at Yankee Stadium.
lead_paragraph: The young man who caught Mariano Rivera’s final pitches at Yankee Stadium was born the year after Rivera made his debut in the minor leagues. John Ryan Murphy, known as J. R., No. 66 in your Yankees program, grew up a Red Sox fan in Bradenton, Fla., though he came of rooting age when the Yankees and Rivera owned major league baseball.

headline: TV Talk: The Fall Season
abstract: Bill Carter and Brian Stelter, reporters at The New York Times, assess the latest offerings by television networks to score primetime hits in the fall season.
lead_paragraph: Bill Carter and Brian Stelter, reporters at The New York Times, assess the latest offerings by television networks to score primetime hits in the fall season.

headline: Burden of Proofing
abstract: In Jane O’Connor’s novel, a copy editor turns to detective work.
lead_paragraph: Will nobody cut Rannie Bookman some slack? Her mother constantly judges her. (“Your sisters never find dead bodies!”) Her teenage son, Nate, is just as faultfinding. (“What are you, some kind of corpse magnet?”) Even Rannie’s new lover, a strapping ex-cop named Tim, has the nerve to tell her how to live her life. (“You’re not Nancy Drew. You’re a copy editor. Stick to that.”) How dare they all rebuke her! Then again, might they have a point? There’s a coldblooded killer on the loose in Manhattan, a criminal who’s fed up with Rannie’s meddling ways and whose criticism may come at the edge of a knife. If she doesn’t watch it, curiosity just might kill the copy editor.

headline: Senior Moments
abstract: Manhattan hospital patients are “catching” dementia in Lore Segal’s novel.
lead_paragraph: In “Lucinella,” an eccentric little novel published in 1976, Lore Segal’s title character, a writer, confesses: “I’m no good at plotting. What I love is to get right down to the excruciations.”

headline: Bitter Fruit
abstract: In Hanya Yanagihara’s novel, a scientist discovers the secret of immortality.
lead_paragraph: In 1976, Dr. D. Carleton Gajdusek won a Nobel Prize for identifying a fatal disease in a remote tribe in Papua New Guinea. By the time of his death in 2008, Gajdusek had achieved another kind of notoriety, having been imprisoned for sexually abusing one of the dozens of native children he had adopted. Hanya Yanagihara’s suspenseful first novel, “The People in the Trees,” is based loosely on this true story, with a number of horrifying twists. From the start, she sets her narrative dial to creepy, and challenges to the extreme the notion that a protagonist needs to be “likable.” Yet thanks to her rich, masterly prose, it’s hard to turn away from Dr. Norton Perina, her antihero inspired by Gajdusek. Some might say he’s a sociopath, and not even the charming kind (see Tom Ripley).

headline: Crosscurrents
abstract: Sunil S. Amrith examines the impact of the Bay of Bengal on the diversity of the region.
lead_paragraph: A few miles up the road from my home, on a sandy beach in the Indian state of Tamil Nadu, there is a crumbling fort that extends into the Bay of Bengal. The fort was built in the 17th century; over the years, it has been controlled by Mughal rulers from the north, by the French and by the British. Farther down the coast, past a string of fishing villages, sits the former French colony of Pondicherry, its wide boulevards and elegant villas overlooking the shimmering waters of the bay. A few miles away is an ancient Roman trading outpost. And two and a half hours beyond sits the former Danish port town of Tranquebar, its yellow fort blending into the sand, its rusty cannons pointing at the ocean.

headline: A Sea Lion Cuts A Rug
abstract: Fine rum and chocolate, mmm. Conan the Barbarian vs. Conan O’Brien.
lead_paragraph: Fine rum and chocolate, mmm. Conan the Barbarian vs. Conan O’Brien.

headline: The 9.15.13 Issue
abstract: Readers respond.

headline: The Apocalypse Market Is Booming
abstract: It’s the end of the world as we know it. (And we feel fine.)
lead_paragraph: When I was a kid, one of my first literary obsessions was the 1953 sci-fi classic “Childhood’s End,” by Arthur C. Clarke. As the novel opens, a race of aliens called the Overlords has appeared. Rather than decimating humankind, they foster unprecedented peace and prosperity. Only decades later does their true purpose emerge: to recruit Earth’s children into a single cosmic entity called the Overmind, which represents the summed consciousness of all the civilizations in the universe. What begins as a utopian collaboration ends with the planet itself evaporating in a pulse of light.

headline: Correcting the Crackpot Next Door
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Ethics (Personal)', 'Ethicist, The (Times Column)', 'Science and Technology']
abstract: Candid; branded.
lead_paragraph: I frequently encounter scientific evidence misused and misinterpreted to advance ideological viewpoints. As a scientist, what is my ethical obligation to confront pseudoscience and antiscience attitudes? Is there a difference in how I should engage relatives, co-workers or the Internet community? AMY HENRY, CHICAGO

headline: Two-Wheeled Greek Chorus
abstract: Tragedy transforms a stock character into a fully realized one.
lead_paragraph: I called her the “anorexic biker.” My sisters and I didn’t know the woman’s name, but for years we saw her riding on our streetin Washington: grinding up the hill past our house, then coasting down to Massachusetts Avenue, then beginning the same climb again. She would go up and down our street for at least an hour every day. She was out there in all kinds of weather, always wearing headphones and a backpack, often chewing gum.

headline: Paradise, Paved
abstract: Who wants to spend the night in a Walmart parking lot?
lead_paragraph: Who wants to spend the night in a Walmart parking lot?

headline: Who Made Speed Dating?
abstract: Plus: Which New York City ZIP codes give singles the best odds.
lead_paragraph: At a matchmaking event he organized in 1998, Rabbi Yaacov Deyo brought along a gragger, the noisemaker Jews use during Purim. That night, in a Peet’s Coffee & Tea in Beverly Hills, the Orthodox rabbi twirled his gragger to signal when it was time for the single men and women present to switch partners and spark up a conversation with the next stranger. “We thought 10 minutes for each date, because that was just an easier number to use in a busy coffeehouse,” Deyo says. This entirely practical measure would inspire matchmakers all around the world — Jews and Gentiles alike.

headline: Collateral Damage
abstract: Promoting their opening to China, Richard Nixon and Henry Kissinger countenanced mayhem in South Asia.
lead_paragraph: In the 40-odd years that America and the Soviet Union faced off in the cold war, the people who presumed to run the world started with the knowledge that it was too dangerous, and possibly even suicidal, to attack one another. But the struggle was fierce, and what that meant in practice was that the competition played out in impoverished places like Cuba and Angola, where the great statesmen vied, eyed and subverted one another, and sometimes loosed their local proxies, all in the name of maintaining the slippery but all-important concept known as the balance of power.

headline: Sins of the Brothers
abstract: In Jhumpa Lahiri’s novel, the consequences of siblings’ actions reverberate for decades.
lead_paragraph: The personal is political, the countercultural upheavals of the ’60s claimed, but in Jhumpa Lahiri’s new novel, “The Lowland,” which takes its inspiration from an Indian variant of that upheaval, it is the political that is always personal. Udayan, the younger of two brothers in the eastern Indian city of Calcutta (now Kolkata), gets drawn into a radical left movement called Naxalism, its name derived from Naxalbari, a tiny village to the north of Calcutta where impoverished peasants rose up against the police and landlords in 1967, sparking off dreams of a nationwide insurgency that would replicate Mao’s earlier revolution in China. But Udayan is killed by the police, and his older brother, Subhash, apolitical, passive, but responsible, returns home from graduate school in the United States to console his parents. Finding himself confronted with his brother’s pregnant widow, Gauri, and her ill treatment by his grieving parents, Subhash marries her and brings her to Rhode Island. Gauri gives birth to a girl, Bela, while also pursuing an academic career of her own in philosophy. By the end of the novel, when Bela is almost 40, the reader will have encountered four generations of this particular family.

headline: Fire and Ice
abstract: Hannah Kent’s novel explores murders that occurred in 1820s Scandinavia.
lead_paragraph: In 1828, an Icelandic servant named Agnes Magnusdottir was convicted of killing her employer and another man, then burning their bodies. Pending ratification of her death sentence in Denmark, which then controlled Iceland, she was interned for many months on an isolated farm. Hannah Kent’s fictional take on this promising material was written, she explains in an author’s note, “to supply a more ambiguous portrayal” of a woman who has commonly been seen as a “witch, stirring up murder.”

headline: A Brutal Peace
abstract: Ian Buruma’s global history of the pivotal year 1945, when a new world emerged from the ruins of war.
lead_paragraph: All wars require a heroic narrative — to inspire soldiers to risk their lives and, afterward, to make them or their survivors feel they have not suffered or died in vain. Never has a heroic narrative been more durable than for the deadliest conflict of them all: World War II. It was the Good War, fought by the Greatest Generation, who bravely stopped Hitler, put the evildoers on trial at Nuremberg, restored democracy to a grateful Europe and brought it to a feudal Japan.

headline: Hey Kids, Let’s Put On a Show
abstract: How an inspired high school theater teacher in a troubled Pennsylvania town changed lives.
lead_paragraph: Many public schools across the country reopened this month hanging by fraying threads. With arts programs already slashed, staffs have been cut even further in cities from Los Angeles to Washington. Suburbs — long considered a haven from such scarcity — aren’t necessarily faring much better. And certainly not the once-model suburb of Levittown, which suffers the particularly bad fortune of being in Pennsylvania, where schools have been starved of late. There, as Michael Sokolove notes in his stirring chronicle of the flourishing drama program at a Levittown high school, Gov. Tom Corbett suggested that state colleges short on funds should drill on their campuses for natural gas.

headline: It Started in Naples
abstract: Two friends pursue divergent paths in Elena Ferrante’s novel.
lead_paragraph: Every so often you encounter an author so unusual it takes a while to make sense of her voice. The challenge is greater still when this writer’s freshness has nothing to do with fashion, when it’s imbued with the most haunting music of all, the echoes of literary history. Elena Ferrante is this rare bird: so deliberate in building up her story that you almost give up on it, so gifted that by the end she has you in tears.

headline: Skills Practice | Summarizing an Article
abstract: Use an article about the Yankees’ pitcher Mariano Rivera to practice summarizing, then move on to the Times article or section of your choice. This feature is still in the experimental phase, so let us know what you think.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Week 1 of our new Skills Practice series. Though we plan to work with the New Jersey teachers Jonathan Olsen and Sarah Gross and their students this year, just as we did last year, we’re still perfecting a format that works for both of their schools, so this edition is just an experiment. Please tell us what you think, below.

headline: Handling the Grandparents’ Unsolicited Parenting Advice
abstract: We got plenty of suggestions for handling the inevitable advice from new grandparents to new parents, from those who had survived with their relationships intact, and from those whose relationships with their parents and in-laws never recovered, and who are determined to do things differently.
lead_paragraph: Last Friday, in the New Parent, Old Parent collaboration between Motherlode and Booming, we posed the question: How Did You Handle Grandparents’ Unsolicited Parenting Advice?

headline: Ex-Bear Stearns Chief Questions JPMorgan’s Mortgage Deal
abstract: Alan D. Schwartz, the former chief of Bear Stearns when it collapsed in 2008 and was absorbed by JPMorgan Chase, told Andrew Ross Sorkin that a proposed $11 billion settlement with the Justice Department “doesn’t feel like it makes sense, but it makes good headlines.”
lead_paragraph: Alan D. Schwartz, the former chief of Bear Stearns when it collapsed in 2008 and was absorbed by JPMorgan Chase, told Andrew Ross Sorkin that a proposed $11 billion settlement with the Justice Department “doesn’t feel like it makes sense, but it makes good headlines.”

headline: Christian Dior: Spring 2014 RTW
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: In Belgium, a Museum About the People Who Left It
abstract: The Red Star Line Museum in Antwerp, Belgium, is focused on the people who sailed from the port city, including Albert Einstein and Golda Meir.
lead_paragraph: A museum that explores the topic of migration is scheduled to open in Antwerp, Belgium, on Saturday. The Red Star Line Museum, located in the former warehouses of the Red Star Line shipping company, tells the story of the company, now defunct, and of the people who sailed from the port city of Antwerp on its ships.

headline: What’s Also Under the Bridges
abstract: A roundup of events at the Dumbo Arts festival this weekend.
lead_paragraph: There’s more to the Dumbo Arts Festival than the Kabakovs and their “Ship of Tolerance.” A sampling:

headline: All That We Hold Dear
abstract: Dara Horn’s novel weaves stories from Genesis, medieval philosophy and the digital frontier.
lead_paragraph: In a recent New Yorker article about his time as a Google Glass Explorer, Gary Shteyngart discussed the challenge of setting a novel in the current moment, given the speed of social upheaval and technological advances. “To write a book set in the present, circa 2013,” he declared, “is to write about the distant past.” Dara Horn’s ambitious fourth novel, “A Guide for the Perplexed,” bears this exact burden: it is set partly in contemporary Egypt, post-­revolution, and much of its plot involves a technology not unlike Google Glass itself.

headline: Scientific Americans
abstract: Andrea Barrett’s stories are set near the turn of the 20th century, at moments of intellectual and historical change.
lead_paragraph: “You have turned your back on the common man, on their elementary needs and their restricted time and their intelligence,” H. G. Wells wrote in a 1928 letter to James Joyce, after reading sections of “Finnegans Wake.” “Do I get much pleasure from this work? No. Do I feel I am getting something new and illuminating as I do when I read . . . Pavlov’s badly written book on Conditioned Reflexes? No.” In other words, science involves new illuminations, messiness, even creative destruction, but literature is something else entirely: the common reader needs clarity, simplicity and a hopeful outlook, a sense that, in Wells’s words, progress is “not inevitable but interesting and possible.”

headline: Brogue States
abstract: Kevin Barry’s story collection borrows from the vernacular of his native Ireland.
lead_paragraph: The title story of Kevin Barry’s new collection records the thoughts of a teenage girl struggling against the urge to cut herself. Instead of working or traveling, as most Irish kids do on their “gap year” before college, Sara holes up alone in a country house built by her father, “a radical architect who had reinterrogated the concept of walls.” His cool-father texts are unhelpful, as is the fact that he pointedly left the designer knives in their block in the kitchen space.

headline: Writers’ Retreat
abstract: In Tim Finch’s Orwellian satire, a London sanctuary for persecuted journalists is shaken up by a new arrival.
lead_paragraph: Imagine an 18th-century London town house, once a fashionable address but recently home to successive huddled masses: Jewish refugees, Irish then Bangladeshi then Somali immigrants. Now fill that house with 30 foreign writers who have fled oppression and violence, all asylum seekers specially chosen for favored treatment. Call them “fellows.” Hang identity cards, with their mug shots petrified in plastic, around their necks. Appoint a chairman whose paranoia and megalomania recall, in madcap picayune, the dictators who tortured and imprisoned many of them. Outfit the house with security cameras that scan the corridors, the surveillance tapes complemented by the human watchfulness of ever-­solicitous volunteers. What you have is the premise for “The House of Journalists,” the former BBC reporter Tim Finch’s clever debut novel.

headline: Clinton Aides to Help in McAuliffe Fund-Raising Efforts
abstract: Friends of the Clintons are raising money for Terry McAuliffe, the Democratic candidate for governor in Virginia who is in a close race against the Republican Ken Cuccinelli.
lead_paragraph: Friends of Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton have come out of the woodwork to help raise money for Terry McAuliffe, the Democratic candidate for governor in Virginia who is close with the former president and served as chairman of Mrs. Clinton’s 2008 presidential campaign.

headline: Today in Small Business: Postal Arbitrage
abstract: America’s ‘toilet turnaround.’ The biggest start-up incubator in the world. And what percent of Yelp’s reviews do you think are fake?
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Joe on WNYC’s “Money Talking”: Sept. 27, 2013
abstract: Does JPMorgan’s $11 billion settlement to end its numerous investigations mark the last chapter in the story of the financial crisis?
lead_paragraph: Joe Nocera and Rana Foroohar of Time magazine join Charlie Herman on WNYC’s Money Talking to discuss JPMorgan’s possible $11 billion settlement to end numerous investigations into how the bank handled mortgage-backed securities. That’s more than what Google earned last year and more than two and a half times as much as BP paid to settle after the massive oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico. Is this the last chapter in the story of the financial crisis?

headline: Image of the Day: Sept. 27
abstract: Sania Mirza, Indian tennis player, in action during a women’s doubles match in Tokyo, Japan.

headline: F.T.C. Votes for Inquiry Into Patent Businesses
abstract: Edith Ramirez, the chairwoman of the Federal Trade Commission, said it would seek information on businesses whose main purpose was to sue other companies to collect patent royalties.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Stepping into a volatile debate in the technology sector, the Federal Trade Commission on Friday said it would use its subpoena power to begin an investigation of so-called patent trolls, businesses whose primary purpose is to stockpile patents and use them to sue other companies.

headline: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety Tests Crash Avoidance Systems
abstract: Ahead of N.H.T.S.A. and Euro N.C.A.P., I.I.H.S. has rated 74 cars equipped with crash avoidance features such as automatic braking and crash warning systems.
lead_paragraph: Until now consumers who bought frontal crash prevention systems – including forward collision warning and automatic braking – had to take the word of automakers that the systems did something besides pump up the price. But today the first ratings of 74 vehicles with such systems were released by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety, a group financed by the insurance industry.

headline: Crossword Contest Wrap Up and Winners
abstract: The results of the crossword contest based on Mike Selinker’s September 22 puzzle.
lead_paragraph: SPECIAL POST — More than 5,300 solvers sent answers to Mike Selinker’s “Letterboxes” crossword in last Sunday’s New York Times. As crossword contests go, this one wasn’t so hard. About 95% of the answers were correct.

headline: U.N. Investigates More Alleged Chemical Attacks in Syria
abstract: Inspectors were looking into reports that chemical weapons were used seven times, including three after the Aug. 21 attack that set off an international crisis.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — As the pace of efforts to scrutinize Syria’s chemical weapons stockpiles quickens, United Nations inspectors said on Friday that they were investigating reports that the weapons were used seven times in Syria, including three after an attack on Aug. 21 on the outskirts of Damascus, the Syrian capital, that set off an international crisis.

headline: Immigrant Influx Tests a Minneapolis Hospital
abstract: About 20 percent of Hennepin County Medical Center’s patients were born in other countries, and interpreters are called on to help more than 130,000 times a year.
lead_paragraph: About 20 percent of Hennepin County Medical Center’s patients were born in other countries, and interpreters are called on to help more than 130,000 times a year.

headline: On the Market in the Region
abstract: An expanded ranch in Manalapan, N.J., and a colonial in Old Greenwich, Conn.
lead_paragraph: An expanded ranch in Manalapan, N.J., and a colonial in Old Greenwich, Conn.

headline: Dior: Visual Feast in the Fashion Jungle
abstract: Raf Simons’s collection offered so many things to look at, from the cut of the shirt dresses, to the wisteria-like clumps of beaded necklaces, to the intense colors, to the new interpretation of Dior’s tailoring.
lead_paragraph: Imagination exhilarates, and that’s what Raf Simons of Dior does for the fashion industry. He did that in men’s wear for years. But now, after less than two years at Dior, he has everyone’s attention.

headline: What We Resist Persists
abstract: Acknowledging uncomfortable feelings can be viewed as self-indulgent, but unspoken tensions can take a toll in the workplace, the author writes.
lead_paragraph: A few days ago, it dawned on me that for the past several weeks I had been feeling vaguely anxious, uneasy and sad.

headline: Iris van Berne Transforms Backstage at Hussein Chalayan
abstract: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Spring 2014 Fashion Week in Paris.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Spring 2014 Fashion Week in Paris. Here, the model Iris van Berne before (left) and after (right) makeup by Aaron de Mey and hair by Anthony Turner.

headline: On the Market in New York City
abstract: A Chelsea studio; a duplex on the Upper West Side; and a Prospect Heights apartment with a terrace.
lead_paragraph: A Chelsea studio; a duplex on the Upper West Side; and a Prospect Heights apartment with a terrace.

headline: Pakistan, Citing Religious and Social Values, Bans L.G.B.T. Web Site
abstract: Access to the queerpk.com site was shut down inside the country by the authorities in Pakistan, where homosexuality is outlawed, though the banning has renewed attention on Pakistani gay and lesbian citizens.
lead_paragraph: The Queer Pakistan Web site was meant to be a virtual refuge for gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender people in a religiously conservative country where homosexuality is illegal.

headline: Japan’s Leader Gives No Ground in Islands Dispute
abstract: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan said he was open to dialogue with China about disputed islands in the South China Sea but that Japan owns them.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan on Friday rejected any concession in a standoff with China over a group of islands claimed by both countries, declining to even acknowledge that the islands are disputed.

headline: A Tussle Over Service Dogs
keywords: ['Service Dogs and Other Animals', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Discrimination', 'Disabilities']
abstract: Landlords and owners are faced with difficult decisions when considering medical waivers allowing dogs in no-pet buildings.
lead_paragraph: Landlords and owners are faced with difficult decisions when considering medical waivers allowing dogs in no-pet buildings.
