keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Service Dogs and Other Animals', 'Disabilities', 'Landlords', 'Discrimination', 'Dogs', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Cooperatives']
abstract:
Requests for waivers of no-pet rules on disability grounds
are on the upswing. This is creating St. Bernard-size
headaches for buildings.
lead_paragraph: What does it take to get a dog into a no-pet building?

headline: Is Health Care Reform Creating More Part-Time Work?
keywords: ['Part-Time Employment', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: No, but that hasn’t stopped Republicans from pretending that’s the case.
lead_paragraph: Republican critics of the Affordable Care Act often argue that the reform law has caused a big uptick in the number of part-time workers. The A.C.A. requires companies with 50 or more employees to provide health insurance to those working 30 hours or more a week, or pay a penalty. The theory spun by Republicans is that employers are maneuvering to escape that penalty by reducing the hours of most workers to below the 30 hour threshold. The critics say that’s why many job-seekers can’t find full-time work and many job holders are finding their hours reduced. As Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the Republican leader, said on the floor of the Senate recently, “Obamacare is a big reason we’re turning into a nation of part-time workers.”

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Ian Buruma’s ‘Year Zero’
abstract: This week, Ian Buruma discusses “Year Zero: A History of 1945”; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Diane Ravitch talks about “Reign of Error: The Hoax of the Privatization Movement and the Danger to America’s Public Schools”; Gary J. Bass on “The Blood Telegram: Nixon, Kissinger, and a Forgotten Genocide”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.
lead_paragraph: This week, Ian Buruma discusses “Year Zero: A History of 1945”; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Diane Ravitch talks about “Reign of Error: The Hoax of the Privatization Movement and the Danger to America’s Public Schools”; Gary J. Bass on “The Blood Telegram: Nixon, Kissinger, and a Forgotten Genocide”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: L.S.U.’s Mad Hatter Delights Fans or Drives Them Daffy
abstract: The writer, a Louisiana State football fan, talked to the team’s enigmatic coach, Les Miles, about the movies, his clapping and even his final meal.
lead_paragraph: BATON ROUGE, La. — On a cruelly hot August day, Les Miles, wearing purple shorts and a black vest over a white, long-sleeve T-shirt, sat at a table in his office after practice. He was eating what his secretary, Ya’el Lofton, said was the same lunch he had eaten nearly every day of his eight-year tenure as Louisiana State’s football coach: a Cobb salad with grilled chicken and ranch dressing, washed down with diet iced tea.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Ian Buruma’s ‘Year Zero’
abstract: This week, Ian Buruma, Diane Ravitch and Gary J. Bass.
lead_paragraph: This week, Ian Buruma, Diane Ravitch and Gary J. Bass.

headline: Calendar: Coming Events in New York; Edinburgh; Albuquerque
abstract: A weekly capsule of events around the globe curated by our writers and editors.
lead_paragraph: A Taste of Iceland, New York A celebration of Iceland’s music, food and culture will take place from Oct. 3 to 6 in New York. Some festival events are free, including a concert featuring emerging Icelandic musicians at Le Poisson Rouge in Greenwich Village. Culinary events, held in conjunction with the North Nordic Food Festival, feature meals prepared by Gunnar Karl Gislason (above), chef at Dill restaurant in Reykjavik; master classes in new Nordic cuisine; and a Nordic Christmas cooking class.

headline: E.A. Sports and Collegiate Licensing to Pay $40 Million to Compensate Athletes
abstract: A plan to distribute the money has not been decided, and the settlement leaves the N.C.A.A. as the lone defendant in the lawsuit filed more than four years ago.
lead_paragraph: E.A. Sports and Collegiate Licensing Company are set to pay $40 million to settle their roles in a high-profile lawsuit seeking compensation for college athletes.

headline: Big Ticket | A Hint of Europe for $13.579 Million
abstract: A four-bedroom penthouse in an Upper East Side luxury condominium building, with its own elevator and a reception gallery, was the most expensive residential property sale of the week.
lead_paragraph: A four-bedroom penthouse, one of four that crown the Touraine, a new luxury condominium with distinct European overtones at 132 East 65th Street (at Lexington Avenue), sold for $13,579,371.82 and was the most expensive transaction of the week, according to city records. The listing price for the 3,695-square-foot simplex, PH4, was $13,675,990, and the monthly carrying charges are $6,631.

headline: Isabel Marant: Spring 2014 RTW
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: ‘Big Bang’ Reinforces Its Status as Biggest Hit on Network TV
abstract: The CBS sitcom had an audience of almost 19 million, and the highest rating on any series this season. The audience for Michael J. Fox’s return was relatively modest.
lead_paragraph: “The Big Bang Theory” left no doubt about what show is truly the biggest hit on network television, opening its new season Thursday night with overwhelming ratings, the best premiere in its seven-year history.

headline: What We’re Reading Now
abstract: A list of links for this early autumn weekend.
lead_paragraph: The San Francisco Department of Public Health released a map that shows just how many full-time minimum wage jobs you’d need to rent a two-bedroom apartment in San Francisco at fair market rates. The number of jobs ranges from three to eight.

headline: Why More Climate Science Hasn’t Led to More Climate Policy – Yet
keywords: ['Air Pollution', 'Filibusters and Debate Curbs', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'International Relations', 'Third World and Developing Countries', 'Treaties', 'United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Why there’s a gap between climate science and climate policy.
lead_paragraph: It’s worth offering a bit more context on a point I raised in my morning post on the new report from the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change:

headline: Eating the Color Purple
abstract: Even though it’s officially autumn, the summer crop of eggplant is still in full swing at farmers’ markets across the country.
lead_paragraph: They say “eat your greens,” but this week Martha Rose Shulman’s Recipes for Health provide ways to eat purple, cooking up eggplant in five new ways.

headline: New Albums by Drake and the Weeknd
abstract: Jon Caramanica and Ben Ratliff discuss artistic personae, new theories of the hip-hop mainstream and the ongoing story of the Aubrey-Abel axis.
lead_paragraph: Jon Caramanica and Ben Ratliff discuss artistic personae, new theories of the hip-hop mainstream and the ongoing story of the Aubrey-Abel axis.

headline: Sonia Rykiel: Spring 2014 RTW
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: When Do ‘Family Rules’ Change for Teenagers?
abstract: It was so easy when my children were little: they went where we went, end of story. But now, between my teenagers’ homework, after-school activities and social lives, I can’t assume that they’re always available.
lead_paragraph: “But I hate going to their house. The other kids ignore me and it’s boring,” my 9-year-old complained when I told her we were going to a dinner party with my old high school friends and their families.

headline: Shortcuts Seen by Firm Doing Security Checks
abstract: The details of USIS’s government contract provided insight into the company, whose background checks have included those of Edward J. Snowden and Aaron Alexis.
lead_paragraph: The calls and e-mails from top executives came toward the end of each month, former managers at USIS recalled. The company needed to swiftly complete investigating security clearances for the government in order to reach its monthly revenue goal, the managers said they were told. Finally, there was an order: “Flush” everything you’ve got.

headline: Putting an Estate Value on the Assets Unique to You
keywords: ['Wills and Estates', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Appraisals and Valuation (Property)', 'Inheritance and Estate Taxes']
abstract: The unknowable vagaries of time can complicate the appraisal of the assets in an estate — and yet appraise you must, or risk incurring penalties from the I.R.S.
lead_paragraph: MICHAEL JACKSON and J. D. Salinger would seem to have had little in common beyond being famous, reclusive (to different degrees) and the subject of much speculation about their personal lives. But in death the King of Pop and the author of “The Catcher in the Rye” have become sources of fascination and speculation among estate lawyers and the people charged with putting a price on hard-to-value assets, like royalties that continue paying after they are gone.

headline: Book Review Podcast: The World After War
abstract: Ian Buruma discusses “Year Zero: A History of 1945.”
lead_paragraph: In The New York Times Book Review, Adam Hochschild reviews Ian Buruma’s “Year Zero: A History of 1945.” Mr. Hochschild writes:

headline: Never-Ending Story
abstract: The national “conversation about race” has advanced to another phase, but it has not ushered in an era of colorblind consensus.
lead_paragraph: The “conversation about race” that public figures periodically claim to desire, the one that is always either about to happen or is being prevented from happening, has been going on, at full volume, at least since the day in 1619 when the first African slaves arrived in Jamestown. It has proceeded through every known form of discourse — passionate speeches, awkward silences, angry rants, sheepish whispers, jokes, insults, stories and songs — and just as often through double-talk, indirection and not-so-secret codes.

headline: Power of 10 | The Secrets of an A-List Divorce Attorney
keywords: ['Child Custody and Support', 'Dating and Courtship', 'Divorce, Separations and Annulments']
abstract: The celebrity divorce lawyer Laura Wasser, who has represented clients like Kim Kardashian and Maria Shriver, has a new book and a whole lot of advice about the right way to split up.
lead_paragraph: Divorce is becoming “crazier,” according to the Los Angeles lawyer Laura Wasser, though that could have something to do with the clients she has represented, including Kim Kardashian, Maria Shriver and Ashton Kutcher. Men have a reputation for being scoundrels, but Wasser said she increasingly sees women behaving badly. “Wives end up cheating with the math tutor or the swim coach, then snapping, ‘You deserve it! You neglected me!’”

headline: A Guide to the New Exchanges for Health Insurance
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Personal Finances']
abstract: Details on the Obama administration health care plan are scheduled to be disclosed next week, but it’s never too early to examine the basics.
lead_paragraph: Given all of the rhetoric about the Obama administration’s health care law, it’s not surprising that many consumers are confused about how the new insurance exchanges will actually work. Some states that oppose the law have gone as far as intentionally limiting the information that trickles out to its residents.

headline: Investors and Fed Talk Past Each Other
abstract: Investors were confused when the Federal Reserve decided not to curtail its stimulus efforts last week. Ben Bernanke became exasperated too.
lead_paragraph: Last week’s announcement by the Federal Reserve chairman, Ben Bernanke, that the central bank wouldn’t immediately begin tapering its asset purchases seemed to be just what markets were hoping for: stock and bond prices both rallied on the news, increasing the net worth of millions of Americans — at least until the specter of a fiscal cliff again raised its ugly head in Congress.

headline: Nostalgia Meets Virtual World
abstract: The hip-hop festival Rock the Bells began in 2004 as a rebuke to what was then commercial in hip-hop.
lead_paragraph: The hip-hop festival Rock the Bells began in 2004 as a rebuke to what was then commercial in hip-hop: boasts about luxury consumption, the drug trade and nights in strip clubs. Rock the Bells promoted, instead, the storytelling, social consciousness and complex wordplay of the 1980s and 1990s, with headliners like Wu-Tang Clan and A Tribe Called Quest. But then hip-hop turned yet another corner. With the Internet gaining on radio as a way to build audiences, storytelling and complex concepts — not just easy hooks — made a resurgence among younger rappers.

headline: An Exhibit of All That ‘Alaïa’ Says
abstract: A Paris retrospective for the Tunisian-born designer.
lead_paragraph: The title of the exhibition says it all: “Alaïa.” No extra words of puffery, not even his first name (Azzedine). Just his surname, all vowels and one rising consonant, a word people have been saying in Paris for 35 years with respect, love and kinship: uh-LIE-aah.

headline: Dizzying Search for ‘God Particle’
abstract: Although you have to be knowledgeable in physics to fully grasp the concepts in Mark Levinson’s documentary “Particle Fever,” this movie is a mind blower.
lead_paragraph: Although you have to be knowledgeable in physics and cosmology to fully grasp the concepts laid out in Mark Levinson’s documentary “Particle Fever,” this movie about one of the greatest scientific ventures in history is a mind blower. Visually snazzy, the film follows the search for the theoreticalHiggs boson, a k a “the god particle,” by scientists seeking the origins of matter. It follows the multinational teams who conceived and built the Large Hadron Collider, an 18-mile-long supercollider used in the preliminary discovery of the particle, near Geneva.

headline: Humans at Helm: Is Any Flight Safe?
abstract: Cellphone videos and such have made images of airplane calamities fairly familiar, but often they are seen only as scary snippets on the news.
lead_paragraph: Cellphone videos and such have made images of airplane calamities fairly familiar, but often they are seen only as scary snippets on the news. The Smithsonian Channel went with an alarmist title, “Terror in the Skies,” for the series it begins on Sunday night, but the program serves up much more than just alarming videos of crashes, near crashes and in-flight chaos.

headline: Pictures of a Day Lodged in Memory
abstract: This show revisits the assassination of President Kennedy and the whiplash series of consequences that followed.
lead_paragraph: If you were around in the early 1960s, you probably have at least one shared communal experience lodged in your memory: the recollection of where you were when you first heard news of the Kennedy shooting in Dallas. On the half-century anniversary of the assassination, the International Center of Photography brings us back to that moment in a documentary exhibition called “JFK November 22, 1963: A Bystander’s View of History,” which opens Oct. 4.

headline: Interpreting ‘Rite’ in 2 Parts
abstract: The courageous Nora Chipaumire examines the notion of sacrifice through a contemporary lens.
lead_paragraph: Do we need another “Rite of Spring”? In this centennial year of the transgressive 1913 original, it’s hard not to greet every new take on this rabble-rouser with that question. Of the dozens of interpretations to emerge, how many wring something new from Stravinsky’s staggering score, or subvert the expectations of their own time? And how many are just obligatory tributes to a ballet that the history books have deemed important?

headline: An Opening Gala, Then a Premiere
abstract: In his second season as the Philadelphia Orchestra’s music director, the French Canadian conductor Yannick Nézet-Séguin has already galvanized this ensemble.
lead_paragraph: In his second season as the Philadelphia Orchestra’s music director, the French Canadian conductor Yannick Nézet-Séguin has already galvanized this ensemble’s audiences and inspired its musicians. New Yorkers mostly know Mr. Nézet-Séguin, 38, from his appearances with the Metropolitan Opera. He brings his orchestra to Carnegie Hall for a gala concert to open the season.

headline: 140 Character Assassination
abstract: Even the sane conservatives, aren’t.
lead_paragraph: The question of the moment is whether the sane Republicans will, out of fear for their own political skins, defer to the insane Republicans and allow a government shutdown, or the much scarier possibility of debt default. Amid this drama, however, it’s worth remembering that even the sane ones are pretty much off the deep end, all too willing to buy into crazy conspiracy theories. Remember how Jack Welch accused Obama of cooking the jobs numbers?

headline: The Week in Pictures for Sept. 27
abstract: Pictures include unlawfully painted bike lanes in Manhattan, oyster planting in the Bronx, and environmentalists in the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Pictures include unlawfully painted bike lanes in Manhattan, oyster planting in the Bronx, and environmentalists in the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn.

headline: Notes From Canada, a Career and the Distant Future
abstract: Notable releases include a dystopian but perky concept album, stretches of free improvisation and a track-by-track remake of a 1976 album by the fiddler Kenny Baker.
lead_paragraph: Deltron 3030

headline: Popcast: New Albums by Drake and the Weeknd
abstract: Jon Caramanica and Ben Ratliff discuss artistic personae, new theories of the hip-hop mainstream and the ongoing story of the Aubrey-Abel axis.
lead_paragraph: The new-model rapper Drake, a k a Aubrey Graham, and the new-model R&B singer the Weeknd, a k a Abel Tesfaye, are both from Toronto, and have had linked careers: in late 2010, the highly visible Drake rapidly spread the word about the publicity-shy Mr. Tesfaye through a viral blog post, and one of the best tracks on Drake’s 2011 album “Take Care” was “Crew Love,” with Mr. Tesfaye delivering bad vibes in a high and vulnerable voice.

headline: Giants’ Snee and Baas Out Against Chiefs
abstract: The Giants’ offensive line, coming off a dreadful performance in last Sunday’s loss at the Carolina Panthers, will be missing two starters when the 0-3 team visits the 3-0 Kansas City Chiefs.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The Giants’ offensive line, coming off a dreadful performance in last Sunday’s 38-0 loss at the Carolina Panthers, will be missing two starters when the 0-3 team visits the 3-0 Kansas City Chiefs on Sunday.

headline: Rights Groups and Clinics Sue Texas Over Provisions in Its New Abortion Law
abstract: The plaintiffs are seeking to block two provisions: one would require doctors to have admitting privileges at a nearby hospital and the other requires a different drug protocol for medical abortions.
lead_paragraph: National women’s rights groups and Texas abortion clinics filed suit on Friday in federal court in Texas, seeking to block provisions of a new state law that they said would have “dramatic and draconian effects” on women’s access to the procedure.

headline: ‘The Slave to His Star’
abstract: What an 1863 poem in The Anglo-African newspaper reveals about the black experience during the Civil War.
lead_paragraph: Near the end of April 1863, on the eve of the first muster of African-American regiments in the North, William Slade, the head servant in the White House, sent Abraham Lincoln a petition from Washington’s black community recommending officers for the district’s first regiment of black troops. Sixty-seven men signed the petition, addressed to Secretary of War Edwin M. Stanton, including members of the Israel Lyceum of Washington City, an African-American debating society. A letter from Slade to Lincoln accompanied the petition, acknowledging that he and the other men wanted Lincoln to see the petition at the “earliest practicable moment.”

headline: Explorations in Identity and Pleasure
keywords: ['Movies', 'New York Film Festival', 'Cannes International Film Festival']
abstract: Two new films — Stacie Passon’s “Concussion” and Abdellatif Kechiche’s “Blue Is the Warmest Color” — address same-sex relationships between women in new ways.
lead_paragraph: A century and a half after Gustave Flaubert wrote “Madame Bovary,” and 50 years after the advent of the sexual revolution, popular art still shrinks from truly reckoning with female desire. After a flurry of 1960s art-house erotica (“I Am Curious (Yellow)”) and quasi-feminist camp (“Barbarella”), women-centric movies in the main have returned to status quo-bolstering narratives of marriage, melodrama and moral guilt. Which makes the near-simultaneous arrival of two new films that explore varieties of female sexual experience suggest the stirring of a newly liberated cinema.

headline: Maison Martin Margiela: Spring 2014 RTW
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: Waking Up at Walmart
abstract: A Q. and A. with Nolan Conway, who photographed people who spend the night in Walmart parking lots.
lead_paragraph: This week’s Look features photographs of people who have the spent the night in their vehicles in Walmart parking lots in Arizona (Walmart welcomes this practice, with the idea that overnighters will shop at the store). The images were taken by Nolan Conway, who previously captured for the magazine people in McDonald’s restaurants all over the country and young children being smeared with sunscreen. I put some questions to Conway about his most recent series.

headline: After Rout in German Elections, Social Democrats Consider Coalition With Merkel
abstract: The defeated Social Democrats convened to decide whether to enter into talks with Chancellor Angela Merkel’s conservatives over a possible coalition, and what price to extract from her if they do.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — In the first step of what could be a long road to building a new German government, the defeated Social Democrats agreed on Friday to enter into talks with Chancellor Angela Merkel’s conservatives over a possible coalition, naming fair wages, good jobs and a strengthening of the country’s social system as key points.

headline: Coconut Dulce de Leche With Pineapple
abstract: Melissa Clark uses coconut milk to make an intensely flavored and dairy-free dulce de leche.
lead_paragraph: Melissa Clark uses coconut milk to make an intensely flavored and dairy-free dulce de leche.

headline: With Kareem Abdul-Jabbar
abstract: The former Laker Kareem Abdul-Jabbar has a new children’s book out, and something to say about the expectations that come with being tall.
lead_paragraph: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar has found plenty to occupy himself since his N.B.A. playing days — acting, coaching, writing some best-selling books, serving as a cultural ambassador for the United States. He was in Manhattan this week to promote his new children’s book, “Sasquatch in the Paint,” the first installment in a planned trilogy.

headline: Off the Charts: Big Government States
abstract: States with a larger government presence tended to vote Republican in the 2012 election, while states with a smaller government presence tended to vote Democratic.
lead_paragraph: States with a larger government presence tended to vote Republican in the 2012 election, while states with a smaller government presence tended to vote Democratic.

headline: Still Waters Meet Their Sparkling Counterpart
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Weddings and Engagements', 'Vows (Times Column)']
abstract: Celebrating a loving relationship that developed in fits and starts and culminated in a wedding of taste and friendship.
lead_paragraph: For David Hagedorn and Michael Widomski, friends for many years, the hardest parts about falling in love were shaking off the fantasies each had harbored about how love would arrive and admitting to themselves and each other that what they had was the real thing after all.

headline: Restoring the Thrill to Dulce de Leche
abstract: This thick caramel pudding was once a mystery — nutty, smooth on the tongue and unlike any other.
lead_paragraph: BACK BEFORE DULCE DE LECHE became ubiquitous in the dessert world, I had my first taste at my friend Zoë’s house. It was a recipe she had learned from her Chilean ex-mother-in-law and couldn’t wait to make for me. The thick caramel pudding was nutty, smooth on the tongue and unlike any other I’d had.

headline: In Republican States, More Government Jobs
keywords: ['Government Employees', 'States (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States Economy']
abstract: A look at measures of state economies, their reliance on government employment, and how those states voted.
lead_paragraph: FAMILIARITY, it is said, breeds contempt. Or perhaps, it is dependence that breeds resentment.

headline: Documentary Keeps It Completely Real
abstract: “Let the Fire Burn,” about the radical group Move and its 1985 bombing by the Philadelphia police, consists entirely of found footage.
lead_paragraph: Over the 12 years it took to make “Let the Fire Burn,” about the radical group Move and its 1985 bombing by the Philadelphia police, the director Jason Osder — like any good documentarian — filmed interviews with crucial people.

headline: Total Immersion, on Screen and in Life
abstract: Rupert Friend, who plays Peter Quinn, an enigmatic agent on “Homeland,” prefers life experience as the key to a persuasive performance.
lead_paragraph: Early on in the third season of “Homeland” — which begins on Showtime on Sunday — the actor Rupert Friend, as the enigmatic black-ops agent Peter Quinn, hunches, shirtless, over a homemade explosive device. There is a stillness to Mr. Friend’s performance, a noiseless stoicism that only amplifies his character’s inscrutability: whatever Quinn is up to with that bomb (and in that moment, it’s fruitless to even guess), it seems extraordinarily unlikely that he’ll miss his target.

headline: Lady Murasaki’s Masterpiece and Its Update
abstract: “Genji’s World in Japanese Wood-Block Prints” is about two books: an 11th-century classic, “The Tale of Genji,” and its 19th-century parody.
lead_paragraph: Filled with romance, conflict, sex, adventure and the occasional malevolent visitor from the spirit world, the new print show at the Frances Lehman Loeb Art Center at Vassar College has so much going on that it would take a book to cover it. Actually, more than one — and it’s not surprising.

headline: Is It Going Away to College if College Is Close to Home?
abstract: Many students who have a choice are factoring in the distance from home when they chose a college, and not in the hopes of getting as far away as possible.
lead_paragraph: From “When College Is Close to Home, What are the Boundaries?” in the Styles section:

headline: When College Is Close to Home, What Are the Boundaries?
abstract: Students and parents try to find a balance between “comfortable” and “too close.”
lead_paragraph: “I was the last person people thought would stay in their hometown for college,” said Laura Johnson, a senior at Macalester College who lives in a house a half-hour walk from her home in St. Paul. “Even my parents wondered why I wasn’t going away.”

headline: Judge Orders New Jersey to Allow Gay Marriage
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: The judge ruled that in light of the United States Supreme Court’s decision striking down the Defense of Marriage Act, “same-sex couples must be allowed to marry.”
lead_paragraph: A New Jersey judge ruled on Friday that the state must allow same-sex couples to marry, saying that not doing so deprives them of rights that were guaranteed by the United States Supreme Court in June.

headline: J.C. Penney’s Troubling Stock Sale
abstract: Capital misallocation is a new bad sign for the struggling retailer.
lead_paragraph: J.C. Penney’s stock sale reflects a particular sort of dimness about discounts. The troubled U.S. retailer is struggling to get prices right in its stores and isn’t faring any better in the markets. It is selling over $900 million of shares at $9.65 each, after spending a similar sum to buy them back two years ago while paying nearly $37 apiece. Capital misallocation is a new bad sign for J.C. Penney.

headline: Works in Conversation With Photography
abstract: The exhibition “Chuck Close: Recent Works” at Guild Hall Museum offers some insight into the shifts, however subtle, in Mr. Close’s work since his breakthrough in the late 1960s.
lead_paragraph: Although he came of age as an artist in the tumultuous 1960s, Chuck Close did not adopt the most radical innovations of that era in his work. Instead, Mr. Close chose to work in portraiture, one of the most traditional art genres, using it as a vehicle to explore how photography relates to painting, and how these mediums both represent and affect our view of the world and ourselves.

headline: Lacking Rules, Insurers Balk at Paying for Intensive Psychiatric Care
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: A 2008 law was supposed to make it easier for mental health patients to get treatment, but without clear rules, insurance companies are often reluctant to pay the bill.
lead_paragraph: THE first time Melissa Morelli was taken to the hospital, she was suicidal and cutting herself, her mother says. She was just 13, and she had been transferred to a psychiatric hospital, where she stayed for more than a week. Her doctors told her mother, Cathy Morelli, that it was not safe for Melissa to go home. But the family’s health insurance carrier would not continue to pay for her to remain in the hospital.

headline: Moving Offstage to Seek Harmony
abstract: Some orchestras are hiring musicians as chief executives, seeding hope that bitter labor standoffs can be avoided or resolved.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — When the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra began rehearsals recently for its season opener this weekend under the baton of its music director, Jacques Lacombe, one player who has been central to the ensemble was missing onstage — one so central, in fact, that everyone used to tune to his A.

headline: After 45 Years, Freedom Salted With Hindsight
abstract: Opening a two-week season at the Joyce Theater, Lar Lubovitch’s company will survey the trajectory of his career while presenting a new twist on his 1989 piece “Fandango.”
lead_paragraph: About 10 years ago, the choreographer Lar Lubovitch found himself watching a black-and-white film of an unusual dancer. It showed a slender young man curling up from the floor, then whirling around an empty room, as if discovering how his body moved for the first time.

headline: Technology and the College Generation
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'E-Mail', 'Text Messaging', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Regarded as too slow, e-mail is barely a second thought for college students, who prefer texting. But that sets them up for trouble with their professors.
lead_paragraph: As a professor who favors pop quizzes, Cedrick May is used to grimaces from students caught unprepared. But a couple of years ago, in his class on early American literature at the University of Texas at Arlington, he said he noticed “horrible, pained looks” from the whole class when they saw the questions.

headline: Still Making Music Together, Far Apart
abstract: Bernie Taupin comes up with the words, and Elton John, separately, the music, in a pairing that has been successful for decades.
lead_paragraph: The partnership started with an ad in an English music magazine in 1967. Liberty Records was looking for songwriters, and Bernie Taupin, a farmworker and amateur poet from Lincolnshire, sent in a sheaf of lyrics, not expecting much. Around the same time a frustrated young blues pianist named Reg Dwight auditioned for the label. An executive didn’t like Mr. Dwight’s material but tossed him a stack of Mr. Taupin’s lyrics and said, “See what you can do with these.”

headline: Seven Days of Style | Lizzy Caplan Gets Randy, Saks Gets Smelly and Moschino Celebrates
abstract: Plus, Kanye West’s latest odd move, LVMH’s new wunderkind and more as we run the numbers from the last week in style and culture.
lead_paragraph: ALL THE NUMBERS THAT MATTER FROM THE WEEK IN STYLESept. 21 – 27

headline: Full Decision From New Jersey Court on Same-Sex Marriage
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: Read the full ruling from Judge Mary C. Jacobson on same-sex marriage.
lead_paragraph: Read the full ruling from Judge Mary C. Jacobson on same-sex marriage.

headline: Rossellini and Bergman’s Break From Tradition
abstract: Moments of metaphysical rapture and transformation distinguish three collaborations between Ingrid Bergman and Roberto Rossellini released in a Criterion set.
lead_paragraph: “In the 10 days since she bore a son to film director Roberto Rossellini in Rome, actress Ingrid Bergman has become the center of a spirited controversy,” The New York Times noted on Feb. 12, 1950. Indeed, Bergman’s decision to leave behind both Hollywood and her husband, Dr. Petter Lindstrom, to make a low-budget film in Italy with the most audacious filmmaker of the day had already touched off shock and outrage in the American press. That the boy, Renato, was born out of wedlock only increased the furor.

headline: Pictures of the Day: India and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from India, Pakistan, Syria and Kenya.
lead_paragraph: Photos from India, Pakistan, Syria and Kenya.

headline: Death, Up an Apple Tree
abstract: In “On Borrowed Time,” death comes to visit an old man who tricks it into climbing an apple tree from which it cannot escape.
lead_paragraph: The incarnation of death, who materializes early in “On Borrowed Time,” is no hooded specter with a scythe in a skeletal claw. Rather, in Paul Osborn’s 1938 play, death is mildly personified as Mr. Brink, a gentlemanly fellow sporting a natty tan suit and a homburg hat. But he still means mortal business.

headline: Nicholas Kirkwood: Plucking a Commoner From an Exalted Family
abstract: The shoe designer cherishes the outlandish quality of orchids. But the ones he chooses are among the most ordinary.
lead_paragraph: In today’s parade of outrageous shoes, Nicholas Kirkwood is the maddest hatter of all.

headline: So, It’s Your Father, or Me. Decide.
abstract: Stuart Zicherman, the writer-director of “A.C.O.D.,” and his parents and sister riff on their own experience with divorce.
lead_paragraph: In the vintage home-movie prologue to the writer-director Stuart Zicherman’s debut comedy “A.C.O.D.,” a boy’s ninth birthday party is ruined by the profane screams of his parents before he can even blow out the candles. Then, in a madcap montage, the divorcing parents, played by Catherine O’Hara and Richard Jenkins, do what modern-day parenting books explicitly forbid: They bribe their children with gifts and force them to choose whom they will live with, while assassinating each other’s characters and introducing a dizzying number of new partners and stepsiblings.

headline: Gaming With Chrome, and Bypassing Windows 8
abstract: Fans of the game Minecraft may be able to get it to play on a Google Chrome notebook, and how to go directly from Windows 7 to Windows 8.1
lead_paragraph: Gaming on a Google-Powered Notebook

headline: A Road Trip Through Cajun Country
abstract: Sampling big flavors and lively culture on a drive through southern Louisiana.
lead_paragraph: Sampling big flavors and lively culture on a drive through southern Louisiana.

headline: Ominous Signs, Then a Cruel Attack
abstract: With Kenya’s growing affluence and the mayhem next door in Somalia, the attack on the mall in Nairobi was inevitable.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — THIS was the attack we all knew was coming.

headline: Photo Booths, the Party’s Hot Spot
abstract: Photo booths, which resemble mini studios with professional backdrops and lighting, are being spotted at just about every party, as guests pose for selfies.
lead_paragraph: The party was for VFiles, the online fashion hub and store, and as expected, cameras were everywhere. In addition to the half-dozen photographers assigned to cover the Fashion Week affair, guests posed for selfies and snapped pictures of the rapper A$AP Rocky and the artist Mykki Blanco.

headline: Elements: Texture at Paris Fashion Week
abstract: Explore the notion of texture in the first of thematic visual diaries from Paris Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: Explore the notion of texture in the first of thematic visual diaries from Paris Fashion Week.

headline: Zalaznick, Once a Programming Force at NBCUniversal, Is Leaving
abstract: The announcement wasn’t a surprise within the company. Promoted because of her work at Bravo, she had recently lost  a corporate power struggle, executives said.
lead_paragraph: Lauren Zalaznick, whose leadership at Bravo turned that cable network into a lucrative asset for its parent, NBCUniversal, is leaving the company, Steve Burke, the chief executive of NBCUniversal, told the staff in a memo released on Friday.

headline: Hyundai’s Brother Act
abstract: The redesigned Santa Fe comes in two versions: a muscular midsize crossover and a Sport model that trains its sights on best-selling compacts.
lead_paragraph: The redesigned Santa Fe comes in two versions: a muscular midsize crossover and a Sport model that trains its sights on best-selling compacts.

headline: Athletic Socks that Give a Foot Bragging Rights
abstract: It’s not just about the sneaker anymore.
lead_paragraph: It took Winston Robson, 15, nearly a solid day of lawn-mowing and a little bit of luck to buy one of his most prized possessions: a pair of $60 limited-edition socks.

headline: Microeconomics: A City in Miniature
abstract: For years, Randy Hage has been snapping photos of storefronts in changing New York neighborhoods, and then making scale models of them.
lead_paragraph: For years, Randy Hage has been snapping photos of storefronts in changing New York neighborhoods, and then making scale models of them.

headline:
U.S. and Iran 
Agree to Speed
Talks to Defuse
Nuclear Issue
abstract: President Obama said he saw the basis for a deal after speaking on the phone with President Hassan Rouhani of Iran, the first discussion between leaders of the two countries since 1979.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The long-fractured relationship between the United States and Iran took a significant turn on Friday when President Obama and President Hassan Rouhani became the first leaders of their countries to speak since the Tehran hostage crisis more than three decades ago.

headline: Weekend Reading: JPMorgan Settlement in Sight
abstract: No one can be certain how much JPMorgan Chase will ultimately have to pay for questionable mortgage practices, but everyone seems to have an opinion.
lead_paragraph: After another week of intense negotiations, the Justice Department and JPMorgan Chase continue to inch closer to a multibillion-dollar accord over questionable mortgage practices. No one can be certain how much the bank will have to pay, but everyone seems to have an opinion.

headline: The New iPad App You’ll Want Grandma to Download
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Computer and Video Games', 'Grandparents', 'iPad', 'Mobile Applications', 'Parenting']
abstract: Ustyme allows grandparents and distant friends to share books and games with children over video, but is smart enough to make that connection and get out of the way.
lead_paragraph: Ustyme is the kind of app the iPad was made for. Two users, connected online and by video, can read or play games together in an experience that is as close to really being together as I’ve yet found online. Particularly for a young child interacting with an adult at a distance, ustyme created a shared experience in a way Skype and FaceTime never could.

headline: Dancing, Dining and Daiquiris in Cajun Country
abstract: Fall is one of the best times to visit this region of big flavors and lively culture in southern Louisiana.
lead_paragraph: Whenever I visit Cajun country, in southwest Louisiana, the land of crawfish, gumbo, gator steaks and les bons temps personified, my first stop is at a cultural icon that, in itself, elevates this region to the status of an American touristic treasure: the drive-through daiquiri hut. This was my intention in mid-July; however, the plane was late, and I had pressing business to address midday — sampling boudin balls (deep-fried rounds of pork and seasoned rice). Boudin in these parts is what lobsters are in Maine, or crabs in Baltimore. And you find them everywhere — in butcher shops, in delis, at food stands, even at gas stations. More on these — and the daiquiris — in a moment.

headline: Review: 2014 Hyundai Santa Fe
abstract: Live large in Santa Fe even if your home is in Duluth. Hyundai’s three-row crossover is a very serious competitor. Tom Voelk checks out a loaded Limited model in Driven.
lead_paragraph: Live large in Santa Fe even if your home is in Duluth. Hyundai’s three-row crossover is a very serious competitor. Tom Voelk checks out a loaded Limited model in Driven.

headline: Dogfish Head Brewery to Open an Inn
abstract: The Dogfish Head Brewery plans to open a hotel called the Dogfish Inn in Lewes, Del., next year.
lead_paragraph: The popular Dogfish Head brewery in Delaware has announced that it plans to open its first hotel, the Dogfish Inn, in spring 2014.

headline: The Ghosts of Amsterdam
abstract: Walks in the city can evoke figures from the past, from Rembrandt to Anne Frank, who continue to have profound stories to tell.
lead_paragraph: It only recently occurred to me that one very fine if not exactly intentional purpose for historic preservation is to keep dead people alive. Having spent the past several years living in Amsterdam and researching a book about its history, I now find that virtually anywhere I walk in this city, whose center has been so tenderly and smartly maintained, I am jostled by ghosts.

headline: From Grapes to Goat Cheese on the North Fork
abstract: Settle into a rural pace on this trip out to the eastern end of Long Island.
lead_paragraph: Settle into a rural pace on this trip out to the eastern end of Long Island.

headline: Looking for the Hamptons? Go the Other Way
abstract: The North Fork of Long Island, dotted with farm stands and wineries, offers a rustic contrast to its glitzy southern neighbor.
lead_paragraph: At the end of the line, the very last stop on the Long Island Rail Road, there is a huge rusted anchor. Beyond it, there is water and there are boats. The ferry to Shelter Island chugs back and forth, a purposeful ship among the flighty sailboats.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Forever Plaid
abstract: Grunge is still influential 25 years after it first appeared on the runway at Perry Ellis.
lead_paragraph: Grunge is still influential 25 years after it first appeared on the runway at Perry Ellis.

headline: Documenting a Massacre in Kenya
abstract: Tyler Hicks, a Times photographer, narrates a look at his photographs from inside the Westgate mall in Nairobi, Kenya, after assailants opened fire.
lead_paragraph: Tyler Hicks, a Times photographer, narrates a look at his photographs from inside the Westgate mall in Nairobi, Kenya, after assailants opened fire.

headline: A Nightly Dinner Out That’s Like Therapy
abstract: At 103, Harry Rosen eats dinner every evening at a fine restaurant, always ordering fish, and often lying to fellow diners curious about his age.
lead_paragraph: It never fails, Harry Rosen said on Wednesday evening as he enjoyed another fine meal by himself in another top-rated Manhattan restaurant.

headline: Swift Movement Is Seen on Syria After U.N. Action
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: The full Security Council approved a resolution to ensure Syrian compliance on chemical weapons, and the organization responsible for destroying those weapons announced a timetable that starts on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: The diplomatic drive to purge Syria of its chemical weapons accelerated Friday, as the full 15-member United Nations Security Council approved a breakthrough resolution to ensure Syrian compliance, and the organization responsible for carrying out the destruction of those munitions announced a timetable that starts Tuesday, sooner than some had expected.

headline: Answers to Some Questions About Health Care Exchanges
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Your Money columnist Tara Siegel Bernard has answers to your questions about the new health care exchanges opening on Oct. 1.
lead_paragraph: It’s a little like an election: Most people don’t focus on it until they prepare to vote. Now that the new health care exchanges are about to open, potential buyers of the new plans are trying to understand the law. Your Money columnist Tara Siegel Bernard has answers to some of the most perplexing questions and is standing by to answer more from readers. You can find her full column here.

headline: Songs Between Trains
abstract: Subculture.FM aims to make the encounters between subway riders and musicians less fleeting.
lead_paragraph: You’re trudging back to Brooklyn, utterly worn out. The last thing you want to do is wait for the train, and you hope as you head underground that the L will arrive immediately. But there’s a violinist in the station and she’s playing the most soothing, beautiful music.

headline: House Republicans Should ‘Knock it Off’
abstract: Republicans in the Senate don’t want a shutdown. But their colleagues in the House have shown themselves far less interested in the general welfare.
lead_paragraph: The health care obsessives in the Senate, led by Ted Cruz and Mike Lee, have spent days trying to portray Democrats as out of touch with the public. “The Senate Democrats are not listening to the millions of Americans who are being hurt by Obamacare,” Mr. Cruz said this morning in his last stand in this particular round of the budget battle.

headline: ‘Llewyn Davis’ Concert to Benefit Recording Preservation
abstract: A concert Sunday at Town Hall with Joan Baez, Jack White and others will raise money to help preserve archives of the music that inspired many of the performers.
lead_paragraph: When Town Hall agreed to host a fund-raiser for the National Recording Preservation Foundation on Sunday, its executive director, Lawrence Zucker, was thinking about 22 boxes of old recordings sitting in a warehouse in New Jersey.

headline: A Wedding Party of Five
abstract: On the second night of Marco’s, a new restaurant in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, Kristin Meidell and Philip Birch marked the occasion of their low-key backyard wedding.
lead_paragraph: If love, food and family are life’s simple ingredients, then putting them together in one place, at one table, can be celebration enough. And so it happened on the second night it was open at Marco’s, a restaurant in the space formerly occupied by  Franny’s pizzeria on Flatbush Avenue in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn. The owners, Francine Stephens and Andrew Feinberg, moved Franny’s up the block in April and opened this chic, understated trattoria in its place, naming it for their 5-year-old son. They kept only the brick walls and the pew from a Crown Heights synagogue that formed a banquette by the kitchen, now featuring a wood-fired grill and a rotisserie. On Tuesday, neighbors waited outside for the dressed-up farm fare without the pizza, while a family of five came to mark the low-key occasion of their backyard Brooklyn wedding, delighting in the warmth of something old, new and true.

headline: Cosmos-Rowdies: That ’70s Rivalry, Updated
abstract: First place in the N.A.S.L. will be up for grabs Sunday night when the Cosmos host Tampa Bay.
lead_paragraph: It was once one of the fiercest rivalries in North American soccer.

headline: Obama’s Statement on Iran
abstract: President Obama said he spoke with President Hassan Rouhani of Iran by phone, the first direct contact between leaders of Iran and the United States since 1979.
lead_paragraph: President Obama said he spoke with President Hassan Rouhani of Iran by phone, the first direct contact between leaders of Iran and the United States since 1979.

headline: New York Sues Teachers’ Union Over Deal on Disciplinary Hearings
abstract: The 2010 agreement closed “rubber rooms” and was supposed to expedite the hearing process, but the union has been slow in helping select arbitrators, the Bloomberg administration said.
lead_paragraph: Three years ago, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and New York City’s teachers’ union celebrated an agreement to end the use of “rubber rooms,” the much-ridiculed holding pens where teachers accused of wrongdoing or incompetence would report for years on end, doing no work but drawing full salaries.

headline: Renovated With or Without Family Room
abstract: The new Santa Fe has grown and become more family friendly. The Sport model, meanwhile, stays roughly the same size as before, but it’s also much improved.
lead_paragraph: Automakers, logo designers and plastic surgeons all adhere to an unshakable credo: make it bigger.

headline: Vestas Joins With Mitsubishi for Offshore Turbines
abstract: The venture will develop Vestas’s 8-megawatt offshore turbines, each of which can power roughly 8,000 households.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Danish wind turbine manufacturer Vestas received a financial lift on Friday as it announced a joint venture with Mitsubishi Heavy Industry of Japan to develop offshore wind energy.

headline: New Spanish Budget Free of Austerity Measures
abstract: The government called the proposal for 2014 “the budget of economic recovery” and forecast a 0.7 percent rise in gross domestic product.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Confident that Spain is emerging from a prolonged recession, the government on Friday presented a budget for 2014 that was largely free of the unpopular austerity measures of recent years.

headline: Daniel Peddle, Casting Director, Can See for Miles and Miles
abstract: The wide-ranging vision of Mr. Peddle, the casting director for shows like Givenchy fall men’s.
lead_paragraph: It was the day after the Givenchy fall men’s show in June, and the casting director, an exhausted Daniel Peddle, was in Paris at a Seventh Arrondissement cafe.

headline: The Unstuffy Taco
abstract: The ideal taco consists of a warm corn tortilla with a spoonful or two of a savory filling.
lead_paragraph: There is only one good way to eat a taco, and that is to eat it as soon as it has been assembled. No waiting, no fanfare and certainly not wrapped to go. It’s all about immediacy, devouring it while it is still in prime shape.

headline: Yohji Yamamoto: Spring 2014 RTW
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: Listen Up | An L.A. Band Obsessed With ‘Insanity, America and Women’
abstract: They call themselves Papa. Their first album, “Tender Madness,” is out next month. Check out the track “If the Moon Rises,” premiering exclusively here.
lead_paragraph: “If the Moon Rises” by Papa

headline: First-Round Picks Pay Off in Jets’ Pass Rush
abstract: Sheldon Richardson, Quinton Coples and Muhammad Wilkerson have solidifed a pass rush that was never among the N.F.L.’s best under Coach Rex Ryan.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — A complex formula may explain the success of the Jets’ defensive line, explain how four large men can get past five larger men with such apparent ease. Such an explanation might require a chalkboard or an applied sciences degree.

headline: A Government Shutdown, by the Numbers
abstract: A look at the costs, closings and other ramifications of a government shutdown.
lead_paragraph: A look at the costs, closings and other ramifications of a government shutdown.

headline: A Break From the Wildlife, With Family
abstract: On weekends, Cristián Samper, president of the Wildlife Conservation Society, relishes downtime with his wife and two children.
lead_paragraph: Cristián Samper, a tropical biologist, is the president of the Wildlife Conservation Society, which runs four zoos and an aquarium in New York City, including the Bronx Zoo, and oversees conservation programs around the world. Before taking the job last year, he directed the Smithsonian National Museum of Natural History in Washington. Born in Costa Rica and raised in Colombia, Dr. Samper, 48, was formerly chief adviser for biodiversity to the Colombian government. On weekends, he relishes downtime with his wife, Adriana, 42, a lawyer, and two children, Carolina, 7, and Martin, 4. Dr. Samper and his family live on the Upper East Side, where their apartment overlooks Carl Schurz Park.

headline: Getting Their Trucks in a Row, Europeans Revisit the Convoy
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Research', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Roads and Traffic']
abstract: Researchers in Europe are working on an electronic communications system that enables a wagon train of tractor-trailer trucks and cars to make semiautonomous road trips.
lead_paragraph: Researchers in Europe are working on a concept that will be familiar to anyone who has seen films about the bands of travelers who settled the American West. The project is developing an electronic communications system that enables a wagon train of tractor-trailer trucks and cars to make semiautonomous road trips possible — without the complexity of efforts like Google’s driverless vehicles.

headline: Before Appetizers Are Served, a Quick Diagnosis From the Valet
abstract: While working as a parking valet at a Los Angeles restaurant, Bruno Cavallini helps troubleshoot, and sometimes fix, problems with customers’ cars.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The “check engine” light of the BMW had been glowing for a few days when its owner pulled up to the valet drop-off at Ink, the much-discussed restaurant opened here two years ago by Michael Voltaggio, a “Top Chef” reality show winner.

headline: Add Another Small Sporty Pickup to the Endangered List
abstract: Small pickups have been disappearing from the lineups of automakers, and even the Toyota Tacoma X-Runner will go away soon. Too bad, because this quick little pickup is fun to drive.
lead_paragraph: TESTED 2013 Toyota Tacoma X-Runner

headline: Expires 2013: Models That Won’t Return
abstract: It’s that time of year again. As 2014 models appear, a host of discontinued models are disappearing from company Web sites and dealership lots.
lead_paragraph: Every fall, the new-car season brings fresh models and industrywide optimism, but it’s also the time when automakers are forced to acknowledge what’s not selling as discontinued models disappear from company Web sites and dealership lots. With few exceptions, a canceled car is a slow-selling car.

headline: Fill, Empty, Stack, Hold: Art With a 6-Sided Object
abstract: Andrea Miller’s “Fold Here,” danced for the first time by her Gallim Dance Company at the Alexander Kasser Theater, does much with simple cardboard boxes.
lead_paragraph: MONTCLAIR, N.J. — As a prop, the cardboard box — like that old standard, the folding chair — holds myriad theatrical possibilities. It can be a container for smaller things, a building block for larger ones. It can be hoisted, flung, crumpled, collapsed, climbed inside of, jumped on top of. It calls up metaphors like “boxed in” and “outside the box.” And, while mundane, it has a certain intrinsic mystery: what’s inside?

headline: At Christian Dior, the Perfect Black Pump
abstract: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway. Today’s pick: a simple heel that stuns with its classic simplicity.
lead_paragraph: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: Diving Into the Past, They Land in the Present
abstract: Earth, Wind & Fire played its decades-old Top 10 hits, as well as some newer songs, at its show at the Beacon Theater.
lead_paragraph: At first, an Earth, Wind & Fire concert is all about Verdine White. If you want to go in this direction, you can go a long way. American music used to be about bands; bands are powered by rhythm, clarified by precision and enlivened by extravagance, the sound of the strong and the strange. Mr. White, Earth Wind & Fire’s bassist and one of its three longtime touring members, is all of that: discipline and impatience, generative past and impulsive, wasteful present. He’s in the class of bass players who will not be denied, who play as if they wanted to wrestle down the music and bite it.

headline: Jolted to Attention by Dior
abstract: In Paris, a string of captivating images from several labels including Dior, Chalayan, Lanvin, Ricci.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Most good days here you sort of feel you are on a collision course, and it’s not only the traffic or a pair of naked protesters at Nina Ricci (well, it was warm in the tent) or the bystanders who have come to watch the freak parade. No, it’s the clothes that constantly work you over.

headline: Obama on the Looming Shutdown
abstract: The president delivered a strong message to Congress not to shut down the government and the economy and to think about the concerns of the American people.
lead_paragraph: The president delivered a strong message to Congress not to shut down the government and the economy and to think about the concerns of the American people.

headline: Few Words, but Sound Abounds
abstract: Indie-rockers provide the live score for “We Have an Anchor,” a film by Jem Cohen, at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
lead_paragraph: Cape Breton, the island at Nova Scotia’s northeastern tip, is a windswept, rainy, hardscrabble, isolated, workaday and majestically beautiful place in “We Have an Anchor,” a film by Jem Cohen that was presented with live musicians playing the score on Thursday night. It began a three-night run at the Brooklyn Academy of Music’s Harvey Theater. Images were shown on up to five screens, and the score was performed by the seven-member ensemble of indie-rockers who had composed it. The event was presented by the Next Wave Festival in association with the Wordless Music series.

headline: Senate Urges House to Allow Vote
abstract: The Senate majority leader, Harry Reid, urged the House to allow a vote on the Senate budget bill that would prevent a government shutdown.
lead_paragraph: The Senate majority leader, Harry Reid, urged the House to allow a vote on the Senate budget bill that would prevent a government shutdown.

headline: There’s Always a Market for a Few Surprises
abstract: A review of the Anthony Vaccarello, Balmain, Cédric Charlier, Gareth Pugh, Paco Rabanne collections.

abstract: A new survey shows that Hispanics have grown negative toward the Republican Party during the immigration fight and lean liberal on social issues like gay marriage.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — A new survey shows that Hispanics, the nation’s largest minority group, have grown increasingly negative toward the Republican Party during the political battle over changing immigration law and lean surprisingly liberal on social issues like gay marriage — a combination of factors that presents a steep challenge for Republicans in trying to win back Hispanic voters.

headline: Another Tryst

lead_paragraph: Television has featured some high-stakes extramarital affairs of late, with the presidency (“Scandal”) and the very security of the United States (“Homeland”) among the things at risk. The garden-variety affair at the heart of “Betrayal,” a new drama that ABC offers on Sunday night, seems ordinary by comparison, at least what we see of it in the pilot.

headline: Feeling For | The Doge Table, an Icon of Postwar Italian Design, Gets a New Home
abstract: The elegantly minimal piece, created by the architect Carlos Scarpa, was made by the pioneering company Simon, which has been acquired by the furniture manufacturer Cassina.
lead_paragraph: Like his architecture, Carlo Scarpa’s furniture designs were elegant, substantial and beautifully detailed. A case in point: his Doge table, with its crisp steel base and jewel-like exposed brass screws. The table was the first piece made by Simon, a company that was founded in 1968 by the legendary entrepreneur Dino Gavina, who died in 2007. A champion of postwar Italian design who once called production “a medium that can be used as a vehicle for stupidity or for civilization,” Gavina turned out meticulously designed, luxurious furniture by Scarpa, Kazuhide Takahama, Enzo Mari and other influential names, and reproduced iconic Surrealist pieces like Meret Oppenheim’s Traccia table, with its gilded birds’ legs, and Man Ray’s Les Grands Transparents mirror. The good news for design fans is that the Simon brand has been acquired by the pioneering Italian furniture manufacturer Cassina. The line, which will be folded into Cassina’s I Contemporanei collection, will be available in the United States in November.

headline: In Tehran, Phone Call Between Presidents Is as Good as a Handshake

lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — Night had fallen here in the Iranian capital as Hassan Rouhani, the new president of Iran, sent a message via his now-famous Twitter account: He had just gotten off the phone with President Obama, who had called him.

lead_paragraph: “I dunno how to live,” says the man in the rumpled evening wear, having struggled back to consciousness through a hangover haze. He peers out from exhausted eyes in confusion and pain, and although his mind may still be fogged by alcohol, you have the sharp, sad sense that he’s never before understood his own unhappiness with such piercing clarity.

headline: Like a Rolling Revue, the Art Is Coming to Town
abstract: The Station to Station train has been traveling across the country laden with artists, seeking to turn places like Barstow, Calif., into temporary cultural destinations.
lead_paragraph: BARSTOW, Calif. — Hours late, the Station to Station train blew into town here this week to absolutely no fanfare, despite being covered in discofied flashing lights. The caravan, nine retro cars, discharged dozens of svelte young people in good pants and expensively shaggy haircuts, along with one guy in Google Glass. It’s likely that no one sports such high technology here, an economically depressed rail and military city of 22,000, about two hours northeast of Los Angeles. Once a regular stop on Route 66, with the vintage Stardust and Sands Motels to show for it, Barstow is now mainly just a place to pass through on the way to Las Vegas. But on Sunday night, the Station to Station crew was staying put, ready to turn Barstow into a cultural destination, if only for a few days.

headline: The Natural History of American Design
abstract: An exhibition at the Bard Graduate Center of artifacts from the Americas, which were lent to New York fashion designers by the American Museum of Natural History nearly a century ago, is unexpectedly relevant today.
lead_paragraph: The trove of rare photographs, textiles, design manuals and garments on display in “An American Style: Global Sources for New York Textile and Fashion Design, 1915-1928,” which opens today in the Focus Gallery at the Bard Graduate Center, calls attention to a relatively unknown effort after World War I by the American Museum of Natural History to inspire and energize New York fashion designers. The initiative granted the designers unfettered access to the museum’s ethnographic collections of Native American, Mesoamerican, Andean and South American relics. Curators opened up the museum’s specimen storage rooms and lent artifacts, like beaded Native American dresses from the Blackfoot tribe, to design firms and department stores for inspiration. The goal was to develop a distinctly American (as opposed to European) design language, but the museum ultimately abandoned the project and its fleeting dream of building a separate museum devoted to non-Western textile arts and industrial design, modeled after London’s Victoria & Albert Museum.

headline: Washington as Reader, Not Soldier
abstract: A new library and exhibition at Mount Vernon make abundantly clear that George Washington was not simply a man of action.
lead_paragraph: MOUNT VERNON, Va. — If you make your way into the inner sanctum of the imposing new research library that opened here at George Washington’s Mount Vernon on Friday, past its handsome reading room and through its rare-book suite, into a small oval chamber sparsely stocked with Washington’s own books, you might be tempted to accept conventional wisdom: Washington was first in war, first in peace, and first in the hearts of his countrymen — but, as a reader among the Founding Fathers, he was one of the last.

lead_paragraph: The first thing you notice is all the screaming. Icona Pop is a Swedish duo, Caroline Hjelt and Aino Jawo — singers both, but shouters more. Their hit is “I Love It,” inescapable for the last year, at home at indie dance parties and sports arenas alike. The hook is naïve and cheeky and, depending on your angle, exuberant or petulant: “I! Don’t! Care! I love it!”

headline: The Shifting Mandala
abstract: The concept of an elaborate art can be applied to the conservation of native plants.
lead_paragraph: RACING through our school lobby on the way to recess, my sixth-grade classmates and I stopped short. Usually, we would barrel onto the street for our 20 minutes of sunlight, but a Buddhist monk dressed in brilliant saffron robes caught our attention. He was creating a mandala. In this ancient art form developed by Tibetan Buddhist monks, millions of grains of multicolored sand are painstakingly poured into complex patterns. After hours of work, the sand painting is only one square meter yet symbolically portrays our entire universe in its shifting complexities.

Wright did not sustain a concussion, Manager Terry Collins said, but his thumb was bothering him enough that the Mets decided to sit him for Friday’s game against the Milwaukee Brewers, which the Mets lost, 4-2.

headline: Shelby’s Great Raid
abstract: The epic story of a Southern brigade’s 41-day ride through Union territory.
lead_paragraph: In the aftermath of the Union’s capture of Little Rock, Ark., on Sept. 10, 1863, the Confederate general Sterling Price led 8,000 rebels on a dejected march toward the southwest corner of the state, near Arkadelphia. Once there, the soldiers settled into their camps with the enthusiasm of a chain gang. Out on the edge of town, on a near-empty creek bed, Col. Joseph Orville Shelby, known as Jo, his arm in a sling, staked out a fittingly bleak campsite.

headline: The Silence of the Leaves
abstract: All the trees are turning in concert, rushing to a foregone conclusion, quietly.
lead_paragraph: The other night, one of the dogs rolled over in its sleep and fell off the bed. The crash woke me up, though it didn’t seem to disturb the dog. The moon was shining, even brighter for the veil of clouds around it. It was one of the restless hours — a few minutes after 2 — when thoughts come alive the way forks and knives used to do in the old cartoons after the humans had gone to bed.

headline: Reimagining a Boardwalk, This Time in Concrete

lead_paragraph: One of the enduring symbols of Hurricane Sandy’s fury — and there were many — was the havoc wreaked on the five-mile Boardwalk at Rockaway Beach in Queens, which was variously banged up, destroyed or swept away. For months after the storm, the parks department raced to ready the beach for the summer season, repairing concession areas and creating safe entry points.

headline: Israel: Violent Intifada Anniversary
keywords: ['Palestinians', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Hundreds of Palestinians clashed with Israeli security forces on Friday as Palestinians marked the 13th anniversary of the outbreak of the second intifada.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of Palestinians clashed with Israeli security forces across the West Bank, East Jerusalem and Gaza on Friday as Palestinians marked the 13th anniversary of the outbreak of the second intifada, or uprising. In the West Bank, protesters hurled rocks and firebombs at Israeli forces, who responded with tear gas, rubber bullets and the limited use of live fire, according to an Israeli military spokeswoman. In Gaza, dozens of Palestinians marched toward the border with Israel and threw rocks at Israeli forces by the fence. In the central Gaza Strip, Hamas organized a demonstration led by masked gunmen carrying rockets. Dozens of Palestinians were injured, according to Palestinian news reports. The military said five Israeli soldiers had been injured by rocks.

headline: Police Continue Search for Suspect in L.I. Shootings

lead_paragraph: More than 100 law enforcement officers continued to search on Friday for a man who the authorities say shot two men at his former workplace in Nassau County, killing one and seriously wounding the other. The suspect, San Ho Kim, 63, fled after the shooting.

headline: Collaborating Across Cultures
abstract: There is a joy to singing mysterious, melodious and beautiful sounds without knowing what you are saying.
lead_paragraph: When Sidiki Conde and I get together to write a song, the process begins with a formal greeting and a hug. Good morning, says Sidiki. How are you? I’m fine, I say, How are you? as if we’re testing the English language out to see if it works. We’ve known each other since 1999, when I began taking djembe lessons with Sidiki. Since then we’ve worked in each other’s bands and discovered we share an uncanny musical connection, despite our vastly different cultures. The language Sidiki and I are most comfortable using with each other is the language of pure sound. We stumble through conversations in English, but the guitar, drum and our voices have no trouble communicating. That is the realm in which we meet and it’s the soil our songs spring from.

headline: Thanks to the Digital Revolution, a Conservative Uprising Can Rally Its Troops

abstract: A fervent group of conservatives is harnessing the power of the Internet, determined to tell the story of the current budget showdown on its terms.

lead_paragraph: His nickname was Rambo. He was a sergeant in the Army, and he trained soldiers to be snipers. But after leaving the military in 2004, the authorities say, he put his skills to work in a less honorable way: earning a living as a contract killer.

headline: Narrow Escapes and Questions on Emergency Response in Attack at Kenya Mall
abstract: Pretending to be Muslim, hiding in a box and using the blood of a shooting victim were among the ways that potential victims escaped death.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — One man showed the militants his voting card, very gingerly placing his thumb over his first name and pretending he was Muslim.

headline: Tale of ‘White Widow’ Fills British Press
abstract: While there is no evidence that Samantha Lewthwaite was involved in the Kenya mall attack, British newspapers remain fascinated with the woman they call the “white widow.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British fascination with the “white widow” — a woman of 29 rumored to have been involved in the terrorist attack on a shopping mall in Kenya last Saturday — continued unabated this week, with tabloid and broadsheet newspapers retracing every step of her life’s journey, from soldier’s daughter to wanted terrorist.

headline: One State’s Way to Bolster Health Coverage for Poor
keywords: ['Medicine and Health', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Arkansas has come up with a plan to expand Medicaid using the new health care exchange, and other states are taking a look at it.
lead_paragraph: Federal officials said Friday that they had approved a novel proposal from Arkansas to expand Medicaid by buying private coverage for poor people through the insurance marketplace being set up under the new federal health care law.

headline: Islanders Coach Is Tough on Himself and His Team
abstract: Coach Jack Capuano has used his background in various levels of professional hockey to turn his young Islanders team into a club with playoff experience.
lead_paragraph: UNIONDALE, N.Y. — On a recent sunny Monday morning before his team’s charity golf event, Islanders Coach Jack Capuano smiled and nodded like a proud parent when, for the first time, John Tavares pulled on a blue sweater emblazoned with a captain’s “C.”

headline: What the French Think

headline: Rejecting Incumbent, International Cycling Union Elects Briton as President

lead_paragraph: Pat McQuaid was ousted as president of the International Cycling Union on Friday after leading the governing body through a tumultuous eight years noted for doping scandals and suspensions.

abstract: Victims of Hurricane Sandy who have been living in hotels since the storm lost a court battle against eviction and will have to find beds elsewhere, according to a judge’s ruling.

headline: Set to Play, Bulls’ Rose Puts Focus on Future
abstract: Derrick Rose offered no apologies in explaining his decision to not return last season from an A.C.L. injury, and said the time off had helped make him a better player.
lead_paragraph: DEERFIELD, Ill. — Derrick Rose sat in front of a microphone at Bulls media day dressed in his home white jersey. He took a sip of Gatorade, then flashed the megawatt smile Chicago had been waiting for since the day he collapsed in a heap on the United Center floor with a torn anterior cruciate ligament during a playoff game nearly a year and a half ago.

But after the section went to press the promoters of the festival canceled those shows, and two others in Washington, because of lackluster ticket sales.

headline: Who Goes to Work? Who Stays Home?
abstract: With the government shutting down after Congress failed to resolve a budget impasse, some federal employees will continue reporting to their departments and agencies, while others will be furloughed.
lead_paragraph: With the government shutting down after Congress failed to resolve a budget impasse, some federal employees will continue reporting to their departments and agencies, while others will be furloughed.

headline: For Yankees, Emotional Conclusion Isn’t End
abstract: The Yankees play a series at Houston after Mariano Rivera’s send-off in the Bronx. Manager Joe Girardi said Rivera could play anywhere he wanted.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — No sooner had the glow of Mariano Rivera’s emotional send-off in the Bronx faded than the Yankees found themselves in Texas. Thursday night seemed the perfect sentimental ending to a sad season at Yankee Stadium, but the schedule summoned the Yankees to unfamiliar territory for a bizarre conclusion to the year.

headline: The Non-Rivera Gets Booed
abstract: The fans in Houston let David Robertson know that he’s no Mariano Rivera.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — A loud wave of boos accompanied David Robertson to the mound in the ninth inning Friday night. It wasn’t so much what Robertson had done or not done. It was just who he wasn’t.

headline: What’s On Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (Showtime) LINCOLN (2012) Daniel Day-Lewis, below, in the role that won him his third Oscar for best actor, portrays Abraham Lincoln as he struggles to abolish slavery while the Civil War rages in this drama directed by Steven Spielberg from a screenplay by Tony Kushner. Sally Field plays Mary Todd Lincoln, his wife, who is grieving the death of their son Willie; Tommy Lee Jones is the abolitionist Thaddeus Stevens, who, along with his fellow Republican radicals, is demanding a vote on a Constitutional amendment; Hal Holbrook is Preston Blair, a party conservative who prefers peace talks with the Confederacy that evade a decisive solution. And David Strathairn is William Seward, Lincoln’s secretary of state, who is willing to trade patronage jobs for votes in Congress. “The genius of ‘Lincoln,’ finally, lies in its vision of politics as a noble, sometimes clumsy dialectic of the exalted and the mundane,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “Our habit of argument, someone said recently, is a mark of our liberty, and Mr. Kushner, whose love of passionate, exhaustive disputation is unmatched in the modern theater, fills nearly every scene with wonderful, maddening talk. Mr. Spielberg’s best art often emerges in passages of wordlessness, when the images speak for themselves, and the way he composes his pictures and cuts between them endows the speeches and debates with emotional force, and reminds us of what is at stake.” “Lincoln,” he added, “is a rough and noble democratic masterpiece — an omen, perhaps, that movies for the people shall not perish from the earth.”

headline: 2 Days, 3 Teams: A.L. Wild-Card Race Tightens
abstract: The Rays lost at Toronto and forfeited their one-game margin over the Indians with two games to go and the Rangers just a game behind.
lead_paragraph: The Tampa Bay Rays won an 18-inning game against Baltimore last Friday and did not look back, winning six more games in a row and, in the process, building a small lead in the battle for the two American League wild-card spots.

headline: The Quotable Bob Dylan
abstract: Bill Wyman offers his views on why Bob Dylan deserves the Nobel Prize in Literature.
lead_paragraph: Bob Dylan, a fierce and uncompromising poet whose writing, for 50 years and counting, still crackles with relevance, should win the Nobel Prize in Literature. Following these excerpts from songs written by Bob Dylan, I offer my views on why the lyrics deserve literary praise.

headline: Greece Arrests Senior Members of Far-Right Party
abstract: The arrests of Golden Dawn members, including the leader of the party and top members in Parliament, are part of a widening Greek crackdown on extremism.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Moving to drain power from one of the most violent rightist organizations in Europe, the Greek government conducted an extraordinary crackdown on the neo-fascist Golden Dawn party on Saturday, arresting 5 members of Parliament, including the leader of the group, and at least 15 other people.

lead_paragraph: Dave Eggers, author of eight books, including “The Circle,” out next week from Knopf, wrote this week’s cover story, an adaptation from his new novel. It tells the story of Mae Holland, a young woman whose life becomes subsumed by her work when she’s hired at the world’s most powerful Internet company.
