headline: Three’s a Trend | Ruffles Transform Ordinary Staples Into Showstopping Looks
abstract: The embellishment is everywhere this season, often presented with unfinished edges, adding volume and visual interest to the spring women’s collections.
lead_paragraph: Ruffles are the voluminous embellishment du jour at the spring 2014 shows. Sometimes origami-pleated and often tiered, the decorative accent looks fresh this season with the addition of feminine, frayed edges. The modern take on Victorian trimming also creates soft volume and shape, as in this suit at Marni, which was elevated by tightly arranged chiffon on the bottom of the white jacket. At Dries Van Noten, layers of pleats in white, cream and gold made a simple dress more compelling. Finally, at Rochas, the designer Marco Zanini’s sugary, eclectic collection included this simple shift dress with showstopping ruffles that swirled from the collar to the hem.

headline: Viktor & Rolf With a Few Touches of Punk
abstract: Designers Viktor Horsting and Rolf Snoeren, of Viktor & Rolf, did not go overboard with their concept of teenage rebellion and showed some charming takes on school uniforms with a few touches of punk.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The set of the Viktor & Rolf show Saturday afternoon in the Tuileries looked like the inside of a white-tiled bathroom at some fancy prep school, with the name of the designer label spray painted on the wall. It was created by Studio Job, and the soundtrack was by the indie artist Joan as Police Woman, who sang covers of Pink Floyd and Britney Spears (“… Baby One More Time”), so the idea was classic teenage rebellion.

headline: Of Girlish Pranks and Canine Koans

headline: In Collapse in Mumbai, Hopes Fade on Rescues
abstract: After rescuing 33 people, disaster officials said that they did not expect to find any more survivors in the rubble of a five-story building that collapsed early on Friday morning.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — After rescuing 33 people and finding 50 dead, disaster officials said Saturday evening that they did not expect to find any more survivors in the rubble of a five-story building that collapsed early on Friday morning, the fifth deadly building collapse in and around Mumbai this year.

headline: London Is Special, but Not That Special
abstract: For London to have its own exclusive immigration policy would exacerbate the sense that immigration benefits only certain groups and disadvantages the rest.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — NOT so long ago there was a beer commercial on British TV in which two pointy-headed aliens order a pint in a rural pub. “Up from London, are we?” the barman asks politely.

headline: Senate Democrats Respond to House Maneuvering
abstract: Senator Patty Murray of Washington, the Democrat who chairs the Senate Budget Committee, stated on Saturday what is becoming more and more obvious: Washington is heading toward a shutdown at midnight Monday.
lead_paragraph: Senator Patty Murray of Washington, the Democrat who is chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, stated on Saturday what is becoming more and more obvious: Washington is heading toward a shutdown at 12:01 a.m. Tuesday.

headline: In the Expanding World of Times Video, a Boss ‘From Another Planet’
abstract: Rebecca Howard, the general manager of video production at The Times, straddles the traditional wall between business and journalism.
lead_paragraph: When Rebecca Howard came to The Times about six months ago to run its newsroom video-production operation, one of her first moves was to discontinue something called TimesCast. The setup – a couple of journalists sitting around talking – just didn’t measure up to what she had in mind, she said.

headline: Why Judges Are Scowling at Banks
keywords: ['Mortgages', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Foreclosures', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: District court judges are not generally known as flamethrowers, but some seem to be losing patience with banks in cases involving lending practices.
lead_paragraph: LAST week, for the first time since the financial crisis, the government faced off in court against a major bank over lending practices during the mortgage mania. Lawyers for the Justice Department contend that Countrywide Financial, a unit of Bank of America, misrepresented the quality of mortgages it sold to Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the taxpayer-owned mortgage finance giants, starting in 2007. Fannie and Freddie incurred gross losses of $850 million on the defective loans and net losses of $131 million, the government said.

headline: Why Verizon Wanted It All
abstract: Verizon Communications’ move to buy the remainder of Verizon Wireless reflects the extraordinary profit advantage of wireless over landline service.
lead_paragraph: IT didn’t come as a complete surprise when Verizon Communications agreed earlier this month to pay $130 billion for the 45 percent of the Verizon Wireless unit that it didn’t already own. What’s startling, though, is the parent company’s dependence on its wireless unit’s operating profit. Without Verizon Wireless, the value of the old Verizon — the giant telephone company that provides dial-tone service as well as Internet and fiber optic TV to millions of customers — is vanishingly small.

headline: ‘Affordable Care’ or a Rip-Off?
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: Americans will begin signing up next week to buy insurance. Will the policies deliver care at manageable prices, or will “affordable” seem like a hollow promotion?
lead_paragraph: IT is no wonder the Obama administration branded its signature health care legislation the Affordable Care Act. For many Americans the basic problem with medicine — health insurance and health care — is that it has simply become too expensive, especially in a sluggish economy.

headline: Is the Game Over?
abstract: Baseball has never been healthier. So why does it feel so irrelevant?
lead_paragraph: MAJOR LEAGUE BASEBALL is doing just fine. Unlike the N.F.L. and the N.B.A., it has been free of labor strife for nearly 20 years. It has more exciting young stars than I can ever remember. It has even achieved that elusive “competitive balance,” with seven different champions over the last decade. Teams across the country are playing in brand-new ballparks that they somehow persuaded local governments to help pay for. Over the last 20 years, baseball revenues have grown from roughly $1 billion to nearly $8 billion.

headline: Dawn of a Revolution in Health Care
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Editorials']
abstract: Subsidies on new insurance exchanges will make coverage affordable for millions.
lead_paragraph: The United States is embarking on a truly historic journey toward near-universal health care coverage this week. Starting Tuesday, the federal government will make it possible for millions of uninsured Americans who can’t get health insurance, or can’t afford it, to obtain coverage with the aid of government subsidies. It is a striking example of what government can do to help people in trouble.

lead_paragraph: CRUISES. Conferences. New forms of advertising. Fancy multimedia storytelling.

headline: The Log Cabin Republican
abstract: Mike Fleck, a four-term state representative in Pennsylvania, hunts, prays and comes from a family with deep roots in his verdant stretch of the heartland. Will being gay nullify all of that?
lead_paragraph: ORBISONIA, Pa. — MIKE FLECK, wholesome country boy, cruised to a second term in the State Legislature in 2008, running unopposed in both the Republican primary and the general election. He got 100 percent of the vote in a largely rural, religious, conservative district.

keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'United States Economy', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Editorials']

lead_paragraph: The public has every reason to be confused about where the housing market is headed. Even analysts and experts have been backing and forthing about recent housing data, in part because what appears to be good news is, on closer inspection, mixed.

keywords: ['Poverty', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Malaria', 'Infant Mortality', 'Children and Childhood', 'Medicine and Health']

headline: Reform With Chinese Characteristics
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Editorials']
abstract: China is establishing a free-trade zone in Shanghai. Will it lead to the broader changes the country needs?
lead_paragraph: The Chinese government says it will start an unusual experiment this weekend that could be the first step in long-awaited reforms of its financial system. On Sunday, the country will establish an 11-square-mile free-trade zone in Shanghai where foreigners will reportedly find it easier to set up businesses; investors will be able to move capital into and out of the country with few restrictions; and banks, not the government, will set the interest rates on deposits.

lead_paragraph: BLUFFDALE, Utah — AT the Husband and Wife lingerie store here in Mormon country — where babies are welcome amid the sex toys and the motto is “Classy, tasteful and comfortable” — no one had heard of it.

headline: Imagining a Remapped Middle East
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'International Relations', 'Geography']
abstract: Borders could easily change under the pressures of war and ethnic conflict.
lead_paragraph: THE map of the modern Middle East, a political and economic pivot in the international order, is in tatters. Syria’s ruinous war is the turning point. But the centrifugal forces of rival beliefs, tribes and ethnicities — empowered by unintended consequences of the Arab Spring — are also pulling apart a region defined by European colonial powers a century ago and defended by Arab autocrats ever since.

headline: The World According to Team Walt
abstract: In “Breaking Bad,” there’s an alternative moral code with an internal logic all its own.
lead_paragraph: ACROSS five seasons of riveting television, the antihero of AMC’s “Breaking Bad,” Walter Hartwell White, has committed enough crimes to earn several life sentences from any reasonable jury. He has cooked crystal meth in bulk, hooking addicts from his native Albuquerque all the way to Prague. He has personally killed at least seven people and is implicated in the deaths of hundreds more. He has poisoned an innocent child, taken out a contract on his longtime partner, and stood by and watched a young woman choke to death.

headline: Hassan Does Manhattan

lead_paragraph: I HAD the chance this past week to take part in two press meetings with Iran’s new president, Hassan Rouhani, and they left me with several distinct impressions:

headline: Principal and Teacher, a Complex Duet
abstract: In Chicago, administrators have to devote lots of time to a new teacher evaluation system, and will also have to work hard to build trust.
lead_paragraph: Dedicated principals tend to work endless, exhausting hours. Along the way, they struggle with budgets, staffing problems, disengaged parents, gang violence, holes in the roof and finding clean clothing for impoverished children who arrive disheveled and unwashed.

headline: Hey ‘Starry Night,’ Say ‘Cheese!’
abstract: Museum bans on picture-taking are practically unenforceable and are obsolete.
lead_paragraph: ARE you thinking of seeing the big fall art exhibitions, including the Magritte show at the Museum of Modern Art or the Balthus show at the Metropolitan Museum of Art? Please be advised: photography is not permitted. Please also be prepared for skirmishes in the galleries between museum guards charged with enforcing no-photography rules and a public that is likely to ignore them. These days, many museum visitors arrive with smartphones and the assumption that they have an inalienable right to life, liberty and the pursuit of good photographs.

headline: Rolf-Dieter Heuer

lead_paragraph: The physicist Rolf-Dieter Heuer is director general of the European Council for Nuclear Research, or CERN, in Switzerland, where he oversees efforts to discover the subatomic underpinnings of the universe using the 17-mile Large Hadron Collider.

headline: I’ll Have What She’s Thinking
abstract: Researchers confirm the spontaneous orgasm.
lead_paragraph: SCIENCE has looked into some strange things over the centuries — reports of gargantuan sea monsters, purported images of Jesus, sightings of alien spaceships and so on. When I first heard of spontaneous orgasm, while researching a book on yoga, including its libidinal cousin, tantra, I figured it was more allegory than reality and in any event would prove beyond the reach of even the boldest investigators.

lead_paragraph: This interview with  Jonathan Klein , chief executive of Getty Images, a distributor and creator of photographs and other media, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: A Jet Groomed for Danger and Running Full Speed Toward It

lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Ellis Lankster has a large extended family, and growing up in Prichard, Ala., he spent a lot of time with his cousins — older, bigger, stronger cousins who dispensed tough love in maximum doses.

headline: The Enigma of Chinese Medicine
abstract: If a system of medical treatment practiced for thousands of years can’t meet Western scientific standards, should it be dismissed?
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, while visiting Beijing, I caught a cold. My wife, who is Chinese, and wanted me to feel better, took me to a local restaurant. After we sat down, she ordered a live turtle. The proprietors sent it over. I startled as the waiters unceremoniously cut the turtle’s throat, then poured its blood into a glass. To this frightening prospect, they added a shot of baijiu, very strong grain alcohol. The proprietor and waiters, now tableside, gestured with obvious pride for me to drink the potent medicine. I winced, found the courage, and drank up.

headline: Housing Market Is Heating Up, if Not Yet Bubbling
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', "Standard & Poor's Case-Shiller Home Price Index", 'United States Economy', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Inflation (Economics)']

lead_paragraph: HOME prices have been rising rapidly, so much so that there is talk that we are entering another national bubble.

headline: Mets Stumble With Extension for Collins on Horizon
abstract: The Mets, who are set to give Manager Terry Collins a two-year contract extension, lost their third straight.
lead_paragraph: After presiding over three rebuilding seasons, it appears Terry Collins will have the chance to oversee what the Mets hope is a resurgence. The team is set to give Collins a two-year contract extension, with a club option for 2016, according to a person familiar with the situation. The deal is expected to be announced Monday.

headline: The Progress Against Global Poverty
abstract: Readers comment on my column about the remarkable progress against global poverty and disease.
lead_paragraph: My Sunday column looks at something that has been happening over time so that we haven’t given it the attention it deserves–even though it may be the most important thing going on in history right now. I’m referring to the decline of extreme poverty. When I was in college, a majority of the world’s people lived in extreme poverty, and the proportion will have dropped to virtually zero by the time I retire. That’s astounding progress, and it’s also reflected in mortality rates. When I was in college, around 15 million kids a year were dying annually. Now the figure has dropped to a bit more than 6 million, and in my lifetime the figure will drop below 1 million. Illiteracy is also on its way out. Look, we will still face immense problems — the US is a good example of how even a rich country can have a severe problem with an impoverished underclass — and some kinds of poverty will be with us for decades or centuries to come. But the kind I’ve reported on in so many places, where illiterate parents have eight children who die young and are always on the edge of famine or disability, that kind of extreme poverty may be on its way out, along with river blindness, malaria, trachoma and other ailments.

headline: Last Shutdown a Lesson Lost on Capitol Hill
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'United States Economy', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Even those who lived through past government shutdowns, including in 1995-96, have varied recollections, or none at all, about how and why they happened.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The ghosts of shutdowns past are lurking in the halls of the Capitol, influencing Congressional leaders as they look for a way out of the latest budget standoff and wonder who will take the fall. But there is one little problem: even those who lived through those government shutdowns have varied recollections, or none at all, about how and why they happened.

abstract: Mr. Brown hit .370, including .450 as a pinch-hitter, to help lead Detroit to the World Series in 1968.
lead_paragraph: Gates Brown, a clutch pinch-hitter for the Detroit Tigers and one of the most productive in baseball history, who helped the Tigers in their march to the World Series in 1968, died on Friday. He was 74.

abstract: For musicians, crowd-sourced fund-raising is lessening the financial risk of performing in new markets.
lead_paragraph: A TWITTER user from Monterrey, Mexico, issued a challenge this month to the indie rock band Clap Your Hands Say Yeah: If it would perform in his home country, he would tattoo the face of the lead singer, Alec Ounsworth, onto his own left buttock. The band retweeted the offer for the amusement of its followers.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Punk Appeal at Viktor & Rolf
keywords: ['Cosmetics and Toiletries', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Models (Professional)', 'Paris Fashion Week']
abstract: The designers’ varsity-inspired collection was paired with masculine beauty cues: archless eyebrows and Elvis Presley-like hair.
lead_paragraph: At the Viktor & Rolf spring 2014 show, as covers of Pink Floyd’s “Another Brick in the Wall” and Britney Spears’s “Baby One More Time” resounded overhead, the designers’ varsity-inspired collection was paired with sophisticated, toned-down makeup. Pat McGrath kept the face nude and dewy — adding that dewy is the new matte — and focused on a “strong, boyish brow,” using a variety of brow pencils and powders. “We’re making the brows darker, filling them in,” she said. “We’re taking out the arches.” To experiment with a strong brow off the runway, she recommended using products only one or two shades darker than one’s natural brow color. The hairstyle, which Luigi Murenu created and described as “a bit masculine in the front,” also erred on the side of slightly subversive. The heightened roots were shellacked back into rockabilly stiffness, while the length of the hair was flat-ironed stick straight. Murenu summed it up as “a street look but more glamorized. It’s cool, it’s punky” — not unlike the collection.

headline: Modern Offices, Chock-Full of Offenses
keywords: ['Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Workplace Environment', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: A new book from Judith Martin, known as Miss Manners, and her son is both a sad and hilarious commentary on the state of the modern, open-space workplace.
lead_paragraph: THIS is a very confusing time to be alive. Life is changing so quickly that unless you are a hermit without electricity, you are likely to encounter social situations in which you simply don’t know how to behave. This is especially true in the world of work.

headline: Reid Calls House Bill ‘Pointless’ and Says Senate Will Reject It
abstract: Before House Republicans could even vote on their plan to tie government funding to a one-year delay of the Affordable Care Act, the Democratic leader in the Senate declared the House bill dead-on-arrival and “pointless.”

headline: Knock, Knock, Knockin’ on Nobel’s Door
abstract: Bob Dylan, a fierce and uncompromising poet whose writing, for 50 years and counting, still crackles with relevance, should win the Nobel Prize in Literature.
lead_paragraph: THIS year’s Nobel Prize in Literature should be announced in early October, and over on the tony British betting site Ladbrokes, Haruki Murakami of Japan, riding the waves of acclaim for his fantastical novel “1Q84,” is the favorite. Other well-known names — Milan Kundera, Philip Roth, Joyce Carol Oates — are bandied about, but Mr. Murakami is unique: among perennial Nobel front-runners, it would be difficult to find a writer more influenced by the popular music and culture born of the social and cultural upheavals of the 1960s.

headline: Report Cites Poor Communication Before Firefighters’ Deaths in June
abstract: Investigators did not assign blame for the deaths of 19 men in an Arizona wildfire, saying they followed procedure but ended up trapped.
lead_paragraph: PRESCOTT, Ariz. — For 33 minutes on June 30, as 19 members of an elite firefighting crew known as the Granite Mountain Hotshots marched through a burning forest south of this city in central Arizona, no one knew for sure where they were or why they had descended from the ridge they had been traveling and onto a basin where they would die.

headline: A Polling Place of Their Own: Students Win a Long Battle
keywords: ['Voting and Voters', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Voting Rights Act (1965)']

lead_paragraph: Students at Prairie View A&M University, the state’s oldest historically black public college, have fought for decades to persuade Waller County to allow a polling place on the campus. Now an unlikely coalition has succeeded, by cobbling together a compromise in time for the November election.

headline: Candidates in Midland Play Down Ethnicity
abstract: In Midland, a city with a white majority, the two front-runners in the mayoral race are Jerry Morales, who is Hispanic, and John James, who is black.
lead_paragraph: MIDLAND — In this Permian Basin city, which has never had a non-Anglo mayor, two minority candidates are considered the front-runners in this year’s mayoral race. And although political observers acknowledge that the city’s demographics have shifted drastically, they say that the candidates’ rise is primarily a result of their business expertise and their ability to guide this fast-growing city.

headline: For Old 97’s, a Collaboration That Never Ages
abstract: In 1996, the Texas band recorded with Waylon Jennings, one of their musical heroes. The band members recall the session, which yielded two songs being released for the first time.
lead_paragraph: In 1996, five Texans met in Nashville to record two songs together. At the time, the four members of the Dallas band Old 97’s were awaiting the release of their major-label debut for Elektra Records, “Too Far To Care.” But already they were considered too loud for country, too country for rock. It was a struggle that the fifth Texan in the room, Waylon Jennings, knew all too well.

lead_paragraph: The .45-caliber pistol that killed Lucas Heagren, 3, on Memorial Day last year at his Ohio home had been temporarily hidden under the couch by his father. But Lucas found it and shot himself through the right eye. “It’s bad,” his mother told the 911 dispatcher. “It’s really bad.”

lead_paragraph: Articles in this series examine the gun industry’s influence and the wide availability of firearms in America.

headline: Resignations Threaten Italian Coalition
abstract: The loss of government ministers from Silvio Berlusconi’s party left open the possibility of a confidence vote or talks on a new coalition.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Italy confronted a new political crisis on Saturday as the ministers in former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi’s center-right party resigned from the fragile coalition government, setting up a showdown that could shake the current political stability in Europe.

headline: House Plans Late-Night Votes on Spending Measures and Health Care Law Delay
abstract: House Republican aides estimated that final votes on the health care delay, the repeal of a tax on medical devices and a separate bill to ensure military troops continue to be paid during a government shutdown would begin around 11.
lead_paragraph: The House began grinding toward the addition of measures that would make further financing of the government contingent on a one-year delay of President Obama’s health care law and a repeal of one of the taxes that finances it — with a late night ahead.

headline: Former Chilean Intelligence Chief Commits Suicide, Officials Say
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: Gen. Odlanier Mena, 87, shot himself, officials said, after the government announced it would transfer him to a less privileged prison.
lead_paragraph: SANTIAGO, Chile — A former director of a Pinochet-era intelligence agency killed himself on Saturday, officials said, days after the government announced that it would close the exclusive military prison where he was being held for human rights crimes and transfer the inmates to a less privileged detention center.

headline: Documents on N.S.A. Efforts to Diagram Social Networks of U.S. Citizens
abstract: Details on N.S.A.’s push to exploit phone and e-mail data of Americans.
lead_paragraph: Details on N.S.A.’s push to exploit phone and e-mail data of Americans.

headline: Hagel Scolds Congress, Warning That Shutdown Undermines Military
abstract: Secretary of Defense Chuck Hagel excoriated his former colleagues in Congress for the current state of fiscal affairs.
lead_paragraph: Aboard a United States military aircraft en route to Korea, Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel excoriated his former colleagues in Congress for the current state of fiscal affairs and said that the new House bill to finance military troop pay in the event of a government shutdown would still leave United States forces undermined.

headline: Federal Agencies Lay Out Contingency Plans for Possible Shutdown
abstract: As Congress continued to spar on Saturday over a stopgap spending measure to keep the government running, federal agencies made contingency plans for a potential shutdown.
lead_paragraph: As Congress continued to spar on Saturday over a stopgap spending measure to keep the government running, federal agencies made contingency plans for a potential shutdown. Read the full article here.

headline: Georgia Wins Showdown Reflecting Airborne SEC
abstract: Georgia’s Aaron Murray and Louisiana State’s Zach Mettenberger combined for 7 touchdowns and almost 700 yards of offense in a duel between two of the top quarterbacks in the Southeastern Conference.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS, Ga. — The Southeastern Conference has not misplaced its identity, but the identity it built over a stretch of seven straight college football national championships has been snatched away by quarterbacks, most of whose surnames start with M. They fit passes into tight windows, manipulate safeties around the field with eye control and spread the field with darts to wide receivers and quick flips to running backs.

headline: Big Challenges Remain Despite Progress on Iran
abstract: A crucial question is whether the country’s divided leadership is truly willing to dismantle its formidable atomic infrastructure in order to end crippling economic sanctions.
lead_paragraph: During his travels through New York, President Hassan Rouhani of Iran answered hundreds of questions, and even took a historic call from President Obama as he left town.

headline: Without Closer, Indians Still Roll Toward a Wild-Card Spot
abstract: Two days after Chris Perez stepped aside as the team’s closer, the Indians clinched at least a spot in a wild-card tiebreaker after beating the Twins, 5-1, for their ninth consecutive victory.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — On Thursday night, after a harrowing 6-5 victory over the Minnesota Twins, Cleveland Indians closer Chris Perez reacted to his second consecutive rough outing by walking into Manager Terry Francona’s office and essentially firing himself from the job. Perez feared one more flub might ruin his team’s wild-card chances.

headline: In Damascus, Tension but Also Hope
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: Beneath the surface of what looks like a return to normalcy, the Syrian capital is deeply altered by the country’s civil war, now in its third year.
lead_paragraph: Beneath the surface of what looks like a return to normalcy, the Syrian capital is deeply altered by the country’s civil war, now in its third year.

headline: Vice Admiral Is Suspended in Gambling Investigation
abstract: Vice Adm. Timothy M. Giardina was the No. 2 officer at the United States Strategic Command before being suspended earlier this month.
lead_paragraph: A vice admiral who is second in command at the United States Strategic Command, which oversees nuclear war-fighting forces for the military, has been suspended amid an investigation into his possible involvement in illegal gambling, officials said on Saturday.

headline: A Surface Calm, Punctured by Artillery and Weary Arguments
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: Syria’s capital is now a city of checkpoints, new arrivals and a pervasive sense of war weariness, where even those of opposite views seem worn out by their differences.
lead_paragraph: DAMASCUS, Syria — Camouflage-clad militiamen guard sandbagged checkpoints along this storied city’s elegant downtown boulevards. Merchants who once owned their own shops are reduced to selling plastic trinkets on the street. Families from war-torn provinces sleep in mosques and schools.

headline: Shopping for Coverage
abstract: Those who are expected to enroll in the new individual health exchanges tend to have less education than the currently insured population, according to projections by PricewaterhouseCoopers’ Health Research Institute. They are also far more likely to be unmarried.
lead_paragraph: Those who are expected to enroll in the new individual health exchanges tend to have less education than the currently insured population, according to projections by PricewaterhouseCoopers’ Health Research Institute. They are also far more likely to be unmarried.

headline: On the Threshold of Obamacare, Warily
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Freelancing, Self-Employment and Independent Contracting', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: Some uninsured people are eager to sign up for new state marketplaces, but for others the decision will require a series of complicated calculations.
lead_paragraph: The insurance marketplaces that form the centerpiece of President Obama’s health care law are scheduled to open on Tuesday, a watershed moment for the Obama administration, but also a crucial turning point for millions of Americans who will finally get the chance to square the law’s lofty ambitions with their own personal needs.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, September 29, 2013
abstract: Quotation of the day for Sunday, September 29, 2013.
lead_paragraph: “I always thought I had Alex protected from being killed by another child by a gun that was not secured. Unfortunately, I was mistaken.”

headline: Creationists on Texas Panel for Biology Textbooks
abstract: The panel reviewing publishers’ submissions has stirred controversy because some of its members do not accept evolution and climate change as scientific truth.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — One is a nutritionist who believes “creation science” based on biblical principles should be taught in the classroom. Another is a chemical engineer who is listed as a “Darwin Skeptic” on the Web site of the Creation Science Hall of Fame. A third is a trained biologist who also happens to be a fellow of the Discovery Institute, the Seattle-based center of the intelligent-design movement and a vice president at an evangelical ministry in Plano, Tex.

headline: Germany's Dirndl Revival
abstract: Long considered the dusty uniforms of an older, more conservative generation of Bavarian women, dirndls are making a comeback, even catching the eye of fashion designers.
lead_paragraph: Long considered the dusty uniforms of an older, more conservative generation of Bavarian women, dirndls are making a comeback, even catching the eye of fashion designers.

headline: Dirndl, Dress of Past, Makes a Comeback in Bavaria
abstract: Long considered the dusty uniform of an older generation, the dress has become a wildly popular symbol of the good times and good life of Germany’s most prosperous region.
lead_paragraph: MUNICH, Germany — If there is one thing that Claudia Nowka understands, it is the desire of every woman to stand out at Oktoberfest. Nine years ago, dreading that she might sit down at a beer table only to see another woman wearing the same low-cut, tightly laced, traditional Bavarian dress, she designed her own dirndl in red satin, topped with a colorful apron.

headline: Last Shutdown a Lesson Lost on Capitol Hill
abstract: Even those who lived through past government shutdowns, including in 1995-96, have varied recollections, or none at all, about how and why they happened.
lead_paragraph: The ghosts of shutdowns past are lurking in the halls of the Capitol, influencing Congressional leaders as they look for a way out of the latest budget standoff and wonder who will take the fall. But there is one little problem: even those who lived through those government shutdowns have varied recollections, or none at all, about how and why they happened. Read the full article here.

headline: Álvaro Mutis, Novelist Who Created a Rambling, Ruminative Soul, Dies at 90
keywords: ['Writing and Writers', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Books and Literature', 'Poetry and Poets']
abstract: Mr. Mutis’s best-known character, Maqroll, wandered the world unwillingly, but always with a book.
lead_paragraph: Álvaro Mutis, a Colombian poet and novelist who created one of Latin American literature’s more memorable characters, the rambling and ruminative Maqroll, an inadvertent explorer of jungles and his own jaded soul for whom life seemed a long and futile boat ride, mostly upriver, often running aground, died on Sept. 22 in Mexico City. He was 90.

headline: Didn’t Ace SAT? Just Design Microbe Transplant Research
abstract: Beginning this fall, Bard College will look beyond grades and test scores by offering a new option for applying: writing four, 2,500-word research papers.
lead_paragraph: High school seniors with poor grades and even worse SAT scores, you may be just what one of the nation’s most prestigious liberal arts colleges is looking for.

headline: Sample Topics for Applicants’ Research Papers
abstract: In lieu of sending transcripts and SAT scores, students applying to Bard College can now write four research papers on various prompts.
lead_paragraph: Bard College is offering applicants a way to get in without sending transcripts, SAT scores or recommendations: write four, 2,500-word research papers that earn a B+ or better from Bard professors. Applicants must pick one topic from each of three categories, and a fourth from any category. Here are some of this year’s choices:

headline: With a Win, the Ending to Pettitte’s Illustrious Career Is Complete
abstract: In a start that tied him with Whitey Ford for the most by a Yankee, Andy Pettitte pitched his first complete game of the season and beat the Astros, his former team.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — They had a secret signal worked out. If Andy Pettitte, 41 years old and aching in almost every joint in his body, could not go any longer, if he needed to be rescued by a reliever, he would go to the rosin bag at the back of the mound. It would be his sign he was ready to leave baseball for good.

headline: Controversial Site Casts Shadow on Junior Event
abstract: The decision to hold the World Junior Championship tournament in a Turkish town near the Syrian border led some countries, including the United States, to keep their players home.
lead_paragraph: Two elements make for a successful world title tournament: easy access for all eligible competitors and reasonable assurance that they will be safe. Not every event has met these requirements.

headline: Rodriguez, Too, Calls It a Season
abstract: With one meaningless game to go, Alex Rodriguez joined a host of Yankees in saying he was done playing for 2013.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Along with Andy Pettitte, Mariano Rivera, Derek Jeter, Mark Teixeira and a host of other Yankees, Alex Rodriguez said he is done for 2013.

headline: House Passes Bill Linking Government Financing to Health Law Delay
abstract: The House, under the shadow of a looming government shutdown, voted early Sunday morning to link further financing of the federal government to a one-year delay of President Obama’s health care law and a repeal of a tax that helps finance the law – all but ensuring large swaths of the government will close this Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: The House, under the shadow of a looming government shutdown, voted early Sunday to link further financing of the federal government to a one-year delay of President Obama’s health care law and a repeal of a tax that helps finance the law – all but ensuring large parts of the government would close on Tuesday.

headline: College Football Around the Country
abstract: Teams, players and games that stood out in the third week of college football.
lead_paragraph: THE DAY’S BEST

headline: Rivera Says There Will Be No Encore Performance
abstract: Mariano Rivera, who revealed that he was pitching through forearm pain, said he was satisfied with ending his career with Thursday’s dramatic farewell at Yankee Stadium.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Mariano Rivera came to realize what all his fans understood Thursday night at Yankee Stadium. His ending there, amid tears of sadness and joy, was too perfect an ending to mess with. He revealed before Saturday’s game that there would be no encore to his dramatic farewell.

headline: Israel and Others in Mideast View Overtures of U.S. and Iran With Suspicion
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Embargoes and Economic Sanctions']
abstract: Iran’s rivals worry about its sincerity, and fear that President Obama’s desire for a diplomatic deal will only buy Iran time to continue its march toward building a nuclear weapon.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — For Israel and Persian Gulf states like Saudi Arabia, President Obama’s telephone call with President Hassan Rouhani of Iran on Friday was the geopolitical equivalent of discovering your best friend flirting with your main rival.

headline: Music With a Message About Poverty
abstract: The second Global Citizen Festival in Central Park featured Stevie Wonder, John Mayer, Alicia Keys, Kings of Leon, Elvis Costello, as well as a visit from Ban Ki-moon, of the United Nations.
lead_paragraph: Stevie Wonder went slightly off message at one point in his performance on Saturday night at the Global Citizen Festival in Central Park. “We must do something about the gun laws in this country,” he declared, noting that John Lennon had died at the hands of a gunman years ago. He expanded on this idea for a moment, before starting into “Imagine,” Lennon’s hymn of yearning idealism. In context it felt like a realignment.

headline: Mine Accident Devastates a West Virginia Town
abstract: The death toll from a blast at a coal mine in Montcoal, W.Va., has risen to 25, making it the worst mining accident in the United States in 25 years.
lead_paragraph: The death toll from a blast at a coal mine in Montcoal, W.Va., has risen to 25, making it the worst mining accident in the United States in 25 years.

lead_paragraph: A new television ad scheduled for broadcast on Sunday will call on President Obama to “do the right thing” to prevent climate change by rejecting the Keystone XL pipeline.

keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Any delays could prolong a five-year economic slump in much of the euro zone that has driven unemployment to record highs.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Mario Draghi will soon get another job besides being president of the European Central Bank: chief zombie hunter.

headline: Militants Blamed After Dozens Killed at Nigerian College
abstract: Gunmen believed to be Islamic militants from the extremist group Boko Haram shot more than 40 students as they slept in northeast Nigeria.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — Dozens of gunmen attacked an agricultural college in northeastern Nigeria late Saturday and early Sunday, killing more than 40 students, local officials said. The attackers were thought to belong to the extremist group Boko Haram.

abstract: Chinese police crack down on Internet gossip.
lead_paragraph: Chinese police crack down on Internet gossip.

lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: Don’t Dress Your Toddler Like a Hipster
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Parenting', 'Shoes and Boots', 'Social Media']
abstract: The stylish children on fashion Tumblrs don’t look like children so much as eerie, miniature-size versions of hipsters and socialites, and they are splashed across social media to inspire the style of actual grown-ups.
lead_paragraph: After watching my 3-year-old consider and reject 14 pairs of sneakers, I was just about beat and ready to call it a day when he spotted a pair of Crocs, the clunky and unfortunate footwear trend I was hoping would pass before my children caught wind of it. Of course, he loved them. And because it was nearing 8 p.m. and I was weak from hunger, I consented to purchasing the ugliest pair of shoes I swore I would never spend money on. And there was my son, sporting a style he loved, and I loathed.

headline: Southern California Calls Kiffin Off the Team Bus and Then Fires Him
abstract: The dismissal of Lane Kiffin came hours after a 62-41 loss at Arizona State, when the team arrived back in Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Two weeks ago, when Southern California Athletic Director Pat Haden was asked about the status of his embattled football coach, Lane Kiffin, he said, “We support all our coaches 100 percent until they’re not our coaches.”

lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: A Deadly Week in Northwestern Pakistan Ends With a Car Bomb Blast
abstract: A powerful car bomb ripped through a marketplace in Peshawar on Sunday, killing at least 38 people in the third attack in and around the city in a week.
lead_paragraph: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — A powerful car bomb ripped through a busy marketplace in Peshawar, the regional capital of northwestern Pakistan, early Sunday, killing at least 38 people in the third major attack in and around the city in the past week.

headline: Disruptions: Visually Impaired Turn to Smartphones to See Their World
abstract: Advocates for the blind say smartphones and tablets could be the biggest aid to come along since Braille was invented in the 1820s.
lead_paragraph: Luis Perez loves taking photographs. He shoots mostly on an iPhone, snapping gorgeous pictures of sunsets, vintage cars, old buildings and cute puppies. But when he arrives at a photo shoot, people are often startled when he pulls out a long white cane.

headline: Trying to Widen His Appeal, Cameron Accelerates Aid to Help Britons Buy Homes
abstract: Prime Minister David Cameron said he would immediately begin the second phase of a program that lets buyers get mortgages with small down payments.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Attempting to demonstrate that Britain’s Conservatives are on the side of working people, Prime Minister David Cameron on Sunday announced the acceleration of a program to increase home purchases.

headline: Ysaunny Brito Transforms Backstage at Kenzo
abstract: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Spring 2014 Fashion Week in Paris.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Spring 2014 Fashion Week in Paris. Here, the model Ysaunny Brito before (left) and after (right) makeup by Aaron de May and hair by Anthony Turner.

headline: What’s On Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (Showtime) MASTERS OF SEX Michael Sheen and Lizzy Caplan star as Dr. William H. Masters and his collaborator, Virginia Johnson, the groundbreaking researchers who sought to demystify arousal during the dark ages before the sexual revolution, in this new series based on Thomas Maier’s biography “Masters of Sex.” He was a brilliant, obsessed and often imperious surgeon determined to make his name by decoding the physiology of pleasure. She was a former nightclub singer and sexually liberated woman with a desire for a career and a deft touch with people. Together they spent thousands of hours watching others masturbate and copulate while wired to monitors. They also had lots of sex with each other, though Johnson told Mr. Maier that at first she didn’t want Masters — she wanted a job. Eventually, Masters left his wife to marry Johnson; they, too, later divorced. Though it takes liberties with facts and interpretation, Alessandra Stanley wrote in The New York Times, the show “does an elegant job of reframing their strange, complicated and at times deeply cynical partnership into a twisted but intriguing love story.” It’s enjoyable, she said, “mainly because the actors are so good. Michael Sheen (above, with Nicholle Tom), who is best known for playing likable charmers like Tony Blair and David Frost, is convincing as a driven and stilted egotist, a man who has compassion for patients and almost no time for his infertile, unhappy wife, Libby (Caitlin FitzGerald). As Virginia, a twice-divorced single mother of two, Lizzy Caplan (‘Party Down,’ ‘Bachelorette’) is dazzling in a role that isn’t easy: Virginia is sensual and sexy, strong-willed and good-humored, a modern woman trying to forge her own way in a world that is still backward about sex and the role of women.” And, like sex, Ms. Stanley added, “ ‘Masters of Sex’ gets better as it goes on.”

headline: Dueling Narratives in Iran Over U.S. Relations
keywords: ['Embargoes and Economic Sanctions', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'United States International Relations', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots']
abstract: Iran’s foreign minister said there was a “real chance” for a pact with the United States over his country’s nuclear program, but his deputy said Tehran would “never trust America 100 percent.”
lead_paragraph: Iran’s foreign minister said on Sunday that there was a “real chance” to reach an agreement with the United States over his country’s nuclear program, as long as Washington was prepared to end sanctions and recognize Tehran’s right to peaceful nuclear enrichment.

headline: Virtual Teamwork: Double Duty for One
abstract: In Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons, a player controls both brothers as they try to find a cure for their ill father in a medieval European town.
lead_paragraph: The conventional video game controller is threatened with displacement, or at least diminished appreciation, in our Candy Crush Saga- and Angry Birds-obsessed era of finger swiping on cellphone screens. In the controller’s defense stand those who say that the 16-button, twin-stick controllers — enticing and alienating as they may be — give players a sense of minimally acceptable, precise control.

headline: Chloé: Spring 2014 RTW
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: Robert Barnard, Award-Winning Writer of British Crime ‘Cozies,’ Dies at 76
abstract: Mr. Barnard, the author of 40 novels, was an accomplished creator of the “cozy” genre, murder mysteries that feature picturesque settings, colorful characters and minimal violence.
lead_paragraph: Robert Barnard, an award-winning British crime writer known for skewering hypocrites, snobs and prigs in his cast of characters as energetically as he dispatched murder victims, died on Sept. 19 in Leeds, England. He was 76.

headline: Philippine Standoff Ends, but Fighting Goes On
abstract: Sporadic clashes between soldiers and rebels continued in Zamboanga City after officials had declared an end to a three-week standoff.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — Sporadic fighting continued Sunday in Zamboanga City, the embattled southern Philippine city where government officials a day earlier had declared an end to a three-week standoff with separatist militants.

headline: China Sends a Real Estate Mogul to Prison
abstract: The banker, Gong Aiai, was sentenced to three years in prison for forging or illegally purchasing documents to buy dozens of houses.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — To millions of Chinese, the enterprising banker from the gritty northern province of Shaanxi is known by the nickname House Sister, and it is not exactly a term of endearment.

headline: Tibetan Dies After Setting Himself on Fire
abstract: The man in Sichuan Province was the 122nd person to carry out a self-immolation protest in Tibetan areas since 2009.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — A Tibetan man in China’s western Sichuan Province died on Saturday after setting himself on fire to protest Chinese policies in the region, according to Tibetan exile groups and Radio Free Asia, a news service financed by the United States government.

headline: N.F.L. Protects the Pocket as Black Quarterbacks Transcend It
abstract: Even as the number of starting black quarterbacks increases, the pro football establishment resists their freewheeling style of play.
lead_paragraph: A reporter called recently and said he wanted to talk about a golden era of the black quarterback. A record nine African-Americans started at quarterback in Week 1 of the N.F.L. season, signaling to some that this was the beginning of a dynamic new day in the N.F.L.

abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: Paris: Pleated City for Chloé and Céline
abstract: What started as a ripple in New York has turned into an all-out spring trend, as both Phoebe Philo of Céline and Clare Waight Keller of Chloé showed pleated looks in their shows.
lead_paragraph: What started as a ripple in New York, with Proenza Schouler’s silver pleated skirts, has turned into an all-out spring trend, as both Phoebe Philo of Céline and Clare Waight Keller of Chloé showed pleated looks in their shows on Sunday. Raf Simons also made a statement in his Dior show with pleats.

headline: Senate Action on Health Law Moves to Brink of Shutdown
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Government Employees', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: The Senate is expected to reject decisively a House bill that would delay the full effect of President Obama’s health care law as a condition for keeping the government running.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate is expected to reject decisively a House bill that would delay the full effect of President Obama’s health care law as a condition for keeping the government running past Monday, as Senator Harry Reid, the Democratic majority leader, expressed confidence that he had public opinion on his side.

headline: Greece Arrests Senior Members of Far-Right Party
abstract: The arrests of Golden Dawn members, including the leader of the party and top members in Parliament, are part of a widening Greek crackdown on extremism.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Moving to drain power from one of the most violent rightist organizations in Europe, the Greek government conducted an extraordinary crackdown on the neo-fascist party Golden Dawn over the weekend, arresting six members of Parliament, including the leader of the group, and at least 15 other people.

headline: Kipsang Sets World Record at Berlin Marathon
abstract: Wilson Kipsang of Kenya shaved 15 seconds off the previous record of 2:03:38, set two years ago in Berlin by his countryman Patrick Makau.
lead_paragraph: In late September, Berlin has become a kind of autobahn for marathon running, with seemingly no limits on speed, no strictures on the swift wonder of putting one foot in front of the other for 26.2 miles faster than any competitor who has come before.

headline: Families Drive ‘Cloudy 2’ at Weekend Box Office
abstract: The animated comedy “Cloudy With a Chance of Meatballs 2″ dominated a crowded field of films aimed at adults to finish No. 1 at North American theaters.
lead_paragraph: The lone family-friendly new release at the North American box office over the weekend, the animated comedy “Cloudy With a Chance of Meatballs 2” (Sony), dominated a crowded field of films aimed at adults to finish at No. 1 with estimated ticket sales of $35 million.

headline: Once-Calm Area of Iraq Is Shaken by Bombings
abstract: Several explosions struck Iraq’s northern Kurdish region, killing at least six people and setting off chaos in the streets of the capital, Erbil.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Several explosions, some of them from suicide bombers, struck the heart of Iraq’s northern Kurdish region on Sunday, setting off chaos and gunfights in the streets of the capital, Erbil.

headline: Some Bipartisan Support for Repeal of Medical Device Tax
abstract: The Times’s Eric Lipton wrote in March about new tactics employed by lobbyists in an effort to repeal the medical device tax.
lead_paragraph: The House voted in the early hours of Sunday to rescind a tax on medical devices that pays for a part of the health care law and delay the health care law by a year as conditions for financing government operations and avoiding a shutdown.

headline: Glow Art Festival Illuminates a Beach
abstract: The third installment of Glow, an overnight event in Santa Monica, Calif., had fewer artworks and a mellower, more ethereal ambience than its predecessors.
lead_paragraph: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — It took an entire week for Janet Echelman — along with a team that included a composer, landscape architects, lighting technicians and a bulldozer crew — to construct her art installation in the sand along the beach here. They dug a crater and strung enormous, handmade fishing nets overhead that were illuminated with colored light. It was the most expensive piece at this year’s Glow, this city’s all-night, interactive art festival.

headline: Nowhere to Run: Public Housing Elevators Remain Crime Magnets
keywords: ['Crime and Criminals', 'Elevators and Escalators', 'Video Recordings and Downloads', 'Public and Subsidized Housing']
abstract: The New York Police Department says elevator crime, in which the target is alone with the criminal, has persisted even as street crime has fallen.
lead_paragraph: The 13-year-old girl walked into the elevator on a Sunday summer morning, pressing the button for her floor. As soon as the elevator door in the South Jamaica Houses in Queens slid shut, a man who had followed the girl draped his left arm around her, pulling her close.

headline: Health Insurance Exchanges Scramble to Be Ready as Opening Day Nears
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'States (US)']
abstract: Officials are warning that despite fevered efforts, their new online markets where people can shop for health plans will not be fully operational at first.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — Rocky King, the executive director of Oregon’s new health insurance exchange, has done everything in his power to tamp down expectations for its opening on Tuesday.

headline: George Bignotti, Master Mechanic of the Indianapolis 500, Dies at 97
abstract: George Bignotti, the chief mechanic in seven wins at the Indianapolis 500, died Friday at 97.
lead_paragraph: George Bignotti, the record-setting chief mechanic of major American oval-track racing and a pioneer in making the successful transition from front-engine roadsters to sophisticated rear-engine Indianapolis 500 cars, died Friday at his home in Las Vegas. Bignotti, a native of San Francisco, was 97.

headline: Minnesota Orchestra Musicians Reject Latest Contract Offer
abstract: The musicians of the Minnesota Orchestra voted Saturday to reject management’s latest proposal for a new contract in the yearlong labor dispute.
lead_paragraph: The players of the Minnesota Orchestra voted on Saturday to reject management’s latest contract proposal, the fourth since April 2012. The previous contract expired last year on Oct. 1, and the players have since been locked out, a standoff that killed the orchestra’s 2012-13 season.

headline: Resignations in Italy Put Government in Crisis
abstract: The withdrawal of five ministers from the coalition government sets off a new crisis that could put Europe’s stability at risk.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Prime Minister Enrico Letta said that he would call for a confidence vote in Parliament, most likely on Wednesday, to clear up the political uncertainty surrounding his fragile government after the sudden resignation of five ministers belonging to Silvio Berlusconi’s center-right party.

headline: In BP Trial, the Amount of Oil Lost Is at Issue
keywords: ['Gulf of Mexico Oil Spill (2010)', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Fines (Penalties)', 'Clean Water Act', 'Oil Spills']
abstract: The fines against BP hang in the balance, and depend on the level of negligence that is determined and how much oil was spilled.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — With billions of dollars in penalties at stake, the civil trial of the British oil company BP begins its second phase on Monday, which will set the amount of oil that spilled into the Gulf of Mexico from the 2010 Deepwater Horizon rig explosion that killed 11 workers and soiled hundreds of miles of beaches.

lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Schohaja.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Wave-Inspired Eyelids at Kenzo
abstract: A bold streak of eye paint linked the beauty look to the beach-inspired collection.
lead_paragraph: To complement Kenzo’s beach-themed collection, the makeup artist Aaron de Mey used a bright white stripe on the upper lash line to evoke the crests of waves. De Mey used a fine, angled brush to apply the bold potion from a M.A.C. Paint Pot. “The finish is not at all chalky,” he explained. “It’s very matte.” The shape of the line is “blunt at the ends, to get a slightly more aggressive, punk feeling.” De Mey offered advice for applying liquid liner, an ever-daunting beauty task, at home: “Start the line in the middle of the eye, and then pull it outwards, and wing it. Always look towards the end of the eyebrow to give you direction. Then start the line again at the very inner corner, and bring it to the center to meet. That’s a good way to balance it.”

headline: Chiefs Deflate Giants’ Momentum, Sending Them to Another Loss
abstract: The Chiefs’ Dexter McCluster returned a punt 89 yards for a touchdown that broke open a close game in the third quarter that left the Giants at 0-4 for the first time since 1987.
lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — The Giants’ patchwork offensive line had played reasonably well. The team’s running game, while not overpowering, was not a hopeless liability for the first time this season. Eli Manning had time to throw, even if his receivers were dropping some passes. The Giants, for a change, did not have a ton of turnovers, and their defense, which had yielded only one touchdown, had recovered a fumble and intercepted two passes.

abstract: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Kasia Bobula.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Kasia Bobula.

headline: Fools and Fixers
abstract: A reminder of the haplessness of the Fix the Debt types.
lead_paragraph: Lydia DePillis has an interesting piece interviewing Paul Stebbins — a CEO who was very involved with Fix the Debt — in which Stebbins acknowledges that business is part of the problem in Washington, and proceeds to illustrate, unintentionally, just why that is. You see, if he’s any indication, big business is completely clueless about both the economics and the politics of the situation.

headline: The Tailgate Experience, British Style
abstract: Millions of Britons follow American football, but the one thing many of them have no experience with is tailgating.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — On his nationwide tour of N.F.L. stadiums a few years ago, Adam Goldstein sampled just about every delicacy tailgaters cooked up: cheese steaks, jambalaya, bratwurst, clam chowder and once, to his dismay, raccoon fajitas.

abstract: With political disagreements appearing more intractable, the battle over a shutdown and the threat of no accord on a debt limit, are beginning to rattle markets.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:40 a.m. |

headline: As Casino Vote Nears, Bishops Warn of Social Risks
abstract: Citing the potential for “enslavement” to gambling, New York’s Roman Catholic bishops issued a statement on the casino expansion referendum.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — With a little more than five weeks until voters decide whether to authorize up to seven full-scale casinos around New York, the state’s Roman Catholic bishops on Sunday warned of social problems linked with gambling, but did not tell residents how to vote on Nov. 5.

headline: Veterans of City Opera, Proudly Wistful, Reflect as the Curtain Falls
abstract: New York City Opera’s performers past and present mourn after what may have been the company’s final performance.
lead_paragraph: Shortly before New York City Opera put on what will most likely be its final performance on Saturday night, Julius Rudel, the maestro who helped build and lead the company in its heyday, sat in his Manhattan apartment and, surrounded by mementos from the troupe’s glory days, expressed his dismay at its probable impending demise.
