headline: Smaller Parties Gain in Austrian National Elections
abstract: The two biggest parties appeared likely to keep enough seats in Parliament to stay in power in their “grand coalition.”
lead_paragraph: VIENNA — Austria’s two biggest political parties made their worst showings in decades in the national election on Sunday, losing votes to an array of smaller parties, according to preliminary official tallies. But they retained enough seats in Parliament to stay in power.

headline: Bahrain Dissidents Said to Get Prison Sentences
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Political Prisoners']
abstract: Human rights activists said that 50 defendants have received terms of 5 to 15 years on charges of membership in a violent movement.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — A court in Bahrain handed down sentences of between 5 and 15 years in jail for 50 people on Sunday whom the authorities accused of belonging to a protest movement seeking to overthrow the government, human rights activists said.

headline: Global Citizen Festival
abstract: Scenes from the concert in Central Park.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the concert in Central Park.

headline: Indians Get Wild-Card Slot as Rays and Rangers Go to a Tiebreaker
abstract: The Indians beat the Twins to secure home field for Wednesday’s wild-card play-in game. The Rays and the Rangers also won, forcing a game Monday to decide the final wild-card berth.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — The day began with three teams vying for two American League wild-card berths. For the Cleveland Indians, it ended with a begoggled Nick Swisher drenched in Champagne in the visitors’ clubhouse at Target Field, a bottle of it in his hand, standing on soggy plastic while looking for somebody to hug.

headline: Spy Activities
abstract: In which we call Ian Livengood in from the field.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Put on your dark sunglasses, turn up your trench coat collars, and join me as we meet our minder, Ian Livengood, who is currently out standing in his field. And if you weren’t able to make it to the Westchester Crossword Puzzle Tournament held at Will Shortz’s table tennis club, fear not: the Monday through Thursday puzzles you solve this week are the very same ones that the contestants solved there, but without the ping pong.

headline: The Mets Recall the Past, Then Look to the Future
abstract: On a day fans flocked to Citi Field to celebrate Mike Piazza and the Mets’ proud past, the team managed a victory and promised good days were ahead.
lead_paragraph: Fans flocked to Citi Field on Sunday to celebrate Mike Piazza and the best of the Mets’ past.

headline: Still Meaty, Film Festival Lightens Up
abstract: The New York Film Festival, now in its 51st year, has expanded and developed what might be described as a split personality.
lead_paragraph: A Ben Stiller comedy in the New York Film Festival? Well, why not? Four years ago, amid complaints that the festival expressed a snobbish, ivory-tower contempt for movies as popular entertainment, such a possibility seemed unthinkable.

headline: A Rare Cutting From a Garden of Another Era
abstract: The protagonist of Elizabeth Gilbert’s novel “The Signature of All Things” would never have read Ms. Gilbert’s “Eat, Pray, Love” because her interests lie elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: Alma Whittaker, the large, spinsterly botanist who carries Elizabeth Gilbert’s new book, “The Signature of All Things,” on her strong shoulders, is a born scholar. She knows every species of plant on her father’s vast estate. Calculus puts her into “fits of ecstasies.” She reads in many languages, the older the better, even if this knowledge can be a hindrance. When Alma’s mother faints, the daughter’s mind leaps from Latin (“bring me sal volatile”) to chemistry (“ammonium carbonate”) to archaic chemistry (“spirit of hartshorn”) to Pliny the Elder (“hammoniacus sal”) before she can make herself clear to the plebeians on her staff. “Smelling salts!” is what she meant to demand.

headline: Experimenting Begins as the Music Starts to Play
abstract: Atoms for Peace played songs from the albums “Amok” and “The Eraser” at Barclays Center on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Atoms for Peace signaled what they’d be up to just a few minutes into their opening song, “Before Your Very Eyes,” at Barclays Center on Friday night. The band’s most mobile musicians, the singer Thom Yorke of Radiohead and the bassist Flea from the Red Hot Chili Peppers, had already begun what would be a full set of nearly nonstop, merrily unsynchronized dance moves: Mr. Yorke with jittery head, shoulders, hands and feet, and Flea with rubbery long legs and limber hips. The dance music they were making for themselves wasn’t taking anything for granted.

headline: Musical Celebration With the Highest of Aspirations
abstract: A program called “Promise of the New Word” kicked off the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra’s 91st season.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — I’m not a big fan of gala opening nights, which tend to be all about fancy dress, floral arrangements, celebrity guests and a feel-good repertory that extends from canon fodder to bonbon. On Friday evening at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center here, the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra kicked off its 91st season with a gala program that aimed higher, showing that it’s possible to impart a meaningful artistic experience without spoiling anyone’s fun.

headline: Giddy Freedom (a Little Mambo!), as Well as Pianistic Elegance and Wit
abstract: The New York Philharmonic’s first subscription concert of the season featured the pianist Yefim Bronfman.
lead_paragraph: Work began in earnest on Thursday evening at Avery Fisher Hall for the New York Philharmonic after a weeklong flirtation with film music and Wednesday’s season-opening gala. But there were many moments during this first subscription concert, in which Alan Gilbert conducted works by Ravel, Bernstein and Tchaikovsky, when the musicians seemed to be having far too much fun to justify the word “work.”

headline: American Team Wins Venice Cup in Indonesia
abstract: At the world championships in Bali, Indonesia, which ended Sunday, the American teams won two events and were second once.
lead_paragraph: At the world championships in Bali, Indonesia, which ended Sunday, the American teams won two events and were second once.

headline: A Big, Booming Show With Space for Reflection
abstract: The title of “Massive Attack V Adam Curtis” provides the basic information of this film-concert combination but cannot capture the space and sound of the experience.
lead_paragraph: The great virtue of “Massive Attack V Adam Curtis,” a 90-minute concert and film that opened at the Park Avenue Armory on Saturday night and runs through Friday, is the space afforded you to listen and think. I mean space in the physical and metaphorical sense. The Armory is huge, and the echoey, bass-heavy, slow-moving sound of the British band Massive Attack, playing live behind a few of the 11 surrounding screens, feels pretty capacious, too.

headline: ‘Just for Fun’
abstract: Scenes from the New York City Ballet program at Lincoln Center.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the New York City Ballet program at Lincoln Center.

headline: An Impish Faun, Swans, and a Lively Card Deck
abstract: Christopher Wheeldon’s “Carnival of the Animals,” Peter Martins’s “Jeu de Cartes” and Jerome Robbins’s “Four Seasons” were part of the New York City Ballet’s “Just for Fun” program.
lead_paragraph: Animals, playing cards, seasons: in all three items in the “Just for Fun” program at New York City Ballet on Friday, dancers continually portrayed something other than themselves. The program, at the David H. Koch Theater, encouraged you to see ballet as an art of representation.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Sept. 30
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Public Advocate Runoff on Tuesday
abstract: The two Democratic candidates are Letitia James, a city councilwoman, and Daniel L. Squadron, a state senator.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, Oct. 1, New York City will hold a runoff primary to choose a Democratic nominee for the office of public advocate, because no candidate received 40 percent of the vote or more in the Sept. 10 primary. The two candidates are Letitia James, a city councilwoman, and Daniel L. Squadron, a state senator.

headline: India and Pakistan Talk, but Tensions Are High
abstract: Nawaz Sharif and Manmohan Singh, prime ministers of Pakistan and India, shared promises of mutual restraint in Kashmir but little hope of a fresh start.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The leaders of Pakistan and India held their first official meeting in New York on Sunday, leaving with renewed promises of mutual restraint in Kashmir but little real hope for a fresh start in relations.

headline: A Swing and a Jaunt Around the Globe
abstract: The second program in the Fall for Dance Festival started in India with the company Nrityagram and ended uptown with the Dance Theater of Harlem.
lead_paragraph: When the Fall for Dance Festival works, it seems as if you’ve taken a trip around the world. The second program was unveiled on Friday night at City Center. The voyage started in India with the company Nrityagram and ended uptown with the Dance Theater of Harlem.

headline: Fall for Dance
abstract: Images from the festival at City Center.
lead_paragraph: Images from the festival at City Center.

headline: Paris Fashion Week: Céline Spring/Summer 2014
abstract: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Barbara Anastacio.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Barbara Anastacio.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week of Sept. 30
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Company Reports']
abstract: Data will include auto sales for September and employment reports, and Walgreen is among the companies reporting earnings.
lead_paragraph: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data to be released this week includes construction spending for August, the Institute of Supply Management’s manufacturing index for September and auto sales for September (Tuesday); the ADP employment report (Wednesday); initial jobless claims for the latest week, the Challenger report on job cuts, factory orders for August and the I.S.M. nonmanufacturing index (Thursday); and the Labor Department’s employment report for September.

headline: Editing Wikipedia Pages for Med School Credit
abstract: Students from the University of California, San Francisco, will be able to share their knowledge with the public and do research that has a life beyond the classroom.
lead_paragraph: Medical students at the University of California, San Francisco, will be able to get course credit for editing Wikipedia articles about diseases, part of an effort to improve the quality of medical articles in the online encyclopedia and help distribute the articles globally via cellphones. While professors often incorporate Wikipedia work into classes, hoping that student research can live on online, the university and others say this is the first time a medical school will give credit for such work.

headline: Apple Passes Coca-Cola as Most Valuable Brand
abstract: Apple, named most valuable brand by Interbrand, a corporate identity and brand consulting company, is one of five technology companies among the top 10.
lead_paragraph: APPLE is the new most valuable brand in the world, according to a closely followed annual report.

headline: News From the Advertising Industry
abstract: Account assignments, executive appointments and miscellaneous news from advertising agencies.
lead_paragraph: Accounts

headline: House Republicans Demand Senate Appear
abstract: Republican members of the House assembled on the steps of Congress and said the Senate should have opened a special Sunday session ahead of a looming government shutdown. A woman passing by responded.
lead_paragraph: Republican members of the House assembled on the steps of Congress and said the Senate should have opened a special Sunday session ahead of a looming government shutdown. A woman passing by responded.

headline: U.S. Plans to Unveil New Insurance Options
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'States (US)', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The Obama administration will announce on Monday new health insurance options to be offered through Blue Cross and Blue Shield in 30 states next year.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration plans on Monday to announce scores of new health insurance options to be offered to consumers around the country by the Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association and the United States Office of Personnel Management, the agency that arranges health benefits for federal employees, according to administration officials.

headline: China Ban on Items for Nuclear Use to North Korea May Stall Arms Bid
abstract: The export ban, if it is implemented fully, would give a boost to United Nations sanctions imposed this year that were meant to starve the North’s increasingly sophisticated nuclear programs.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — During the George W. Bush era, North Korea and Iran were joined together as the Axis of Evil, but with President Obama’s phone call to President Hassan Rouhani of Iran last week, that pairing — already out of favor in some quarters in Washington — was no longer so tight. It is virtually impossible, analysts say, to imagine Mr. Obama reaching out anytime soon to the leader of North Korea, Kim Jong-un, who has already tested a nuclear bomb and threatened to stage a nuclear attack against the United States.

headline: For Journalists, More Firepower to Protect Sources and Secrets
keywords: ['News Sources, Confidential Status of', 'Freedom of the Press', 'News and News Media']
abstract: What appeared to be a low point in a long campaign to rein in reporters and chill their sources may turn out to be a very big blessing in disguise.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this year, federal investigators secretly obtained two months of phone records of reporters and editors at The Associated Press, including calls on their home phones and cellphones. They did so without providing notice to The A.P., which could have asked a judge to quash the requests, or at least negotiated the scope of the investigation. It was an extraordinary incursion into the operations of a news organization, but the Justice Department did not violate any laws, which manages to be both comforting and shocking at the same time.

headline: British Game Maker Behind Candy Crush Seeking I.P.O. in U.S.
abstract: King, based in London, has filed for a public offering in the United States, in what investors and deal makers hope will signal a revival amid a slump in the technology sector.
lead_paragraph: The game maker King has conquered the mobile gaming world from its home base in London. Now, King, the company that created Candy Crush Saga, has its eye set on becoming a top technology initial public offering — across the Atlantic Ocean.

headline: Talk of Dynasty Adds to Buzz Surrounding Young Blackhawks
abstract: Chicago’s Stanley Cup championship in June was its second in four years, and the Blackhawks, with a talented nucleus intact, are the only team with two titles in the salary cap era.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — On the first day of Chicago Blackhawks training camp, the questions came hard and fast. They were not about line pairings or the familiar early-season talk of expectations. These queries were larger in scope, more historical in perspective: Are the Blackhawks a budding dynasty?

headline: City’s Web Site is Redesigned for First Time in a Decade
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Smartphones', 'Traffic and Parking Violations']
abstract: Visitors can quickly tell if alternate-side parking is in effect, if garbage will be collected that day and if schools are in session.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has spent much of his three terms shepherding New York’s march into the Internet age. He has encouraged the creation of new apps for finding public bathrooms and avoiding dangerous bike routes, among others. He has deployed a squad of data-crunchers to streamline everyday services. And one of his dearest wishes has been to transform the city into a second Silicon Valley.

headline: Memorable End for Two; Forgettable Year for Yanks
abstract: After sentimental farewells of their own to Mariano Rivera and Andy Pettitte in recent days, the Yankees had no tears left as they beat the Astros to finish the season with an 85-77 record.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — There was little emotion left to squeeze from the Yankees by the time the Houston Astros put on their show to honor Mariano Rivera on Sunday.

headline: Jean Anyon Dies at 72; Wrote ‘Ghetto Schooling’
abstract: Professor Anyon, who taught at the City University of New York, asserted that the problems that plague urban schools are inextricably linked to larger social ills.
lead_paragraph: “If I had a gun I’d kill you,” the teacher said. “You’re all hoodlums.”

headline: Intel and Sony Ambitions for Internet TV Services Meet Skepticism
abstract: Intel’s goal of introducing its OnCue service by the end of the year has been scrapped, and Sony, like Intel, has yet to announce deals to carry any channels.
lead_paragraph: Television services delivered via the Internet by companies like Intel and Sony could someday transform how Americans watch TV shows. But the services have to get off the ground first, and there are new doubts about whether that is going to happen.

headline: Amid Nuclear Issue, Israel Said to Arrest Iranian Spy
abstract: The announcement came as Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu prepared to speak at the United Nations and warned against what he viewed as a deceptive charm offensive by President Hassan Rouhani of Iran.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israel announced Sunday that it had recently arrested an Iranian spy who had photographed the United States Embassy building in Tel Aviv, among other things, in what appeared to be a serendipitous catch as Israel scrambled to ward off any speedy international embrace of the new Iranian leadership.

headline: Marcella Hazan, Author Who Changed the Way Americans Cook Italian Food, Dies at 89
abstract: Even people who have never heard of Mrs. Hazan cook and shop differently because of her, and the six cookbooks she wrote.
lead_paragraph: In his early days as a rising star chef, Mario Batali received a letter from Marcella Hazan after he had made risotto in a sauté pan on his television show, “Molto Mario.”

headline: Rei Kawakubo Says a Lot With Nothing
abstract: A review of Comme des Garçons, Junya Watanabe, Céline, Yohji Yamamoto and Jean Paul Gaultier
lead_paragraph: PARIS — It is a familiar scene, cartoonish in its intensity. One by one, on a plywood runway that rises at the center like a bridge through a garden, the models come out and stop under a spotlight swinging on a metal arm. It sweeps each woman’s outfit with light as the music, at first classical, dissolves in static.

headline: The Glass-Floor Problem
keywords: ['ADMISSIONS STANDARDS', 'Children and Childhood', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Income Inequality', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: Until we let affluent children fail, talented lower-income students will be unable to climb the ladder of social mobility.
lead_paragraph: WHEN it comes to the economic malaise facing America, the biggest problem is not the widening gap between rich and poor, but the stagnation of social mobility. When the income gap of one generation becomes an opportunity gap for the next, inequality hardens into social stratification.

headline: The House Rushes to a Shutdown
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'National Debt (US)', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Editorials', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Scorning the impending deadline, Republicans piled high their ideological demands.
lead_paragraph: This time, it wasn’t just a few Tea Party hotheads who drove the United States government to the brink of shutting down. Early Sunday morning, all 231 House Republicans (along with 17 Democrats) decided that crippling health care reform was more important than keeping the government’s doors open. It was one of the most irresponsible votes since the last shutdown in 1996.

headline: Psychotherapy’s Image Problem
keywords: ['Therapy and Rehabilitation', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Psychology and Psychologists']
abstract: The profession needs to promote its empirically supported methods.
lead_paragraph: PROVIDENCE, R.I. — PSYCHOTHERAPY is in decline. In the United States, from 1998 to 2007, the number of patients in outpatient mental health facilities receiving psychotherapy alone fell by 34 percent, while the number receiving medication alone increased by 23 percent.

headline: Nixon and Kissinger’s Forgotten Shame
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: They aided a regime as it killed thousands of Bangladeshis.
lead_paragraph: PRINCETON, N.J. — BANGLADESH is in fresh turmoil. On Sept. 17, its Supreme Court decided that Abdul Quader Mollah, a leading Islamist politician, should be hanged for war crimes committed during the country’s 1971 war of independence from Pakistan. When he was given a life sentence by a Bangladeshi war-crimes tribunal back in February, tens of thousands of Bangladeshis took to the streets demanding his execution. Since then, more than a hundred people have died in protests and counterprotests.

headline: Our Outlaw President?
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'National Debt (US)', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Constitution (US)', 'Federal Budget (US)']
abstract: Failure to raise the debt will force the president to violate the Constitution, one way or another.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — THE United States government is likely to shut down nonessential services tomorrow, after House Republicans voted before dawn yesterday to attach a one-year delay of President Obama’s health care law (and a repeal of a tax to pay for it) to legislation to keep the government running. The Democratic-led Senate is expected to refuse.

headline: Shrinking List of Video Games Is Dominated by Blockbusters
abstract: As video game players’ tastes shift toward smartphones and tablets, more and more of the money spent on console games goes to a small number of blockbusters.
lead_paragraph: Big video game makers, like their cousins in books and music, have scrambled in recent years to adapt to the digital technologies buffeting their business. Tens of millions of people now play games on smartphones and tablets, usually for a sliver of the cost of playing on a game console.

headline: In Trial, Romania Warily Revisits a Brutal Past
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Political Prisoners', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The decision to charge a former Ceausescu prison commander has raised hopes among victims and advocates that the country may finally be shaking off a national amnesia about its brutal past.
lead_paragraph: BUCHAREST, Romania — Remembered as a brutal sadist by inmates who managed to survive the prisons he once ran, Alexandru Visinescu bubbles with violent fury. “Get away from my door, or do you want me to get a stick and beat you?” the 88-year-old former prison commander screamed recently when a reporter called at his fourth floor apartment in the center of this capital city.

headline: Tennessee Turns Smith’s Giveaways Into Touchdowns
abstract: Geno Smith committed four turnovers and the Titans scored touchdowns after each one, as the Jets blundered their way to another loss at LP Field in Nashville.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — All that is new and supposedly improved about the Jets this season — the starting quarterback, the offensive philosophy, Rex Ryan’s coaching staff — was viewed at LP Field on Sunday with a fair amount of skepticism: the theme music to “The Benny Hill Show” accompanied their pregame stampede out of the tunnel.

headline: Writing Off Lives
abstract: With life sentences turning prisons into geriatric centers, states need to  encourage more rational sentencing and revive the use of executive clemency.
lead_paragraph: The prison population in the United States has declined modestly in recent years after three decades of growth. This is partly the result of saner sentencing policies for nonviolent drug offenders, who are more likely to be given probation and drug treatment than in the past.

headline: The Fault in Those Web Site Stars
abstract: As New York’s attorney general has shown, online reviews that shine too bright could be fakes.
lead_paragraph: Having consumers review restaurants, contractors or even doctors is a healthy concept. The problem, as New York’s attorney general, Eric Schneiderman, explained last week, is that some of those online reviews are fakes, written by people who are paid for them. And that, he said, is “worse than old-fashioned false advertising.” He announced agreements with 19 companies to stop manufacturing fake reviews. The companies also agreed to pay a total of $350,000 in penalties.

headline: In Florida, the Front Lines of a High-Pitched, Bite-Size War
abstract: Fears of dengue fever — an outbreak occurred this summer in Florida’s Martin County — have given added urgency to the effort to control mosquitoes.
lead_paragraph: MARATHON, Fla. — Much has changed since 1929 when newcomers to Florida, fed up with swarms of mosquitoes, erected a bat tower in Sugarloaf Key, hoping the bats would succeed where they had failed. Badly outnumbered, the bats abandoned the tower, leaving the monumental task to the locals.

headline: Birth Control and a Boss’s Religious Views
keywords: ['Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Editorials']
abstract: There are no legal grounds to exempt private businesses from the contraception mandate in the health care law.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration’s rule requiring employer health plans to cover birth control without a co-payment has given rise to a slew of lawsuits by private companies claiming the mandate attacks religious freedom. Three federal appeals courts have ruled on the issue, with two correctly rejecting that view as without legal foundation. Given the conflicting rulings, it is a good bet the Supreme Court will agree to address this issue in the next term.

headline: Grand Theft Auto Franchise Playfully Flicks Mud at Its Birthplace: Scotland
abstract: Far from the crime-scarred turf its avatars inhabit, Grand Theft Auto was created in Dundee, Scotland. Its authors fondly seeded it with inside jokes.
lead_paragraph: Since its introduction 16 years ago, the wildly popular video game franchise Grand Theft Auto has been set in some of the most recognizable cities in the United States. There were New York, Miami and San Francisco, and in the fifth installment, released to great fanfare this month, Los Angeles.

headline: For the Washington Area, a Second Lightning Strike
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Government Employees', 'United States Economy', 'Unemployment', 'Federal Budget (US)']
abstract: A shutdown of much of the federal government would hurt the capital region, already hobbled by sequestration and a stalled economy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A temporary shutdown of much of the federal government, disruptive though it might be, would probably have only a modest effect on the government’s cost of doing business and would do minimal damage to the economy over all. But not so for the capital region.

headline: Kreider Will Begin Season in Minors for Rangers
abstract: Forward Chris Kreider was sent down to the Hartford Wolfpack, the team’s top minor league affiliate, having not quite convinced Coach Alain Vigneault that he is ready for the N.H.L.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Their preseason over, the Rangers on Sunday trimmed their roster to 24 players, and there were a few surprises.

headline: S.E.C. Again Takes On Mark Cuban in Insider Case
abstract: On Monday, a new trial will begin in the Securities and Exchange Commission’s five-year battle with the Dallas Mavericks owner over accusations of insider trading.
lead_paragraph: Mark Cuban has tussled with Bill O’Reilly, Donald Trump and an array of N.B.A. referees.

headline: The Battle in Congress on Spending and Debt
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Federal Budget (US)']
abstract: Answers to questions about a possible government shutdown and what one would mean for federal employees and the economy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — If Republicans in Congress and the Obama White House fail to resolve their differences in time, the federal government will begin a partial shutdown at 12:01 a.m. Tuesday, with all but essential services curtailed or closed entirely.

headline: Qaeda Plot Leak Has Undermined U.S. Intelligence
keywords: ['Classified Information and State Secrets', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Terrorism', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: The disclosure in August of a terrorist plot by Al Qaeda has caused more damage to American counterterrorism efforts than the vast trove of data from Edward Snowden, the former N.S.A. consultant, analysts said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the nation’s spy agencies assess the fallout from disclosures about their surveillance programs, some government analysts and senior officials have made a startling finding: the impact of a leaked terrorist plot by Al Qaeda in August has caused more immediate damage to American counterterrorism efforts than the thousands of classified documents disclosed by Edward Snowden, the former National Security Agency contractor.

headline: For Girardi, Yanks’ Goodbyes Won’t Get Any Easier
abstract: As the Yankees look to 2014 and a transitional period, Joe Girardi’s experience in phasing out franchise stars could be invaluable.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — If there is one thing that Joe Girardi has developed a knack for, it is how to phase out franchise stars, whether it was the awkward and turbulent last year of Jorge Posada or the smooth goodbyes the past few days for Mariano Rivera and Andy Pettitte.

headline: American Sewn
abstract: For Edward Johnson, 44, a criminal record made it hard for him to get a job. He turned to an industrial sewing program after enduring bouts of homelessness and unemployment.
lead_paragraph: For Edward Johnson, 44, a criminal record made it hard for him to get a job. He turned to an industrial sewing program after enduring bouts of homelessness and unemployment.

headline: A Wave of Sewing Jobs as Orders Pile Up at U.S. Factories
keywords: ['Factories and Manufacturing', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Sewing', 'Vocational Training', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Textiles']
abstract: Factories are finding that years of doing business overseas has withered what once was a thriving textile and apparel work force in the United States.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — It was past quitting time at a new textile factory here, but that was not the only reason the work floor looked so desolate. Under the high ceilings, the fluorescent lights still bright, there were just 15 or so industrial sewing machines in a sprawling space meant for triple that amount.

headline: Lhota Seeks to Persuade a Liberal City to Elect a Disciple of Goldwater
abstract: Joseph J. Lhota, the Republican nominee for mayor of New York, has long combined penchants for fiscal discipline and for social laissez-faire.
lead_paragraph: A little-known underdog in a hotly contested race, Joseph J. Lhota knew his fledgling campaign needed a miracle.

headline: Legacy Meets Ambition at a Bronx Firehouse
abstract: Firefighter Ryan Blackwell, who was 13 when his father, also a firefighter, died in the Sept. 11 attacks, carried a woman to safety from a burning fifth-floor apartment.
lead_paragraph: It was only a few months after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, had killed eight members of Rescue Company 3 in the South Bronx that the family of one of the fallen firefighters, Christopher J. Blackwell, returned to the firehouse to help clean out his locker.

keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Prisons and Prisoners']

headline: Populist Left Makes Warren Its Hot Ticket
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Senator Elizabeth Warren, a powerful Democratic fund-raiser who has seized on economic issues, says she is not interested in seeking the presidency.
lead_paragraph: After Senator Elizabeth Warren spoke at a luncheon in Beverly Hills, Calif., last month, women from the audience swarmed around her, many of them asking the same question: will you run for president?

headline: Snapshots From the 2013 Baseball Season
abstract: This season had its top performers, memorable moments and players making headlines off the field. Here is a look at some highlights from 2013.

headline: Walter White's Soul, and Yours
abstract: Can a television show, where complicated characters stay with you week after week for years,  make you question your own moral judgement?

headline: At Kennedy Airport, a Complex Dance Over a U.N. Meeting
abstract: When delegates gather for the United Nations General Assembly, at some airports it could cause havoc, but at Kennedy International Airport, it is just another day.
lead_paragraph: The prime minister of the Czech Republic was due to fly in at just about the same time that contingents of diplomats from Brazil and Ukraine were scheduled to take off. At many airports around the world, this confluence of very important persons would presumably cause havoc.

headline: Marcella Hazan on Writing
abstract: The Times’s Mark Bittman visited the Italian chef and author in her home and asked her to tell the story of how she first started to write cookbooks.
lead_paragraph: The Times’s Mark Bittman visited the Italian chef and author in her home and asked her to tell the story of how she first started to write cookbooks.

headline: Photo Replay: Sept. 23-29
abstract: Athletes often insist that critical moments feel as if they happen in slow motion, but that’s when their instincts and experience kick in.
lead_paragraph: Athletes often insist that critical moments feel as if they happen in slow motion, but that’s when their instincts and experience kick in.

headline: Popular Demand
abstract: Fans choosing movies online seek out small coming-of-age dramas like “Mud,” which earned $21.6 million over 20 weeks in theaters, and big-studio extravaganzas like “The Great Gatsby.”
lead_paragraph: Fans choosing movies online seek out small coming-of-age dramas like “Mud,” which earned $21.6 million over 20 weeks in theaters, and big-studio extravaganzas like “The Great Gatsby.”

headline: In a Queens Diorama, a Favela Comes to Life
abstract: As part of a celebration of Brazil this year at Queens College, an artist has built a model of a favela, or shantytown, which moves past the areas’ reputation for violence and drugs.
lead_paragraph: A model city has arisen at Queens College. It is a sprawling, crazy-colored jumble of bricks and wires, concrete and plastic on the plaza steps near the library. Look closely and parts resemble Rio de Janeiro, down to the Christ figure overlooking that city. Nearby is our own Empire State Building.

headline: Giants Close-Up
abstract: A quick look at key moments from the Chiefs’ win over the Giants.
lead_paragraph: KEY PLAY/PERFORMANCE With the Giants trailing by 3 late in the third, Steve Weatherford lofted a 59-yard punt to the Chiefs’ Dexter McCluster, who returned the kick 89 yards for a touchdown. After the game, Giants Coach Tom Coughlin lamented that Weatherford’s punt was “right down the middle” and alluded to Weatherford’s low punt down the middle during the Giants’ loss to the Denver Broncos on Nov. 15 that was returned 81 yards for a touchdown. But Sunday’s punt was not down the middle of the field. It was high, far and caught on the numbers by McCluster, not too far from the right sideline. “I’ve got to try to get it closer to the sideline,” Weatherford said. “All things considered, it wasn’t a perfect punt, but it wasn’t a bad punt.”

headline: 2 Senators Call for Inquiry Into Metro-North Disruption
abstract: The pressure from Charles E. Schumer of New York and Richard Blumenthal of Connecticut came as the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said disruptions would go into this week.
lead_paragraph: Four days after a power loss upended service on much of the Metro-North Railroad’s New Haven line, two United States senators on Sunday called for a federal audit and investigation, assailing both the railroad and Consolidated Edison for the episode that has produced disruptions that are expected to last well into this week.

headline: Jets Close-Up
abstract: A quick look at key moments from the Titans’ victory over the Jets.
lead_paragraph: KEY PLAY/PERFORMANCE Alterraun Verner accounted for three of the Jets’ four turnovers, snaring both of Geno Smith’s interceptions and scooping up Smith’s second-quarter fumble. Smith and the Jets’ receivers thrived last week against Buffalo’s cornerbacks, but they could not handle the Titans’ physical secondary.

headline: High-Cost Runoff for Public Advocate’s Post Prompts Calls for Reform
abstract: New York City will spend about $13 million to hold a runoff in the Democratic primary, which has some suggesting a switch to instant runoff voting.
lead_paragraph: The numbers are attention-getting: on Tuesday, New York City will spend about $13 million to hold a runoff in the Democratic primary for an office, public advocate, that is budgeted only $2.3 million a year. And the combination of a little-known post with a little-understood election process is expected to lead to startlingly low turnout — maybe 100,000 to 175,000 voters, in a city of 8 million people. Yet the election is likely to determine the occupant of one of the city’s top offices, because there is no Republican candidate.

headline: In a Father’s Footsteps
abstract: Ryan Blackwell, a new firefighter at Engine 62 in the Bronx, had his first rescue mission alongside some of his father’s colleagues. His father was a firefighter who was killed on 9/11.
lead_paragraph: Ryan Blackwell, a new firefighter at Engine 62 in the Bronx, had his first rescue mission alongside some of his father’s colleagues. His father was a firefighter who was killed on 9/11.

abstract: Dennis Eckersley, a Hall of Fame pitcher who had 197 wins and 390 saves, discusses starting, relieving, his memories and Mariano Rivera.
lead_paragraph: Dennis Eckersley earned his Hall of Fame credentials as a pitcher capable of dominating both the start and finish of games.

headline: To Address ‘Greater Wrongs,’ de Blasio Outlines Wide Path to Hurricane Recovery
abstract: Bill de Blasio, the Democratic candidate for mayor, said he would seek to use the recovery money heading to create living-wage jobs, affordable housing and community health care sites in areas damaged by Hurricane Sandy.
lead_paragraph: Bill de Blasio on Sunday said he would seek to use the recovery money heading to New York City’s storm-battered coastline to achieve liberal aims at the heart of his mayoral campaign: creating living-wage jobs, affordable housing and community health care sites in areas damaged by Hurricane Sandy.

headline: The Push for Universal Pre-K
abstract: Despite apathy and opposition, publicly financed pre-kindergarten programs are likely to continue expanding in the United States, offering important economic benefits, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Nancy Folbre is professor emerita of economics at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst.

headline: Survey Shows Confusion Over Health Care Law but Support for Medicaid Expansion
abstract: A survey by The Commonwealth Fund shows support for the Affordable Care Act increases as consumers gain better understanding of its provisions
lead_paragraph: A day before the new health care exchanges open across the country, a new report shows that the more people understand it, the more they’re inclined to participate. But while most people are aware of the law’s requirement to buy insurance or face a penalty, a much smaller number have any understanding of the insurance exchanges opening on Tuesday or of the financial aid available to help people buy insurance.

headline: Justice Department Poised to File Lawsuit Over Voter ID Law
keywords: ['Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Minorities', 'Discrimination', 'United States Politics and Government', 'States (US)', 'Voting Rights Act (1965)', 'Identification Devices', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The Obama administration is expected to challenge North Carolina’s new law requiring strict photo identification as part of an escalating effort to protect minority voters.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department is expected to sue North Carolina on Monday over its restrictive new voting law, further escalating the Obama administration’s efforts to restore a stronger federal role in protecting minority voters after the Supreme Court struck down part of the Voting Rights Act, according to a person familiar with the department’s plans.

headline: A Youthful Glow, Radiating From Within
abstract: Business is booming in the anti-aging market, with many clamoring for lifts, tucks and fillers, but research has shown that youthfulness must come from within.
lead_paragraph: At a party I recently attended, a woman in her 60s proudly announced that her periodic facial treatments “have made me look 10 years younger.” A man of similar vintage said he was considering “facial tucks” to raise his sagging jowls.

lead_paragraph: Lt. Gen. James B. Vaught, the commander of the Carter administration’s disastrous April 1980 mission aimed at freeing more than 50 American hostages held in Iran, died Sept. 20 in Conway, S.C. He was 86.

lead_paragraph: Abelardo Morell went from a small Cuban beach town to New York City in 1962. The streets and its people were chaotic, unfamiliar and overwhelming to a 14-year-old exile who barely spoke English.

headline: Daily Report: In Video Game Market, Blockbusters’ Dominance Grows
abstract: As players’ tastes shift toward cheap smartphone and tablet games, the biggest console and PC games — usually big-budget franchise games — are posting spectacular sales figures.
lead_paragraph: Big video game makers, like their cousins in books and music, have scrambled in recent years to adapt to the digital technologies buffeting their business. Tens of millions of people now play games on smartphones and tablets, usually for a sliver of the cost of playing on a game console. But one part of the games business is thriving as never before: the blockbuster, Nick Wingfield reports.

headline: Putin’s All-Purpose Weapon
abstract: Drug charges are the perfect intimidation tool for the Putin regime: many Russians know how easy it is to end up behind bars, and the inhumane conditions that await them there.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Nadezhda Tolokonnikova, the leader of Pussy Riot, has been on a hunger strike for a week and has not been heard from in three days. The prison authorities claim she has been hospitalized and have indicated that her condition is serious.

headline: Fiscal Fight Unsettles Markets
abstract: The fiscal fight and threat of a government shutdown are causing greater unease than past political disputes. | Mark Cuban is sparring with the federal government. | The British game maker King has filed for an I.P.O. in the United States. | Warren E. Buffett paid tribute to “Breaking Bad” on Twitter.
lead_paragraph: The current fiscal battle raging in Washington, and the looming threat of a government shutdown on Tuesday, is causing greater unease than past political disputes and may rattle markets when they open on Monday, Nathaniel Popper reports in DealBook. Stocks in Japan closed down 2.06 percent, while major markets in Europe were down about 1 percent at midday. Stock index futures in the United States are pointing to a lower opening on Monday.

headline: Francis Sets a Date in April for 2 Popes to Become Saints
abstract: The decision to declare John Paul II and John XXIII saints on April 27, 2014, was seen as a gesture intended to promote unity within the church.
lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — Pope Francis said Monday that he would canonize two of his most influential predecessors, John Paul II and John XXIII, on the same day next spring, a highly unusual move that was taken as an effort to promote unity within the Roman Catholic Church.

headline: Marco Zanini Going to Schiaparelli, the Long-Dormant Couture House
abstract: Mr. Zanini will join the small ranks of designers in Paris who also present couture.
lead_paragraph: The long-dormant couture house Schiaparelli named Marco Zanini its creative director on Monday, confirming the longstanding reports that Mr. Zanini, who has been designing Rochas since 2009, would come on board. The company said Mr. Zanini’s first collection would be presented during the couture week in January. (His last Rochas ready-to-wear collection was shown in Paris last week.)

headline: Suspected Drone Strike Kills 4 in Pakistan
abstract: The Pakistani Foreign Ministry condemned the attack, the second in two days in North Waziristan, a volatile tribal region bordering Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — A suspected American drone strike killed four people in an attack on a compound in North Waziristan, a volatile tribal region bordering Afghanistan, a Pakistani intelligence official and local journalists said.

headline: Former Bihar Chief Minister Convicted in “Fodder Scam”
abstract: A court on Monday convicted Lalu Prasad for his involvement in a corruption scandal that siphoned off public funds earmarked for animal husbandry.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI – A longtime political heavyweight from the eastern Indian state of Bihar was found guilty on Monday of participating in a corruption scheme known as “Fodder Scam,” in which mid-ranking officials created false receipts and siphoned off public funds earmarked for animal husbandry for more than a decade.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Public Relations and Publicity', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: Sponsorship spending for cause marketing is expected to total $1.78 billion this year, up almost 5 percent over last year.
lead_paragraph: Sponsorship spending for cause marketing is expected to total $1.78 billion this year, according to IEG, Chicago, up 4.8 percent from $1.7 billion last year. By comparison, spending last year rose only 1.2 percent from 2011. The most active companies sponsoring causes – as determined by the percentage of causes reporting the companies as sponsors – are Bank of America, 18 percent; Coca-Cola, 14 percent; and three tied at 13 percent: Wells Fargo, Johnson & Johnson and Wal-Mart Stores.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
abstract: More colorful epithets for the companies you love to hate.
lead_paragraph: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

headline: Lessons From a Famous Bet
abstract: A conversation with Paul Sabin, author of a new book on a storied 1980 wager over the prospect of overpopulation — and the applications for the current debate over global warming.
lead_paragraph: Julian Simon, frustrated by the huge attention that Paul Ehrlich was receiving for his apocalyptic warnings about overpopulation, offered Mr. Ehrlich a bet in 1980. If a selected basket of commodities became more expensive over the coming decade  — which would signal scarcity caused by a crowded planet — Mr. Ehrlich, an ecologist, would win the bet. If the commodities fell in price — signaling a triumph of human ingenuity — Mr. Simon, an economist, would win.

headline: Mazda Recalls 161,000 Mazda 6 Cars
abstract: Following an N.H.T.S.A. investigation over faulty door latches, Mazda is recalling a number of 2009-13 models.
lead_paragraph: Mazda will recall about 161,000 of its 2009-13 Mazda 6 cars because the doors may not latch properly, according to a report posted over the weekend on the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration’s Web site.

headline: A Village in Muzaffarnagar Recounts Rapes and Murder
keywords: ['ARSON', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Law and Legislation', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Police', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Sex Crimes', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Survivors of sectarian violence in the northern state of Uttar Pradesh narrate how women in their families were raped.
lead_paragraph: KANDHLA and LISARH, Uttar Pradesh—More than three weeks after deadly sectarian violence broke out in the Muzaffarnagar district of the northern Indian state of Uttar Pradesh, cases of sexual violence against women during the rioting are beginning to surface. Only five such complaints have been taken up by the police so far.

headline: Government Shuts Down in Budget Impasse
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)']
abstract: The federal government will shut down for the first time in nearly two decades after last-minute moves in both chambers of Congress failed to break a bitter budget standoff over the president’s health care law.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A flurry of last-minute moves by the House, Senate and White House late Monday failed to break a bitter budget standoff over President Obama’s health care law, setting in motion the first government shutdown in nearly two decades.

headline: Tell Us Your Favorite Marcella Hazan Recipe
abstract: Her tomato sauce with butter and onion is perhaps Mrs. Hazan’s best-known recipe, but there are many others that became staples.
lead_paragraph: Marcella Hazan, the cookbook author who had a profound impact on the way Americans cook Italian food, died on Sunday at 89. Her tomato sauce with butter and onion is perhaps her best-known recipe, but there are many others that became staples in kitchens across the country. Tell us your favorite recipes from Mrs. Hazan’s books below; we’ll select a few to feature here later today.

headline: How a Debt-Ceiling Crisis Could Become a Financial Crisis
abstract: A play-by-play by The Financial Times tells how a default by the Treasury could unfold.
lead_paragraph: Come mid-October, the United States will have only $30 billion of cash on hand. On any given day, its net payments can reach as high as $60 billion. That means that unless Congress raises the debt ceiling, allowing the Treasury to issue new debt, the United States may find itself unable to make all of its payments — stiffing government contractors, or state and local governments, or even its bondholders.

headline: No Limit on Strikes for JPMorgan Chase

lead_paragraph: The effort by JPMorgan Chase’s chief executive, Jamie Dimon, to resolve a host of Justice Department cases will most likely result in a multibillion-dollar fine and the usual promises not to violate the law again. Simply paying money to get rid of investigations raises questions about whether JPMorgan should be viewed as a recidivist, and if so how the law should treat the bank.

headline: Almost a Year After Storm, TKTS Booth at Seaport to Reopen
abstract: The site, which was closed when Hurricane Sandy damaged the South Street Seaport last October, will reopen on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: The Theater Development Fund, the nonprofit group that runs the city’s TKTS discount theater-tickets booths, said it would reopen its TKTS site at the South Street Seaport on Tuesday. The site, which is at John Street and Front Street in Lower Manhattan and sells half-price tickets to Broadway and Off Broadway shows, had been closed after Hurricane Sandy damaged the Seaport last October.

headline: Invoking Sept. 11, Syrian Accuses U.S. of Hypocrisy
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Terrorism', 'Biological and Chemical Warfare']
abstract: In a point-by-point rejection of the West’s version of the conflict in Syria, the Syrian foreign minister likened the “devastations of terrorism” in Syria and the United States.
lead_paragraph: Seeking to rebut Syria’s political opposition and its outside supporters, the Syrian foreign minister on Monday equated his country’s brutal conflict to the Sept. 11 attacks and accused the United States of hypocrisy.

headline: The Good, the Bad, the Ugly … and the Beautiful
abstract: While preparing for his spring show on Monday, Fausto Puglisi took a moment to answer some questions at the Ungaro studio on the Avenue Montaigne.
lead_paragraph: Anna Dello Russo, the Italian editor and stylist who attends the shows with a mobile wardrobe, turned up in Paris this week wearing a dress with embroidered palm trees made of sparkly sequins on its stiff teacup skirt. Anyone who had been at the spring shows in Milan last week would have recognized it as the work of the Sicilian-born Fausto Puglisi, one of the city’s rising stars, right from the runway. Mr. Puglisi, whose brash fashion lives up to his personality, also recently took over the troubled ready-to-wear house of Ungaro in Paris, and his first collection, for fall, has turned out to be a surprise hit of the season. While preparing for his spring show on Monday, Mr. Puglisi took a moment to answer some questions at the Ungaro studio on the Avenue Montaigne.

abstract: The vast majority of small-business owners are worried about cybersecurity and nearly half report their businesses were victims of cyberattacks.
lead_paragraph: The National Small Business Association recently released its 2013 Small Business Technology Survey, a study of small-business owners selected by the association. Among the findings were that 94 percent of small-business owners were worried about cybersecurity and nearly half reported their businesses were victims of cyberattacks.

headline: Many Nursing Homes Operate Without Adequate Sprinkler Systems
abstract: More than 1,100 older nursing homes do not have sprinklers or have only partial systems.
lead_paragraph: Now and then, you learn something about caring for the elderly that stops you in your tracks.

headline: Somali Militants Mixing Business and Terror
abstract: The Shabab, which claimed responsibility for the deadly mall siege in Nairobi, Kenya, makes money through illegal endeavors and even employs a team of accountants.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — Illicit ivory, kidnappings, piracy ransoms, smuggled charcoal, extorted payments from aid organizations and even fake charity drives pretending to collect money for the poor — the Shabab militant group has shifted from one illegal business to another, drawing money from East Africa’s underworld to finance attacks like the recent deadly siege at a Nairobi shopping mall.

headline: Monday Motorsports: John Force, 15-Time Funny Car Champion, Wins Midwest Nationals in a Close Race
abstract: Now 64, John Force shows that he is still a force on the drag strip by winning the Funny Car title at the N.H.R.A. Midwest Nationals on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: John Force, 64, the 15-time Funny Car champion, won Sunday’s National Hot Rod Association Midwest Nationals near St. Louis. Force’s victory over Jack Beckman in a close race in the final round was Force’s 136th win in a career that began in 1978. It moved Force to within six points of the points leader, Matt Hagan.

headline: Left Behind At Chickamauga
abstract: The horrors of the Civil War’s second-bloodiest battle continued after the fighting stopped.
lead_paragraph: For the title of his definitive book on the Battle of Chickamauga, the historian (and Disunion contributor) Peter Cozzens took three words from the diary of a Union soldier who fought there. “This Terrible Sound,” as described by Pvt. Alva Griest of the 72nd Indiana Infantry, did not refer to the ear-splitting cacophony that usually prevailed on a Civil War battlefield — the roar of cannons, the crack of muskets and the shrieks of a charging enemy — but “a worse, more heart-rending sound” that haunted him for years afterward. Like every other soldier, federal and Confederate alike, who spent the night of Sept. 19, 1863, on the front lines, Griest was deeply affected by “the groans from thousands of wounded in our front crying in anguish and pain, some for death to relieve them, others for water. Oh, if I could only drown this terrible sound, and yet I may also lie thus ere tomorrow’s sun crosses the heavens.”

headline: Disability Rights Group Rallies in Support of Health Law
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Members of a grass-roots disability rights group called Adapt, many of them in motorized wheelchairs, gathered on the steps of the Longworth House Office Building to protest House Republicans’ attempts to repeal and delay the health care law.
lead_paragraph: By midday Monday, roughly three dozen members of a grass-roots disability rights group called Adapt, many of them in motorized wheelchairs, had gathered on the steps of the Longworth House Office Building to protest House Republicans’ repeated attempts to repeal and delay President Obama’s health care law.

headline: Evolution, Speeded by Computation
abstract: Nature speaks in algorithms, says a new book, “Probably Approximately Correct,” which suggests that computation has always been the dominating force on earth.
lead_paragraph: Our daily lives are growing ever more dependent on algorithms, those omnipresent computational procedures that run programs on our laptops, our smartphones, our GPS devices and much else. Algorithms influence our decisions, too: when we choose a movie on Netflix or a book on Amazon, we are presented with recommendations churned out by sophisticated algorithms that take into account our past choices and those of other users determined (by still other algorithms) to be similar to us.

headline: Online Map Helps New Yorkers Understand Federal Health Law Benefits
abstract: The New York Health Foundation has unveiled an online map that shows estimates of how the health care law affect coverage for New Yorkers.
lead_paragraph: More than one million New Yorkers are expected to gain coverage under the federal health care law, according to estimates from the New York State Health Foundation. On Monday, the foundation unveiled an online map, where people will be able to view estimates by region of how many people are expected to be covered under Medicaid and how many will get private insurance – as well as how many are likely to remain uninsured.

headline: A Scramble as Day 1 Approaches
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: With fewer than 24 hours to go, officials are still working to prepare and explain the new health insurance exchanges scheduled to open on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: With fewer than 24 hours until the new health insurance exchanges are scheduled to open, even some of the states that have prepared the most are describing Tuesday as a “soft launch” and warning of technical glitches and other delays, The Times’s Abby Goodnough reported Monday.

headline: Westerners’ Smuggled Letters Offer Glimpse of Egyptian Prisons
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots']
abstract: Two Canadians and one American caught up in the crackdown in Egypt said they were beaten, made to sleep on bug-infested floors and denied medical care.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The prisoners were stripped and beaten, and their heads were shaved. They slept packed “like sardines” on concrete floors of cells infested with cockroaches. One said that an open wound on his arm was left oozing, that a cellmate suffered a heart attack without getting medical attention, and that another prisoner was 11 years old.

headline: Powerful North Indian Politician Is Convicted of Siphoning Funds

lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — A longtime political heavyweight from northern India, Lalu Prasad, was found guilty on Monday of participating in a scheme that siphoned off public money for more than a decade, ending a trial that was seen as a watershed in India’s struggle with corruption.

headline: Obama Says He Isn’t Resigned to a Shutdown

abstract: In comments at the White House on Monday, the president said he was not resigned to a government shutdown and indicated that he expected to speak with Congressional leaders in the coming days.
lead_paragraph: As a midnight deadline for Congress to finance the domestic and military operations of government, President Obama has largely remained on the sidelines – in “wait and see mode” as one aide put it – as Congress prepares for the latest go-round in the debate over financing the government and Mr. Obama’s signature health care law.

headline: Republicans Reject Prospect of One-Week Extension
abstract: House Republicans repeatedly rejected the idea as they walked into their closed-door conference meeting Monday afternoon.
lead_paragraph: Though Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the Republican leader, briefly floated the idea of a one-week stop-gap measure to fund the government and avert, at least briefly, a government shutdown, House Republicans repeatedly rejected the idea as they walked into their closed-door conference meeting Monday afternoon.

headline: House to Add Measure Cutting Health Subsidy for Congress

headline: Need Birth Control Advice, Fast? Text Planned Parenthood
abstract: Planned Parenthood’s experts have reached more than 250,000 people by text or chat since it began offering that option.
lead_paragraph: When teenagers or young adults need advice from an organization like Planned Parenthood, they tend to think they need that advice now — not the next time they can grab an educator after health class, not the next time they are alone and can call a hotline, and certainly not at their next appointment for reproductive health services, if they even have such an appointment. This is now as in, the condom broke; my period’s late; or I told him to pull out and he didn’t.

headline: An Ex-Trader, Now a Sociologist, Looks at the Changes in Goldman
abstract: “What Happened to Goldman Sachs” examines the bank’s evolution from an elite private partnership to a vast public corporation – and the effects of that transformation on its culture.
lead_paragraph: There once was a time, before JPMorgan Chase’s woes dominated headlines, when Goldman Sachs was the symbol for Wall Street’s dark side. Its depiction as a bloodsucking “vampire squid” in a Rolling Stone article captured the public’s imagination. And “Why I Am Leaving Goldman Sachs,” a damning resignation letter published as an opinion article in The New York Times, also touched a nerve.

headline: Iran Signals Cultural Thaw With Oscar Choice
abstract: Iran selects “The Past” as its foreign-language Oscar nominee, something of a surprise given the subject matter.
lead_paragraph: Iran’s hostile political attitude towards the United States isn’t the only thing that has been in flux since a new president, Hassan Rouhani, took office in August. There are also signs of an incipient cultural thaw, made most evident this weekend when the country’s film selection committee chose to submit Asghar Farhadi’s “The Past” as its candidate for the Academy Award for best foreign-language film.

headline: Weekend Gun Report: September 27-29, 2013
abstract: A weekend in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: The number of children accidentally shot and killed by adults or other children in America is higher than previously reported, according to a front-page story in yesterday’s Times. A review of hundreds of child firearm deaths by Michael Luo and Mike McIntire found that accidental shootings occur roughly twice as often as records indicate because of idiosyncrasies in how such deaths are classified by the authorities: more than half of the 259 accidental firearm deaths of kids under age 15 identified by The Times in eight states were not recorded as accidents. Such shootings are routinely classified as homicides, a common practice when one person unintentionally shoots another.

headline: Should Slowing Trade Growth Worry Us?
abstract: No law says that trade has to grow more rapidly than GDP.
lead_paragraph: I’ve spent most of today both under pressure to get an assignment out the door and under the weather; still sniffling, but the piece has been emailed off, so a bit of time for the blog. Except I feel like taking a vacation from both the shutdown and Obamacare. So let’s talk about trade — specifically, a recent post by Gavyn Davies, “Why world trade growth has lost its mojo,” which expresses deep concern over the fact that in recent years trade hasn’t grown much faster than global GDP. He suggests that hidden protectionism may be partly to blame, and that this may have large economic costs.

headline: Bloomberg Says City Opera Is On Its Own
abstract: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said Monday that neither the city nor his private foundation would step in to save New York City Opera, which has said it will file for bankruptcy protection without support.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 6:48 p.m. | Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is not riding to the rescue of New York City Opera, which has said that it plans to file for bankruptcy and dissolve itself if it fails to raise $7 million by the end of Monday.

headline: Polls in Overtime on Affordable Care Act

abstract: A series of polls show gaps in knowledge but more acceptance as consumers gain understanding of Affordable Care Act.
