headline: Old Atrocities, Now Official, Galvanize Afghanistan
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: The details and names of nearly 5,000 people killed by the Afghan Communist government in 1978 and 1979 were unearthed by Dutch investigators and made public by the Netherlands national prosecutor’s office.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — So many people were buried alive by bulldozers in the barren fields around the Pul-e-Charkhi Prison on Kabul’s outskirts that guilty soldiers later said it was like an earthquake as their victims tried to claw their way out.

headline: The Board of Elections: An Ongoing Disgrace
abstract: The board took more than two weeks to count votes after the primary election on September 10.
lead_paragraph: Elections in New York City are an ongoing disgrace. In a city where everything is supposed to happen faster than anywhere else (hence the New York minute), the Board of Elections took more than two weeks to count votes after the primary election on September 10 — finally finishing on Friday, September 27. That’s an eon by today’s standards, and it’s an embarrassment.

headline: For Markets, a Shutdown Is Usually a Ripple
abstract: Previous government shutdowns have not been catastrophic to the markets, but no precedent exists for how they might react to a failure to raise the debt ceiling.
lead_paragraph: As a government shutdown draws closer, many analysts are looking to past shutdowns for some guide as to what might happen — particularly in the markets. The precedent is not all that frightening, according to data put together by Joseph P. Quinlan, chief market strategist at U.S. Trust, Bank of America Private Wealth Management. The chart below shows how much the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index moved from the beginning of the shutdown to the end. The last time it happened, in early 1996, the market actually ended up slightly.

headline: CBGB Festival Is Expanding in Its Second Year
abstract: My Morning Jacket, the Wallflowers and Grizzly Bear will perform in Times Square on Oct. 12 as part of the festival’s expanded second year.
lead_paragraph: My Morning Jacket, the Wallflowers and Grizzly Bear will perform free concerts in Times Square on Oct. 12 as part of the second annual CBGB Music and Film Festival, the event’s organizers said.

headline: BMW Recalls 76,000 Vehicles for Brake Booster Problem
abstract: A number of BMW vehicles equipped with the 2-liter 4-cylinder engine are being recalled because a malfunction can cause power brake assist to fail, leading to hard braking.
lead_paragraph: BMW will recall about 76,000 vehicles from the 2012-14 model years that are equipped with turbocharged 2-liter 4-cylinder engines because of a loss of power brake assist, the automaker has informed the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

headline: Cuckoo Finches Come Up With a New Con
abstract: Scientists have discovered that the birds have another way of duping other species into raising their young: laying multiple eggs in the foreign nest.
lead_paragraph: Scientists have discovered still another trick in the portfolio of brood parasites — the birds that deceitfully lay their eggs in the nests of other species, that way increasing their own numbers by duping other mothers into raising their young.

headline: Reid Denounces House Republicans Over Health Law
abstract: Shortly after the Senate voted to reject a spending bill that has the backing of the conservative House Republican conference, Senator Harry Reid of Nevada excoriated his House colleagues.
lead_paragraph: Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, the majority leader, has made little secret of his disdain for Tea Party Republicans, saying they will own the blame for any government shutdown.

headline: Turkish Premier Announces Proposals Aimed at Kurds
abstract: Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s measures appeared intended to revive a stalled peace process, but Kurdish leaders largely dismissed them as inadequate.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan announced a package of measures on Monday that appeared intended to revive the stalled peace process with the country’s ethnic Kurds, who have fought a decades-long insurgency against the Turkish state.

headline: New Government Shutdown, New Rules
abstract: In November 1995, Newt Gingrich, then speaker of the House, led an effort that resulted in a shutdown of the federal government. Now, Congressional Republicans have done the same.
lead_paragraph: In November 1995, Newt Gingrich, then speaker of the House, led an effort that resulted in a shutdown of the federal government. Now, Congressional Republicans have done the same.

headline: On the Verge | Pasadena, a Place With Many Hidden Charms
abstract: The sleepy town just might be the Los Angeles area’s next great bohemian enclave. Kevin and Bo Carney, who opened a new outpost of their shop Mohawk General Store there on Saturday, give a rundown of their favorite Pasadena attractions.
lead_paragraph: Everyone knows that Los Angeles is having an art and fashion renaissance. But the transformation of Pasadena, its eastern neighbor, has happened under the radar. Developed in the 1880s as a winter retreat for the East Coast elite, the sedate college town at the foot of the San Gabriel Mountains has long been an antipode to Hollywood, a place with family-friendly neighborhoods, numerous Ph.Ds from the Jet Propulsion Laboratory and Caltech, and a general air of all-American normalcy. Fashion types usually only come out for the monthly Rose Bowl Flea Market. Pasadena is so uncool that Rodarte designers Kate and Laura Mulleavy’s address there is often cited as evidence of their status as fashion outsiders.

headline: 3 Teams, 27 Games, 2 Losses
abstract: Fighting for the American League’s two wild-card spots, the Indians won their final 10 games, the Rangers won their final 7 and the Rays won 8 of their last 10.
lead_paragraph: Although baseball’s decision to go with two wild-card teams in each league has a gimmicky feel to it, there was nothing dubious about the way the top three American League wild-card contenders played down the stretch as they vied for a spot in the postseason.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Washington and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Washington, Iraq, Italy and Syria.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Washington, Iraq, Italy and Syria.

headline: What’s on Tuesday
abstract: A listing of shows to watch on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (ESPN) HAWAIIAN: THE LEGEND OF EDDIE AIKAU In this “30 for 30” entry, the director Sam George chronicles the life and times of Mr. Aikau, the Hawaiian surfer and lifeguard who made a name at Waimea Bay by riding monster waves said to reach heights of 40 feet — and in the process inspiring bumper stickers that said “Eddie Would Go.” He died in 1978, when, as a crew member on a Polynesian voyaging canoe that was following an ancient route between Tahiti and Hawaii, he paddled on his surfboard for help after the vessel had capsized south of Molokai.

headline: Britain Plans to Require Community Service for Long-Term Unemployment Benefits
abstract: A top minister’s announcement applies to the long-term unemployed in the Conservative Party’s latest effort to crack down on “welfare dependency.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Jobless Britons could be forced to do community work to keep their unemployment payments, Britain’s top economics minister said Monday, announcing the latest in a series of moves to tighten benefits rules and crack down on “welfare dependency.”

headline: Sampling a Humpback's Breath
abstract: Researchers from the Provincetown Center for Coastal Studies pursue a humpback whale to catch the spray from its blowhole, which turns out to have all kinds of good data in it.
lead_paragraph: Researchers from the Provincetown Center for Coastal Studies pursue a humpback whale to catch the spray from its blowhole, which turns out to have all kinds of good data in it.

headline: In the Kitchen, Talk of Love, Life and Art
abstract: “Shakespeare’s Sister,” performed by an accomplished quintet of women, is having its New York premiere at La MaMa.
lead_paragraph: Who can say whether one of Shakespeare’s sisters was a frustrated writer, as Virginia Woolf imagined in “A Room of One’s Own”? But Peter Brook’s daughter, Irina Brook, is by now an established director, albeit still firmly in her father’s shadow, so it’s easy to understand why Woolf’s scenario would be too tempting for her to resist.

headline: A Sew-Sew Labor Market
abstract: Garments to the rescue.
lead_paragraph: For years people like me have been engaged in a running argument with people who insist that the reason we have high unemployment is that American workers don’t have the skills required for a 21st-century economy. It’s normally implied, although not always stated, that we’re talking about technological skills, knowledge of science and math, and in general the cutting edge.

headline: A Wealth of Data in Whale Breath
abstract: Researchers are learning how to use the breath, or “blow,” of whales and dolphins to extract and measure hormones, microorganisms, DNA and the byproducts of metabolism.
lead_paragraph: MYSTIC, Conn. — On her trainer’s command, an alabaster-skinned beluga whale named Naku placed her chin on the deck of her outdoor pool and exhaled several times, emitting a hollow “chuff” sound with each breath. The vapor rose into a petri dish a researcher held over her blowhole.

headline: Amanda Knox’s Retrial Begins in Italy
abstract: Ms. Knox, an American who was convicted and later acquitted, of killing her British roommate in Italy, did not travel to Italy for the new trail.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Amanda Knox, the American student who was convicted and later acquitted of killing her British roommate, went on trial again in Italy on Monday, but neither she, nor her former Italian boyfriend and co-defendant, Raffaele Sollecito, were in court.

headline: Life Is Long, but Then So Are the Country Roads of Argentina
abstract: In an Argentine road movie by Javier Rebollo, a former hit man and a new companion are going nowhere slowly.
lead_paragraph: Stories of humanized hit men make for a small but well-trod patch of screenwriting terrain, but “The Dead Man and Being Happy” quickly transcends that territory to become a beguiling road movie. Directed by Javier Rebollo and written with Lola Mayo and Salvador Roselli, this reserved, tragicomic story of existential flight across Argentina is defined by its shifting, literary voice-over about the textured, wide-screen expanses crossed by its protagonist.

headline: In Opening Prayer, Senate Chaplain Touches on Politics
abstract: When the Senate began its new legislative day as it customarily does with a prayer, the chaplain departed from his usual apolitical messages.
lead_paragraph: When the Senate began its new legislative day on Monday as it customarily does with a prayer, the chaplain, the Rev. Dr. Barry C. Black, departed from his usual apolitical messages and asked God to help senators “remember that all that is necessary for unintended catastrophic consequences is for good people to do nothing.”

headline: Defining and Demanding a Musician’s Fair Shake in the Internet Age
keywords: ['Music', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Royalties', 'Audio Recordings and Downloads', 'Copyrights and Copyright Violations']
abstract: David Lowery, leader of the bands Camper Van Beethoven and Cracker, is pressing for higher royalties for musicians.
lead_paragraph: RICHMOND, Va. — In the music business, they still talk about the “Lars curse.”

headline: Breast-Feeding Services Lag Behind the Law
keywords: ['Babies and Infants', 'Breastfeeding', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Though the Affordable Care Act require insurers to cover breast pumps and professional lactation support, many new mothers are left frustrated.
lead_paragraph: Under the Affordable Care Act, insurance companies are required to pay for breast pumps and counseling for new mothers to address breast-feeding problems. The aim is to encourage more women to breast-feed so their infants can reap the health benefits, including reduced risks of asthma, leukemia and Type 2 diabetes.

headline: A Quake Shakes Loose an Island
abstract: An island that emerged in the Arabian Sea, off the Pakistani coast, after a magnitude 7.7 earthquake last week was probably created as freed methane gas pushed up a section of shallow seafloor.
lead_paragraph: A small island that appeared in the Arabian Sea off Pakistan after an earthquake last week most likely formed when the shaking released methane gas and water trapped in undersea sediments. The gas and water forced part of the seabed to the surface, experts said.

headline: Triple Play: Week 26 Results
abstract: Readers were asked to put their predictive skills to the test one last time for the 2013 baseball season.
lead_paragraph: There did not seem to be any rush to win the National League batting title. Michael Cuddyer of the Rockies hung on to win with a .331 average, but he hit .250 for the week (4 for 16). The Braves’ Chris Johnson, meanwhile, was 2 for 19 and finished at .321. Andrew McCutchen of the Pirates, the top choice with nearly 40 percent, was 5 for 19 but finished at .317.

headline: T Fall Travel
abstract: All it takes for an easy, breezy getaway is a classic carryall — so roomy you can take it with you.
lead_paragraph: All it takes for an easy, breezy getaway is a classic carryall — so roomy you can take it with you.

headline: Dripping Blood, a Young Actress Transforms Into a ‘Human Monster’
abstract: The director of the new film “Carrie” describes working with the movie’s lead actress, who in real life is around the same age as the troubled teen she plays.
lead_paragraph: Kimberly Peirce, whose new film is a remake of “Carrie,” was profiled in this past weekend’s magazine. Here, she describes behind-the-scenes footage of a scene in which Carrie White, played by Chloë Grace Moretz, comes home after the prom (there is no audio in the beginning of the clip).

headline: Video: New Shutdown, New Rules
abstract: In November 1995, Newt Gingrich, then speaker of the House, led an effort that resulted in a shutdown of the federal government. Now, Congressional Republicans seem ready to do the same.
lead_paragraph: In November 1995, Newt Gingrich, then speaker of the House, led an effort that resulted in a shutdown of the federal government. Now, Congressional Republicans seem ready to do the same.

headline: Boehner on Funding Measure
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation', 'Federal Budget (US)']
abstract: John A. Boehner, the House speaker, said that a clean budget bill was “not going to happen.”
lead_paragraph: John A. Boehner, the House speaker, said that a clean budget bill was “not going to happen.”

headline: How the Deal for Rue21 Could Fall Apart
abstract: A report of weak sales by the retailer rue21 has spooked potential investors in a private equity deal to buy the company. The question now is whether the three banks on the deal want to risk their reputations by trying to kill it.
lead_paragraph: The fashion retailer rue21 is about to find out how much reputation in private equity deals still matters.

headline: Obama Scolds House Republicans Over Possible Shutdown
abstract: President Obama castigated House Republicans for failing to perform one of their most basic functions by not providing money for the government. He said a shutdown would harm the economic recovery.
lead_paragraph: President Obama castigated House Republicans for failing to perform a basic function by not providing money for the government. He said a shutdown would harm the economic recovery.

headline: Good Reviews Propel ‘Glass Menagerie’ Sales on Broadway
abstract: In a mixed week at the box office for most Broadway shows, the new revival of “The Glass Menagerie” enjoyed unusually strong ticket sales.
lead_paragraph: In a mixed week at the box office for most Broadway shows, the new revival of “The Glass Menagerie” enjoyed unusually strong ticket sales after theater critics weighed in Thursday night with stellar reviews for the production and its cast, led by the two-time Tony Award winner Cherry Jones.

headline: The Blow and Haim Release New Albums
abstract: New pop releases, both smart and rapturous, from the Blow and Haim.
lead_paragraph: HAIM

headline: The Many Forms of Masa
abstract: Whether it’s arepas, tortillas or pupusas, masa remains a Latin American cornerstone.
lead_paragraph: Whether it’s arepas, tortillas or pupusas, masa remains a Latin American cornerstone.

headline: Masa Offers the Kernels of a Culture
abstract: Many foods native to Latin America have been absorbed into global kitchens, but masa remains stubbornly, proudly Latin.
lead_paragraph: Without the tortilla, there is no taco. And, as the Mexican saying goes: Sin maíz, no hay país.

headline: Peeling Off Layers to Find an Underlying Truth
abstract: The inaugural recital at the Board of Officers Room in the Park Avenue Armory featured Christian Gerhaher and Gerold Huber.
lead_paragraph: Over the past few years, the Park Avenue Armory has built a reputation for thinking big. Outsize art installations and immersive performances of music, theater and dance presented in the 55,000-square-foot drill hall often become the talk of the town.

headline: Comment Ban Sets Off Debate
keywords: ['Science and Technology', 'Magazines', 'News and News Media', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: The magazine Popular Science has decided to shut off comments on its articles, saying ignorant, insulting and counterfactual posts were polluting the discourse and sowing confusion.
lead_paragraph: Care to comment on a Popular Science article — say, “These Magnetic Nanobots Could Carry Drugs Into Your Brain” or “FYI: Do Animals Have Orgasms?”

headline: In Performance: ‘Waiting for Godot’
abstract: Shane Baker and Nicholas Jenkins, as Vladimir and Boy, in a scene from Samuel Beckett’s play, being presented in a new Yiddish-language production by the Castillo Theater and New Yiddish Rep.
lead_paragraph: Shane Baker and Nicholas Jenkins, as Vladimir and Boy, in a scene from Samuel Beckett’s play, being presented in a new Yiddish-language production by the Castillo Theater and New Yiddish Rep.

headline: TV Talk: Numbers for ‘Breaking Bad’
abstract: The Times’s Bill Carter and Brian Stelter discuss the unexpectedly high viewership for the “Breaking Bad” finale.
lead_paragraph: The Times’s Bill Carter and Brian Stelter discuss the unexpectedly high viewership for the “Breaking Bad” finale.

headline: A Noticeable Thawing at Saint Laurent
abstract: The mood at Hedi Slimane’s spring showing on Monday night was decidedly less hostile than in the past, both from the perspective of the audience and, it would appear, that of the designer.
lead_paragraph: Since we last met at Saint Laurent and the ongoing reinvention of the storied Parisian label by Hedi Slimane, the tides have turned remarkably in the designer’s favor. Coverage in fashion magazines of his fall collection, shown in February, has been overwhelmingly positive, prompting grunge features in W, Vogue, Elle, Harper’s Bazaar, and that’s just in the United States.

headline: Traditional Folk Frolic, With Old-Time Fervor and Youthful Yelps
abstract: Leading lights of the folk revival genre performed Sunday night at Town Hall in a concert keyed to a new film from the Coen brothers.
lead_paragraph: The folk revival of the 1950s and ’60s was a tangle of contradictions from the start, and half a century later, those contradictions have only multiplied. They were just part of the charm of “Another Day, Another Time,” a concert on Sunday night at Town Hall spun off from “Inside Llewyn Davis,” a film by Joel and Ethan Coen that is set in Greenwich Village in 1961 and loosely derived from the peregrinations of Dave Van Ronk.

headline: Warner Bros. Agrees to Deal for Financial Backing
abstract: The agreement with RatPac-Dune Entertainment could help finance as many as 75 films.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Warner Brothers and RatPac-Dune Entertainment said that they had agreed to a deal under which Warner will receive financial backing for as many as 75 films over four years or more.

headline: What the F.A.A. Is Considering on Devices
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Electronics', 'Aviation Accidents and Safety', 'Wireless Communications']
abstract: Some answers to questions about the review panel’s recommendations for electronic devices on planes.
lead_paragraph: Q. What are the changes that the F.A.A. is considering?

headline: Battles Without End
keywords: ['Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Books and Literature', 'Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: “Thank You for Your Service” is David Finkel’s account of how soldiers scarred by war try to adjust to civilian life.
lead_paragraph: In his deeply affecting 2009 book, “The Good Soldiers,” David Finkel gave us a harrowing and unnervingly intimate picture of the Iraq war as seen by members of an Army battalion sent to Baghdad during the surge in 2007. This was not Washington’s “macro” war, but the “micro” war on the ground, made up of “specific acts of bravery and tragedy” experienced by the soldiers of Battalion 2-16 as they patrolled streets riddled with sniper fire and improvised explosive devices that would claim the lives and limbs of their comrades.

headline: Body of Suspect in L.I. Shootings Is Discovered in the Hudson River
abstract: The body of Sang Ho Kim, 63, was discovered in the Hudson River, just south of the Bear Mountain Bridge.
lead_paragraph: The body of the man who the authorities said shot two people at his former workplace on Long Island was discovered on Monday in the Hudson River, the Putnam County Sheriff’s Department said.

headline: Looking for Lincoln, and an Early Fish Fossil
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Global Warming', 'Jaw (Body Part)', 'Biology and Biochemistry', 'Science and Technology', 'Medicine and Health', 'Fish and Other Marine Life']
abstract: Recent developments in health and science news. This week: A substitute for silicon in computer chips and a United Nations warning on carbon emissions.
lead_paragraph: Last year, moviegoers saw our 16th president star in two different films. This year, two software-wielding history buffs are seeing Abraham Lincoln in different spots in the same photograph.

headline: Art Collections a Click Away
abstract: Amazon’s art venture seems to be doing well, as it has enticed more than 180 galleries to sell through its site.
lead_paragraph: When Judy DeFord, a retired high school art teacher in Seattle, received an e-mail from Catherine Person Gallery recently, she saw a familiar name on its list of artists. It was a former student of hers, Allyce Wood.

headline: Portuguese Voters Punish Leader’s Party for Austerity Policies
abstract: The Social Democratic Party, the main party in Portugal’s center-right coalition, suffered a heavy defeat in municipal elections over the weekend.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — The main party in Portugal’s governing center-right coalition suffered a heavy defeat in municipal elections over the weekend as voters punished the government of Prime Minister Pedro Passos Coelho for the tax increases and spending cuts it has carried out since coming to power two years ago.

headline: German Politician Faces Plagiarism Accusations
abstract: A German university is looking into allegations that Frank-Walter Steinmeier, a leading Social Democrat and a former foreign minister, plagiarized parts of his doctoral dissertation.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — A German university is looking into allegations that Frank-Walter Steinmeier, a leading Social Democrat and a former foreign minister, plagiarized parts of his doctoral dissertation.

headline: Obama’s Remarks on the Budget and Health Law
keywords: ['Speeches and Statements', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Following is a transcript of President Obama’s remarks from the White House briefing room on Monday afternoon.
lead_paragraph: Following is the of President Obama’s remarks from the White House briefing room on Monday afternoon, as transcribed by Federal News Service:

headline: Passion, Principle or Both? Deciphering Art Vandalism
abstract: “Art Under Attack,” an exhibition opening on Wednesday at Tate Britain, argues that purposeful assaults on artworks shed light on history, politics and passions.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Taking scissors to a van Gogh landscape, smearing paint over a Rembrandt, setting fire to a Leonardo drawing — even imagining such acts can make the stomach clench. We’ll never own these masterpieces, cannot touch them, may never see them up close. Yet their destruction prompts outrage.

headline: NBC Scraps Hillary Clinton Mini-Series
abstract: The project drew strong opposition from Republicans, who saw it as a potential boon to Mrs. Clinton as she considers a run for president in 2016.
lead_paragraph: On the same day that a filmmaker announced he was abandoning plans for a CNN documentary on Hillary Rodham Clinton, NBC Entertainment pulled the plug on its planned mini-series on Mrs. Clinton.

headline: Obama’s Statement Before Shutdown
abstract: President Obama urged House Republicans to pass a funding measure, saying it would be the “height of irresponsibility” to shut down the government.
lead_paragraph: President Obama urged House Republicans to pass a funding measure, saying it would be the “height of irresponsibility” to shut down the government.

headline: With Accusations of Sabotage, Venezuela Expels 3 U.S. Embassy Officials
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates']
abstract: Accusing the officials of supporting efforts to sabotage the nation’s electrical grid, President Nicolás Maduro announced the move on live TV.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — Stepping up hostilities with the United States, President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela expelled the top American diplomat and two other embassy officials from the country on Monday, accusing them of supporting plots to sabotage the country’s electrical grid and the economy.

headline: Hitting Pay Dirt on Mars
abstract: The first rock examined by Curiosity last year turns out to be an uncommon alkaline rock, with a tiny amount of water.
lead_paragraph: It looked to be uniformly bland, which is why scientists chose it as the first rock to be examined up close last year by the Mars rover Curiosity: a run-of-the-mill volcanic rock, something to test and calibrate the rover’s instruments.

headline: Two Marine Corps Generals Are Forced to Retire Over Fatal Security Breach
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Terrorism']
abstract: The punishment, considered unprecedented in modern Marine Corps history, came after an insurgent attack in Afghanistan in 2012 killed two Marines and destroyed six fighter jets.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Two senior Marine Corps generals have been ordered to take early retirement after being found responsible for errors in judgment and failure to provide adequate security at a base in southwestern Afghanistan that was the scene of a deadly — and humiliating — insurgent attack last year that killed two Marines and destroyed six Harrier attack jets.

headline: Minnesota Orchestra Withdraws From Two Carnegie Hall Concerts
abstract: Unable to reach an agreement in a yearlong labor dispute with its musicians, the orchestra announced on Monday that it was withdrawing from two concerts scheduled for November.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 7:40 p.m. | MINNEAPOLIS – The Minnesota Orchestra announced on Monday that it was withdrawing from its two concerts at Carnegie Hall in November, because it has not been able to come to agreement on a new contract with its players.

headline: The World as They Knew It
abstract: A new exhibition features over 40 objects that provide an overview of Greco-Roman geographical thinking and representation, tracing the roots of modern mapmaking.
lead_paragraph: Long before people could look upon Earth from afar, completing a full orbit every 90 minutes, the Greeks and the Romans of antiquity had to struggle to understand their world’s size and shape. Their approaches differed: the philosophical Greeks, it has been said, measured the world by the stars; the practical, road-building Romans by milestones.

headline: A Little More Legroom, Priced as an Upgrade
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Business Travel']
abstract: Airlines have been busily adding fees on most aspects of flying, spurred by spectacular revenue increases, and now they are charging premiums for seating.
lead_paragraph: AS the director of data for a company called Routehappy, John Walton might be forgiven for putting the very happiest spin on a major airline trend, roping off parts of the coach cabins — or selling the better seats ad hoc — to accommodate those who want more comfort (or, to put it another way, less knee-crunching misery).

headline: House Schedules Next Vote on Stopgap Measure
abstract: The House’s latest volley in the war over President Obama’s health care law will come to a vote around 8 p.m., leaving the Senate just four hours to respond before much of the government shuts down.
lead_paragraph: The House’s latest volley in the war over President Obama’s health care law will come to a vote around 8 p.m., leaving the Senate just four hours to respond before much of the government shuts down.

headline: Despite Cries of Unfair Treatment, JPMorgan Is No Victim
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: Some banking experts say they believe that the government is picking on JPMorgan Chase, but the bank may not be the martyr some think it is.
lead_paragraph: The government’s legal pursuit of JPMorgan Chase strikes many people on Wall Street as unfair.

headline: A Lizard That Slithers
abstract: Scientists have identified four distinct species of legless lizards in California.
lead_paragraph: Scientists have identified four distinct species of Anniella, legless lizards in California, including Anniella grinnelli, the Bakersfield legless lizard. This species, which has a purple belly, is found mostly in the southern San Joaquin Valley. The findings were reported last month in the journal Breviora by Theodore Papenfuss and James Parham, who used DNA testing to distinguish the species, which they named after natural historians who documented California’s biodiversity.

headline: Sounds of Britain, Old and Newish
abstract: The Juilliard Orchestra played a program of Benjamin Britten and Edward Elgar conducted by the early music specialist Nicholas McGegan.
lead_paragraph: For much of his career, Benjamin Britten, whose centennial is being celebrated this year, disliked the music of Elgar, which he deemed too conservative. Britten often made snarky comments about that eminent British composer, declaring about Elgar’s Symphony No. 1, for example, that “only in Imperial England would such a work be tolerated.” But during the last few years of his life, Britten had a change of heart and began to appreciate Elgar’s music, conducting various scores and recording “The Dream of Gerontius” and “Introduction and Allegro.”

headline: The Herman Miller Archive Unearths a Lost Moment in Design History
abstract: On the furniture giant’s new online editorial platform, the great curator Mildred Friedman recalls a pioneering multimedia class that influenced the future work of Charles Eames, George Nelson and Alexander Girard.
lead_paragraph: Over the summer, the furniture manufacturer Herman Miller started Why, a digital platform that features designer interviews, discusses current design issues and mines a company archive that is rich with material from and about the legendary figures who helped make Herman Miller a leader in postwar American design.

headline: Aleksandra Kurzak Withdraws From ‘Rigoletto’
abstract: Aleksandra Kurzak is withdrawing from the Metropolitan Opera’s production of Verdi’s “Rigoletto” this fall because she is expecting a baby with her partner, the tenor Roberto Alagna, the Met announced Monday.
lead_paragraph: The Polish-born soprano Aleksandra Kurzak is withdrawing from the Metropolitan Opera’s production of Verdi’s “Rigoletto” this fall because she is expecting a baby with her partner, the tenor Roberto Alagna, the Met announced Monday. The role of Gilda will instead be shared by two sopranos making their Met debuts ahead of schedule: Irina Lungu , a Russian soprano, and Sonya Yonche, a Bulgarian Soprano. Mr. Alagna’s marriage to the soprano Angela Gheorghiu — the pair were marketed as opera’s ”love couple” at one point — ended in divorce.

headline: Congressman Proposes New Rules for Music Royalties
abstract: The Free Market Royalty Act would let record companies and performing artists collect royalties when their songs are played on the radio.
lead_paragraph: The music industry is gearing up for yet another fight over one of its most intractable issues: radio royalties. Only this time, it involves the online world as well.

headline: Just Let Instincts Take Over
abstract: Clare Waight Keller of Chloé and Stella McCartney present very wearable collections in Paris.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — It isn’t because they are women that Clare Waight Keller of Chloé and Stella McCartney have designed some of the sanest clothes for spring. It is because they aren’t beholden to a female archetype. They can design based on instinct.

headline: A Tale of Two Countries, and Promises Broken
abstract: Boyzie Cekwana and Panaibra Canda presented “The Inkomati (dis)cord,” which refers to the nonaggression pact between Mozambique and South Africa, at Live Arts.
lead_paragraph: The choreographer Boyzie Cekwana is from South Africa. The choreographer Panaibra Canda is from Mozambique. The title of their collaboration, “The Inkomati (dis)cord,” refers to a 1984 nonaggression pact between their neighboring countries, and to promises that weren’t kept. The work is an attempt to find a common language in which a shared past of violence and lies might be expressed. And, as performed at New York Live Arts on Wednesday as part of the French Institute Alliance Française’s Crossing the Line festival, it is an effort to communicate that past to people who presumably know little of it.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: McAfee’s Gadget to Foil the N.S.A., and a Change in the I.P.O. Game
abstract: Monday’s highlights from around the Web include a claim by John McAfee, an antivirus software pioneer, for having a cheap box to thwart government surveillance. Plus, how the new “confidential filing” clause in the JOBS Act is encouraging more companies to go public.
lead_paragraph: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: Storytelling Coming to Life at the Library
abstract: The French choreographer Fanny de Chaillé brought “The Library” to New York libraries, as part of Crossing the Line 2013, the interdisciplinary arts festival.
lead_paragraph: The French choreographer Fanny de Chaillé doesn’t fight whimsy, she relishes it. In New York for two presentations courtesy of Crossing the Line 2013, the interdisciplinary arts festival, Ms. de Chaillé hosted “The Library,” an unconventional storytelling experience held last week at two libraries. On Thursday, in collaboration with the visual artist Philippe Ramette, she unveiled “Passage à l’acte/Acting Out,” a movement installation, at the Invisible Dog Art Center in Brooklyn, showing that one of Ms. de Chaillé’s talents is finding intimacy in public spaces.

headline: A Not Entirely Lost Mets Season
abstract: Something does seem to be changing over in Flushing.
lead_paragraph: It was around the middle of May. The Mets were something like 15 games under .500, and even the games they were winning were a slog. For even the truest Mets fan, the season was already long and getting longer by the inning. The trials of the modern Mets, which began with the called third strike in the ninth inning of Game 7 of the 2006 National League Playoffs, and extended through the collapses of 2007 and 2008 and then to the “modern era” of the their beautiful, cursed new ballpark, Citi Field, seemed endless.

headline: At a Festival, Molly Danced but Didn’t Cut In
abstract: The first TomorrowWorld electronic dance-music celebration this weekend seemed to go off without any serious health problems from drug use.
lead_paragraph: CHATTAHOOCHEE HILLS, Ga. — Plastic mushroom statues outnumbered hay bales last weekend on a horse farm near here, about 25 miles southwest of Atlanta. A stage designed as a massive facade of books with titles like “Beauty and the Beat” and “The Story of Us” sprouted in the center, with seven smaller stages scattered over 500 acres of rolling countryside.

headline: The Back and Forth Over the Shutdown and Debt Ceiling
abstract: Tracking the legislative efforts to end the shutdown of the federal government and to prevent breaching the nation’s debt limit.
lead_paragraph: Tracking the legislative efforts to end the shutdown of the federal government and to prevent breaching the nation’s debt limit.

headline: Obama’s Message to the Middle
abstract: He seemed to speak to moderates in the House when he explained what a shutdown would look like.
lead_paragraph: President Obama’s demand this afternoon that Congress do its fundamental job and keep the government open will have no more influence on hard-liners in the House than it ever has, even with only a few hours left until the midnight shutdown. But he made an interesting choice by beginning his remarks with the effects of a shutdown. That suggested that his real audience was not just the public, but moderate House Republicans, who could use a reminder of what is about to happen to them.

headline: Polls Show a More Negative View of G.O.P. Over Shutdown
abstract: With a possible government shutdown just hours away, new national polls find bad news for Congressional Republicans – they are rated more negatively than President Obama in handling budget negotiations, and more Americans would hold them responsible if a shutdown occurs.
lead_paragraph: With a possible government shutdown just hours away, new national polls find bad news for Congressional Republicans: they are rated more negatively than President Obama in handling budget negotiations, and more Americans would hold them responsible if a shutdown occurs.

headline: Hotels Fight Comparison Shoppers With Lower, Locked Rates
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Business Travel']
abstract: Repeatedly booking and canceling rooms can help a customer get a deal, but the snubbed hotels get empty rooms and no revenue.
lead_paragraph: For hotels, they are some of the most maddening of customers — those who repeatedly book and cancel rooms at no cost in search of the best deal. While the customer ends up with a low rate on a good room, the snubbed hotel is left with an empty room and no revenue.

headline: Ford C-Max Hybrid Owners Get Rebate for Disappointing Mileage
abstract: Ford will pay owners of the car $550 to compensate for what they will spend on gas beyond what the original rating had led them to expect.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Ford Motor Company has started mailing checks to owners of the C-Max Hybrid to compensate them after lowering its fuel economy rating.

headline: Kenzo Puts in a Word for Fish
abstract: A review of Kenzo, Isabel Marant, Carven and Acne Studios.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — On a gray Sunday morning in Paris, when there is little traffic and the only signs of life on the streets are a few ambitious joggers, an excursion to the suburb of Saint-Denis for the Kenzo show did not sound so bad. The designers, Carol Lim and Humberto Leon, had set up their runway in a glass-ceilinged hall the size of a railway station in La Cité du Cinéma, a film studio complex recently opened by the director Luc Besson. At the entrance is a trailer-size model of the Brooklyn Bridge. And there were cookies.

headline: Roomy Carryalls That Are Ready for Takeoff
abstract: A big bag and a few classic separates are all you need for a quick weekend getaway.
lead_paragraph: All it takes for an easy, breezy getaway is a classic carryall — so roomy you can take it with you.

headline: A Vivier Shoe Retrospective, Buckles and All
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Paris Fashion Week', 'Shoes and Boots']
abstract: Roger Vivier, the designer shoe label that made buckles a fashion statement, is the subject of a new retrospective at the Palais de Tokyo.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Roger Vivier, the designer shoe label that has done more than the Pilgrims to make buckles a fashion statement, is the subject of a new retrospective here that opened on Monday night at the Palais de Tokyo. Curated by Olivier Saillard, the director of the Musée Galliera that reopened across the street last week, the show is a shoe spectacular, whimsically tracing the history of the brand from Mr. Vivier’s years at Christian Dior in the 1950s through the current incarnation of Roger Vivier, which has been designed by Bruno Frisoni since 2003.

headline: Besieged by Chirping Crickets in the Terminal
abstract: Kenneth Baggett, co-chief and partner at CohnReznick, once found himself in a Mississippi airport, in full-throated company.
lead_paragraph: AS a partner and co-C.E.O. at CohnReznick, I’m meeting with clients, visiting our offices or going out on business development calls all the time. Last year I flew about 200,000 miles just in domestic flights alone.

headline: Olympics Loom Large Over N.H.L.
abstract: The 2013-14 N.H.L. season will begin on Tuesday with plenty of story lines, but much of the hockey season will be about the Sochi Games.
lead_paragraph: A full schedule after a lockout-shortened season, a new divisional setup, outdoor games galore, the Chicago Blackhawks seeking their third Stanley Cup in five years. Those are all solid story lines for the 2013-14 National Hockey League season, which begins with three games on Tuesday. But make no mistake, much of the season will be about the Winter Olympics.

headline: Obama Calls Boehner Ahead of Budget Deadline
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Just hours before the government was set to shut down, President Obama called House Speaker John A. Boehner of Ohio, according to a spokesman for Mr. Boehner.
lead_paragraph: Just hours before the government was set to shut down, President Obama called House Speaker John A. Boehner of Ohio, according to a spokesman for Mr. Boehner. But it did not appear they resolved much of anything.

headline: Perry Capital Cuts Stake in J.C. Penney
abstract: The hedge fund began to cut its stake on Friday, coinciding with J.C. Penney’s disclosure of a planned sale of as much as 96.6 million new common shares.
lead_paragraph: The hedge fund Perry Capital pared its stake in J.C. Penney by nearly half as the troubled retailer announced plans last week to raise as much as $932 million in fresh capital.

headline: Procedural Vote Quells Fledgling Republican Revolt
abstract: Though there had been brief talk of moderate Republicans revolting against the latest House stopgap spending bill, a procedural vote on the rule for consideration of the measure passed Monday night, 225 to 204.
lead_paragraph: The House’s most conservative Republicans, with some help from a handful of moderate Republicans, tried Monday evening to bring down the Republican leadership’s latest effort to link further government funding to a knock on President Obama’s health care law.
